column2: BRICQUEBEC, Normandy, June 25 -- With the goose-stepping enemy cleared from this village, Frenchmen are having their revenge on those who collaborated or fraternized with the Nazis and the hair has been sheared from the head of many a woman who was friendly to Nazi troops during the four-year occupation.

ROME, June 25 -- American forces of the Fifth Army, storming up Italy's west coast, have thrown back German tank and artillery units all along the line, occupied the coastal route city of Follonica and smashed within thirty-eight miles of the Germans' anchor city of Pisa, headquarters announced today.

The Museum of Modern Art and five galleries open shows this week. On Wednesday the auditorium galleries of the museum will place on view an exhibition entitled "Hayter and Studio 17: New Directions in Gravure." Tempera decorative panels by Marie Swartwout will be shown at the office gallery of Theodore Kohn Son's, jewelers.

Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam, who was appointed recently to supervise the Methodist churches in the New York area, has leased an apartment of nine rooms at 1165 Fifth Avenue through the M. Morgenthau-Seixas Company and Douglas Gibbons Co.

LONDON, Monday, June 26 -- The Russians have encircled the White Russian stronghold of Vitebsk and are fighting in the streets with the trapped garrison of perhaps 45,000 men, Moscow announced early today, as fighting flamed along a 325-mile front and the Red Army shredded the vaunted Fatherland Line, built to guard the shortest road to Berlin.

The Hotel Gladstone, a fifteen-story building at 114-22 East Fifty-second Street, and the adjoining two-story annex at 112 East Fifty-second Street have been sold by the Dry Dock Savings Institution to Gladstone Hotel, Inc., Julius Bashlow, president, for cash over a mortgage of $500,000.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations pressed today its demand for wage increases beyond the Little Steel formula of the National War Labor Board by offering a new report declaring that the cost of living had increased 45.3 per cent between January, 1941, and March of this year, and again disputing the report of the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Four new films will open in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

The Republicans meeting in Chicago today are facing a national situation more critical than that which existed when they met in the same city in 1860 and again when they met at Baltimore in 1864. As on both those historic occasions, they believe they have a chance for victory.

CHICAGO, June 25 -- A rewriting of international law to restore morality in the dealings of nations, to prohibit under extreme penalties such devices as robot planes, such practices as the execution of prisoners and other procedures repugnant to civilized society is proposed in the draft of the foreign policy plank submitted for the Republican platform, it was learned tonight.
Mrs. Benjamin Rogers of Tuxedo Park and Washington, D.C., is at Hampshire House.
BOSTON, June 25 (AP) -- The Red Sox and Senators split a double-header today, the visitors coming from behind to win the opener, 5 to 4, and the Sex taking the second, 4 to 0.
LONDON, June 25 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin:

Reuben Fine of Washington, former City College star, won the national speed tournament of the United States Chess Federation for the third time in a row when he finished with a score of 10 -- 1 in the finals at the Hotel Astor last night.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 25 -- Despite lowering lead-colored clouds, sixty-five craft went out on Long Island Sound today for the sixth championship regatta, which was scheduled for the Seawanhaka Yacht Club over at Oyster Bay but held by the Larchmont Club.

Influenced by developments in price control legislation, domestic cotton prices last week moved into new high ground. A portion of the earlier gains, however, was erased in the late dealings. At the close on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains for the period of 19 to 39 points, with the strength centered in the more distant deliveries.

A new phase of the war in eastern Europe begins with the opening of the massive Russian offensive around Vitebsk. Throughout the vast struggle in Russia all previous emphasis has been laid on expelling the invader from the motherland. Now Moscow sounds a different note. The Battle of Vitebsk is the start of the Russian march on Berlin.
Dorothy Sutherland was assigned by the Army Nurse Corps to follow hospital installations on the Italian front and report what she considered of particular interest for the women at home.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Monday, June 26 -- American infantry drove into the streets of Cherbourg from the east, south and southwest yesterday and a spokesman at headquarters said last night that the city was "almost in our possession."

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 25 (AP) -- Maj. Gens. Leonard Town-send Gerow, who trained United States forces in Britain for the invasion, and Joseph Lawton Collins, who drove the last Japanese from Guadalcanal, were disclosed today as corps commanders of American forces in France.

BASEBALL is more than a hundred years old. Generally speaking, youth is rash and often radical. The ancients are the ultra-conservatives. But, despite its respectable old age, the diamond sport is going completely haywire tonight. An event is scheduled for the Polo Grounds whose plot seems, either stolen from a surrealist's dream or lifted bodily from an epic outlined by a demented Hollywood scenarist.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 25 (AP) -- Communique 39:

PHILADELPHIA, June 25 -- Performing in a manner strikingly reminiscent of their more impressive days of old, Joe McCarthy's suddenly revived Yankees gathered a total of 27 hits today, including three homers. By spreading this attack quite evenly over the afternoon's double-header, they succeeded in downing the Athletics twice to make a clean sweep of the three-game series and advance to third place.

How problem boys and juvenile delinquents can be helped through a constructive program designed to direct their energies into wholesome channels is shown again in the annual report of the Berkshire Industrial Farm. A school for young boys who have been committed for truancy, vagrancy, petty theft and similar anti-social misbehavior, the institution, now in its fifty-eighth year, has established a remarkable record in reclaiming youth.
KANDY, Ceylon, June 25 (UP) -- A communique:

CHICAGO, June 25 -- The Ohio delegation to the Republican National Convention emphasized its determined and continuing support for the nomination of Gov. John W. Bricker as standard-bearer by adopting today a resolution requesting the convention to invite "all persons whose names are to be presented in nomination" to address the convention.

CHICAGO, June 25 -- A demand by outspoken Republican internationalists, headed by Gov. Walter E. Edge of New Jersey, that the party stand up and "take it" on the international issue, stood tonight as the chief possibility for important new developments at the party's national convention, which opens in the Chicago Stadium at 10:15 A.M. tomorrow.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Monday, June 26 (AP) -- A communique:

Pedestrian traffic was tied up for several hours yesterday on Fifty-first Street between Madison and Fifth Avenues while passersby thronged the Service Men's Outdoor Art Show, sponsored by the National Catholic Community Service.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 25 -- The French Forces of the Interior received today a status in the Allies' operations comparable to that of the invasion forces.

CHICAGO, June 25 -- Talk of Gov. Earl Warren of California for second place on the Republican ticket gained volume today despite his reiteration that he was not a candidate and had asked his State's delegation not to out him in nomination.

Blond-haired William F. Hulse, outstanding middle-distance runner from the home club, turned in the fastest outdoor mile of the season in winning the highlight of the 148th annual summer games of the New York Athletic Club yesterday at Randalls Island.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 25 (Reuter) -- A sketch drawn on the back of an envelope four years ago has played a big part in the American advance to Cherbourg.

ALBANY, June 25 (AP) -- Governor Dewey today appointed a State Industrial Council of nine members, reduced from fifteen, under a reorganization as the result of a long State investigation into administrational aspects of the Workmen's Compensation Law.

Leading American educators and representatives of twelve foreign nations have joined together to form a world education council, designed to raise money in the United States for the destroyed schools of Europe and Asia and to aid in the rehabilitation of the teaching professions of the occupied lands, it was learned yesterday.

TEANECK, N.J., June 25 -- As the setting sun played hide and seek with the rain clouds over this town today, Mrs. Sherman R. Hoyt of Stamford, Conn., waved to the winning post that outstanding boxer, Champion EL Wendie of Rockland.

CHICAGO, June 25 -- Mr. James A. Farley issued a political declaration of independence today, confirming a report that she will vote Republican unless the Democratic nominee is other than the present occupant of the White House.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., June 25 (AP) -- Freedom is "won and saved by individuals who know its true value to the soul of man," Under-Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson told members of the graduating class at the 149th commencement of Union College today.

When a church becomes more concerned with its self preservation than with the service it can render it ceases to be a church, the Rev. Ralph Beryl Nesbitt, associate pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue at Fifty-fifth Street, said yesterday in a sermon on "Are We Expendable?"

LONDON, Monday, June 26 (AP) -- Some 1,000 Flying Fortresses and Liberators escorted by 500 American fighters thundered out toward Spain from Britain yesterday and blasted the fuel depot and airdromes near Toulouse and other enemy plane nests in central France, including those at Bourges, 125 miles south of Paris, and Avord, twelve miles east of Bourges.

CHICAGO, June 25 -- Considering that the movement of winter wheat at far Southwest markets already has reached a substantial volume, there is still no great pressure on wheat futures, and on the other hand the market was strengthened several days last week by excellent buying by millers.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Monday, June 26 (AP) -- Maintaining their intense pressure against Japanese flank airbases which might menace the Saipan invasion, Gen. Douglas MacArthur's bombers smashed again at Yap Island, 650 miles southwest of the Marilanas, and hit fourteen other objectives in widespread raids, headquarters announced today.

Urging the adoption of an extensive program of child care as a plank in the platforms of both political parties this year, the Committee for the Care of Young Children has issued a plan to be considered by the Republican and Democratic conventions, Mrs. Elinor Gimbel, committee chairman, said yesterday.

LONDON, June 25 -- The Board of Trade's index of commodity prices for May, based upon 1930 as 100, set a new high for the war period of 166.1, compared with 165.5 in April and 163.3 a year ago. The aggregate increase since August, 1939, now is 69 per cent.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 25 (AP) -- Cherbourg's multiple harbors and elaborate port installations offered the Germans many chances for demolitions and obstructions, but it was doubtful whether their best efforts could prevent the Allies from swiftly exploiting this prize once it was securely in their hands.

ABOARD A UNITED STATES CRUISER, Off the French Coast, June 24 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The task of moving thousands of wounded men from the Normandy beach-head to Great Britain by sea has almost been completed and was accomplished with complete success, Navy Capt. George Dowling said today.

As the result of negotiations started in 1941, which subsequently involved litigation, the Niagara Falls Power Company, which supplies electric power to large war industries in the western part of New York State, will reduce its rates by approximately $1,000,000 a year in accordance with an order of the Public Service Commission of New York State, the commission announced yesterday.

The No. 1 objective of the American Red Cross is to start flowing to the Far East a steady stream of supplies such as it is sending to Europe, Maurice Pate, national director of American Red Cross Relief to Prisoners of War Service, yesterday told 1,000 next of kin of prisoners of war and interned civilians.

Col. Arthur V. McDermott, city Selective Service Director, announced yesterday that the city's local boards had been instructed that they might reclassify in 1-A and order for induction all doctors and dentists under 38 years old certified as available for military or naval service by the Procurement and Assignment Service of the War Manpower Commission, but who had failed to apply for commissions or who had declined to accept them.

ST. LOUIS, June 25 (AP) -- Marking up their 10th and 10th victories of the season over the Detroit Tigers, the league-leading St. Louis Browns won a doubleheader this afternoon, 5 to 4, in 10 innings and 5 to 2. The Detroit club has stopped the Browns only three times this year, twice last Sunday.

PROCESSED FOODS (various canned or bottled vegetables, fruits, fruit juices, soups, baby foods, jams, jellies and other special products, and certain dried beans). Blue stamps A8 through V8 in War Book 4 are good indefinitely, at 10 points each. No additional blue stamps become valid until July 1. Frozen fruits and vegetables and dried fruits are now point-free.

Mayor La Guardta used part of his radio broadcast from City Hall yesterday for an earnest appeal to New Yorkers to provide foster homes for 428 children whose parents were unable to give them proper care. The shortage of foster homes has become so great, the Mayor said, that some of the children in the best of health are now housed in city hospitals.

ALBANY, June 25 -- Governor Dewey returned here tonight from a week-end visit to his farm at Pawling avowedly still not a candidate for the Presidency, despite the fact that he is an odds-on favorite to win the Republican nomination on the first ballot.

Closing their twenty-fifth national convention at the Hotel Commodore, 200 members of the Yankee (26th) Division World War Veterans attended a solemn memorial mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday for members of the division killed in World War I and in the present conflict.

Hendrick Hudson Apartments, Inc., sold to Henry Goelet, operator, the eight-story apartment house at 380 Riverside Drive, occupying the blockfront from 110th to 111th Street. The building, which is on a plot 206 by 135 feet, contains 102 apartments of two to eight rooms each and was bought subject to a first mortgage of $735,000, which has just been extended for five years by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (U.P.) -The first two wounded soldiers to arrive in this country from the invasion beachhead in France were identified today by the War Department as Lieut. Col. Michael C. Murphy, 37, of Lafayette, Ind., and Pfc. James A. Lester, 21, of Route 3, Clio, Mich.

Citations for meritorious duty by 181 members of the Police Department were made public yesterday by Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine. The awards, covering all the 1944 cases reported upon by the departmental honor committee to date, included two honorable mentions, seventy-seven commendations and 102 citations for excellent police duty.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 25 (AP) -- The Jersey City Giants captured both ends of a doubleheader from the Rochester Red Wings today, 8 -- 4 and 3 -- 2. The Little Giants staged a thrilling last-inning rally to win the opener, scoring six runs after two were out.
Bill Voiselle hurled his tenth victory of the campaign at the Polo Grounds yesterday and kept the Giants in the first division of the National League's pennant chase.

LONDON, June 25 -- A British-American-Canadian communications center of the dimensions of a small town was busily at work 100 feet under the quiet English countryside controlling the assault on Cherbourg. Its first great function was to transmit orders for the invasion of Normandy, but its construction had been launched two years before D-day.

Three books on Argentina have been published or announced for summer publication. The first, "Argentina: Pivot of Pan American Peace," by Henry Albert Phillips, analyzes the South American problem from the Latin point of view.

CHICAGO, June 25 -- With Governor Dewey's nomination for President by the Republican National Convention now assured on the first ballot, the three New Yorkers heading the "draft Dewey" movement, J. Russel Sprague, national committeeman; Edwin F. Jaeckle, State chairman, and Herbert Brownell Jr., chairman of the law committee of the State committee, have won the admiration of party leaders for the effective way they have conducted their campaign for the New York Governor's nomination.

ALGIERS, June 25 -- The French Committee of National Liberation has protested to the American diplomatic mission here against the Stars and Stripes' publication of an article from the United States News saying that the differences between President Roosevelt and Gen. Charles de Gaulle had been caused by the President's reluctance to sanction the return of French overseas possessions without guarantees for American security.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 25 -- Harry Cohn of Columbia has announced the signing of Charles Boyer for a co-starring role, with Irene Dunne and Charles Coburn, in an untitled romantic comedy to be made late this summer. The story, dealing with the adventures of a famous sculptor in a small American town, is credited to Stanley Russell and based on an idea by Mark Hellinger.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., June 25 -- "We are winning great and historic battles in the Pacific because the Navy functions like a team," Secretary Forrestal told the graduating class at the commencement exercises of Swarthmore College today.

Although "Love on Leave" had every intention of continuing, the comedy, with juvenile delinquency for its theme, abruptly departed from the Hudson on Saturday night. In an effort to overcome adverse notices and to give the management an opportunity to make both ends meet, the actors had agreed to a one-third reduction in salary.

CHICAGO, June 25 -- Approval of the opening phases of a candy industry advertising campaign to start July 8 was given here this week-end at a meeting sponsored by the National Confectioners Association and presided over by Theodore Stempfel, chairman of the council on candy of the N.C.A.
MONTREAL, June 25 (AP) -- The Montreal Royals and the Newark Bears divided a twin bill today, the Royals taking the opener, 9 -- 8, but dropping the short second game, 2 -- 0.

Forecasting a huge rise this week in subscriptions to the Fifth War Loan with the opening of the intensive campaign for corporate subscriptions, Nevil Ford, State chairman of the War Finance Committee for New York, expressed his satisfaction yesterday with the progress of sales to individual buyers and predicted complete success for the over-all State campaign.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The Office of Price Administration moved today toward further simplification of maximum price regulations by enabling wholesale and retail sellers of bulk household soaps and cleansers to use the same mark-up factor for determining ceiling prices which they already use in figuring prices for the same goods in bar or package form.

CHICAGO, June 25 -- With Senator Albert W. Hawkes, of Montclair, N.J., the lone dissenter, the New Jersey delegation to the Republican National Convention recorded itself as 34 to 1 for Governor Dewey for President at a caucus held this noon at the Hotel Blackstone.

NEW ORLEANS, June 25 -- Word that the new extension bill for the Office of Price Administration would allow mills to pay about forty-seven points more for raw cotton than heretofore, with differentials for locations to be used as a basis for calculating goods ceilings, overshadowed favorable crop and war reports in cotton futures here last week.

WITH THE AMERICAN FORCES BEFORE CHERBOURG, June 25 -- Few battles have been as visible and as spectacular as today's. I watched much of it from the edge of a cliff looking directly down on most of Cherbourg, like a box seat at a theatre. It was the forward observation post of one of the leading elements in this assault and for a while an officer watched and gave directions for the supporting artillery fire.

While large numbers of buyers were in the market last week there has been a tapering off in arrivals, with a consequent lessening in demands for fall lines being noted. Deliveries of some fall merchandise already have begun, in some instances surprising buyers, according to a summary of activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

Official Washington breathed a sigh of satisfaction and relief at the news that the big Russian offensive was under way. It had been expected ever since the Allied invasion of France, for the grand strategy mapped at Teheran called for a simultaneous drive against Germany from the east and the west.

What better investment can an American make than in America? In other words, we are merely lending our dollars to the Government. Today these bonds represent the speeding of our forces on to Victory. Tomorrow they will enable us to continue to live in a democracy.

LONDON, June 25 -- The exuberant activity in the stock markets here that immediately followed the successful invasion of Normandy has given place to renewed inactivity and a slightly downward trend in prices. For this mild reaction despite continued good news from France, Germany's novel form of pilotless bombing of southern England is partly responsible.

Pan-American Airways did in 1943 a gross business of $126,000,000, Juan T. Trippe, president, says in the sixteenth annual report of the company, which will be mailed today to stockholders. This represented a gain of $16,500,000 over 1942.

Declaring that vandalism in the city parks costs the city at least $250,000 a year in repairs and that recently this evil has been aggravated by the shortage of park employes, police and material, Park Commissioner Robert Moses appealed yesterday to parents to control the acts of their children in city parks.

Baseball fans will witness a unique twist to the national pastime at the Polo Grounds tonight when the Yankees, Giants and Dodgers collide in the much-heralded three-cornered exhibition contest in support of the Fifth War Loan drive.

HEADQUARTERS OF THE CHINESE EXPEDITIONARY FORCE, June 25 -- Despite heavy artillery fire and ground attacks, 150 Japanese soldiers on Sungshan above the Salween River Burma Road crossing still occupy their tiny but murderous area near the crest of the mountain.

An ingenious job of creating a homelike atmosphere in starkly unhomelike surroundings -- and doing it on a shoestring -- has been turned out by Miss Gretchen Green in furnishing the Lady Halifax Club at 587 Fifth Avenue, recently opened for British service women stationed in New York.
LONDON, June 25 -- The battle for Cherbourg, which was reaching its climax tonight, is a battle for time as well as conquest.

PACIFIC FLEET HEADQUARTERS, Pearl Harbor, June 25 -- One hundred and nine aircraft and several damaged ships have been added to the enemy's losses in the Marianas campaign as a result of a more complete check-up.

Cherbourg has been entered, and the first great prize of the invasion is virtually in Allied hands after a great final assault that began with the war's mightiest combined barrage from land, from the sea and from the air, and is ending in bitter hand-to-hand fighting from house to house and from street to street.

Contributing in an extraordinary manner both to the amusement and amazement of 13,320 Flatbush fans, the Dodgers yesterday ran their winning streak to five games by flattening the Phillies twice and closing out their home stand with a clean sweep of the four-game series with Freddy Fitzsimmons' allegedly disorganized athletes.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The Veterans Administration was speeding preparations to carry out the terms of the new "GI Bill of Rights," Brig. Gen. Frank T. Hines, Administrator of Veterans Affairs, said today.

CHICAGO, June 25 -- A prediction that "our country is about to get back on the right road to sanity and success" under the leadership of a Republican President was made tonight by Representative Joseph W. Martin of Massachusetts, who will preside as permanent chairman at the party's national convention.
ROME, June 25 (AP) -- A communique:

On what auspicious and memorable day was that roadless roadster, the jeep, born? The world lay jeepless, not knowing what it had missed. Then, almost as suddenly as in a transformation scene in the theatre, the world was full of jeeps. They are in every country, indispensable in war.
CHUNGKING, China, June 25 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

Statisticians in Washington asi well aM marketing men everywhere were pleased to learn that the 1945 agricultural census was assured by the $7,250,000 appropriation voted by Congress last week. It is estimated that the cost of the census will come to about $1 for each farm family in the country.
PHILADELPHIA, June 25 -- The plan of the Cincinnati Stock Exchange for special offerings has been approved by the Securities and Exchange Commission, it has been announced.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 25 -- Playing even par golf and with their putters killing off the opposition, Harry C. Leyser and his guest, George Baird of the Rockville Country Club, won the best-ball tournament at the Cherry Valley Club today.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 25 -- Election of James Childs Rea, '04, Pittsburgh business executive, and Richard Folsom Cleveland, '20, Baltimore lawyer, as alumni trustees of Princeton University was announced today by Robert M. Green, '13, of Essex Fells, N.J., chairman of the university's National Alumni Association.

LONDON, June 25 -- Evidence from reconnaissance photographs indicates that the bombing of Berlin in the Eighth Air Force's attack Wednesday was the most devastating ever inflicted on the Nazi capital by day, United States Strategic Air Forces headquarters reported today.

LONDON, June 25 -- What seems to be definite confirmation of the view that the invasion of Europe by the Allies would bring about a decline in currency circulation is contained in last week's decline of more than 4,000,000 in the Bank of England's note circulation.

The full slate or regular organization candidates for Congress, the State Senate and Assembly and Municipal Court, to be passed on by Democratic voters in the August primaries, was announced yesterday by the New York County Democratic Committee.

PITTSBURGH, June 25 (AP) -- The Pirates rallied with three runs in the ninth inning to salvage a 5-5 tie in the second game of a twin bill against the Cardinals today, after dropping a 2-1 verdict in the curtain-raiser.

CHICAGO, June 25 (AP) -- The White Sox climbed into second place in the American League today when they swept a double-header from Cleveland, 11 to 0 and 4 to 3, before 26,442 fans. The second game was interrupted by rain with the tying run on first base in the Cleveland half of the eighth inning and, though the downpour soon ceased, the game was called after a fifty-minute wait because of wet grouns.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast domestically in Finland and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

LONDON, June 25 -- Dr. Ivan Subasitch, Yugoslavia's one-man government, and 21-year-old King Peter returned to London today from their mission to the Mediterranean to seek peace with Marshal Tito, Communist leader of the Yugoslav National Liberation Army.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- Lieut. Comdr. Chester W. Nimitz Jr., 29-year-old son of the Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet, has received the award of the Gold Star in lieu of a second Silver Star medal for "conspicuous heroism" and navigation skill during patrols in enemy waters, the Navy announced today.

The New York branch office of the Veterans' Administration, now occupying the entire building at 346 Broadway, is soon to occupy also the entire building at 350 Broadway. This will give the agency more than 100,000 square feet additional space for its activities, now centering in the building at 346 Broadway.

The egg supply situation has changed so sharply in the last three weeks because of decreasing production that dealers now are offering to buy back from the War Food Administration the same eggs they recently sold at lower prices.

ON THE CHERBOURG FRONT, June 25 -- The Allies' invasion of France probably saved Britain from even more severe bombing by robot planes. When the Germans retreated to Cherbourg, at least twenty-nine sites from which the enemy planned to launch pilotless planes were found.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 63:

CHICAGO, June 25 -- New York took officially tonight its long-delayed action in endorsing Governor Dewey for President, instructing the chairman of its delegation to the Republican National Convention to cast its solid bloc of ninety-three votes for him on the first ballot.

CHUNGKING, China, June 25 (AP) -- Japanese troops plunging down the Canton-Hankow railway have pierced the outer defenses of Hengyang, most important city yet attacked by the enemy since the fall of Canton and Hankow in 1938 the Chinese High Command announced tonight.
literary phenomena of our time.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- The War Manpower Commission has compiled a list of 10,000 civilian jobs in which returning veterans may use the specialized training received in the service.

The appointment of Darragh A. Park, vice president of the Manufacturers Trust Company, as general chairman for the annual campaign of the Travelers Aid Society of New York, which will move into high gear this week and continue through the summer, was announced yesterday.

Hundreds of wounded soldiers and sailors from nearby hospitals forgot the lines of war news blinking above Times Square last night to laugh at the lines in "The Voice of The Turtle," the hit comedy, which this week is being staged for the benefit of service personnel in the Morosco Theater, under the auspices of the New York Defense Recreation Committee.

CINCINNATI, June 25 (AP) -- The Reds and Cubs divided a doubleheader today, the Reds taking the opener, 4 to 3, to give Bucky Walters his twelfth triumph of the year, but dropping the nightcap, 5 to 0, victims of Claude Passeau's four-hit pitching.

Jesus Christ was portrayed as a master interpreter of life in a sermon yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks, rector of St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street.

WITH GENERAL STILWELL'S FORCES, in Burma, June 25 -- Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's forces made a big step forward in the process of destroying Japanese remnants in the Mogaung-Kamaing-Myitkyina area of North Burma yesterday when they broke into Mogaung, inflicting heavy casualties on the garrison.

New Yorkers are not ordinarily regarded as sensitive people, but it is possible to observe in them a growing allergy to one phrase often heard on the lips of their guests: "New York is a swell place to visit, but you couldn't pay me to live here."

BERNE, Switzerland, June 25 -- Some leaders of the resistance movement in France are preaching tolerance under the watchword, "France first," and their action implies a rebuke for all who advocate a general "purge" as a prerequisite to reconstruction.

CHICAGO, June 25 -- In the drive for unity which is in progress here by Republican leaders who feel it will be necessary in the campaign to make up for a certain lack of enthusiasm over the prospective Presidential candidate, members of the late movement in behalf of the renomination of Wendell L. Willkie are conspicuous.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
CHICAGO, Tuesday, June 27 -- The text of the draft of the Republican plank on foreign policy as approved by the foreign affairs committee follows:
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast domestically in Finland and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
LONDON, June 26 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Benjamin Schwartz, formerly director general of the Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel and chief of the scrap metals division of the Foreign Economic Administration, has been elected executive vice president and a member of the board of directors of the New York Commodities Corporation, it was announced yesterday at the offices of the company at 60 Broad St., New York.

The old-fashioned Christmas motif will return in this year's Yuletide displays in stores all over the country, it was reported here yesterday as the New York Display Market Week opened under the auspices of the National Association of Display Industries.

ABOARD JOINT EXPEDITIONARY FORCE FLAGSHIP, Saipan, June 26 (June 25, U.S. Time) (Via Navy Radio) -- American troops have captured towering Mount Tapotchau and held it against a pre-dawn counter-attack this morning as the fast-developing victory of Saipan gave high-ranking officers here every confidence that capture of the whole Marianas chain was assured.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26 -- In compliance with a consent decree filed in the Federal court today, a check for $20,000 was turned over to the Federal Treasury by Bornot, Inc., chain cleaners and dyers, with headquarters here, in repayment of over-ceiling prices allegedly charged its customers.

John E. Wade, City Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday that there would be no cessation of waste paper salvage during the ten weeks after schools are closed on Friday for the summer vacation. He said the Board of Education's 345 vacation playgrounds would be organized for the scrap drive.
Before we commit triple murder against the newly coined English word "triphibious," let us give it a chance.

BUFFALO, June 26 (AP) -- The Newark Bears rallied for a tally in the ninth inning to capture a 5-4 decision over the Buffalo Bisons here tonight. It was the fourth reverse in five starts for the locals since returning from a long road trip.
TOLEDO, June 26 (AP) -- Notre Dame and Washington University of St. Louis scored heavily today in the 1944 National Intercollegiate Golf Tournament.

Your timely editorial on Magna Carta Day, usually celebrated in England the Sunday after June 15, recalls the fact that the best-preserved of the three extant copies of this great monument of freedom lies hidden from human gaze in an obscure vault under the aegis of the Librarian of Congress.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- Expectations of heavy hedging sales incident to a large movement of new winter wheat in the Southwest resulted today in an early dip of 1/2 to 3/4 cent a bushel in wheat futures on the Board of Trade. The pressure came mainly from professional traders, but later there was short covering based on the strength of cotton.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, June 26 (AP) -- The principal Japanese Burma bastion of Myitkyina, where fighting already raged within the city on the southern side, was under strong American attack from the north. This force was near a junction with Chinese attacking the western outskirts, the communique announced.

There is little prospect that style restrictions on men's and boys' clothing will be lifted in any manner this year, industry observers declared yesterday. The War Production Board, they said, had no plans for easing limitations of L-224.

WASHINGTON, June 26 --]3y July the navy yards and private shipyards will require 138,000 workers in addition to the present force of 1,475,000, Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the Var Manpower Commission, said today.

The Government should adopt promptly a policy "which will declare jigs, dies and fixtures to be scrapped when they are no longer being used for production purposes," E.M. Martin, special assistant to the Surplus War Property Administrator, said yesterday at the seventh annual convention and exhibit of the National Supply Association of America in the Commodore Hotel.

ALBANY, June 26 -- The speed with which the Dewey bandwagon is rolling along at Chicago made it possible tonight that Governor Dewey would fly to the Republican National Convention to accept the nomination for the Presidency rather than travel by train as originally scheduled.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 26 -- Harry R. Bridges, West Coast longshoremen's leader, received the second rebuff today in his Federal Court fight to avoid deportation to his native Australia as an undesirable alien who once allegedly was a member of the Communist party.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Tuesday, June 27 -- United States Flying Fortresses and Liberators 500 to 750 strong roared from Italian bases to the Vienna area yesterday through the heaviest Luftwaffe opposition in recent weeks and attacked oil refineries, rail yards and a Nazi aircraft plant.

Yesterday Siena, that fought so much in her great days, was approached by the American forces. Perhaps there is no other Italian city that bears so completely the seal of the Middle Ages. Yet its Roman origin is marked by its arms, which it shares with Rome. The Sienese claimed to be descendants of Senius, son of Remus.

LONDON, Tuesday, June 27 -- The Red Army, tearing out the northern and southern anchors of the German defense line in White Russia, captured the fortress cities of Vitebsk and Zhlobin yesterday and seized more than 1,700 towns and settlements, while the vanguard of their victorious forces advanced more than twenty-two miles toward Minsk for a great pincer assault on that city.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26 -- A plan for the merger of four of the operating subsidiaries of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation to form a new company to be known as the Manufacturers Light and Heat Company was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Stockholders of the Brill Corporation and of the American Car and Foundry Motors Company, two subsidiaries of the American Car and Foundry Company, were informed yesterday by Charles J. Hardy, president of Brill, and Lester A. Blackford, president of American Car and Foundry Motors, of details of the plan to merge the two companies into a new company to be called A.C.F.-Brill Motors Company.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The State Department resumed today the publication of changes of assignments in the Foreign Service, on the grounds that the war had progressed to the point that the information would no longer be of real value to the enemy. Publication of the changes, which formerly was announced periodically, was discontinued alter Pear Harbor for reasons of security.

CHICAGO, Tuesday, June 27 -- Sixteen Republican Governors, delegates to the National Convention, who demanded last night that they be made better acquainted with the platform, apparently succeeded early today in inspecting the proposed planks but not in changing any of them substantially.

Although hailing the Government's objective of raising by current taxation the largest practicable portion of funds required for waging war as "sound fiscal policy," the Guaranty Trust Company in the current issues of the Guaranty Survey, declared that with the return to peace, a distribution of the tax load "will become again the vitally important question that it was before the war."

Although well aware that they would have to purchase against quotas, some of which previously had been filled, 3,500 buyers of furniture for retail dealers crowded into the Furniture Exchange Building yesterday at the opening of the semi-annual New York Furniture Market.

Governor Warren's keynote speech last night to the Republican convention follows pretty closely the long-established bipartisan pattern for such addresses. The gist of this, for the party in power, is to claim credit for all good things as of its own creation, and for the party out of power to blame the in's as the source of all misfortune.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, June 26 (AP) -- A traveler arriving here today said seventy persons had been injured last night in a pitched battle in Guatemala City between armed civilians and police, and that tension was mounting throughout the country.
CHICAGO, June 26 -- The only genuinely warm spot at this convention, when you're out of the sun or get from under the stadium kliegs, is Bricker headquarters.

MOSCOW, June 26 -- The listing of no fewer than twenty-four generals for commendation by Premier Stalin in his orders of the day to the commanders of four fronts engaged in tearing up the German defenses in White Russia provides an indication of the sweeping regrouping that has been carried out by the Red Army during its strategic pause preceding the summer offensive.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Tuesday, June 27 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today the creation of a new air arm, to be known as the Far Eastern Air Force, with headquarters in Australia.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull again raised his voice against the mistreatment of Jews by Axis countries in commenting today upon the resolution of the House Committee on Foreign Affairs calling upon Hungary to halt her mistreatment of Jews.

It is a coincidence that whales of the familiar type have been appearing in local Long Island waters just when a new cetacean form of life has come prominently to the fore in the remoter seas. The recent visitors in Oyster Bay and Flushing Bay are described as small whales, but even a small whale is a pretty big creature.

NEWARK, N.J., June 26 -- Mrs. Winthrope Crowhurst, 32-year-old mother of four children, was found dead this morning in the front seat of her automobile in the garage back of the family home at 761 Parker Street. An autopsy report ascribed the death to "carbon monoxide poisoning, pending further investigation."

The partial revelation by Prime Minister Winston Churchill, in the House of Commons, on June 20, that a great deal of sea-borne apparatus which had been poised for an invasion of Britain in June, 1940, was sunk by the RAF in European ports dears up, in part, one of the war's mysteries.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 26 -- Dosoris Pond, a 110-acre lake on the former estate of the late J.P. Morgan at Matinecock Point on East Island, a landmark here for 300 years and one of the beauty spots of the East, was preserved for posterity today when two owners of estates bordering on it bought it from a real estate operator.

ABOARD H.M.S. GLASGOW, off Cherbourg Harbor, June 25 (Delayed) -- American battleships and heavy cruisers, supported by two British cruisers and seven destroyers, are firing broadside after broadside into German shore batteries at vital key points on the fringes of Cherbourg harbor in support of the Army.

BOSTON, June 26 (AP) -- Max Marmorstein's Baroque overcame a claim of foul by Jockey A. Daniels on Mrs. Rose M. Buccola's Billy O today to win the featured $2,500 Peabody Purse of a mile and a sixteenth at Suffolk Downs.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The prosecution in the mass sedition trial sought today to establish its right to try the case in the District of Columbia on the ground that some of the defendants' propaganda allegedly designed to disaffect the armed forces was received here.

WITH THE AMERICAN TROOPS in Cherbourg, 9:12 P.M. June 26 -- Fanatic defenders of Cherbourg made a last desperate effort today to hold out against doughboys closing in to wipe out the last pockets of resistance.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- When Governor Dewey appears before the Republican National Convention this week to accept its Presidential nomination, his hearers will include many in the convention as well as in the radio audience who will not find sufficiently precise and forthright a number of planks in the party platform.
Net profit reported yesterday by the Cosden Petroleum Corporation and its subsidiary for the fiscal year ended with April disclosed a net profit of $411,959 after Federal tax provision of $341,368.

ST. LOUIS, June 26 (AP) -- Dr. Irving Langmuir, Nobel prize winner in physics, and Dr. Arthur H. Kehoe, vice president of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, received awards for contributions to electrical engineering in today's session of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers.

CHICAGO, June 26 (AP) -- Hog marketing conditions improved considerably today with holdovers negligible. Trading was more nearly normal at all markets throughout the Midwest than at any time since April. Good clearances were reported at most of the markets that have been experiencing difficulties recently. The main factors in the improvement were reduced receipts and good clearance last week.

CHUNGKING, China, June 26 (AP) -- Chinese troops have held their ground in bitter fighting around Hengyang, and American planes have been thrown into the battle around that vital rail junction and elsewhere in Hunan Province, it was announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- The destroyer escort Fechteler was lost in combat in the Mediterranean last month, the Navy announced today. Indicating that casualties had occurred, the Navy said that next of kin had been notified.

ALGIERS, June 26 -- In one of the most optimistic speeches that he has made Gen. Charles de Gaulle told the Provisional Consultative Assembly today of the agreement just made with the Allies for cooperation with the resistance forces.

Three more former champions have been added to the list of players who will take part in the Red Cross Victory Drive tennis exhibitions to be held at Forest Hills Sunday, Monday and Tuesday, Independence Day.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- Montgomery Ward Co. filed suit today against the War Labor Board to enjoin enforcement of the board's June 6 order requiring maintenance of membership at their Chicago plaint.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The value of strategic materials bought in foreign countries with Government funds and used in the manufacture of war materials by either the United States or its allies totaled about $265,800,000 in the first three months of this year, Leo T. Crowley, Foreign Economic Administrator, reported today.

Simon Guggenheim, late president of the American Smelting and Refining Company and former United States Senator from Colorado, left a gross estate of $17,030,160 and a net of $16,557,291, according to schedules approved yesterday by David Krakaur, metropolitan district appraiser.
How can we manage to buy War Bonds? Corporations, by paying only moderate dividends during the war period, can help their Government and themselves by investing their surplus funds in War Bonds.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- With Governor Dewey as good as nominated, interest in New York State's delegation to the Republican Convention has naturally switched to the major place at stake in New York State itself, that of candidate for United States Senator to oppose Robert F. Wagner in November.
CHUNGKING, Tuesday, June 27 (U.P.) -- Chinese and Chindit troops have completed the occupation of Mogaung, second of three powerful Japanese bases in Burma, a Chinese communique announced today.
Mr. and Mrs. William Robertson Coe have gone to Hot Springs, Va., to remain a few weeks before spending the Summer on their ranch at Cody, Wyo.

Closer adult companionship and understanding in child care was urged yesterday by Miss Cornelia Goldsmith of the New York City Bureau of Child Hygiene at a conference on planning for younger children held at Teachers College, Columbia University.

The city's facilities for dealing with juvenile delinquency are so inadequate that probationary supervision by the Children's Court is frequently an "empty gesture," many delinquents who should be committed to institutions are placed on probation, and truancy is superficially handled in the school system, according to four reports made public yesterday by Mayor La Guardia's Committee on Juvenile Delinquency.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 26 -- Humphrey Bogart, under contract suspension from Warners for his refusal of the lead in "God Is My Co-Pilot," is expected to be named this week by that company for the co-starring role opposite Bette Davis in the screen version of "The Two Mrs. Carrolls."

FOR most purposes, whether it is sailing from New York to Liverpool or following the progress of the fighting on any one of the world's many war fronts, almost any old north-south-axis map will do. But if you want to know the "why" of any particular action on the earth's surface, the standard maps may be completely misleading.

A warning against efforts to destroy unity in this country in the prosecution of the war was given last night by Assistant United States Attorney General Norman M. Littell in an address in Madison Square Garden, where 20,000 attended a Negro Freedom Rally.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- Wendell Willkie's statement, calling the foreign-affairs plank "ambiguous" and ineffectual, caught supporters of the 1940 candidate off guard tonight. They said they were "completely astonished" by the statement of their principal.

The German people are probably too busy and possibly too apathetic to do much more than try to cope with the ever-growing problems of daily and hourly existence. Food, clothing, shelter, refuge from Allied bombs, escape from Gestapo terror, and the creeping fear of millions of hostile foreign workers in the land are even more pressing and immediate matters for the individual at home than developments on still-distant fronts.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- Selection of Governor Warren of California as running-mate for Governor Dewey appeared a virtual certainty tonight as the Republican National Convention settled down to the task of filling out its 1944 ticket.

CHICAGO, Tuesday, June 27 -- The Republican party platform will favor "participation by the United States in post-war cooperative organization among sovereign nations to prevent military aggression and to attain permanent peace."

In your issue of June 14 you published a cable from London with respect to King Leopold's deportation to Germany. This report said in part: "The King, who ordered his armies to lay down their arms and who concluded an unexpected armistice with the Germans on May 18, 1940."

LONDON, June 26 -- The British are taking Adolf Hitler's newest weapon, the pilotless dynamite plane, in stride, just as they did the blitz of 1941, but it appears as if they may be called upon to stretch that courage a bit further. Hitler has promised an even more fiendish weapon than V-1.

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 26 (AP) -- The New Jersey State women's tennis tournament opened at the Oritani Field Club today with third-seeded Miss Helen Germain of New York, 1942 titleholder, moving into the quarter-finals after a severe second-round test almost ended her come-back attempt.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- George P. McNear Jr., president of the Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad Company, today made application to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to issue promissory notes to be limited at this time to $500,000, and at the same amount at any one time, and to sell at this time $100,000 of these notes at par, bearing interest at 3 per cent.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 26 -- A movement for immediate rapprochement with the Soviet Union is spreading across the country and the number of leading Turks advocating a Turkish-Russian alliance is increasing daily.

Competition, which is so often called the spice of life, was sorely lacking at Aqueduct yesterday when less than fifty horses were sent to the post to provide entertainment for the 21,961 racing fans who turned out in greater number than on Saturday, War Bond day.
LONDON, June 26 (AP) -- The Berlin radio said tonight that Viscount Lascelles, 21-year-old nephew of King George VI, had been captured on the Italian front.

Interests headed by A.S. Kirkeby, nationally known hotel man, who have operated the Hotel Gotham at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street under a lease for the last five years, have purchased the property from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, it was announced yesterday.

Chilling spines, an excellent idea for warm weather, is the aim of Agatha Christie's mystery thriller, "Ten Little Indians," opening tonight at the Broadhurst instead of the Barrymore, as originally planned. Rampant murder is the theme of this "whodunit," the action of which develops on a lonely island off the coast of England.

As time passes, the extent of our victory in the great air battle over the Marianas will be more fully realized. The dramatic pursuit of the task force which brought the enemy planes to action, and the escape of the force with four ships lost and thirteen damaged, have obscured the decisive nature of the Japanese defeat in the air off Saipan the day before.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The Pennsylvania Railroad Company filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission objections to the submission of the plan of reorganization of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company to the creditors of the New Haven for voting.

Dead fish by the hundreds collected at dams and obstructions along a twenty-two mile stretch of the Ramapo River yesterday as one of the worst cases of fresh water pollution in this region became known.

The cookery of Czechoslovakia is a favorite subject with Mrs. Jan Papanek, the American-born wife of that country's Minister here. In fact, Mrs. Papanek's hobby is making Czech pastries according to the recipes she gathered abroad. Whenever she talks about the cuisine of her husband's native land, it is of these desserts that she speaks first.

After a lapse of two years, New York University will field a football team this fall, it was announced yesterday. The council of the university, governing body of the institution, voted its approval of the recommendation submitted by the Board of Athletic Control, of which Prof. Philip O. Badger is chairman.

The editorial "On Expecting the Millennium" appearing in today's issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES needs clarification inasmuch as it ignores facts of historical importance to the future of our relations with the liberated countries.

LONDON, June 26 -- The final chapter in the checkered history of the British Overseas Bank, formed after the last war to revive trade with eastern Europe, was written today with announcement of transfer of its business to Glyn, Mills Co. Realization of the bank's assets, once valued at 2,000,000 but now about 300,000 because they are frozen in occupied Europe, will be undertaken by the Continental Assets Realization Trust.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- The arrival of Governor Dewey to accept the Republican nomination for President will be timed to suit the convenience of the delegates to the national convention. This was made known today by J. Russel Sprague, National Committeeman from New York, who has been leading the "Draft Dewey" movement now approaching success.

Three dimensional baseball, presented by the War Bond Sports Committee in connection with the Fifth War Loan, made its debut at the Polo Grounds last night and produced a most astounding series of results.
LONDON, June 26 -- The satisfactory war news had a cheering effect on today's stock markets and a demand developed for some of the leading industrials.

Sales of New York and Brook lyn department stores showed a rise of 26 per cent last week over the like period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the .preceding week the bank had reported a rise of 6 per cent.

The Himoff Machine Works Corporation has purchased a plot, 50 by 100 feet, on the south side of Forty-fourth Road, near Crescent Street, in Long Island City, adjoining its plant, for improvement with an addition. The Roman-Caswell Company was the broker.
ADVANCED NINTH AIR FORCE FIGHTER BASE, on Cherbourg Front, June 25 (Delayed) -- This is just to report another chipped place in that fabulous mosaic that portrays the German as a super soldier.

HAVERFORD, Pa., June 26 (AP) -- Top-seeded Charles Oliver of Perth Amboy (N.J.) High School, defending champion, eliminated C. Wesley Kittleman, Andover Academy, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 0, and Linton Baldwin, Brooklyn Poly, 6 -- 5, 6 -- 4, in the first day's play of the national interscholastic tennis championships at the Merion Cricket Club today.

A few hours after Wendell Willkie had received the text of the proposed Republican foreign-policy plank, the 1940 Presidential candidate issued a statement denouncing the plan as ambiguous, subject to opposing interpretations and capable of being used to throttle effective collaboration by the United States with other countries to maintain peace.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (U.P.) -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, predicted tonight that the $668,695,428 farm machinery program for 1943-44 would be "substantially achieved," although it was 10.7 per cent behind schedule on June 1.

Even before it has ended, June has set new financial records. D-day brought a spirited advance in the stock market, sending prices to the best level since May, 1940, when France collapsed. THE NEW YORK TIMES rail average rose to the best point since September, 1937.

A series of twelve "starlight" dances for service men will be opened tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Heckscher Playground in Central Park, near Fifty-ninth Street, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Harold I. Pratt, who is supervising the series.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Tuesday, June 27 (UP)

CHICAGO, June 26 -- The twenty-third national convention of the Republican party finally opened at 11:17 A.M. today in a mixed atmosphere of hope and optimism that this year may work a return to the national control wrested by the Democrats from the "Grand Old Party" in 1932.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast in English from, Chungking to the United States and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26 (AP) -- W. Alton Jones, president of the Cities Service Company, testified today before the Securities and Exchange Commission that his purchases of preferred stock and debentures of the Cities Service Power and Light Company had "no relation to any plan, suggestion or idea regarding subsequent recapitalization of Power and Light."

ROME, June 26 (AP) -- American and French troops slugged their way within less than fifteen miles of the inland city of Siena and within forty-five miles of Florence after American forces rolling up the west coast had captured the port of Piombino without a fight, headquarters announced today.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- A plan to give small plants a head start in the return to essential civilian production was announced today by Maury Maverick, chairman of the Smaller War Plants Corporation.

KANDY, Ceylon, June 26 (UP) -- A communique: ropping up continued west and east of the Kohima-Imphal road. Enemy parties are disorganized and appear in bad physical condition: In addition to stores and equipmen 'two 70-ram. guns and two gnU-tank guns were captured. The body of Mrs. Mary Brush Williams, a writer, who was found dead in her room at 100 West Fifty-fourth Street on Sunday, remained in the morgue yesterday while detectives sought relatives.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 26 (AP) -- The Jersey City Giants made it three victories in two days over the faltering Rochester Red Wings here tonight, taking a loosely-played game, 11 to 7.

Yesterday's session on the New York Stock Exchange was the twelfth out of the last thirteen in which the volume of trading has been more than 1,000,000 shares. The actual figure, in a market which advanced selectively and closed generally higher, was 1,720,260 shares, against 1,301,015 on Friday.

The film can be developed at home by the user, with only fifteen minutes of the development time spent in the dark room.

The British radio said yesterday that Benito Mussolini had a film made of the execution of his son-in-law, Count Ciano, and other members of the former Fascist grand council sentenced to death for their "betrayal of fascism."
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Twenty-seven small concerns have won the Army-Navy Production Award. They are:
A check for $42,500, representing the net profit from the Red Cross open golf tournament held, recently at the Wykagyl Country Club, was turned over to the Red Cross yesterday.

With the graduation of 1,350 new ensigns on Thursday, the Naval Reserve Midshipmen's School at Columbia University will have trained 15,500 officers, or twice the number of line officers in the Navy at the time of the school's inception four years ago, Capt. John K. Richards, commanding officer of the school, announced yesterday.

"Bathing Beauty," a musical produced by Metro and filmed in Technicolor, will open this morning at the Astor. The film stars Esther Williams, a former swimming champion, and Red Skelton; Basil Rathbone, Donald Meek, Jean Porter, Bill Goodwin and Harry James and Xavier Cugat and their bands are among the featured players.

WITH THE AMERICAN FORCES at Cherbourg, June 26 -- The Germans fought a last-ditch defense in Cherbourg this evening, though the outcome was inescapable. Substantial elements of the American forces got into the city from the south only after a piece-by-piece conquest of succeeding strong points and the Germans were still firing on them in the city and from two pillboxes remaining on Fort du Roule with 88-mm. field-pieces and machine guns.

LONDON, June 26 -- France's army without uniforms was reported today to have been joined in resistance by miners of northern France, who are staging a sit-down strike. This is the first instance of its kind reported from France since the invasion began.

The German Air Force, absent from the Normandy invasion, went into the air to attack a "diversion" fleet that the Allies sent on D-day into the Calais-Boulogne area, Comdr. Anthony Kimmins, British naval intelligence officer, said yesterday.

A crowd of 50,000 baseball fans, all of whom paid their way into the park by buying war bonds, turned out last night at the Polo Grounds to witness a bizarre contest in which the Yankees, Giants and Dodgers participated in a nine-inning contest.

It must be said in all candor that the list of the American delegates to the United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference is not encouraging. While it includes one or two good appointments, the qualifications of the membership as a whole fall distinctly below those, for example, of the British delegation.

ROME, June 26 -- Prime Minister Jan Christiaan Smuts of South Africa told South African and British troops today, before ending a brief visit to Italy, that they could look forward to a conclusive victory in the not distant future. Field Marshal Smuts had just come from a trip with Prime Minister Churchill to Normandy.

The Regional Office of Price Administration announced yesterday that it had moved in the Federal court to break up a black market in radios. This black market, according to Daniel P. Woolley, regional OPA administrator, has been "assembling ersatz radio sets from surplus excess parts in the hands of dealers and manufacturers" and selling them to families of servicemen and war workers at exorbitant prices.

Possible allocation of fluid milk to dealers in the New York-New Jersey metropolitan area next fall when production ebbs was discussed at a conference of 200 milk handler representatives and health authorities at the Hotel Commodore by Dr. C.J. Blanford, local Market Agent for the War Food Administration's milk conservation program.
OTTAWA, June 26 -- Presenting his budget estimates to the House of Commons tonight, Finance Minister J.L. Ilsley announced that he would abandon as of July 1 "compulsory savings."

The Opera Festival at the Lewisohn Stadium got under way last night with a performance of Verdi's "Aida," sung by a cast drawn largely from the roster of the Metropolitan. Orchestral support was provided by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony conducted by Alexander Smallens.

At graduation exercises, where she saw her fellow classmates for the first time, a 16-year-old poliomyelitis victim who, despite her handicaps, including an inability to write, had attained an average grade of 93 and with only eight months' training developed a fine soprano voice, yesterday received one of 301 diplomas awarded in the Joan of Arc Junior High School auditorium, 154 West Ninety-third Street.

The strangely identical death cries of a mother and daughter who died apparently of natural causes twenty-eight months apart started an investigation that culminated last night in the revelation that they had been murdered by strychnine poisoning.

A new issue of $3,900,000 of airport bonds was announced yesterday by St. Louis, Mo., for award on July 11. The bonds will be dated Aug. 1, 1944, and will mature serially on Aug. 1, 1949 to 1956. Bidders are to name the coupon rate.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- Reports coming out of executive sessions of the Resolutions Committee engrossed feminine delegates to the Republican convention today, now that gossip has almost ceased about the probable nominee. Two planks of special interest to the women's group have been written into the document, according to reports, one of them over the protests of Senators Taft of Ohio, Danaher of Connecticut and Milliken of Colorado.

Indications that the War Production Board's procedures for appeals from material control orders will play an important part in the reconversion of plants to civilian production were seen here yesterday when P.L. Salussolia, regional appeals manager for the agency, reported that appeals by manufacturers had increased between 30 and 40 per cent in the last three months.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Occupational therapy programs, which have been under way in the sixty general hospitals of the Army, will be extended into sixty regional hospitals starting July 1 and progress as fast as it is possible to obtain trained personnel.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- France was falling as the Republicans met four years ago. It was an hour of defeat for democracy and all the traditional whoopee was turned on to make the delegates forget what the disaster portended for the United States.

A syndicate of investors formed by Harris Newmark has purchased the seventeen-story business building on a plot 68 by 100 feet at 37 West Forty-seventh Street from Frederick Brown, who acquired it three months ago from the Roosevelt Hospital.

PACIFIC FLEET HEADQUARTERS, Pearl Harbor, June 26 -- Mount Tapotchau on Saipan Island has been scaled by United States Marines who are now established in positions near the summit. Marines and Army troops have made substantial gains on both the eastern and western shores of the island.

EVANSTON, Ill., June 26 (AP) -- Francisco (Pancho) Segura, the defending champion from Miami University, paced sixteen survivors into the third round of the national collegiate tennis singles at Northwestern University today with a 6-1, 6-3 victory over Utah's Dick Warner.
CHUNGKING, China, June 26 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

CHICAGO, June 26 -- The declining prospect that Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio can win the nomination as Republican standard bearer failed today to diminish the persistency with which he and his backers are pressing his campaign.

Shortages of cocoa beans, employes and packing materials are preventing the candy industry from supplying much more than half the needs of the armed forces and about one-quarter of the civilian demand, Irving C. Shaffer, president of the Association of Manufacturers of Confectionery and Chocolate, said yesterday.
CHICAGO, June 26 -- The official program for tomorrow's sessions of the Republican National Convention is as follows:

Details of how the Maritime Commission took over a $2,000,000 privately owned shipyard with a good producing record -- the Marine Maintenance Corporation of Bayonne, N.J. -- and turned its operation over to a company headed by a former official of the commission, were spread on the record of a hearing of a sub-committee of the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee yesterday afternoon in the Federal Building.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Tuesday, June 27 -- Cherbourg, France's third greatest port, has fallen to the American troops in the first outstanding victory of the Allied campaign to liberate France.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- The Republican Platform Drafting Committee was racing with the clock late tonight, despite the development of new complications from outside the policy-framing body itself, to complete its budget of declarations and pledges to the now formally organized Resolutions Committee by 9 o'clock tomorrow morning and for its tests before the convention as a whole before the end of the day.

"Fair Stood the Wind for France," by H.E. Bates, published in May by Little, Brown, will be the first book to be dramatized on the new series of the Council on Books in Wartime's radio program, "Words at War," which will be broadcast under new sponsorship over the NBC network Tuesdays at 9:30 P.M. beginning tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Heeding War Department calls for aid in the "pressing problem" of keeping the European and Pacific air offensives aloft and adequately fueled, the Office of the Rubber Director announced today plans for diverting up to 400,000 barrels of butylene, a petroleum product, from the synthetic rubber program to the manufacture of 100-octane aviation gasoline.

CHICAGO, Tuesday, June 27 -- A triple pledge to bring the boys back home quickly and "victorious," to reopen the doors of opportunity to "all Americans," and to guard the peace in the future, was sounded yesterday as the Republican battle-cry at the opening of the party's twenty-third national convention.

Four 'teen-age youths, charged with being members of a gang of thirty boys who molested a young soldier on furlough in front of his home and threatened him with a mugging, were held in $100 bail each by Magistrate Anna M. Kross in Night Court last night.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 26 -- The uneven strength of divisions, the wide use of non-German troops and the lack of uniformity in armament contribute to the belief that the German army facing the Allies in Normandy is a lesser vehicle than the military machine that awed Europe in 1940 and 1941.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26 -- The Savannah Gas Company, a subsidiary of the American Gas and Power Company, asked permission today of the Securities and Exchange Commission to reduce its capital stock from $1,400,000 to $672,000 by cutting the par value of each of the 56,000 outstanding shares, all owned by the parent, from $25 to $12 a share.

Thomas L. Norton, chairman of the regional War Labor Board, issued a statement yesterday denying charges appearing in an advertisement placed in THE NEW YORK TIMES by Local 425 of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, an affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Tuesday, June 27 (AP) -- The badly mauled Japanese air force in the New Guinea-Solomons theatre may have withdrawn to safer bases within the Netherland Indies and the Philippines, headquarters disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 64:

Interest in properties in Hoboken, N.J., was stressed yesterday in the purchase of the eighteen-family apartment house at 504-06 Adams Street by the Young Corporation of Newark from the City of Hoboken. The C.B. Snyder agency was the broker in the deal.

NEW DELHI, India, June 27 -- An objective as important as Myitkyina fell to Lieut. Gem Joseph W. Stilwell's forces on Monday with the capture of Mogaung, railway town at the entrance of the Mogaung Valley in northern Burma.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27 (AP) -- Charlie Oliver of Perth Amboy, N.J., defending champion, was knocked out of the national interscholastic tennis tournament today by Bernard Bartzen, fifth seeded player from San Angelo, Tex., who racked up an 8 -- 6, 6 -- 2 victory to reach the semi-final round.

RYE, N.Y., June 27 -- Ellis Knowles of Apawamis, who in his first two years of United States senior competition established a pair of records, stood on the threshold of a third history-making event this evening after shattering par with 36 35 -- 71 in the opening round of the Seniors' Golf Association fortieth annual championships tournament at the Apawamis Club.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Scrolls to the cities of Leningrad and Stalingrad, signed by President Roosevelt and commemorating in the name of the people of the United States their admiration for the heroic defense of the two cities, were presented to Premier Joseph Stalin today by W. Averell Harrirnan, the American Ambassador in Moscow.

STANTON, Del., June 27 (AP) -- Jacian, under the silks of Sammy Hicks and ridden by Johnny Breen, won the featured mile and a furlong fifth race at Delaware Park today, scoring by a half length over Charles Turner's Red Cin.
Once again the stock market marched into higher ground, and the close yesterday came at about the best levels of the current movement. Coppers were in the lead.
LONDON, June 27 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- Civilians who plan railroad travel this summer especially over July 4 were warned tonight that they might be roused from their berths to spend the night in the smoking room.

The site of New York's proposed World Fashion Center, Mayor La Guardia disclosed yesterday, will extend from Twenty-fourth to Thirtieth Street, inclusive, between Broadway and Sixth Avenue, and from Twenty-fifth to Twenty-seventh Street, between Broadway and Fifth Avenue.

New issues of notes, aggregating $19,632,000, will be offered on July 6 by eight housing authorities in various parts of the country. All the issues will be dated July 25, 1944, but they will mature variously from Feb. 27, 1945, to Aug. 28, 1945.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 27 -- The breakdown of relations between the Germany Army and the Propaganda Ministry was further accentuated today by the surprise and fear with which the announcement of the loss of Cherbourg was greeted by the German people, neutral dispatches from Berlin said tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- A statement regarding the post-war economic policies of China was made today by Dr. H.H. Kung, who in his capacity as Vice President of the Executive Yuan is virtually Premier of China.

ALBANY, June 27 -- Governor Dewey devoted the afternoon to putting finishing touches on the acceptance speech which he will make tomorrow night at Chicago if nominated by then as the Republican candidate for President.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- This was wash-out day for the Wasp training program, with Army orders carrying out the closing-down legislated by Congress.

Mayor La Guardia yesterday kept a promise made to a little girl eight years ago. Not only did he witness the graduation exercises at Public School 9, at 466 West End Avenue, and see his little friend, Dorothy Davis, 13, get her diploma, but he himself handed out the hard-earned "sheepskins" and addressed the graduates.

Businesses now making a taxable profit can buy expanded advertising at a large discount, according to the Eddy-Rucker-Nickels Company, management and advertising counselors, 1400 Massachusetts Avenue, Cambridge, Mass., and in the case of firms in the excess profits bracket that discount is 85 1/2 per cent.

ONEIDA, N.Y., June 27 (AP) -- Holders of 7 per cent cumulative and participating preferred stock of Oneida, Ltd., were notified today of the creation of a new class of 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock, in 95,660 shares of $25 par value each.

Today the City Planning Commission will open a hearing which ought to have special interest for the young, for it concerns the future city. As stated in the official announcement the subject is fairly formidable. It is a revision of the zoning resolution, arrived at by the usual method of adding new matters in italics and omitting old matter in brackets.

The New York State Conservation Department is a stolid body not given to whimsy or idle apprehensions for the future, but right now it is expressing concern over what will happen to the State's natural resources when our service men return and direct the marvelous new devices of war against fish and game.
CHICAGO, June 27 -- The prepared text of the speech by Representative Clare Boothe Luce of Connecticut before the Republican National Convention tonight was as follows:...

Of the clubs in the American League that have troubled the pace-setting Browns none has been more bothersome to Luke Sewell's high-flying aggregation than the Yankees. A glance at the standings reveals that the teams have met seven times so far and in five of the meetings the decision has gone to the New Yorkers.

Town clothes take on increased importance since vacations in New York are a patriotic necessity. The stores have risen to the occasion, offering a variety of styles for all the divertissements New York City offers. Style and comfort go hand-in-hand in combinations of cottons and sheers designed with chic.

LONDON, Wednesday, June 28 -- Four powerful Soviet armies, smashing the crumbling remains of the German defense line in White Russia, encircled and captured Orsha yesterday, advanced within seventy-four miles of Minsk in a great pincer movement and killed or captured more than 42,000 Germans.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- The Republican National Convention adopted without a dissenting vote today a twenty-seven-point platform which, although it provoked back-stage and open outbreaks during the six days it was in the making, lent itself in the final draft to sufficiently broad, if not elastic, interpretations as to win general acceptance for the coming campaign.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Convention delegates wore themselves out today talking about Chicago's heat and fanning themselves. When they finally reached the Stadium in cabs, and buses that were so many rubber-tired Black Holes of Calcutta, they had no heart for business.

Criticism of the proposed World Fashion Center, made in the spring by the West Side Association of Commerce, was not answered at yesterday's luncheon meeting to the satisfaction of the association, the group said last night.

The function of child care programs is to supplement and strengthen family ties, Dr. Ernest G. Osborne, Professor of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University, declared yesterday in urging educators to cooperate more closely with parents.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 27 (AP) -- Communique 43:

As many and as trite as mother-in-law jokes are the stories about the coffee the young bride makes. These might be put to an end, once and for all, if every beginner cook were to receive a useful little leaflet that has just been issued by the Pan-American Coffee Bureau.
