Pointing out that sugar rationing probably will continue during 1945, B.W. Dyer Co., sugar economists and brokers, yesterday stated that one major reason for the continued sugar shortage will be the conversion during this year of nearly 1,000,000 tons of Cuban sugar into high-test molasses for industrial alcohol distillation.

The two-party system under which American democracy operates requires compromise. Both the Republican and Democratic parties are in fact coalitions of many minor parties. If they are to avoid being pulverized into fractions their right wings and their left wings must somehow get together.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Supporters of Governor Dewey took steps today to accelerate the Republican convention by nominating the candidates for President and Vice President tomorrow afternoon with both nominees accepting tomorrow night.

WITH THE BRITISH FORCES IN FRANCE, June 27 -- Hundreds of guns, spaced a few yards apart, opened a barrage today over a front of several miles. After they had pounded the German positions for two and a half hours the infantry went over to take village after village in hand-to-hand fighting.

FARGO, N.D., June 27 (AP) -- Lynn U. Stambaugh, former national commander of the American Legion, who based his campaign on United States cooperation in world affairs, was leading Senator Gerald P. Nye in returns tonight from the Republican primary.

ALGIERS, June 27 -- A growing belief that France will soon be liberated through the withdrawal or collapse of the German forces before the Allies' overwhelming power has greatly altered recent pessimistic conceptions of the emergence of France from the occupation.

The St. Denis Building, a six-story store, office and loft structure at 797-99 Broadway, southwest corner of Eleventh Street, has been sold by the Seamen's Bank for Savings to David S. Meister, operator. It is on a plot 75.7 by 199.7 by 94.9 by 126.8 feet, opposite Grace Church, and is assessed at $280,000.

In what appears to be a contradiction of Mayor La Guardia's crusade against city employes holding dual jobs, the Board of Estimate will be asked tomorrow to approve the transfer of $6,000 so that the Controller can engage the Remington-Rand Company to supply sixteen employes for special work on city payrolls from 5 P.M. to 10 P.M.

Mr. Willkie's final effort to obtain what he believes to be a necessary clarification of the foreign policy plank of the Republican platform failed, but he went down fighting. Mr. Willkie is a good soldier in any cause in which he believes.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, June 28 (AP) -- A communique:

PHILADELPHIA, June 27 (AP) -- Reorganization plans of the Federal Water Service Corporation, before the Securities and Exchange Commission intermittently since 1937, came before it again today with reargument of the SEC's suspended order of April 17 denying an amendment to a fourth plan.

The Army has brought hundreds of thousands of tons of foodstuffs and other supplies for Italy, but supplemental aid is needed for many of the 17,000,000 persons in liberated Italy, Justice Juvenal Marchisio of the Domestic Relations Court declared yesterday.
CHICAGO, June 27 -- Following is the text of the Republican platform, as adopted by the national convention:...

CHUNGKING, June 27 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Gen. Liu Wei-chang, one of China's foremost military experts, said in a war analysis published today by the army newspaper Sao Tang Pao that "China's only hope now is an Allied victory.
A communique, as broadcast from Chungking in English to North America yesterday and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
Despite sixty-six carloads of beef released to date to the New York City civilian trade by the War Food Administration, the local meat supply situation was described yesterday as extremely tight.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Benjamin F. Feinberg, President pro tem of the State Senate, left here tonight for Albany so that New York will not be without a Governor while Thomas E. Dewey is out of the State as a result of his scheduled trip to the Republican National Convention.

Al Woods is in action again. The veteran producer has just opened offices at 1560 Broadway and is planning to put on "Help Wanted -- Female" in September or October. This is a comedy dealing with the maid problem, a delicate topic these days, written by Howard Buermann and Alfred Golden.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- The Republican Party is fighting the arrogant and bureaucratic dictatorship which is leading the people to national bankruptcy and complete regimentation, but the Republicans must have more help from the people if they are to hold the lines of constitutional government, Joseph W. Martin Jr., House minority leader, told the Republican National Convention today.

LONDON, June 27 -- Maj. Gen. Raymond O. Barton, commander of the Fourth Infantry Division, which helped take Cherbourg, is going back to Germany in this war to rehoist the Stars and Stripes he hauled down as commander of the last United States troops to leave the Reich after World War I.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Henry P. Klein of New York, counsel for Eugene N. Sanctuary, one of the twenty-nine defendants in the mass sedition trial, was fined $200 by Justice Edward C. Eicher today on the ground that he was "obstructing justice by dilatory cross-examination."

An official announcement yesterday by the French Committee of National Liberation, detailing activities of the French Forces of the Interior from June 21 to 24, declared that numerous canals and line cables had been sabotaged and added that "in the Departments of central France not one railway line remains in service."

The action of L. Metcalfe Walling, administrator of the Wage and Hour Division, United States Department of Labor, in banning the employment of home workers in the embroidery industry, was upheld in a two-to-one decision of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals here yesterday.

Lillian Smith is working on a dramatization of her best-selling novel, "Strange Fruit," and expects to complete it this fall, according to her publisher, Reynal Hitchcock. Contracts have been signed for production in late fall or early next year.

A uniform license fee of $10 on all passenger automobiles in New York State and exemption of A-card motorists from the $5 Federal use tax were urged yesterday by the board of directors of the Automobile Club of New York at their annual meeting, which was held in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

LONDON, June 27 -- The stock markets here were cheerful today as a result of the fall of Cherbourg and the latest Russian news. Dollar stocks advanced and there was renewed investment support for leading industrial issues.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- President Roosevelt said today that the Administration's plan to unite the peace-loving nations of the world in an organization to prevent future wars, by force if necessary, had had a generally favorable public reaction.

SOUTHERN ENGLAND, June 27 (U.P.) -- A month ago some of the British regarded American soldiers as fellows with too much money and too little to do. Today the same doughboys are heroes to British victims of the robot bomb blitz.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- The Republican National Convention today promulgated a platform of national and foreign policies -- highlighted by a pledge of post-war international collaboration to maintain order -- by which it proposes to convince the American electorate next fall that it can be depended upon to win the war, keep the peace and restore prosperity, if returned to power in Washington.

The men's and boys' clothing industry, with the exception of plants manufacturing uniforms for the armed forces, will shut down all over the country for the week of July 3 to permit 150,000 members of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, an affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, to have their first vacations with pay under collective bargaining agreements.

The War Manpower Commission's "controlled referral plan," covering changes in employment for all youths and men more than 17 years of age, effective July 1, may not hit the banking industry as hard as was believed only a short time ago.

" Christmas Holiday," a drama produced by Universal starring Deanna Durbin and Gene Kelly, will have its local premiere this morning at Loew's Criterion. An adaptation of the W. Somerset Maugham novel, the film, which was directed by Robert Siodmak, features Richard Whorf, Gladys George, Dean Harens and Gale Sondergaard.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 27 -- Twenty-two Notre Dame athletes, headed by four-letterman Johnny Lujack, were among the Navy and Marine trainees who were transferred to other bases today.

LONDON, June 27 -- The Allies' triumphs in Italy, Russia and the Cherbourg Peninsula are having a sobering effect on German propagandists who only a few days ago were vaunting the rather apocryphal success of their "secret weapon."

WITH A BRITISH NAVAL TASK FORCE, June 26 (Delayed) -- At 8:15 this morning I watched the fifteen-inch guns of the monitor Lord Roberts open up in support of British and Canadian ground troops driving on Caen.
KANDY, Ceylon, June 27 (UP) -- A communique:

LONDON, June 27 -- Cherbourg had hardly fallen to the Allies when Army engineers and Navy repair units were at work restoring the great harbor and preparing an entrance to Europe, more than 300 miles closer to New York than London is. Considerable time will be saved, when troops and material can be moved directly to France without a stop-over in Britain.

MOSCOW, June 27 -- Premier Joseph Stalin gave high praise to the job done by American business, labor and agriculture and by the United States Government in aiding the Soviet Union's victorious war effort when he conferred for two and a half hours last night with Eric Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission was urged today by it public utilities division to condition its approval of the plan for dissolution of the Northern States Power Company of Delaware upon the submission of amendments that virtually would eliminate participation by the Standard Gas and Electric Company, former parent of the holding company.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Allied strategy in pressing the invasion of Europe consistently will follow a pattern of striking sharp, overwhelming blows, in which we will expect and accept considerable losses, but avoiding, in so far as possible, any costly stalemates in which huge forces are locked with the enemy while the attrition mounts up on both sides.

ROME, June 27 (UP) -- A violent patriot insurrection was reported raging throughout Tuscany today and the Germans were said to have shot 200 Italian youths in the city of Novara for refusal to report for military service.

Sales of war bonds in New York City rose to a total of $693,199,815 and in New York State to $837,200,000 through the close of business on Monday, it was announced yesterday by Nevil Ford, State chairman of the War Finance Committee. These figures included sales to corporations for the first time since the opening of the Fifth War Loan on June 12.

Withdrawal by the War Production Board and the Office of Civilian Requirements of priority assistance on fabrics will mean a cut in production in the near future ranging from 25 to 100 per cent in infants', toddlers' and children's low-end dresses, and many manufacturers will be unable to fill retail orders, speakers warned yesterday at a special meeting called by the United Infants' and Children's Wear Association at the Hotel McAlpin.

Miss Christina Schweidtman, 17-year-old high school student, of 967 Bergen Street, Brooklyn, was held a prisoner for an hour in the kitchen of her home early yesterday by an armed Negro who tried unsuccessfully to attack her and escaped with two rings he pulled from her fingers.
CHICAGO, June 27 -- Following is an official "condensation" of Herbert Hoover's address tonight at the Republican National Convention:

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- In about half the critical labor shortage areas women as well as men are to be included under the new July 1 manpower priority system seeking to put workers in the most war-necessary jobs.

IT'S too bad no one thought of it in time. But the sports writers' committee in charge of Monday's zany War Bond "triple-header" should have recruited Two-Top Bruskin, the two-headed pitcher, and Three-Mitt Mickey McGoon, the three-armed catcher, to act as the battery for the Dodgers, Yankees and Giants in the version of baseball lunacy which was unfolded in the hitherto sedate Polo Grounds.

AT THE BRITISH FRONT IN FRANCE, 7:15 P.M., June 27 -- A heavy tank and infantry battle between the British and Germans raged tonight a few miles west of Caen and southwest of that stronghold, and moving up to the front I saw evidence that German armored formations had taken a terrific beating near St. Manvieu.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Reflecting the impact of shortages to a greater degree than any of its wartime predecessors, Sears, Roebuck Co.'s 904-page fall and winter catalogue was in the mails today, with large sections of its textile offerings placed in the "not available" class after the printing had been completed.

Operation of two plants of the Bendix Aviation Corporation in Brooklyn, manufacturing marine equipment for the Navy, was rippled yesterday by a strike of 800 employes in protest against alleged violation of seniority rights in recent layoffs and other provisions of a collective agreement.

TORONTO, June 27 (Canadian Press) -- Increases in wages amounting to about $225,000 a month granted to the operating staff in Brazil have brought to the front the problem of obtaining sufficient new business to take care of them and the additional costs of operating, the president, Sir Herbert Couzens, told shareholders of the Brazilian Traction, Light and Power Company, Ltd., at their annual meeting here today.

Although the rubber industry is producing truck tires at about twice the rate maintained in 1940, supplies of large-size tires are expected to become increasingly short during the third quarter of this year. Invasion may add to the military demand, and the production limit has been approached.

In your issue of June 15, 1944, you published a dispatch from your brilliant correspondent at Algiers, Mr. Callender, in which he stated that certain Frenchmen were wondering whether President Roosevelt's policy toward General de Gaulle was inspired by "Camille Chautemps and Henri de Kerillis."

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Dr. H.H. Kung, Chinese Finance Minister, who called on President Roosevelt today, will have several associates on China's delegation to the United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference opening Saturday at Bretton Woods, N.H., the Chinese Embassy said tonight.

Revelle W. Brown, president of the Lehigh Valley Railroad, has been elected president of the Reading Company to succeed E.W. Scheer, who will retire on Friday, Roy B. White, chairman of the board of the Reading, announced yesterday after a meeting of its directors at the Reading Terminal.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Wednesday, June 28 -- The British Army on the east of the Normandy bridgehead has launched an offensive that in its initial stages has been strikingly successful.

LONDON, June 27 -- A Polish underground commando unit was reported in a message to the Polish Government today to have seized and held for several hours on June 11 the town of Pinczow, freeing 400 political prisoners. Pinczow, in the Kieloe district about fifty miles northeast of Cracow behind the German front based on Lwow, had a peacetime population of 7,500.

CAIRO, June 27 -- The deliberate German devastation and destruction in Italy is so ruthless that Allied soldiers' rage is mounting, with demands for full Nazi retribution. An example of this comes in a letter written by a South African, Maj. Craig Anderson, to his wife at his Hyde Park estate in Johannesburg, made public here today, describing the ruination of Pescara.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Government-operated Inland Waterways Corporation and its subsidiary, the Warrior River Terminal Company, operated "in the black" in 1943 after showing an operating deficit of $726,492 in 1942.

ROME, June 27 (AP) -- British troops, striking hard at the core of German resistance some eighty miles above Rome, recaptured the ruins of Chiusi in heavy fighting and were slugging with infantry and tanks tonight in the outskirts of Castiglione del Lago, nine miles northeast of Chiusi on the shore of Lake Trasimeno.

The blueprint for global air service by the lines of the United States, made public by the Civil Aeronautics Board on June 12, has the approval of every agency of the American Government concerned, of the President, and our principal allied powers in the war, it was reported yesterday.

LONDON, June 27 (AP) -- An American scientist closely associated with the war effort and one of the developers of radar, described the flying bomb today as "a development as revolutionary as the airplane, with a tremendous future and a definite political problem."

The North Side Savings Bank has sold the factory building at 239 East 149th Street, the Bronx, to the 239 East 149th Street Corporation. James, Murphy was the broker. City Title Insurance Company insured the title.
America stands at the supreme moment of her history. She looks to every citizen (and rightly so) to display brave-hearted loyalty and discharge the duties which the privilege of citizenship commands.

If melodrama could be graded only quantitatively by the number of corpses, "Ten Little Indians" no doubt would run forever. There is no disputing the fact that it has bodies, enough of them, indeed, to fill the stage of the Broadhurst, which is large enough to comfortably enfold a musical show.

We look forward with confidence to next Sunday night and our favorite radio prognosticators. They will remind us that six months ago or nine months ago or perhaps even as far back as four years ago they told us who would be the Republican nominee in June, 1944.

ON THE SALWEEN RIVER FRONT, Burma, June 21 (Delayed) -- Land communication was formally established today between the broken abutments of the Huintung bridge across the Salween River. Lincoln Hwang, engineer for the Yunnan-Burma highway, was pulled over in a breeches buoy.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Mrs. George M. Dewey of Owosso, Mich., who never has witnessed a political convention, will be on hand tomorrow morning when the roll-call of States begins for nominees for the Presidency. The mother of the outstanding candidate, Governor Dewey, motored here today with friends from home.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 27 (AP) -- Jersey City made it five in a row over the Rochester Red Wings by sweeping both ends of a doubleheader tonight, 10 -- 3 and 5 -- 1. The double defeat ran the Wings' losing streak to nine straight games.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, June 28 (U.P.) -- Liberators of the Far Eastern Air Force concentrated attacks on Sunday and Monday on Japanese airdromes in Netherland New Guinea and the Caroline Islands, sinking or damaging four enemy cargo vessels in the widespread raids, Allied Headquarters announced today.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Liberalizing its restrictions on the manufacture of footwear in a number of respects, the War Production Board announced today that manufacture of two-toned shoes with other than leather soles will be permitted on Sept. 1.

Apprentice Bobby Permane, New Jersey youngster who left Florida ablaze with his riding glory, gained himself at least a few new friends yesterday when he rode the Wheatley Stable's Free Lance to an upset triumph in the Celt Handicap, a six-furlong event that was one of the features on Aqueduct's racing card.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- United States mints have completed one "large order" of coins for the Netherlands Government-in-exile in London and have started work on a second order, the Treasury Department disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Relations between the United States and Argentina took a sharp turn today, possibly toward a deepening cleavage, when the State Department announced that Norman Armour, our Ambassador in Buenos Aires, had been instructed to return "immediately for consultation." The Ambassador will be followed in a few days by Mrs. Armour.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- Democratic Congressmen derided, today, Republican party platform proposals with expressions such as "an avalanche of words" and "a straddle," while their Republican colleagues applauded the planks as "dandy."
A "City Center" for blind persons housing the occupational, recreational and employment facilities of the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind was dedicated yesterday at 1880 Broadway.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 27 -- An experiment which saw a bigleague gridiron squad go right through spring training without a football anywhere in sight has been concluded at Yale and Coach Howie Odell expressed delight today over results.

In five days of one of the greatest offensives in military history the Russians have made sure that the Nazis will not detach any divisions from the Eastern Front to bolster up their defenses in the west. The Nazis haven't enough divisions in the east. On Monday they lost the strongholds of Vitebsk and Zhlobin, 150 miles apart.

Witnesses testifying yesterday before a subcommittee of the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee in the Federal Building here filled in the picture presented Monday of the United States Maritime Commission's turning over an established Bayonne shipyard -- the Marine Maintenance Corporation -- to a newly formed company headed by a former official of the commission.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal., June 27 -- Joan Crawford's first starring picture for Warner Brothers, where the former Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer star has been under contract for more than a year, will be "Mildred Pierce," a James M Cain novel involving a divorced woman and her adult daughter.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Following the refusal of Gov. Earl Warren of California to be a candidate for the nomination for Vice President, Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio seemed likely tonight to be the choice of the Republican National Convention tomorrow for second place on the ticket.

In your issue of June 20 Count Coudenhove-Kalergi explained that Marshal Petain, having been kidnapped by the Germans, his powers were transferred to Admiral Darlan, and after the death of Darlan to General Giraud, who finally transferred them to the Algiers committee.

Manufacturers of upholstered furniture have not yet been as hard hit by material shortages as those making wood furniture, or what is known in the trade as "case goods," a canvass of several representatives of upholstered furniture producers brought out yesterday at the semi-annual New York Furniture Market at the Furniture Exchange.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday numbered 1,184, which compares with 1,917 in the preceding week and 949 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals totaled 512 as against 788 for last Tuesday.

EVANSTON, Ill., June 27 (AP) -- Francisco (Pancho) Segura of Miami University breezed a step closer today to his second straight singles championship in the N.C.A.A. tennis tournament with a decisive triumph over Dale Lewis of Utah State, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 0.
CHUNGKING, China, June 27 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

CHICAGO, June 27 -- The foreign policy plank finally adopted by the Republican convention differs but slightly from the draft on which the resolutions committee began to work. Yet for a week of days beginning early in the morning and lasting late into the night this statement has been more debated than any other part of the party platform.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Wednesday, June 28 -- Clearing weather late yesterday enabled formations of both American and British heavy bombers to resume their attacks on the Nazis' flying bomb bases in Pas-de-Calais while missions against enemy military objectives near the Normandy front were carried out by the lighter planes of the United States Ninth Air Force.

Democrats in New York City were confronted last night with a rash of primary fights as the deadline for filing designating petitions with the Board of Elections expired at midnight. This resulted partly from the reapportionment of Congressional and legislative districts that becomes effective with this year's elections.

Music from Dimitri Shostakovich's version of Moussorgsky's famous opera, "Boris Godounoff," will be heard for the first time on July 23, when excerpts from the Soviet composer's revision will be broadcast over the Columbia Broadcasting System by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under the direction of Fritz Reiner.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Persistent buying of wheat futures, which brokers regarded as for milling account against sales of flour, gave the market a strong undertone today on the Board of Trade. The close was slightly under the top, net gains were 1 3/8 to 2 cents a bushel.

A group of five four-story store and apartment buildings at 839-47 Third Avenue and a one-story business and storage building at 205-07 East Fifty-first Street, the northeast corner, has been sold by Byram L. Winters after an ownership of nearly fifty years to William H. Gompert, architect, who is considering plans for a center for antique and art dealers on the property.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 27 -- American business can remember that, if it chafes under Government restrictions, part of the blame can be placed on its own shoulders, G.H. Dennison, president of the National Association of Better Business Bureaus, Inc., told delegates to the thirtieth annual conference of the association today.

The Board of Transportation approved yesterday a pay rise of 5 cents an hour for 13,500 employes on three divisions of the city's transit system. The rises during the coming fiscal year will amount to $1,200,000.
LONDON, June 27 -- Sir James Grigg, Secretary of State for War, refused today to reconsider his decision not to accredit a war correspondent for the Communist newspaper, The Daily Worker.

The business building formerly known as the Yellid Building on Bedford Road, Mount Kisco, has been sold by the Bank of Westchester to Morris Egan and the bank also sold the three-story commercial structure at 12 Croton Avenue, Ossining, to Dominick La Regina.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The freedom of less essential workers to transfer to any but essential jobs will be curtailed by new regulations, effective Saturday, promulgated yesterday by the regional office of the War Manpower Commission for the area of New York City and vicinity.

LONDON, June 27 (AP) -- The total casualties for British forces up to the fall of Rome were 667,159, of which 158,741 were killed, 78,204 missing, 159,219 wounded and 270,995 prisoners, Prime Minister Churchill told the House of Commons today.

Due to increased acceptance of intercommunication systems developed through wide use of such systems in war production, the Dictograph Sales Corporation is planning to maintain post-war production at its present level, which is 100 per cent higher than any peacetime year, Frank H. Lehman, vice president of the company, stated yesterday.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 27 -- Copenhagen residents staged a minor revolt Monday against the Germans in which seven civilians were killed and about 100 were wounded.

BUFFALO, N. N., June 27 (;P)-The ]3ears kept tile Bisons deep in the throes of a losing streak tonight as they won their second straight victory, 9 to 1, and made it five out of six losses for the Bucky Harris' outfit since returnLug home.
Yesterday the New York Curb Exchange held a war bond rally and an informal reception to celebrate the twenty-third anniversary of its location indoors at 86 Trinity Place.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Once again a woman had the last word, and Representative Clare Boothe Luce, who spoke it, made it also the most effective of the evening at the Republican National Convention. Her ringing address was undeniably the peak of the program as she arraigned the Democratic party and warned her own party to prepare for the home-coming of the G. I. Joes.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast domestically in Finland and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
ROME, June 27 -- Col. Charles A. Poletti explained today the elaborate plans under way for the purge of Fascists.

Due to increased acceptance of intercommunication systems developed through wide use of such systems in war production, the Dictograph Sales Corporation is planning to maintain post-war production at its present level, which is 100 per cent higher than any peacetime year, Frank H. Lehman, vice president of the company, stated yesterday.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 27 -- Copenhagen residents staged a minor revolt Monday against the Germans in which seven civilians were killed and about 100 were wounded.

BUFFALO, N. N., June 27 (;P)-The ]3ears kept tile Bisons deep in the throes of a losing streak tonight as they won their second straight victory, 9 to 1, and made it five out of six losses for the Bucky Harris' outfit since returnLug home.
Yesterday the New York Curb Exchange held a war bond rally and an informal reception to celebrate the twenty-third anniversary of its location indoors at 86 Trinity Place.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Once again a woman had the last word, and Representative Clare Boothe Luce, who spoke it, made it also the most effective of the evening at the Republican National Convention. Her ringing address was undeniably the peak of the program as she arraigned the Democratic party and warned her own party to prepare for the home-coming of the G. I. Joes.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast domestically in Finland and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

CHUNGKING, China, June 27 (AP) -- The Japanese, while pressing a frontal assault from the north toward the strategic Hunan Province railway town of Hengyang, have begun a flanking movement to the southeast apparently aimed at cutting the railway south of Hengyang, a Chinese communique indicated today.

IN Italy and Normandy, and probably soon in the Balkans, on the Riviera, in Belgium and the Netherlands, young American soldiers are setting foot upon European soil for the first time. While they wade through cold water in the darkness, crawl across bullet-swept beaches and flatten into the ground to dodge bombs, shells and machine-gun fire many of them are probably saying, "This is a hell of a way to see Europe."
ROME, June 27 -- Col. Charles A. Poletti explained today the elaborate plans under way for the purge of Fascists.
LONDON, June 27 -- The capture of Cherbourg three weeks after the first landing in Normandy represents the greatest Allied strategic triumph of the war.

LONDON, June 27 (U.P.) -- A German DNB news agency broadcast, recorded here today, said that Reich Foreign Minister von Ribbentrop had visited Helsinki and made an agreement with the Finnish Government by which Germany would give military help to the Finns to enable Finland to stay in the war.

LONDON, Wednesday, June 28 (U.P.) -- German flying bombs hurtled sporadically over southern England early today. The enemy is apparently now launching at least two types of robot explosives equipped with three kinds of warheads.

The steel industry consumed 313,364,000 tons of raw materials in 1943, the record year, exclusive of ferro-alloys and alloying elements, according to a survey by the American Iron and Steel Institute, which believes that the industry uses more materials than any other industry in the world.

The market on the New York Cotton Exchange again was moderately active yesterday, continuing its upward movement into new highs for the life of the contracts, and gaining 16 to 20 points net on active months. It started with gains of 4 to 9 points, influenced by continued New Orleans support and buying for trade accounts. Selling was mostly on the scale up by merchant firms.
CHICAGO, June 27 -- The reaction here to the Republican platform was favorable.
ROME, June 27 (AP) -- A communique:

ABOARD JOINT EXPEDITIONARY FORCE FLAGSHIP, Saipan, June 27 -- Japanese infantry resistance stiffened all along the island-wide front this morning as Marine and Army forces reached a sector possibly chosen for the beginning of Japan's last-ditch defense of Saipan.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- There was an undertone in the convention keynote sounded last night by Gov. Earl Warren of California which, though he blended it with the general theme, quickly became an overtone of this Republican national gathering.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- At 10:30 o'clock, the scheduled hour for opening the second day of the Republican convention, only a scattering of delegates was on the floor of the Stadium. Governor Warren was on the platform, surrounded by friends who congratulated him on his keynote speech of last night.

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 27 (AP) -- Miss Betty Rosenquest of South Orange and Miss Helen Germain of New York moved into the semi-finals of the Women's New Jersey State Tennis Championship today at the Oritani Field Club.

TOLEDO, Ohio, June 27 (AP) -- Louis Lick, 20-year-old University of Minnesota medical student from St. Paul, turned in the first big upset of the national intercollegiate golf tournament today when he uncorked a sub-par round to beat the medalist, James Jackson of Washington University of St. Louis, 6 and 5, and gain a place in the semi-finals.

Shipments of war materials by the Sperry Corporation and its subsidiaries in 1943 were at a new high record of $460,006,689, it announced yesterday. The total was more than double the previous high of $216,281,899 after contract renegotiation in 1942. The deliveries included products recently developed, according to Thomas A. Morgan, president.

The remaining three of the eight "boiler-room boys" who last winter defrauded numerous business men of contributions up to $650 each for advertising in a spurious labor-union publication, pretending support of the war bond drive, the Red Cross blood bank and other war activities, pleaded guilty yesterday in General Sessions Court at their three-week trial.

The 5,615,877 pounds of beef recently released by the Government from military and lend-lease supplies will be spread among twelve northeastern States instead of going to New York City as was first supposed, the War Food Administration announced yesterday, disclosing that seventeen carloads had already been diverted to the New England area.
CHUNGKING, China, June 28 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

RYE, N.Y., June 28 -- Unless some dark horse springs from the second division of about seventy-five veterans who start their two-day, 36-hole quest of the United States Seniors Golf Association championship at the Apawamis Club tomorrow, Ellis Knowles of the host club will capture his third consecutive title by the time this fortieth annual tournament ends Friday evening.

CHICAGO, June 28 -- The scheduled opening hour of 10:30 A.M. set for the Republican national convention today found the Stadium floor a milling mass of excited persons, apparently oblivious to the suffocating heat which, yesterday, all but emptied the hall during the reading of the party's platform.
ABOVE CHERBOURG, June 26 (Delayed) (AP) -- Until Friday afternoon 300 Germans behind twenty-six guns held this place frantically.

Earle Doucette reports from Augusta that one of our highly esteemed game fish, the Atlantic salmon, has been taking the hook in Maine's Denny, and Narraguagus River greater numbers than in the recent past, thus rewarding his State's attempts to bring this battler back to the United States.
Yesterday's communique as broad-cast domestically in Finland and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

ED McKEEVER'S record will be smashed to smithereens in a couple of months but he is surprisingly cheerful about it. By nature he would be cheerful about anything because he is ever smiling and happy. The grinning Texan is the only football coach in the history of Notre Dame whose teams have never met defeat. Of course, he only served as a mastermind during three games in 1942 when Frank Leahy was ailing.

The report in today's NEW YORK TIMES that Mr. Oliver Lyttelton made an "abject apology" in the House of Commons for his inaccurate remarks about the United States seems in its way as inaccurate and undiplomatic as the original offense, I refer, of course, to the phrase "abject apology," which your article uses twice, apparently with no thought of its connotation.

CHUNGKING, China, June 28 (U.P.) -- Japanese troops have encircled the key Hunan Province railroad junction of Hengyang and cut the Canton and Kweilin railroads south and southwest of it, it was announced tonight.

CLYDE BRION DAVIS, who in private conversation is one of the most intelligent of men, has an ineradicable yearning to write about dopes, mopes, twirps, lunkheads and quarter-wits in all their banal and spiritually sordid settings. Give him a choice between an avenue and an areaway, and he will invariably skulk along the latter.

The Appellate Division denied yesterday to the city the right to have the Court of Appeals review a decision of Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer, who, on March 6, granted to former Municipal Court Justice Edgar Hirschberg a summary judgment for $5,649 as salary for a period during which he was absent from his post as general law assistant to the justices of the Supreme Court.
LONDON, June 28 -- Premier Ivan Subasitch of Yugoslavia, who is engaged in forming a Government acceptable to Marshal Tito, conferred today with Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden.

No longer is the Bronx Coliseum a mecca for aspiring young pugilists, opera companies or politicians. Today the spacious structure at 177th Street and Tremont Avenue is playing a war role as a "ward" in the automotive infirmary of the Army's Second Service Command, where mechanical surgery is performed by motor specialists to restore automotive casualties from all the theatres of war.

In an editorial, "Winged Gunners," in THE TIMES of June 16 reference was made to the return of 30,000 air cadet trainees to the ground services. The editorial calls attention to a statement attributed to Gen. H.H. Arnold, nothing that with "a crying need by other branches of the armed forces for men suitable to become officers the step was the only one which could be properly taken."

The United States has five fighter planes capable of speeds above 400 miles an hour, while Britain has three, Germany two and Japan none, according to the 1944 edition of "The Aircraft Year Book," edited by Howard Mingos as the reference annual of the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce and published today by Lancair Publishers, Inc.

Because of confusion over contemplated action in regard to ceiling prices on cotton goods and floor prices for raw cotton under the price-control bill that the President is expected to sign on Saturday, liquidation of cotton contracts increased yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange and prices declined 13 to 21 points.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 28 -- The recall of Norman Armour, United States Ambassador in Argentina, to Washington for consultation, threw the Argentine Government into such a state of agitation that its first reaction was to try to keep the news from the Argentine people and yesterday's evening newspapers were forbidden to make any mention of it.

LONDON, June 28 (UP) -- British air officials announced progress today in the fight against German robot bombs and their bases and, as the intermittent bombardment of southern England continued, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden rejected a proposal that the British seek the Pope's condemnation of the new German weapon.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Albert W. Dilling, former husband of Mrs. Elizabeth Dilling and her attorney in the mass sedition trial, was fined $200 today for what Judge Edward C. Eicher considered repetitious tactics. His fine, the seventh imposed upon the defendants or their lawyers since the trial began, follows a similar penalty assessed yesterday against Henry P. Klein, lawyer for Eugene H. Sanctuary.

Women shoppers no longer are fussy about having their bundles individually wrapped, leading department and chain grocery stores revealed yesterday. One Manhattan store reported that women walk out carrying everything from brooms to antique coffee tables without wrappings.

The Countess Gisele de Chambrun, wife of Jean de Chambrun, a French writer and painter, of 155 East Seventy-second Street was exonerated by Magistrate D. Joseph De Andrea in Homicide Court yesterday on an assault charge made after her automobile injured 10-year-old Robert L. Pell of 156 East Seventy-ninth Street on Dec. 24.
CHICAGO, June 28 -- Following is the text of Governor Bricker'a speech withdrawing from the race for the Presidential nomination:

Without ever becoming a spectacular figure in politics, Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio has built up, at the age of 51, an outstanding record as a vote getter. This is shown in returns that thrice have made him Chief Executive of his native State.
CHICAGO, June 28 -- The prepared speech of Gov. Dwight Griswold of Nebraska, placing Thomas E. Dewey in nomination for the Presidency at the Republican National Convention, was as follows:

Under-Secretary of State Edward R. Stettinius announced last night at a Jewish Unity Dinner honoring Representative Sol Bloom that the British Government had just agreed to the establishment of a new war refugee haven in one of the former Italian colonies in Libya.

LONDON, Thursday, June 29 -- Onrushing Soviet troops overwhelmed and captured Mogilev yesterday and launched a frontal assault on Minsk, gateway to Warsaw and Berlin, while other Russian forces, advancing twenty-three miles, rolled to within fifty miles of the White Russian capital and rapidly closed a great pincers on the city.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 28 -- There was still doubt as to who is Mayor of this city as the "Mayor No. 2," Michael A. Sullivan, reported today for his second day on the job to find police barring him from the Mayor's office.

CINCINNATI, June 28 (AP) -- The Reds took both ends of a twilight-night double-header played for the War Relief and Service Fund, Inc., tonight, defeating the Braves, 4 to 3, in the ten-inning opener and grabbing the second, 3 to 2, on Estel Crabtree's pinch-single with one out in the ninth.

The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company reported yesterday for the first five months this year a net income of $8,631,690, equal under the participating provisions of the shares, to $2.69 a share on combined preferred and common stock.

The Appellate Division unanimously denied yesterday to the Mexican Government permission to seek a Court of Appeals review of a decision dismissing its claim and a plea of immunity in connection with an accounting proceeding involving $7,000,000 now being held for distribution to holders of Mexican bonds now in default.

James G. Blaine, president of the Marine Midland Trust Company of New York, announced yesterday that the company has established the first discretionary common trust fund in this State, with the approval of the State Banking Board, pursuant to a recent amendment to the State Banking Law.

A special award was given to all American railroads for their "outstanding contribution to the war effort" and their "notable record of safety" and regular E.H. Harriman Memorial Medals were awarded to three railroads for their 1943 safety records at a dinner of the American Museum of Safety last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

At the Fifth War Loan starts, the military forces of the United States and its Allies have brought the war into the very gates of the enemy, on territory that the enemy has been fortifying for four years. In this terrific battle, the greatest in which we have ever engaged, our armies will be using vast quantities of the weapons of war that American industry has produced at such an amazing rate.

Stocks chose yesterday to underline once more the fact that, for more than a year, they have had two or more markets simultaneously. While the general list on the New York Stock Exchange softened, there was a boom in low-price motors and motor accessories, several of which pushed ahead to new highs for several years.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Thanks to the law which put first, second and third class postoffices in the civil service in June, 1938, the coming election will not affect the largest number of women postmasters on record.

" Ninety-nine Park," headquarters of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, Inc.,* offers a partial list of free amusements available today through the generosity of the entertainment world. Afternoon tickets from 11 A.M.; evening tickets after 4 P.M. Apply 99 Park Avenue (at Fortieth Street) for tickets.

Charles Ebbets, son of the former owner of the Brooklyn Dodgers, who died on May 15, left two-thirds of his estate, valued at "more than $10,000," to his housekeeper, and one-third to his widow, Mrs. Martha Joan Ebbets, 191 Parsons Drive, South Hempstead, L.I.

LONDON, Thursday, June 29 -- The morning newspapers, which had forecast the nomination of Governor Dewey, were content to record briefly the formalities of the Chicago convention today. Their reports were factual and in keeping with the British line of "non-interference" in American domestic affairs.

Enthroned upon his cloudy tower and a big block of ice, our New York looker into the seeds of weather certified that yesterday would be "hot and humid." "Hot" is too cold a word for 93. Perhaps "bilin'" is too exact to be scientific. It is sad to remember that the good old word "muggy" was dropped some years ago and its Latin successor appointed, probably in the vain hope of improvement.

Four Wacs, French style, arrived in New York yesterday, the first group of Volontaires Francaises to be trained at Camp Meade, Md., and now heading back to their homeland via North Africa. There they will join the land forces of the French women volunteers now numbering 4,000.
CHICAGO, June 28 (AP) -- Governor Dewey's nomination for President was applauded today by eighteen Republican Governors attending the party convention.

The Vocational Rehabilitation Division of the Education Department of the State of New York, now located in the State Office Building, 80 Centre Street, will move on or about July 1 to the Trinity Building, 111 Broadway, where a lease has been taken for the entire fourth floor, comprising about 15,000 square feet.

High bidder yesterday for a new issue of $1,500,000 Dallas, Texas, airport, street and sewer bonds, due serially from July 1, 1945 to 1964, was a syndicate comprising the Northern Trust Company of Chicago, the First National Bank of Chicago, and Louis B. Henry Investments of Dallas.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 65:

EN ROUTE WITH DEWEY, by airplane, to Chicago, June 28 (AP) -- Smiling and assured, Governor Dewey sped toward Chicago this afternoon through fleecy white clouds in a chartered craft to accept the Republican Presidential nomination.
CHICAGO, June 28 -- War relief agencies profited handsomely but the Dodgers ran into a deficit in the benefit double-header with the Cubs today by losing both games, 12 -- 6 and 6 -- 2.

FARGO, N.D., June 28 -- Lynn U. Stambaugh, former National Commander of the American Legion, had lost tonight 1,900 of the 2,500 vote lead which he had maintained throughout the day over the incumbent, Senator Gerald P. Nye, in the primary contest for the United States Senatorship.

LONDON, June 28 (AP) -- Somewhat improved weather conditions enabled American and British fighter-bombers today to join the almost-endless procession of daylight air attackers. The light planes raced along the battle lines in Normandy, hammering Nazi convoys, troop concentrations and supply dumps.
CHERBOURG, France, June 28 (AP) -- Diehard Germans hopelessly trapped on Cap de la Hague northwest of this fallen port fought sporadically today against American troops methodically ironing them out.

Discussions both of a possible merger between the General Aniline and Film Corporation and its sales agent for dye products, the General Dyestuff Corporation, respectively 98 per cent and 100 per cent vested in the Alien Property Custodian, and of the sale of these properties in a manner to insure continuous American ownership have been in progress some time, it was revealed yesterday by George W. Burpee, president of General Aniline.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 28 -- In another desperate effort to persuade the left-wing Eam and its guerrilla army inside occupied Greece to cooperate with his Government in achieving complete national unity, Greek Prime Minister George Papandreou tonight appealed in a broadcast to his enslaved nation, calling on the reluctant bloc to collaborate with his Cabinet in the united program decided on at the recent Lebanon meetings -- or face the consequences.

The five-story apartment building at 86 West 183d Street, the Bronx, assessed at $130,000, has been purchased by an investing client of Snyder Co, Inc., from the 325 West Thirty-sixth Street Corporation. Emil Leepson represented the buyer.

Even for these subnormal times the Brownies looked like anything but a first-place club yesterday at the Stadium, where Luke Sewell's men, hurting themselves more than the Yankees hurt them, virtually handed the McCarthymen a 7-2 decision.

Mrs. Virginia Wolfenden Kovacs, former member of the first ten, and John Nogrady of Rockville Centre, one of the leading professionals of the country, have been added to the cast of players who will take part in the Red Cross victory drive tennis exhibitions at Forest Hills Sunday, Monday and Tuesday.

As the initial move in a campaign to capitalize during the post-war period on lessons learned since 1941, the National Supply Association of America, Inc., formed yesterday a group-buying organization known as National Distributors, Inc.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The Office of Price Administration ruled today that exporters of products which are subsidized in domestic sales may add the amount of that subsidy to the base export price if the payment is not made for export sales, or if it must be refunded.

Hot weather evidently is not going to discourage the salvage of waste paper by New Yorkers this summer, as Commissioner William F. Carey reported that his Department of Sanitation trucks picked up 396 tons of paper yesterday, or nine tons more than was collected a week ago.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 28 (AP) -- Communique 45:

New York City and New York State have both passed the billion-dollar milestone in the Fifth War Loan, it was announced yesterday by Nevil Ford, State chairman of the War Finance Committee. He disclosed that the city's all-investors' total at the close of business on Tuesday was $1,046,552,432, and that of the State was $1,241,300,000.

PHILADELPHIA, June 28 -- Continuing to assert that its recently enunciated "5 per cent spread philosophy" did not constitute a rule, the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., told the Securities and Exchange Commission today that the opponents of the idea had misled themselves by standing mute when a simple inquiry would have brought forth the truth.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The claim to the $1,000,000,000 in French gold frozen here that recognition as the Provisional Government of France would give the French Committee of National Liberation is cited by officials here as a factor of some importance in the controversy over the Committee's status.

ABOARD A JOINT EXPEDITIONARY FLAGSHIP, at Saipan Island, June 28 -- Overcoming natural obstacles almost as formidable as the Japanese, Americans on Saipan crunched down the rocky northern slopes of Mount Tapotchau today with their goal in full view after thirteen days of invasion of the Marianas Islands.

Many furniture manufacturers represented at the semi-annual furniture market at the Furniture Exchange sold and are selling to old accounts for the third quarter 25 per cent of what such accounts received in 1942, mill representatives disclosed yesterday.

Attorney General Goldstein has reported adoption of a new technique for enforcement of the Martin Act. His office was unable to prosecute George J. Chapman, permanently enjoined in 1938 from engaging in the securities business in this State, on a complaint alleging violation of the fraud statute some months after the injunction.

SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, June 28 (AP) -- Taking swift advantage of their capture of the Japanese North Burma supply base of Mogaung, Chinese troops have lunged six miles eastward toward Myitkyina, embattled bastion thirty-five miles away, and have captured Namti, Allied Headquarters announced tonight.

OTTAWA, June 28 (Canadian Press) -- Prime Minister Mackenzie King announced today that the Canadian delegation to the United Nations monetary and financial conference opening Saturday at Bretton Woods, N.H., would be composed of:

Spokesmen for the New York State Federation of Labor, the Central Trades and Labor Council of Greater New York and the International and State Associations of Fire Fighters urged city firemen yesterday to sign the special waivers required of them by Mayor La Guardia as a condition of eligibility for a cost-living pay rise of $420 a year.

The Western Union Telegraph Company refused yesterday a telegram from Wendell Willkie congratulating Governor Dewey on his selection as candidate for President. But it accepted and transmitted a "thank you" message from the Governor to the 1940 candidate.

When Representative Clare Boothe Luce was addressing the Republican National Convention on Tuesday evening the American casualty lists for the first two weeks of the Normandy fighting were being added up in London -- 3,082 known dead; 7,959 missing, some of whom are dead; 13,121 wounded, of whom many will never again be whole and well men.

CHICAGO, June 28 -- For at least 10,000 women who have sweltered through three days of torrid weather, the Republican Convention reached its penultimate peak as Mrs. Thomas Dewey, slim, shy and smiling, stepped onto the speakers' platform tonight to hear and share in the applause for her husband.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (U.P.) -- Democratic leaders here hailed Governor Dewey's nomination tonight as a guarantee that a Democratic President would continue to occupy the White House after the election.

The Appellate Division held yesterday in a unanimous decision that the city must bear the financial burden of relocating its transit facilities in the path of a project to eliminate grade crossings at Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, along the line of the Long Island Railroad.
" GI Joe" danced with "Miss Manhattan" last night.

Accepting the suggestion of Col. Maurice Simmons, police property clerk, that a paid of diamond and platinum clips valued at $1,500 be divided between them, two former employes of a cleaning concern walked out of the clerk's office at 400 Broome Street yesterday, each the owner of one clip.

CHICAGO, June 28 -- Gardner Cowles Jr., Des Moines and Minneapolis editor, who was one of Wendell L. Willkie's strongest supporters for the Presidential nomination and was his companion on the trip to Soviet Russia and China, said today that he approved Mr. Willkie's criticism Monday night of the foreign relations plank of the Republican platform.

An exhibition of fourteen paintings by Van Gogh opened yesterday at the Brooklyn Museum in the fifth floor galleries, to remain through Sept. 24. These pictures are from the collection of V.W. Van Gogh, nephew of the artist, and are being shown through the courtesy of the Netherlands Government.
ALGIERS, June 28 -- The French Committee of National Liberation announced tonight that it had appointed four more regional commissioners for liberated areas of France.

CHICAGO, June 28 -- Thomas E. Dewey, Michigan-born, racket-breaking Governor of New York, was overwhelmingly chosen by the Republican convention today as its Presidential candidate to meet the fourth term bid of President Franklin D. Roosevelt, who is expected to be nominated by the Democrats in this same hall three weeks from today.

It now looks as if Miss Gertrude Donovan has something worthwhile in Fighting Don, her bay son of Fighting Fox. At Aqueduct yesterday he scored his third triumph in as many starts, capturing the fifty-fourth running of the $10,000 added Great American, first six-furlong trip of the year for juveniles.
Saul Z. Schachter, formerly buyer of boy's clothing and furnishing, at Stix, Baer Fuller, St. Louis has joined Saks-Thirty-fourth Street as buyer of men's clothing and sportswear.

The nation's crude oil output last week again reached a new peak, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The daily average output of 4,583,200 barrels exceeded by 14,950 the record of 4,568,250 established in the preceding week.

ALBANY, June 28 -- Senator Benjamin F. Feinberg of Plattsburg took over the reins of the State government as acting Governor this afternoon a few minutes after the plane bearing Governor Dewey and his party left for Chicago.

ROME, June 28 (AP) -- American troops were some thirty miles from Leghorn today after a savage all-night battle in which they hurled the Germans out of San Vincenzo, a little coastal town converted into a fortress.

ELMSFORD, N.Y., June 28 -- John Kakerbeck, New York construction engineer, went over the top today in his independent drive to sell $100,000 worth of war bonds in memory of his son, Lieut. Robert L. Kakerbeck, Mustang fighter pilot killed in England two weeks ago.
KANDY, Ceylon, June 28 (UP) -- A communique:
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Thursday, June 29 (AP) -- A communique:
CHUNGKING, China, June 28 (AP) -- A communique:

CHICAGO, June 28 -- A crowd of a thousand persons raised a mighty cheer as Governor Dewey arrived at the Municipal Airport at 7:30 (Central time) tonight at the end of his now historic flight from Albany to face the Republican National Convention and ac cept its nomination for President.

ON THE BRITISH FRONT IN FRANCE, 7:15 P.M., June 28 (AP) -- Tank-led British Tommies reached within two and one-half miles of the Orne River southwest of Caen tonight, and a British staff officer described the Germans as in "complete turmoil" along the front west and southwest of Caen.

PHILADELPHIA, June 28 (AP) -- The Athletics escaped a drop into the American League cellar by taking the first game of their series from the Indians, 7 to 3, today. The winning runs came across on Dick Siebert's home run inside the park with two out and one on in the third.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- Advance shipments for the invasion piled up more than 16,000,000 tons of supplies in Britain in a year, twice the tonnage that Gen. John J. Pershing received during World War I, Lieut. Gen. Brehon Somervell reported today.

Magistrate J. Roland Sala always wears a fresh white carnation in his buttonhole. Yesterday, as he was sitting in Manhattan Traffic Court, an attendant brought him a box that held three dozen of the flowers. There was no card.

The Foreign Economic Administration has begun forming economic "missions of business men" to visit various liberated areas to examine trade conditions and possibilities for practical private operations in such areas, Sidney H. Scheur, executive director of the agency's bureau of supplies, disclosed yesterday.
LONDON, June 28 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

WASHINGTON, June 28 (Science Service) -- In thirty to sixty days, health departments can have for free distribution to children anywhere in the country the measles preventive obtained as a by-product from blood donated by the American people to the Red Cross for the fighting forces.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Lend-lease aid from this country to the United Kingdom, Australia and New Zealand is being paid back in goods and services to American troops overseas at a rate "considerably in excess" of two billion dollars a year, Leo T. Crowley, Foreign Economic Administrator, stated today.

Misfortune plagued the twenty-one graduates of the kindergarten class of the Children's Aid Society's West Side Center, 409 West Thirty-eighth Street, yesterday, as the five- and six-year-olds held a dress rehearsal in preparation for today's big event -- their commencement exercises.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 28 -- A shortage of $250,000 in the funds of Local 60 of the International Hod Carriers, Building and Common Laborers Union is indicated by books of the local, District Attorney Elbert T. Gallagher of Westchester County charged in court here today.

CHICAGO, June 28 (NBC) -- Governor Dewey should give President Roosevelt his first real competition in radio appeal during the 1944 campaign, according to NBC commentators who covered the meeting here in Chicago. Their opinions are based on the assumption that President Roosevelt will be a candidate for a fourth term.

" Once Upon a Time," a comedy romance produced by Columbia and starring Cary Grant, will open this morning at the Radio City Music Hall. Based on "My Client Curley," a radio script by Norman Corwin and Lucille Fletcher Herrmann, the film was directed by Alexander Hall and features Ted Donaldson, local stage juvenile in his screen debut, Janet Blair, James Gleason, William Demarest and Howard Freeman.

The strike of 800 employes in two plants of the Bendix Aviation Corporation at 754 Lexington Avenue and 49 Junius Street, Brooklyn, begun on Tuesday, continued yesterday without any apparent possibility of an early settlement. Local 853 of the United Automobile Workers, an affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, has asked President Roosevelt to seize the plant but there was no information from Washington as to the course the government was likely to take.

LONDON, June 28 -- The stock markets here generally continued firm in tone, but trading was on the quiet side. Dollar stocks were again good. International Nickel, Brazilian Traction and International holdings recording small gains.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- Johnny Niggeling, right-handed knuckleballer, hurled a three-hit game tonight as Washington defeated the Tigers, 4 to 1. Two of the three singles off Niggeling were infield scratches. He struck out nine and walked six.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (U.P.) -- The Government is completing plans for restricted world-wide distribution of American penicillin for civilian use, the War Production Board announced tonight.

LONDON, June 28 -- Philippe Henriot, eloquent and implacable foe of the French resistance movement, was executed before the eyes of his wife in their Paris bedchamber shortly after dawn this morning. Nine bullets from the revolvers of guerrillas disguised as militiamen or policemen ended the life of the Vichy Minister of Propaganda.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- Among 146 casualties announced today by the Navy Department were the following from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut:

Three hundred-thousand Polish children, both Jews and non-Jews, have been used to supply the blood bank for the German Army, and most of them have died as a result of the large amount of blood taken from them, Dr. Stefan de Ropp, director of the Polish Office for Research and Planning, asserted yesterday.

If people were really consistent they would hesitate to speak of a thousand-odd Republican delegates in Chicago as just a crowd of politicians whose sole concern is to pick a winner; and the same of the thousand-odd Democratic politicians who will be convening in a few weeks.

The proposal of the City Planning Commission to place further restrictions on the height and bulk of new buildings was endorsed "in principle" yesterday by spokesmen for a score of civic, business and technical organizations at a public hearing in theBoard of Estimate chamber at City Hall.
Felix R. Gerard, vice president of the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company, was elected yesterday president to succeed Revelle W. Brown, who resigned to become president of the Reading Company.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Second bronze Oak Leaf Cluster to the Distinguished Flying Cross to the following members of the Fifth Air Force; Staff Sgt. Newton Kalman, 1510 Unionport Road, the Bronx, New York; Sgt. John J. Glatz, 58 South Fourteenth Avenue, Mount Vernon, N.Y., and Staff Sgt. William F. McCaffrey, 1136 North Avenue, Elizabeth, N.J.

Mayor La Guardia indicated yesterday, after a public hearing in his office at City Hall that he would sign the local law withholding tax exemption from housing projects receiving public aid if they practiced racial discrimination.

TOLEDO, Ohio, June 28 (AP) -- Thousands of war workers in this city of 300,000 population walked, hitch-hiked and went on bicycles to their jobs today as a strike of AFL-unionists against the Community Traction Company, paralyzed public transportation.
CHICAGO, June 28 -- Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio won the Republican nomination for Vice President today on a first ballot which was unanimous.
LONDON, June 28 (UP) -- A United States Tactical Air Force announcement:
Thomas Edmund Dewey, if elected President as the Republican nominee, will be the youngest Chief Executive ever to occupy the White House, but only by twenty-one days.
CHICAGO, June 28 -- Twenty-five thousand Republicans met Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York, their Presidential nominee, in the stadium tonight.

ALBANY, June 28 -- Governor Dewey was his every-day self as he greeted the press a few minutes after his nomination. Nothing in his smiling demeanor betrayed any pent-up excitement or jubilation as he descended the stairs to the main floor of the Executive Mansion amid the clicking of a dozen camera shutters.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The holiday from rationing of most meat since May 3 will end at 12:01 A.M. next Sunday as several point values are restored to lamb and the ration prices of beefsteak and roasts of beef are raised to all-time highs, the Office of Price Administration announcd today.

PITTSBURGH, June 28 -- The Giants gave their all in the name of charity on Forbes Field tonight before a gathering of 18,479 fans, who paid receipts of $24,995 to be contributed to baseball's War Relief Fund by the National League.

While the principle of material stockpiling has gained many protagonists and there are indications that the nation may embark on such policy, the United States must formulate a mineral policy which will encompass sanctions against future aggressors, coordinate public interest with that of big mining interests and provide future mineral stocks for American industry, Dr. C.K. Leith, mineral consultant for the War Production Board, declared last night.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Three Japanese dive-bombers were shot down in thirty seconds by Lieut. Comdr. Robert A. Winston of New York City and Washington, skipper of the "Meat-Axe" Squadron of Navy fighter pilots, in an action near Palau on March 30 the Navy revealed today.

CHICAGO, June 28 (AP) -- Jug McSpaden, the season's top pro golf money winner, equaled the Edgewater course record today with a 29, 35 -- 64, seven under par, to boost his foursome into the team competition lead of the Chicago Victory national golf championships.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The Navy's next targets, after the occupation of Saipan is completed, will include the mainland of Japan itself, the Philippines and most of the Netherlands Indies, Secretary of the Navy James Forrestal declared today.
VATICAN CITY, June 28 -- The vast interior of St. Peter's was decorated today for the feast of SS. Peter and Paul that occurs tomorrow.

STOCKHOLM, June 28 -- After the loss of Vitebsk and Cherbourg, the German authorities find the situation so serious that the man in the street cannot be left quite unaware of the facts any longer. The German press, therefore, has been authorized to reveal some of the troubles that the Government and the General Staff have to fight.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Reports were widespread today that the United States would sever diplomatic relations with Finland as a result of the "perfect understanding" reached between Helsinki and Berlin and the German promise of military assistance for Finland in her fight against Russia.

In recent years neither the Democratic nor Republican party has managed to resist the pressure groups which have come to its conventions demanding special favors. This was again true at Chicago. Few groups that went there came away empty-handed.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The Navy Department said today that the Government-owned Brewster Aeronautical Corporation plant at Johnsville, Pa., will be opened as an aircraft modification and engineering center on or about July 3 and will employ about 2,500 of the plant's 3,500 to 4,000 workers.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 28 -- While Stockholm awaits the next act in the Finnish drama and wonders of what it may consist, details from Helsinki support the impression that German Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop's "agreement" with President Risto Ryti of Finland was nothing less than a carefully planned coup backed by German bayonets.

OWOSSO, Mich., June 28 (AP) -- Main Street of the quiet little southern Michigan city of 15,000 population rang with cheers tonight in celebration of Thomas E. Dewey's nomination as the Republican candidate for President.

PHILADELPHIA, June 28 -- The public utilities division of the Securities and Exchange Commission recommended today that the voluntary plan of reorganization of the United Gas Corporation be approved precisely as submitted by the holding company on March 6.
BOSTON, June 28 (AP) -- The Red Sox gained their eighth straight victory of the season over the White Sox by a 4-3 margin tonight in a twilight contest that attracted a slim crowd.
PEARL HARBOR, June 28 -- The most substantial gains yet made in the Battle of Saipan were reported today by Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet and Pacific Ocean areas.

John W. McCartney, who on Monday had testified before a Congressional subcommittee in the United States Court House that he considered the Government seizure and transfer of the Marine Maintenance Corporation shipyard at Bayonne, N.J., a "steal," reported yesterday that he had received a threatening anonymous telephone message.

Changes in regulations for correspondence with prisoners of war and interned civilians outside the United States, as received from the Office of the Provost Marshal General, Prisoner of War Division, War Department, were made public yesterday by Postmaster Albert Goldman of New York.
Mayor La Guardia, reached by telephone at his home, Gracie Mansion, made the following comment yesterday on Governor Dewey's nomination:

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- President Roosevelt paid tribute to the patriotic service of Miss Mary Anderson, who is retiring Friday as Director of the Women's Bureau of the United States Department of Labor after serving under five Presidents, in a letter read tonight at a testimonial dinner in her honor, attended by 200 co-workers and friends.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Vice Admiral Ross T. McIntire, Surgeon General of the Navy, reported today that the Navy now had within the continental limits of the United States alone 38 hospitals, of which 5 are convalescent hospitals, providing 70,000 beds.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Thursday, June 29 -- An iron ring of tanks and men is closing around Caen to the north, west and south of that ancient city, which today forms the hinge of the German battle line in Normandy.

CHICAGO, June 28 -- The issues and slogans the Republicans are going to stress in the opening campaign were clearly indicated in the nomination speeches this morning. They were accepted along with the party leadership by Governor Dewey in his address of acceptance tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The new manpower priority referral system does not mean that a worker is compelled to take a job offered him, it was emphasized today by Chairman Paul V. McNutt of the War Manpower Commission.

Wendell L. Willkie, with the help of the press associations, got a message to Governor Dewey yesterday that said, "Hearty congratulations on your nomination. You have one of the great opportunities of history." Observers immediately noted that it omitted any promise of support in the Presidential campaign.

CHICAGO, June 28 -- Had arrangements not been made for the Republican nominee for President to address in person the convention that drafted him, and had circumstances not arisen to ease the sting of the rejection of the Vice Presidential nomination by another Republican marked for the draft, these delegates of 1944 would have gone home in the depths of depression.

ALGIERS, June 28 -- While French officials declined today to confirm or deny President Roosevelt's statement that a date had been fixed for General de Gaulle's visit to Washington, it was assumed that he would go at approximately the time mentioned by the President.

Three cotton dealers were jailed yesterday and two concerns were fined $82,500 for violations of Office of Price Administration ceilings on finished piece goods and cotton products. The defendants included Amin E. Adjmi and Leon Adjmi, respectively president and secretary of both the Adjmi Importing Company, Inc., 5 West Thirtieth Street, and the New York Infants Wear Company, Inc., 868 Sixth Avenue.

Untrimmed coats continue toI lead in the volume of fall orders placed by retailers. I-Iowever, con-I i siderable attention is being given fur-trimmed merchandise, chiefly from the standpoint of style emphasis for the start of the new season.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Thursday, June 29 (AP) -- Compressing the eastern jaw of a trap on thousands of Japanese, Australians have advanced eighty miles in twenty-eight days to points within seventy miles of Wewak, British New Guinea.

PEARL HARBOR, June 28 -- Details of new tactics employed by the Japanese on Saipan and their use of the peculiar terrain over which fighting raged in the first week of the battle came to light as wounded men, now recovering in Hawaii, described the action through cane fields, farm lands, up the slopes of the old volcanic craters and around man-made caves gouged out of the hillsides by the enemy.

The body of Norine Prunty, 35-year-old pianist, was discovered yesterday in the kitchen of her two-room penthouse apartment above the twenty-third floor of 785 Park Avenue, shortly after an explosion and fire had shattered the room.

LONDON, June 28 -- Unless some unexpected difficulty arises, the draft agreement between the British Government and the French Committee of National Liberation on such urgent problems as the issuance of currency and the civil administration of liberated territory will be reached before the week-end.

LONDON, June 28 (UP) -- Marshal Tito's Yugoslav forces have killed, wounded or captured 2,270 German and other Axis troops in five days' fighting against three German divisions in western Bosnia and in other sectors of Yugoslavia, said a communique broadcast by the Free Yugoslav radio tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, June 28 -- The distinction between large, tenuous stars and clouds of gas called planetary nebulae may eventually disappear as a result of future discoveries concerning the sizes of star like those reported by Dr. Sergei Gaposchkin of Harvard to the American Astronomical Society meeting here today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 28 -- William Bendix has been named by Paramount for one of the co-starring comedy character parts in the screen version of "Duffy's Tavern." His role will run through the entire picture in conjunction with those of Ed Gardner, Charley Cantor and Eddie Green of the radio show.

CHICAGO, June 28 -- Thomas E. Dewey, reaching a climax of his thirteen-year political career, declared upon accepting the Republican nomination for the Presidency that only through electing a young, vigorous Republican administration could the people of the United States attain lasting peace and economic security.

CHICAGO, June 28 (AP) -- A stocky 54-year-old Wisconsin farmer captured the spotlight temporarily at the Republican National Convention today when he cast his vote for Gen. Douglas MacArthur and thus prevented the unanimous selection of Governor Dewey as the Presidential nominee.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., June 28 -- A survey of the realty situation in New York shows that the market generally is more active than it has been in fifteen years, with sales of small homes and farms approaching an all-time high, Henry G. Waltemade of the Bronx, president of the New York State Association of Real Estate Boards, reported at the opening of the fortieth annual meeting of the association here tonight.

BOSTON, June 28 -- A. Warren Norton announced today his resignation as manager of the Christian Science Publishing Society to become president of Press Wireless, Inc. He will assume his new post Saturday.

CHICAGO, June 28 -- Millers again were aggressive buyers of wheat futures in the early trading today on the Board of Trade, advancing prices 1 to 1 3/8 cents a bushel over yesterday's finish to a new high on the current recovery, September at $1.60, showing 4 1/2 cents above the low of last week.

The twenty-one-story Broad Exchange Building at 25 Broad Street, southeast corner of Exchange Place, has been purchased by the City Investing Company, Robert W. Dowling, president, from the Prudential Insurance Company of America, it was announced yesterday.

LONDON, June 28 (U.P.) -- A tiny force of 160 Norwegian patriots, believed to be men who escaped the German labor call-up, has been battling 3,000 German soldiers and military police equipped with tanks and field guns in the mountains of central Norway near Fagernaes for the past fifteen days, a Norwegian official spokesman said today.

In Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio the Republican party has nominated for second place on its ticket an experienced and successful State Executive who is popular in the Middle West and far better known in the rest of the country than he was six months ago, when he announced himself openly as a candidate for the Presidency.

Wartime restrictions in England which have eliminated much branded merchandise from the market lead producers there to wonder what their status will be during the post-war period, Lorimer B. Slocum, director of foreign offices of Young Rubicam, Inc., and vice president and managing director of the agency's Canadian offices, told the Export Advertising Association, Inc., yesterday at a meeting in the Belmont Plaza Hotel.
