Gone from the markets for another year are fresh shad and shad roe, but in their place are two canned products, representing this season's pack, which would satisfy the most discriminating shad fancier as good alternates. What's more, they will make light work for whoever presides over the kitchen.

ST. LOUIS, June 28 (AP) -- Max Lanier pitched only six and two-thirds innings but he lost two ball games tonight when the Phillies clinched the play-off of a game he started May 16 by a score of 6 to 5 and then defeated the Cardinals, 4 to 0, in a regulation contest.

The eight-story and penthouse building containing a store, four offices and thirty-eight apartments at 284 Fifth Avenue, northwest corner of Thirtieth Street, has been sold by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company to Maxwell Handelsman for investment.

Eleven members of a syndicate, headed by Harry Fromkes, who also is president of City Title Insurance Company, have bought the air-cooled Playhouse, 137 West Forty-eight Street, from Brady Enterprises, Inc., which is controlled by William A. Brady, 81-year-old dean of producers, and his wife, Grace George.

WITH ALLIED ARMIES in Normandy, June 28 -- A number of false and misleading accounts have been circulated regarding the attitude of French peasants toward the Allied forces

Clare Regan of Cathedral High School, Fiftieth Street and Lexington Avenue, won four prizes and two scholarships yesterday afternoon as she was graduated at exercises held in St. Patrick's Cathedral. The school is known as the Archbishop Hughes Memorial.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Thursday, June 29 -- Long Range American bombers have achieved new distinction, when for the first time a number of them landed in Italy Monday after having been based successively in Britain and the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The three victorious American divisions that cracked German resistance at Cherbourg may be considered now as available for other offensive actions, military observers here indicated today.

ABOARD JOINT EXPEDITIONARY FORCE FLAGSHIP, Saipan, June 29 -- American Marine and Army troops which have seen front line action for two weeks -- a Pacific war record -- today sought to develop the razor ridge mountain pocket northeast of Mount Tapotchau against the fiercest opposition yet encountered on this bloody island.
Mr. and Mrs. Warner L. Jones and Miss Ethel C. Jones of Louisville, Ky., are at the Ritz-Carlton.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Argentina has completed arrangements with Germany for repatriating Nazi diplomats and semi-official persons from their respective countries, it was announced today by Adrian Escobar, the Argentine Ambassador here.

Senator Alben W. Barkley of Kentucky told members of the Tammany Society last night that taxes could be reduced 50 per cent after victory, that America could look forward to a post-war economy in which 54,000,000 persons would be employed at fair wages and under decent conditions and in which investors willing to risk their capital could hope for a fair return.

Under the revised plan for the exchange of securities filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the United Corporation, the utility holding company will be enabled to retire about 45 per cent of its outstanding $3 preference stock.

LONDON, June 29 -- An estimate that 200,000 to 300,000 Poles have been forced into service in the German Army was given today by authoritative Polish quarters, which produced evidence of a German scheme to make these conscripts appear as willing and even eager volunteers.

Advancing their matriculation date by three months, medical, dental and veterinary schools will begin their program for new civilian students tomorrow morning instead of on Oct.1 as originally scheduled. This will permit these institutions to obtain occupational deferments for civilian freshmen for the coming year.

LONDON, June 29 -- A retroactive Anglo-Polish agreement was signed today whereby military supplies, materials and facilities used by Polish forces in Britain, the Middle East and Italy since June 3, 1940, and to be used in the future will be supplied by Britain on lend-lease.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The United States Treasury will resist efforts by some countries to include silver as an international monetary medium in the agreements reached at the Bretton Woods, N.H., Monetary and Financial Conference which opens on Saturday.

LONDON, June 29 -- With American help the British Ministry of Information has defeated all Dr. Joseph Goebbels' efforts to keep Europe ignorant of what is happening in the free world, Brendan Bracken, Minister of Information, said today.

LONDON, Friday, June 30 -- Victorious Russian armies, killing or seizing more than 125,000 Germans in the first week of the Red Army's summer offensive in White Russia, yesterday captured the encircled city of Bobruisk, forty miles behind the rapidly moving front.

Though there will be no Stadium Concert on July 4, the Stadium management has donated the evening to the Treasury Department for the Fifth War Loan, it was announced today. The Stadium will be used for an inter-racial rally. Eileen Farrell, radio soprano, will be one of the featured artists.

A BRITISH PORT, June 29 (AP) -- Three top-ranking German officers captured at Cherbourg, Lieut. Gen. Carl Wilhelm Dietrich von Schlieben, Admiral Walter Hennecke and a General Stattler were brought to England today in a tank landing ship.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 29 -- Enemy troop movements into the Normandy battle zone by rail have been reduced to a negligible trickle because of the effective bombing of railways, a member of the target section of the Allied Expeditionary Air Force said today.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 29 -- Fourteen Danes were killed and many seriously wounded when anti-Nazi rioting again broke out in Copenhagen last night, it was reported here today.

In your editorial of June 25 "Television at Chicago" it was stated that "for the first time the conventions at which the two great parties are to nominate their respective candidates are to be brought right into the home -- alas, at second-hand twenty-four hours later in the form of motion pictures transmitted by local stations."

The battle for Cherbourg is over, but only now that all the reports from both official sources and battlefront correspondents are at hand is it possible to realize what a grim and bitter struggle it was. By all accounts it was marked by the fiercest fighting of the whole invasion, fiercer even than the first assault on the Norman beaches.

A Frenchwoman, who recently came to this country on the repatriate ship Gripsholm, reports an abundance of luxuries, including silk stockings and ladies' handbags, in the Paris shops because the bottom has fallen out of the black market there.

CANTON, Ohio, June 29 (AP) -- furnaces were being emptied and heat pulled in four divisions of the plant of the Timken Roller Bearing Company tonight as a work stoppage spread to about 10,000 employes, CIO union officials reported.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Lack of oil, caused by our determined bombings of enemy refineries and synthetic oil plants, is one of the principal answers to the riddle of why the Lufawaffe is not flying, military authorities here believe.

ROME, June 29 (AP) -- Fighting in stifling heat and against intensified German resistance, Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark's American troops clubbed their way another five miles up the west Italian coast yesterday and captured the town of Castagneto, twenty-five miles from the major port of Leghorn.

Producing shows is a fascinating business, especially when one is fortunate enough to start out with the right script. Lately quite a few newcomers have announced their intentions of joining the managerial ranks, an indication that the supply of capital is plentiful.

ROME, June 29 -- Vittorio Orlando is no ghost from the past, even though Americans have been reading about him for years as one of the "Big Four" of the first World War. At 85, older than David Lloyd George, he is still very active and very much of a force in Italian politics.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- Chairman Connally of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, in a statement criticizing Governor Dewey's speech accepting the Republican Presidential nomination, called today for establishment of peace machinery with naval and military powers to crush "international criminals and outlaws."

CHUNGKING, China, Friday, June 30 (AP) -- Encircled and battered Hengyang has been bombed by American planes and left aflame after abandonment of the American airbase near by, it was disclosed last night by an American communique which referred to that vital Hunan Province railway junction as a "Japanese stronghold."

GARDEN CITY, June 29 -- Peter Ladislaw and Frank Graven, Plandome, cut two strokes from par to win the fifteenth annual best-ball championship of the Long Island Golf Association with 71 -- 3 -- 65 over the Garden City Golf Club course today.

Three new films will arrive in midtown theatres today. "Marine Raiders," a topical drama produced by RKO, win open at 8:30 P.M. at the Palace. Proceeds of the first showing, which is open to the public, will go to the Marine Corps League Rehabilitation Fund.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- Thomas E. Dewey, in his first day as Republican Presidential nominee, filled in the language of the Republican party platform on two important points where, he admitted, the necessity for compromise in the platform committee had left the actual stand open to two interpretations.

Hotels and restaurants that have been getting more than their fair share of the juicier roasts and tenderest steaks soon will have to yield some of the preferred cuts to the retail butcher shops so that the housewife may serve up a special treat more often, the Office of Price Administration promised yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- With seven of the defense lawyers in the mass sedition trial all described as covertly wearing badges proclaiming themselves members of the "Eicher Contempt Club," Judge Edward C. Eicher, presiding jurist, suddenly imposed still another $200 fine on one of the attorneys as the session recessed today until next Wednesday.

Inexorably and with gathering momentum, the three Allied spearheads forged at Teheran continue to thrust forward toward the heart of Nazi Germany. In the west General Montgomery has unleashed a powerful offensive against the German armored forces clinging to the anchor city of Caen, only a little more than 100 miles from Paris.

PHILADELPHIA, June 29 -- The U.S.S. Wisconsin, launched at the Philadelphia Navy Yard Dec. 7 as the mightiest battleship in the world, has been commissioned in record-breaking time and even now is on the prowl for the enemy in an undisclosed war zone.

AN ADVANCED COMMAND POST, June 29 (AP) -- Planning at least ninety days ahead in the campaign for the liberation of Europe, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Allied Commander-in-Chief, has held an important series of conferences here this week with Prime Minister Churchill, it was disclosed today.

Impulse sales, stimulated by new types of packaging and display technique, can be developed into an important post-war means of reducing retail selling costs, M.C. Pollock of the cellophane division of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., said yesterday.

The Fifth War Loan has hit a new peak of $12,605,000,000, or 79 per cent of the nation's $16,000,000,000 goal, it was announced yesterday by the Treasury Department in Washington. Sales of $2,271,000,000 were reported Wednesday, according to The Associated Press.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- Mrs. Thomas E. Dewey held her first press conference this morning and won her audience. She passed the ordeal with a unanimously favorable vote from the corps of interviewers, with whom she went on record unequivocally as to her role in the coming campaign.
LONDON, June 29 (UP) -- A German communiques, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press.

ST. LOUIS, June 29 (AP) -- The Phillies and Cardinals played it out on pitching entirely today as Bill Lee gained a 1-to-0 victory over the champion Red Birds in ten innings.

PACIFIC FLEET HEADQUARTERS, Pearl Harbor, June 29 -- All organized resistance behind our northward moving lines across the island of Saipan has been wiped out and the entire southern area is now securely held while marines and Army troops push doggedly ahead on the western shore and in the center sector.

TRENTON, June 29 -- State Motor Vehicle Commissioner Arthur W. Magee urged New Jersey motorists today to stay at home on Independence Day, but if they must go some place to celebrate, to walk rather than ride to the nearest resort.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Three canned vegetables, asparagus, peas and tomatoes, will rejoin the list of rationed foods on Sunday after being point-free several weeks, the Office of Price Administration said today.

The porcupine's taste for the Scotch pine, a European tree used extensively in reforestation, is such that the New York State Conservation Department no longer recommends its planting in those parts of the State where the porky abounds.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Over- all war production in May increased 1 per cent over April, the War Production Board reported today, but it said some of the most urgent production programs failed to meet their schedules during the month because of critical material and labor shortages.

Naval power will be the key to eventual victory, Vice Admiral Herbert F. Leary, commander of the Eastern Sea Frontier, declared yesterday at graduation exercises for the eighteenth class of the Naval Reserve Midshipmen's School at Columbia University.

CAIRO, June 29 -- Some nervousness has been occasioned in Arab circles by the nomination of Governor Dewey as the Republican candidate for President, and a report printed in the press here that his party intended to include in its platform a plank or declaration urging the British to implement the Balfour Declaration on Palestine.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- American casualtiies in the war, including the first two weeks of battle in Normandy, total 251,158. Of these, 55,206 are dead -- 35,104 soldiers and 20,102 naval, Marine and Coast Guard personnel.

The Mutual Life Insurance Company announced yesterday that it will open bids on July 5 on nineteen blocks of State and municipal bonds, aggregating $7,269,000, i now held in its investment portfolio. Offerings include bonds of the States of Illinois and Mississippi, and the cities of Detroit, Mich., and Chattanooga, Tenn.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 29 (U.P.) -- Finnish Foreign Minister Henrik Ramsay undertook today to explain to American Charge d'Affaires Edmond A. Guillion the events leading to Finland's agreement with Germany for German aid against Russia, advices from Helsinki said tonight.

The poultry supply situation, which was so tight a few months ago that black market operators were getting 15 per cent and more a pound in excess of legal ceiling prices, has improved to the extent that chickens and other fowl are now being sold in this city at several cents below ceiling, the Office of Price Administration reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Two members of the staff of Chief of Operations for the Army -- Col. Carl D. Silverthorne and Lieut. Col. Frederick G. Terry -- have been killed in action at Saipan, where they were on duty as official observers for the Chief of Staff, the War Department disclosed today.

Otto Kinz, president of Oppenheim, Collins Co, Inc., announced yesterday a dividend of $1 a share on the capital stock outstanding, payable on July 25. The previous dividend was 80 cents paid on June 30, 1943.

Plans for a "streamlined" program for Protestants of the five boroughs were announced yesterday by Cleveland E. Dodge, president of the recently organized Protestant Council of the City of New York.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The manufacture of passenger automobiles for American civilians, the first major effort under the Government's general reconversion program, will be on paper, at least, by the middle of next month.

Edward J. Flynn, Democratic leader of the Bronx, praised the Democratic political leaders of the county last night for their honest and efficient services locally and nationally. He spoke at a dinner in the Concourse Plaza Hotel, Concourse and 161st Street, attended by 1,000 civic, political and business leaders, representative citizens and public officials, in observance of the thirtieth anniversary of the creation of the Democratic county organization.
