RYE, N.Y., June 29 -- A second division of contenders for the United States Seniors Golf Association championship, numbering only sixty-six, considerably smaller than the opening-day section of 185, began their chase after Ellis Knowles and his pace-setting 145 at the Apawamis Club today, but at sundown all that appeared remaining undecided was the battle for runner-up honors.
ROME, June 29 (AP) -- A communique:

SAN FRANCISCO, June 29 -- The State Railroad Commission, which regulates public utilities in California, took preliminary steps today toward studying possible rate reductions so as to save residents of this State large sums by denying to utilities the right to charge war taxes to operating expenses.

A heavy thunderstorm hit the city at 8:30 o'clock last night, bringing relief to a citizenry worn by four days of an unbroken heat wave in which the mercury touched 89 degrees at 5 P.M., one notch under the year's record.

LONDON, June 29 -- A pitched battle with French guerrillas, in which the Germans employed 155-mm. guns and mortars as well as fighter planes and bombers and incurred 600 casualties, was reported today by authoritative French quarters in London. The battle, the date of which was not given, took place in the central mountains of France.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 29 -- A Negro acted as a German spy in Dr. Joseph Goebbels' set-up in Brazil, authorities charge. William Marcus Baan, a Dutch Negro, and William Henry Koepf, white, former president of the Hamburg Chamber of Commerce, later a business man in Peru, landed near Rio de Janeiro at midnight on Aug. 9, 1943, and were caught later by police.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Charles Michelson, the sage of the Democratic National Committee, has been recalled for active publicity service during the coming Presidential campaign. He will be on hand to do his share during the Chicago convention starting July 19.

Ignoring a request from the Regional War Labor Board that they return to work pending adjustment of their dispute, striking employes of the Bendix Aviation Company's two plants in Brooklyn last night voted to continue their walkout until Wednesday at 5:30 P.M.
" What this country needs is a good 5-cent cup of coffee," said Daniel P. Woolley, regional head of the Office of Price Administration, yesterday.

WITH ADVANCED ALLIED FORCES, Near Caen, June 29 -- From a ridge near the River Odon I have been watching the biggest tank battle of the Normandy campaign -- fought between Nazi Panzers and British and Canadian armored units with the ferocity of two heavyweights going all-out for a knockout.

An American Army band in front of the Cherbourg City Hall gave a few preliminary toots on its brasses and then sailed into the thrilling strains of the Marseillaise hymn. Ten days ago no one would have dared even whistle that song in Cherbourg. It wasn't a song the Germans cared for and Vichy regarded it as inappropriate for a regime which had repealed the Rights of Man.

Winfield Sawtelle, formerly metropolitan New York sales manager, and head of the new products division of Corn Products Refining Company, has been appointed president of Dr. Swett's Root Beer Company, it was announced yesterday.
LONDON, June 29 -- The fall of Cherbourg and the start of a British offensive around Caen mark the beginning of a third phase in the Battle of France.

Despite pleas from Government agencies urging prospective Fourth of July vacationists to remain at home, transportation systems prepared yesterday to handle what were expected to be record-breaking crowds during the long, four-day holiday week-end.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Plans for the enlistment of American women for the Wac for both England and Hawaii were announced today by the War Department.

Discussions between OPA representatives and members of the textile industries should consider the position of the apparel manufacturer and his costs as well as mills and converters, according to a letter sent to Horace L. Allen, acting head, men's clothing section, consumer goods price division, by Max J. Lovell, counsel and director of the National Association of Shirt and Pajama Manufacturers.

During May estimated withdrawals of domestic whisky from bonded warehouses, based on sales of Treasury tax stamps, declined only 5 per cent under the like month last year, according to a survey made public yesterday by Allied Liquor Industries.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Rupture of diplomatic relations between the United States and Finland was considered imminent today as a result of the "perfect understanding'' reached between Helsinki and Berlin, and the extent to which Germany has sent military forces into the country.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS in New Guinea, Friday, June 30 (AP) -- Strategic Yap Island was hit as planes of the Far Eastern Air Force roamed thousands of miles in raids reported today by headquarters.

Advertising in United States daily and Sunday newspapers during March covering the war effort totaled $4,779,693, the Bureau of Advertising, A.N.P.A., announced yesterday in releasing the latest in a series of monthly compilations made for it by the Advertising Checking Bureau, Inc.

Permission by the Office of Price Administration to canners to sell major vegetables of the current pack to the Government at prices to be adjusted when OPA ceilings are announced, means, it was learned yesterday in the industry, the clearing of storage space in canners' warehouses for goods for the trade.

The British radio said in a broadcast last night that an earlier report that Col. Gen. Eduard Dietl, German commander in Finland, had been killed in an airplane accident in Lapland with a member of his staff, had been confirmed by Stockholm messages.

PHILADELPHIA, June 29 -- The outburst of energy which would engulf the earth were the sun suddenly to become a nova would probably only scorch the top layer of the earth's crust, Dean B. McLaughlin of the University of Michigan said today before the American Astronomical Society meeting here.

BOSTON, June 29 (AP) -- The Red Sox took their ninth game in nine starts from the White Sox today, 5 to 4, with Tex Hughson marking up his eleventh victory, although he was relieved in the fifth inning after giving eleven hits. Red Barrett pitched the last four innings, holding the 5-to-4 advantage he inherited.

THE NEW YORK TIMES of June 25 published a statement by an OPA official that the gasoline black market operates mostly by way of counterfeit coupons and not because part of the gasoline, intended to flow through the crystal clear pipe of the rationing regulations, is diverted into the black pipe of the clandestine market.
Casualties among members of the merchant marine have been given as 6,000 out of 120,000, or one in twenty. Yet these men are discriminated against.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- During the week ended June 28 member bank reserve balances decreased $677,000,000. Reductions in member bank reserves arose from decreases of $363,000,000 in reserve bank credit and $8,000,000 in gold stock and increases of $227,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks and $128,000,000 in money in circulation, offset in part by decreases of $25,000,000 in Treasury cash and $22,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts.

Agitation for a basic classification of cosmetic colors, particularly lipsticks, rouges and powders, has been reported recently from several sources. Principal reason given for the suggested move is that color names, as they exist today, often give no hint of the color of the cosmetic to the purchaser.

GRAND CANYON, Ariz., June 29 (AP) -- Three Army fliers who have been marooned in a little-explored area of the Grand Canyon for more than a week started the long climb out to civilization today under the guidance of a ranger-native and an Eastern college professor whose hobby is mountain climbing.

CHUNGKING, China, June 28 (Delayed) -- By taking a small outpost three miles north of Tengyueh yesterday the Twentieth Chinese Group armies face the most formidable obstacle of the Salween campaign -- Tengyueh.

The Brewster Aeronautical Corporation's bank borrowings under a Regulation V credit, totaling $30,000,000, have been paid off by the Navy Department, preparatory to the cessation of Navy fighter plane production by the company, it was learned in banking circles yesterday.

ALGIERS, June 29 -- While American soldiers stationed abroad will be able to vote in the Presidential election, the bulk of them will have little opportunity to keep informed of the issues through adequate news of events and speeches at home.
Six crippled children of Bellevue Hospital in cots and wheelchairs, received high-school and eighth- grade diplomas yesterday afternoon at commencement exercises in the medical board room there.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The Tenth Army Air Force now is concentrating heavy attacks on Japanese shipping at Bangkok, Thailand, since enemy ships apparently have been driven from Rangoon on the western side of the Malay Peninsula, the War Department said tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 29 -- Ellen Drew, who has been signed to a term contract by RKO, will have the lead in "Isle of the Dead," the first of two "horror films" in which Boris Karloff will be featured. The picture, scheduled to start in two weeks, will be Miss Drew's second since her return from England.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Department store sales for the week ended June 24 were 15 per cent above sales in the corresponding period of last year. The following table shows percentage changes from like periods of a year ago:

The Guaranty Trust Company of New York is redeeming the Cities Service Company's warrants for fractions of shares of $10 par value common stock, at the rate of $1.5267 for each one-tenth of one share.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- Demand for flour showed no signs of falling off today and brokers on the Board of Trade said that, based on the volume of futures purchased recently by millers, sales of flour probably exceeded 2,000,000 barrels. Reports were current late in the session that a large Army order for flour had been filled.

The accident of the calendar makes the Fourth of July week-end this year an unusually long one. But more than any other holiday in generations this one should be celebrated not with carefree selfishness but with true patriotism. We should heed the plea of Goverment and of the carriers themselves not to travel except for true necessity.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Friday, June 30 -- The Germans have launched a violent counter-attack against the right flank of the British pincers slowly closing in on Caen.

The Lever Brothers Company of Massachusetts, soap manufacturer, has acquired the Pepsodent Company, maker of dentrifices, for $10,000,000 in cash. Announcement of the deal, without disclosure of terms, was made yesterday by Francis A. Countway, president of Lever, and Charles Luckman, president of Pepsodent.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Although some communicable diseases are at epidemic levels and others above normal expectancy, the general health status of the country has not changed significantly in 1944, the Public Health Service reported to the Federal Security Administrator today.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Friday, June 30 -- At least 2,000 American aircraft fanned out over a score of industrial targets in Germany yesterday as the full-scale offensive against enemy war production was resumed. Nothing approaching the weight or scope of this attack had been attempted since the invasion.

A biography of Thomas E. Dewey has been announced two days after his nomination as a Presidential candidate. It is written by Stanley Walker of The New York Herald Tribune and author of "City Editor," who has known Mr. Dewey for fifteen years.

There is no denying that the luck of the Irish fails to attach itself to the Wheatley Stable's chestnut colt Irish Tar. Beaten out of first place in six of his seven previous starts, Irish Tar managed to cross the finish line ahead of the others at Aqueduct yesterday.

Seven amateur cooks, finalists in a cooking contest held among the borough's teen-age scouts, took over the kitchen of the Hotel New Yorker's grand ballroom yesterday to demonstrate their culinary skills and to vie for the title "Best fish fryer among Manhattan's 8,000 Boy Scouts."

Governor Warren of California said he was chosen keynoter for the Republican convention because he comes from "the great, hopeful, energetic West." That is a fair enough description. When he said, "Ours is the youngest part of America," he was correct if he was thinking of the whole West.
CHICAGO, June 29 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows:

CHICAGO, June 29 -- It is a matter of opinion whether the identity of a vice presidential nominee has any important affirmative effect on the result of an election. Politicians are agreed that the candidate for second place can lose votes, possibly enough to affect the outcome, and this argument will be made vigorously against Vice President Wallace at the forthcoming Democratic National Convention, if he insists on renomination and the President supports his claim.

Nothing developed overnight in the local cotton market which would clarify the ultimat interpretation of the new price control law, but futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 7 to 13 points higher on active months, with the tone very steady.

When the 3 o'clock bell rings this afternoon it will mean that classes are over for the summer for 900,000 elementary and high school children, as well as for 35,000 teachers and supervisors in the New York City school system.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 29 (AP) -- Communique 47:

CHERBOURG, June 28 (Delayed) -- Until artillery and air force experts can make a thorough study of the egg-shaped network of strongpoints protecting this port city from both land and sea, a definitive report on the relative effectiveness of bombing by planes and shelling by big guns will have to wait.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Friday, June 30 (AP) -- A communique:

Reporting on operations of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation in 1943, G.W. Vaughan, president, informed stockholders in the annual report issued for publication today, that its shipments of aircraft, engines and propellers totaling $1,295,236,317 rose 68.1 per cent over the 1942 volume of $770,594,882.

DULUTH, Minn., June 29 -- Asserting that many businessmen have actually come to rely upon wartime controls and restraints about which they complain, William L. Batt, vice chairman for international supply of the War Production Board, stated today in an address prepared for delivery before the Duluth Chamber of Commerce that "business's primary responsibility is to prepare plans for reconversion."

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed a decrease of $99,350,000 in holdings of Government securities during the week, while note circulation for the system as a whole increased $116,521,000. The ratio of reserve for the system rose to 56.1.

WITH AMERICAN ARMY in France, June 29 (AP) -- Although the entire American front was relatively quiet today, Doughboys were put into attack in the St. Lo Sector to straighten out the lines by capturing enemy-held positions. In the early morning, dive bombers roared in to pound strong points and then artillery laid down a heavy barrage in advance of troops, signalling the flareup of activity on the southern front.

Yesterday was the Feast of St. Peter and St. Paul, a solemn commemoration now verging toward its two thousandth year. It is a very ancient tradition that Peter and Paul suffered on the same day and in the same year. Peter was crucified with his head downward, probably in the Gardens of Nero and at the foot of the Vatican Hill.

Executive Vice President, The Blue Network; Co-Chairman, Stage, Screen and Radio Section, Commerce and Industry Division, War Finance Committee for New York. When you buy a bond you are staking your claim in two kinds of freedom. The first is the freedom of a free America in a free world.

Women interested in entering the field of practical nursing are urged to register immediately at Montefiore Hospital for Chronic Diseases, Gun Hill Road and Bainbridge Avenue, Bronx, for a new training school scheduled to open Sept. 1.
Bank clearings climbed last week to a new high for fourteen years with the volume at New York exceeding last week's peak and transactions at major cities holding at a high level.

World-famous tennis players converged on New York yesterday for the Red Cross Victory Drive exhibitions to be held in the stadium of the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, Sunday, Monday and Tuesday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 29 -- In a wartime setting but with all the traditional color and dignity, Harvard University staged its greatest military commencement in its 308 years today and its smallest civilian graduation exercises since 1861.

NEVER before have so many self-appointed guides to the unknowable future so clamored for attention. "Follow me," some shout, "and I will lead you by magic short cuts straight to the Elysian fields." "My route is longer," shout others, "but if you come with me I will show you how to compound a panacea that will cure all the world's troubles at once, absolutely everything from dandruff to athlete's foot, from cannibalism to original sin.
LONDON, June 29 (AP) -- The weekly condition statement of the Bank of England reported an increase in circulation of 2,152,000 for week ended yesterday.

LONDON, June 29 -- There were indications in the House of Commons today that the present rigid censorship restrictions on the German flying bomb might be lifted. Under the current ruling, information regarding the total number of casualties, specific location of the bombings and the extent of damage may not be published.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Leaders of the French resistance movement held a meeting of Cherbourg civilians yesterday while the sound of guns still crashed through the city, Larry Lesueur reported in a broadcast over the Columbia Broadcasting System.

PITTSBURGH, June 29 -- Amid the crash of thunder, the flash of lightning and the patter of intermittent rain, the Giants and the Pirates battled to a 1-all deadlock today in a game that lasted just long enough to become legal.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Following a decline of the previous week, commodity prices in primary markets steadied and the general average remained unchanged during the week ended on June 24. The Bureau of Labor Statistics' comprehensive index of nearly 900 price series held at 103.7 per cent of the 1926 average.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- A new regulation aimed at controlling the prices of virtually every public eating and drinking establishment in the country and further strengthening the rules by requiring ceilings to be "prominently" posted was made public today by the Office of Price Administration.

Volume on the New York Stock Exchange continued heavy yesterday and prices, after easing moderately, recovered and closed firm. Turnover was 1,889,640 shares, against 1,745,810 on Wednesday. Of the 923 issues traded, 368 rose, 333 fell and 222 were unchanged.

LONDON, June 29 -- The stock markets here were generally quiet today. Falls were seen in the home rail junior stocks, and dollar securities also eased. Industrials were firm, with good support for Woolworth following the company's announcement of a maintained interim dividend. Rayons, tobaccos and breweries also hardened.

Sharp increases in loans and investments, a drop in demand deposits and a further gain in excess reserves were experienced by New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System in the fiscal week ended Wednesday, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

A twin project calling for the post-war expansion of the central building of the New York Public Library and the construction of an entirely new main circulating library was disclosed yesterday when a preliminary appropriations measure came before the Board of Estimate.

CHICAGO, June 29 (AP) -- Johnny Revolta of Evanston, Ill., the Texas open winner last February, duplicated a four-under-par 67-round today for a thirty-six-hole total of 134, which gave his foursome the momentum to roll up three of the four team titles in the Chicago victory national golf matches.

HE is a little more gray, but he is just as lean, just as restless and just as belligerent as ever. Bill Tilden breezed into town yesterday -- if breeze is an advisable word to use on a day so sultry -- in order to play in the Red Cross tennis matches at Forest Hills on Sunday, Monday and Tuesday, his first appearance in New York in three years.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 29 -- Still crippled in finding "explanations" from authoritative sources for the increasingly frequent "elastic withdrawals" by the Wehrmacht because of the protraction of the Propaganda Ministry-Army controversy, the German press, on orders from Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels, was tuned down today to a "we-must-await-forthcoming-developments" theme.

Three Brooklyn gangsters, all ex-convicts, found themselves held without bail yesterday on a robbery charge because Ernest Rupolo, known in gangland as "The Hawk," felt that he had been double-crossed.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 29 -- Ambassador Armour left Buenos Aires this morning by plane for Santiago, Chile, en route to Washington. Much comment was occasioned when the Chilean Ambassador, Senor Rios Gallardo, traveled to Santiago on the same plane.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The Office of Price Administration reported today that discussions relating to the pricing of cotton textile products under the Stabilization Act of 1944 had successfully got under way this morning between executives from the cotton industry and Government officials.

Although receipts of fresh fish during the last few days have been only moderate, demand has been slow and in consequence supplies should be adequate today. The most abundant variety on the market is haddock, according to the Fish and Wildlife Service, which says that hard clams and whiting also are in liberal supply.

FARGO, N.D., June 29 (AP) -- Senator Gerald P. Nye and Lynn U. Stambaugh, former national commander of the American Legion, were virtually neck-and-neck in the contest for the senatorship tonight as returns from Tuesday's Republican primary continued to come in slowly.

ALGIERS, June 29 -- The killing of Henriot in Paris is described here as an execution. It is considered to be the administration of justice by the Superior Council of Resistance, acting as a self-constituted revolutionary tribunal, much like the Committee of Public Safety in the French Revolution.

ON THE BRITISH FRONT in Normandy, 8:25 P.M., June 29 -- Field Marshal Gen. Karl von Rundstedt, "reacting violently," is rushing major reinforcements from the south in an attempt to check the British break-through across the River Odon, a field headquarters officer said tonight.

Secretary Hull has announced that the United States Government is giving full consideration to the question of breaking off relations with Finland. This announcement, which must be taken as the herald of the accomplished fact, is in line with the Teheran agreements, which called for the elimination of Finland from the war -- by peace negotiations if possible, or by force if necessary.
PHILADELPHIA, June 29 (AP) -- Allie Reynolds held the Athletics to three hits and banged out two doubles and a single himself in a 6-0 shutout for the Indians today.

EVANSTON, Ill., June 29 (AP) -- Charles Samson, Notre Dame tennis captain, came from behind in three successive sets today to defeat Harry Likas of Gonzaga University, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, 7 -- 5, in a semi-final match of the N.C.A.A. tennis tournament at Northwestern University.

Further unit expansion of limited-service ready-to-wear retailers here will depend on whether they can learn the new lesson of how to operate profitably without high sales volume, inasmuch as the number of areas of high retail trade concentration in this city is now exhausted, George Farkas, president of Alexander's in the Bronx, said yesterday.

Gregory Ferend told a Congressional subcommittee in the United States Court House here yesterday how a United States Maritime Commission official had threatened to take away the shipyard that his Sword Steamship Line had developed in Bayonne, N.J.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., June 29 -- The first full contingent of American casualties of the Normandy beachhead to return to this country arrived here today after a nineteen-hour airplane trip from the British Isles. The wounded, one Army officer, twelve enlisted men and a Navy Seabee, were flown in a C-54 Air Transport Command plane piloted by Capt. Charles A. Ryan of American Airlines.

BERN, Switzerland, June 29 -- No further details are given of the killing in Paris yesterday of Philippe Henriot, Vichy's Propaganda Minister, but it seems fully confirmed that he was "executed" by patriots impersonating militiamen. In view of the situation in France today, it is possible that no successor will be appointed.
CHUNGKING, China, June 29 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

CAMP MacARTHUR, L.I., June 29 -- Refinements in our airborne technique resulting from our experiences in the Pacific, Sicily, Salerno and Normandy, were displayed today in the mock seizure of a landing strip here by 600 infantry and field artillery paratroopers.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Dr. Charles Greeley Abbot, secretary of the Smithsonian Institution since 1928 and one of the world's leading authorities on solar radiation, announced today his retirement, effective tomorrow. He will be succeeded by the assistant secretary, Dr. Alexander Wetmore, biologist and head of the National Museum.

Childhood everywhere is hurt by this global war. In the devastated regions, in subjugated countries, even in our own land far from the battle fronts, children suffer. Some of the ill effects in this city are brought to clear light in the ninety-first annual report of the Children's Aid Society.

The appointment of Henry J. Fisher, publisher and civic leader, as chairman of the advistory committee of the Contributors Information Bureau of the Welfare Council of New York City was announced yesterday by Edward K. Warren, first vice president of the council, at a luncheon meeting at the Gremercy Park Hotel.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- Hal Newhouser turned Washington back with two hits as Detroit blanked to Senators, 4 to 0, tonight. Rudy York clouted his eighth home run of the season into the left-field bleachers to open the Tiger scoring in the eighth.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- Herbert Brownell Jr., long-time friend of Governor Dewey, will be elected chairman of the Republican National Committee at a meeting at Hotel Blackstone tomorrow morning, at which the Presidential nominee will be present.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- A recreation upswing so great that "the care of American children is no longer on the tailend of this war's priorities, but well up the list of national concerns," was reported today by Mark A. McCloskey, director of community war services.
The rarefied atmosphere that prevails in the upper levels of the American League's sizzling pennant race is still proving entirely too much for Luke Sewell and his pace-setting Browns.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 29 -- Sweltering amid stacks of union records -- more than a ton of them -- District Attorney Elbert G. Gallagher and accountants strove today to unravel for further grand jury presentation the intricate fiscal operations of Local 60 of the International Hod Carriers, Building and Common Laborers Union, AFL, from which the prosecutor alleges $250,000 has been stolen.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 29 (AP) -- The five directors of the Phoenix Securities Corporation of 44 Wall Street, New York City, have been appointed trustees in dissolution of the company by Chancellor W.W. Harrington, it was disclosed today.
WITH AMERICAN FORCES in France, June 30 (AP) -- Allied forces have killed, captured and wounded an equivalent of seven full German divisions since the invasion of France twenty-four days ago.

From the Army Exchange Service procurement branch yesterday came news that its 1944 Christmas gift suggestion catalogue is just arriving overseas. The Army Exchange Service is now waiting to see if the boys on the beachheads will heed its advice about early shopping.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The United States severed diplomatic relations with Finland today on the grounds that the Helsinki Government had entered into an irrevocable military partnership with Germany to fight the allies of the United States on the side of the enemies of the United States and that the Finnish operations had a direct bearing on the success of the Allied effort.
LONDON, June 30 -- The latest war news cheered the stock markets today, but business was on a small scale with the general undertone firm.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, July 1 (U.P.) -- Far Eastern Air Force Liberators hammered Yap Island with sixty-three tons of bombs Wednesday in the fourth consecutive day of raids on the Japanese base, while other bombers hit Palau and Sorol Islands, also in the Carolines, Gen.

During the ten years since June 19, 1934, in which the twelve central Federal Reserve Banks were empowered to make loans to industry for working capital, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York made only 376 loans, which, together with commitments, aggregated only $31,759,000, the bank reported yesterday in the July 1 issue of its monthly review.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Saturday, July 1 -- British infantry and tanks are systematically widening the nose of the salient they have thrust across the Odon River toward the Orne, south of Caen, despite repeated heavy counter-attacks in which the Germans are employing veterans of the Russian campaign rushed to Normandy to counter the Allied onslaught.

WITH A NAVY TASK FORCE, in the North Pacific, June 26 (Delayed) -- Guns of this fog-prowling task force blazed like roaring wraiths of destruction in a new attack -- the second in two weeks -- on Japan's Kurile Islands today.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The War Manpower Commission's most ambitious and comprehensive plan for solving an acute manpower shortage in critical industries will go into effect tomorrow when all male labor must be hired through the United States Employment Service or such channels as it may designate.

CHUNGKING, China, June 30 (AP) -- The vital rail junction of Hengyang is encircled by three Japanese divisions but still is in Chinese hands, a Chinese Army spokesman said in a press conference today. He reiterated charges that the enemy was using poison gas against the defenders of the city.
Despite the current crisis with Argentina, the War Food Administration announced yesterday that it is granting permits for the importation of 5,000,000 pounds of Argentine cheese.

Films depicting the activities of the Coast Guard in all the major invasions of the war to date, fighting equipment and a large group of paintings by noted combat artists are features of an exhibit entitled "Your Fighting Coast Guard," which will open today at the International Building, Rockefeller Center, and continue through Aug. 4.

At his first press conference following his nomination Governor Dewey was asked whether he approves of Secretary Hull's reciprocal trade agreement program. His answer was: "You mean the Republican reciprocal trade agreement program which Secretary Hull has been carrying out.

LOS ANGELES, June 30 -- Kurt Haugwitz-Reventlow, former Danish count, has notified his former wife, Barbara Hutton Grant, who is now the wife of Cary Grant, the actor, that he and their son, Lance, 9, are in Canada and that she faces a Canadian court fight for custody.

GRAND CANYON, Ariz., June 30 (AP) -- Nine days after they floated by emergency parachute into the depths of the Grand Canyon, three Army airmen clambered out of the mile-deep gorge today, safe and well but badly sunburned.

Plans are now being completed to open 345 play centers on public school grounds Wednesday, officials at the Board of Education said yesterday. The plans, emanating from the Department of Recreational and Community Activities, are in keeping with the highest appropriation ever made for the long summer holiday, and will make it possible to keep the play centers going for a full day schedule for the first time.

The local engagement of "Othello," Broadway's longest-run Shakespearean production, comes to a conclusion with tonight's performance, the 296th, at the Shubert Theatre. Starring Paul Robeson, Jose Ferrer and Uta Hagen, the play was revived Oct. 19, 1943, by the Theatre Guild.

The performance of Verdi's "La Traviata," originally scheduled for Thursday night but postponed because of rain, was given last night at the Lewisohn Stadium before an audience estimated at 17,000 persons. With a cast headed by Bidu Sayao, Jan Peerce and Alexander Sved, the work received a smooth and highly creditable presentation.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 30 -- The revolt of the Danes against German curfew orders was followed in Copenhagen today by a general strike that paralyzed the city. The Nazi execution of eight Danish saboteurs is believed to have drawn the already delicate situation to a head.

With activities in the marketing of new securities virtually suspended in the last three weeks, while investment bankers centered their efforts on the sale of Government bonds in the Fifth War Loan drive, new offerings of bonds here last month declined from the total of the preceding month, but were the largest for any June since 1941.

CHICAGO, June 30 (AP) -- Federal Judge Michael L. Igoe approved today a modified plan of reorganization for the Chicago, Milwaukee St. Paul Pacific Railroad in line with a decision given by the United States Supreme Court last March and Interstate Commerce Commission action last December.
FARGO, N.D., June 30 (AP) -- Absentee voters and soldiers' ballots may be an important factor in the race for the Republican nomination for Senator from North Dakota.

MEXICO CITY, June 30 -- Foreign Secretary Ezequiel Padilla is expected to leave tomorrow or Sunday by plane for Washington, it was learned today. His trip, the first he will have made to the United States since the spring of 1942, was linked with a decree issued by President Manuel Avila Camacho today that the Mexican Government had decided to undertake with its own capital the industrialization of Mexico.

Today the representatives of more than forty nations will gather at Bretton Woods to open a monetary conference. In several respects the conference will get off to an unfortunate start. Important as the problem of stable exchanges and world monetary soundness is, it would be impossible to imagine a more difficult time for individual nations to decide at what level they can fix and stabilize their national currency unit.

Due to procurement purchasing and increases in export quotas of M-317 there will be less civilian cotton goods available during the third quarter than in any calendar quarter since the start of the war, according to Donald B. Tansill, vice president of the Pepperell Manufacturing Company.
LONDON, June 30 (AP) -- Germany's blindly aimed robot bombs droned across southern England all day today, taking a number of lives, including those of babies in a rural nursery home.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- More tires, but fewer automobiles, will be the lot of civilian motorists in July, the Office of Price Administration revealed today.

RICHMOND, Va., June 30 -- Among the 434 patents -- the fewest issued in a week for many months -- listed in the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office, are Nos. 2,352,378 and 2,352,379, granted to Eric Geertz of Glen Allyn, Ill., on fire-extinguishing apparatus designed for use in coal mines or other enclosed spaces where dust-producing materials are handled.

The introduction of a bill to make former Presidents voteless members at large of the Senate for life by Representative Gordon Canfield, Republican, of New Jersey, is an excellent idea and a good sign of progress in these troubled times.

Conversations with opposing Polish factions have convinced Prof. Oscar Lange that there is grave danger of civil war in Poland when that country is liberated from German occupation, he said yesterday in an address to the New York State Industrial Union Council meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

L.B. (Jack) Nelson has been appointed general manager of the Sweets Company of America, Inc., Hoboken, N.J., it was announced yesterday by Bernard D. Rubin, president. Mr. Nelson, who had been vice president and treasurer of the Empire Electric Brake Company, has had thirty-two years' experience in the candy industry.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- One man and six women members of the American Red Cross overseas staff on a plane trip between Italy and Sardinia have been missing since June 14, national headquarters announced today following notifications from the Casualty Branch of the War Department.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, June 30 (AP) -- Chinese troops southwest of the Chinese-held supply base of Mogaung in north Burma are advancing down the main railway leading to Mandalay, a communique of Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten's headquarters announced today.

The Pennsylvania Railroad has spent nearly a billion dollars in improvements since the panic year of 1929, according to a review of its research activities just completed for distribution to passengers and shippers.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The text of Secretary of State Hull's note to Alexander Thesleff, Finnish charge d'affaires, on the severance of diplomatic relations with Finland follows:

Samuel Knepper bought from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company for cash over a mortgage of $350,000 for ten years the fifteen-story apartment house for sixty-one families at 290 Riverside Drive through H. Weller Co. The assessed valuation is $610,000.
Neighbors in Jackson Hole have asked me to say a word for them here in the East about your editorial of June 14 on the Jackson Hole Monument.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- President Roosevelt signed today the bill extending the life of the Price Control Act for another year with the statement that by its action Congress had performed "a signal service" and had made clear that it was the wish of all "that the line against inflation should be held."

ALGIERS, June 30 -- On the eve of Gen. Charles de Gaulle's expected visit to Washington his officials here have resumed their active cooperation with Allied civilian agencies in this theatre. That cooperation had been virtually suspended shortly after the decision of the French Committee of National Liberation on June 2 to call itself a provisional government, despite the Allies' refusal to recognize it as such.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Saturday, July 1 (UP) -- A communique:

The New York Stock Exchange has suspended from dealings Cuban-American Sugar Company 5 1/2 per cent convertible preferred stock, $100 par value, which has been called for redemption; American International Corporation twenty-year 5 1/2 per cent convertible debentures due in 1949, called for redemption, and Battle Creek and Sturgis Railway Company first mortgage 3 per cent 100-year bonds due in 1989, because of the small amount outstanding.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 30 -- As a result of an airplane accident on Long Island Sound this afternoon it became known that District Attorneys Edward J. Neary of Nassau County, Frank S. Hogan of New York County and Elbert T. Gallagher of Westchester were conferring on a Nassau police launch on ways and means of breaking up "a big mob of criminals" operating in the three counties.

A special meeting of stockholders of The Fair, operator of a department store in Chicago, has been called for July 26 to vote on a recapitalization plan to eliminate certain restrictive provisions applicable to the 7 per cent preferred stock on which arrears of dividends amount to $31.50 a share.

The Solar Aircraft Company reported yesterday in its annual statement of operations covering the fiscal year ended with April a net profit of $849,988, equal to $2.57 a share on the common stock. In the previous year it cleared $515,116, or $1.52 a share.

CHICAGO, June 30 (AP) -- Tournament golf followed a familiar pattern today as Byron Nelson -- putting for birdies on 15 holes and eagles on three -- scorched the compact Edgewater course in 32 -- 33 -- 65, six strokes under par, to take the first-round lead for the Chicago victory national championship.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, June 30 (U.P.) -- Twenty merchant seamen and four United States Navy gunners were lost when a small Panamanian freighter was blown to pieces by an underwater explosion in the Caribbean on an afternoon this month.

Walter H. Sammis, vice president and a director of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, was elected yesterday president of the Ohio Edison Company, one of the larger operating units in the Commonwealth and Southern systems.

The richest running of the famous Brooklyn Handicap will take place at Aqueduct today. Inaugurated in 1887, the Brooklyn is one of the specials that have been raised in value to $50,000 added this season. Despite the increase in the worth of the stake over the $30,000 prize of last season, only nine owners have signified their intentions of being represented in the event.

Finding themselves backed to the wall, with victory almost a "must," the Browns collected their forces, rallied and counter-attacked yesterday at the Stadium. The charge, led by Lefty Al Hollingsworth, who permitted only two Yankees to reach second base, brought the pace-setting St. Louis club a neat 3-0 triumph that couldn't have been much more timely.
ST. LOUIS, June 30 (AP) -- The Cardinals batted from toeholds today, rapping two Philadelphia pitchers for seven doubles out of 13 hits and an 8-to-4 victory.

In an attempt to "strike juvenile delinquency a body blow" the Metropolitan Federation of Daily Vacation Bible Schools will operate 311 such schools in Protestant churches for five weeks this summer. The majority will open Monday.

RYE, N.Y., June 30 -- Ellis Knowles of Apawamis gained the United States seniors' golf championship for the third successive year today when no one in the second section of the field was able to equal or beat his thirty-six-hole total of 145.

Purchase of war bonds in the nation have reached a total of $13,235,000,000, or 83 per cent of the quota, with a full week remaining of the Fifth War Loan drive to attain its goal of $16,000,000,000, it was announced yesterday.

TRENTON, N.J., June 30 (AP) -- Eric Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, who is on a visit to Russia, may be asked upon his return to call a meeting of insurance groups throughout the nation to discuss possible results of the recent decision of the United States Supreme Court that insurance is interstate commerce and subject to the anti-trust laws.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Hope for the future of the small powers among the United Nations was expressed today in an interview by the Norwegian Ambassador, Wilhelm Munthe de Morgenstierne, on returning from nearly three months in London, during which he witnesesd the effects of the German robot bombs.

Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam, recently named Resident Bishop in the New York Methodist area, and his wife, will move here from Boston in the next fortnight. The clergyman, who has been Resident Bishop of the Boston Methodist area since 1939, succeeds Bishop Francis J. McConnell, who recently was retired after having served as Resident Bishop here for sixteen years.

Retail trade here continued active this week, although gains over a year ago were not as heavy as a week ago. Estimates put the increase for department stores at around 15 per cent. Main floor, sportswear and vacation items were in strong demand.
CHUNGKING, China, June 30 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

Shipping offices in lower Manhattan piers on both the East and North Rivers have joined in the house-cleaning plan of the local salvage division of the War Production Board, it was announced yesterday by J.J. Kelleher, vice president of the United Fruit Company, who has been named chairman of the maritime group's waste paper collection drive.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The twelve United States delegates to the United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference opening tomorrow at Bretton Woods, N.H., left Washington this afternoon accompanied by m any delegates from the other participating countries, forty-four of which are expected to be represented.

The United States is suffering from the dictatorship of an anti-democratic economy, operating through politicians to prevent the winning of full employment, an economy of abundance and equal opportunities for all, declared the United Christian Council for Democracy, 457 West 123d Street, in a report yesterday to 10,000 church leaders over the nation.

Testimony on the seizure and transfer to different private management of a Bayonne, N.J., shipyard, was given before a Congressional subcommittee in the United States Court House yesterday by Gregory Ferend, who lost control of the yard, and R. Earle Anderson, United States Maritime Commission financial official who had much to do with the seizure.

A taxpayer's suit charging Mayor La Guardia and the Board of Estimate with making an illegal lump sum appropriation of $3,500,000 in the 1944-45 budget was begun yesterday in the Supreme Court by Lucius Wilmerding, a trustee of the Citizens Budget Commission.

CHICAGO, June 30 -- Strictly in keeping with the weather, the Dodgers and Cubs played "freeze out" for eight innings today before a shivering ladies' day crowd of 7,814. Then Andy Pafko turned on the home run heat, Ed Head's undefeated four-game streak was shattered and Jolly Cholly Grimm's Bruins took the game, 2 -- 0, to complete a sweep of the series.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The significant development in the European war, in the opinion of military observers here, is that Germany has lost the power of initiative on the three fronts where she is so relentlessly engaged and that she seemingly is unable to strike any major blow anywhere that will disrupt Allied plans.

Financial control of the City College Store, which has been managed by a faculty-student committee for the last twenty-eight years, was to be transferred today to John B. Goodwin, college business manager, by Harry N. Wright, president.

LONDON, June 30 (U.P.) -- Adolf Hitler announced today in an order of the day broadcast by Berlin the death of Col. Gen. Friederich Dollmann, Commander in Chief of the German Army on the French invasion front.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 30 -- A proposed change in the Federal court rules of criminal procedure, whereby a defendant would be required to file the names of alibi witnesses at least three days before the opening of a trial, was outlined today before nineteen judges of the Third Federal Judicial Circuit (New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware) at their annual conference at the Claridge Hotel.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Saturday, July 1 -- Several hundred aircraft of all types, in a great Allied air offensive, bombed and strafed enemy airfields and lines of communication, notwithstanding thick cloud banks lying over most of northwestern France yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Sales of wholesalers, as reported for 2,808 establishments, were 10 per cent higher in May than in May, 1943, according to an announcement released today by the Census Bureau. May sales this year were 4 per cent over the dollar volume recorded for the preceding month, and for the year to date (five months) sales were 5 per cent higher than for the corresponding period of 1943.

CHICAGO, June 30 -- Mill buying and short covering ran wheat prices up 1 to 1 1/4 cents a bushel in the early trading today on the Board of Trade, September, in which is the bulk of trading, selling at the highest price in about two weeks and up 5 cents from the low of last week.

PACIFIC FLEET HEADQUARTERS, Pearl Harbor, June 30 -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced today that total casualties in two weeks of the Saipan Island battle were 9,752 killed, wounded and missing in action.

Total newspaper advertising in fifty-two cities during May, 1944, amounted to 117,776,135 lines, compared with 120,985,116 for the like month a year ago, according to a study by Media Records, Inc. The linage compares with 116,471,443 for April, 1944.

With the signing of the Price-Control Extension Bill by President Roosevelt, there appeared yesterday to be just as much confusion in the cotton trade over interpretation of the law as there was a week ago, and this was reflected in a downward adjustment in cotton prices on the New York Cotton Exchange, where prices finished at about the lowest levels of the day and 6 to 14 points net lower.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30 (AP) -- Mickey Rocco's twelfth-inning single drove Roy Mack across the plate with the run that gave the Indians a 5-to-4 victory over the Athletics tonight and dropped the Mackmen into the American League cellar while the Indians scrambled out.
A communique, as broadcast domestically yesterday by the Finnish radio and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Over the radio early Wednesday afternoon it was startling, if just for a moment, to hear Elmer Davis casting Indiana's 29 votes for Thomas E. Dewey. Thereupon you lost no time in asking yourself what would the chief of OWI be doing at a Republican national convention?

The Philippines are to be independent as soon as possible after the last armed Japanese has been killed, captured or driven out of the islands. Such is the purpose of the joint resolution signed yesterday by President Roosevelt in the obvious confidence that the Japanese will be disposed of before the old independence date of July 4, 1946.

CAMDEN, N.J., June 30 -- More than 20,000 employes of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation yards here staged a twenty-minute demonstration this morning in protest against a delay in negotiations for a new labor contract between the company and Local 1 of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, CIO.
A communique, from a Berlin broadcast recorded in New York by The Associated Press:
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 30 -- Ghostly bagpipes are playing from the Saar to the graveyards at Saint Valery, for the Fifty-first Division is back in action in France.

After Vittorio Orlando, sometime Prime Minister of Italy, withdrew from public life in 1925, he wrote that "a profound oblivion has descended on my name." It was true till the other day. Many of us had probably forgotten him, though he was here as late as 1931.

Stocks yesterday closed the heaviest month of trading since the collapse of France in May, 1940, with railway shares at their best level in seven years and industrials at peaks for four years. Prices improved moderately and closed irregularly higher on the day.

For diverting industrial diamonds to jewelry use in violation of War Production Board orders, the Allied Diamond Company, 527 Fifth Avenue, has been suspended from buying or selling rough diamonds until Oct. 31, R.A. McGovern, regional compliance manager for the agency, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The War Production Board is studying the possibility of relaxing its controls over the manufacture and distribution of textile, clothing and leather machinery through amendments to Limitation Order L-215, it was learned today.

Post-war education should be a liberating force that "frees men from ignorance, superstition, fear, prejudice, unnecessary physical handicaps and the need to use force in the solution of national or international social problems," Dean Harry J. Carmen of Columbia College declared yesterday at the college's third wartime commencement exercises.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, June 30 (U.P.) -- Monsoon rains limited activity throughout the north Burma front yesterday, but a communique said Chinese troops had knifed deeper into the northern part of Myitkyina, while Japanese attacks west and south of the city were repulsed.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange expanded last month to the largest of any month in four years, or since May, 1940, when Germany invaded the Low Countries, and to the largest for any corresponding month since 1933, when prices rallied after the first inauguration of President Roosevelt in March of that year.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- Milo Candini scattered Detroit's seven hits as Washington defeated the Tigers, 4 to 2, tonight. Candini weakened only in the fourth, when doubles by Pinky Higgins and Eddie Mayo, a single by Chuck Hostetler and Johnny Sullivan's error produced their two runs.
SOUTHERN ENGLAND, June 30 (U.P.) -- Prime Minister Churchill paid a six-hour visit to anti-aircraft emplacements battling Germany's winged bombs today, fifteenth day of the robot blitz.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- Among 261 casualties announced today by the Navy Department were the following from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut:

For a good many years now the bed pillow has been tucked away beneath the top of the spread -- a custom that often has proved a trial to fussy bedmakers. Now pillow shams are back, some of them very similar to the ones whose starchy whiteness need to stand up stiffly against imposing Victorian headboards.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 30 -- One of the great rescue feats of the war was described here today when the War Shipping Administration identified as the 12-year-old Grace luxury liner Santa Elena a troopship sunk by German torpedo planes while it steamed toward Italy in a convoy last fall.

Election of Werner W. Schroeder of Illinois, as a vice chairman of the Republican National Committee and the dropping of Sinclair eeks, of Massachusetts, as committee treasurer appeared last night to be goading Wendell Willkie, the 1940 nominee, nearer to an open break with the party.

A special meeting of stockholders of Willys-Overland Motors has been called for July 12 in Toledo, Ohio, to ratify options to be granted to Charles E. Sorensen, new president of the company, to purchase 100,000 common shares at $3 a share.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- President Roosevelt signed today a $3,920,320,000 supply bill to finance aid to the country's allies during the fiscal year starting tomorrow.

Except for the public offering of a small block of municipal bonds, the new-issue market here this week was virtually at a standstill, a condition that has existed since June 12, when the Fifth War Loan drive began. While new flotations were scarce, however, buying departments of investment banking firms continued to do a modest business during the week acquiring tax-exempt securities.

Representative James M. Fitzpatrick of the Bronx and Arthur G. Klein of Manhattan, both Democrats, withdrew yesterday as candidates for re-election as the statutory deadline for declining primary designations was reached at midnight.

In a last-minute appeal by radio to vacation crowds starting a mass exodus yesterday from New York that jammed railroad and bus terminals, Col. J. Monroe Johnson, director of the Office of Defense Transportation, warned that the transportation systems had no room for holiday travelers.

WHITE PLAIN, N.Y., June 30 -- The will of H. Edward Manville, filed for probate here today, established a trust to be known as the Hiram Edward Manville Foundation and endowed it with a major portion of his estate for use in financing intellectual and charitable activities of broad variety.

PATERSON, N.J., June 30 -- Nobody in Washington or elsewhere seems to be able to do anything about crowded trains and buses, but ten Paterson men have done something about the crowded barber shop, another wartime irritant to the tired business man.

YENAN, China, June 9 (Delayed) -- The first group of foreign correspondents to visit Yenan, the directing center of the Chinese Communist areas, found a hatred of the Japanese and a determination to defend their achievements against all interference.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 30 -- Warner Brothers has named Alexis Smith for the feminine lead with Errol Flynn in the proposed Technicolor production, "San Antonio." Zachary Scott, who portrayed the title role in "The Mask of Dimitrios," will be the principal "heavy."
ROME, June 30 (AP) -- A communique:

CINCINNATI, June 30 (AP) -- The thirteen jinx held nothing for Bucky Walters tonight as he pitched the Reds to a 3-to-2 triumph over the Braves to record his thirteenth victory, against three losses this year. However, all of Cincinnati's runs came by way of the unearned route.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, June 30 (AP) -- Communique 49:

LONDON, Saturday, July 1 -- Soviet troops, hurling back German reinforcements, swept nineteen miles across the Berezina River north of Borisov yesterday to within thirty miles northeast of Minsk, while other Red Army forces outflanked the White Russian capital by capturing Slutsk, sixty miles south of Minsk.

CHICAGO, June 30 -- Plowing through stacks of bills, Chairman Walter S. Hallanan of the Republican Arrangements Committee found today that the Republican gathering cost only one-third as much as that of 190 in Philadel. phia, while establishing the following "firsts" in the party's history:

PITTSBURGH, June 30 -- The Giants spattered Forbes Field with twenty-nine assorted hits today in a double-feature celebration of the thirty-fifth anniversary of the plant's dedication, but they had to settle for a split with the Pirates.
NEWARK, N.J., June 30 -- Four men lost their lives in New Jersey during storms last night and early today, three being killed by lightning and the fourth by shock from a broken power line.
BOSTON, June 30 (AP) -- The Red Sox regained second place from the Yanks by routing the White Sox, 11 -- 0, tonight in a twilight contest. It was the tenth straight victory over Jimmy Dykes' forces.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast by the Moscow radio to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- President Roosevelt has approved two resolutions of Congress covering the policy of the United States toward the Philippines in the future, and in announcing this today he promised full restoration of democratic government in the islands, removal of enemy collaborationists and constructive measures for rehabilitation.

ALBANY, June 30 -- New regulations simplifying the collection of stock transfer taxes by eliminating the adhesive stock transfer stamps on over-the-counter sales by members of registered exchanges were announced today by Rollin Browne, president of the State Tax Commission.

ROME, June 30 -- Allied troops, smashing forward for gains of up to nine miles along a 100-mile front across western Italy, drove to within twenty airline miles of the great port of Leghorn today, and inland menaced Siena on the Rome-Florence road and captured Castiglione del Lago, western anchor of the German defense line around Lake Trasimeno.
In supporting an Amendment to the Constitution changing the method of ratifying treaties, you repeat two statements which, considering the importance of the subject, should not pass without question.

To help Mayor La Guardia's "At Home" vacation program, a group of artists has volunteered to give free sketching lessons in Central Park this summer. No experience is required of those wishing to attend the classes, which will last two hours each.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- About 10,000,000 gallons of beverage alcohol will be added to the 50,000,000 or more gallons which distilleries will be free to make during the August "holiday" from war production, it was disclosed today.

An inspection tour yesterday of the newly completed Army Hospital Ship Wisteria, the first permitted in this area by the War Department, revealed an up-to-the-minute seagoing hospital, equipped to handle virtually any kind of an emergency.

CANTON, Ohio, June 30 (AP) -Four divisions of Timken Roller Bearing Company were virtually shut down today as 9,000 of the 10,000 employes walked out in protest over what union leaders termed "a complete breakdown in labor relations."

ON BOARD GOVERNOR DEWEY'S TRAIN EN ROUTE TO ALBANY, ELKHART, Ind., June 30 -- Governor Dewey, Republican nominee for President, headed back from Chicago to his home State job tonight, with his party lodged in five cars attached to the second section of the Lake Shore Limited, regular New York Central train.
KANDY, Ceylon, June 30 (UP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- Harold Boeschenstein, acting director of the Forest Products Bureau of the War Production Board, today "advised" newspaper publishers who have placed orders for thirty-pound newsprint from Canada for manufacture after July 1, to switch the orders to thirty-two-pound paper.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Figures for trade with Latin America, which have been withheld since Pearl Harbor, were issued today by Secretary of Commerce Jesse H. Jones, showing for 1943 exports of $819,000,000 and a record total of imports of $1,310,000,000.

PITTSBURGH, June 30 (AP) -- A wave of walkouts affecting war production swept over Pennsylvania today, disrupting operations in a steel mill and seven other industrial plants, including five coal mines, and making more than 6,500 employes idle.

This week the death was recorded of Seth Thomas, great-grandson of the Seth Thomas who founded the great industry still flourishing at the Connecticut town named after him. The first Seth Thomas, 1785-1859, was a carpenter and skilled woodworker, who in the first years of the last century joined Eli Terry, a little older man, and Silas Hoadley in setting up a clock factory in the Connecticut Plymouth.
CHICAGO, June 30 (AP) -- White Governor Dewey mapped his campaign today his wife kept appointments with women leaders of the party and saw personal friends.

Outstanding performers of the stage, radio and night clubs, plus the swing bands of Charlie Spivak, Cootie Williams, Lionel Hampton and Tab Smith, will participate in "The Stars Salute," the mammoth war bond show to be held next Tuesday night at Lewisohn Stadium.

Admiral King and Generals Marshall and Arnold must collectively know more than any other three Americans about the present and future needs of our fighting forces. They have returned from their trip to Normandy convinced that the extent of those needs is not realized at home.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., June 30 -- The New York State Association of Real Estate Boards today adopted a broad program for redevelopment of cities, rebuilding of slums and revision of tax laws and announced that its members would begin work immediately to promote the program as a means of stabilizing realty values, promoting orderly neighborhood growth and helping to provide employment during the period of readjustment after the war.

THE return of New York University to intercollegiate football will be greeted with deep feelings of satisfaction and rejoicing everywhere. The decision to abandon the game in February of 1942 was accompanied by violent protests from undergraduates and alumni. Presumably the move was dictated by motives of economy, and the fact that the country had been at war for a couple of months had little bearing on it.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- Harold Boeschenstein, acting director of the Forest Products Bureau of the War Production Board, today "advised" newspaper publishers who have placed orders for thirty-pound newsprint from Canada for manufacture after July 1, to switch the orders to thirty-two-pound paper.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Figures for trade with Latin America, which have been withheld since Pearl Harbor, were issued today by Secretary of Commerce Jesse H. Jones, showing for 1943 exports of $819,000,000 and a record total of imports of $1,310,000,000.

PITTSBURGH, June 30 (AP) -- A wave of walkouts affecting war production swept over Pennsylvania today, disrupting operations in a steel mill and seven other industrial plants, including five coal mines, and making more than 6,500 employes idle.

The first Seth Thomas, 1785-1859, was a carpenter and skilled woodworker, who in the first years of the last century joined Eli Terry, a little older man, and Silas Hoadley in setting up a clock factory in the Connecticut Plymouth.

Outstanding performers of the stage, radio and night clubs, plus the swing bands of Charlie Spivak, Cootie Williams, Lionel Hampton and Tab Smith, will participate in "The Stars Salute," the mammoth war bond show to be held next Tuesday night at Lewisohn Stadium.
