Owing to the fact the eight local housing authorities throughout the country decided to enter the market with short-term note issues, next week's calendar of municipal issues up for award will amount to $20,372,000, compared with this week's total of $4,440,000.

MIAMI, Fla., June 30 (AP) -- Lieut. Richard L. East, son of Dr. and Mrs. Bion R. East of Ralston, N.J., died in air battle over Tunisia and the parents asked for return of his brown-eyed spaniel as a living link.

ALBANY, June 30 (AP) -- Although thirty-two cases of infantile paralysis were reported this month in the State, as compared with six cases in June, 1943, the State Health Department said today that there was no cause for alarm.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- The United States' rupture with Finland came at the end of a ten-day period which may later be recognized as one of the most critical in the history of the twenty-five-year-old Finnish Republic. In those ten days a planned pro-Allied coup failed to come off at Helsinki, according to reliable reports here.
ALBANY, June 30 (AP) -- To working women of New York State is guaranteed a wage equal to that paid to men for the same work under a new law which becomes effective tomorrow.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30 (AP) -- The Brooklyn Union Gas Company, Brooklyn, N.Y., registered today with the Securities and Exchange Commission $12,000,000 in twenty-five-year sinking fund debentures for refinancing of its outstanding funded debt.

With more than $9,450,000 in unloaned funds in its treasury, the Provident Loan Society of New York, founded fifty years ago to kill the loan-shark racket, has decided to pay off at par all its $10,650,000 certificates of contribution on Sept. 30.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- Government officials worked late tonight preparing scores of changes directed in new price control and wage stabilization legislation effective tomorrow, with indications that not all the revisions can be made on time.
CHERBOURG, June 30 -- It is a moving experience to watch a dead city come to life again.

The cast for the Red Cross victory drive tennis matches, which will be held tomorrow, Monday and Tuesday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, was completed yesterday when the committee announced that Lieut. (j.g.) Donald McNeill, national champion in 1940, has been added to the all-star array.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30 (AP) -- The Pennsylvania Supreme Court upheld today the constitutionality of the State's franchise act of 1935, which, during the last three years, the Commonwealth said, has enabled the State to collect more than $30,000,000 in taxes from out- of State corporations.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- A first anniversary announcement that the United States Cadet Nurse Corps had exceeded by 500 its enlistment quota of 65,000 was made today by Surgeon General Parran of the Public Health Service.

H. H. Chang, who has received degrees from Johns Hopkins and Harvard Universities, taught in China's universities, founded and edited a Chinese weekly newspaper, and served as Chinese Minister to Poland, Porttgal and Czechoslovakia, has written a biography of Chiang Kai-shek, whom he knows personally.

The immediate results of the new program effective today for channeling nonessential workers into war jobs will not be as great in New York City as in most of the country because of modifications of the national program for this area, Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the War Manpower Commission, said yesterday.

Oriental cooks tell us that chop suey isn't genuinely Chinese, but even so, it's a good dish and offers a pleasant way to vary menus on occasion. From now on -- at least, in this vicinity -- it's apt to appear more often on tables, for the Birds Eye division of the General Foods Corporation is introducing it in simple-to-use, quick-frozen form.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- The Boardwalk, dark for the last two years, will blaze again on the Fourth, when the traditional fireworks display goes into action. The display will highlight a patriotic spectacle envisioning the fall of Berlin. During the day a gala outdoor rally will have as an added attraction a group of movie stars, now filming a show in the neighborhood, participating in a war bond appeal.

Disclosure by the American Automobile Association of country-wide disregard for wartime speed regulation and indifference to automobile and tire conservation is disquieting. The findings, which have been reported to appropriate Government agencies, are based upon a preliminary swing around the country of two AAA road cars which are testing the wearing qualities of tires made of synthetic rubber.

WITH his sense for dramatics Hitler sees the present struggle as a personal contest between himself and the forces of evil, personified since 1941 above all by Roosevelt, the favorite target for what he calls his irresistible wit and devastating criticism.

DALLAS, July 1 (AP) -- E.B. Germany, former Texas Democratic Committee chairman and leader in the State revolt against the renomination of President Roosevelt, said today that he expected Texas and other Southern delegations to support James A. Farley for President against Mr. Roosevelt if they received voting seats at the convention.
THE author of this book, a professor emeritus of English literature at the University of Pennsylvania, suffers from a disease that has never killed anybody and may have helped keep many men alive.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Sunday, July 2 (AP) -- A heavy bombing attack on Numfor Island, Japanese air base off north Netherland New Guinea, and the sinking of a small Japanese merchantman near Palau, western Carolines, were reported today by headquarters.

AFTER he had wrapped up his film edition of "The Hairy Ape," Producer Jules Levey was filled with an understandable curiosity as to how familiar John Q. Public was with the title and the author of the work, for familiarity, in this case, would breed good box-office.

SAIPAN, Marianas Islands (Delayed) -- For one hour this morning, in a nip-and-tuck battle to keep intact a beachhead hammered out by assault forces, we lay with badly battered Marines in the water's edge, behind damaged tanks and landing craft.

HE'S a fidgety 12-year-old who hops from one foot to the other, scratches his head, hitches up his pants. The woodworking instructor in the settlement house sees him as a disorganized youngster who can't handle tools, who "never finishes anything."

Some of the bass fishermen who began their activities with the opening of the New York season yesterday may be in a position to do a favor for the State Conservation Department. Those who operate in the Lake Ontario-St. Lawrence River region may find that their prize small-mouth is tagged.

I WATCHED this journey in my dream a long time. I saw where they came down to the white beaches of a bay of the sea, the western end of the world; a place very ancient, folded many miles deep in the silence of the forests; a place, in some sort, lying rather at the world's beginning, as though men were born traveling away from it.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast by the Moscow radio to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

DAVID JOFFO, American business man who was financial adviser to a former ruler of Afghanistan and who has contributed numerous stamps to the collection of President Roosevelt, sends from Lisbon to THE NEW YORK TIMES a cover on which the postage is paid with stamps issued by Portugal to commemorate the Third Philatelic Exhibition.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- While the current controversy over the cost of living would ordinarily be an economic question, this year it is at least as much political as it is economic. The Republican National Convention's platform this week takes cognizance of the controversy by condemning "the freezing of wage rates at an arbitrary level."

PRE-HOLIDAY trade last week, which featured the usual buying of summer and vacation items, maintained the larger gains recently noted in merchandise volume. Comparisons with a year ago are being affected, of course, by the variations in store schedules for the summer.

Markets did little yesterday, Stocks held within narrow ranges and closed firm. Government bonds were virtually unchanged. Corporation bonds had a small turnover and prices held steady. Grains were mixed but on the firm side. Cotton gained 7 to 8 points.

Prospects for the domestic whisky and gin industry definitely are brighter than at any time since Oct. 8, 1942, when distillers converted to war alcohol production and, in the opinion of distillery spokesmen, the shortage threat has been practically submerged through granting by the War Production Board of the August "holiday", for production of potable spirits.

OMAHA, July 1 -- These Midwestern farm States took lackadaisical note of the proceedings in Chicago this week. The languid concern over the proceedings of the Republican National Convention was but corroborative evidence of the lack of popular interest in politics apparent for some time and previously reflected in the small primary vote cast here.

When General Eisenhower signaled the mightiest army of all time to move into action, it spelled "reveille" for America's citizen army to shed its lethargy, shake off its complacency, and "back the attack" in a united drive unequaled in enthusiasm and energy.

GUATEMALA CITY, July 1 -- General Jorge Ubico resigned as President of Guatemala today and turned the Government over to a military junta composed of Generals Eduardo Villagran Ariza, Buenaventura Pineda and Federico Ponce.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 1 -- Dr. Joseph Goebbels' Ministry early last week suffered a jolt. Last Sunday evening, shortly after 9 o'clock, a spokesman for the German Army announced to the home front that Cherbourg had fallen.

THOSE of us who recall the hot, anxious days of July, 1914, will remember how incredible it all seemed. The world was too civilized and men were too intelligent to permit such a disaster as a general war. In the long nightmare which followed we said to ourselves: "Never again," and Woodrow Wilson spoke for the conscience and determination of mankind in a stricken and repentant world.

Despite the war, more than 7,000 foreign students are attending American colleges and universities at the present time, and the total is expected to increase when the fall term opens. A tremendous growth is noted in the number of Latin-American students here on fellowships and scholarships, owing in large part to the "good neighbor" policy.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The White House today made public the text of a message that Vice President Henry A. Wallace took to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek from President Roosevelt along with a scroll for the city of Chungking which Mr. Wallace presented to the Generalissimo on June 23.
ROME, July 1 (AP) -- A communique:

SUPERFICIAL knowledge, dangerous under any circumstances, becomes a deadly weapon in war, especially in the hands of untrained, on-the-spot observers who, commanding a hearing because they were eyewitnesses to action, are apt to interpret the whole in the light of their own restricted experience -- like the blind men who judged the elephant by the particular portion of his anatomy that each of them encountered.

THE ranks of refrigerator repair men have dwindled in the past year and the work of those who are left is hampered by the scarcity of parts and by transportation difficulties. An "out of order" complaint this summer may be followed by weeks of buying ice or borrowing space in a neighbor's refrigerator.
CHUNGKING, China, July 1 (AP) -- A later communique:

FOR years corset manufacturers, fashion leaders and exercise authorities have disagreed as to the value of girdles and corsets in promoting better figures and better posture. Another angle of the controversy was brought out recently by Miss Mary Anderson, director of the Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor, when she stated that the shortage of corsets might cause many older women to quit their war jobs.

An English translation made for the United grates Embassy in Moscow of the text of the study in Pod Znamenem Marksizma (Under the Banner of Marxism), to which attention was called in a news article in THE NEW YORK TIMES of April 2 reporting that Marxist economic theories as their had been officially taught in Soviet Russia have been basically revised, reached New York yesterday.

Income tax law governing replacements of equipment will be an especially important subject to industry in the post-war transition period. While the law in respect to exchanges of property used in business is reasonably well settled, the treatment thereof for tax purposes may depend upon the manner in which the transaction was consummated.

LONDON, July 1 -- Prime Minister Churchill may make a statement on the flying-bomb menace when Parliament meets next week. He has yet to speak on this subject and it is expected that now, as in the past, he will reassure the British public on defense measures while bidding them to take courage for the ordeals to be faced until victory.

LONDON, July 1 (AP) -- Pressure has developed in Parliament for a franker official reporting on the robot bombs. One member, Alfred Denville of Newcastle-on-Tyne, said he would ask British Home Secretary Herbert Morrison to shorten the siren sound for raid warnings and all-clears, or discontinue them, as a step to counteract the inconvenience caused by the steady procession of robot bombs.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 1 -- The monetary and financial conference which opened here today midst the White Mountains is generally regarded by the American delegation as the first round in the battle to win the peace. To many of its members this, the economic side of the peace, is a more important stone in the foundation of future world security than forthcoming political agreements.

NOW and again this department likes to put in a word for a good book, not sufficiently well known to be in one of the reprint libraries, and which has been lost sight of in the long procession of books that have followed it.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1 (AP) -- Following an announcement today by the New York Stock Exchange and the New York Curb Exchange of their suspensions of trading in Finnish securities, pursuant to the action of the Department of State, the Securities and Exchange Commission made public today the text of a letter sent yesterday to the two Exchanges and to the National Association of Security Dealers, Inc.

CHERBOURG, July 1 -- Cherbourg's restoration to normal life is being accomplished with the aid of American and British personnel. It is only aid, however. The Americans and British are not running the city's affairs.

LONDON, July 1 -- Damage caused by the war in Europe is not confined to bombed buildings and homeless populations. Dr. Goebbels and his editors and writers have had an open field since 1940 and for a long time after the war we shall have to reckon with the distrust and suspicion sown among the European peoples by the German propaganda offensive.

Roderick Stephens, who is opposing the Republican organization designee for Congress in the new Twenty-fifth District of the Bronx, disclosed last night that detailed specifications will be filed tomorrow with the Board of Elections covering general objections to his opponent's nominating petitions.

Salvatore Badalamente, 27-year-old machinist, was arrested early yesterday morning charged with grand larceny after, the police say, he admitted the theft of a truck containing 2,500 women's dresses valued at $10,000.

RICHMIOND, July 1 -- The boom for Senator Harry F. Byrd of Virginia for the Republican Vice Presidential nomination, started informally by certain Republican Congressmen last week, came to nothing, but it stirred a lot of talk hereabout.
MOSCOW, July 1 -- The United States break with Finland was welcomed in the army newspaper Red Star today as proof of Allied solidarity on the Finnish question.

VENTNOR CITY, N.J., July 1 -- With Mayor Harry S. Hodson of Ventnor City and George Sturgis of Boston, president of the United States Chess Federation, welcoming the players, the sixth annual invitation chess masters tournament started on the municipal pier this afternoon.

Gen. J.S. Simmons states that bacillary dysentery is "one of the most formidable hazards to be encountered by American troops, ranking second only to malaria in certain tropical theatres." The Army reports about seven cases per 1,000 men in continental United States for 1942.

"Ninety-nine Park," headquarters of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, Inc.,* offers a partial list of free amusements available today, through the generosity of the entertainment world. Afternoon tickets from 11 A.M.; evening tickets after 4 P.M. Apply 99 Park Avenue (at Fortieth Street) for tickets.

WITH but little hope for a solution of the dispute between Mr. Petrillo's Musicians Union and the major recording companies, the future for new records -- and especially for serious music albums -- appears none too bright at the moment.

ON one of the Foggia airfields in Italy a formation of Flying Fortresses was sweeping in for a landing. They were back from an engagement they had kept with certain German railroad marshaling yards up north of the Brenner Pass. One of the planes signaled that it had wounded men aboard.

Buyer attendance at the New York Furniture Market last week was as large as at the January event, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the McGreevey, Werring Howell Company. Stores could purchase only their usual allocations and these fell far below their actual needs in both case goods and upholstered furniture.

At a Nazi party rally in Munich in November, 1939, Adolf Hitler said: "On the day the British declared war I commanded Goering to make all preparations for a five-year war, not because I believe this war will last five years but because we will never capitulate in five years."

China enters its eighth year of war this week. Friday will be the Day of the Double Seventh (seventh day of the seventh month), anniversary of the clash between Chinese and Japanese troops at the Marco Polo Bridge near Peiping that marked the start of "the China incident" in 1937.

Spurred by recollections of the tidal wave of cancellations of orders for many millions of dollars of merchandise which followed the last war, a move aimed at uniform order contracts and confirmations, and designed to minimize difficulties which may be encountered when hostilities cease, is now under way, it was learned here at the week-end.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 1 -- The Copenhagen revolt against the Germans is increasing and the general strike has spread to the provinces. Fifteen thousand Danish underground men equipped with machine guns, automatic rifles and revolvers are reported to have launched an attack against the Germans, after establishing that the Nazis had only 3,000 troops in the city.

WHEN -- many years hence, one hopes -- George Hogg goes to meet his ancestors he can ask for no better epitaph than this: Through his being and working, many blades of grass will grow in places where none grew before."

HARLAN, Ky., July 1 (U.P.) -- Rescue crews this afternoon brought eighteen miners, shaken but alive, to the surface from a shaft of the Ridgeway Darby Coal Company, fifteen miles east of Harlan, after they had been trapped for nearly seventeen hours by fire.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Probably no other Presidential candidate in the history of the office ever opened a campaign the success of which was more dependent on things unseen and unpredictable than did Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York when he accepted the Republican nomination Wednesday night in the sweltering Stadium in Chicago.

As New Yorkers continued to desert the city for vacation spots over the Fourth of July, throngs in railroad and bus depots were increased yesterday by the peak influx of service men and women on week-end furloughs. Packed trains and buses to New Jersey shore and near-by resorts in other States shattered previous holiday records.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 1 -- With delegates from forty-four countries participating, the United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference opened here this afternoon on a solemn but hopeful keynote struck in a message from President Roosevelt.

ONE of September's arrivals will be the John C. Wilson-Nat Goldstone "Bloomer Girl," either at the Shubert or Broadhurst. Such being the law of things on Broadway, the musical figures to cost about $150,000 with costumes making the heaviest dent in the bankroll.
PITTSBURGH, July 1 (AP) -- The Pirates put together eight hits today to hand the Braves a 5-1 beating behind the six-hit pitching of Ray Starr.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- Expression, a trim 2-year-old eastern filly sired by the 29-year-old The Porter, raced to her first stake victory today in winning the $38,000 Arlington Park Lassie Stakes by the margin of a head over the Calumet Farm's Twosy.
MEXICO CITY, July 1 -- Francisco Iavier Gaxiola, Secretary of the National Economy was succeeded today by Gustavo P. Serrano, former President of the Mexican Mining Chamber.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 1 -- The long and rolling North Hempstead Country Club layout, with its sloping fairways and elevated greens, proved quite a problem to most of the teams in the fifth annual member-guest best-ball golf competition today as thirty-three combinations teed off in the qualifying round.

LONG BEACH, L.I., July 1 -- Edward J. Agnew, former police chief here, died today during an argument with two sailors of the Lido Receiving Station in front of his garage at Long Beach Road and Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Military observers in the capital, while frankly admitting the seriousness of the situation in southeast China, where the Japanese invaders are progressing rapidly in their apparent drive to split that long-suffering country in two, now are calling attention to the few brighter spots in the discouraging picture.

WITH AMERICAN TROOPS on Cap de la Hague, 11:10 P.M., July 1 -- The last organized German units northwest of Cherbourg laid down their arms early tonight before the pressing bayonets of American troops who completed mopping up the peninsula by bagging 5,000 prisoners in the last forty-eight hours.

IT seems more surprising than it actually is that education, especially college education, should be so much in the public imagination at the present time when college education is almost at a standstill. For even in these critical days the debates continue and the country is studded with conferences on the future of liberal education.

IT takes some looking to find them, because they are being carried only on local stations; but when you do run across the Arch Oboler-William N. Robson quartet of half-hour dramas, collectively known as "Four for the Fifth," you are likely to find that your search was worth the trouble.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- The British Embassy and United States officials are understood to be seeking means to solve a problem in British visa regulations which has caused costly delays in travel to the United Kingdom by persons officially certified as vital to the war effort.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1 -- The Rotary Electric Steel Company of Detroit registered today with the Securities and Exchange Commission 150,000 shares of $10 par value common stock. Under an agreement executed on June 26 the stock was to be sold today to underwriters including W.E. Hutton Co., Hemphill, Noyes Co., E.H. Rollins Sons, Inc., and Stein Bros. Boyce for $11.37 1/2 a share.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The War Food Administration is rounding out arrangements for leasing of a seventy-five-year-old limestone mine of 12,000,000 cubic feet near Atchison, Kan., and plans to store there government-held lard, eggs and other perishables in an unprecedented project which promises to have significant effects on the nation's food and agricultural programs, it was learned today.

Retail trade was again active here last week, with seasonal and vacation merchandise in strong consumer demand. Gains over a year ago were not as marked as in the preceding week but were estimated as running around 15 per cent for department stores.

LONDON, July 1 -- A severe blow to Germany's military and economic fronts has been dealt by the mining of the Danube River where it flows through Bulgaria, Rumania and Hungary, carrying supplies to the Eastern Front and bringing vital materials back to the Reich from satellite countries.
SOME of the boys in one of my classes thought you were spoofing with your "foxhole receiver" last Sunday, though any old radio nut can see that it ought to work if the signal is strong enough.

BOSTON, July 1 -- Despite all efforts to show that delight was as strong as harmony among Republican leaders in the nomination of Governor Dewey as a Presidential candidate, delegates returning here from Chicago wrinkled their brows over what they said would be the gigantic task of selling the New Yorker to New England.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 1 -- More than 200 officers and 2,300 enlisted men of the New York Guard now undergoing a twelve-day training period at Camp Smith here are taxing the training field facilities and housing capacities of the reservation with the quartering of a brigade command, three full regiments and a truck company.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 1 -- In an address today at the third commencement of Vassar College in the academic year, President Henry Noble MacCracken made a plea for the education of the whole human personality, declaring that current emphasis on man as a psychological being was as misleading as emphasis in former years on man as a political or an economic being.

SHE was born shiny new on an assembly line in Toledo, just like 250,000 others. Like the others, too, she was a queer-shaped, quarter-ton pygmy truck 11 feet long and 5 feet wide and a little more than 3 feet high. She was just another jeep then.

LONDON (By Wireless). THE Third Reich, once the most powerful and highly organized military state in the world, faces its ultimate test in battle during the next eight weeks still comparatively strong in manpower and material and with higher morale than might have been expected a year ago. With simultaneous offensives on the French, Italian and Russian fronts, the war has entered its decisive phase.

For the first time in eighty years a national political convention is not the whole show. The Republican Convention last week was not and the Democratic Convention week after next will not be. In the old exuberant sense the conventions cannot be a show at all. An innate sense of decency, which is American and not partisan, keeps down the parades.

Retail trade was again active last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey made for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Main floors were very busy, particularly hosiery, notion and beach accessory departments.

ONE of the world's notable collections of drawings is that at Windsor Castle. To Leo Van Puyvelde, formerly director of the Royal Museums of Fine Arts in Brussels, has fallen the delightful task of compiling catalogues of this collection.

A boy's unwillingness to return to the New York State Training School at Warwick, where he had been committed for a robbery last year, resulted in his narrow escape from death early yesterday when he fell down a dumbwaiter shaft in a tenement at 279 St. Ann's Avenue, the Bronx.

ST. LOUIS, July 1 -- Tonight's madness under the mazdas at Sportsman's Park won't be forgotten soon by any of the 17,023 St. Louis fans who saw the league-leading Cardinals beat the Dodgers, 8 -- 3, to run the Durocher crew's losing streak to four games.

ALBANY, July 1 -- Thomas E. Dewey returned today to the capital of the State of which he is Governor and from the steps of the limestone and granite structure which houses the State Government hailed the American election system as the greatest in the world.

WHO'S got the button -- the one that is said to have been worn by Louis XIV? Jake Slezak had it, but he is dead, and the button is missing. Perhaps some other button collector (there are many of them in this book) killed him to obtain possession of this rare item.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that special arrangements, effective on July 7, suspending certain formalities governing crossings of the International Border would permit Canadian threshing personnel and equipment crews from this country to help harvest the Western Great Plains grain crops and later to help harvest the grain in the Dominion's Prairie Provinces.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Transportation officials, in and out of government, viewed their situation with new alarm this week as graphs showed both passenger and freight traffic climbing, not according to plan, but far ahead of it.

WE come now to our annual round-up of books dealing with art; books that have reached my desk since July of last year. Due to war conditions, and especially with paper shortage what it has become, the pile at hand isn't quite as imposing as usual.

TOMORROW will see the opening of the summer season at Jacob's Pillow, near Lee, Mass., when the "University of the Dance" will get under way under the direction of Ted Shawn. The first of the weekly performances will take place on Saturday afternoon when the artists participating will be Arthur Mahoney, Thalia Mara, Grant Mouradoff, Tatiana Semenova and Mr. Shawn.

CINCINNATI, July 1 -- Frank Seward played no favorites today. The 22-year-old Giant hurler, with two years of organized baseball experience, was out on Crosley Field's pitching hill, and the result was a holiday for Bill McKechnie's hitters.

MOSCOW, July 1 -- The Union of Polish Patriots in the Soviet Union through its central board of administration has declared its conviction that the National Council of Poland provides the basis for a provisional national government capable of rallying Poles within and beyond the frontiers for the struggle against Germany.

PROFESSOR SHOTWELL long has been a leader in the American peace movement. He was a member of the House Commission in World War I. Later, as director of the Division of Economics and History of the Carnegie Endowment, he not only carried on researches into the first war, but made acquaintance with the scholars and statesmen of many countries; he was active in promoting the anti-war pact of 1928.

FUTURE historians will doubtless place the turning point of this war within the calendar year 1942 -- the year of Stalingrad, of El Alamein, of Midway and Guadalcanal. Yet they will surely mark 1943 as the year in which the tide of history began to flow powerfully once more in favor of the democratic way of ordering men's affairs.

More than fifty picked doctors, dentist, teachers, scientists from Latin American countries will arrive at the University of Michigan this week to start learning to speak English as we Americans talk it. Two months later, due to new and intensive methods of teaching developed by the English Language Institute, these men and women will be ready to attend university classes, to travel, get along on their own.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1 (AP) -- The Tigers hammered Lum Harris for five runs in five innings and added four off Joe Berry, relief pitcher, for a 9-4 victory in their series opener with the Athletics today.

DETROIT, July 1 -- Jockeys Mike Caffarella and Johnny Adams rode all eight winners today at the Detroit track, Caffarella booting home five to equal the Detroit record. Making up for quantity, Adams guided Abe Hirschberg's Black Badge to a popular triumph in the $10,000 Sport of Kings Handicap.

Delegates representing forty-four nations assembled yesterday at Bretton Woods, N.H., for an eighteen-day conference on one of the most complicated problems of the peace. Their purpose was to assure all nations sufficient foreign exchange to carry on international trade.

NOW that the armies of the United Nations have begun their crusade to liberate a continent, they may truly claim to represent Europe. In their ranks one finds, besides the British, many other Europeans, Frenchmen and Dutch, Norwegians and Czechs.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 1 -- The parents of 8-month-old Hugh Teal Jr. won a victory over their landlord yesterday in a court decision that the infant was not a nuisance and that his birth was not a violation of OPA regulations.

Just the outline of a sketch of an idea: How would it be to (1) give the drama critics a chance at a more constructive job in the theatre; (2) save some theatrical money and reputations, and (3) raise the average worth of the plays that reach production?
ITHACA, N.Y., July 1 -- Appointment of Robert J. Kane as Cornell University athletic director was announced today. He succeeds James Lynah, resigned.

ABOARD JOINT EXPEDITIONARY FORCE FLAGSHIP, Off Saipan, July 1 -- The hardest battle of the Pacific war moved toward its climax today as American invaders of Saipan drove ahead in tropical heat to a new line of ridges above the enemy city of Garapan.

STANTON, Del., July 1 (AP) -- The Brandywine Stable's 3-year-old filly, Everget, never out of the money in her twenty-six starts, won the seventh running of the New Castle Handicap, mile and a sixteenth race for fillies and mares, which featured the final Saturday of racing at Delaware Park today.

SWITZERLAND -- Berne -- The short wave transmitters of this neutral land adopted a revised schedule last week, broadcasting on a new band, 9.185 megacycles, in addition to their older frequencies of 9.539 and 6.165.

FRED ALLEN, unlike most writers, is a comedian. But unlike most comedians -- and human beings -- Fred Allen has never owned an automobile, a house or a boat. These possessions, common to most, have never infringed on Fred's life. "They make me nervous" is Fred's clarifying comment.

Injunctions obtained against retailers by the Office of Price Administration for alleged violations of the highest price line limitation of MPR 330, 177 and 178 have become ineffective legally with the signing by President Roosevelt of the new price control bill entitled "Stabilization Extension Act of 1944," according to Maxwell C. Katz of Katz Sommerich, attorneys for the W.T. Grant Company.

AS rule, the film producers don't watch the calendar in order to flash their productions at particular seasons of the year. They may finish a drama for August and an ice-show for Christmas-time. A "hot-weather show" in the movies is seldom a mentioned thing.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (UP) -- The State Department tonight followed up the United States break in relations with Finland by adding the names of sixty-nine Finnish business concerns and individuals to its economic blacklist.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1 -- Big Bill Tilden, still lean and bronzed but a little grayer at 51, demonstrated his old-time wizardry on the tennis courts today, stealing the show as usual as 3,000 fans bought $4,000,000 worth of War Bonds to see a four-star court exhibition at the Merion Cricket Club.

A new transatlantic record was set yesterday when Capt. Charles A. Thompson brought an American Export Lines' Flying Ace into the marine terminal at La Guardia Field after eighteen hours and sixteen minutes' flying time from Foynes, Eire.

A new international currency system may develop from a common acceptance among nations of the need to maintain a high level of employment and economic stability, according to a League of Nations report soon to be published by the Columbia University Press, it was announced yesterday by the International Documents Service of the Press.
CHUNGKING, China, July 1 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

PEARL HARBOR (By Telephone). STEP by step -- huge steps for the distances are gargantuan -- we are retracing the Pacific road along which we fled two years ago. We are now in the Marianas, 3,600 statute miles from Pearl Harbor. What is taking us along the road back is the kind of warfare which we have learned by costly trial and error, by experiment and adjustment, by bloody experience.

Five new stores affiliated with the Eastern Cooperative Wholesale, Inc., were opened yesterday, indicating further growth of the cooperative movement in the United States, L.E. Woodcock, manager of the company announced at the week-end.

Since Pearl Harbor the Todd Shipyards Corporation has build repaired or converted ocean-going merchant tonnage that totals more than three times the total pre-war tonnage of the American Merchant Marine, according to a statement by John D. Reilly, president of the corporation, in his annual report.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., July 1 -- Nearly 2,000,000 men and women in this State are engaged directly or wholly in war work to mark an "all-time high peak for industry in New York," M.P. Catherwood, Commissioner of the State Department of Commerce, reported today at the closing business session of the fortieth annual meeting of the State Association of Real Estate Boards.

LONDON, Sunday, July 2 -- Two powerful prongs of the Red Army further imperiled the fortress position of Minsk yesterday by pushing within twenty-five and thirty-two miles, respectively, of the all-important Warsaw-Minsk and Vilna-Minsk railroads, which supply the Nazi-held White Russian capital.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- Treasury experts see less room than a lot of other people see for downward revision of Federal taxes after the war.

Beginning this fall Knox College will put into operation a new program of integrated higher education, designed to meet the needs of students in the post-war period. It is intended to give both unity and organization to the student's education "so that as a reasoning, resourceful and responsible citizen he may deal with the ever-increasing complexities of life."
BOSTON, July 1 (AP) -- Col. C.V. Whitney's Flyweight, choice in the field of thirteen starters, scored a three and a half length victory at Suffolk Downs today in the $10,000 added Betsy Ross Stakes.

NEW ORLEANS, July 1 -- Apparently abandoning hope of blocking the nomination by the Democrats of President Roosevelt in Chicago and of obtaining platform pledges meeting with their approval, anti-New Dealers in Louisiana and several other Southern States are planning a meeting in New Orleans or some other Southern city to map a course of action.
LONDON, July 1 -- The fall of Cherbourg last week was a great strategical victory for the Allies, perhaps the greatest of the war, but it marked only the beginning of the French campaign.
ROME, July 1 (AP) -- The German lines fell back tonight all along the 165-mile Italian front under blows of the Fifth and Eighth Armies marching on the prize cities of Leghorn, Florence and Ancona.

BETTY SMITH, whose first novel, "A Tree Grows in Brooklyn," is still high on bestseller lists almost a year after its publication, is hard at work on another novel -- also about Brooklyn. . . . The third and final volume of Douglas Southall Freeman's "Lee's Lieutenants," covering the period between Gettysburg and Appomattox, will appear this fall.

ROME, July 1 -- Lieut. Gen. Sir Frank N. Mason-MacFarlane's sudden return to London, which became known here today, is being interpreted in Italian circles as punishment for his having failed to get Marshal Pietro Badoglio into the new Rome government.

AT the age of 10 Arthur age Loveridge, curator of reptiles and amphibians at Harvard's Museum of Comparative Zoology, had already decided to adopt his present calling. In keeping with his determination, he festooned his little sister with snakes.

Industry-wide advertising campaigns, sponsored by associations and aimed at overcoming consumer sales resistance developed as a result of "too much dream product expectancy," were urged yesterday by Lawrence Valenstein, president of Grey Advertising Agency.

LONDON, July 1 -- Since D-Day hundreds of ships heavily laden with troops and equipment have steamed unharmed through the world's most heavily mined waters to deliver their cargoes to France. Many factors contributed to make this feat possible, but among the foremost, and probably the least heralded, are the men on the mine- sweepers, whose job is highly dangerous and completely unromantic.

The New York City Veterans Service Center, established two months ago as a clearing house for discharged service men seeking information about the various agencies whose facilities are available to them, already has aided more than 7,500 veterans, Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the War Manpower Commission, reported yesterday.

FARRAGUT, Idaho, July 1 -- Thomas W. Russell, boatswain's mate, first class, of Bridgeboro, Ga., told today how a skipper of a destroyer saved his blazing ship by giving it a bath in the wake of the aircraft carrier Enterprise.

AN unusual experiment in programming is scheduled to be tried this week by the Blue network. Phillips Carlin, vice president in charge of programs, has long held the theory that a worth-while offering might be repeated profitably.

Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell signed yesterday an order requiring the Interstate Color Company, 5 Beekman Street, and its president, Samuel H. Ebert, to show cause why they should not be enjoined from shipping in interstate commerce two coal tar coloring agents manufactured.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Independent retailers' sales were up 10 per cent in May as against May, 1943, and 7 per cent over the April mark, according to an announcement released today by the Census Bureau. Year-to-date sales ran 6 per cent ahead of those for the corresponding five-month period of 1943.

Four Freedoms yesterday entered the "golden circle," restricted to winners of $100,000, when he annexed the fifty-sixth running of the $50,000 added Brooklyn Handicap, featured event of the Queens County Jockey Club's closing day at Aqueduct.

LONDON, July 1 -- Sir Samuel Hoare, who has been British Ambassador to Spain since May, 1940, has received a peerage. From 10 Downing Street tonight came the announcement that King George VI had made the man for whose scalp Liberals and Leftists have been hunting as an old appeaser a peer of the realm.

Returning from a three-week business trip that took him as far south as Mexico City, James A. Farley, who resigned recently as Democratic State Chairman, declined yesterday to comment on political developments, including the nomination of Governor Dewey as Republican Presidential candidate, witnessed by Mrs. Farley from a special convention box.

MANCHESTER, Vt., July 1 -- One hundred and four players participated in the qualifying round of the Robert Todd Lincoln Cup golf tournament for the benefit of War Relief, Inc., at the Ekwanok Country Club today.

CHUNGKING, China, July 1 (AP) -- American Liberators from China joining in Admiral Chester W. Nimitz's central Pacific campaign, have smashed at the docks and harbor of Takao, important Japanese shipping center on the southwestern point of Formosa, it was announced today.

American steel companies, concerned over the Congressional movement led by Senator Patrick J. McCarran, Democrat, of Nevada, to decentralize industry, are collecting data which they will utilize at the proper time in support of the economic and historical reasons for the concentration of iron and steel facilities in a few well defined areas.

HOLLYWOOD, July 1 (U.P.) -- Counsel for Count Kurt Haugwitz-Reventlow said today that the Danish nobleman had taken his son, Lance, 9 years old, to Canada to forestall a reported plan of his former wife, who was Barbara Hutton and is now Mrs. Cary Grant, to take the boy to Spain. Joseph L. Lewinson revealed that the Count had arrived with the boy in Vancouver, B.C.
Along about 4:15 by the Stadium clock yesterday afternoon all was sunny and serene so far as either the Yankees or a crowd of 11,620 onlookers could make out.

While the success of the Fifth War Loan Drive was virtually assured yesterday as national purchases reached $13,728,000,000, or 86 per cent of the $16,000,000,000 goal, concern was expressed over the possibility of meeting E bond and other individual investors' quotas before the close of the current campaign on Saturday.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 1 -- Even a West Coast up to its neck in war-material and foodstuffs production, a section alert to war's demands if any part of the country is, sighed with relief for a few days this week to find something besides war usurping newspaper headlines and radio comments.
BOSTON, July 1 (AP) -- The Browns collected ten walks off three Boston pitchers today as they gained an easy 9-to-1 victory behind the five-hit pitching of Nelson Potter, a Red Sox castoff.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- Dutch Leonard limited Cleveland to five hits tonight as the Senators collected twelve safeties to beat the Indians, 4 to 2, before 11,749.

FLINT, Mich., July 1 -- The Buick Division of General Motors Corporation has produced its 50,000th Liberator Bomber engine, bringing the total aircraft horsepower manufactured by this automobile firm in the first thirty months of war to more than 60,000,000.

A UNITED STATES ARMY HOSPITAL in Southern England, July 1 -- A young Virginian from the Twenty-ninth Division wounded in action in France on June 22 and now recovering in this hospital is a good case example of the kind of medical service American boys are getting.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Urgent action to remedy the condition of roads in many city areas all over the country was recommended today in a report of the American Automobile Association addressed to all Government agencies concerned with transportation problems.

Shortly before the end of the Office of Price Administration's meat-rationing holiday last night. Walter F. Straub, retiring deputy administrator in charge of food rationing in Washington, explained that OPA planned no upward readjustment of the consumers' allotment of red points this month.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 1 -- Military courts which have tried many hundreds of civilians in Hawaii since the start of the war were denounced before the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals here today as tribunals which were made up of men who "never had been in a law court," gave "nobody" a fair trial and punished lawyers who tried to object to their procedure.

THIS war has been unique in military history in the number, magnitude and importance of its amphibious operations. This phase reached its climax, but not its conclusion, with the tremendous invasion of western Europe.

THIS is Clyde Brion Davis' eighth book, his sixth adult novel. As those who have followed his work might expect, it is quite different from any of the others. He doesn't repeat himself. He doesn't need to.

DESPITE heat, war and political conventions the New York galleries last week maintained a semblance of activity as June came to a close. The Midtown's show includes both new and familiar paintings, including, among others, portraits by Binford and Laning, William Thon's new and timely "Convoy," Sepeshy's novel figure composition, "Driftwood," and a recent ballet canvas by Gladys Davis.
DENVER, July 1 (U.P.) -- A report adopted tonight at the closing session of the quarterly meeting of the Interstate Oil Compact Commission opposed further acquisition of land by the Government.

The cotton trade was still awaiting yesterday news from Washington which would clarify numerous points in the new Price-Control Act as they may affect cotton prices. When these points are settled, the trade will resume its study of weather and crop reports as market factors. Yesterday these reports continued to be favorable but the market on the New York Cotton Exchange was inactive.

A LETTER of exceptional interest and importance because of the possibilities it outlines to music in New York City has been received by THE TIMES. Our correspondent is Electus Litchfield, the distinguished architect and public servant, and for long the influential president of the Municipal Art Society of this city.

NEW faces are seldom seen at the big estate at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue in this city, but two residents -- evidently permanent -- who moved in recently have caused quite a stir among the "lower levels" of White House personnel.
I am rarely impressed with the War Bond appeals of even the most prominent speakers. To me they appear to be too lush, too glib, too theatrical.

The Republican party last week met in national convention in Chicago, scene of twelve of the party's twenty-three national conventions, the place where in 1860 the Republicans nominated their first President and Vice President -- Abraham Lincoln and Hannibal Hamlin.

BARI, Italy, June 30 (Delayed) (AP) -- The Albanian collaborationist Government, headed by Rexhep Mitrovic, has fallen, it was reliably reported here today, and Parliament has just concluded an extraordinary two-day session after the resignation of the Rev. Anton Harapi, one of four members of the Regency Council.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., July 2 (AP) -- Norman H. Davis, veteran diplomat and national chairman of the American Red Cross, died early this morning. He was 66 years of age.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, ON NEW GUINEA, Sunday, July 2 (UP) -- Communique

PACIFIC FLEET HEADQUARTERS, Pearl Harbor, July 1 -- Our hard-won positions on Saipan's upper heights are being consolidated and a few pockets of resistance that were by-passed in earlier advances have been wiped out, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz stated in his communique this morning.

DURING the months January through June the world's stamp-printing presses apparently were less active than during any previous calendar six-month period in recent times. Reports up to the close of Friday showed only 429 varieties released in 1944 for chronicling in future editions of the Standard Postage Stamp Catalogue, whereas for many years the total for each half- year, January through June, has exceeded 800.

This war will not produce the same degree of facial disfigurement as the first World War. One great reason is that so much more is known today about anesthesia than was known twenty-five years ago. Four hours now can be spent on a simple operation, something too hazardous a quarter of a century ago.

CHUNGKING, China, July 1 -- The Japanese have launched their long-expected general offensive northward from the Canton area, the Chinese High Command announced tonight, with the enemy making an effort to join with forces driving down the Canton-Hankow railway through battered Hunan Province which, if successful, would be a disaster for the Chinese.

IN a neat and well-produced compendium of questions and answers Mr. (Gallup tells the public how their pulse is taken by the diagnosticians. You may be curious to learn, for example, why you have never been interviewed, why you have never met anyone who has been interviewed, what actually happens at an interview, what makes a representative sample for polling purposes, what the chances are of the forecasts going wrong, and so forth.

LONDON, July 1 -- Now that we have hurdled the Atlantic Wall and again set foot in France the problem of the relief of Europe, long planned and debated by the United Nations, has ceased to be academic and promises to become urgent. That it is not immediately pressing is due to the fact that the province in which we have set foot, Normandy, has long been the feedbag of France.

WHEN a magazine short-story writer kneels each night beside his bed his first prayer is, of course, for the health and happiness of those editors who like his stuff. His second, the money-ball, is for a character.

CHUNGKING, China, Sunday, July 2 (U.P.) -- The Fourteenth United States Army Air Force, charged with the defense of an area as large as Texas, has destroyed 464 enemy aircraft and has sunk 414,939 tons of Japanese shipping since July 4, 1942, Brig. Gen. Claire L. Chennault's headquarters announced today.

THE Hollywood and Mexico City motion picture industries, involved in an international incident all their own over the use of Mexican actors for Spanish-language-dubbed (voice synchronization) pictures, settled their differences last week and arrived at an understanding which, it is believed, will govern future across-the-border dubbing procedure.

The American Astronomical Society was presented last week with computations by Dr. Dean B. McLaughlin (Michigan) to show what would happen if the sun became a "nova." Any star may become a "nova" merely by exploding. Dr. McLaughlin's study allows the sun to shine with an increase in brightness of about 100,000 times for ten days.

LONDON, July 1 (U.P.) -- A French communique tonight announced that French Forces of the Interior had captured a number of German mountain troops and a customs agent along the Franco-Swiss border and would execute them in reprisal if the Germans kill FFI prisoners.

LONDON, July 1 -- Unsettling as it may be to American and British military pride, it is now evident that the Red Army has begun an offensive of terrific power and extraordinary speed which in numbers of men involved and effect on the Wehrmacht surpasses anything yet done by the western powers in Italy and France.

PARTY platforms invariably receive an undue amount of discussion before and during the conventions; interest in them continues keen until election day; after that they too frequently become merely historical documents.

PERENNIALS have their limitations as to longevity, contrary to what is implied in their classification. Though many of them live for years, the time comes when some kinds are past a top-notch showing, and should be removed.

LONDON, July 1 -- Long-silent Adolf Hitler, speaking at the funeral of Col. Gen. Eduard Dietl, Nazi commander in Finland who was killed in a plane crash, said "in this fifth year of the war we often find ourselves confronted with difficult situations," but expressed belief "national fanaticism" would bring victory.

I read with considerable interest the article in last Sunday's TIMES about film theatre admissions. It interested me particularly as a theatre operator and as president of the Independent Theatre Owners Association, Inc. But the article did not, in my opinion, present the full picture of the situation.

Very critical events for the future of the world are now imminent, and sooner or later the war must end. God grant that it may be sooner than we all really dare to hope, but also that this time it may be once and for all.

CHICAGO, July 1 (AP) -- Dick Barrett, right-hander cast off by the Cubs last summer, smothered them with two hits today as the Phillies ended the Chicagoans' four-game winning streak, 4 to 2. The defeat kept the Cubs from climbing out of the cellar, which has been their abode since the second day of the season.

The Women's Reserve of the United States Naval Reserve is serving as the "perfect proving ground for the practical advantages of a liberal arts education for women," in the opinion of Lieut. Comdr. Margaret C. Disert, USNR, dean-on-leave of Wilson College and officer in charge of midshipmen at the Naval Reserve Midshipmen's School, Northampton, Mass. College women trained in the liberal arts, she said, have learned to view specific courses against a general background.

Two projects in public relations for Higher education have been planned for this month, the first of their kind undertaken. The first will be a Short Course in Public Relations for Colleges at Scarritt College for Christian Workers, Nashville, Tenn., July 10-11, and the second a Seminar in Public Relations for Higher Education at Syracuse University, July 18-20.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- The War Department, declaring that its monthly goals of war material deliveries are not being met, said tonight that it had urged the War Production Board not to permit relaxation in production controls and to exert "even more vigorous efforts" to increase manufacture of weapons.

The ebb of Finland's military fortunes last week was accompanied by two moves, one by Berlin, the other by Washington. Fearing Finnish capitulation to Russia, Nazis staged a diplomatic coup. Allegedly answering a Finnish call for help, Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop flew to Helsinki to confer with President Risto Ryti.

FARGO, N.D., July 1 (AP) -- Attorney General Alvin C. Strutz ruled in Bismarck today that any soldiers' ballots reaching the State Canvassing Board through regular channels before July 27 can be counted in determining the result of Tuesday's primary election.

EVANSTON, Ill., July 1 (AP) -- Francisco (Pancho) Segura, representing the University of Miami, today defeated Notre Dame's Charley Samson in straight sets for his second straight N.C.A.A. tennis singles title.

Those critics who looked with such doubt at the skies after Pearl Harbor can take comfort from the picture of airpower today as revealed in the authoritative Aircraft Year Book. The United States has today no fewer than five fighter planes capable of better than 400 miles an hour, while England has but three, Germany two and Japan none.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, July 1 -- The Argentine Government has accepted the challenge represented by the United States State Department's publication of the lecture delivered on June 10 by the Minister of War, Col. Juan Domingo Peron, at the University of La Plata and has replied to it by trying to arouse a wave of anti-United States sentiment among the Argentines.

Because of the complex situation in Palestine, the Jews must be prepared with a plan for governing that country when and if it becomes a Jewish state or commonwealth, according to a report of the policy committee of the Jewish Reconstructionist Foundation, Inc., given last night at a meeting of the foundation at 15 West Eighty-sixth Street.

Plans for a conference of business leaders from the allied and neutral nations, to be held in Atlantic City, on Nov. 10-18, were announced yesterday by four of the leading business organizations of this country.

The addition of any reservation charge to hotel bills presented to guests constitutes "a raise in rent and will be considered illegal if the total is larger than the maximum scheduled room rent of that hotel," it was announced yesterday by Daniel P. Woolley, Regional Administrator of the Office of Price Administration.

The resounding crash of the "Fatherland Line" falling to ruin on a 250-mile front in White Russia writes the last chapter to a myth on which Germany has lived for a year. This was her desperate belief in the security of fortified lines. Now that the Atlantic Wall and the Eastern Wall have been breached almost simultaneously this faith can hardly survive.

ONE miserable day in March of 1866 a Yankee lad from Revere, Mass., complete with flowered carpetbag and a Harvard accent, arrived at the Battery in New York City. He had little cash and no knowledge at all of the business of producing commercial literature, but a few days later the editor of Student Schoolmate, a goody-goody periodical for boys, received a manuscript that sat him up in his chair.

THE leap from Joe Bascom, slippery American numbers racketeer of "Mexican Hayride," to "Richard III" may be unprecedented, but Bobby Clark is the man who can do it. Take Mr. Clark's word for it. Possessor of eight editions of the Bard, Mr. Clark has thumbed those tomes to a fare thee well.

OTTAWA, July 1 -- Indications continue to multiply that Canada may have a wartime general election about the same time that the United States goes to the polls. In ordinary constitutional practice, an election would have to be held next summer, and Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King has already declared that he will not seek to extend the life of the present Parliament.

THE British poet, scholar, novelist and devotional writer, Evelyn Underhill (1875-1941), is best known as an authority on mysticism. It was her conviction that life "attains reality [only] in so far as it is consciously lived in the Presence of God."

SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, July 1 (UP) -- Allied jungle troops have accelerated mopping-up operations in northern Burma and Manipur State, a communique said today, killing 352 Japanese soldiers, capturing 200 and seizing two more of the enemy's powerful 150 mm. anti-tank cannon.

Soon after war was declared on the Axis powers 45,000 enemy patents were seized, whereupon the Alien Property Custodian made arrangements for the granting of non-exclusive licenses to make the most of them.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- Little Ben Hogan, burned up because someone said men in the service probably would have a hard time becoming tournaments threats after the war, let some of the heat sink into his game today as he coupled a 66 with a first-round 68 for a 36-hole total of 134 -- eight strokes under par -- to take the halfway lead in the Chicago Victory National golf meet.

Broadway matinee crowds scattered and ducked yesterday when Detective Peter Rodriguez fired six shots before recapturing an alleged thief who had broker away from him at the doors of the West Fifty-fourth Street police station.

The 466-acre estate, Sherwood Hall, at Warwick, N.Y., has been purchased by R.H. Macy Co., Inc., as the site of a new vacation resort for its employes and those of affiliated stores in Newark, N.J.; Atlanta, Ga., and Toledo, Ohio, it was announced yesterday.

JULIA WARD HOWE will probably be remembered by most readers, rather vaguely, as a nice little old lady who dashed off "The Battle Hymn of the Republic." So she did, but in "The Sounding Trumpet," by Louise Hall Tharp, we discover that she was a fascinating woman of many parts, a beautiful bluestocking who loved a party even better than Greek and music.

The decision of the Navy to start drilling its petroleum reserve lands at Elk Hills, Calif., was taken so as to make more oil available for its war needs in the Pacific. Private industry in California has supplied heretofore the bulk of the oil needed for the Pacific theatre, but recently it became apparent that, with the expansion of operations there, the naval oil reserve at Elk Hills had to be tapped.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sunday, July 2 (AP) -- Two separate forces of Allied heavy bombers, one British and one American, attacked German robot bomb installations across the Channel in northern France just before dusk yesterday, beginning a new month of operations after they and other planes had flown more than 100, 000 sorties in June.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- The National Food Distributors Association has been assured by Director Chester Bowles, Office of Price Administration, no general revision of store-store-door or wagon wholesaler mark-ups is under consideration, but E.J. Martin, secretary-manager of the association, said today that he would continue to watch the situation nevertheless.

In the current issue of the Political Science Quarterly, the economist John Maurice Clark offers some extremely useful hints on "How Not to Reconvert." The political hints merit special attention at this time:
Lady Glasgow, wife of Sir Thomas William Glasgow of Australia, has arrived from Ottawa, Ont., and is at the Chatham.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 1 -- The more than 700 delegates and the secretariat at the monetary conference who arrived yesterday and this morning from sweltering Washington and New York found that warm woolen clothes served for comfort where a bathing suit was the preferred mode of dress in the cities from which they came.

So far, this has been a boom year for insect pests, and nobody has yet come along with a really satisfactory explanation. First there was a particularly heavy crop of tent caterpillars, which made lace and skeletons of the wild cherry trees, in particular. Then came the inch worms, of various kinds, which stripped the trees indiscriminately.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sunday, July 2 -- A deluge of shells from hundreds of guns and bitter resistance by the infantrymen of the British Second Army have repelled eleven German counter-attacks on the British salient southwest of Caen by the greatest armored force the enemy has gathered in Western Europe since 1940.
BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 1 -- President Roosevelt's message to the opening session of the United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference was as follows:

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Senator Samuel D. Jackson of Indiana, a candidate for Governor of that State, was chosen today to be permanent chairman of the Democratic convention which opens in Chicago July 19.

Elliott V. Bell, State Superintendent of Banks, made public yesterday the Banking Department's mid-year additions to and withdrawals from the list of securities considered eligible for savings bank investment purposes.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Senator Samuel D. Jackson of Indiana, a candidate for Governor of that State, was chosen today to be permanent chairman of the Democratic convention which opens in Chicago July 19.

We are beginning to suffer seriously from the intellectual aridity of the thirty years just past. Mr. MacLeish and a host of other men with a strong sense of responsibility have attempted to make this situation clear. Nowhere have we been caught more unprepared than in appreciating the meaning of our politics, and nowhere else, with consequences as devastating, than in working out arrangements for the national education.

DETROIT, July 1 -- Production of 5,000 Liberators in less than two years is announced by the Ford Motor Company. The Willow Run plant built half of those bombers during the first six months of this year ,in a surge which has brought the production rate to one bomber every hour.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- The Office of Price Administration issued tonight the first of the many changes in price and rent control regulations ordered by Congress in the new price control extension law. Additional changes will be announced tomorrow.
THIS is eyewitness stuff told without sentimentality and the stronger for it. In many ways it is the strongest book to come out of the Asiatic war theatre.

LONDON, July 1 -- Fifty-two tough, rough and ready Navy officers and men and the Army GI's who fought with them on the hard road to Cherbourg won't talk any more about that "Franklin Field mentality." An account of the adventures of a Navy shore party, released here today, revealed that Army-Navy football rivalries are forgotten in the Cotentin Peninsula.

RICHMOND, Calif., July 1 (AP) -- The United States can and should be willing to sell to our Allies a great many ships at price concessions which will restore a wholesome competitive balance in postwar maritime trade, Henry J. Kaiser said today in an address at the launching of the Benjamin Warner, 519th and last Liberty ship built by his No. 2 yard.

The Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company's shipyards, at Kearny and Port Newark, N.J., have been turning out a ship every five days since the attack on Pearl Harbor -- ships that have met the highest of Navy and Maritime Commission standards, it was disclosed yesterday by Lynn H. Korndorff, president of the company.
With an all-star cast including some of the most famous players in the history of tennis, the Red Cross Victory Drive exhibitions open today in the stadium of the west Side Club at Forest Hills.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Too rigid enforcement of the laws restricting operation and control of one form of public transport by another, such as a bus line by a railroad or an air line by a shipping concern, is decried in a mail referendum on policy started today among the members of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

We commented recently in this department on some work done by Drs. Michael M. Miller, B.L. Pacella and I.H. MacKinnon on the treatment of insomnia by reducing the amount of table salt consumed. The correspondence which has resulted convinces us that more information on what has been done should be presented and a word of warning uttered.

HAVING just finished staging a political convention of his own, Director Henry King says, and with conviction, he can organize a better convention than the G.O.P. affair staged last week. Not enough corn in the Chicago convention, says Director King.

NINE times out of ten a pool is built primarily for the enjoyment of waterlilies. But these lovely summer flowers like sunlight. When closely planted trees grow up and the pool becomes too shaded for successful waterlily culture it is well to remember that there are plants which love the shade and revel in spots where their roots are perpetually wet.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Mercantile and industrial establishments planning to close on July 3 and 4 were asked today by the Office of Defense Transportation to keep at work on these days a sufficiently large staff to receive incoming freight, particularly in less than carload lots.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Ceilings on sweet cherries for table use will revert, effective tomorrow, to the higher levels which prevailed before June 15, the Office of Price Administration announced today, and will remain at the higher level for the rest of the season.

AN ambitious plan to furnish musical equipment for hospital ships bringing wounded service men back from foreign battlefronts is now being put into action by the National Federation of Music Clubs, under the guidance of its president, Mrs. Guy Patterson Gannett.

Gradually the two problems of the New York Curb Exchange selecting a paid president and getting new listings -- are beginning to merge. In the last week there have been discussions among members and governors of the possibility of finding a paid president whose qualifications fit him for the job of getting new listings rather than handling internal affairs.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 1 -- Bobby Mosbacher, at the helm of his International sloop Susan; Don Laflin, in the Class S sloop Flying Colors; A.E. Monetti, in the Atlantic Hera, and Ed Waldvogel, with his handicap yawl Voyager, proved the best drifters today in the sixth special regatta on Long Island Sound.
A communique, as broadcast by the Chungking radio in English to North America and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

CHICAGO, July 1 -- Central Westerners, apparently confident that President Roosevelt will seek a fourth term, stressed one question in their discussions immediately following the nomination of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey as Presidential candidate on the Republican ticket: "Can he beat F.D.R.?"

The new regulation of the American Kennel Club imposing a recording fee of 25 cents became effective yesterday. This fee is to be collected with every entry to a dog show or field trial held under the rules of the governing body as part of a program to place the finances of the organization on a sound basis and to prevent recurring deficits.

CLEVELAND, July 1 (AP) -- Volo Song, Hambletonian winner of 1943, traveled to a straight-heat triumph in the $2,090 Matron Stake for aged trotters at North Randall today, equaling his record of 2:02 1/2 in the first mile and stepping the last half of the final round in 0:59 1/2, though his complete time for that trip was 2:07 1/2.

TWO of the great names in Brooklyn baseball history are Zach (Buck) Wheat and Nap Rucker. These old-timers were reunited last week as part of the sideshow for the War Bond game. Naturally, they began talking about the almost forgotten past and about the never-to-be-forgotten Wilbert Robinson, the beloved Uncle Robbie of hallowed memory.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 1 -- The Helen Kenyon estate, Cliffdale, one of the showplaces of Dutchess County, has been bought for temporary use as a research and engineering laboratory by the International Business Machines Corporation, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Strengthening its lumber control order which will regulate virtually all deliveries from the sawmill to the ultimate consumer, the War Production Board issued today five directions designed to assure further the delivery of supplies for the military services at the expense of the non-essential user.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 2 -- By cutting Copenhagen off from all food from the provinces and depriving the capital of water, gas and electricity, the Germans tonight forced the Danes to call off the general strike from tomorrow morning.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Twenty-five Western Senators, including Democrats and Republicans, urged President Roosevelt today to remedy a "basic, organic defect" in the Treasury Department's plan for monetary stabilization after the war by including a provision for the use of silver.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Prices on cotton textiles, amounting to about one third of the production of the country's mills were raised today by the Office of Price Administration, acting in accordance with the Bankhead Amendment to the price extension act.

ST. LOUIS, July 2 -- Those beloved bums from Brooklyn now have lost six straight games. They achieved that deplorable state by playing twenty-three innings of baseball against the leage-leading Cardinals today and scoring a total of only three runs.

Accused by the police of operating an abortion mill, Mrs. Elizabeth Mallach, 59 years old, a widow and a former licensed midwife, and her daughter, Mrs. Marie Price, 40, both of 150-45 125th Street, Ozone Park, Queens, were to be arraigned today in Queens Felony Court.

Warning that this country seems to be acquiescing in a peace of power politics and nationalistic expediency, the Rev. Dr. Arthur Lee Kinsolving, rector of Trinity Episcopal Church, of Princeton, N.J., declared yesterday in a sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine that only by holding strong to our faith and hope in God will the sacrifices of the present not have been made in vain.
The International Workers Order, a labor fraternal organization, opened last night its annual convention in Carnegie Hall with 3,000 delegates from various parts of the United States attending.

LONDON, Monday, July 3 -- British opinion, as expressed by Government spokesmen, editors and others seems to indicate that Great Britain will make no commitments at the monetary conference which will interfere with the stabilization of employment, her internal price level or the maintenance of her position with the "sterling bloc."

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 2 -- The port of Cherbourg is being restored to working order on schedule, and, furthermore, the rail and road facilities serving it can be expanded to meet the heavy traffic demands of the Allies' invasion forces, Maj. Gen. Cecil Ray Moore, chief engineer for the United States Army in Europe, said this afternoon.

The special feature of last night's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Alexander Smallens, at the Lewisohn Stadium, was the performance of the Chopin E minor piano concerto, with Eleanor Fine as soloist.
LANCHOW, China, July 2 (AP) -- Vice President Henry A. Wallace left for home today after a visit here to the shrine containing the supposed remains of Genghis Khan.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Mr. Bowles estimated the average increase to the mills on account of his action today at 7 1/2 per cent, or about $150,000,000 a year, but he said part of that might be absorbed before reaching the retail level.
SAIPAN, Marianas Islands (Delayed) -- Twenty-four hours ago, 300 yards to the rear of our present positions, our existence hung by a thread as enemy shells drove us into the water's edge.

THERE was an item in the paper not so long ago which may have escaped your attention. It mentioned that sixteen officers and men of the "Little Beavers" destroyer squadron received Bronze Star medals for courageous service in the Pacific last fall and winter. Among them was Lieut. (jg) Byron R. White. Upon receipt of his decoration, Lieutenant White was quoted as saying, "I just got in on the gravy train.
Mr. and Mrs. Alexander H. Rutherford, who had been at the Savoy-Plaza since their recent return from Palm Beach, have gone to their summer home in Rome, N.Y.
LONDON, July 2 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

After a long silence during which Germany's impending catastrophe has been made evident to all, including the Germans themselves, Adolf Hitler has again found the courage to raise his voice in a speech It was only fitting this first speech after the Allied invasion of France, the fall of Rome and the new German disaster in Russia which initiate the final Allied offensive against Berlin, should have been a funeral oration.

CHICAGO, July 2 -- Heavy and persistent buying of wheat futures attributed to mills, estimated to have aggregated at least 2,000,000 bushels daily for more than a week, offset liberal receipts of cash grain at terminal and subterminal markets last week.

The Rev. Dr. Norman Goodall has been named secretary of the International Missionary Council, with headquarters in London, England, it was announced yesterday at the council's American headquarters, 156 Fifth Avenue.

By way of demonstrating that the art of losing can be exploited by both sides to a degree of sensationalism hitherto undreamed of the Yankees and the White Sox fired a pair of ball games at each other at the Stadium yesterday in a manner that left 39,565 onlookers gaping with amazement.

MILLIONS of words have been written about the armed services of the United States. But most of them, save for technical publications, histories of particular units designed for their members, etc., have not been official works intended to inform the general public. Individuals in the services and professional writers have had plenty to say about our fighting men, but their books have been personal ventures.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The New York State Bar Association and the New York State Motor Bus Association responded to the Government's "Don't Travel" appeals by canceling conventions which already had been scheduled.

Buttons achieve a new importance as accents on clothes and accessories. There is a wide variety and the decorative styles include ceramics, metals, lucites and plastics. The range of sizes is from thumbnail to overbulky types. Sewing centers recommend that consideration be given to size, color and styles in relation to the costume or accessory they will adorn.

LONDON, Monday, July 3 -- Triumphant Soviet troops yesterday cut off Minsk, main Nazi stronghold before Warsaw, from all railroad communications westward, and sent armored spearheads racing to within twelve and one-half miles of the city's northeastern gates as they rapidly began to encircle the White Russian capital.

Strong winds and a flood tide sent the municipal ferryboat Mary Murray crashing into the heavy wooden piling of her slip at South Ferry with unusual force at 5:59 P.M. yesterday and injured thirty-two of the 1,900 passengers en route from Staten Island.

PITTSBURGH, July 2 -- A combination of such factors as hot weather, shortages of manpower, outlaw strikes and need for repairs cut the steel ingot operating rate last week one and one-half points to 96 per cent of rated capacity. Indications are that the rate this week will not be bettered and may even be less, although most primary steel equipment will be scheduled for steel-making over the Fourth of July.

CHICAGO, July 2 (AP) -- Reflecting its current stem-to-stern pennant struggle, the American League today played the field in nominating its twenty-five representatives for the twelfth annual major league all-star game at Pittsburgh, July 11.
CHUNGKING, China, July 2 (AP) -A Fourteenth United State Air Force communique:
