CINCINNATI, July 2 (AP) -- Members of the United Mine Workers, seeking the right to elect their own district officers and international executive board, formed a temporary organization today to carry their fight to the union's biennial convention in September.

Pvt. Frank L. Kovacs of Menlo Park, Calif., returned with William Tilden to the turf of Forest Hills yesterday and in spite of a remarkable exhibition of serving by the former world champion, Kovacs won, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4.

ROME, July 2 -- American Fifth Army infantrymen -- emerging victorious in one of the stiffest battles in Italy since the occupation of Rome -- have captured the German stronghold of Cecina, twenty miles below Leghorn, Allied Headquarters announced tonight.

George Biddle, who was sent overseas by the War Department to obtain an artists's record of the war in the form of drawings, is the author of "Artist at War," a July 14 publication of The Viking Press. The book contains halftone illustrations, line drawings and mays.

" More Christ-like love in action among men" is the prerequisite for peace and for a better world, the Rev. George H. Guilfoyle declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. He warned against "hoarding Christ."

BOSTON, July 2 (AP) -- The Red Sox climbed to a game and one-half behind the Browns today by humbling the pace-setters in both ends of a double-header, 1 -- 0 and 4 -- 3 in eleven innings before more than 32,000.

The new Federal $5 "use" tax stamps that motorists were supposed to purchase by last Saturday to operate their automobiles legally were conspicuously absent yesterday from the windshields of a large percentage of the cars jamming the highways leading to mountain and beach resorts.

Charging a "betrayal of the Republican party," Paul Windels, former Corporation Counsel, demanded yesterday that the Republican leaders of Brooklyn and the Bronx "publicly repudiate" party candidates for local office in their counties who have accepted American Labor party endorsements.
KANDY, Ceylon, July 2 (AP) -- A communique:

In an Independence Day sermon at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, the Rev. Paul L. McKay, associate pastor, warned that the greatest tragedy in human life is loss of faith. Calling for steadfast faith in the "eternal good of things," he declared that "faith in God caused our Founding Fathers to believe in the freedom of man."

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 2 (AP) -- Jersey City snapped its losing streak at three straight by taking both ends of a double-header from the Newark Bears before a crowd of 7,606 today, 4 to 3 and 3 to 2.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 2 -- Eighty-four craft, which topped the previous season's mark by nine boats, were out today in the seventh championship regatta of the Long Island Sound series, which was held by the New Rochelle Yacht Club.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Use of termination control centers staffed by "settlement teams" of accounting, disposal, legal and technical officers is proposed in a six-point plan to expedite the settling of war contracts made public today by an advisory group of the National Association of Manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Two crew members who died trying to land a crippled Flying Fortress, whose pilot lay wounded in the plane, have been honored posthumouslyby award of the Congressional Medal of Honor, the War Department announced today.

Police of the Grand Avenue station in Brooklyn yesterday morning arrested Arthur Edwards, 19 years old, of 320 Sumner Avenue, Brooklyn, on charges of assaulting a young patrolman and his woman companion in Prospect Park and later disclosed that the suspect was being questioned in the slaying of a woman last year.

Physically handicapped and cardiac children and their mothers will start at 8:30 A.M. today from Pier 70 aboard the Lloyd I. Seaman, St. John's Guild floating hospital, for the first seasonal excursion up the Hudson. From now through Sept. 2, every day save Sunday, the Seaman will carry a cargo of patients and mothers to Yonkers and back, with doctors and nurses aboard to cater to their needs, and diversion planned on her canvas-topped decks.

WITH UNITED STATES CARRIER TASK FORCE, Somewhere in the Pacific (AP) -- This fighter squadron has given the rest of the Navy airmen in the Pacific something to shoot at -- a record of 187 Japanese planes wiped out.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 2 -- Dick Ciuci of Fresh Meadow dropped a 14-foot putt at the nineteenth hole for a birdie three to give him and Russ McVoy, medalists, a one-hole victory over Reginald Narelle and W.N. Fulkerson, Garden City Golf Club, in the feature match of the quarter-finals in the annual North Hempstead Country Club member-guest golf tournament today.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- A Pacific Fleet announcement:

G.R. Prout has been appointed manager of the air-conditioning and refrigeration division of the merchandise and appliance department of General Electric Company. Mr. Prout's headquarters will be in Bloomfield, N.J.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 2 -- The joint statement of principles for a post-war international monetary fund which is to be discussed at the United Nations monetary and financial conference faces much criticism in detail from various national delegations among the forty-four participating, as well as from bankers in the United States, Harry D. White, authorized spokesman for the United States delegation, disclosed today.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 2 -- The Chelsea Playhouse opened this evening with the comedy "Arsenic and Old Lace", and again Atlantic City found itself with a legitimate theatre on the boardwalk.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES at Balleroy, France, July 2 (AP) -One of the strangest battlefield scenes in all the invasion of France occurred this afternoon in No Man's Land near here when eight German nurses captured in Cherbourg were returned to the enemy lines.

LONDON, July 2 -- The contribution of the Royal Air Force to the softening-up of Hitler's European fortress during June was a record 64,000 tons of bombs dropped during 27,000 sorties, the British Air Ministry reported today. Operations were carried out on twenty-nine of thirty nights, with key assaults directed against the enemy's vital railway and road points.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, July 2 (U.P.) -- British and Indian troops, converging on the Japanese supply base of Ukhrul in India, today drove to within four miles of the city on the northeast and neared a junction with other Allied troops advancing from the west and southwest.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast domestically in Finland and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
ROME, July 2 (UP) -- A communique:

The shift of American industry from peace to war production took place gradually. The output of war goods could increase only slowly because time was required to create the productive plant. After the tools were created, however, the output of these goods increased sensationally until it became a veritable flood.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS in New Guinea, Monday, July 3 (AP) -- More than 150 planes cascaded 230 tons of bombs on Numfor Island, off north Netherland New Guinea, in the heaviest air assault on that already-battered islet, Headquarters announced today.

STOCKTON, England, July 2 (UP) -- Sir Stafford Cripps, Minister of Air Production, said today that plans for post-war international cooperation must be based on more than a "mere sentimental desire for world prosperity."

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Army's medical treatment of wounded soldiers was praised today by Maj. Gen. A.W. Kenner, chief medical officer of Supreme Headquarters of the Allied Expeditionary Forces, who said that "the high standard and the great effectiveness" of the care was important to the morale of casualties who were found "eager to return to battle."

No man in American life ever devoted himself more whole-heartedly to the public service than Norman Davis. The scope of his activities was bounded only by the world itself, and there is hardly a nation which at one time or another has not felt his influence. The multiplicity of his diplomatic missions is bewildering.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers and Philadelphia Athletics swapped shut-outs before 17,815 fans today, with Jesse Flores pitching the A's to a 2-0 victory in the nightcap after the Tigers, behind Dizzy Trout, had won the opener, 8 -- 0.

LONDON, July 2 -- The battle for Minsk, perhaps a decisive battle in the history of this war, was joined over the week-end as the extraordinary Russian advance of 100 to 150 miles in less than a week carried the Red Army into northern Poland.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Monday, July 3 -- Broken and scattered by the withering fire of the British vanguard, German forces have slowed down the pace of their counter-attacks on the British Second Army's salient across the Odon River while Field Marshal Gen. Erwin Rommel prepares his eleven divisions, the largest number he has ever commanded, for his big assaults on the southern arm of Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery's pincers around Caen.

Substantial decline in potato prices and lesser declines in lamb and poultry outweighed the price increases for last week, thus causing the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices to drop from 113.00 to 112.81.

MANCHESTER, Vt., July 2 -- C.W. Price of the Burlington Country Club, the medalist, today made short work of his opponent, J. Balciunas, Indian Hill Country Club, in the annual Lincoln Cup golf tourney.

We in the large cities are not in a position to set a proper value on small talk. We are too constantly in the midst of large affairs. It is a poor fellow indeed whose life does not touch the outer fringe of important enterprise.

LONDON, July 2 (AP) -- Negotiations lasting for two weeks between the British and French on civil administration and currency questions in France were concluded today with the completion of drafts that will be submitted to the British Government and the French Committee of National Liberation.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., July 2 -- A championship that he won seventeen years ago came back into the possession of Edmund H. Driggs Jr. today. It was the Metropolitan Amateur golf title, for which Driggs and John Dolan of the Crestwood Golf Club battled in a 36-hole final match at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club, Driggs' home course.

Considerable covering has been completed on fall merchandise, but there will be fill-in activities right along, according to a summary of activities in the wholesale markets prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

The United Jewish Appeal for Refugees, Overseas Needs and Palestine, 342 Madison Avenue, announced yesterday its constituent organizations spent a record sum of $20,600,000 in six months to aid Jewish victims of war and oppression.

GENEVA, Switzerland, July 2 -- Information reaching two European relief committees with headquarters in Switzerland has confirmed reports of the existence in Auschwitz and Birkenau in Upper Silesia of two "extermination camps" where more than 1,715,000 Jewish refugees were put to death between April 15, 1942, and April 15, 1944.

LONDON, July 2 (U.P.) -- Premier Edwin J. Linkomies, in a broadcast to the Finnish people, today committed his Government to continue the war with Russia until released by Germany, but claimed that Finland was innocent in the circumstances whereby the United States "has unfortunately broken off" diplomatic relations.

Broadway will have only one film opening this week, "Sensations of 1945," a musical produced and directed by Andrew Stone for United Artists release, which will arrive at Loew's State on Thursday. Eleanor Powell is starred in the picture.

MELBOURNE, July 2 -- A literary hoax has been perpetrated by two Sydney poets whose collection of what they describe as "Nonsensical Sentences" was accepted by an Australian literary magazine as representing the work of a "poet of tremendous power."

Family welfare agencies in this city, serving tens of thousands of families each year, have long been considered in the public mind as "charity" organizations established to give financial aid to the needy. While these agencies continue to meet many pressing financial needs, their work has been undergoing a significant change in recent years.

SAIPAN, Marianas, July 1 (Delayed) -- Bordered by the pockmarks of artillery shells and the gutted remains of an enemy ammunition dump, an American national cemetery occupies a portion of sandy beach tonight on this island which is being hacked away from the Japanese Empire.

Exactly a century ago today Caleb Cushing of Newburyport, Mass., sat down with a Chinese mandarin named Kiyeng, in the Wang Hiya temple outside Macao, and signed the first treaty between the United States and China. It was a hot day, and the American delegation, in their formal occidental clothes, suffered severely.

LONDON, July 2 (U.P.) -- As British authoriities threatened to take action under Defense Regulations against persons spreading robot bomb rumors or sightseers obstructing rescue work, in which Air Raid Precaution workers used sound detectors to locate survivors in piles of debris, four leading Sunday newspapers demanded the ruthless eradication of undefended German towns and villages in reprisal.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 2 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Omar N. Bradley commands the United States First Army, which alongside the British Second Army forms the Twenty-first Army Group of the Allied invasion of Normandy, it was disclosed tonight.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The new United States money orders soon will make their bow and a large business in them is expected.

PACIFIC FLEET HEADQUARTERS, Pearl Harbor, July 2 -- Marines and Army troops, the latter principally New Yorkers of the Twenty-seventh Division, are battering the Japanese back along the entire Saipan front and on the eastern flank are within five and a half miles of the northern tip of the island.

UNITED STATES NAVAL HOSPITAL, Corona, Calif., July 2 (AP) -- Penicillin has been successfully used to combat a complication of tuberculosis hitherto relieved only by extensive surgery. Doctors at this hospital have employed it in two cases to check empyema, a formation of puss in the leura, the envelope-like sack which covers the lungs.

ROME, July 1 (Delayed) (AP) -After a year's experience in Allied Military Government, Lieut. Col. Charles Poletti, regional commissioner for the Rome area, is convinced the Allies must remain in Italy after the war, at least until the Italians decide what form of government they want.

CHUNGKING, China, July 2 (AP) -- Mercilessly battered Hengyang, key Hunan rail junction, was officially reported tonight still in Chinese hands, although pounded by American bombs and showers of Japanese incendiaries.

STOCKHOLM, July 2 (U.P.) -- The Danish patriot press service said that the German command had delivered an ultimatum demanding an immediate return to normal in Copenhagen with the alternative that the city of 900,000 persons would be bombed by planes as a hostile area.

LONDON, Monday, July 3 (AP) -American and British heavy bombers dealt powerful blows against the Germans' flying bomb-launching platforms in the Pas-de-Calais area of France yesterday. Strong forces of Allied heavy bombers from Italy blasted oil refineries, rail yards and industrial areas near Budapest and at other points in Hungary and in Yugoslavia.

CHICAGO, July 2 (AP) -- Outfielder Jimmy Wasdell, with two doubles and two singles, led the Phillies to a 4-to-2 victory in the second game of a double-header before 28,307 today after the Cubs pounded out an 8-to-1 triumph in the opener. Wasdell scored two runs and drove in a third.

A nursery school center to care for fifty children of mothers in a migrant labor camp at Kings Ferry has been opened under the joint sponsorship of the Home Missions Council of North America and the Federal Works Agency, it was reported yesterday by Miss Edith E. Lowry, executive secretary of the council.

In the post-war period Soviet Russia intends to continue as a closed economy, sealed off from crises produced by competition in the world economy, but taking part in the world market as buyer and seller to take advantage of the international division of labor in order to build up as rapidly as possible her technological plant.

M. Levy and B. Joseph have purchased for cash over a first mortgage of $80,000 held by the Central Savings Bank the ten-story store and loft building at 105-07 East Sixteenth Street, between Union Square East and Irving Place, from the East Sixteent Realty Company.

President Roosevelt, in a letter made public yesterday, declared that the appeal to be made in the fall by the New York War Fund in behalf of the thirty-one National War Fund and local war-related agencies was "one more essential step on the road to victory and peace."
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 2 (AP) -- Commuique 53:

WASHINGTON, July 2 (U.P.) -Cheap, second-hand or poorly mad American products, especially clothing, will not be allowed to damage United States prestige in the liberated areas of Europe, responsible quarters asserted tonight.
CHUNGKING, China, July 2 (AP) -A commnique:

Notwithstanding victories for the Allies in Normandy (where Cherbourg was taken) and despite further advance by Russians in the East, the Stock Exchange moved little last week. Although the market again scored an unbroken series of five-hour million-share days, prices alternately advanced and declined only fractionally, closing strong.

About the middle of August the ragweed will begin to shed its pollen and millions will suffer the miseries of hay fever. Of all the 130,000 pollens known to botanists that of the ragweed is the worst. Why not uproot the growth and thus reduce the incidence of hay fever in these parts by at least 70 per cent?

CHICAGO, July 2 (AP) -- In one of the most phenomenal rallies in golf, Jug McSpaden today made up a six-stroke deficit by shooting a 34, 31 -- 65, six under par, on the last round -- capped by a forty-foot birdie putt on the final green -- to tie leader Ben Hogan at the end of seventy-two holes and force the Chicago Victory National tournament into an eighteen-hole play-off tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Members of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States were asked by their officers today to express their views on a proposed joint Federal-State program for the development of "a system of airports adequate to serve the nation's post-war needs."

With Mayor La Guardia leading the way in a police launch, and three fireboats throwing water displays high into the sunlight, a flotilla of twenty-one craft moved down the North River yesterday from Seventy-ninth Street to Bedloes Island, where 3,000 Americans of twenty-four different national origins participated in a war bond rally.

The advantage of having a top director like George S. Kaufman on the job is that he is qualified to jump in whenever necessary to do some script polishing himself. This dual capacity is not lightly regarded in theatrical circles. Besides staging "The Late George Apley," Mr. Kaufman will receive program credit as "full collaborator" of the dramatization, along with John P. Marquand, who wrote the Pulitzer Prize novel.

ALBANY, July 2 -- Thomas E. Dewey rested at home today after four days of continuous strain and excitement which started when he flew to Chicago Wednesday to accept the Republican nomination for President.

A woman who had lived at 152 East Thirty-fifth Street, two doors from the East Thirty-fifth Street police station, only a week, was found strangled in her one-room furnished apartment on the second floor early Saturday evening. The body was clad only in a slip.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 2 -As the result of negotiations undertaken at the request of the United States, E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. is making its neoprene synthetic rubber process available to Russia.

CINCINNATI, July 2 -- The 39-year-old Johnny Allen snapped a three-game Giant losing streak on Crosley Field today with the first shut-out by a Giant hurler this season to give Mel Ott's band an even split in a double-header, viewed by 14,052 fans.
LONDON, Monday, July 3 (UP) -The Russian Sunday midnight supplementary communique as broadcast from Moscow:

GUATEMALA, July 2 -- Members of the military junta left in temporary control of the Government after the resignation of President Ubico Jorge said today that they would remain in power only until the people of Guatemala had chosen a President.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 2 -- Subjects to come before the monetary and financial conference, it was indicated at the press conference today by Harry D. White of the American delegation, include means of dealing with gold loot of the Axis, looted securities and the monetary use of silver.

AN ADVANCED COMMAND POST, on the Salween Front, July 1 (Delayed) -- Nothing has succeeded in seriously jeopardizing the security of the 250 Japanese sitting in pillboxes on top of Shungshan, a mountain above the Salween River.

Kidder, Peabody Co. have announced receipt from Baldwin B. Bane, director of the corporation finance division of the Securities and Exchange Commission, of an opinion on recent "when issued" trades in the obligations of the Government of Brazil.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 2 -- Dr. H.H. Kung, China's Minister of Finance and head of its delegation to the Monetary and Financal Conference, declared today in an interview that the efforts of the conferees to agree would provide "a real test" of whether the nations could hope to get along in a peaceful world after the war.

Empire City's racing program will start today. But the horses won't be running at the Empire City Racing Association's intimate track in Yonkers. Instead, exactly as was the case last year, they will be chasing each other at the Jamaica Race Track on Long Island, where competition will be conducted for twenty-four days through July 29.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- Cleveland took both ends of a double-header from Washington today before a crowd of 13,982, winning the nightcap, 6 to 3, after edging out the Senators, 4 to 3 in the ten-inning opener. Ken Keltner, Indian infielder, collected seven hits, including a homer, in eight trips to the plate.

Mayor La Guardia unveiled his "transportation tax" plan yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall. Designed to raise an estimated $51,700,000 a year to cover the cost of subway deficits and transit improvements, the proposal calls for a levy on all rent payers and owner-occupants in residential, business and commercial buildings, supplemented by a tax on mortgage interest and an impost on all persons employed in the city but living elsewhere.

Mayor La Guardia unveiled his "transportation tax" plan yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall. Designed to raise an estimated $51,700,000 a year to cover the cost of subway deficits and transit improvements, the proposal calls for a levy on all rent payers and owner-occupants in residential, business and commercial buildings, supplemented by a tax on mortgage interest and an impost on all persons employed in the city but living elsewhere.

The revolt in Copenhagen, now ended, is one of the most surprising and significant episodes of the war. The Danes dislike violence, and normally the Danish capital is the gayest and most easygoing city in Scandinavia. Business and politics were conducted with a cheerful moderation that saved Denmark both from the political extremism that divided Norway in peacetime and from the serious strikes that occasionally interrupted the steady pulse of economic life in Sweden.

LONDON, July 2 -- A German formation in Normandy was observed yesterday to be operating on producer gas, according to Supreme Headquarters, Allied Expeditionary Force. Thus within one week a prediction made last Friday by the Ministry of Economic Warfare at a press conference here that Germany's acute oil shortage would soon make itself evident in the use of this substitute, even in the front line, has been fulfilled.

Price policy during the reconversion period will be of vital importance in determining the smoothness of the transition back to peacetime production and the speed with which wartime controls can be abandoned. In this connection Price Administrator Bowles' letter of June 18 is of considerable interest.

The Eitel Field Building Restaurant Corporation, of Chicago, Ill., has added hospital and surgical expense benefits to its group insurance program, which already provided its employes with life insurance, accidental death and dismemberment coverage, and sickness and accident benefits.
Increases in its holdings of Government securities, total deposits and aggregate assets during the second quarter of this year were reported yesterday by the Manufacturers Trust Company.

WITH THE EIGHTH ARMY, near Perugia, July 2 -- Germans recently captured in fighting on the Italian front reveal one prevailing hope of military triumph based on the alleged fantastic performance of the pilotless aircraft now operating against Britain.

ST. LOUIS, July 2 (AP) -- One hundred Congressional Medals of Honor have been awarded since Pearl Harbor, according to a summary by W. Ray Loomis, night editor of The St. Louis Globe-Democrat. In the first World War the highest military decoration was awarded to 114.

ROME, July 2 (AP) -- Maj. Paul D. Shriver, regional property control officer for the Rome area, announced today that holdings of more than forty American firms representing investments in Rome of about $30,000,000 had been assessed and inventoried, and that statements would be submitted to the owners in due time.

Consumption of food on the Continent generally, with the exception of Soviet Russia, is 85 to 90 per cent of the amount normal before the war, according to the office of foreign agricultural relations of the United States Department of Agriculture.

As the need of a smooth reconversion of industry looms up if full post-war employment is to be attained, advertising executives find that Government agencies are inclined to look with more favor upon promotional expenditures. Production will supply the jobs only if the goods are sold, it is explained, and the most bitter critic of advertising will not deny that it does the selling.

CHICAGO, July 2 -- The corn crop has made rapid growth in the last two weeks due to favorable weather conditions and by the end of the week the growth is expected to be up to the seasonal normal in many areas, especially where the seed went into the ground early.

The Chancer Corporation, representing Herman Z. Baum and Sigmund Dornbush of Newark, has bought for investment the two-story commercial building at 58389 Central Avenue, southwest corner of Sanford Street, in East Orange, N.J., from the National Commercial Title and Mortgage Guaranty Company.

Fair weather and the long Fourth of July holiday drew great numbers of New Yorkers out of the city yesterday, despite all official warnings against travel, gasoline restrictions and shortage of equipment on railroads, buses and airlines and the warning that they would have difficulty returning tomorrow night.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 2 -- Celeste Holm, the singing comedienne of the stage production, "Oklahoma!", has signed a term contract with Twentieth Century-Fox after an extensive series of camera tests. Refusing to sign until an opportunity had been given her to see herself on the screen, Miss Holm's tests in black and white and in color involved scenes with Sir Cedric Hardwicke, Dick Haymes, Vincent Price and Mischa Auer.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

VENTNOR CITY, N.J., July 2 -- Each of the three games adjourned from the first round of the sixth annual chess masters' tournament, concluded on the municipal pier today, produced decisive results to the end that Capt. Joseph Rauch of the Royal Canadian Air Force, the first victor, was tied by three others.

LONDON, July 2 -- The stock markets maintain the less exuberant mood into which they relapsed when the new form of enemy air attack developed more than a fortnight ago. In some cases where the previous advance of prices had been over-rapid, reaction had been rather sharp.

Leaseholders in residential buildings cannot be evicted for refusal to sign renewal leases containing "escalator" clauses requiring them to pay, during the term of the new lease, any rent increase authorized during that term by the Office of Price Administration, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall.

LONDON, July 2 -- More of the Nazis' flying bombs continued to smash into southern England today, but with waning intensity during daylight after a night in which "further damage and casualties" were reported by British officials.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (U.P.) -- The National Association of Manufacturers said today that certain unidentified government officials have admitted that the United States has made secret trade agreements with Great Britain for "war purposes," and asserted that these treaties are "freezing" American industries out of their pre-war markets in British possessions.
PITTSBURGH, July 2 (AP) -- After winning, 4 to 1, the Braves tied the Pirates, 5 -- 5, in the second game of a double-header, play being halted after eight innings by the Sunday baseball law.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Monday, July 3 (AP) -- A communique:

You are right in saying that Diesel locomotives have done excellent service in the last few years, although it is hard to see why you give secondary rating to the switcher. It is in switching service that the Diesels have shown unquestioned superiority.

Cotton prices advanced into new high ground in the early dealings last week, but subsequently lost a portion of their gains. At the close of trading on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were 24 to 35 points above the close of the previous week.

Sales of Series E bonds -- the issue of lower denominations designed for purchase by the man in the street -- lagged sadly last night as the city, State and nation rapidly approached over-all quotas in the Fifth War Loan Drive ending Saturday.
SOMEWHERE IN NORMANDY, June 30 (Delayed) (AP) -- Monsieur le Comte, who is a millionaire with one pair of shoes to his name, spoke for all the French in Normandy when he said:

Vladimir Golschmann, French conductor, last night made his first appearance at the Lewisohn Stadium since 1937, and an audience estimated at 9,000 was on hand to greet him. Mr. Golschmann devoted the first half of the program to Weber's "Oberon" Overture and Brahms' First symphony, while the second half listed Beethoven's Violin Concerto with Bronislaw Huberman as soloist.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The glider troops who have played a prominent part in each of the invasions by United States forces will hereafter receive the same pay as paratroopers, under the terms of a bill which became law today with signature by President Roosevelt.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast domestically in Finland and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WHY do German soldiers fight on even when they know there is no chance of winning? The Czech novelist, Franz Weiskopf, suggests the answer in a macabre novel called "The Firing Squad,"* which is the story of six Nazi soldiers who were detailed to shoot hostages in and around Prague after the assassination of Heydrich, the notorious hangman of the Gestapo.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- In an effort to utilize a supply of aluminum that is relatively more available than sheet steel, the War Production Board authorized use of 7,000,000 pounds of aluminum during the next three months in the "experimental" manufacture of cans for specified products.

The Central Railroad Company of New Jersey appealed yesterday to the Interstate Commerce Commission for higher lighterage and carfloatage allowances out of the present joint freight rates. Also, it asked for an order requiring other railroads serving New York to stop accepting the present below-cost allowances for such port delivery service.
CHUNGKING, China, July 3 (AP) -- A communique.

A 16-mm. print of "Action in the North Atlantic" has been presented by Warner Brothers, the producers of the topical melodrama, to the United States Maritime Training Station at Sheepshead Bay, N.Y. The film, starring Humphrey Bogart and telling the story of a merchant marine convoy to Murmansk, will be used for instruction purposes at the training station.

Garments and utility articles made by Greater New York Junior Red Cross members in elementary and high school clubs are beginning to arrive at the group's headquarters at the Board of Education, 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn, Miss Catherine Griffin, executive secretary, said yesterday.

ROME, July 3 -- The American flag that flew over the Capitol in Washington on Dec. 8, 1941, when Congress declared the existence of a state of war with Japan, and three days later, when war was declared on Italy and Germany, will be flown from the first captured enemy capital on July 4, it was announced today.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 3 (AP) -- A bipartisan appeal by twenty-five Western Senators for inclusion of silver in plans for an international currency stabilization fund met a chilly response today from the American delegation to the United Nations monetary conference.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 3 -- An eighteenth century New Yorker's plan to cool Congressional chambers with saltpetrous air drawn upward through ducts by stove heat, was disclosed here today by Dr. Julian P. Boyd, Princeton University librarian.

Albert A. Volk's plan for labeling speech is excellent as theory but doubtful of practice. His use of the term "well enforced" seems to indicate that he himself cannot be too sure of its success. The time, the place and the occasion are probably all too closely tied up with both speech and writing to make possible any strict censorship such as Mr. Volk suggests.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The strength of the competitive two-party system in this country was demonstrated once more at Chicago last week when the suggestion that Senator Byrd of Virginia be nominated for Vice President by the Republicans expired on the moment of its arrival from Washington.
WITH AMERICAN FORCES in France, July 3 -- United States troops launched a new offensive today and by tonight had made substantial progress over difficult terrain against stubborn resistance.

Leonard J.A. Smit, 58-year-old dealer in industrial diamonds, pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal court to seven indictments accusing him and three concerns he controls of violating United States export control laws by shipping strategically important diamonds out of this country.

The ten-story and penthouse apartment building at 226 East Twelfth Street has been sold by the Godfrey Realty Corporation to the Scherman Development Corporation (Isaac Scherman, president) for cash over a first mortgage of $340,000.

MIAMI, July 3 -- Morris Stanley Neff, 23, who remained hidden in his home for three years, sought in court today to take upon himself the blame for draft evasion which the Government has charged to his parents.

ROME, July 3 -- American and French forces occupied the medieval city of Siena, thirty-one airline miles from Florence, early today without damage to its famous art and architectural treasures, while American troops on the west coast who had evicted the Germans from Cecina in bitter house-to-house fighting thrust on within fifteen miles of the prize port of Leghorn.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 3 (AP) -- Lieut Gen. Brehon Somervell, Chief of the Army Service Forces, declared today that war production was continuing to lag and asked that fishing trips be put off until victory is won. Production has fallen off steadly since November, he added.

Out-of-town buyers reported in the market during the week ended yesterday totaled 458, against 1,136 in the preceding week and 1,136 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Last month's arrivals numbered 7,222, a new high for any one month since the listings were started and compares with, 5,654 for June, 1943, an increase of 27.7 per cent.

CHICAGO, July 3 (AP) -- Tournament-wise Harold (Jug) McSpaden of Philadelphia shot a one-under-par 70 today to beat Lieut. Ben Hogan by three strokes in a playoff for the Chicago Victory national championship -- the Easterner's fifth golf title of the year.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Reports circulated today in executive and Congressional quarters usually close to White House activities that President Roosevelt, as a bid for party harmony, might not ask the Democratic National Convention at Chicago this month to renominate Vice President Wallace.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- President Roosevelt approved today legislation broadening the scope of the United States Public Health Service and in a statement commended the department for "its excellent record in protecting the health of the nation."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS in New Guinea, Tuesday, July 4 (AP) -Warships started shelling Numfor's west coast beaches before dawn while small landing craft made their rendezvous offshore and fighters and bombers flew overhead in support.
All securities and commodity exchanges and all banks in the United States will be closed today in observance of Independence Day. All Canadian and British banks and markets will be open as usual.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- Chicago banks increased their participation in the financing of business and industry in the second quarter of 1944 and achieved still higher peaks in deposits and in holdings of Government securities. The trend was shown today in figures issued in response to calls for condition of State and national banks as of June 30.

Working boys and girls are helping eagerly in the war effort, as would be expected in a time of scarcity of manpower. But the need for their help and their willingness to help do not excuse their exploitation at the hands of the greedy or the careless. Commissioner Edward Corsi, head of the State Labor Department, reveals that attempts to break down the legal safeguards of child labor are widespread and increasing.

With the effective date of the new lumber order L-335 as amended rapidly approaching, the furniture industry still has no idea how much lumber it will be able to obtain for third-quarter production, it was said yesterday in the trade.

LONDON, July 3 -- Surpassing all previous monthly records, the United States Eighth Air Force cascaded bombs on Germans during the invasion month of June at the rate of one and one-third tons for each minute of the month. Altogether the Eighth Air Force dropped 58,750 tons in 49,520 sorties.

IN THE FIELD, France, July 2 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Allied Supreme Commander Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower made a special trip across the Channel to France today to pin twenty-two Distinguished Service Crosses and two emblems of the Legion of Merit on heroes of the United States "Fighting First" Division.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 3 (AP) -- Communique 55: During yesterday morning our Odon bridgehead was further strengthened. The enemy's activity was on a reduced scale, owing probably to the severe mauling he received on Saturday. There were some enemy attacks, but they were firmly repuised

C. Courtney Keller, assistant vice president of Blair Co., bankers, purchased the dwelling at 16 Birch Brook Road, Bronxville, Westchester County, from L. Allen Osborne Jr. William H. Watson acted as broker. Francis H. Horan represented the seller as attorney and Theodore K. McCarthy represented the buyer.

The New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday that it will open sealed tenders on July 12 on a new issue of $5,517,000 of temporary loan notes. The issue will be dated Aug. 14, 1944, and will be payable on Feb. 14, 1945. This issue is in addition to that of $2,209,000 announced last week for award on July 11.

Reductions in the assessed valuations for 1941-42, 1942-43 and 1943-44 in the aggregate amount of $211,000 of the total assessed valuations of the nine-story apartment building at 350 West Fifty-fifth Street and in the aggregate amount of $175,000 of the total assessed valuations for the same years on the fifteen-story apartment house at 39 Fifth Avenue have been ordered by Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 3 -- The Westchester County Board of Supervisors doubled today from $245,000 to $490,000 the wartime cost-of-living annual bonuses for county employes and adopted a plan to keep future bonuses in harmony with changes in living costs.
The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company reported yesterday in its annual statement covering the fiscal year ended on Feb. 29, a net profit of $12,567,821 after taxes and other deductions.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- The State Department has sent to Gen. Charles de Gaulle an outline of this Government's ideas for forthcoming conversations with him "on the conduct of the war," it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- A Women's Bureau study which has as its purpose the inclusion of women workers along with male workers and veterans in the postwar plans of American communities, is now well under way.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3 (AP) -- Johnson Johnson, New Brunswick, N.J., manufacturers of surgical dressings, registered today with the Securities and Exchange Commission 77,252 shares of $12.50 value of common stock and 36,218 shares of $100 par value cumulative second preferred stock, 4 per cent Series A.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, July 3 -- President Tiburcio Carias, who two weeks ago asserted that there were no political prisoners in Honduras, today ordered the release of all "political prisoners."

Joseph W. Rothmeyer, who resigned on June 7 as a director of the Hupp Motor Car Corporation, sold on June 2 66,666 1-3 common shares of the company, retaining one share, according to a report filed with the New York Stock Exchange pursuant to the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Tuesday, July 4 (AP) -- A communique:

Salads, summer's perennial favorite so far as menus are concerned, invariably team well with a hot bread. One kind of hot bread that is unusual, easy to prepare and sure to appeal to a good many people consists of strips of biscuit dough, flavored with chopped parsley, spread with peanut butter and bacon, folded over, twisted and baked.

AN ADVANCED NINTH AIR FORCE FIGHTER BASE, in France, July 2 (Delayed) (AP) -- A dive-bombing mission of such unusual importance that Maj. Gen. Elwood (Pete) Quesada, chief of the Ninth's Fighter Command, himself led the flight was carried out late today by Ninth Air Force fighter pilots in advance of the big American push in the southern Cherbourg Peninsula.

ALBANY, July 3 -- Governor Dewey, at a press conference in his office today, stated that in his acceptance speech at Chicago, he had disposed of a question as to whether he had the right to run for President and leave the Administration of New York State in other hands should he be elected.

Big numbers were in evidence everywhere yesterday at the Jamaica track as the meeting of the Empire City Racing Association began. New records for the transplanted session were established, involving attendance, daily double wagering, complete handle and the handle for a single race.

Unification of the elementary school curriculum is urgently needed if education is to meet the demands of modern society, William E. Young, director of the division of elementary education, New York State Department of Education, declared yesterday.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

Headed by a half-dozen Cardinals, hardly a surprise, in view of the manner in which the St. Louis aggregation is dominating the race, the personnel of the National League All-Star squad, which is to oppose the American League representatives in the twelfth annual classic at Forbes Field, Pittsburgh, next Tuesday night, was announced yesterday by President Ford Frick.

A questionnaire sent recently to 5,000 locker plants across the country revealed that 1,187 of the operators, or 24 per cent, are aware of new trends in the food processing industry, F.F. Duggan, manager of the refrigeration sales division of the Edison General Electric Appliance Company, announced yesterday.

One week after the fall of Cherbourg and twenty-four hours after the final mopping up of Cap de la Hague, the United States First Army under General Bradley has already launched a new offensive along a thirty-mile front stretching from the west coast of the Cherbourg peninsula to near the center of the whole Normandy battle line at St. Lo.

Declaring that organized labor has lost its "punch" and influence on Government because of its disunity, Daniel J. Tobin, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, largest affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, yesterday called upon the AFL and the Congress of Industrial Organizations to resume their efforts to achieve amalgamation.

" The Voice of the Turtle," as well as two of its performers, Margaret Sullavan and Audrey Christie, were among the winners in the first annual Donaldson Awards poll conducted by The Billboard, trade paper of the amusement industry, it was announced yesterday.
LONDON, July 3 -- From Stockholm, Madrid and Lisbon, since the Germans started their campaign of robot bombing, there have come whispers and rumors of peace moves.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 3 -- Copenhagen remained under a state of siege today and a general strike spread to the Danish mainland despite appeals of municipal authorities and labor leaders for an end of demonstrations which had caused the Germans to threaten to starve the capital and, if necessary, to bomb it.

MOSCOW, July 3 -- Details were given out here today about the structure and activity of the National Council of Poland, whose representatives from Nazi-held territory are now in Moscow to establish contact with the Allied Governments.

Two Australian soldiers and poets have played a good joke on a literary magazine of their country. They put their heads together and invented a "poet of tremendous power" named Ern Malley. They foisted upon that innocent periodical poems which they call "Nonsensical Sentences."

Despite the definite announcement by Donald Nelson, War Production Board chairman, that controls on the purchase of machinery, tools and dies for civilian production were scheduled to be modified on July 1, a check at the agency's regional offices disclosed yesterday that no final action has as yet been taken.

VENTNOR CITY, N.J., July 3 -- Winning their adjourned games from the second round and also their third-round matches, today, Albert S. Pinkus and Anthony E. Santasiere, both of New York City, forged out in front in the sixth annual invitation chess masters' tournament on the Municipal Pier.
ATLANTA, July 3 -- The right of qualified Negro voters to cast their ballots in Georgia's primaries will be tested tomorrow.
LONDON, July 3 -- The stock markets here held firm today, but trading was light. Chief interest was shown in Kaffirs, where continued demand met few offerings. Oils came in for some support.
Yesterday's communique as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- President Roosevelt today disapproved a bill which would have allowed the computation of double-time credits for foreign service between 1898 and 1912 in determining Army retirement pay.

ABOARD JOINT EXPEDITIONARY FORCE FLAGSHIP, Off Saipan, July 3 -- The Second Marine Division -- the conqueror of Tarawa -- tightened its vise around the blazing coastal point that was the city of Garapan today, while Fourth Marine Division troops advanced on the right flank to a point within five miles of the northern tip of the island.
ROME, July 3 (AP) -- A communique.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 29 (Delayed) -- The recall of the British Ambassador, Sir David Victor Kelly, from Buenos Aires came just two days after the whole pro-Government segment of the Argentine press had announced under prominent headlines that the British Foreign Office had decided not to follow the State Department's example and would leave him at his post.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The United States Army Air Forces have definite information that, because of its blows against German oil centers, which have reduced the enemy's fuel supply to an estimated 30 per cent of normal, the Luftwaffe and the rest of Germany's mechanized forces are being "rationed," Gen. H.H. Arnold revealed today. Luftwaffe may never fight effectively again.
LONDON, July 3 -- Belgium, too, awaits liberation, but meanwhile --

A string of military bases from Canada to the Falkland Islands, to be maintained by North and South America, was advocated as a postwar policy yesterday by Francisco de Assis Chateaubriand of Rio de Janeiro, publisher and owner of radio stations in Brazil.
LONDON, July 3 -- Mopping up of the Cotentin Peninsula was completed last week, and the first phase of the Allied Navy's job in the invasion of western Europe was finished.

LONDON, Tuesday, July 4 (AP) -- A thundering force of up to 750 American heavy bombers surged up from Italy and blasted important southeast European off facilities of the Axis yesterday. The attackers included Flying Fortresses and Liberators of the Fifteenth Air Force and also Fortresses of the Eighth Air Force that had flown on shuttle Air Force from Britain via Russia.

Considerable caution prevails in the fur industry, representing a combination of factors, it was reported here yesterday. The revision by the Office of Price Administration of the manufacturers' regulation, MPR 178, is expected momentarily, but this was said to be only one reason for conservatism.

Reports over the week-end that the OPA had raised the price on about one-third of the production of cotton textiles caused a sharp early advance in cotton futures, and sent the entire list to the highest prices reached for the last sixteen years.
The letter of Elisha M. Freedman appearing in THE TIMES of June 25 is, I believe, one of the most comprehensive and sensible summations on our economic system that I have ever seen.

ROME, July 3 (U.P.) -- German forces still were fighting around Cecina Marina, two miles southwest of Cecina. Inland, between Volterra and Montecatini on a line only twenty miles south of another secondary highway between Pisa and Florence, American advanced elements made contact with the German Sixteenth SS Reichsfuehrer Division and the Nineteenth Luftwaffe Division.

CHICAGO, July 3 (AP) -- Prices of hogs rose today above the support price, of $13.75 a hundredweight for the first time in more than two months when Eastern concerns paid $13.85 for choice 210-pounders. The day's report of the livestock market here by the War Food Administration follows:

It need not be the Burma jungle or the desert spaces on the slopes of the Himalayan "hump." It can happen right here at home in the Grand Canyon where American airmen bail out and find themselves stranded.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 3 (AP) -- Miss Kay Byrne, the defending champion, won the medal in the qualifying round of the New York State women's golf championship today with a 79, one better than Mrs. Ruth Torgerson of Cherry Valley.

The end of the second World War is certainly much nearer today than was the end of the Revolutionary War on July 4, 1776. The Declaration was a desperate act. Nothing less would hold the Colonies together, yet even united they had little with which to make the bold words good.

From Wac of the Week, Private Iva M. Taylor of Fort Worth, Tex., was promoted to Wac of the Month yesterday at Second Service Command headquarters, where she told interviewers the story of her Army career. The title was bestowed on her for military achievement, devotion to duty, bearing, neatness, civilian career, relatives in service, and the recommendation of the commanding officer of the post.

Advertising for South American audiences must be prepared by South Americans, according to Ricardo H. Pueyrredon, head of the large Argentine advertising agency bearing his name. Too much advertising for South America, he states, is created in the United States by Central Americans, whose language, customs and psychology differ from those of South Americans.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Twenty-one additional plants have won the coveted Army-Navy production award for excellence in the manufacture of war materials. They are: American Red Cross, Blood Donor Center, Oakland, Calif.; American Red Cross, San Diego, Calif.; Clopay Corporation, Cincinnati, Ohio; Electro-Voice Manufacturing Company, Inc., South Bend, Ind.; Ethyl-Dow Chemical Company, Kure Beach plant, Wilmington, N.C.; General Engineering Works, Chicago; General Motors Corporation, Bay City, Mich.; Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, Decatur, Ala.

LONDON, July 3 (U.P.) -- Patriot Yugoslav forces of Marshal Tito have stormed three German-held railway lines, including the vital connection between Doboj and the important central Bosnia steel center of Zenica, a communique announced today.

LONDON, July 3 (AP) -- An authoritative French source declared today that there scarcely was a region in France where fighting was not in progress. He estimated that the French guerrillas were pinning down about eight German divisions that otherwise would be in action against the Allies in Normandy.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The Argentine situation will be taken up for intensive study upon the arrival here tomorrow of Norman Armour, who was recalled from his post as United States Ambassador in Buenos Aires, for consultation.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3 -- A registration statement covering the issuance and sale of $10,600,000 of 3 1/2 per cent first mortgage bonds, due in 1969, and the sale of 350,000 shares of $10 par value common stock was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Empire District Electric Company of Joplin, Mo.

Curt Riess, author of "Total Espionage" and "The Invasion of Germany," has compiled dispatches from more than 125 correspondents and columnists, many of whom are authors of books, to form a running account of this war from Hitler's rise to power to the present.

IT seems hardly possible, but twenty-five years have passed since Jack Dempsey bludgeoned into submission the Pottawatomie Giant, Jess Willard, and thus became the heavyweight boxing champion of the world. However, it was a quarter of a century ago today that the Manassa Mauler spotted big Jess a weight advantage of sixty-five pounds and still gave him the most murderous one-round beating that any man absorbed in the history of the sport.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 3 -- Confidence was expressed today by members of the American delegation to the United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference that the level of American export trade can be raised from the average of $3,000,000,000 annually of the prewar years to around $10,000,000,000 if the proposed International Monetary Fund and World Bank for Reconstruction and Development are established.

Damage amounting to several thousand dollars was done Sunday night by three vandals who forced their way into Public School 38, at 701 St. Ann's Avenue, the Bronx, and, according to the police, wrecked thirty-nine of the forty-eight classrooms.

CHUNGKING, China, July 3 (AP) -- Chinese troops have been hurled against a strong enemy spearhead that stabbed forty-six miles south of encircled Hengyang on the Canton-Hankow railway, the Chinese High Command announced tonight. Bloody fighting raged in the area, where the Japanese were attempting to complete seizure of the 1,000-mile north-south rail route in China.

The American Chain and Cable Company, Inc., Bridgeport, Conn., has acquired the business of the Pennsylvania Lawn Mower Works, Inc., Primos, Pa., which was started in 1877. Nelson D. Perine will continue in charge of sales.

GENERAL STILWELL'S HEADQUARTERS, North Burma, July 2 (Delayed) -- The dogged, at times suicidal, Japanese resistance is denying complete control of the Mogaung and Myitkyina valleys to the Allies despite the arrival of the monsoon rains at midsummer intensity.

SIENA, Italy, July 3 -- Siena is ours. This is being written in historic Palazzo Communale at 8 in the morning today while madly joyous crowds outside on the Campo shout themselves hoarse. Yesterday should have been Palio Day, when the famous horse race of the Siena Contrade ordinarily is held, but we have given them something better to cheer about.

IN NORMANDY, July 3 -- Flying from fields so close to the front line that enemy artillery can shell them easily, swift rocket-firing Typhoons of the British Second Tactical Air Force are giving the German tank units opposite the British sector around Caen a headache that probably could be relieved only by large and frequent doses of Tuftwaffe fighters.

CLEVELAND, July 3 (AP) -- Nora, finishing fourth to Precision in the first heat of the $5,000 rainy day stake for 2-year-old trotters at North Randall today, came back to bag the second and final round, in which Precision broke gait to finish seventh.

The women's reserve of the Marine Corps has reached its national quota of 19,000, Washington headquarters of the corps announced yesterday. Recruiting now will be carried on merely "to take care of the normal attrition of personnel, which is estimated at 100 per month."

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- William H. Stanley, Inc., 103 East 125th Street, New York, and the Ketchikan Packing Company, lietchikan, Alaska, have denied violating Federal statutes in the sale and purchase of canned salmon, the Federal Trade Commission said today.
LONDON, July 3 -- Twenty-one German generals have been captured or killed in the last three weeks, a heavy blow to the officer corps which is heart and brain of the Wehrmacht.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- Class I railroads had a net income of $59,000,000 in May, compared with $85,731,956 in May, 1943, the Association of American Railroads reported today. Net operating income, before interest and rentals, totaled $98,505,213 in May, 1944, compared with $129,478,115 in May, last year.

With warm, overcast, rainless weather forecast for today, New York was ready last night to celebrate the Fourth of July quietly, and to face one of the worst traffic jams in its history as holiday-makers seek to return from beaches and resorts this afternoon, tonight and tomorrow morning.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- American aircraft plants, plagued suddenly by defective parts, faultry inspection and new specifications in some instances, turned out only 8,042 planes of all kinds in June and fell short of the May output of 8,902 planes by 9.5 per cent, Charles E. Wilson, chairman of the Aircraft Production Board, reported today.

ST. LOUIS, July 3 -- The Giants arrived here today to enjoy a breather before tackling the champion Cardinals in a four-game series which opens with the usual holiday double-header tomorrow. A night fray on Wednesday and a matinee game Thursday will close out the visit.

ROME, July 3 -- Henry L. Stimson, United States Secretary of War, arrived today at an airfield in Italy for a brief tour of this theatre of war. He plans to visit the front line and inspect troops and hospitals as well as to hold conferences with important figures.

The five-cent fare is admittedly a sacred cow. If we could operate our city transit system and still leave this pleasing animal at ease in its pasture, who would not be glad? But Mayor La Guardia's proposed "transportation tax" reduces the whole plan to absurdity.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Chester Bowles, Price Administrator, informed consumers today that "a substantial part" of the increased prices for cotton textiles required under the price control extension law would be absorbed before the fabrics and clothing reach the retail store.

Additional condition statements issued yesterday by leading Wall Street banks as of June 30 generally showed substantial gains in deposits and in total resources for the quarter. The same was true of holdings of United States Government securities.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- In a fiscal year in which Treasury receipts and expenditures reached "unprecedented peaks," the Government spent nearly $90,000,000,000 on the war, Secretary Morgenthau reported today.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., July 3 -- Anthracite production slumped an estimated 90,000 tons today as 60 per cent of the industry's 74,000 workers failed to report for duty despite efforts of the Government to have the men forego their annual vacation to build up fuel reserves to avert a crisis in the east this winter.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 3 -- James Melton, Metropolitan Opera Company tenor, who sang two numbers for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's "Ziegfield Follies," will be starred by the studio in a musical version of the Edna Ferber novel, "Cimarron."

WESTBURY, L.I., July 3 -- Four new records were set tonight at the Roosevelt Raceway trotting meet. A new high in attendance, 9,618, turned out for the sport and these fans wagered $307,435, surpassing the old handle, $285,950, for a single night.

Somehow the delusion persists that the era of great opportunities for humble people in this country has ended. There is talk that the time is over when a boy starting at the foot of the ladder could expect, with reasonable care of his health, his morals and his manners, to arrive anywhere near the top.
CHUNGKING, China, July 3 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique.

BUENOS AIRES, July 3 -- Argentina's Minister of War, Col. Juan Peron, received the foreign press at noon today and handed to them a written statement saying that the United States State Department summary of the lecture he delivered June 10 at the University of La Plata was mutilated and distorted in such a way as to alter completely the meaning of what he said.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, in New Guinea, Tuesday, July 4 -- American troops have landed on Numfor Island, roughly 100 miles west of Biak Island and 800 miles southeast of the Philippines, as Gen. Douglas MacArthur resumed his advance toward his announced goal.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 3 -- Lord Keynes, chairman of the British delegation to the United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference, described for the first time today the broad outlines of the plan for setting up of a $10,000,000,000 international bank for reconstruction and development to "guarantee" international loans somewhat after the fashion of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in domestic loans.

Three years ago this month the Germans took Minsk. It was then that Hitler himself began editing the official communiques. So the fall of the city was announced as the end of a "battle of annihilation" in which the flower of the Russian Army had been destroyed forever.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, July 3 -- Japanese-held New Britian is now a blackened ruin of blasted supply dumps, burned-out bivouacs and wrecked enemy planes created by our incessant air pounding, the New Zealand Air Department review of the South Pacific sky offensive said today.

PITTSBURGH, July 3 -- Two thousand delegates, representing most of America's million school teachers and administrators, meeting at their third wartime conference, pledged themselves today to work with members of the community to foster tolerance and better understanding of minority groups and races in this country.

Once again William Tilden furnished the big thrills yesterday in the Red Cross victory drive tennis exhibitions at Forest Hills. Played to a standstill in the first four games, the 51-year-old marvel of the sports world came back to challenge Lieut. (j.g.) W. Donald McNeill so cleverly that for a while there seemed a real prospect that the national champion of 1940 would lose to the champion of 1920.
WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The slump in consumer stocks of coal was halted in May for the first time in ten months, Harold L. Ickes, Solid Fuels Administrator, reported today.

Three more productions will quit Broadway on Saturday, thereby increasing the total to four. Newly added to the list, which started off with "Three Is a Family," are "Over Twenty-one," "Ramshackle Inn" and "For Keeps." These departures will whittle down the "To Be Continued" inventory to eighteen shows next week, four less than the same period last year.
LONDON, July 3 (AP) -- Another deadly parade of Nazi flying bombs droned over southern England tonight and an undisclosed number of American soldiers were among the day's victims of the Nazi weapon.

BEDFORD, N.H., July 3 (AP) -- Blowing scores of houses off their foundations and rocking an area seventy miles in radius, a terrific explosion blew apart the John P. Bedrick Powder Works late tonight, creating panic in near-by Manchester and surrounding communities.
Vice President, New York Central Railroad Company, Member Advisory Committee, Commerce and Industry Division, War Finance Committee for New York.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- Heavy sales of wheat futures by cash interests, said to have been hedging against large purchases of the actual article in the Southwest, gave the market a heavy undertone today on the Board of Trade. July dipped more than 2 cents a bushel from Saturday's finish to a new low since late last November and closing sales were about the bottom with net losses of 1 3/4 to 2 3/8 cents.

LONDON, Tuesday, July 4 -- Red Army forces yesterday captured the ancient White Russian capital of Minsk, last major enemy bastion in pre-war Russia on the road to Warsaw, while troops of the Soviet northern wing moving toward Latvia and Lithuania pushed into the streets of Polotsk, where vicious fighting was reported.

Herbert Brownell Jr., the new Republican National Chairman, announced yesterday that he will open his headquarters, from which he will direct the Republican Presidential campaign, in the Hotel Roosevelt tomorrow. Telephones, desks and filing cabinets were being installed yesterday in the suite.

Home decorators who have balked at going to the trouble and expense of calling in a carpenter to build window cornices or frames for drapery valences can look for a handy alternative in the new ready-made cornices announced last week by the Faraday Electrical Corporation, whose former stock in trade has been such things as electric bells, buzzers and hearing aids.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3 -- A registration statement covering 50,000 shares of 5 per cent $100 par value cumulative preferred stock was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Marathon Paper Mills Company, the name of which is to be changed this month to the Marathon Corporation.

The usual pre-holiday stalling factors were brushed aside yesterday by the stock market as a fresh forward movement developed under the sponsorship of the steels. Buyers enjoyed the advantage throughout the session with no hint of pressure, and this despite a slackening in business.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3 -- A registration statement covering 50,000 shares of 5 per cent $100 par value cumulative preferred stock was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Marathon Paper Mills Company, the name of which is to be changed this month to the Marathon Corporation.

The usual pre-holiday stalling factors were brushed aside yesterday by the stock market as a fresh forward movement developed under the sponsorship of the steels. Buyers enjoyed the advantage throughout the session with no hint of pressure, and this despite a slackening in business.

A poster showing a blue service star in a window and bearing the warning: "Don't Make This a Gold Star by Careless Talk," has been awarded first prize, and a poem entitled, "The Less Said the Less Dead," has won honorable mention in a city-wide "Safeguarding Military Information" contest of the Junior Auxiliary of the American Women's Voluntary Services, it was announced yesterday by Miss Alice Winslow, AWVS Greater New York Junior Auxiliary Director.

The German robot plane or "flying bomb" has been generally tagged in the press as a nuisance weapon. This assignment to a secondary place is justified. Though the device is ingenious and another proof of German scientific skill, the manner in which it is being applied cannot prove decisive.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY NURSE CORPS, In Italy, June 1 (Delayed) -- The Eighth Evacuation Hospital began to receive its first casualties at 10 A.M. today. By noon some 200 men had arrived and by twilight there were 200 more.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Wednesday, July 5 -- The campaign in Normandy has entered a new phase with American, Canadian and British forces smashing forward in two sectors.

The apartment house accommodating fifty-four families at 9100-9110 Hudson Boulevard, North Bergen, N.J., has been bought by Julius Vinik for investment from the Waldorf Apartments, Inc., through the C.B. Snyder Realty Company, brokers.

BOSTON, July 4 (AP) -- Bobby Doerr drove in five runs -- three with his eighth home run of the season -- to give the Red Sox a 7-to-4 victory and an even break with the Tigers today before 24,195 patrons. The Tigers took the first game, 4 to 3, for Hal Newhouser's twelfth verdict.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 4 (U.P.) -- French Forces of the Interior have cut the main railway line between Calais and southern Germany and have struck devastating blows against communication lines in widely scattered sections of France, an announcement issued today by authoritative French quarters disclosed.

CHUNGKING, China, July 4 (U.P.) Japanese forces, pushing on from the north and south along the Canton-Hankow Railway, today were 175 miles apart and Chinese authorities ordered civilian evacuation of Kweilin in Kwangsi and Shiuchow and Yingtak in Kwangtung.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 4 (AP) -- General strikes, which resulted in the resignation last week of Gen. Jorge Ubico, President of Guatemala, have spread to two other Central American republics, said reports reaching San Jose tonight.

MANCHESTER, Vt., July 4 -- The Robert Todd Lincoln Memorial golf tournament, for the benefit War Relief, Inc., was won today by Ray Hansbury, United Shoe Country Club, Beverly, Mass. He defeated the medalist and pre-tournament favorite, C.W. (Kiki) Price, Burlington Country Club, Burlington, Vt., in the final at the Ekwanok Country Club.

WITH THE BRITISH ARMY, Somewhere in France, July 4 -- All's well at the headquarters of Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery because the crusty, diminutive general whom the Germans fear as a ruthless foe now has some canaries -- three of them -- and also a love bird.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4 (AP) -- Making his first racing start since 1926, Jack Kelly, 1920 Olympic singles champion, stroked the Vesper Boat Club veteran senior quadruple sculls to a length victory over the University Barge Club crew in one of the features of the annual People's Day Regatta on the Schuylkill River today.

First the verdict and then the evidence, as Alice was astonished to find at one point in her Wonderland travels. But that was because Alice was only a child and the only kind of verdict she knew was in connection with jury trials.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 71:

WITH BRITISH AND CANADIAN FORCES, Near Caen, July 4 -- Clinging to the land that they love so much, Norman peasants went about their workaday chores in the midst of battle today as Canadian troops stormed and captured the village of Carpiquet, a key strong point in the defenses of Caen.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 4 -- Pete Lamberson and Jimmy Smith, Hempstead, played one-under-par golf -- 71 -- to defeat Lester G. Clark and George Stuhr Jr., Garden City Country Club, by 1 up in the final of the North Hempstead Country Club member-guest tourney today.
ROME, July 4 (AP) -- A communique:
The Millbrook Stable's Alex Barth, formerly known as Poacher, yesterday annexed the Yonkers Handicap on Empire City's National War Fund charity program at Jamaica.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Pre-convention talk of plans for the drafting of a brief, simple Democratic platform, standing pretty much on the Administration's record and programs without elaboration or reservation, to contrast with the nearly five thousand words of declarations and pledges adopted by the Republicans at Chicago last week, is raising questions in some Congressional quarters as to the effects of such a document on party nominees in general.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, started a campaign today to recruit 15,000 to 20,000 men "with the muscular equipment of football players" to work in foundries and forge shops.

LONDON, July 4 (AP) -- British and American tactical air operations over Normandy today were linked so closely with the ground fighting that fliers could see Allied soldiers swarming in to take German strong points that had just been "neutralized" from the air.
ROME, July 4 -- The fall of Siena indicates that Florence will be spared the devastation of war.

Volunteer workers in the Fifth War Loan Drive celebrated Independence Day yesterday with redoubled efforts to increase E bond sales through the campaign's final week. Though tabulations were not available, it was indicated that E bond sales for the Fourth of July would rank high on the list of one-day totals for the drive.
The two-family home at 2328 Eightieth Street, Brooklyn, has been sold through the office of Slomka Brothers for a client of Mario Musicaro.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The National War Labor Board today reversed a decision of its Sixth Regional Board in Chicago and remanded for further panel hearings the dispute between the Minneapolis branch of Sears Roebuck Co. and the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union (CIO).

CHICAGO, July 4 (AP) -- The 1944-45 "Who's Who in America," distribution of which began today, might well be called a wartime "silver and gold" edition -- silver for generals' stars and gold for admirals' braid.

That hoped-for break in the weather came too late yesterday afternoon to do the holiday matinee business any real good. Managers and ticket brokers said attendance would have been much better had there been rain or even threatening weather around noon, forcing amusement seekers to indoor attractions.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 4 (AP) -- Two defending New York State golf champions today demonstrated they may be hard to beat as Miss Kay Byrne of the Westchester Country Club won her opening match in the women's tournament and Duane L. Tower of Niagara Falls captured the medal in the men's senior division.

PITTSBURGH, July 4 -- A warning that the United States faces the greatest teacher shortage in its history with more than 70,000 trained instructors now lacking and the outlook for this fall gloomier than ever, was issued today by school leaders and administrators attending the sessions of the National Education Association.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4 (UP) -- Sigmund (Jack) Jakucki, a 62-year-old former soldier from Camden, N.J., and Honolulu, pitched his third shutout in four starts today as the league-leading Browns split a double bill with the Athletics before 23,858 fans.

Informed Americans know that this country is speedily approaching a moment of great decision, when the die will be cast for an expanding economy on the one hand or economic chaos on the other. There are certain policies which, if pursued, will make it possible for us to realize the great opportunity for prosperity which our expanded productive power gives us, but which, if omitted, can send us into an economic tailspin.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 4 -- Scooting along into the teeth of a thunder squall from the north, the trailers in a fleet of eighty-five craft, another top figure for the year, finished rail-under today in the sixty-third annual regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club, which was the eighth of the summer championship series.
STANTON, Del., July 4 (AP) -- Two track records fell today before a crowd of 18,453 that poured $1,213,996 through the mutuels.

According to reports from London, the still neutral capitals of Europe are again full of rumors and speculations about impending moves for peace. Such rumors have been a perennial accompaniment of this war, louder at some times than at others, but always bearing the easily recognized stamp of Axis origin.

Schools will be faced with a post-war demand to develop loyalty among children toward any international organization that will be established after the war, Dr. Goodwin Watson, Professor of Education at Teachers College, Columbia, University, declared yesterday at a college conference on "Elementary Schools of Tomorrow."

At the end of her first year of war against us Japan had seized every inch of land in the Pacific she believed would be of value to her with the exception of Australia and the Hawaiian Islands. The ocean map looked like a Japanese lake dotted with enemy strongholds.

PACIFIC FLEET HEADQUARTERS, Pearl Harbor, July 4 -- Widespread carrier aircraft attacks along Japanese islands, from the Bonins to the lower Marianas, have been carried out in the last two days as the Battle of Saipan neared its inevitable climax.

LONDON, July 4 -- Careful consideration is being given to the question of establishing a Jewish military formation of brigade size, Lord Croft told the House of Lords today, but he held out little hope for acceptance of a proposal to form a complete Jewish army under a British or United Nations command.

The opening of the black bass season in most of New York State last Saturday overshadowed the start of fishing for another and bigger fresh-water fighter, the muskalonge. The musky took second place quite property, for the anglers who try for bass greatly outnumber those who seek the striped tiger fish.

Interest in Bronx properties continues strong. One of the notable investment transactions announced yesterday was the five-story apartment house with stores at 757 East 169th Street, corner of Boston Road, purchased by a client of Thomas V. Tozzi, attorney, from the North Side Savings Bank.
A communique, as broadcast yesterday from Chungking in English to North America and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

PHILADELPHIA, July 4 -- The current offensives against Germany and Japan have so restricted the enemies' areas of occupation as to bring close at hand the time when the Axis forces "must stand and fight it out," Admiral Ernest J. King, Commander in Chief of the fleet and Chief of Naval Operations, asserted today in an Independence Day address before more than 50,000 of the civilian and military personnel at the Philadelphia Navy Yard.

Freight carloadings in the third quarter of this year are expected to be 9,948,356, an increase of 0.8 per cent over actual loadings of 9,871,654 in the third quarter last year, according to estimates compiled by the thirteen Shippers Advisory Boards. Seven of the boards estimate increases, but six forecast decreases.

FLAGSTAFF, Ariz., July 4 (AP) -- The Santa Fe's train, the Chief, speeding 158 passengers toward the West Coast, eased over a mountain hump, rounded a slight curve and headed into a long straightaway last night, then piled up in a spectacular wreck.
