WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle, who is due here this week, is expected to spend approximately three days in Washington.

WITH THE RED ARMY, in Rumania, July 4 (AP) -- It can now be said with complete conviction that the Russians in the initial venture of this war beyond their borders have adopted a strict attitude of non-intervention in local affairs.

Owners of dogs and other pets were advised yesterday by Daniel P. Woolley, Administrator of the Regional Office of Price Administration, that they did not have to pay extra apartment house rent for their pets unless it had been the landlord's custom to make a pet rental charge on March 1, 1943, the base at which rents here were frozen by the OPA.

A CHINESE FIELD HOSPITAL on the Salween Front, July 3 (Delayed) -- At random we selected one soldier from a long row of wounded who were lying on a straw-covered platform attached to the building. He was Corp. Kwan We-hui, a Szechwanese.

The National City Bank and the Guaranty Trust Company made Wall Street banking history yesterday by issuing complete reports of the make-up and extent of their earnings for the first half of 1944 in connection with their statements of condition as of June 30.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS on New Guinea, Wednesday, July 5 (AP) -- A communique:
CHUNGKING, China, July 4 (AP) -- A Fourteenth, United States Air Force communique:

At least one New Yorker spent the Fourth of July in New York and traveled at the same time. Although he did not go outside of the city he covered 103 miles. He was Mayor La Guardia, who went out yesterday to prove that New York was a city of play, that its recreational facilities could offer vacation fun to the millions who live in it.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Immediate enactment of an expanded social security system as proposed in the Wagner-Murray-Dingell bill was urged last night by Senator James E. Murray of Montana, one of the authors of the bill, at a meeting in Madison Square Garden under the auspices of the Jewish-American section of the International Workers Order.

The Swedish home radio said yesterday that the Danish Freedom Council, patriot organization that led the anti-Nazi general strike in Copenhagen, had issued a resolution "urging that work be resumed to the full extent tomorrow (Wednesday) morning."

A total of 194,057 turf followers wagered $8,763,036 at twelve race tracks yesterday, making an aggregate of $24,554,661 poured into the mutuel machines during the three racing days over the holiday period, The Associated Press reports.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- The Veterans Administration recommended today that the Federal Board of Hospitalization approve new building projects in twenty States for 16,000 additional hospital beds for veterans.
The Nazis continued yesterday to fish for information regarding the whereabouts of Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton Jr. and the American Seventh Army.

LONDON, July 4 -- American forces in Europe spent the Fourth of July fighting for independence, not celebrating it. Americans in southern England made nervous jokes about the free fireworks provided by Adolf Hitler. And Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden jokingly declared Britain's independence from the United States of America.
CHERBOURG, July 2 (Delayed) -- The French have proved themselves valuable allies in this first campaign on their home soil.

NEWARK, N.J., July 4 (AP) -- Newark hung a double defeat on Jersey City today before a crowd of 6,853. The Bears captured the opener, 6 to 5, then Mel Queen hurled an 8 -- 2 triumph in the seven-inning nightcap.

VENTNOR CITY, N.J., July 4 -- Both held to drawn games in the fourth round, Albert S. Pinkus and Anthony E. Santasiere, New York experts, remained tied for the lead tonight in the sixth annual invitation chess masters tournament on the Municipal Pier.
Administrative Assistant to the President, Fifth Avenue Coach Company Chairman, Commercial Section, Commerce and Industry Division, War Finance Committee for New York.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 4 -- Pierre Laval is not expected to remain long as "Chief of Government" in occupied France. The Germans have decided that he is "outdistanced" by his cabinet, according to several reliable sources today.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- The first trickle of surplus government-owned airplanes has begun to flow into the hands of civilians, the Defense Plant Corporation disclosed today.

Time was, before the mowing machine was invented, when a man's skill with snath and scythe was a matter of importance. The grass of the upland fields, and low-lying meadows was cut by hand. The countryman can remember when a dozen men, one offset behind the other, cut their swaths across big fields in the early morning when dew was still on the grass.

No wonder we use the expression "a good egg," says the United States Department of Agriculture in its new booklet caned "Egg Dishes for Any Meal," for this food has a triple value in the form of protein, vitamins and minerals. The booklet, prepared by the department's Bureau of Human Nutrition and Home Economics, gives a wealth of information on eggs, including fundamental rules for their care and storage, as well as twenty-five recipes.

LONDON, July 4 -- When monuments are put up on the Normandy beaches in the future, one of them should certainly be dedicated to the Navy demolition parties and it might well bear this inscription: "They were really tough potatoes."

WITH JOINT EXPEDITIONARY FORCE to the Marianas Islands (Delayed) -- Ten Canadian Army officers are accompanying units of the Twenty-seventh Army Infantry Division into battle on the Marianas as observers. Their presence in this task force forecasts eventual participation of Canadian troops against the Japanese, possibly not until the war in Europe is ended.

Six hundred thousand pairs of odd-lot shoes, including men's and women's styles in all sizes and boys' shoes, sizes 1 through 6, will go on sale ration free in New York City in the three weeks from July 10 through July 29, Daniel P. Woolley, Administrator of the Regional Office of Price Administration, announced yesterday.

Two large West Side apartment houses have been added to the recent investment purchases by Herman Knepper, president of the Knepper Management Corporation, operators. The larger of the two was the sixteen-story building at 230 West End Avenue, northeast corner of Seventieth Street, fronting 100 feet on the avenue by 70 feet on the street.

In an effort to inform the American public of the need for a "healthy foreign trade" after the war and the advantages of maintaining an adequate peacetime American merchant marine, the United States Lines will start soon a newspaper and magazine campaign along those lines.

In a masterful display of versatility Pvt. Frank L. Kovacs of Menlo Park, Calif., defeated Lieut. (j.g.) Donald McNeill of Quonset, R.I., 6 -- 4, 6 --4, yesterday as the Red Cross Victory Drive tennis exhibitions ended at Forest Hills.

CLEVELAND, July 4 (AP) -- Yankee Maid, owned by A.L. Derby of Wichita, Kan., won both heats of the $5,321 Championship Stallion Stake today, her second successive victory at the North Randall Grand Circuit meeting, to become an odds-on choice for the $40,000 Hambletonian Stake at Goshen, N.Y., on Aug. 9.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, July 5 (AP) -Numfor, the island off Netherland New Guinea invaded Sunday, has no seaworthy approaches and aerial reinforc, ement was the most efficient method available.

ROME, July 4 (U.P.) -- Americans of the Fifth Army, in a general advance in Italy, smashed through mine fields and artillery fire laid down by reinforced German units to points within fourteen airline miles of Leghorn and within eighteen and a half miles of a secondary road from Pisa to Florence.

"Going My Way," today enters its tenth and final week at the Paramount, thereby equaling the theatre's long-run record recently established by "Lady In The Dark." Paramount, the producers of the starring vehicle for Bing Crosby, announces that the picture's total gross receipts will exceed those of "Lady In The Dark."

ATLANTA, July 4 (AP) -- Senator Walter F. George won renomination in today's Democratic primary over a politically unknown opponent, sweeping every reporting county on the basis of unofficial returns.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, July 4 (U.P.) -- British troops, slogging through the rain-swept Manipur hills, have captured the Japanese base of Ukhrul, thirty-four miles northeast of Imphal, and have brought total Japanese casualties on the 700-mile Burma front to 40,000, it was announced today.
The letter from Edward S. Corwi published in your June 30 issue discusses constitutional procedure treaty making.

WASHINGTON, July 4 Permission to produce in the current fiscal year slightly more than onethird of the electric water heaters turned out for civilian use in the fiscal year 1940-41 was granted the industry today by the War Production Board. The quota is fixed on an annual basis.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 4 -- If leaders of the United States delegation to the United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference get their way, the highly controversial question of exchange rates for the post-war era will be delayed until some future date.
KANDY, Ceylon, July 4 (UP) -- A communique:

Apparently having exhausted ways and means of blowing ball games in the closing rounds, the Yanks sharply switched tactics yesterday to show 40,108 somewhat unappreciative onlookers how the same results could be obtained in the first inning as they dropped both ends of their twin bill with the Indians.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 4 -- The United States Government picked as its only woman delegate to the United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference Dr. Mabel Newcomer, head of the Economics Department of Vassar College.
LONDON, July 4 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

ROME, July 4 -- Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson arrived in Rome today on the first train from Naples while on the track next to his another train bearing more than 700 tons of coal crept into Benito Mussolini's new station.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Wednesday, July 5 -- American troops have advanced from one to two miles all along the front in the Cherbourg Peninsula, driving to a point near Ste. Catherine, one mile north of La Haye du Puits.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- Leroy Schalk's sharp single in the twelfth inning of the nightcap brought in the winning run as Chicago defeated Washington, 3 to 2, for an even break in a doubleheader today. The Senators blanked Chicago, 2 -- 0, in the opener behind Johnny Niggeling's four-hit hurling.

"The Second Chance" is the title chosen by the Princeton University Press for the symposium on America and the peace to be edited by John B. Whitton and published this fall. The book grew out of the work of the Princeton Group for the Study of Post-War International Problems.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Wednesday, July 5 -- The Allied air offensive swung into full strength again yesterday.

ALBANY, July 4 -- Dr. Marion S. Van Liew, head of the Bureau of Home Economics in the State Education Department since 1930, retired today. She began her work in 1913 as head of the Home Economics Department of the State College for Teachers in Albany.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4 -- Four plans filed in connection with the reorganization of the Portland Electric Power Company under Chapter X of the Bankruptcy Act were disapproved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which as an alternative proposed in broad outlines another solution designed to meet the complex problems involved in the case.

By signing a bill which gives the United States Public Health Service the authority to make grants-in-aid for medical research in public or private institutions, increase appropriations to States engaged in general public health work, establish a national tuberculosis program and foster preventive medicine, the President has enabled the Government to take a forward step in safeguarding the population against disease.

CHICAGO, July 4 (AP) -- Georgie Drum, a five-year-old gelding, who only a couple of years ago was running in cheap races on the Pacific Coast, bounced into major competition today by winning the $59,350 Stars and Stripes Handicap at the Arlington Park meeting to thrill a crowd of 36,000.

EARLY in the eighteenth century, when the Sun King ruled with such effulgent splendor and such military might that Versailles "was the Berchtesgaden of the baroque age," the ladies of Spain used to rouge their shoulder blades. In Spain, too, the pure essence of blue-blooded nobility could be judged by the size of the lenses in spectacles.
STOCKHOLM, July 4 -- Danish patriots dynamited the southern part of the harbor of Aarhus, on the east coast of the Jutland mainland today, totally wrecking a large section of the port.
LONDON, July 4 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:
The War Food Administration announced yesterday an end of its support purchases of "current receipts" of eggs.

NEWARK, N.J., July 4 (AP) -- The Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company marked America's third wartime Independence Day by launching three fighting vessels, a heavyweight destroyer and two destroyer escorts, from its Kearny and Newark yards.
CAIRO, Egypt, July 4 (AP) -- A Middle East air communique:

PITTSBURGH, July 4 (AP) -- The Pirates won the second game of a double-header from Philadelphia, 4 -- 0, today behind Max Butcher, after losing the opener, 3 -- 2, before 16,285 fans. Butcher scattered eight singles over nine innings to beat Big Bill Lee.

LONDON, Wednesday, July 5 -- Russian troops yesterday captured the outflanked, five-point rail junction of Polotsk, gateway to the Baltic States, as two Soviet armies, advancing up to twenty-seven miles in twenty-four hours, launched a two-pronged drive against Vilna.

Creation of a group of prominent American business, banking and educational representatives to assist in the solution of pressing post-war international economic problems was announced yesterday by Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board of the Chase National Bank.

LONDON, July 4 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden told the House of Commons today that the War Cabinet had decided it was advisable for Prime Minister Churchill to withhold his statement on the Germans' flying bombs until Thursday.

In surrendering to Major General Collins, General von Schlieben evaded the unconditional surrender formula. He imposed on his adversary the condition of his personal safety but refused to give the stop-fire order to his soldiers.

Harry Friedgut, managing director of the New York City Center of Music and Drama, was reported yesterday to be resigning his post in a dispute with the City Center management. It was understood that the dispute centered around matters of policy in the running of the municipally sponsored project.

CHICAGO, July 4 (AP) -- After being in the cellar continuously since the first week of the season, the Cubs climbed to seventh place today by defeating the Braves twice, 7 to 1 and 4 to 2, before 31,718 fans. The defeats put the Braves in last place.

ATLANTA, Ga., July 4 -- Negroes were refused ballots when they attempted to vote in the Georgia Democratic primary today and thereby laid the basis for legal action. There were no reports of incidents because of the refusal by election officials.

BALTIMORE, July 4 (AP) -- Fire of undetermined origin razed the stands of famed Oriole Park, home of the Baltimore International League Club, today, causing a loss estimated by club officials at $150,000.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (U.P.) -- Axis broadcasts said today that 'heavy fighting" was in progress between the Japanese and Allied task force units at Chichi and Iwo Islands, 600 and 725 miles southeast of Tokyo, implying that Allied forces had landed there.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Norman Armour, who has been recalled from his post as Ambassador in Buenos Aires for consultations with Secretary of State Cordell Hull, arrived today and held his first conversation with Mr. Hull in the State Department late this afternoon.
The American Chain and Cable Company, Inc., has acquired the business of the Pennsylvania Lawn Mower Works at Primos, Pa.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 4 -- Gloria Hallward, local actress, who was in the Chicago cast of "Goodnight Ladies" for a year but more recently appeared on Broadway in "Star Dust" and "A Highland Fling," has been signed to a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer term contract. .Her first screen part will be the romantic' juvenile lead in the proposed "Autumn Fever," to be directed by Richard Whorf.

Assemblyman Peter A. Quinn has been picked by the Bronx Democratic organization to succeed Representative James M. Fitzpatrick as a member of Congress from the Twenty-sixth district, it was disclosed yesterday. Mr. Quinn recently declined renomination to the Assembly at the same time that Mr. Fitzpatrick withdrew as a candidate for Congress.

In a communication forwarded last week to the United States Government, General de Gaulle emphasized that his sole purpose in visiting this country was to pay his respects to the President and to do homage to the American war effort.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Thirty-eight survivors of the American freighter Richard Hovey have been rescued after sixteen days adrift in a lifeboat under a blistering sun in the Arabian Sea following the sinking of their ship by a Japanese submarine, the War Shipping Administration announced today.

ST. LOUIS, July 4 -- All the celebrating was done by the Cardinals today at Sportsman's Park. The Giants were just so many props on the field as Billy Southworth paraded his sluggers around the basepaths and captured both ends of the holiday double-header, 6 -- 2 and 9 -- 1.

LONDON, July 4 -- There is one psychological aspect of the German's robot attack on southern England that Adolf Hitler probably overlooked when he launched his crewless planes against this country. That is the way in which it has drawn American troops and the British people together.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (U.P.) -- War appropriations have "passed their peak" and, barring serious military reverses, will diminish at an accelerated rate until the end of hostilities, Representative Clarence Cannon, Democrat of Missouri and chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, said today.

The Russian forces are sweeping along the historic road to Warsaw and Berlin. Travelers familiar with that route remember how endless and featureless is the encompassing plain. This correspondent once thought of it as a vast blank page waiting for headlines -- and the headlines are now being written in blazing letters, Cyrillic superimposed on Gothic, by the retreating and pursuing armies.
With travel curtailed and more children staying at home this summer, the Junior Museum program in Newark, N.J., has been expanded greatly for the vacation season.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 4 (AP) -- Communique 57:

The race relations department of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America will present a $1,000 United States savings bond next February to the American citizen, white or Negro, whose work in the removal of racial tensions and conflicts has been outstanding, it was announced yesterday by the department's executive secretary, Dr. George E. Haynes.
CINCINNATI, July 4 -- The Dodgers have yet to win a game on this trip and their feelings tonight are in a state of lamentable laceration.

THE letter arrived a couple of days after this reporter had had a chance to chat with Zach Wheat. Since the request in the opening sentence was taken care of the floor will be turned over to Roy Skelly of Brooklyn to do a little raving on his own account about his favorite ball player. He wrote:
New York celebrated a particularly safe and sane Fourth of July with only one fireworks accident and none of the expected jams of homecomers.
WITH THE AMERICAN FORCES, in France, July 4 -- The bright spot of today's fighting was a Fourth of July celebration arranged by Lieut. Gen. Omar N. Bradley at the expense of the Germans.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 4 -- Differences of opinion developed today as the working committees of the United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference came to grips with specific problems involved in the proposed post-war international monetary fund.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, July 5 -- Supported by tanks, paratroop forces that landed on Numfor Island on July 2 have established a strong perimeter around captured Kamiri airfield and are advancing toward Kornasoren airport against scattered enemy opposition, Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters announced today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 4 -- Denmark's Freedom Council has directed the Copenhagen population to resume work tomorrow after a five-day general strike and street rioting that wrung concessions from the German occupation authorities, the Free Danish press service reported today.

BOSTON, July 4 (AP) -- Setting a scorching pace, Louis B. Mayer's Whirlabout, a small filly with a big heart, today captured the $25,000 added Yankee Handicap at a mile and three-sixteenths for 3-year-olds before 28,338 patrons at Suffolk Downs.

Gen. Charles de Gaulle's arrival in this country tomorrow will be a happy augury for better relations between our Government and the French Committee of National Liberation. General de Gaulle will be welcomed by those who do not have to worry about diplomatic protocol but who have an honest admiration for the gallant soldier who refused to betray his country and his country's allies.

Vacation days are here. People will soon be leaving for the country, mountains and seashore, many taking with them carefully selected books for their summer's reading. Will readers of THE TIMES remember the merchant seamen who are playing such a deeply significant part in the war and mail to us those books they have themselves enjoyed?

A new issue of $35,000,000 of New York City revenue bills was sold yesterday by Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick by allotment to the syndicate of twenty-five banks and trust companies that customarily buys the city's bill issues.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 5 -- Mrs. Ernest Lundeen, widow of Senator Lundeen, was married to Senator Rufus C. Holman of Portland, Ore., by Judge Levi M. Hall of the Hennepin District Court at the judge's home here last night.

AN EIGHTH AIR FORCE FIGHTER BASE in Britain, July 5 (AP) -- Lieut. Col. Francis Gabreski, 25-year-old Thunderbolt pilot, who wanted to shoot down a twenty-eighth German plane before going home to get married, got his wish today when he knocked down a Messerschmitt 109 near Evreux, France, and became the top-scoring ace in the United States Army Air Forces.

ALBANY, July 5 -- Thomas E. Dewey, while revealing a part of his own campaign plans, today challenged President Roosevelt to carry out persistently reported plans to make some major campaign move on the battlefields abroad, such as the delivery from Normandy of the acceptance speech to the Democratic convention.

WASHINGTON, July 5--The War Department has sent a group of officers overseas to help members of the armed forces who wish to vote in the November elections. Twenty-four of these officers already have left for the major war theatres and more will be assigned in the next few weeks.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 5 -- Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Under-Secretary of State, speaking at the 178th anniversary commencement of Rutgers University, declared today that the future security of the world depended not on one nation alone but upon "the peace-loving nations of the world learning to work together in peace as they have learned to work together in war."

VATICAN CITY, July 5 -- Secretary of War Henry L. Stimsom was received in private audience by Pope Pius XII this morning for a half-hour's talk, which, together with similar audiences that Myron C. Taylor, President Roosevelt's personal representative to the Vatican, has had in recent weeks, will undoubtedly take a prominent part when the diplomatic histories of World War II are written in later years.

"Sensations of 1945," a musical starring Eleanor Powell, will have its local premiere this morning at Loew's State. Produced and directed by Andrew Stone for United Artists release, the film features Dennis O'Keefe, W.C. Fields, Eugene Pallette, Sophie Tucker, C. Aubrey Smith, Lyle Talbot and Mimi Forsythe.

Detectives and uniformed policemen searched Staten Island in vain last night for four husky boys, the oldest 15 years old, who had escaped twice Tuesday from the shelter of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children at 118 Castleton Avenue, Tompkinsville, S.I.

CHUNGKING, China, July 5 (AP) -- The wild, mountainous terrain is delaying a meeting of the Chinese fighting along the Yunnan-Burma border and Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's American and Chinese forces in North Burma, although they are only twenty-six miles apart.

Beginning today it will be illegal to sell plums in this city at more than 18 1/2 cents a pound or apricots at more than 19 1/2 cents. These fruits have been selling at from 35 to 50 cents a pound, according to Daniel P. Woolley, regional head of the Office of Price Administration, who announced yesterday they were going on the weekly price ceiling list of fresh fruits and vegetables for the first time.

The average daily attendance at elementary and junior high schools in 1943 dropped to a level lower than at any time since 1918, it was revealed yesterday in the annual financial and statistical report of the Board of Education.

Mr. and Mrs. Felix E. Notebaert of Montreal and New York, who are spending the summer at the Seigniory Club in Canada, have been joined there by Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Notebaert of 434 East Fifty-second Street.

LONDON, July 5 -- Encouraged by the latest war news, the stock markets here today were cheerful. Buying was in good volume and support was given to gilt-edge issues and leading industrials and Kaffirs.
WITH THE BRITISH ARMY, in France, July 5 -- The Canadian and British advance toward Caen met a slight setback today.

Supported by a strong buying movement in the steel section, the stock market confirmed yesterday the previous high marks of this year and then proceeded to exceed that level. Two moderate waves of profit-taking were brushed aside easily, with only a slight retreat from the best figures as volume reached the second heaviest so far in 1941.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The Republican platform plank relating to Negroes, which calls for a permanent Fair Employment Practice Commission; immediate action looking to repeal of poll taxes through a constitutional amendment, and hints at an early move to revive anti-lynching legislation, is causing concern among Democrats in Congress over how this phase of their 1944 platform will be handled in view of the repeated intra-party fights on these questions.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 5 (AP) -- Communique 59:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Thursday, July 6 (U.P.) -- While American troops on Numfor Island, off Netherland New Guinea, captured the Kornasoren airdrome on Tuesday, Royal Australian Air Force crews prepared the near-by Kamiri airstrip for operation, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 5 (AP) -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Supreme Commander of the Allied Invasion Forces, has returned to his headquarters in England after a five-day trip in Normandy, where he held conferences with Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery and Lieut. Gen. Omar N. Bradley, and went on a Fourth of July fighter plane sweep behind the German lines.

LONDON, July 5 -- Prime Minister Churchill is expected tomorrow to dispel some of the mystery surrounding what has been happening in this country since Adolf Hitler pushed the button that started robot bombs flying over this country.

All cosmetic preparations and beauty items are available today, though sometimes in limited quantities, a survey of leading New York department stores reveals. While a woman may not be able to go to one store and conveniently buy there all her beauty needs, she can, if she is willing to shop at several stores, find all her requirements.
ROME, July 5 (AP) -- A communique:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 5 -- Mrs. Renee Guy Perkins Hatch, 31 years old, wife of Lieut. Aldis B. Hatch Jr. of the Navy, was booked today on two charges of first-degree murder for the slaying last night of her children, Georgette, 3 years old, and Aldis, 16 months.

Culminating a six-month period in which trade here set new records for dollar volume, sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 11.6 per cent in June over the like month last year, according to the monthly survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The dictionaries define politics as the science and art of government and politicians as persons who practice these. But the Political Action Committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, which is committed to the re-election of President Roosevelt, Vice President Wallace and lesser candidates for office who are "friendly to labor," is making more practical definitions.

Hitler has made another speech, the second since the beginning of the all-out offensive against Germany, in which he still presumes to talk of no capitulation and final victory. But even his long-deluded people must now be impressed by the way in which the stature of this would-be world conqueror shrinks with each successive utterance.
PITTSBURGH, July 5 (AP) -- Philadelphia played only ten innings against the Pirates today but gained two victories, 9 -- 4 and 12 -- 2.

The Chase National Bank reported yesterday that, as of June 30, its deposits were $4,677,872,688 and its total resources $4,990,182,843, high records, not only for this bank but for any commercial bank in the world. Three months ago the respective figures were $4,457,581,731 and $4,765,999,575.

That script Jed Harris was angling for last week now belongs to him. Temporarily called "Home Fires," the comedy is the work of Reita Lambert and calls for an all-women cast of eight. The entire plot, which concerns the wives of soldiers, develops in Washington.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 5 -- George Brent, who is to be co-starred with Hedy Lamarr in "Experiment Perilous" in two weeks at RKO, has been signed by the studio to a contract calling for two additional pictures within a year. The company has signed an associate producer contract with William Pereira, who recently was co-producer of "Guest in the House" with Hunt Stromberg.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Secretary Henry J. Morgenthau Jr. announced today that the official Treasury Department circulars governing the current offering of 2 1/2 per cent Treasury Bonds of 1965-70 and 2 per cent Treasury Bonds of 1952-54 have been amended to permit deferred payment for such bonds allotted to life insurance companies, to savings institutions and to States, municipalities, political subdivisions and similar public corporations and agencies thereof.

All but a few of the candidates originally designated by the American Labor party for public offices at stake in this fall's elections were replaced last night, as the deadline for substitutions was reached, with Democrats and Republicans who are receiving ALP endorsements.

LONDON, July 5 -- British submarines operating in Far Eastern waters have taken a heavy toll of enemy supply shipping in recent actions, sinking a total of nine ships, the Admiralty announced in a communique today.

Cotton mill men have mixed feelings with reference to increases in prices of cotton textiles covering about one-third of the industry's production, averaging 7 1/2 per cent, but the majority is inclined to believe that a step has been taken in the right direction with probably "more equitable" pricing to result.
I believe there would be little need to appeal for workers on surgical dressings if more information were given to the public as to how these are used and why they are needed in such vast quantities.

Eddie Arcaro, Kentucky-bred jockey, forced of late to watch Ted Atkinson and Bobby Permane take the bows, caught the riding fever yesterday at Jamaica and got it bad with three triumphs and one second on his first four mounts.
It was a big holiday fishing week-end. That much can be said without equivocation, but the results depended on where the fishermen went and what they were after, a check yesterday showed.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- Criminal informations charging eighty-nine violations of the Emergency Price Control Act were filed by the Government in the Federal District Court today against Swift Co., Armour Co. and Wilson Co., alleging coercive sales to butchers in this city.

As an aid to Victory gardeners, and all others who are complying with the Government's request to do as much home canning as possible this year, the American Soil Products Company has brought out a compact and useful guide. It consists of a flat cardboard disk, about a foot in diameter, containing directions for canning fruits and vegetables.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 5 -- German "carelessness" engendered by more than two years of successful concealment of the existence of two "model extermination camps for Jews" at Auschwitz and Birkenau, in Upper Silesia, has finally led to the revelation of many startling facts and figures concerning their operation for the two years ended April 15, 1944, during which the execution and "disposal" of 1,715,000 Jews were effected "without a hitch."

Attorney General N.L. Goldstein threw a bombshell into the department stores and similar establishments by declaring that vitamins are drugs and may be sold only by drug stores. But what is a drug store nowadays? Apparently a place where sandwiches, sundaes, books, electric lamps, candy, razor blades, tobacco, toilet articles, perfumes are dispensed as well as the items that we associate with a pharmacy.

A survey of public opinion to help industry in its public relationships, including war and postwar advertising campaigns, will be inaugurated by the Association of National Advertisers, it was announced yesterday. The study will be made under the direction of the group's public relations committee, of which Charles C. Carr of the Aluminum Company of America is president, with Opinion Research Corporation, Princeton, N.J., doing the research work.
A composite index of American life for the week now drawing to a close would give the following picture:
CHUNGKING, China, July 5 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

ROME, July 5 (U.P.) -- American forces have driven into the outskirts of Rosignano, twelve airline miles below Leghorn, headquarters disclosed today, but German defenses were thickening and more enemy tanks and big guns were lumbering down from the north toward the Fifth Army's front.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Seventeen more enemy vessels, including two warships, have been sunk by United States submarines in the Pacific and the Far East, the Navy announced today. Simultaneously dispatches from London reported the sinking by British submarines of nine Japanese supply ships in Far Eastern waters during recent patrols. Two other Japanese ships were damaged by British undersea craft in the same operations.

In his letter published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of June 25 Elisha M. Friedman pleads for flexible wage rates. When he advocates a wage scale that will slide up or down with the cost of living, few will quarrel with him. Other things being equal, the increase or decrease in money wage to compensate for fluctuations in cost of living merely results in a real wage which is constant.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The exploratory conversations between representatives of the United States, Britain, Russia and China on the formation of a world organization to enforce the peace have been delayed because of their failure to reach agreement on questions of approach and procedure.

VENTNOR CITY, N.J., July 5 -- Albert S. Pinkus and Anthony E. Santasiere, New Yorkers who share the lead in the sixth annual chess masters' tournament on the Municipal Pier, met today in the fifth round. The result was a well-played draw in twenty-eight moves.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Thursday, July 6 -- The Allies are punching out small gains on the western and eastern sectors of the Normandy front despite heavy enemy counter-attacks and stiffening resistance all along the line.
WASHINGTON, July 5--The official reception for Gen. Charles de Gaulle, who is expected here tomorrow, will approximate that reserved for heads of States, it is understood tonight.

CHICAGO, July 5 (AP) -- Jim Tobin, the Boston Braves' master of the "butterfly" pitch, fluttered his knuckleball past the Cubs for his season's ninth victory, 7 to 2, today and thereby returned the Chicagoans to the cellar after their one night of disinterment since April.

Mayor La Guardia's proposed "transportation tax," consisting mainly of a tax on rents, received faint praise yesterday from Russell V. Cruikshank, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, who declared that the real answer to the city's fiscal troubles arising from its subway deficit was an increased fare.

CHUNGKING, China, July 5 (U.P.) -- Chinese forces, battling desperately to prevent a junction of the north and south hooks of a Japanese pincers driving on the vital Canton-Hankow railroad, have killed 7,300 Japanese in the past ten days, it was announced today.
WITH THE AMERICAN FORCES, In France July 5 -- Today's fighting in this sector was just hard slugging for small gains against stiffening German resistance.

LONDON, July 5 (AP) -- A dare-devil squadron of Royal Air Force Mosquito planes braved the world's most heavily defended waterway on the moonlit night of May 12, sowing mines that blocked traffic in the Kiel Canal for ten days in a spectacular pre-invasion preparation, it was disclosed today.

The problem of communism has "practically disappeared" at City College, Prof. John J. Theobald, chairman of the faculty committee on student activities, declared yesterday. The committee presented to the general faculty a report on student affairs in which it declared that the group was "convinced that the number of actual Communists among the students is small.
KANDY, Ceylon, July 5 (UP) -- A communique:

While Americans returned to work yesterday after celebrating the Fourth of July, they learned that what had been estimated earlier as a comparatively safe holiday week-end had resulted in the death of 447 persons, The Associated Press reported.

PACIFIC FLEET HEADQUARTERS, Pearl Harbor, July 5 -- American forces are crowding the enemy on Saipan hack into a death trap on Marpi Point at the northern end of the island and Admiral Chester W. Nimitz said today that the battle was near the end.
LONDON, July 5 -- As the Allies expand their beachhead in France, the job of the Navy's minesweepers -- the unhonored and unsung "toilers of the sea" -- becomes more and more difficult and dangerous.

LONDON, Thursday, July 6 -- As Berlin disclosed that the great Nazi base at Kovel, southwest of the Pripet Marshes, had been evacuated "to shorten German lines" in South Central Poland, the onrushing Red Army swept to within 143 miles of the pre-1939 border of East Prussia yesterday and began an all-out assault in the direction of Vilna, Lida, Baranovichi and Luninets, a chain of intermediate German defense strongpoints along the vital north-south railroad.

Reports I have received from all over the State indicate that labor is greatly exceeding the generous response which it gave to previous War Loan appeals. The D-day invasion is now successfully launched and we of the trade union movement realize that we must back up our fighting men with every dollar and every ounce of energy.

A syndicate headed by Leo J. Margolin, which owns the building at 141 West Seventeenth Street, has purchased the adjoining six-story loft building at 135-37 West Seventeenth Street, on a plot 68 by 96 feet, through the S. Goodman Company, broker.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Thursday, July 6 -- Flying Fortresses and long-range Mustang fighters of the United States Eighth Air Force, numbering about 200 planes in all, landed in England yesterday after completing a 7,000-mile mission that took them to Russia, then Italy and finally on a bombing strike in South France on the way back here.

A vaccine against infantile paralysis, prepared by a new method, which in tests on mice has given "a high degree of protection" against a special mouse-strain of infantile paralysis virus subsequently injected into their brains, is announced in the forthcoming issue of The Journal of the American Medical Association.
GENERAL EISENHOWER'S ADVANCE COMMAND POST, July 5 (AP) -- The whole purpose of General Dwight D. Eisenhower's five-day trip was to enable him to study the front himself.

ST. LOUIS, July 5 -- One savage thrust by an old team-mate sent the Giants to their third straight defeat tonight at Sportsman's Park. Ken O'Dea, who used to do some catching for the Polo Ground troupe, exploded his second home run of the campaign atop the right- field pavilion with two aboard in the third inning and this blow carried the Cardinals to their seventh victory in a row, 4 to 1.

Frederick Brown has sold the six-story garden apartment house at 960 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, to the 960 Grand Concourse. Inc., of which Frederick P. Galardi is president. The property, assessed at $435,000, is opposite Joyce Kilmer Park.
BOSTON, July 5 (AP) -- Paul (Dizzy) Trout pitched his tenth victory today, scattering eight hits in as many innings as the Tigers defeated the Red Sox, 8 to 1, in twilight game.

The first New York performance of a "Pastel Sonore" by the contemporary French composer, Albert Verley, was given by the Philharmonic-Symphony orchestra under the direction of Vladimir Golschmann at Lewisohn Stadium last night. M. Verley, a scientist by profession and a musician by avocation, is now living in New York and was at the Stadium to acknowledge the applause of the audience.

Reductions of 1 to 2 cents a pound in the retail ceiling prices of poultry, both live and dressed, were announced yesterday for this city by the Office of Price Administration. In lowering the price ceilings, effective today, Daniel P. Woolley, regional OPA head, brought the legal limits closer to actual selling prices. These have been several cents below ceilings more than a week because of the abundance of poultry in the local market.

Waste paper salvaged throughout the city yesterday by Department of Sanitation trucks dropped to 380 tons, or sixteen tons less than was collected on the preceding Wednesday, but officials of the War Production Board and the Real Estate Board of New York said their "house-cleaning plan" for office buildings is now well under way and is augmenting considerably the weekly tonnage totals of paper sent to mills for conversion into containers for war supplies.

Elton E. (Tad) Wieman, who succeeded Fritz Crisler as head football coach at Princeton in 1938 and continued in that post until he became chief of the Army's college physical training program after the 1942 season, yesterday was named line coach at Columbia University under Lou Little.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 5 -- The Greek political situation crystallized further today into a deadlock and a crisis when the Cabinet met all morning and decided that the terms submitted by the Left Wing Eam in Greece on which any cooperation with the Government of Premier George Papandreou could be agreed on were excessive and unacceptable.

Corporations and other non-banking investors have far oversubscribed their Fifth War Loan quotas, increasing national sales through Monday to $14,984,000,000, or 94 per cent of the $16,000,000,000 goal, the Treasury Department announced yesterday.

Thoughtful attention should be given the recent report of the Welfare Council in which a number of important community projects are outlined. A federation of 600 welfare and health agencies in New York City, the council has achieved distinction in the social-work field, and its recommendations for that reason are worthy of consideration.
WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- Dutch Leonard, veteran knuckle- baller, held Chicago to five blows tonight as Washington defeated the White Sox, 3 to 1.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 5 (AP) -- Contending that an order of the Interstate Commerce Commission increasing intrastate passenger railway fares violates regulations of the Office of Price Administration, the OPA tendered today a petition to Federal Court here asking that it be made a party to a suit on file against the ICC by the Kentucky, Alabama Tennessee Railway.
LONDON, July 5 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:
The following awards for valor were announced yesterday by the armed forces:

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, July 5 (U.P.) -- Rain-drenched Gurkha riflemen battled today to clear the last remaining Japanese resistance groups from Ukhrul as the Southeast Asia Command announced the recent visit of Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten to the monsoon-swept Kohima-Imphal area.

CINCINNATI, July 5 -- There is no balm for the Dodgers on this Western tour. They continued their precipitous plunge down the second division stairway today as Bill McKechnie's Reds beat them, 4 -- 1, behind the three-hit pitching of Ed Heusser to run the Brooklyn losing streak to nine games.

Several thousand boys and girls, dripping wet from the showers, swarmed into seventeen city pools yesterday morning as the Department of Parks opened its free "Learn to Swim" campaign for children of 6 to 14. Lesson hours are 10:30 for boys, 11:15 for girls.

Data filed with the New York Stock Exchange disclosed yesterday that Marjorie Post Davies, wife of former Ambassador Joseph E. Davies, was the owner of 76,900 shares of the General Foods Corporation, which was sold in a secondary distribution here on June 1.

When the Japanese thrust from Hankow toward the China coast swept around Hengyang and forced General Chennault's fliers from one of their main fields it was assumed that the city itself had fallen. The assumption was wrong. Surrounded and battered, Hengyang still stands.

WHEN the last peace was made, the Russians, then in the midst of civil war, had nothing to say about it. But this time they will have plenty to say. Need the nations of the West fear the result? It is the firm belief of Sir Bernard Pares, eminent British authority on Slavonic studies, that the West has nothing to fear.

A residence club for girls who may become confirmed delinquents if they remain in bad home environments is one of the most critical needs in the city's program to reduce juvenile and adolescent delinquency, according to magistrates and probation officers of the Wayward Minors Court.

One interesting item keeps cropping up in this war, just as it did in the last one. James MacDonald refers to it in a dispatch to this newspaper from a hot spot near Caen. He saw the Norman peasants going "about their workaday chores in the midst of battle," plowing, harrowing, looking after their livestock or "driving their donkey-drawn milk carts toward Bayeux."

PITTSBURGH, July 5 -- Reporting on a recent country-wide tour, Mrs. Agnes E. Meyer, co-owner with her husband, Eugene Meyer, of The Washington Post, told 2,000 teachers and administrators today at the National Education Associaciation convention that 4,000,000 children were now receiving an inadequate education.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- Government buying mistakenly believed to be a move to bolster wheat prices caused a rally today of 2 1/2 to 3 3/4 cents a bushel from early lows, and closing sales on the Chicago Board of Trade were up 1 3/8 to 2 5/8 cents over Friday's final prices, July leading.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Pressed by an "urgent need" for cotton goods in the Middle East which is not being met by private exporters, the Foreign Economic Administration announced today that the United States Commercial Corporation will buy that portion of the second quarter allocation of textiles for export to Middle East areas that has not been taken up in commercial channels.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 5 -- Strong nerves and yet greater endurance power alone will enable the German people to measure up to the demands of the hour, Adolf Hitler told a gathering of Reich war production leaders at his headquarters in Berchtesgaden yesterday, according to German accounts today.

Manager Joe McCarthy devoted yesterday's forenoon to a deal of heavy thinking as he performed a series of major and minor operations on his line-up and batting order in the hope of snapping his flagging Yankees into the American League pennant race.

Edward J. Flynn yesterday invited the major Democratic leaders of the State to take part in a conference Monday on the selection of a successor to James A. Farley as State chairman. The invitations were issued in Mr. Flynn's capacity as Democratic national committeeman from New York.

Noting that tomorrow, the seventh day of the seventh month, is the seventh anniversary of China's war against Japanese aggression, leaders of six national organizations concerned with Chinese-American cooperation called yesterday for "Triple 7" tributes to China by patriotic, religious and economic organizations.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 5 (AP) -- Max Marmorstein's Best Reward, a $26.20 return on a $2 investment, drove to victory today in the $7,500 added Camden handicap, feature event as Garden State Park opened its third wartime season.
Romantic hats employing color harmonies, jewels and rich fabrics to enhance their femininity typified the collection presented yesterday by Reine at 4 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange again closed firm yesterday at the best levels of the day or at net gains of 25 to 36 points on active months. All months established new highs for the life of the contracts, and were at new sixteen-year highs.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Thursday, July 6 (UP) -- A communique:
PACIFIC FLEET HEADQUARTERS, Pearl Harbor, July 5 -- The turret gunner saw flames but he was suddenly hot and the turret itself was getting warmer and beginning to steam. He knew the plane was afire.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Vegetable and field seeds are playing a growing part in lend-lease shipments from the United States as land formally held or dominated by Germany is being freed for production of foodstuffs for the United Nations, Leo T. Crowley, Foreign Economic Administrator, revealed today.
WITH THE ALLIES In Normandy, July 5 (U.P.) -- The runway of the Carpiquet airdrome marks the border line of a bitter battle. It divides the Germans and the Canadians.

An aftermath of the Reno gambling syndicate, which up to 1938 had cheated a hundred victims out of $2,500,000, developed yesterday with the arrest in Shreveport, La., of an alleged confidence man described by Postal Inspector Herbert N. Graham as Hillary Mayn, alias "Mexican Fred."

WASHINGTON, July 5--President Roosevelt today vetoed a bill that would have permitted a corporation to sue the United States in the Court of Claims for damages allegedly suffered in loss of a contract because contracting officers of the Government threw out a low bid on the ground that the manner in which it was offered did not conform to specific standards.

Representing what is believed to be the largest and most complete display of war products of any major industrial producer, the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company this evening will open its special exhibit in the Grand Ballroom of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

PHILADELPHIA, July 5 -- A registration statement covering 86,310 shares of $1 par value common stock of National Automotive Fibres, Inc., of Detroit, was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

A twenty-year-old mother, whose conscience bothered her, went to the Kings County District Attorney's office Monday and told members of the staff that she and her husband had buried their three-week-old daughter after the infant had died suddenly.

Walter Lippmann, columnist and author of "United States Foreign Policy," published in 1943 by Little, Brown, is the author of a peace plan called "United States War Aims," which will be released on Monday by the same house.

BRETTON WOODS, N. H., July 5--Harry D. White, member of the United States delegation and authorized spokesman for the United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference, said today that the conference may have to adjourn on July 20 without reaching a complete agreement.

Earnings of the Schenley Distillers Corporation for the nine months ended on May 31, last, after all charges including $2,250,000 provision for contingencies and post-war adjustments, but before taxes, rose to $49,733,684 from $25,131,738 earned on the same basis in the corresponding period of the previous year, the report disclosed yesterday.

While blocked sterling balances in England have risen sharply during the course of the war, too much attention and emphasis has been placed on the danger of such balances to the future of international trade, Thomas R. Wilson, chief of the British Empire Unit of the Department of Commerce, asserted in a statement made public yesterday at a meeting of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
A communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

AURORA, Ill., July 5 (AP) -- Seated in a rocking chair under a huge oak tree on the lawn of her home, Mrs. Friedericka E. Truemper, an invalid, yesterday accepted the Congressional Medal of Honor awarded posthumously to her son.

Problems of price and the use of the material in manufacturing are posed by the authorization by the War Production Board of the use of 7,000,000 pounds of aluminum for cans for specified products, officials of the American Can Company said yesterday.

Playtime on a broad and organized basis opened for the city's children yesterday in 345 play centers operated by the Board of Education and forty play schools sponsored by the Play School Association -- the largest program to date.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Japanese morale on Saipan Island seems to be disintegrating, and "completion of the Saipan operation may be expected with confidence," Secretary of the Navy James Forrestal said at his news conference today.

Stopping off in New York for a brief rest before continuing his tour of Army and Navy installations and industrial centers as the guest of the War Department, Col. Miguel A. Llona, Chief of Staff of the Peruvian Air Force, said yesterday that he was "greatly impressed with the spirit of cooperation and organization that I have observed here, not only in the Armed Services but among civilians as well."

For the part played in a successful five-day struggle to prevent capsizing of the Seas Shipping Company's liner Robin Sherwood when the vessel's ballast of coal slag shifted in high seas in the North Atlantic, nine residents of metropolitan New York and New Jersey among the Navy armed guard unit aboard received yesterday commendations signed by Vice Admiral Randall Jacobs, chief of naval personnel.

BASEBALL is a pleasant enough way to earn a living but it has one serious handicap. There is no future in it. An athlete is "old" at 35 and positively doddering and senile at 40. Eight years ago Sammy Byrd suddenly realized that he was not too far away from the end of the diamond road. He still had a half dozen seasons or so ahead of him.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Federal Judge Edward C. Eicher today dismissed James J. Laughlin, a defense attorney, from participation in the mass sedition trial and ordered Henry H. Klein, another defense lawyer, to return after Mr. Klein had absented himself and filed a motion to withdraw.

Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican national chairman, announced yesterday his appointments to the new executive committee of the Republican National Committee. The selections have the approval of Governor Dewey, the party's candidate for President, and Gov. John W. Bricker, the Vice Presidential nominee, and are representative of all shades of Republican opinion, according to Mr. Brownell.
LONDON, July 5 -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:
PHILADELPHIA, July 5 (AP) -- The Browns broke a 2-all tie in the ninth tonight to win from the Athletics, 4 to 2, before 12,882.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- President Roosevelt declined today to relax Selective Service regulations and grant further exemptions to pre-medical students, explaining that the needs of the armed services for "young, vigorous men" must be given first consideration.

LONDON, July 5 -- Frantisek Nemec, chief of the "pocket government" that the Czechs hope to send into their home territory soon, behind the Red army, appealed to the great powers today to rehabilitate not only the body but the soul of liberated Europe.
CHUNGKING, China, July 5 (AP) -- A communique:

One of the largest sales of vacant property this season in the Forest Hills area of Long Island was announced yesterday in the purchase by the Windland Realty Corporation of New York City of a plot containing 32,000 square feet extending from Sixty-eighth Avenue to Sixty-eighth Road, 180 feet north of Queens Boulevard.

LONDON, July 5 -- Widespread deportations and massacres of Hungarian Jews, despite repeated warnings by the United Nations that the German and Hungarian instigators would be punished, were regretfully confirmed by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden in the House of Commons today.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- A new order from the Office of Price Administration classifying Canada as a "domestic" market for American textiles and thereby depriving the Dominion of the privilege of paying a 7 per cent "export premium" for cotton textiles purchased in this country, is in the course of preparation at OPA, it was learned today.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast domestically in Finland and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- A shipper or association of shippers which sends goods to a central point to be consolidated into carload lots may be defined legally, in certain circumstances, as a "freight consolidator" and receive the benefit of "assembling rates," the Interstate Commerce Commission decided today.

"99 Park," headquarters of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, Inc.,* offers a partial list of free amusements available today through the generosity of the entertainment world. Afternoon tickets from 11 A.M.; evening tickets after 4 P.M. Apply 99 Park Avenue (at Fortieth Street) for tickets.

One of the largest sales of vacant property this season in the Forest Hills area of Long Island was announced yesterday in the purchase by the Windland Realty Corporation of New York City of a plot containing 32,000 square feet extending from Sixty-eighth Avenue to Sixty-eighth Road, 180 feet north of Queens Boulevard.

LONDON, July 5 -- Widespread deportations and massacres of Hungarian Jews, despite repeated warnings by the United Nations that the German and Hungarian instigators would be punished, were regretfully confirmed by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden in the House of Commons today.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- A new order from the Office of Price Administration classifying Canada as a "domestic" market for American textiles and thereby depriving the Dominion of the privilege of paying a 7 per cent "export premium" for cotton textiles purchased in this country, is in the course of preparation at OPA, it was learned today.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast domestically in Finland and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- A shipper or association of shippers which sends goods to a central point to be consolidated into carload lots may be defined legally, in certain circumstances, as a "freight consolidator" and receive the benefit of "assembling rates," the Interstate Commerce Commission decided today.

PEARL HARBOR, July 6 -- One of the fast carrier task groups that struck in the Bonin and Volcano Islands last Monday attacked the important enemy base on Chichi Island in the Bonins, sent five enemy craft to the bottom in the Chichi area, probably sank six and damaged ten others, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz revealed in a communique today.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The National War Labor Board decided unanimously today to refer the Midwest (truck) Operators' Association's refusal to comply with a board order to President Roosevelt for "appropriate action."

Since its inception on June 26, the veterans' vocational rehabilitation center at City College, Amsterdam Avenue and 137th Street, has completed the testing of twelve former servicemen, outlined a course of study for each and begun examination of twenty-two others, it was revealed yesterday by Earle W. Dudley, head of the Veterans' Administration staff at the center.

In anticipation of his possible election next Tuesday as Democratic State chairman, Joseph M. Ryan of Batavia, N.Y., yesterday said farewell to his associates in the State Liquor Authority and informed them that yesterday's meeting of the Authority was the last he would attend as a member. He has been one of the commissioners of the Authority at $7,500 a year since 1935.

Shoe retailers are looking for a new pricing program to be announced by the Office of Price Administration in the near future, it was learned yesterday. Details of the proposal are not known but reports are that it will include a cost-plus mark-up formula.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- As of May 31, the North African campaign, which includes operations in Sicily and Italy and air raids from the Mediterranean theatre, was the most costly to the United States Army in terms of casualties, with the Philippines second and European theatres third, the War Department revealed today.

Billie Burke, actress and widow of Florenz Ziegfeld, obtained a temporary injunction yesterday from Supreme Court Justice Benjamin F. Schreiber, restraining a Queens night club from using the word "Follies" or "Frolic" in connection with the name of "Ziegfeld."

Seven members of the New York Port Coordinators group yesterday received Coast Guard Security Shields of Honor for "outstanding efforts in keeping the vital Port of New York safe from fire or sabotage."

Ralph P. Fahey, personnel director of the Bridgeport propellor division of Remington Rand, Inc., has been named national service manager of the electric shaver division, succeeding E.C. Holloway, resigned.
LONDON, July 6 -- Two Ministers of the British Cabinet have declared during the last few days that Great Britain was "broke."

Although they are not available in any quantity as yet, the first California seedless grapes of the season reached here last week and the War Food Administration reports that small shipments have been arriving daily since then. Nectarines are another recent addition to the fruit market and fresh figs are coming to town in increasing quantities.

LONDON, July 6 -- The exodus of London's children has already begun. About 10,500 of them have left the city which has been blasted by on ton flying bombs these past twenty-three days and more children will go. The blitz has returned to London and brought with it the old familiar scenes.

Hats at Walter Florell's are on the up and up. His particular trick in making the larger headgear that is by now firmly ensconced in the mode is to see to it that only a comparatively small part of the hair is covered. His headsizes are not overpowering whether the hat be a turban, sailor or Breton.

LONDON, July 6 -- Field Marshal Gen. Karl von Rundstedt, professionally the most able and politically the most unreliable of Adolf Hitler's generals, has been replaced as Supreme Commander in the west by Field Marshal Gen. Guenther von Kluge, either as the result of his inability to prevent the successful establishment of the Allied beachhead in Normandy or because the Fuehrer no longer trusted so lukewarm a Nazi in so important a command.

The New York Trust Company issued yesterday, for the first time in its history, a semi-annual report on its operations and earnings, showing for the first six months of 1944 a net operating income of $2,045,810, or $3.41 a share. This compared with $1,715,524, or $2.86 a share in the first half of 1943.
CHUNGKING, China, July 6 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

ROME, July 6 (U.P.) - Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark's Fifth Army was within ten miles of Leghorn and twenty-six miles of Florence tonight, little more than a month after Rome fell, and Allied Headquarters announced that enemy losses in Italy since May 11 have been "beyond calculation," with at least three German divisions virtually destroyed and many of the twenty-four remaining reduced to skeleton forces.

CHUNGKING, China, July 6 (U.P.) -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek said today that Japan's offensive on the China front was a last desperate -- and vain -- attempt to keep open avenues for the eventual retreat of her forces from invaded areas and the South Pacific islands.
Mrs. Cecil Barret of Ardmore, Pa., who is at the Carlyle, will leave tomorrow for Mariposa, Bar Harbor, Me., to join Mr. Barret and their daughter, Miss Hermione Barret, for the summer.

Lifting the veil of secrecy from Germany's secret weapon, Prime Minister Churchill has revealed the full menace, but also the limitations and the vulnerability of Hitler's flying robot bombs. They are no joke and no mere nuisance, but a major weapon of murderous potency, especially designed to bring death and destruction to the civilian population.

LONDON, Friday, July 7 (AP) -- More flying bombs smashed into the London area last night after a lull of several hours and while rescuers still dug for victims from Thurs day morning's barrage -- some of them mill workers trapped under fifty tons of debris.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 73:

The one creditable fact about an otherwise shocking record for the Fourth of July week-end is that no deaths caused by fireworks were reported. It would have supplied a last touch of irony for Americans to use powder to blow themselves up at a time when powder is needed for the battlefronts.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 6 -- Hitherto the Germans have been only too ready to increase the confusion since every "incident" served as a pretext for reprisal. They announced today, for instance, that they had "exterminated" forty-three saboteurs parachuted in central France and had followed this by executing 108 terrorists.
CHUNGKING, China, July 6 (AP) -- A communique:

JELLICO, Tenn., July 6 (AP) -Nine persons were killed and probably 200 injured tonight in the plunge of a southbound sixteen-car Louisville Nashville passenger train, carrying troops, into the Clear River Gorge near here.

With latest tabulations placing Fifth War Loan sales within 4 per cent of the $16,000,000,000 national goal, an eleventh hour appeal was made yesterday to increase the lagging sale of E bonds and other individual issues before the close of the formal drive tomorrow.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 6 -- Delegates to the financial conference struggled tonight with a serious problem raised by Russia regarding the amount of her gold contribution to the proposed international monetary fund.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 6 -- Lord Keynes, chairman of the British delegation at the United Monetary and Financial Conference, challenged critics of the proposed international monetary fund today to produce a better plan.

ALBANY, July 6 - Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, chairman of the State Veterans Commission, announced the appointment tonight of Col. Edward C.O. Thomas, State Director of Civilian Protection, as director of the State Veterans Service Agency.

FOURTEENTH UNITED STATES AIR FORCE BASE, China, June 29 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Capt. Ralph F. Thompson, a United States Army chemical warfare intelligence officer, confirmed today that the Japanese were using poison gas against the Chinese defenders of Hengyang.

LONDON, July 6 -- Polish quarters in London, still fighting a rearguard action against Soviet attacks, challenged in detail today claims emanating from Moscow on the strength and broad political support of the Polish National Council formed early this year inside Poland.

Continued excellent weather in the Cotton Belt, evidence of some technical weakness in the market and reports that hot weather is checking weevil infestations in the South brought in yesterday sufficient liquidation in the futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange to cause declines of 5 to 19 points on active months.

The story in THE TIMES of June 27 about the young singer, Laura Machen, who graduated with honors from Joan of Arc High School, despite the handicap of infantile paralysis, mentioned the Handicapped Children's Home Service. I think the public ought to know more about the unusual work done by this organization.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 6 -- Norman D. MacLeod, president of the Abrasive Machine Tool Company and a veteran of the first World War, was nominated as Republican candidate for Governor at the State convention tonight.

Thomas J. Whelan was arrested yesterday by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents, partly as the result of his inability to understand Chinese characters. A zone deputy collector fro the Bureau of Internal Revenue for less than a year, the 53-year-old defendant was said to have obtained nearly $3,000 in bribes from a dozen Chinatown merchants.
The year's highest temperature was registered yesterday at 4:30 P.M. when the mercury touched 90.1 degrees. Today's forecast is for sunny and hot weather with moderate winds.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- The mid-summer furniture market got under way here today with buyer attendance up to average for an opening day, shortages plentiful, and interest keen in the supply outlook over the next six months.

Despite the many changes baseball has undergone in these hard-pressed times, that delectable bit of amusement known as "spilling the Indians" apparently has not become a lost art with the Yankee, I as many had reason to fear a few days ago.

PITTSBURGH, July 6 -- Establishment of universal military service in this country as a permanent peacetime policy, to include a year of active training in the armed forces for all able-bodied boys when they reach 18, was advocated by Warren K. Atherton, national commander of the American Legion, before 2,000 teachers and school administrators attending the National Education Association convention today.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 6 (AP) -- Shaving 12 strokes off par with a best ball of 61, Byron Nelson and Jug McSpaden set an all-time team record today in tying with the Bill Kaiser-Bob Hamilton duo for the first round lead in the Golden Valley invitation golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- A minor victory has been won by the Office of Civilian Requirements of the War Production Board in its fight to assure civilians essential quantities of low-cost cotton textiles for clothing, it became apparent today.
LONDON, July 6 -- Although business in most sections of today's stock markets was quiet, fresh investment buying sent prices of leading industrials up again.
LONDON, July 6 (AP) -- The condition statement of the Bank of England for the week ended yesterday reported an increase of 3,244,000 in note circulation.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Friday, July 7-- Doughboys of the American First Army are slowly and steadily hammering their way out of the iron ring that Field Marshal Gen. Erwin Rommel tried to draw around the Allies' beach-head in Normandy, while on the eastern sector Canadian tank and infantry forces are holding their lines in the protracted and bloody battle for the shell-pocked acres and shattered hangars of the Carpiquet airfield.

Consolidated net sales of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation for the fiscal year ended on April 30 increased 16 per cent to the record volume of $97,833,812 from the $84,656,362 sales of the previous year, according to a report which will be issued today.
PHILADELPHIA, July 6 (AP) -Bob Muncrief racked up his eighth pitching victory against four defeats as he hurled the Browns to a 5 -- 0 shutout over the Athletics today.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- A twenty-three member subcommittee on resolutions and platform to conduct hearings in advance of the opening of the Democratic Convention at Chicago July 19 was appointed today by Robert E. Hannegan, chairman of the Democratic National Committee.

The next time you cast and cast and all you get is a sore arm and a blistering sunburn and someone comes up and says: "Yes, it's pretty slow now, but you should have been here last week," don't drape that landing net around his ears.

A general court-martial will be held July 17 at the New York Navy Yard in Brooklyn as the result of an investigation that disclosed that "a small number of naval personnel" had been selling Government gasoline coupons in the black market.

Warning against prolonging the war in the Far East through failure to ward off Japan's attempt to cut the vast trunk lines of interior China, Gen. Shang Chen, Minister of Defense in China, made a plea yesterday for a strong defense by the United Nations against this Japanese strategy.

To promote understanding and good-will between the women of Russia and the United States, Mrs. Joseph E. Davies, wife of the former Ambassador to Moscow, yesterday afternoon presented the first in a series of exchange exhibits from the Women's Committee of the National Council of American-Soviet Friendship, Inc., to the Women's Anti-Fascist Committee of the Soviet Union.

China is entering the eighth year of her war of resistance. We salute a gallant ally who has been fighting in the midst of invasion, devastated cities, complete blockade, with millions enslaved and other millions slaughtered.

Although the German robot bombs have proved terrifying to many persons and are doing "a great deal of damage," Londoners are taking the bombings with courage and fortitude, Bertram De N. Cruger, chairman of the London committee of the British War Relief Society of America, who arrived Tuesday from England, said yesterday.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 6 -- All the facilities of the Hartford Chapter of the American Red Cross, and especially those of its highly trained Disaster Emergency Committee, were brought into play today when the circus fire occurred in northern Hartford this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The Office of Price Administration has collided with a provision in its new appropriations act which officials feel may affect the ceilings on the whole series of canned fruit and vegetable price regulations, it was learned today.

Despite serious shortages in manpower and materials, the third year of the war in the New York region was characterized by a Department of Commerce report issued yesterday as one of "peak production, full employment, increased income payments and, with few exceptions, highly profitable business."

Some time between 6 o'clock Saturday night and early Monday morning a thief removed a small tin box, containing $402.75 in cash and $262.50 in war bonds, from the large safe in the Chief Inspector's Office at Manhattan Police Headquarters, and disappeared.

Gasoline stocks dropped last week more sharply than in any week this year. At the end of the period, they amounted to 83,859,000 barrels, a decline of 2,441,000 from the 86,000,000 at the end of the preceding week, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

Leave it to Mike Todd to hit upon a novel method to stimulate the sale of war bonds. Only purchasers of bonds ($100-$100,000) at the Manufacturers Trust Company, 513 Fifth Avenue, will be able to buy tickets for the premiere of "Catherine Was Great," starring Mae West, at the Shubert on Wednesday night, Aug. 2.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, July 6 -- A new weapon in the history of amphibious warfare -- air-borne infantry specially trained and specially armed for jungle fighting -- made a brief appearance in this area when paratroopers dropped behind a smoke screen on Monday to aid the American landing force that captured Kamiri and Kornasoren airfields on Numfor Island.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Sharp increases in prices for most agricultural products brought the Bureau of Labor Statistics' index of commodity prices in primary markets up 0.4 per cent during the last week of June. The all-commodity index of nearly 900 price series rose to 104.1 per cent of the 1926 average.

Widely circulated reports that the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company plans great post-war expansion in the number of its own retail stores were denied here yesterday by Harvey S. Firestone Jr., president of the company. In an interview at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, Mr. Firestone said reports that the company will increase the number of its stores to 7,500 from the present figure of 700 were without foundation.

Net asset value for each outstanding share of the Lehman Corporation was $41.55 on June 30, the close of its fiscal year, comparing with $38.97 on March 31, 1944, and with $37.35 on June 30, 1943, Robert Lehman, president, announced yesterday.

When the civil and military heads of the nations pay each other flying visits today it is literally so. President Roosevelt has flown the Atlantic twice, and as far as Teheran. Winston Churchill has ranged ever farther; he has been in Moscow.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed a decrease of $342,658,000 in holdings of Government securities during the week, while note circulation for the system as a whole increased $139,341,000. The ratio of reserve for the system rose to 56.5.

John Wanamaker has leased space in the Chamber of Commerce Building at 65 Liberty Street for a men's retail store. This will be the second branch store in this neighborhood for the department store, which opened a women's specialty shop last September at 150 Broadway, two doors west of the Chamber of Commerce Building.

National Service Life Insurance awards granted by the Veterans Administration for deaths in the present war increased from 26,000 in May, 1943, to 73,000 in April, 1944, Brig. Gen. Frank T. Hines, Administrator of Veterans Affairs, reported last night at the National Catholic Action and Rehabilitation Conference of the Catholic War Veterans at the Hotel New Yorker.

PANAMA, July 6 -- Conditions in Guatemala and El Salvador were reported to be improving today while discontent was increasing in Honduras and Nicaragua to the extent that the resignation or ousting of Presidents Tiburcio Carias Andino and Anastasio Somoza would not be surprising.

LONDON, July 6 -- A suggestion by some Labor members in Parliament today that peace could be negotiated with a democratic German regime coincided with a declaration by Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Propaganda Minister, in Berlin that no Government could be formed in Germany other than the present one.
Several sales of East Side residences enlivened the Manhattan realty market yesterday.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 6 (AP) -- Co-medalist Pete Ladislaw of Plandome reached the quarterfinals of the New York State amateur golf championship today with a second-round victory over Joe Stevens of Syracuse, 3 and 2.
