The other co-medalist, Mal Galletta of North Hills, was turned back in the second round by Ed Bednarz of Buffalo, 5 and 4.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 6--One hundred and thirty-nine dead and 174 badly burned persons were pulled from the charred ruins of the main Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey circus tent in Hartford this afternoon after fire swept the enclosure end to end along its entire 520-foot length.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Setting foot on American soil for the first time, Gen. Charles de Gaulle today stepped out of a big United States Army transport plane at the National Airport here in weather far hotter than that he had left in North Africa, made a little speech in English that he had carefully rehearsed in the plane and was received by President Roosevelt and his Cabinet at the White House.
BOSTON, July 6 (AP) -- The Red Sox put on their most powerful offensive of the season today to defeat the Tigers, 13 -- 3, behind Tex Hughson, whose won-and-lost record now is those same figures.
LONDON, July 6 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Col. Robert L. Scott, who told of his exploits as a fighter pilot in the Pacific war in "God Is My Co-Pilot," now tells the story of battles fought by other pilots in "Damned to Glory," to be published in September by Scribner's. This time he writes of all the fighting fronts.

Today, the seventh anniversary of the China "incident," finds China's mortal enemy reeling under hard blows on all battlefields except those in China itself. Even in China the Japanese are meeting stout resistance and suffering heavy losses in their attempts to close the gaps in the Hankow-Canton railway.

LONDON, July 6 -- When the time comes to punish those responsible for the deportation and slaughter of Hungarian Jews, the German General Staff should be the first to be dealt with, Brendan Bracken, Minister of Information, said today.

Withdrawal of his charges against Seymour S. Leikind of conduct "unbecoming a member of the staff of Brooklyn College," was requested yesterday by Harry D. Gideonse, president of the college. Mr. Gideonse's request was made after Mr. Leikind expressed his regret that a letter written by him "was subject to an interpretation that might damage or discredit Brooklyn College or bring the college or its officials into disrepute."

Restraint in advertising the availability of civilian goods, now coming back mostly in "driblets," until at least there is a sufficient quantity of such goods in the store to merit such advertising is advised by the Illinois Federation of Retail Associations in its current weekly bulletin.
LONDON, July 6 (AP) -- Following is the text of Prime Minister Churchill's speech on the robot bombs:
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -Washington, behind the four-hit pitching of Mickey Haefner, shut out the White Sox tonight, 5 to 0.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- The Government appeared set today to use psychology and funds of its multi-billion-dollar Commodity Credit Corporation to steady the uneasy wheat market and carry out a recent Congressional price-supporting mandate.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Stanton Griffis and Douglas Poteat, experts of the Foreign Economic Administration, who are said to have worked out an agreement by which Sweden will cut her exports of ball-bearings to Germany by more than 50 per cent below the levels maintained early this year, returned to Washington today.

It was reported yesterday that the British believed they had intercepted the first attempt of the Germans to evacuate the Channel Islands, which they seized at the end of June, 1940. Most of the population of 90,000 or so had been evacuated. These islands belong geographically to France, and it doesn't appear that their seizure was of any particular use to the Nazis.

CHICAGO, July 6 (AP) -- The Cubs and Braves pounded twenty-nine hits for forty-two bases in their battle for seventh place today but the Chicagoans got there first with the most for a big early lead that held up for an ll-to-6 victory. The triumph gave the Cubs the series, three games to one, and sent the Braves into the cellar again in their stead.
Wage and salaried workers have been asked by Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. to invest at least $100 in the Fifth War Loan. This may include payroll deductions to the end of July.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Harry L. Hopkins, known as President Roosevelt's closest friend and holder of two key positions in the Federal Government, returned to work today after an absence of six months required by a recurrence of the gastric troubles from which he has suffered for several years.

ALBANY, July 6 -- The metropolitan division of the State Emergency Food Commission, headed by Mrs. Roger W. Straus, reported to Governor Dewey today that during the twelve months ended June 15 it has brought nutrition information and techniques on meeting wartime food needs to thousands of families in New York City and in Westchester, Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

New issues of notes, aggregating $19,632,000 were awarded yesterday by eight local Housing Authorities in various parts of the country. The Chemical Bank and Trust Company was awarded $14,868,000 of the notes and Salomon Bros. Hutzler $4,764,000.

SAN JUAN, P.R., July 6 -- For the first time a Puerto Rico insular organization has decided to oppose a Presidential nomination. The Puerto Rican Bar Association has cabled President Roosevelt it would fight Senatorial confirmation of his appointee, Rafael Bosch, to the Puerto Rico Supreme Court to fill the vacancy created by the retirement of Chief Justice Emilio del Toro.

Silent Tom Smith, the venerable trainer who made Seabiscuit one of the greatest race horses of all time, may have another colt awaiting his Midas touch. This one is the Maine Chance Farm's War Jeep, who scored his second victory in a row yesterday at Jamaica, where Col. Matt J. Winn is presiding over the Empire City meeting.

ST. LOUIS, July 6 -- The Giants subjected Bill Voiselle to the strange sensation of a three-run start at Sportsman's Park today as they took leave of the champion Cardinals. Instead of swooning dead away, though, the brawny youth from Ninety-Six, N.C., maintained his equilibrium under another, and yet a third cluster of three runs, to carve his eleventh victory, 10 to 1.

In the first change of ownership in ninety years, the L-shaped plot at 57 Stanton Street and 217 Eldridge Street, on the lower East Side, have been acquired by Guiseppe and Fannie Pizzo from the 138 East Fortieth Street, Inc., of which Major George W. Galinger, now in military service, is president.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 6 (AP) -- The Wallendas, aerial artists, had just climbed up the rope ladder to their perch above when behind me I heard a woman gasp, "Look -- fire." There, near the main entrance to the tent, a tiny tongue of flames crept up the side wall.
A ten-story apartment house, several loft buildings and two garage properties were among the East Side realty holdings which figured in deals reported yesterday.

The seventh annual program devoted to works by George Gershwin was presented by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Alexander Smallens, last night at the Lewisohn Stadium, with Oscar Levant, pianist, as soloist. Again the yearly memorial event attracted a vast audience, attesting to the unflagging popularity of the composer's creative output.
CHUNGKING, China, July 6 -- Japanese forces have begun a general retreat on the Hunan and Honan fronts of the China war theatre, it was declared here today.
ALBANY, July 6 -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan, a leading figure in Republican foreign policy discussions, arrived tonight for a conference with Gov. Thomas E. Dewey.

Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican National chairman, wants to coordinate the Republican Presidential campaign closely with the New York State campaign and the national Senatorial and Congressional campaigns, he disclosed yesterday after a series of conferences aimed at achieving this purpose.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Friday, July 7 (AP) -- United States infantry units have occupied Manim Islet to outflank by sea the last major Japanese position on American-invaded Numfor Island off North Netherlands New Guinea, headquarters announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- In a tale of "sheer fantasy" the State Department reported today that a group of American traders had been trying for three years to sell some Allied nations a million Army rifles which do not exist and a billion rounds of .30-caliber ammunition, also imaginary.

"El Globo de Cantolla," a Mexican importation starring Mapy Cortes and Jose Cibrian, will have its local premiere today at the Belmont Theatre. The film's dialogue and songs are Spanish. There are no English titles.

LONDON, July 6 -- Statistics and speeches cannot tell the whole story of the new bombardment of London. It is a story of men and women trying to go about their daily work and being killed and maimed in the effort.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 6 -- Early this morning a 20-year-old aviation mechanic at Kastrup airport near Copenhagen suddenly had the idea that he wanted to fly over to England to join the Free Danes and help defeat Germany.

Today the New York City Defense Recreation Committee is three years old, but its sponsors decided that, in view of the seriousness of the time, a birthday celebration would be out of order. Besides, the committee is busy.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast domestically in Finland and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 6 -- George Sanders has been signed by Twentieth Century-Fox for one of the three co-starring roles in the forthcoming "Hangover Square," an adaptation of Patrick Hamilton's psychological "horror" novel to be produced by Robert Bassler, who handled "The Lodger" for that company.

GARAPAN, Saipain, Marianas Islands (Delayed) -- We crouched in the gutters along First and Second Streets, the first marines to enter the bomb-pitted and shell-scarred mass of rubble and swaying walls that was Garapan, the principal town on this island, and one of the largest cities in all the Japanese mandated islands.

Mayor La Guardia's plan to wipe out the city's subway deficit by means of taxes on rents, mortgage interest and commuters was assailed yesterday by Paul Windels, chairman of the Citizens Transit Committee, who described the Mayor's scheme as impractical, complicated, costly and difficult to enforce and in some respects discriminatory and illegal.

General de Gaulle was welcomed in Washington yesterday with the military honors due to a soldier who typifies the unconquerable soul of France. In the hearts of the American people, deeply troubled in recent months by the thought that any misunderstanding could cast even a temporary cloud on the friendship that has bound the two republics together since Revolutionary days, he is welcomed as the representative of France.

Attorney General Francis Biddle in an address last night at the opening session of the twenty-sixth annual convention of the New York County organization of the American Legion at the Hotel Pennsylvania appealed to members of the Legion to take the lead in bringing about better understanding between the fighting men of this country when they come home and the workers in industry.

The Rockefeller Foundation disposed of substantial amounts of railroad bonds and stocks of the Standard Oil Company (N.J.) and National Fuel Gas Company, in 1943, the report for the year showed yesterday, according to The Associated Press.
VENTNOR CITY, N.J., July 6 -- Albert S. Pinkus of New York forged ahead in the chess masters tournament today with a draw in nineteen moves against George Shainswit, also of New York.

The Stratford-Avon, a fourteen-story apartment house on a plot 114.5 by 100.8 feet at 210 Riverside Drive, northeast corner of Ninety-third Street, has been sold by Louis Schlechter to Tupton Associates, headed by Irving Brodsky, attorney.

Further shifts in the character of their deposits, as a result of the war loan drive, from private account, against which reserves are required to be kept, to Government war loan account, where such requirements do not obtain, again enabled the sixteen regularly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City to expand greatly further their investments.

The stock market was juggled about yesterday by alternating periods of strength and realizing which produced a mixed closing. The recently active lower-price issues were less in demand and heaviest trading centered in the medium-price category.
HARTFORD, Conn., July 6 (AP) -- Eye-witness accounts pieced to-gather many paignant details of the frenzied minutes when thousands tried to flee possible cremation in the circus fire.

VATICAN CITY, July 6 -- One of the most baffling mysteries of the war -- Who bombed the Vatican last winter? -- can now be partly cleared up. It will be recalled that Vatican authorities always refused to comment on the bombing, although they immediately made a thorough investigation, and that refusal still stands.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Friday, July 7 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The Allies are building up "on and over Europe" a fire power four times greater than that of the Germans, Acting Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson revealed today at a news conference at which he also asserted that the Allies had given proof they have no intention of being "cooped up by German defense tactics."

LONDON, July 6 -- Prime Minister Churchill's factual statement before the House of Commons today halted the anxiety throughout the country caused by German propaganda and rumors that thrive in periods of rigid censorship.

LONDON, Friday, July 7 -- Russian troops, advancing westward twenty-four miles in twenty-four hours, smashed to within thirty-two miles of Vilna, capital of Lithuania, yesterday, while at the southern end of the Eastern Front Marshal Konstantin K. Rokossovsky's First White Russian Army occupied Kovel, great German base 175 miles southeast of Warsaw.

A tightening up by rationing boards here in the issuance of supplemental gasoline rations has reduced the number of B and C books in use by more than two-thirds since the beginning of the year, it was learned yesterday.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS Allied Expeditionary Force, July 6 -- The French underground, its reputation growing daily, was credited by Supreme Headquarters today with "liberating" five areas of France.
Michael Loris, 61-year-old retired Brooklyn insurance man, was proclaimed the nation's champion salesman of E bonds yesterday by the War Finance Committee.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
Two sales of apartment houses on Walton Avenue and deals on Prospect and Forest Avenues were among the Bronx realty transactions announced yesterday.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Friday, July 7 -- Mustering their strength for a full-scale assault on German Europe the Allied air forces struck at the enemy yesterday from this country, France and Italy with the massive weight of at least 5,000 planes of every operational type.

BELLAIRE, Ohio, July 6 (AP) -Faint hope for the rescue of sixtyfour men sealed by a fire deep in Powhatan coal mine was raised tonight with plans to sink a shaft, nine inches in diameter, through 350 feet of earth.
LONDON, July 6 -- The old question, "Where is the Luftwaffe?" more pertinent than ever since D-day, might well be matched by the question, "Where is the German Navy?"

LONDON, July 6--Netherlanders aiding the invasion are finding it hard to suppress their longing to return to the Netherlands. Since D-day there has been a token fleet of more than fifty merchantmen, supported by Dutch gunboats and MTB's serving the invasion armies in Normandy.

CINCINNATI, July 6 -- The Brooklyn program of building for the future continued tonight as the Reds pounded two 'teen age pitchers mercilessly to win 10-4, and hand the cellar-bound Dodgers their tenth consecutive defeat.

WITH BRITISH FORCES, in France, July 6 -- All was quiet along the British-Canadian front lines today. Nowhere was there activity of any significance and if there were any changes in positions on both sides of the lines they were of no importance.

Eugene P. Connolly, secretary of the New York County committee of the American Labor party, conceded last night that the ALP had requested Assemblyman John P. Lamula, Republican, to sign a statement that he would not campaign directly or indirectly for the Dewey-Bricker ticket as a condition for giving him its endorsement for re-election in the Second Assembly District, Manhattan.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 6 (AP) -- Communique 61:

CHUNGKING, China, July 6 (U.P.) -- Chinese forces at the bitterly embattled railroad base of Hengyang have killed more than 600 Japanese in the past twenty hours and fought their way back into more than ten enemy-held strong points on the city's outskirts, it was announced today.
PITTSBURGH, July 6 (AP) -- A six-run spree in the sixth inning gave the Pirates all they needed tonight to defeat the Phils, 6 -- 5.

TRENTON, N.J., July 6 (AP) -Railroads operating in New Jersey will be asked by State officials on Monday to pay their respective shares of about $60,000,000 in delinquent taxes and interest which the State Court of Errors and Appeals has held the lines owe the State, it was said today by a source close to Gov. Walter E. Edge.

Acting upon complaints by vacationists, the Office of Price Administration began yesterday an investigation of rates at mountain and beach hotels, country boarding houses and other resorts which may lead to the establishment of rent controls upon summer rentals.

The Treasury made known yesterday afternoon that it will make further withdrawals on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday from Government war-loan accounts in the principal commercial banks throughout the country. For the Second Federal Reserve District it will withdraw $55,271,000 on each day, and for the nation as a whole, $137,027,300 daily.

CHICAGO, July 6 (AP) -- Twilight Tear, queen of the American turf, gained her ninth straight triumph today in winning the $10,000 added Arlington Skokie Handicap in record-breaking time at Washington Park.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- Announcement that a reported Government program to support the wheat market was a continuation of buying begun early last year and designed to obtain a stock of that grain for feeding purposes was construed as bearish by the grain trade and led to general selling today on the Board of Trade.

HEADQUARTERS OF THE CHINESE EXPEDITIONARY FORCE, July 5 (Delayed) -- Chinese troops on the Salween front celebrated July 4 by capturing Japanese fortifications on Hungshaw, the mountain that controls the Burma Road crossing the Salween and taking all but one of the Japanese defenses around Tengyueh.

The world witnessed a moving and touching ceremony in the recent presentation by the Allies of the Tricolor to the liberated French in Normandy. This, together with the cessation of firing in order to return to the Germans four members of their Nurse Corps, who had been captured, is abundant evidence that chivalry is still alive.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 6 -- The women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association, in order to perpetuate the memory of its former champion, Mrs. James M. Robbins of Mount Kisco, staged its first annual Jane Robbins Memorial tournament at Bonnie Briar today.

The impact of the war has been felt strongly by the French Hospital, says the annual report, made public yesterday, of the French Benevolent Society of New York and the hospital. However, the report added, contemplation of wartime difficulties "would be depressing were it not for our confidence that we can rely on our key personnel, our medical staff and our faithful benefactors."

Although the advance sale/s unusually brisk, the Yankee management, anxious to promote a sellout for the benefit double-header between the world champions and the Tigers at the Stadium on Sunday, announced yesterday that there still was on hand a substanItial supply of reserved seat tickets.
KANDY, Ceylon, July 6 (UP) -- A communique:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 6 -- After questioning Mrs. Renee Guy Perkins Hatch at her bedside in Grasslands Hospital at East-view, Dr. Amos O. Squire, County Medical Examiner, said today that she blamed an unhappy married life for her actions Tuesday night in poisoning and strangling to death her children, Georgette, 3 years old, and Aldis, 16 months, at their home near Armonk.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Ordered from the courtroom of the sedition trial for the second time within two days, James J. Laughlin, who has been counsel for Edward James Smythe and Robert Noble, filed today a formal protest with the Circuit Court of Appeals, but that tribunal deferred action.

A new college "look" -- young and spontaneous yet neat and attractive -- will begin to appear at Stephens College, Columbia, Mo., in the next year or so if girls take to heart the principles included in a new course, Fine and Applied Fashion, to be offered there this fall, Muriel King, designer, who was recently appointed non-resident director of the course, declared yesterday.

Although batters insist the ball is no livelier than it has seen right along, there certainly seems to be something more spirited about it as it keeps popping out of outfielders' gloves. Derry took a turn at parking himself carefully under a high fly and then blinking in amazement as it squirted out of his mitt.

Schools have not aided in solving important community problems, Dr. Harold Clark, Professor of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University, asserted yesterday as he placed blame upon teachers for not attacking local social and economic problems or making their pupils aware of methods to remedy them.

One of the materials forecast for many and sometimes startling uses in the post-war home is glass. Some of the proposed uses are apt to leave the homemaker a little cold, as well as being open to doubt by experts. Glass furniture, however, already has achieved a certain acceptance before the war, and decorators note it as an important trend for post-war homes, many of which are expected to be of modern design.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- China's example was hailed by President Roosevelt as "an inspiration to all of the United Nations" in a message today to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek on the occasion of the seventh anniversary of the Japanese attack on China.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 6 (AP) -- A Berkshire County jury today convicted John F. Noxon Jr. of murder in the first degree in the electrocution slaying of his 6 months old mentally deficient son, Lawrence. Death in the electric chair is the mandatory penalty.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 6 -- Yale alumni have been urged in a special bulletin of the Yale Alumni University Fund to make bequests and "in memoriam" gifts.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 6 (AP) -Lieut. Beaufort Swancutt, under sentence to hang for fatally shooting four persons, carried out in his own way today the judgment of an Army court-martial.

In another move to conserve railroad facilities, the Office of Defense Transportation yesterday limited wartime use of special cars, special trains and extra sections to members of the armed services, prisoners of war and Government-recruited workers.

HARTFORD, Conn., Friday, July 7 -- Warrants charging manslaughter were issued at 2 o'clock this morning by Police Court Prosecutor S. Burr Leikind, calling for the appearance at 9 A.M. in Hartford Police Court of five officials and employes of Ringling Brothers circus.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -Congressional tax experts had a word of cheer today for fall newlyweds and for couples expecting the birth of a baby in the latter part of the year.

LONDON, July 6 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill disclosed to the world today what has been a matter of bitter knowledge to Londoners for three long weeks -- that this blitzed old capital of Great Britain has borne the brunt of the Nazi attack with flying bombs ever since it began in earnest on June 15.
ROME, July 6 (AP) -- A communique:

LONDON, July 7 -- Germany has lost four more of her generals -- two killed and two captured -- it was announced today, increasing to thirty-one the number of top-flight Nazi officers killed in action or accidents or taken by the Allies since warfare blazed out on three fronts in June.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 7 -Germany will never tolerate that the value of her currency be determined by a foreign government or wall Street banker, nor will she permit German wheat prices to be fixed on the Chicago Exchange, Walther Funk, head of the Reichsbank and German Minister of Economy, told a gathering of Germans and satellite economists in Koenigsberg today.

By way of taking time out from fishing for the moment, herewith is presented a somewhat dismal but not altogether discouraging report on the duck situation as seen by Tom Main, general manager of Ducks Unlimited of Canada.

Dr. Clilan B. Powell, publisher of The Amsterdam News of New York and a member of the State Athletic Commission by appointment of Governor Dewey, was named yesterday by Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican national chairman, as assistant director of publicity for the Dewey-Bricker campaign.
KANDY, Ceylon, July 7 (UP) -- A communiqu:
LONDON, July 7 -- The stock markets here were cheerful today, with most activity in the industrial and Kaffir sections.

Elmer Wagner, 20-year-old restaurant worker, who admitted that he had killed his 3 1/2-week-old daughter because she cried too much, was held without bail on a charge of homicide yesterday by Magistrate Robert F. Mahoney in Brooklyn Felony Court.

Thomas Cunningham, 53 years old, of 1142 Bryant Avenue, the Bronx, is a man of action as well as words. When an elderly suitor tried to court his 17-year-old daughter he simply lifted his trusty air rifle and fired several shots at him.

Supported flawlessly by his mates, Ernie Bonham twirled the Yankees to a 3-1 triumph over the Tigers yesterday at the Stadium. Ordinarily, the defeat of a team tied for sixth place does not carry much weight, but Detroit had given more trouble to the New Yorkers than any other outfit. Until yesterday Steve O'Neill's men had taken six out of seven.
Yesterday's communiqu, as broadcast domestically by the Finnish radio and reported by the Federal Communication Commission:

The Bainbridge Building corporation, representing Bainbridge Colby, has sold the thirteen-story office and loft building at 37-39 West Fifty-seventh Street to Leo Silver, operator, in a deal in which the seller assigned to the buyer a second mortgage originally in the sum of $556,500 and extended a first mortgage with the Mutual Life Insurance Company originally in the sum of $643,500.

CHICAGO, July 7 -- President Horace Stoneham arrived today in time to see both sides of his harassed Giants. They were good and bad, but not in that order, as they split a double-header with the Clubs before 21,810 ladies' day fans.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The war in China is not going well, although the Japanese are facing strategic problems in the long extension of their lines, President Roosevelt said today.

Any civilian in doubt as to whether service men and women appreciate the good-will extended to them by the city in the way of entertainment and hospitality should have attended the birthday party at 99 Park Avenue yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, July 7 -- Owing mainly to curtailment of working schedules, business here declined a little more last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. The bureau's seasonally adjusted index fell from 171.8 per cent of the 1935-39 average in the week ended June 24 to 171.3 as of July 1.

BELLAIRE, Ohio, July 7 (AP) - Sixty-six men entombed in the Powhatan mine will be officially pronounced dead tomorrow, but tonight rescue workers began drilling the first of two shafts toward them on the faint chance that they might be found alive.

One of the best things that can happen to a slave of the office desk on the hottest day of the year is to be remembered by lucky friends at the shore, in the mountains or where rolls the Housatonic. Once upon a time it was the crude fashion for vacationists to write postcards to friends in town saying, "Is it hot enough for you?"

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 7 -- An agreement by two war factories and the Village of Peekskill to end the pollution of the Hudson River at Lent's Cove was announced today by Dr. William A. Holla, Westchester County Health Commissioner, who said it was the "most concentrated pollution" in the county and lower Hudson Valley.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- L. R. Boulware, operations vice chairman of the War Production Board, announced today that the next meeting of the Automobile Industry Advisory Committee will be held Friday, July 14.

King Vidor, who recently completed filming "An American Romance" for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, is planning to follow that soon-to-be-released epic drama on the industrial growth of America with a picture about the development of the West.

The Board of Education was restrained from continuing its indirect method of hiring custodial help in a decision handed down yesterday in Queens Supreme Court by Justice Charles W. Froessel. The court declared the indirect system in violation of the State constitution, but in an attempt to give the board time to prepare for the necessary change-over, stayed execution of the judgment pending an appeal.

Another of racing's big days is at hand. This time it's the day of the Empire City Stakes with $50,000 added, the fattest purse in the event's thirty-six-year history. The scene will be Jamaica, where the Empire City Racing Association is conducting its meet under the guidance of Col. Matt J. Winn.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, July 7 (U.P.) -- Allied forces today had dislodged the Japanese from at least three more towns and driven them to the northrn fringes of Ukhrul in the Manipur Hill region.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 7 (AP) -The teams of Bill Kaiser-Bob Hamilton and Byron Nelson-Jug McSpaden tied today for the lead in the $10,000 Golden Valley best ball matches at the end of 54 holes.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Super fortresses of the new Twentieth Air Force roared over the Japanese islands again today to attack the great naval base of Sasebo, which Japan regards as one of her "Pearl Harbors," and also to hit for the second time the steel center of Yawata.

The Navy's first twin-engined fighter, the Grumman F-7-F, was put through its paces in public for the first time yesterday before Rear Admiral A.W. Radford, acting deputy Chief of Naval Air Operations, and Assistant Secretary of the Navy Artemus L. Gates at the Grumman plant at Bethpage, L.I.

Reduction of most export quotas on cotton fabrics in the latest revision to the War Production Board Order M-317 brought favorable comment in the garment industry yesterday, but a cautious attitude was noted on the part of spokesmen, who believe that full benefits for the domestic industry will not be effective until the latter months of the year.

In a leasehold transaction said to involve nearly $4,000,000, Webb Knapp have acquired from the New York Central Railroad control of the property at 385 Madison Avenue, at the southeast corner of Forty-seventh Street.

Mrs. Norma Taubele Barber of New York and Miss Connie Clifton of Rollins College gained the final round of the women's New York State tennis championship yesterday at the Knickerbocker Field Club in Brooklyn. They will meet for the title at 3 o'clock this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- James J. Laughlin, defense lawyer whom Federal Judge Edward C. Eicher recently ousted from the mass sedition trial because of his conduct, was accused by the Government today of having been "continuously contemptuous and disrespectful" toward the judge.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The Mexican Army is prepared to send men to the fighting fronts, Dr. Ezequiel Padilla, the Mexican Foreign Minister who is on an official visit here, said at a press conference today. This war, he declared, is one of self-defense; it involves Mexico's existence and principles.

RICHMOND, Va., July 7 -- Patents on devices aimed at making aerial navigation safer and more practical are outstanding among the 528 listed as granted in the current issue of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- Milo Candini blanked the Browns with six blows as Washington turned back the league leaders, 7 to 0, before 17,983 fans at a war relief contests tonight.

Fabrics labeled "Army rejects" which have been in demand for an odd assortment of civilian items from sports clothes to window draperies have turned out to be a special boon to the makers of shower curtains. They are of far better quality than most of those previously available.

Operations of the Childs Company, chain restaurant operator, in the first five months of this year resulted in a net profit of $394,894 or slightly more than $358,508 cleared in the five months ended on May 31, 1943, according to the trustee's report announced yesterday.

Today's events: Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Vladimir Golschmann, with Ania Dorfmann, piano, as soloist, Lewisohn Stadium, 8:30 P.M.; Concert featuring excerpts from Gilbert and Sullivan operettas, Goldman Band, Prospect Park, Brooklyn, 8:30; Katherine Bacon, piano, in Victory concert, New York Public Library, 5:30; City Amateur Symphony Orchestra, under Judge Leopold Prince, with Mildred Hieber, as soprano, as soloist, the Mall, Central Park, 8:30.

ROME, July 7 -- Fourteen hundred pounds of plastic explosives, a large quantity of other explosives and enough material for five radio transmitters were seized by Allied authorities in the grounds of the German Embassy in Rome, it was announced today.
You may be glad to hear from someone who has been in close touch with some of your lads for some months and to know how we get along with them.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 7 (AP) -- Protesting his innocence, John F. Noxon Jr., 47-year-old lawyer, was sentenced today to electrocution for the slaying last Sept. 22 of his mentally deficient child, killed by an electric current.

The discovery of an illicit cache of $85,000 worth of high-grade zipper fasteners was announced here yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The incident was directly connected, it was said, with the arrest in Meadville, Pa., Thursday night of a junk dealer who had paid the Talon Corporation there $641 for the scarce items.

China faces her most critical year in her struggle against the Japanese invader and American aid in providing war materials is more vital than ever, former Gov. Charles Edison of New Jersey, chairman of the United China Relief, Inc., declared yesterday at exercises held in City Hall Plaza to commemorate the seventh anniversary of China's war with Japan.

ABOARD JOINT EXPEDITIONARY FORCE FLAGSHIP, Off Saipan, July 7 (AP via Navy Radio) -- American military forces opened a pathway to life today for 10,000 to 15,000 Japanese civilians still hiding out on Saipan, while United States troops moved ahead to deliver a death blow to the shattered and battle-benumbed Japanese garrison.

Mayor La Guardia's proposal to replenish the rapid transit treasury by a curious series of taxes is described in a statement issued by Chairman Paul Windels of the Citizens Transit Committee as "complicated, enormously expensive and difficult to enforce." The kindest thing that can be said about the plan, in fact is that it has brought an important subject up for discussion.
CHUNGKING, China, July 7 (AP) -- A communique:
CHUNGKING, China, July 7 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communiqu:

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 7 -Johnny Farrell, national open champion in 1928, and Richard Henry, both of Baltusrol, captured the New Jersey amateur-pro golf championship today at the Montclair Golf Club as a forerunner to the twenty-fourth New Jersey open on Sunday.

The Texwell, Inc., bought the six-story sixty-six-family apartment building at 340 East 184th Street, the Bronx, from the 1305 Sheridan Avenue Properties Corporation. Jacob and Emil Leitner, Inc., were the brokers. The sale was made subject to a mortgage of $197,000.

PHILADELPHIA, July 7 (AP) -- Luman Harris of the Athletics pitched a 4-3 victory over the White Sox tonight in his last major league game before donning a Navy uniform. The veteran right-hander will leave for his home in Birmingham, Ala., tomorrow and will report for duty with the Navy on July 14.

IN NORMANDY, July 7 (AP) -- In a trampled hayfield within earshot of booming guns supporting the American attack, Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery pinned British ribbons of valor on seven Americans today for their heroism in the invasion of France.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman paid tribute to the Chinese people yesterday morning at a mass celebrated in St. Patrick's Cathedral to commemorate the seventh anniversary of the incident at the Marco Polo Bridge near Peiping, China, that began the war with Japan.

LONDON, July 7 -- Two Republican Representatives, Gordon Canfield of Paterson, N.J., and Hugh D. Scott Jr., of Philadelphia, have arrived in London after shipping to Britain as ordinary crew members of an American tanker loaded with high octane gasoline.

The West Side Iron Works, engaged in ship repairing, will embark on an extensive fall advertising program in October in newspapers and the trade press, it was announced yesterday by Walter W. Wiley Advertising, agents. Post-war plans of the company already have been mapped for the conversion of war cargo vessels into peacetime commercial carriers.

Beyond the fact that London has been the principal target of German rocket bombs and that so far 2,752 have been killed and 8,000 injured, Mr. Churchill was not very explicit in his speech. Much had to be held back that the Germans would like to know. What methods of counter-attack have been adopted besides the use of fighters and the bombing of fixed launching platforms in France?

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 7 -Ann Richards, the Australian screen actress, has been signed to a term contract by Hal B. Wallis for featured roles in his forthcoming Paramount pictures. Miss Richards also is under contract to RKO for two pictures a year.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 7 -- Small groups of highly trained volunteers from the British and Greek armies are constantly at work in the Aegean gnawing at German defenses on many islands, it was revealed here today.

John Wanamaker, a concern well known in clothing and retail merchandising circles in New York and Philadelphia for two generations, is planning to open a new department store in midtown Manhattan, it became known yesterday.
CAIRO, Egypt, July 7 (AP) -- An Allied Middle East air communiqu:

DAVE BURGHLEY had to overcome tremendous handicaps in order to become a great athlete. Most serious of these were his name and position. The name was David George Brownlow Cecil, Lord Burghley. The position his lordship will one day hold will be that of the sixth Marquis of Exeter, hereditary grand almoner of the British Crown and the head of the historic English house of Cecil.
North American Newspaper Alliance. An all round understanding is expected to be the outcome of the conversations in progress between President Roosevelt and General Charles de Gaulle.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Saturday, July 8 -- Engineers and infantrymen of the United States First Army have smashed across the Vire River north of St. Lo, to establish a small but secure bridgehead that threatens the Germans in St. Jean de Daye and the entire right flank of the German corps opposing the American drive southward from the base of the Cherbourg Peninsula.
CHICAGO, July 7 (AP) -- The Mortgage Bankers Association of America said today that Government agencies own less than one-tenth of the country's mortgage loans.

UNITED STATES ARMY HEADQUARTERS in Normandy, July 7 -- Allied airpower made one of its heaviest attacks on communication and transport lines today in support of the ground forces. Launching attacks over an area said to be about 9,000 square miles Allied bombers and fighter bombers destroyed nine bridges and knocked out hundreds of motor vehicles.
LONDON, July 7 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- President Roosevelt absorbed in his press conference today a barrage of questions regarding Democratic political affairs without budging one iota from his say-nothing attitude regarding himself, the Democratic convention and its next nominee for the Presidency.

Policies affecting the international balance of payments of each country are of fundamental importance in any program to stabilize currencies. Yet the present monetary conference at Bretton Woods is not dealing with many such problems, of which tariffs furnish an illustration.

LONDON, July 7 -- A new Yugoslav Cabinet with places for two representatives of Marshal Tito, commander of the Partisan forces, has been formed by Premier Ivan Subasitch and received the approval of King Peter, it was announced tonight.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, July 7 -- The Argentine War Minister Col. Juan Domingo Peron, whose rash statements in a recent lecture about military preparedness at the University of La Plata aggravated the present crisis in relations with the United States, was appointed Vice President to fill the post vacated by Gen. Edelmiro Farrell when he assumed the Presidency last March.

PITTSBURGH, July 7 -- As confidently expected by close observers, the Dodgers today kept in-tack their unenviable record of not having won a game on this western tour by succumbing to the Pirates, 13-2.

The Fifth Avenue Bank reported as of June 30 total deposits of $102,289,026 and total assets of $108,133,663, compared, respectively, with $98,072,194 and $104,394,090 on March 31. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $15,885,382, against $16,914,014; holdings of United States Government securities, to $72,327,530, against $67,027,193, and loans and discounts to $14,948,272, against $14,893,699.

J. Edward Breuer was the broker in the recent sale of two acres of business property on Middle Neck Road, Great Neck, L. L, for the Intervale Corporation of New York and the Gateway Corporation of Great Neck.
LONDON, July 7 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

CAMDEN, N.J., July 7 (AP) -Signal Corps, racing for Miss E.M. Hayman and ridden by Jockey Nick Wall, was easily best of the five that opposed him in the mile and a sixteenth race that was fifth and best on today's card at Garden State Park.

VATICAN CITY, July 7 -- The Duke of Aosta was received in a private audience by Pope Pius XII this morning, talking to the Pontiff for forty minutes. Afterward he went to see Cardinal Maglione, Papal Secretary of State, with whom he conferred for forty-five minutes.

Miss Edna Dessau of 611 West 113th Street told Judge Jonah J. Goldstein in General Sessions yesterday she had less interest in what sentence he might impose on Dr. Samuel Weinrib, a dentist, for shooting and seriously wounding her in a Greenwich Village restaurant last Dec. 29 than in regaining the girdle through which the bullet passed.

ROME, July 7 (U.P.) -- The American advance toward Leghorn has ground to a virtual halt in the face of aggressive counter-thrusts launched by the Germans along the 170-mile Italian battlefront for the first time since the fall of Rome, it was disclosed today, and reports showed the enemy was working feverishly to bolster his Gothic Line through the mountains around Pisa and Florence.

CHICAGO, July 7 -- Formal announcement that the Commodity Credit Corporation would purchase No. 1 grades of cash wheat at 6 cents a bushel over the current Government loan rate in storage in terminal and subterminal market elevators, and intimations that the loan rate on the 1944 crop would be raised around 7 cents sent wheat prices soaring today on the Board of Trade.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Saturday, July 8 -- The German Air Force came up to fight yesterday for the first time since the invasion and was decisively beaten by American pilots and gunners deep inside Germany.
PEARL HARBOR, July 7 -- The evacuation stage apparently has been reached in the Battle of Saipan. The enemy has made an attempt to salvage part of its beaten garrison.
The State of New York, which had been asked to deliver 30 per cent of the nation's $16,000,000,000 Fifth War Loan quota, officially met its assignment yesterday afternoon.

A continuation of the current sultry weather for today and over the week-end with cloudy skies and occasional light showers today is the forecast of the local Weather Bureau, with the only hope for relief coming from expected moderate wind.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 7 -- The British and United States delegations to the United Nations monetary and financial conference were reported officially tonight to be in agreement on a new draft plan for the proposed Bank for Reconstruction and Development which a will be circulated among the conferees within the next few days for suggested amendments.
BOSTON, July 7 (AP) -- The Indians blasted relief pitcher Mike Ryba for three runs in the eighth to break a deadlock and defeat the Red Sox, 8 -- 5, today.

The outlook for business and industrial companies planning to use air express for distribution of postwar products is distinctly optimistic, as well as for current expansion, according to Kinsey N. Merritt, general manager of public relations of the Railway Express Agency.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- That the question of a Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee may boil over Sunday or soon afterward was the inference in informed political circles tonight when it became known that Vice President Wallace was back on the American continent and apparently faced with deciding whether to fight for the nomination without the backing of his chief or gracefully bow out of the picture.

GENERAL STILWELL'S HEADQUARTERS, in North Burma, July 5 (Delayed) -- The defeat of the Japanese by Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's Chinese, British and American troops in the last eight months of campaigning in north Burma has been thorough and decisive.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- For the first time since the United States entered the world conflict, England is shipping steel plate to this country on reverse lend-lease, William L. Batt, chairman of the Combined Raw Materials and Related Boards, revealed today.

VENTNOR CITY, N.Y., July 7 -- Anthony E. Santasiere, former New York State champion and present holder of the New England title, was defeated for the first time in the sixth annual chess masters tournament on the Municipal Pier today.

ALBANY, July 7 -- Governor Dewey filled his last remaining Cabinet position today when he named Herman T. Stichman of New York City as State Commissioner of Housing. Mr. Stichman succeeds Ira S. Robbins, who has been Acting Commissioner for the last year and a half, following the resignation of Edward Weinfeld at the end of the Lehman Administration.

HEADQUARTERS, CHINESE EXPEDITIONARY FORCE, near Yunnan Burma Border. July 6 (Delayed) -- Chinese troops have captured a small settlement within one mile of the eastern wall of Tengyueh, the strongest Japanese base in western Yunnan or northern Burma.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on July 1 were 897,800 cars, the -~ssociation of American Railroads announced today. This was 16,533 cars, or 1.9 per cent more than for the preceding week; 45,718 cars, or 5.4 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 144,069 cars, or 19.1 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Patrolman Daniel McPadden's memory served him well yesterday. He was directing traffic at Flat-bush and Atlantic Avenues, Brooklyn, when he spotted a familiar figure entering a restaurant on that corner. Patrolman McPadden followed.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- Twentieth Air Force headquarters communique 3:

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- Lt. Col. Curtis B. Dall, former son-in-law of President Roosevelt, told a Congressional committee today that he neither had nor wanted White House influence in his business operations.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Prices for the basic construction of denim (2.20's) were advanced 1 cent a pound today by the Office of Price Administration in its first action pricing a major cotton item in accordance with the recently signed Stabilization Act of 1944.
ROME, July 7 (AP) -- A communiqu:
HARTFORD, July 7 -- Hartford and small towns fifty miles round about in this part of the Connecticut River Valley counted their dead from yesterday's circus tent fire at 152 tonight.

New municipal bonds amounting to $47,959,500 will come up for award next week, according to The Daily Bond Buyer, compared with this week's revised total of $29,491,000, and with the weekly average for 1944, thus far, of $20,237,545. The largest single piece of new financing next week will be that of $18,000,000 St. Petersburg, Fla., refunding bonds, scheduled for award next Saturday.

PHILADELPHIA, July 7 -- Aiming to prevent potential abuses in trading of stocks of manufacturers declaring dividends in the form of assets other than cash or securities, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today the adoption of two rules "based largely on the trading experience" with respect to recent whisky dividends.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 7 -- A divergence of views, admitting of no possible immediate reconciliation, between the Greek Government of Premier George Papandreon on the one hand and the Eam Communist organization within Greece on the other, was frankly admitted in a five-page communique issued tonight by the official Hellenic news agency.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Department-store sales for the week ended July 1 were 12 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
ADVANCE ALLIED HEADQUARTER, ON NEW GUINEA, Saturday, July 8 (AP) - A communiqu:

BRETTON WOODS, N. H., July 7 -- The steering committee of the United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference has taken action, it was announced today, to speed up the committees and subcommittees deliberating on plans for an international monetary fund to stabilize post-war currencies.

CHICAGO, July 7 -- Members of the National Retail Furniture Association, meeting today in connection with the midsummer market, were told by Henry R. Dinegar, deputy director of consumer durable goods of the OCR, that effect of the recent WPB lumber order "will be much less severe than you have been led to believe and will not be discriminatory or unduly detrimental to the operations of the furniture industry."

Total market values of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange was $53,067,698,691 at the end of June, an increase of 4 per cent over the $50,964,039,424 value reported on May 31, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. On June 30 there were 1,242 stock issues, aggregating 1,492,874,003 shares listed on the Exchange.

It is not merely a coincidence that General de Gaulle's overdue visit to Washington occurs after the Allied armies have opened a door into France. His presence is a sign that we are again in communication with a country that has been shut off from our world for four years. France is no longer an abstraction.
The pace of trading in cotton futures was slowed yesterday and the price range narrowed on the New York Cotton Exchange and the market closed 2 points higher to 2 points lower than on Thursday.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., July 7 (AP) -- Nearly 3,000 members of the famed First Marine Division, first to see action in the Pacific ground warfare, reached home today.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- Gen. John J. Pershing, 83-year-old commander of the World War American Expeditionary Force, told Gem Charles de Gaulle in a dramatic interview today that he believed the world struggle was nearing its end.

Your editorial on hay fever reaches correct conclusions. Possibly 10 to 15 per cent of all hay fever sufferers under medical care are benefited by injections, and possibly another 10 per cent are relieved, but little can be done for the rest of those who are affected by the ragweed family of pollens.

YONKERS, N.Y., July 7 -- After tying with Bill Goldbeck, Mount Kisco's pro, and C.W. (Gus) Benedict of Winged Foot for best-ball honors at 64 in today's Westchester P.G.A. pro-amateur event at Hudson River, Clarence Doser, Scarsdale pro, also teamed with Benedict captured first place on matching cards.

As Office of Price Administration authorities consider fixing summer rental ceilings at seashore, mountain and other resorts in this region, vacationists were reported yesterday to have bombarded the office of Chester Bowles, National OPA Administrator in Washington, with complaints of soaring summer rentals in Southern New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- The War Food Administration moved today to bolster unsteady wheat markets by increasing grower loan rates on the 1944 grain crop by 7 cents a bushel. The new rates will average $1.35 a bushel nationally.

ROME, July 7 -- United States Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson went on to other parts of the Italian theatre today, leaving correspondents with the warning that the enemy still was strong and this was no time to let up.

A vacant plot of twenty-five lots at St. Nicholas, Hillside and Fairview Avenues, in the Washington Heights section, has been sold by the DeWitt Holding Company to the 3536 Park Avenue Corporation for improvement with an apartment house after the war from plans by H.I. Feldman, architect.

A report showing drastic cuts in B and C gasoline rations in this city released by the Regional Office of Price Administration on Thursday was corrected yesterday by Daniel P. Woolley, Regional OPA Administrator. Mr. Woolley pointed out that the figures released from his offices the day before were "incomplete."

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The Allies have authorized Premier Ivanoe Bonomi to move the seat of his Government from the south of Italy to Rome, it was learned today. The move is expected to take place in the near future.

St. Matthew's Lutheran Church oldest Lutheran congregation in the United States, chartered in 1664, moved this week from Convent Avenue and West 145th Street, where it has been situated for thirty-eight years, to Park Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street.

Four hundred and nineteen repatriated seamen, the largest contingent of members of the American Merchant Marine to arrive here, came in yesterday afternoon aboard a transport. The majority, it was said, took part in the invasion of France.
The resignation of Gen. Luis Cesar Perlinger as Minister of Interior in the military Government of Argentina is an encouraging sign. Whether it is more than that remains to be seen.

Deliveries that will permit rapid turnover, labels that will sell merchandise and the reinstatement of advertising allowances are among the requests by chain and supermarket operators of food manufacturers for the post-war period, according to a survey by William A. Dolan, president of Wilbert Products Company, to be published by the Grocery Manufacturers of America, Paul S. Willis, president of the group announced yesterday.

The motion-picture theatre and taxpayer at 931-55 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, have been sold by the Vankirk Operating Corporation to the Selstort Corporation. The transaction involved the refinancing of the theatre by the Excelsior Savings Bank and cancellation of existing leases on the theatre.

For the second time American Super-fortresses have bombed the main islands of Japan, striking both at the great naval base of Sasebo and at the steel plants of Yawata, which were the target of the first attack. Two facts are made clear by this achievement. First, that the recent Japanese drive into Honan and Hunan Provinces has not endangered the bases from which the great American planes take to the air.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Saturday, July 8 -- The capture of Namber airfield, last Japanese military installation of any importance on Numfor Island, was announced by Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters today.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The Office of Price Administration today instructed all shoe establishments, from manufacturer to retailer, to take inventory of their rationed shoes and ration currency as of the close of business on Monday, July 31.

ATLANTA, July 7 (AP) -- Major Louis Rothschild Lefkoff, 34, of Atlanta has been court-martialed and found guilty of ordering the flogging of nine military prisoners at Camp Van Dorn, Miss., Fourth Service Command Headquarters reported today.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 7 (AP) -- Joe Ruszas of Albany and Steve Doctor of Buffalo won semi-final matches today in the State amateur golf championship and will meet in tomorrow's thirty-six-hole final over the Lake Placid Club course for the title left undefended by Ray Billows, now in the Army.

CHUNGKING, China, July 7 -- Chinese troops in a dramatic comeback, have smashed through the encirclement ring around vital Hengyang, surrounded Japanese troops east, south and west of the city, and seized the initiative in all sectors of the Hunan Province fighting, the Chinese High Command said tonight.

THE TIMES reports additional cases of hoodlums throwing stones at passenger trains, endangering the life, limb and eyesight of passengers. This writer knows of a little girl who lost the sight of an eye by having a stone strike her as she was riding in a train.

Robert E. Mitchell, until recently president of Paint Engineers, Inc., and Clifford W. Chapman, certified public accountant, formerly with Gould, McIntosh Co. have been appointed general manager and treasurer, respectively, of the Richmond Screw Anchor Company, Inc., Brooklyn.

While officials of one large baking company described the offer of the Office of Price Administration of an increased allotment of sugar for a greater use of eggs as unpractical, Ralph D. Ward, president of Drake Bakeries, Inc., and chairman of the American Bakers' Association, said yesterday that most baking companies in the country would try to help the Government by applying for part or all of the extra sugar.

ST. LOUIS, July 7 (AP) -- Hammering four pitchers for seventeen hits, including a homer by Ab Wright, the seventh-place Braves walloped St. Louis, 10 to 5, tonight. The league-leading Cardinals had their best inning in the fourth, when they collected four runs on six hits.

Do you know what to do with yourself in New York in the summertime? The Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, in starting its "At Home Vacations" campaign yesterday, has a lot of answers for those who want to go places and see things. On the circular ledge in the middle of the CDVO Pershing Square Information Center on East Forty-second Street opposite Grand Central Station a huge master-file made its debut yesterday.

PAWLING, N.Y., July 7 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, arriving here for a week-end at his farm, Dapplemere, told a welcoming crowd of about 800 of his neighbors today that what America was really fighting for in this war was the neighborliness and the spirit of the type he had come to know so well in the seven years he had lived in the community.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (U.P.) -- A careful War Department check disclosed tonight that six United States Army Air Force officers Tokyo claimed were killed during the first Superfortress raid on Japan were alive and well when the Japanese broadcast was made.

TRENTON, N.J., July 7 (AP) -- The advisory committee of the State Board of Education reconsidered today the application of the Essex College of Medicine and Surgery of Newark for a license to confer the degree of Doctor of Medicine.

BEFORE the new book season begins in earnest the old one should be cleaned up. Staring at me with accusing eyes is Oswald Garrison Villard's "The Disappearing Daily: Some Chapters in American Newspaper Evolution,"* which I read in May in the hospital largely for the pleasure of its gossip value about the trade I practice.

Activities in the investment field, already dormant because of the war loan drive, were curtailed further this week by the Independence Day holiday. No new issues of bonds were offered for public subscription, but several in the tax-exempt class were awarded to bankers.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- President Roosevelt at his press conference today said the question of recognizing the French Committee of National Liberation as a provisional government would not be discussed here during Gen. Charles de Gaulle's visit any more than it had been at London.

A strongly worded speech of a thinly veiled political nature by Senator Frederic R. Coudert Jr., New York City Republican, was censored last night by Radio Station WMCA shortly before it was to be delivered to the New York County convention of the American Legion at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 7 -Physicians, surgeons and nurses in local hospitals crowded with circus fire victims gave fervent thanks today for blood plasma made available by the Red Cross and other agencies.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast by the Moscow radio to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communique Commission:

The right of justices of the Supreme Court of Kings County to determine what salaries shall be paid to its administrative, clerical and other personnel was upheld yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Felix C. Benvenga.

Philadelphians who had been looking forward to viewing the world premiere last night of the new Mae West play, "Catherine Was Great," were temporarily frustrated. At the eleventh hour, Mike Todd, the unpredictable showman, decided to postpone the opening, until Monday evening, because he felt that "the best efforts could be effected" only if more work were put in the show within the next few days.

CHICAGO, July 7 -- Faced by a situation in which 80 per cent of the capacity of the piano industry is idle while OPA pricing policies are blocking limited resumption of production authorized by the WPB, members of the executive committee of the National Piano Manufacturers Association announced today a "last ditch" meeting to be held in this city July 24.
Lady Richards, wife of Sir Arthur Frederick Richards, Governor of Nigeria, is at the Barclay.

Retail trade here continued very active this week with buying well sustained after the July 4 holiday. Some stores here had increases of up to 20 per cent over last year. Seasonal and vacation merchandise was in brisk demand.

LONDON, July 7 -- One of the most interesting developments today in the unseen war being fought against Adolf Hitler's robot bombs was the announcement that the Royal Air Force's 12,000-pound "earthquake" bombs can penetrate the heavy concrete structures from which the enemy is believed to be preparing to launch his heavier rockets.

JELLICO, Tenn., July 7 (AP) -Army and civilian rescue squads worked today to remove the dead and injured from the wrecked engine and four cars that plunged fifty feet into a gorge when a southbound troop train was derailed eleven miles from here last night.

LONDON, Saturday, July 8 -- Advancing Soviet troops, nearing the border of Lithuania, drove to within twenty miles of Vilna, its capital, yesterday, while 110 miles to the south other Red Army units began an artillery bombardment of the great Baranovichi rail junction.
CINCINNATI, July 7 (AP) -- Young Charley Schanz tripped the Reds today and broke their four-game winning streak with a 3-2 decision for the Phillies.

ALGIERS, July 7 -- Because of differences of opinion with War Department officials regarding political censorship, Col. Egbert White, director of Mediterranean editions of The Stars and Stripes, service men's daily newspaper, has been relieved of his command and ordered back to the United States, it was learned reliably today.

FORT WORTH, Tex., July 8 (AP) -Ater a "round the world" flight of more than 37,000 miles during which he visited Army Air Forces installations and observed American airmen in combat in virtually every theatre of the war, Lieut. Gen. Barton K. Yount last night returned to headquarters of the AAF training command, which he heads.
YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, July 8 -- Frankie Sinkwich, former University of Georgia All-America halfback, will report to the Army Monday for induction.

ADIRONDACKS -- This week finds the sports and social fronts here in full action. The Schroon Lake Golf Club's tricky course moves into the limelight this month with many tourneys and benefit events planned. Among evening activities are old-fashioned square dances every Friday in Lockwood's barn for the benefit of the national war fund and round dancing in the town park on Wednesdays.

"REX OF THE COAST PATROL," which adds another breed to the long list of excellent dog portraits by these author artists, is a war story as well as a dog story. Rex, a fine German police doff, is separated from his master and left in charge of an unimaginative man with no real liking for animals.

DETROIT, July 8 (AP) -- With Gov. Harry F. Kelly, Republican, unopposed for renomination in next Tuesday's primary election, major interest centered today on a three-way race for the Democratic Gubernatorial nomination and a contest for the Republican nomination for Lieutenant Governor.

Says OPA Survey Supports Contention of Income Drop William J. Demorest, general chairman of the Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee, issued a statement yesterday in which he said that the committee recognized the necessity of the Government action in stabilizing rents, "but we believe that rigid and inequitable ceilings, which leave little or no margin over fixed charges, should be adjusted in the spirit of sound economic stabilization.

THE vacation-near-home policy is being well observed, according to the American Express travel survey for July. The Adirondacks, runs the report, in addition to its usual New York City clientele, shows a strong draw form New York State.

Probably nine out of every ten business men in the United States are blissfully unaware that there is brewing a domestic battle to determine whether the traditional American system of business for profit shall survive, or whether the post-war days will see our economy taken over by a socialistic adventure that is known as the cooperative democracy or the cooperative commonwealth.

IT may be assumed that, this last week, the drama students have been dusting off their Eugene O'Neill collections to find what Hollywood did -- or didn't do -- to that author's "The Hairy Ape." It is fair to assume this because it invariably happens when the film people, with hopeful sighs and jutting chins, invade the solitary master's premises of abstractionism, expressionism and allied dimensional mechanisms.

THE National Victory Garden Institute has announced a "Green Thumb Contest" for Victory gardeners. A $1,000 war bond is the national grand prize for the best adult gardener, and $500 bonds will be awarded to the winning elementary and high school entrants.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Severe criticism of the New Deal's handling of food problems, a demand for the setting up of a single control agency "free from White House domination," such as was conducted by Herbert Hoover during the World War, and a charge that inefficient administration was responsible for the black market were in the Republican Congressional Food Study Committee report submitted today to Joseph W. Martin Jr., House minority leader.

CLEVELAND, July 8 (AP) -- Seven stables and a feed storage barn at suburban North Randall, scene of the season's initial Grand Circuit harness racing meeting, were destroyed by fire late today but all horses quartered in the buildings were led to safety.

SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND, Kandy, Ceylon, July 8 (UP) -- Triumphant British Imperial troops have dislodged Japanese invasion remnants from positions northeast, southeast and southwest of liberated Imphal in India's Manipur State, an Allied communique said today, bringing to 11,000 the number of Japanese killed since their invasion began March 12.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The reason that Gen. Charles de Gaulle has been visiting President Roosevelt this week is that the relations between his French Committee of National Liberation and the two great western Allies have come increasingly to turn upon -- indeed, consist of -- the relations between General de Gaulle and Mr. Roosevelt.

PHILADELPHIA, July 8 (AP) -- With the veteran Bobo Newsom tossing three-hit ball, the Athletics scored their second victory in a row over the White Sox, 3-1, today. Newsom held Chicago hitless in the last four innings, chalking up his seventh victory against the same number of defeats.

BY way of preparation for a trip to Florida this fall, Stuart Cloete (the rancher from Africa who wrote "Congo Song" early in 1943 and is now completing "Against These Three," a triple biography of Cecil Rhodes, Paul Kruger and Lobengula, last king of the Matabele) purchased at Macy's a rubber raft, in lieu of a fishing boat, and two chicken houses, to be used as living quarters for himself and his wife.

As an inveterate moviegoer, though not the type who would stand in line for an hour or more to get into a theatre, I take issue with Harry Brandt's defense of producers asking the public to pay higher than regular prices for ultra-expensive pictures.

Drs. Albert Milzer, Franz Oppenheimer and Sidney Levinson write in The Journal of the Medical Association that they have developed a vaccine which has given encouraging results in mouse poliomyelitis, Milzer, Oppenheimer and Levinson kill the virus of polio by ultraviolet irradiation.

Miss Marion Martin of Bangor, Me., who founded the National Federation of Women's Republican Clubs of America in 1938, was named yesterday as assistant chairman of the Republican National Committee with the full power and vote of a national officer.

PHILADELPHIA, July 8 -- T.C. Swarts, president of the Pennsylvania Bankers' Association, announced today the appointment of a committee on international monetary exchange which would "boil down to brass tacks" the conclusions reached by the United Nations Monetary Conference and would assist in presenting "the considered views of Pennsylvania business and banking" regarding the conference to Congress 'in the right way."

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- Reflecting unfavorable planting weather and a shortage of labor, Southern farmers planted this year the smallest acreage to cotton since 1895, the Department of Agriculture reported today. Cotton in cultivation on July 1 was estimated at 20,472,000 acres, which was 6.7 per cent less than last year and about 35 per cent less than the 1933-42 average.
VATICAN CITY, July 8 -- The famous Basilica of Loretto was "gravely damaged" in an air attack, the Vatican learned today.
Major league baseball goes on its annual mid-summer vacation this week to make room for the All-Star game Tuesday night under the lights at Forbes Field, Pittsburgh.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 8 (AP) -- Communique 65:

Record-breaking deposits and total resources, sizable gains in loans and discounts, comparatively small gains in holdings of United States Government securities and of cash, and fairly substantial increases in earnings marked the quarterly condition statements issued last week by leading Wall Street banks.

Last Friday -- July 7, anniversary of the start of Japan's war on China in 1937 -- the skies over Japan's Kyushu Island were filled again with the roar of American B-29's, the new Super-fortresses. Down on to the steel center of Yawata, the naval base of Sasebo (comparable to the American Norfolk) and other vital area, whistled tons of explosives and incendiaries.

Nowhere in our economy, except in railroad transportation, do we have today less Government intervention than in the earlier World War. Yet railroad service has kept fully apace with the enormously increased demands of industry and the armed services -with only negligible net additions to plant.

THIS official guide, a directory, almanac, and chronicle of achievement of the Army Air Forces, has been made available to civilians because, in the words of Gen. H.H. Arnold, "in a democracy it is fitting that the people should have the opportunity to obtain a thorough understanding of their military organization."

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Lagging production in several key war programs caused concern this week among officials responsible for maintaining the flow of munitions to fighting fronts at peak levels. May production was off 1 per cent from schedule, and preliminary reports on June output indicated that last month's production also might have declined.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The ever-widening split between the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations and signs of increasing dissatisfaction in certain AFL quarters with the Roosevelt Administration may have an important effect on the November elections, in the opinion of veteran labor observers here.

WHEN Margaret Landon happened on the curious story of Anna Leonowens, the English governess at a Siamese Court, her first impulse was to free the bright legend from a weight of stuffy detail and the threat of oblivion.

VENTNOR CITY, N.J., July 8 -- Play in the eighth and semi-final round of the annual chess masters tournament on the municipal pier tonight gave the leaders little occasion for satisfaction. Although they continued in a tie for the lead, Jacob Levin of Philadelphia and Albert S. Pinkus of Brooklyn played to adjournment with anything but simple tasks facing them.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 8 (AP) -- David Hinshaw, representative of a New York public relations firm, left a press conference at the United Nations monetary conference today after a reporter demanded to know "by what authority" he was present.

We have a new peace plan. Mr. Lippmann's proposed system for the organization of the world throws overboard so many ideas which have received much consideration, tosses away conceptions dear to so many hearts, that it is bound to be received with ample criticism, but no one will question its characteristic of novelty.

SELECTIONS from the writings of more than 150 American foreign correspondents are here gathered together under chronological and geographical headings, with the intention of composing an eyewitness history of the present war.
It was Eddie Arcaro again yesterday in the $50,000 added Empire City -- Arcaro and Stir Up, Greentree's chestnut gelding.

PITTSBURGH, July 8 -- Meeting for the third summer under war conditions, the National Education Association, representing the bulk of the nation's teaching profession, completed a week's deliberations during which the most critical problems facing teachers were considered and analyzed.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sunday, July 9 -- A smashing offensive on Caen, keystone of the German positions on the eastern front in Normandy, was launched yesterday by British and Canadian divisions of the British Second Army.

While many countries in Latin America, along with larger countrie like Great Britain, Ireland and China are pioneering in the midst of the war to develop programs to aid the small farmer and to restore the family-sized farm in the nattional economy as a measure for post-war stability, the United States is lagging far behind.

Although marked advances have been made in heeding appeals of racial minorities, more issues of civil liberty have arisen from the "conflicts in our democracy than from the war itself," the American Civil Liberties Union asserted in an annual review released yesterday.

WHERE were you on the afternoon of Dec. 7, 1941? At the movies? Listening to the Philharmonic? Sitting down to Sunday dinner without bothering to turn off the radio? Or did the phone ring and an excited voice exclaim, "Have you heard what's happened?" Mercedes Roseberry begins her book, "This Day's Madness," at this crucial point in our nation's history, and goes on to tell what happened after that.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- A check of the proceedings of Democratic National Conventions showed an 1864 precedent for barring participation by delegates who say they will not abide by the convention's decisions.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Constantin Fotitch, Ambassador of Yugoslavia, conferred with Under-Secretary of State Edward R. Stettinus Jr. today and then announced his refusal to recognize the new Yugoslav Cabinet formed in London on the grounds "that it contains no Serbs from Serbia and does not represent the views of the great majority of the people in Yugoslavia."

ROME, July 8 -- Jascha Heifetz came back to Rome today for his first concert since he played at the Augusteo ten years ago, but this time it was a quite different audience. He was playing for Allied soldiers at the opera house without charge -- and the result was the theatre was only half full to begin with and at best three-quarters full later.

TECUMSEH, Mich., July 8 (AP) -- Henry Ford came to Tecumseh today to help Perry Hayden and his neighbors harvest the fourteen-acre field of wheat with which Mr. Hayden, a miller, is providing a living Scriptural illustration.
LONDON, July 8 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communiqe:
MADRID, Spain, July 8 (AP) -Goebbels, in his weekly Reich today, said that "the greatest political error our adversaries committed in this war was imposing a war of life and death on the Reich."

THE Presidential campaign now beginning is unique in so many respects that it is a sore trial to veteran political observers. It hinges on contingencies quite without precedent, which puts the soothsayers on the spot; for the signs and portents on which they are accustomed to base their predictions may not be any good this year.

CAIRO (By Wireless). ALLIED advances into Nazified Europe from the east, south and west are making a reality of a problem that has been under discussion ever since the Battle of Britain four years ago: What is to be done to reinsure the liberties of the people of the Continent when they are released from slavery? How are they and the world to be prepared for what idealists hope may be a millennium of peace?

NOT for the first time these columns are moved to something approaching awe at the arrival of a new daytime serial or, in the vulgate, a soap opera. The awe is in direct ratio to the apathy that precedes the advent of one of these works, which have a curious way of creeping into Radio Row in a slightly shamefaced manner, as if they expected to be turned away at the door.

THE Man From Down Under popped into the office, puffing furiously at his pipe and living wreaths of smoke behind him. In his usual brisk style M.P. Greenwood-Adams, the lecturer and author, pulled up a chair, pinned his listener firmly with a pipe-stem and fired away with both barrels.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 8 -With added and better equipment now in use, the training of State Guard troops at Camp Smith here has undergone a distinct change. Little instruction is now in evidence as virtually all exercises are conducted in practical demonstrations on the fields and rugged hillsides of the 2,500-acre reservation.
