The National Maritime Union announced yesterday receipt of a "far-reaching" National War Labor Board decision that Howard McKenzie, vice president of the NMU and chairman of its negotiating committee, asserted would stabilize wages and conditions in the maritime industry, adding that "it lays a cornerstone for unimpeded labor-management cooperation."

A SANDWICH LOAF -- made by slicing a loaf of bread lengthwise, interlaying the slices with a flavorful filling and "frosting" the whole thing with mayonnaise -- provides a light but satisfying main course for summer luncheons or suppers.
I'VE just been told that over 3,000 of our American boys died in the first eleven days of the invasion of France.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 8 -Winding up a week of unprecedently pessimistic pronouncements, Dr. Joseph Goebbels, the German Propaganda Minister, addressing a mass meeting of 200,000 "some- where in Western Germany" this afternoon, warned his listeners there will be no "next time" for Germany in "ten, twenty or fifty years * * * because our adversaries if we do not throw them back now will erase Germany and everything German from the face of the globe."

CHUNGKING, China, July 8 (AP) -- American airmen continued their pulverizing attacks on the highly vulnerable Japanese lines of supply throughout Hunan Province, as the Chinese in a savage counter-attack recaptured and occupied the town of Liling, Japanese stronghold along the front north of the Canton-Hankow railway junction of Hengyang, the Chinese High Command said tonight.

WHEN a theatre veteran of John Golden's eminence contributes $100,000 for "the general benefit and cultural advancement of the legitimate theatre" the applause should be terrific. That in the present case a dissenting voice is raised is the fault not of the gift but of the philosophy in which it is wrapped.

LETTUCE, peas, beans, beets have been in the vanguard advancing to the day when all vegetables on the table will be home grown. The quality of these garden fresh vegetables is one of the principal rewards for which Victory gardeners have been working and waiting, a quality that depends in no small degree upon harvesting them at the right time and using them promptly.
A billion dollar show will be staged tomorrow morning when New York's dress industry will present a preview of styles for next winter to the nation's fashion press.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 8--Scoring a pair of best-ball 63s, a total of twenty strokes under par, the consistent Byron Nelson-Jug McSpaden twosome picked up nine points in today's two rounds and jumped into an almost unsurmountable lead with only 36 holes remaining to be played in the $10,000 Golden Valley team golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Plans for reorganizing and modernizing Congress with a view to greater efficiency in operations with less strain upon its members, have been entered upon the Senate calendar after nearly seven months of consideration of Senate and House jurisdictions and prerogatives in the working out of legislation for setting up a joint body to undertake the streamlining job.

THE collision of the American reader of 1832 with Mrs. Trollope's "Domestic Manners of the Americans" produced an explosion which rumbled on for decades. Read in every village, town and city, the book wrung a war whoop of wrath out of an outraged Republic.

THE radio audience in this country cannot hear either the enemy's domestic broadcasts or our own assiduous broadcasting to enemy territory. The story of our part in this radio warfare is not yet told. But the other story, the story of the changing line taken by the Nazi home radio as the war has passed from phase to phase, is for the first time fully exposed in the volume before us.

When airplanes fly at altitudes of nine or ten miles, as some designers predict they will, some difficult electrical equipment problems will have to be solved, Lieut. Col. T.B. Holliday of the Army Air Forces told the American Institute of Electrical Engineers at St. Louis recently.

I READ with great interest the letter of Electus Litchfield, published in your columns last Sunday, suggesting the eventual use of the Henry Villard residential unit on Madison Avenue as a music library, with certain rooms reserved for the presentation of chamber music.

The cold-blooded massacres of virtually the entire populations of the Greek village of Distomo and the French village of Oradoursur-Glane and the burning of both towns by vengeance-mad German soldiers were reported in accounts reaching this country yesterday, according to The Associated Press.

I READ with some amusement and a little irritation Harry Brandt's letter in last Sunday's NEW YORK TIMES. When Mr. Brandt chooses to laugh off lightly the predicament of a man who stands in line fifteen minutes and sees the admission price change right before his eyes, it's obvious that Mr. Brandt hasn't stood in line much recently.

BOSTON, July 8 -- Now that private enterprise as well as international cooperation has become a Presidential campaign issue, thoughtful New Englanders talk much of what the war and Washington have done to commerce.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 8 (AP) -- Ogden Phipps' Subdued, fresh from a victory at Aqueduct, won the first division of the Rancocas Stakes at Garden State Park today, coming from far back in her first attempt at the six-furlong distance.

LONDON, July 8 -- For the first time in many days the people of southern England today went about their business without disturbance from flying bombs from early morning until evening.

Compulsory savings is one of the fiscal devices developed for the first time during this war. Such savings are effected by increasing the tax rate and then refunding part of the increase after the war. Both England and Canada have adopted this device to help meet their financial needs.

AT THE ITALIAN FRONTIER, July 8 (AP) -- Sabotage, street fighting and violent strikes in German-held northern Italian cities are bringing murderous but ineffectual reaction from the Nazis, according to reports reaching here today.

The engineering curriculum of the future should place greater emphasis on training students in civic and professional responsibilities, it is recommended in a recent report prepared for the Society for the Promotion of Engineering Education. Engineers must assume a more important share in shaping public policies and practices in the post-war era, the report held.
BOSTON, July 8 -- In a roughly run event Mrs. Weston W. Adams' Kewey Dee emerged a nose winner of the $10,000 added Myles Standish Stakes at Suffolk Downs today before a crowd of 19,013.

YENAN, China, July 1 (Delayed) -- Chou En-lai, major Communist leader, explained today the negotiations in Chungking between Lin Chu-han, Communist representative, and Government officials. In an interview he said:

CHICAGO, July 8 -- The amazing Melvin Ott deposited his twentieth home run of the campaign in Wrigley Field's right field bleachers this afternoon, clubbed home his fiftieth run of the season, and ambled on his 2,000th pass in his nineteen years' career as a Giant.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 8 -- Loss of the 13,050-ton President Grant of the American President Lines was announced today by the War Shipping Administration as crew members, returning here, told of a vain three-month battle to save the ship after it had struck a submerged reef in a South Pacific war zone.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 8 -- Joe Ruszas, Albany war plant worker, captured the men's State amateur golf crown on the Lake Placid Club course today, overwhelming Steve Doctor, Buffalo, by 13 up and 11 to go.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Strategically -- at least so far as geographical considerations are concerned -- the United States now is close to the crucial phase of the Pacific war. Our B-29 Superfortresses have struck their second blow against Japan, and our Navy ranges the Pacific with impunity.

FEW countries in the world face such urgent, numerous and difficult problems as Australia. A nation of seven millions lying only a day or two by air from a teeming, hungry, restless continent of nearly a billion Asiatics, it has reason to feel its exposed position keenly, for it realizes that in 1941-42 it escaped disaster only by a narrow margin.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 8 -- The French Committee for National Liberation has developed an ambitious plan for a western European federation which its representatives at the monetary conference regarded as an important supplement to the international monetary agencies under discussion here.

Extending gains of the previous day, stocks closed strong and active yesterday around the best levels of the movement. The volume of trading on the Stock Exchange, 855,360 shares, was the largest for a Saturday in three weeks and the second largest for a two-hour session this year.

Retail trade was very active in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles following the Independence Day holiday, according to the survey made for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Main floors were crowded and sportswear sections were rushed.

LONDON, July 8 -- Statistics on the decline of the British coal industry since 1938 were made public today by Major Gwilym Lloyd George, Minister of Fuel and Power, in a White Paper.

The hay-fever season will be here about the middle of August. The eyes and noses of millions will run. Many who simply cough and sneeze will not know that they have hay fever. All live east of the Rocky Mountains. Only those in the northern Great Lakes region, northern New England and southern Florida will go unscathed.

Urging support of the plans of Pope Plus XII for world peace, 500 delegates to the tenth annual convention of Catholic War Veterans Inc., adopted resolutions yesterday seeking representation on the Peace Commission for their comrades who have fought in world wars.

SOMEWHERE around 10,000 bales of oriental rugs were released from customs warehouses at the end of last month when the new reciprocal trade treaty between the United States and Iran went into effect, slashing the rug tariff by about 50 per cent.

HOLLYWOOD will continue to keep up a heavy production schedule during the next year, despite earlier reports from major studios of a probable sharp curtailment. A few months ago, in the midst of tremendous box-office successes and longer-than-usual theatre runs, some top executives talked of slashing filming 50 per cent and more in face of a theatre inability to absorb all of the new products.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 8 -- Groping their way around Long Island Sound today in fog, forty-nine sailing craft competed in the special regatta of the Echo Bay Yacht Club. After several days of extreme heat, the gray haze settled over the water, which was much colder than the air.

RICHMOND, Va., July 8 -- Prolonged drought and abnormal heat have combined to create a serious situation in the eastern parts of Virginia, North Carolina, Kentucky and Tennessee. Crops are withering rapidly under the searing July sun, cattle are finding it difficult to get pasturage or water, and many victory gardeners are awakening to some of the farmer's old problems, of which previously they had been only dimly aware.

Yet to judge from the crowds waiting to get into film revivals, there is a sizable public for thoughtful movie criticism.

WASHINGTON, July 8--The American B-29 Superfortresses in their second strategic mission against Japan yesterday struck not only at three important enemy targets on the island of Kyushu of the Japanese islands proper, where they inflicted damage, but they also made important attacks at two strategic points in occupied China, it was disclosed today when a communique was issued at the War Department giving latest details.

Response to the newly announced Senior College to be launched this fall by the New School for Social Research has been "most gratifying," Dr. Alvin Johnson, director, has disclosed. Dewey underwent the ordeal to which nearly all Presidential candidates are subjected, that is, the revelation to an interested world, for newsreels, still camera shots and reporters, of the homelife of the family of a potential President.

Cohn of Buffalo, national finance committeeman of the organization, in an address at the Rhode Island D.A.V. convention.

The Fifth War Loan came to a triumphant close yesterday as the American public, once again demonstrating homefront support of the nation's fighting men, subscribed well over the $16,000,000,000 national bond quota.

Yesterday was the city's hottest day of the year, with the temperature soaring to 92.2 degrees at 3:15 P.M. The previous high mark for the year was established Thursday at 90.1 degrees.

The corridor is about ten feet wide and 100 feet long.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. BOWFIN Pearl Harbor, July 8 (AP) -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz today awarded the Presidential Unit Citation to the submarines Bowfin and Sailfish, which, together, sank seven Japanese ships despite persistent counter-attacks.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- A House subcommittee reported today that 24 per cent of all land in the continental United States was under Federal ownership.

THIS department in a recent issue published an interview with Dr. Artur Rodzinski, conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, suggesting practical steps to be taken jointly by orchestra conductors and music publishers to advance the product of the American composer.

CHICAGO, July 8 -- Members of the Cedar Chest Manufacturers Association of America, which met here this week-end, expressed belief that the supply outlook for their product is not too bad, notwithstanding WPB lumber order L-335, but expressed bewilderment at the problem of keeping pace with the rising tide of orders from men in the service.

HARRISBURG, Pa., July 8 -- Stella Walsh scored a brilliant triple triumph in today's women's national A.A.U. track and field championships, establishing a new meet record of 24.6 seconds for the 200 meters. The 33-year-old Cleveland Olympic star gained her sixth straight victory in the broad jump and beat Miss Alice Coachman of Tuskegee by a scant foot in the 100-meter dash.

WRITTEN with an engaging humor, "Life With Alice," is a delightful "true story" about animals. The tale began forty years ago when the author, young and out of work, applied for a job at the Hippodrome and was given a chance to help with the elephants.

Again the time has come to hear the politician agonize. He splits the quivering stratosphere with melancholy cries. He wails of wrongs to be redressed. His tears of woe, they flow in floods. He beats his inconsolable breast with dull and sickening thuds.

Liquidation by operators in New Orleans and scattered local profit-taking for the week-end checked yesterday an early advance in the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange and final prices were from 4 points net lower to 3 points net higher than on Friday, on active months, with the distant months relatively steadier than the near positives.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 8 -- California's wartime electric power pool will be increased substantially Friday when two 75,000-kilowatt generators go into operation at Shasta Dam, built at an estimated cost of $87,000,000.

To meet the demands of war and essential civilian requirements, operations in the domestic oil industry since the attack on Pearl Harbor have been expanding at a rapid rate, and indications now are that there will be adequate supplies of all petroleum products for the remainder of the war, even if it should be prolonged much more than now is expected.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The intensive study of the Argentine situation which Secretary of State Cordell Hull undertook this week with Ambassador Norman Armour, who was recalled from his post in Buenos Aires (for that purpose), runs much deeper than an inquiry into the question solely of pro-Axis sympathies that have been manifested by the revolutionary government now in control of the country.

From all the active fronts comes continuing evidence that Germany and her satellites are suffering attrition of materials and munitions of war at a rate which must already far surpass their ability to replace. The destruction by Allied forces is both at the source and in the field, both by airpower and by ground forces.

TO every parent there comes a time when the "book" doesn't provide the answer. As Mrs. Ruth T. Stone once told this reporter, "At certain times, with certain children, you have to know the picture, size it up, and then act, sometimes in spite of all the rules in the book."

SOLDIERS all over the world are always telling me that the Sad Sack, the gawky little round-shouldered private in the comic strip I draw for Yank, the Army Weekly, is a typical GI. They don't mean that everybody in the United States Army looks and acts like the Sad Sack.

A letter in THE TIMES from Elbert S. Brigham, former Representative in Congress and author of the Oleomargarine Color Test Law of 1931, concludes with the following paragraph: "Let the oleomargarine manufacturers build up a reputation for their product on its own merits and with a distinctive color of its own, and let the dairy farmer's trade-mark, represented by the yellow color of his product, alone. This is all the dairy farmers ask."
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- Sig Jakucki pitched a six-hit game tonight as the league-leading Browns defeated Washington, 5 to 4, before 14,693 fans.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -Two merchant ships effected the rescue of six Army and three Navy fliers who crashed at different points in the Pacific far from land, the War Shipping Administration reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The War Department replied tonight to criticisms of its "censorship" of political news reaching United States fighting men by reiterating that its conduct in this matter was guided by the provisions of the Soldier Voting Law.

DAYTON, Ohio, July 8 -- America's air might as demonstrated thus far in the war has been established by planes designed and tested before Pearl Harbor, Maj. Gen. Bennett E. Meyers, commanding general of the Army Air Forces Materiel Command, told editors and reporters who made a two-day visit to his headquarters at Wright Field.

During the last year and a half the Maritime Commission has accepted suggestions by shipyard employes that have resulted in improving shipbuilding operations and effected savings in man-hours and materials equivalent to $20,000,000, the commission estimated last week.

The other day we heard of a fisherman who was asked to produce his Coast Guard identification card on Peconic Bay. When the coast guardsman saw that it was one of the old ones bearing the signature of Comdr. J.S. Baylis the fisherman was told that it was no longer valid.

A GROUP of Catholic scholars undertook some time ago to discuss the doctrine of "race" as expounded by modern totalitarians. One volume, dealing with scientific aspects of the subject, was published in 1941. The present book contains nine careful essays which, while treating in part of race, are concerned more generally with the human person and its bearing on "race" and "nation," properly understood.

IN writing a book about young children for parents and teachers the most fatal error is certainly to load it with academic jargon. Dr. Blatz's "Understanding the Young Child" (and let no one be deceived by the title) is for all the world like the college psychology courses of our youth.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- A Congressional inquiry will be made to determine why nearly 5,000,000 young men are mentally or physically unfit for military service.

MRS. CLAPPER writes in her introduction to this, her husband's second and last book, that as early as 1917 Ray Clapper had but one ambition -- "he was going to be the best political writer in the country." It would be impossible to prove that he realized this ambition, for political writers can't be graded like apples.

JERUSALEM, July 8 -- The possibility that Chief Rabbis Isaac Halevy Herzog and Ben Zion Meir Uziel of Palestine will proceed to Vatican City to seek an audience with Pope Pius XII and urge him to intervene in behalf of the stricken Hungarian Jewry has been raised here.

ONE of philately's most precious pieces, a Boston-to-China cover bearing an 1860 90-cent stamp, changed hands at the recent auction of the United States collection of Henry C. Gibson, a retired Philadelphia bank president.

New York's Park Commissioner recently addressed some sharp words to parents about the "vandalism" of children which runs up a big annual bill of repairs for the city. One specialist in child guidance sides with Mr. Moses in calling parents to account, but it is his impression that there is more initial-carving and equipment-breaking by grown-ups and by older young people than by boys and girls.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Prospective supplies of butter for the balance of this year will probably be less than those of the last six months and the Government will have to continue its butter set-aside program through September and October, according to points developed here this week at a conference between Government officials and representatives of the butter industry.

Every borough, with the exception of Richmond, showed a steady increase in the number of juvenile delinquents for the first half of this year, compared with corresponding periods of 1942 and 1943, the children's division of the Do mestic Relations Court disclosed yesterday.
ALICIA MARKOVA and Anton Dolin will make their first local appearances since the expiration of their contracts with the Ballet Theatre on July 17 at the Lewisohn Stadium.

With a goal of 7,000 Christmas boxes for merchant seamen to be filled by Dec. 1, the Seamen's Church Institute of New York has announced that preparations for filling the boxes are in progress and that mid-summer is none too soon to begin on the project.

THE public controversy over what kind of peace should be imposed upon Germany has now -- reached such a peak of intensity that elaborate rival organizations have been set up to publicize the opposing points of view.

Sara Kosanovitch in his first interview as member of the new Yugoslav Cabinet said yesterday that he hoped to see a post-war democratic Yugoslav federation that would include Bulgaria, and a Balkan confederation which would cover also the non-Slavic countries -- Rumania, Greece and Albania.

A LOVELY, one-family, semi-tropical island off the coast of the Carolinas proves an ideal hot spot for Nazi dirty work at the crossroads of the Atlantic. The American Baroness Sophie had acquired the island after her divorce from Toby Millett.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast by the Moscow radio to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications commission:

EVERY owner of a crossroads store and every little one-room manufacturer has a stake in how the monetary questions posed at Bretton Woods are finally answered even if most merchants and producers do not understand what the conference is all about and often care less.

PEARL HARBOR, July 8 -- A fierce counter-attack by cornered Japanese troops on Saipan penetrated American lines on the island's western shore and gained more than a mile on Thursday. Several thousand Japanese hurled themselves at our left flank and, at terrific cost in casualties, advanced up to 2,000 yards, reaching the outskirts of Tanapag town, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz stated this morning.

PHILADELPHIA, July 8 -- The Philadelphia Transportation Company indicated today that it had accepted a directive of the Fair Employment Practices Committee on the hiring and "up-grading" of Negroes as operational employes with the posting of notices in car barns stating that all qualified applicants for employment will be accepted "without regard to the applicant's race, creed, color or national origin."

ROME, July 8 -- The Jewish community of Rome, one of the oldest in the world, lost 40 or 50 per cent of its members during the nine-month reign of German terror in Rome, and those who remain are economically, spiritually and physically prostrate, Prof. Anton Zolli, Chief Rabbi of Rome, said today.

NOBODY is in a better position to observe the reading tastes and preferences of the American book-buying public than the members of the Book of the Month Club's Committee on Selection. They have an unexcelled vantage point from which to survey whatever change and growth there may be in the attitude of that public toward contemporary books.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 8 -- The relentless Allied air attack on the Germans' dwindling oil supplies was maintained today when strong formations of United States heavy bombers from Italy struck at three refineries in the Vienna area.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 8 -Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr., chairman of the United States delegation and president of the United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference, expressed confidence today that the conference would "conclude" a successful agreement which would be "amicable and fair to all" before the scheduled end date of July 20.

NEENAH, Wis., July 8 (AP) -- Francisco (Pancho) Segura, National Collegiate A.A. champion from Ecuador, and Miss Pauline Betz of Los Angeles, national women's champion, scored victories today to reach the title rounds in tomorrow's championship play in the Western Senior Tennis tournament.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- A special Senate sub-committee voted 3 to 2 today in favor of a second five-year term for Leland Olds, chairman of the Federal Power Commission.

MAURICE SAMUEL'S later writings (excluding his translation of "The Apostle," etc.) fall roughly into categories: his provocative, ironic disquisitions on Jewish-Gentile problems, in which he bluntly assails anti-Semites as well as "assimilationist Jews"; and his informative, sometimes nostalgic, studies of Jewish life in the past and present, as exemplified in "The World of Sholem Aleichem" and in his books on Zionism, the latest of which is the beautifully written "Harvest in the Desert."

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The Defense Plant Corporation, Reconstruction Finance Corporation subsidiary entrusted with the acquisition of plants and equipment for the production of war goods, will shortly market some $13,000,000 worth of the $8,717,000,000 in land and plant it owns, it was learned here today.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 8 -- The Board of Public Works here rejected this week demands by Army air authorities that Elizabeth limit the height of all buildings erected here in an area extending from the meadowlands near Newark Airport to the heart of the city's business district.

Feeling the occasion momentous enough to do something startling, the Yankees yesterday exploded the myth that they have been suffering from an inferiority complex in their relations with the Tigers this year by upsetting Steve O'Neill's Detroiters in both ends of the afternoon's benefit double-header at the Stadium.

PHILADELPHIA, July 9 (AP) -- The Phillies will ask at tomorrow's National League meeting in Pittsburgh for permission to play five or six additional night games at Shibe Park, General Manager Herb Pennock said today.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Sales of all retail stores in May are estimated at $5,726,000,000 -- 10 per cent higher than sales in May a year ago -- the Department of Commerce estimated today.

Some additional caution on the part of buyers is being noted, due to progress of the war. This takes in so-called victory lines, with buyers believing the time may have arrived when the government will release materials for standard merchandise, according to a summary of activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
WITH AMERICAN FORCES in Normandy, July 9 -- La Haye du Puits is in American hands at last, after five days of hard fighting in and all around it.

PITTSBURGH, July 9 -- Some holiday shutdowns, combined with furnace repairs and unauthorized strikes, caused the ingot rate for the country last week to fall off 1 1/2 points to 94.5 per cent of rated capacity. Indications are that this week the rate will resume the level of the pre-holiday week.

If the public, in some future referendum, rejects both an increased fare and his proposal to tax rents, mortgage interest and commuters' pay checks, the five-cent fare will be preserved, but not for long, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall.

LONDON, July 9 -- In the twenty-six days since the Germans started trying to raze London by remote control the Guards Chapel in Birdcage Walk, a stone's throw from Buckingham Palace; the annex of the Regent Palace Hotel in Piccadilly Circus and the Bankruptcy Building, just behind the law courts near the Temple Bar, have all been hit by robot bombs.

More than half of the families aided by the Community Service Society last year received nursing and health services, according to the annual health services report of the agency, to be made public today.
CHICAGO, July 9 -- The Giants wound up their Western jaunt at Wrigley Field today by taking two on the chin from the Cubs before a gathering of 38,434.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (U.P.) -- One of the surgical miracles of the war was disclosed tonight in a War Department report telling how Army doctors laid open a soldier's chest and removed a half-inch shell fragment which had lodged against his heart seven months before in an African battle.

Cotton prices soared again into new high ground during the first half of last week, but subsequently lost a part of their gains. At the close of trading on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed for the week net advances of 13 to 40 points, with the best gains in the most distant positions.
NEWARK, N.J., July 9 (AP) -- The Syracuse Chiefs ended Newark's winning streak at seven games today by taking the nightcap of a twin bill, 9 to 3, after dropping the opener, 10 to 1.

NEENAH, Wis., July 9 (AP) -- Francisco (Pancho) Segura of the University of Miami and Miss Pauline Betz of Los Angeles today won the Western senior tennis championships. Segura won a grueling three-hour match from Bill Talbert of Indianapolis, while Miss Betz took the measure of Miss Dorothy Mae Bundy of Santa Monica, Calif., 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2.

Careful training from babyhood in the physical life and neglect of training in the spiritual life are serious inequalities in the care given by parents and teachers to children, the Rev. Dr. Bernard Iddings Bell of Providence, R.I., declared yesterday in a sermon in Trinity Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Chungking in English to North America and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

ST. LOUIS, July 9 (AP) -- The Cardinals finally climbed above the .500 mark in their season's series with the Braves today as Morton Cooper and Harry Brecheen pitched them to shutout victories, 1 to 0 and 9 to 0.

VENTNOR CITY, N.J., July 9 -- Jacob Levin of Philadelphia, former city and State champion, today emerged as the victor in the sixth annual invitation chess masters tournament on the Municipal Pier. Undefeated in nine games, Levin repeated his triumph of 1941,

WITH THE AMERICAN ARMY at Caumont, July 9 (AP) -- Eight German nurses, captured in an underground hospital near Cherbourg, were returned by the Americans through enemy lines today in the second no-man's land truce of the beachhead.
ROME, July 9 (UP) -- A communique:

Your reference in THE TIMES of July 3 to Mayor La Guardia's plan for a so-called "transportation tax," to raise $51,700,000, most of which would be levied on all rent payers, recalls that this is by no means the first time that such a tax has been proposed and rejected by New York.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 9 -- Warner Brothers will start production Wednesday to remake Somerset Maugham's "Of Human Bondage," previously filmed in 1934 by RKO, with Leslie Howard and Bette Davis co-starred. In its newest version Paul Henreid, who has just completed a part opposite Hedy Lamarr in "The Conspirators," will portray the Howard role and Eleanor Parker will have the feminine lead.

Samuel and Jesse H. Barkin have purchased the twelve-story loft building at 22-24 West Thirty-eighth Street from a client of Abraham L. Sobil, attorney, in a deal negotiated by Elizabeth Dornbierer, broker. The property is 50 by 100 feet and is assessed at $250,000.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 9 (AP) -- Jersey City and Baltimore divided a double-header before 6,379 fans today, the Orioles taking the opener amid riotous scenes by a score of 3 to 2, with the Little Giants coming back to slug out a 9-to-1 victory in the nightcap.

CHICAGO, July 9 -- Pullman, Inc., will not appeal to the Supreme Court a decision of a Philadelphia court ordering the divorce of its car servicing and car manufacturing operations. Instead, it indicated that it is preparing a separation plan.

The classified advertising columns of newspapers and magazines are ordinarily thought of as prosaic, utilitarian affairs. Somebody wants a job; he looks in the want ads. He wants to rent an apartment; the back pages of the newspaper are the place to find it.
LA HAYE DU PUITS, France, July 9 (AP) -- Skylarking infantrymen on captured bicycles and German shells are giving combat military police a traffic problem in this blitzed village.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- Orders which would set in motion the disputed plans of the WPB chairman, Donald M. Nelson, for limited resumption of civilian goods production were reported tonight to be "still in the works" at the War Production Board but making slow headway.

ROME, July 9 (AP) -- The Fifth Army has captured Volterra, the last good mountain road hub guarding the approaches to Leghorn, and Allied vanguards were fighting today within ten miles of the great Tyrrhenian port -- aflame with large fires apparently set by the enemy to destroy naval stores.

The Brown Sharpe Manufacturing Company reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $2,298,429 for 1943, comparing with $2,226,756 the year before, a rise of $71,673. Net sales were $60,6,53,478, comparing with $54,844,699, after a $5,300 renegotiation payment in 1942.

CHICAGO, July 9 -- The Government loan rate on the 1944 wheat crop was boosted 7 cents a bushel late last week to a national average of $1.35 a bushel, which, after allowing for freight and other charges results in farmers being able to obtain $1.56 here and about $1.50 for No. 1 grades of red and hard winter wheat at Kansas City.

VAL d'OR Que., July 9 (Canadian Press ) -- Forest fires that have swept the northern Quebec gold mine belt during the past three days, destroying one village, appeared to be dying down tonight at all threatened points.

NYACK, N.Y., July 9 -- Representative Hamilton Fish, standing for re-election in the new Twenty-ninth district, taking in Rockland, Orange, Sullivan and Delaware Counties, went out of his way today to take a pot shot at Helen Hayes, actress, who has been campaigning against him in behalf of Augustus W. Bennet, who is opposing him in the Republican primaries and will be the Democratic nominee.

BELLAIRE, Ohio, July 9 (AP) -- Drillers broke today into the tunnel where sixty-six miners were imprisoned 400 feet underground by fire last Wednesday, but hope of finding any of the men alive virtually vanished when only echoes answered calls down the nine-inch vent over a surface amplifier.
ROME, July 9 -- The Rev. Stanislaus Orlemansky, traveling "in a private capacity," will soon arrive in Rome, according to a report here today.
CHUNGKING, China, July 9 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

Strong price advances in cotton and eggs exceeded moderate price declines in wheat, poultry, lamb and naval stores, thus raising the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices from 112.81 to 112.95.

MOSCOW, July 9 -- The Soviet Government issued a stringent decree yesterday making important changes in divorce procedure. In future, a divorce will be obtainable only after a decision of the courts. The old method of divorce by declaration and registration at the marriage bureaus has been superseded.
LONDON, July 9 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin:

WASHINGTON, July 9 (U.P.) -- The first job of the platform committee of the Democratic national convention must be the drafting of a plank calling for effective international collaboration for world security, Representative John W. McCormack of Massachusetts, chairman of the committee, declared tonight.

CAEN, Sunday night, July 9 -- Caen has been severely battered as the result of Allied air attacks and the heavy shelling of the week-end. Further large-scale advances by the British and Canadians will be delayed until the wreck-strewn streets have been made passable again.

We have endeavored to substitute the standards of Hollywood for the Ten Commandments and for the Word of God and we have made a tragic blunder, the Rev. Joseph Irvine Chapman, pastor of Trinity Baptist Church, Brooklyn, declared in a sermon yesterday at the New York Avenue Methodist Church, Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, July 9 -- Dry and hot weather has forced the oat crop along to maturity at a rapid rate and harvesting is under way in central Illinois and Indiana and is expected to start in Iowa this week. Although the crop is reported as spotty, brokers expect a fairly liberal yield.

There are so many Broadway playhouses yawning at this time of the season that a producer can have his choice of the lot. And with any kind of luck his attraction can settle down to a comfortable run. On the other hand, those who prefer to wait for the arrival of cooler weather have nothing in common with the early bird.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- The league-leading Browns split a pair of shutouts with the Senators today before 17,210 fans, taking the opener, 10 to 0, on Tex Shirley's two-hit hurling and dropping the nightcap, 4 to 0.

On another daily two-million-share market, the average both for stocks and bonds went last Wednesday to the highest of 1944. Of stocks, the average was highest since May 13, 1940; of domestic bonds, highest of THE TIMES' compilations, which began in 1913. Later in the week, prices went somewhat higher.
CHERBOURG, July 9 (AP) -- A free French court, sitting in France for the first time since the German conquest, sentenced two young men yesterday to life imprisonment for spying on Allied troops.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Decreases in the supplies for civilians of butter, cheddar cheese and evaporated milk during the July-through-September period will be offset, in large measure, by increases in allocations of other fats and oils, other cheeses and condensed milk, the War Food Administration announced today.

Fireflies are Lilliputian lamplighters. Mr. Webster's prosaic and succinct definition of the on-again, off-again light givers as "small, elongated and flattened soft-bodied beetles producing a soft, intermittent light from the lower abdomen" covers sufficient technical details.
CAIRO, Egypt, July 9 -- The discovery of a buried city at Helwan on the outskirts of Cairo is announced by the Societe des Antiquites, an Egyptian archaeological organization.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- Two Senators who will help draft the Democratic platform at Chicago called today for a strong, plainly worded foreign policy plank to let the world know that America will take a hand in international affairs after the war.

A SECRET B-29 BASE, in Western China, July 9 (U.P.) -- American B-29 Superfortresses, which on Friday attacked Sasebo, one of Japan's largest naval bases, were believed to have struck while its workmen were repairing Japanese warships that the American Navy already had damaged in the Marianas, it was announced today.

A new recreation center for Bronx boys and girls, styled the Teen-Age Canteen, goes on full summer schedule today at Juvenile House, a youth center at 974 East 156th Street affiliated with Melrose Settlement House. The canteen is sponsored jointly by Juvenile House and the child care division of the Greater New York American Women's Voluntary Services.

BRETTON WOODS, July 9 -- With the problem of comparative national quotas still unsettled, another controversial issue took the center of the stage at today's discussions among delegates from forty-four united and associated nations to the United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference.

PHILADELPHIA, July 9 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics nicked two pitchers for eleven hits, including a homer by Frankie Hayes, to defeat the Chicago White Sox, 8 to 2, before 17,288 today after losing the first game of a double-header, 4 to 3.

LONDON, July 9 -- Certain physical difficulties are being imposed on Stock Exchange dealings by flying bomb raids because from the beginning of the war it has been the practice to clear the floor of the house during raid warnings. Members, however, have quickly adjusted themselves, and what business cannot be transacted in the Exchange itself is done either in the street or by interoffice communication.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 9 (A.P) -- Communique 67:

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 9 (AP) -- The three top-seeded women in the Eastern clay courts tennis championship all breezed through first and second round matches today, the second day of the tourney on the Montclair Athletic Club courts.

LONDON, Monday, July 10 -- Russian troops, rapidly driving the Germans back toward their last major defense line in the East, captured the important rail junction of Lida, fifty-six miles south of embattled Vilna, yesterday and reached the Latvian border in a powerful new offensive aimed at Dvinsk, Riga and the Baltic Sea.

PAWLING, N.Y., July 9 -- Governor Dewey left the quiet of his Quaker Hill farm today, refreshed by a week-end in the country, for a series of important conferences this week in Albany with Republican Congressional leaders and candidates.

WITH FIFTH ARMY NURSE CORPS, Anzio, Italy, June 8 (Delayed) -- Nurse traveling by motor from Anzio to Rome today were cheered along the Appian Way by Italian civilians who seemed impressed to find American women in uniform following so closely behind the troops.

In protest against the persecution of Jews in Hungary, Americans of Hungarian descent held yesterday special services. At Castle Hill Garden Park, the Bronx, 2,000 gathered at 5 P.M. for a ceremony sponsored oy the New Light Temple of Yorkville and the American Hungarian Federation of Washington.

It is part of our nation's tradition that rural economy be based on the small farm. Now that science is entering agricultural production, some groups are alarmed lest the farming philosophy of Jefferson be eliminated. Certain planners favor the large-scale, corporation type of agriculture.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 9 -- Long Island Sound's racing fleet today moved east to Great Captain Island off here for the Indian Harbor Yacht Club's regatta and sixty-five craft engaged in about the best competition of the summer.

Despite their satisfaction at the over-all success of the Fifth War Loan in the city, State and nation, officials of the Treasury and the War Finance Committee pointed out yesterday that a tremendous job remains to be done to reach the objectives set for the sale of E bonds, the popular-priced savings bonds that are especially important for their anti-inflationary effect.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 9 -- Private reports from France indicate that the principal concern of Frenchmen is whether liberation of their country from the Germans and Vichy is to be accompanied by restoration of all liberties. In the final analysis this question arises also between Washington and Algiers.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (U.P.) -- The Government is taking all possible steps to insure that small businesses started by veterans with Government-guaranteed loans will succeed, Quincy Adams, chief of the Division for Small Business, Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce, said tonight.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 9 (AP) -- Nazi Elite Guard troops have been placed in charge of the campaign against French patriots to release units of the German Army for front line duty, it was reliably reported today after a tour of the front by the new German commander in France, Field Marshal Gen. Guenther von Kluge.

Delegation of provisional authority to fourteen private non-fee-charging employment agencies to refer to employment men between 18 and 45 years old under the War Manpower Commission's priority referral program was announced yesterday by Stephen S. Sheriden, WMC director for the New York City area.

The robot bombings of England by the Germans will only hasten Hitler's undoing for they serve only to accentuate the vicious circle of self-destruction, spiritual if not always physical, in which the Germans are entrapped, declared the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, the pastor, in his sermon yesterday in Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.
CHICAGO, July 9 (U.P.) -- An electronic automatic pilot device has been developed which permits a Flying Fortress bombardier to make course changes at the moment he is sighting a target.

NEWARK, N.J., July 9 (AP) Shortages of apartments in almost every section of the State, and also of modern, usable industrial property have been revealed by the third annual survey of the real estate market conducted by the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards, President Howard W. Van Ness said yesterday.

BOSTON, July 9 (AP) -- Bunching three of their five hits with two walks in the first two innings, the Red Sox defeated the Indians, 4 -- 2, in the second game of a double-header today. Cleveland won the first game, 8 -- 2.

Declaring that the city's parking problem "has been exaggerated" and is "acute only in exceptional small areas of great density," Park Commissioner Robert Moses in a report to Mayor La Guardia yesterday said the city's contribution to a solution will be chiefly in present and future boulevards, expressways and parkways with service roads and incidental parking facilities.

Samuel F. Pryor, Eastern campaign manager for Wendell L. Willkie in the 1940 Presidential race, predicted victory for the Republican national ticket this year in a statement, issued yesterday, in which he voiced unqualified approval of Governor Dewey and his running mate, Governor John W. Bricker of Ohio.

CINCINNATI, July 9 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds took both ends of a double-header from the Philadelphia Blue Jays today, 9 to 5 and 7 to 5, in a pair of raggle-taggle contests which saw none of the four starting pitchers finish his game.
Following is the text of Vice President Henry Wallace's speech as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

A quick turnover of the ten-story-and-penthouse apartment building at 192 East Seventy-fifth Street has been made by Samuel Silk, who bought the property recently and now has resold it to an investor through Farber-Wittman, Inc., and Paul P. Zinner, brokers.

CHUNGKING, China, July 9 (AP) -- Grim fighting without much change in positions along the Canton-Hankow railway was reported by the Chinese High Command today, which said that Chinese units who broke the siege of Hengyang, 200 miles north of the Japanese-held lower part of the line, were still locked tightly in battle with the Japanese.

Seventy-two per cent of retailers plan the same advertising budget for next Christmas as in 1943, according to the results of a nation-wide survey of 1,804 retail stores, made by the Meyer Both Reports. Seventy-eight per cent will use a high percentage of appropriations for newspapers and a small percentage for radio.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Eight Regional Verification Centers to tighten the control over ration currency are now being established, according to the Office of Price Administration.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 9 (AP) -- Byron Nelson and Jug McSpaden, never behind in team scoring in 126 holes of play, today won the Golden Valley golf championship with a three-point margin over the second-place twosome of Bill Kaiser and Bob Hamilton.

Preaching yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral, the Rev. Robert E. Woods, of the cathedral staff, declared that attempts to "naturalize" the multiplication of the loaves and fishes, as related in St. Mark's Gospel, attack the compassion of Christ which was the divine motivation of His earthly sojourn, His Passion and the sacrifice of His human life.

HEADQUARTERS, CHINESE EXPEDITIONARY FORCE, July 8 (Delayed) -- Between 40 and 45 per cent of all Japanese troops on the Salween front have been killed or wounded since the Chinese offensive began May 11, according to informed sources here.

The goodness of man and his capacity for noble spiritual achievement should be stressed in this time of universal war and hatred if we are to emerge into a better world, the Rev. Du Bois Le-Fevre of Youngstown, Ohio, declared yesterday in a sermon in the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue.

A sailor in the Merchant Marine was being sought last night by the Brooklyn police on a charge of having stabbed to death, in a jealous rage, his sister-in-law and his mother-in-law and of having seriously wounded his wife and his father-in-law.
LONDON, July 9 -- There is no indication that the German Army is suffering from material shortages in the front line, but it may be growing short of gasoline there, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -Senator Stewart, Democrat of Tennessee, said today that his party could strengthen itself in the South and West by adopting a platform plank advocating favorable action on the pleas of those areas for rail rate parity with the East.

MONTCLAIR, N.J. July 9 -- Sgt. Vic Ghezzi of the United States Army repeated his 1943 performance at the Montclair Golf Club today, winning the New Jersey State Open Championship. Ghezzi came from behind after a fair morning round to win with a 143.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Monday, July 10 (UP) -A. cotttqud:

PHILADELPHIA, July 9 -- The National Administrative Council, ruling body of the Zionist Organization of America, called on the United Nations here today to take "every possible measure to affect the escape and rescue of the surviving remnants of the unfortunate Jewish people of Europe."

In Caen the Allies have captured not a city but a ruin. "The devastation is simply infernal," says a British colonel. The front-line reporters compare it to Cassino and Stalingrad. Along the river front the wreckage is so complete that even the jeeps are stalled. Not a soul is to be seen in the skeleton houses. Only a few wounded civilians remain out of the 54,000 inhabitants of the most interesting town in Normandy.

Now that salads are making more than their usual number of appearances in menus, one way to keep them appealing is to vary the dressings used. The following recipes, tested in THE NEW YORK TIMES kitchen, will lend diversity to vegetable, meat, fish and green salads.

NEW DELHI, India, July 9 (AP) -- A shattered Japanese army is fighting desperately in the jungles of northern Burma and just inside the frontier of India to avoid complete annihilation, and the threat of a full-scale attack on Imphal, Manipur capital, appears definitely ended.

The Army hospital ship Blanche F. Sigman, named in honor of an American nurse killed by a German bomb on the Anzio beachhead, has left the Hoboken division of Todd Shipyards Corporation, the first of six Liberty ships that the corporation will convert into ships of mercy, the corporation announced yesterday.
ELIZABETH, N.J., July 9 (AP) -- Jack McManis of New York captured the New Jersey State men's singles crown today when he defeated Dick Bender of Westfield, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- A group of national organizations, including those representing housewives and other consumers, today asked Chester Bowles, OPA Administrator, to take steps to protect the public from any possibility of having to pay top-quality prices for low-quality canned goods.

In the chorus of victory that swells from Allied fronts all over the world the one discordant note was heard from China. Wearily entering her eighth year of war, her very life as a nation was threatened by a Japanese drive toward the sea which had almost cut her in two.

Total shipments of all types of hosiery during May were 12,656,941 dozen pairs, compared with 12,315,671 for the like month a year ago, according to the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers. This is an increase of 2.8 per cent and is accounted for by larger shipments of women's full-fashioned stockings, bundle goods, athletic socks, and children's and infants' hosiery (excluding anklets).

The editorial "Swinging the Scythe" is a rural prose poem, a sparkling gem -- easy to read and enjoy even though somewhat nostalgic to oldsters reared on the farm. It has one minor flaw, however, when it says:

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Monday, July 10 -- The city of ruins and rubble that was Caen, key to the eastern wing of the Germans' Normandy battle line, fell to the British and Canadian forces yesterday at the end of an audacious thirty-six-hour thrust that finally overran the northern two-thirds of the city so stubbornly defended for the past month.

LONDON, June 9 (U.P.) -- When the robot bomb that was to strike the Guards Chapel came over the barracks area and its engine stopped, which meant it was about to explode, a King's Guard of eighty-six men was at attention ten yards from the chapel, it was disclosed today. Not a man moved when the bomb exploded. Not one of the eighty-six was injured.

Almost simultaneously with reports that Adolf Hitler has assumed personal command of the German front in the west, the Allies announce a double victory of decisive importance for their further operations in France. The British and Canadians, in an irresistible assault which began with a "triphibian" barrage from land artillery, heavy naval guns and from the air, have captured the long-contested city of Caen, the eastern keystone of the German position in Normandy.

There is a growing resentment at pressure groups who, by organized efforts, attain special privileges which are inimical to the best interests of the country. Politicians who fear these groups should grasp the fact that there are many more voters who gain nothing because of special privileges granted politically-minded pressure groups.

MOSCOW, July 9 (AP) -- The Supreme Soviet's new divorce decree, which went into effect yesterday, requires both parties to file a petition in court and appear personally before a Peoples' Court, which hears all the evidence, then seeks to determine it if cannot effect a reconciliation.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (U.P.) -- James G. Patton, president, of the National Farmers Union charged tonight that Will Clayton, surplus war property administrator, had secretly assigned to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation responsibility for disposing of 8,000,000 acres of surplus farm land bought by the Government for the war emergency.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 9 -- Much more important than the precise amount of foreign exchange which becomes available to member nations under the quotas to be agreed upon in connection with the international monetary fund is the matter of national prestige in the ranking of one country against another in the new scale of relative national economic importance being fashioned here.

ROME, July 4 (Delayed) (AP) -- Exhumation of the bodies of 320 Italians mowed down by German machine guns and buried in a cave on the outskirts of Rome will begin about July 15, giving Anglo-American authorities their first opportunity to investigate mass executions in German-occupied Europe.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- A group of business men of Minneapolis and St. Paul is offering a post-war tax program designed to meet revenue obligations and encourage use of capital for private venture which is needed for peace-time recovery and prosperity.

NEW ORLEANS, July 9 -- Smaller crop guesses, early-week news that the Office of Price Administration had boosted some ceiling prices by 7 1/2 per cent and fixation of prices by some mills on the new higher ceiling levels combined to give cotton futures on the New Orleans Cotton Exchange a strong tone last week when new highs for the last sixteen years were established.

LONDON, Monday, July 10 (AP) -- About 1,000 United States heavy bombers, with fighter escorts of equal size, closed in on Hitler's Europe from the west and south yesterday, joining with Allied tactical air units in a campaign designed to starve out the German war machine -- a campaign that is beginning to show concrete results on the Normandy battlefront.

" I don't see any hope for the world today unless you and I, America and Great Britain, hold together," declared the Rev. Dr. Adam W. Burnet, minister of St. Cuthbert's Church, Edinburgh, Scotland, yesterday at the 4:30 P.M. vesper service in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill reported jointly today that "Hitler's submarine fleet failed on all counts in June, 1944."

PITTSBURGH, July 9 -- Brooklyn's bewildered Dodgers dropped their thirteenth game in a row today and were well on their way to losing No. 14 when hostilities ended with the second contest of their double bill with the Pirates incomplete.

Occupied with the flood of war and political news, the general public outside of investment circles is likely to be unaware of certain proceedings in Washington which threaten the financial status of our whole business structure.

No relief from the heat wave that has sent the mercury to 85 degrees or above every day since July 4 was foreseen until today by the Weather Bureau yesterday. Its prediction was "partly cloudy, warm and humid, becoming cooler this evening, with a top temperature of 90 degrees in the city and of 85 degrees at the beaches."

PITTSBURGH, July 9 (AP) -- The baseball clans will gather at Forbes Field Tuesday night for the twelfth major league all-star game, but before the men of Managers Billy Southworth and Joe McCarthy tee off the club owners will attempt to solve a few knotty problems involving the future of the game.
KANDY, Ceylon, July 9 (UP) -- A communique:

PANAMA, July 9 -- Tension apparently increased in Honduras and Nicaragua in the past week and unrest continued in El Salvador and Guatemala. The situation is believed to be most critical in Honduras, where armed clashes, with deaths, occurred.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- A program to create closer working relationships between the Office of Price Administration and industry was announced today by Price Administrator Chester Bowles as he appointed Mrs. Ethel B. Gilbert of New York as director of the newly established Office of Industry Advisory Committees.
PEARL HARBOR, July 9 -- The furious battle for Saipan is over after twenty-five days. "Our forces have completed the conquest," Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced this morning.
LONDON, July 9 -- The great Russian advances of the past two weeks have plunged German strategy, already bankrupt by the loss of Cherbourg, deeper and deeper into liquidation.

LONDON, July 9 -- Current British comment on the Bretton Woods conference seems to indicate a feeling that the conferees are not yet dealing with what are considered here to be "the real issues" posed by the fast-moving war and the coming peace.

CHICAGO, July 9 -- Country offerings of cash corn for deferred shipment have fallen off recently as farmers are busy with haying. Cultivation of the new corn crop is making rapid progress. Much is now too tall to permit field operations, while the very late planted is just through the ground and the latter part of the crop will need a long season of favorable weather in order to mature commercial grain.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Monday, July 10 (AP) -- Savage, no-quarter mopping-up battles in which American troops are hunting down the remaining enemy remnants on Biak Island have cost the Japanese an additional 213 dead during the first week in July.

New Yorkers can be both patriotic and assured of an interesting time by avoiding long-distance travel in favor of the "nickel circuit." The Department of Parks offers a highly diversified program with endless appeal to youngsters and their elders. For the sports conscious there are places galore for baseball, basketball, handball, paddle and court tennis, shuffleboard, field hockey, cricket, rowing, golf, archery and horseback riding.
BOMBAY, July 9 (AP) -- Mohandas K. Gandhi has proposed that India be partitioned into separate Hindu and Moslem States as a means of breaking the political deadlock over India's independence.

A VILLAGE IN NORMANDY, July 9 -- At one time or another during an ordinary day many of the citizens of this tiny Channel coast fishing village pass through the grocery of Marcel Nicomette. While purchasing a bottle of Normandy cider or a piece of Camembert cheese they exchange all sorts of chitchat with Marcel, whom they know as one who never even thought of collaborating with the Germans.

SEATTLE, Wash., July 9 -- Vice President Henry A. Wallace called today for close cooperation between the United States and "the new world of the north Pacific and eastern Asia" in the post-war world, and said that China, lacking materials and training to enter the machine age, needed "a break -- a New Deal."
PHILADELPHIA, July 9 -- Charles D. Barney's greatest ambition came true today when he celebrated his 100th birthday.

In the tawny beauty of the Grand Central and the cavernous spaces of the Pennsylvania Station, where tall columns frame the great American flag, the lines at the ticket windows are endless. In a stupendous migration the railroads are nearing their saturation point, with more civilian passengers and more members of the armed forces than even the experts forecast.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast domestically in Finland and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
HARTFORD, Conn., July 9 -- Three more deaths today brought to 157 the total of victims of the circus fire last week.

CHERBOURG, July 8 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Battered Cherbourg is still a war-torn city, but some signs of organization are emerging from the chaos.

BUENOS AIRES, July 9 -- The traditional Independence Day military parade gave Buenos Aires today its first opportunity to judge the success of the efforts made by the Government since the June 4, 1943, revolution to modernize the army and equip it with up-to-date material.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Samuel H. Jaffe, trial examiner of the National Labor Relations Board, proposed today six geographic divisions of the Western Union Telegraph Company and the home office in New York City as the appropriate divisions for the purposes of collective bargaining in an election to be held for the company's 60,000 employes.

Three persons named McArthur were accused yesterday of what may be the most complicated draft dodging plot of the war. They are William Clonnie McArthur, 27 years old, of 10 Columbus Place, Brooklyn; Lula Freeman McArthur, 26, his wife, and Roman Lawrence McArthur, 35, his brother.

MOSCOW, July 10 -- On the same day that the Soviet press announced that Eric Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, had left Russia, the Moscow newspaper Literature and Art reported that the capital's famous Maly Theatre was rehearsing a play entitled "Mr. Perkins' Mission in the Land of the Bolsheviks," a four-act play by Alexander Aidar dealing with the visit of an influential American industrialist to the U.S.S.R.

The regional Office of Price Administration suspended yesterday six key officers of the Scranton, Pa., district OPA. Administrative charges were filed that may provide the basis for criminal prosecution of some of the officials and Scranton business men alleged to have been involved in illegal traffic in ration stamps.

LONDON, July 10 -- British economic warfare experts have received confirmation in the last week of their intelligence reports that the first serious strains have appeared in Germany's food economy. A revealing broadcast on the Berlin radio by Bauer Hecht, German "potato king," disclosed that the latest potato harvest was the smallest in twenty years and 20,000,000 tons below the previous crop.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- James F. Byrnes, Director of the Office of War Mobilization, indicated today his willingness to act as arbiter in the controversy between Army and Navy officials and Donald M. Nelson, War Production Board chairman, over the question of reconverting industry back to civilian production.

Three hundred religious leaders from thirty States and Canada gathered yesterday at Union Theological Seminary, Broadway and 120th Street, for the opening of the Twenty-fourth Annual Ministers Conference. The opening session attracted a record attendance, and 500 representatives of the Protestant faith are expected to attend one week or more of the four-week conference.
LONDON, Tuesday, July 11 (AP) -- For the first time in twenty-five nights the London area was not attacked by German flying bombs last night, it was announced officially today.

ROME, July 10 -- Adolf Hitler promised Benito Mussolini that he would not provoke war in 1939, according to an article that will appear in tomorrow's Italian Nuova, giving further details of the Fascist Grand Council meeting of July 24, 1943, that ousted Mussolini.

Like Wendell Willkie, Vice-President Wallace returns from his travels with an exciting conception of America's place in the world. It is not a controversial conception. Except for a few casual references, a liberal Republican might have made Mr. Wallace's Sunday speech at Seattle. The Vice-President paid tribute to "the American way of life."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 10 -- Sufficient gasoline to keep the Germans on the Normandy front going for fifteen days went up in smoke in an American air raid in the first days of July on Gennevilliers when some four hundred and fifty Flying Fortresses blasted three German tank-car trains parked in that locality, according to a traveler who left Paris recently.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Germany's war production machine, crippled by bombings and starving from material and manpower shortages, faces a crisis that will leave our European enemy in a "nearly hopeless position" by the end of this year, an analyst of the Foreign Economic Administration declared today.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 10 -- A proposal by the Norwegian delegation to the Monetary Conference to bar enemy nations from membership in the proposed international monetary fund and Bank for Reconstruction and Development before they have been admitted to whatever international political organization is formed after the war, was disclosed today.

LONDON, July 10 (UR) -- The Danish Freedom Council here and{' the Moscow radio announced simul-[ taneously tonight that Thomas] Doessing, director of the Danish State Library Commission, had been designated Free Danish rep-I resentative in Russia with the rank of Ambassador.

CLEVELAND, July 10 (AP) -- Volo Song, Hambletonian winner of 1943, broke the world's record for trotting stallions in a race here today when he traveled the second mile of the $2,090 championship stallion stakes in 1:57 3/4.

WITH BRITISH FORCES Southwest of Caen, July 10 -- Backed up by strong artillery support, British forces operating on a sector about 5,000 yards long made substantial advances today in a new push that, if successful, will become a serious threat to the Germans who are strongly entrenched in Faubourg de Vaucelles on the south side of the Orne River opposite open itself.

General de Gaulle leaves the United States today with every evidence that his mission here has been a success. The General is no spellbinder. The good impression he made is based on his unflinching loyalty to the cause of Free France. If in the past he has been cold and suspicious in his dealings with Britain and the United States he did not show himself so during this visit.

Economy of space has become as much a part of the interior decorator's stock in trade as a knowledge of color harmonies and textures, of fabric designs and furniture styles. Modern architects who believe in planning a whole house complete with furnishings are designing post-war homes that stress comfort and convenience rather than the ornamental magnificence envied by home owners of past decades.

ALBANY, July 10 -- Two Republican members of the United States Senate, both regarded as internationalists and friendly to Wendell L. Willkie, left conferences with Governor Dewey today expressing satisfaction with the foreign policy views of the Republican presidential nominee.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Vice President Wallace returned to Washington today from an extended visit to Russia and China and spent two hours and five minutes with President Roosevelt. But he gave no hint as to his political future.

The triple Allied offensive mapped out at Teheran is now proceeding with growing might and speed. In the east the Russian armies continue their spectacular advances at a pace which suggests increasing German disorganization. Striking with unprecedented force and daring, the Russians are cutting to pieces one German defense line after another.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Proposals for reorganizing Congress in the interest of efficiency have focused attention on a long-ignored piece of legislation designed to halt the growing practice of attaching irrelevant "riders" to appropriation and other measures to force enactment of pet projects which could not survive alone, or to escape Presidential vetoes.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- A finely drawn controversy over when political information is "designed" to affect the votes of the armed forces in the Presidential election and when it is "calculated" to affect their votes is developing between the Executive and legislative branches of the Government.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- Willis Mahoney, Democratic nominee for Senator in Oregon, emerged from a conference with President Roosevelt today predicting that the Chief Executive would "sweep the Pacific Northwest" should he seek a fourth term this year.

LONDON, July 10 (UP) -- The Polish underground army has launched large-scale operations against the retreating Germans on the Eastern Front, especially in the Vilna and Novogrudok areas, on direct orders of the Polish Government in London, it was learned today.

Three Borough Presidents came to City Hall late yesterday at the behest of Mayor La Guardia for the organization of a committee on parking he had appointed last January. These three, Edgar J. Nathan Jr. of Manhattan, John Cashmore of Brooklyn and James J. Lyons of the Bronx, were puzzled, for they had read in the morning papers stories of a report made by one member as chairman, Robert Moses.

TRENTON, N.J., July 10 -- Legal representatives of major railroads in New Jersey, in conference today with Attorney General Walter D. Van Riper, assented to full payment of a past-due tax and interest accumulation of about $60,000,000.

LONDON, July 10 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Various branches of the fur industry are being sounded out this week on the possibility of selecting a "coordinator" whose function would be to foster trade harmony and develop a united front on national matters of vital import to the industry, it was reported here yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, July 10 -- The American League, at an executive meeting held today, moved to ask an early renewal of Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis' contract, which expires on Jan. 12, 1946. The officials present, representing all clubs, voted for complete renewal of all the present extensive powers held by the 77-year-old Landis.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communication Commission:
PEARL HARBOR, July 10 -- The enemy naval and air base on the island of Guam has been under attack by Pacific Fleet carriers for six straight days.

CHICAGO, July 10 -- Traders placed a bearish construction on a Department of Agriculture estimate on the wheat crop issued late today showing that a new high record yield was in prospect. However, brokers expressed the belief that unless there were much heavier hedging sales the report probably would have only a temporary effect as a price-making influence.

It must be cooler by Potomacside than by Hudsonside, for the poet of the National Geographic Society has written and the Society has published a news bulletin called "Summer, Forecaster's Delight, A Season Bossed by the Sun." The poet we revere, but his news is not strictly contemporary. "'Fair and Warmer' once more are official passwords to the enjoyment of outdoor America."

Thousands of medical graduates have entered the armed forces with less than the usual clinical training. To prepare them for practice in civilian life, and to acquaint them with the progress that has been made while they were at the front, the New York Academy of Medicine has set itself the ambitious task of making this city one of the leading centers of post-graduate medical education.

Semi-annual visits to New York by fashion writers on newspapers all over the country have proved very helpful and should be continued after the war, many of the seventy-seven women here for the third National Press Week, sponsored by the New York Dress Institute, said yesterday.

Democrats of all shades of opinion joined last night in paying tribute to James A. Farley as he relinquished his party's State chairmanship after holding it longer than any other man since Samuel J. Tilden. Fifteen hundred of his friends attended a testimonial dinner in his honor at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria to testify that they value his friendship and wish him success for the future.

Thomas Gilroy, 38 years old, of 357 East 137th Street, the Bronx, who had a police record of four arrests and a penitentiary sentence for burglary, was shot dead at 4 A. M. yesterday on the second floor of 143 East Sixtieth Street when he failed to obey the command of Patrolman Elias Gottlieb to halt.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (UP) -- A forecast of a bumper wheat crop of 1,128,000,000 bushels and a very large corn crop of 2,980,000,000 bushels topped today a report by the Department of Agriculture predicting that 1944 crop production will be larger than in any year prior to the record year of 1942. It was the Crop Reporting Board's first forecast of this year's corn crop.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 10 -- Joe Turnesa, veteran Rockville pro, carded an individual 69, two under course figures, to share twice in the five-way tie at 65 in the amateur-pro event of the Long Island P.G.A. at the Sands Point Club today.

The largest audience of the season crowded into the Lewisohn Stadium last night to hear Marian Anderson, famous contralto, sing with the Philharmonic-Symphony, and to witness the first appearance of the season of Efrem Kurtz, the Russian-born conductor.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, in the Southwest Pacific, Tuesday, July 11 (UP) -- Liberator Bombers of the Far Eastern Air Force dropped 43 tons of explosives on the Jefman airdrome at Sorong Sunday, causing large fires among enemy installations in the raid, which was unopposed either by enemy airplanes or anti-aircraft fire, it was announced today.
Three gangs of young hoodlums, Negroes, engaged in a gun battle at 10:30 o'clock last night at 148th Street and Bradhurst Avenue, outside Colonial Park, where a Harlem block party was in progress.
A communique, as broadcast from Chungking in English to North America and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

It was heartening to read the letter from Agnes Miller of Grafton, Vt., published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of July 6, emphasizing once again that the Army depends on the American Red Cross to provide at least 90 per cent of the surgical dressings used for our wounded.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., July 10 -- Miss Helen Hayes, actress, made her "maiden" speech here tonight in the political campaign between Representative Hamilton Fish and Augustus W. Bennet, opposing candidate for Congress in the new Twenty-ninth District.

BOGOTA, Colombia, July 10 -- President Alfonso Lopez and several members of his Cabinet, while watching army maneuvers at Pasto, capital of the State of Narino in the southern part of Colombia, were seized by a group of rebellious army officers today and are being held prisoners.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Adolf Hitler had ready in 1940 a complete plan for invasion of the United States, J. Carlton Ward Jr., president of the Fairchild Engine and Aircraft Company, told the subcommittee on War Contracts of the Senate Military Affairs Committee today.

Net income of the Western Union Telegraph Company during the first five months of 1944 amounted to $3,011,435, compared with $2,747,139 for the corresponding period of last year, it was announced yesterday by A.N. Williams, president.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 10 (AP) -- First-seeded Jack McManis, Forest Hills, N.Y., today moved into the quarter-finals of the Eastern clay courts tennis championships after a few minutes of playing

CHICAGO, July 10 -- A forecast of a 50 per cent cut in the near-by production of furniture, made by Richard N. Greenwood, president of the National Association of Furniture Manufacturers, contrasted sharply today with the optimism over the post-war outlook expressed at a series of conferences held here today in connection with the summer furniture market.

Something new in desserts is on its way and may soon be generally available to consumers, according to announcement of the United States Department of Agriculture. Although the American appetite for fruit has always been strong, fruit ices and sherbets have never measured up to ice cream in popularity, largely because they lack its rich smoothness.
KANDY, Ceylon, July 10 (UP) -- A communique:

The Ninth Federal Savings Loan Association of New York City has sold the "taxpayer" building on the northeast corner of North Avenue and Winyah Place, New Rochelle, to the Winor Realty Corporation of White Plains through Myron L. Blum and Samuel Orlofsky, associate brokers.
French patriots in Allied-held Normandy are ferreting out German troops and agents, the British Broadcasting Corporation reported yesterday.
ADVAIVCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Tuesday, July 11 (AP) -- communique:
ABOARD A JOINT EXPEDITIONARY FORCE FLAGSHIP, Saipan, July 10 (via Navy Radio) -- The American flag flew over Saipan Island today.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The grave condition of the country's health, as disclosed by examinations for Selective Service, and the need for national community action to combat this condition in war and peace, were brought out by witnesses today at the opening session of hearings before the Senate Subcommittee on Wartime Health and Education, presided over by Senator Claude Pepper.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 10 -- The United Nations monetary and financial conference declined today to accept a proposal made by the delegation from India that the $12,000,000,000 blocked sterling balances which, in effect, represent Great Britain's external war debt, should be dealt with by the proposed international monetary fund.
CHUNGKING, China, July 10 (AP) -- A communique:
