WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The plea of free speech offered by the Reliance Manufacturing Company of Huntington, W.Va., in extenuation of its acts in a case involving the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, has been rejected by the Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals, which has ruled the company guilty of contempt of a decree holding it in violation of the National Labor Relations Law.

Sales were substantially above normal yesterday in metropolitan shoe stores, where 600,000 pairs of odd-lot men's, women's and boys' shoes were released from rationing. No signs of a "mad scramble" for ration-free footwear were observed in the midtown area, however, and store officials agreed that no rush was likely to develop during the rationing holiday which extends through July 29.

Victory now shines in the skies over France, Gen. Charles de Gaulle declared yesterday in acknowledging a tumultuous welcome from cheering crowds of New Yorkers. Speaking at the official reception in his honor at the City Hall, he characterized the conversations he had just concluded with President Roosevelt as "comforting talks."

The Indiana Michigan Electric Company, a subsidiary of the American Gas and Electric Company, has under consideration plans for the refinancing of its $3,958,500 of 7 per cent and $3,571,800 of 6 per cent preferred stocks, it was reported yesterday in underwriting circles.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- A nation-wide survey of the country's need for textiles and wearing apparel was disclosed today by the War Production Board to show an average shortage of 15 per cent for a selected list of seventy-two separate items during the first three months of this year.

LONDON, July 10 -- Although the stock markets here started the week on a quiet note the tone throughout was cheerful. Leading industrials and home rail junior stocks were in demand and numerous small rises were seen.

CAEN, France, July 10 (Reuter) -- The story of Caen is not the story of the soldiers who took it nor the soldiers who have been driven from it -- it is the story of the people whose lives have been one long nightmare since the night of June 6 when the city was first bombed.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- At a press conference just before his departure for New York today, Gen. Charles de Gaulle made a highly favorable impression on Washington correspondents by straightforward answers to a series of questions that clarified his attitude toward the United States and the Allies on several important and hitherto obscure points.

MOSCOW, July 10 -- In an article by its foreign editor, Yakov Khavinson, the Soviet newspaper Pravda today tries to reassure its readers that the claim advanced by certain Poles at the recent Buffalo conference that a Polish bloc of 6,000,000 voters might become an important, if not a decisive, factor in the forthcoming elections in the United States, is wholly at variance with statistical evidence.

When the American Civil Liberties Union reports that the Bill of Rights is standing up fairly well under the hammerings of war we can well believe it. The Union is as vigilant in this field as any organization we have. It notes that the Chinese Exclusion Act has been repealed; that the Supreme Court

Views that Wendell L. Willkie, Republican candidate for President in 1940, wished to incorporate in the party's platform for 1944 were revealed last night from an actual copy of the draft Mr. Willkie had sent to Chicago for the guidance of the convention.

Steel production in the United States for the first half of 1944 set a new high record of 45,061,874 net tons, compared with 43,886,451 in the 1943 period and 44,949,915 in the second half of last year. Output in June, however, was lower than any month in the current year except February, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

NASSAU, Bahamas, July 10 -- Today the Legislative Council, which functions similarly to the House of Lords, concurred in an amendment to the New Providence Ballot Act of 1939 making it permanently New Providence, unanimously expressed disapproval of the action of the House of Assembly by refusing to extend the secret ballot to the "out islands" and passed a resolution expressing its views for transmission to the Secretary of State for the Colonies.

Previews of our postwar world have failed to take note, as far as we can recall, of the future of the bow tie as against the four-in-hand for men's summer wear. The problem comes to mind every time President Roosevelt smilingly shakes hands with a visiting provisional French Chief of State or a couple of Americans receiving their Congressional Medals of Honor.
Mrs. F. Raymond Draper of St. Louis has arrived from Dover, N.H., and joined Lieutenant Commander Draper, USNR, at the Ambassador.

Advertising linage in all New York daily newspapers in the first six months of this year aggregated 48,828,928 lines, or 5 per cent less than in the corresponding period of 1943, according to figures compiled from Media Records. Classified advertising, most strictly curtailed, had the largest decrease with 27 per cent.

ALLIED ADVANCE COMMAND POST, July 10 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Supreme Commander of the western invasion forces, speaking with feet-on-the-ground confidence, warned today against rosy optimism, saying long and bitter fighting must be expected around the European battle perimeter.

ROME, July 10 -- The once famous organ of the Italian Republican party Voce Republicana, suppressed under the fascist regime, resumed its free publication this afternoon with a challenging editorial by Randolfo Pacciardi, commander of the Garibaldini Brigade in the Spanish Civil War and Italy's leading Republican exile.
SUPREME HEADQARTWRS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Jury 10 (AP) -- Communique 69:

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 10 -- The Americans have several new secret weapons to use in their march to Berlin, Maj. Gen. Henry Benton Sayler, Chief Ordnance officer for the European theatre, disclosed today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 10 (AP) -- A final decree confirming a plan, amended five times, for reorganization of the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company was signed today by Judge William H. Kirkpatrick of the United States District Court.

With the blessings of the War Department and the USO-Camp Shows, the American Theatre Wing has received the go-ahead signal to send a company of players overseas. Not just an ordinary troupe, mind you. The A.T.W. doesn't do things that way.

" The Amazing Bob Davis: His Last Vagabond Journey" is a biography of The New York Sun's columnist by Fred S. Mathias, who traveled with him on a transcontinental motor tour through the Southwest and Mexico and wrote down, like a modern Boswell, his account of the newspaper man. Longmans, Green will publish it on Aug. 30.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a rise of 2 per cent for the week ended July 8 over the like week last year, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The showing for the week was affected by the variation in number of business days, most stores having one less business day.

Front-line dispatches from Saipan telling of the last suicidal counter-attack of the remnants of the Japanese garrison of 20,000 men, of enemy soldiers charging machine guns and well-protected artillery emplacements armed only with hand-made spears or a few grenades, of others plunging into the sea to drown rather than accept defeat, help explain the disparity between our casualty lists and confirmed losses of the enemy.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., July 10 -- With a stiff wind causing the players considerable anguish, Ralph Strafaci of Plandome and Frank Paley of Woodmere each turned in a 76 at the Cherry Valley Club today as the qualifying round of the Long Island amateur golf championship got under way.

Objections filed by Representative Vito Marcantonio to the designating petitions of Representative Martin J. Kennedy, his opponent for the Democratic Congressional nomination in the new Eighteenth district, Manhattan, were dismissed yesterday by the Board of Elections for failure to file specifications.

LONDON, Tuesday, July 11 -- Russian troops yesterday completely surrounded Vilna, where a fierce street battle raged through a third day, while other Red Army forces, advancing thirty-five miles northwest across Poland and Lithuania, hammered a wedge between the German strongholds of Dvinsk and Kaunas and reached a point 116 miles southeast of Riga on the Baltic Sea.

LONDON, July 10 -- Three days after forming a Government of Serb, Croat and Slovene representatives Premier Ivan Subasitch of Yugoslavia addressed the people of that country by radio tonight. He called on them to forget petty differences and unite against the hatred and envies spread through the country "by the enemies of our peoples and their henchmen."

LONDON, Tuesday, July 11 (AP) -- German troops pushed into the woods southeast of Caen by the British-Canadian forces that captured the city were smoked out today by rocket-firing Typhoons and bomb-carrying Spitfires and Mustangs of the British Second Tactical Air Force, which set the woods afire and shot up the fleeing Nazis.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- The War Shipping Administration ruled today that William Watson of Brooklyn must accept $10 for his 32-foot, $5,000 motor launch which he wanted to give to the Government, after the Navy no longer needed it at Bayonne.

The statement of the newly organized Committee on International Economic Policy, of which Winthrop W. Aldrich is chairman, calls for a multilateral trade agreement for the United Nations, creating an international economic charter to define the rights of traders and investors in foreign countries.

A more general use of concentrated insecticides and chemical fertilizers in package form and a huge demand for "substantial" toys and games for five years after the war are among the predictions voiced in surveys of the drug and chemical industries and of the toys, games and novelties business, compiled for the post-war planning committee of the National Paper Box Manufacturers Association, Philadelphia, and made public yesterday.

SOMEWHERE IN FRANCE, July 8 (Delayed) -- The Germans left this particular section in a hurry but they also left their mark. It could be seen on the beachhead and even now seven and a half miles behind the front it is quite apparent in many ways.

LONDON, July 10 (UP) -- Striking even as Vichy named a successor to Propaganda Minister Philippe Henriot, assassinated less than two weeks ago, French patriots today killed Georges Bartelemy, pro-Fascist collaborationist and friend of Pierre Laval, Chief of Government.

Although trading in cotton futures yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange was light, the undertone continued steady and the close was 2 to 8 points higher than Saturday's final prices on active months.

One again John-Frederics has sounded a prophetic note. The collection shown yesterday afternoon was forward-looking in character. It emphasized the ultra-feminine; it stressed hat importance; and, more than that, it showed John's -- he is the designer of the firm -- conception of the future dress silhouette.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Tuesday, July 11 -- Braving a shower of German shells, troops of Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery's British and Canadian forces have thrown a right hook around the southwest of partly invested Caen almost to the Orne River, where the Germans are standing stanchly in defense of the escape line for their comrades still rooted in the southern suburbs of the city.
BOSTON, July 10 (AP) -- Miss Jean Beattie's Oxie scored by a length and a half in the $2,000 allowance feature of six furlongs that topped today's card at Suffolk Downs.
The text of Wendell L. Willkie's proposed Republican platform follows:

President Alfonso Lopez Pumarejo appointed Dr. Dario Echandia as Minister of Foreign Relations in the Colombian Cabinet on July 1, after having himself resumed the office of head of the state earlier this year in response to the insistent pleas of labor leaders.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (U.P.) -- The War Labor Board ordered today 2,000 striking employes of the Kimball Glass Company, Vineland, N.J., engaged in making vials for penicillin, to return to work.

Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Buffalo contractor, real estate man, industrialist and insurance dealer, was chosen yesterday by key Democratic leaders at a luncheon conference at the Hotel Biltmore as the political successor of James A. Farley, who is retiring today after fourteen years as Democratic State chairman.

CHUNGKING, China, July 10 (UP) -- Chinese forces, in grim and bloody close-quarter fighting, have repulsed scores of scattered thrusts at Hengyang by Japanese troops attempting to capture the city that guards the northern approach to the Chinese-held sector of the Canton-Hankow railway, a Chinese communique announced today.

Charles W. Oliver of Perth Amboy, N.J., led a large field into the third round as the Eastern junior tennis championship tournament started at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, yesterday. Oliver, seeded first, drew a first-round bye and then beat Jack Kahn of Newark, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 1.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- An immediate increase by several hundred per cent in the production of heavy artillery ammunition for the Army to meet unprecedented demands from the combat zones was announced today by the War Department.
An editorial, "Nazi Naturalization," in THE NEW YORK TIMES not long ago caught my attention because I had just finished reading a book about the composer, entitled "Chopin," by Antoni Gronowicz.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The Democratic State Convention of Virginia, which met Saturday at Roanoke, affords an excellent illustration of the quandary in which anti-New Dealers and anti-fourth-termers of the President's party find themselves in the traditional Democratic States.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (U.P.) -- The United States will recognize the newly formed pro-Tito Yugoslav Government in London despite the refusal of the Yugoslav Ambassador here to recognize it or to resign his post, well informed diplomatic sources indicated today.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, July 10 -- A fresh instance of the nationalist folly that at present is sweeping over Argentina is provided by a decree of the Federal Commissioner of the Province of Entre Rios. He has ordered that every town of any importance in the territory under his jurisdiction shall immediately give the name "Sovereignty" to one of its principal streets.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Thirty-nine enlisted Wacs in nine Army hospitals completed today their physical therapy training of almost a year and were commissioned second lieutenants in the Medical Department of the Army. Three of these are at Halloran General Hospital, Staten Island -- Rhea C. Disney, Dora Tidwell and Mary E. Wood.

PITTSBURGH, July 10 -- This big steel town is steaming tonight for two reasons, the sweltering heat and the twelfth renewal of the annual All-Star game, in which the National and American Leagues pit the best players of sixteen clubs against each other in one furious fray.

Unless the Office of Price Administration rules cotton garments to be "major" items, entitled to price relief in accordance With the Bankhead amendment to the Price Extension Act, court action will be taken by manufacturers seeking such a declaratory judgment, it was revealed yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, July 10 -- Mae West returned to the stage tonight after four years of retirement from both the stage and screen, appearing in her own vehicle, "Catherine Was Great," which was produced by Michael Todd and opened a pre-Broadway run of two weeks at the Forrest Theatre before a capacity audience.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The mass sedition trial crept into its thirteenth week today with a session in which only half an hour was given to testimony. The remainder of time was consumed by a conference in chambers of Judge Edward C. Eicher and arguments that the rights of the defendants had been so prejudiced that a mistrial was in order.

With $4,605,595,007 in war bond purchases tabulated through Saturday, New York City achieved 110.5 per cent of its over-all goal in the Fifth War Loan drive, Nevil Ford, State chairman of the War Finance Committee for New York, announced yesterday.

CHUNGKING, China, July 10 (AP) -- Chinese troops on the Yunnan front have fought to the walls of the big Japanese base of Tengyueh which blocks the way to a junction with Allied forces in Burma, the Chinese High Command announced today.

CHICAGO, July 10 (AP) -- Mrs. Elizabeth A. Conkey, official hostess for the Democratic National Convention, proposed Representative Mary Norton of New Jersey today as a possible candidate for the Democratic Vice Presidential nomination.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, July 10 (AP) -- All organized Japanese resistance has ceased in Ukhrul, advance enemy base inside the border of northeastern India, Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten's headquarters announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The British capture of Caen probably will be followed by further expansion to the east, for the British undoubtedly will desire to gain "elbow room" to protect this potentially valuable inland port, informed sources here believe.
BOSTON, July 10 (UP) -- The United Fruit Company reported today that its controller's estimate of earnings for the first half of this year was $5,955,000.

A young man in love is apt to forget many things -- even $350 in war bonds, it developed yesterday. While police searched for the bonds and $407.75 in cash stolen from a safe in headquarters on July 1, the bonds lay for eight days in an apartment in the Bronx, not considered as important as love.

CAEN, France, July 10 -- Almost everyone in a throng of several hundred civilians gathered in the tiny Cathedral Square of Caen for a liberation ceremony today, shed tears of joy when the flag of the Republic of France, bearing the Cross of Lorraine, whipped out from the town's flagstaff for the first time.

CHERBOURG, July 10 (Reuter) -- Commodore William A. Sullivan, United States port salvage expert who cleared Naples, Bizerte and Palermo, said today, "Cherbourg is one of the worst jobs we have tackled so far, but we have been considerably helped by members of the French underground, who have done a really fine job."

For months before D-day the decline of enemy submarine operations in the Atlantic was explained on the theory that Hitler was withdrawing his U-boats to repel the great invasion when it occurred. Yet when it did occur the U-boat fleet seemed almost as conspicuously absent as the Luftwaffe itself.

The Unity Club, a Brooklyn Jewish organization, has purchased the three-story brick Weber mansion at 101 Eighth Avenue, corner of President Street, Brooklyn, from the widow of John W. Weber. Mr. Weber, president of the Ulmer_ Brewing Company, built the house about thirty-five years ago and he and his family occupied it until his death ten years ago.

Patrolman George Lutzel Jr., 40 years old, with fourteen years of service in the Police Department and attached to the Fifth Street station in Manhattan, was booked early today in the Queens Village police station, with two other men, on charges connected with a $15,000 burglary in the United Parcels delivery depot on Merrick Road, St. Albans, Queens, on May 17, 1942.
CHUNGKING, China, July 10 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:
CHICAGO, July 19 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows:

WITH THE AMERICAN ARMY IN FRANCE, July 10 (AP) -- Hard-driving American troops broke out of the bottleneck on the western side of the Cherbourg Peninsula today with the backing of one of the greatest continuous artillery barrages of this war.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- The Veterans of Foreign Wars said tonight that it had relayed to the War and Navy Departments complaints that men returning from combat duty overseas were being "discriminated against" in furloughs, liberty and physical examinations.

BRISBANE, Australia, Tuesday, July 11 (AP) -- One of Australia's leading newspaper publishers characterized the United States today as the "world's strongest naval and air power -- strong enough to bring Japan to her knees without waiting for British Navy and air strength and for a big army advance up the coast of China."
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- When the war ends, an estimated quarter of a million women who are veterans will have an inside track in the employment race.

ROME, July 10 (U.P.) -- Allied troops boring slowly toward the Germans' Gothic Line of upper Italian defenses have advanced on four sectors toward roadways connecting Florence and the Ligurian Sea, it was disclosed today, and have made new gains toward Leghorn.

Making a plea for better care of young babies after they leave the hospital, Dr. Leona Baumgartner, director of the Health Department's bureau of child hygiene, said yesterday that infant deaths for the first six months of 1944 showed a slight upward trend for the period from 10 days of age to 1 month.

It was only an ordinary card that was presented yesterday at the Jamaica track where the Empire City Association's program swung into its second week, but to twenty-three fans, whose identity was not established, it was a program that combined all the best features of racing.
A communique, as broadcast from Chungking yesterday in English to North America and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

A special offering of 8,177 shares of Florsheim Shoe Company's Class A stock made at 10:06 A.M. yesterday at 30 1/2 on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange by Lehman Brothers was oversubscribed by 10:11 A.M. Bids were received for 11,680 shares, requiring allotments on the basis of 70 per cent.

BOSTON, July 11 (AP) -- Fred W. Hooper's Pry, choice in the field of eight starters, scored a four-length victory in the Arbutus, $1,800 allowance feature at Suffolk Downs, today before a crowd of 11,794. J. Sansetta's Flying Connie raced second, a length in front of R.J. Daily's Army Glider.
Perhaps to no group of children can two weeks in the country bring a greater lift than to the hundreds of young Americans living in the thickly populated blocks of New York's upper East Side.

Because they look as cool and refreshing as they taste, jellied soups make ideal summer fare. Well timed is the arrival on the market of a new kind, so simple to prepare that it requires only the addition of water. It is a jellied tomato consomme -- the latest supplement to the Dry-Pack Corporation's long list of excellent dehydrated products.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Secretary Hull, in opening a new press room in the State Department today emphasized the responsibility of news correspondents in the maintenance of an alert public opinion. Mr. Hull held his regular press conference in the room.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The text of President Roosevelt's letter to Chairman Hannegan, saying he will accept a nomination by the Democratic National Convention is as follows:

Characterizing the recent shutdown of the Burchell Products Corporation plant here a continuation of the "ruinous Brewster formula" on contract cancellations, the Greater New York Congress of Industrial Organizations Council, central body of the CIO in this city, in a telegram yesterday to Ralph A. Bard, under-secretary of the Navy, placed the entire blame upon the Navy Department for the closing of the plant.
KANDY, Ceylon, July 11 (UP) -- A communique:
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 11 (AP) -- Communique 71:

The great shifting of families into war centers miles from their homes has made America a new kind of melting pot with Americans feeling like aliens in their own country, four field workers for the Young Women's Christian Association reported after a cross-country study of cities where munitions are produced.

CHUNGKING, China, July 11 (AP) -- Chinese troops have recaptured Yungfeng, forty-five miles northwest of the Hunan Province rail city of Hengyang, while withstanding Japanese pressure in the outskirts of Hangyang itself, the Chinese High Command announced tonight.

Service on the BMT subway line to Queens was tied up completely for forty-five minutes and greatly curtailed for hours more yesterday afternoon and evening as the result of the derailment of a four-car Manhattan-bound train in the Sixtieth Street tunnel under the East River at 2:04 P.M. Normal traffic was resumed at 7:30 P.M.
The Maine Chance Farm again yesterday had occasion to thank its lucky stars in getting silent Tom Smith as trainer when Jean Miracle won the Tuxedo Purse on the Empire City card at Jamaica.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 11 (AP) -- Startling upsets today eliminated two high-seeded quarter-finalists from the women's Eastern clay courts tennis championship.

Gen. Charles de Gaulle and the French Committee of National Liberation are unlikely to approve of any arrangement whereby Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower would receive full discretion to select for administrative posts in France other Frenchmen than those nominated in Algiers.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- A dispute over rates for freight lighterage service in New York harbor has been brought before the ICC by a group of lawyers representing Shelton Pitney and Walter P. Gardner, trustees of the Central Railroad Company of New Jersey, as complainants.

The City Council, in a resolution adopted yesterday, "earnestly called upon" and "urgently requested" Mayor La Guardia and the Board of Estimate not only to grant a cost of living bonus to those city employes who have not received one but also to make the bonus a permanent salary increase for all city employes.
"The Six Weeks' War," Theodore Draper's history of the fall of France, will be released to members of the Book Find Club at the end of this month. The book was published in June by Viking.

Yesterday was another hot day, the eighth in a chain of daily maximum temperatures in the upper 80s or above. The high was 88.8 at 2 P.M., and the mercury seemed headed for a record, when along came a scattered thunder-shower.

PHILADELPHIA, July 11 -- A voluntary plan providing for the reclassification of the outstanding preferred and common stocks of the United Public Utilities Corporation into a single class of $5 par value common stock was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Mrs. John Edward Lancaster of 300 Park Avenue has gone to Poland Spring House, Poland Spring, Me., for the summer.
LONDON, July 11 -- Evidence is accumulating to support the theory that Adolf Hitler has decided to stake everything on a decision in the west.

Hairdressers are more interested in demonstrating their own artistic ability than they are in making women more attractive, Mr. Paul, head of hair styling at the ten Charles of the Ritz salons throughout the country, told a meeting of the Millinery Executives Association at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday morning.

A closer understanding between labor and religious leaders was urged yesterday by John G. Ramsay of Columbus, Ohio, public relations officer for the United Steel Workers of America, at the Twenty-fourth Annual Ministers Conference at Union Theological Seminary, Broadway at 120th Street.
LONDON, July 11 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recor by The United Press:

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Health problems of veterans, and especially the psychoneurotics, who form a high percentage of the discharges from service, were discussed today at the second session of the three-day hearing before the Senate subcommittee on Wartime Health and Education.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Despite the setbacks she has experienced in the last year, Japan is still able to maintain and expand her munitions output, in the opinion of foreign traders and others familiar with that nation's internal economy.

CHICAGO, July 11 (AP) -- Free for All, unbeaten son of Questionnaire that races for John Marsh of Chicago, solidified his position as favorite for Saturday's $65,000 Arlington Futurity by capturing today's five and one-half furlong Advance Guard Purse before 13,500 spectators at Washington Park.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The United States has granted to the French Committee of National Liberation the status of a working "de facto authority" in French civil affairs in liberated areas but has left full authority to handle occupation matters to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, President Roosevelt announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Members of Congress remaining in Washington received generally without surprise today President Roosevelt's announcement that he would accept a renomination. Only one, a Republican, professed to having "played a hunch that he would not run."

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 11 -- Although a drive is being made to reach some kind of agreement by the United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference it was said authoritatively tonight that eight principal issues were still unsettled in connection with the proposed international monetary fund to stabilize post-war currencies.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- A strong stand against group care of very young children as a means of freeing mothers for war work in labor shortage areas was taken today by a score of child specialists and welfare workers after a day-long conference at the Children's Bureau.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- President Roosevelt will accept a nomination for a fourth term from the Democratic National Convention. He will serve if elected.
WITH AMERICAN FORCES, in Normandy, July 11 -- Americans crushed an ambitious German tank attack today.

Because a considerable amount of the equipment now being used for war products can be utilized for the manufacture of electric razors, Schick, Inc., will have a minimum of change-over problems as soon as production for civilians is permitted, Kenneth C. Gifford, president of the company, said yesterday.

The Hat Research Foundation was organized yesterday by leading hat manufacturers and suppliers of the country to represent the $250,000,000 industry in an extensive post-war planning and research program. The new group succeeds the Hat Style Council, which for several years has concentrated efforts to promote greater style consciousness.

PITTSBURGH, July 11 -- Even hotter than the torrid temperature, the National League All-Stars, led by Manager Billy Southworth, tonight blazed through the American Leaguers, piloted by Joe McCarthy, for the widest victory margin in the history of the twelve-year-old classic.
President Roosevelt's announcement of his willingness to accept a renomination was greeted with acclaim by his supporters in New York yesterday.

Unless a Jewish State in Palestine is established as a homeland for the Jewish people, the moral side of the war will not be won, Dr. Israel Goldstein, head of the Zionist organization of America, declared last night.

PITTSBURGH, July 11 (AP) -- It looked -- and sounded -- as if school had closed for the summer when the National League All-Stars trooped, shouting and whistling, into their dressing room tonight after handing the American Leaguers their worst defeat in the "dream game's" 12-year-old history.

CHICAGO, July 11 -- Retailers attending the Chicago midsummer furniture market today were given a somewhat more hopeful picture of the near-by supply situation and several very rosy prophecies concerning potential demand for household appliances of every type.

OTTAWA, July 11 -- In quietly spoken phrases in a public speech on Parliament Hill and in a half-hour interview with 200 newspaper men, Gen. Charles de Gaulle made it quite clear today that he was satisfied with what had been accomplished in Washington and that he intended to go forward along the road he had followed until France had been completely liberated and restored to her place among the great nations.

Six consecutive days of bombing and shelling by American planes and a powerful American task force off shore cannot leave the Japanese on Guam in much doubt that we are finally closing in to reclaim our stolen island. Nor will the conquest of near-by Saipan reassure them.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 11 -- Paul Muni and Alexander Knox have been named for the leads in Columbia's screen version of Janet and Philip Stevenson's play "Counter Attack," which, backed by the picture company, played at the Windsor and Adelphi Theatres, New York, last spring.

Conveniently for the purpose of today's comments the complete text of Vice President Wallace's report on his Far Eastern journey in this newspaper day before yesterday, Monday, appeared on a page facing our new-style globular map of the Pacific illustrating the conquest of Saipan.
Apartments led the realty market on the East Side of Manhattan in reports received from brokers active in that section of the city.

As trade reports indicated that from six to a dozen milk dealers were short of fluid milk and that supplies might become shorter by the end of the week, Dr. C.J. Blanford, Administrator of the New York Milk Marketing Area, last night called a conference here Friday of all qualified dairy cooperatives in the six States of the New York milkshed.

Net assets of General American Investors Company, Inc., on June 30 were $28,955,152, equal to $17.38 a common share, comparing with $15.68 three months before and $14.50 six months before, a gain of $3,802,572 for the six months. Had all outstanding warrants been exercised by June 30, the net asset value would have been $16.50 a share, according to the report of Frank Altschul, president.

Marking the first distribution of shares in the Howard Stores Corporation to the public, A.G. Becker Co., Inc., head an investment banking group which will offer today 27,736 shares of $100 par 5 1/4 per cent preferred stock and 50,000 shares of $1 par common stock at prices of $101 and $13.50 a share respectively.

PITTSBURGH, July 11 (AP) -- Major league baseball moved another step nearer becoming a night sport today when the National and American Leagues approved additional arc-light games for clubs desiring to take advantage of the opportunity to draw more fans.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The Lincoln Warehouse Corporation, 63-year-old storage warehouse concern, has just passed into the hands of the realty firm of Simon Brothers, who have acquired the stock of the corporation and of the Lincoln Safe Deposit Company, together with the real estate and other holdings.

NEWARK, N.J., July 11 -- A suit in Federal court here before Judge Guy L. Fake, to compel the leather tanning firm of A.J. Crowhurst Sons, of Belleville, to reinstate in his former job a medically discharged soldier opened today what is said to be the first legal test in the East of the reemployment provisions of the Selective Service Act.

More than one producer has offered Beatrice Lillie all sorts of inducements to get her back on Broadway. What seemed well-nigh impossible has been accomplished by Billy Rose, who has signed the British comedienne for his revue, "Seven Lively Arts," due at the Ziegfeld on Dec. 7.

AN ADVANCED NINTH AIR FORCE BASE, Normandy, July 11 -- Thunderbolt fighter-bombers, furnishing close support to American ground units driving southward in the St. Lo sector today, caught thirty-five German tanks sneaking toward the front under cover of what the enemy probably thought was unflyable weather conditions.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 11 -- Outraged over the German "film monopoly methods," the Swiss Cinematographic Guild, which controls all Swiss moving picture theatres, at a meeting in Berne last Wednesday adopted a resolution calling on all its members to boycott German films entering Switzerland after July 5 at midnight, "until such time as the safeguarding of Switzerland's economic and cultural values has been assured by the restoration of transit facilities for Anglo-Saxon production."

Miss Dorothy Wilson, 23 years old, daughter of William Wilson, a retired State employe of 768 Jefferson Avenue, Brooklyn, is in a serious condition at Kings County Hospital, Brooklyn, where she was taken after having been stabbed yesterday afternoon by an unidentified man while she was attending Loew's Gates Theatre at Gates Avenue and Broadway, Brooklyn.
LONDON, July 11 -- Without any tangible or concrete evidence to support it, the impression prevails here that the atmosphere is becoming more favorable for a Russo-Polish rapprochement.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended July 5, the Federal Reserve Board announced today:

The stock market became more alert and selective yesterday but, while prices stumbled about, the list's position was not injured. Periods of weakness came with considerable frequency throughout the session although there was no sustained selling; in fact, business contracted on the decline.

PITTSBURGH, July 11 -- Mr. Frank Frisch picked up the telephone and requested the bell captain to put Bill Klem on the wire. The voice of the Old Arbitrator almost could be heard booming up from the lobby.

It is good news that there is to be immediate and expert study of the problem of parking and street congestion. Even under conditions of restricted wartime driving that problem is serious. From the long-rang point of view, looking to the post-war increase over pre-war peaks in automobile ownership which is sure to come, the prospect is little less than alarming.

HEADQUARTERS, CHINESE EXPEDITIONARY FORCE, July 11 -- Even the most acid curmudgeon must now admit the monsoon has begun. Although weather wise snobs belittled the torrential rains in May and June they cannot take a superior view of the evening deluge that is now falling on the tent as if rain clouds had been ripped wide open.

More than one-half the boys and girls under 18 years of age employed last summer in the six industries covered by minimum wage orders -- hotels, restaurants, laundries, beauty service, cleaning and dyeing and confectionery establishments -- were working in violation of some section of the Labor Law, according to a report issued yesterday by the Division of Women, Child Labor and Minimum Wage, New York State Department of Labor.

The Petroleum Administration for War declared yesterday that while the supply of gasoline in the East had been cut severely by the tremendously increased military needs it expected to be able to meet coupon demands.
ALBANY, July 11 -- Thomas E. Dewey made public today his first major campaign move, a conference with the twenty-five Republican Governors in the country, to be held in St. Louis Aug. 2 and 3.
WITH AMERICAN FORCES, in Normandy, July 11 -- Fighting hard over most of a forty-eight-mile front today, American troops captured a height overlooking the important transportation center of St. Lo.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, July 12 (UP) -- A communique:

The $1,000,000 advertising campaign authorized by the National Confectioners Association to correct "popular misinformation that candy is fattening and causes tooth decay," should be augmented by efforts of candy salesmen to educate the public that candy is a food and should be on the daily menu of everyone, J. Howard Watson, president of the National Confectionery Salesmen's Association of America, declared yesterday.
LONDON, July 10 - London and other parts of southern England have been under attack by the enemy's flying bombs for four weeks tonight.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast domestically in Finland and reported by the Federal Communication Commission:

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Labor leaders appearing before a Senate subcommittee on war contracts agreed today with representatives of management of the aircraft industry who testified yesterday as to reconversion and peacetime plans with exceptions on bearing the costs.

BOGOTA, Colombia, July 11 -- President Alfonso Lopez Pumarejo, abducted early yesterday at Pasto, capital of the southern State of Narino, by a rebellious Army group, has been rescued from his captors by an expedition of citizens and loyal troops, according to a report late tonight.

Richard M. Lederer, president of the Associated Real Estate Corporation, sold the six-story apartment house at 4241 Broadway, at the northwest corner of 180th Street, to a group of investors represented by Samuel Sprung, lawyer, the property is assessed at $350,000, and the sale was made subject to a mortgage of $274,500.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUSHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, July 12 (U.P.) -- Liberator bombers of the Far Eastern Air Force dropped thirty tons of explosives on the Yap Island airdrome and township area on Monday, shooting down five intercepting fighters in the eighth raid this month against the Caroline Islands base, it was announced today.

CHICAGO, July 11 -- Movement of cash wheat has become so heavy that with a critical shortage of labor with which to unload the grain, railroads have been forced to embargo shipments except on permits to eight leading markets. Chicago was added to the list today, following like action at Kansas City yesterday.

BOSTON, July 11 (AP) -- Exactly what effect the influence of the CIO Political Action Committee had on the voting remained in doubt, since endorsed candidates for Congress failed to show the strength displayed by Mayor Tobin.

Plans for a Harlem River Drive from the East River Drive at 125th Street two and one-third miles north to the old Harlem River Speedway, a major pest-war improvement, will make ample provision for commercial uses along the river front, Manhattan Borough President Edgar J. Nathan Jr. announced yesterday.

CAEN, France, July 11 -- This devastated but liberated city, which is still digging itself out of the ruins caused by the Allies' bombing last Friday night, is already being administered by French officials, and the needs of its citizenry for food, shelter and medical care are being met by a joint French and British civil affairs organization.

LONDON, July 11 -- The robot attacks on London caused the Government to lift the ban today on visits to Cornwall, Devon, Dorset and parts of Hampshire. Since the new blitz on London began thousands of women and children who left London have created a housing problem in the north.

Two new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. At the Paramount the newcomer will be "And the Angels Sing," a comedy with music starring Betty Hutton, Fred MacMurray and Dorothy Lamour. Among the supporting players at the Paramount picture are Diana Lynn, Mimi Chandler, Eddie Foy Jr. and Raymond Walburn. . .

LEDO ROAD FORWARD HEADQUARTERS, July 9 (Delayed) -- This year's monsoon is a testing time for the Ledo Road, the new route from India to China. Its builders figure that if the newly built, still loose-packed roadway with its many bridges, causeways and culverts can be kept open in this rainy season it will be a thoroughly proved highway.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Generals and admirals stationed here and near by are in something of a dither these days over an obscure provision of the Independent Offices Appropriations Act, passed by Congress before it adjourned last month, which subjects them, as well as other governmental officers, to summary removal if they ride between their homes and places of work in a Government car

WHEN Renee de Fontarce McCormick was a little girl in France she once sang the "Marseillaise" idly to herself without thinking much of what she was doing. Her father, his royalist convictions outraged by that "song of assassins and murderers" upon his daughter's lips, burst into the room and struck her violently across the cheek, for the first and last time in his life.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Four years ago, when the President was informed on the telephone by his floor managers at the Chicago convention that the leaders were about to nominate him for a third term but were resisting his selection of Henry A. Wallace as running-mate, Mr. Roosevelt sent word that his acceptance would be conditional on the choice of Mr. Wallace.
LONDON, July 11 -- Although business on today's stock markets here was limited mainly to fresh investment buying of industrial shares, a firm tone ruled throughout all sections.

Replies to the dual job questionnaire submitted to 32,000 employes of the Board of Transportation show that 1,000 of them hold outside, part-time jobs, it was learned from a reliable source last night. The questionnaire, a result of the crusade against dual jobs started by Mayor La Guardia a couple of months ago, was distributed to the employes with their latest paychecks.

SUPREME HADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 11 -- Anti-aircraft gunners with the United States forces in Normandy have destroyed more than 100 enemy planes for certain in addition to a number of unconfirmed successes, Col. Walter B. Goodrich, artillery officer, said here today.

MONTREAL, July 11 (Canadian Press) -- The Dodgers beat their Montreal farmhands in an exhibition game before 12,000 fans tonight, 11 -- 8. The Royals outhit Brooklyn, 15 to 14, but they committed six errors.

CHICAGO, July 11 -- A call for a meeting of the American Democratic National Committee to be held next week at the same time as the Democratic National Convention and an invitation to other anti-New Deal groups to rally around were issued today by former Representative John J. O'Connor of New York, chairman of the executive committee.

The Republican party has "gone back to Hooverism," Sidney Hillman, chairman of the Congress of Industrial Organizations Political Action Committee, declared yesterday in branding the party platform "an insult to the intelligence, integrity and the patriotism of the American people."
Frank R. Buckbee has been elect- a member of the Put and Call Brokers and Dealers Association, Inc.

LONDON, Wednesday, July 12 -- Soviet tanks and infantry, cutting through stiffening enemy resistance, smashed forward eighteen miles yesterday in a new drive toward East Prussia, while northeast of embattled Vilna other Red Army forces broadened their wedge between the German strongholds of Dvinsk and Kaunas.

ROME, July 11 -- Evidence that a new political crisis is brewing over the Allied armistice terms continued to pile up today. As the situation is developing it is becoming almost impossible for the Bonomi Government to avoid publishing the armistice terms, but if it does, it is likely to face a storm that may blow it away because those terms, according to every Italian's belief, are extraordinarily severe.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Wednesday, July 12 -- Eleven hundred American heavy bombers, with strong fighter escort, yesterday attacked Munich, birthplace of the Nazi party and one of the key industrial and rail centers of southern Germany.

The formation of a regional aviation committee to work with the Civil Aeronautics Administration and other Federal and State agencies for the construction of hundreds of new airports in this area after the war was approved last night at a meeting of chief executives of eighteen surrounding counties and the five boroughs at a meeting held in the Hotel New Yorker.

The fall and winter Millinery Fashion Promenade, presented last night at the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the Millinery Stabilization Commission, showed the beginning of a new cycle in millinery. The era of the doll-size, silhouette has passed to allow for the upswing of the cycle of "more hat."

CHICAGO, July 11 -- President Roosevelt will be renominated at the Thursday night session of the Democratic National Convention next week, it was tentatively decided at the party's national headquarters today after receipt of the news that he had consented to run.

In January Senator Andrews introduced a concurrent resolution providing in part that every bill or joint resolution passed by Congress "shall embrace but one subject and matter properly connected therewith, which subject shall be briefly stated in the title."

Twelve Harlem youths were held in $15,000 bail each on charges of felonious assault and a thirteenth without bail by Magistrate Harry G. Andrews in Felony Court yesterday as an aftermath of the battle of Negro street gangs on Monday night in which a Negro policeman was critically wounded, a Negro boy shot dead and four others wounded.

CHUNOKING, China, July 11 (U.P.) -- Despite monsoon rains, Chinese forces on the Yunnan front have knifed their way to the high stone wall surrounding the Japanese-held bastion of Tengyueh on three sides of that base and now control all except a two-mile stretch of the highway to Lungling, it was announced today.

One hundred and twenty-six housewives from New York City and Westchester will be asked beginning Tuesday to keep a daily record of all the food they buy, it was announced yesterday by Gene H. Harris, assistant regional supervisor of the special surveys division of the United States Bureau of the Census.

Seeded players from New Jersey, Charles W. Oliver, No. 1; Richard Savitt, No. 2, and Allen Watson, No. 3, won third-round matches in the Eastern junior tennis championship at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, yesterday.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, July 11 (U.P.) -- Japanese forces retreated Wildly in all directions from Ukhrul, in India, today, many without staging any resistance, indicating complete collapse of what they had planned as a mighty offensive.

The Packard Motor Car Company has established a separate division at its Toledo plant to handle advanced aircraft engine development at the request of the Army Air Forces Material Command, it was announced yesterday by George T. Christopher, president and general manager.

Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,161, against 458 in the preceding week and 1,337 in the like period a year ago, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 802 arrivals listed yesterday.

Through presently accelerated amortization practices, the Interstate Commerce Commission estimated yesterday the operating expenses of the Class 1 railroads would be reduced by $23,400,000 annually after 1948. At the close of last year, the railroads had purcased equipment amounting to $688,800,000 which they could amortize in five years since it was for defense purposes.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The War Production Board, in recognition of the critical shortage of wood pulp and paper products, placed material and inventory controls today over the manufacture and use of paper milk containers.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Senator Taft of Ohio predicted today that no agreement for an international monetary fund drafted on the terms of the original joint statement of experts, sent out by Secretary Morgenthau to the representatives of the other United Nations at the Bretton Woods conference, would be approved by either Senate or House.
MOSCOW, July 11 -- In a leading article today Wolna Polska stresses that the Union of Polish Patriots never laid claim to political ascendancy in the life of Poland or a monopoly in patriotism.

President Roosevelt made it clear yesterday that our Government will give General de Gaulle and the French Committee of National Liberation all the cooperation it needs to restore civil administration in liberated France. In Mr. Roosevelt's opinion, this policy does not add up to the recognition of the French Committee as a provisional Government.
CAMDEN, N.J., July 11 (AP) -- Mrs. R.H. Heighe's Rene B equaled the track record in winning the six-furlong Jobstown Purge, feature event at Garden State Park today.
An appeal for volunteer farm laborers, especially women and girls, was issued yesterday by Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the War Manpower Commission.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Wednesday, July 12 -- Tenacious German forces, extravagantly expending men and materiel have struck back with a series of vicious counter-attacks against the British efforts to break out across the Orne River into the open battleground south of Caen.

SOUTH PORTLAND, Me., July 11 -- Twelve persons, including several children, were killed and twenty-one other persons were injured today when a twin-engined Army bomber crashed and exploded in the Westbrook trailer camp.

In your issue of July 7 you report Senator Vandenberg conferring in Albany with Governor Dewey on foreign policy. Senator Vandenberg is quoted to the effect that the Mackinac declaration had set the pattern on foreign policy "not only for the Republican party but the Senate, the country and, finally, the Administration itself."

Surpassing all of Hitler's Blitzkrieg tactics in the heyday of his might, the Russian armies are now waging a Blitzkrieg of their own, which is opening up the chance of a repetition of the same maneuver with which the Germans broke through the French front in 1940 and precipitated Dunkerque and the collapse of France.

PEARL HARBOR, July 11 -- Light surface units of the Pacific Fleet shelled Guam on Sunday, the day carrier aircraft staged the last announced bombing attack on the island's gun emplacements and other military objectives, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- At the insistence of James F. Byrnes, Director of War Mobilization, a compromise was reached today which is likely to end the dispute between Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, and the Armed Services over the matter of reconverting industry to civilian production.

The seizure of President Alfonso Lopez Pumarejo of Colombia and several members of his Cabinet by a group of army officers at Pasto is disturbing news. Whatever the motives, and the dispatches from Colombia so far have failed to give them, all friends of democracy in both the Americas must view with concern this latest attempt to supplant by force a Government elected by the people.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Mrs. Chase Going Woodhouse, Secretary of State of Connecticut, received the endorsement yesterday of the Connecticut Federation of Democratic Women's Clubs for the Democrtic nomination for the Senate for the seat now held by John A. Danaher, Republican.
West Side trading interests yesterday centered in the West End Avenue section. A hotel and several large apartment properties there figured in sales.

Sir Daniel participated in many of the educational, welfare and civic activities of the community, and was honored by organizations in half a dozen countries for his work. He was president of the British Institute of Florence and was made a Freeman of the city of Glasgow in 1929.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Further moves were made to quash the sedition trial on the ground that the rights of defendants had been jeopardized as the case continued today to plod slowly along.

LONDON, July 11 -- The news that the United States would recognize the French Committee as the de facto authority for liberated France was read here with gratification, but official comment was completely lacking.
M.C. Horine, for the past year research consultant to the director of the Automotive Division of the War Production Board, has returned to Mack Trucks, Inc., as sales promotion manager.

MONTEVIDEO, July 11 -- The Federal commissioner in the Argentine Province of Corrientes today issued a decree canceling the municipal concession under which Compania de Electricidad de Corrientes [Corrientes Electricity Company] hitherto operated.

For thirteen minutes, on May 3, Harry Miller, a mail handler at the General Post Office on Eighth Avenue at Thirty-third Street, pretended to "help out" the blind man who sells candy and cigarettes to postal employes there. Yesterday, for what he actually did during that brief time, Miller received a six-month jail term and a tongue lashing from Federal Judge Stephen Brennan.

The Fifth War Loan Sports Committee, of which Max Kase, sports editor of The New York Journal-American, is chairman, has been directly responsible for the sale of $16,730,170 worth of bonds, it was announced yesterday by the Treasury Department.

Herman Forster, president of the New York State Conservation Council, wants to do something now to preserve and promote outdoor facilities for the service men who will demand them after the war. No visionary, Mr. Forster asks serious, realistic people to work on a down-to-earth program that will solve what he admits is a complex problem.

New Yorkers who witnessed the demonstrations for General de Gaulle, at the City Hall, the Waldorf, the Stadium, wherever he appeared, kept commenting on the "royal welcome" he had received. They compared it to the reception given to the King and Queen of England when they visited that "World of Tomorrow" that already seems as much part of the world of the past as the lost Atlantis.

Temporary loan notes of the New York City Housing Authority, amounting to $2,209,000 and due on Feb. 6, 1945, were sold yesterday to the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company and the Bessemer Trust Company of Jersey City.

An electrical method that its originator maintains reveals cancer of the stomach in its early stages, before it can be detected by X-rays, was described yesterday at the Office of the Co-ordinator of Inter-American Affairs, 444 Madison Avenue, by Dr. Jose Risco, Peruvian physician, who has been carrying on research on cancer at the Institute for Scientific Investigation, University of Havana, Cuba.

Johnson Johnson, manufacturer of surgical dressings, showed in 1943 a net income of $3,203,364 after all charges including taxes, according to figures filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Basil Harris, president of the United States Lines Company, disclosed yesterday that his company has agreed to accept $19,200,000 from the Government in full settlement of all the company's claims in connection with the requisitioning of the former transatlantic liners Manhattan and Washington.

Warning that business has practically oversold the public and itself on the overnight coming of a post-war millennium, G.T. Sweetser of the Abbott Kimball Company said yesterday the actual impact of airplanes and television on retail trade is a long way in the future, possibly ten years after the end of the war.

The Government's action in seizing the Bayonne, N.J., shipyard of the Marine Maintenance Corporation and turning it over for operation by East Coast Shipyards, Inc., was defended yesterday in testimony before a Congressional subcommittee sitting in the United States Court House here.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 11 -- Long and ominous shadows of fast-moving Russian Armies are already spreading terror in East Prussia, the vulnerable northeastern bastion of the Reich and neutral military quarters are seriously speculating whether the Wehrmacht will be compelled to retire behind the Vistula River for a last defense in view of the fate now threatening Vilna and the immediate German frontier.

Members of the Police Department were called upon yesterday by Mayor La Guardia and Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine to maintain the vigilance required by the high standards of their organization in the event of enemy action, however remote, and in the period immediately following an announcement of victory.

Treble damage actions aggregating $700,000 were filed in Federal Court yesterday by the Regional Office of Price Administration against thirty-four Manhattan dress manufacturers charged with violating OPA price regulations.

Magistrate Harry G. Andrews became indignant yesterday in the Felony Court when Miss Ronnie Rogers, 21 years old, a blond model, refused to sign a complaint that William Cassidy, 18, was the youth who on June 2 climbed through a fifth-floor fire escape window of her home at 121 East Ninetieth Street, attempted to attack her and fled to his home on the floor below when she screamed.

It is certainly much easier for a hostess who doubles as chief cook and bottle washer to give a houseful of vacationing guests their first meal of the day in the kitchen. During the work-a-day months when the family is rushing off to jobs or school, a kitchen breakfast is almost a must unless the housewife wants to get up an hour earlier than everyone else.
Further tabulations at the Federal Reserve Bank yesterday advanced Fifth War Loan sales for New York City to a figure exceeding the original quota for the entire State.
WITH THE AMERICAN FORCES In Normandy, July 11 -- Two American soldiers have just had an unusual adventure, it was revealed tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- The Surplus War Property Administration announced today that all surplus Government-owned real estate, except industrial real estate, Maritime Commission property and property controlled by the National Housing Agency and the Federal Works Agency, has been assigned to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for disposal.

CHICAGO, July 11 (AP) -- Francisco (Pancho) Segura today failed to make his scheduled debut in the River Forest open tennis tournament because of an ankle injury that may keep the Ecuador star on the sidelines for two weeks.

Paul E. Fitzpatrick of Buffalo was elected officially without opposition yesterday as Democratic State chairman, replacing James A. Farley, who had held that office since 1930. With the change in leadership the New Deal forces took over complete control of the Democratic party machinery in President Roosevelt's home State.
CHUNGKING, China, July 11 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

CHICAGO, July 11 -- The year following peace will bring the reintroduction of 1941-42 models of home equipment which are still new to the market, rather than brand-new ones, according to speakers today before appliance retailers attending the summer markets of The Furniture Mart.

The heat was trying enough in Foley Square yesterday but when Mrs. Alfredo Cinados, the former "Honeychile" Wilder, was called to the witness stand in Supreme Court before Referee John P. Cohalan and she continued to chew her gum, the referee reminded her, "This is a court of law and chewing gum is not allowed on the witness stand."

Plans for post-war higher education in this State include establishment of two-year technical and vocational institutes and the grant of more State scholarships to outstanding high school graduates, Dr. J. Cayce Morrison, assistant commissioner of research for the New York State Department of Education, declared yesterday at a conference for school administrators at Teachers College, Columbia University.

ROME, July 11 (UP) -- French troops, their advance spearheaded by American tanks, were within twenty miles of Florence tonight and the Fifth Army was fighting its way against everything that the Germans could offer along three river valleys leading to the Arno River, guarding the front of the enemy's "Gothic line."

TASHKENT, Uzbekistan, U.S.S.R., July 6 (Delayed) -- Eric Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, today concluded a nine-day, 4,150-mile tour of the Soviet Union's great new Ural-Siberian-Central Asia industrial area on which officials unfolded for him the full panorama of the mighty home-front effort that saved the nation in its darkest days and now contributes materially to each victory.

The need of systematic planning to preserve the future peace and to frustrate Germany's scheme to turn defeat in war into victory in peace is the consensus of opinion expressed in reply to a questionnaire addressed to a group of prominent citizens and leaders of American public opinion by the Post-War Economic Committee, of which Benjamin A. Javits is chairman.

Your recent editorial, "New Welfare Trend," is a splendid recognition of the most important new development in family case work which has occurred in many years -- that of extending the experience and helpfulness of family case work to a group who are able to pay.

Cotton prices continued their upward climb yesterday to new high levels for the season, and closed very steady, 16 to 22 points net higher than Monday's final quotations on active months on the New York Cotton Exchange.

Nowhere, either at home or abroad, will there be surprise over the President's announcement that he will accept renomination by the Democratic party and serve a fourth term if elected. For many months it has been apparent both that Mr. Roosevelt would wish to run and that a large majority of the delegates to the Democratic convention would want him to.

New Government restrictions on the amount of wood allotted to furniture manufacturers have resulted in predictions by the trade that this coming season's supply will be from 25 per cent to 50 per cent less than last year's, which was about 85 per cent of normal.

The City Planning Commission closed yesterday the public hearings on its proposal to amend the zoning resolution by tightening the restrictions on the height and bulk of new buildings. The commission asked that all objections, memoranda and suggestions not presented at the two hearings held to date be submitted by Aug. 1.

PITTSBURGH, July 12 -- The twelfth All-Star battle is over and even the American Leaguers were willing to admit -- although with understandable reluctance -- that it probably was just as well that the Nationals triumphed last night. A lop-sided series is never good for any sport and this one has borne a distinct junior circuit imprint from its very beginnings.

Many children living in East Harlem have never been out of this congested slum, where some 200,000 people are crowded into 204 square blocks. Most of them, except for occasional trips with the settlement group leaders, seldom even see a city park.

At a joint commencement exercise of the Schools of Education and Business of Fordham University last night in Keating Hall on the campus thirty-three seniors received diplomas from the Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, in Australia, Thursday, July 13 (U.P.) -- Believed sadly lacking in ammunition, stores and transport, the isolated members of the Eighteenth Japanese Army appeared bent on a suicide offensive, Gen. Douglas MacArthur's daily communique revealed.

Warning that the already critical paper shortage "has finally caught up with such an essential food as milk," Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, urged yesterday that every branch of the food-processing industry re-examine immediately its use of paper containers so as to be ready for possible new Government regulations requiring quick shifts to less essential packaging.

Germans accused of crimes against the Jews of Europe should be tried by tribunals of the Jewish people where the alleged crimes were committed, Dr. Joseph Tenenbaum proposed yesterday in his first statement as president of the American Federation of Polish Jews.
LONDON, July 12 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

After spending twenty-one months as a prisoner of war in the Japanese internment camps of San Tomas and Los Banos in the Philippines, Richard Sanford, actor, made his first stage appearance in this country on Tuesday at the Jacoby Playhouse, Cedarhurst, L.I., in Noel Coward's "Blithe Spirit."

One of your correspondents -- referring to Prime Minister Churchill's recent references to the aid furnished by British newspapers in publishing information on reducing dangers from Germany's pilotless bombing planes -- raises a question: "Why is it that Mr. Roosevelt never does this but has only words of abuse for the press of the United States?"

Among the French Departments where the patriots of the underground have risen against the Nazis is that of the Ain, in northern France between the Saone, the Rhone and the Canton of Geneva. Its northeast frontier town of Ferney, or Ferney-Voltaire, has been famous for nearly two centuries.
Back in World War I, there was published here a German propaganda paper called The Fatherland, dedicated to "fair play for Germany and Austria-Hungary."

CAMDEN, N.J., July 12 (AP) -- Max Wexler's Plucky Raider, the favorite at 1 to 2, made it three in a row, two of them at Garden State Park, when he drove to the wire a length and a quarter before W.E. Johnson's Ballast at the end of the mile and seventy yards sixth and best race today. William Helis' Aera was a fast- closing third in the field of seven 3-year-olds.

WITH THE CHINESE ARMY, on the Salween front, July 11 (Delayed) -- Some day there should be a monument at Tatangtzu. Not to the 2,000 Japanese who were killed in that vicinity. Not necessarily to the thousands of Chinese who died or were wounded struggling up that lethal slope into machine-gun fire, rain and sleet.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12 (AP) -- R.H. Teed of Hot Springs, Ark., prospective purchaser of the Springfield (Mo.) Gas and Electric Company, has informed the Securities and Exchange Commission that simultaneously with the purchase of Springfield's common stock from the Federal Light and Traction Company he will "irrevocably deposit with a trustee or paying agent funds sufficient for the redemption of all outstanding bonds and preferred stock."

John P. Marquand, Pulitzer prize-winning novelist, has joined the editorial board of the Book-of-the-Month Club, Harry Scherman, president, announced yesterday. Mr. Marquand, whose "H.M. Pulham, Esq." and "So Little Time" were club selections, thus forfeits the right to have any future novels selected as books of the month.

LONDON, July 12 -- Although it is generally known that East Prussia is to be severed from Germany after the war, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden said in the House of Commons today that no "final decision" had been reached at Teheran or elsewhere on how it should be apportioned between Poland and Russia.
LONDON, Thursday, July 13 (AP) -- The German news agency DNB, in a Berlin broadcast, announced today the death of Edouard Herriot, former French Premier. The broadcast gave no details.

" Stars of Tomorrow," opening next Wednesday night at the Malin Theatre, 137 West Forty-fourth Street, is one show where the management actually invites the audience "to cheer them or jeer them." Sponsored by Jules Denes, the variety bill will be performed every evening, except Sunday, with a cast including Rose Mortel, Gea Gianna, Roy and Gladyce Royce, "Professor" H. Warren Hyer, Maria Karolyi, Susanne Pierre and Jimmy McGarry (master of ceremonies).

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The question of whether the musical number, "Don't Change Horses in the Middle of the Stream," has any hidden political significance is a matter beyond the power of the Federal Communications Commission to determine, James L. Fly, FCC chairman, said today.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Women as well as men who volunteered for military service have been rejected for lack of physical fitness in percentages high enough to raise serious questions.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- She saw Salerno and she saw Anzio, she spent twenty-two months on two hospital ships evacuating frontline wounded, and that was what Second Lieut. Virginia Saydus, of the Army Nurse Corps, a former Powers model, talked about while she was being photographed today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Bazil, July 12 -- Coffee exports were at a low level in June, according to coffee authorities here, because speculators were hoarding coffee and preventing shipments to the United States. Against a monthly average for six months of 1,181,840 bags -- shipments from January to May were 5,909,200 bags -- the June shipments totaled 789,433 bags.

Prices of cotton for future delivery declined yesterday 1 to 5 points on the N.Y. Cotton Exchange, influenced by liquidation in July, profit-taking on an early advance and favorable crop reports from theh South.

Fresh buying power appeared yesterday in the stock market as selective buying returned prices to approximately the high marks set on Monday. Many buyers were obviously on a shopping expedition, and in some eases there was evidence of testing current levels.

ROME, July 12 -- That the bombs that damaged the venerated shrine of Our Lady of Loretto came from German planes was announced by Osservatore Romano tonight. The Vatican City newspaper took the opportunity in strong terms to denounce the destruction which both sides in the war are causing to objects of sacred and cultural value.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12 (AP) -- Coach George Munger expects a squad of 100 to report for the opening of the University of Pennsylvania's summer football drills tomorrow, including only one man, Guard Walt Stickel, from the team that started against Cornell in the final game of 1943.

John R. Morris, manager for the United Press Association in the Far East, died in Bellevue Hospital yesterday afternoon after he was picked up on the roof of a one-story building just east of the Daily News Building, at 220 East Forty-second Street, his back broken.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 12 -- The proposed Bank for Reconstruction and Development, from which the word "bank" probably will be dropped in favor of a substitute, was urged today by an official conference spokesman as the only way to avert chaotic conditions in post-war Europe and avoid a cycle of revolutions with the introduction of "all kinds of isms."

Eric Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, came home yesterday after an eight-week trip to the Soviet Union, but paused only briefly in New York before continuing on to Washington.

Continued dissatisfaction with price increases granted or planned by the Office of Price Administration under the new Stabilization Extension Act of 1944 was expressed yesterday by two major divisions of the cotton textile industry.
A communique, as broadcast from Chungking yesterday in English to North America and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
If they want to save time, racing officials may just as well hand over the Demoiselle Stakes to Jim Fitzsimmons to have and to hold.
ALBANY, July 12 -- The official Republican campaign attitude toward President Roosevelt's acceptance of a fourth term nomination was expressed today by Herbert Brownell Jr., the national chairman.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The United States will ask its Allies and compel its enemies to remove or minimize all restrictions on the free exchange of news and other information in the post-war world.
Seven years ago, when Joseph F. ]Seehan was 12 years old, Howard !Chandler Christy used him as the ifresh-cheeked model for the Police Athletic League poster, 'Pals All."

" The Liberation of Rome," a two-reel fact-film about the Allied campaign in Italy, will open simultaneously today at the Astor, Paramount, Strand, Rivoli, Music Hall, Loew's State, Loew's Criterion, Victoria, Capitol, Hollywood, Gotham, Manhattan and Broadway Trans-Lux Theatres.

PITTSBURGH, July 12 (U.P.) -- There is a steady back-to-the-gridiron movement among the nation's colleges which in the past two seasons have dropped the intercollegiate sport and many are planning to field teams once again in 1944, a survey disclosed tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Negotiations between the United States and Great Britain on the subject of oil will be resumed soon with Secretary Hull and Lord Beaverbrook heading the American and British delegations, respectively.

WASHINGTON. July 12 (AP) -- An employer may appeal to the gratitude of his workers not to organize a union, providing the appeal does not imply a threat to withdraw employe benefits, the Court of Appeals held in effect today.
Yesterdays communique, as broadcast domestically in Finland and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

STAMFORD, Conn., July 12 -- The first race of the midget yacht racing championship series of Long Island Sound was sailed off the Riverside Yacht Club today in a heavy sou'westerly and was won by Don MacNary of Manhasset Bay.
LONDON, July 12 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:
Donald Barr, in 1 E End Ave; Mrs. J. Guitierrez, in Hampshire House; Frederic A.W. Bryan, in 455 E 57th St; Donald E. Walsh, in 1175 Park Ave -- Douglas L. Elliman Co, Inc, broker.
KANDY, Ceylon, July 12 (UP) -- A communique:

Stocks of all principal oil products in the United States showed gains last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the end of the week gasoline stocks amounted to 83,709,000 barrels, an increase of 150,000 over the 83,559,000 in the previous week.

Substantial increases in domestic slaughter of cattle since the first of the year have been offset to great extent by decreases in hide imports, tanners declared yesterday, with a continuing tight leather situation regarded as certain.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 12 -- Two leading Cairo newspapers, Al Balagh and El Makattam, severely criticize the Republican platform policy regarding unrestricted immigration to Palestine, the former calling it "an outrage against a small and friendly nation" and favoring the return of Jews to the countries of origin in Europe.

Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, made public yesterday a letter addressed to member firms reminding them of the applicability of two rules of the Exchange to the reports of substantial increases in the use of currency in settlement of business transactions in recent months.

In THE TIMES was printed not long ago what purported to be a quotation from a writer in the Korean National Herald, published in Honolulu, stating: "Although Korea is only half as large as California, its some 23 million inhabitants speak so many dialects that as soon as the Japanese yoke is thrown off, the new Korean Government may make teaching of one form of the language obligatory in all the thirteen provinces."
LONDON, Thursday, July 13 (UP) -- The Russian Wednesday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 12 -- Brian Aherne, whose Columbia contract was suspended recently because of his refusal to appear in the forthcoming "Stalk the Hunter," is back in the good graces of the studio and has been lent to Charles R. Rogers for the lead in the producer's United Artists picture, "High Among the Stars."
ROME, July 12 -- The municipal junta of Rome, which includes two Communists went in a body this morning to pay their homage to the Pope.

Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican national chairman, announced yesterday that he had arranged to discuss campaign financing with James S. Kemper of Chicago, thereby giving rise to speculation that Mr. Kemper may be named chairman of the Republican finance committee for the Dewey-Bricker campaign.

Permission to operate day nurseries in the city school buildings from July 1 to Sept. 1 was granted yesterday to the Mayor's Committee on Wartime Care of Children by the Board of Education at its regular meeting. Kindergarten rooms in selected schools are to be used.

CHUNGKING, China, July 12 (AP) -- Japanese troops have slashed forward twenty-five miles in the Kwangtung Province drive seeking to close a vise on the Canton-Hankow Railroad, but the Chinese contained the northern jaw in Hunan Province in the face of gas attacks, the Chinese High Command declared tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Another war will give the United States no time to prepare and the development of long-range bombardment will make every objective in the United States vulnerable from overseas bases, Robert P.
