Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, told the Murray War Contracts Subcommittee of the Senate Military Affairs Committee today in submitting the War Department's ideas on the kind of air forces and aviation industry the country will need.
OTTAWA, July 12 {AP) -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle today visited Quebec and Montreal, the principal French-speaking cities of Canada, after a day spent in Ottawa as the guest of the Canadian Government.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- Prices of wheat held within rather narrow limits today on the Board of Trade, operators regarding them as too close to the Government loan to take the selling side freely despite the record crop being harvested. This resulted in erratic fluctuations with the close 1/4 cent a bushel lower to 1/4 cent higher than yesterday.

WALTER LIPPMAN, for many years a believer in a Wilsonian League of Nations, has finally completed the shifting of his ground. A. year ago, in his "U.S. Foreign Policy; Shield of the Republic," he advocated a "nuclear alliance" of Britain, Russia, the United States and perhaps China to maintain the fruits of victory.

The second battle of Britain, precipitated by Hitler's flying bombs, has now been under way for four weeks. All reports from London agree on its disturbing character. But despite German threats of bigger bombs to come, Allied military opinion, shared by General Eisenhower, confirms the initial impression that, as a last desperate weapon that was to win the war for Hitler, the flying bomb has proved a failure thus far.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Thursday, July 13 (AP) -- A communique:

PAMPLONA, Spain, July 12 -- The siege of Paris already is under way, with the former capital isolated from the rest of France and in the throes of a serious food shortage, while German occupation troops live in fear of emboldened patriots, afraid to venture beyond gun shot range of their patrols, refugees from the north reported today.

A group of forty-two "highly employable" women, whose average age is more than 55, were graduated from the household training course of the Department of Welfare at a ceremony held yesterday at the department's household training project, 325 East Thirty-eighth Street.
The powerful motors of the big Douglas transport lifted the silver plane and its passengers off Santos Dumont Airport in downtown Rio de Janeiro just as the sun was coming up out of the Atlantic.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Thursday, July 13 -- At least 1,200 heavy bombers of the United States Eighth Air Force with about 750 fighter escorts flew to southwest Germany yesterday and attacked Munich, which was bombed by 1,100 of the Eighth's "heavies" twenty-four hours earlier.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet press and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Though the capture of Caen was an Allied victory no one can take pleasure in what has happened to that once lovely French city nor in what has befallen La Haye du Puits, taken by American troops, nor in the by-products of bombing attacks on the naval base of Toulon.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12 (AP) -- Edward G. Budd announced today in annual reports to stockholders that the Edward G. Budd Manufacturing Company and the Budd Wheel Company had net incomes of $2,008,137 and $1,413,278, respectively, for 1943, exclusive of tax reductions and renegotiation provisions.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, called upon the steel industry today to show sufficient "industrial statesmanship" to assure its employes that they would not move into "another apple selling era" when the war ends.

The disagreement between the armed services and Mr. Nelson of the War Production Board, over the question of when and how to begin reconverting a part of industry to civilian production, has ended at least temporarily in what some Washington observers describe as a compromise and others as a victory for Mr. Nelson.

LONDON, July 12 (U.P.) -- An agreement has been reached between the British and German Governments, with Switzerland acting as an intermediary, for the exchange, with certain exceptions, of all imprisoned civilian nationals, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden announced today in the House of Commons.

An achievement in long-distance law enforcement was claimed by the Federal Bureau of Investigation here yesterday with the announcement that on Tuesday in San Francisco G-men had picked up two seamen wanted for transporting stolen fountain pens.

Sales of leading mail order and chain store companies in June increased 2.1 per cent over the same month last year, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES, covering twenty-eight companies. Total sales were $361,578,916, compared with $354,136,620 in June, 1943. In May there was a gain of 11.3 per cent.
LONDON, July 12 (UP) -- A joint Air and Home Security Ministries communique:

Though the Germans still fight doggedly, American troops are now within a few miles of the burning port of Leghorn. Its fall seems inevitable. Once we hold the city and have restored its harbor facilities, we can pour in men and supplies against the entire Gothic Line across the Italian peninsula.

ROME, July 12 (U.P.) -- An American light armored force, breaking a week's stalemate along the Tyrrhenian coastal road, has captured Castiglioncello and advanced beyond it toward Leghorn, it was announced today, while, on the opposite end of the Italian front, British Eighth Army artillery was shelling enemy installations around the port of Ancona.

Mayor La Guardia said yesterday that he had been notified by John H. Delaney, chairman of the Board of Transportation, that all employes of the board holding outside jobs "will be kept under strict supervision, and disciplinary action in accordance with the rules and regulations of the board will be taken."

The Navy Department in Washington issued a statement yesterday denying the charge made by the Industrial Council of the Congress of Industrial Organizations in this city that the Navy had been responsible for the dismissal of 900 employes of the Burchell Products Corporation at 238 William Street.

Under the terms of the proposed merger of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York and its various operating subsidiaries into a single operating company, filed yesterday with the Public Service Commission, an interesting financial aspect is raised with respect to minority mtoekhold of the New York Steam Corporation.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- American casualties on Saipan up to July 10 totaled 15,053 -- 2,359 killed in action, 11,481 wounded and 1,213 missing -- Secretary of the Navy James V. Forrestal announced today.

Advocating universal military training in the future to obviate conditions that produced the millions found mentally and physically deficient for service in this war, Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, national director of Selective Service, declared yesterday that only men under 30 years old would be required by Selective Service under present war conditions.

The city's milk supply was described yesterday as critically short by small distributors, who said they were already 150,000 quarts below their daily requirement, but spokesmen for the large milk companies said they would be able to meet all or nearly all normal demands over the week-end.

LONDON, July 12 -- A quieter bone was noticeable in today's stock markets, but buyers appeared to be in the majority. There was some evidence of profit-taking and prices were somewhat irregular at the opening.

An investigation of ceiling price violations at Coney Island, the Rockaways and Monticello, N.Y., is being conducted by the Office of Price Administration, Daniel P. Woolley, regional administrator, revealed yesterday.

Continuing his fine tennis, Charles Oliver of Perth Amboy, N.J., the top seeded player, reached the semi-finals of the Eastern junior championship by defeating John Riihiluoma of Ozone Park, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 4, at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, yesterday.

BOSTON, July 12 (AP) -- Robert W. Collins' Scottsville, 31-1 shot in a field of nine starters, scored a surprise length decision in today's allowance feature at Suffolk Downs, the $2,500 Fieldstone Purse.

NOVOSIBIRSK, U.S.S.R., July 2 (Delayed) -- A quick look at the factories of the Urals-Siberian area is all one needs to confirm the belief that here is not only a great war production center, but an area that will be one of the world's most important industrial sections in the future, benefiting immensely from the two five-year plans that Premier Joseph Stalin projects for the immediate post-war period.

LONDON, July 12 -- Trains bound west and north were heavily laden with small children and their mothers today as the evacuation of London and the other dangerous areas continued. After its second successive raidless night the London area today again felt the weight of flying bombs.

CAEN, July 12 (NANA) -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle's organization for the relief and rehabilitation of liberated French towns and cities is proving so brilliantly effective in the case of Caen that the preparations of the Allies' civil affairs detachments seem, to some extent, superfluous.

On June 9 there was a fight near the town of Distomo, in Greece, in which thirty German soldiers were killed. Next day, June 10, the second anniversary of the slaughter at Lidice, the Germans rounded up the inhabitants of Distomo in the public square and cut down one thousand men, women and children with machine guns.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES, In Normandy, July 12 -- La Meauffe is an obscure village huddled beside an ancient chateau and a church on the Vire River five miles north of St. Lo. Our soldiers call it "Murphy," partly because that is the nearest that they can come to pronouncing it and partly because a "murphy" in Army slang is a bad situation.

Continued emphasis on the placing of contracts with smaller war plants by the Jersey Quartermaster Depot was displayed in the depot's contract statistics for June, Col. George F. Spann, commanding officer, stated yesterday. Out of a total of 4,441 prime contracts awarded during June, 2,634, or approximately 60 per cent, were awarded to firms employing 500 or fewer wage earners.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Judge Fred M. Vinson, director of the Office of Economic Stabilization, was expected to resolve the controversy between the Office of Price Administration and the War Food Administration over continuation of subsidy payments to canners of corn, peas, tomatoes, beans and tomato juice which has delayed action on the major canned goods items for some time.

SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, July 12 (AP) -- The juncture of the Chinese Twenty-second and Thirty-eighth Divisions about seven miles west of Mogaung has cleared the Kamaing-Mogaung road and given the Allies control of approximately 300 miles of the new Ledo supply road to China, it was announced today.

Explaining another drop in the weekly tonnage of waste paper salvaged by his Department of Sanitation trucks, Commissioner William F. Carey said yesterday that the city's housewives "could contribute four times as much to the war effort if they would separate paper from garbage."

A display of lace and embroidery made by American Indian women in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries went on public exhibition for the first time yesterday at the Cooper Union Museum for the Arts of Decoration at Cooper Square.

Producers of trade-marked goods were warned yesterday by John W. Scott, president of the American Fair Trade Council, to prepare for protection of their lines against severe cut price competition immediately after the war. Fair trade laws, he added, "will be the target of flank attacks in a general movement against the institution of advertising."

BERNE, Switzerland, July 12 -- The Hungarian radio tonight broadcast an order to the parents of Budapest children under the age of 14 to arrange for their immediate evacuation "in view of the intensification of enemy aerial activity over the capital area."
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Orders which will set in motion the War Production Board program for industrial reconversion are completed and ready for printing.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Signs of impatience and nervousness appeared today among supporters of Vice President Wallace as President Roosevelt remained silent regarding his preference for a running mate.

A group headed by Blair Co. will offer today a new issue of $3,850,000 City of Birmingham, Ala., 4 per cent, 3 per cent and 1 1/2 per cent industrial water works refunding bonds, due serially Aug. 1, 1945-70, at prices to yield 0.50 to 1.75 per cent, according to maturity.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., July 12 (U.P.) -- Two rings on a party line phone and the two words "Washington calling" were all Mrs. Wands Holzbaur needed here today to tell her that Vice President Henry A. Wallace was calling to tell her about his visit with her husband in a western China hospital where Mr. Wallace visited recently.

LONDON, July 12 -- One of the most dramatic stories of the war was told today by a senior officer of the United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe when he traced the contribution to the present Allied offensives on the Continent of the American heavy bomber and long-range fighter squadrons working as a team from bases in Britain, Italy and Russia.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (U.P.) -- President Roosevelt may issue a statement tomorrow disclaiming any wish to dictate to the Democratic convention on the Vice Presidency, but stating that he would vote for Henry A. Wallace if he were a delegate to the convention.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Denmark's opposition to the German oppressors as evidenced in the recent general strike was hailed by Secretary of State Cordell Hull today as an example for the peoples of other occupied countries. The Danish people are side by side with the people of the United Nations, he declared.
BERNE, Switzerland, July 12 -- Germany has more tricks in the bag, it was stated today, in response to threats of Allied reprisals for Germany's robot bombs.

While efforts of the War Finance Committee are centered on the sale of E bonds, it was disclosed yesterday that sales of all categories of bonds in New York State during the Fifth War Loan campaign had passed beyond the State's record for all previous drives and that new totals for the city and nation also indicated possible attainment of new records.

An over-all plan for complete consolidation of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York and its utility subsidiary companies so as to form a new single operating company was filed yesterday with the New York State Public Service Commission.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- A contest is under Way in Congress to elect a Midwesterner as Republican leader of the House if the party wins control in the November elections and Representative Martin of Massachusetts steps up to the Speakership.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Thursday, July 13 -- Remnants of the Japanese Eighteenth Army, isolated in the Wewak area since April, have begun a desperate attempt to break through the American positions at Aitape, British New Guinea, General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters announced today.

Two four-story apartment buildings on a plot 40 by 83.6 feet at 116-18 Third Avenue, near Sixty-fifth Street, were sold by Harris D. Colt and Lucius H. Beers, trustees of the Richard S. Ely estate, to the Netmar Corporation, George E. Netter secretary, for investment. The Payson McL. Merrill Company was the broker.
PITTSBURGH, July 12 (AP) -- Night world series games may be just around the corner, but baseball men streaming out of town today agreed 1944 definitely was not the time.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Twenty-five of the States and the District of Columbia increased in population between April 1, 1940, and July 1, 1943, and the other twenty-three States had decreases, according to a Census Bureau report.

The new Libera lparty intends to nominate a full slate of candidates for this year's elections, John L. Childs, State chairman, and Joseph V. O'Leary, State secretary, announced yesterday. The group has already announced its indorsement of President Roosevelt, Vice President Henry A. Wallace and Senator Robert F. Wagner for re-election.

William E. Kress, for the past two years Southwestern division manager with headquarters in Kansas City for the Philco Corporation, has been appointed sales manager of the Middle West, with headquarters in Chicago.

LONDON, July 12 (AP) -- The German radio tonight reported that a big Allied push in Normandy was under way with an "artillery barrage exceeding anything that has gone before' 'and a "strategy utterly new in the history of warfare."

A 15-year-old high school boy, Frank Beninati of 1437 Sixty-first Street, Brooklyn, was at Kings County Hospital last night with a punctured lung and a police bullet lodged against his spine, while his sister, two soldiers and another woman were booked at the Parkville station, Brooklyn, as members of a hold-up gang.

Lack of rain and continued heat are threatening victory gardens and truck farms in the metropolitan area and have already damaged them heavily in Virginia and States to the southwest and in the Midwest, reports indicated yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 79:

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The name of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate for President, was brought into the mass sedition trial today when the Government presented a wealth of documentary evidence designed to prove the twenty-nine defendants pro-Nazi and anti-semitic.

Charles Tobey, Republican, of New Hampshire, and Elmer Thomas, Democrat, of Oklahoma, the only two incumbent Senators whose renominations were opposed in primaries Tuesday in six States, won their contests on the basis of nearly complete returns, as reported by The United Press.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 12 -- The United States has asked Russia to expedite her reply as to whether she is willing to abandon or modify her position that war-devastated countries should be allowed to pay less gold than others into the proposed International Monetary Fund to stabilize currencies.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Alarmed by the sharply rising need for carbon steel to satisfy war orders, the War Production Board embarked today on a drive to cut down inventories and reduce outstanding orders by users of this material.

Board members of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs were welcomed by officers of the New York State group at a dinner given last evening at the Waldorf-Astoria, where the board opened yesterday a three-day meeting preliminary to the 1944 convention of the national membership.

The Chemical Bank and Trust Company announced yesterday in its report for the first six months of this year that net earnings after expenses and taxes amounted to $3,462,641, equal to $1.73 a share of capital stock. This compares with $2,590,966, or $1.29 a share, for the first half of 1943.

When the thermometer hovers in the upper eighties and nineties, as it has recently, we instinctively change certain food habits -- eat more vegetables and fruits, drink increased quantities of water and other liquids, etc. A member of the medical information bureau of the New York Academy of Medicine thinks that some of the alterations we make are good, while others are not.

The one-story "taxpayer" building, containing nine stores at the southwest corner of Queens Boulevard and Union Turnpike, Kew Gardens, Queens, has been purchased by the Huyler Realty Corporation, represented by Joseph G. Abramson, from the Como Realty Corporation, an Alexander S. Bing syndicate, which acquired it in 1937.

LONDON, July 12 -- British Liberals are expressing some interest in views for the future of India, reported to be those of the aged Mohandas K. Gandhi. The theme of his latest pronouncement is that a national government should be established in control of the civil government of the country, leaving the Viceroy, Viscount Wavell, in charge of all military affairs.

ON THE NORMANDY FRONT, July 11 (Delayed) -- Out in a narrow swamp that separated the American and German lines, forty-two Germans surrendered today to two sergeants while their own Elite Guard troops tried to prevent it.
LONDON, July 12 -- The types of flying bombs being launched against Britain are only some of several kinds of jet or rocket-propelled bombs of varying sizes and potentialities.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Thursday, July 13 -- The vanguard of the American drive on St. Lo has smashed within 2,600 yards of the ancient fortress and the whole First Army line is rolling slowly forward in Normandy, it was announced today.

LONDON, July 12 (U.P.) -- German broadcasts today glumly warned the German people to expect big new retreats on the Eastern Front, and dispatches from neutral capitals indicated that the hard-pressed Wehrmacht was being prepared to fight on German soil.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Hearings on wartime health and education before a Senate subcommittee ended today with witnesses agreed on the need of a concerted community effort for education, prevention and treatment in the serious health situation in the country.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 12 -- Edward M. Waters of 361 West Fifty-first Street, New York City, who makes a practice of returning items that forgetful passengers leave in his cab, had to travel to Port Washington today to collect a reward, but he figures that it was well worth it.

A 22-year-old Philadelphia Quaker who was decorated by the British for courageous service as an ambulance driver in North Africa said yesterday he was convinced that soldiers and conscientious objectors all were "fighting for the same thing -- peace in the world and democracy."
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 12 (AP) -- Communique 73:

Public hearings to investigate the censorship by Station WMCA of State Senator Frederic R. Coudert Jr.'s speech before the county convention of the American Legion last Friday night were urged in a telegram sent yesterday to the Federal Communications Commission by National Commander Edward T. McCaffrey of the Catholic War Veterans and three Past National Commanders.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Problems involved in easing Mexico's economic position that has developed out of war conditions, with food and other essential supplies reported affected, occupied first place in the official conversations conducted here for the past week by Ezequiel Padilla, the Mexican Foreign Minister.

An example of forethought wisely directed is the series of manuals planned in Washington on how to succeed in small business. They are intended for the use of war veterans who intend to use their savings and Government loans to set up in business for themselves.

PACIFIC FLEET HEADQUARTERS, July 12 -- Approximately 1,200 Japanese troops, the first such body of enemy fighting men taken in the central Pacific, were captured in the battle of Saipan, it was announced today.

Max Paul of 144-04 Seventy-first Avenue, Kew Garden Hills, Queens, pleaded guilty yesterday before Judge Robert A. Inch in Brooklyn Federal Court to an indictment charging violation of the Office of Price Administration ceiling prices on whisky.
WINNIPEG, July 12 (AP) -- A United States airman was killed and another officer is missing following the crash of a mercy flight plane in Hudson Bay, 1,000 miles north of Winnipeg.

Rear Admiral Howard L. Vickery, chairman of the board of awards of the United States Maritime Commission, yesterday assumed responsibility for initiating the seizure of the Bayone (N.J.) shipyard of the Marine Maintenance Corporation.

The Goelet-Harris Corporation has purchased the fifteen-story apartment house on a plot 100 by 100 feet at 610 West 110th Street, near Riverside Drive, from the Glenmere Management Corporation for cash over a mortgage of $450,000. Rubin Nason were the brokers in the sale of the building, which contains sixty-nine suites and is assessed at $500,000.

A syndicate has purchased from the Bowery Savings Bank the sixteen-story office building at 254-56 West Fifty-fourth Street and the adjoining three-story structure at 258 West Fifty-fourth Street for cash over a purchase money mortgage of $360,000.

Interest in home canning is lagging this season despite Government warnings that the commercial pack must still be supplemented, officials of local agencies concerned with the problem declared yesterday.

LONDON, Thursday, July 13 -- Soviet troops, launching a great new offensive drive toward the Baltic Sea against the last German-held territory in pre-war Russia, have crashed through powerful German defenses east of Latvia on a ninety-three-mile front and advanced as much as twenty-two miles, Moscow revealed last night.

LONDON, June 12 -- A bill to replan and to redevelop Britain's blitzed and blighted areas easily obtained second reading in the House of Commons tonight, but only because the Labor members contented themselves with a sitdown protest rather than a hostile vote against a measure they considered inadequate but which their own representatives in the coalition Cabinet had sponsored.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 12 (AP) -- Remaining places in the men's and women's semi-finals of the Eastern clay court tennis championships were filled today with no further upsets, at the Montclair Athletic Club.

At 5 P.M. yesterday Detective Lieutenant Edward Feeley of the Morrisania station, the Bronx, was quite contented as he called it a day. He had been on the job since 4:15 A.M. and the result was a confession from 24-year-old James Robert Alston that he had set fire to at least eleven apartment houses, ten in the Bronx and one in Harlem.
ROME, July 12 (AP) -- A communique:

LONDON, July 12 (U.P.) -- Franz von Papen, German Ambassador to Turkey, has burned his papers and left Ankara, unconfirmed reports said tonight, and observers saw in expressions of Turkish regard for Russia and other factors the possibility that Turkey was ready to cast her lot with the Allies or even enter the war.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, in a memorandum filed today with the Supreme Court of the United States, said that it would welcome a legal showdown with the American Power and Light Company and the Electric Power and Light Corporation on the constitutional questions involved in the order of the SEC directing the dissolution of the two sub-holding companies in the Electric Bond and Share Company system.

A court test case that may have widespread interest for sportsmen is impending in Pennsylvania. It involves the right of private clubs and individuals to close some twelve miles of Broadhead Creek in the Poconos to fishermen. Assemblyman Jacob L. Moser contends that the navigable waters in question are "public highways," basing his stand on acts passed by the State Legislature more than 100 years ago.

NEWARK, N.J., July 12 -- Trial of the suit of Edward Grasso, medically discharged soldier, to compel A.J. Crowhurst Sons, Belleville leather tanners, to restore him to his job under the provisions of the Selective Service Act, brought about today an examination of the feet of Federal Judge Guy L. Fake, who is presiding.

The North Side Savings Bank sold the five - story apartment building and stores at 890 Longwood Avenue, corner of Hewitt Place, the Bronx, to the 793 Hewlitt Corporation. Sale was made subject to a mortgage of $24,000. The property is assessed at $64,000.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The President, having announced without any stated condition that he will accept a fourth-term nomination, has left the Democratic National Convention free to choose a running-mate other than Vice President Wallace. Among the insiders there is little doubt that the President prefers the Vice President on his ticket above any other aspirant or eligible, and will make that known before the convention assembles next week at Chicago.

TRENTON, N.J., July 12 -- Two railroads today authorized State Controller Homer C. Zink to cash checks totaling more than $7,750,000 as their initial payments on delinquent taxes and interest for the years 1932 through 1940.

" Curvacious" was the epithet coined by Sally Victor as being the most descriptive of the rounded lines that flow through her fall and winter millinery collection. By a deft trick of manipulation she has managed to give more size to her hat silhouette and yet to reveal the face.

CHICAGO, July 13 -- Persistent hedging sales in wheat and a lack of aggressive support carried prices lower today on the Board of Trade and closing sales were about the bottom with losses of 1/2 to 7/8 cent a bushel. Sentiment was inclined to be bearish, due largely to the continued favorable crop comments, some indicating a possible upward revision in wheat in the final returns.

LONDON, July 13 -- Lord Vansittart, who has made himself the spokesman of a growing group in Britain who favor harsh terms for Germany, today proposed in the House of Lords that as a prerequisite of an armistice the United Nations demand the surrender of 50,000 members of the Gestapo.

There have been two sources of extra gasoline. The first has been an over-liberal issuance of B and C books; the second has been the black market. Measures have been instituted to combat each of these developments. As a result of a comprehensive review of permitted rations, the number of B and C books has been reduced in the New York area.

LONDON, July 13 -- Details of the destruction by German SS troops of the village of Oradoursur-Glane and the slaughter of all but eight of its 800 inhabitants were disclosed tonight by French headquarters in London. A grimly ironic pendant to this tragedy was the statement of a German official quoted by the Neue Zurcher Zeitung that it was committed "in error."

LONDON, July 13 -- The technique of coal mining as developed in the United States was coupled with nationalization as the most hopeful means of saving the industry here in a House of Commons debate today.

Is an enemy entitled to justice? Put more specifically, shall an enemy accused of crime be judged according to domestic principles of law? In our jurisprudence we say that guilt is personal. We do not execute or imprison the wife and children of the murderer merely because they are related to him.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Friday, July 17 (AP) -- A communique:

The filing of a Federal court action to prevent Westchester County land acquired for a parkway from being turned over to the State for use as a highway called the "New England Thruway" was announced yesterday. The suit, in which Mrs. Genevieve M. Meyer is plaintiff, was filed through the law firm of Rogers Condon in association with William E. Schramek.

Teddy Powell, leader of an orchestra and prominent figure in many a jam session --including the movie of that name--was arrested in Detroit yesterday on charges of having dodged the draft. Powell was picked up by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation as his organization was finishing an engagement and preparing to move on to Colorado.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Friday, July, 14 -- It was Munich again yesterday for the third successive day. Another 1,000 bombers plastered the railroad tracks, very nearly indispensable to the German war effort, and other military objectives in the area of the stricken city.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The War Department has decided to discontinue sending to commanders abroad requests for soldiers overseas to be returned home because of illness in the family or other emergency reasons.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- Joe Baksi of Wilkes-Barre, Pa., and Ike Williams of Trenton, N.J., advanced to the select class among the heavyweights and lightweights, respectively, in new quarterly ratings announced today by the National Boxing Association.

Evidence that the stock market is meeting moderate resistance m its effort to push through the high marks of the current movement was supplied yesterday when the list went through a slight shaking. Prices were not shaded to any considerable extent, however, and an improvement in the final hour permitted some lessening of the inroads.
LONDON, July 13 (AP) -- Note circulation here increased 1,953,000 to the new high record of 1,136,064,000, the Bank of England reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Objections of the War Manpower Commission to the issuance of reconversion orders of Donald M. Nelson, War Production Board chairman, on the same date that the WMC was setting up its controlled hiring program, was responsible for the failure of the production board to issue the orders July 1, Charles E. Wilson, executive vice chairman of the board, said today.
Intimations that American bombers mightier by far than the B-29 Superbombers are "in the works" have just come from Gen. Bennett E. Meyers, head of the Army Air Forces Material Command.

The total of E bond sales in both the city and State surged upward yesterday as the War Finance Committee urged further purchases of individual bond issues to achieve Fifth War Loan quotas before the end of the month.

CHICAGO, July 13 -- Both Mayor Edward J. Kelly of Chicago and Governor Robert S. Kerr of Oklahoma expressed the belief today that there would be a lively contest for the Democratic nomination for Vice President and that the party's national convention, which will convene Wednesday, would not be "a cut and dried" gathering.

ALBANY, July 13 -- A delegation of about 500 persons, under the sponsorship of the Citizens' Non-Partisan Committee for the Servicemen's Vote, held a mass meeting here today, urging acceptance of the Federal ballot by New York State, and a special session of the Legislature to eliminate the requirement of applications by the soldiers before they could receive State ballots.

Mrs. Richardson Pratt gave a luncheon yesterday at the RitzCarlton for Mrs. Eric H. Haight, finance chairman; Mrs. William Malcolm Mather, special lists chairman, and other members of the men's and women's committees who have been working since June 1 on the special gifts project of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service.

In your issue of June 29 you printed an editorial, "Hot and Humid," commenting upon the muggy weather of the day before and adding: "We assume that New York was drowned in mugginess on account of that exasperating pressure group, the Bermuda or Somers Islands.

The Nazi spokesmen are talking now of "Fortress Germania" instead of "Fortress Europa." Berlin announces a major retreat along the whole Baltic front, the Red armies are within a few miles of the borders of East Prussia, and all the Nazi commentators, led by the authoritative voice of Lieut. Gen. Kurt Dittmar, warn their countrymen that the enemy is at the gates.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 13 -- Kay Francis has signed a deal with Jeffrey Bernerd whereby she will be starred in three pictures to be produced by him for Monogram release. She will also serve as associate producer of the stories, the first of which will be "Divorce," a contemporary domestic drama to be filmed in September.

Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican National chairman, devoted most of his time yesterday to planning the financing of the Republican Presidential campaign and coordinating its money raising and spending programs with those of State Republican organizations.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Vice President Wallace knows tonight, according to positive reports here, just what President Roosevelt will say on his behalf for renomination as the President's running mate. And what the Chief Executive will say, the reports add, will be acceptable to Mr. Wallace.

Every once in a while a report of a freak fish or animal that defies identification by experts comes to this desk. The descriptions make entertaining reading, even though this writer sometimes suspects that the creatures originate in somebody's fertile brain.

Public offering of 204,075 shares of $1 par common stock of Sterling Engine Company will be made today at $3.75 a share by a group headed by Burr Co., Inc., and including Dempsey-Detmer Co. and Hirsch, Lilienthal Co. Upon completion of the financing the capitalization of the company will consist of 450,000 common shares.

Dean Mathey of Princeton, N.J., provided the first upset of the Eastern junior tennis championship on the courts of the West Side Club, Forest Hills, by defeating the No. 2 seeded player, Robert Savitt of Bayonne, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2, yesterday. The victory advanced Mathey, seeded No. 5, to the semi-final round against Alan Watson Jr., of Short Hills, rated No. 3, at 2 o'clock this afternoon.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast domestically in Finland and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

CHICAGO, July 13 -- Demand for civilian consumer goods will probably reach $102,000,000,000 in the first year after the war, giving business its first $100,000,000,000 year in this category alone, Sumner H. Slichter, Economics Professor at Harvard University, said today.

Late last February there were five days of clear weather over Europe. On each one of them several hundred United States bombers, manned by several thousand American boys, took off from bases in the British Isles and from Italy, climbed the blue skies to cruising altitude and headed for the nerve centers of the Luftwaffe, the plane factories in Germany and Austria.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 13 -- Don MacNary of Manhasset Bay, L.I., won the midget sailing championship of Long Island Sound by one point as he took second place in the third and final race off the Riverside Yacht Club this afternoon.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 13 -- After three years of German occupation Greece's economic condition is so shattered that in forestry alone it is estimated that it will require twenty-five years to restore the areas cut down by the invaders, according to figures released here today by Greek official sources.
Yesterday's communique as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

PEARL HARBOR, July 13 (AP) -- Cruisers and destroyers of a speedy and powerful fleet shelled Guam Monday and Tuesday, making four consecutive days of naval bombardment of that American sland lost early in the war.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- As a sudden penalty for the unruly conduct of Robert Noble, at the mass sedition trial, Judge Edward C. Eicher, on motion of the Government, decided late today that the case of the California subversive must be severed from that of the other twenty-eight defendants and that Noble would have to be tried separately.

LONDON, July 13 (U.P.) -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and seven other Allied leaders sent a message to the people of France tonight on the eve of the 155th anniversary of the storming of the Bastille, while millions of French patriots prepared to launch a new wave of sabotage that promised to rival the first Bastille Day itself.

LOS ANGELES, July 13 -- Morgan Howard, treasurer of Hearst Publications, Inc., announced today that the tenders of Class A stock of Hearst Consolidated Publications, Inc., for redemption exceeded the 600,000 shares which the company proposed to accept.

Barbara Ann Goggin, 6 months and 20 days old, blonde, blue-eyed daughter of a working couple, was kidnapped from her crib in New York Foundling Hospital, 175 East Sixty-eighth Street, before dawn yesterday.

Consolidated net profit of the Truax-Traer Coal Company for the fiscal year ended with April amounted to $1,133,504 after all charges, including $1,575,000 Federal income and excess profits taxes, the report disclosed yesterday.

LONDON, July 13 (AP) -- The Susan B. Anthony sank in the channel while carrying troops to France without the loss of a soldier. Some fifty or more of the 400 naval personnel aboard still are unreported, but most are believed safe.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- President Roosevelt appointed D. Basil O'Connor, his former law partner and intimate friend, today to be chairman of the American Red Cross.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- President Roosevelt today issued a special statement hailing the French celebration of Bastille Day tomorrow, in which he looked forward "with full confidence" to celebration of the holiday a year hence by a France "liberated" alike from the invader and from the "puppets of Vichy."

In the wake of the club's disastrous trip through the West and on the eve of an invasion of Boston, the Dodgers yesterday lost the services of Pitcher Ed Head. The big right-hander received word from his draft board at Monroe, La., to report for induction into the Army and departed immediately.

SAMARKAND, Uzbekistan, U.S. S.R., July 7 (delayed) -- Here in ancient, glamorous Samarkand it is possible to get the full flavor of the great experiment in industrial, agricultural and cultural uplift being carried out among the peoples of Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan at a pace that has been spurred rather than retarded by the impact of the greatest war in the world's history.

Women white-collar workers have made gains in several directions during the war period, a fact-finding committee yesterday reported to the board of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs in session at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Asserting that the report by the Federation of British Industries on foreign trade makes it apparent that British industry is more in favor of a planned economy than American industry, the National Foreign Trade Council, Inc., declared yesterday that the report's reception here was marked by "disappointment that the FB leans so definitely toward a nationalistic trade policy of the type pursued by Great Britain before the war."

ROME, July 13 (AP) -- American troops have captured the German stronghold of Laiatico, seventeen miles inland from the Italian west coast, in some of the bitterest fighting in weeks and tonight were reported battering their way slowly down the Era Valley toward the Arno River, first great obstacle in front of the enemy's Gothic Line defenses.

JUST before the All-Star game in Pittsburgh there were several nostalgic references in the papers of that city to the fact that Joe Cronin was coming home. Perhaps this was stretching the truth a trifle, because the San Francisco Irishman hardly could call the steel town his native village. But Pittsburgh is proud of him because it was the Pirates who gave him his first big league chance.

LONDON, July 13 -- German broadcasts heard in London tonight said that before the Russian "peril" could penetrate the Reich's borders the Nazis would "turn this Continent into a maelstrom of destruction where only one cry is heard -- the cry of blood."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Friday, July 14 (AP) -- The 45,000 Japanese trying to break out of a British New Guinea trap northwest of Wewak have suffered heavy losses, headquarters announced today.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, American Expeditionary Force, July 13 (U.P.) -- More than 700 German soldiers were killed in a recent battle with Maquis in France, it was disclosed here today by a British colonel who serves as liaison officer between the command of the French forces of the interior and Allied Supreme Headquarters.

ALBANY, July 13 -- Thomas E. Dewey said today that many new functions of government were here to stay. He pledged himself to see that government did not become so big and complicated that it lost touch with the people.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 80:

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Soviet Russia will cooperate with the United States in promoting peace and trade after the war, but will not be a serious competitor in the world export markets "in our lifetime," Eric Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, told reporters today.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Friday, July 14 -- Eleven villages were captured by the American First Army yesterday in its offensive on the western sector of the Normandy front, and the defenses of St. Lo, Periers and Lessay, the three principal objectives of the drive, were being systematically reduced to ruins by heavy American shelling as Lieut. Gen. Omar N. Bradley's advance neared its climax.

The Permane for President Club, already a substantial organization, gained additional strength yesterday at Jamaica when the New Jersey youngster registered one of his best vote-getting triumphs on board The Doge, a brown juvenile colt from the Pentagon Stable, in the Playland Purse to return one of the Empire City meeting's most fetching payoffs.

In an interview, published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of July 9, the former Yugoslav Ambassador, Constantin Fotich, refused to recognize the new Yugoslav Government on the grounds "that it contains no Serbs from Serbia and does not represent the views of the great majority of the people in Yugoslavia."

A crowd of 5,100 at the Fort Hamilton Arena last night saw Tami Mauriello, Bronx heavyweight, score a knockout over Vincent Pimpinella of Red Hook in the feature bout of ten rounds. Pimpinella, outfought by his heavier rival from the start, was unable to continue the battle when the bell sounded for the eighth round.

FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., July 13 -- The Dodgers broke their thirteen-game losing streak tonight, but it won't count in the records. They turned back Fort Monmouth, 4 to 1, by pushing over three runs in the eighth inning.

Listing a balance of $19,069,764 due its principal stockholders in addition to unpaid interest of $439,700, the New York World's Fair of 1940, Inc., applied yesterday in Queens Supreme Court for a final order of dissolution. Its assets, not stated in the petition, are to be distributed among its creditors.

ALBANY, July 13 -- Two hundred and seventy-one cases of infantile paralysis have been reported in the State and in two areas the outbreak has reached epidemic proportions, the State Health Department said today. There are 135 cases up-State and 136 in New York City.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The twenty-six Republican Governors, of whom two are the party's national standard-bearers, by virtue of their offices are the political leaders of their States. They are in daily direct touch with the people and in most instances control the party organization which has the responsibility of bringing out the vote.

The domestic oil industry is considerably interested in the full-dress conference on world oil resources which, according to a joint announcement by the United States and British Governments, will be held soon. This will follow the meeting of several weeks held in Washington in April and May at which technical representatives of both countries were represented.

Banks throughout the country will begin to receive early in August copies of an Office of War Information booklet entitled "Planned Spending and Saving," containing suggested advertisements for local publication which will urge the public to budget its money, it was disclosed yesterday.

While there is sufficient beef in the market this week-end to meet consumer requirements, shoppers may not care for its quality since it is largely utility or C grade. Choice cuts are going to Government agencies, hotels and restaurants, with only a small percentage reaching retail channels, according to the War Food Administration and the New York Council of Wholesale Meat Dealers.

Bastille Day, the chief national holiday of France, marking the storming of the Bastille in 1789 at the beginning of the French Revolution, will be observed here today by the French colony and Franco-American organizations with rallies and exercises.

The Yankees and Red Sox, starting a six-game series with second place at stake, battled each other for four hours at the Stadium yesterday only to finish the day exactly where they had been when they began it.
. and Mrs. Clifford N. Carver[ have come to the Ritz-Carlton from their s,,mmer home in Searsport, Me.

LONDON, Friday, July 14--Russian troops yesterday captured Vilna, capital of Soviet Lithuania, after five days of fierce street battles in which 8,000 Germans were killed, and have smashed closer to East Prussia in a mighty pincer movement aimed on Grodno, northern anchor of the main German defense line in the east.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 13 -- Federal Judge Alexander Akerman has ruled that all of the $24,543,000 in Seaboard Air Line Railway bonds purchased by receivers for the line are secured by a mortgage of Aug. 1, 1925.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 13--Mme. Chiang Kai-shek arrived here by plane late today.

Lawrence M. Phillips, executive vice president of United Service Organizations Campshows. yesterday appealed to concert artists to volunteer for overseas entertainment tours. Mr. Phillips made his plea at a press conference held for Polyna Stoska, soprano; Robert Weede, baritone; Frederick Jagel, tenor, and Alex Zakin, pianist, who, together with Isaac Stern, violinist, have just returned from nine weeks' tour of the South Pacific war theatre.

WINNIPEG, July 13 (Canadian Press) -- The Hudson's Bay Company had a net profit from trading of $607,762 for the year ended Jan. 31, 1944, it was announced today in a statement from the Canadian committee's office here. The net profit in 1943 was $555,509.

Two new films will open in midtown theatres the morning At the Rialto the attraction will be "Jungle Woman," a melodrama produced by Universal. J. Carrol Naish, Acquanetta, who appears in the title role; Samuel S. Hinds, Lois Collier and Douglas Dumbrille are among the featured players.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed an increase of $78,078,000 in holdings of Government securities during the week, while note circulation for the system as a whole decreased $12,914,000. Ratio of reserve for the system declined to 56.2.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -Newspaper publishers in the United States may consume an estimated 781,166 tons of newsprint during the fourth quarter of 1944, the War Production Board's printing and publishing division said today.

We wonder if all the members of the group of organized Sherlock Holmes fans known as the Baker Street Irregulars will agree with a statement put out by one of its officers. The claim is advanced that "it was Frederic Dorr Steele, and not Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, who gave to millions of Americans their conception of Sherlock Holmes."

DETROIT, July 13 (AP) -- The Tigers scored eight runs on seven hits off Orval Grove in the second inning tonight to defeat the White Sox, 9 to 1, in a twilight game before 12,185 spectators. Rudy York hit his ninth homer to start the big inning. Paul Trout pitched a three-hitter for Detroit for his eleventh victory.

CHICAGO, July 13 (AP) -- Frank Colman's second pinch triple of the year against the Cubs helped the Pirates record a 3-to-2 victory in the opener of a five-game series today. It was their fifth straight triumph.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey moved yesterday in Federal court for injunctions to compel return to it and three affiliated concerns of securities and patents turned over under protest to James E. Markham, alien property custodian.

Representative Vito Marcantonio won first place on the Democratic primary ballot in the new Eighteenth Congressional District, Manhattan, and second place on them Republican ballot at a drawing conducted yesterday by the Board of Elections.

PITTSBURGH, July 13 -- Business in the Pittsburgh district last week tumbled to the lowest level reported since the week ended Jan. 1, 1944, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. Sharp declines in production schedules were reflected in all major industries in the district and the volume of originating shipments fell to the lowest levels since last fall. Retail sales were down substantially.

GEORGE BIDDLE of the Philadelphia Biddles, brother of Attorney General Francis Biddle, is one of this nation's foremost artists. From April until December, 1943, he plodded about the Mediterranean front in Tunisia, Sicily and Italy, sharing the soldiers' dangers and discomforts and filling notebooks with sketches.
LONDON, July 13 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

GARDEN CITY, L.I., July 13 -- The lowest medal round ever scored in the Long Island amateur golf championship was achieved today by Jimmy Smith of Hempstead when he went around the Cherry Valley course in 69, three under par.

PEARL HARBOR, July 13 -- Vice Admiral Chuichi Nagumo, the Japanese Navy's Commander in Chief for the Central Pacific area, met his death on Saipan Island during the American invasion, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced tonight. Rear Admiral Yano, whose first name is not immediately available, also lost his life during the island fighting.

FIRST UNITED STATES ARMY HEADQUARTERS, in Normandy, July 13 -- Brig. Gen. Theodore Roosevelt, son of the late President, died suddenly last night at the command post of the division to which he had been attached. In all ways except one he died as he would have wished.

BUENOS AIRES, July 13 -- The departure from Argentina of German diplomatic and consular officials was completed when the Argentine State, a merchant fleet steamer, left Buenos Aires last night for Lisbon carrying 120 persons of German nationality, who will be exchanged for Argentine officials in the Portuguese capital.

It is only an hour's flight by air or an overnight trip by boat from Buenos Aires to Montevideo, but a gulf much wider than that through which flows the Rio de la Plata separates the capitals of Argentina and Uruguay.

ROME, July 13 -- The Catholic church and communism should be 'mutually tolerant," Palmiro Togliatti, Communist leader, said in an interview today at which Mauro Scoccimarro, vice secretary of the Italian Communist party, also was present.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The basis of the expected French-American agreement for administration of liberated areas in France during military operations there was said authoritatively tonight to be as follows:

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The Allies may expect "much closer cooperation" from Turkey, Laurence A. Steinhardt, United States Ambassador to Ankara, said today after he had reported to President Roosevelt on progress of the four-power talks involving Turkey and the United Nations.

CLEVELAND, July 13 (AP) -- The Indians divided a twilight-night double-header with the league-leading Browns before 27,102 fans tonight. St. Louis won the arclight contest, 4 to 1, in the tenth inning after the Tribe had taken the opener, 6 to 5.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES in Normandy, July 13 -- The Germans threw tanks against our lines again today south of Carentan, where they are fighting fiercely to block our slow push southward. But though they seem to be hurling everything they can get into the field against us their armored efforts have dwindled to half-hearted hit and run sorties.

Robert J. Glenn, general manager of the Governor Clinton Hotel, protested yesterday against the removal by the police of a telephone from a room in the establishment, after plainsclothesmen had locked up an alleged bookmaker found in the room.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- About half as many automobiles as were being produced in this country before the war will be authorized for manufacture as soon as Germany falls, and they will go on sale to motorists at prices about 25 per cent above the pre-war levels.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended July 8, 1944, totaled 745,141 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 152,659 cars, or 17 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week; 63,489 cars, or 7.9 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 110,017 cars, or 12.9 per cent, fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Further wage increases at this time while industry is making preparations to resume the manufacture of civilian goods not now produced would seriously hamper the whole program of reconversion, it was declared yesterday by eight members of the Economists Committee on Reconversion Problems.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The State Department has reached an agreement in principle with Spain for the granting of landing rights in that country to American commercial aircraft. Details will be worked out by technicians who have already left for Spain, the State Department said today.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, July 13 (U.P.) -- Chinese troops, slashing at disorganized Japanese units in the rain-drenched Manipur hills have driven the enemy from the entire Maibi Khunou ridge dominating the vital Palel-Tamu supply road, it was announced today.

An old friendship must have played some part in President Roosevelt's choice of his former law partner, Basil O'Connor, to succeed the late Norman Davis as Chairman of the American National Red Cross. But the friendship and the partnership were mostly cemented by good works in a field which eminently qualifies Mr. O'Connor for his new position.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- A 1,200 to 1,500 word platform draft, expressing principles and giving pledges reported to have been approved by President Roosevelt but inviting further condensation for the sake of more brevity, is scheduled for study tomorrow at Chicago by the twenty-three-member resolutions subcommittee appointed here last week by Robert E. Hannegan, Democratic national chairman.

Spring collections of members of the Fashion Originators Guild of America will be shown beginning Oct. 23, it was announced yesterday by Leonard W. Gendler, executive secretary. The lines to be shown will be the sole collections for the season, following a policy that is being successfully pursued for the present fall season, he said.
LONDON, July 13 -- A cheerful tone prevailed throughout today's stock markets here and further support was given to selected industrials and Kaffirs.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- Announced American battle casualties in this war are approaching the total casualties incurred in the World War. Unreported losses in the last three weeks of fighting in France may have put the total past the 1917-1918 mark.

When the Bastille was captured and sacked 155 years ago today it contained only seven prisoners, whose very names were unknown. But it was not seven men who were released on that bloody day, nor, as we look back, was it the mob spirit. The best of what was done survives the violence and horror.

Supreme Court Justice Meier Steinbrink presided yesterday at three sessions on the question of whether City Court Justice Sylvester F. Sabbatino had enough valid signatures to justify his running in the Democratic primary on Aug. 1 as a candidate for Kings County Judge.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 13 -- A move to untangle the legal and practical complexities attending the receivership into which the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus was thrown yesterday was under way today, following the appointment of a committee of three from the Hartford County Bar Association to work out a formula in handling death and injury claims resulting from the fire disaster a week ago.
ROME, July 13 (AP) -- A communique:

In your editorial of July 3, "The Hay Fever Season," you stress the removal of the ragweed plants in the city in order to benefit hay fever sufferers, and you also mention treatment of hay fever by means of injections.

CHUNGKING, China, July 13 (U.P.) -- Chinese forces have occupied the last enemy strong point outside the encircled Japanese bastion of Tengyueh on the Yunnan front, and supporting B-25 Mitchell medium bombers have breached the ancient stone wall surrounding the city, it was announced today.

THE NEW YORK TIMES of July 8 reported the visit of Gen. Charles de Gaulle to Gen. John J. Pershing. During the visit the French leader had time to quote Mohammed. He is reported to have said that the Arabian prophet once observed "that the world without a war would stagnate."

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Published reports that current schedules for the war program will be met are untrue, Robert P. Patterson, Acting Secretary of War stated today. On the contrary, he told his press conference today, actual production for the second quarter of 1944, was $400,000,000 worth of equipment behind the estimates made on April 1, reflecting an 8 per cent lag in the goals set.

A soldier who is wounded in battle or who falls ill is taken without unreasonable delay to a field hospital, where he receives preliminary treatment and his case is diagnosed and classified. Whereupon he is transported to a base hospital for such further surgical or medical attention as he may need.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The German Army has been suffering from an acute manpower shortage for some time, acting Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson said today.

CLEVELAND, July 13 (AP) -- Fighting Scot, a Scotland-sired Hambletonian Stake candidate owned by Joseph F. Burke of Plainfield, N.J., trotted a mile in 2:04 1/4, fastest time by a 3-year-old this year, as he won the first heat of the $2,500 Peninsular Farm Stake at North Randall today, but he was far back when Red Tower nosed out Rapid Hanover in the second and third heats.

The uniform price to dairy farmers supplying milk for the New York metropolitan area broke a twenty-four-year record for June, it was announced yesterday by Dr. C.J. Blanford, administrator of the New York Metropolitan Milk Marketing Area.
CHUNGKING, China, July 13 (AP) -- A communique:

More than 1,000 New York City physicians have been found guilty by their respective medical associations of participating in workmen's compensation kickbacks as unearthed recently by the Moreland Commission investigation conducted by Commissioners William F. Blearkley and Herman T. Stichman, it was disclosed yesterday by Edward Corsi, State Industrial Commissioner.

A further expansion in the loans and investments of the sixteen regularly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City to a new record high of $21,092,000,000 was revealed yesterday. Contained in the figures released by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, and covering the fiscal week ended on Wednesday, these two items showed a jump of $375,000,000.

Magistrate J. Roland Sala, sitting in Brooklyn Felony Court, held four persons in bail yesterday for a series of robberies of bars and grills in Brooklyn. The fifth alleged robber, Frank Beninati, 15 years old, of 1437 Sixty-first Street, Brooklyn, is in a critical condition at Kings County Hospital after being shot by a detective.

The first service banner ever unfurled here for Australia's fighting men was dedicated yesterday at a brief ceremony in the eastern headquarters of the Rheem Manufacturing Company, 570 Lexington Avenue.
KANDY, Ceylon, July 13 (UP) -- A communique:

The right of the Public Service Commission to regulate fares charged by franchised bus lines, regardless of any rate fixed in the franchise contract, as asserted yesterday by Philip Halpern, counsel for the commission.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- A supplemental plan for reorganization of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company has been approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission, the ICC announced today.

The first thing Mussolini did when he gained complete power in Italy, the first thing Hitler did when he took over control in Germany, the first thing the Japanese imperialists did when they stamped out the fragile beginnings of parliamentary government in their own country, was to impose a censorship.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 13 (AP) -- Communique 75:

WASHINGTON, July 13 (U.P.) -The Navy's fabulous Task Force 58 has made history again by destroying 767 Japanese planes and sinking or damaging nearly seventy enemy vessels in a month of sustained combat action in the Pacific, the Navy revealed tonight.

The 100-gallon gasoline inventory coupon, doomed by the Office of Price Administration to extinction after tonight because it lately became the counterfeiters' favorite, brought about the arraignment in Booklyn Federal Court yesterday of a house painter accused for the second time of possession of bogus rationing coupons.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 13 -- The fashionable Low-Heywood School for Girls at Shippan Point here, founded in 1865, has been sold and will be converted into a boys' military school for opening this fall. The new school, to be known as the Eastern Military Academy, will be headed by Roland Reed Robinson, who for eighteen years has been associated with the Peekskill (N.Y.) Military Academy.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- Government sources disclosed today the full list of 124 scarce consumer articles to which has been given tentatively "preferential treatment" under Donald M. Nelson's program for limited civilian production starting Aug. 15.

ST. LOUIS, July 13 -- Warning that "premature termination of shoe rationing would be a boomerang," I.M. Kay, president of the National Association of Popular Price Shoe Retailers, Inc., said today that such a move, "would result in a stoppage of buying by retailers and the public would get fewer shoes.

LONDON, July 13--With a striking absence of "holiday spirit," 525 children departed from a north London railway station this morning for safer areas to the north, bringing to more than 41,000 the number of children of school age evacuated from London.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Seasonally lower prices for apples, oranges and onions and a reaction in wheat and cotton markets brought the Bureau of Labor Statistics' index of commodity prices in primary markets down 0.2 per cent during the first week of July.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Completion of the first stage in organization of the National Citizens Political Action Committee was announced today by Sidney Hillman, chairman of the CIO Political Action Committee, who has also assumed the chairmanship of the new organization.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Pressed by sharply increased military needs for products made of waste paper, Donald M. Nelson, Chairman of the War Production Board, appealed to newspaper publishers today for "still greater efforts" in their campaign for salvaging waste paper.

Getting into the spirit of the two big national political conventions, the New York Dress Institute yesterday afternoon staged in the ballroom of the Astor Hotel a pageant of dresses priced under $50 retail. With considerable humor the nominating session was called the "Chic" (Congress Honoring Inexpensive Clothes) party.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 13 -- Still awaiting a reply from Moscow on the amount of gold it is willing to pay into the proposed $8,500,000,000 international monetary fund, the United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference remained stalled tonight on the big issues of quotas, gold payments, voting power, determination of exchange rates and the length of the transitional post-war period during which wartime exchange controls will be allowed to continue.

The concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night at the Lewisohn Stadium was conducted by Leonard Bernstein, who had not directed previously in the amphitheatre. Nathan Milstein, violin, was the soloist at this event, which drew an audience of 10,500 persons.

LONDON, July 13 -- London had several alerts today and defenses were busy knocking down incoming flying bombs. New bombing techniques have been reported, with some bombs making a circle before crashing. They have been seen gliding in, rather than plunging down, whistling slightly after their engines cut out.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 13 (U.P.) -- Sailing through heavily-mined waters against the attacks of German submarines, motor torpedo boats and airplanes, the American and British Navies have lost fourteen small warships and one transport in the invasion of France -- the greatest and most dangerous operation of the sort ever essayed -- Allied headquarters announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- The Department of Justice said today that the Government's anti-trust and price-fixing suit against four leading chemical manufacturers and seven of their officers had been postponed until after the war.

Testimony supporting the good faith and good effect of the Government's seizure of a shipyard in Bayonne, N.J., from the Marine Maintenance Corporation, and the subsequent appointment of East Coast Shipyards, Inc., to operate it, was received by a Congressional subcommittee in the United States Court House yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Germany's retreating hosts are devising new tricks by which to lure Allied soldiers into booby traps which kill or maim. This was demonstrated today by officers from Fort Benning at the press conference at the Pentagon building of Acting Secretary Patterson.

CHICAGO, July 13 (AP) -- Three investigators at the Mayo Clinic reported today in the Journal of the American Medical Association new experiments from which they concluded that nicotine causes constriction of blood vessels.

Gov. Prentice Cooper of Tennessee, in an interview here yesterday, declared that the South would unite on a Vice Presidential candidate for presentation to the Democratic National convention next week unless President Roosevelt insists upon the naming of his own running-mate.

This is not the time to replace President Roosevelt with an inexperienced stranger, Gov. Prentice Cooper of Tennessee said last night at a rally that opened the sixth biennial State meeting of the Affiliated Young Democrats of New York in the Hotel Piccadilly, 227 West Forty-fifth Street.

ROME, July 13 -- The Bonomi Government, most of whose members have now reached Rome, have agreed to the publication of the Italian armistice terms, it was learned on high Italian authority today. It is now up to the Allies to make the decision whether the terms should be published and when.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- A system of "depreciation prices" which will guide the Government in "a prompt and orderly disposal" of its surplus used machine tools was announced today by the Surplus War Property Administration as the first step in utilizing surplus tools for post-war production.

The Tide Water Associated Oil Company announced yesterday that it had concluded arrangements through Kuhn Loeb Co. and Lehman Brothers for the issuance of $24,500,000 of serial notes maturing from 1945 to 1954 and that the notes had been placed with commercial banking institutions.

CHUNGKING, China, July 13 (AP) -- The Japanese have launched a strong assault on Chinese lines in the bomb-scarred suburbs of Hengyang in an apparent attempt to spark back to life their flagging drive to erase the last 160 miles standing between them and their goal of splitting China in two.
CHUNGKING, China, July 13 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

CHICAGO, July 14 -- Although friends of Vice President Henry A. Wallace have not abandoned support of his candidacy in advance of the Democratic National Convention, those here took a rather gloomy view today of his chances of renomination.

The fortieth anniversary of the death of Anton Chekhov is being widely observed today in the Soviet Union, with many theatres presenting his plays. Chekhov died one year before the Russian revolution of 1905. He had never ceased to affirm the grandeur of his country and its promise, at the same time rejecting as tragic the era in which he lived.

More than 2,000 summonses were issued yesterday by agents of the Third United States Internal Revenue District to motorists who had overlooked purchasing the $5 Federal "use" stamp that was to have been pasted on automobile windshields on July 1.

Resolutions acclaiming President Roosevelt's decision to accept the Democratic nomination for another term, urging the renomination of Vice President Henry A. Wallace and pledging full support to Senator Robert F. Wagner of New York for re-election were adopted yesterday at the sixth biennial state-wide meeting of the Affiliated Young Democrats at the Hotel Piccadilly.

The Republican National Committee has about $125,000 on hand to finance the opening phases of its campaign to elect Governor Dewey as President and Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio as Vice President, Herbert Brownell Jr., national chairman, reported yesterday after conferences with James S. Kemper, chairman of the finance committee, and other finance officers. Earlier it had been estimated that funds on hand were $200,000.

A charge that attempts had been made to demoralize the operation of a Bayonne shipyard seized by the Government from the Marine Maintenance Corporation and turned over to East Coast Shipyards, Inc., was made yesterday by John E. Otterson, president of East Coast, before a Congressional subcommittee sitting in the United States Court House.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Lieut. Gen. Ben Lear has been assigned to command the Army Ground Forces, succeeding Lieut. Gen. Lesley J. McNair. The latter, who was wounded in Tunisia in April, 1943, and was succeeded temporarily by General Lear as acting commander, has received "an important assignment overseas."
Judging from Harry M. Konwiser's note printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES of July 6 there seems to be a great deal of ignorance about the metric system.

The Office of Price Administration brought suit yesterday for $300,000 in treble damages against a men's underwear manufacturing company that it accused of keeping up its prices on shorts, although wearers were having increasing difficulty in keeping up the garments because of deteriorated quality and workmanship.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -The newspaper industry advisory committee has recommended strict enforcement of newsprint rationing "including criminal prosecution for wilful violations," the War Production Board reported today.

Cooperation between Catholics and Communists in Italy has led to misunderstanding both as to its nature and implications, particularly in the United States. No party in Italy has forsaken its basic principles, but all have put aside questions not of urgent importance, with the single aim of helping the rebirth of the nation and participating with the Allies in the war effort.
ALBANY, July 14 -- The State Health Department is working on a plan to develop a program to make whole blood, blood plasma and other derivatives available for civilians throughout the State.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- President Roosevelt has selected Robert H. Hinckley, former Assistant Secretary of Commerce, to be Director of Contract Settlement, subject to confirmation by the Senate when Congress reconvenes.
LONDON, July 14 -- The stock markets today showed their usual week-end signs and business was quieter than it had been.

PHILADELPHIA, July 14 -- A registration statement covering 280,138 shares of $2.50 par value common stock was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Brill Corporation in the name of the ACF-Brill Motors Company, which is to be the name: of the registrant after the pending merger of the Brill concern with the American Car and Foundry Motors Company.

Life for the OPA enforcement squads would be one glad, sweet song if soda stands and hot-dog counters in Coney Island were like the New York subway system. All over Coney Island two-thirds of the soda dispensers charge 10 cents a bottle, instead of the prescribed nickel.

Interest continued to be displayed in Wall Street yesterday over the circumstances of the letter addressed early this week by Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, to member firms, cautioning them against the presence of "hot money" that may or may not have been used to purchase securities.

Those who have the best interests of real estate at heart must check commercial rent-gouging in this city quickly if they hope to avoid not only State rent control, and all its inconveniences, but complete loss of tenant cooperation in any activity that affects their future interests.

The Underwood-Elliott-Fisher Company reported yesterday in an operating statement for the first half of this year net profit of $956,0S0, equal to $1.30 a share, against $861,354, or $1.17 a share, for the corresponding six months of last year.

Charles Oliver of Perth Amboy and Alan Watson of Short Hills, seeded No. 1 and 3 respectively, reached the final round of the Eastern junior tennis championship at the West Side Club, Forest Hills, yesterday.

LONDON, Saturday, July 15 -- Soviet tanks and infantry, aided by river gunboats, yesterday captured the Nazi supply base of Pinsk in the heart of the Pripet Marshes, and also advanced to within six and a half miles of Grodno, cornerstone of Nazi defenses before East Prussia, in a series of sweeping victories over the retreating German Army.

Net asset value of the American Cities Power and Light Corporation, an investment company, on June 30 were reported yesterday as $22,029,615. This, it was explained, was equal, after $2,800,000 bank borrowings and provision for Class A preferred stocks, to $2.91 a share for 2,901,940 Class B common shares, comparing with $15,651,357, or $1.63 a Class B share after allowing for $2,940,000 bank loans, on Dec. 31, 1943.

"Minstrel Man," a musical featuring both old and new tunes and with Benny Fields and Gladys George in the leads, opens at the Victoria this morning. Alan Dinehart and Roscoe Karns have supporting roles. This will mark the first picture for Benny Fields who, for the last twenty-five years, has been well known to Broadway's musical comedy and vaudeville stages and as a radio personality.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 14 (AP) -- First-seeded Jack McManis of Forest Hills, L.I., defeated Thomas Burke, also of Forest Hills, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4, in a men's singles semi-final today in the Eastern Clay Court Tennis championships at the Montclair Athletic Club.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The National War Labor Board told the American Federation of Labor today that the Congress of Industrial Organizations had "repudiated and violated" a "no-raiding" pledge made to the board and to the AFL in the plants of the International Harvester Company.
