WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Maximum prices to be established soon for bulk neutral spirits and bulk whisky produced during the "alcoholic holiday" in August were announced today by the Office of Price Administration.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 14 -- Soviet Russia has tentatively agreed to utilize a foreign ruble for the first time in its history to facilitate foreign trade, a spokesman for the monetary conference said today.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (Delayed) (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 81:

CHUNGKING, China, July 14 (AP) -- Japanese troops have again encicled Hengyang, and enemy forces are advancing from the south toward a junction at the pivotal Hunan Province city, which, would cut China in two, the Chinese Command announced tonight.

"99 Park," headquarters of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, Inc., offers a partial list of free amusements available today, through the generosity of the entertainment world. Afternoon tickets from 11 A.M.; evening tickets after 4, P.M. Apply 99 Park Avenue (at Fortieth Street) for tickets.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Saturday, July 15 (AP) -- Japanese forces, struggling to break two compressed Allied traps in New Guinea, are reorganizing for a new offensive in one area and are crawling through hazardous jungles in the second, Headquarters announced today.

RICHMOND, Va., July 14 -Patents on a method of recovering magnesium by using supersonic waves, a way to make black glass, and a process of improving thread made from vinyl resins are among the 507 listed in the current issue of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

LONDON, July 14 -- To arrest any false sense of security that four successive bombless nights might have encouraged, Herbert Morrison, Minister of Home Security, declared today, "We may have to put up with quite a bit yet."
LONDON, July 17 -- Confidence that this will be the last July 14 on which German soldiers will stand on French soil sounded through celebrations of Bastille Day in Britain today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, July 14 -- Allied aircraft and light naval patrols striking from the Solomons to the Netherlands Indies -- a front of more than a thousand miles -- are now sinking, destroying or heavily damaging Japanese ships at a rate of better than ten a day, figures released today from Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters revealed.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Constantin Fotitch, who has been the diplomatic representative of Yugoslavia here since Oct. 29, 1935, vacated the embassy at 12:15 o'clock this afternoon and informed Secretary of State Cordell Hull in person that he had relinquished the post of Ambassador.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 14 -Describing the small business man as "the backbone of the West" despite the creation here of "gargantuan war babies," Maury Maverick chairman of the Smaller War Plants Corporation, suggested six points today as "the basis for small business to help in winning the war and to strengthen free enterprise."

ALBANY, July 14--Before leaving for a week-end at his Pawling farm Gov. Thomas E. Dewey conferred today with Representative Charles A. Halleck of Indiana, chairman of the Republican Congressional Committee. Mr. Halleck told reporters later that he had assured the Presidential nominee of a Republican House after November.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Government's program for an early start in the reconversion of the automobile industry to civilian production suffered a setback today when nine leading concerns protested that they were too deeply engaged in war work to permit them to make any preparations now for the manufacture of passenger cars at a future date.

ROME, July 14 (U.P.) -- The Germans had defended Poggibonsi, key to the Elsa Valley, strongly. French forces first had advanced south of Poggibonsi from the direction of Siena. Yesterday, they captured San Gimignano, five miles west, and pushed on to within three miles of a German escape road running northwest, and threatened to turn the German right flank completely.

NEWARK, N.J., July 14 -- A glib confidence man today persuaded 17-year-old Leo Schiner, a messenger boy for the United Jewish Appeal of Essex County, to turn over an $804 payroll by promising to help get him into college.

TASHKENT, Uzbekistan, U.S.S.R., July 9 (Delayed) -- For the first time foreign correspondents have been able to see and hear the details of the world's greatest industrial migration -- the swift movement of men and machines from German-occupied or threatened industrial sections of the Soviet Union to the refuge of the Urals, Siberia and central Asia.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Office of Price Administration brought most articles of used and reconditioned plumbing and heating equipment under new price ceilings today by establishing dollars-and-cents prices for sixty-five items and maximums determined by a discount formula for most of the others.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 14 -- United States bomber formations are using daylight "pathfinder" planes to guide them to German targets shrouded by clouds or artificial smoke screens, it was disclosed today.

CHUNGKING, China, July 14 (AP) -- Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, China's First Lady whose arrival in Rio de Janeiro for a rest cure was announced here today, was pale and listless, friends said, when she departed Sunday in the utmost secrecy.

WITH THE CANADIAN FORCES IN NORMANDY, July 14 (Reuter) -- French people came from all the villages northwest of Caen today to join with French Canadian troops in a Bastille Day ceremony held in the heart of a wrecked village.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Saturday, July 15 -- Infantry and tanks of Lieut. Gen. Omar N. Bradley's American First Army, advancing on a crescent-shaped front fortyeight miles long, punched out gains of 1,000 yards to a mile and a half yesterday and captured nine villages in face of stout resistance from troops drawn from elements of eleven German divisions.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 14 -- The Vichy radio tonight announced that Georges Mandel, hitherto believed detained in Germany, was killed this morning "while French authorities were transferring him to a new place of imprisonment."

The American Power and Light Company, one of the largest sub-holding units in the Electric Bond and Share Company system, applied yesterday to the Securities and Exchange Commission for permission to retire at face value and accrued interest $37,853,900 of debentures, or the total amount of the company's outstanding indebtedness.

Schelke, displayed a sample of his ability when he was the easiest sort of winner of the Meadow View Purse, an allowance race at one mile that was best on the card at Garden State Park today.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- An expansion of the authority of the Office of Price Administration to permit that agency to exert the same control over rents on commercial properties as it does over dwellings, was urged upon Congress today by spokesmen for the City of New York and for small business interests there, including manufacturers in the city's garment area.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull today indicated that no single act by the Government of Argentina seeking a rapprochement with the United States would solve the diplomatically delicate situation between the two Governments.

Women of the United States and Great Britain have advanced both politically and economically during the war years, but are still far from their goal of equal opportunity, speakers at the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs declared last night, while urging them to fight for full recognition.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- A joint committee of medical leaders and physical fitness experts laid plans today for long-time health improvement of the American people and called for "statesmanship" on the part of organized groups in helping the individual attain physical fitness.

PEARL HARBOR, July 14 -Carrier attacks went in the tenth straight day yesterday when planes of a fast task group again streamed over the island, dropping bombs, and with heavy rocket fire set buildings and ammunition dumps ablaze.
A letter to THE TIMES asks that foreigners who want to do business with us, yield their "older" metric system in favor of the simple American system of measurement.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers (AFL) has established and endowed a national electronics school by arrangement with the Engineering College of Marquette University.

Frank Crosetti, star shortstop of the Yankees who had been working in a Stockton (Calif.) shipyard this year, notified President Ed Barrow yesterday that he expected to rejoin the club next Tuesday in St. Louis.

CHICAGO, July 14 (AP) -- Pittsburgh got four homers to the Cubs' one today, but the Chicagoans pieced together twelve other hits, seven walks, a double steal and sundry other ingredients to end the Pirates' five-game winning streak, 11 to 5.

CHERBOURG, July 14 -- With American guns firing a salute and the United States flag draped over the city's war memorial, Cherbourg led the liberated portion of France today in the first free celebration of Bastille Day in five years. A battery of twelve 105-mm guns, similar to those that helped drive the Germans from the peninsula, roared out over the city at 8 A.M. (2 A.M. Eastern war time) to open the day's ceremonies.

DETROIT, July 14 (AP) -- Southpaw Frank Overmire stopped the White Sox with two scratch singles today as the Tigers won, 2 to 0, for a 2-0 edge in the six-game series. Detroit touched Bill Dietrich for six hits, including Dick Wakefield's second-inning homer.

CHICAGO, July 14 (AP) -- Joseph J. Jablonski, an escaped convict went back to the Joliet, Ill., penitentiary today to resume a life sentence for murder after eleven years of freedom during which police said he had "gone straight." Police Capt. Louis Capparelli said that Jablonski's wife, Carmell, disclosed her husband's secret that he fled the penitentiary prison farm in 1933.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -Russ Christopher turned Washington back for a 4-3 victory in the second game as Philadelphia took both ends of a double-header with the Senators tonight before 12,231 fans. The Athletics took the twilight contest 4 to 3.

DETROIT, July 14 (AP) -- Lee Oma, returning to his home town from a successful campaign in the east, gained a ten-round decision tonight over Lou Nova of Van Nuys, Calif. There were no knockdowns. Nova weighed 207 for a 22-pound edge.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 14 -The first Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer picture for Clark Gable, following his discharge from the Army, will be "Strange Adventure," a film to be based on the Clyde Brion Davis' novel "The Anointed." Myrna Loy has been named for the feminine lead.

German Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels declares in this week's issue of the German magazine Reich that Germany and her enemies both "want peace and calm," according to a summary broadcast by the Berlin radio.
CLEVELAND, July 14 (AP) -Steve Gromek, Indians' freshman pitcher, won his own game from the Browns today, when he smashed a fourteenth-inning single to score Ray Mack for a 3-to-2 decision.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- In compliance with legislation passed just before Congress adjourned directing the Secretaries of War and the Navy to investigate the facts regarding the Pearl Harbor attack of Dec. 7, 1941, Secretary Forrestal and Acting Secretary Patterson have named members of their departments who will participate.

The Rev. Dr. Adam W. Burnet, minister of St. Cuthbert's Church, Edinburgh, Scotland, who arrived by plane last week on a five weeks' preaching mission, will deliver the sermon tomorrow at Yale University, New Haven, Conn. ROME, July 14--German resistance to the advancing Americans on the Fifth Army front has suddenly withdrawn, front-line dispatches reported tonight, with the doughboys making gains up to five miles along most of the line in a bid to enter the big port of Leghorn possibly this week-end.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -Department stores sales for the week ended July 7 were 2 per cent above sales in the corresponding period of last year despite the fact that many stores were closed for two days over the Independence Day holiday in contrast to a one-day holiday last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

LONDON, Saturday, July 15 (AP) -With the evacuation of LonderL greater even than during the 1940!41 blitz, a serious situation developed today in finding refuge from robot bombs for women and children.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEAD QUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, July 14 (U2) -- Allied troops, driving down the Mogaung-Mandalay railroad, which bisects Burma, have captured a railway station seven miles south of Mogaung in northern Burma, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The mass killing of Jews in Hungary was condemned by Secretary of State Cordell Hull today for the second time in recent days in view of reports that the entire Jewish community in the country, numbering nearly a million, is now threatened with extermination.

Barbara Ann Goggin, 6 months old, stolen before dawn Thursday from her crib in New York Foundling Hospital, was found at noon yesterday in a three-room flat at 201 West Ninety-fifth Street, unharmed except for a slight cold.

HEADQUARTERS CHINESE EXPEDITIONARY FORCE, July 13 (Delayed) -- Everything at Tengyueh indicates a fight to the finish. Within the besieged walls of the city on the ancient caravan route from Burma 2,000 Japanese are prepared to stay a long time.

They attacked the Ferenczvaros railway yards at Budapest as well as four oil refineries near the Hungarian capital.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Henry H. Klein, a New York lawyer, who left the defense of Eugene Sanctuary in the sedition trial ten days ago, was ordered today to appear next Friday and show cause why he should not be cited in contempt of court.

LONDON, July 14 -- The British Government is considering what controls it will be necessary to retain after Germany is defeated that Prime Minister Churchill's pledge to fight the war against Japan with as much vigor as that in Europe can be honored to the full, it was explained in the House of Commons today by Herbert Morrison, Home Secretary.

Gentle zephyrs coming in from the ocean have brought a welcome let-up in the ten-day heat wave and the Weather Bureau forecasts a fairly comfortable temperature for the week-end and possible showers Sunday morning.

PHILADELPHIA, July 14 -- The charm that Harry Feldman wields over enemy hitters under the Mazda lamps was maintained at Shibe Park tonight as the Giants' right-hander turned back the Phillies before 11,137 fans, 2 to 1.

The City of Syracuse, N.Y., yesterday awarded $1,500,000 of certificates of indebtedness to Barr Brothers Co., Inc., and the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company at an interest rate of 0.40 per cent. The certificates, to be used for tax anticipation purposes, are dated July 17, 1944, and fall due on April 17, 1945.

Maintenance of cigarette production to take care of rising exports to the armed services abroad and expanded civilian demand will hinge to considerable extent on an anticipated favorable tobacco crop this year, trade sources here reported yesterday.

Day after day while out fishing for tuna Capt. Crawford Savage has been sighting marlin off Ocean City, Md. They have been so plentiful that he thinks there are as many now as in 1936, before heavy fishing at the shoals diminished them.

CHICAGO, July 14 -- Prices of wheat held within very narrow limits today on the Board of Trade. They are so close to the Government loan basis in southwestern markets that speculators are not inclined to take the selling side. A little buying by cash interests was in evidence at times and was accompanied by reports that Eastern chain bakers were in the market for flour and that Mexico was inquiring for 200,000 sacks.
Three indictments alleging fraudulent financial operations said to have cost the victims at least $200,000 were handed up yesterday in Federal court.

Although admitting no immediate shortage of milk to consumers in the metropolitan area over the week-end, Dr. Charles J. Blanford, Administrator of the New York Milk Marketing Area, warned dairy cooperatives of the six-State milkshed yesterday to send their quotas of fluid milk to the New York market in conformity with the existing New York State-Federal Marketing Order.

Retail trade continued active here last week, with buying for the most part following a normal seasonal pattern. Department store volume was estimated as about 10 per cent above the like week of 1943. Shoe department sales were given a fillip by the release of some types of women's shoes from rationing.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- This country's wartime oil production requirements for 1944, as estimated by the Petroleum Administration for War, will be met as the result of a vigorous new drilling campaign, J. Edgar Heston, assistant PAW production director, asserted today.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 14 -Under the terms of an order signed tonight by Superior Court Judge John H. King, the Ringling Brothers and Barnum and Bailey circus will be permitted to leave town tomorrow, nine days after the disastrous fire which to date has caused 162 deaths with another twenty-three persons still in critical condition in local hospitals.

A Nazi-controlled radio has affirmed and then denied the death of Edouard Herriot. He is now said to be "in excellent health," but his whereabouts is not disclosed. All that is known of him is that he remains in "German custody."

Investors this week were offered the largest amount of new bonds in a month, as bankers resumed their regular business following a month devoted almost exclusively to the war loan drive just ended. Nine new issues of bonds aggregating $30,681,000 were offered to the public -- $13,421,000 in five municipal loans, $12,000,000 in two industrial flotations and $5,260,000 in two railroad offerings.

In an effort to gather audience data on television programs from the beginning of the post-war expansion expected, the Cooperative Analysis of Broadcasting, Inc., announced yesterday a new list of eighty-one cities in which such expansion is expected and in which the organization will conduct interviews.

Leonard Bernstein took the dual role of conductor and piano soloist with the philharmonic-Symphony at the Lewisohn Stadium last night. A crowd of 6,500 was on hand to hear the young composer-conductor-pianist play the solo part in the Ravel Concerto and conduct Tchaikovsky's "Romeo and Juliet" and Fourth Symphony.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The Navy has reached its desired strength of 3,650,000, bringing the combined strength of the armed forces up to its scheduled peak of 11,350,000 and putting further induction calls on a replacement basis.

Retail trade was brisk last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Main floors were active with handbags, jewelry and notions in the spotlight.

A BRISK workaday style and a village setting (both reminiscent of Mabel Seeley's mysteries) make this a homey sort of murder story -- and a good one. Three middle-aged Harris sisters and a young nephew live on a small cove at Ogg Lake. Of the five cove cottages, one is occupied by Max and Mommie, their three little girls and Grampie.

ALBANY, July 15 -- Governor Dewey, who insists New York's soldier vote law is "simple and workable," permitted the deadline to pass today without taking the executive action necessary to permit use of the Federal ballot by members of the armed forces from this State.

LONDON, July 15 -By this week-end as many as 200,000 persons will have left London. That is more than left their homes in London at the outbreak of the war, and even more than fled from London in the second evacuation after the bombs started falling in September, 1940, when 170,000 sought sanctuary in the country.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- It was at least partly as a result of the visit to Washington by Gen. Charles de Gaulle that President Roosevelt indicated this week that a solution was in sight for the problem of assuring the presence in liberated France of satisfactory civil officials to whom the Allied Commander in Chief might hand over the authority of local government.
CHUNGKING, China, July 15 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

In three sectors last week the Allied ring of steel and flame moved closer to Hitler's inner fortress. In the west the Americans surged ahead all along their half of their front in Normandy and the British appeared to be preparing for a decisive battle around Caen. In the east the Russians, sweeping ahead, were within fifty miles of East Prussia.

Some type of federation system that would unite the five Central American nations for their mutual benefit was recommended last night by Dr. Arturo Romero, civilian co-leader of the April 2 revolt in El Salvador.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 15 -- Post-war construction of a transcontinental chain of super-highways and airports, estimated to provide employment for 2,000,000 persons, at a cost of about $10,000,000,000, was proposed here today by Maury Maverick, chairman of the Smaller War Plants Corporation, and endorsed by the executive committee of the Builders of the West, Inc., an organization dedicated to the development of this part of the country.

CHICAGO, July 15 -- Members of the meat industry here are preparing intensively to handle what is expected to be a record influx of range grade beef that will begin late in August and probably reach its peak in late September and early October.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet press release 475:

DETROIT, July 15 (AP) -- Navy dischargee Dick Wakefield belted his second homer in two days and got three other hits before 9,315 spectators today as the Tigers divided a double-header with the White Sox, winning the nightcap, 8 to 2, after dropping the opener, 5 to 4.

BOYDEN SPARKES, North Carolina squire and biographer of industrial men and organizations, bought three lamb carcasses, put them in his "farm freezer," and found a new shortcut to the better life. That was a little over two years ago.

SQUASH with their broad, heavy leaves and eagerly running stems are one of the most vigorously growing plants in the entire vegetable garden. So it is with a distinct sense of shock that some morning we find a single runner or the whole plant has suddenly wilted.

A survey conducted by the Central Office News Letter reveals that more colleges will play football in the coming season than did in 1943. The authority for this revelation, the Central Office News Letter, is a publication dedicated to the future of intercollegiate athletics in a nation at war, and is released by the Central Office for Eastern Intercollegiate Athletics.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- Two Americans, with a bluff backed up by nothing more than penknives, foiled an attempt to loot a torpedo-shattered freighter off the North African coast recently, the War Shipping Administration reported today.

Some years ago the National Hospital for Speech Disorders announced the opening of a free clinic for patients whose larynxes had to be removed because of cancer. Since then almost one hundred men and women have registered in the clinic and have been trained in the technique of developing a substitute (esophageal) voice.

THE hero of this biblical novel in the wake of "The Robe" is a skeptical Roman noble, Sergius Cumanus, sent out on a medical mission to make a survey of the disease-ridden provinces of Palestine. He meets with Jesus Christ, and the main theme of the narrative is his conversion from a rationalistic cynic into a believer in the miraculous.

AT 1,100 hours one morning not long ago I was a harassed but fairly irresponsible enlisted man; at 1,101 hours I had completed the tortuous wrigglings of changing my skin and was an upstanding, clear-headed Leader of Men. At least that's the way the formula read, and I should have felt like a Leader of Men, but I didn't; I felt strange, bewildered and half-done.

Bidders paid the unprecedented amount of $6,156,632 for art and literary property during last season at auction sales at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., 30 East Fifty-seventh Street. This is the highest total ever realized in a single season by these galleries or by predecessors occupying the premises.

The Smith College School for Social Work is offering four seminars on rehabilitation and its attendent problems to experienced social workers from July 24 through Aug. 5. The seminars are open to executives, supervisors and experienced case workers, both men and women, in public and private agencies.

BOSTON, July 15 -- No more surprised than the rest of the country by President Roosevelt's decision to run for a fourth term. New Englanders nevertheless regarded his announcement as the big news of the week, overshadowing a sound rebuke delivered by labor to the CIO Political Action Committee which sought to dictate the choice of State primary candidates.

DESPITE the rigid ban on new radio station construction until the present war emergency has passed, applications for transmitters are being filed with the Federal Communications Commission at Washington in unprecedented numbers, it is learned.

IT is obvious that the movie-going public -- or a considerable segment thereof -- is not thoroughly in agreement with the proverb that "he who steals my purse steals trash." For the innocent publication in this section a few weeks ago of a report on the trade press' anxiety over wartime kitings of box-office scales has brought forth a flood of correspondence expressing public accord with that complaint.

A MIDSEASON survey of Ontario resorts recently made by the Ontario Travel Bureau reveals that Americans now vacationing in that Province are spending their holidays in one place, much as they did before there was an automobile in every garage.

CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- Charlie Grimm's Cubs with Charlie himself a mere spectator during the late innings, leap-frogged over Brooklyn into sixth place today, their highest position since the opening week of the season, by defeating Pittsburgh, 4 to 3, on a 13-hit attack and Paul Derringer's effective relief pitching.

Behind a heavy barrage of three home runs -- two by Herschel Martin, the other by Bud Metheny -- the Yankees widened their beachhead in the battle for second place at the Stadium yesterday by battering Joe Cronin's Red Sox into submission in the fourth game of the current series, 9 to 7.

OMAHA, Neb., July 15 -- Men, women and children are working long hours in this area to bring their share of a record wheat crop, recently estimated by the Department of Agriculture for the year at 1,128,000,000 bushels. The animating thought is that every bushel must be saved.

THANKS to the energies of boys and girls, newly planted fruit trees are flourishing on Florida farms; a drab little school in British Columbia is bright with new paint and gay with flowers; war has been waged on insect pests in New Hampshire.

Education in the years ahead must become more concerned with the training of youth for citizenship and social living and not merely place its emphasis on preparing students for vocations, according to a recent report prepared by a special committee of the National Association of State Universities to Study Post-War Educational Problems.

" LITTLE COQUETTE, the Story of a French Girlhood," is written by a French-woman, Renee de Fontarce McCormick. The title suggests a chromo of the "Good Morning, Papa!" "Cherry Ripe" series, but this picture of French life between 1899 and 1914 is anything but smug.
The following is a letter published recently in Yank Magazine:

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Caught in the combined pressures of improved enforcement methods and an aroused public opinion, gasoline black-market racketeers have begun to give ground. The withdrawal to date, say officials of the Office of Price Administration, has been slight, but the pace is accelerating and, barring unforeseen developments, should assume the appearance of a rout by the end of the year.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- German generals, faced with defeats on every front and unable to meet the demands of Nazi party leaders, are suffering an "epidemic" of heart failure and apoplexy, an overseas broadcast of the Office of War Information said today.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 15 -- The cloud-filled skies over France gave the German armies in Normandy more protection today and, if the legend of St. Swithin holds true, the Allies' airmen can expect forty more days of the same.

SOMEWHERE IN ITALY, July 15 -The Allied entry into Rome followed immediately by the successful invasion of Normandy and later by the tremendous Russian advance has inevitably brought up reports of peace possibilities and that situation in turn has put the State of Vatican City back on the map as a neutral power which could be used as a channel for negotiations.

CONTRACTS have already been signed for the translating of Sumner Welles' "The Time for Decision" into five foreign languages. . . . The John Day Company's fall catalogue reads almost as though it had gone to press in Chungking: twelve of the eighteen books listed are about the Orient.

DETROIT, July 15 (U.P.) -- Production of B-24 Liberator bombers at the Ford Motor Company's Willow Run bomber plant was halted today by a walkout of 200 crane operators and riggers, who are members of the United Automobile Workers, CIO. The strike caused the shutdown of the plant and made 18,000-workers idle.

CAROL, darling of the stage-struck junior misses who have breathlessly followed her ventures in dramatic school and straw-hat theatre, now tackles Broadway. Like a good many other girls, she is limited both as to time and money.

THE title of this book is the motto which appears on the coat of arms of the 513th Bombardment Squadron, the outfit to which Captain Rowan's Flying Fortress was attached during and after the Tunisian campaign, previous to that time it had been one of an "Orphan Squadron," so called because it was constantly being shifted from one command to another.

LONDON, July 15 -- The first mobile emergency American information center -- one of several designed to fill the gaps in intellectual and cultural sources in Europe caused by years of enemy occupation -- will have a working demonstration by the Office of War Information at the Manchester central library from July 18 to Aug. 1.

I HAVE just seen "The Searching Wind" and would like to put my oar into the discussion of the value of the second plot. Mr. Nichols says that "in dealing with the state of the heart," Miss Hellman is less successful than "in dealing with the state of the world."

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The Senators capitalized on Dutch Leonard's five-hit hurling and four errors by Philadelphia's shortstop, Edgar Busch, to whip the Athletics, 5 to 2, tonight before 10,256 fans. The A's got three blows in the first inning to chalk up their only runs.

SOMEWHERE IN ENGLAND. THE town where I live, like many other towns in England, has been invaded by Americans. On buses and trains you hear as many American voices as British. At the street corners, in the cinemas and pubs -- everywhere there are American uniforms, and on the roads there are American jeeps and lorries.

For some time after World War I there was evident an aversion on the part of Congress to relieve taxpayers of the burden of war taxation. Although rates of the excess-profits tax were reduced for 1919 and again for 1921, this form of taxation was not discontinued until the close of 1921 and the individual surtax remained at the peak of war rates through 1921 -- more than three years after the armistice.

Sales of all categories of bonds in the Fifth War Loan drive in New York City amounted to $5,000,354,388, a quota attainment of 120 per cent, Nevil Ford, State chairman of the War Finance Committee, announced yesterday.

At the recent commencement exercises of Brown University Nathaniel Davis of the Class of 1945 stated in an oration the ideals for which he believes Americans are lighting in the war. The following article is based on his oration:

Designed to stimulate and advance public thinking on significant problems dealing with post-war education, a new eight-week series of radio broadcasts, titled "Pursuit of Learning," will start on Sunday, Aug. 13, under the auspices of the United States Office of Education, the National Education Association and the American Vocational Association.

Groups of survivors of the expedition into north Burma led by the late Maj. Gen. Orde Charles Wingate more than a year ago are being rescued by British air-borne Chindits fighting their way through the jungles of north Burma, the British radio said yesterday, according to the Columbia Broadcasting System.

NEW ORLEANS, July 15 -- Despite opposition to the New Deal and a fourth term for President Roosevelt, political leaders in this part of the South now realize that his nomination in Chicago is assured. With this settled, they are turning their energies toward defeating Henry A. Wallace for the Vice Presidential nomination.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 15 -- A two-engined Army plane, plunging to earth during a violent storm last night, carried to instant death Maj. Gen. Paul W. Newgarden, commander of the Tenth Armored Division, and five other Army men, including two colonels.
CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows:

" EAST OF MALTA, WEST OF SUEZ" is the official Admiralty account of the British Fleet from 1939 to 1943. The publishers bill it as "the dramatic inside story of the winning of naval control of the Mediterranean."
LONDON, July 15 (Reuter) -- The Times discussing the Democratic convention in an editorial says:

IT was some eighteen years ago -- at tea in an English laboratory -- that I first heard the idea advanced that in the next war the Germans would probably drop bombs loaded with deadly bacteria upon the civil populations of their enemies.

Inexorably and with growing momentum the tide of Allied power continues to rise to its flood, destroying the foundations of German might and shaking the whole Nazi structure which Hitler built on it. In the east, where the Russian armies are smashing all German resistance in blitzkrieg fashion, this tide is already beginning to lap at the borders of the Reich itself, and threatens to spill over them soon onto German soil.
LONDON, July 15 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 15 -- Although a few of the toughest problems of this United Nations monetary and financial conference remain to be settled as this is written, with only a few days to go before the conference deadline on Wednesday, confidence is expressed on all sides that the representatives of the forty-four nations gathered here will achieve their goal of building an important milestone on the road to international security.
ROME, July 15 (UP) -- A communique:

A Japanese broadcast directed to United States forces in the Pacific announces the highest pitch of barbarism and the lowest depth of degradation reached by any nation in the war. It informs us that several American aviators captured last month in the first Superfortress attack on Yawata in Kyushu have been executed and that all our fliers hereafter seized in Japan will be similarly executed.

BOSTON, July 15 (AP) -- The Cain Hoy Stable's Good Morning, excellently ridden by Jockey Don Meade, scored a handy two and a half length victory in the $10,000 added Hannah Dustin Handicap, mile and a sixteenth for fillies and mares, at Suffolk Downs today before 23,940 patrons.

Revision of a recent directive concerning overtime pay for National Maritime Union seamen has been proposed to the National War Labor Board by the American Merchant Marine Institute in behalf of twenty-three Atlantic and Gulf Coast steamship companies, Frank J. Taylor, president of the institute, made known here yesterday.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 15 -- In its sixty years as a training reservation for State troops, Camp Smith here, originally known as State Camp, has never before housed as many guardsmen at one time nor, in the opinion of training instructors, have the exercises ever been more productive of vital results.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- Two of the four Cuban baseball players with Washington are quitting their positions on the team and are returning to Cuba, while a third is undecided as to the course he will follow.

JULIA MARLOWE -- always impeccable in taste -- declared of Shakespeare's plays that "we cannot go far wrong if we let the lines have the center of the stage and allow them to show the poet's meaning. We cannot aid him by a multitude of gestures or by creating of intricate 'business.'"

IN my reintroduction to "the States" after twenty-one months overseas the first thing that hit me was not what I saw but what I sensed. The tempo of America -- it spun me about, it woke me up after almost two sluggish years of war. Speed, man alive, what speed we have in this country!

The opening gun in a campaign to make this country aware of the economic value of a large, fast American Merchant Marine -- one that is capable not only of carrying a large share of our foreign commerce, but actually does this --was fired last week by the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company at a meeting of a group of marine editors, shipping officials and Government representatives.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 15 -- Summer yaching on Long Island Sound reached the halfway mark with the special regatta of the Manhasset Bay Club, and sixty-one craft had sail-full racing under a splendid southwest breeze that sprang up after a tantalizing calm and held true and steady.
ROME, July 15 (AP) -- George Nelson Page, former chief of the radio division of the Fascist Ministry of Popular Culture, has been arrested for questioning by the Allies.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, July 15 (AP) -- Representative Alvin W. Weichel of Sandusky protested to the War Department today against the "finely outfitting" and "entertaining" of Italian prisoners of war who now are organized into service troops of the United States Army.

BOSTON, July 15 -- Practically anything that happens to the Dodgers now will be for the best. They brought their suspended thirteen-game losing streak into Braves Field today after a hiatus of six days and lost little time in extending it to fourteen as Bob Coleman's boys, chiefly on the wings of a three-run homer by Chuck Workman, outscored them, 6 -- 3, and tumbled them back into seventh place.
CHUNGKING, China, July 15 (AP) -- A communique:

OF St. John Perse one might as the poet says of his Prince: "I have heard you spoken of in this part of the world, and the praise was not meager." St. John Perse is largely known through T.S. Eliot's translation of his epic, "Anabasis."

Activity in the accessories markets has been slow, although there have been a number of buyers in the market, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring and Howell Company.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 15 -- Thirty-three tenants of New Rochelle apartment houses, demanding Office of Price Administration rent ceilings and protesting rent "gouging" in Westchester County, put on a demonstration today in front of City Court on Lawton Street, where one tenant was scheduled to defend an eviction suit.

SOMEONE happened to mention that in the 1937 All-Star game Dizzy Dean had his toe broken by Earl Averill's line drive and never was the same again. Thereupon Frank Frisch, who used to be the Great Man's chief keeper, reared up in a state of righteous indignation and asked: "Do you mean to insinuate that the Old Flash didn't use Dean properly?" He was calmed down promptly before his feathers could get too ruffled.

THE famous cartoonist, Thomas Nast, couldn't possibly have known how prophetic he was being when he invented the symbols of the elephant and the donkey which have stood for more than seventy years as the respective signs of the Republican and Democratic parties in the United States.

LONDON, Sunday, July 16 -- In a deep advance to within thirty-nine miles of pre-war East Prussia, Red Army troops yesterday outflanked Grodno and Kaunas, twin Nazi bastions protecting the approaches to that easternmost part of Germany, while Berlin reported the Russians had opened a powerful new offensive toward the fortress city of Lwow in southeastern Poland.

CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- Josephus Daniels, who, as Secretary of the Navy in the first World War, was President Roosevelt's boss, predicted today a "crystal clear" Democratic platform that would condemn isolationism and "straddlers" and cause "all lovers of peace to rejoice."

MR. GALLAGHER used to ask Mr. Shean, "How're you feelin'?" to which Mr. Shean yawned, "Not so good -- my wife kept me awake talkin' and talkin' all last night." "What was she talkin' about?" inquired the interested Mr. Gallagher. "

The arrest of Wesley F. Wood, secretary-treasurer of the Bakery and Confectionery Workers International Union of America, Local No. 50, in Boston yesterday on a charge of stealing $60,000 of the local's funds here was announced by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan, who said detectives have sought the union official since his indictment two weeks ago for grand larceny.

THE war maybe going badly for Germany in Europe, but she is apparently doing well in South America. Official breaks with the Axis there have not hampered her too much, for she has the Spanish Falange to do her bidding -- and local army men as willing pupils, ready to upset local Governments and spread the kind of confusion she is so adept in turning to her own profit.

THE Argentine postal authorities are preparing two semi-postal sheets, 5-centavos plus 1-pesos and 5c plus 50p, the surtaxes to go into a fund being raised to improve living conditions in the northwestern provinces of La Rioja and Catamarca.

WITH THE FIRST ARMY in France, July 15 (U.P.) -- Few prisoners were taken on either side and many a throat was cut today as thousands of doughboys, in some of the bloodiest hand-to-hand fighting yet seen in Normandy, charged into strong German positions between Lessay and St. Lo.

PHILADELPHIA, July 15 -- In an attempt to offset the unfavorable impression apparently created in a stockholder's mind through the disclosure of salaries paid by corporations to their top executives and employes, a growing number of concerns has adopted the practice of stating in proxy solicitations both the gross and the "take-home" pay of the highest-paid personnel.
CHICAGO, July 15 -- Helen Gahagan Douglas, Democratic nominee for Congress from California's Fourteenth District, said today she would not "fence" with Representative Clare Boothe Luce.
Yesterday's Finnish communique, as broadcast domestically by the Finnish radio and reported by the Federal Communications Comission:

U. S. A. -- Though short-wave listening is apt to be associated chiefly with broadcasts from overseas, the stations here at home are by no means without interest. Practically around the clock, the overseas division of the Office of War Information is beaming news programs and special shows which frequently are singularly informative in that they represent the government's formal position on the war's manifold problems.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 15 -- Twenty to twenty-five German divisions, comprising 240,000 to 300,000 men, are massed in Normandy to check the Allies' thrust inland.

Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons continued his practice of repeating in stakes events yesterday when Dossuet, whom he trains for William Woodward's Belair Stud, annexed the thirty-first running of the $10,000 added Fleetwing Handicap before a crowd of 31,147 at Empire City's halfway point in its meeting at Jamaica.

NEW LONDON, Conn., July 15 (U.P.) -- The Navy today awarded the Legion of Merit, two Silver Star Medals and five Bronze Star Medals to eight submarine officers and enlisted men for heroism in action against the Japanese in Pacific waters.

ALICIA MARKOVA and Anton Dolin will be the soloists at the Lewisohn Stadium tomorrow evening. Their program will consist of the "Blue Bird" and the "Grand Pas de Deux" from "The Sleeping Beauty," the pas de deux from "Les Sylphides," and one solo each.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The Foreign Policy Association said today that an "open door" policy assuring all countries access to the world's oil fields under a system of international cooperation was essential to world peace and security.

ONE of this department's readers has a theory about the appeal of mystery stories which seems to me worthy of a little thought. As I turned it over in my mind it occurred to me that possibly my correspondent's suggestion might apply equally well to Westerns, to spy stories and to tales of adventure in general.

THIS novel, based on an inside knowledge of early Nazi training for war, was written by a man who was a member of the National Socialist party until 1930, when he left to combat that organization. In 1933 after, it is said, a death warrant was issued for him, he fled to France, where he began work on the present book.

WHEN man first embarks in a new element there is a feeling of high adventure. He has set himself apart from his plodding fellows and an aura of glamour surrounds him. He is driven forward by a mental hunger for knowledge of what lies beyond -- whether his quest is a golden fleece, a new land over the horizon or that limitless world that reaches out from the stratosphere.

HEADQUARTERS UNITED STATES FOURTEENTH AIR FORCE, In China, July 15 (AP) -- After several months secrecy, it was disclosed today that Capt. Winfree A. Sordelett, a 24-year-old Virginian flying an unarmed P-38 reconnaissance plane, photographed areas of Japan on Oct. 31, 1943, and returned to China with precious film and weather data.

Overhauling and coordination of Federal labor and salary stabilization policies to ease the plight of "white collar" workers was urged yesterday by the National Association of Manufacturers in an editorial in its weekly publication. Without such revision, it was declared, "management's best efforts toward sound and fair treatment of its 'white collar' workers will be balked."

WITH THE AMERICAN ARMY IN NORMANDY, July 14 (Delayed) (UP) -- A Russian general and two colonels, the first Soviet visitors to the American beachhead, said today that they were "pleased and impressed" and that the Americans were now in a position where they could open up and go places.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 15 (AP) -- A laundry truck driver who said today that his mind was "perfectly blank" about much of his life since 1930 identified himself to Hartford police as John A. Commons, 53, formerly in the faculty at the University of Wisconsin and listed as missing for fourteen years and legally declared dead in 1938.

THE coldframe, instead of lying idle during the summer, can be put to the practical use of housing new stock, principally cuttings. Many shrubs, vines and herbaceous plants can be multiplied there without much difficulty.

CLEVELAND, July 15 (AP) -- Supported by the heavy bats of Pat Seerey, Roy Cullenbine and Ray Mack, Ed Klieman, rookie pitcher, held the Browns in check today as the Indians romped in with a 13-to-2 victory, their third in four games played with the American League leaders in the current series.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., July 15 (AP) -- Jeanette MacDonald, actress, received a black and swollen eye and scratches and cuts on her face in an encounter with a prowler in her El Encanto Hotel cottage last night. Police arrested a 14-year-old bellboy as her assailant and charged him with battery.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., July 15 -- Mike Cestone, former metropolitan amateur champion and runner-up in this year's State open, won the New Jersey State Golf Association's second annual amateur open championship over the Essex County West Course today.

MONSIGNOR HOLZNER'S book is an attempt to set the life and writings of St. Paul against the intellectual and social background of his time. While it is obviously dependent on Harnack, Schweitzer and others, this biographical commentary has notable qualities of style and feeling which the translator has caught and to a considerable extent accurately reflected.

DETROIT, July 15 (AP) -- George Romney, managing director of the Automotive Council for War Production, said today that as a result of production cut-backs, contract cancellations amounting to $14,000,000,000 to date, and design modifications on war production "mountainous piles" of obsolete parts, scrapped manufacturing equipment and idle raw materials are beginning to clutter up valuable manufacturing space in automobile plants.

Cooperation vital to a lasting peace can be attained only by "leaders of understanding and experience who have been tested, trained and proved in action," the Affiliated Young Democrats of New York declared yesterday in a platform endorsing the National Administration.

RICHMOND, July 15 -- Refusal of the recent Virginia State Democratic Convention at Roanoke to seat several regularly elected Negro delegates from Roanoke and Newport News has brought renewed discussion of the role of Negro citizens in Southern politics.

The closing of the public and parochial schools for the summer will make the next six weeks the most critical in the collection of waste paper since the salvage drive began, Paul W. Zeckhausen, executive secretary of the New York City salvage division of the War Production Board, said yesterday.

Throughout its long history, the Republican party has been known as the sound money party, the anti-inflation party. In this connection may be recalled the various monetary actions that followed the Civil War and the Battle for Gold around the turn of the century.

Entry blanks now are available for the municipal golf championships to be played on the ten golf courses operated by the Department of Parks, it was announced yesterday. The tournament is part of the Fifth Annual Summer Sports Tournament, which also includes tennis and swimming.

" TO OBTAIN a pictorial record of the war in all its phases" was the general assignment given forty-two artists by the War Department. One of these was George Biddle, the brother of Attorney General Francis Biddle, who was to organize and act as chairman of the Art Advisory Committee and to go himself to the Mediterranean and draw.
To know Venezuela one must study three things, the careers of two men and one substance. The men are Simon Bolivar, the Liberator, and Gen. Juan Vicente Gomez. The substance is oil.

ALBANY, July 15 -- Acting Chief Inspector Francis S. McGarvey of the State Police, who has been acting in that office since January, was named chief inspector today by Capt. John A. Gaffney, superintendent of the force. Captain Gaffney also named Howard W. Nugent as deputy chief inspector.

The domestic oil companies are a bit disturbed as to what may be done at the forthcoming full-dress conference on the world's petroleum resources which will be held soon between representatives of the British and United States Governments.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The Japanese suggestion in a broadcast from Singapore today of executions of B-29 aviators and the threat that a similar fate awaits other American airmen who are shot down over targets of the Japanese homeland will fail to affect our bombing operations, according to all indications today.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- Contracts for 262 additional cargo ships and tankers were placed by the Maritime Commission today at "the urgent request" of the Joint Army and Navy Chiefs of Staff.

ACCORDING to Dean Dixon, the talented young conductor, his New American Youth Orchestra, whose formation was announced last week, has a double function. Its primary purpose is to bring serious music to New York's younger generations; but it will also serve as a proving ground for young musicians who might otherwise be unable to get first-hand professional experience.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- Congress of Industrial Organizations members of the War Labor Board today labeled "false" the contention of American Federation of Labor members that the board's decision in the International Harvester Company case was "equivalent to abrogation of the maintenance of union membership clause in the CIO contracts with the company."
BUFFALO, July 15 (U.P.) -- Col. John M. McDowell's knowledge of the Bible is credited with quelling an incipient strike of war prisoners in the Second Service Command which he heads.

LONDON, July 15 -- To the modern commander of armies the weather is still the variable, somewhat unpredictable and yet decisive factor it always has been. And the weather on the whole had not been favorable to the Allied plans since the war began, and least of all has it been so in the vitally important campaign in Normandy.
The American forces in the Pacific last week added the name of Saipan to their battle rolls. After a last, frenzied and hopeless counter-attack, Japanese resistance collapsed and Saipan was won.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 15 -- The fourth week of robot bombing finds German propaganda somewhat subdued on the subject. Finding the home front increasingly skeptical about the devastating effect on England of this "wonder weapon," Joseph Goebbels' propaganda department switched to hinting darkly that later improved versions of the robot engine would work miracles that the allegedly experimental version No. 1 could not reasonably be expected to achieve.

ROME, July 15 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark, commander of the Fifth Army, narrowly escaped death or serious injury off the Anzio beachhead last Jan. 28 when an American minesweeper, alerted against attack by the Germans, fired on his PT boat, killing one officer and an enlisted man and wounding two enlisted men.

CHICAGO, July 15 -- The first test of whether President Roosevelt will receive the twenty-three electoral votes of Texas will come Monday when a subcommittee of the Democratic National Committee will hear arguments on the contest between the delegates elected at the State convention and those elected at a rump meeting, participants at which bolted the regularly called convention and elected delegates pledged to the renomination of Mr. Roosevelt.

WHEN what Messrs. Graves and Hodge have called "the long weekend" came to a calamitous close in September, 1939, G.B. Stern at 49 was a popular, long-established novelist and a vivacious member of the international literary circle that also included such figures as Somerset Maugham, Noel Coward and Alexander Woollcott.

PHILADELPHIA, July 15 -- Hundreds of Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Delaware members of the armed forces (some of them recently returned from battle-fronts) are using furloughs to help ease manpower shortages in critical war industries.

EVERY so often Arthur Hopkins utters a jeremiad against Broadway and its works. In a recent issue of The Callboard, an actors' organ, Mr. Hopkins was in full cry, predicting, among other things, that "the theatre of the future will be American and not Broadway."

LONDON, July 15 -- The role of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration will be strictly limited in most European countries to health, welfare and the repatriation of displaced persons, according to an official of that organization speaking in a press conference.

RETAIL trade resumed its normal seasonal pattern last week and larger gains over a year ago were noted in most areas following the letdown occasioned by the holiday in the previous week. Merchants report developing consumer interest in early fall merchandise, particularly women's suits.

Professor Edman's article on current trends in education does not seem entirely fair. St. John's, for instance, teaches science and the values of science, and no one is proposing to do away with these. Certainly we need to know the functioning of our scientific, technical civilization.

PEARL HARBOR, July 15 (AP) -- Admiral Raymond A. Spruance's warships joined Vice Admiral Marc A. Mitscher's carrier groups in shelling and bombing Guam Friday -- extending attacks by air on that former United States outpost through the eleventh straight day.

ROME, July 15 (Reuter) -- An appeal for men at this "turning point of history" to clear their minds regarding the principles that must be the basis of world reconstruction is made today in an article in the Vatican newspaper Osservatore Romano.

To help meet an emergency of war Illinois Institute of Technology has adapted its educational facilities to serve Chicago war industries. Through a unique plan of cooperation between education and industry the institute has taken the college classroom to industries' plants.

WHEN the Magee family broke up housekeeping in the city, Merry Carol went with her parents to run the farm which grandmother Magee had left to them, and David stayed with his uncle until he should finish high school.

A taxicab driver was credited last night with capture of a motorist pursued at high speed through the Bronx for more than a hour after a woman was run down as she was about to board a street car at Webster Avenue and 173d Street.

LONDON, Sunday, July 16 (AP) -- Five oil refineries and a pumping station at Ploesti, Rumania, were blasted by 750 United States heavy bombers from Italy yesterday as the worst flying weather ever encountered over western Europe kept the great Allied air forces in Britain virtually idle until late in the evening.

THE bronzed figure in the tower chair at the beach this summer, the husky person in the white hat, next-to-nothing trunks and sun glasses, the lad whose whistle is a clarion warning and whose megaphone is the voice of the law -- he isn't the man he used to be.

It was with regret that I read in THE TIMES Magazine Staff Sergeant Martin's "The Biography of a Jeep," in which he again miscalled the famous quarter-ton military vehicle a "jeep." Maybe I'm too much "old Army," but in the old days, when such vehicles first became available to the services, they were called "peeps" to distinguish them from their older and bigger predecessor, the true "jeep."

Marked reduction in any black market activities in the lumber industry is expected to result from that portion of the recent War Production Board Order L-335 as amended, prohibiting acceptance of orders not allotted by the board, it was pointed out in the furniture industry yesterday.

Last winter the California Medical Association commissioned the firm of Foote, Cone Belding to make "a study of the public relations problem of the California medical profession to arrive at recommendations for a program to improve the public's attitude toward the profession."

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sunday, July 16 -- American infantrymen pushed their way into the outskirts of Lessay, westernmost of the bastions of Field Marshal Gen. Erwin Rommel's defense line at the base of the Cherbourg Peninsula, yesterday while other doughboys were closing in on Periers and St. Lo in the center and on the extreme east of the battlefront.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration in effect recognized the French Commitee of National Liberation today as the Provisional Government of the French Republic.

CHICAGO, July 15 -- Seemingly anxious to avoid answering questions about the Vice-Presidential nomination, Robert E. Hannegan, Democratic national chairman, shunned newspaper reporters on his arrival today and his whereabouts during most of the day was a good deal of a mystery.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 15 -- After more than a week's delay the table of quotas (subscriptions) to the proposed international monetary fund was adopted today by the United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference. The aggregate was increased to $8,800,000,000, compared to the original $8,000,000,000 and a subsequent proposal of $8,500,000,000.

WITH AMERICANS ON THE AY RIVER FRONT, Normandy, July 15 -- Two bearded figures looking like sourdoughs out of the Klondike ambled down the road to hail the first American troops reaching the village of St. Patrice-de Claids yesterday on the heels of the retreating Germans.

The invasion of France did not disrupt the wedding plans of Norman Lantaigne, 22 years old, messman aboard the Liberty ship that led the freighter convoys to the beaches of Normandy on D-day. Yesterday, back in New York with all of the ship's crew except one man, who is reported missing, he hurried on to Springfield, Mass., where he lives at 38 Redlands Street.

CHICAGO, July 15 -- The Chicago Stadium, where the Republican National Convention was held last month, is getting a few bright touches for the Democratic national conclave, which will open next Wednesday.

VICTORIA LINCOLN is the author of "February Hill," a book which received acclaim ten years ago. This, her second book, is a collection of prose and poetry, some of which has appeared in the New Yorker and other magazines.

More than 400,000 registrations have been recorded at the five United Seamen's Service clubs for merchant seamen in New York City, Edward P. Mulrooney, former Police Commissioner, chairman of the USS New York Port Area Executive Committee, was informed yesterday in a special report by George A. Horton, executive director of the port area.

IT is always highly desirable to have at least eight cards of the trump suit in the combined hands of declarer and dummy. For this reason good players avoid raising partner's suit with fewer than three trumps even when partner may have a five-card suit.

CHUNGKING, China, July 15 (U.P.) -- A strong Japanese force smashed into the southern suburbs of bomb-scarred Hengyang and seized a main thoroughfare of that pivotal Hunan Province city, a Chinese communique said today, but a desperate Chinese garrison, led personally by its commander, threw it back in hand-to-hand fighting.

PANAMA, July 15 -- Colombia, after the kidnapping of President Alfonso Lopez and the forty-eight hour revolt, and Nicaraugua, with her increasing opposition to President Anastasio Somoza, are today the most disturbed countries in this area.

MOSCOW, July 15 -- The Soviet Government's latest decree on marriage, divorce and bonuses, and taxes against single persons or married couples with small families, commanded Moscow's attention this week almost to the subordination of the war itself.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 15 -- A "harmony" delegation of Democrats left for Chicago this evening to represent California at the national convention, aware of deep-seated feuds in the party in this State but refusing to admit that this will put California into the doubtful column in November.

WHEN I feel too confident about careers for women, I try to bring back the shock of reality that I once felt go through a women's club. A lecturer was insinuating himself by telling his audience how wonderful women were.
This is the third of a series of articles on the use of various cosmetics, representing the advice of leading beauty authorities.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 15 (AP) -- The American Seventy-ninth Division under Maj. Gen. Ira Wyche was the first to enter Cherbourg, with the Fourth and Ninth Divisions collaborating on the flanks, Supreme Headquarters disclosed today.

Formulating the second phase of its broad-scale post-war program, credited with being the first developed by any organization of wholesalers, the National Association of Tobacco Distributors has taken the initiative in seeking the collaboration of manufacturers in devising methods for speedier, more efficient and more economical distribution, it was learned here last week.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., July 15 -- Speaking in behalf of her father, Representative Hamilton Fish, who seeks renomination in the Republican primaries in the Twenty-ninth District, Mrs. Insley B. Pyne, who is the wife of a pilot of a Navy bomber, charged today that the Roosevelt Administration was responsible for plunging this country into war.

Retail trade continued active here last week. Demand continued brisk for a wide variety of seasonal and vacation items. Department store volume ran about 10 per cent ahead of the same week of 1943. Shoe volume increased due to the release of women's shoes of certain types from rationing. Main floor departments were busy.
KANDY, Ceylon, July 15 (UP) -- A communique:

CHICAGO, July 15 -- Indications that President Roosevelt will not come to the Chicago Stadium to electrify a packed Convention Hall and a vast radio audience with an address accepting the fourth-term nomination are proving a source of disappointment to residents here.

CHERBOURG, July 12 (Delayed) -- The Germans were driven out of this city on June 26. That night, two Frenchwomen worked for hours making a French flag from silk that had once been American parachutes.

MR.DABNEY has added a well-written volume to the growing list of histories of individual newspapers. The number of good ones is fewer than should be the case. Most such books fail in objectivity, make too much of curious incidents from old files and neglect the broader stream of life, and, lastly, lack candor in dealing with journalistic mistakes.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, including its principal operating subsidiaries, reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $172,196,862 after all expenses and charges for the twelve months to May 31. This was equal to $9.15 a share on A.T. T.'s outstanding capital stock.

OMAHA, July 15 -- The President's letter announcing his readiness to accept a fourth-term nomination, and the withdrawal of Senator Gillette from the Iowa delegation to avoid participation in that nomination, might, under other circumstances, have produced considerable political fever in the Midwest.

CHICAGO, July 15 -- John Marsch, Chicago contractor, drove convincingly toward the 1944 Futurity championship today when his sleek brown colt, Free for All, cakewalked to victory in the $61,425 Arlington Futurity.

NOEL BUSCH, a peripatetic editor of Life, has visited the Argentine, South Africa, Cairo, Saudi Arabia, England and Eire for that enterprising journal since the autumn of 1942. This volume is a cross between a byproduct of these assignments and a labor of love.

AMONG those who regard the art of the radio with a disparaging, not to say surly, eye, a favorite subject of protest is the sound of the human voice as it emerges from the loud-speaker into the Great American Living Room.

A beach "commando" unit, organized among students of Samuel J. Tilden High School to combat a series of small thefts at Brighton Beach, resulted yesterday in the appearance in Brooklyn-Queens Night Court of a defendant booked as Jack Isaacs, 21 years old, of 251 Hinsdale Street, Brooklyn.

A SUBJECT of particular concern in summer, according to inquiries received by this department, is that of food refrigeration. At this time of year food is more perishable than in winter months and additional care is required to combat spoilage and waste.

The stock market moved in a narrow range yesterday and closed irregularly higher with selected issues leading the list in the dullest trading in a month. Business on the Stock Exchange was the smallest since June 3 with a turnover of 420,640 shares, compared with 855,360 on the preceding Saturday.

SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, July 15 (AP) -- The Japanese are in retreat from the Manipur Hills of India, it was announced today, and Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten declared that the Allies' strong stand had "contributed to one of the greatest defeats the Japanese Army has suffered in its history."

The first official intimation that the Republican party would seek to prevent President Roosevelt from standing for re-election in the role of Commander in Chief came yesterday in a statement by Representative Charles A. Halleck, chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, delivered to the press with Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican national chairman, sitting at his side.

Much more important than most of the allegedly "secret" weapons of which we read is an ingenious computer which corrects the aim of guns aboard one of our new planes. Housed in a small black box, the computer does most of the gunner's calculating for him in making allowances for plane speed, distance of target, wind and other factors as he aims.

FRED WARING and his Pennsylvanians, as expected, were not long in finding a new sponsor after Johnny Mercer took over their five-a-week chores on NBC. Beginning Sept. 7 they will be heard in a weekly half-hour show at 7 P.M. Thursdays over the Blue network and WJZ.

An impasse has been reached between certain divisions of the cotton textile, yarn and garment industries and the war agencies that is regarded as indicative of a "show-down" attitude on the part of the producers involved which should come to a "head" in the near future, according to spokesmen for the various groups.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 15 -- Declaring that the French Forces of the Interior were operating against the Germans as armies under his command, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower warned the enemy today to cease treating the members of these forces as francstireurs or face the consequences as war criminals.
LONDON, July 15 (UP) -- A communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

CAMDEN, N. J., July 15 (AP) -- Blue Cyprus, consistent 3-year-old filly who carries the silks of Mrs. M. E. Whitney, dominated the running of the six-furlong Benjamin Franklin Handicap, top offering at Garden State Park today.

WASHINGTON July 15 -- What could be called the Democratic Vice Presidential convention will assemble next week at Chicago, for the chief contest that impends is over the choice of a running-mate for the President. There will be disputes over the phrasing of the platform, and the settlement of these and of the Vice Presidential nomination may menace electoral votes which the Democratic candidates normally can count on in the South.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Sunday, July 16 (U.P.) -- Boston medium bombers struck in force against the great petroleum center of Bula, Ceram, in the Netherland, East Indies, on Friday, and burning oil from ruptured storage tanks flowed through the streets of the town, enveloping the entire target in flames, it was announced day.

THIS book guarantees cold shivers on three counts -- howling blizzards just south of the Canadian border, seances involving an evil spirit at dead of night, and finally bloody murder. Not at all a cozy book. A group gathers at a long unoccupied hunting lodge to ask a dead man a question.

THE future of American films in the post-war world is of more than passing concern to the motion-picture industry, and for the first time since the war Hollywood is seriously looking business-wise beyond the country's borders.

MURRAY BAY, Que. -- Several swimming meets starring exhibition swimmers and divers will be held throughout the season at the Manoir Richelieu; a biweekly fishing competition is an amusing event at the Canada Steamship Line wharf.

THE Netherlands Information Bureau in New York has made available photographs of the six stamps released on June 15 as part of the series printed for the Royal Netherlands Government in London for use in Holland after liberation.

THIS mystery begins in a thin way and quickly builds up to keen interest and excitement. Gamadge, who's a dilettante at studying old documents, has a young woman visitor at his New York town house. A drab person, she has a fixed idea that Mr. Crenshaw, a casual summer acquaintance with no friends and relatives, is the victim of queer happenings.

UNITED STATES Y FORCE FIELD HEADQUARTERS, July 14 (Delayed) -- In less than an hour we flew a distance that takes at least two days overland. As soon as American bombers had dropped their loads on Tengyueh yesterday afternoon Tech. Sgt. Rollin E. Bates of Tulsa, Okla., and the writer took off in a small plane to see what damage had been done.

CHENG CHI-YU'S manifesto will sound more like compromise than revolution to Western readers unless they realize the extent to which rigid formalities and a 4,300-year-old tradition have governed Chinese poetry. Dr. Cheng's charter for the emancipation of poets includes use of the vernacular, free rhymes based on modern pronunciation, interchangeable rhymes of even and oblique tones, and creation of new forms based on rhythms and musical scales.

Like the rest of the country, the Pacific Northwest is booming, and it is booming, for one reason, because of Columbia River electric power. The region has one-third of the nation's aluminum capacity. It is producing magnesium, ferro-alloys, calcium carbide, chlorates, metallurgical coke, zinc, copper, mercury, tungsten, antimony.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation inquired into 16,295 instances of suspected sabotage and found 1,736 cases of deliberate destruction in the twelve months ended June 30, but reported today that none was enemy directed.

PHILADELPHIA, July 15 -- With a sparkling five-hit victory Jack Brewer, fresh out of Uncle Sam's Navy with a medical discharge, today celebrated his major league pitching debut, and gave the Giants a split of a twin bill at Shibe Park before 7,835 fans.

CHICAGO, July 15 -- Buying of July wheat late in today's session on the Board of Trade, said to be against sales of 100,000 barrels of flour to Mexico, sent the price up sharply with the close at gains of 1 1/8 cents a bushel. Other months gained 1/4 to 1/2 cent.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 15 (AP) -- Communique 79:

COUNTERFEITING goes away back in history. There were passable forgeries of the early coins of Aegina and Lydia. During the Middle Ages and the Renaissance, in England and Europe, the striking of false coins was at once a popular pastime and a capital offense.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Approximately 35,000 out of 50,000 Italians who have been brought to this country after capture or surrender in the fighting zones are now part of what are called the Italian Service Units. These men, once our enemies, are now, as the Army states it, "co-belligerents," who have volunteered to aid the American Army.

ROME, July 15 -- American troops brought the great port of Leghorn into artillery range from the mountain positions three and a half miles away and in a sweep along a twenty-five-mile front, occupied all important heights nine miles from the Arno River guarding Florence and Pisa, it was announced today.

Nerve grafting is becoming a fine art in the hands of neuro-surgeons in England. In the early days of the war the spinal cord of rabbits was used by the French in accordance with the practice of World War I. Today man's own "spare nerves" are transplanted, and possibly "nerve banks" are just ahead.
A communique, as broadcast yesterday from Chungking in English to North America and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
ANKARA, Turkey, July 14 (Delayed) (AP) -- Rumors circulated in Ankara today that diplomatic and economic relations might be broken shortly between Turkey and Germany.

CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- Two California stars -- Miss Dorothy Bundy of Santa Monica and Miss Mary Arnold of Los Angeles -- who meet tomorrow for the singles title, today teamed to win the women's doubles championship of the River Forest open tennis tournament.

The Federal Reserve Bulletin bears the imprint of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System. It is an influential organ widely read in business and financial circles, issued monthly under the direction of a staff editorial committee. The committee disclaims responsibility for interpretations and opinions expressed in signed articles.

IT would seem in so knowledgeable a time as ours that a book about ancient saints and their doings with dragons might seem a little dull. But when Sister S.M.C. of the English Dominican Congregation of St. Catherine of Siena sets down such tales, look for evidence of a tongue hidden in a cheek, and a brightness of the eyes hidden by lowered lids.

SEATTLE, July 15 (AP) -- The American minesweeper's accidental ire on the PT boat carrying Genral Clark was described here by a survivor, who reported that the general had completed an inspection trip after having aided the wounded.

A bride and bridegroom of two weeks grinned proudly and clasped hands yesterday as Harry Conover announced, in his 52 Vanderbilt Avenue studios, the name of the girl chosen "most typical Wac" in the Air Transport Command's Ferrying Division and that of the soldier who had written the prizewinning letter in her behalf.

Short-covering and price-fixing credited to Southern mill accounts brought about yesterday a steady market for cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange, where final prices showed gains of 1 to 4 points on active months.

BEFORE going off to war (as a lieutenant in the United States Army), Joseph Stanley Pennell sat himself down in Junction City, Kan., and wrote "The History of Rome Hanks and Kindred Matters," an extended and fully amazing novel. The book is the story of the American forebears of Robert Lee Harrington, who has at least a superficial resemblance to Pennell himself.

A net profit of $1,043,294 was realized in the first six months of this year by the Superheater Company, according to a report of operations released yesterday. The results of operation of the company's Canadian affiliate were not included in this figure.

LONDON, July 15 -- Following the fifth consecutive night during which no flying bombs fell in London, speculation today centered on whether the Germans were shifting their launching installations from the Channel beach area.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES, in Normandy, July 15 -- The general had a little goat, but its fleece had more brown and black than white and was very dirty besides. And the goat was most unhappy. It didn't like the war.

GROWING up in Georgia over a hundred years ago, Lebanon Fairgale was so purely a child of nature that her dealings with human beings led to misunderstandings and persecution through no fault of her own: the history of her misfortunes is Caroline Miller's first novel since the Pulitzer prize-winning "Lamb in His Bosom."

SAN FRANCISCO, July 15 -- New population estimates showing big gains for the West Coast, with California leading the nation between 1940 and 1943, threw into sharper focus this week the general concern in this region over industrial reconversion problems.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES, in Normandy, July 15 -- The hard crust of German resistance still held firm today along the whole American front in Normandy. Our troops fighting almost incessantly nibbled little dents in it here and there.

THE pulse of the New York art world continued to beat last week, with several group exhibitions of more than passing interest on the calendar.
