In a well selected show, entitled "Britain in War Time," at the American-British Art Center, Ala Story, the director, has brought together paintings which are more art than reporting, although overtones of war are always to be noted in the work of these British war artists.
ST. LOUIS, July 15 (AP) -- Knocking Harry Gumbert out of the box in the first inning when the scored seven runs, the Cardinals coasted to a 12-to-1 victory over the Reds tonight.

Charles Oliver of Perth Amboy, N.J., became the Eastern junior tennis champion yesterday when he defeated Alan Watson Jr. of Short Hills, N.J., 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2, 9 -- 7, in the final at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

MOTION pictures can well take leadership in sowing the seeds of greater understanding between Asia and the West, according to Pearl Buck who feels she has sown some of these seeds herself in the novels from which have come the pictures "The Good Earth" and "Dragon Seed," the latter to be released here on Thursday.
DALLAS, Tex., July 15 (AP) -- The nation's top golf professionals have been invited to compete for $10,000 in war bonds, the highest stakes ever offered in Texas, in the Victory Open, Sept. 7-10.
ROME, July 15 -- A powerful attack against the Allies' occupation was launched in L'Avanti today by Pietro Nenni, Socialist leader.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 15 (AP) -- "It's not every day you travel at fourteen miles a minute -- and live" said Lieut. Robert E. Knapp of Norwich, N.Y., as he told today at the Army Air Forces redistribution station here of his 840-miles-an-hour plane dive when chasing Nazi fighters over Emden, Germany.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Sunday, July 16 (AP) -- A communique:

Major General Newgarden had been combat commander of the Tenth Armored Division since 1942. He was born in Philadelphia Feb. 24, 1892, the son of George Joseph and Margaret Woolever Newgarden. He received a B.S. degree from the United States Military Academy in 1913 and was a distinguished graduate of the Command and General Staff School in 1926 and of the Army War College in 1932.

WARD GREENE, the Georgia newspaper man who has already published several glib and exciting novels of the Deep South, now offers us a glib and rather unexciting sketch of the home front, World War II. The sketch is developed as a novel and worked out in that form to a conventional and fairly happy ending.

Daily newspapers in the United States consumed 16.1 per cent less newsprint paper in the first six months of the year than they did during the first half of 1943 and 20.4 per cent less than for the comparable period in 1941, base year for conservation rules, the American Newspaper Publishers Association estimated today on the basis of reports from its membership.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Production of a wide variety of aluminum products for civilian use was made possible today for the first time since early 1942 by orders issued by the War Production Board, releasing aluminum and magnesium for the production of civilian goods.

LONDON, July 15 -- As Allied pressure on the German war fronts increases, the burden of government weighs more heavily on the shoulders of the Nazi leaders. The principle of leadership according to which Germany is supposed to be governed loses a great deal of attraction when most of the vital decisions involve possible loss of prestige, and when it is so easy to fix the responsibility and put the blame on the leaders.

Mrs. Joan Schlutter, the 29-year-old former welder, of 201 West Ninety-fifth Street, who abducted six-months-old Barbara Anne Goggin from her crib in the New York Foundling Hospital early Thursday morning, was committed yesterday to Bellevue Hospital for observation following her arraignment before Magistrate Harry G. Andrews in the Felony Court.

A broadcast over the Japanese-operated Singapore radio at 7 A. M., E. W. T., yesterday referred to the B-29 Superfortress raids on Japan and said that American airmen had "bailed out to meet the same fate which was meted out to raiders of Tokyo...

Fully coordinated plans as thorough as those that are bringing us military victories are needed for the post-war period, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday, and the lack of them has him "frankly worried," he told the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs in convention at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

IF attaches of Paramount (both the theatre and the producing company) go statistically berserk these humid days don't blame it on the heat but on "Going My Way," the Leo McCarey picture starring Bing Crosby, which completed a ten-week stand at the Broadway house last Tuesday night.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 15 -- Albie Booth, Yale's mighty mite who shot into the nation's headlines over a decade ago as an athletic hero, today joined the Blue's football coaching staff. He'll assist Howie Odell and direct the junior varsity.

Generally Arthur Eilenberg of Brooklyn sees good in all of nature's creatures, but he can't warm up to pigeons. Mention here of a pigeon nesting in a Times Square ventilator prompted him to write rather bitterly of this bird's uselessness, shiftlessness and vanity. He even questioned its patriotism.

Jennie Tourel, mezzo-soprano, was the assisting artist at last night's concert at the Lewisohn Stadium given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Leonard Bernstein conducting. She sang the finale of Mr. Bernstein's symphony, "Jeremiah," which had its first performance at the Stadium, and the Rondo from Rossini's largely forgotten opera, "La Cenerentola."

CHICAGO, July 15 -- Montgomery Ward Co. sent a lavishly illustrated 860-page fall and winter catalogue into the mails today that was about fifty pages larger than the spring catalogue, and which showed only a few changes in the type of goods previously offered.

The only automatic, continuous-flow oxygen regulator in use today by our armed forces, the A-11, goes into action whenever high mountain ranges, or combat, or weather conditions require planes to fly at undisclosed heights. With this small device, large speedy transport and cargo planes can climb and screen themselves in heavy clouds or quickly change their flight level as the need of the moment demands.

Definite plans are being made to form a combined pool by cotton spinners and weavers and textile machinery manufacturers to buy up all used textile machinery in the post-war period in order to insure it being junked and withheld from use by foreign countries, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The Petroleum Administration for War, asking petroleum refiners to push production of oil products, said today that military demands were mounting faster than had been expected.

BUFFALO, July 15 (AP) -- Labor throughout the State is "friendly" to Governor Dewey's Administration, Edward M. Corsi, Industrial Commissioner, said today in predicting that Mr. Dewey would carry New York as candidate for President in November.

LONDON, July 15 -- The Polish Cabinet has been in almost continuous session for the past two days, discussing Premier Stalin's order of the day of July 13 announcing the capture of Vilna and the "liberation of the capital of the Lithuanian Soviet Republic."

" THE SEARCHING WIND" has been enthusiastically received by the professional critics. It will prove, I believe, to have been one of the most significant dramas of this generation. Significant, that is, of the power of a reputation.

THIS story, published in Moscow last year under the title "The People Immortal," tells about the defense of a Ukrainian village during the Russian retreat of 1941. Vassili Grossman, himself a Ukrainian, and war correspondent for the Red Star, wrote the book right on the scene of action.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that cotton consumed during June totaled 805,735 bales of lint and 118,866 bales of linters, compared with 831,889 of lint and 120,831 of linters during May this year, and 918,433 of lint and 97,334 of linters during June last year.

ON THE AY RIVER FRONT in France, July 15 (AP) -- Field Marshal Gen. Erwin Rommel is throwing a potpourri of "kitchen commandos" in the fighting on this front after pulling back badly mauled first-line troops.

The exact role James A. Farley will play at the Democratic National Convention this week remained in doubt yesterday as he stepped aboard the Twentieth Century Limited for Chicago, announcing that his actions will be "prompted by what my conscience dictates."

ALBANY, July 15 -- The Association of New York State Republican Clubs named a campaign committee today to map plans for participation in the coming campaign. The committee is headed by Joe Mencher of Tuckahoe, as chairman; Mrs. Helen S. Casalett of Utica, vice chairman, with the general membership including:

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The proposal to set up a foreign trade division within the Smaller War Plants Corporation and man the division with experts who can help small business men build up export or import lines, in the post-war era, is nearing final form at SWPC, it was learned here today.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- More than twoscore members of the country's armed forces -- nurses, Wacs, Waves, marines -- have died in line of duty since the start of the war and even more are prisoners of war.
LONDON, July 15 -- The Germans have apparently "lost" three trains in France carrying 900 British civilians being repatriated for Germans from South Africa, Lisbon reports said tonight.

ROME, July 15 -- San Gimignano "of the beautiful towers," one of the most famous medieval towns in Italy, was virtually destroyed in the past thirty-six hours by the Germans, according to official information from the front.

OTTAWA, July 15 -- Canada just now seems to the observer to be suffering in an astonishing degree the inconveniences and unhappinesses of sudden growth. In reality the country was never so prosperous and never had such cause for pride in its accomplish ments.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Holding that the rulings of a Government executive cannot be set aside unless they are clearly illegal, arbitrary or capricious, Judge T. Whitfield Davidson of the Federal District Court upheld today an order of Postmaster General Walker revoking Esquire Magazine's second-class mailing privilege.

DAYLILIES are one good answer to the problem of finding an easily grown hardy perennial. They require comparatively little care or attention, yet provide attractive bloom over a long period. The number of orange daylilies to be seen blossoming riotously in old, deserted gardens long after almost all other plants have died of neglect testifies to their amenability.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 15 (AP) -- Mrs. Norma T. Barber of New York won the women's Eastern clay courts tennis championship for the fourth time today when she defeated Miss Helen Germaine of New York at the Montclair Athletic Club, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2. Mrs. Barber won the crown in 1930, 1932 and 1936.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 15 -- Harness racing, an old sport in a comparatively new setting, went over the top tonight as the summer meeting of the Old Country Trotting Association at Roosevelt Raceway was concluded with new records for attendance, 10,055; mutuel handle, $310,149, and daily double pool, $14,566.

HEADQUARTERS, United States First Army, Normandy, July 15 -- In the few weeks since the capture of Cherbourg the Allies' line in Normandy has nowhere moved forward more than a few miles. In the same few weeks the Russians have made gains of 100 to 200 miles in their march toward East Prussia and Berlin.

Apprehensions felt by some members of the home building and home furnishings industries that too much emphasis on "dream products" for the post-war period may seriously curtail demand for new homes following the peace were substantiated by a recent survey by the National Association of Home Builders on what the public is expecting in new homes and what manufacturers will be prepared to give them immediately after the war.

Germany's vaunted "integration" of Europe's transportation systems will not survive the downfall of the Nazi regime, according to a study just completed in connection with a research project conducted under the Institute of World Affairs here.

" At the earliest possible time after the cessation of hostilities we will bring home all members of our armed forces who do not have unexpired enlistments and who do not volunteer for overseas duty."

ANOTHER Sir Thomas Beecham recording of Mozart's music is added to the already generous list with Columbia's new album of the C major Symphony No. 34 (K. 338) (M-MM-548, three 12-inch records). Sir Thomas conducts the London Philharmonic Orchestra, and the set is thoroughly representative of the British conductor's style.

THAT certain liberality of mind which the cultivated man habitually reveals seldom embraces what he designates as "metaphysical speculations." No longer bred on the classics, he dismisses Greek and Latin literature as so much moldy mythology.

At the request of the War Production Board the War Food Administration is organizing a campaign to collect at least 1,500,000 pounds of milkweed floss to meet military requirements this year. With supplies of kapok cut off by the war, milkweed floss has been found to be the best material available for use in life jackets.

THE fifth annual purchase of works of art by American artists has just been announced by Elizabeth S. Navas, trustee of the Louise C. Murdock Estate Art Fund, for the Wichita Art Museum, Wichita, Kansas. Seven paintings and one piece of sculpture have been acquired, bringing to fifty-three the total number acquired for this especially discriminating and impressive collection of American work, chiefly by contemporaries.

Educators attending the National Education Association convention at Pittsburgh reported that the war has depleted the teaching corps to a greater extent than is generally realized. Figures presented by N.E.A. officials tell their own story and call for prompt action.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Solution of three paramount issues confronting the industrial economy in the change-over from war to peace was proposed today in "a statement on national policy" by the Committee for Economic Development, a group of business and industrial executives.

HOT weather usually means vacation time to everyone but the hostess. Those who live in the country or have city apartments with cool terraces would probably like to invite guests oftener if only it didn't mean so much fuss and bother.

GEOGRAPHICALLY, some of the tiny South Sea atoll islands are among the few remaining spots for escape writing. Frisbie of the South Sea Islands now writes his fourth book about that fascinating region, and he does a handsome job of carrying the reader far away from the world struggle to a happy, clean, unhurried, gracious never-never land, where much is comic and gay, and even tragedy seems muted.

WE have a new version of the opera "Carmen" coming. This new version is the opera in its original form, though in English translation by Lewis Sydenham, after text of Meilhac and Halevy, music by Bizet.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (U.P.) -- Assembly lines in this country in April turned out twenty times the amount of munitions produced in July, 1940, when the defense program was started, the War Production Board reported tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- Midwest farmers, by providing almost 68,000,000 bushels of corn for war use, "have fought the war as truly as though on the battle front," War Food Administrator Marvin Jones said today.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The "ceiling" prices for ten basic grades of waste paper are being increased $2 to $5 a ton by the Office of Price Administration to stimulate greater collection and to encourage dealers to pack waste paper properly for mill consumption.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission issued today a report giving typical electric bills for residential service in all communities with more than 2,500 population as of last Jan. 1.

With each new season we like to stop and review some of the outstanding products mentioned in this column in the previous few months. Two particularly timely ones to bring to attention again are ice cream mixes. One called Frizz, put up by the Kraft Cheese Company, is a powder that requires only the addition of water, vigorous beating and freezing, to produce a good, smooth-textured cream.

There is something satisfying about a farm shop on a rainy day in midsummer. Partly, perhaps, it is because one is glad of a leisurely day in the midst of haying. Or it may be that the steady fall of the rain on the roof, the low-lying nimbus clouds, and the soft, gray light over the upland fields and valley meadows create an atmosphere which relaxes.

From the beginning of the war there has been evidence of a new spirit of cooperation in many fields of endeavor. Industry has achieved its astonishing production by whole-hearted cooperation between peacetime rivals. Scientific societies, and scientists of many individual companies, have shown a commendable spirit of mutual help in research.
A production crisis in the German armament industry is well under way, the British radio said yesterday in a broadcast recorded by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

That the Metropolitan Opera Association may be able to avoid an operating deficit next season was forecast by George A. Sloan, president of the association, in his report on last season's operations, just issued.

FLORES POINT, Saipan Island, Marianas, July 8 (Delayed) (AP) -- The "banzai" counter-attack started in a valley thick with semi-tropical plants. It began in the rainy dawn and ended with clouds of black flies hanging over the torn bodies at nightfall.

CHICAGO, July 16 -- Movement of old corn from the country has fallen off, due in part to the fact that industrial buyers are having the grain stored in interior elevators until needed. This tends to relieve the pressure on terminal markets where the big run of wheat is causing some congestion, due to a shortage of labor to unload the cars.
CHICAGO, July 16 (AP) -- The Cubs and Pirates divided a pair of 1-0 shut-outs today before 40,920, Chicago's largest baseball crowd of the year.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Among announcements made today by war agencies were the following:

Your recent editorial "No Peace With Butchers" deserves to be read and reread. Unfortunately, it literally is "impossible for a civilized mind to grasp the reality of figures given out [last] week as to the fate of Europe's Jews." Most of us simply cannot take in the full horror of the wanton murder by the Nazis and their agents of more than one-half of Europe's 7,000,000 Jews.

CHICAGO, July 16 -- The Southern revolt against the renomination and re-election of President Roosevelt seemed today to be weakening as it became evident that the regular delegations from Texas and South Carolina would be seated, with the probability that the contests from these States would not be carried to the floor of the national convention.
ALBANY, July 16 -- Maj. George M. Searle, veteran of two wars and a member of the State Police since 1922, today was named deputy superintendent by Governor Dewey.

Residents of New York and vicinity are eigible for a special free training course to become "white collar" girls in an important war agency in Washington after twelve weeks' instruction on the Rhode Island State College campus, President Carl R. Woodward announced yesterday.

CLEVELAND, July 16 (AP) -- The league-leading Browns increased their margin over the Yankees to two games today by sweeping a double-header from the Indians, 8 to 7 and 2 to l, before 32,553 fans. Both games went twelve innings.

PHILADELPHIA, July 16 -- The Pennsylvania baseball curfew law was unexpectedly advanced at least five minutes today to keep the Giants in the dark on whether they split a double-header with the Phils before a gathering of 16,266 fans.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 16 (AP) -- The Stockholm newspaper Tidningen published today a story that did not give the source, saying robot bombs weighing as much as ten tons and capable of being shot through the stratosphere as far as New York had been concentrated in western Jutland, Denmark.
LONDON, July 16 (AP) -- An Air Miniztry communtqud :

LONDON, July 16 -- As the Red Army approaches East Prussia the Polish Government here has issued a pamphlet documenting its proposal for the incorporation of Germany's easternmost province into Poland after the war "completely and unconditionally."

A warning to travelers who plan to leave the country that wartime regulations require the censorship of all written, printed or pictorial matter that they plan to take with them, was issued yesterday by Byron H. Spinney, New York district postal censor, Office of Censorship.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast domestically in Finland and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

ROME, July 16 (UP) -- A column moving up Highway 1 rolled over the town of Quercianello, five and one-half miles southeast of Leghorn, and another driving up east of the city reached a point five and one-half miles east-southeast of Leghorn.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 16 -- Some people may wonder why powerful combined Allied air forces cannot operate despite bad weather. The answer is that the elements are even more powerful.
Today, across the country, the Army will start a new recruiting drive for women to handle work described only as "highly confidential."

CHICAGO, July 16 -- Representative John W. McCormack, chairman of the Committee on Resolutions of the Democratic National Convention, stated today that the committee would devote all day Wednesday to public hearings on foreign policy. He requested all persons wishing to be heard on other matters to appear before the committee tomorrow and Tuesday.

YONKERS, N.Y., July 16 -- Edward Luther Stevenson, historian and geographer, who was Professor of History at Rutgers University from 1891 to 1911, died here tonight at his home, 17 Lake Avenue, at the age of 85.
ROME, July 16 (AP) -- A communique:

The Yankees' determined drive toward the top of the American League before plunging into their second Western trip of the campaign struck a bog from an unexpected quarter at the Stadium yesterday, to the displeasure and discomfiture of a gathering of 44,849.

Three hundred Harlem boys have been transferred from so-called illegal and legal employment as a result of a United States Employment Service experiment to combat juvenile delinquency at the James Fenimore Cooper Junior High School, Madison Avenue and 120th Street.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Monday, July 17 -- Allied tanks and infantry bit into two wings of the German line in Normandy yesterday under the cover of a violent artillery and aerial barrage along the front from Lessay to St. Lo and from Evrecy to Caen.

RYE, N.Y., July 16 -- Eightyfive yachts that set forth today in the championship series regatta of the American Club here drove through one of those outbursts from overhead termed by atmospheric observers and sailors a white squall, and it was a mean one in its short life.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- Leo T. Crowley, Foreign Economic Administrator, reported today that almost $1,400,000,000 worth of lend-lease goods were sent to the China-Burma-India theatre from the beginning of the war to May 1, 1944.

War news was favorable last week. Russian armies in particular advanced toward East Prussia; Nazi demoralization was again in evidence. Both for stocks and bonds, prices went at times above the year's previous high level; but at east forward movement speculative selling of stocks on the rise grew heavier and the average declined.

Time Out for Lunch We have been watching in vain for the postwar planners, who almost daily widen their scope, to get around to the question of the American quick lunch. It is a little surprising that nothing effective was done about this abuse of good health in the dim, leisurely days of peace.

WITH BRITISH FORCES, SOUTHWEST OF CAEN, July 16 -- British Tommies on this sector taught the enemy a severe lesson today at a house near Jouvigny that the Nazis had been using as a machine-gun and forward observation post.

Jack Belden, Life correspondent and author of "Retreat with Stil-well," has written a story of the human side of the war in China, Africa and Sicily called "Still Time to Die." The book will be published by Harper's Sept. 13.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES in Normandy, July 16 -- The Germans have flooded the Ay River valley and appear determined to hold us up along the present front as long as possible. Our troops nowhere today made appreciable progress.

BOSTON, July 16 -- The travail has ended for the long-suffering Dodgers. Today, before 11,269 jeering fans, they ran their losing streak to an all-time high of fifteen for a Brooklyn team by dropping the first game to the Braves, 8 -- 4.

In your issue of July 7, commenting on Hitler's flying robot bombs, you conclude: "This much the world will agree upon: By resorting to indiscriminate murder of civilian populations Germany has forfeited the right to complain about anything the world inflicts on her in retribution and atonement."

ROME, July 15 (Delayed) (AP) -- Mrs. Melissa Reid Galassi, an American woman who has spent most of her life in Italy, is safe in Rome after having spent nine months under Fascist rule on a small island in the Mediterranean, escaping from it with her husband in a little boat and being rescued at sea by a British warship.

CHICAGO, July 16 -- July oats developed congestion last week on the Board of Trade as the result of lack of cash grain for delivery purposes. New oats are moving in small volume in the Central West, but brokers expect the run will be of short duration, and if new ceiling prices are set below the current level little grain may be disposed of.

Following an upward trend of almost two months, the cotton market turned irregular last week and net changes were mostly on the downside. At the close of trading on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were 1 point higher to 5 points lower than they were at the close of the preceding week.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 16 (AP) -- Communique 81:

CHICAGO, July 16 (AP) -- Billy Talbert of Indianapolis, seeded second, today captured the men's singles title in the River Forest (Ill.) open tennis tournament, easily vanquishing Norman Bickel of Oak Park, Ill., 6-0, 6-2, 6-0.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Larger numbers of buyers were in the market last week, with some caution being noted in placing forward commitments. This was due in part to announcements that additional materials would be made available for civilian goods.

Stiffening of the divorce laws in Russia was cited yesterday by the Rev. Thomas A. Donnellan, assistant chancellor of the Archdiocese of New York, as recognition of the "bad results" that follow "any action or policy contrary to God's law."

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Monday, July 17 -- Germany was subjected yesterday to heavy, wide-spread Allied air attacks aimed at strategic communication centers. Britain-based Flying Fortresses and Liberators, numbering more than 1,000 and escorted by about 500 fighters, struck at Munich and Saarbruecken.
Four new films are slated to arrive in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

MELBOURNE, Australia, July 16 (AP) -- Australian Information Department monitors, who clearly heard the Japanese broadcast yesterday referring to the execution of American airmen, said today the statement was made by "a known irresponsible Singapore commentator."

Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen, Professor of Philosophy at Catholic University of America, urged 1,500 celebrants of the 693d anniversary of the Brown Scapular last night to pray for the "conversion" of Russia and China.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -The Senators defeated the Athletics in both ends of a double-header today, taking the nightcap, 4 to 3, behind Mickey Haefner's tight hurling after bunching a dozen blows for an 8-4 victory in the opener. A crowd of 12,000 turned out.

LONDON, July 16 (U.P.) -- The eerie drone and explosion of robot bombs were heard in London again last night, breaking a lull of five consecutive nights. The missiles struck sporadically by day in the city and in southern England.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Public Service Electric and Gas Company of Newark, N.J., has been directed by the Federal Power Commission to show cause why the commission should not order the company to make adjustments in its plant accounts, involving nearly $68,000,000, established as excess over original cost of facilities, in conformity with the FPC staff's recommendations.

Administration of relief in liberated countries by the Allied armies was criticized yesterday as "pure nonsense" and unfair to both the Army and the victims of war, by Miss Anna Schwarzenberg, executive secretary of the International Council of Nurses.

A spectacular summer thundershower gave to the metropolitan area temporary relief from the heat yesterday, halted air traffic for almost two hours and brought joy to Victory gardeners, but not to commercial farmers.
Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, heard last night over the Blue Network in a radio talk from a tent in the jungle of North Burma, heaped high praise on the Chinese troops in that war theatre.

LONDON, July 16 -- The stock markets here are steadily improving, despite a sharp reduction in activity imposed in earlier days of the flying bomb attacks, on the strength of the news, particularly from Russia, which is having a stimulating effect on sentiment and materially assisting in the general resumption of an upward movement of prices.

SOMEWHERE IN YUGOSLAVIA -- British and American and Yugoslav Partisan forces have combined in a series of coordinated "Commando" raids in recent months to kill or capture large numbers of Germans garrisoning the Dalmatian islands.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- The War Department announced today the award of battle honors in the name of the President to the fighting Seabee unit, officially known as the Fortieth Construction Battalion of the Navy "for outstanding performance of duty on Los Negros Island, where its members fought as they built and employed their few leisure hours off duty to attack the enemy."

PASADENA, Calif., July 16 (AP) -- A letter from Frank Sinatra with a word of encouragement, bolstered by an enclosed $100 check, has been receiveed by J.T. Ross, 20-year-old discharged sailor, and his bride, Rosemary, 22.

PITTSBURGH, July 16 -- The rate of output of steel ingots last week barely reached its pre-holiday level of 96 per cent of capacity, up 1 1/2 points from the Independence Day week period. Indications are that this week it will be at about the same level as last week.

LONDON, July 16 -- A British submarine, in a swift and daring eighteen-minute attack within a mile of the breakwater of a German-held Aegean Sea harbor, recently destroyed seven German ships, damaged several others and then, after a three-hour battle, escaped safely, it was announced tonight.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., July 16 (AP) -- The Eastern Veteran's Tennis championship play at the East Orange Tennis Club succeeded in completing five third-round singles matches and three first-round doubles before today's thunderstorm rained the players out.
KANDY, Ceylon, July 16 (UP) -- A communique:

BERNE, Switzerland, July 16 -- Field Marshal Guenther von Kluge, who succeeded Field Marshal Karl von Rundstedt as Commander in Chief of the German Atlantic front forces, professes to be confident of his ability to defeat the Allied invading forces so decisively they will take back with them a lasting impression of their repulse.

ST. GERMAIN-SUR-AY, Normandy, July 16 (U.P.) -- A number of towns in the western sector are still standing and their civilians are safe in evacuation centers because of the bravery of a French priest who was once a captain in the French army.

LONDON, Monday, July 17 -- Two Soviet armies, storming through some of the most powerful Nazi fortifications in the east, yesterday captured the fortress city of Grodno, the greatest prize before East Prussia.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 16 -- Having reached an agreement with reservations by Russia, France, India and a few other countries on most of the isues involved in an $8,800,000,000 international monetary fund to stabilize post-war currencies, the United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference began today detailed consideration of the proposed $10,000,000,000 International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

The recent order of the War Production Board permitting some consumer goods to go back into production will work to the advantage of the city's industries seeking an early resumption of non-war manufacturing, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 16 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer is planning a musical remake of "Paradise for Three," a comedy produced by the studio in 1938 with Robert Young, Frank Morgan and Mary Astor in the leads and based on "Three Men in the Snow," a German novel by Eric Kaespner.

A nation-wide rating of the importance of manufacturing plants and public services to the war will be carried out by the War Production Board under the direction of its production executive committee in Washington, the regional office of the WPB disclosed yesterday.

DENVER, July 16 (U.P.) -- Fire which swept through a darkened "tunnel of love" in an amusement park here late today killed at least six persons, four of them soldiers and their wives and destroyed the structure. The other two dead were park employes who rushed into the tunnel to rescue the occupants.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, July 16 (UP) -- Allied units closing in on the beleaguered Japanese base of Myitkyina in northern Burma advanced up to 300 yards today from the northwest, killing more than 100 Japanese in the day's operations.
CHUNGKING, China, July 16 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

Automobile traffic over the five bridges controlled by the Triborough Bridge Authority in the first half of 1944 was 48.8 per cent above traffic in the same period of last year, while revenues derived from tolls and parking fees at Jacob Riis Park was 44 per cent over the first half of 1943, according to the semi-annual report issued yesterday.

The Monetary Conference in session at Bretton Woods is the third conference of the United Nations. The first, on Food and Agriculture, was held at Hot Springs in June, 1943. The UNRRA council held its initial meeting in Atlantic City in November of the same year.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- A great impetus to Negro nursing education is being given by the United States Nurse Cadet Corps under the Public Health Service recognizing the medical need among Negroes.

A STRANGE book is published today, a powerful, eloquent, lusty and lyrical book that is also an irritating, perplexing, over-written and inchoate book. "The History of Rome Hanks and Kindred Matters"* is its name and its author is Lieut. Joseph Stanley Pennell. It is unlikely that any novel this year will cause such furious disagreements, such enthusiasm and such rage.
ADVANCE ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Monday, July 17 (AP) -- A communique:

A tenant of the Lyceum since Dec. 30, 1942, "The Doughgirls" will reach the end of its Broadway career on July 29. That stay will represent an engagement of 668 performances for the Joseph Fields comedy, the author's first solo attempt and the theatre's longest run attraction, according to the management's attention-caller.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 16 (AP) -- Armless "Mac" and legless "Tony," veterans of the first World War, plan to show the country's industrial leaders that handicapped men of this war can fill many jobs with the dexterity of normal persons.

PEARL HARBOR, July 16 -- United States carrier planes attacked Guam for the twelfth consecutive day on Saturday, Pacific Fleet Headquarters announced today. Rockets and bombs damaged buildings and set bivouac areas afire.
LONDON, July 16 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:
Mrs. James H. Colfelt of the Weylin has gone to the Irving, Southampton, L. I., for the summer.

The Rev. Dr. Paul Mansfield Spencer, pastor of the undenominational Church of the Strangers, 309 West Fifty-seventh Street, announced his retirement yesterday at a special holy communion service marking the thirty-fifth anniversary of his pastorate.

DETROIT, July 16 (AP) -- Paul Trout won his second game in four days from the White Sox to give the Tigers an even break in a double-header today before 33,307. Detroit took the nightcap, 7 to 3, after Jake Wade pitched a sixhitter in the opener for a 7-to-2 victory, his first of the season.

ROME, July 16 -- Benito Mussoini lost nearly fifty pounds, about one-third of his weight, in the feverish month before his overthrow. I learned this and other facts that throw a new light on Mussolini's ideas in that historic period from a remarkable document today.

LONDON, July 16 -- The United States destroyer Glennon lay wounded in shallow Channel waters off a Normandy beach, her stern broken by an explosion and a sitting target for German shore batteries because her propellers were dug into the sand.

Salvatore Ross, 20 years old, held yesterday in Brooklyn on a charge of grand larceny, told a tale of having traveled 150 miles to Northampton, Mass., in a stolen car and of making the last lap with a tank full of benzene. He was picked up in Northampton on Saturday.

New York's position as an international airport is at least as important strategically as her historic place as a seaport, according to an azimuthal map showing direct great circle distances to be published today by the port of New York Authority.

HONOLULU, T.H., July 16 (U.P.) The New York Yankees' Joe Gordon today joined a galaxy of former major and minor league stars playing for the Seventh Army Air Force nine as the Schofield Redlanders beat the fliers, 8 to 4.

PAWLING, N.Y., July 16 -- Governor Dewey, resuming his conferences with Republican leaders of various States, will meet the party's members of Congress from Maine at Albany tomorrow. Views on the Presidential campaign will be exchanged at a luncheon in the Executive Mansion.
The application of electronics to the food industry now and after the war is being studied by some manufacturers and put into use by others, a check up of leading companies revealed last week.

Through the ages Normandy has been fighting ground. Nine centuries ago it was a battlefield, as it is today. Then William of Normandy was fighting from boyhood to manhood to hold the troubled duchy his father left him. On that field he acquired the military skill that enabled him to conquer England and weld it into a new nation.

ROME, July 16 (AP) -- A dispatch distributed to correspondents in Rome today said on behalf of Marshal Tito of the Yugoslav Partisans that his National Committee of Liberation did not consider itself officially represented in the reorganized Royal Yugoslav Government in London.

CHUNGKING, China, July 16 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command announced tonight that 14,000 Japanese had been killed in the fighting for the Canton-Hankow railway junction of Hengyang between June 23 and July 14. The claim was accepted by foreign observers here with some reserve.

ROME, July 16 (AP) -- A game comeback by Lieut. W.J. Mehl, U.S.N., who overcame the agony of a pulled tendon in the left leg and won a grueling 1,500-meter race, featured the 1944 Allied track and field championships before a crowd of 10,000 today in the Italian Forum, otherwise known as Mussolini Stadium.

While American women are enjoying a not too bad present in cosmetic supplies and can anticipate an expansion of the industry in the post-war era, British women are not too hopeful of even a normal supply after the war's end.

ST. LOUIS, July 16 (AP) -- Harry Brecheen, leading National League pitcher until today, lost his second game of the season as the Reds scored their winning run on a balk to defeat the Cardinals, 3 to 2, in the second game of a doubleheader.

The regional War Labor Board has adopted tentatively approvable salary rates for 55,000 employes of commercial banks in metropolitan New York, it was announced yesterday by Thomas L. Norton, chairman of the board.

Pressing home their attacks with unrelenting vigor which gives the enemy neither rest nor a chance to regroup his forces for a counter-stroke, the armies of the United Nations continue to make progress on all fronts. Every day produces a new crop of victory reports as cheering to the Allies as they are discouraging to Nazi Germany.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (U.P.) -- Dr. H. H. Kung, Chinese Finance Minister, who has been conferring with President Roosevelt, indicated tonight that the United States soon would strengthen China's perilous economic and military position with substantial deliveries of civilian goods and war materials.

CHICAGO, July 16 -- Dr. Ernest A. Hooton of the Department of Anthropology of Harvard University told the final session of the war-time conference of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People today that "racial prejudice is little more than the cloak to cover an apparently universal desire of selfish and morally low-grade human beings to dominate their fellow-beings."

For three weeks, as the Americans in Italy moved into gun range of Leghorn, the French cut through the Tuscan hills, and even the Italians were recovering some villages toward the Adriatic coast, Gen. Sir Oliver Leese's Eighth Army seemed stalled at Olmo Pass in the center of the line.

ABOARD A CARRIER FLAGSHIP, in the Central Pacific, July 9 (Delayed) (AP) -- While Killer Kene's air group scored bomb hits that sank or damaged four Japanese carriers in the June 18-19 Battle of the Marianas, Comdr. William R. Kane became a fighter ace.

An underwriting group headed by Shields Co. has completed an offering of the unexchanged portion of an issue of 35,000 shares of the General Printing Ink Corporation's $4.50 preferred stock at $102.50 a share.

For the seventh time this year, the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose to an all-time high, this time reaching 113.07, which was an increase of 0.1 per cent above the previous week's level of 112.95.

Beginning today, automobile owners will receive broader protection without extra charge not only under new or renewal policies issued from now on but also under policies already in effect, it was announced yesterday by the National Bureau of Casualty and Surety Companies.
MOSCOW, July 16 (U.P.) -- The newspaper Pravda said today that the city of Vilna, part of pre-war Poland, "has once more been returned to the Lithuanian people and returned forever."

In regard to the recent letter from Mrs. Tuckerman, president of the Vivisection Investigation League, protesting the proposed research center at or near the Bronx Zoo, kindly be advised that Mrs. Tuckerman unfortunately completely misunderstood the purpose of this project.

A new twist in confidence rackets, with tickets to Broadway hit shows as the lure, was described by the police yesterday when Edward Lehman, 47 years old, of 349 West Forty-sixth Street, was arraigned in Week-End Court. He was held in $1,000 bail by Magistrate Harry G. Andrews for a hearing tomorrow on a grand larceny charge.

DETROIT, Monday, July 17 (U.P.) -- Production at the Ford Motor Company Willow Run plant, the only plant where four-engined B-24 Liberator bombers are constructed, resumed soon after midnight following intermittent work stoppages Saturday which halted work on all shifts.

CHICAGO, July 16 -- The contest over the Democratic nomination for Vice President was greatly intensified today with official confirmation of reports that President Roosevelt had sent a letter to Chicago "personally" endorsing Vice President Wallace for renomination, but hardly in terms to be considered an ultimatum to the national convention.

In your thought-provoking editorial "Is Ruthlessness Inevitable?" in THE TIMES of July 9, which concludes with these words: "Until the forces of evil are irrevocably destroyed we will continue to seek a positive answer to the question: Does it really pay to be humane?" we are face to face with the choice of being inhumane or of waiting for a repetition of the slaughter that has all but wrecked the world twice in one generation.

Now that the present indirect custodial system has been termed unconstitutional, the Board of Education has not only the opportunity but the responsibility of getting rid of this antiquated plan. For many years the board has operated its school buildings under the indirect method.
Shulton, Inc., toiletry and perfume company, announced yesterday the largest fall advertising schedule in the history of the company. Wesley Associates handles the account.

Sale of E bonds to individual investors is still far below the Fifth War Loan quota set for the city and State and volunteer workers in a house-to-house canvass for the remainder of the month will continue to press the sale of this series, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- In the two years immediately following Pearl Harbor 1,073,000 American business enterprises closed their doors, while only 572,000 new businesses were organized, the Department of Commerce reported today through its publication "Survey of Current Business."

AT THE FRENCH FRONTIER, in Switzerland, July 16 (AP) -- Deep inside France, almost within striking distance of Vichy, French patriots are holding a 140-square-mile area, quietly waiting for the Allies' battle-front to move close enough to warrant their going into action.
A communigue, as broadcast from Chungking yesterday in English to North America and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Approval of an eleven-point program for reconversion and economic development in the post-war period was voted at the midsummer meeting of directors of the United States Chamber of Commerce just ended.

EVER since Bill Bonthron graduated, Coach Matty Geis has been yearning for another mile sensation to bob up on the Princeton campus. Old Nassau has one at long last. He is a junior grade lieutenant who is undergoing his indoctrination at the naval school there. Maybe the name will sound familiar to you. It's Glenn Cunningham.

CHICAGO, July 16 -- James A. Farley, former Postmaster General and former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, known foe of the renomination of President Roosevelt for a fourth term, said today that he would take no part in the contest for the nomination for Vice President.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 16 -- Gas as a purely defensive weapon to replace fixed lines of defense once the Reich is penetrated by the enemy is reported by neutral observers just out of Germany to be receiving "exceptional attention" in semi-official German military quarters.

A plea for a joint proclamation on the requisites of a Christian peace by Pope Pius XII and the Archbishop of Canterbury, chairman of the Provisional Committee of the World Council of Churches, was made yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Bernard Iddings Bell of Providence, R.I., in Trinity Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street.

The arrest of Robert C. O'Grady, a former special attorney in the Customs Division of the Department of Justice here and a draft board official, on a charge of having accepted $250 from a restaurant owner in Rockville Centre, L.I., for a deferred draft classification, was announced yesterday by E.E. Conroy, special agent in charge of the local offices of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

The Hotel Half Moon, the only luxury hotel on the Coney Island waterfront and the tallest building in the resort, was taken over by the Navy at noon yesterday, and, after remodeling, will be used as a convalescent station for naval personnel.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Coal, wood and fuel oil will be short the coming winter, according to a survey based on reports from the Solid Fuels Administration, the Petroleum Administration for War, the Forest Service of the Department of Agriculture, the OPA and other agencies.

A BRITISH ARMY BASE, Somewhere in England, July 16 (Canadian Press) -- In Audrieu in Normandy at least thirty Canadians who died in the invasion were "murdered," according to Lieut. Leo Heaps of Winnipeg.
Bernard Price, formerly with Gimbel Brothers, has been appointed production manager of the sales promotion department of Kirby Block Co.

" More effective use of community resources" represents a marked change in emphasis of the work of the Bureau of Child Guidance and will be continued in the expanding work next year, Dr. Caroline B. Zachry, director of the bureau said yesterday in an interview.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS in New Guinea, Monday, July 17 -- By plugging holes in the jungle-choked front, reinforced American troops have cut off the advance Japanese force that cracked Allied lines on the Driniumor River, twenty-one miles east of Aitape in British New Guinea, headquarters announced today.

LONDON, July 16 -- Royal Air Force Typhoon fighter-bombers now carry a 1,000-pound bomb under each wing -- twice their former load and more than double that of the medium bombers Britain was using at the start of the war -- the Air Ministry disclosed tonight.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Tuesday, July 18 -- In widespread attacks on Japanese lines of communications Saturday and Sunday, Allied planes sank or heavily damaged five ships totaling 16,500 tons in Netherlands Indies waters, exclusive of barges and small coastal craft, Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters announced today.

Four weeks after the defeat of the Japanese fleet in the Philippine sea and nine days after the American conquest of Saipan, the Japanese Navy Minister, Admiral Shimada, has been ousted from his post. It was to be expected that some high-ranking Japanese would have to pay the price for the successive disasters to Japanese arms in order to save Emperor Hirohito's face.

The Taft amendment to the Soldier Voting Law was not "designed," as Senator Taft has testified, to keep American soldiers and sailors from reading serious books, but it has certainly proved "calculated" to produce that effect. The present controversy as to its application in the Army reveals a ludicrous situation.

Within a week after receiving a tip that counterfeits of the Federal automobile use tax stamps were being sold in western New York the United States Secret Service broke up the ring, John J. McGrath, supervising agent for the New York District, disclosed yesterday in announcing eleven arrests in Buffalo, Rochester and Syracuse.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Documents and pictures purporting to show connections between the German-American Bund and the Ku Klux Klan and to prove that at least one defendant raised the hint that President Roosevelt is of Jewish ancestry were submitted to the jury in the mass sedition trial today.

With "ten or twelve requests for every domestic servant we can find," the New York City office of the War Relocation Authority succeeded in placing nearly 80 per cent of the 137 Japanese who came to this district in June from nine West and Midwest relocation offices, Director E. Price Steiding announced yesterday in his office in the Empire State Building, 350 Fifth Avenue.

Fritz Kreisler, at last yielding to the call of the air, made his first broadcast last night. The distinguished violinist, the last of the major prophets of interpretative musical art to consent to appear on a radio program, appeared in the Bell Telephone System's "The Telephone Hour" at 9 o'clock, over the National Broadcasting Company's network.
ROME, July 17 (AP) -- A communique:
KANDY, Ceylon, July 17 (UP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- Reports in Latin-American capitals that the United States and Britain were preparing to appease Argentina were denounced today by Secretary of State Cordell Hull as deliberately false.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The War Production Board topped today its 1944 goal of 2,000,000 electric irons by authorizing the manufacture of another 278,500 units by four manufacturers, the eighth group to be assigned quotas under the program.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- Sidney R. Fleisher, a New York lawyer, was listed today as the top man in the Treasury's report of 1942 corporation payments to individuals for personal services.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation virtually has completed arrangements for the sale of $60,000,000 of new notes to institutional investors. The proceeds of the financing will be used to retire slightly in excess of that amount of the company's 3 1/2 per cent convertible debentures and serial debentures now outstanding.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Saving this year's bumper fruit crop, expected to be 18 per cent higher than in 1943 for the eight major deciduous fruits, is the job ahead for the Women's Land Army, according to its director, Miss Florence Hall.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (U.P.) -- Eggs, fresh fruit, vegetables, butter and other perishable foods continued to pile up in public warehouses in June, the War Food Administration reported tonight.

WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, July 17 (Netherlands News Agency) -- Oil companies of the Royal Dutch group have prepared detailed plans for the rehabilitation of properties in the Netherlands East Indies and in British possessions in the Far East and these plans are ready for execution, the Royal Dutch Petroleum Company disclosed in its annual report today.

Something quite as delightful as it sounds is mint marshmallow whip -- a smooth, fluffy marshmallow preparation of pale green that is infused with fresh tang. This newest acquisition of Altman's grocery department is offered by the California Fruit Chimes Co., San Gabriel, Calif.

Two large East Side apartment houses were sold yesterday by the New York Life Insurance Company. The thirteen-story and penthouse structure at 1145 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of Ninety-sixth Street, was bought by Frederick Brown, and the twelve-story building at 1238 to 1242 Madison Avenue and 17 East Eighty-ninth Street was bought by Peter Doelger, Inc.

CHUNGKING, China, July 17 (UP) -- A strong Japanese force penetrated the southern section of Hengyang, broke into the municipal hospital and threatened to drive on into the heart of the beleaguered Hunan Province city, a communique announced today, but the Chinese garrison regrouped in time, retook the hospital and smashed the enemy thrust in a desperate two-hour counter-attack.

The Tri-Continental Corporation reported yesterday that its net assets on June 30 were $36,573,193, equal after providing for debt and preferred stock to $6.20 a share on the common stock, comparing with $32,760,010, or $4.63 a share, on Dec. 31, and with $34,355,600, or $4.88 a share, on June 30, 1943.

Sales of all categories of bonds in New York City on Saturday added $23,004,810 to its Fifth War Loan total, making $5,023,359,198, Nevil Ford, State chairman of the War Finance Committee, announced yesterday. This gave the city 120.6 per cent of its $4,167,028,000 all-investor quota.

A gentle rain is all right in its place and time, say spring or fall and somewhere between dusk and dawn, but for sheer sensuous satisfaction no gentle rain can match a sudden downpour such as that which swept in from the north Sunday afternoon to break the heat wave and revive the browning lawns and pastures of suburbania and up-State New York.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- British merchant ships, despite the Nazi blockade of the Skagerrak, have this winter been maintaining a special service to Sweden, according to the British Information Services here.

" Return of the Ape Man," with Bela Lugosi and John Carradine, and "Sundown Valley," a Western starring Charles Starrett, compose the week's new double-feature pro gram, starting today, at the New York Theatre.

BOSTON, July 17 (AP) -- The Greentree Stable's Dockstader qualified nicely for Saturday's $25,000 added Mayflower Stakes today at Suffolk Downs by scoring a neck decision in the $3,500 General Eisenhower Purse.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow radio to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

CHICAGO, July 17 (/P) -- Three ol the top four spots in the America League batting race were monopo, lized today by members of th third-place Red Sox, with Pete Fo2 taking over the lead from Bobby Doerr by notching .329.

Although Congress has eliminated the highest price line limitation, the Office of Price Administration has declined to drop the suits that it has brought against leading chain store organizations for alleged violations of the limitation, it was learned here yesterday.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Tuesday, July 18 -- Infantrymen of the United States First Army hacked a path through stubborn German defenses east of St. Lo yesterday and by last night they had established positions in the outskirts of the shattered town while combat patrols were smashing their way from house to house toward the heart of the town on which Field Marshal Gen. Erwin Rommel's line in western Normandy is anchored.

Illegal trafficking in gasoline ration stamps in the Third District Naval Intelligence office, 90 Church Street, was revealed yesterday with the testimony of several witnesses called during the first day's proceedings in the general court-martial of Albert R. Doerr Jr., 23 years old, yeoman second class, USN, in the Navy Yard, Brooklyn.

Baseball addicts of this town will have to wait until nightfall for their entertainment, what with the Yankees on the road and both the Giants and Dodgers playing under the floodlights tonight. At the Polo Grounds the Giants, who did not fare too well in the hinterlands, but returned in better condition than the Dodgers, will tackle Frankie Frisch and his Pirates, while the Brooks take on the pace-setting Cardinals over at Ebbets Field.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- Mrs. J. Borden Harriman, former United States Minister to Norway, told reporters today that the kind of feminine delegate she would like to see appointed to the peace conference was typified by Mrs. Anne O'Hare McCormick of THE NEW YORK TIMES, Mrs. Ogden Reid of The New York Herald Tribune and Miss Dorothy Thompson of The New York Post.

Alicia Markova and Anton Dolin were the stars at the Lewisohn Stadium last night in the only dance program scheduled for the season, and the crowd which assembled to see them numbered some 22,000. This is the largest audience that has attended a dance performance at the stadium in many seasons, which may indicate that the out-of-doors dance public is more interested in one or two stellar personalities than in presentations of full ballets.
The Japanese Board of Information announced yesterday that Admiral Shigetaro Shimada had been replaced as Japanese Navy Minister by Admiral Naokuni Nomura, commander of the Kure naval station.

New York State yesterday levied transfer taxes of $1,775,155 on the estate of Viscount Astor (William Waldorf Astor), American-born British peer, who died at Hever Castle, Kent, England, on Oct. 18, 1919. He left an estate of $46,173,690, according to an appraisal filed yesterday in the State Transfer Tax Office.

TRENTON, N.J., July 17 (AP) -- The State Supreme Court decided today to reopen the John Longo appeal case to go into details on the question whether evidence relating to the findings of a handwriting expert was suppressed at his trial.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 17 -- Discarding all further pretense of "elastic defense," German home service broadcasters, since early this morning have transmitted appeals and urgent "reminders" to the population of East Prussia that it stands as an "advance bastion of defense to the sacred soil of the Reich."

MOSCOW, July 17 -- Pravda, the Communist party organ, declared today that the Republican Convention last month was dominated by "old reactionary leaders," and that its foreign policy plank was a "step backward" as compared with the Mackinac Declaration.

ABOARD A U.S. CARRIER FLAGSHIP, off the Marianas Islands, June 26 (Delayed) (AP) -- Shot down near Guam, rescued by a seaplane while under fire, and then finishing their day as spectators aboard a destroyer that dared the fire of Japanese shore artillery to dash in and sink a big freighter -- that's the story of torpedo pilot Charles S. Brookes and his crew.

Asserting that we still have not started to meet the munitions requirements of the armed services, Lewis S. Greenleaf Jr., War Production board regional director, declared yesterday that the nation's production lines "must speedily exceed the highest peaks of production that we have yet reached."

WITH AMERICAN FORCES IN NORMANDY, July 17 -- Our troops forced their way within the city limits of St. Lo today and then withdrew to points in the eastern outskirts of the town. But they were under heavy counter-attack and savage artillery fire tonight, and the last long mile is still ahead of them before they can claim this key point in the present German line.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- Supporters of President Roosevelt are in complete control of the Democratic National Convention, with Robert E. Hannegan filling the dual role of Democratic National Chairman and personal representative of the President, positions held respectively by James A. Farley and Harry L. Hopkins at the party's convention here four years ago.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The proved possibility of the holding down of jobs in foundries by women was stressed today by Paul V. McNutt. The chairman of the War Manpower Commission made the observation in launching a campaign to recruit 20,000 men for the forge and foundry industry.

Whether or not the man Benito Mussolini is alive today is uncertain. We do know, on authority of a medical document for which this newspaper's correspondent in Rome, Herbert L. Matthews, vouches, that this person had duodenal ulcers as early as 1923, that the trouble recurred in 1929, and that a year ago they cost him a loss of fifty pounds during the last month of his Roman rule.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Tuesday, July 18 (AP) -- A communique:

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 17 -- The closing date of the United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference, originally scheduled for Wednesday, was postponed today until Saturday because discussions of the proposed $10,000,000,000 International Bank for Reconstruction and Development have been stalled by demands of various countries for lower capital subscriptions.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The War Department said today that Lieut. Gen. William S. Knudsen would head a new Air Forces Materiel and Services Command and that Brig. Gen. Kenneth B. Wolfe, who formerly headed the Twentieth Bomber Command, which bombed Japan with the new B-29 Superfortresses, would be one of his deputies.
NOBODY ever learned anything by asking questions," says John Dos Passos in his latest travel book, "State of the Nation."*
There are those who disagree with Judge Learned Hand's statement, in his address on "I Am an American Day," that "the spirit of liberty is the spirit which is not too sure that it i right."

Major oil companies, with few exceptions, will discontinue the sale of soft lines in the service stations after the war and will revert primarily to merchandise linked with the sale of petroleum products, it was learned yesterday from retail sales executives of large oil concerns operating chains of filling stations.

ALBANY, July 17 -- Governor Dewey announced tonight that he will visit Pittsburgh July 31 on his way to the Republican Governors' conference at St. Louis, and that he is determined to unite the Republican party in its approach to the problem of reconverting the country's industry from war to peace production.

ROME, July 17 (AP) -- An official Allied announcement said tonight that "a general advance has been made along the whole front, but strong German resistance is expected along the line of the Arno to the sea and thus further progress through the mountains between Arezzo and Florence may be expected to be hard fought and difficult."

A large number of commercial truck operators in New York City will put into effect the Office of Price Administration's new plan, intended to help curb the black market, permitting delayed payments by ration checks for gasoline bought at filling stations by drivers, Daniel P. Woolley, Regional OPA Administrator, said yesterday.

Frank Hurley and Pat Ciuci of Salisbury sliced six strokes from par to win the weekly one-day amateur-pro tournament of the Long Island Professional Golfers Association with 33, 33 -- 66, over the Pomonok Country Club course in Flushing yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- The faithful among the first Democratic Convention delegates to hit town prayed that the current cool wave may hold. The city was comfortable under overcast skies, with fresh breezes off the lake. The local forecaster said he's reasonably sure the thermometer won't go above 92 during the convention.

Virtually all leading oil companies will report improved earnings in the first half of this year over the similar period of 1943. The gain reflects a larger volume of sales, particularly to the various agencies of the United States Government.

BOSTON, July 17 (AP) -- The highly polished Willie Pep of Hartford, Conn., left-jabbed and hooked himself into a clear-cut decision over Manuel Ortiz of El Centro, Calif., in the ten-round non-title bout waged by those champions tonight before a 10,000 crowd at Braves Field.

ALBANY, July 17 -- Large numbers of workers in aircraft and shipbuilding plants in New York State were laid off in the period from middle of May to the middle of June, depressing the employment figures 1.3 per cent, with a decline of 0.7 per cent in payrolls, according to Edward Corsi, Industrial Commissioner.

SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, July 17 (AP) -- Allied forces have removed a formidable barrier to the advance southward in India along the Tiddim Road with occupation of a heavily fortified village which was reduced by a tremendous artillery barrage, headquarters announced tonight.

The prank of a skylarking young foursome who invaded the Central Park Zoo at 2 A.M. yesterday and clambered over a 3-foot protective railing to bait a polar bear ended disastrously when the aroused animal turned on one of the girls and tore her arm off at the elbow.

Three jockeys had things all to their liking on the Empire City Racing Association's program at the Jamaica track yesterday. These monopolists were Johnny Longden, Ted Atkinson and Bobby Permane, who combined to sweep the seven-race card.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 17 -- For the second successive week, Clarence Doser, Scarsdale pro, and C.W. (Gus) Benedict, Winged Foot amateur, shared the spotlight in Westchester P.G.A. one-day competition, taking honors in respective flights at the Elmwood Country Club today.

CIVITELLA, Italy, July 17 (U.P.) -- This is the home town of death. There is death in the sound of creaking shutters. There is death in the sickening shell pouring from crumbling masonry, in the soiled baby's shoe on the doorstep, in the blood-stained flagstones.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Corporate profits for the first three months of this year held at a high level, with earnings after taxes estimated at $2,213,000,000 as compared with $2,200,000,000 for the first quarter of 1943, reflecting the stability of operations in industry, according to preliminary reports published in the July "Survey of Current Business" of the Department of Commerce.

Even before the critical shortage of lumber began to slow up the production of all kinds of furniture, children's furniture was on the hard-to-get list. The shortage was especially noticeable because there are few manufacturers in the children's field, and since early spring it has become even worse.
LONDON, Tuesday, July 18 (AP) -- German flying bomb attacks on southern England continued throughout the night and an alert was sounded in the London area.

The proposed line for an express highway through Fairfield County, Connecticut, from the New York boundary to a point just east of the Saugatuck River in Westport, has been submitted to town and city officials by William J. Cox, State Highway Commissioner. Mr. Cox pointed out that the plan involves no immediate steps toward construction and that, as the result of discussion, minor details of the route may be changed.

Gen Dwight D. Eisenhower's warning to Germany that French patriots were considered part of the Allies' armies in France brought a retort from Berlin yesterday that all Frenchmen were bound by the French-German armistice and that those who refused to abide by its terms would be dealt with accordingly, The Associated Press reported.

Capt Dan Topping, USMC, president; Tom Gallery, general manager; Pete Cawthon, coach, and John McDonald, secretary of the Brooklyn Tigers, formerly and more familiarly known as the Brooklyn Football Dodgers, were hosts at a luncheon at Toots Shor's yesterday, when they outlined plans and hopes for the forthcoming National Football League campaign.

American-bred luxury furs were spotlighted in a show presented yesterday by I.J. Fox. Chinchilla, platina fox and silver blue minks bred in America were prominent in a preview that covered other luxury furs and exhibited deft tailoring in a variety of styles.
BOSTON, July 17 -- William James Sidis, boy prodigy of thirty-five years ago, who was graduated from Harvard at the age of 16, died today in a hospital. His age was 46.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 17 -- Irene Manning has been named by Warner Brothers for the second feminine lead in "A Night at Tony Pastor's" a "gay Nineties" vaudeville comedy, scheduled for fall production, with Ann Sheridan and Dennis Morgan in the romantic leads.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- Freedom of all men to gather news without interference from governments and to transmit it quickly at uniform communications rates will increase understanding among countries and promote peace, Kent Cooper, executive director and general manager of The Associated Press, told the resolutions committee of the Democratic National Committee today.

OLD ORCHARD BEACH, Me., July 17 (AP) -- The veteran Tom Berry drove winners in five of the ten heats at the Old Orchard Beach track as an eighteen-day Grand Circuit light harness racing meet got under way today.

Efforts to interest Miriam Hopkins in "The Perfect Marriage" have proved successful, it became known yesterday. She will be costarred with Victor Jory in the Samson Raphaelson play, which Cheryl Crawford will escort to the stage.
LONDON, July 17 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Trade controls will be relaxed as speedily as possible after the war, but only after basic transitional problems have been worked out between this country and Great Britain, Charles P. Taft, director of Wartime Economic Affairs of the Department of State, said last night.

WASHINGTON, July 17- Nurses will be recruited at the rate of 1,000 a month for the Army and 500 a month for the Navy until 5,500 Army nurses and 3,000 Navy nurses have been added to the present strength, Chairman Paul V. McNutt of the War Manpower Commission announced today.

UNFORTUNATELY, though, these particular Tigers don't want to be held. They aim to be wild, ferocious and unrestrained. They are the Brooklyn Tigers of the National Football League, yclept Dodgers, and their brain department gathered at Toots Shor's yesterday for a get-together with the Gentlemen of the Press.

The stock market sustained yesterday its worst reversal in three months as liquidation in the steels and motors ignited a wave of selling that soon spread throughout the list. Extreme retreats ranged to 3 points in Bethlehem Steel, but closing prices revealed the recovery of about one-half of the declines, with support appearing in the last thirty minutes of trading.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The Army Medical Corps was reported today to have on hand only a three-day supply of vials used as penicillin and blood plasma containers because of a week-old strike of about 1,500 members of the AFL American Flint Glass Workers Union at the Vineland, N.J., plant of the Kimball Glass Company.
ROME, July 17 -- The Arno River was crossed yesterday in a surprise dash by British Eighth Army units that had taken Arezzo.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- Undercurrents of revolt against the New Deal and a fourth term for President Roosevelt made it virtually certain tonight that the renomination of Mr. Roosevelt by the Democratic National Convention will not be by acclamation, or even unanimous.
CHICAGO, July 17 (AP) -- The four seeded players in the junior division of the River Forest open tennis tournament won their matches today and advanced to the third round.

CANBERRA, Australia, July 17 (AP) -- Prime Minister John Curtin told Parliament today that though a transfer of main British efforts must await Germany's defeat large and powerful forces would become available this year in the war against Japan.

I read the letter of Professor John Hanna in your issue of July 14 with a growing sense of uneasiness. In his first paragraph he seemed to be setting up all the safeguards of our domestic law for the benefit of the German war criminals, a procedure which would enable a great percentage of them to escape justice.

CHICAGO, July 17 (AP) -- Twilight Tear scored by a length today over Pensive, the Kentucky Derby and Preakness Stakes winner, in Arlington Park's Isolater Purse, a tune-up for Saturday's $50,000 added Arlington classic. It was the second time the Calumet Farm's little filly beat her champion stable-mate and was her tenth consecutive victory.

A Japanese Imperial Headquarters announcement claimed yesterday that the Japanese forces had "shot down, heavily damaged or set ablaze" a total of 1,460 "enemy" planes, including eleven B-29 Superfortresses, during June, while losing only 369 of their own aircraft.

ROME, July 17 -- Another of what is becoming a series of sharp political attacks against the Allies was made in today's Voce Repubblicana, by Randolfo Pacciardi, former commander of the Garibaldini during the Spanish civil war. Signor Pacciardi likewise lashed out against Premier Ivando Bonomi's government as being "fictitious and farcical."

TRENTON, N.J., July 17 (AP) -- More than half of the $60,000,000 in delinquent taxes and interest which the State Court of Errors and Appeals has held that seven railroads owe New Jersey for the period 1932 through 1940 has been collected in less than a week, Controller Homer C. Zink reported today.

" Meet me at the fountain near the Mall" brought out so many embryo artists for the free art classes sponsored by the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office that yesterday CDVO disclosed an expansion of its summer art program.

Every United Service Organizations club in the continental United States will receive five copies of a nine-page digest of the various State service men's voting laws, it was learned yesterday after a meeting in the Empire State Building of the USO national program committee.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- The choice of a Democratic candidate for Vice President was thrown wide open for the party's forthcoming national convention tonight when a letter was received here from President Roosevelt saying, in effect, that he would not dictate the renomination of Vice President Henry A. Wallace.

VINELAND, N.J., July 17 -- About 1,500 members of the American Flint Glass Workers Union remained on strike this afternoon despite appeals by Harry H. Cook, international union president, to return to their jobs at Kimble Glass Company and follow orderly proceedings set up by Congress in handling wage disputes.

LLANERCH, Pa., July 17 (AP) -- Joe Zarhardt, 39, Jeffersonville, Pa., pro, clipped par by six strokes to win the 1944 Philadelphia open golf championship with a 36-hole total of 138 at the Llanerch Country Club today.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 17 (AP) -- Miss Pauline Betz, Los Angeles, national tennis champion, made her first competitive appearance here today by defeating two opponents in the opening round of the forty-fourth annual Pennsylvania and Eastern States lawn tennis championship at the Merion Cricket Club.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y. July 17 -- Eight thousand persons gathered in Kingsland Point Park here this noon to great Aviation Ordnance Mate Kenneth Bratton of the Navy, hero of a fight with Japanese Zeros over Rabaul, and to watch Rear Admiral Clark H. Woodward present the Air Medal to him.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast domestically in Finland and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

CHICAGO, July 17 -- The national Political Action Committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations is not only supporting Henry Wallace for the Democratic Vice Presidential nomination, but has assembled a formidable team here to work in his behalf.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., July 17 (AP) -- An 82-year-old father and his middle-aged son, missing fourteen years and declared legally dead six years ago, were reunited on a railroad depot platform here tonight in an exchange of embraces and kisses.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The United States has paid $4,000,000 to the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration to cover this country's share of administrative expenses of the organization during this year, Herbert H. Lehman, director general of the agency, announced today.

LONDON, Tuesday, July 18 -- Red Army forces, in a sensational twenty-five-mile advance down the Minsk-Warsaw highway, pushed to within fifteen miles north of the Polish fortress city of Brest-Litovsk yesterday, while a northern Soviet spearhead smashed two miles into Latvia.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a rise of 14 per cent for the week ended July 15, according to the flash report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the preceding week the bank had reported a gain of 2 per cent in volume.

The Aviation Corporation had a consolidated net income in the six months ended with May of $2,317,853 after all charges, including Federal taxes, according to the report of Victor Emanuel, president, issued for publication today. The result is equivalent to 40 cents each on the 5,793,513 shares of capital stock and compares with $1,902,164, or 33 cents a share, in the corresponding period of the preceding year.
CHICAGO, July 17 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows:
LONDON, July 17 -- The Stock markets here today showed renewed firmness, with industrials attracting additional buyers.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- The United Mine Workers Journal, edited by K.C. Adams, who also serves as a spokesman for John L. Lewis, today endorsed the Dewey-Bricker ticket of the Republican party. A four-page article in the current issue also praised the labor and security plans of the Republican platform.

Persons who have been transplanted into completely new surroundings are far more receptive to modern design in the home than those living in the same environment they grew up in, said Richard J.
