Neutra, architect and designer, addressing the Home Furnishings Division of the Fashion Group at luncheon in the Murray Hill Hotel yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, July 17 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission was asked today to approve a plan providing for the sale by the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation to the New York Power and Light Corporation of all the outstanding capital stock of the Hudson Valley Fuel Corporation, in exchange for 192,105 shares of the no-par value common stock of New York Power.

MOSCOW, July 17 -- A part of the German Army -- 57,000 "strong" -- marched through the streets of Moscow today, but not in the role of conquerors, as Chancellor Hitler mistakenly dreamed three years ago.

CHICAGO, July 17 (AP) -- Senator Carl A. Hatch of New Mexico said tonight that he would sponsor a clear-cut Democratic platform declaration for a world-wide free press as "a guarantee against future wars."

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Long under consideration among the four big powers, exploratory conversations on an international organization for maintaining peace have been agreed upon and will be held here, beginning probably early next month, Secretary of State Cordell Hull announced tonight.

Isn't it strange that the newest instrument of h,,mRU destruction contrived by the Nazis has aroused so little indignation by the public? If newspaper accounts are accurate, the robot bombs cannot be aimed at any particular objective, but only into some wide area like London.

A number of landlords in the garment district may abandon their insistence on five-year leases, Mervin C. Pollak, special attorney of the Department of Justice, announced yesterday after he had interviewed about nine of the landlords in his office at 30 Broad Street.

In plain view of many passersby along Broadway, a holdup man fatally shot Paul Volchok, 45-year-old proprietor of the Paradise Lingerie Shop at 2666 Broadway, between 101st and 102d Streets, at 10 A.M. yesterday. Several persons who had seen the killing chased the slayer up Broadway to 102d Street, then to Amsterdam Avenue, and back to 101st Street, where he disappeared into a building.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 17 (AP) -- Three Swedes just returned from Munich estimated today that the Bayrische Motorenwerke, where the Germans were believed to be manufacturing engines for flying bombs, was 80 per cent destroyed.

C.

Grayson Shops, Inc., operators of a chain of more than forty ladies' ready-to-wear stores throughout the country, have taken a twenty-year lease on the entire property at 43-45 West Thirty-fourth Street and the upper floors at 41 West Thirty-fourth Street.

PEARL HARBOR, July 17 -- A one-sided duel between shore batteries on the island of Guam and a powerfully gunned force of the Pacific Fleet, including battleships, cruisers and destroyers, took place on Saturday, Pacific Fleet headquarters announced late today.

Genuine international economic cooperation after the war will be possible only if there is a profound change from the ideology of the Thirties. Nations must learn that their own economic salvation is not to be attained by making economic war upon their neighbors.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 17 (AP) -- Three Swedes just returned from Munich estimated today that the Bayrische Motorenwerke, where the Germans were believed to be manufacturing engines for flying bombs, was 80 per cent destroyed.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- While the reaction of many delegates and observers tonight to the Roosevelt letter on Vice President Henry A. Wallace was that it had "finished" Mr. Wallace so far as the renomination for the Vice-Presidency was concerned, Mr. Wallace's supporters took an entirely different point of view.

Glenn Stadler, Columbia Broadcasting System correspondent, reporting from Madrid last night, said Gen. Francisco Franco, speaking at the annual meeting of the Falange Party's National Council, "repeated his previous offer of Spain's good offices for peace."

PHILADELPHIA, July 17 (AP) -- Pennsylvania Gas and Electric Corporation, Wilmington, Del., today asked the Securities and Exchange Commission's approval of a series of transactions leading to the liquidation and dissolution of Old Dominion Gas and Electric Corporation, Petersburg, Va.

Norbert Brown has been appointed manager of public relations of F.W. Dodge Corporation. With the exception of last year, when he served as field director of the National Committee on Housing, Inc., Mr. Brown has been associated with the Dodge organization as an editor and manager since 1929.

A four-point program to overcome after the war the lack of adequate marketing facilities for electrical equipment, which is believed to be the principal obstacle to the sale of complete kitchen installations, has been set up by the Edison General Electric (Hotpoint) Appliance Company, Inc., it was revealed yesterday by H.E. Warren, advertising division manager.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 17 (AP) -- Communique 83:
CHUNGKING, China, July 17 (AP) -- A communique:

CHICAGO, July 17 -- The changes which the President's long tenure, the state of war and the shifting sources of normal political power have had on the Democratic party are strongly in evidence here as the leaders assemble.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- More numerous, more official and more vocal than ever before in the history of the party, Democratic women got off to a lively start in the pre-convention program, in the renewal of an old feud before the resolutions sub-committee this afternoon.

The New York State Public Service Commission issued new regulations yesterday under which all gas utilities in the State henceforth will be required to install gas mains and connections within a public street to a customer's property line at their own expense.

Continued favorable war news from Europe and fears of a sudden peace induced yesterday considerable liquidation in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange, where final prices were 1 point lower to 1 point higher than Saturday's closing levels.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Tuesday, July 18 -- Detour signs on railways, roads and bridges leading from the German supply pools to the Normandy battle front began to appear almost on the very borders of France yesterday after American heavy bombers from Britain and Italy and the Royal Air Force's big planes made one of the strongest series of attacks yet undertaken against enemy communications in France.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- The problem of reconciling with the known views of the Southern Democrats the demands of Negro voters for au anti-discrimination plank confronted the subcommittee of the resolutions committee today as it opened hearings preparatory to drafting the platform for the Democratic National Convention.

A UNITED STATES BOMBER BASE in Britain, July 17 (AP) -- Two engines of the Flying Fortress piloted by Lieut. Gwynne Skelton were dead and the entire nose section was blown off, but the youthful skipper flew on to the target and then topped off the day by saving a wounded gunner after a crash landing in the English Channel.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- George P. McNear Jr., president of the Toledo, Peoria and Western Railroad, which is being operated by the Government sought permission some time ago to borrow $100,000 for working capital for the road, but the Interstate Commerce Commission asked Mr. McNear how he proposed to pay the note and interest and so far he has failed to reply, it was stated today.
A nostalgic feeling prompts me to differ with the one who in THE TIMES of July 10 questioned a point in the re, cent editorial, "Swinging the Scythe."
WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- A Pacific Fleet announcement:

Officials of the Consumers Public Power District of Nebraska announced yesterday they would receive on July 26 bids on $1,400,000 of the District's North Platte Division revenue refunding bonds. The securities will be dated Aug. 1, 1944, and will mature from 1945 to 1950.

A decrease in the enrollments of teachers' colleges sharper than that suffered by any other professional group during this war, and a supplementary lowering of the standards of teacher preparation, can in a large part be attributed to the fact that the American people have failed to recognize the importance of training teachers adequately to guide children in democratic citizenship, Dr. Edward S. Evenden, Professor of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University, declared yesterday.
Pending war developments and the announcement of revised cotton goods ceilings, trading in cotton futures slowed yesterday and prices at the close were 5 to 7 points lower.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, ON NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, July 19 (UP) -- A communique:

It is disheartening for a pregnant woman to board a crowded bus and face a solid phalanx of sitting men, not one of whom will offer his seat; and finally, after one tries to balance a clumsy body in a narrow aisle, have a middle-aged woman clamber over laps to give up her seat.
KANDY, Ceylon, July 18 (UP) -- A communique:

Increasing military demands upon the oil industry indicate that fuel oil for civilian use will be even scarcer than coal next winter, John D. Collins, director-in-charge of District 1 of the Petroleum Administration for War, warned yesterday in an effort to head off an abnormal upsurge in the number of applications from home owners and industrial consumers for oil allotments to permit conversion from coal to oil.

The Owensboro (Ky.) Bridge Commission sold yesterday $1,325,000 of bridge revenue refunding bonds, due Aug. 1, 1967, callable on or after Aug. 1, 1946, to Almstedt Brothers, Louisville, Ky., and associates on their bid of 100.34 for a 2 1/4 per cent coupon.

The President's letter to the Democratic convention about Mr. Wallace can only be read as a disavowal of any intention on his part to attempt to dictate the choice of a Vice Presidential candidate, as he did four years ago. Mr. Wallace is warmly described in this letter as a "personal friend," for whose nomination the President would vote if he were a delegate.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- Sharp controversy over the racial issue stirred the Democratic resolutions committee today as it labored to complete an acceptable platform for presentation to the national convention on Thursday.

BAYONNE, N.J., July 18 (AP) -- A tightening of restrictions concerning Italian prisoners of war stationed at the Army Port Johnston Terminal in Bayonne was assured today, Mayor Bert Daly announced after a meeting with Army officers.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- As the tug-of-war between two determined factions of women stiffened today into what is developing as an epochal fight over insertion in the Democratic platform of a plank favoring submission to the States of an Equal Rights amendment to the Constitution, wordage on the theme grew apace in the records of the resolutions subcommittee.

New figures indicating the magnitude of overseas traffic by air under the Air Transport Command were made public here yesterday. Lieut. Col. Richard L. Meiling of the Air Surgeons Office revealed that in a recent month the ATC had returned 3,839 patients to the United States from overseas.
LONDON, July 18 -- Today's stock markets here again were cheerful and further buying was seen among industrial equities. Gilt-edge stocks were in good demand, although prices remained unchanged.

The drive for a $10,000,000,000 International Bank for Reconstruction and Development illustrates once more the fetish of machinery that possesses the minds of the governmental delegates at Bretton Woods. Like the proposed $8,800,000,000 International Monetary Fund, it rests on the assumption that nothing will be done right unless a grandiose formal intergovernmental institution is set up to do it.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The long-awaited agreement between Washington and the French Committee of National Liberation covering civil administration in military areas in France is approaching completion, it was said tonight in circles in touch with the negotiations.
ALBANY, July 18 -- Governor Dewey declared today that a group with "unlimited financial resources' was "playing politics with the right of New York State's fighting men to vote."

The way Republicans harp upon their twenty-six Governors one wonders why the Republicans have gone to the trouble of nominating candidates for President and Vice President, and why are they making additional preparations to elect a Republican House of Representatives.

Thefts of gasoline coupons to the value of 24,000 gallons from the Naval Intelligence Office of the Third District were disclosed yesterday at a general court-martial on black market dealings at which Albert R. Doerr Jr., yeoman second class, was found guilty on two of four charges, after conflicting testimony by Government witnesses.

MOSCOW, July 18 -- A sharp attack upon the "reactionary policies" of the Chinese Government which assertedly create disunity among the Chinese people and prevent full collaboration of the entire armed forces of the country for defeat of the Japanese invaders was published today in War and the Working Class.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The German General Staff is aware of Germany's inevitable defeat and has already made "detailed plans for a later renewal of its attempt to dominate the world," Sumner Welles, former Under-Secretary of State, declares in a book to be published tomorrow.

WHENEVER professional football men gather for a bit of conversational bag punching they always get around to discussing Don Hutson. They can't miss. The Green Bay Packer wonder has performed so many incredible feats on the gridiron that any recountal of spectacular plays automatically includes more on the Alabama Antelope than any other athlete.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 18 -- "China Sky," the Pearl S. Buck novel of China under Japanese invasion, which has been on and off the RKO filming schedule several times during the last three years, now has a definite starting date, Aug. 17.

The Bronx -- "abode of the Yankees, borough of universities and culture, the local home for the finest Holland tulip bulbs" -- has a new distinction. In the words of its chief panegyrist, Borough President James J. Lyons, the Bronx now has "the finest doghouse in the world."

CHICAGO, July 18 -- With Vice President Wallace rushing here from Washington to fight personally for his renomination and his opponents trying desperately but thus far unsuccessfully to center on a champion, the Democratic National Convention, scheduled to open at the Chicago Stadium at 11:30 A.M. tomorrow, appeared tonight to face the real possibility of an old-time Democratic battle royal over the selection of a running mate for President Roosevelt.

The racketeer record of Joseph (Socks) Lanza a decade ago in Fulton Fish Market labor union extortions was recalled yesterday when Salvatore (Salvie) Gencarelli, 39 years old, the last of six men who were indicted with Lanza, was arraigned in General Sessions and his pleading on the indictment was put off by Judge Jonah J. Goldstein until tomorrow.
AMERICAN FIRST ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Normandy, July 18 -- The United States Army is engaged in one of the most brutal slugging matches in its history in the hedgerows of Normandy.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Ellis O. Jones, one of the twenty-six defendants in the mass sedition trial, circulated a publication charging that President Roosevelt was trying to get this nation into war against Germany at the behest of Jewish advisers, the jury was told today.
CHUNGKING, China, July 18 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

There are two misnomers whose daily application by the press and radio is quite dangerous -- the use of Nazi instead of German, of nationalist for isolationist. Headlines often use the term Nazi when reference is made to the German Army.

TRENTON, N.J., July 18 (AP) -- The practice of the State Board of Medical Examiners in granting licenses only to graduates of medical schools accredited by the American Medical Association was upheld today by the State Supreme Court.

BOSTON, July 18 (AP) -- With six pounds the best of it, the Greentree Stable's Four Freedoms will have another try at Mrs. E. Mulrennan's crack First Fiddle tomorrow when a field of ten meets in the $50,000-added Massachusetts Handicap at Suffolk Downs.

IN THE CAEN SECTOR, July 18 -- One of the mightiest air forces that ever took to the air -- thousands of American, British and Dominions bombers and fighter-bombers -- struck awesome blows early today at every enemy target northeast, east and southeast of Caen.

With the purpose of obtaining more plasma for the Army and Navy, and the same time honoring McClelland Barclay, artist killed a year ago by a Japanese torpedo at New Georgia Island in the South Pacific, the memorial blood donors committee was organized yesterday at the New York Athletic Club.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- Rawson G. Lizars, chairman of the Certain-teed Products Corporation, building materials manufacturer with headquarters here, announced today a plan for the retirement of all the company's preferred stock and disclosed that if the shareholders accept the offer the directors intend to declare common dividends for the first time since 1928.

Buying shoes for baby these days is likely cost a mother more than cash and a ration stamp. Wear and tear on her own shoes is now part of the price, it was agreed yesterday by retailers and manufacturers, who reported varying degrees of shortage in supplies and production.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- Persistent hedging sales and pressure from professional traders and commission houses as the result of peace talk engendered by continued favorable developments in the European war theatre resulted in wheat yielding a small fraction of a cent a bushel today on the Board of Trade, the grain going to a new low since early this month.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- New Jersey's thirty-four votes in the Democratic National Convention stayed on the fence in the Vice Presidential nomination contest tonight, despite an attempt by a supporter of former Gov. Charles A. Edison to record the delegation in favor of Henry A. Wallace.

Competition in the collection of waste paper by boys' teams of the city public school playgrounds has yielded 296,526 pounds in a little more than a week, Francis J. Brennan, acting director of the Division of Recreation of the Board of Education announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- How Pullman, Inc., will divorce its sleeping car and car manufacturing operations to comply with the recent order of the Federal District Court at Philadelphia was the subject of speculation today among railroad executives.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- Most of the beefsteaks and roasts now available in butcher shops would become ration point free under an order prepared today by Marvin Jones, War Food Administrator.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- Mrs. Helen Gahagan Douglas, Democratic nominee for the House from the Thirteenth District of California, paid tribute this afternoon to Wendell Willkie, even while proclaiming her endorsement of Henry Wallace for nomination to succeed himself as Vice President.

"Step Lively," RKO's adaptation of the Broadway play, "Room Service," which was slated to open at the Palace on Friday, instead will arrive there next Wednesday, it was reported by the management. The current tenant "Marine Raiders," will continue through Tuesday, July 25.
CLEVELAND, July 18 (AP) -- The Athletics rallied for three runs in the ninth inning tonight, but Al Smith was able to put down the threat and the Indians emerged with a 4-to-3 triumph.

After a five-month term as active head of the Japanese Army in the concurrent position of Chief of Staff, Premier General Hideki Tojo was "relieved" of that job yesterday in a drastic new High Command shake-up that was accompanied by the first Japanese acknowledgment of the loss of Saipan and a statement by Premier Tojo himself in which he told his people that "imperial Japan has come to face an unprecedentedly great national crisis."

That incipient Dodger winning streak of one game, which followed a record losing skein of fifteen, suffered a not unexpected ate under the Ebbets Field lights last night when Max Lanier, Cardinal southpaw nemesis of the Brooks, whitewashed them with four hits.

The Belasco has been leased for two years by the newly organized theatrical firm of Jelin Productions, Inc., of which Max J. Jelin is president, it was confirmed yesterday by Mr. Jelin. A syndicate headed by John Wildberg recently purchased the house for $315,000 from the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, trustees of the David Belasco estate.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- P. Ballantine Sons, producers of Ballantine's beer and ale, has been charged by the Federal Trade Commission with violation of Section 7 of the Clayton Act by acquiring the capital stock of the Christian Feigenspan Brewing Company, a competing corporation, it was announced today.

Harry Feldman and Johnny Rucker were on the sick list, but there was nothing wrong with Phil Weintraub last night at the Polo Grounds. The veteran Chicagoan, who leads his team in batting, paced the Giants to a 5-2 victory over the Pirates and himself to the league leadership in runs batted home as the New Yorkers opened a twenty-one-game home stand before 26,164 fans.

The disappointing aspect of your frequent editorial comment on black market gasoline is that you never seem to question the fairness of the alleged equities involved. To accept the basis of your contentions one must attach no value to the frequent protests of leaders of the petroleum industry who contend that the gasoline ration can be greatly increased.

A suit seeking to collect $752,000 in damages caused by alleged loss of business and attorneys' and litigation fees was filed yesterday in Federal court by Toffenetti Restaurant Company, Inc., of Forty-third Street and Broadway, against officials of the Hotel and Restaurant Employes International Alliance and Bartenders International League of America, the union's joint board and nine former employes of the restaurant.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Wednesday, July 19 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. George A. Kenney's Far Eastern Air Force sank or damaged four merchantmen, three coastal vessels and several barges in more attacks on Japanese shipping, headquarters announced today.

PORT CHICAGO, Calif., July 18 (AP) -- From Orinda, twenty miles away, last night's Port Chicago ship explosion appeared "to fiill the sky with flame," Jack S. McDowell, San Francisco Call-Bulletin staff writer, said today.

A twelve-point program for the disposition of Government-owned plants, equipment and supplies, formulated by its subcommittee on disposal of war surpluses was announced yesterday by the National Association of Manufacturers. The program has the formal approval of the NAM board of directors, representing about 12,000 American manufacturing organizations.

Arrested in the Chrysler Building branch of Schrafft's restaurants yesterday, Harry Jack Kenyon, assistant industrial commodity specialist of the procurement division of the Treasury Department, was accused of having demanded a bribe of $4,000, of which he was said to have just accepted the first installment, forty $20 bills.

George H. Baker Jr. of Springdale, Conn., 28-year-old crippled son of a New York Central Railroad executive, plunged to his death from the sixty-fourth floor of the Chrysler Building at 1:30 P.M. yesterday as thousands of office workers were strolling by at lunch hour. The body landed on a fifth floor extension.
WITH AMERICAN FORCES, in Normandy, July 18 -- St. Lo fell this evening before a massive American assault -- and one battalion's entry was led by the body of its major, who had died in the assault.
ROME, July 18 (AP) -- A communique:

Discriminatory employment practices of fifty shipping companies have been corrected through intervention of the New York regional office of the President's Committee on Fair Employment Practice, Edward Lawson, regional director, announced yesterday.

The trustees of the three principal mortgages of the Central of Georgia Railway filed yesterday with the Interstate Commerce Commission objections to the plan of reorganization proposed by Merrel P. Callaway, trustee of the road, on Jan. 28, 1944.

In an address taken to forecast a new Republican campaign battle line, Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran attacked yesterday President Roosevelt's foreign policy as an "international tumbleweed" and "a day-to-day patchwork."

Mayor La Guardia was urged yesterday by Martin Sweeny, president of the Hotel Association of New York City, Inc., to withdraw his request to Mayors of all American cities that they urge their residents not to come to New York City for vacations.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The National Gallery of Art has received one of the greatest donations of eighteenth century French paintings ever given to any museum, the gift of a group of nine paintings from Samuel H. Kress of New York and the Samuel H. Kress Foundation, according to an announcement today by David E. Finley, director of the gallery.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, July 19 -- A great new offensive aimed at the very heart of Germany was announced late last night by Marshal Joseph Stalin, who said that forces of the First Ukraine Front in three days had driven thirty-one miles through a 124mile-wide breach in the German lines, captured 600 inhabited points and crossed the Bug River almost at the 1941 Soviet-Polish frontier.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, July 19 -- By virtue of a decree signed at his "field headquarters" on July 13, Adolf Hitler removed the administration of Belgium and northern France from the hands of the military government under Lieut Gen. Baron Alexander von Falkenhausen and installed a Reich Commissioner, with headquarters in Brussels, to "rule" both areas, it was learned here today.

The Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company reported yesterday for the first half of this year net earnings of $3,529,349 after all charges, including $2,550,000 for Federal income tax. The earnings are equal to $1.38 a share on the 2,548,855 shares of stock outstanding, and compare with $1,392,681 or 55 cents each on 2,524,000 shares for the corresponding six months a year ago, when $945,105,105 was provided for taxes.

Moses Dyckman, wholesale jeweler, has purchased the five-story business building at 31 West Forty-sixth Street from the United States Trust Company and Gifford Pinchot 2d, as trustees. The property abuts 28 West Forty-seventh Street, purchased by Mr. Dyckman in March, 1922, from the Bank for Savings.

The stock market underwent yesterday another major reaction with a reversal of approximately the extent suffered on Monday. The new dip met some scale absorption, however, which permitted prices to close above the low points of the day.

LONDON, July 18 -- Allied Air Forces have built up such superiority that a balance of potential air crews for the Royal Air Force has been established beyond immediate needs and thousands of young men awaiting entry to RAF are to be transferred to army.

DETROIT, July 18 (AP) -- Jimmy Outlaw singled to center field in the eleventh inning to score Joe Hoover from second base and give the Tigers a 6-to-5 victory over the Senators in a twilight game before 10,666 spectators tonight. Hal Newhouser gained his fourteenth victory in a relief role.
CHUNGKING, China, July 18 (AP) -- A communique:

LONDON, July 18 -- Playing upon the very substantial help that they claim the Polish underground army gave to Soviet forces in the capture of Vilna, Polish circles in London let it be known unofficially today that Prime Minister Stanislaw Mikolajczyk was ready to go to Moscow at any time to settle differences with the Soviet regime.

Telegrams were sent to Chicago yesterday by spokesmen for the new Liberal party and the Greater New York Council of the Congress of Industrial Organizations urging the Democratic National Convention to renominate Henry A. Wallace for Vice President.

PEARL HARBOR, July 18 -Heavy American surface forces moved on Guam on Sunday to bombard its defenses for the second straight day with battleships, cruisers and destroyers, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz's headquarters revealed today.
CHICAGO, July 18 -- Undismayed by the lukewarm endorsement of President Roosevelt, Vice President Wallace will arrive here tomorrow morning to take personal charge of his fight for renomination.

HARRISBURG, Pa., July 19 -- Vance C. McCormick, newspaper publisher and former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said today that his papers would not support President Roosevelt in the coming election.

Deep in the interior of South America on one of its disease-scourged rivers a motor launch flying the Stars and Stripes and the white and red flag of the science that knows no frontiers makes a landing at a jungle clearing where is located a small cluster of grass huts and tin shanties.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Norman Armour, United States Ambassador to Argentina, who recently was recalled for consultation, was appointed today acting chief of the Office of American Republic Affairs in the State Department. Laurence Duggan, who had held that office, resigned for personal reasons.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Commendation of a Wac unit for being able to keep military secrets was announced today by the War Department

LONDON, July 18 -- The deportation and execution of Hungarian Jews by Nazis is leading to an increasing demand that the British Government take a stronger stand than it has adopted yet against these atrocities. There is authentic evidence that has been received through trusted Allied Government sources that the Jews of Hungary are being used as pawns in a Nazi game for high stakes.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- Democratic leaders move through lobbies and in the streets with their heads pulled in turtlewise to get by swarms of potential Vice Presidents. "Every time one of us stops," a New England Senator confided unhappily, "some one sidles up and says, 'If there's a hopeless deadlock, count on me.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Wednesday, July 19 -- Flaunting its air supremacy in the face of the enemy, the Allied Command yesterday supplemented a major effort over the Normandy battle front by dispatching more than 1,200 American planes in an attack on the Nazi robot sources at Peenemuende and Zinnowitz on the Baltic coast sixty miles northwest of Stettin.

Magistrate James A. Blanchield, sitting in the Flatbush Court in Brooklyn yesterday, reminded a woman and two men, charged with heeding and annoying the bears in Prospect Park Zoo, of the fate of Catherine Searles, whose right arm was torn off by a polar bear in Central Park Zoo early Monday morning.

H.A. Ross, president of Ross Federal Service, Inc., national research organization, has purchased for occupancy the five-story dwelling at 12 East Sixty-seventh Street, formerly occupied by the Munson family of the Munson Steamship interests.

The arrest of Max Feld, 36 years old, and seizure of 5,000 shoe ration coupons alleged to have been illegally in his possession, was announced yesterday by Daniel P. Woolley, Regional Administrator of the Office of Price Administration. Following his arrest by city detectives, Feld was held in bail of $500 for action of a Federal grand jury, on orders of United States Commissioner Garrett W. Cotter.

FEW of the many voluble participants in the great debate about war and peace and the future organization of the world have brought to the rostrum such valuable qualifications, both in intellectual capacity and in experience, as Sumner Welles. The former Under-Secretary of State is the author of a major contribution to the post-war discussion in which we all are now engaged.
The hole card of a horse named Card Game, sired by Case Ace, evidently has been found by Jockey Steven Murphy, for he got him home first yesterday at Jamaica for the third race in a row.

The announced arrival in Italy yesterday of the Brazilian Expeditionary Force is a historic event. The unfurling in Europe of the green, blue and yellow flag of the United States of Brazil adds another banner to the array now confronting the Germans. It is the first time an army from the Western Hemisphere other than those of Canada and the United States has gone overseas to strike a blow for freedom.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18 (AP) -- Hearings by the Securities and Exchange Commission on the Washington Railway and Electric Company's simplification plan began today, with Robert N. Hunter of the Department of Justice representing the Government's consumer interest.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 18 (AP) -- Communique 85:

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- A program for the construction of several thousand housing units by the end of this year and about 100,000 more in 1945 to meet the needs of war workers, now inadequately housed, was announced jointly today by the War Production Board and the National Housing Administration.

LONDON, July 18 (AP) -- A British Army spokesman, in a broadcast directed to the German armed forces, warned today that punishment would be meted out without mercy to any German soldier known to have committed an atrocity.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- Opposition to the New Deal and a fourth term for President Roosevelt appeared tonight to have gathered at least 125 votes in the Democratic National Convention and sufficient determination to continue the fight as to make good the threats to put up third tickets in some States unless material concessions are granted the Democratic South in the party platform.

CHUNGKING, China, July 18 (AP) -- Defiant Chinese, still holding the Canton-Hankow railway junction of Hengyang in the face of furious enemy assaults, have thrown themselves against the Japanese on the approaches to the city and "penetrated many enemy positions," the High Command announced tonight.

Mrs. Herbert Witherspoon has been appointed managing director of the new Ballet International, the company to be sponsored by the Ballet Institute, of which George de Cuevas is head. Mrs. Witherspoon was for four years executive secretary of the American Guild of Musical Artists, and before that was a member for five years of the board of governors of the Metropolitan Opera Guild.

This is a report on a shotgun shell that you cannot buy now and will not be able to buy after the war, but it is offered as an item that may interest shooting enthusiasts, nevertheless. Not that it wouldn't have peacetime uses, but in its present form it's as likely to set fire to the hunter's surroundings as bring down birds.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Net public and private indebtedness, representing the obligations of ultimate borrowers, was estimated at $295,000,000,000 as of the middle of this year, against $274,000,000,000 at the end of 1943 and $166,000,000,000 at the end of 1940, the Department of Commerce disclosed today in an article in its Survey of Current Business, written by Alvin Slater of the national income unit of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Secretary Hull received today the Citizenship Medal, highest decoration of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, in recognition of his "outstanding service" as Secretary of State, in other public offices, and with the Fourth Regiment of Volunteer Infantry of Tennessee during the Spanish-American War.

W. Kingsland Macy has received tentative promises of the support of the Republican organizations in the four Long Island counties, the Bronx and Westchester for the nomination for United States Senator, it was learned last night. The pledges are conditional upon Mr. Macy's ability to win the approval of Governor Dewey.
GENERAL EISENHOWER'S ADVANCED COMMAND POST, July 18 -- On the night Brig. Gen. Theodore Roosevelt died in Normandy, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower prepared an order placing him in command of a division.

Fred Schmidt, a 24-year-old truck loader and ex-convict who was released on parole only two months ago, confessed yesterday, according to the police, the killing of Paul Volchak in an attempted hold-up on Broadway near 101st Street Monday morning.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Responding to the mounting demand for lumber by the armed services in the face of a shortage daily growing more critical, the War Production Board prohibited the use of several grades and species of lumber in the manufacture of twenty-six types of products made wholly or in part from wood.

A warning that, though rentals of commercial premises are not regulated by the Office of Price Administration, ceilings on the rates of certain services furnished on such premises will be strictly enforced, was issued yesterday by Daniel P. Woolley, Regional OPA Administrator.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve board announced today, shows for the week ended July 12 increases of $869,000,000 in holdings of United States Government obligations and $838,000,000 in United States Government deposits.

ST. LOUIS, July 18 -- The Yankees' expected quick dash to the top in the American flag race crashed head-on into a complete disaster tonight as the pennant-hungry Browns upended the McCarthymen in the opening clash of a four-game series, 8 to 0, before a cheering crowd of 19,003.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- The American Federation of Labor denounced today the action of the Farrell-Peron Government of Argentina in imprisoning Juan Antonio Solari, described by the AFL as "one of the most articulate aggressive advocates of democracy and free trade unionism in that country."

KINGSTON, N.Y., July 18 (AP) -- A Supreme Court jury acquitted former State Senator Roy M. Page today of all fourteen counts of grand larceny and corrupt bargaining for office. Mr. Page, upon hearing the verdict, walked over and thanked the jurors.
Lilly Dache has caught the spirit of the new fashion and has given it form in her fall millinery collection.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, July 18 (U.P.) -- Remnants of two Japanese divisions, fleeing southward from Ukhrul in India, are waging a losing battle against starvation as the heavy rains wipe out their supply routes and Allied patrols maintain constant harassing pressure, Adrenal Lord Louis Mounbatten's headquarters reported today.

A new Wac recruiting substation, said to be the most glamorous in the country, was opened yesterday at 638 Fifth Avenue in Rockefeller Center with a reception for military officials and members of the Second Service Command Advisory Committee on the Women's Army Corps.

LONDON, July 18 (AP) -- Thirty-three more Allied fliers have been shot by the Germans, most of them allegedly while attempting to escape, bringing to 152 the known total of prisoners killed by their Nazi captors, War Secretary Sir James Grigg disclosed in the House of Commons today.

LONDON, July 18 -- Two members of Marshal Tito's national liberation movement, which until a few weeks ago was being described in Royal Yugoslav Government circles as a bandit gang, arrived in London from Yugoslavia today to become members of the new Government.

LONDON, July 18 (U.P.) -- British and American paratroops, specialists in sabotage and silent warfare, are operating with the French Forces of the Interior inside a sixty-square-mile area near Paris, where they roam freely.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- Ralph McGill, editor of The Atlanta Constitution, urged the resolutions committee of the Democratic convention today to support a policy of removing all unnecessary restrictions on the freedom to gather and transmit news throughout the world.
LONDON, July 18 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

CHICAGO, July 18 -- The omnibus character of the Democratic party was never more apparent than on the eve of this convention. There are at least fifty-seven varieties of Democrats and they are all here, enjoying their disagreements while they can. The differences of accent, temperament, background and political philosophy are more visible and audible before the gavel falls at the first session than they will be afterward.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- All governments from the municipal to the federal level were ordered by the War Production Board today to cut their use of paper for printing needs 25 per cent below their consumption in 1942.
Restyling old furniture to adapt it to current decorating trends is the mission of Modernized Antiques, a shop at 202 East Fifty-sixth Street. The formal opening was yesterday afternoon.

LONDON, July 18 (AP) -- Flying bombs fell sporadically on southern England today and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden announced in Commons that the War Cabinet had ruled out a secret session on the robot attacks.

Your editorial of July 12, "The Nation's Health," very pointedly presents a problem that has been recognized by any physician active in medicine today. I agree regretfully with your comment that "too many pay no attention to physical well-being for reasons only partially known."

PORT CHICAGO, Calif., July 18 -- A description of the Port Chicago explosion was given by K.E. Knapp of Hayward, a railroad worker who was atop a box car a mile away when the ammunition was detonated.

Of necessity Mr. Dewey spoke both as Governor and as Presidential candidate in his statement on the soldier vote yesterday. As Governor he defended the law which he himself urged upon the Legislature. As candidate he resented what he calls "the campaign of deceit" carried on by "a group with unlimited financial resources" to discredit the New York law.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The resignation of Premier Hideki Tojo as Chief of Staff of the Japanese Army was said by Secretary of State Cordell Hull today to be rather a desperate sign, as it related to Japanese military operations.

PORT CHICAGO, Calif., July 18 -- Hardly had the concussion of the Port Chicago munitions blast subsided when disaster relief workers of the American Red Cross moved on the devastated area with blood plasma, cots and blankets.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- James A. Farley, who managed the Democratic National Conventions of 1932 and 1936 and was still national chairman when the 1940 gathering ended, analyzed the 1944 convention of the party today with this answer to a questioner who wanted to know who he thought would be nominated for Vice President: ...

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY IN ITALY, July 18 (U.P.) -- One thousand truckloads of food were rushed into the liberated Italian capital of Rome during the first ten days after the Allies moved into the city and 150,000 needy persons were fed without charge, it was revealed today in a 146-page book prepared by Brig. Gen. Erskine Hume, chief of the Fifth Army's Military Government Section.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 18 -- The Peruvian delegation to the United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference expressed today the sentiments of many delegates when it asserted that the proposed international monetary fund and bank for reconstruction and development could not succeed in the absence of international agreement to assure proper commercial policies.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 18 -- Reports from Paris confirm the killing there on Bastille Day of Georges Mandel, many times a Cabinet Minister, who was imprisoned by Vichy for early participation in the resistance movement.

Two Swedish newspapers, commenting editorially on London dispatches that told Monday how specially constructed, small, British speed boats ran a regular merchant service through the German blockade between Britain and Sweden, yesterday hailed the achievement as a "successful experiment" and a "good omen."

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The Federal Communications Commission approved today, with Commissioner J.C. Purr dissenting, the transfer of all the capital stock to THE NEW YORK TIMES, for approximately $1,000,000, of station WQXR in New York and Frequency Modulation Station WQXQ.

STOCKHOLM, July 18 (AP) -- The long-awaited four-minute mile, first envisioned in 1937 when England's Sydney Wooderson ran the distance in 4:06.4, approached reality today when Arne Andersson, 28-year-old school teacher, turned in a record-shattering 4:01.6 at Malmoe.

The earthquake that has struck Japan's military might as a result of the eruption of Allied power in the Pacific continues to reverberate through the Japanese High Command. A shake-up of the top naval command has now been followed by a similar shake-up of the top army command.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Plans for adding to the list of clothing items under dollars-and-cents price ceilings so as to improve the cost and quality situation in the apparel and household textile fields is a subject uppermost in the discussions of the OPA's Consumer Advisory Committee, which is in session here.

The first great victory parade of the war has been held in Moscow. No one cheered from the crowds that lined the streets and the marchers were silent. Yet it was as impressive a spectacle in its way as any that will come with flying banners and blaring bands at the end of the war.

BRETTON WOODS, N. H., July 18 -- Lord Keynes, chairman of the British delegation to the United Nations monetary and financial conference, abandoned today a fight to maintain London's traditional position as the financial center of the world by holding the door open for it to be selected as headquarters for the proposed International Monetary Fund and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

While sales of E bonds to civilians continued to lag, various units of the nation's fighting forces were disclosed yesterday to have invested a considerable part of their income in bonds during the Fifth War Loan.
ROME, July 18 -- American troops of the Fifth Army, after having fought their way through difficult mountain terrain, reached the Arno River between Pisa and Florence today at the town of Pontedera.

Expansion of membership to include women workers in war industries was called for by Miss Margaret A. Hickey of St. Louis, in her speech to the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs, which elected her president yesterday at its closing convention session at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull emphasized at his press conference today that the exploratory discussions here next month on post-war security among representatives of the United States, United Kingdom, the Soviet Union and China would be subject to the approval of the Governments before there would be final action on a completed document.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The United States will participate in exploratory talks in London late this month and early in August with Great Britain and the Netherlands on post-war problems of crude and synthetic rubber, it was announced by the State Department today.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission issued today a modified reorganization plan for the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company that substantially follows a compromise plan introduced last October.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The War Department is expected to issue within a few days a liberal list of magazines, approved for distribution to personnel in the armed services in this country and overseas.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, July 19 -- A special communique of the International Red Cross headquarters issued late last night announced that as a result of energetic action on its part with Admiral Nicholas Horthy, Regent of Hungary, and the Hungarian Government in Budapest, it has been officially informed that the deportation of Hungarian Jews has been "suspended."

Leases by firms of two entire buildings in downtown Manhattan were reported yesterday. The Cleveland Twist Drill Company leased 18-20 Thomas Street from the New York Hospital for a long term of years and the Brecht Corporation took a ten-year lease on the recently modernized five-story building at 255 Pearl Street.

PORT CHICAGO, Calif., July 18 -- Three hundred and fifty or more persons were killed in the double explosion which shattered two munitions ships late last night, wrecked a Navy loading pier and left a "scorched earth" scene in this war boom town, forty miles northeast of San Francisco.

CHICAGO, July 18 (AP) -- The Red Sox, held hitless after the fifth frame, broke out with four singles in the eleventh inning tonight to give Tex Hughson his season's fourteenth victory, 4 to 2, and beat the White Sox for the seventh time in as many meetings this year. A crowd of 23,266 saw the game.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Wednesday, July 19 -- The British Second Army has cracked the German defensive position around Caen in the successful opening of a major offensive.

Compulsory standardization of essential apparel items, far from expanding supplies of such garments, will work the other way, according to A.F. Allison, secretary of the International Association of Garment Manufacturers, who declared yesterday that "any Victory model' channeling of cotton piece goods distribution can only result in serious and immediate loss in production of cost-of-living apparel."

LONDON, July 18 -- Prime Minister Churchill and Foreign Secretary Eden were criticized in the House of Commons today for insisting that Germany surrender unconditionally. It was suggested that the German people might overthrow their Nazi masters sooner if the Allies could define now what they meant by those grim words.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The Federal Trade Commission announced today an investigation had been ordered under the Export Trade Act to determine whether the Phosphate Export Association of New York and the Florida Hard Rock Phosphate Export Association of Savannah, Ga., have entered into illegal agreements and engaged in practices in restraint of trade.

Point of sale advertising will be increased materially in auto service stations as soon as metal sign material becomes available, it was learned yesterday. One chain voiced its intention of ordering swing signs for all its stations and in addition will use sheet poster signs that can be changed frequently.

Thirty-four years ago last January an audience of Harvard professors and advanced students listened attentively to a lecture by a boy of 11 in knickerbockers on "Four-Dimensional Bodies." He was said to be rather too deep at times for his learned audience. He was already famous.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 19 -- The United and Associated Nations took their first important steps toward preventing the Nazis from cashing in on billions of dollars' worth of stolen wealth which could provide a basis not only for continuing German financial power after the war but also for luxurious living by any Nazi officials who survive their country's defeat.

The accepted pattern for a keynote address at an American political convention is well established. It consists of claiming on behalf of one's own party a perfect record of foresight, intelligence and courage and finding on the opposition's side only a dismal trail of negligence, incompetence and betrayal of the public trust.

Men in the armed forces are leading the way to a revolution in men's summer clothing styles that will place the "shirt suit" in a permanent place in the wardrobe of practically every man in the country, Henry L. Jackson, special fashion counsel and consultant, Quartermaster Corps, told members of the International Association of Clothing Designers yesterday at the group's semi-annual meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

This is the week-end-in-the-country season, when every New Yorker who can wangle an invitation goes to Long Island, New Jersey, Westchester or Connecticut for an "over-Sunday" stay with friend, aunt or cousin. As an alternate to the box of candy that is usually bought in haste at the station for the hostess, we offer some ideas for gifts that are among many to be found in city establishment.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Thursday, July 20 -- Southwest Germany's armament factories, railways and airports were blasted yesterday by nearly 2,000 American heavy bombers operating from Britain and Italy.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- Paul E. Fitzpatrick, new Democratic State chairman in New York, issued from the State headquarters today an answer to Governor Dewey's defense of the State Soldier Vote Law. Mr. Fitzpatrick declared that Governor Dewey "realized President Roosevelt's popularity with those in the armed services and approved the toughest law in the country on soldier voting."
LONDON, July 19 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

As the first step in a plan to consolidate all the mortgages on its properties into one general mortgage lien, the Great Northern Railway Company announced yesterday through the First National Bank of New York, financial adviser to the railroad, that it will call for redemption $119,887,700 of its bonds and notes.

In the mining communities of Pennsylvania, Illinois, West Virginia and other coal regions a distinct swing to the Republican ticket is under way this year because "miners and their wives believe that their chances of jobs in the post-war era would be better under a Republican administration,"

LONDON, July 19 -- With trading conditions rather difficult, owing to "alerts," much of today's stock market business was arranged between offices or in the street. However, prices held firm, particularly in leading industrials.

ALBANY, July 19 -- Representative James W. Wadsworth of Geneseo, one of the leading advocates in Congress of military preparedness, prior to Pearl Harbor, left a conference with Governor Dewey today, stating that he and the Republican Presidential nominee see eye to eye on the necessity of maintaining American military might when this war ends.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Thursday, July 20 -- A formidable force of British tanks has hammered through a maze of German strong points to the area of Cagny and Grentheville, southeast of Caen, and advance elements of this force are engaging the German anti-tank screen in the woods a mile northwest of Vimont, which lies eight and a half miles south-east of Caen.

" Ninety-nine Park," headquarters of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, Inc.*, offers a partial list of free amusements available today, through the generosity of the entertainment world. Afternoon tickets from 11 A.M.; evening tickets after 4 P.M. Apply 99 Park Avenue (at Fortieth Street) for tickets.
A communique, as broadcast from Chungking yesterday in English to North America and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Massachusetts Investors Trust has completed twenty years of operation with a quartely report showing net assets on June 30 of $153,547,373. This is equivalent to $22.22 a share, against $20.95 on March 31 last, and $20.82 on June 30, 1943.

A public offering of 77,252 shares of common stack and 36,218 shares of second preferred stock of Johnson Johnson, 57-year old manufacturers of surgical dressings and related products, is being made today. The preferred shares are being offered by Morgan Stanley Co. and Dominick Dominick.
CHICAGO, July 19 (AP) -- Only one Southern State, Georgia, will go down the line for a Roosevelt-Wallace ticket at the Democratic Convention, it appeared today.

CHICAGO, July 19 (AP) -- J.H. Rouse's Three Dots today captured the Myrtlewood Handicap on the Arlington Park program at Washington Park. He finished in 1:10 to break his own track record for six furlongs.

BOSTON, July 19 (AP) -- Airtight pitching gave Nate Andrews his tenth triumph of the season today and enabled the Braves to shake the Cub jinx and defeat the visitors, 6 to 1, in the opener of a four-game series.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES IN NORMANDY, July 19 (U.P.) -- This is the story behind the headline: "Yanks Take St. Lo" -- the story of a lad loved by a girl and how he kept her letters with him until he dropped and they carried him away -- the story of him and thousands like him.

BOSTON, July 9 (AP) -- After being bumped twice at the eighth pole, Mrs. Ed Mulrenan's game gray First Fiddle resumed his thrilling stretch drive and outran the Millbrook Stable's Alex Barth by three-quarters of a length in the $50,000-added Massachusetts Handicap today at Suffolk Downs.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Thursday, July 20 (AP) -- A communique:

Replying to Governor Dewey's charge that "a group with unlimited financial resources has been playing partisan politics" and waging a "campaign of deceit" in connection with the State soldier vote law, groups that have fought for revised voting provisions retorted yesterday with demands for a special session of the Legislature to "liberalize" the law and with counter-charges of "political conniving."

CHICAGO, July 19 -- Without naming names or belaboring the issue, Mrs. Charles W. Tillett of North Carolina, assistant chairman of the Democratic convention, retorted tonight to the address of Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce before the recent Republican conclave, which attacked the record of the Roosevelt Administration in its pre-war phase.

CAMP SHANKS, N.Y., July 19 (AP) -- An enthusiastic crowd of soldiers saw the Cardinals defeat the Camp Shanks nine today, 22 to 7. Before the game, Manager Billy Southworth told the soldier spectators the Cards were going to bear down all through the game, as many of those assembled had never seen major league players in acton.

Bernard Bosley, in 401 E 58th St; Robert Wagner, Mrs. Martha Honella, Miss Berta Messinger, Valdimer Dimitriew, in 49 W 57th St; Hugh C. Cailler, in 405 E 51st St; Nickolas Muray, Miss Clara F. Porter, Dr. Gregory Schwartzmann, in 230 E 50th St; Carlton Cooley, Benjamin Dean, Mrs. Hattie Schinasi, in 162 E 46th St -- Culver, Hollyday Co, Inc, brokers.
CHUNGKING, China, July 19 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United, States Air Force communique:

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, July 19 (AP) -- Allied troops have pushed the Japanese invaders of India back as far as thirty miles below Imphal into the Palel sector near the Burma border and beaten down sharp counter-attacks, headquarters announced today.

Immediate action for the rescue of the surviving Jews in Europe, including the use of poison gas against Germany, was demanded at a "rebirth of a nation" rally in Town Hall last night under the auspices of the American League for a Free Palestine.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- Prospects for the 1944 college football season are "very bright," commissioners of four of the country's top conferences declared today.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- Although liberal hedging pressure from the Southwest and liquidation of a line of December wheat attributed to a mill, which is said to have obtained sufficient cash wheat to take care of a recent flour order, had a depressing effect at times today on the Board of Trade, these factors failed to cause a wide open break.

Stephen S. Sheriden, New York City area director of the War Manpower Commission, announced yesterday exemption of the entertainment industry in this city, and all men between 18 and 45 years of age now working in the industry, from provisions of the WMC priority referral regulations.

ST. LO, France, July 19 -- From the first day on, the Germans subjected the tiny hilltop area held by Colonel Bingham to almost incessant rifle, machine-gun, automatic-pistol and mortar fire. The Americans held their own and finally the Germans moved up two tanks, which began firing at point-blank range.

May an ex-Oklahoman utilize your columns to pass along to his Texas neighbors a reminder from Andrew Jackson? "Old Hickory" was quick on the trigger, too, but he always remembered to consider the rights of the people, and his message to Congress dated Dec. 8, 1829, seems especially applicable at this time:

CHICAGO, July 19 -- As the withdrawal of James F. Byrnes cleared the way for those opposed to the renomination of Vice President Wallace to center upon the candidacy of Senator Harry S. Truman of Missouri a sharp conflict arose tonight among Democratic leaders.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The German-American Bund's national headquarters received and distributed anti-Jewish and anti-Administration propaganda written by nearly a dozen of the defendants in the mass sedition trial, the jury in the case was told today.

Two years of hospitality and entertainment in behalf of officers of the armed forces of the United States and Allied Nations will be celebrated tomorrow evening at the Hotel Delmonico, Park Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, by the Open House for Officers.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The Army announced today an approved list of 189 magazines, based on a combined poll and survey of soldiers' preferences, which may be distributed to troops without scrutiny of political content.
GEN. MONTGOMERY'S HEADQUARTERS, In France, July 19 -- Sir Bernard L. Montgomery estimated today that, since D-day, the Allies had "written off" 156,000 Germans.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 19 -- Winning four of five races and missing a perfect score by only 2 points, Bob Monetti sailed the Manhasset Bay entry to its second straight triumph in the annual Commodore Law Challenge Trophy series off the Indian Harbor Yacht Club today.

LONDON, July 19 (AP) -- Four members of the Women's Army Corps of the United States, the first in the European Theatre of Operations to receive the Purple Heart award signifying wounds in action, were decorated today in a hospital where they are recuperating from shock and minor injuries suffered in a robot bomb blast.
WITH THE NINETIETH DIVISION, In Normandy, July 19 -- Ever since D-day, when they stormed up the beaches, thousands of officers and men have fought their hearts out as anonymous entities.

Carstairs Bros. Distilling Company, Inc., is surveying retailer outlets seeking estimates of consumer demands, in line with prospects for expansion in distribution due to the August liquor holiday, it was announced yesterday. Distribution programs will be worked out following a recapitulation of the replies.

Like other magazines, Esquire is a publication which some people are interested in and buy and others are not interested in and do not buy. Like a number of other magazines it is frank in its treatment of the feminine form -- as frank as any bathing beach -- and in pictures and text it frequently treats sex as a fascinating joke.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- A Pacific Fleet announcement:

A "three ring" canning demonstration with spectators privileged to roam from one room to another to watch the progress of fruits, vegetables and meat from a state of rawness to preservation in a jar by three different methods was held yesterday at the Red Cross instruction center, 401 Fifth Avenue.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., July 19t A memorial service will he held on Monday at 4 P. M. in Christ Episcopal Church here for Brig. Gen. Theodore Roosevelt, who died of exhaustion in Normandy Thursday, while with the invasion forces during a battle.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

It isn't everyone who can go tuna fishing these days, but Army Air Forces combat veterans stationed at Atlantic City will be given the opportunity starting today. The tuna are running off the New Jersey resort and while they are around the returned warriors will pursue them on a schedule tentatively set for every other day, depending on weather and fishing conditions.
JOHNSON, Vt., July 19 (AP) -- In northern Vermont a Congregational pastor with a burr of old Scotland in his voice has initiated a program of what he likes to call "aggressive good will."

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 19 -- The United Nations monetary and financial conference reached a deadlock tonight when the Russian delegation, after communicating with Moscow, refused to recede from its demand for a reduction in its subscription to the proposed $10,000,000,000 international bank for reconstruction and development.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- The War Manpower Commission today announced approval by the Governors of Delaware, Florida, Maryland, North Carolina, Virginia, West Virginia and Pennsylvania of an interstate movement of workers to relieve labor shortages at canneries during which the processing season which will reach its peak in the next few weeks.

ROME, July 19 -- Two great Italian ports -- Leghorn on the west coast and Ancona on the east -- fell to the Allies in the past twenty-four hours. They have been demolished with German thoroughness, but the Fifth Army on the west and the British Eighth Army on the east will soon have workable ports that will immensely shorten and speed their lines of communications for the smash through the Gothic Line.

Production of crude oil in the United States last week averaged 4,602,350 barrels daily, a new high record and an increase of 23,350 over the 4,579,000 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was only 3,750 barrels below the recommendation of 4,606,100 daily for July by the Petroleum Administration for War.

Appointment of Lieut. Gen. William S. Knudsen as the head of a new Air Forces Materiel and Services Command is a happy one. In this post he should be particularly at home, dealing with familiar problems of research, design and procurement, inspection, supply and maintenance.

The story of how New York City's schools "trained, equipped and sent forth 500 battalions, or more than a quarter of a million workers, to the industrial front" is told in a three-year report of the Board of Education's War Industries Training Program.
LONDON, July 19 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

CHICAGO, July 19 -- In contrast with the Republican convention surprisingly little argument has developed among the Democrats on their platform's foreign policy plank. As it is being drafted in final form tonight, the plank will be a combination of the statement formulated by Judge Samuel Rosenman and that prepared in the State Department and brought here by Breckenridge Long, assistant secretary.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- The pro-Roosevelt Texas "rump" delegation brushed aside the advice of party leaders today and planned to take its fight for recognition to the floor of the National Convention tomorrow and raise issues by which it hopes to break the backbone of opposition to the New Deal and the fourth term and of the bolting of delegations and individual delegates to Senator Byrd of Virginia.

Blasting records for durability is Ike Williams' forte. Tonight the hard-punching lightweight from Trenton, who has put away Joey Peralta, Cleo Shans and Mike Delia recently will take it upon himself to be the first to administer a quietus to Julie Kogon of New Haven in the main ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden.
KANDY, Ceylon, July 19 (UP) -- A communique:

CHICAGO, July 19 -- Aside from the Vice Presidential candidates, daily dwindling in number, the most interested observers at the convention are members of the President's Cabinet. The five present in Chicago are not much in evidence, but they are playing an important role in the background.

Officials of St. Petersburg, Fla., announced yesterday they would receive bids on July 27 on a proposed issue of $18,000,000 of refunding bonds. Last week the city rejected a single offer submitted for a refunding operation. The new invitation specifies an interest rate of not more than 3 per cent with a minimum price of 98.

Selective Service officials said yesterday at its New York City headquarters, 1 East Forty-fourth Street, that only a "very small group" of men had been classified 4F in the draft because of their criminal records. They declined to give out statistics on the number on the ground that these were confidential.

Consolidated net earnings of the Johns-Manville Corporation and its subsidiaries for the quarter ended on June 30 amounted to $1,242,194 after all charges, equal to $1.46 a share of common stock, it was announced yesterday. This compares with $1,059,802, or $1.19 a common share, for the second quarter of 1943.

The day after Mussolini had been voted out of office by his own Fascist Grand Council a year ago and arrested he was talking to his doctor. The fallen Duce described his symptoms in great detail, but found time to talk about other things.

Additional returns from primaries in three Western States, Arizona, Wyoming and Montana, showed last night that incumbents experienced little difficulty in winning party renominations, The Associated Press reported.

The annual report of the New Jersey Power and Light Company, released yesterday by H.C. Thuerk, president, shows a net income for 1943, after all expenses and charges, of $975,750, an increase of $26,643 over 1942. Gross operating revenues for the year were $5,400,528, compared with $5,171,782 the year before.

CHICAGO, July 19 (AP) -- Clear skies prevailed over the eastern corn belt today and the weather forecast promised no relief from drought conditions that have persisted in some areas for more than a month.
Premier General Hideki Tojo's "entire Cabinet" has resigned, the Japanese Domei agency announced last night in a wireless dispatch to Japanese-occupied areas.
ST. LOUIS, July 19 -- There was no rush tonight, so far as anyone could detect, to file hurried ticket applications for that long-cherished All-St. Louis World Series.

Two new films will have world premieres in midtown theatres this morning. At the Capitol, the attraction will be "Since You Went Away," David O. Selznick's first offering in more than four years. Heading the cast are Claudette Colbert, Jennifer Jones, Joseph Cotten, Shirley Temple, Monty Woolley, Robert Walker and Lionel Barrymore.

Representative Albert Gore, 36-year-old Democrat from the Fourth District of Tennessee, will come up for renomination on Aug. 3. He will be a test case, and what happens to him will be of national significance. Young Mr. Gore has made an outstanding record in Congress.

Mr. Kress' gift to the National Gallery of Art includes works of three painters whose names evoke France from the austere close of the reign of Louis XIV to the Revolution. Watteau, Boucher and Fragonard are still historians and poets in their way, recording or imagining a vanished, corrupt yet somehow charming way of life for the well-born and the rich.
CHICAGO, July 19 -- Vice President Wallace, who reached Chicago today to take personal charge of his fight for renomination, declared at once that he was in the fight to the finish.

ALBANY, July 19 (AP) -- The Court of Appeals ruled unanimously today that the Railway Mail Association was a labor union and came under the New York State Civil Rights Law prohibiting discrimination as to membership because of race, color or creed.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 19 -- Lieut. Gen. Baron Alexander von Falkenhausen's ouster from the military control of the northernmost department of France and Belgium followed by the installation of a Gestapo regime under Himmler's "Deputy righthand man," Gauleiter Joseph Grohe, has precipitated a crisis in the upper brackets of the Wehrmacht High Command, according to dependable sources on the German frontier late tonight.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 19 -- The Chateau de Wyden, near Ossingen, in the Canton of Zurich, property of Prof. Max Huber, president of the International Red Cross and former judge of the Permanent Court of International Justice at The Hague, was seriously damaged just before noon today when an American B-24 Liberator bomber, returning from operations over southwestern Germany, crashed into its roof.

Striking out from Caen with the same tactics but with far greater power than at El Alamein, General Montgomery and his British and Canadian troops have been able to score a success which may prove as important for the campaign in France as El Alamein was for the conquest of North Africa.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Thursday, July 20 (AP) -- Stung by the loss of 1,369 men in unsuccessful frontal assaults, the Japanese have changed their tactics and now are attempting to outflank the Allied lines on the Driniumor River, in British New Guinea, headquarters announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (U.P.) -- All beefsteaks and beef roasts will remain on the list of rationed meats at least through the first two weeks of August, it was indicated today, despite a War Food Administration order to the contrary.

Nazi mass murder of civilians, execution of our captured fliers, looting, robbing, extinguishing whole towns of innocent women, children and the aged, ghastly and incredible as they are, still continue.

Curt Riess, author of "Total Espionage" and editor of "They Were There," a chronological account of this war by leading war correspondents, has written of Nazi plans for World War III in "The Nazis Go Underground." Doubleday, Doran will publish it July 28.

LONDON, July 5 -- Not every land army girl milks cows, or takes the bull for an airing. The girl in the bright green sweater and cord breeches, sporting a badge on her sleeve with two crossed axes, belongs to a special division of the Women's Land Army -- the Women's Timber Corps.

The almost simultaneous capture of Leghorn and Ancona brings the Allied armies in Italy directly into position for a frontal assault on the Gothic Line. Through these two fine ports on opposite sides of the peninsula we can pour our full power for a major drive across the last mountain barrier into the broad plains of the Po River valley.

Investment trust executives measure the success or failure of their management techniques against the performance of the stocks used to compute market averages, such as those of THE NEW YORK TIMES and DOW, Jones Co.

Details of the T-1 bombsight were made public here yesterday by officials of the AC Spark Plug division of General Motors. It is made by that division for the British on a mass production basis and is used extensively in Wellingtons and other British night bombers.
CHICAGO, July 19 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follow:

CHICAGO, July 19 -- Behind locked doors tonight the Democratic Convention's platform-drafting committee was perfecting a platform for presentation to the convention some time tomorrow. Included in the party declaration, it was understood, will be a plank calling for membership of this country in a world organization of nations empowered to keep the peace by force if necessary.
CHICAGO, July 19 -- Following is the prepared text of Gov. Robert S. Kerr's keynote speech before the Democratic convention tonight:

LONDON, July 19 -- Field Marshal Viscount Gort, Governor and Commander in Chief of Malta, has been appointed High Commissioner and Commander in Chief for Palestine and High Commissioner for Trans-Jordan in succession to Sir Harold MacMichael, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Fourteen more Japanese ships, including a destroyer and a medium-sized naval auxiliary, have been sunk by American submarines in the Pacific and the Far East, the Navy Department announced today.

The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, major American agency for the relief of Jews abroad, in the first half of this year appropriated $10,459,472 for rescue, relief and rehabilitation of refugees overseas, the committee reported yesterday.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES, in Normandy, July 19 -- This is the full story of the two "lost battalions" of the force that finally conquered St. Lo. It was gleaned today, sentence by sentence, from a modest lieutenant colonel who was a major yesterday and has just been promoted in the field for gallantry and efficiency.

To help meet the need for cotton duck tenting, mill representatives in Worth Street, who have been hard pressed for this material by the Amy and Navy, advanced the suggestion yesterday that an immediate survey be undertaken by the War Production Board of rayon weavers to determine what looms can be converted to cotton duck production, and that a directive be issued to bring these looms into the program.

Advertising linage in newspapers in fifty-two cities throughout the country during June was off 1.2 per cent, compared with the same month last year, according to Media Records. Classified had the largest loss, or 11.5 per cent; department store advertising was next with a loss of 3.7 per cent, and general third with .2 per cent.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 19 -- Gene Tierney has been named by Twentieth Century-Fox for the role of Tina, the feminine lead in "A Bell for Adano." As the heroine of the John Hersey story was described as a blonde, Miss Tierney will wear a wig in the picture.

In a concerted effort to break up Harlem hoodlum gangs, a special squad of twelve plainclothes patrolmen early yesterday arrested seven Harlem youths on various charges ranging from disorderly conduct to violation of the Sullivan Law.

WITH THE EIGHTH ARMY, near Gubbic, Italy, July 19 (U.P.) -- A group of 232 Italian refugees, including seventy children, kneel almost constantly in prayer in a monastery atop Monte Ingino, asking deliverance from the fate that befell civilians in the famed Monte Cassino Abbey, while 2,000 feet below a British officer dodges German shells and wonders how long he can withhold his fire.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- Long before the scheduled meeting hour of 11:30 A.M., Central War Time, delegates to the Democratic convention began crowding to the floor of the Stadium, while the galleries were filled to about one-third of the 25,000 capacity.

PHILADELPHIA, July 19 -- A rule providing for uniform accounting procedure in the treatment of tax savings resulting from accelerated amortization of war plants and other installations in the public utilities industry has been recommended to the Securities and Exchange Commission by the public utilities division, it was disclosed today.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 19 (AP) -- Mrs. Virginia Wolfenden Kovacs of Oakland, Calif., gained a hard-fought upset victory today over Mrs. Helen Pedersen Rihbany of New York to advance to the semifinals in the 44th annual Pennsylvania and Eastern States Women's Tennis championships at the Merion Cricket Club.

The present beef crisis and the black market was blamed yesterday on the Office of Price Administration, the Office of Economic Stabilization and the War Food Administration by Wesley Hardenbergh, president of the American Meat Institute.
LONDON, July 19 -- Salvos of flying bombs rained on London and southern England yesterday, last night and today in the greatest sustained attack since the German terror weapon was introduced.

Police Department general order was read to all uniformed members of the department when they went on duty yesterday, directing them to check up on the draft status of all men between the ages of 18 and 64 who were interrogated by them or who came into the buildings of the department.

Crown Princess Martha of Norway formally opened yesterday the new 127-room Norwegian Seamen's house in Brooklyn, which the Norwegian Government has established at a cost of $400,000 and now operates through the Social Welfare Committee for Norwegian Seamen in America.

In its first change of ownership in sixty years, the three-story residence at 222 East Sixty-second Street was sold by the J.L. Hiller Realty Corporation, W.J.
