Kearney, president, to a client of McLaughlin Stickles, attorneys. It is assessed at $22,000 and will be occupied by the new owner, according to Pease Elliman, the brokers in the sale.

ALBANY, July 19 -- The Court of Appeals, in a six-to-one decision, ruled today that the Albany County Jury Act, passed by the 1944 Legislature under pressure from the office of Governor Dewey, was unconstitutional, in that it violated the Home Rule Provision of the Constitution.

RAY JOSEPHS, a Philadelphia newspaper man, went to Buenos Aires for a three-month visit in 1940 and stayed on for four years. As journalistic tenure is reckoned these days, this makes him a veteran foreign correspondent, a person who has the right to speak his mind on the country of his professional adoption.

If mothers were better fed before the birth of their infants the number of babies that might be shifted from a "poor health" to a "good health" classification during the first two weeks of their lives would reach 900,000 in a single year, it was estimated yesterday in a report on food research activities conducted during the last two years by the Nutrition Foundation, Inc.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- Democratic women balanced frivolity against diligence today, providing an interlude of relaxation in the middle of a schedule which began early and ended late. They went to school this morning to absorb electioneering techniques, recessed for supper and wound up at the evening session of the convention.

Concerned with the growing trend among prime manufacturers of "pulling back" subcontracts, officials of the Smaller War Plants Corporation are planning a strong campaign to support its case for wider participation of small plants in the "spot authorization plan" which is scheduled to go into effect on Aug. 15, it was learned yesterday.

Two detectives from the Hunters Point police station stopped little Alberta Joseph, 5 years old, as she was riding a tricycle yesterday on the sidewalk near her home at 41-21 Forty-third Street, Long Island City.

A graphic demonstration of the uses to which plastics have been put in military, industrial and civilian life may be seen in a new exhibit that opened yesterday under the sponsorship of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office in cooperation with the magazine, Modern Plastics, at the CDVO Information Center at Pershing Square.
U.S. ARMY HEADQUARTERS, in the Central Pacific, July 19 -- Maj. Gen. Ralph C. Smith has been named commander of an unidentified division in the Hawaiian Islands, the Army announced today.

FAIRVIEW, N.J., July 19 -- An explosion believed by county and local detectives to have been caused by a bomb dropped from a single engined silver monoplane that had passed over the spot seconds before tore a hole ten feet wide and six feet deep in Mount Moriah Cemetery just off Bergen Boulevard here at 10:40 A.M. today.
Large apartment buildings on West End Avenue were among West Side properties reported in new ownership yesterday.

The appropriately named War Jeep, son of War Admiral, won a wartime renewal of the East View Stakes, run yesterday at Jamaica as the climax for 2-year-olds at the Empire City meeting. The test grossed $14,150 and saw some excitement before and after in addition to what thrills the running brought.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Earl G. Harrison of Philadelphia resigned today as Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization after having served two years and having completed the reorganization of the service following its transfer to the Department of Justice.

THE female of the species may be more deadly than the male but no lover of the thoroughbred ever has been willing to believe it before. However, the horsemen are weakening on the subject and by nightfall on Saturday they probably will be convinced. If Twilight Tear can win the rich Arlington Classic, she undoubtedly will be acclaimed as the champion 3-year-old of the season, the first filly ever to be so honored.

Mayor La Guardia scolded Martin Sweeney, president of the Hotel Association of New York City, Inc., yesterday for having written him a letter urging that he withdraw his recent appeal to Mayors of other cities to discourage their residents from making vacation trips to New York.

According to last Saturday's TIMES, Brig. Gen. Bryan, provost marshal in charge of prisoners of war, stated that the United States was adhering to the Geneva Convention "entirely." He should have added except with regard to Austrian prisoners.

CHUNGKING, China, July 19 (U.P.) -- Chinese forces have hammered out further gains in the Hengyang fighting in Hunan Province and again driven the Japanese back in the region south of Leiyang, forty miles below Hengyang on the bitterly contested rail route to Canton, but a spokesman for the Chinese Government, describing the battle in Hunan as "reaching its climax," today cautioned against undue optimism.

The chewing gum industry which did a volume of more than $300,000,000 in 1940 and which at present is enjoying unprecedented prosperity, has a future potential of even greater magnitude, according to B.A. Bolt Jr., sales manager of Bowman Gum, Inc., Philadelphia.

A special portfolio for use by newspapers in selling the idea of "public relations advertising" to the nation's small businesses has been designed by the Meyer Both Company and sent to clients of that agency, it was announced yesterday.

ALBANY, July 19 -- James J. Hines, convicted Tammany leader who sought by certiorari to compel the State Parole Board to review its action in refusing him a parole, was denied that authority by the Court of Appeals this afternoon.

MOSCOW, Thursday, July 20 -- Marshal Ivan S. Koneff's swift-driving First Ukrainian Army swept across the western Bug River north and south of Sokal yesterday and advance forces drove to a point within eight and a half miles of Lwow, while mopping up troops in the rear completed the encirclement of a German army group, estimated to consist of four to five divisions, west of Brody.

PORTBOU, Spain, July 19 (AP) -- French patriot organizations have turned their energies against the Germans' dwindling fuel supplies throughout France, destroying gasoline, oil and coal already stored or enroute to dumps and sabotaging mines and production plants, border reports said today.

The less urgent trade demand, small selling orders from the South, and liquidation from New Orleans, carried prices for cotton futures to net losses of 13 to 18 points yesterday, on the New York Cotton Exchange.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- Ralph A. Bard, Under-Secretary of the Navy, reported today a shortage of 30,000 workers in Navy shipyards and production plants, principally on the Pacific Coast."

CHICAGO, July 19 -- Rallying uproariously to repeated calls to stand by the "Commander in Chief," but faced with the bitterest inter-party row of the last twelve years over the selection of a candidate for Vice President, the twenty-eighth quadrennial Democratic Convention got under way in the stadium today.

The major's name is not yet known. Last Sunday he led his battalion up the Bayeux road to a hamlet called La Madeleine, in front of St. Lo. There he reinforced another gallant officer, Maj. Sidney V. Bingham of Dallas, Tex., and there both battalions found themselves surrounded.

MOSCOW, Thursday, June 20 (UP) -- Along an almost continuous 800-mile front from Lake Ladoga to Lwow, nine Russian armies, fighting in five countries, were hurling the Germans back to Germany yesterday in the greatest Red Army offensive of the war.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 19 -- Nazi Germany will attempt to meet the critical situation arising from this week's reverses to German arms on all fronts by giving Heinrich Himmler such powers within the Wehrmacht that he will henceforth, for all practical purposes, be the new Fuehrer, thus supplanting Hitler, this writer has learned from the best Berlin sources.

Early speed and late foot, tremendous assets to a thoroughbred but sadly lacking to Brooklyn, a horse of another color recently, helped the Dodgers record a 10-5 victory over the Reds at Ebbets Field last night.

PEARL HARBOR, July 19 -- Guam Island is now pounded every day by powerful American fleet units pouring a tremendous weight of steel into the defenses, and its skies are shadowed without relief by swarms of American carrier planes bombing the Japanese installations and blasting them with rocket guns.

Shoe rationing will not be relaxed this year nor will any clothes or cosmetics rationing programs be undertaken, so far as the Office of Price Administration knows, Charles Philips, deputy OPA administrator in charge of rationing, declared yesterday.

During the two-year period since it was formed on June 1, 1942, the United Theatrical War Activities Committee, which represents all branches of the entertainment world, supplied 45,682 performers in 16,225 acts to 3,459 events, according to an editorial in the new issue of Equity, the magazine published by the stage actors union.

A Kings County Grand Jury handed up a presentment to Judge Franklin Taylor yesterday requesting assistance from the State Attorney General's office in its inquiry into borough gambling and charges of police irregularities. The panel, which has been active since July, 1943, called upon Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein to appoint for this purpose a special deputy or an assistant attorney general.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Publicly reported cash dividend payments in the United States amounted to $444,400,000 in June, which represents an increase of $28,700,000 over the $415,700,000 distributed in the same month of last year, the Department of Commerce announced today.

DETROIT, July 19 (AP) -- Successive errors in the tenth inning by Joe Kuhel, George Myatt and Rick Ferrell enabled the Tigers to gain a 2-to-1 victory today over the Senators. It was Detroit's second straight triumph in the series and its ninth in 12 games with Washington this season.
ROME, July 19 (UP) -- A communique:
CHICAGO, July 19 (AP) -- After losing eleven straight games to the Red Sox this year, the White Sox finally managed to squeeze out a victory in their twelfth meeting today, 5 to 4.
Chicago, July 19 -- Following is the scheduled program of the Democratic Convention tomorrow:

LONDON, July 19 (U.P.) -- French Forces of the Interior, reinforced with Allied arms, have beaten off strong German forces in two battles and inflicted considerable casualties on the Nazis, a communiqu issued tonight by authoritative French quarters reported.

Can it be that THE TIMES was indulging in a quiet pun when, in the caption of a photograph from Normandy, it called a group of Army bakers "doughboys"? CHICAGO, July 19 -- Sentiment for Wallace for Vice President was apparent in the New York delegation today as it held its first caucus.
PHILADELPHIA, July 19 (AP) -- Holder of a shut-out until two were out in the ninth, Ken Raffensberger held the Pirates to six hits in pitching the Phillies to a 4-2 victory tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 19 -- Circumstances of the disastrous Port Chicago munitions explosion of Monday night, as well as the damage it did to government and private property, will be checked by a Navy court of inquiry convening at the blast scene on Friday morning.
MOSCOW, July 19 -- Barriers to establishing normal relations between Moscow and the Vatican are not considered insurmountable here.

LONDON, July 19 -- London newspapers that asked the French Committee of National Liberation to repudiate the action of Norman citizens who have shaved the heads of minor women collaborators got their answer today from Emmanuel d'Astier de la Vigerie, Algiers Commissioner of the Interior.

The office of Price Administration, it was learned yesterday, is working out a plan to give the same sort of price protection to the eater of exotic dishes as its recently announced regulation will give after Aug. 15 to those who order ham and eggs, sirloin steak or any of thirty-eight other staple dishes in public eating establishments.
CLEVELAND, July 19 (AP) -- The Indians pounced on Bobo Newsom for a dozen hits today as they defeated the Athletics, 7 to 1. The victory was the Tribe's second of the series with the Mackmen.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- The Connecticut delegation to the Democratic convention held a caucus this morning and by a vote of 16 to 2, decided to cast the State's 18 votes, under the unit rule, for the renomination of Vice President Wallace.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The Office of Price Administration transferred several items of industrial machinery, farm equipment and other industrial equipment today from the price regulation for consumer durable goods to other rulings "better suited" for these particular articles.

LONDON, July 19 -- A tall, slender Frenchman with the face of a matinee idol talked in London today of one of the things for which France is most celebrated -- food. He spoke, not gaily of truffles and pate de foi gras and snails with butter and garlic, but gravely of the everyday Frenchman's daily bread and meat and milk.

ROME, July 20 -- Another large stretch of southern Italy was turned over to the Italian Government today and at the same time it was announced that Rome and the surrounding territory would be placed under Italian jurisdiction on Aug. 15.

BOSTON, July 20 (AP) -- Charlie Rufi's favored Dense Path registered a two-and-a-half-length victory today at Suffolk Downs in the $2,500 Vice Admiral Waesche purse of a mile and a sixteenth, feature event of Coast Guard Day.

Yesterday's German report of the attempted assassination of Hitler is the second officially admitted attempt to kill the Fuehrer since his accession to power in 1933, although there have been many unconfirmed stories of other occasions when assassins and plotters sought to take his life.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 20 (AP) -- Stockholders of the Pan American Airways Corporation, at an annual meeting today, re-elected J.T. Trippe as president and named three new members to the board of directors.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- American organizations aiding in the evacuation of European refugees through Spain have had the support of the United States Embassy in Madrid and the Spanish Government, a State Department official said today.
Composite 1, the air squadron that blazed the trail for the Navy in "baby flat-top" operations against the U-boat, was disbanded recently, Third Naval District Headquarters announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The Federal Trade Commission announced today that complaints had been issued against three New York companies, the National Electric Manufacturers Company, distributors of shafting for ship valves, and the firms of Lewis Conger and the C. W. Products Company, both engaged in the sale of "foxhole pillows."

Sir Bernard L. Montgomery's drive eastward across the Orne River, were so utterly stunned that they had not recovered their calmness today.

While police have not relaxed regulations to permit "doubling-up" of passengers in taxicabs, they have adopted a more tolerant attitude toward the practice and now permit doubling up under certain conditions in as many as thirty-eight places in the city, it was learned yesterday.

ALBANY, July 20 -- A two-hour meeting with his State Cabinet and an evening conference with Herbert Brownell Jr., national chairman, occupied the attention of Governor Dewey today as the Democratic national convention proceeded with the renomination of President Roosevelt as his opponent in the November election.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

THE TIMES editorial "Herriot" is so timely and deserving that I cannot resist breaking a long silence regarding the French political background, gained through four years among them, to draw attention to at least another evidence of Herriot's stanchness and willingness to sacrifice himself for the honor of "old France."

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Shoe dealers were authorized by the Office of Price Administration today to apply for permission to sell certain types of factory-damaged men's and women's shoes on a ration-free basis.

The new chapel to be erected !after the war at Pine and William Streets by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York will be called Our Lady of Victory Church, it became known yesterday when details qf the project were announced at the Chancery Office, 477 /%{adison Avenue.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- Democratic forces opposing the renomination of President Roosevelt and continuance of the New Deal polled 90 of the 1,176 votes of the national convention this evening after repeated demonstrations which brought the party disharmony into the open and during which thirty-three of fifty-five "regular" delegates and alternates from Texas walked out of the convention.

The recent "let-down" of blood donors who made appointments with the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross after the invasion of Normandy has interfered with the steady supply of plasma for the men in the armed forces, Maj. Gen. Robert C. Davis, executive director of the chapter, declared yesterday.

Eight thousand Brooklyn boys made large contributions to the waste paper salvage campaign yesterday and at the same time gained free admission to the ball game at Ebbetts Field between the Dodgers and the Cincinnati Reds.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- Asserting that "we must not commit the lives and the future of the American people to inexperience and negation," Mrs. Helen Gahagan Douglas, Democratic national committeewoman from California, and formerly a well-known actress, predicted the triumphant re-election of President Roosevelt in an address tonight before the Democratic National Convention.

Adolf Hitler had a narrow escape from death by assassination at his secret headquarters, the Berlin radio reported yesterday, and a few hours later in a radio broadcast to the German people he blamed an "officers' clique" for the attempt to kill him.

The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday that its subsidiary, the H.C. Frick Coal Company, is now pushing to completion the development of a new mine at Robena, in Greene County, Pa., which will be the largest bituminous coal producer in the world.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- The foreign policy plank adopted by the Democratic convention this evening not only goes beyond the plank approved by the Republicans three weeks ago, but goes further in defining the means by which peace should be enforced than the Roosevelt administration has ever gone before.

A bomb explosion almost in Adolf Hitler's face cast a lurid and momentary light yesterday over the darkness of Germany and Nazi-held Europe. The story is not complete and may not be until after the war.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- By allowing mothers to be up on the third or fourth day after delivery, instead of remaining in bed ten or twelve days, experience in Sinai Hospital of Baltimore and elsewhere indicates that the confinement period can be safely shortened and that bed shortages can be relieved in part, Dr. Morris L. Rotstein of Baltimore reports in The Journal of the American Medical Association.
LONDON, July 20 (AP) -- The weekly condition statement of the Bank of England for week ended July 19 reported a decrease of 2,493,000 in note circulation.

The New York Stock Exchange membership of the late John J. Ahern has been transferred to George C. Dinsmore of Stokes, Hoyt Co. The Exchange board of governors has approved William F. O'Connor as an alternate for Garrow T. Geer Jr., and A. Brendan Cooke as alternate for Herbert W. Sierck.

LONDON, July 20 -- Although business was on a small scale again today, the stock market continued cheerful in tone.
On the seventieth birthday of the veteran trainer, Jim Fitzsimmons, one of his charges, Free Lance, got home first with most in the Empire-at-Jamaica crowd of 19,897 hanging on the outcome.

Bander, vice president of McKesson Robbins, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The recently reported 15 per cent shortage for seventy-two selected textile and clothing items which the War Production Board's Office of Civilian Requirements found in a survey covering the period January to March, 1944, cut deepest in the lowest age groups, a further analysis of the figures showed today.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- American warships constituted approximately one-quarter of the fighting craft participating in the invasion of Normandy, and about two out of five of all vessels concerned, Capt. A.H. Maxwell-Hyslop, commander of the British battleship Nelson, said today in an interview.

The "preference delivery quota" program that will be utilized by the Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation to insure smooth distribution of its radios following the peace, will be started next week, Benjamin Abrams, president of Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation, announced yesterday.

With the National War Fund's 1944 appeal scheduled to start Oct. 1 and continued until Nov. 1, the War Advertising Council released yesterday a new campaign guide in cooperation with the Office of War Information and the National War Fund.

More than fifty poems by William Rose Benet, Pulitzer Prize winner and brother of Stephen Vincent Benet, make up "Day of Deliverance: A Book of Poems in Wartime," to be published Aug. 17 by Knopf. The poems are written about many of the States of this country, many of the United Nations, and some of the historic battles of this war.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 20 -- The newest attempt to blow up Hitler heralds, in the minds of competent Stockholm observers, a fresh Himmler terror wave.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Friday, July 21 -- Tanks and infantry of the British Second Army, battling stubborn German rearguards at Troarn and St. Andre-sur-Orne, yesterday, widened the eleven-mile front south and east of Caen that Lieut. Gen. Miles C. Dempsey's troops have punched out in three days of audacious and arduous fighting.

Nearly 8,000 boys carted 120 tons of scrap paper to Ebbets Field yesterday as their tickets of admission, and when the ball game was over the screeching and screaming youngsters were ready to add the Dodgers themselves to the scrap heap.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- The arrest last night by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents at Knoxville, Tenn., of Waldemar Othmer, 35-year-old naturalized citizen, on an espionage charge was announced today by the Department of Justice.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Friday, July 21 (UP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Top officials of the War Department are deeply concerned over what they term the country's "peace jitters," a state of mind which they say is affecting, and which they fear may affect more seriously, current war production.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- In sharp contrast to four years ago, New York this evening gave 94 1/2 of its 96 votes to President Roosevelt, for a fourth-term nomination. Two of James A. Farley's intimate friends cast half votes apiece for the former national chairman, while Mr. Farley himself cast his half-vote for Senator Byrd of Virginia.

A boxing card that is likely to attract the sum of $50,000,000 into the United States Treasury was arranged yesterday by the Treasury Department and the Fifth War Loan Sports Committee, of which Max Kase, sports editor of The New York Journal-American, is chairman.
CHICAGO, July 20 -- The text of the Democratic platform as adopted late this afternoon is as follows:

GREAT NECK, L.I., July 20 -- Alarmed over the geographical expansion of the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, a committee representing property owners in eight incorporated villages on the Great Neck Peninsula sent a telegram and a delegation to Washington today to protest two recent acquisitions and to seek assurance that no further land would be added.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- A platform calling for the participation of this country with the United Nations in a world organization, empowered to use armed force when necessary to preserve international peace, was adopted by the Democratic convention tonight.

HEADQUARTERS OF THE UNITED STATES FOURTEENTH AIR FORCE, China, July 20 -- Although news from central China continues to sound grave and perhaps ominous, Maj. Gen. Claire L. Chennault of the United States Fourteenth Air Force retained his usual long-range cheerfulness in an interview today.

A transition period of about a year is being allowed by the State Department of Labor for the education of employers and employes affected by the new equal pay law that became operative July 1, Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi declared yesterday.

Fresh produce continues in liberal supply this week-end with a good choice of vegetables offered, some of which have declined in cost, according to the War Food Administration. Lima beans, snap beans, beets, tomatoes and green peppers are among those selling at lower levels.
Two apartment houses and a private dwelling in the Greenwich Village section passed to new owners in deals announced yesterday by Frances Spencer, Inc., broker in the transactions.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- Gov. Robert S. Kerr of Oklahoma, temporary chairman of the Democratic National Convention, called the third session to order at 11:58 A.M. with the great majority of delegates in their seats, but less than half the public seats occupied by spectators.
Tariff discussions often confuse rather than enlighten the average reader because of failure to clearly define some of the terms.
Following is the text of Adolf Hitler's speech, as broadcast over the German radio "from the Fuehrer's headquarters" to the German people and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

THE late Alexander Woollcott was a fabulous individual who took infinite pains in building up his own legend, infinite relish in his own personality. He wrote with charm and gusto. He spoke on the radio with contagious enthusiasm. He was generous, sentimental, talented and witty. He had an enormous gift for friendship that won the devotion of scores of persons, most of them witty and celebrated, too, but by no means all of them.

CHICAGO, July 20 (AP) -- The Red Sox became the first major league team to win the season's series from another today when they made it twelve victories in thirteen games with the White Sox by taking a free-hitting contest, 11 to 7.

ROME, July 20 (U.P.) -- Details of an air battle over southern Germany Tuesday in which a Fifteenth Air Force Flying Fortress group lost half its bombers was revealed today and bad weather was blamed for much of the death toll.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- During the week ended July 15 the Bureau of Labor Statistics index of commodity prices at the primary market level remained unchanged at 103.9 per cent of the 1926 average. In the last four weeks the bureau's all-commodity index has risen 0.2 per cent and it is 1 per cent higher than in mid-July of last year.

ROME, July 20 -- American troops battered their way across the Arno River Valley on a 25-mile front between Pisa and Florence today as German forces, bewildered by the sudden breakthrough, retreated across the Arno into the mountain defenses of their Gothic Line.

CANBERRA, Australia, July 20 -- Though wages generally are pegged as part of the Australian Government's wartime control of industry, regulations have been promulgated empowering not fewer than three judges of the Commonwealth Arbitration Court to increase women's minimum wages in vital industries where it finds them unreasonably low compared with those paid to women employed in other essential industries under other awards of the Arbitration Court or State tribunals.

PEARL HARBOR, July 20 -- Fleet forces are continuing attacks along the chain of islands pointing northward to Japan and the use of land-based aircraft is increasing, an early and as yet small indication of what Japan may expect in the future as a result of the loss of its important Saipan base.

Plans for post-war education in Britain call for an extension of the national school system to include the training of all children between 2 and 18 years old, as well as a great increase in number of nursery schools, Kenneth Lindsay, British Member of Parliament and former Minister of Education, declared yesterday.

LONDON, July 20 -- Broadcasting so that the German people could hear his voice and know that he was unhurt after the attempt to assassinate him, Chancellor Adolf Hitler confirmed tonight all rumors and suspicions of disaffection and unrest in the Reich.

Three landlords who pleaded guilty to having increased rents in violation of Office of Price Administration regulations were fined a total of $240 yesterday by Magistrate Joseph DeAndrea in Flushing Court. Bernard Fremont, OPA enforcement attorney, told the court the defendants had paid back the overcharges.
Following is the text of President Roosevelt's acceptance speech from a Pacific Coast naval base, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

In your editorial "Anniversary in Greece" you compare the total destruction of Distomo, in which all men, women and children were tortured and killed by the Germans, to a similar event at Lidice, in Czechoslovakia, two years ago. In the interim, readers of the daily papers have often seen the name of one Greek village after another labeled "A Greek Lidice."

Immediately after announcing the "attempt on Hitler's life" to the German people, Nazi propagandists began yesterday to exploit the story by saying that every German was now under "obligation to intensify his effort in this struggle," and Hitler himself in his broadcast last night said that "by stamping out this very small clique of traitors and conspirators we will now at last create that atmosphere in the rear, at home, that the fighting front needs."

Official announcement of the departure of Archbishop Francis J. Spellman to confer with Pope Pius XII and visit the war fronts as Military Vicar of the Armed Forces of the United States was made yesterday at the Chancery office of the Archdiocese of New York, 477 Madison Avenue.

Gen. Kuniaki Koiso, a member of the same Kwantung Army group to which former Premier Gen. Hideki Tojo belongs, arrived in Tokyo from Korea yesterday to participate with Admiral Mitsumasa Yonai in the formation of a new "critical decisive war time" Cabinet by "command" of Emperor Hirohito, it was disclosed in Japanese broadcasts and press dispatches reported to the Office of War Information by the Federal Communications Commission.

LAREDO, Texas, July 20 -- Travelers from Mexico City said this evening that a riot occurred in front of the National Palace at 2 P.M. today when several thousand persons attempted to force their way through the gate and to the office of President Manuel Avila Camacho.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- The Chicago Stadium rocked and vibrated for almost forty minutes this afternoon after Senator Barkley of Kentucky closed his nominating speech with the announcement, "I present to this assembly for the office of President of these United States the name of Franklin Delano Roosevelt."
CHICAGO, July 20 -- The prepared addresses by Senator Barkley, who put President Roosevelt in nomination, and of Vice President Wallace, who seconded the nomination, were as follows:

DETROIT, July 20 (AP) -- Rudy York batted in four runs and Dick Wakefield belted his third homer today as the Tigers defeated the Senators, 7 to 6, for their third straight victory of the series and tenth triumph over Washington in thirteen games this season.

OTTAWA, July 20 (Canadian Press) -- The Belgian Embassy here said today the British Broadcasting Corporation Belgian service had broadcast a message to Belgian workers deported to Germany urging them to prepare plans immediately for action against their Nazi conquerors.

The three-story business building at 512 Eighty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, assessed at $295,000, has been purchased by Warren Steven Realty Corporation from Samuel Lemberg and Nathan S. Goldstein through Joseph H. Nassoit, Inc. Sale was subject to a consolidated mortgage of $254,400.

ST. LOUIS, July 20 -- Touching off a five-run explosion in the seventh inning with a pair of rousing home runs by Mike Chartak and George McQuinn that sent Hank Borowy hurtling off the mound, Luke Sewell's Browns went back to taking another firm grip on first place in the American League tonight by drubbing the Yankees, 7 to 3.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 20 (AP) -- Two Army pilots and one civilian were killed and a dozen civilians injured today when two Army pursuit planes crashed into a residential section. The planes damaged houses, some badly, along a two-block stretch and debris was strewn for blocks.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- Well pleased with what they termed its "forthright" declarations on foreign and domestic issues, Democratic leaders predicted here tonight that the platform would insure success for the party in November.

Paul McGuarde, 30 years old, of 116 West Ninetieth Street, a special patrolman for the Long Island Railroad, who was an applicant for appointment as a temporary patrolman on the city force, was held in $3,500 bail in the Felony Court yesterday on the accusation of Edward Doyle, 17, a clerk, of 157 West 105th Street, that McGuarde, posing as a city detective, extorted $40 from him under threat of arrest.

It was with considerable relief that Wall Street yesterday saw election betting odds -- 3 to 1 for Roosevelt, 1 to 2 1/2 against Dewey -- being quoted in St. Louis rather than in the financial district. There always has been a good deal of misunderstanding about election odds coming out of Wall Street.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, July 20 (U.P.) -- American, British and Chinese forces have dealt further reverses to the weakening Japanese along the rain-soaked, tortuous 700-mile Burma front, particularly near the border of India's Manipur State, where the enemy has been driven out of the Imphal plain into the hills to the south.
CHICAGO, July 20 -- The prepared address of Senator Samuel D. Jackson of Indiana, permanent chairman of the Democratic National Convention, was as follows:

Reports of unrest in Europe, continued uncertainty regarding Office of Price Administration ceilings on yarns and goods and favorable weather in the cotton belt brought out further liquidation in the local cotton futures market yesterday and active months on the close were 13 to 15 points net lower.
LONDON, July 20 -- The pattern of everyday life in southern England is being slowly readjusted to ever present threat of sudden death from flying bombs.
CLEVELAND, July 20 (AP) -- Steve Gromek hurled the Indians to their third straight triumph over the Athletics today, the Tribe winning, 2 to 1, on the strength of Roy Cullenbine's double.
YENAN, China, July 16 (Delayed) -- The slogans of the Communist party are carefully planned as concise expressions of their immediate policies as well as of the platform on which they seek support.

This is the time that people roaming the woods find young animals that appear to be deserted and, out of a spirit of kindness, adopt them. Dr. Ira N. Gabrielson, director of the Fish and Wildlife Service, made an appeal yesterday that these tender creatures be left alone.

Nevil Ford, State Chairman of the War Finance Committee, issued a reminder yesterday that only nine business days remain during which sales of individual war bond issues, including E bonds, can be counted toward Fifth War Loan quotas.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Friday, July 21 -- More than 1,200 United States heavy bombers and 750 fighters from Britain and 500 bombers with some 300 escorting planes from Italy scorched airplane-engine factories, fighter-assembly plants and oil installations in central Germany yesterday.

Schenley Distillers Corporation is reviving "floor" price protection for its brands and next week will mail to package store retailers a new list to become effective under the Feld-Crawford fair trade law, it was learned yesterday. This action will follow that already taken by Hiram Walker, Inc., both distilling organizations using Office of Price Administration ceilings as their fair trade prices.

Nervousness over the war situation became noticeable yesterday in the stock market as the reactionary movement was reinstated. A renewal of the demand for the rails brought about an extension of the Wednesday recovery in the morning, but a wave of selling in the final hour eliminated the earlier gains and set the list back as much as a point in several favorite issues.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- Franklin Delano Roosevelt of New York was nominated today for a fourth term as President of the United States by a noisy, irritable Democratic convention, meeting in the same hall where he was chosen for his first term in 1932 and for a third in 1940.
The Axis has taken several blows in the last few days that recall Prime Minister Churchill's remark that "the worm is in the apple" -- made at the time of the flight of Rudolf Hess, three years ago.
ROME, July 20 (UP) -- A communique:

LONDON, Friday, July 21 (U.P.) -- The Red Army's new offensive -the eighth in less than a month -- had carried the southern wing of Marshal Konstantin K. Rokossovsky's First White Russian Army last night to within twenty-six miles southeast of Brest-Litovsk and forty-seven miles east of Lublin, one of the outer bastions of Warsaw.

If there is anything more futile these days -- or nights -- than playing a game of baseball against the Cardinals it's playing them twice in the same afternoon. The Giants, if they didn't know it before, learned that much yesterday at the Polo Grounds where the team that is admittedly the best in the league made merry at the expense of the locals.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) --Ninety-one of the country's ninety-eight registered distillers plan to produce beverage alcohol during the August "holiday" from war alcohol production, the War Production Board reported today.

SPRINGDALE, Conn., July 20 -- Miss Polly Andrews of Innis Arden, a three-time association champion, playing in her first tournament of the season, won low-gross honors in the one-day event of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association at Woodway Country Club today, with a card of 43, 42 -- 85.

"Ninety-nine Park," headquarters of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, Inc.*, offers a partial list of free amusements available today through the generosity of the entertainment world. Afternoon tickets from 11 A.M.; evening tickets after 4 P.M.

WITH THE PRESIDENT AT A PACIFIC COAST NAVAL BASE, July 20 (AP) -- President Roosevelt's acceptance speech, broadcast from here tonight to the Democratic Convention at Chicago, climaxed a cross-country trip that was shrouded in secrecy.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 20 -- Belgium's extensive and complicated network of rail and road communications was reported in a special Allied communique today to have been "largely disrupted" as the result of the "highly satisfactory" operations of the Belgian underground.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- The Democratic party capitulated today and incorporated in its platform a plank favoring submission to the States of a constitutional amendment providing for equal rights for women.

Many patriotic savers of waste paper must agree with the letter of Jeanne B. Bayne. However, they will feel better if they realize that the Government may not accept a gift and does not have the means of collecting or processing paper.

Rarely have I received a greater shock than when it was announced that not a single quiz program contestant knew the name of the doctor who discovered penicillin -- the drug that will not only prevent untold suffering, but will also save millions of lives. Just think of it -- the name of Dr. Alexander Fleming is unknown to a vast adult population.

The New York City Selective Service headquarters has granted to a committee of the Office of Defense Transportation authority to investigate requests for draft deferment by essential automotive mechanics and to submit recommendations on the applications, it was announced yesterday by the ODT district office in the Empire State Building.
KANSAS CITY, July 20 (AP) -The 91-year-old mother of Senator Truman does not want her son to be Vice President. She believes he should stay in the Senate where 'e can do more good."

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended July 15, totaled 904, 804 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 159,663 cars, or 21.4 per cent mote than for the preceding week, 27,469 cars, or 3.1 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year and 47,658 cars, or 5.6 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The War Production Board advised pre-war manufacturers of household washing machines today to take advantage of the reconversion orders which have already been issued to facilitate the adjustment to civilian production once again, and to prepare for other orders still to come.

Eugene Holman, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, estimated yesterday that the consolidated net earnings of his company for the six months ended on June 30 were about $71,000,000 after providing for all taxes and $13,500,000 for wartime and post-war contingencies.

Among voters who haev decided how they will cast their ballot in this year's Presidential election, President Roosevelt holds a decided edge, according to a poll conducted for Fortune magazine and made public yesterday. The results showed the President with a 6:5 per cent lead.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- America has accomplished "the greatest military and industrial miracle of the ages under the leadership of Franklin D. Roosevelt," Quentin Reynolds, war correspondent and author, told the Democratic Convention tonight.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- In an attempt to bolster the waning strength of Senator Harry S. Truman of Missouri for the nomination for Vice President, Robert E. Hannegan, Democratic national chairman, made public tonight the letter written to him by President Roosevelt, saying that either Senator Truman or William O. Douglas, justice of the United States Supreme Court, would be satisfactory to him as a running mate and would add strength to the ticket.

It is no accident that foreign policy gave the Republican platform-makers their chief trouble, whereas the hardest problem for the Democrats this week has been what to say, or whether to say anything, about the position of the Negro in American life. These are the two historic questions on which different Republicans in one case and different Democrats in the other have long held conflicting opinions.

Republicans began yesterday an investigation of all signatures on petitions designating Representative Vito Marcantonio as a candidate for the Republican Congressional nomination in the new Eighteenth district. Their action was based on reports that many signatures were forged.

Day nurseries will not be operated this summer in city school buildings. Although the Board of Education last week granted it permission to use school facilities from July 1 to Sept. 1, the Mayor's Committee on Wartime Care of Children has found that it "can't possibly" equip new nurseries in time to make the project worthwhile, Helen Harris, the committee's executive director, disclosed yesterday.

Thirteen independent suburban slaughterers, accused by the Office of Price Administration of having diverted half a million pounds of dressed beef from rationing channels by failing to turn in sufficient red points, were ordered yesterday to appear Monday and Tuesday at hearings in the Empire State Building.

Hollywood to Broadway transition: Jane Withers, who achieved prominence in the film capital, will essay her first Broadway part in Dave Wolper's forthcoming musical, "Have a Good Time." In a singing and dancing assignment she will share stellar billing with Lupe Velez.

BRETTON WOODS, N. H., July 20 -- The silver-using nations, led by Mexico, won a concession today from the United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference when a resolution was approved which pledges the nations interested in silver to give the problem further study.

CHUNGKING, July 20 (U.P.) -- The confused behind-the-lines fighting east and west of the Siang River in Hunan Province continued today, the communique said, but there were no indications of decisive results for either side. Fighting still is going on near Liuyang, forty miles east of Changsha, at Liling, fifty miles southeast of the large enemy base, and in the Chaling and Yushien sectors due east of battle-scarred Hengyang.

BOSTON, July 20 (AP) -- The Braves pulled into a sixth-place tie with the Dodgers and dumped the Cubs into the National League cellar today by sweeping a double-header by 5-4 margins, the opener in fourteen innings.
OLD ORCHARD BEACH, Me., July 20 (AP) -- The Ambassador, winner of the 1942 Hambletonian, showed his heels to the field in winning both heats of the 2:08 trot today's Grand Circuit feature.

MOSCOW, Friday, July 21 -- Revealing another terrific Red Army offensive, Marshal Joseph Stalin announced last night that forces led by Marshal Konstantin K. Rokossovsky, after three days' fighting in the Kovel sector, had driven a wedge thirty-one miles deep on a 123-mile front, pushing the Germans back to the western Bug River.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 20 -- A plenary session of the United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference adopted tonight the report of its fund commission, which agreed on machinery for an international monetary fund to stabilize post-war currencies, stimulate world trade and prevent competitive currency depreciation and other economic rivalries which might endanger world peace.
LONDON, July 20 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 20 -- Hal B. Wallis has negotiated a deal with David O. Selznick whereby Joan Fontaine will be starred by Wallis in a Paramount picture, "The Affairs of Susan." The comedy will be based on the original story, "Chameleon" by Lazlo Gorog and Thomas Monroe, about a thrice-divorced actress.

Financial operations in the wake of the Fifth War Loan drive dominated the report released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York for the week ended on Wednesday. The sixteen reporting New York City banks showed a sharp reduction of $200,000,000 in their loans to brokers and dealers for the purpose of carrying United States Government obligations as the securities business rapidly reduced the positions it had taken.

BALTIMORE, July 20 (AP) -- Howie Moss' fourteenth home run of the season, coming in the twelfth inning with Blas Monaco on base gave the Orioles a 2 to 1 victory over Newark in their International League tilt tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Former Ambassador Joseph C. Grew, who represented the United States in Tokio during the pre-Pearl Harbor decade; Secretary of State Cordell Hull and Acting Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson Jr., all agreed today that the ousting of Premier Hideki Tojo recorded a Japanese realization of their serious military situation, but warned that it would be a mistake to expect that Japan would slacken her fanatical resistance.
LONDON, July 20 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Ike Williams, Trenton (N.J.) lightweight battler, had little trouble with Julie Kogon of New Haven in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. Carrying the action to his rival at every opportunity, the Trenton athlete pounded Kogon about virtually at will to gain the unanimous vote of referee Frank Fullam and judges Bill Healy and Frank Forbes.
CHICAGO, July 20 -- Following is the ballot by which President Roosevelt was nominated for a fourth term, the total vote of each State being bracketed:
BARI, Italy, July 20 -- Allied intervention has managed to stave off temporarily, and possibly to avert permanently, a serious outbreak of civil war between rival guerrilla groups within Albania.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Department stores for the week ended July 15 were 14 per cent above sales in the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

Supreme Court Justice Benjamin F. Schreiber reserved decision yesterday on a suit brought by the Citizens Budget Commission to restrain the city from transferring any part of a $3,500,000 "miscellaneous appropriation" in the 1944-45 budget.

PHILADELPHIA, July 20 (AP) -- The Phillies won the second game of a swing-shift double-header, 3 to 2, today on Ford Mullen's eleventh-inning single with the bases loaded, after losing the first game, 4 to 1, before a crowd of 7,309.

MEXICO CITY, July 20 -- Mexico's first direct military contribution to the war will be in the form of an air squadron, the members of which will leave this week for training in the United States, it was made known today in circles close to the Presidency.

Patio sun, vista beige and hacienda tan comprise the three new colors portrayed in the regular edition of the fall, 1944, hosiery card, just released by the Textile Color Card Association. Margaret Hayden Rorke, managing director, explained that these shades, which are in accord with the Government's dyestuff conservation policy, have been selected for their fashion value and for their harmony or contrast with a wide range of basic costume colors for fall and winter.

NEWARK, N.J., July 20 -- Stripped of its twelve machine guns and wearing fifty or more flak holes and scars, the "Mild and Bitter," a B-26 medium bomber that was the first Allied warplane in the Mediterranean theatre to complete 100 missions over enemy territory, rolled down the runway at the Army airfield here today in one of the final laps of its last journey.

"Jungle Woman" will start a second week today at the Rialto. "Shadows in the Night," the Columbia melodrama starring Warner Baxter which was scheduled to open today, instead will arrive at the Rialto next Friday. . . . Entering second weeks today are "The Adventures of Mark Twain," at the Strand, and "Una Carta de Amor," the Mexican picture, at the Belmont.

Mayor La Guardia made public yesterday at City Hall a letter in which he warned Martin Sweeney, president of the Hotel Association of New York City, Inc., that friendly relations between himself and the hotels would terminate unless they stated publicly their willingness to cooperate with the Federal Government in efforts to restrict vacation travel by rail.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- Reports of black stem rust damage from Central South Dakota where fields that appeared good for thirty bushels an acre three weeks ago are now said to be likely to yield five bushels gave the wheat market a firm undertone early.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- The Argentine Ambassador for the United States, Adrian Escobar, today "categorically repudiated" a recent published report that he said "presents the Argentine Government as harboring hostile plans toward Chile and Uruguay."

Senator Robert A. Taft, at a luncheon conference here yesterday, told representatives of the publishers, the radio and the Army that he would sponsor a liberalizing amendment to the Federal law that gives the Army censorship powers over reading matter purchased by the Government for the armed services.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- With the attention of the Democratic National Convention focused sharply upon the intensive and spectacular fight of the Congress of Industrial Organizations' Political Action Committee for the renomination of Vice President Wallace, the rival American Federation of Labor, operating so quietly as to be unobserved, was working apparently with much effect for Senator Truman, the nominee.

The best the Dodgers could do in their game against the Reds at Ebbets Field yesterday was to come from behind on two occasions to tie the score. When the Reds went ahead of them a third time, though, the home cohorts found themselves unequal to the task of squaring matters again, and they had to settle for the short end of a 3-to-2 count.

Five lieutenants in the Fire Department, who were transferred on May 1 to posts remote from their homes after newspapers had published their joint statement criticizing Commissioner Patrick Walsh, retracted yesterday that part of their statement accusing their superior officer of branding as "slackers" all firemen who quit the department to enter the armed forces.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- A sharp controversy involving four Government agencies has snarled in uncertainty the War Food Administration's directive ordering the removal from rationing of most of the available beef steaks and roasts by Aug. 1.

Vice President Wallace's defeat might conceivably bring him more satisfaction than his success four years ago. In 1940 he was forced by Mr. Roosevelt's mandate on a convention which obviously would have preferred any one of half a dozen other candidates. His victory was a tribute not to himself but to the President.

WITH BRITISH FORCES, near Caen, July 21 -- Appalling devastation, innumerable strange stories and many ghastly sights were seen and heard yesterday on a survey of the territory east of the Orne River, which was laid waste Tuesday morning by Allied air forces in a prelude to Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery's drive east and southeast of Caen.
There are no looms making filament rayon and few looms on spun rayon that would be suitable for conversion to cotton duck for tenting, spokesmen for the rayon fabric industry stated yesterday.

A quick turnover featured housing property deals in Manhattan yesterday, when Alexander Hirsch, attorney, announced that a syndicate of operators headed by him had resold the thirteen-story apartment building at 565 Park Avenue, between Sixty-first and Sixty-second Streets, to a client of Livingston Livingston, attorneys.
Referring to the letter written by "Major," and in defense of your paper, there appears to be no reason, based upon the references unearthed by "Major," why a baker should not be a doughboy.
Around the President's position as Commander in Chief a political controversy is developing in which both Republicans and Democrats have begun to make mistakes.

The production of "Bloomer Girl," one of the season's most pretentious musicals, is all set to roll. To be produced by John C. Wilson in association with Nat Goldstone, the show goes into rehearsal on Aug. 7, with an out-of-town bow set for Sept. 7.

A concert of Viennese music, with the genial Robert Stolz presiding over the Philharmonic-Symphony, was presented at the Lewisohn Stadium last night. An audience of more than 10,000 persons joined in the informality of the occasion, hummed their favorite pieces and marked the infectious one-two-three beat of the waltz with tapping feet.
CHICAGO, July 21 -- All records for food and drink consumption in the Chicago Stadium were broken by the Democratic Convention.

Retail trade here continued active this week, with seasonal lines of merchandise in active demand. Estimates put sales gains by department stores at 10 to 15 per cent above the like period of 1943, or about the same rate of increase as noted last week.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 21 -Three Navy captains who have seen combat duty recently sat down behind closed doors today at Port Chicago as a court of inquiry to investigate the munitions explosion of Monday night which blew up two ships, wrecked a Navy ammunition depot on Suisum Bay and killed about 320 persons.

Princequillo, rated one of 1943's best stayers over a distance of ground, but slow to come to hand this year, nevertheless looms as the favorite in this afternoon's $10,000 Questionnaire Handicap, big feature on Empire City's program at Jamaica.

CHICAGO, July 22 -- The following is a tabulation of the second and final roll-call for the Vice Presidential nomination at the Democratic National Convention. It was compiled from official records of the convention.

PEARL HARBOR, July 21 -- United States assault troops and sea forces began yesterday the long awaited invasion of the big island of Guam and have established good beachheads against light opposition, although resistance increased in some sectors as the Americans drove inland.

MADISON, Wis., July 21 (AP) -- Federal Judge Patrick T. Stone has set Aug. 22 as the date for trial of the Government's injunction suit against the Kraft Cheese Company, which is accused of evading OPA ceiling prices on cheese.

CHICAGO, July 21 (AP) -- Warren Wright of Chicago, owner of the famed Calumet Farm Stable trained by Ben Jones, today entered a trio of 3-year-olds in tomorrow's $81,350 Arlington Classic in the hope of scoring a grand slam, as he did in the 1941 Arlington Futurity.

DON'T look now, but the fabulous four-minute mile is just around the corner. Arne Andersson moved another giant stride closer to it the other day when he ripped off a 4:01.6 effort. The way the Swedish school teacher and his compatriot, Gunder the Wunder Haegg, have been mutilating the record books this season is startling.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., July 21 -Robert Shreve of Suburban won the Metropolitan Golf Association's annual Beers Memorial tournament at the Baltusrol Club today when he carded 73 -- 7 -- 66. John Dox of Green Brook was second in the field of 95, posting 76 -- 9 -- 67.

A report from Beach Haven, N.J., yesterday indicating that the restriction limiting off-shore party boat fishing to vessels of thirty-eight feet and over had been lifted in the Fourth Naval District led to investigation of the possibility of a similar move here, the Third Naval District.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- The high pitch of excitement among Democratic convention delegates aroused by the imminence of nomination of a Vice President caused an impromptu demonstration today long before Senator Samuel D. Jackson, chairman, called for order at 12:12 P.M. (Central war time).
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 21 (AP) -- Communique 91:

CLEVELAND, July 21 (AP) -- Jim Bagby made his first start for the Indians since resigning from the Merchant Marine and doled out five hits to the Athletics tonight as the Tribe won, 4 to 1, for a sweep of the four-game series.

ALBANY, July 21 -- Governor Dewey left Albany for his Pawling farm tonight after discussing postwar trade with Russia and reconversion of American industry for several hours with Eric Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce.

Even though he was listed as missing in action from the Mediterranean area in morning newspapers yesterday, Capt. James H. Cruickshank Jr. was eating breakfast in his home at 103 East Eighty-fourth Street. It seemed that the war hero, who had been captured during the Anzio beachhead fighting but had managed to escape from the Nazis, had not yet been officially accounted for by the War Department.
Yesterday's communique as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

BERNE, Switzerland, July 20 -- On orders from Heinrich Himmler Berlin has been occupied by the Elite Guard since early Thursday afternoon, according to telephoned reports from Berlin. Some "small formations" of the army billeted in or near the capital have been confined to barracks pending "investigation of their sympathies, but calm has otherwise been restored," it was said.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., July 21 -Tony Manero of the Hubbard Heights Country Club, Stamford, Conn., United States open golf champion in 1936, returned a card of 73, 68 -- 141 for low score in the sectional qualifying round for the P.G.A. championship today at the Cherry Valley Club.

WEEHAWKEN, N.J., July 21 -Four men, posing as railroad workers, did a neat job of banditry here today, taking a $27,543 payroll from two messengers of a detective agency, after disarming one of them, and vanishing in an automobile.

Whether an attack was made against Adolf Hitler by a "small clique," said to have been led by "two generals and their adjutants," Nazi propagandists yesterday exploited the alleged assault in an apparent attempt to bolster home-front morale, minimize possible discord and whip up German fighting spirit for continued prosecution of the war, the Office of War Information reported.

CHICAGO, July 21 (AP) -- Vice President Wallace said tonight that "the cause of liberalism has been further advanced" by developments at the Democratic convention and announced that he would whole-heartedly support the Roosevelt-Truman ticket.
ST. LOUIS, July 21 -- The Yankees finally got the Browns out into broad daylight this afternoon and what they saw was most encouraging.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The attack on Adolf Hitler is a clear indication that a realization of impending defeat is spreading in Germany, Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today, while at the same time warning the American people against overoptimism.

LONDON, July 21 (U.P.) -- German flying bombs, in a continuation of the new salvo-firing technique, resumed their roar over the London area, and southern England today, even as British Home Secretary Herbert Morrison warned that the strain on civilians might grow worse before it could be finally removed.

Cantaloupes, a name given to several varieties of muskmelon, reach many production peaks in the course of a season -- one, in fact, for each area in which they are grown. At present the fruit is coming from California, Arizona and Maryland, the markets are well stocked and prices are 7 to 9 cents a pound.

DETROIT, July 21 (AP) -- The Tigers swept a four-game series from the Senators by staging a 3-run ninth inning rally today to win, 6 to 5. Roger Cramer singled home two runs and scored the winning marker on Chuck Hostetler's single to give Paul Trout his thirteenth victory.
LONDON, July 21 (AP) -- Signs that Turkey soon may swing from neutrality to a possible declaration of war against the Axis increased today.
ROME, July 21 (AP) -- A communique:

ALBANY, July 21 -- Governor Dewey refused today to order an extraordinary grand jury investigation of a $7,000 embezzlement from a Syracuse baking company, for which Rolland B. Marvin, Onondaga County Republican leader, was attorney.
The Gamewell Company announced yesterday the declaration of a 75-cent dividend payable on Aug. 15 to holders of the common stock. Shareholders received $1 in May and 50 cents last February.

" 99 Park," headquarters of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, Inc.,* offers a partial list of free amusements available today, through the generosity of the entertainment world. Afternoon tickets from 11 A.M., evening tickets after 4 P.M.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- Senator Harry S. Truman, Democratic candidate for the Vice-Presidency, will conduct whatever campaign President Roosevelt desires him to make, he said tonight in his first press conference as assistant standard bearer for the Democratic party in this year's elections.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Navy's Manpower Survey Board disclosed today that it has recommended transfer of 84,972 officers and enlisted men from shore to sea duty, but holds that the shore establishments need an increase of 39,325 in personnel.
ABOARD A FLAGSHIP AT GUAM, July 21 (Guam Time) -- A liberation force of Third Amphibious Corps marines and Army troops thundered ashore at Guam today with the destructive blast of a Pacific typhoon.

Municipal bonds listed for sale next week total $62,419,000, compared with only $2,086,500 for this week, according to the Daily Bond Buyer. The weekly average of offerings for the year to date is now $20,662,576.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 21 (AP) -The Central New York Power Corporation petitioned the State Public Service Commission today for authority to issue and sell $50,000,000 in general mortgage bonds for the purpose of redeeming $45,000,000 of bonds, 3 3/4 per cent series, due in 1962, and $5,000,000 of the 3 1/2 per cent series, due in 1965.
LONDON, July 21 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Force communique:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 21 -- Dennis Morgan has been named by Warner Brothers for the lead in the forthcoming "God Is My Co-Pilot," which originally was set for Humphrey Bogart. The latter is now under contract suspension from the studio for his refusal to do the part.

CHICAGO, July 21 (AP) -- Pitcher Nelson Potter of the league-leading Browns was suspended by President Will Harridge of the American League today pending investigation of Umpire Cal Hubbard's charges that Potter had violated the rules of pitching by "expectorating" on the ball.

A dirt farmer whose mother has frequently boasted that he could "plow the straightest row of corn in the county," Harry S. Truman came into politics as a protege of "Big Tom" Pendergast, former boss of the Kansas City Democratic machine which once was known as the strongest political organization west of the Mississippi.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The lowest infant mortality rate on record. 39.9 infant deaths for each 1,000 live births for the year 1943, was reported today by the Children's Bureau. Maternal death figures for 1942 were also analyzed, and showed remarkable gains in the Southern States.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The total of $5,094,000,000 in State tax revenue for last year was 2.4 per cent above the $4,975,000,000 collected during the twelve months of the preceding year, the Department of Commerce reported today.

The State Board of Regents at its monthly meeting yesterday in the State Building, 80 Center Street, was asked to declare eight trustees of the Peiping Union Medical College "incapacitated," because they are interned in occupied China and are thus unable to act in behalf of the college.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- Inconspicuous among the thousands of spectators in the sweltering auditorium, Mrs. Henry A. Wallace and Mrs. Harry S. Truman sat quietly through the tensest of convention sessions this afternoon, while the political fate of their respective husbands was being settled before their eyes.

The craze for everything Victorian -- from hair sofas to wax flowers in plush frames -- seems to have passed the stage where decorators rummaged through attics in hopes of finding a what-not that might be "amusing' if given a few coats of white paint.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 21 -"On the day of reckoning" war criminals may be tried and punished "for arrogant contempt of humanity and of fundamental moral values" and international law needs no precedent for this, the Commonwealth Club was told today by Dr. Max Radin, Professor of Law at the University of California.

CHICAGO, July 21 (AP) -- Through four runs batted in by Catcher Tom Turner and four double plays, the White Sox wrestled their way out of their Red Sox bondage today and beat the Bostonians, 5 to 3, for an even split of the four-game series. It was their second victory in fourteen meetings with the Boston club.

NEWARK, N.J., July 21 -Richard Stockton, 75 years old, prominent lawyer here, who is a former United States Commissioner and former Advisory Master in Chancery, was arrested today on a charge of embezzlement on the complaint of Miss Alice Stokes, 60, a cook, of 17 Glenwood Place, Summit.
LONDON, July 21 -- The latest war news had a stimulating effect on today's stock market. There was good support for many industrials, especially those with post-war prospects.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- The Pullman-Standard Car Manufacturing Company was forced today to shut down half of its large plant in Michigan City, Ind., because of a strike of 120 riveters which began a week ago. Between 500 and 600 employes were thrown out of work.

A recent communication, "The President and the Press," states in effect that, although the bulk of American newspapers violently opposed Roosevelt in 1932, 1936 and 1940, the opposition merely resulted in the election of a President "who forthwith gathered more votes in three successive elections than any other Chief Executive in our history."
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- The Navy reported today establishment of a contract termination system, designed to provide eventually for "an orderly transition from war to peace production."

The expanded liquid resources accumulated by industry during the war will be of help in meeting the problems of conversion to peace activities, but "it should not be concluded, however, that they are adequate to meet all needs in the post-war period, either in the aggregate or in particular industries or firms," according to the Federal Reserve Bulletin for July.

The nation's fleet of school buses, reduced in number since 1941 from 93,000 to 79,000 for lack of replacements, is being gradually built up again this year, it was reported yesterday by the Office of Defense Transportation. Five thousand new buses will have been purchased by the end of this year by school boards or private operators serving schools, the statement said.

ROME, July 21 -- The attempt to assassinate Adolf Hitler was naturally the chief topic of conversation and speculation in Rome and the Vatican City today, and it gave rise to a report that the Pucci agency in Vatican City put out to the effect that the Pope "is presumed to have sent a telegram to Hitler expressing pleasure at Hitler's escaping death."

The Christian and Missionary Alliance says in its annual report that it is supporting 476 missionaries in eighteen countries. The report, presented to the Alliance General Council, was made public this week at the headquarters, 260 West Forty-fourth Street, by the Rev. Dr. Alfred S. Snead, secretary of the Foreign Department.

RICHMOND, Va., July 21 -- Patents on a method of making soap from coffee, a process for accelerating the "aging" of tobacco, and a means of controlling sound through the sub-audible tempo frequency of music or speech are among the 550 listed in the current issue of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.
PEARL HARBOR, July 21 (AP) -Rear Admiral Richard L. Conolly, commanding the amphibious operations against Guam, is one of the hardest-hitting, farthest-ranging admirals of this war.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Reversing their usual roles, industry members of the National War Labor Board's Shipbuilding Commission today voted for a union security provision while labor members voted against it.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- New Yorkers asked by the Office of Civilian Requirements to state their clothing complaints covering the first three months of this year added their full quota to the protests on price, quantity and quality which resulted from a textiles poll of 4,499 households.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- In an effort to provide meats to inadequately supplied hotels and restaurants, the Office of Price Administration authorized retailers today to sell more than 20 per cent of their meat inventory to commercial eating establishments under price ceilings somewhat lower than those applying to consumer sales.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- Evening up operations in July wheat, trading in which ceases at the close tomorrow, found offerings relatively light and with short covering the close was 5/8 cent higher today on the Board of Trade. The deferred deliveries were sold by hedgers and professional traders, with internal difficulties in Germany furnishing the background for a very bearish sentiment.

An increasing number of reports of political unrest in Germany, and the continued favorable weather in the Cotton Belt yesterday brought in the heaviest liquidation in the cotton futures market in weeks, and the market closed virtually at the lows of the day and 30 to 38 points net lower on active months.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 21 -- Capt. A.S. Rogoff of the Army Medical Corps, whose fight against an increase from $80 to $95 a month in his apartment rent here led to a demonstration by sympathizers last Saturday in front of City Court, settled the dispute at $90 today with the landlord, according to his wife. Tenants objecting to rent increases here considered it a test case.
Yesterday's Soviet communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communication Commission:

" Yankee Poodle Dandy" and sixty-two other dogs of New York's total canine population of 325,000 received their first lessons in a ten-week etiquette course least night which Miss Fannie Hurst, novelist, found a "most encouraging occasion."

More than 1,20 retailers already have replied to the questionnaire recently sent out by the Carpet Institute of America asking for qualifications of their most efficient salesmen, it was stated yesterday at a meeting of New York representatives of carpet manufacturers and distributors at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The selection of Senator Truman as the candidate for Vice President on the Democratic ticket obviously represents a compromise. He is not, on the one hand, an extreme New Dealer, like Mr. Wallace or Mr. Justice Douglas, nor has he, on the other hand, become so closely identified with the conservative wing of the party as to incur the enmity of the CIO leaders responsible for vetoing the Vice Presidential aspirations of Mr. Byrnes.

Reported assertions from Moscow that an "unequivocal and public declaration against the Nazis" by Pope Pins XII must precede better relations between the Soviet Government and the Vatican were described as "misleading and calculated to destroy the basis of such an agreement" in a statement here by the Rev. John LaFarge, S.J.

Playing fairy godfather to two service men, the Pepsi-Cola Times Square Service Man's Center celebrated its second anniversary yesterday by providing one soldier with a complete wedding ceremony, and another with the makings of a "perfect furlough."

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, July 21 (AP) -- Giving no rest to beaten Japanese straggling through the monsoon rains out of eastern India, Allied raiders have struck at the enemy's staging camp at Meiring and captured great quantities of equipment, Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten's headquarters announced today.

LONDON, July 22 (U.P.) -- Two powerful Soviet armies have reached or crossed an almost continuous 250-mile stretch of the Bug River, Adolf Hitler's "East Wall" guarding Warsaw and central Poland, and, having outflanked Brest-Litovsk in a new push to the river, have smashed to within eighty-two miles of the Polish capital, Moscow revealed last night.

Two significant comments came out of Germany yesterday. One was from Dr. Alfred Rosenberg, who described what has been taking place as "the opening of hostilities on the Fifth Front." The other was from Field Marshal Guenther von Kluge, commander in the West, who said that "there will be no repetition of the year 1918."

CHUNGKING, China, July 21 (U.P.) -- Chinese relief forces attacking Japanese troops in the suburbs of Hengyang in Hunan Province drove deeper into the enemy lines today, as the battle to free the beleaguered garrison within the shattered city raged unabated in its twenty-sixth day.
PHILADELPHIA, July 21 (AP) -Given a four-run lead in the first two innings, Max Butcher pitched the Pirates to a 5 -- 3 victory in the rubber game of their series with the Phillies tonight.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Saturday, July 22 -- British and Canadian infantrymen, their uniforms muddy and sodden after thirty-six hours of heavy rains, were fighting a grim, bloody battle for Verriers and St. Martin-de-Fontenay on the British Second Army sector south of Caen last night, but the remainder of the Allied front in Normandy was quiet save for the measured pounding of cannon and mortars.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The State Department would carry forward on a strictly nonpartisan basis, its plans for a post-war security organization, Secretary Hull said today in commenting on the foreign-policy plank in the platform.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 21 -- A summary of the constructive achievements of the United Nations monetary and financial conference was adopted tonight at a plenary session of the conference. as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, July 21 -- Promising that a "full democracy" will rise in China as soon as the war ends, Gen. Shang Cheng, chief of the Chinese military mission to the United States, pleaded today for the swift provision of heavy weapons to enable Chinese soldiers to stop the Japanese attempt "to split China in two."
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Saturday, July 22 (AP) -- A communique:

A great deal of stirring American history has centered in and around New York, and boys and girls who visit the museums and historic sites listed each Saturday on this page may become full fledged members of the City History Club of New York, 1220 Fifth Avenue.
Following are expressions of opinion of the country's press on the renomination of President Roosevelt:
In the still, early hours of the morning I heard a sound like the long drawn-out wail of a tin horn. Instantly I was back in the rag-bag days.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- Recommendations that the United States be "exceedingly practical" in postwar financial arrangements with Allies as well as enemies were made in a speech here today by Senator Kenneth McKellar, chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee.
BOSTON, July 21 (AP) -- Home runs brought in all the tallies today as the Cubs took the finale in a four-game series with the Braves, 4 to 2.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 21 -- The United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference reached an agreement today on a plan for an $8,800,000,000 International Bank of Reconstruction and Development to guarantee post-war international investments. The total capital of the world bank is the same as the aggregate of the international monetary fund to stabilize currencies which was accepted last week.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- Senator Harry S. Truman of Missouri was nominated tonight as the Democratic candidate for Vice President in the fifth and final session of the twenty-eighth national convention of the party.

WHILE others talk of the road to Teheran, or the road to perpetual peace, Hugh Gibson, a career diplomat with a background of thirty years' foreign service, speaks more modestly in "The Road to Foreign Policy."* To Mr. Gibson it seems obvious that we must learn to walk before we can begin running. As a nation, he says, we have had "scraps of policy."

ATLANTA, Ga., July 21 (U.P.) -- Charles Bunn, consultant of the State Department Division of Commercial Policy, told a Foreign Policy Association meeting tonight that after the war "we can properly expect a great increase in foreign trade in all directions, all around the world," if pre-war restrictions were removed.

TRENTON, N.J., July 21 (AP) -The application of the Essex College of Medicine and Surgery of Newark for a license to confer the degree of Doctor of Medicine will not be considered by the State Board of Education until the college has been in operation for two years, the board decided today.
The Cardinals rode roughshod over the Giants last night before a gathering of 21,209 at the Polo Grounds.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 82:
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -Mrs. Frances P. Bolton, Ohio Republican member of Congress, is going to England to study facilities for treating wounded American soldiers.

A stay-at-home week-end was in prospect last night for thousands of city motorists who were unable to redeem their gasoline ration coupons at local service stations. The gasoline drought, first noticed in Brooklyn and Queens, had spread in the last few days to other parts of the city.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- In keeping with recent medical findings that pregnant women need plenty of protein, nutrition experts of the Children's Bureau issued for them a weekly protein plan today.
