CHICAGO, July 21 -- A political convention in wartime is a noisy affirmation that American democracy can carry on as usual in spite of anything. Otherwise there would be little excuse for the waste time, the waste motion, the waste breath expended here this week. The politicians are like old troupers in their feeling that the show must go on whatever happens.

BARI, Italy, July 20 (Delayed) -- Marshal Tito now wears a special Russian-made uniform flown to him from the Soviet Union. Despite this external evidence, those who know the commander of the Yugoslav National Liberation Army and his Communist party record say it would be unfair to say "he is in the pocket of the Russians," as his enemies do.

As a guide for advertising designed to aid in recruiting more women for work in war plants, essential civilian jobs and for the armed forces, a booklet entitled "Women at War" was sent yesterday by the War Advertising Council, Inc., to advertisers, agencies and media throughout the country.
CHUNGKING, China, July 21 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Saturday, July 22 -- Hundreds of officers, many of them highly placed, were shot by Henrich Himmler's firing squads in Berlin Thursday, according to travelers from Germany. Berlin, in a state of siege, is an armed camp with Elite Guards milling everywhere among the ruins.

So far, we are bound to confess, our mild demurrers to the reckless way in which the new geographers have begun to stand this terrestrial globe on its head have borne no fruit. Here or there a reader with an exceptionally retentive memory may recall the occasion of our first feeble protest.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Saturday, July 22 (AP) -- Seasoned Americans still firmly held their British New Guinea jungle lines after sharply repulsing a Japanese night probing attack, headquarters announced today.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Saturday, July 22 -- The United States Army Air Forces in Britain and Italy threw 3,000 more planes yesterday into the continuing attack against key points in the German aircraft industry.

MOSCOW, Saturday, July 22 -- The Soviet battle for the liberation of Poland began in earnest yesterday as the Red Army smashed across the Bug River from Lyuboml on a thirty-seven-mile front and advanced up to nine miles beyond the west bank.
ROME, July 21 -- The Allies moved today to meet one of the greatest Italian grievances by announcing steps to recognize and reward Italian Partisans, or patriots, as they are more correctly labeled.

ROME, July 21 -- American Fifth Army combat patrols pierced strong German Arno River defenses today, forcing the river into the mountain fringes of the Gothic Line in at least one point, while artillery blasted German installations north of the river from captured high points on the south bank.

LONDON, Saturday, July 22 -- Although reports from Berlin insist that the plot of army officers to overthrow the Nazi regime and seize power themselves has been suppressed and its instigators liquidated, the isolation of the Reich from the rest of the world continues ad it is apparent that counter-measures are being pressed.
LONDON, July 21 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:
A National Broadcasting Company report from Ankara, Turkey, last night said that reports that Adolf Hitler had been arrested were widespread in that city.

In contrast with the week before, when offerings were the largest in a month, flotations of new bonds in the local market here this week were comparatively few, totaling only $1,996,000 for two new issues, compared with $30,681,000 for nine emissions last week.

LONDON, July 21 -- Although the news from Germany is taken as an indication of a grave crisis within the Reich, there is no disposition here to regard it as a ground for hoping for an early termination of hostilities. As The Times of London will say tomorrow, when the enemy "wavers," that is the time for throwing in reserves, not for relaxing.

LONDON, July 21 -- After witnessing the strength and determination of Marshal Tito's guerrilla army, Premier Subasitch expressed the conviction today that "if these people receive enough arms they will be able to drive the Germans out of the country."

WITH BRITISH FORCES IN THE CAEN SECTOR, July 21 -British officers in the newly captured village of Soliers said today that when they entered the bomb-blasted hamlet they found one living human being, a frail elderly French woman who had lived all alone through the ordeal of the colossal Allied air assault Tuesday and the subsequent shellfire from advancing British troops and the answering mortar fire of the enemy.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- Sidney Hillman, chairman of the Political Action Committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, said tonight that his organization regretted that the Democratic convention did not renominate Vice President Wallace, but declared that Senator Harry Truman was "eminently qualified for the office of Vice President."

Fifty youngsters had an unusual treat yesterday. They stood on the fo'c'sle of a real United States Navy ship, they climbed to the bridge, peeped into the galley and the crew's quarters and witnessed that most nautical task -- rope-splicing.

Hendrik Willem van Loon's last book, finished a few days before his death, follows "Thomas Jefferson" and "The Life and Times of Simon Bolivar" in his young people's series of biographies of fighters for freedom. The new book is the story of Sweden's liberator and is called "Adventures and Escapes of Gustavus Vasa."

CHICAGO, July 21 -- New York held the spotlight in the convention hall early this evening as the outcome of the first roll-call in the Vice-Presidential race was held up by the inability of the delegation to agree on a division of the vote between Truman and Wallace.

The American Car and Foundry Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries had net earnings of $5,591,832 after all charges and taxes in the fiscal year ended with April, according to the forty-fifth annual report issued for publication today.

An appropriation of $90,000, designed to aid Belgians abroad in hiding from the Gestapo or imprisoned by the Nazis, will be sent to Berne, Switzerland, Maj. William Wickham Hoffman, executive director of the Belgian War Relief Society of the U.S.A., disclosed yesterday at its headquarters, 420 Lexington Avenue.

Gen. Kuniaki Koiso, a Kwantung Army man and former Governor-General of Korea, has been named Premier of Japan in a new Cabinet in which Admiral Mitsumasa Yonai becomes Minister of Navy and Field Marshal General Sugiyama returns to a prominent military role as Minister of War, the Domei agency announced this morning.

Reorders on women's fall apparel, particularly suits and coats, are beginning to come in from retailers, indicating the new season is off to an early start at retail, it was reported in the markets here yesterday. Active consumer interest at this stage, it was added, will cause retailers to follow up deliveries on their orders more intensively and to increase commitments on merchandise which they may have underbought.

Inspectors from the Department of Housing and Buildings have been inspecting guest rooms in midtown hotels for the last several weeks, it was learned yesterday. The object of their "search" was cooking utensils which, excepting in the case of apartment hotel rooms with pantries, constitute a violation of the Building Code.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- Lord Beaverbrook, Lord Privy Seal, arrived in Washington from England today with the British delegation for an Anglo-American conference to conclude a final agreement on international oil policy.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- Anti-Roosevelt Texans who bolted the national convention sent word to "the Democrats" of Texas today that the Texas pro-New Deal forces which won a convention victory yesterday would not be permitted to take over party control in the State.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- James A. Farley, former Democratic national chairman and former Postmaster General, announced tonight that he would support President Roosevelt for re-election despite his opposition to a fourth term.
The War Finance Committee announced yesterday that Otsego County had sold 101.8 per cent of its E bond quota, making it the first county in the State to go over the top.

The practice of permitting mothers to be up and around on the third or fourth day after delivery, an experiment tried in a Baltimore hospital as described in the current issue of The Journal of the American Medical Association, is not only not being followed in New York hospitals but is severely frowned upon by leading obstetricians, a check yesterday showed.

Reports of further internal unrest in Germany produced yesterday the sharpest reaction on the stock market in more than three months. Prices were set back a month as popular issues snapped 1 to 3 points with wider retreats in some preferreds.

SCRANTON, Pa., July 21 -Seven persons, including four former officials of the Scranton district, Office of Price Administration, were named in bench warrants issued today by Federal Judge Albert L. Watson following presentation to the court by the office of United States Attorney Frederick V. Follmer of criminal informations containing sixty-six counts against the seven men.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., July 21 -The Securities and Exchange Commission was urged today by its public utilities division to issue an order requiring the recapitalization of the Tidewater Power Company through the substitution of a single class of common stock for its outstanding preferred and common stocks.
LONDON, July 21 (AP) -- The London Star, commenting editorially on the reported attempt on Hitler's life, said today "the enemy is back to September, 1918, and well he knows it."

Lieut. Comdr. Alec H. Laurie, a shy, smiling, British naval officer and a great-great-great nephew of Annie Laurie, walked into the Open House for Officers at the Hotel Delmonico last night and was immediately overwhelmed by the senior committee, anxiously awaiting the appearance of the canteen's 100,000th visitor.
AUSTIN, Tex., July 21 (AP) -- In the Texas Democratic primary tomorrow Gov. Coke Stevenson has seven opponents. For seven other general State offices there are also contests.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- Somewhat belatedly, leaders of the Democratic organizations in a score and a half of States, headed by big city bosses, Edward J. Flynn and Frank V. Kelly of New York, Mayor Edward J. Kelly of Chicago, Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City and Robert E. Hannegan, national chairman, of St. Louis, brought about the nomination of Senator Harry S. Truman of Missouri for Vice President by the Democratic National Convention.

A proposal for the erection of a $1,500,000 amphitheatre on Flushing Meadows as a "Memorial to Queens Veterans of All Wars" was made by James A. Burke, Queens Borough President, last night at the twenty-sixth annual Queens County convention of the American Legion in Flushing High School, Northern Boulevard and Union Street, Flushing.

Paul W. Havener, a general partner of Mallory, Adee Co. and an allied member of the New York Stock Exchange, was suspended from the Exchange yesterday for six months. At a trial that lasted late into Thursday evening he had been found guilty of entering a single order to buy from time to time and then allocating the most advantageous executions to an account in which he had an interest.

A four-course hot dinner made from dehydrated foods, and cooked under canvas on Governors Island yesterday gave newspaper men and women a taste of the kind of meals that Army cooks are serving on fighting fronts. Their appetites were first whetted with a tour of a simulated field kitchen, where white-coated cooks demonstrated the processes used to transform the contents of paraffin-wrapped boxes and tin cannisters into a nourishing meal.

President Roosevelt's use of a naval base "as a platform for a partisan speech to a political convention" will be deeply resented by the American people, Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican national chairman, declared yesterday. In a press interview at Republican headquarters he added that he had not listened to the speech and indicated that Governor Dewey, the Republican candidate for President, had not either.

The New York Women's League for Animals is asking the help of its friends in keeping open the watering stations for horses which it maintains in the traffic districts of New York. Thousands of horses drink at them every day. Without this water they would suffer and some might die.

The record seventeen-day air and sea bombardment of Guam by the Pacific Fleet has now been followed, as was expected, by landings on the island we lost to the Japanese with hardly a struggle in 1941. Its conquest will add another link to the chain that is tightening around the neck of Japan.

The six-story factory at 561 Grand Avenue, southeast corner of Dean Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Dean Realty Corporation to the 561 Grand Avenue Corporation. The property, containing 80,000 square feet of space, is occupied by tenants in various manufacturing lines and is assessed at $200,000.

Asserting that any proposal designed to legalize tie-in sales would be contrary to the spirit of the Stabilization Act of 1944, A.F. Guckenberger, executive secretary of the New York Food Merchants' Association, disclosed yesterday that he had protested a tentative amendment which would permit tie-in sales on numerous fruits.
CHUNGKING, China, July 21 (AP) -- A communique:

Full cooperation in the investigation of the commercial rent situation in New York City is promised by the Real Estate Board of New York, the Greater New York Taxpayers Association, the Midtown Realty Owners Association and other associated groups, in statements issued yesterday by Russell V. Cruikshank, president of the Real Estate Board, and Clarke G. Dailey, chairman of the board's special committee on commercial rents.

' Teen-age children turned the tables yesterday on adult authorities and offered their own solutions to the problem of "what to do !about juvenile delinquency ?" At the annual conference on Youth Problems at Benjamin Franklin High School, ll6th Street and East River Drive, they placed the blame upon parents and community officials for failing to provide adequate recreational facilities and supervised constructive play.
KANDY, Ceylon, July 21 (UP) -- A communique:

The fourth and last member of a hold-up band, one of whose members was arrested Tuesday for the murder of Paul Volchak, lingerie shop owner of 2666 Broadway, was seized yesterday by the police and charged with violating the Sullivan Law.

CLEVELAND, July 12 (AP) -- Federal District Judge Paul Jones, in an order filed today, dismissed a libel suit for $1,000,000 damages brought against the Beacon Journal Publishing Company of Akron, Ohio, by officers of the National Maritime Union of America (CIO).

More than a million postcard applications for war ballots are available for distribution in New York City today and tomorrow to relatives and friends of men and women in the military service. Service personnel who complete and return the cards will receive, without further action on their part, a State war ballot on which they can record their votes for candidates in this year's general election.

The French Committee of National Liberation, in the words of an Associated Press dispatch from Algiers, has "published and thereby legally adopted a press law establishing a single French agency, with exclusive rights to distribute all French and foreign news within France."

The Erie Railroad recorded in June a net loss of $122,739, in contrast to a net income of $639,990 in June last year, R.E. Woodruff, president, said yesterday after a meeting of the directors. He attributed the loss to the payment of additional taxes in New Jersey, resulting from the decision of the Court of Errors and Appeals setting aside the 1941 and 1942 railroad tax compromise legislation.

Events in Germany have brought about a general but limited decline in New York stocks and have sent London and Liverpool prices sharply upward. A study of the makeup of the British stock lists supplies the answer. The bulk of popular issues in Britain are colonials -- gold, copper, tin, rubber -all of which are affected seriously by the shut-down of world trade and other effects of the war.

NEW stamps issued by Germany, together with information regarding others printed by the Nazis, somehow manage to reach America. Buying and selling them, either mint or canceled, is, of course, forbidden by Federal regulations, but their existence in collections in this country is not uncommon.

MIDWAY between Moscow and the China coast, in Asia's heartland, lies Sinkiang, ("New Dominion"). It is a battleground of clashing British, Russian and Chinese interests; a land of mystery and intrigue; sparsely peopled region of deserts, unexplored mountains, endless pastures and untapped riches.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- An international G-man organization to track down potential war criminals was suggested for the post-war world today by Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation.

Reports from Chicago that Senator Truman had received congratulatory telegrams from the President and Vice President recalled the difficulties encountered last month by Wendell L. Willkie when he sought to telegraph his congratulations to Gov. Thomas E. Dewey when Mr. Dewey won the Republican presidential nomination.

SALT LAKE CITY, July 22 (AP) -- Byron Nelson of Toledo, Ohio, shot another flawless round of golf today to move four strokes ahead of the field as the Utah seventy-two-hole Open reached the halfway mark. The final thirty-six holes will be played tomorrow.

SLOW growing vegetables and the long season crops are now likely to require extra feeding to bring them rapidly to maturity. No vegetable can be of high quality if its growth has been at a standstill from lack of plant food.

For months before the top blows off a mountain the delicate instruments of the volcanologists record the approach of nature's cataclysm. An eruption seldom is a sudden, unheralded outburst. It is preceded by earth tremors, by escape of gases generated by the terrific internal heat and by minor upflingings of rock and lava.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- While the course of Japan's future military strategy hung in the balance this week-end after the resignation of the Tojo Cabinet, Japan reeled under another important military blow: the return of American assault forces to the important island of Guam.

In their effort to meet competition from of other sources, railroad transportation in the post-war period is expected to undergo changes that virtually are revolutionary. With present equipment likely to be reasonably well worn out from the hard service in war work, stress will be placed as soon as peace is declared on obtaining improved locomotive power as well as rolling stock.

BERKELEY, Calif., July 22 -- A means of studying areas of less than one-one hundred millionth of a square inch to determine their chemical makeup was reported by Dr. Ladislaus L. Marton, Associate Professor of Electron Optics at Stanford University, at a meeting today of the Pacific Coast section of the American Physical Society.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- A proposed revision of limitation order L-38, covering industrial and commercial refrigerating and air-conditioning machinery and equipment, was discussed at recent meetings of the general refrigeration and air conditioning and the commercial refrigeration industry advisory committees, the War Production Board announced today.

LONDON, July 22 (AP) -- German broadcasts today said the Reich Government had refused to communicate further with the British on the killing of fifty British and Allied fliers after breaks from German prison camps in March.
CHUNGKING, China, July 22 (AP) -- A communique:

Retail trade continued active last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both reports. Sportswear clearances attracted great sales. Dress trade was brisk.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 22 -- A dramatic announcement that Moscow has agreed to increase the Russian subscription to the post-war Bank for International Reconstruction and Development by one-third was made late tonight by Secretary Morgenthau, chairman of the United States delegation and president of the United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference.
CHICAGO, July 22 -- The Democratic party tonight pitched its campaign to re-elect President Roosevelt on the keynote that mass voting is the secret to success in November.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The machinery and mathematics of the soldier vote are not calculated to flutter a poet's pulse, but the spectacle of an Administration calmly engaged in giving its citizen army an opportunity to vote it out of office is at least worth a passing note.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Sunday, July 23 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Continuance of the current draft induction and deferment policies is expected, with mose Selective Service needs to be filled from the country's manpower pool of youths under 26 years, the House Military Affairs Committee reported today.

BACK TO THE ROAD: Last week back in headquarters at Sarasota, Fla., after the fire disaster in Hartford which took 163 lives, the "greatest show on earth" was preparing to take to the road again. One thing will be different: there will be no big top. Spokesmen for Ringling Brothers-Barnum Bailey Circus said: "We will never go out under a main tent of canvas until a suitable fireproofing process has been discovered."

ALEXANDER WOOLLCOTT kept no copies of his correspondence, a fact which is apparently the basis for a preposterous statement by Beatrice Kaufman and Joseph Hennessy, who prepared his collected letters for publication, that "he wrote with no idea that his letters would ever be published."

In the belief that industry and business, as a result of the war experience, will make new and varied demands upon the colleges of science and engineering, Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn is introducing comprehensive changes in its traditional undergraduate curriculum to meet the needs of post-war education.

MOSCOW, July 22 (AP) -- Russian sea power, on the eve of a nationwide celebration of Red Navy Day, athoritatively was credited today with having sunk more than 2,500 enemy surface craft, having damaged more than 1,200 others and having destroyed 6,600 planes in three years of war.

Equaling the track record of 2:43 flat for a mile and five furlongs, Princequillo of the Boone Hall Stable scored his first 1944 victory yesterday in the $11,350 Questionnaire Handicap before 33,764 persons at Jamaica. In this renewal of another of Empire City's stake events, the outcome was expected in that the winner was the only horse of stake caliber in the field.

Hundreds of thousands of applications for State war ballots were distributed to friends and relatives of those in the armed services, as well as to service personnel, as public and private agencies, marking the first day of the cites "War Ballot Week-end," joined forces yesterday in an effort to get out the soldier vote.

Most Americans are resigned, if not cheerful, under the restrictions imposed by the war upon their pursuit of happiness. Some complaining is heard, nevertheless. There is murmuring at the scarcity of such things as whisky, chewing-gum, nylon hosiery and touring gasoline.

BOSTON, July 22 (AP) -- With the score tied at 5 to 5, Connie Ryan whacked out a homer in the eighth inning with two out today to give the Braves a 6-to-5 victory over the Cardinals.

LONDON, Sunday, July 23 -- Marshal Konstantin K. Rokossovsky's First White Russian Army yesterday captured the Polish junction city of Chelm and smashed to within seventy-six miles of Warsaw, while other Soviet troops drove closer to Riga and broke into the streets of Pskov, the last Russian city in German hands and the southern gateway to Estonia.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Plans are being made here for the rebuilding and re-equipment of French railways and industries on a huge scale, to begin almost immediately for military purposes and to continue on a different basis after the armistice, it was learned today.

IN the literature of the last war it was fiction and poetry rather than factual reporting that brought home to the civilian the truths about modern warfare. This war has encouraged a new brand of factual reporting, the best of which is honest, vivid and compelling.

OWEN DAVIS has written another play -- it may be the 250th or then again it may be the 300th, the gentleman has lost count. This one is labeled "Together" and has been scooped up by David Tor, a Californian connected with "little" theatres on the Coast.

THE Metropolitan Opera's Statement on Operations issued last Monday was a heartening document to the patrons and supporters of that institution, whose numbers are now in the millions and whose audiences, in the theatre and on the air, are now more than nationwide.

BOSTON, July 22 -- Walter M. Jeffords' unbeaten Pavot, with Georgie Woolf riding, stamped himself as one of the best 2-year-olds of the season by registering a smashing two-and-a-half-length victory in a star-studded field in the $25,000 added Mayflower Stakes before today's closing-day crowd of 27,546 at Suffolk Downs.

NOW that travel is being discouraged, the party fishing boat at near-by beaches is the answer to many a sportsman's yearning for a day of fun, for such sport can be found practically at New York's door.

Training for the New York football Giants will commence Aug. 31 at the Bear Mountain grate Park, with fifty-seven or more players expected to report to Coach Steve Owen. The turnout is likely to be considerably larger than last year.

CHICAGO, July 22 -- The hectic atmosphere of a successful candidate's headquarters Mrs. Harry S. Truman and her daughter, Margaret, scurried busily from room to room this morning in their hotel suite.

A new type of vaccine against cholera has been developed at the Biochemical Research Foundation. Newark, Del., under the direction of Dr. Ellice McDonald, by Drs. Robert J. Jennings and Richard W. Linton. It is described by them in the current issue of the Journal of the Franklin Institute.

Drawing a comparison between Germany's situation in 1918 and 1944, a military correspondent of the British radio yesterday pointed out that Germany now has a casualty list of 10,000 men a day against 6,000 men during the worst period twenty-six years ago.

Supported by the evidence of an azimuthal map, the Port of New York Authority contends that this city can expect to take its place as one of the great air-traffic centers of the world in the post-war era of expanded commercial flying. No doubt a number of new "Great Circle" routes which by-pass New York will come into being.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -With announcement that 400,000 Federal war ballots are being distributed for merchant seamen outside the country, the War Shipping Administration said today that all Merchant Marine personnel would have an opportunity to vote "unless the military situation prevents."

PHILADELPHIA, July 22 (AP) -- After Frank McCormick's three-run homer had tied the score in the seventh, the Reds defeated the Phillies, 4 -- 3, tonight when Steve Mesner singled Ray Mueller across the plate in the ninth.

MOSCOW, July 22 -- The Soviet summer offensive was one month old yesterday and still increasing in intensity, each new advance adding to the threat it holds to the bulk of the German Army and that army's rapidly diminishing prospects of keeping land fighting away from German soil for more than a few months.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Awards to twenty-three employes of the Department of the Interior for suggestions to improve "home-front service" were announced tonight by Secretary Ickes.

Terming Senator Harry S. Truman of Missouri as "an eminently satisfactory candidate" for the Vice Presidency, the new Liberal party in New York State announced yesterday that he would receive the second spot on its ticket, headed by President Roosevelt, as soon as Henry A. Wallace complied with the legal formality of filing a declination.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 22 -- The Ploesti oil refineries of Rumania were bombed today for the eleventh time by about 500 Flying Fortresses and Liberators of the United States Fifteenth Air Force from Italy. The Nazis resorted to a thick smoke screen as well as the fire of ground batteries and attacks by fighter planes to defend the area.

The City of New York took technical charge of the Stork Club at the height of the dinner hour last night when it placed a custodian in charge to protect its interest in a levy of $186,000, allegedly due on the city sales tax for the last six years.

A MIDWESTERN television and radio concern, contributor of much significant and brilliant pioneering work to the television art, has found time amid a current 100 per cent wartime schedule to preview -- simultaneously with the issuing of its annual report here last week -- the future of the video art.

PAWLING, July 22 -- A program for his St. Louis conference with the Republican governors of twenty-five other states was drafted in part today by Governor Dewey, who is spending the week-end at his Quaker Hill farm.

MR. GIBSON, who is always keen-witted and clever, and who sometimes is brilliant, has written a book which precisely fits its title. He does not tell us (except in very general terms) what our foreign policy should be. He does tell us how he thinks we can best reach a sound foreign policy.

STONY POINT, N.Y., July 22 -- Ralph Genova, 10 years old, of 336 Melrose Street, Brooklyn, lost his life today in an attempt to rescue his sister, Camille, 12, when she became panicky and went under in deep water in a cove of the Hudson River here.

WITH THE AMERICAN ARMY in France, July 22 (AP) -- "New York's own," the Sixteenth Infantry Regiment of the Fighting First Division, and Virginia's 116th Infantry Regiment of the Twenty-ninth Division shared honors today in citations for their heroic battle on D-day that smashed through the German's Atlantic Wall in a costly, bloody sacrifice.

HERE is an excellent dictionary of the homely folk speech of America. Mr. Wentworth's 15,000 entries and 60,000 quotations, numberless definitions and pronunciations, dated and located in these United States, will warm the heart and prompt the memory and the imagination of every adult American.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sunday, July 23 -- British and Canadian troops wiped out a small German salient across the Orne River yesterday by capturing Maltot, west of the river, and Etavaux, on the east bank, while on the American front, doughboys crossed the River Severs, six miles east of Lessay, near the town of Severs itself.

LONDON, Sunday, July 23 (AP) -- A total of more than 5,000 Germans were captured of the remnants of four to five Axis divisions surrounded northeast of Lwow in southern Poland. That encircled enemy group now has been completely smashed, Moscow said.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Continuance of the German robot bombings of England, despite the lack of knowledge as to their destructiveness and accuracy, suggests that the robot is the first new weapon brought into action in World War II which will have an influence on future warfare comparable to that of the tank introduced by the British in World War I.

In the gigantic replacement program American steamship companies will face in the post-war era there will be no place for the super-liner class, according to Frank J. Taylor, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 22 (AP) -- Frank Buttitta, 28, victim of what police termed a "gang bumpoff," was identified today by Eugene J. Donnelly, assistant Federal attorney, as "the chief Buffalo area distributor for a western New York ring which produced counterfeit gasoline coupons and auto-use tax stamps."

NEW ORLEANS, July 22 -- Close on the heels of the South's revolt against President Roosevelt come the shadows of a counter-revolution. Texas and Mississippi will have their hands full on their home grounds.

SOMETHING is cooking in Bermuda, and it smells like fish, so Zach Taylor, who holds a reserve commission in United States Military Intelligence, is sent there to find out what it is. His most important clue is the word "wahoo," the name of a fish found in Bermuda waters.

PROFESSOR STRANG of Teachers College, Columbia University, and her collaborators have provided much-needed help to boys and girls, to teachers, librarians and parents. ON country roads in July and August passers-by will see bands of blue, pink, white and mauve, blended in lovely mass near an abandoned house or alongside an old fence. Closer examination proves it to be that fine midsummer perennial, Phlox paniculata, or garden phlox.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Sunday, July 23 (AP) -- Celebrating the first birthday of the Thirteenth Air Force, Liberators pounced on Yap Thursday and again Friday to keep that Japanese air base from interfering with the landings on Guam.

PEARL HARBOR, July 22 (U.P.) -- Admiral Nimitz, in the course of the press conference with Admiral King, said that American troops who stormed ashore on Guam Thursday morning suffered fewer casualties than did those in the Saipan landings.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 22 -- Comdr. Harold E. Stassen, former Governor of Minnesota, announced today, after a year at sea with the Navy, that his "No. 1 aim" after the war would be "to help develop a strong foreign policy for America.''

CHICAGO, July 22 -- A rush to even up commitments in July wheat in the last few minutes of trading today on the Board of Trade resulted in violent price changes, a break of 1 1/4 cents a bushel occurring in the last thirty seconds of the session, with the close covering a range of 1 1/2 cents, and showed an average net loss of 1 3/4 cents for the day.

ROME, July 22 -- Three Allied columns marched on Florence tonight and one force was less than fourteen miles away. Patrols on the west stabbed within four miles of Pisa. LONDON (By Wireless). HOW long will the war in Europe last? As Allied armies on three land front -- Russia, France and Italy -- drive closer and closer toward the borders of Germany, that has become the newest question of military and political strategy. It is a question no longer defined in doubt or framed in indecision; Rome, Cherbourg, Minsk and Vilna almost certainly mean the beginning of the end of Germany.

Plans to open a large residence and recreation club for United States merchant seamen in the port of Cherbourg are being completed by the United Seamen's Service, working in cooperation with the War Shipping Administration, Douglas P. Vic Creighton, who threw the trunk over, was only doing a favor for a lady, but that explanation, even if he were inclined to give it, would only make matters worse, so he contents himself with a simple denial.

Losses were extended 1 to 2 points on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Volume was heavy -- 837,270 shares, against 420,640 for the preceding Saturday -- and the market was exceptionally broad. Of the 834 issues traded only seventy-eight rose.

WITH THE PACIFIC FLEET, July 12 (Delayed) -- The first American to set foot on Guam since the island's capture by the Japanese in December, 1941, was Lieut. (j.g.) William Rufus Mooney, 22-year-old Navy fighter pilot, who spent fifteen nights there after his plane was shot down on June 16.

BUENOS AIRES, July 22 -- The Argentine Government decided this morning to abolish censorship on outgoing news, and early this afternoon censors in cable companies were instructed not to interfere with news dispatches sent by any properly accredited correspondent.

With a week and a day remaining to reach Fifth War Loan quotas, sales of E bonds in New York City amounted to $160,679,012 or only 70.6 per cent of the goal in the latest tally taken Friday, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, today announced formation of a committee of nine industry repre sentatives to study ways of conserving and fully utilizing labor forces to meet critical shortages.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (U.P.) -- Officials of the Bureau of Prisons said today that there was strong hope that American scientists may have developed a cure for malaria after four months of an unusual government experiment at the Atlanta Federal Penitentiary.

THERE is no doubt that there is at the present moment, and that there has been for some time past, great need for a simple and factual book about General de Gaulle. There is need of it as much because of the fanaticism with which his followers extol him as because of the fury with which his opponents attack him.

Retailers are now showing more discrimination, both with regard to standards of goods purchased and time of delivery, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIME by Kirby, Block Co.

We were very interested to read in a morning paper that Milton Drake first heard the words of "Mairzy Doats" from his little daughter, two years ago. How do people get away with it! It would be as easy as my putting "Mary had a little lamb" to music and telling the world that my little daughter, Barbara Mary, lisped it to me two years ago.

AFTER an amount of rumor and unofficial information unprecedented even in the ballet world, formal announcement has at last been made of the new ballet institution organized by George de Cuevas which has taken a long-term lease on the Park Theatre in Columbus Circle and plans to open its first season some time in October.

Dr. William Bierman, attending physical therapist at Mount Sinai Hospital and assistant clinical professor of therapeutics at the New York University Medical College, one of America's foremost pioneers in physical medicine, has during the past twenty years served as a "one-man Baruch committee" to extend the frontiers of our knowledge in physical medicine.

WAR has bulked large in the recently opened summer group exhibitions. The American British Art Center recently opened a show of paintings by British war artists. The Metropolitan Museum is now showing (through August) paintings and drawings by men and women of the Canadian forces, chiefly dealing with training activities.

A new lead in the search for a chemical means of treating cancer is described by Dr. M.J. Shear, principal biochemist at the National Cancer Institute, United States Public Health Service, Bethesda Md., in a recent issue of that institute's Journal. The report is the ninth in a series of papers by Dr. Shear on the "chemical treatment of tumors."

WASHINGTON, July 22 (U.P.) -- Federal Communications Commission officials indicated today that the transmission of congratulatory telegrams from President Roosevelt and Vice President Wallace to Senator Truman probably was a violation of the Government ban on such messages.

PHILADELPHIA, July 22 -Gov. Edward Martin of Pennsylvania, speaking before 5,000 persons at the dedication of a war honor roll in Cheltenham Township today, declared that it was the country's duty to supply to returning war veterans self-supporting jobs rather than bonuses and "made work" for which they would ultimately be taxed.

Men's clothing manufacturers and retailers, seeking to anticipate demands of ex-service men at the war's end, do not believe generally that extraordinary changes will eventuate, but at the same time are rather certain that a new era in apparel is on the way, according to industry spokesmen.

WITH reorders for some types of fall merchandise already coming through from retailers in areas where cool weather has been noted, retail trade maintained an active pace last week. Clearances of seasonal merchandise met good consumer demand, and, while considerable business at retail remains to be done on summer goods, the emphasis is fast shifting to fall items.

I was surprised to read in THE TIMES Magazine that Gen. Bernard Montgomery's mother was the daughter of the Rev. Frederic W. Farrar, D.D., F.R.R., rector of St. Margaret's Church, Westminster, Archdeacon and Canon of Westminster and Chaplain-in-Ordinary to Queen Victoria.

THERE is nothing to equal a family feud for stirring up trouble. The two Clark families live in adjoining houses. In the one live James Clark, his second wife, Margaret, and her daughter, Margo. In the other are Clark's two sisters, Mary and Elizabeth, and his daughter, Linda, none of whom can abide Margaret.

In an atmosphere of noisy enthusiasm that failed to hide tensions and bitter irritations, the Democratic National Convention last week chose its candidates and launched the party's bid for victory in November. The setting was Chicago's Municipal Stadium, scene of the Republican convention in June.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., July 22 -Jimmy Smith of Hempstead, the medalist; Mal Galletta of North Hills and Pete Ladislaw of Plandome were all eliminated in the second round of match play in the Long Island amateur golf championship today at the Cherry Valley Club.

A review of the decorations presented to members of our merchant fleet showed that upward of seventy Merchant Marine Distinguished Service Medals, authorized by Act of Congress and presented in the name of the President, have been awarded to officers and seamen of the American Merchant Marine since this country's entrance into the war, the War Shipping Administration disclosed last week.

On D-day five sister-ship destroyers, in their first taste of battle since they left the ways of Todd Pacific Shipyards in Seattle, helped Allied troops land in Normandy by knocking out German pillboxes and machine-gun nests, the Todd Shipyards Corporation disclosed here yesterday.

CHUNGKING, China, July 22 (AP) -- Chinese troops have thrown a block across the Burma Road between Mangshih and Lungling, cutting off the Japanese garrison within encircled Lungling from the east, north and south, the Chinese High Command announced tonight.
OMAHA, July 22 -- Prohibition has its foot back in the door of the Middle West and means to keep it there until it forces its way back in or is forcibly shoved out.

CHICAGO, July 22 -- Twilight Tear, beautiful wine-colored filly, streaked to her eleventh consecutive triumph today in winning the $80,600 Arlington Classic that stamped her uncompromisingly as the outstanding 3-year-old of the year.

Plans for the establishment of between seventy-five and 100 vocational counseling and rehabilitation centers in colleges and universities throughout the United States, to help disabled war veterans who may wish to go to school or learn a trade, have been prepared by the Veterans Administration in cooperation with educational institutions.

CAEN, France, July 22 (AP) -- Newly captured German prisoners, commenting on the attempted assassination of Adolf Hitler, said today they long had known of a bitter quarrel between the Chancellor and the German General Staff.

ROME, July 22 -- Probably nowhere in the world today are more people shaking their heads knowingly over Adolf Hitler's troubles than in Rome, because this capital went through something similar a year ago.

ROBOT, that five-letter word now in the news, is causing almost as much of a flurry as the flying weapon named for it. Although this new German machine is also called a pilotless plane, the name robot plane seems to be the accepted term.

A GOOD condiment can do much to enhance the flavor of any meal, and is an especially valuable asset to present-day menus in which fine quality meats make such infrequent appearances. The recipes given here for home-made relishes use fruits and vegetables that are abundant, or will be during the next month, and provide a pleasant way of varying the usual home-canning regimen.

ST. LOUIS, July 22 (AP) -- Collecting thirteen hits off three Browns' pitchers, the Red Sox defeated the American League leader, 8 to 4, tonight. Boston advanced within half a game of the second-place Yankees, who now trail St. Louis by two and a half lengths.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Navy communique 532:

PEOPLE in business and industry are usually familiar with the conventional terms necessary to a general understanding of building construction, house furnishing and household equipment. The language of the shipbuilding and ship furnishing industry includes maritime terminology not encountered in other business.

The classics library of the late Dr. Gonzalez Lodge, Professor of Latin and Greek at Teachers College, Columbia University, has been presented by Mrs. Lodge, according to the wishes of her husband, to the libraries of Columbia University and of Franklin and Marshall College, it was announced yesterday.

BRETTON, WOODS, N.H., July 22 -- As the official acts of the United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference were finally approved, reservations were expressed today for France against what her representatives regarded as inequitable treatment of the devastated countries.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 22 -In a strange northwest breeze that rose and fell like tide-controlled buoys, the New Rochelle Yacht Club today held its second special regatta out on Long Island Sound. It was New Rochelle's last event of the season, the club already having held its championship one.

TWO anniversaries are celebrated this year by Sergei Alexandrovitch Koussevitzky, born a Russian, now a citizen of America and one of the preeminent orchestra conductors of our time. The first is the celebration of his twentieth year as conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra -- an organization which he has developed into the most highly perfected and sensitized symphonic ensemble in the world.

LONDON, July 22 -- Adolf Hitler issued an appeal today for loyalty from the revolt-ridden German Army, many of whose top leaders remained ominously missing from those publicly professing allegiance to the National Socialist dictator and his shaken regime.

CHICAGO, July 22 (U.P.) -- Sidney Hillman, political spokesman of the CIO, threw to the Roosevelt-Truman ticket today the support of two independent political committees which have a potential campaign chest of $6,000,000.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Representatives of the growers of flue-cured tobacco, who are threatening a general market holiday in protest against price ceilings set for the 1944 crop, will meet here Monday with officials of the Office of Price Administration to ask an upward adjustment of the ceilings.
LONG, long ago -- way back in 1941 -- there was a well-known slogan issued by a well-known department store:

When THE TIMES Magazine prints an article like Catherine MacKenzie's "Young Art," does it stop to consider the extent of its influence in fostering false ideas in the instruction of our children? Before any person may paint a picture that has merit, that person, first of all, must have learned how to give form to the objects to be painted -- in short, must have learned how to draw.

It is extremely doubtful that the prettiest petunia -- throw in a tomato, but make certain it's been removed from the can -- that grows in Squire Frank Frisch's New Rochelle garden would give the Flash more pleasure than did the Dodgers at Ebbets Field yesterday.

CLEVELAND, July 22 (AP) -- Washington ended its four-game losing streak and at the same time snapped the Indians' string of four straight triumphs today with a 9 to 6 victory in a free-swinging contest.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Among war production planners this week there appeared to be little doubt that readjustment of war industry to the manufacture of civilian peacetime goods had, in broad terms, just about reached the light. What was needed now was a major turn in the war to sweep reconversion plans forward.

Two American Export Airline flying aces, taxiing to a halt at the Marine Terminal at La Guardia Field within an hour of each other yesterday broke the old commercial airline record for a transatlantic flight from Foynes, Eire, to New York.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Despite the pressure of wartime traffic, the primary highways of this country are holding up better than the less-traveled urban streets and most of the back country roads under the stress of current restrictions on new construction, lack of adequate maintenance equipment and manpower shortages, according to a report issued today by the Office of War Information.

After opening at the lows of the day -- 1 to 15 points net lower -- the futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned stronger, rose at one time to gains of 14 to 16 points on active months, and closed steady 7 to 10 points net higher than Friday's final prices.

Announcing the loss of Saipan, just before his Cabinet was turned out of office, Premier Tojo told the Japanese people that "imperial Japan has come to face an unprecedentedly great national crisis." He was not overstating the case. Two and a half years of war have changed radically the picture in the Pacific.

HOW workers can do more in less time and be less tired after the job is finished has concerned industrial management specialists for over fifty years. Thanks to the application of their "motion and time studies" to war industries, bombers have rolled off the assembly lines and ships slid down the ways at rates that no one thought possible back in 1941.

In one sense it can now be said that the Presidential campaign of 1944 has taken shape. The leading personalities have been chosen. The keynote speeches, neither one destined to be remembered long after its echoes have died away, have been made. The platforms have been drawn up and adopted.

DETROIT, July 22 (AP) -- South-paw Hal Newhouser, aided by Rudy York's tenth homer, became the first American League pitcher to win fifteen games when the Tigers today defeated the Athletics, 4 to 3. It was Detroit's sixth successive victory and Philadelphia's eighth straight defeat.

BOSTON, July 22 -- Although widespread reports of racial discrimination in Boston have been highly exaggerated, many parts of New England are struggling with the problem of what to do with members of the fascist master races who have been dumped here in recent months as prisoners of war.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The spread of communicable diseases has been increased by the war and the consequent expansion of air traffic, Dr. Abdel Wahidel-Wakil, Minister of Health and the first Egyptian Cabinet Minister to visit the United States, said in an interview here today.

The report of the Thatcher Manufacturing Company, for the six months ended on June 30, shows a net profit of $469,001, after deducting $312,667 for Federal income taxes. This is equivalent to $1.71 each on 154,186 shares of common stock, and compares with $166,340, or $1.46 a share on 146, 836 shares of preferred stock in the first six months of last year, when taxes amounted to $150,622.

TO the bookishly inclined, "Sleuthing in the Stacks" is a wonderfully appealing title. It conjures up visions of classic adventures in literary detection: a Lowes watching "The Ancient Mariner" being created, phrase by phrase, in the deep well of Coleridge's imagination; a Hotson coming upon the true report of Kit Marlowe's sudden demise; a Carter-Pollard team exposing the audacious bibliographical deceptions of T.J. Wise.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES, in Normandy, July 22 -- American forces surge ahead and take Cherbourg and cheers go up at home for a mighty stride toward victory. The British take Caen and then their tanks rip through a bomb-shattered line and hopes ride still higher.
ALBANY, July 22 (U.P.) -- Examination of witnesses by the Extraordinary Grand Jury that is investigating legislative spending will be resumed on Aug. 1.

CHRYSANTHEMUMS which are perfectly hardy in many localities sometimes fail to provide the desired effect because of damage from frost in the early fall. Gardeners are thus seeking earlier blooming kinds, even though these are not always what is wanted either in growth or color.

PACIFIC FLEET HEADQUARTERS, Pearl Harbor, July 22 -- From two strongly held beachheads in Guam American assault troops are fighting inland against the defending enemy garrison and making satisfactory progress in both sectors, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced this afternoon.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 22 -- Secretary Hull's announcement of the International Security Conference to be held within the netx few week brought statements tonight from three member's of the United States delegation here for the United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference hailing the coming meeting as carrying forward the steps toward post-war international collaboration.

ROME, July 22 -- The incompatibility between communism and the Catholic doctrine was authoritatively expressed again today by Osservatore Romano in an article by the Rev. Mariano Cordovani, master of the sacred pontifical palace.

ANYBODY who has read manuscript plays steadily for a number of years knows that nothing is less true than the claim that hundreds of good plays are lying around begging hopelessly for performance because producers are stupid and sordid. That is not the blockade that has stopped the flow of good dramas to our theatre.

The threat to Hitler in the west last week took on new dimensions. The Nazis had committed large quantities of men and armor to an attempt to seal the Allies in the Norman peninsula. Against this challenge Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery, Allied commander in France, gathered great tank and artillery strength.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Special Senate Committee on Fuel Oil Shortages reported today that, "unless the war picture changes substantially," the country only by careful management of its fuel oil and coal supplies will be able to come through next winter "without undue suffering."

IN slightly less than two weeks -- on Aug. 4 to be precise -- Connie Mack will celebrate his golden anniversary as a big-league manager. It seems a bit difficult to comprehend or appreciate. Fifty years of baseball leadership! Fifty years of ups and downs, of joys and sorrows, of success and disappointments! Fifty years in the same job without the slightest diminution in wisdom, shrewdness or ability.

CHICAGO, July 22 (AP) -- Saved by a decision of the Appellate Court from death in the electric chair, Otto R. Wergin and Walter O. Froehling pleaded guilty today to charges of misprison of treason and were sentenced to five years each in prison.
LONDON, Sunday, July 23 (Reuter) -- A station calling itself "Free Germany" was heard early today broadcasting an appeal to German officers. It said:

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Kansas City Terminal Railway Company, which operates a belt line and terminals in Kansas City, Mo., and Kansas City, Kan., today asked authority of the Interstate Commerce Commission to issue $47,000,000 of its thirty-year first mortgage serial bonds to be dated Oct. 1, 1944, and to mature serially to and including Oct. 1, 1974.
LONDON, July 22 -- Tech. Sgt. Lewis Coburn of Niagara Falls, N.Y., came to London today to "start a long rest."

THE end of the first World War found America unprepared for reconversion to peace. The transition was unplanned, disorderly, costly. Government contracts were canceled abruptly. Production and price controls were removed almost overnight. Four million soldiers were demobilized within a year, each of them with $60 in cash and carfare to his home.

More rapid action is now likely on the final draft of the new retail price-control regulation designed to supersede the General Maximum Price Regulation for most lines of merchandise, it was reported in retail circles here yesterday.

At a conference called by Surrogate Anthony Savarese in the Queens General court house in Jamaica at the request of the John Marks Post of the American Legion, plans were discussed for creating a permanent organization to take charge of a program for rehabilitation and for obtaining jobs for returning veterans.

CHICAGO, July 22 (AP) -- The Democratic National Committee accepted Mrs. H.H. Weinert of Seguin today as the Texas national committeewoman, thus making the Texas "regulars" winners in the last of a series of bitter battles with the pro-Roosevelt faction at the national convention.

Last week was a black week for the Axis. Hard-hit on their fighting fronts, both Germany and Japan suddenly faced crisis within. Their strategy failing, the Allied threats mounting, the Axis partners executed drastic changes of leadership.

THE time has come to raise a bleat against the length of some pictures again. The time has come to strike a blow on behalf of the poor anatomy. For several years now this writer has been watching with fearful alarm the tendency of movies toward longer and longer size and wondering, in grave apprehension, what disaster this bodes the human frame.

DALLAS, Sunday, July 23 (AP) -- Veteran Speaker Sam Rayburn and Hatton Sumners appeared to be headed for victory over young opponents in their races for re-election to Congress as returns at midnight mounted in their favor in the Texas Democratic primary.

IN the season just ended, what we have come to call "abstraction'' had its full share of attention in exhibitions, in controversy and in other activities. Too much of the controversy has been waged in terms of violent partisanship.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- The War Department has issued mandatory orders to six clothing companies to manufacture field jackets for troops in Europe, stating that the firms "refused to accept their fair share" of contracts for 4,600,000 such jackets.

OTTAWA, July 22 -- Political fever is running higher in Quebec Province than at almost any other times in its modern history. Harsh words are being used, passions aroused and boasts made that even those who are most sympathetic with the long effort of French-speaking Canada to preserve its culture, its language and its ways of thought find gravely disturbing.

HOLLYWOOD has rediscovered the West and is going back to its traditional standbys, the cowboy, the Indian and the United States cavalry, as subjects for a forthcoming cycle of so called super-productions. The proposed epic Westerns, most to be photographed in color, have been given places on filming schedules previously earmarked for war dramas, a type of story now frowned upon because of the fast changing status of the world battlefronts.
CHICAGO, July 22 -- Vice President Wallace left Chicago today for a brief rest at his home in Des Moines.
THE play of ducking to conserve entries occurs constantly at no-trump contracts. In its simplest form, this play is known to all experienced players.

A UNITED STATES ARMY REHABILITATION HOSPITAL, in England, July 22 -- At this hospital tucked away in the quiet, wooded countryside, the Army Medical Department is rebuilding the bodies and minds of men recently wounded.

OTTAWA, July 22 -- The request of Canada's leading fighter ace of the war, Flight Lieut. George (Buzz) Beurling, to resign his commission and return to civil life has been granted by the Royal Canadian Air Force, Air Force headquarters announced today.

THIS is euphemistically described by Margaret Lee Runbeck's publishers as a novel -- more so, an absorbing one. Actually, it is not a novel in any sense of the word. Rather it is the day-by-day account of minor happenings in a home, with the incidents told in a treacly manner, heavily sugared with philosophic meditations.

LISBON, July 2 (AP) -- German Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebels' weekly newspaper, Reich, arrived today, filled with Nazi propaganda which blew up with the bomb in Adolf Hitler's headquarters, and obviously prepared before the explosion.

Bouncing Bet, the pink that came here from Europe as a garden flower and escaped to the roadsides, has spread itself over the July landscape in great banks and patches of pale pink bloom. If it were less profuse it would still be cultivated with care and given a measure of respect, for it has a distinct beauty in a minor way.

Anyone reading Mr. Downes' column in THE TIMES of Sunday, July 9, would, I am afraid, get the unfortunate impression that the American Music Center had attempted to belittle the plan proposed by Dr. Rodzinski, an outline of which was the subject of an article in the issue of June 4.

Two first appearances at the Lewisohn Stadium marked last night's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, and attracted an audience of 14,000. One was the General Platoff Don Cossack Russian Chorus directed by Nicholas Kostrukoff, and the other introduced Ignace Strasfogel as conductor of the orchestra.

THE new volume of Churchill's war speeches, covering the year 1943, gives full display of the elements in his character which made him seem -- for many so unexpectedly -- a firm stronghold in our time of gravest peril. Four years ago, in a world that was threatened with disintegration, people of democratic nations, free or oppressed, found in Churchill's unforgettable words strength and fresh courage.

PEARL HARBOR, July 22 (AP) -- Admiral Ernest J. King, Commander in Chief of the United States Fleet, said today after visiting the Mariana Islands invasion scene, within 1,500 miles of Tokyo, that our fleet now has the bases to smash directly at Japan, China and the Philippines.

The only fresh-water sharks known to exist are in a lake in Nicaragua. They are savage man-eaters and so numerous that bathing in deep water is a suicidal pastime. Hardly a year goes by that the sharks do not claim at least one life.

GUAM, Sunday, July 23 (East Longitude Time) -- Grim-faced marines and soldiers are fighting fiercely today over the wild terrain of Guam, expanding their two beachheads against stiffening Japanese resistance.

As special feature of its sixth week of the season, the Lewisohn Stadium is planning "something for the boys" in the form of an Army and Navy night by, and for, our servicemen. The conductor will be Warrant Officer Thor Johnson, who will be making his Stadium debut, and the soloists will be Sgt. Eugene List, pianist, and Seamen 1/c Arthur Wittemore and Jack Lowe duo-pianists.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, July 22 -- When the infantrymen and marines of the Third Amphibious Force made good their initial beachhead on Guam, a tremendous job in their support had been done for more than a month by heavy bombers of the Far Eastern Air Force -- a job that is still continuing and probably will continue until the island has been won.
ROME, July 22 (AP) -- A communique:

Post-war income tax revision would not be complete without a repeal of the capital gains tax. This column ventures the opinion that no other single revision of our tax system would do as much to create incentive and investment ability as the elimination of the tax on capital gains.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Secretary Forrestal said today that an additional 194,000 enlisted men were needed by the Navy before Dec. 31 and that another 189,000 might be required by June 30, 1945, to meet the accelerated pace of the war against Japan.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- The Office of Price Administration announced today that beginning Aug. 1 ration boards would refuse to issue full supplemental gasoline rations for home-to-work driving by motorists who have not organized a full-car club.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The loss of two American submarines, the Trout and the Tullibee, presumably in Pacific action, was announced today by the Navy Department in a brief communique that described them as overdue from patrol duty.

Your recent editorial "The Commander in Chief" sufficiently rebuts the implications contained in the Republican platform and in Governor Dewey's acceptance speech that the Army and Navy alone should conduct the war, and this without interference from the President.

CAPT. BILL CRAWFORD is one of those young men who, in Flying Fortresses, lighter bombers and fighting planes, helped turn back the Japanese invasion of New Guinea in the days when Americans were outnumbered on the ground, in the air and on the sea -- and won because of plain guts and fighting ability.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- L.W. Mosby, Solid Fuels Administration information chief, said tonight that householders and other consumers of scarce Southern Appalachian-mined bituminous coal would "get 10 per cent less than they were theoretically entitled to last winter."

THIS is a present-day story of two Chinese children who live on one of the hundreds of beautiful Chinese river boats that take cargoes from Canton to Hong Kong. The children are separated from their parents when enemy planes drop bombs in the river.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The white uniform of the Army nurses has fallen victim to the changes which war brings about and is being discarded in favor of a brown-and-white pin-stripe seersucker for wear in Army hospitals in this country, the War Department stated today.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 22 -- Comments have been made from time to time that, in spite of its great war effort, the West Coast would take a more serious view of things if the Japanese dropped a few bombs on San Francisco. Many Coast residents have shared this thought during the last two years.

ROME, July 22 -- Henry Grady, who has been chief of the Allied Control Commission's economic section, left Rome today for the United States after his second sojourn in Italy, during which he has been credited with having done a great deal to start the country back on the road to what it is hoped will be some degree of economic recovery.

LEO T. McCAULEY, Eire's consul general in New York, has made available the design of the 1-penny green and 1-shilling red-brown stamps released by Eire on June 30 to mark the tercentenary of the death of Michael O'Clery, "the greatest of Irish historians."

CHICAGO, July 22 -- The nomination last night of Senator Truman of Missouri as President Roosevelt's 1944 running mate by the Democratic National Convention brought immediate pledges of support of the ticket from Central West delegations which supported the candidacy of Vice President Wallace.

THERE must be several thousand different plastics by this time. Many are older than the war and many have been developed to meet the necessities of war. Most books about plastics are addressed to technicians; occasionally a more popular treatment of the subject appears in general books on industrial chemistry.

LONDON, July 22 -- Strengths and weakenesses of the Allied positions in Normandy have been stressed by events of the past week during which the Twenty-first Army group cracked two of the strongest German defensive positions in the battle area -- Saint Lo and Caen -- but was unable to follow either success with any considerable immediate penetration beyond the German front.
BRITISH SECOND ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Normandy, July 22 -- The startling news of the attempt on Adolf Hitler's life has not yet produced any combat reaction on the Normandy front.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 22 -- The text of the agreement on an international monetary fund shows that anyone of the three major powers (the United States, Great Britain or Soviet Russia) could block a uniform change in exchange rates.

JAMES B. CONNOLLY is an old seafaring man who has been aboard practically every type of craft afloat. His forebears were Aran Islands folk accustomed to the rough seas off the Irish coast and down through the years the Connollys have abjured land for the adventure to be found on the main.

AS in other phases of building ships, the electric wiring installation follows practices only encountered in the maritime industry. The work is done by marine electricians who in normal times have learned their trade in the same manner as in other trades, by an apprenticeship system which provides a combination of practical and technical training.

SOME of the peace plans proposed by authors but, for obvious reasons, still in manuscript are: to forbid Germany to use any currency of her own; to send 5,000,000 Chinese to Japan to rule the empire; to allow the small nations in Europe three months each in Germany to do whatever they wish.

NINETEEN "pointers" to bear in mind in looking over a nursery school are outlined for parents in a little green folder issued by the National Association for Nursery Education. Under the heading "Some Ways of Distinguishing a Good Nursery School," the items begin with the physical set-up -- quarters that are clean, safe and in good repair, offering plenty of space, fresh air and sunshine.

THE average man, beset by worries of all kinds in an anxious world, seeks something to give his spirit a lift. He hears that there is a fine, big art show going on and decides to go, because he likes to look at things anyway, and people who know always say that art is inspiring and uplifting.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Industry received the go-ahead signal tonight to build models of post-war goods embodying new materials and wartime improvements in design and technology.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 22 -- Brooklyn units of the Fifth Brigade, commanded by Brig. Gen. Emil M. Podeyn, the first contingent of State Guard troops from the metropolitan area to encamp this season at Camp Smith here for twelve days of field training, arrived on last Monday and have completed half of a strenuous schedule, with high morale and excellent health prevailing.

CHICAGO, July 22 -- After the outbursts and attitudes witnessed at the Democratic National Convention which ended here last night, and on the basis of manifestations from the Republican meeting held three weeks earlier, little is left to the imagination as to the main lines the two parties will follow in their bids for votes in the campaign next fall.

PORTLAND, Ore., July 23 (U.P.) -- A half-dozen sailors yesterday protested a union picket line by AFL men concentrated at the "Kanteen," a restaurant owned by the mother of a Navy rating, by forming a picket line of their own and "picketing the picket."

DETROIT, July 23 (AP) -- The Athletics smashed an eight-game losing streak today by taking both games of a double-header from the Tigers, 13 to 3 and 3 to 2, before 29,673. A three-run ninth-inning rally won the nightcap for Jesse Flores.

The Union Dime Savings Bank, which took over the fifteen-story and penthouse building at 165-73 West Seventy-ninth Street by deed in lieu of foreclosure less than three months ago, has resold it to a syndicate represented by Glekel Drimmer, attorneys.

If there was ever a moment in the course of the war which called for close watching, continuous consultations and a joint statement on the part of the three major Allied Governments, it is now. The crisis in Germany is not final, but it is profound and decisive. The first break in the innermost fortress of the Third Reich takes the long-anticipated form of a revolt within the upper ranks of the army.
LONDON, July 23 -- The biggest boom in the history of the British book publishing industry is continuing through the fifth year of the war.

J. Howard Pew, president of the Sun Oil Company, announced yesterday that the company and its subsidiaries had a net income of $7,787,133 in the first six months of 1944. This figure is after all charges, but before any provision for wartime contingencies or renegotiation of government contracts.

A group of 100 armed men belonging to the French Forces of the Interior occupied the French part of the little town of St. Guingolphe on the Swiss border, south of Lake Geneva Saturday, the British radio said yesterday, quoting a dispatch from Lausanne.

The church in these days need not stand back apologetically, urging people to follow the faith, but should rather be dogmatic in proclaiming that those who accept Jesus shall be saved and those who do not shall be damned, the Rev. Dr. Frederick Brown Harris, chaplain of the United States Senate, declared in a guest sermon yesterday morning at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

LONDON, July 23 -- In the first official Allied word on the crisis in Germany Prime Minister Churchill said during a visit to Normandy today there were "grave signs of weakness" in the Reich and predicted the war "might come to an end earlier than we have a right to say."

LONDON, Monday, July 24--Russian armies pouring swiftly through crumbling enemy lines in Poland yesterday fought their way into the big rail city of Lublin, within twenty-five miles of the Vistula River--last Nazi defense barrier short of Germany--and farther south, in a thirty-two-mile advance, reached the San River on a broad front, 150 miles from German Silesia.
PEARL HARBOR, July 23 -- United States Marines landed today on Tinian, near Saipan, continuing on to the third island in American amphibious moves against the Japanese in the Marianas.

LONDON, Monday, July 24 (U.P.) -- Adolf Hitler, suffering from severe mental strain as the result of the attempt to assassinate him and fearing possible further attempts on his life, has fled with a few trusted advisers to a heavily guarded estate in the Rhineland, reports from Stockholm said today.

The final text of the articles of agreement of the proposed International Monetary Fund differs very little, except in the elaboration of details, from the proposal submitted before the conference met. In view of the instructions of the President to the American delegation, this is not surprising.

Japanese fighter pilots in China regard as acts of valor and boast of the machine-gunning or killing with their propellers of Allied airmen who have bailed out in combat, according to accounts broadcast by the Tokyo radio. One such broadcast was reported yesterday by the official Chinese News Service through its New York office.

Premier Kuniaki Koiso, head of the newly-appointed Japanese Cabinet, declared in his first press interview following his assumption of the premiership that Japan would "further strengthen her ties with Germany in a positive pursuit of the common war objective," the Tokyo Domei agency reported yesterday.

ROME, July 23 -- Fifth Army troops fought their way into Pisa last night, taking part of the town south of the Arno River and all the land along the bank to the sea, seven miles away. Resistance pockets were being mopped up today and have probably been cleared by now.
CHICAGO, July 23 (AP) -- Farmers, encouraged by the larger feed supplies and continued high prices, are expected to revise upward the number of pigs they will raise this year.

BOGOTA, Colombia, July 23 -Commenting on the manifesto of the national committee of the Conservative party denying any responsibility for the military revolt that for a time made President Alfonso Lopez a prisoner, Enrique Santos in Tiempo says it is an attempt to deceive the public.
LISBON, Portugal, July 23 (Reuter)--The first trainload of the 1,000 British civilian internees from camps in France and Germany steamed into Lisbon today lustily singing "Tipperary."

Foreign holdings of common shares of United States Steel Corporation dipped nearly 3,000 shares in the second quarter of 1944 to 478,676 shares, or 5.5 per cent of the total number outstanding, comparing with 481,557 shares, or 5.533 per cent, on March 31.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Information is being asked on all types of public-works construction planned for after the war, in a country-wide survey made by the House Committee on Post-War Economic Policy and Planning, Representative William M. Colmer of Mississippi, chairman of the committee, said today.

What is needed, of course, is an organized campaign to promote some specific type of hot-weather dress for men. It is of no use to hope that individual boldness will ever achieve universal emancipation from winter-weight sack coats and trousers.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP)--William A.M. Burden, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, said today that the Civil Aeronautics Administration would soon recommend to Congress a billion-dollar program for building 3,000 new airports, all except 100 to be small fields intended largely for private flying.
LONDON, July 23 (AP) -- The Moscow radio listed the officials of the Polish Committee of National Liberation and its departmental directors as follows:

Some let-down in buying activities was noted last week. The number of buyers in the market dropped off, due to previous covering on fall merchandise, according to a summary of activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
LONDON, July 23 (U.P.) -- The death whine of robot bombs continued at an accelerated pace in London and southern England today, indicating an increase in the number of German launching bases.
AN ALLIED AIRPORT, Italy, July 8 (Delayed) (AP) -- The hour hand on the lieutenant's watch had moved past midnight and was coming up on 1 A.M. when he saw the red light. "Start rolling," he said.

Christianity is fighting for its life with the rise of many strange religions and semi-religious movements, the Rev. Edward Jay Manning of Brooklyn warned yesterday in his sermon delivered at the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Lexington Avenue and Eighteenth Street.

Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark, in a message marking the first Jewish broadcast from territory liberated by the United Nations, yesterday termed the broadcast "the promise of what the United Nations will bring to a liberated world."

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 23 -- The following telegram was sent to Governor Dewey by Fred S. Rogers of this city, who is chairman of the Republicans-for-Bennet Committee. Augustus W. Bennet, lawyer of Newburgh, is opposing Representative Hamilton Fish for the Republican nomination for Congress in the Twenty-ninth District, which takes in Delaware, Sullivan, Orange and Rockland Counties.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (UP) -- Pacific Fleet communiqe 85:

Some credit for the recent noticeable trend toward the increasing use of institutional advertising copy containing subjects dealing with business' profits and with plans for re-employment of discharged servicemen can be attributed to the pilot survey of public opinion being made by the Association of National Advertisers, part of which has been completed, it was pointed out in the advertising trade last week.
BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 23 -- The text of the articles of agreement of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development is as follows:

THERE must be something about French saints that is particularly appealing to German authors fleeing just one jump ahead of the Nazi armies. In 1940, while France tottered into collapse, while the refugees poured south in their pitiful migration and the triumphant young German athletes in uniform completed their easy conquest, Franz Werfel arrived at Lourdes and be came fascinated with the miracle-working shrine of St. Bernadette.

UNITED STATES FIFTEENTH AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS, Italy, July 19 (Delayed) -- A British transport plane carrying to Yugoslavia an Allied mission that included Major Randolph Churchill, the Prime Minister's son, as well as Major Evelyn Waugh, well-known English novelist, crashed in Yugoslavia the night of July 17.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -The Federal Government will follow a policy of selling its surplus real estate in family-size parcels and to farm purchasers who will cultivate the land themselves, W. L. Clayton, Surplus War Property Administrator, announced today.
