SKANEATELES, N.Y., July 23 (AP) -- Returning service men, when their war duties are fulfilled, will find jobs awaiting them in a vacuum cleaner and quick-freezer unit manufacturing industry, if the plans of this village of 2,000 in Onondaga County bear fruit.

Although persons bent on achieving worldly success are pursuing the wrong goal, they use the right methods, which should be emulated by persons seeking eternal salvation, the Rev. John C. McCarthy of the New York Apostolate declared yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

UNITED STATES ARMY HEADQUARTERS, in France, July 22 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Four Americans were recently leading six German prisoners, who were carrying a seventh wounded one on a stretcher, to the rear when a mortar shell exploded.

Miss Amparo Iturbi, pianist and sister of Jose Iturbi, made her first appearance as a soloist at the Lewisohn Stadium last night when she played the Liszt Fantasia on Hungarian Melodies for Piano and Orchestra with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under the direction of Ignace Strasfogel.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Veterans of the second World War already are showing widespread interest in the educational and other provisions of the GI Bill of Rights -- the Service Men's Readjustment Act of 1944 -- Brig. Gen. Frank T. Hines, Administrator of Veterans affair, made known today.

The real events in Germany remain hidden behind a veil of censorship pierced only by official pronouncements which give us but a dim view of the situation. Judging from these pronouncements and attendant circumstances, Hitler and his gory executioner Himmler have, for the moment at least, mastered a crisis which threatened to put a sudden end to their careers and lives and the whole Third Reich.

A new course designed to prepare women to vote intelligently in the coming Presidential election was announced yesterday by Mrs. C. Ruxton Love, vice chairman for the Borough of Manhattan division of the American Women's Voluntary Services. Though not scheduled to begin until after Labor Day, registration for the course opens today at the AWVS Manhattan headquarters, 19 West Fiftyseventh Street.

HONOLULU, July 23 -- A general alert was sounded in Honolulu and throughout the big Island of Oahu early this morning and lasted until well after daylight. No sirens were sounded, but the military and naval areas were blacked out and stringent precautions were taken against the movement of unauthorized persons through or near installations.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- Heavy trucks are as militarily important as B-29 bombers and heavy artillery, the War Department said in an appeal today to workers and employers in the truck-manufacturing industry to increase production.

If future citizens of the country are to have a comprehensive knowledge of their nation's history, then the courses taught in the average school must be overhauled and made interesting and meaningful to young people. The problem is acute in all levels of education. According to Dr. Erling M. Hunt, head of the Department of Teaching Social Sciences at Teachers College, Columbia University, dull and repetitious history courses turn students from the field.

Retrogression continued at Ebbets Field yesterday as the Dodgers struggled in vain until darkness fell. Brooklyn's hapless crew was sunk twice by the Pirates, first by 7 -- 5 in nine innings and later (much later) by 9 -- 4 in eleven innings.
ROME, July 23 -- Pope Pius took the unusual step today of condemning the newly formed Communist Catholic movement. He merely alluded to the movement, but his remarks were clear.

PHILADELPHIA, July 23 -- Federal alcohol tax unit agents arrested a man here today and said he was Louis R. Cohn of Reading, Pa., operator of "one of the largest black market liquor businesses in the country," who had been sought for more than two weeks on a bench warrant issued by a Federal court in New York City, charging him with violation of the Internal Revenue Act.

BOSTON, July 23 (AP) -- Mort Cooper chalked up his twelfth victory of the season today as the league-leading Cardinals defeated the Braves, 5 to 2, at Braves Field, to sweep a double-header. The Cards won the first game, 3 to 2.

CHUNGKING, China, July 23 (AP) -- Chinese troops were said by the High Command tonight to be pressing attacks to drive the Japanese out of Siangsiang, stronghold about sixty miles north of besieged Hengyang and western anchor of a long enemy line north of the rail junction.

Our War Department is studying the "mission, size and composition of the post-war air force necessary for the protection of this country," Under Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson disclosed some days ago. He added, sensibly, that definite decisions probably could not be made before the end of the war.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 23 -- The delegations from forty-four nations which took part in the United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference left here tonight for New York and Washington on two special trains, after signing the "final act" of the conference, which included the agreements on an $8,800,000,000 International Monetary Fund to stabilize post-war currencies and a $9,100,000,000 Bank for International Reconstruction and Development.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast domestically in Finland and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
KANDY, Ceylon, July 23 (UP) -- A communique:

Distribution of postcard applications for war ballots continued at a high level yesterday, closing day of the "War Ballot Week-end" proclaimed by Mayor La Guardia, and many organizations reported before the day was over that their supply of forms was exhausted.

NEW DELHI, India, July 22 (Delayed) -- The Japanese retreat from forward strong points along the Bishenpur track and Tiddim road during the last week is proof that the enemy pulling out of the battles for Imphal is carrying out a general withdrawal in the whole south Manipur area.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Monday, July 24 (AP) -- A communique:

LONDON, July 23 -- Prime Minister Churchill has made a second visit to Normandy and his return to London after three days spent touring the beachhead from Cherbourg to Caen was announced tonight. On Saturday the Prime Minister drove with Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery through Caen, which was cleared of Germans only last Tuesday.

The Army is going into the production of jet propulsion aircraft turbines. Quantities were not revealed, but the General Electric Company, in a release cleared by the War Department, announced yesterday that it would devote 600,000 square feet of floor space to manufacture of the turbines.

The gasoline drought, which had been spotty in the metropolitan area for several weeks, spread yesterday to several New Jersey communities, where "No Gas" signs appeared on service stations for the first time in six months.

ABOARD UNITED STATES INVASION FLAGSHIP, off Guam, July 23 -- Marine veterans of Pacific jungle and atoll fighting -- supported by elements of the Army's Seventy-seventh or "Statue of Liberty Division" -- are closing the jaws of a huge pincers around one of the best harbors in the Marianas tonight setting the stage for seizure of the strategic port of Apra on the doorstep of the Japanese Empire.

NEWARK, N.J., July 23 (AP) -Before a crowd of 7,248 fans, the Newark Bears and Jersey City Giants today exchanged one-run decisions. The Bears captured the opener by 5 -- 4, then lost the nightcap, 2 -- 1, with Mike Mellis turning in a superb two-hitter.

CHERBOURG, France, July 20 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Prime Minister Churchill visited captured German flying bomb emplacements in the Cherbourg area today, after his arrival here aboard an American transport plane.

A UNITED STATES AIR BASE, Somewhere in Russia, July 23 (AP) -- Two Americans who flew side by side in bombing Germany now lie side by side in Russian soil in the first United States cemetery of this war in the Soviet Union.

PEARL HARBOR, July 23 -- Substantial gains were made by our forces on Guam all day yesterday and during the previous night. In the northern area Piti town and near-by Cabras Island were captured from the Japanese, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz reported today.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 23 (U.P.) -- Plans to establish what will be the only existing cooperatively owned village in the United States have been disclosed by A.J. Smeby, general manager of the Midland Cooperative Wholesale of Minneapolis. He announced the plans on the 100th anniversary of the founding of the world's first cooperative village, Rochdale, England.
CHUNGKING, China, July 23 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

A survey made public yesterday by the Twentieth Century Fund revealed that 197 public and private agencies of national scope were actively engaged on post-war problems and indicated America's determination to meet effectively the problems that will arise with a return to peace.

LONDON, Monday, July 24 (U.P.) -- Italy-based Lightnings and Mustangs of the United States Fifteenth Air Force, flying an estimated 900 miles in the first all-fighter shuttle operation to Russia, blasted two Luftwaffe stations guarding the Ploesti oil fields Saturday.

Designs for a new town of Lidice, to be erected in Czechoslovakia after the war, are being developed at Columbia University under the auspices of the Czech government-in-exile, it was announced yesterday by Leopold Arnaud, dean of the Columbia School of Architecture.

One hundred and sixty-one years ago today, in the beautiful valley that shelters the city of Caracas in the Venezuelan highlands, was born Simon Bolivar, who called himself "The Liberator." No man deserved that title more than he, for he put the impress of his ideas and personality on half a continent.

Gas generated by fumes from garbage in a Department of Sanitation pit yesterday cost the lives of three department employes, overcome two others who went to their rescue and provided a puzzle for chemical laboratory experts.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The supply of choice and good grades of beef in New York now amounts to only about 60 per cent of the retail trade's needs and conditions will get worse, a representative of one of the large packers said yesterday. Shipments to customers, he said, have to be allocated on that basis.

LONDON, July 23 (Netherland News Agency) -- German authorities in occupied Holland have embarked upon a new reign of terror, shooting innocent civilians, sometimes without even giving the cynical explanation, "shot trying to escape."

The Congress of Industrial Organizations threw its support yesterday behind the bids of Representative Charles A. Buckley of the Bronx and Representative Donald L. O'Toole of Brooklyn for renomination in the Democratic primary for Congress.

Among habitual investors -- those who make the market in famine as well as feast -- enthusiasm for low-priced stock issues appears to have waned in the last eighteen months. Among amateur investors -- those who play the market as if it were a race card -- the sentiment is otherwise.

MOSCOW, July 23 -- Ilya Ehrenburg, one of Russia's best-known authors, declared today that, no matter what was happening in Germany, her fate would be decided on the battlefield by her enemies and not at home by her generals.

Over the signatures of Prof. John Hanna, Prof. D.F. Fleming and Mr. George Stewart respectively you have recently published three interesting contributions on the future of Germany as that shall be covered by the coming peace terms. I use the words "peace terms" to cover any exactions that may be imposed between the cessation of actual warfare and the final settlement.

Forty per cent of industrial illnesses are traceable to foot ailments, Dr. Raymond V. Healy of Albany, president of the New York State Podiatry Society, told 200 chiropodists and guests at its three-day convention opened yesterday in the Pennsylvania Hotel.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., July 23 -The Long Island amateur golf championship remains in the clan Strafaci for at least another year.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., July 23 (AP) -- Nomination of Senator Harry S. Truman for the Vice Presidency by the Democrats could open the way for Missouri Republicans to gain his Senate seat, which in the past has been occupied principally by Democrats.

CHICAGO, July 23 -- For a time today it looked as if the Yankees would make up a lot of lost ground in their pursuit of the Browns in the American League flag race. Somewhere along the line, though, they lost their way and at the close of the arduous afternoon they had made no headway at all.

The New York State Public Service Commission has been informed by the investment concern of Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., that it is prepared to market $42,000,000 of Brooklyn Union Gas Company's refunding bonds "on better terms than those proposed by the utility" in a proceeding now pending before Chairman Milo R. Maltbie, the commission announced yesterday.

MEXICO CITY, July 23 (AP) -Ezequiel Ordonez, a geologist who reported that he had just made a hazardous trip through the lava-covered region of Paricutin, denied official and travelers' reports today that the village of Zirosto, five miles from the volcano, was totally destroyed.
ROME, July 23 -- Some light on Adolf Hitler's difficulties in keeping his armies fighting in the field can be gleaned from statements of German prisoners in Italy.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Monday, July 24 -- Allied Southwest Pacific fliers sank a Japanese freighter within seventy miles of Mindanao, southernmost of the Philippines, in their wide-ranging drive to sweep the seas of enemy shipping, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today.

CHICAGO, July 23 -- The wheat market has reached an impasse, with hedging sales and peace talk having a depressing effect, but this is largely offset by fears of Government support and the earmarking of large amounts of cash grain for Federal loans.

No surer index of the mounting supremacy of Allied airpower can be found than the manner in which American and British planes continue to be sent on strategic as well as tactical missions. For example, during the last few days 7,000 tons of bombs were dropped in less than four hours in close support of General Montgomery's successful extension of his front below Caen.

CAEN, France, July 20 (Delayed) -- The war began moving away from this stricken, almost silent city today, and, as it did so, French state funds that had lain in hiding ever since the Germans invaded Caen four years ago began emerging.

LONDON, July 23 -- Despite the physical difficulties under which the Stock Exchange continues business, the volume of transactions expanded further last week, with an almost general advance in prices. Industrial equities again figured prominently in the rise, the index number of this group creating a new wartime record.
ROME, July 23 (UP) -- A communique:

EUREKA, Calif., July 23 (AP) -- An indictment charging twenty-six Japanese-Americans of the Tule Lake segregation center with violations of the Selective Service Act was dismissed yesterday by Judge Louis E. Goodman of Federal court, who ruled that an internee was not accorded due process of law.

The newest book by George Bernard Shaw, who will celebrate his eighty-eighth birthday on Wednesday, is "Everybody's Political What's What," in which he presents his political philosophy. It will be published early in October by Dodd, Mead.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 23 -- George Raft has been signed by RKO for "Johnny Angel," a story of maritime spies and mutiny, to be directed by Ray Enright, when the latter finishes the forthcoming "China Sky." "Johnny Angel" is to be an adaptation of a national magazine serial, "Mr. Angel Comes Aboard," by Charles Gordon Booth.

Beauty and personality courses or girls from the age of 7 on up through those who are already holding jobs will begin today on an experimental basis at the center of the Police Athletic League it 12 West 108th Street. If the twenty-five-hour program in the essentials of good grooming proves a success, according to Mrs. Harry Hult, the teacher, similar sessions will be undertaken at PAL centers all over the city.

The National Association of Manufacturers in a current supplement to NAM, its weekly publication, urges special training of foremen for the important role they must play in the rehabilitation of veterans returning to industry.

Manufacturers seeking to introduce new products who are faced with space restrictions in national publications have no alternative but to turn to direct mail and point-of-sale advertising to gain permanent footholds for their products, an advertising executive pointed out yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Recommendations for a national fiscal, monetary and tax program, including a balanced budget on a high level and the abolition of the income tax on corporations, are contained in a report by the experts, Beardsley Ruml and H. Christian Sonne, issued today by the National Planning Association.

LONDON, July 23 (Reuter) -The Manchester Guardian considers that the defeat of Henry Wallace at the Democratic convention in Chicago marks the beginning of "qualified liberalism" in the United States.
CLEVELAND, July 23 (AP) -- The Indians moved into fourth place today by sweeping a double-header with the Senators, winning the opener, 4 to 3, and taking the nightcap, 9 to 5.

Of the three night clubs in which the Department of Finance had placed custodians to safeguard the city's claims for a total of $232,094 in taxes, only La Vie Parisienne at 3 East Fifty-second Street had its "watch dog" last night. Gone was the custodian from the Stork Club, 3 East Fifty-third Street, by force of a court order obtained from Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora about 3 A.M. yesterday.

The return of the butterless luncheon in public eating places was suggested yesterday after the Office of Price Administration had increased the ration value of butter from 12 to 16 points a pound because civilian consumption was exceeding allocations.

CHICAGO, July 23 -- Drought conditions were intensified last week in parts of the Corn Belt, especially in southern Iowa, Illinois and Indiana and some sections of Ohio. However, there was good rain in western Kansas, and some areas in Oklahoma and Kentucky that will tend to prevent additional damage.

To take advantage of the release last week by the War Production Board of aluminum for the manufacture of cans for specified products, many canners have placed large orders for the metal, George J. Stanley, vice president and general sales manager of the Aluminum Company of America, announced yesterday.

LONDON, Monday, July 24 (AP) -- Royal Air Force heavy bombers in "very great strength" struck the German port of Kiel during the night, and speedy Mosquito bombers attacked Berlin, British officials announced today.
STAMFORD, Conn., July 23 -After giving promise of fine support to the Stamford Yacht Club's regatta today, a south-southwest breeze faded, leaving sixty-seven craft floundering about for hours.

Pskov was the last stronghold the Germans held in pre-war Russia. Its fall now finally clears the enemy from the motherland and brings Hitler's invasion to a historic close. But the capture of the ancient city, founded before Rurik welded the Russians into a nation, is much more than symbolic.

SALT LAKE CITY, July 23 (U.P.) -- Jug McSpaden won the Utah open golf tournament championship today over the long Fort Douglas course with a score of 271, nosing out Byron Nelson by two strokes for the $700 first money. McSpaden sewed up the tournament with a record-breaking 63 on his morning round and coasted home with an even par 72.
LONDON, July 23 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

ST. LOUIS, July 23 (AP) -- After a crushing 12-to-1 defeat, the Browns rebounded with a bang to break a three-game losing streak and stop the Red Sox, 9 to 3, in the nightcap of today's double-header.

PHILADELPHIA, July 23 (AP) -A home run by Ray Mueller with one on base in the seventh inning gave the Cincinnati Reds a 2-1 nightcap victory over Philadelphia after losing, 7 -- 6, to the Phillies in the first half of a doubleheader before 16,895 fans today.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditiionary Force, July 23 (AP) -- Communique 95:
Sharp price decreases for a large number of farm products caused the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices to drop from the previous week's all-time high of 113.07 to 112.89.

The Polo Grounds was splattered with a lot of curious baseball yesterday as, before a gathering of 25,725 fans, the Giants and Cubs split a double-header that consumed 5 hours and 8 minutes, elapsed time.

We are engaged in a total war and fighting for a total victory, which will not be won outside the United States alone, the Rev. Dr. Peter Marshall, pastor of the New York Avenue Presbyterian Church, Washington, D.C., said yesterday in a sermon in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at Fifty-fifth Street.

Walter B. Force of Brooklyn, president of the coffee shipping and transportation business bearing his name, has purchased the Shrewsbury riverfront estate of J.R. Hensler at Rumson, N.J. It is a medium-sized property on Wilson Circle with a nine-room house and frontages of 150 feet on the river and a depth of 500 feet on the road.

Impressed by the American Negro Theatre's recent tryout of "Anna Lucasta" in Harlem, John Wildberg was determined to acquire the Philip Yordan play. He did by paying advance royalties of $2,500, which is somewhat unusual in the case of a playwright who hasn't been represented previously on Broadway.
The revolutionary opinion that properly fried food may be fed to children with no harmful effect is held by many authorities, Dr. Frank H. Richardson of Black Mountain, N.C., reports.
Rear Admiral Charles W. O. Bunker, USN, and Mrs. Bunker have come to the Waldorf-Astoria from Bethesda, Md.

PITTSBURGH, July 23 -- Raw steel output in the nation last week advanced one point to 97 per cent of rated capacity. The outlook for this week indicates that the production of steel will be as heavy or heavier than it was last week. Slowly, in the face of heat, manpower shortages and production difficulties, the steel industry has been able to stem the downward trend in steel output.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -The Navy disclosed officially tonight that on Aug. 18, when the destroyer escort Grady is launched, the number of United States fighting ships in service will be 1,149, or more than three times the total available when the fleet began to grow in mid-1940.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The application of incentive wage plans to some producers of automotive parts has made necessary a change in the formula pricing provisions of the regulation governing manufacturers' maximum prices, the Office of Price Administration said today.

DALLAS, July 23 -- Speaker Sam Rayburn and Representative Hatton Sumners, both elected first to Congress in 1912, and seven other Congressmen won renomination today in returns from yesterday's Texas Democratic primary election.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, July 23 (U.P.) -- Allied units have pushed the battered and beaten Japanese "invade India army" to within forty miles of the Burma border in Manipur State and today were almost within sight of their goal of driving the enemy from India.

Pressure groups responsible for the charge that juvenile delinquency has increased to an alarming extent are guilty of a ridiculous indictment of "the whole childhood of the city," Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall.

ROME, July 23 (Reuter) -- There is reason to believe that the Holy See views the situation in Germany as sufficiently critical to require the utmost readiness on the part of the Vatican Secretariat of State to play a part if the opportunity should arise for mediation between the Allies and Germany.

PAWLING, N.Y., July 23 -Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, prolonging his usual week-end rest at his Pawling farm, completed today a general outline of the program for the St. Louis conference with Republican Governors at which special attention is expected to be given the problems of returning war veterans.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (U.P.) -The Office of Price Administration announced tonight that prices for the 1944 pack of fruits and vegetables will be based on grades established in commercial channels to protect buyers and consumers against "up-grading."
WITH BRITISH FORCES in France, July 22 (Delayed) (Reuter) -- Prime Minister Churchill made a hustle tour through the dust and debris and wreckage of the streets of Caen today.

Selection of Senator Harry S. Truman of Missouri as running mate for President Roosevelt makes the Democratic national ticket "a natural," Edward V. Loughlin, leader of the New York County Democratic Committee, declared yesterday as he returned with other members of the Tammany delegation from Chicago.

Last week was a period of news, at home and abroad. The stock market at times reflected opposite inferences from the week's war bulletins, but went lower. Notwithstanding capture by the Allies of important cities in Normandy, Italy and on the Russian border, and despite removal of Tojo from his Japanese command, the market lost ground rapidly.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Monday, July 24-- Allied infantrymen, who are bearing the heaviest burden in the second battle of France, captured a number of German positions in local attacks and repelled sharp but disconnected enemy assaults along the Normandy front yesterday as both sides prepared for new and greater battles under the clearing skies.

WASHINGTON, July 23 --Women doctors are making a war record both in civilian life and in the Army which should entitle them to a larger place in the present too-scanty medical school enrollments, in the opinion of Maj. Margaret Craighill, director of the Women's Medical Unit in the Office of the Surgeon General of the Army.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES, in Normandy, July 23 -- The news of the attempt on Adolf Hitler's life and the revolt in high German Army circles is filtering down to the men in the ranks despite officers' attempts to suppress it and is causing bewilderment and confusion.

A UNITED STATES AIR BASE in Russia, July 23 (AP) -- United States air bases in Russia have now served in a new type of shuttle operation, with fighter planes arriving here alone from Italy after shooting up enemy air fields in Rumania.

LONDON, July 23 -- The British Government has set its face against any partial demobilization of British wartime industry such as was announced by Donald Nelson for American manufacturers after July 15. The American announcement led to a flood of inquiries here.

Joseph Hudnut, dean of the Harvard School of Architecture, in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine today made what he apparently considers a reply to my article on planning which appeared in a previous number. By way of rebuttal I would like to call attention to Mr. Hudnut's recent remarks at the Museum of Modern Art at which he gave us his dicta on how to plan New York City.
WITH BRAZILIAN FORCES IN ITALY, July 23 (AP) -- Encamped side by side in this tree-shaded bivouac area Brazilian soldiers and American doughboys are making the Good Neighbor policy come true.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -Ceiling prices to be established soon on canneries' sales of red sour pitted cherries packed in New York and Pennsylvania were announced today by the Office of Price Administration.

On selling influenced by war and political developments, cotton prices in the domestic market declined sharply last week. At the close of trading on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net declines for the week of 51 to 68 points.

LONDON, July 23 -- Col. Gen. Heinz Guderian, Adolf Hitler's new army chief of staff, disclosed today that some officers in active service had been involved in the plot against Hitler and the National Socialist regime.

CAIRO, July 23 (AP) -- The swoop on Symi was disclosed as reports increased that Turkey might be veering toward war against Germany. It demonstrated that the Germans, massively engaged on three fronts, could expect no rest or security anywhere in their line.

IF the Columbus team of the American Association had not had eleven third basemen and no shortstops appear at training camp one year, if Cal Griffith of Chattanooga had been more generous with his free tickets and if a 12-year-old boy had not had both the courage and fortitude to fight his way back from a crippling fall, Martin (Slats) Marion probably would not be unveiling his wizardry at shortstop for the Cardinals this season.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 23 -- A British and Greek force that had been specially trained for amphibious operations wiped out the enemy garrison of the Island of Symi in the southeast Aegean Sea north of Rhodes and off the coast of Turkey, it was disclosed today.

ST. LOUIS, July 24 (AP) -- Denny Galehouse, taking over the starting assignment left by Nelson Potter's suspension, couldn't quite go the distance against the Red Sox today, but the league-leading Browns nevertheless won, 6 to 5, for an even break in the series with the third-placers.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Tuesday, July 25 (AP) -- American artillery and rifle fire turned back three desperate Japanese attacks along the Driniumor River front in British New Guinea, headquarters announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Holding that the Mann Act does not apply to transportation of women for immoral purposes within the District of Columbia, the United States Court of Appeals today reversed the conviction of Carmen Beach grow-out of a series of vice raids last year.

LONDON, Tuesday, July 25 (U.P.) -- The bombardment of southern England and the London area by German robot bombs continued last night, keeping rescue squads busy digging through wreckage in a search for living victims.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Can Germany be knocked out of the war "earlier than we have a right to say," as Prime Minister Churchill remarked to British airmen in Normandy yesterday?

Lieut. Comdr. McClelland Barclay, famous illustrator, who has been missing in action since July 18, 1943, is now assumed to be dead, according to a letter from the Navy Department received yesterday by his brother, Robert H. Barclay, chief electrical engineer of the J.G. White Engineering Corporation, 80 Broad Street.

LONDON, Tuesday, July 25 (AP) --i-iVIarshal Rokossovsky's forces have torn more than 9,000 square miles out of the Axis grip in German-occupied Poland, and beyond their immediate objective, Warsaw, lie the plains leading to Germany on the shortest road to Berlin -- 365 airline miles from Siedlce.

CHICAGO, July 24 -- A pessimistic executive committee of the National Piano Manufacturers Association sent a telegram today to Chester Bowles, Office of Price Administration chairman, urging a pricing policy by his organization that would permit resumption of piano production.

The seven-story office building at 186 Fifth Avenue, southwest corner of Twenty-third Street, has been sold and resold in cash deals. The building, extending 100 feet on Twenty-third Street, contains seven stores with offices on the upper floors.

Thanks to the disqualification of the first one over the finish line, the Belair Stud's Thread o' Gold reaped the honors in the feature event on the card of the Empire City Racing Association at Jamaica yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (U.P.) -Carl J. Schoeninger, commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars of the United States, tonight announced an agreement with labor leaders pledging certain employment benefits and preferential consideration for returning war veterans.

The Twentieth Century Fund announces that it will make a study of what post-war America can do about trends toward monopoly in domestic business and cartels in international trade. As Evans Clark, executive director of the Fund, has pointed out:

With all the eagerness of youngsters off to camp, a party of oldsters, ranging from 71 to 881 years old, left the Home of Old Israel yesterday for a two-week stay in the country. Several score of the 300 residents of the home at 70 Jefferson Street crowded outside to watch ten fortunate members leave.

HOUSTON, Tex., July 24 (AP) -- In what one Democratic party official described as the first such action ever taken by Negroes in the South, one group of Negro voters here organized a Democratic precinct convention Saturday and another elected Negro delegates to the county convention July 29.

OLD ORCHARD BEACH, Me., July 24 (AP) -- Youngsters predominated today's Grand Circuit racing, Gibson White taking the feature with Leta Long, by Volomite, from the stable of W.N. Reynolds of Winston-Salem, N.C.

ABOARD UNITED STATES INVASION FLAGSHIP, off Guam, July 24 -- The two-beach assault by American forces on Guam continued toward the single front objective of the Apra Harbor area today, trapping an unknown number of Japanese troops on Orote Peninsula.

E-bond sales in the Fifth War Loan in New York City had reached $104,577,782 at the close of last week, or 72.3 per cent of the $227,526,600 quota, Nevil Ford, State chairman of the War Finance Committee for New York, announced yesterday.
Mr. and Mrs. George Sloane of 154 East Seventy-eighth Street and Warrentown, Va., will spend August at Pointe au Pic, P.Q.
LONDON, July 24 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

MOSCOW, Tuesday, July 25 -- Soviet troops drove to within fifty-seven miles of Warsaw yesterday, capturing the rail junction of Lukow and cutting all rail means of escape or supply for the embattled and outflanked German garrison in Brest-Litovsk.

ROME, July 24 -- The Municipal Food Bureau was stormed and damaged today by thousands of fruit venders who had struck to protest against the enforcement of a tax on the sales of fruits and vegetables.

DETROIT, July 24 (AP) -- Paul Trout gained his sixth straight victory and fourteenth of the season tonight as the Tigers blanked the Athletics, 1 to 0, in a twilight game before 10,805 fans. Rudy York's double sent Roger Cramer home with the only run in the fourth.

LONDON, July 24 (U.P.) -- The ] I4itler order that the Ni saluteI be given henceforth by all men of the armed forces was a sensation to those who recalled that after more than eleven and a half years of Nazi rule in Germany the Junker officers had still exercised such control over fighting men that the normal salute of armed forces had still been official except for Nazis of the Elite Guard units.
The first administrative concentration camp for liberated France "has been set up near Cherbourg," the Brazzaville radio said last night in a broadcast recorded by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

Bob Montgomery, the lightweight champion, and Beau Jack, former titleholder, both now in the Army, arrived here yesterday to complete training for their ten-round non- title bout on Aug. 4 in Madison Square Garden. Admission to the show will be by War Bond purchase only.

ROME, July 24 -- British and American forces, surging in a giant swinging drive toward Florence, have pushed within twelve miles of that pivotal Italian road center from the south and cleared forty-nine miles of the south bank of the Arno River from its mouth past Pisa to San Miniato.

BASLE, Switzerland, July 24 -- Since Wednesday at dawn -- a whole day before the attempt to kill Adolf Hitler -- German officers from the rank of field marshal down to that of major have been undergoing a purge, the magnitude of which is just beginning to emerge in reports from the Reich.
SUPREME HEADQUARTEES, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 24 (AP) -- Communique 97:

Blouses assume greater importance than ever for fall as a result of the current silhouettes in the dress market. The two-piece dress and the dress with the contrasting top have influenced blouse fashions to a marked extent.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Officials here fear that the "knockout" of the enemy will be delayed by a critical shortage of castings and forgings, components of almost every important type of war equipment.

BURLINGTON, Vt., July 24 -- As author of the phrase "peace forces" in the international relations plank of the Republican national platform, Senator Warren R. Austin of Vermont told Burlington Rotarians today that he felt the declaration went further than that of the Democratic platform.

ALGIERS, July 24 (U.P.) -- One of] the youngest but most outstanding delegates of French resistance movements to the French Consultative Assembly said today that the Committee of National Liberation had recently made a formal request that the Allies limit the bombing of French towns.
CHUNGKING, China, July 24 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

SALEM, N.H. July 24 (AP) -- Closing with a rush, P.T. Catalano's 4-year-old Zacabrand, Georgie Hettinger in the saddle, won the $2,000 Bristol allowance race, a six-furlong sprint, feature of the opening day of Rockingham Park's summer meeting.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Devotion to the ideals and traditions of the American Red Cross was pledged today by Basil O'Connor of New York, national chairman, at a press conference as he assumed his duties as successor to the late Norman H. Davis.

NEWARK, N.J., July 24 -- Charged with fraudently soliciting funds ostensibly for the Navy Relief Society, Edward A. Cornez of 116 234th Street, Laurelton, Queens, went on trial in Federal Court here today after Judge George Bell Timmerman granted severances to three labor union officials indicted with him.

Bizet's opera "Carmen" was presented for the first time this season at the Lewisohn Stadium last night with a cast drawn largely from the Metropolitan Opera Company and with orchestral support provided by the Philharmonic-Symphony directed by Alexander Smallens.

NEWARK, N.J., July 24 (U.P.) -- Heavyweight fighter Lem Franklin, unconscious for nearly an hour after a knockout punch delivered by his opponent. Larry Lane, suffered a probable brain concussion but is not in a serious condition, attending physicians reported after the fight tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Miss Margaret Hickey, new president of the Business and Professional Women's Clubs, as well as chairman of the Women's Advisory Committee of the War Manpower Commission, said today she meant women war workers generally when she said, in her acceptance speech, that these clubs should extend their membership to the women fresh to the working world as a result of the war.

" Gerard Manley Hopkins," a biography by Eleanor Ruggles, will be published by W.W. Norton on Friday, the centenary of the poet's birth. Hopkins' verse, unknown to the public during the author's lifetime, was first published through the efforts of Robert Bridges, poet laureate.

A preliminary examination report "unfavorable" to construction of an intracoastal waterway between Manasquan Inlet and the Shrewsbury River in New Jersey and to erection of coastal erosion defenses in that area has been complete Col. Albert H. Burton, Army Corps of Engineers, said yesterday.

CHUNGKING, China, July 24 (U.P.) -- Chinese troops, fighting to regain control of the territory east and west of the Changsha-Hengyang railway in Hunan Province, have captured a number of important positions northwest of Hengyang and are pouring through the north gate of Siang-siang, fifty-six miles north of Hengyang, the Chinese High Command said today.

ALBANY, July 24 -- Governor Dewey announced today the complete itinerary for his trip to St. Louis next week. It will include a previously unscheduled visit to Springfield, Ill., where he will spend Tuesday, Aug. 1.

During the period June 15-July 15 almost 96 per cent of all retail outlets in metropolitan New York received shipments of Schenley Distillers Corporation products, the company stated yesterday. Described as the first distribution plan of its kind to be put into effect, the program is designed to serve the best interests of the trade and the public "by providing a certain monthly delivery to every licensee, regardless of pre-war purchases,'' it was said.

BRITISH SECOND ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Normandy, Tuesday, July 25 -- Canadian and British troops astride the Falaise road resumed the attack on the eastern flank of the Twenty-first Army group early this morning and heavy fighting is raging along a wide front, Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery announced today.

Information that the Army has placed orders for 4,600,000 troop field tunics, to be used in the European war theatre, is indicative of shortages of men's clothing much larger than had been anticipated for the coming fall and winter seasons, according to industry observers yesterday.

Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, charged yesterday that 23.240 merchant seamen who live in New York State are completely excluded from participating in this year's Presidential election under State laws that Governor Dewey recently defended as models of simplicity.
LONDON, July 24 (AP) -- A special communique on the First Baltic, First, Second and Third White Russian Fronts, as broadcast from Mos cow and recorded by the Soviet monitor in London:

CHICAGO, July 24 -- By way of demonstrating that, come what may, they still retain their time-honored habit of bouncing back when adversity crowds them hardest, the Yankees thrashed Jimmy Dykes' White Sox in the series final tonight, 11 to 5, before a crowd of 20,411 disappointed onlookers.
I have read with much interest in your recent issue the discussion of the problem of adult delinquency at the third annual conference on youth problems at Benjamin Franklin High School.

Our landings on Tinian at the height of the battle for Guam bring into clear perspective our developing Pacific strategy. Conquered Saipan is not to remain an isolated bomber outpost against Japan. The entire group of Marianas may be welded into a single coordinated base to help us to drive across the ocean to the Philippines, Formosa, the China coast and Japan itself.

The Western Electric Company has leased for five years the six-story Lane Bryant Building at 529 West Forty-second Street from Lewis Spencer Morris, John D. Pea-body and City Bank Farmers Trust Company, as trustees. Containing a floor space of about 196,000 square feet, the building extends through to Forty-third Street between Tenth and Eleventh Avenues.

A delicious whole-wheat bread called Sweet Content that has been served in several restaurants in the city for the last two years is being introduced in retail stores. The formula was evolved by a New York physician, who has it prepared by a commercial baker under his supervision.

LONDON, July 24 -- The stock markets here continued today to go ahead on the war news, the demand being accentuated by the shortage of stock. Renewed strength was shown by industrials, fresh buying causing a further advance in prices although the best levels were not always maintained owing to some profit-taking before the close.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 86:

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Tuesday, July 25 -- The Royal Air Force's heavy bombers loosed about 3,300 tons of bombs in fifteen to twenty minutes early yesterday on Kiel, the great naval base where the Nazis might try to gather sufficient ships to rescue the German armies now almost isolated in the Baltic States.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 24 -- An upward revision of $15 a month in the stabilized wage rates for "white collar" workers in the San Francisco and Los Angeles areas, announced in May by the Tenth Regional Way Labor Board, was rescinded in a communication today from the National WLB.

CHICAGO, July 24 -- Liquidation developed in the grain markets today on the board of trade following a moderate showing of strength early when shorts covered on continued dry weather in parts of the Corn Belt. Rye was the first grain to develop weakness, and prices receded quickly under pressure from commission houses with Eastern connection.

The City Bank Farmers Trust Company sold the four-story brownstone dwelling with sixteen rooms on a lot 16.8 by 120 feet at 558 Washington Avenue, in Brooklyn, assessed at $6,500. The bank also sold 407 Tompkins Avenue, a four-story apartment house on a lot 20 by 85 feet assessed at $7,500.
Two United States Senators, including the only woman Senator and the dean of that chamber, face multiple opposition today in their bids for renomination.

A slender, 18-year-old youth, John Peter Safranek of 1544 Second Avenue, was booked yesterday at the East Sixty-seventh Street police station on a charge of strangling his mother, Mrs. Dora Safranek, 51, at their home shortly after midnight Sunday.

LONDON, July 24 -- The new Polish Committee of National Liberation, which has been established on Polish soil under Red Army control and has started elbowing the exiled Polish Government in London out of the future administration of Poland, was denounced by Polish spokesmen here today as a body of "usurpers, nobodies, turncoats and Communists."

CHICAGO, July 24 -- Describing the Democratic National Convention here last week as the "wake" of the party and denouncing the convention activities of New Deal's "communistic allies," the American Democratic National Committee, anti-fourth term group, outlined today its plan for the campaign.

LAWRENCE, Kan., July 24 (AP) -- E.C. Quigley, whose cry of "You can't do that!" has roared over many sports fields in his long career as an arbiter, took a new job today, that of rebuilding the athletic fortunes of Kansas University.

BOSTON, July 24 (AP) -- The 101st Infantry Veterans Association, AEF, has sent a resolution to the War Department criticizing Army authorities and private citizens for what it calls "pampering and coddling" Italian war prisoners.

The destruction of railroads in Europe and the success of the B-29 bomber have deprived the general public of hope of new tires next fall, according to a National Broadcasting Company radio talk last night by Harvey Firestone Jr., president of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company.

ALBANY, July 24 (AP) -- New York State, which produced more than 5,000,000 barrels of high-grade crude oil last year, has reserves for at least a quarter of a century more at the same rate, according to a report issued today by Dr. Chris Hartnagel, State Geologist.

Operations of the Shell Union Oil Corporation in the first half of 1944 resulted in a consolidated net income of $14,507,369, equal to $1.08 a share, after deducting estimated Federal taxes on income and provision for post-war adjustments and other contingencies, R.G.A. van der Woude, president, reports in the operating statement released today.

At a hearing by the Public Service Commission yesterday, Arthur H. Dean, representing the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, stated that Halsey, Stuart Co. will take up at par $12,000,000 of twenty-five-year sinking fund debentures out of a total of a $42,000,000 refinancing program which the company is planning.

Representatives of the retail liquor industry of twenty-one States will take action next month in Washington to seek an amendment to the provisions of the war excise tax increase law that went into effect April 1, whereby a refund will be asked from the Federal Government on tax-prepaid spirits on the date the tax is reduced from $9 to $6 per proof gallon, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Surface harmony prevailed at the meeting of the Democratic National Committee in Chicago Saturday, at which Chairman Robert E. Hannegan was unanimously re-elected to conduct the campaign and Mayor Kelly of Chicago denied reports that the chairman had used his office to defeat the will of the delegates and nominate Senator Truman instead of the Vice President for second place.

LONDON, Tuesday, July 25 (AP) -- The RAF delivered another heavy blow to Germany during the night, a large force of bombers carrying out a powerful raid on Stuttgart while Mosquitos attacked battered Berlin.

LONDON, July 24 (Netherlands News Agency) -- Eelco N. Van Kleffens, Netherland Minister for Foreign Affairs, today declared that some universal organization for promoting peaceful development of international relations will almost surely come out of this war, but at the same time he warned that Japan and Germany, even in defeat, would remain dangerous to the peace of the world.

Federal aid granted to child care projects in New York State from April 1, 1943, to June 30, 1944, has reached a total of $1,745,794, with additional applications pending for grants of $306,903. In addition to this sum, the cost of child care projects has required a State expenditure of $166,557 for the year beginning April 1, 1943, according to figures released yesterday by the Committee on Child Care of the State War Council.

Tax-evasion schemes, by which night clubs in the city "cheat" not only the city but also their patrons, were charged in a report by Commissioner of Investigation Edgar Bromberger made public yesterday.
PEARL HARBOR, July 24 -- The battle for complete domination of the Marianas is raging today on two islands, Guam and Tinian, where marines and Army assault troops have made important gains.

Reports that the Department of Justice is preparing anti-trust action, against the National Association of Securities Dealers, or against one or more large investment banking houses, or against the association and the firms as well, gained credence in Wall Street yesterday.

One day last week Lawrence M. Phillips, an executive of USO Campshows, was credited in THE TIMES with a statement that concert artists have failed to come through as generously as they should with offers to entertain the armed forces; and he ventured the opinion that perhaps the artists might be under the impression that USO is not interested in serious music.
Dr. Walter M. Mitchell has been appointed director of research for Mack Trucks, Inc.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 24 -- Small but sharp sallies by British and Canadian infantrymen against the German lines and enemy counter-attack on the newly won American bridgehead across the Seves River were all that broke the quiet along the Normandy front today. The weather was clearing and it was a day of preparation for new operations. Long convoys of Allied trucks rolled along the drying Continued on Page 3

A brief story in your issue of July 20 quotes Henry L. Jackson, special fashion counsel and consultant, Quartermaster Corps, as saying that men in the armed forces are leading the way to a revolution in men's summer clothing styles that will give the shirt suit a permanent place in men's wardrobes.

CLEVELAND, July 24 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians pounded out fifteen safeties, including two triples and six doubles, to support Ed Klieman's four-hit hurling and take today's game from the Washington Senators, 10 to 1.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- William Y. Elliott, vice chairman for Civilian Requirements, War Production Board, told a newly organized theatre owners industry advisory committee that the erection of new theatres will be authorized only when the WPB is convinced that a new movie house is "absolutely essential in the community."

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan ordered an inquiry yesterday into charges that the primary designating petitions of Representatives Vito Marcantonio and Martin J. Kennedy, both of whom are seeking re-election from the new Eighteenth District in Manhattan, contain many fraudulent signatures and other irregularities.

Great Britain and the United States must lead other industrial nations in finding means "to put the ideals upon which Pan Americanism was founded into practice economically," Frederick E. Hasler, president of the Pan American Society of the United States, declared at ceremonies in honor of the 161st birthday of Gen. Simon Bolivar, Venezuelan liberator and founder of Bolivia.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- An indirect but none the less positive notice has been served on Argentina that the United States considers that country to be working for the benefit of the Axis powers and against the interests of the United Nations and the American nations by its refusal to collaborate in the Pan-American war program.

HANOVER, N. H., July 24 -- Capt. Ford K. Sayre, 34 years old, of the Army Air Corps, who was killed yesterday in a plane collision at Spokane, Wash., was manager of the Hanover Inn at Dartmouth College, from which he got a leave of absence in August, 1942, to accept a commission as first lieutenant.

LONDON, July 24 -- French patriots have struck down Col. Gen. Otto von Stuelpnagel, commander in chief of the German occupation forces in France, a Paris broadcast disclosed tonight. Swiss dispatches revealed that maddened Germans, stung by an attack on a German garrison, had turned the village of St. Guingolph, near the Lake of Geneva, into another Lidice.

The fur industry here closed yesterday an hour earlier than usual while 10,000 workers jammed the 165th Infantry Armory at Lexington Avenue and Twenty-fifth Street to hear a report on the decision of the War Labor Board Panel in the contract dispute with the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers, Inc.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Secretary Hull acclaimed today the monetary conference at Bretton Woods as a success and a full justification of the confidence which he expressed, after his return from Moscow, regarding the ability of the United Nations to work together.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, July 24 (U.P.) -- The tattered, half-starved remnants of two divisions of Japan's India invasion army fled still farther south along the Tiddim road in southern Manipur today as the Allies, supported by Royal Air Force aircraft, drove into the Kuki foothills to clear the Imphal plain of the last of the invaders.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull declined to comment today on the creation of the new Polish Committee of National Liberation, but it is known that this committee was established against the will of the United States and will not be recognized.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., July 24 -- Christ Episcopal Church, the picturesque stone edifice here where members of the Roosevelt family have been christened, married and buried through four generations, was too small this afternoon to hold the 700 persons who came from far and near to attend the memorial service for Brig. Gen. Theodore Roosevelt, who died on July 12 in Normandy of battle exhaustion.

Only 10,115 persons were at Ebbets Field last night, but it seemed as if all of Brooklyn went wild. For the Dodgers, who could not score nine runs in a week, stepped up and counted that many in one inning against the Pirates.
ROME, July 24 (AP) -- A communique:

Today is the first anniversary of the "resignation" of Benito Mussolini. We have to wait until Sept. 3 for the first anniversary of the Calabrian landing and of the signing of the Italian armistice and until Sept. 8 for the announcement of the armistice. We have to wait until Oct. 13 for the first anniversary of Italy's declaration of war against Germany.

The Terminal Building, a landmark in Hoboken, N.J., since its erection in 1911, has been sold by the Fidelity Union Trust Company, as trustee, to the Loppas Holding Company through J.L Kislak, broker.

ROME, July 24 -- Persistent reports linking the visit of Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of New York to Pope Pius XII with possible peace overtures on the part of the Vatican brought a formal denial from Archbishop Spellman today that his trip here had any connection with such a subject.

The Japanese Domei Agency, in an English-language wireless dispatch for overseas consumption, yesterday used the fall of Gen. Hideki Tojo's Cabinet as the basis for a propaganda claim that Tojo was never a "dictator" and that "Japan is a democratic nation in the true sense of the word."

Hitler, taking complete charge of the German Army, imposes the Nazi salute on the Wehrmacht; the Russians drive within fifty miles of Warsaw; the Allies mass in France for a new blow, says the German radio; the stock market closes irregularly higher, butter goes up from twelve points a pound to sixteen and the Reds may drop McKechnie as Cincinnati manager.

Continued pressure to obtain essential cotton goods for the Army and Navy brought sufficient price-fixing into the cotton futures market yesterday to bring about an advance of 20 to 24 points on active months and the finish on the New York Cotton Exchange was at about the best levels of the day.

For the record may I state that apple selling on a large scale by our jobless was not engaged in by veterans at the close of the last war as mentioned by President Roosevelt in his address to the Democratic National Convention. Republican orators at their recent convention made the same error.

LONDON, July 24 (UP) -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden said today in a grim warning to aggressors that "no punishment, however hard, no retribution, however thorough, no surrender, even unconditional, will completely eliminate the dangers of future aggression by those two Hawks of death, Germany and Japan."

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The War Production Board outlined plans today to reduce the country's consumption of boxboard about 73,000 tons a year through restrictions on the manufacture of folding and set-up boxes and the elimination of all types believed unnecessary to the prosecution of the War.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Progress of military aviation during this war has been so great as to abolish barriers and open world commercial competition to domestic airlines, was the opinion expressed here today by A.N. Kemp, president of American Airlines.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 24 -- The stalemate on the Normandy front that followed the halting of the British offensive southeast of Caen focuses attention on a considerable success won by the German Seventh Army in Normandy.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 24 (ONA) -- A list of twenty-four Latvians who either directed or participated in the Nazis' massacres of Jews in Latvia was on its way to the Allied War Crimes Commission in London today after submission to a relief organization here by a Jewish woman who escaped and has just reached Sweden after hiding from the Gestapo for one and a half years.

The prolonged dry weather -- only 6 of an inch of rain has fallen in New York City this month, or 2.01 inches less than normal -- has caused serious losses to farmers in the agricultural regions near the city, a survey yesterday disclosed. The potato crop has been the worst sufferer, but fruits and other vegetables also have been damaged.

MOSCOW, July 24 (AP) -- Prime Minister Churchill's visit to the Normandy front raised Russian hopes high today that the British and Americans would soon hurl an all-out offensive that would drive the Germans from France as the Red Army was pushing them from Russia.

The Japanese Domei Agency reported yesterday that Premier Gen. Kuniaki Koiso had been received by Emperor Hirohito and had "made a report on the political situation" in a day that was otherwise marked by the Koiso Cabinet's efforts to strengthen Japan's propaganda facilities in terms of new problems.

An issue of $24,000,000 refunding 2 3/4 per cent bonds due 1974 of the Cincinnati Union Terminal Company is expected to reach the market in August. Already several syndicates are being formed to bid on the issue. Although no date has been definitely set for the submission of bids, Aug. 8 has been mentioned as the probable date.

" Song of Norway" is getting closer to Broadway. So much so that Lee Shubert is pondering an opening date. He wasn't certain yesterday whether the operetta, dealing with the life and music of Edvard Grieg, would be unveiled on Aug. 17 or 23. As for the theatre, that's a cinch.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- Representatives of the five fluecured tobacco belt States asked the Office of Price Administration today for a two-cent increase in the 1944 ceiling prices announced last week, stated that auction markets would not open until the increase was received and sat back to await results.

HOLLYWOOD, July 24 (U.P.) -- Barbara Hutton Grant, accusing her ex-husband, Count Kurt Haugwitz-Reventlow, of having exerted a hypnotic influence over her in order to gain a portion of her $40,000,000 fortune, asked today for the full custody of their 8-year-old son, Lance.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 24 -- The Rumanian Government and General Staff are so shaken by the political and military events of the last six weeks and by relentless Allied bombings of Rumanian cities -- against which no effective defense has been offered -- that Field Marshal Ion Antonescu, the Premier, is no longer convinced of German victory and now realizes that his policy has failed.

Cash reparation payments, such as were provided for in the Treaty of Versailles, will be impossible after the present war, according to a report made public yesterday by the American Labor Conference of International Affairs, 9 East Forty-sixth Street, a research organization numbering labor leaders among its members.

The cost of advertising in daily and Sunday newspapers throughout the country during April in support of the war effort was $3,204,547, the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, revealed yesterday. Prepared by the Advertising Checking Bureau, Inc., the report covers advertising columns only.

A person turns now and then to the old books for one purpose and stumbles on extra dividends. When you read in the war news about the Russians sweeping in on Nazidom from the East, about General Montgomery pressing from Normandy, about the Allies pushing up from the Gothic Line, it calls up a picture.

BOSTON, July 24 (AP) -- The Cardinals, paced by Marty Marion and Johnny Hopp, blasted three Boston pitchers to gain a 7-1 victory in today's series' wind-up. Marion, who collected three consecutive doubles, started scoring drives in the third, fifth and sixth innings.

KANSAS CITY, July 24 (AP) -- The GI boys of Battery D of the old Missouri National Guard who served under him in France in 1918 gathered around to congratulate Senator Truman today while the Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee awaited word from President Roosevelt as to where and when they would meet to map campaign strategy.

PHILADELPHIA, July 24 -- The United Corporation asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for an additional year in which to comply with the order issued by the commission Aug. 14, 1943, requiring the holding company to change its existing capitalization to a single class of common stock and to go out of business as a holding company.
Master Melvin Ott introduced an experiment at the Polo Grounds last night and cashed dividends forthwith, to the chagrin of Cholly Grimm's Cubs.

A city marshal called yesterday at 125 Guernsey Street, Brooklyn, to dispossess Mrs. Julia Husznay, 67 years, for being five months behind in her rent of $21. The widow pleaded with him to let her stay a few more days, and when he refused she drew a revolver from a bureau drawer and tried to shoot herself.
JERSEY CITY, July 24 (AP) -- Jersey City and Buffalo divided a double-header here tonight, the Little Giants winning the opener, 4 -- 1, with the Bisons coming back to take the nightcap, 9 to 4.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Herbert Brownell Jr., chairman of the Republican National Committee, indicated today, as he paid his first visit to the Washington headquarters, that his party would use the Democratic National Convention as the source of much of the ammunition it will hurl in the campaign.
NAPLES, July 24 -- King George VI of Britain arrived in Naples on Sunday on his fourth visit to a war zone and his first trip to Italy since 1930.
CHUNGKING, China, July 24 (AP) -- A communequi:

The General Foods Corporation, in its semi-annual statement to stockholders issued for publication today, announced that net sales in the first six months of this year were $144,235,180, compared with $119,937,071 in the first half of 1943.

Some semblance of support was accorded yesterday to the stock market, but it lacked sufficient force to produce anything better than an irregularly higher close. Attended by the smallest volume of the month, the character of the buying, however, improved noticeably with the moderate comeback centered in a good grade of stocks.

Eighteen babies, ranging from three weeks old to fifteen months, had their baths and bottles and caught a nap between trains yesterday in the pink-walled nursery just opened off the women's retiring room at Pennsylvania Station.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Charges of politics were flung by defense attorneys when the Government read to the jury in the mass sedition trial today an attack on Thomas E. Dewey, made in 1939 by Robert Edward Edmondson, one of the defendants.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 24 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has bought "A Touch of Heaven," an original screen story by Henry Gilbert and Armin Robinson, as a starring vehicle for Margaret O'Brien. The young actress will do the fantasy, about an angel that comes to work for one day to clear her brother of murder, after co-starring with Jackie Jenkins in "Our Vines Have Tender Grapes."

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 24 -- Having found the winning touch in Westchester P.G.A. one-day competition three weeks ago, Clarence Doser again set the pace today. The Scarsdale Golf Club pro gained his third consecutive double victory by carding 33, 36 -- 69 over the Winged Foot west course.

Exhibitors of household goods made from materials not on the critical list had a "field day" at the Housewares Show which opened yesterday with 730 buyers from stores all over the country crowding into the ballroom of the Hotel Pennsylvania in search of goods.

LONDON, July 24 (AP) -- Advices from the German frontier said the purge had wiped out only a few of the leaders among the army conspirators. It was said the only member of a "High Committee of Opposition" who had been caught was the executed Col. Gen. Ludwig Beck, who had been warned but was taken by accident.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (U.P.) -- Members of a special War Labor Board panel today heard "typical employes" of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company present their own arguments in an effort to prove a union's contention that increases in the cost of living are making it difficult for workers to subsist on present wages.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Tuesday, July 25 (AP) -- A communique:

Black-market dealers in the Newark area were reported yesterday jacking their prices for gasoline from a recent average of 35 cents to 38 and 40 cents a gallon as the shortage in this section became more acute. Along the shore roads in New Jersey some dealers were said to be getting as high as 50 cents a gallon where ration coupons were not demanded.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Mass billeting of American service men in British homes preceding the invasion of France has done more to help British - American relations than any other single factor, according to Miss Dorothy Crook of the British Division, Office of War Information, whose job it is to interpret us to the British.
OLD ORCHARD BEACH, Me., July 25 (AP) -- The $3,718 3-year-old National Stake Pace went in straight heats over the Kite Track today to the promising colt Attorney, by Volomite.

BARNEGAT, N.J., July 25 (AP) -- Barnegat Pines, summer colony of about 600 houses, was completely surrounded by a forest fire, which was brought under control shortly before midnight after burning over 12,000 acres of brush and shrub pine tonight, State Forest Fire Wardens said.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., July 25 -- Daniel Schecter, 8 years old, son of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew Schecter of 32 County Road, Closter, died at Englewood Hospital here this afternoon four hours after he had discharged accidentally a .22 caliber rifle, the bullet entering his head. Mr. Schecter is a mail clerk with the Erie Railroad.

It is difficult to believe that the Dodgers, in their current condition, could teach anyone anything, but the Pirates apparently did learn the value of a big inning, such as the nine-run onslaught by the Brooks Monday night. The only thing unfair about it was that the Pirates moved over to the Polo Grounds yesterday and proceeded to get even at the expense of the Giants.

Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totaled 901 against 1,014 in the preceding week and 721 in the like period a year ago, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals totaled 457 against 438 last Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- Awaiting an answer on their demands for a 2-cent-a-pound increase in ceiling prices for the 1944 flue-cured tobacco crop, spokesmen for growers and warehousemen insisted tonight that if the answer was "no," their fight had "just begun."
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, July 26 (UP) -- A communique:

In the "human interest" story of John A. Commons, who was once a college teacher, who dropped out of sight and after fourteen years was found driving a laundry wagon in Hartford, more than one newspaper account has spoken of his aged father, Dr. John R. Commons, "a retired professor, living in Florida."

Two banking groups, one headed by the Chemical Bank and Trust Company and the other by the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, purchased yesterday local housing authority notes totaling $29,406,000. Chemical Bank and associates bought $24,072,000 of the notes and the Central over group took up the rest.
LONDON, July 25 -- The stock markets here were quieter today. Although there was some profit-taking there were fresh buyers and prices showed only small changes on balance.

One of the most ambitious production schedules in the history of RKO-Radio Pictures -- at least fifty feature-length films and 171 shorts -- was announced yesterday for the season of 1944-45 at the thirteenth annual sales meeting of the company at the Waldorf-Astoria by Ned E. Depinet, president.

ALBANY, July 25 (AP) -- Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein said today that members of the Merchant Marine were not eligible to use absentee ballots under the New York State Constitution because they were not part of the military forces.

STONY POINT, N.Y., July 25 -- Hamilton Fish, Republican member of Congress who is seeking renomination, to the accompaniment of charges of isolationism brought by his opponents, announced tonight that he has started a libel action based on certain published charges against him.
ST. LOUIS, July 25 (AP) -- The Browns donned their hitting togs and pounded three pitchers for sixteen hits to defeat the Athletics, 9 to 1, in the first of a four-game series tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Experts of the Congressional Joint Committee on Internal Revenue Taxation, which has been assigned to work out a post-war tax structure to meet revenue requirements without endangering the economy as it undergoes readjustment, began studies today of "the Twin Cities Plan," submitted recently after fourteen months of preparation by industrialists, financiers and other business men of Minneapolis and St. Paul.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- Silver Star to Capt. Anthony N. Chiappe, 2176 Walton Ave., the Bronx and First Lieut. Ralph G. Wallace, 414 West 120th St., New York.

IN THE ST. LO-PERIERS SECTOR, July 25 -- Probably the heaviest concentration of bombs ever loosed by any air force in close support of ground troops poured down today from the bomb bays of American heavy, medium and fighter bombers on a segment of the German line.

LONDON, July 25 -- Two leaders of the Polish Government in Exile consulted Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden today on the challenge to their authority presented by the new committee and the official backing given to it by Russia.
LONDON, July 25 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

BERNE, Switzerland, July 25 -- Adolf Hitler promulgated a decree today ordering the total mobilization of the Reich and of the occupied territories for the pursuit of the Greater German Reich's total war effort.

At the request of New York Stock Exchange officials certain modifications have been made in the plan whereby 18,733 prior preference shares of Certain-teed Products Corporation are exchangeable until Aug. 21 for 374,660 shares of treasury common stock.

Owing to widespread trade reaction to a form of contract being tendered to American manufacturers of machine tools by the British Ministry of Supply Mission in connection with purchases of equipment to be shipped to the area under its control, Gerald LeVino, chairman of the Foreign Trade Committee of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, has made public clarifying correspondence between the association and the British mission.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Export restrictions over commodities formerly shipped in small quantities under a general export license were relaxed by the Foreign Economic Administration today in what it described as "another step in line with FEA policy to simplify licensing procedures for the export trade."

CINCINNATI, July 25 (AP) -- The second major labor dispute since D-day hit the $155,000,000 Wright Aeronautical Corporation plant in Lockland today, with anywhere between 2,000 and 6,000 day-shift workers idle as the result of a protest against suspension of all union officials and representatives as employes.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Wednesday, July 26 -- German industrial establishments and armament factories in Hitler's Greater Reich and strategic bombing targets in France were heavily pounded yesterday by American and British bombers operating on a night-and-day schedule from bases in Britain and Italy.

The Office of Price Administration is working on an order that will give work-clothing manufacturers partial relief on increased costs since current ceiling prices originally went into effect, it was learned yesterday. This action is expected to take place in the near future, industry spokesmen declared yesterday, following a long-drawn-out controversy between producing companies, associations and the price agency.

The eighty-five-family apartment house at 224 Highland Boulevard, Brooklyn, has been sold by the 224 Highland Boulevard Corporation to the Highland Syndicate, Inc. The property, assessed at $425,000, was sold subject to a mortgage of $300,000.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- With the completion of fourteen weeks of documentary evidence in the mass sedition trial the prosecution said it expects to begin tomorrow offering the jury actual testimony that some of the defendants conspired to undermine the morale of the armed forces.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission today conditionally authorized the Union Electric Company of Missouri to buy virtually all of the electric facilities of the Laclede Power and Light Company and the Laclede Gas Light Company, thus eliminating competition in the electric utility business in the city of St. Louis.

Although sales of the United States Steel Corporation in the first half of 1944 were $96,000,000 greater than in the same period of last year, net profit was only, $1,300,000 higher, Irving S. Olds, chairman of the board, announced after the quarterly meeting of directors yesterday.

This is a report on the fluke situation off Freeport, L.I., as it appeared to eight members of the Ampere Fishing Club of the Bronx and the writer over the week-end from Captain C.C. Amberman's forty-foot Ah Kom On.

CHICAGO, July 25 -- James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, AFL, said today that he had ordered sixteen musicians at radio station KSTP, Minneapolis, to quit work immediately "until that management decides whether it wants the War Labor Board or the courts to handle this dispute."

Maintaining that wholesaling and retailing must be geared to a post-war expansion at least one-third greater than in 1940, the Committee for Economic Development yesterday issued special handbooks for wholesalers and retailers, prepared for it by the Association of Consulting Management Engineers.

IT'S been five years since a queue last formed at Wimbledon for the world's greatest tennis show. The famous carpet of priceless turf, whereon Tilden, Johnston, Lacoste, Cochet, Budge, Vines, Borotra, Richards, Williams, Alonso, Brookes, Wilding, Von Cramm, Lenglen, Wills and all the other glamorous figures gathered from the four corners of the earth for half a century, has been posted with "keep off the grass" signs since 1939.

LONDON, July 25 (AP) -- The Germans have thrown the Skanderberg Elite Guard Divisions and elements of the 181st Division and Second Brandenburg regiment into pitched battles in Montenegro, but Yugoslav Partisan troops are holding in this sector and throughout western Bosnia, Marshal Tito declared today.
LONDON, July 25 (AP) -- The text of the Russian Government statement on Poland, recorded by the Russian monitor from a Moscow broadcast, follows:
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 89:

With Allied armies closing in on him from all sides, and with many of his own generals in revolt against him, Adolf Hitler has now issued one last call to arms. It is a desperate effort to stave off defeat and at the same time to solidify his own and his Nazi party's hold on both the German people and the nations he has enslaved.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Announcing accomplishment of its task, to create a synthetic rubber industry of sufficient magnitude to make the United States independent of foreign rubber imports, the Office of Rubber Director today became the first wartime agency voluntarily to surrender its emergency powers and urge its contraction into a routine division of the War Production Board.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Anglo-American conversations on arrangements to promote the orderly flow of petroleum in international commercial channels after the war were opened here today, with an agreement expected next week. The pact would be preliminary to a multilateral agreement embracing Russia, Venezuela and other oil producing countries.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Wednesday, July 26 -- After a stunning shrapnel attack yesterday by the greatest battle force of heavy bombers ever employed in a single assault, American troops in the western sector of the stiffly defended Normandy battle line are hammering southward on a wide front between St. Lo and Periers in a big offensive.

Predicting that serious objections to the world stabilization fund and the international bank for reconstruction would be raised in the United States Congress, and possibly also in the British Parliament, the Foreign Policy Association expressed hope yesterday that the ensuing discussions "may be conducted objectively."

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company has sold the twelve-story office building, containing stores, at 120-22 Liberty Street and 123-5 Cedar Street to the 123 Cedar Street Corporation. The property is assessed at $290,000. Victor Spitzer was the broker.

LONDON, July 25 (U.P.) -- A revolution to dethrone England's "old school tie" tradition by breaking the centuries-old monopoly of the upper and middle classes on exclusive "public schools" like Eton and Harrow, was proposed today by a committee headed by Lord Fleming.
