Supreme Court Justice John Van Voorhis of Irondequoit, a Monroe County vilage near Rochester, has become a leading possibility for the Republican nomination for associate judge of the Court of publicans to give a bipartisan W. Rippey, Rochester Democrat, who retires this year because of the constitutional age limit, it was disclosed yesterday.

Meeting the Cubs for the first time since Cholly Grimm's boys started them on their toboggan slide in Chicago nearly a month ago, the Dodgers tried manfully at Ebbets Field yesterday to oust the Braves from the dismal quarters of the National League cellar.

KUNMING, China, July 24 (Delayed) -- About noon today some fighter planes roared back from a mission north of Changsha, buzzed the field with a swagger of triumph and landed amid a tornado of dust. Sweaty, tired and dirty, but excited, the pilots piled into the wardroom to report to Col. "Texas" Hill, ace of this theatre.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 25 -- As the Allies' offensive in Normandy acquires momentum, France is divided into compartments virtually isolated from one another. Vichy, in particular, resembles a derelict ship.

While making no definite predictions about the possible length of the war in Europe, the Treasury Department has tentative plans for making the Sixth War Loan a "Victory Loan," it was disclosed yesterday.

LONDON, Wednesday, July 26 -- Marshal Ivan S. Koneff's First Ukrainian Army yesterday encircled the embattled fortress of Lwow and stormed into its southern suburbs while other Soviet troops smashed to within eight miles of the Vistula River in a mighty drive that threatens to outflank Warsaw to the south.

In a brief notice of a pamphlet published at Limerick called "Worthies of Thomond," the Literary Supplement of The Times of London mentions "John O'Tuomy, who has claims to be the originator of the limerick form of verse." From the "Concise Dictionary of Irish Biography" we learn that this gentleman (1706-75) was a Gaelic poet who kept a public house in Limerick, the resort of the Munster bards.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 25 -- Lads and lassies under eighteen years of age served up an appetizer to one of America's greatest yachting events today when they sailed in the sixteenth annual junior Y.R.A. regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club.

After a conference yesterday with Assistant District Attorney Alexander Dreiband, Representative Vito Marcantonio charged that at least 750 of the signatures on the Democratic designating petition of Representative Martin J. Kennedy had been forged.

ALBANY, July 25 -- Governor Dewey said today that he expected his St. Louis conference with Republican Governors next week to result in a statement of party policy on many matters not dealt with in detail in the Republican platform.
Remington Rand, Inc., manufacturer, in peacetime of office equipment, reported yesterday in an estimated operating statement for the quarter ended on June 30, net earnings of $1,340,731.

SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, July 25 (U.P.) -- Scots and Gurkhas of the Fourteenth Army have blasted the Japanese from seven dominating hill positions in India east of Palel on the seventy-three-mile Imphal-Tamu road in their drive to throw the enemy out of Manipur and across the Chindwin River into Burma, headquarters announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- What Pierre Laval plans to do when German domination crumbles in France and the Vichy Government automatically ceases to exist is indicated by some arrangements made on his behalf that financial espionage has brought to light.

Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell yesterday refused to extend an order by which the court last Thursday temporarily forbade the War Production Board to enforce its order against the use of newsprint by K.R.K. Publications, Inc. In dismissing the petition for a further stay, Judge Leibell remarked that to grant it would result in allowing two publishers to use newsprint under a single quota, to the detriment of the war.
PHILADELPHIA, July 25 (AP) -- Al Jurisich shut out the Phillies on six hits, never more than one in an inning, as the Cardinals pounded out a 9-0 victory before 8,945 fans at Shibe Park tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The Administration's tentative plans for international talks looking to post-war commodity agreements to help stabilize prices of essential raw materials have struck a snag in the form of a disagreement between the Department of Agriculture and other Federal departments.

British publishers are in a curious situation. Their allowance of paper is 40 per cent of their consumption before the war, and this is not wood paper. Their paper used to be made of esparto grasses from Spain and northern Africa; now it is made of straw. They are short of labor in all branches of production, and especially in binding.

The new Liberal party, which has endorsed the Democratic national ticket, will open its campaign in New York at a dinner next Wednesday evening at the Hotel Commodore. Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will be the principal speaker.

ALGIERS, July 25 (U.P.) -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle, addressing the Provisional Consultative Assembly in his first public statement since returning from the United States, said today that he anticipated "great assistance, especially from the United States," in re-establishing internal equilibrium and a healthy society in France.
BOSTON, July 25 (AP) -- After being held to one single until the sixth inning, the Reds put on a terrific batting surge to defeat the Braves, 6 -- 2, today in the series opener.
LONDON, July 25 (U.P.) -- A Madrid dispatch said today that Hitler had approved a plan for an imminent attack on New York City with robot bombs launched from submarines in the Atlantic.
DETROIT, July 25 (AP) -- The third place Red Sox continued their successful Western trip today by defeating the Tigers, 7 to 3, in the opener of a four-game series.

PHILADELPHIA, July 25 (AP) -- The E. Kahn's Sons Company, Cincinnati meat packers, registered today with the Securities and Exchange Commission 35,000 shares of 5 per cent $50 par value cumulative preferred stock to be offered to the public at $50 per share.
Mansfield Freeman, president of the United States Life Insurance Company, has announced the entry of his company into the Puerto Rican field.

HEADQUARTERS OF ALLIED ARMIES IN ITALY, July 24 (Delayed)(AP) -- Changing swiftly from the dress uniform of the admiral of the fleet to the field marshal's field dress after inspecting wartime shipping in Naples harbor, King George VI of Britain flew to this behind-the-lines camp for further inspection ceremonies.

PEARL HARBOR, July 25 -- Both beachheads on the Island of Guam have been expanded by hard fighting. An early juncture can be expected, which will give American Marines and Army assault troops a single beachhead more than nine miles in length against the Japanese.

Public sale of the wines and liquors, microphones and loud-speaker systems, pianos, furniture and all appurtenances down to the pots and pans of the Copacabana and La Vie Parisienne night clubs has been ordered by the city for the morning of July 31 unless the clubs settle the tax claims against them before that date or file bond and apply for hearings before the Controller, William Reid, city collector, announced yesterday.

A resolution urging caution in the adoption of the new zoning law, recently proposed by the City Planning Commission, was adopted at a meeting of the board of directors of the Home Title Guaranty Company. A copy of the resolution was sent to the chairman of the Commission.

CHICAGO, July 25 (AP) -- Bill Dietrich took a beating from his own defense, but pitched his eleventh victory with help from Jake Wade as the White Sox defeated Washington, 9 -- 6, today. Wade hurled hitless ball the last four innings after Dietrich had retired for a pinch-hitter.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Plans for the reorganization of the New York, Susquehanna Western Railroad were approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission, which allowed the amount of new capitalization of the railroad to be approximately $14,450,000.

ROME, July 25 (U.P.) -- American and British troops advanced two miles today to points within ten miles of Florence from the south as the Germans fought desperately to halt the Allies' drive on that last remaining large city before their Gothic Line.

Artists who participated in a nation-wide competition received $11,000 in prizes yesterday at a luncheon at Hotel Pierre. Three thousand artists from forty-seven States, as well as from Alaska, the Canal Zone, District of Columbia and Puerto Rico, entered the contest, submitting 5,000 canvases.

Air cargo will be carried at rates lower than those generally discussed in public, according to representatives of the air lines, the Railway Express Agency and Civil Aeronautics Administration men, meeting at the Lexington Hotel yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The House committee investigating the Federal Communications Commission subpoenaed two Japanese from their confidential posts in Government war agencies today to explain how a restricted report on intercepted Japanese radio broadcasts got from the desk of one at the FCC to the desk of another at the Eastern Research Institute, a unit of the Office of Strategic Service.

CHUNGKING, July 25 (U.P.) -- The isolated Chinese garrison within the Hunan Province city of Hengyang continued today to beat off desperate Japanese attacks on that strategic point on the Canton-Changsha rail line, and Gen. Hsueh Yueh, commander of Chinese forces in central China, asserted that the enemy drive in Human Province had definitely been stopped.

BUENOS AIRES, July 25 -- The recall of Dr. Adrian C. Escobar, Argentine Ambassador to Washington, came as a shock to most Argentines. The general impression here was that the diplomatic tension between the United States and Argentina had been eased in recent weeks and that the crisis had subsided.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The end of the European war "is not yet apparent" to the men who are doing the fighting, Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson, recently returned from an inspection of the battlefronts, told the nation tonight.
ROME, July 25 -- Rome is seeing the paradox of a heavy fall in dollars, pounds, Swiss francs and gold in relation to the lira.
Cotton futures prices held within a 10-point range all day yesterday, closing steady 3 to 6 points higher than Monday's final prices on the New York Cotton Exchange.
The text of the "total war" decree of Adolf Hitler, as sent in wireless DNB news agency transmissions to the German press and reported by the Federal Communications Commission, follows:

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 25 (U.P.) -- The only woman member of the Senate, Mrs. Hattie W. Caraway, was running last in a field of four tonight in her fight to return to the upper house for a third full term.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Shipments of military and food supplies to the Allies under lend-lease agreements mounted to a record-breaking value of $1,159,000,000 in May, Leo T. Crowley, Foreign Economic Administrator, reported today.

Remorseful at having inadvertently given poison to his son, who was seriously ill, by mistake for medicine, Sidney Domovs, 55 years old, ended his own life on Monday by swallowing a quantity of the same poison in his home at 1772 Forty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, the police concluded yesterday after an investigation. The son is recovering in Israel Zion Hospital, Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, July 25 -- Alice R. Peppers of the dairy and poultry branch of the War Food Administration estimated today that there would be three pounds of turkey available for every civilian this year, about one-quarter pound less than last year, or, as she put it, "the difference of barely part of a drumstick."

" 99 Park," headquarters of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, Inc., offers a partial list of free amusements available today, through the generosity of the entertainment world. Afternoon tickets from 11 A.M.; evening tickets after 4 P.M. Apply 99 Park Avenue (at Fortieth Street) for tickets.

CHICAGO, July 25 (AP) -- Hog prices reached today the ceiling on weights both under and over 240 pounds for the first time since last October. Weights under 240 pounds brought $14.75, and heavier weights $14.00. Top prices have gained $1.00 since the first of this month, when they were down to the "floor" of $13.75. Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows:

Yesterday the Fifth Army was occupying the southern part of Pisa. In fabulous chronology it is older than Rome. Its legendary founder was Nestor, the Grand Old Man of the Achaeans. It was a member of the Etrurian Confederation. In the Middle Ages it was a great sea power, rival of Venice and Genoa, and conqueror of Amalfi.
LONDON, Wednesday, July 26 -- George Bernard Shaw, Irish playwright, who is 88 years old today, said that Adolf Hitler would "get away with it and end up in the Viceregal Lodge in Dublin."

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Alfred Auerbach of the Office of Price Administration Consumer Durable Goods Division reported today that replies from all over the country showed that second-hand furniture ceilings, in effect since September, were "really doing the job of curbing inflation in this field."

Senator Warren R. Austin told his Vermont constituents the other day that the Republican plank on foreign policy goes farther than the Democratic plank. The statement is interesting for two reasons. Both parties were so careful not to get ahead of public opinion on this issue that it means something that each now claims to be in advance of the other.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, July 26 (U.P.) -- The trapped Japanese Eighteenth Army in Northern New Guinea, repulsed in every attempt to crack United States lines along the Driniumor River in the last two weeks has retreated from the river valley and apparently is trying to re-form its shattered units south of Afua, it was announced today.

Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican National Chairman, yesterday accused President Roosevelt of misusing wartime censorship to conceal the fact that he had conferred with a "high Democratic leader" in Chicago recently while en route to the Pacific Coast naval base from which he delivered his speech accepting the Democratic nomination for a fourth term in the White House.

COLUMBIA, S.C., July 25 -- Sen. Ellison D. (Cotton Ed) Smith, dean of the Senate and bitter critic of President Roosevelt and the New Deal, apparently lost his fight to retain the seat he had held for nearly thirty-six years as returns from South Carolina's Democratic primary today gave a heavy and steadily increasing lead to his opponent, Gov. Olin D. Johnston.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended July 19, the Federal Reserve Board announced today:
ROME, July 25 (AP) -- A communique :

A record total of $625,608 was earned by high school students enrolled in the cooperative education program of the Board of Education in the last school year. This is an increase of $100,000 over the previous year, Miss Grace Brennan, assistant administrative director in charge of cooperative education for the high school division, noted in her annual report, made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- A survey of knit underwear manufacturers is being undertaken to familiarize the Government with the industry's demands for ceiling price adjustments under the Bank-head amendment to the Price Control Act, the Office of Price Administration made known today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 25 (AP) -- Ten days before the attempt was made to kill Adolf Hitler, Berlin was flooded with small leaflets bearing the single line, "Let's make peace now. Smash Hitler and his gang," a source with close connections inside Germany said today.
CHUNGKING, China, July 25 (AP) -- A fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

ALGIERS, July 25 (AP) -- Addressing the final session of the French Consultative Assembly, Gen. Charles de Gaulle asserted today that "the liberation of France, which was for a long time a dream, is now very imminent," and urged that all Frenchmen join in the "final blow against the enemy."

Formulation of a code of ethics for teachers to do away with the "Hitlers in our school system" and direct educators toward the training of children for democratic citizenship was urged yesterday by Dr. Roma Cans, Professor of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University.

ABOARD EXPEDITIONARY FLAGSHIP, off Tinian, July 25 (U.P.) -- United States marines swept onto Ushi Point airdrome and scaled and captured the strategic heights commanding it today after a night of fighting in which several hundred Japanese were killed in desperate, futile counter-attacks.

WITH THE AMERICAN FIRST ARMY, in France, July 25 -- Bede Irvin, Associated Press photographer who went to see the war close up, died today with a camera in his hands near the German lines when a bomb from a B-26 Marauder fell short of its objective in a field where Irvin had been working.

Three distilling organizations in the "Big Four" group either have increased deliveries of their products to distributors or plan to do so during the coming month, it was learned yesterday, anticipating by a month or more industry expectations that the August liquor holiday would mean a practical end of shortages of domestically bottled potable spirits.

LONDON, July 25 -- As spokesman for the British Government today, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden declined to "estimate the full extent of the trouble in Germany or to draw any inferences as to its likely development."

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Fifty-one aviation, business, industrial, educational and governmental organizations were invited today by the National Aeronautic Association to participate in a nationwide educational program to encourage the local development of a comprehensive chain of post-war aircraft landing facilities.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 25 -- In a further invasion of the building materials industry Henry J. Kaiser announced today he had made an agreement with Samuel A. Perkins, president of the Standard Gypsum Company, to "lease, develop and expand the plants and the market" for gypsum products after the war. He already is engaged in producing sand, gravel, cement, light metals and steel.

MOSCOW, July 25 -- Declaring that Germany has been brought to the verge of chaos by "the adventurist political and strategic leadership of Adolf Hitler," sixteen captured German generals appealed today to the generals and officers of the Wehrmacht to break decisively with Hitler and the other Nazi leaders and refuse to carry out their orders so the war may be brought to a quick end, averting further futile bloodshed.

Secretary Hull's revelation that the State Department has sent a memorandum to all United States diplomats in Latin America clarifying this Government's attitude toward the Argentine Government would seem to be a clear indication that the United States is not going to be satisfied with any half measures from Buenos Aires.

A few current protests against the "coddling" of Italian prisoners of war in this country bring up a situation as peculiar as it is embarrassing. The prisoners in question were taken in action against our troops. They were not fighting with enthusiasm at that time, but still any one of them may have fired a shot that took an American life.

Some time ago a small item under the title of "Korean Dialects," written by Donald Kang in the Korean National Herald of Honolulu, appeared in your columns. It was stated that there are several dialects in the Korean language and that a person in Pengyong, in northern Korea, could not be understood by someone in Fusan, in southern Korea.

KWEILIN, China, July 22 (delayed) -- The military situation in central China looks fair at the moment. The second Japanese drive, begun on July 15, has acquired no momentum so far. Inside Hengyang the Chinese, besieged for one month, are still holding.

The Democratic platform provides for the "adaptation of tax laws to an expanding peacetime economy." The acceptance of the idea of an expanding economy, together with its implications, would be a welcome change from the Administration philosophy which prevailed before the war.

Asserting that there has been a definite increase in foot deformity among young children since the war began because of a shortage of small-sized shoes, members of the Podiatry Society of the State of New York adopted yesterday a resolution to petition the Office of Price Administration to relax rationing of shoes to provide at least three pairs of shoes a year for children from 3 to 10 years of age.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- specially trained dogs now are being used by the Army to detect anti-personnel mines and booby traps laid by the enemy, the War Department revealed today. The dogs which do this "dangerous work" with uncanny skill are known as "M-dogs," the elite "of the K-9 Corps," the department said.
A communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Three top naval figures -- Secretary James V. Forrestal, Admiral Ernest J. King and Admiral William F. Halsey Jr. -- indicated today their belief that the Marianas Islands in our hands will be "the key which will unlock the door to Japan, the Philippines and the coast of China."

Floodlights gleamed on the outdoor playground last night at Public School 6, Eighty-fifth Street and Madison Avenue, as boys and girls from the Nineteenth Precinct "jitterbugged" to the jukebox tunes at the Tuesday night teenage dance from 7:30 to 10 P.M.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 25 (AP) -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower made his sixth trip to Normandy today for an eleventh-hour conference with Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery and Lieut. Gen. Omar N. Bradley before the British and American ground forces merged in an all-out attack -- the sequel to another terrific blasting of German positions from the air.

Six months ago William Poll, proprietor of a grocery by the same name at 1120 Lexington Avenue, ordered some dried shredded coconut from Cuba. So slow is transportation these days that it was only yesterday that the product arrived -- 600 pounds of it in huge drums, to go on sale today in bulk form at 75 cents a pound.

Events in Germany and Japan last week, suggesting an earlier termination of the war, brought no reaction in retail trade here, according to figures and comment in local merchandising quarters. On the contrary, sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 20 per cent over the like period last year, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 25 -- A proposal to legalize off-track horserace betting and place the bookmaking establishments under the jurisdiction of the State Racing Commission came up for informal and favorable discussion at the opening session today of the Forty-fourth Annual Conference and Third Wartime Conference of the New York State Association of Chiefs of Police held in the Roger Smith Hotel here.

LONDON, July 25 -- Asserting that Mohandas K. Gandhi's association with the recent proposals for settlement of Hindu-Moslem differences in India "mark a significant change in his attitude," the Earl of Munster, Under-Secretary of State for India and Burma, told the House of Lords today that the Cripps plan of 1942 still stood without change as the British Government's solution for the Indian political deadlock.

NEWARK, N.J., July 25 -- Egil Leines, 38 years old, assistant supervisor of the United States Army Port of Embarkation at Caven's Point, Jersey City, has been arrested on charges of stealing Government property, Samuel K. McKee, chief of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in New Jersey, announced here tonight.

CLEVELAND, July 25 -- The Yankees ran head-on into an unforeseen development tonight as the Indians, hitherto the world champions' best allies in moments of dire need, sent the McCarthy-men crashing to a 10-to-0 defeat before 26,970 wildly cheering enthusiasts in Municipal Stadium.

NEWARK, N.J., July 25 (AP) -- Newark gained a twin victory over Rochester tonight before a crowd of 3,581. The Bears came from behind to win the seven-frame twilight opener, 8 -- 7, and routed the Red Wings in the nightcap, 15 -- 5, scoring nine times in The seventh.

The principle of rationing is to make it so that everybody gets the same share, but in the case of sugar for home canning the better equipped householder who can invest in paraphernalia can obtain an extra supply of sugar, but not the poor one.

Consideration is being given to a number of plans to refund all or part of the $98,000,000 of 3 1/2 per cent bonds of the Commonwealth Edison Company and the $80,000,000 of 3 1/2 per cent bonds of the Public Service Company of Northern Illinois, which it controls, it was announced yesterday by Charles Y. Freeman, chairman of Commonwealth Edison.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 25 -- Charles Constantine, 32 years old, an engineer employed by the Western Electric Company, was held without bail today by Judge N. Louis Paladeau in First Criminal Court on a charge of murdering his wife, Dorothy, 28, mother of two small children.

A tract of 115 acres at Katonah, in Westchester County, has been purchased by Dr. Andrew P. Virtuoso and De Forrest Hibbard, both of Katonah, for development into a community to be called Cherry Ridge Farms. It is on the west side of Cherry Street, a block from the new central school, and formerly was owned by the trustees of the Westchester Title and Trust Company, in receivership.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The manpower problem in the foundry and forge industry is so critical that unless 20,000 workers are added to the present employment roll the entire military program for heavy trucks, tanks, heavy artillery, landing craft, ships, planes and other types of mobile equipment will soon lag dangerously.

ROME, July 25 -- A declaration repudiating the anti-Semitic persecutions by the Hungarian Quisling Government was issued today by Baron Gabriele Apor in the name of dissident Hungarian Ministers to the Holy See, Berne, Helsinki, Lisbon, Madrid and Stockholm.

When Actors Equity has occasion to submit a dispute for arbitration, the union generally comes out on top. The other day, however, an adverse decision was handed down against an Equity member by a three-man board representing the American Arbitration Association.

That typical shoe chains have been forced by the hosiery pricing policies of the Office of Price Administration to abandon their established trade practices was charged yesterday at a conference sponsored by the National Association of Popular Price Shoe Retailers in the Hotel Biltmore.

The report of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on June 30, released yesterday, shows a consolidated net income, after all expenses and taxes, of $32,984,233. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.92 a share on the company's outstanding common stock, and compares with a net of $31,911,442, or $1.83 a common share, in the twelve months to June 30, 1943.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 25 (AP) -- Communique 99:

Leading from start to finish to score by a length and a half, Tex Martin sprang a surprise in yesterday's Stagehand Purse at Jamaica, where 20,538 persons wagered $1,892,307. The Empire City feature was named for Col. Maxwell Howard's famous champion of 1938, and what most had against Tex Martin was that he might not last the route of a mile and a sixteenth.

The stock market furthered yesterday its comeback and on a broader front, but the recovery lacked real conviction, for business dropped under the million-share level for the first full session since June 9.

ROME, July 25 -- Italy repudiated another page of her Fascist past today when Premier Ivanoe Bonomi, in an address to officials of the Foreign Office, pledged his country's future policy to a return to its traditional friendliness with Britain, France, Russia and the United States and denounced its aggressions.

Mrs. Charles S. Payson, through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., duplex apartment in 19 E 72d St; Mrs. William R. Gough, through Duff Conger, in 1160 Park Ave; Mrs. Hans Namuth, garden apartment in 122 E 64th St -- Payson McL. Merrill Company, broker.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner recommended today that the Interstate Commerce Commission deny the application of George P. McNear Jr., president of the Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad Company, for permission for the company to issue $100,000 of 3 per cent unsecured notes.
I was particularly interested in a recent article in THE TIMES regarding an editorial in the weekly publication of the National Association of Manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The War Labor Board made public today the procedure it has adopted to expedite its consideration of evidence by labor organizations to support their contention that the board should seek authority to modify the Little Steel formula, which permits a 15 per cent wage increase to correspond with the change in living costs in the January, 1941-May, 1942, period.

MOSCOW, July 25 -- The Russian Foreign Commissariat announced officially tonight that the Government had decided to enter into an agreement with the new Polish Committee of National Liberation for the civil administration of liberated Polish territory. It also reiterated that it had no territorial or social ambitions inside the territory of Poland, which it regards as a "sovereign, friendly, allied State."

Overhauling the material of our history courses, as urged this morning in your excellent editorial "History Revitalized," will never solve the problem. Our students will merely be crammed, more or less successfully, with a slightly different surfeit of facts.
CHUNGKING, China, July 25 (AP) -- A communique:
Your "Farm Shop on a Rainy Day" and its remembered smells recall several which I knew prior to the first World War.

Families of 1,321 service men who have been killed since Pearl Harbor have received benefit payments of $3,275,000 from the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, Thomas I. Parkinson, president, reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 25 -- Mill buying of wheat, said to be a reflection of enlarged buying of flour on talk of a possible reduction in the Government subsidy, gave the market a stronger undertone today on the Board of Trade. At no time were prices below yesterday's finish and closing trades were about the top with gains of 3/4 cent to 1 cent a bushel, May leading.

A total of $2,178,060 was spent by the British Government during the first three months of this year for advertising in newspapers, magazines and trade publications, according to figures received recently by the J. Walter Thompson Company from its London office and made public yesterday. This is $59,371 lower than for the corresponding period of 1943.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Miss Caroline Haslett, electrical engineer and adviser to the British Government on womanpower and post-war housing, told at a press conference today about the ideas she is taking back to England for post-war use: Shelves that do not bump the head, less noisy vacuum cleaners and thermostats, more effective uses of plastics, glass and nylon, and the Tennessee Valley Authority.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 25 -- Walter Huston will return to Warner Brothers for his first picture since "A Mission to Moscow" for the top comedy role, that of a blustering Army colonel, in the forthcoming "Pillar to Post," the Rose Simon Kohn play about civilian housing problems near a military post.
Blyth Co. and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane will offer today at $99 a share 20,894 1/2 shares of 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock of the Montana-Dakota Utilities Company.

The unwelcome task of pointing out error in "public English" almost invariably brings the critic into disrepute by way of being classified as a piffling purist. But when loose expression is permitted to so sensitive a document as a party platform, especially in its most sensitive provision, the critic is under obligation to speak up.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- are preparing a post-war race for world commercial air traffic which will center on the North Atlantic routes leading to the densely populated regions of Europe, it was indicated today by evidence at the hearing on the American Airlines application for permission to buy stock control in the American Export Airlines.

Dr. Angel Zuniga Huete, president of the Liberal Democratic party of Honduras, announced here yesterday that he would soon return to his headquarters in Mexico City after an unsuccessful attempt to win American support for a "peaceable" overthrow of the "dictatorial Carias government" of Honduras.

First detailed reports of Red Air Force exploits revealed yesterday that the top Russian ace, Lieut. Col. Alexander Pokryshkin, with fifty-nine kills to his credit, is far and away the top Allied ace of the war. According to a letter to Lawrence D. Bell, president of Bell Aircraft in Buffalo, from Lieut. Gen. L.G. Rudenko of the Soviet Embassy in Washington, Pokryshkin got forty-eight Nazi planes with his Bell Airacobra.
ROME, July 26 (AP) -- A communique:

Strong possibility exists that the work now being done in Latin America by the Office of the Coordinator of Latin-American Affairs will be carried on after the end of the war, it was revealed yesterday at a meeting of the Export Advertising Association, at the Belmont-Plaza Hotel.

PHILADELPHIA, July 26 (AP) -- The Cardinals scored two runs in the tenth inning for an 8-6 victory over the Phillies in a National War Fund game tonight that drew 14,863 fans and netted approximately $15,000 for the armed forces.

MOSCOW, July 26 -- Acting in direct support of the Soviet offensive operations against the German forces in the Lwow area, American fighter planes from Soviet bases yesterday shot down twenty-nine enemy planes, destroyed nine on the ground and strafed an airdrome, a railway and motor traffic without the loss of a single American plane, it was announced officially today.

AN AMERICAN COMMAND POST NEAR PISA, Italy, July 26 -- The enemy has installed an observation post in the world-famour leaning tower of Pisa and has heavily fortified the city, forcing the Fifth Army to consider firing upon it as it did the Cassino Monastery to prevent further danger to doughboys, officers said today.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The Central National Committee of Yugoslavia, composed of followers of Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch, which has declared its opposition to the newly created Yugoslav Cabinet formed in London under Dr. Ivan Subasitch, has implied a threat of civil war if the Subasitch Government is maintained, it was revealed today when the text of the National Committee's resolution was released here by Constantin Fotitch, Ambassador of Yugoslavia.

A further improvement, but of a limited range, was registered yesterday by the stock market. The same wariness that has characterized recent sessions was again in evidence and the best gains faltered somewhat near the close. Trading on the Stock Exchange continued to flatten out, with transfers down to 828,995 shares, the smallest for a full session since June 2, compared with 831,423 shares on Tuesday.

An underwriting syndicate headed by A.C. Allyn Co., Inc. will offer today a new issue of $4,815,000 of the State of Washington Toll Bridge Authority, Lake Washington Bridge, 1 1/2 per cent revenue bonds, due Sept 1 1960 The bonds, payable solely out of revenues from the Lake Washington Bridge, are priced to yield from 0.50 to 1.55 per cent, according to maturities.
CHICAGO, July 26 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows:
Following is the text of Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels' speech, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded and translated by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- A pregnancy policy covering its more than 500,000 women civilian employes in more than 1,000 plants and establishments, has just been put into effect by the War Department. It is estimated that more than 60 per cent of the women are married.

Revision of the foreign language program now offered in the New York City schools, to permit students to devote four years to the study of one language, instead of the present method of taking three years of one language and two of another, is proposed in a report prepared by Dr. Jacob Greenberg and Frederic Ernst, associate superintendents.

LONDON, July 26 -- The Nazi High Command increased the ferocity of its flying bomb offensive against England today, introduced for the first time a missile twice the size of those formerly used, and inaugurated the use of incendiary devices in the regular 1,000-pound robot.

An answer to an anti-trust suit instituted by the Department of Justice last January was filed in Federal court here yesterday by E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Lammot du Pont and Walter Samuel Carpenter Jr. Asking dismissal of the action, the defendants generally admitted having made various agreements, but flatly denied that these or any other consideration added up to the "cartel" alleged by the Government.

One measure of the success of racing in New York this season was afforded yesterday at Jamaica when almost a quarter of a million dollars was wagered on a four-horse 2-year-old race, with only straight and place pools. Although a maiden going into the race, the winner was a 4-5 favorite with a crowd of 22,644.

NEWARK, N. J., July 26 -- The Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton, Beth Israel Hospital in this city and other public institutions were among the principal beneficiaries of the will of Mrs. Caroline Bamberger Fuld of South Orange, widow of Felix Fuld and sister of the late Louis Bamberger, which was filed for probate today in the Essex County Surrogate's office.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 26 -- A bench warrant was issued today for the arrest of James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, after he was cited for contempt of court by Judge W.W. Bardwell of Hennepin County District Court for violating a temporary restraining order by directing eight musicians employed by radio station KSTP at its Minneapolis studio to cease work.

VATICAN CITY, July 26 -- More than 150,000 Allied soldiers have been received in audience by Pope Plus since the occupation of Rome, it was estimated today. The enthusiasm and devotion of the troops has caused the greatest pleasure at the Vatican and admiration in Rome, but it is known that the Germans are disgruntled about it.

Condemnation proceedings recently authorized by the Board of Estimate have been started by the Corporation Counsel to acquire title to two proposed post-war low-rent housing projects, one in Harlem and the other in Brooklyn, Edmond B. Butler, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, announced yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 26 -- Anne Baxter, now in "Sunday Dinner for a Soldier," and Joan Blondell, the Aunt Sissy of "A Tree Grows in Brooklyn," are to be retained by Twentieth Century-Fox for the two most important parts in the predominantly feminine cast of "Bon Voyage."

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The National Association of Manufacturers fired back today at critics who have been charging American industry with making exorbitant profits out of the war. The Congress of Industrial Organizations has repeatedly made such charges.

From a financial standpoint the National War Fund game between the Giants and the Pirates last night at the Polo Grounds was something of a disappointment with only 12,909 spectators present. From the Giants' viewpoint it was something less than adequate.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- Fred M. Vinson, economic stabilization director, today rejected appeals of flue-cured tobacco growers and warehouse men for a two-cent-a-pound increase in 1944 "ceiling" prices.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 26 -- Attorneys for Harry R. Bridges filed a petition in the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals today asking for a rehearing of the deportation case in which the judges by a 3-to-2 decision ruled against the labor leader thirty days ago.
Since the National Planning Association issued the Ruml-Sonne report to stimulate public discussion in part, perhaps several of its recommendations can be questioned by mere laymen.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- W.A. Patterson, president of the United Air Lines, told the Civil Aeronautics Board today that his company will not apply for trans-ocean international air routes.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Dr. Alfred Bilmanis, the Latvian Minister, communicated to the State Department today a statement by the underground Social Democrate party charging that Soviet Russia has established an unlawful dictatorial regime in Latvia and proposing a post-war confederation of the Baltic nations independent of the Soviet Union.

LONDON, Thursday, July 27 (AP) -- Russian troops, having reached the Vistula River on a thirty-mile front in central Poland, fought today for bridgeheads on the western bank that would outflank Warsaw, fifty-six miles to the northwest, and place them 140 miles from Germany.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Approximately 50,000,000 yards of cotton fabrics every calendar quarter, or about 2 per cent of the 10,000,000,000-yard annual output will be directed into a selected list of moderate and low-priced articles of civilian wearing apparel under a new textile order issued today by the War Production Board.

The Army has completely revamped its Army Specialized Training Reserve Program to facilitate and encourage the recruiting of 17-year-old high school graduates and develop intellectual skills needed for a command position, fifty educators from New York, New Jersey and Delaware were told yesterday at a conference on pre-induction training, held under the auspices of the Second Service Command at Governors Island.

That blithe and savage old person, George Bernard Shaw, has just celebrated his eighty-eighth birthday by giving out an interview that coming from any other man would stir up a tempest of disagreement. Mr. Shaw doesn't believe a lasting peace possible. He doesn't believe Germany should be disarmed, let alone split up into small states.

Crude oil production last week again established a new peak at an average of 4,615,450 barrels daily, according to the American Petroleum Institute. This represented an increase of 13,100 barrels daily over the output of 4,602,350 in the previous week.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (U.P.) -- R.J. Thomas, president of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, tonight denied that the CIO was either fighting against, or conspiring with, Democratic machine bosses, and asserted that its chief objective was to mobilize the labor vote for the issue, "Roosevelt and victory in war and peace, or Dewey, question mark."
Your recent editorial "The Channel Islands" recalls important passages in history.

The agreements reached at Bretton Woods and the Administration's plans for international talks looking to postwar commodity agreements combine to form a pattern of the kind of postwar economic world that our Government and certainly a number of other Governments have in view.
LENOX, Mass., July 26 -- Dr. Serge Koussevitzky, in a birthday interview, expressed a desire to hold an international music festival to accompany the next world peace conference.

To meet the war demand, the oil industry is establishing new records almost weekly. Last week the nation's crude oil production reached a new peak of 4,615,450 barrels daily, or almost 500,000 barrels a day more than a year earlier.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- To meet "a critical situation arising from an accumulation of unfinished work," Army Service Forces abruptly canceled today all leaves of absence and directed a one-hour-per-day increase in its working day, which directly affects 50,000 and is applicable to 1,302,000 civilian and military personnel.

Not a bit discouraged over the unavoidable delay from last season in putting on a pet project, "The Day Will Come," Harry Green said yesterday he would present the Leo Birinski play (Hitler is one of its characters) at the National on Thursday night, Sept. 7.

The practice of the regional Office of Price Administration of removing a food item from its weekly community chart of flat price ceilings as the supply becomes abundant was questioned yesterday by City Markets Commissioner Henry M. Brundage, who said that egg prices had risen here since eggs were removed from the list.

Halsey, Stuart Co. heads a group of 110 underwriters which today is offering at 103 7/8 and interest $34,500,000 of New Orleans Public Service, Inc., 3 1/8 per cent first mortgage bonds due in 1974. Net proceeds, together with proceeds of the sale of 77,798 shares of 4 3/4 per cent preferred stock and company funds, will be used to redeem all funded debt and $7 preferred stock currently outstanding.

After observation lasting nearly twenty-four hours, physicians at St. John's Hospital, Long Island City, Queens, reported yesterday that they had found nothing seriously wrong with Frank Policastro Jr., 2 years old, although he had fallen out of a sixth floor window at his home, 41-01 Twelfth Street, near the hospital.
LONDON, July 26 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Attorneys for Seatrain Lines, Inc., told the Interstate Commerce Commission today that "the Pennsylvania Railroad has persisted in a policy of endeavoring to destroy Seatrain and to that end is trying in every way to hamper its operations and developments."

THROUGHOUT the years of the Fascist regime Benedetto Croce lived quietly in Naples, a virtual prisoner in his own house. But he continued to write and to publish his work, and Mussolini, who was capable of some lingering respect for philosophers provided their books were too difficult for the masses, let the grand old man go his own intellectual way.

One of the most difficult tasks facing American relief representatives among Polish refugees in the Middle East is telling them that even should the war end soon, it may take three or four years before most of them can return to their native land, the Rev. Aloysius J. Wycislo of Chicago declared here yesterday.

LONDON, July 26 -- A large Allied task force of cruisers, destroyers and submarines yesterday bombarded Sabang harbor at the western end of Sumatra, a Japanese Imperial Headquarters communique broadcast by the Tokyo radio said today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS in Australia, Thursday, July 27 (U.P.) -- Trapped Japanese troops in northern New Guinea have resumed their attacks against the southern flank of United States positions on the Driniumor River line, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today, but there were no details of the latest skirmishing in that sector.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Diplomatic tension between the United States and Argentina reached its highest point tonight with the publication of the State Department's summary of the position of the United States Government on relations with the Argentine regime of President Edelmiro Farrell.

MOSCOW, Thursday, July 27 -- The Red Army yesterday drove in force to the Vistula River, the last important natural barrier between it and Germany, capturing Deblin, which is about fifty-six miles southeast of Warsaw and some thirty-six miles from Lublin and Lukow, whose capture was announced by the Soviet High Command Monday night.

YENAN, China, July 26 -- Two American fliers who were forced to parachute from damaged planes after an attack on Hankow on May 6, were rescued by Chinese guerrillas and later were guests at a dinner given by the Central China Branch of the Japanese People's Emancipation League.

Summer is the time for cold cuts, and we know one store in particular -- Schaller Weber, 1654 Second Avenue, near Eighty-Sixth Street -- where they are so good that the customers buy them in quantity not only at this season but the year round.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- A British suggestion that the Allies write a provisional peace with Italy, which now has the combined standing of defeated enemy and co-belligerent, is before American authorities, it was learned today.

Many manufacturers anxious to produce cost-of-living garments under the revision of the War Production Board Order M-328-B, are being squeezed out of the picture, according to industry comment yesterday, with their applications for fabric priorities being refused.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 90:

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The smallest monthly allotment of heavy truck and bus tires since rationing began was authorized for August by the Office of Price Administration today in a move reflecting fears of production and military officials that the shortage of heavy tires might "slow up American offensives and prolong the war."
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 26 (AP) -- Communique 101:

"Going My Way," the Bing Crosby film, featuring Barry Fitzgerald and Rise Stevens, will begin a second-run engagement today at Loew's State. . . . Two films entering their second weeks today are "Dragon Seed," starring Katharine Hepburn and Walter Huston, at the Music Hall, and "Since You Went Away," with Claudette Colbert, Joseph Cotten and Jennifer Jones at the Capitol.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Following is the text of the State Departmennt's summary of the position of the United States Government on relations with the present Argentine regime:

CHUNGKING, China, July 26 (U.P.) -- The battle for Hengyang raged unabated into its second month as the Chinese garrison, isolated within the city, continued to beat off attempts by four Japanese divisions to capture the strategic point on the Canton-Hankow railway.
Back-to-work moves reduced the number of men and women idle in labor controversies yesterday, but about 5,300 remained away from their jobs.

Alex A. Landesco, in 60 Park Ave; W. Tyler Miller, in 1021 Park Ave; Joseph L. Delaney, in 155 E 72d St; Harry P. Somerville, in 157 E 81st St; Mrs. Eva Finermann, in 45 E 82d St; Mrs. Francis A. Schultz, in 12 E 88th St; Mrs. Joan S. Hulme, in 4 E 95th St; Mrs. Ione W. White, in 60 E 96th St -- Pease Elliman, Inc, brokers.

BUENOS AIRES, July 26 -- In a broadcast address to the Argentine people, delivered at the Foreign Ministry in the presence of President Edelmiro Farrell, Vice President Juan Domingo Peron and the entire cabinet, Foreign Minister Orlando L. Peluffo tonight emphatically denied that Argentina was working against continental solidarity or that she was secretly supporting the Axis cause.

Tuesday was primary day in South Carolina and Arkansas. In the former State Senator Ellison DuRant Smith, Cotton Ed, a Senator since 1909, was beaten by Governor Olin Dewitt Johnston, who with Mr. Roosevelt's blessing ran against him unsuccessfully in 1938.
The Wednesday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet press and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Franz Hoellering, an Austrian, was an editor of a newspaper and a publishing house in Berlin until he was forced to flee Nazi Germany. In the United States he wrote in German a novel, "The Defenders." Now he has written in English a novel called "Furlough" about a German soldier.

ALBANY, July 26 -- Mrs. Thomas E. Dewey and Mrs. John W. Bricker, holding a joint press conference this afternoon at the Executive Mansion, set a high standard in tact, gayety and frankness. The conference came after they had spent some three hours posing for cameramen and was therefore, as remarkable as it was unrehearsed.
WITH AMERICAN FORCES IN NORMANDY, July 26 -- The "hard crust" of German resistance cracked at last today and our armored forces broke through.

Federal Judge John C. Knox fined twenty-eight anthracite coal producers $61,000 yesterday. But before imposing the penalties the jurist commented wryly on the practical and social aspects -- as distinguished from the legal ones -- of the price-fixing charges against which the concerns had refused to offer a defense.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, July 26 (U.P.) -- Driving Japan's beaten India invasion army farther east along the Imphal-Tamu road, Allied Fourteenth Army troops have cleaned out enemy remnants resisting in the Tengnoupal-Kampang area, headquarters said today.

The radishes were still flourishing yesterday in the Victory gar-' den at 5209 Twelfth Avenue, inI the Borough Park section of Erooklyn. Eut the formerly warm friendship of the Sanguedolce andi Conenello families, joint occupants of the two-story house at it hat address; had withered.

Local rationing boards throughout the five-State region were directed yesterday by Daniel P. Woolley, regional head of the Office of Price Administration, to issue no more than a thirty-days' gasoline ration, beginning Monday, to all motorists seeking a supplemental allowance for driving between their home and work unless they submitted proof that they had at least three regular passengers in a share-the-car arrangement.

The International Business Machines Corporation and its subsidiaries showed an increase in earnings before taxes of $1,678,044 to $19,045,517 for the first six months this year from $17,367,473 in the corresponding half of last year, according to the semi-annual report issued yesterday by Thomas J. Watson, president.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Thursday, July 27 -- The major part of the forty-mile American battleline across western Normandy has surged forward and armored columns thrusting ahead of the infantry assault have plunged south toward Coutances and into two important towns, St. Gilles and Marigny, dominating the road network west of St. Lo.

The fire that swept an empty 10,000-ton Liberty ship moored at 133d Street and the Hudson River early yesterday, causing injuries to twenty persons, apparently was started when sparks from a welder's torch ignited oil-slicked water, Fire Marshal Thomas P. Brophy reported after an investigation.
Apartments were in the lead in light trading in Manhattan real estate reported yesterday.

Favorable weather in the cotton belt, and lack of any aggressive demand for spot cotton in the South, caused prices to sag in the cotton futures market yesterday. Led by the relative easiness in October, final prices for active months were 9 to 14 points net lower than Tuesday's close on the New York Cotton Exchange.

Jack McManis, former Californian who now represents the West Side Tennis Club of Forest Hills and is seeking his third clay court title of the season, won his first-round match in the New York State championship which got under way yesterday at the Seminole Club in Forest Hills after a two-year lapse.

Criticizing the increased control of the Federal Government in the liquor field, John F. O'Connell, chairman of the New York State Liquor Authority, declared yesterday that increased taxation and price control had led to bootlegging and permitted beverages of inferior quality to reach the consumer.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- Marriage by mail is okay with the Army, and the wife may collect the allowances of her soldier husband if the State in which the contract is made recognizes it as valid.

NEWARK, N.J., July 26 -- The arrest of William F. Nolden, chief clerk of Selective Service Board 6 in Union City on charges of counseling and aiding and abetting a registrant to avoid Army service was reported today by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

More than 75 per cent of the vehicular traffic moving over the bridges and through the tunnels owned and operated by the Port of New York Authority is in the highly essential class, according to a report issued yesterday by Frank C. Ferguson, chairman of the authority.

Lightweight underwear will be classified as a "major" textile item by the Office of Price Administration and as such will be entitled to price adjustment under the Bankhead amendment to the new Price Control Act, it was learned in the trade yesterday.
LONDON, July 26 -- Apart from weakness in Argentine rails and Kaffirs the stock markets here today again were cheerful, with renewed buying of industrials.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Observers searching for political portents in the defeat of Senator Ellison D. (Cotton Ed) Smith, dean of the Senate, in South Carolina, and of Senator Hattie W. Caraway in Arkansas in yesterday's primaries, said today that local and personal considerations figured so strongly in each race as to becloud such national meanings as might otherwise have resulted.
Press box humorists at Ebbets Field last night worked overtime in the bon mot department when Leo Durocher handed 19-year-old Clyde King his initial big-league starting assignment against the Cubs.

NEWBURGH N.Y., July 26 (U.P.) -- Asserting that his name had been "linked" in newspaper advertisements with alleged Nazi sympathizers, Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. filed a libel suit for $250,000 today against Robert F. Cutler, executive secretary of the Good Government Committee of the Twenty-ninth Congressional District.

WEEHAWKEN, N.J., July 26 -- Cans of uncollected garbage lined the streets of this community tonight as the result of a protest by a labor union to a threat made by Judge Cyrus W. Lunn to have garbage collectors who made unnecessary noise arrested.

The German jet bomb and its indiscriminate destruction of human beings, young and old, may yet serve to bring home a lesson which even our leaders in public life need to learn -- namely, the fundamental distinction between measures for prevention and measures of defense against aggression, and the difference of the means which prevention calls for as contrasted with the means of defense.

LONDON, July 26 -- The Allies' base of operations in Normandy for the past month has been a magnified Anzio, but the decisive battles that will determine the duration of the European war are now opening there and on all other fronts.

The seven buildings on the north side of Fulton Street, between Ashland Place and St. Felix Street, Brooklyn, have been purchased by Mimis Restaurant, which will occupy two of the buildings. The property, on a plot 171 by 130 feet and assessed at $135,000, has been owned by the Chesebrough estate for sixty years.

History will doubtless record that the war effort of the United States, as represented by America's own armed might and American aid to the Allies, has been the decisive factor in this war as in the last. It has saved the Allies from defeat and kept the Axis from victory. It has tipped the balance of power so strongly in favor of the United Nations as to clinch their ultimate victory.

Representatives of business, labor, medicine and the clergy started yesterday a $350,000 fundraising campaign for Harlem's Sydenham Hospital and predicted that its new policy would mark the beginning of an era in which no color lines would be drawn in the care of the sick or the training of doctors.

Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican National Chairman, received information yesterday that two important states, Massachusetts with 17 electoral votes and Indiana with 14, would probably go for the Republican National ticket at November election.
PEARL HARBOR, July 26 -- Japanese forces isolated on Guam's Orote Peninsula are battering desperately at the American steel ring holding them in, but they are trapped.

If Representative Fulbright, as now seems probable, is the victor in the "runoff" primary to choose the Democratic nominee for United States Senator from Arkansas, he will be as good as elected. And if Mr. Fulbright goes to the Senate from the House it will not only mean that this section of the country has selected a higher type of legislator than the South has been sending to Washington in recent years.

LONDON, July 26 -- A plan for the post-war reconstruction of the City of London during the next quarter century or so, at an estimated cost of $600,000,000 or more, was published today by the City Corporation after three years' study.
an open town and yield it without leaving its relics in ruin.

There is no end to the number of normal people who are abnormal. They are even more numerous than the average citizens who are way below the average. This time it is 2,000 Waves in training at Hunter College.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, July 26 -- American troops have now definitely taken the first two rounds in the more than two weeks of confused and often bloody fighting along the banks of Driniumor River in the Aitape region of British New Guinea where the starving remnants of the Japanese Eighteenth Army launched a desperate attempt to break through the ring forged around it by the Allied landings to the west last April.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- Conflicting statements were made today before the Interstate Commerce Commission as to whether the Alleghany Corporation had control of the Chesapeake Ohio, Railroad in 1940 when Congress made it unlawful for a non-carrier to acquire control of a railroad without ICC authority.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission today authorized four subsidiaries of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation to build an estimated $1,927,092 worth of facilities and deliver 15,000,000 additional cubic feet of natural gas per day to the Northern Pennsylvania and Western New York area.

Contract termination and reconversion problems looming more important than ever before due to the rapid developments in both the European and Pacific war theatres, are being given scant attention by Government and none of the positive action highly essential if economic orderliness is to be achieved, Leo M. Cherne, executive secretary of the Research Institute of America, declared yesterday.
BOSTON, July 26 (AP) -- After knocking Bucky Walters out of the box for a 9 -- 2 victory, the Braves dropped the nightcap, 8-to-5, today while dividing a twin bill with the Reds.
CHUNGKING, China, July 26 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

ROME, July 26 (U.P.) -- Fresh British Eighth Army troops, advancing three to five miles on a broad front below Florence, drove within eight miles of that major objective today as Fifth Army forces strengthened their positions along the Arno River for a final assault on Pisa.

Carl Whitmore, vice president of the New York Telephone Company, was elected yesterday president of the company to succeed the late James W. Hubbell. Mr. Whitmore began his telephone career thirty-three years ago as a field man with the Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company in San Francisco.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The Legion of Merit has been awarded to Maj. Gen. Frank F. Scowden of Rochester, N.Y., for services as Deputy Quartermaster General; Brig. Gen. Boykin C. Wright, 63 Wall Street, New York, N.Y., for services as director of the international division, headquarters, Army Service Forces, and Lieut. Col. Frederick O. Britton, 77-12 Thirty-fifth Avenue, Jackson Heights, L.I., for distinguishing himself as exchange officer of the Anti-Aircraft Artillery Command, Eastern Defense Command.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- In a move to divert labor to other fields, the War Manpower Commission today ordered hotels to slash their services and slapped restrictions on their employment of men under 45.

DETROIT, July 26 (AP) -- Rain stopped the Detroit-Boston twilight game in the first half of the eight inning tonight, with the score tied 1 -- all. Two Red Sox players were on base, and only one away, when the downpour came.
CHICAGO, July 26 (AP) -- The White Sox defeated Washington, 4 to 3, on a two-run ninth-inning counter-rally tonight after the Senators had scored two runs in their half.

ALBANY, July 26 -- Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio, the Republican Vice Presidential nominee, arrived in Albany this morning for an overnight stay at the Executive Mansion as the guest of his running-mate, and head of the ticket, Thomas E. Dewey.

"Those great flights of birds we saw last fall are creating new problems of wildlife management, but the basic problem remains the same: To keep the waterfowl flights we must preserve the remaining marshes and waters on which they depend and restore or replace those that have vanished.

To many readers the gains made yesterday by the American First Army in the St. Lo sector, substantial as they were, may have seemed disappointing in relation to the enormous air support employed. But most commanders in combat areas now realize that tactical air support against skilled defense has definite limitations.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Unless 20,000 additional workers are recruited during the summer for foundries and forge shops making indispensable military equipment, the War Production Board will be compelled to close down shops in the field making less critical material, according to Donald M. Nelson, Chairman of the War Production Board.

ALBANY, July 26 -- President Roosevelt could be asked to issue a proclamation which would permit merchant seamen to vote overseas in the November election, William T. Simpson, chairman of the State War Ballot Commission, said today in suggesting a means to extend the State ballot to Red Cross, Merchant Marine, USO and Quaker personnel absent from the State.

LONDON, July 26 (Reuter) -- German Army conscripts from the annexed French Province of Lorraine are deserting on such a scale that the Germans have officially introduced a wholesale punishment of deserters' families, it was stated here today.

CHICAGO, July 26 -- Heavy rains in parts of the dry area in the Central West led traders to believe today there would be an ample supply of feed grains and forage for the 1944-45 crop year, and started liquidation in rye which carried prices off around 2 cents a bushel from Tuesday's finish to a new low since mid-June and 10 cents under the recent high point.

Stocks in the four leading Standard Oil Companies having a total market value in excess of $23,000,000 will be offered today after the close of trading on the New York Stock Exchange through Dillon, Read Co., acting for John D. Rockefeller. They will be priced at or about today's closing levels on the Stock Exchange.

LONDON, July 26 -- The British and American Governments are now trying to convince Premier Stalin that he ought to receive Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk of the Polish Government in Exile, with which Russia severed diplomatic relations more than a year ago.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 26 -- The slaughter of members of the Prussian nobility among German Army officers, the Himmler-staged sequel to the plotting against Hitler, continues in the Reich, according to a traveler who reached here today from Berlin.

BUENOS AIRES, July 26 (AP) -- Small but vocal groups calling for "defense of national sovereignty" and distributing leaflets entitled, "Yankees Should Be Made to Understand," demonstrated tonight in front of the American Embassy and along Florida Street.

Mrs. Violet Halling Knappen, wife of Theodore T. Knappen, consulting engineer of 132 East Seventy-second Street, and former wife of ex-Mayor James J. Walker, named Mr. Knappen as her principal beneficiary in her will filed yesterday in Surrogate's Court.
CHUNGKING, China, July 26 (AP) -- A communique:

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Thursday, July 27 -- Once more the Royal Air Force and the United States Fifteenth Air Force have shouldered the burden of the Allies' strategic bombing, while bad weather grounded the United States Eighth Air Force's "heavies" in Britain.

LONDON, July 26 -- A rehabilitation center for service women, believed to be the first in the world, was recently opened for members of Britain's Auxiliary Territorial Service near London. Injured women and those whose nerves have been tried by long service are receiving recreational, educational and medical services in the peaceful setting of a pleasant home and garden.

As rains in the Middle West began moving eastward yesterday, according to The Associated Press, the Weather Bureau here predicted thunder showers for this area, but said there was a possibility that the rain might become more general and bring relief to the Eastern drought region.

CLEVELAND, July 26 -- To the deep dismay of 25,483 onlookers, who earlier in the evening had so gaily contributed approximately $35,000 into the National War Relief Fund, the Indians tonight learned a new version of an old lesson which Yankee teams have been trying to teach them for a great many years.

The start of a concerted drive against possible violations of child labor laws in New York's summer resort areas was announced yesterday by Edward Corsi, head of the State Department of Labor, who declared that forty inspectors had been sent into the Catskills, the Adirondacks, Chautauqua and parts of Long Island.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 26 -- The blue-ribbon event of metropolitan yachting, the Larchmont Yacht Club's annual Race Week, got under way for its five-day stand this afternoon under favorable wind conditions. The largest fleet seen in local waters for two years was on hand.

The report of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company for the first half of the current year, released yesterday, shows a net income of $10,470,701 after adding the post-war refund of excess profits tax and deducting $42,592,143 for taxes and $3,537,252 for post-war contingencies.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Thursday, July 27 (AP) -- A communique:

Girls in twenty New York City high schools now have the opportunity to learn how to improve their personal appearance, poise, manners, speech to fit them for jobs when they leave school, Mrs. Harriet S. Zucker announced yesterday at a press conference or the Board of Education.

CLEVELAND, July 26 -- As baseball wings through its third war campaign our national pastime, with its inexhaustible supply of entertaining developments, all with outcomes as yet wholly undetermined, seems to be doing quite nicely in its chosen and accepted task of providing war-taut nerves with moments of much-needed recreation and relaxation.

LONDON, July 27 (AP) -- French Maquis is keeping up its widespread and successful warfare against German occupation troops, Supreme Allied Headquarters said today, and even defeating Nazi panzer attacks by ambushes.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 27 (U.P.) -- American heavy bombers, continuing their renewed long-range assault from the south and west against Adolf Hitler's war factories today, bombed Hungary's largest industrial plant, the Manfred Weiss steel works near Budapest, and in western Europe attacked targets around Brussels and Ghent, Belgium, centers for manufacture of German radio and electrical equipment.

Promising that "China is going to be an open market, with abundant possibilities" in the post-war world, Dr. H.H. Kung, Vice President of the Executive Yuan, and Minister of Finance in the Chinese Government, expressed hope last night that the United States would play a much larger part in the economic development of China than it has heretofore.

While attending the Larchmont Yacht Club's race week sailing events as a substitute yachting reporter the other day we ran into Bill Merrill, probably the club's most enthusiastic fisherman, who was just starting out for an afternoon's striper trolling.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Labor, the organ of a group of standard railway unions, attacked the CIO Political Action Committee's program today and declared that it would strengthen the hand of organized labor's foes and increase the demand for more rigid regulation of labor unions.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 27 -- Several hundred Californians in the armed services overseas have already marked and returned Federal ballots for the Presidential election in November, with the result that the votes are worthless, it was revealed today by Frank M. Jordan, Secretary of State.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 27 -- John R. Longo testified today at the deposition proceeding on his appeal from a conviction on a charge of altering his voting record that before he was indicted he was told by an official of the Hudson County Bureau of Elections that he was going to be "framed."

BUENOS AIRES, July 27 -- Argentina's determination to go straight ahead on the road she has chosen was reiterated this evening by President Edelmiro J. Farrell to the great applause of a large crowd gathered outside the Foreign Ministry to cheer Foreign Minister Orlando L. Peluffo for the speech he delivered yesterday.
LONDON, July 27 (AP) -- The weekly condition statement of the bank of England for the week ended July 26 shows an increase of 3,232,000 in note circulation.

JERUSALEM, July 25 (Delayed) -- Unusual interest and even mounting excitement are being displayed by the Jewish population of Palestine in anticipation of polling for its own Parliament -- known as Assephath Haminharin, or Selected Assembly -- as the balloting date, Aug. 1, approaches.

Recent developments do not point to any diminution in the manpower shortage. This week brought the announcement of a continuing shortage of tires because of the inability to secure some 6,000 needed additional workers. The War Manpower Commission has ordered hotels to economize manpower by slashing their laundry, maid and bellboy services.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- At least 174,500 Japanese are known to have been killed by American, British Empire and some Chinese troops since the beginning of the war, not including the thousands who have perished at sea or died behind the lines of wounds or disease.

CHICAGO, July 27 -- The first settlement of a canceled war contract of large size was announced today. The International Harvester Company's $217,000,000 contract to produce tanks at Bettendorf, Iowa, was settled for $25,300,000, or less han 12 per cent of the amount involved.

Multiplicity of orders issued by the war agencies, resulting in unbalanced production and the loss or transfer of output and manpower to other fields, together with inequitable price ceilings, are the principal reasons for current apparel shortages, Oscar J. Groebl, chairman of the board, International Association of Garment Manufacturers, informed the Truman committee in a letter made public yesterday.

ANOTHER Billy Rose show is in the offing, only this one is the golf extravaganza George S. May, Chicago medicine-man to business, puts on at Tam O' Shanter, the club he owns and operates with unique success. May, who runs to shirts as a medium for making himself a man never forgotten once met, was one of the few far sighted enough to see that tournament golf had to be kept in wartime.
ROME, July 27 (AP) -- A communique:

Net earnings of the Continental Can Company, Inc., and wholly owned subsidiaries excluding the Keystone Drum Company, which was acquired last May 26, amounted to $5,941,138 for the twelve months ended with June, according to the report issued for publication today by Carle C. Conway, chairman of the board and president.
LONDON, July 27 -- The stock markets today were unsettled and, with not much business being reported, prices were inclined to be irregular.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Members of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States have approved by referenda proposals which would permit operators of one form of transportation, such as railroads, to engage in other forms of transportation, like airways, and encourage operators of different forms of transportation to coordinate their services.

Charging that the State Administration under Governor Dewey had failed to maintain the democratic pace of the last twenty years, Hyman Blumberg, State Secretary of the American Labor party, made public yesterday the party's 1944 State program.

WASHINGTON1/8 July 27 -- William Dudley Pelley, one of the defendants in the mass sedition trial, was pictured in documents offered for identification today as believing that "the weapons are in our hands to hurl this overseas crowd of subversionists out of our country."

LONDON, July 27 -- With the celebration today of the 250th anniversary of the Bank of England, Montagu Collet Norman, recently retired as governor of the institution, has been named a baron, it was announced this afternoon at 10 Downing Street.

LONDON, Friday, July 28 (AP) -- In a special communique, one of the few ever broadcast by the Free Yugoslav Radio, Marshal Tito announced early today that 5,000 Germans had been wiped out in the Berame area.
CHICAGO, July 27 (AP) -- Orval Grove, finishing his first game in eight starts, shut out Washington on four singles tonight as the White Sox made it three in a row over the Senators, 4 to 0.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on July 22 totaled 903,034 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 1,770 cars, or 0.2 per cent less than for the preceding week; 19,196 cars, or 2.2 per cent, above that for the corresponding week last year, and 47,519 cars, or 5.6 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- Current point values on all rationed meats and dairy products will be continued until at least Aug. 13, the Office of Price Administration stated today.

President Roosevelt was chosen unanimously last night as the recipient of the 1943 Four Freedoms Award of the Italian-American Labor Council at a meeting of organization delegates in their headquarters, 218 West Fortieth Street.

When the rapid conquest of the Malay States and the Dutch East Indies by the Japanese cut off our rubber supply we were faced with the urgent necessity of creating virtually overnight a gigantic synthetic rubber plant. Because of the slowness with which this program matured and the charges of muddled handling, a special committee headed by B.M. Baruch was established.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 27 (AP) -- Communique 103:

ALBANY, July 27 -- Governor Dewey outlined today fifteen specific fields of governmental activity in which he will ask the scheduled conference of twenty-six Republican Governors at St. Louis to approve a proposed demarcation of Federal, State and local powers.

In spite of the fact that holdings of coffee in this country hit a record high as of July 1, a shortage of some types is indicated prior to October, according to a forecast of food supplies for August, issued by the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- A corrected version of Lieut. Gen. Brehon Somervell's directive ordering an extra hour's work daily for all headquarters employes of the Army Service Forces was disclosed today. It was stated that civil service employes were on a forty-hour base week, not a forty-four-hour week, and since they were working forty-eight hours a week they were drawing overtime pay for eight hours.
ST. LOUIS, July 27 (AP) -- Connie Mack's Athletics broke the Browns' winning streak tonight by defeating the league leaders, 7 to 5.

Two Federal agents, who had been searching several months for 2,000,000 gasoline ration coupons that had been stolen in transit to rationing offices, led city detectives yesterday afternoon in a raid on a commercial garage in Brooklyn that they described as a major distribution center for the black market.
