A demand that labor receive the same protection in reconversion from war to peace that the Baruch-Hancock report proposes for industry was voiced yesterday by Albert J. Fitzgerald, president of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- George D. Brooke, former president of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad, told the Interstate Commerce Commission today that he resigned in December, 1942, because of pressure from the Alleghany Corporation and its chairman, Robert R. Young.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA Friday, July 28 (AP) -- A communique:
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -The present World War has now taken a greater toll of dead and wounded Americans than the entire 1917-18 conflict.

A French racing car and a bale of goatskins produced such spirited bidding yesterday at a United States Customs Service auction that Office of Price Administration ceilings were reached and for the first time in its auctions here the Government was obliged to pick the successful bidder by lottery.

The wartime order book of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation has been reduced by nearly $760,000,000 in the last nine months by reason of completion of work undertaken, principally in the shipbuilding division, Eugene G. Grace, president, revealed at the close of the quarterly meeting of directors yesterday.
CHUNGKING, China, July 27 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

The perplexity of many fathers and mothers, willing and able to pay for prefessional help in child guidance but unaware that it is available, has been an important factor in setting up a non-profit fee service, announced yesterday by the Jewish Board of Guardians. It is the first child guidance agency in this area to adopt such a program.

The Harvey Radio Company has purchased the three-story building at 106 West Forty-fifth Street from Henry P. Kirkham and plans improvement of the property for its own business. The property, on a plot 25 by 100 feet, is on the south side of the street about 100 feet west of Sixth Avenue. Tankoos, Smith Co. and Cruikshank Company were the brokers.

WITH UNITED STATES NINTH AIR FORCE, Somewhere in France, July 27 -- Thunderbolt P-47s that took up bases in Normandy some time ago tangled late yesterday with German armor moving up to the St. Lo-Periers sector, Where American troops were punching through the German line, and official Ninth Air Force reports this morning claimed twenty Nazi tanks destroyed, nineteen others probably destroyed and fifty-eight damaged.

LONDON, July 27 (U.P.) -- The Olympic Games produce too many "international brawls" and should not be held for at least twenty-five years after the war so that tempers have a chance to cool, London sports writers asserted today.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Ever since the Democratic National Convention, with at least the acquiescence of the President, declined to renominate Vice President Wallace, the party management has been brooding over the possible injury this action may have done to what had been expected to be a powerful argument in favor of a fourth term for Mr. Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- Clifford J. Durr, Federal Communications Commissioner, expressed fear today that high prices paid recently for radio stations might result in eventual exclusive control of the industry by the "well-to-do."

Mayor La Guardia outlining the post-war works program for New York City before a Congressional committee yesterday, said the city was ready to spend $1,270,000,000, and urged prompt and generous Federal grants to finance the projects planned to furnish employment to many thousands during the five years after the war.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- To avoid enhancing monopoly, small business would be favored in the disposal of an estimated $103,000,000,000 in surplus war goods.
Mrs. John W. Bricker, wife of the Republican Vice Presidential candidate, declared yesterday that she was convinced the women of this country would insist on formulation of a "durable peace plan."
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

MOSCOW, July 27 -- Soviet newspapers gave front-page prominence today to news of the agreement between the Soviet Government and the Polish Committee of National Liberation, which was signed in the Kremlin late yesterday by Foreign Commissar Vyacheslaff, M. Molotoff and Edward Osubka-Morawski, chairman and Foreign Minister of the Polish Committee, in the presence of Premier Joseph Stalin and the committee's commander in chief, Michal Rola-Zhmierski.

PEARL HARBOR, July 27 -- In a heavy two-day carrier plane attack on seven islands in the western Carolines United States fliers sank ten Japanese ships, including a destroyer. They destroyed twenty-six enemy aircraft on the first day and in the attacks spread destruction through enemy defenses, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced today.

The American Legion will conduct an intensive drive throughout the nation to collect waste paper from Sept. 3 through Sept 16 and as long thereafter as is necessary, it was announced yesterday by Edwin S. Friendly, chairman of the executive committee of the United States Victory Waste Paper Campaign.

A grade labeling committee will be named by the National Boot and Shoe Manufacturers Association, it was learned yesterday, with the group to adopt a program to protect the interests of the industry. The committee also will initiate research and study-whenever efforts are made to establish standards and grade labeling.

ROME, July 27 -- Benito Mussolini was, after all, guilty along with the actual assassins in the murder of Socialist Deputy Giacomo Matteotti, June 10, 1924. The solution of this murder, which shook the fascist regime and which is still so hot politically that full publication of information in this correspondent's hands would cause the gravest repercussions here, lacked one element at the time that was the key to everything.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 27 -- The legalizing of off-the-track betting on horse races was advocated unanimously today by 200 members of the New York State Association of Chiefs of Police at their forty-fourth annual conference in the Hotel Roger Smith here.

A formula for compiling standardized information regarding the volume of war theme advertising by the principal media, and coordinating such data under the direction of the War Advertising Council, has been worked out jointly by representatives of the newspaper, magazine, radio and outdoor advertising industries, the council revealed yesterday.

Howard Spring, who wrote "My Son, My Son!" is the author of a new novel, "Hard Facts," which the Viking Press will publish in September. It is the story of a young clergyman in England in the Eighteen Eighties.

On Dec. 13, 1941, the Navy Department announced that it was "unable to communicate with Guam either by cable or radio." Tokyo had claimed the capture of the island on the second day of the war, Dec. 8 by our time. The claim was premature, but the Guam radio was silenced on Dec. 10.

LONDON, July 27 -- Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk has left London for Moscow on a mission of reconciliation with the members of the rival Government of Poland and with its Soviet sponsors. Upon the success of his bold gesture depends the fate of the exiled Government in London and, to a large extent, the whole question of unity and harmony between Russia and the Western democracies in the post-war political resettlement of Europe.

NEWARK, N.J., July 27 -- Herbert Brownell, chairman of the Republican National Committee, was assured today by Governor Walter E. Edge and other Republican leaders in New Jersey that this State, popularly classified as "doubtful" by politicians "will go down the line for Dewey in the coming election."

ROME, July 27 -- Following is the text of the Filippelli memorandum as transcribed and translated from a photostatic copy of the original, which is in Filippelli's handwriting. It is impossible here to give Filippelli's numerous underscorings and the dramatic way wherein he emphasized his points by writing in large scrawling letters.

Legal wrangling marked the proceedings before Justice Samuel Null in Supreme Court yesterday in which the city is trying to collect sales taxes of $181,375 from the Stork Club, and the club is seeking to restrain the city from interfering with its business.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- Labor leaders voiced a new appeal today for immediate adoption of plans to reconvert industry to peacetime production with a mini mum of unemployment and it was suggested that Congress, returning Aug 1, stay in session until the legislation is enacted.

ELMIRA, N.Y., July 27 (AP) -- The Navy turned over to the Army Air Forces today the Carl L. Norden bombsight plant, as a Truman subcommittee continued investigation of the transfer of the plant in December from Remington Rand. Inc., to Norden.
CHUNGKING, China, July 27 (AP) -- A communique

A series of three rooms designed by Gilbert Rohde just before his recent death opens today in Bloomingdale's furniture department. While somewhat disappointing as a complete decorative scheme, the living room with a large dining section at one end and the bedroom contain many individual pieces of Rohde-designed furniture that are notable for beauty of line and material as well as for functionalism.

LONDON, Friday, July 28 (AP) -- Marshal Konstantin K. Rokossovsky's First White Russian Army has all but encircled the embattled and doomed fortress of Brest-Litovsk -- last major bastion to hold out before Warsaw -- leaving the German garrison only a six-mile-wide escape route to the northwest, and reached the east bank of the Vistula River along a fifty-five-mile front.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The Government formally and with finality denied today that it had engaged in a "secret pact" with the United Kingdom which had the effect of excluding American exporters from shipping leather belting to India.

Vincent Guy Calfapietra, former first-grade fireman attached to Hook and Ladder 5, who was dismissed by Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh last May for holding a job outside of the department, got a further setback yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Felix C. Benvenga dismissed his application for an order annulling his dismissal.

The final performance at the giant cash register in Times Square, where bond sales in the Fifth War Loan totaled $2,000,000, will be given this evening, with a WAC Transportation Band from Fort Hamilton as the featured attraction.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 27 -The Huntinoton,t, Bay Yacht Club will sponsor its annual Heckscher Trophy race over a twenty-eight mile course on Sunday, it was announced today. ailboats of /twenty-four to sixty-five feet overall with auxiliary power will be eligible to participate. The event will start off the club in I-/untington Bay and take the craft to Stratford Shoals nd return.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- The $5 annual automobile use tax was paid on nearly 2,400,000 fewer cars in the fiscal year ending June 30 than in the preceding twelve months.

After easing to losses of 3 to 8 points on and after the opening yesterday, cotton futures turned firmer on the New York Cotton Exchange and closed steady, 4 to 10 points higher, influenced by small buying orders by the trade in a market where offerings were limited.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, has appealed to staff members of the United States Employment Service to become "supersalesmen" in persuading essential war workers to stick to their tasks.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- Senator Wagner, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, proposed today to lift the Bretton Woods international monetary agreement out of reach of politics and to delay until after the election any start on legislation to put it into effect.
KANDY, Ceylon, July 27 (UP) -- A special communique:

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- During the week ended July 26 member bank reserve balances increased $39,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. Additions to member bank reserve arose from increases of $125,000,000 in reserve bank credit and $2,000,000 in Treasury currency, and decreases of $35,000,000 in Treasury cash and $24,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 27 -- Parents of the puplis of the former Low-Heywood School for Girls here, and alumnae of the eighty-three-year-old institution, which was sold recently and will be used as a boys' military academy, have formed a non-profit corporation to continue the school, it was learned today.
SALEM, N.H., July 27 (AP) -- Coming through on the rail in the stretch, the Donna Ray Stables' Texas Sandman today won the featured Cheshire Allowance Purse for $2,000 at Rockingham Park.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast domestically in Finland and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

With thunder showers putting a damper on both the Pirates-Giants and Cubs-Dodgers arclight games last night, most of the local baseball activity was centered around Manager Melvin Ott of the Giants and Ford Frick, president of the National League.

Paul E. Fitzpatrick. Democratic State chairman, said yesterday that the meeting of the Democratic State Committee to nominate candidates for United States Senator and associate judge of the Court of Appeals would be held on Aug. 8 or 9.

When this nation began to organize its largest army from millions of raw draftees for the struggle with the Axis powers, the responsibility for their training was turned over to a quiet, unassuming disciplinarian who believed that a good soldier must have "the lust to kill."

We are told that on X-day -- when Germany surrenders -- it will be possible to reduce the production of war equipment by 40 per cent. Excellent! Who wants to produce any more guns or submarines than we need? Besides, we all want autos and houses and refrigerators.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 27 (U.P.) -- Pistol Head, a mournful-looking red cocker spaniel, who survived forty-eight bombing missions in the central Pacific but lost his master, Lieut. Col. S.T. Willis of Brooklyn, was aboard a United Air Lines plane tonight bound home.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Lieut. Gen. Lesley J. McNair, one of the "big four" of the United States Army, who, as commanding general of the Army Ground Forces, directed the greatest military training and conditioning job in history, was killed by enemy fire while observing action of our front-line troops in the new Normandy offensive, the War Department announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- A rise in department store sales to 11 per cent for the week ended July 22, compared with the corresponding period of a year ago, was announced today by the Federal Reserve Board.
Transcontinental travel may be difficult these days for soldiers and civilians alike, but a horse named Zaca Gray made the midsummer jump from California to New York apparently as fresh as a daisy.
LONDON, July 27 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:
PEARL HARBOR, July 27 (AP) -- Palau, gateway to the Philip. pines, is less than 600 miles east of 1V[indanao and 900 miles southwest of invaded Guam.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 27 (AP) -- A temporary injunction against radio station KSTP's musicians, restraining them from striking in the prolonged KSTP-musicians' dispute over a new union contract, was dismissed in the District Court today.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Friday, July 28 -- A smashing tactical success has been achieved on the western sector of the Normandy battle line by a daring American maneuver which late yesterday was within five miles of cutting the escape lines of German forces defending that side of the Contentin Peninsula.

CLEVELAND, July 27 -- The Indians who, as currently the hottest entry in the American League, were considerably cooled off by the Yankees last night, came zooming back this afternoon under the invigorating rays of a sizzling sun with a fresh supply of heat and energy.

Heavyweights headline the boxing program at Madison Square Garden tonight, when the ten round feature bout brings together Turkey Thompson of Los Angeles, and Lee Q. Murray of South Norwalk, Conn. Both men completed their training chores yesterday with light exercises.

Two new films are scheduled to open in midtown houses today. At the Globe will be "The Canterville Ghost," M-G-M's comedy-fantasy starring Charles Laughton, Margaret O'Brien and Robert Young. At the Rialto will be "Shadows in the Night," the latest in Columbia's "Crime Doctor" series, with Warner Baxter again starred.

New high records in both sales and profits before Federal income and excess profits taxes were set last year by department stores and specialty shops, according to the study on departmental merchandising and opearting reults, issued yesterday by the Controllers Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Marilynn Kalkut was inducted yesterday at the new Women's Army Corps recruiting headquarters, 638 Fifth Avenue, the first young woman to apply there and first to be sworn in. Lieut. Col. Katherine Goodwin, assistant director of the WAC under Col. Oveta C. Hobby in Washington, officiated.

LONDON, July 27 (AP) -- The Germans named two comparatively obscure veterans of the Russian front today as central figures, along with the previously identified Col. Gen. Ludwig Beck, in the deep-laid conspiracy against Adolf Hitler that misfired a week ago.

ABOARD INVASION FLAGSHIP, Off Guam, July 27 -- The thunderous naval and artillery barrage that had been pounding Guam like a mighty hammer for twelve hours suddenly faded to a whisper. Then came dive bombers hurtling down out of the morning sky to deposit their destructive loads among the rubble.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- A demand that the United States assume leadership in world affairs after the war was sounded today by Comdr. Harold E. Stassen, who resigned the Governorship of Minnesota to enter the Navy. On leave from duty in the Pacific area, he will return there in a few days.

The speech of Propaganda Minister Goebbels, and some additional semi-official reports from Berlin, have at last lifted a tiny corner of the veil of secrecy which the Nazis have thrown around the revolt of German generals that nearly cost Hitler his life and put an end to the Third Reich.

Christmas had a dress rehearsal yesterday. While the temperature soared 300 postal and Army and Navy officials met with representatives of the advertising and greeting-card industries to start the Early Christmas Mailing Campaign in a Yuletide setting -- complete with holly, eggnog and holiday music.
SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 27 -- After a year's lapse, the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club invitation grass court tournament was renewed today with an entry worthy of pre-war days.

The Greater New York Congress of Industrial Organizations Council and State headquarters of the American Labor party made separate appeals yesterday to Governor Dewey to intervene to break a tie vote on the State War Ballot Commission.

WITH THE FIRST ARMY IN NORMANDY, July 27 -- Hundreds of American tanks are waddling over the green hills through tiny villages west and south of St. Lo rooting out German resistance like gigantic hump-backed hogs in what is surely the most important and skillful armored assault in France since the German break-through in the grim May days of 1940.

Fresh from a press conference with Governor Dewey at Albany, Gov. John W. Bricker, Republican nominee for Vice President, in a press interview here yesterday, again predicted a Republican victory in November.

Three men, charged with operating what police called "a revival of an old patriotic racket" in the vicinity of Pennsylvania Station by pinning small American flags on the clothing of pedestrians and asking contributions "for the returning boys," were found guilty of violating the city's administrative code before Magistrate Robert F. Mahoney in Jefferson Market Court yesterday.

Both the Republican and Democratic conventions stressed the war as the immediate issue. In all likelihood it will be the prime emphasis in the campaign. But it is really no more than the surface issue.

In an attempt to help the police stamp out racketeering that threatens their own livelihood, a group of old-time horse cab drivers were refusing fares last night although their cabs, as usual, were lined up outside of Central Park at Fifty-ninth Street near Fifth Avenue.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 27 -- A fleet of 142 craft started today in the second program of the annual Larchmont Race Week, a turnout that exceeded by one the number that participated in yesterday's activities.

Participation by American fighter pilots in the crushing Red drive against the Nazis in the Lwow area marks a new step in collaboration among the major Allies. It indicates a development of tactical cooperation with the Russians which began with the establishment of bases in Russia for shuttle bombing.

MOSCOW, July 27 -- Tass, the official Soviet news agency, declared today that the roots of the present crisis facing the Japanese Government could be found in the approaching fall of its ally, Germany, and the fact that Japan is waging a hopeless war in China and Burma, while the blows of the Allies in the Pacific continue to increase.

CHUNGKING, July 27 (AP) -- Chinese forces have overwhelmed enemy defenses at Laifengshan, just southwest of their main Yunnan front objective of Tengyueh, after a shattering attack by American fighters and medium bombers, a High Command communique said tonight.

CHERRY POINT, N.C., July 14 (Delayed) -- A new training idea is being tried here at Cherry Point, the Marine Corps, largest air station. Marine officer-pilots are being made to live the dirty, sweaty life of the ground fighter for two weeks.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Dissatisfaction with "the greatly inadequate" number of heavy-duty truck and bus tires which will be rationed during August was expressed today by Col. J. Monroe Johnson, Director of the Office of Defense Transportation, who warned that "a serious curtailment of essential transportation" was in prospect.

Mrs. Julia Husznay, 67 years, of 125 Guernsey Street, Brooklyn, who tried to shoot herself on Tuesday when about to be dispossessed for non-payment of rent, will be aided by the Welfare Department, according to a departmental report made public yesterday by Mayor La Guardia's office.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 92:

When do a man's belongings become his possessions, and when do his possessions become his fortune, and when does his fortune become his ill-gotten gains? We ask these questions because of a desire really to understand why France fell.

DETROIT, July 27 (AP) -- Behind the effective pitching of Cecil (Tex) Hughson, who spaced six Tiger hits to become the first American League pitcher this season to win sixteen games, the Red Sox defeated Detroit today, 6 to 1.

CHICAGO, July 27 -- Lack of offerings and scattered buying attributed to distillers and millers gave the wheat market a firm undertone today on the Board of Trade. Prices were up around 3/4 cent at one time, but weakness in rye led to selling later and the close was 1/8 to 3/8 cent higher.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson warned the American people today against the folly of expecting anything good from the Junker generals, even if they should rebel against Adolf Hitler.

The case of the Western Hemisphere against Argentina has been spread on the record. Argentina has answered. Fair-minded persons now can weigh the evidence. For the first time since Feb. 25, when the present rulers of Argentina drove President Ramirez out of the Pink House in Buenos Aires and President General Farrell assumed the self-tailored robes of office, the Argentine people have an opportunity to hear both sides.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, July 27 -- Battleships, cruisers and destroyers of an Allied Eastern Fleet task force leveled virtually all harbor installations at the Japanese-held naval base of Sabang, off northwestern Sumatra at the mouth of Malacca Strait, in a surprise 35-minute bombardment just after sunrise on Tuesday, and sailed away with only minor damage, it was disclosed today.

LONDON, July 27 -- As spokesman of the Government committee by Prime Minister Churchill to the policy of legitimacy in Greece, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden charged in the House of Commons today that the leaders of the Eam, a left wing faction of the Greek liberation front, with obstructing the cause of unity for selfish interests.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- In a series of revisions of its renegotiation regulations, the War Contracts Price Adjustment Board today exempted several additional commodities and products from the requirements for contract renegotiation.

LONDON, July 27 (AP) -- The Germans' flying bomb barrage increased in ferocity tonight, spreading death through southern England, while Britons pondered the possibility of worse to come -- perhaps huge explosive rockets.

An agreement has been reached between the Standard Oil Company of Louisiana and the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, incorporated in Delaware, to consolidate at the end of this year, M.J. Rathbone, president of the New Jersey company, announced yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 27 -- RKO will co-feature Phillip Terry and Audrey Long in "Pan-Americana," a musical with a Latin-American background, to be put into production Monday, with John Auer producing and directing. Robert Benchley and Eve Arden also have been named for principal parts.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Republicans moved today to have Congress start work at once on reconversion legislation in view of the changing aspect of the war.

Mrs. Ann Joseph, under indictment for burglary with Mrs. Arlene Hanley, was advised yesterday that her husband, Horace, a paratrooper, had been killed in action. The women are said to have looted three apartments in Sunnyside, Queens, because the allotments from their husbands were insufficient for the "nice things" they wanted and they were envious of other women in their neighborhood.

ALBANY, July 27 (AP) -- New York State marriages and births, which increased sharply early in the war, are on the decline and the downward trend probably will continue until peacetime, Dr. J.V. De Porte, director of the Health Department's Division of Vital Statistics, said today.
Your "Farm Shop on a Rainy Day" and the shop in New Hampshire described by your correspondent have taken my thoughts back to happy boyhood days on a farm in North Carolina.

WITH THE AMERICAN FORCES in Normandy, July 27 -- The American break-through west of St. Lo widened and deepened today into a torrent that swept swiftly south and west toward the sea. Tonight the battle had become a race. Our forces, both armored and infantry, with aircraft giving spectacular aid, were boldly driving a wedge through the rear of the German forces.

A taxpayers' suit to wipe out the Board of Education eligible lists bearing the names of 2,000 elementary school teachers, an action that might ultimately endanger the positions of several thousand other teachers in the New York City school system, was heard yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Samuel Null.

ON THE ST LO FRONT, July 26 (Delayed) -- Twenty-four hours after the United States Eightth and Ninth Air Forces combined to give the American ground troops in this sector the heaviest close support ever accorded to any frontline soldiers it is unmistakable that Army leaders here are something less than satisfied with the aerial performance.

Conversion of looms operating on decorative cotton fabrics to ducks, chambrays, denims, print cloth fabrics and sheetings in compliance with the latest change on L-99 will be protested by all of the mills involved, according to Worth Street sources yesterday.

New York City banks improved their reserve position in the week that ended Wednesday, according to a report yesterday by the Federal Reserve Board, but in spite of this, money conditions were not particularly easy. They ended the week with excess reserves of $20,000,000, against a deficit in the preceding week of $60,000,000, achieving this by adding $98,000,000 to actual reserves while reserve requirements rose $18,000,000.

BOSTON, July 27 (AP) -- In comparative privacy -- paid attendance was 785 -- the Reds defeated the Braves, 4 to 2, tonight in a twilight game which was finished in a rainstorm. As usual, Nate Andrews got poor support and was lifted for a pinch bitter in the seventh.

Food service is now available to 5,500,000 workers in the nations' manufacturing plants and soon will be available to 1,500,000 more, according to a survey covering 2,056 representative plants made by the Office of Distribution of the War Food Administration, it was learned yesterday.

Dr. Reinhold Niebuhr, a member of the National Political Action Committee, an offshoot of the Congress of Industrial Organizations Political Action Committee, headed by Sidney Hillman, has accepted election as vice chairman of the Liberal party, holding that there is no inconsistency involved, it was announced yesterday.

ROME, July 27 (AP) -- Driving up the Adriatic coast of Italy against weakening German resistance, Polish troops have pushed seventeen miles beyond the captured Port of Ancona and seized Senigallia at the mouth of the Misa River only twenty-two miles from Pesaro, Allied Headquarters announced tonight.

MOSCOW, Friday, July 28 -- The mighty Red Army, smashing forward on a broad front stretching from the Baltic Sea to the foothills of the Carpathian Mountains, yesterday captured Lwow, Bialystok, Stanislav, Dvinsk, Siauliai and Rezekne -- an unprecedented record of important captures, which resulted in five salutes from Moscow's massed guns last night.

CHUNGKING, July 27 (AP) -- Counter-attacking Chinese have recaptured Leiyang, southernmost point of advance from the north in the Japanese grand stategy to split China in two and seal her off from help from the Pacific, a Chinese communique announced tonight.

As far as the bankers -- and, incidentally, the legislators -- of this country are concerned, the Bretton Woods conference left post-war monetary arrangements an open question. The conference held closely to its instructions, setting up machinery to implement a premise which has been given neither legislative nor business approval.
PHILADELPHIA, July 27 (AP) -- The Cardinals swept their four-game series with the Phillies by taking Both ends of a double-header tonight, 8-7 and 5-0.

Lieut. Gen. Lesley J. McNair has died a soldier's death facing the enemy in Normandy. It was a death he had gladly risked many times and which almost came to him more than a year ago when he was wounded in Tunisia. Behind him lay a great record of achievement as organizer of the training program that has given us an army of 7,000,000 men.

LONDON, July 27 -- No great epidemics such as followed the last World War are foreseen by the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration after this one, a senior official of its health division said today at a press conference.

A lesson in civics stopped Fifth Avenue crowds yesterday as Lord Taylor unveiled a series of windows urging women to vote. Four life-sized tableaux of homemakers at work form the backgrounds for brief legends that are amplified by posters in two smaller displays.

The stock market attempted yesterday to break out of its recent heaviness, but met with only scattered success, since interest contracted to the lightest in two months. At the close, prices differed little from the previous day's level, although some of the low-priced motors generated moderate speculative interest.

NEWARK, N.J., July 27 (AP) -About 500 production employes of the Harrison plant of McKiernan-Terry Corporation were out today in what both company and union officials termed a wildcat strike in protest against new wage rates set by the company after a job re-classification by the War Labor Board.
ROME, July 28 (AP) -- American and German artillery dueled across the Arno River tonight in the battle for Pisa, and the fate of the historic city and its cultural monuments hung in the balance.

The Mutual Life Insurance Company has sold the building at 8 East Thirty-sixth Street to John C. Andresen, dealer in hides and leather since 1857, through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., who will manage the property. Richard McCann was the attorney for the buyer and title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- Accompanied by a list of seventy-two telephone calls, including some declared to have been from CIO Political Action Committee officials to the White House, a report labeling the PAC "the political arm of the New Deal Administration" was made public today by Representative Martin Dies of Texas.

The United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration was formed because the Allies "for humane reasons, for reasons of good, hard-headed common-sense, are determined to see that all the lands that are released from tyranny shall have an equal and early chance to start rebuilding a new and better world," Herbert H. Lehman, director general of UNRRA, declared last night in a radio address.

WHAT will happen when Gen. Charles de Gaulle, leader of the Free French, finally confronts Marshal Henri Philippe Petain? If you want to exercise your historical imagination, the materials for answering that question lie in two recent paper-bound books, "The Truth About de Gaulle,"* by Andre Riveloup, and "Petain: the Old Man of France," by Janet Flanner.
GUAM, July 23 -- United States Marines storming Mount Alifan, 874-foot peak overlooking the Agat beachhead, found Japanese officers already committing suicide on the second day of the battle.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- Buying of wheat futures by a house with Southwestern connections regarded as removal of hedges against sales of cash wheat and a Government-support program offset peace talk and the rapid progress of the Allied armies in Europe today and resulted in prices holding within narrow limits on the Board of Trade.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Saturday, July 29 (UP) -- A communique:

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 28 -- Numerically, by lone digits, the Larchmont Yacht Club Race Week fleet crept up today to 146 starters. There was no customary drop before the expected heavy weekend turnout. In the three days of sailing so far there have been 429 starters.

The new Japanese Ministers of War and Navy yesterday asked the Government of Premier Kuniaki Koiso to consider permitting "freer expression of public opinion with the object of enhancing home front morale" and to take immediate steps to increase the production of weapons, particularly of planes, the Japanese Domei agency said in an English-language wireless dispatch to Pacific areas.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Peter H. Bergson, chairman of the Hebrew Committee of National Liberation, today announced an "end of the road" appeal to the British Government on behalf of Jews in the occupied and Axis satellite countries.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- A list of essential services was issued today by the WPB and WFA to be used in connection with the rationing of heavy-duty and medium-duty tires for trucks and buses. All truck and motor vehicle services are grouped into classes according to their relative essentiality.

BAYEUX, France, July 28 -- There is something familiar about it all as though you had lived it before. You see trucks parked in stableyards of old stone farmhouses, Tommies playing with kids and elderly French women in black picking their way through crowds of soldiers on their way to mass.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Pending further consideration of the complete revision of the shell egg price regulation, the Office of Price Administration today announced new maximum prices for wholesale grades of shell eggs for the period beginning July 31 and ending Sept. 30.

The Boy Scouts of America, whose home front contributions have been lauded by public officials, will launch an intensive two-month drive throughout the country through August and September in the collection of waste paper.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 28 -- Pedro Armendariz, the so-called Clark Gable of Mexico, has been signed by Hunt Stromberg for the part of "Moreno" in his proposed screen adaptation of the Margaret Ayer Barnes and Edward Shelton play, "Dishonored Lady," in which Katharine Cornell was starred on Broadway in 1930.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- James F. Byrnes, Director of War Mobilization, said tonight that he had received assurances from Democratic Congressional leaders that they would cooperate on the reconvening of Congress Tuesday to obtain prompt consideration of legislation designed to complete the charting of an industrial demobilization and reconversion program.

A new variety of the homely frankfurter -- a food evoking the memory of camp fires and picnics at the beach -- is being prepared in canned form by the Claridge Food Company. It is a mildly seasoned sausage, the meat and casings of which are unusually tender.

CHUNGKING, China, July 28 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

Charley Grimm's Cubs yesterday completed the sweep of their series at Ebbets Field by duplicating their victory score of Wednesday night, 4 -- 1. And this setback, the twenty-fourth for the cellar-shackled Dodgers in their last twenty-seven engagements, was "the most unkindest cut of all."

Last week's paper salvage champions, fifty youngsters from the city's summer playgrounds, claimed their reward yesterday -- luncheon at the Hotel Bristol and a tour of Fort Jay on Governors Island. The trip was arranged by the New York Newspaper Publishers Association for the ten-man teams in the five boroughs turning in the most scrap paper for the week of July 21.

With the announcement of invitations for tenders on $1,200,000,000 of ninety-one-day Treasury discount bills, next week will bring the end of a thirteen-week cycle of such offerings and with it interest centers on whether the weekly allotment of bills will be raised, perhaps to $1,500,000,000.

PHILADELPHIA, July 28 -- The Northern Indiana Public Service Company outlined today to the Securities and Exchange Commission a new plan for refinancing the outstanding 220,078 shares of the company's 7, 6 and 5 1/2 per cent cumulative preferred stock.

Rogers, chairman of the technical committee of the Producers Council, the national organization of manufacturers of building materials and equipment.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The distilled spirits industry will turn out nearly 40,000,000 gallons of potable spirits next month for the home market, according to predictions made today by distillers and others.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -Officials of the Chesapeake Ohio Railroad told the Interstate Commerce Commission today that Robert R. Young, chairman of the Alleghany Corporation, held a commanding role on the board of directors of the C. O. from 1938 to 1942.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES, in Normandy, July 28 -- Armored spearheads of our lightning drive smashed into the northern outskirts of Coutances this afternoon and partially sprang a trap that our forces have been weaving around the battered enemy divisions in western Normandy.
Acceding to a request by the city Department of Markets, the Office of Price Administration made available yesterday to New York City housewives the maximum prices that retailers may charge for eggs.
ROME, July 28 -- An urgent plea to the United States to include Italy in lend-lease was made today by Premier Ivanoe Bonomi, who said such a request had been sent to Washington.

CHUNGKING, China, July 28 (AP) -- A communique:

The New York State Public Service Commission announced yesterday that it had asked the Long Island Lighting Company to consider certain suggested modifications in its over-all plan of recapitalization, now on file with the commission.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Saturday, July 29 (AP) -- Allied aircraft, riding herd on the vast domain under its control, sank two Japanese ships, set fire to a third and destroyed numerous smaller craft in a day of unusual activity reported today by headquarters.

CHUNGKING, China, July 28 (AP) -- Both sides are rushing up tanks and infantry in the spreading battles of Hunan Province, whose key rail city of Hengyang remains firmly in Chinese hands despite more than a month of unrelenting Japanese assault, a Chinese Army spokesman said tonight.

MANVILLE, N.J., July 28 -- The driver of an automobile who was stopped by a policeman on a speeding charge was under arrest for murder today after his companion died of injuries that authorities said were inflicted in a fight between the two.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 28 -- Mr. Winslow lived at 28 Byron Place here. He was on Fire Island on an outing with the Ives Committee when he was drowned.

J.L. Ennis Co., operators, have purchased the five-story dwelling at 127 East Sixty-first Street from Mrs. D. Rebecca Cramp of Port Washington, L.I. The property, containing ten suites of one and two rooms, is assessed at $38,500.

Manufacturers of infants' and children's snow suits and legging sets have now placed from 80 to 85 per cent of their fabric priorities with the mills, according to estimates in the trade here yesterday.
New York City's E bond sales now stand at $178,189,984, or 78.3 per cent of the city's Fifth War Loan quota for this issue, it was announced yesterday by the War Finance Committee.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:Reading about the "coddling" of war prisoners is an old story for me and so common in every belligerent country that I would not have asked for any of your space to discuss it. But when I read in THE TIMES a criticism of our War Department policy toward the Italian prisoners of war, from the head of a veterans' organization, I could not keep silent.

PITTSBURGH, July 27 -- Business in the Pittsburgh district last week held about unchanged, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. There were moderate decreases in the volume of industrial production and in originating shipments; but a fairly large gain in trade offset most of the drop.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 28 -- Miss Louise Brough of Beverly Hills and Miss Dorothy May Bundy of Santa Monica, Calif., the second and fifth ranking players of the country, were eliminated from the invitation turf court tournament of the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club today.

ROEBLING, N.J., July 28 (AP) -- Only open-hearth furnaces were functioning tonight at the sprawling wire products plant of John A. Roebling Sons Company as 3,000 workers remained away from their jobs in what the company termed a protest over the dismissal of nine tempering shop employes.

Directors of the North American Company yesterday declared a dividend on the common stock payable in the form of common shares of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company at the rate of one share of Pacific Gas and Electric for every 100 shares of North American common stock held.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast in Finland and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Josef Hofmann, the distinguished pianist, was the guest soloist at the Lewisohn Stadium last night, and the crowd of more than 13,000 that found its way into the amphitheatre was ample testimony to the perennial popularity of the artist. Mr. Hofmann's vehicle for the evening was Beethoven's "Emperor" Concerto, for which the orchestral part was provided by the Philharmonic-Symphony under the direction of Alexander Smallens.

PHOENIXVILLE, Pa., July 28 (UP) -- Sgt. Forrest L. Vosler of Livonia, N.Y., who was blinded in a Flying Fortress raid over Bremen, Germany, will be able to see the President of the United States pin the Congressional Medal of Honor on his chest, thanks to medical science.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The War Production Board, moving gradually toward the reconversion of war industry to the production of essential civilian goods, has drawn up a list of seventy-one wartime restriction orders which may be relaxed on Aug. 15, when regional WPB offices are empowered to authorize civilian production on the basis of local supplies of manpower and materials.

Demands that insurance regulation be left in the hands of the States were voiced yesterday at a conference of insurance officials in the office of Robert E. Dineen, New York State superintendent of insurance. Edward L. Williams, president of She Insurance Executives Association, asserted that that body wants legislation drawn that will return the business to State control.

LONDON, July 28 -- The European general committee of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration today sent to all Allied Governments a draft multilateral agreement to govern the repatriation of the twenty or thirty million "displaced persons" whom the war has uprooted in Europe.

Tired of the rough treatment handed them by the Pirates the last two times they met, the Giants did an about-face last night at the Polo Grounds, where, much to the satisfaction of 12,841 fans, Mel Ott's men blanked the Pittsburgh outfit, 4 -- 0.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The National War Labor Board sent word tonight to James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians (AFL), to order the striking employes of Radio Station KSTP at Minneapolis to return to work immediately.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Saturday, July 29 -- German oil was heavily attacked yesterday by the United States strategic air forces. At least 3,000 aircraft shared two missions 800 miles apart: from Britain to the great Leuna synthetic plant in Saxony and from Italy to the Ploesti natural oil refineries in Rumania.

ALBANY, July 28 -- Governor Dewey announced his opposition today to the renomination of Representative Hamilton Fish Jr., as a Republican candidate for Congress in the Twenty-ninth District. He did this, he said, because Mr. Fish in an interview had raised a "racial" issue in the campaign by referring to the Jews as being for President Roosevelt.

LONDON, July 28 -- With Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk safely in Cairo en route to Moscow for talks on Poland's future with Premier Joseph Stalin and the Polish Committee of National Liberation, members of his Government here took occasion today to voice confidence in him and his mission.

Lee Shubert disclosed yesterday that he has selected the Imperial Theatre to house "Song of Norway," the operetta based on the life and music of the Norwegian composer Edvard Grieg, which he will present in association with Homer Curran, West Coast producer.

Public utility financing featured a larger and more diversified list of new bonds offered for public subscription here this week. Totaling $58,285,000 for seven issues, the new bonds consisted of $39,1500,000 for two public utility loans, $8,120,000 for a railroad issue, $9,165,000 for three tax-exempt flotations and $1,500,000 for an Hawaiian offering.

To prepare for a broad expansion of private flying, as distinguished from the use of commercial air transport, the Personal Aircraft Council of the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce is doing some useful spade work. As a first step the council seeks to spur community interest all over the nation in the creation of air parks.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- The chances for an early victory over Germany were discussed optimistically by members of Con gress today, but Representative McCormack, House majority leader, warned that this was no time to get excited.

NEWBURGH, July 28 -- Standing beside Mrs. George B. St. George, Orange County Republican chairman, Representative Hamilton Fish told the Women's Republican Club of Newburgh at a campaign rally tonight in the County Court House that Governor Dewey's opposition to his renomination would only increase his majority in Tuesday's Republican primary.

The original edition of "The Beards' Basic History of the United States," by Charles and Mary Beard, which will be published at a popular price by the New Home Library on Tuesday, will be re-issued in November under the Doubleday, Doran imprint in a deluxe, enlarged edition -- a reversal of the usual procedure of publishing the more expensive edition first.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- An Office of Price Administration proposal that piano parts makers go ahead and produce, with any increase in ceiling prices to be made retroactive, met with little enthusiasm in the trade here. The proposal was in part a response to a telegram of protest sent by the piano companies at a meeting held here early this week.

WASHINGTON, Tuesday, July 29 -- In their first daylight raid on Japanese territory Superfortresses of the new global Twentieth Bomber Command attacked industrial targets in the Mukden area of Manchuria today (Japanese time). Gen. H.H. Arnold, in his capacity as Commanding General of the Twentieth Air Force, reported the attack at the War Department early this morning.

CLEVELAND, July 28 -- Hammering an odd asosrtment of hurlers for a total of fourteen blows, which included homers by Johnny Lindell and Nick Etten, the Yankees showed today that their old habit of flattening the Indians when the need is great for flattening somebody still has not deserted them.

Retail trade gains here this week were pared by high temperatures and humidity. Despite this, however, estimates put the increase for department stores at about 10 per cent over the like week of last year. Seasonal goods in clearance offerings met a good reception from customers.

COLUMBUS, July 28 (AP) -- Governors Dewey and Bricker, the Republican national standard-bearers, will cover "the whole country" in an intensive campaign starting about Sept. 1, Governor Bricker, the Vice Presidential candidate, said today.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Another indication that the country's transportation system is approaching a crisis was apparent today as the Office of Price Administration announced it would ration only 5,000 new automobiles during August.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 28 -- The Germans have been told that the new total mobilization means that nearly all theatres, movies, concert halls, cabarets, night clubs and music halls must be closed.

Advertisers will shortly be asked to cooperate in an "old clothes for Europe" campaign, it was learned yesterday. A plan of action along this line is being worked out by the War Advertising Council but final details have not as yet been completed.

GUAM, July 24 (Delayed) -- The winding narrow road from Agana to Piti, a pre-war lovers' lane, is a highway of wrath today. Never before has this white limestone roadbed borne such a load of vehicles as its nearly all one-way traffic of amphtracks, tanks and trucks bearing men and material to blast the Japanese from our pre-war naval base at Piti Town.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Using the case of the Brooklyn Central Young Men's Christian Association as its medium, the National War Labor Board followed today its recently announced policy of declining to order an employer engaged in intrastate commerce to recognize or bargain collectively with a union that has neither been certified nor recognized as the exclusive representative of all the employes.

Jack McManis, who put reverse English on Horace Greeley's advice by coming East from California, proved himself a glutton for tennis yesterday when he went through three matches to advance into the semi-final round of the New York State clay court championship now in progress at the Seminole Club in Forest Hills.
Your paper of this morning tells that New York hotel men accept with resignation" the WMC decree which restricts hotel service.

PEARL HARBOR, July 28 -- American forces on Guam have made gains in every sector after killing 2,000 Japanese of a force that made a fierce predawn attack in the northern beachhead area on Tuesday, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced today.

Asserting that the Federal Government "missed the bus" in failing to provide money to help States and cities plan large post-war projects, Commissioner of Parks Robert Moses told a Congressional committee yesterday that threatened mass unemployment after the war may be averted through a flexible public works program aided by Federal subventions.

R.J, Thomas, international president of the United Automobile Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations, and a labor representative on the National War Labor Board, testified as a defense witness yesterday in Federal court for Thomas De Lorenzo, president of the Brewster local of the union.
ST. LOUIS, July 28 (AP) -- The Browns came from behind with four runs in the seventh inning to defeat the Athletics, 8 to 5, tonight.

MOSCOW, Saturday, July 29 -- Soviet troops yesterday captured Brest-Litovsk, main bastion on the central Polish line protecting Warsaw, as well as the city where Russian forces in the last World War gave up the struggle against Germany.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 28 -The three months refusal of American Federation of Labor machinists to work more than forty-eight hours a week in San Francisco uptown shops took a new turn today when business agents of Lodge 68 prevented day shift workers from going into the Federal Mogul plant and forced a shutdown.

Two of the country's leading jockeys -- Johnny Longden and Eddie Arcaro -- narrowly escaped serious injuries yesterday during the Empire City program at Jamaica. Both were spilled from their mounts in spectacular fashion in plain view of a crowd of 20,142 during the fourth race.
L.A. Lacci has purchased for occupancy from Max Klein the one-family dwelling at 205-02 Thirty-third Avenue, Bayside, Queens. The Halleran Agency was the broker.

RICHMOND, Va., July 28 (AP) -The Fourth United States Circuit Court of Appeals today ruled that brokers' commissions may not be added to a price charged a wholesale buyer, but must be absorbed as part of the seller's selling costs, in reversing a decision of the Federal District Court at Baltimore.

LONDON, July 28 (U.P.) -- The Admiralty disclosed today, in the second Allied announcement within twenty-four hours of damaging blows against the western flank of Japanese shipping lanes, that British submarines had sunk twenty-one Japanese vessels and damaged several more in operations carried nearly 300 miles within the Malacca Strait.
LONDON, July 28 -- A robot bomb blew up a crowded restaurant at the noon hour today, killing and trapping a number of persons and causing widespread damage in the surrounding area.

LONDON, July 28 -- For the second time this week the British Government declared today that it stood by the Cripps plan of 1942 as the solution of the Indian political deadlock. Through Leopold S. Amery, Secretary of State for India, it rejected the latest proposals put forward by Indian leaders, which had been described as a "significant change" in Mohandas K. Gandhi's attitude by a Government spokesman in the House of Lords last Tuesday.

With shoe production and retail regulations having been modified in several instances recently, many industry observers are expectant of additional easing of curbs, indicative of a return to more normal merchandising practices. Potentialities were highlighted yesterday by two shoe associations which made moves designed to assure orderliness in the transition from high war demands, which have limited civilian goods production, to a new era when more normal practices will be resumed.

In a desperate attempt to escape through the window of a moving train, a mentally unbalanced German war prisoner well over 6 feet tall, weighing 200 pounds and of tremendous physical strength, went berserk early yesterday morning and was subdued only after his guards had shot him twice.

NORMANDY FRONT, July 27 (Delayed) -- The Germans withdrew from many sectors of the front today, but before they did, their mine-laying units had a field day. American engineers working this afternoon on the outskirts of Periers and Lessay said they had never encountered so many mines.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- More than 20,000 gallons of what is described as "excellent" Sicilian wine is now in this country, awaiting sale to authorized beverage importers, the Foreign Economic Administration made known today.

Dr. H.H. Kung, Chinese Minister of Finance, was honored yesterday by the New York Chapter of the Oberlin College Alumni Association for his contribution to the friendly relations between China and the United States. The minister is a member of the Oberlin class of 1906.
In rather quiet trading the local cotton futures market finished 8 to 10 points lower, influenced by favorable weather in the South, and continued favorable reports from all the war fronts.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (U.P.)--Health authorities sought today to check an "alarming" spread of infantile paralysis by enlisting parents in a four-point program to protect children from the crippling disease.

ROME, July 28 -- Pope Plus in another historic speech on Poland in this war today counseled his Polish soldier-listeners not to take vengeance or reprisals for what had been done to their country and to collaborate with all good men in its restoration.

The first step toward dictatorship is suppression of all intelligence inimical to the designs of the dictator. The cornerstone of democratic decision is a free discussion of issues. The Argentine Government seems to have been sincere in its promise not only to lift the censorship of outgoing information but to remove its strict control of the Argentine press.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- In a move which may be duplicated soon in the United States, the Office of Price Administration ordered rationing tonight in the Hawaiian Islands of used passenger cars of year models 1941 through 1938, effective Aug. 1.

CHICAGO, July 28 (AP) -The White Sox, sweeping the four-game series to make it eight victories in their last ten starts, used the long-range technique against the Senators for an 8-to-2 triumph today.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Federal Trade Commission reported today that Tailored Woman, 742 Fifth Avenue, New York, had replied to the commission's complaint charging the firm with misrepresenting the price and quality of certain types of fur garments.

Despite the Office of Price Administration's week-end announcement that it would base canned food prices for the 1944 pack on commercial grades, the canned-foods market continues inactive, buyers said yesterday. Inasmuch as under the new price-stabilization law the OPA was prevented from imposing mandatory grade labeling, thus maintaining established commercial grades, buyers said the announcement was "meaningless."

The cautious attitude of traders became intensified yesterday as the stock market continued to ease to a moderately lower closing, with business the dullest since mid-May. The list attempted a recovery in the early afternoon, but the lack of additional support soon threw prices back to lower levels.

PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla., July 28 (AP) -- The State Racing Commission assigned dates today for a full 120 days of horse racing next Winter and gave Gulfstream Park, twelve miles north of Miami, permission to reopen and share the Florida season with Hialeah and Tropical Parks.

LONDON, July 28 -- Critics of the pace set by the Allied armor in the Normandy campaign will do well to remember that tanks are sensitive to wooded, hilly or swampy country and operate at a marked disadvantage on land strewn with boulders and tree stumps, a high-ranking officer of the United States Army said here today.

LONDON, Saturday, July 29 (U.P.) -- Soviet troops, advancing in central Poland, also encircled three German divisions -- about 30,000 men -- on the Bug River, west of Brest-Litovsk, Moscow revealed last night.

SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, July 28 (AP) -- The Japanese, in flight from northeast India to their Burma bases, are retreating so rapidly in some sections that only demolitions and the monsoon rains are delaying the Allied advance, headquarters announced today.

New Assembly and State Senate district lines fixed earlier this year by the City Council and State Legislature, respectively, in connection with a reapportionment of seats in the Legislature, will be used for the first time in next Tuesday's primary elections.
Yesterday's communique as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Attacking Representative Vito Marcantonio as "a Communist who during 1940 consistently voted against measures vitally needed in the interest of national defense," fifteen American Legion leaders from the five boroughs urged in a joint statement last night that "all patriotic men and women, irrespective of partisan politics," vote against him in Tuesday's primary.

Stock held by investment trusts administered by Lord, Abbett Co. has been voted against all plans to pay company executives in a manner taxable as capital gain rather than income, Andrew J. Lord, president, declared yesterday in a letter to shareholders of Affiliated Fund, Inc., American Business Shares, Inc., and Union Trusteed Funds, Inc.

BUENOS AIRES, July 28 -- The Argentine press this morning printed ample summaries of the reactions in the United States, Great Britain and other countries to the memorandum on the Argentine situation that the State Department made public on Wednesday, as well as to the reply of Gen. Orlando Peluffo, Foreign Minister, on the same day.
Pistolhead, 2 1/2-year-old cocker spaniel, arrived home -- alone -- from the South Pacific late yesterday afternoon. For the first time since last June, Pistolhead barked with joy.

Decision was reserved yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Samuel Null in the suit brought by the Stork Club to restrain the city from interfering with its business. The court continued the order granted by Justice Ferdinand Pecora removing the "custodian" from the premises and set Aug. 4 for the filing of briefs.

Columbia University's football squad of 110 candidates, by far the largest in the Blue and White's gridiron history, concluded a month of summer training yesterday at Baker Field with Headcoach Lou Little and Line Coach Tad Wieman, former Princeton mentor, directing the session.

Patrolman Benjamin Miller, attached to the West 123d Street Station, Manhattan, and off duty, was entering his home at 310 South Fourth Street, Brooklyn, at 11 o'clock last night when two men sprinted by, shooting at each other.

Fiery blasts from Mayor La Guardia and others have greeted the introduction by landlords of an "up to 10 per cent rent increase clause, should the OPA permit it," on apartment rentals. The gist of these attacks is that the villainous landlord is trying to "put something over" on the unprotected and unsuspecting tenant.

ROME, July 28 (U.P.) -- On the Adriatic front Polish forces battled forward on a ten-mile line against weakening German resistance and patrols braved enemy mortar and artillery fire to cross the Misa River -- the second river barrier forced since the capture of the great port of Ancona.

New Yorkers in general are rather agreeable people. As an authority of nearly two months on the subject, I find the average considerate and well-mannered. But there is one variety that even country-bred tolerance cannot endure.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Dr. Hazel Stiebeling, who has been chief of the Bureau of Home Economics and Human Nutrition for a month, said today that clothing now seemed to be the problem of which people were becoming more and more conscious.

Operating results of the Texas Company, according to the report for the first six months of this year announced yesterday by W.S.S. Rodgers, chairman, disclosed an increase of $7,853,796 in earnings over the corresponding period a year ago.
LONDON, July 28 (AP) -- A European Theatre of Operations communique:
DETROIT, July 28 (AP) -- Cuffing Paul (Dizzy) Trout from the mound in the fifth inning, the Red Sox waltzed to a 15-to-5 victory over the Tigers today, sweeping an abbreviated three-game series.

WITH THE FIRST ARMY, Southwest of Canisy, July 28 -- The Americans met the Germans at Pont Brocard, a tiny village southwest of Canisy. There was a long line of American trucks and guns drawn up outside it as a sergeant hollered: "Come on you Heinies, get the hell outta there."

The Police Department, taking cognizance of the possibility of an early defeat of Germany, took steps yesterday toward a complete mobilization of its manpower and automotive equipment for policing the city on the day when the war in Europe ends.

Continuing their protest against the Police Department's recent invoking of an old ordinance governning rates that Central Park cabbies may charge, only eight of a customary twenty horse-drawn victorias were at their regular stands yesterday at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street.

Two national emergencies in one generation confirm the fact that lack of physical fitness in younger men is a serious problem. The Pepper Senate Subcommittee revealed that approximately one-third of the men examined for military service have been rejected for physical reasons. Now we are informed that Wac rejections are about 31 per cent.
Lee Q. Murray, heavyweight boxer from the Bronx, won the decision from Elbert (Turkey) Thompson of Los Angeles in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.

RICHMOND, Va., July 28 -- A score of patents on developments in the manufacture of rubber articles and others on a leather plastic and on an insulin preparation stand out among the 462 listed in the current issue of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

UNITED STATES NINTH AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS, Somewhere in Normandy, July 28 -- Dive-bombing and strafing German tanks, half tracks, trucks, thin-skinned vehicles and even horse-drawn wagons without aerial or ground opposition, United States Ninth Air Force fighter-bombers based in Normandy had the "best hunting" today of any twenty-four-hour period in this campaign.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 28 (AP) -- Communique 105:

LONDON, July 28 -- A C-47 hospital transport airplane, carrying American wounded home from the Normandy battlefield, crashed yes-day into the crags of the rugged Scottish coast at the Mull of Galloway, killing twenty-two occupants, including a nurse and a Royal Air Force man who was a passenger, as well as the crew of four.

LONDON, July 28 (AP) -- The Japanese today formally denied that they had executed American airmen from Superfortresses that raided Japan and said an "erroneous interpretation" had been placed on a broadcast by their Singapore propaganda station July 15.

LONDON, July 28 -- Following yesterday's bout of profit-taking which tended to price irregularities the stock markets today hardened and buyers came for industrials. Support was given to chain stores. breweries and motors and several other industrials put on a few pence.

NEWARK,-N.J., July 28 -- In the first imposition here of a jail sentence under a city ordinance dealing with violations of Office of Price Administration ceilings, Domingo Rio, 47 years old, was ordered in the First District Police Court today to serve ninety days for boosting rates at two small hotels and a rooming house he owns. He also was fined $600.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Department of Agriculture is urging a "new kind of international commodity collaboration" which would foster "orderly expansion of production" rather than restrict production, department experts said today.

Six religious radio programs will receive certificates of merit today at the annual meeting of the National Federation of Press Women at the Orrington Hotel, Evanston, Ill., it was announced here yesterday by Mrs. Joseph E. Goodbar, chairman of radio for the federation.
KANDY, Ceylon, July 28 (AP) -- A communique:

LONDON, July 28 (U.P.) -- German authorities, desperate in the face of Allied victories on all fronts, have resorted to more severe home-front restrictions, threatening death to anyone caught in possession of leaflets dropped by Allied planes, it was reported today.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Forces, Saturday. July 29 -- By a double thrust from the north and east tank-tipped spearheads have sliced off one body of German troops defending the western end of the Normandy battle line and three other columns are plunging south and west to carve off more segments.

The Rev. Dr. Jesse M. Bader is receiving felicitations on having just completed a decade as executive secretary of the Department of Evangelism of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, at 297 Fourth Avenue. He will be the preacher tomorrow at the 11 A.M. and the 8 P.M. services in the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

ALBANY, July 28 -- The extraordinary grand jury investigating alleged crime in Albany County handed down a twenty-nine-count indictment today accusing John J. Murphy, an Albany Democratic leader, of misappropriating $45,000 of party campaign funds.
Chief Justice D. Lawrence Groner of the Court of Appeals, District of Columbia, and Mrs. Groner have come from Washington to the Vanderbilt.

WITH AMERICAN TROOPS in France, July 29 -- The Germans pulled their battered Second Armored Division from the British front today and threw it into line against the American left flank in a determined effort to halt the drive that threatened to trap thousands of fleeing, disorganized Germans.

When foreign rehabilitation needs are satisfied after the war, our agricultural plant will be capable of producing enough food to provide a minimum adequate diet for all the people of the United States and even superior diets for the majority of the people, Marion Clawson, a research worker on the staff of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, reports in the current issue of The Antioch Review.

A special school for executives is to be held at Jackson's Mill, W.Va., from Aug. 15 to 24 under the auspices of the American Association of Teachers Colleges and the Commission on Teacher Education. It is expected that 150 college presidents and deans will attend this unique "school."

Spearheading the movement by South American countries for a firm foothold in the United States market, the Republic of El Salvador will open tomorrow a permanent exposition to promote the sale of a diversified line of merchandise produced specifically for the United States.

The New York Yacht Club will be one hundred years old today. Considered the greatest yacht club in the world, with only one comparable and that the Royal Yacht Squadron of Cowes, England, it has reached a stage at the end of a century where it is not a local New York institution, as its name implies, but a national one, known world-wide, although to many remotely.

VICTORY gardeners find it easy during summer to abide by the nutrition experts' edict that fresh, raw vegetables should be a part of the daily diet. The advice applies also to winter vegetables and fruits preserved from the summer garden.

Although there was a plethora of features on the program of Army and Navy night at the Lewisohn Stadium concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night, the foremost of them was the performance of Gershwin's "Rhapsody in Blue" by Sgt. Eugene List of the Army with the orchestra.

J. PAT O'MALLEY is that rara avis, a comedian who does not gauge the success of his efforts by the number of laughs he induces at each performance. On the contrary, the bogus South African of "Ten Little Indians" prefers his audiences silent as Cortez on a peak in Darien.

The appropriation at Cornell University of $1,000 for the purchase or production of films for use in connection with the course on Human Growth and Development was announced last week by President Edmund E. Day. The film-making project at Cornell is part of a larger program inaugurated by nine institutions engaged in teacher-training in up-State New York.

SALEM, N.H., July 29 -- Dashing to his second victory of the week, C. Rufi's 5-year-old sprinter, Mintlock, won the $5,000 added Raceland Handicap before 17,521 fans at Rockinham Park today, leading the field by three lengths.

APART from countenancing the existence of the Fascist Grand Council which last July voted Mussolini out of power, it has been remarked that the Duce's greatest error was to permit Benedetto Croce, distinguished Italian philosopher, to continue to live with comparative freedom in the midst of fascism.
From the east and from the west Allied spearheads made notable gains against Hitler's forces last week.

I CAN'T imagine anybody's being so dull in spirit as to write a critical review of Samuel Duff McCoy's book ". . . Nor Death Dismay." To go literary and squeeze phrases about it would be like professorizing to the martial sound of soldiers singing "The Caissons Are Rolling Along."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Sunday, July 30 -- Striking far to the west of the ground positions in New Guinea, American planes staged the first large-scale attack on Halmahera Island in the Moluccas, within 300 miles of the Philippines.

HARRISBURG, Pa., July 29 (AP) -- CIO representatives from all parts of Pennsylvania organized today the Pennsylvania Citizens Political Action Committee and urged "a rally to the call of liberalism" in the general election campaign.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sunday, July 30 -- The tactical success of the American armored offensive that has hacked to bits the Wehrmacht's defenses between the Vire River and the sea was acknowledged yesterday by the Germans who announced that the entire western wing of their forces in Normandy was being withdrawn.
ROME, July 29 (AP) -- A communique:

Resolutions calling for a clean Presidential campaign and condemning the injection of racial and religious issues into politics were adopted unanimously yesterday by the National Executive Committee of the Jewish War Veterans. At a quarterly meeting at the Hotel Commodore, the JWV also went on record as denouncing so-called "mother" organizations which "seek to destroy our democracy from within."
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Sunday, July 30 (AP) -- A communique:

AS someone may have pointed out, the trouble with an academic education is that it's so academic. Youth may have all the resources of fine libraries, with good guidance in their use; its teachers may be sound and forward looking.

SAMUEL GOLDWYN figuratively went on the warpath this week. In an interview, he criticized Hollywood for "making too many bad pictures"; declared that exhibitors, particularly the circuits, are taking advantage of both the public and the producers during the current era of box-office prosperity, and recommended that the public "go on strike against theatres which consistently show poor films on double-feature programs."

LONDON, July 29 -- There is a good deal of optimism in London this week-end regarding the outcome of Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk's visit to Moscow. It has just become known that Premier Stalin cabled Prime Minister Churchill a notification of his willingness to receive the Polish Premier and discuss Russian-Polish problems before the journey was begun.

THAT age-old theatrical poser which no one has ever really solved -- the one of creating foreign characters in a language other than their own -- is forcing the movie-makers into all sorts of incongruities these days when foreign stories are getting more and more play on the screen.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- President Roosevelt and high naval officials congratulated the Waves on the eve of the second anniversary of that organization tomorrow, when country-wide celebrations of the event will be held.

A hand-pulled bull rake is not a tool which appeals to a 14-year-old. A lad who enjoys swinging an axe or hiking long miles with a rifle considers raking after one of the worst jobs in the season's calendar.
HARTFORD, Conn., July 29 -- Nearly 100 dogs competed in the fifth annual obedience trials of the Hartford Obedience Training Club today on the east lawn of the Aetna Life Insurance Company grounds.

OMAHA, Neb., July 29 -- Farmers who have been perturbed over the possible growth of corporation or factory seed farming in the Middle West feel that they have scored a point for the family-sized farm in the manner in which these farms rallied their forces and beat weather adversity.

LONDON, July 29 (U.P.) -- Seeking recognition from Russia similar to that given to the French Forces of the Interior by the Allies, additional divisions of the Polish underground army, estimated at several hundred thousand men, will be thrown against the Germans in Poland alongside Russian troops, a Polish major general said today.

PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 29 (AP) -- Ken Thorburn, Toronto Argonauts' 32-year-old sculler, performed an iron man feat today by winning four singles events in the sixty-second annual Royal Canadian Henley Regatta, thus assuring Toronto the team honors for the third year in a row.

CHICAGO, July 29 -- The prolonged drought menacing crops from the Middle Atlantic States west to the Missouri River is absorbing the attention of Central Westerners while some farmers in their midst worriedly eye their sun-scorched acres.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- More than 4,000,000 men and more than 63,000,000 ship tons of supplies, or more than twice as much as in the first World War, have been shipped overseas in thirty-one months, according to a report of Maj. Gen. C.P. Gross, Chief of the Army Transportation Corps, issued today for publication on the eve of the corps' second birthday.

DETROIT, July 29 -- Events in the American League alter their course so rapidly these days that it is difficult to know just what to expect, and this afternoon proved no exception. The Yankees, who only yesterday were slamming the Indians for keeps in Cleveland, functioned against the Tigers as though they were running uphill and in sand.

Retail trade was generally good last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Main floor activity was brisk.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 29 -- Adolf Hitler's invulnerability was the main theme of the German radio this week, and Dr. Joseph Goebbels devoted much of his Wednesday night speech to the argument that God had taken the Fuehrer under His special protection.

"I READ the Bible every day and recommend you do the same," Gen. Sir Bernard Law Montgomery tells his staff. The commander of the Allied armies in Normandy -- like Oliver Cromwell, Stonewall Jackson, "Chinese" Gordon and Orde Wingate -- belongs to the tradition of "sword and Bible generals," great military leaders who have turned to the Bible for spiritual reinforcement.

PROVIDED the robots are licked, London will get a chance to rant or rave (if the New York pattern is followed) over Thornton Wilder's Pulitzer Prize winner, "The Skin of Our Teeth," according to word from abroad.

LIKE many another young American of his generation -- Col. Robert L. Scott of "God Is My Co-Pilot" fame is an outstanding example -- Capt. Edgar J. Wynn was obsessed from boyhood by the overwhelming urge to fly.

Two Tokyo broadcasts claimed that one of the B-29's that attacked targets in Manchuria was shot down, a Tokyo Italian-language broadcast stating that anti-aircraft defenses at Anshan were responsible for the plane.
