LONDON, Sunday, July 30 -- Russian troops yesterday fought within sight of Warsaw, the halfway mark in the offensive rolling along the road to Berlin, while in the north other Soviet units surged across the southern Latvian border in their swift drive against the almost-encircled Nazi armies of the Baltic.

IF Captain Tom Blythe hadn't been startlingly trustful for a naval officer, in time of war, young Jason Cobb wouldn't have left his stepfather's inn on a wintry night in 1814 in a desperate flight for his life. Nor would he have realized his ambition to go to sea quite so soon, on the frigate Thunderbolt, which, under the doughty Captain Tom, slipped through the British blockade, bound for Haiti.

PRIZE-WINNING delphiniums, seven feet tall and with florets three to four inches in diameter, attracted much attention at the recent flower show of the Horticultural Society of New York. The question that occurred to those who have tried growing delphiniums was what special routine was followed and how were the plants treated to produce such colossal spikes and giant flowers?

SAN FRANCISCO, July 29 -- It is easy this week on the West Coast to pick up wagers on the date of Germany's collapse and there is nothing simpler than promoting an argument over whether President Roosevelt lost votes out here by delivering his acceptance speech from a "Pacific Coast naval base."

LONDON, Sunday, July 30 (U.P.) The flying bomb offensive against civilian England continued into the early hours today. Yesterday the enemy stepped up the bomb schedule, apparently launching the robots from several points and timing them to reach the English coast simultaneously and in bunches.

Times and manners have changed in Germany since April, 1890, when Wilhelm II dismissed Bismarck. The amenities observed on that occasion are reflected in Sir John Tenniel's famous Punch cartoon, "Dropping the Pilot." Bismarck carried with him a formal expression of the Kaiser's "immortal gratitude."

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 29 -- Although she finished tenth in the Atlantic Class today with her sloop Carolina. Miss Charlotte Perry of the Pequot Yacht Club, Southport, Conn., maintained her lead in the Larchmont Race Week point scoring.

STRANGE things have happened in the South Pacific the last two and a half years -- things so incredible that you wouldn't believe them if you hadn't seen them, which makes Commander Chambliss' tall tale of what happened when the Japanese destroyer Hokaidokaze came steaming into a lagoon already occupied by a United States Navy seaplane tender sound almost plausible.

KOHLRABI is an interesting vegetable to grow and it provides a nice change in table fare, yet it is seen in proportionately few gardens. Many people have excluded it as a coarse and unsavory vegetable. But they may only have sampled it at an over-ripe stage.

Eight Latin-American teachers of English have returned to their countries after three months of study in the United States, where they examined American methods of teaching in an effort to improve instruction of English in their own schools.

Cotton merchants and exporters, individually and through their trade association, began last week a series of discussions on the future of cotton textiles as the rush of events presaged an earlier end to the war than had been anticipated.

AUSTIN, Tex., July 29 (AP) -- Fist fights and rump meetings broke out in bitterly contested Texas Democratic county conventions today as pro-Roosevelt forces pressed for control of State party machinery.

SOMEWHERE IN ITALY, July 29 -- As the war in Europe approaches its climax or perhaps even its end, everyone starts wondering how and through whom the Germans are going to sue for peace. Judging from stories being published in the United States and from other reports and rumors, millions of eyes are turning toward Vatican City.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- One of the first and major jobs to face political leaders in a campaign is to soften or smooth over disputes which come to light or are generated during the great quadrennial party conventions.

WHEN a gasoline dump in Africa caught fire and no fire-fighting apparatus was available a sergeant put it out by shoveling dirt on the flames with a bull-dozer, thereby saving a huge supply of precious fuel. In India four Liberator bombers were out of action because their generator cannon plugs, made of composition rubber, had cracked and broken.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Among 826 Army casualties announced today by the War Department were the following from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut:

A copy of the letter that Secretary of the Navy Forrestal sent to Congressman James C. Auchincloss announcing relaxation of the thirty-eight-foot rule for party-boat fishing off shore in the Fourth Naval District has been relayed here by the Long Beach Island (N. J.) Board of Trade.
I was very much interested in Anne O'Hare McCormick's column "Republicans and Democrats on Foreign Policy," in THE NEW YORK TIMES of July 26.

ACCORDING to his physician, Hardin Jeffers has only six months to live, but someone is unwilling to wait so long and Jeffers dies suddenly. Judge Peck is suspicious and arranges for an autopsy, which proves that Jeffers died of oxalic acid poisoning.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The general index of basic commodity prices based on the August, 1939, level, declined from 182.3 on July 21 to 182.0 on July 28, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
Adequate police protection of polling places in Tuesday's primaries is planned in a directive issued by Acting Police Commissioner Louis F. Costuma last night.
CHUNGKING, China, July 29 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

The German news agency DNB said yesterday that Col. Gen. Heinz Guderian, new German Army Chief of Staff, had boasted that "the present Soviet assault will not only be broken but the Bolshevist intruders will again be thrown out of all the territory that at present they are devastating so cruelly."

A gray horse named First Fiddle, ridden by a courageous but ailing jockey named Johnny Longden, yesterday at Jamaica captured by a nose the $56,350 Butler Handicap, richest feature of the Empire City meeting which came to the end of its twenty-four days with record-breaking betting of approximately $50,000,000.

LAKE PLACID -- With interest mounting daily in Lake Placid's thirteenth annual midsummer figure-skating operetta, to be presented at the Olympic Arena Thursday, Friday and Saturday nights and at a special Saturday matinee, the season here is rapidly approaching its height, with all hotels and rooming houses filled.

The United Seamen's Service will add four units to its world-wide chain of rest and recreation clubs for American merchant seamen with the opening, in the near future, of two additional clubs in Australia and two in Arabia, Douglas P. Falconer, executive director of the service, announced yesterday.
KANDY, Ceylon, July 29 (UP) -- A communique:
PHILADELPHIA, July 29 -- Here is Connie Mack's all-time, all-star team of living baseball players:

Physicists attending the recent meeting of the American Physical Society at the University of Rochester (N. Y.) watched Prof. Felix Ehrenhaft present the most dramatic evidence so far in support of his hypothesis that "not only electric currents but also magnetic currents flow through the universe."

DES MOINES, July 29 (AP) -- Vice President Wallace said today that the Democratic party could succeed in the November elections "only if it brings the farmer and the worker together on a liberal, constructive platform," and that one function of "a liberal, constructive Democratic party is to keep the West and the South united."
PEARL HARBOR, July 29 -- "Orote Peninsula is ours," Adm. Chester W. Nimitz announced tonight, reporting the outstanding triumph of the invasion of Guam.

IS Turkey about to give the Allies the "go ahead" signal? The military and political significance of such a Turkish decision, the indications of recent days that it may be in the making, and Dr. Jackh's distinguished reputation as an interpreter of Turkey's policies make it impossible not to note at once the answers to that question which he gives in the last chapter of this book.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 29 (AP) -- J. Kenneth Bradley, who has been at odds for some time with Governor Baldwin over party policies, resigned today as State Republican chairman, saying that he did so "in the interest of party harmony and party welfare."

LONDON, July 29 -- Recent happenings within the Reich have provoked a rather critical examination of Allied policy toward Germany in some quarters here. The question is being asked whether "unconditional surrender" is not a term that needs definition, or at least delimitation.

Pointing out that the job-producing possibilities of a greater foreign trade and a larger merchant marine are being somewhat overlooked, Robert H. Patchin, vice president of W.R. Grace Co. and the Grace Line, maintains that a permanent step up of prewar levels of agricultural, mineral and industrial production will be necessary to keep our national yearly income over $100,000,000 during the post-war era.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Continuance and extension of the World Court, organized in 1922 at The Hague as "the highest tribunal of an accessible system of interrelated permanent international courts with obligatory jurisdictions," and the setting up or a permanent International Circuit Court in the capital of each member nation were among recommendations made in a report issued here today by the coordinating committee of the American Bar Association's Section of International and Comparative Law.

ADDED to the general curiosity about the picture "Wilson," which has its premiere Tuesday night, there has been some minor speculation as to why an Irish woman was chosen for the role of Edith Galt Wilson, the second wife of the World War I President.
ROME, July 29 -- Interested parties are deliberately holding back the publication of the late Count Ciano's diary, the Communist newspaper Unita charged today.

Retailers will have difficulty in obtaining enough cotton merchandise for their holiday business, particularly in towels and bedspreads, as nearly all bedspread looms are converted to Government production, and it does not seem likely that jacquard spreads will be available for the remainder of the year, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Sunday, July 30 (AP) -- Allied patrol planes have kept octopus-shaped Halmahera under constant survey, and many surface vessels have been sunk in surrounding waters and in harbors. The first assault against land installations in months was reported last week in an undetailed bombing of villages.

NOT since the Hoover-Smith campaign of 1928 has there been so much speculation as there has been this year over the South's probable course in a Presidential contest. A well-nigh unprecedented number of newspaper men crossed the Potomac and the Ohio in the spring of last year, bent upon exploring the political predilections of the Southern States, and they have been coming ever since.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

HAVANA, July 29 (U.P.) -- Eugenio de Sosa Jr., acting director of Diario de la Marina, today announced he had sent his seconds to Dr. Guillermo Belt, challenging him to a duel, as the result of Dr. Belt's "interference" in Mr. de Sosa's published attacks against United States Ambassador Spruille Braden.

The chief organizers of the German generals' revolt against Hitler "were two men, Col. Gen. Zeitzler, Chief of Staff of the German Amy, and Col. Gen. Fritz Fromm, Commander in Chief of the Reserve Army and Chief of Army Equipment," according to "a reliable report reaching London," quoted by the British radio last night.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 27 (Delayed) (AP) -- The Government of Premier Ivan Bagrianoff has asked Germany to evacuate all German armed forces from Bulgaria, and there are indications that the request may be heeded, according to information received here today. The Bulgars reportedly were told that the Government would defend the nation against attack "from any quarter."

IS the Russian revolution over, or at least is it settling down, as other revolutionary movements have done, to something more mellow and conservative? And if so, what does this mean for the future of Russia and her relations with the rest of the world?

FORT LEONARD WOOD, Mo., July 29 (AP) -- Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, speaking at a conference of officers of the Army Service Forces, declared today that the falling-off in production of important items in the Army supply program was a result of public feeling that the war was about over.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- Ten new areas in nine States are being brought under rent control Tuesday, the Office of Price Administration stated today.

ABOARD EXPEDITIONARY FLAGSHIP, off Tinian, July 27 (Delayed) -- Pushing Japanese garrison troops steadily backward, a great weight of American men and metal bore down today on the town of Tinian, largest unconquered, all-Japanese settlement in the Marianas Islands.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 29 (AP) -- The Christiana Stable's Alexis withstood a grueling stretch drive with the Longchamps Farms' Bill Corum today to earn a nose decision in the William Penn Stakes at Garden State Park. In the six-furlong dash seven youngsters engaged, and Mrs. John W. Stanley's Freddie's Pal was third before Max Wexler's Agate.

"A MAN reading a play is better than a man seeing one," William Saroyan once wrote in a preface -- an observation that hardly seems to apply to the best of his own works, since to miss the spectacle of a Saroyan play is to miss half the fun.

ALLAN A. MICHIE originally intended to write a book limited to his ideas on how to keep the peace through air power. He apparently thought most Americans realized that the peace will have to be kept -- that it will not keep itself, but will have to be enforced -- and was concerned only with arguing in favor of one method of enforcement as opposed to others.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 29 -- (AP) -- A high ranking officer in Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's command spoke out today against what he said was a tendency of military writers -- both British and American -- to compare gains made by the British and American armies in the Normandy campaign.

ROME, July 29 (AP) -- The final phase of the battle for Florence opened violently in the rolling hills to the south today as veteran New Zealanders of the British Eighth Army drove to a point just five miles below the city and the Germans quickly countered every Allied thrust with strong forces of Mark VI tanks.

Current widespread interest in post-war tax planning is a healthy sign for the future welfare of the free-enterprise system. The nation appears to have become tax-conscious. While the saying that "the power to tax is the power to destroy" long has been recognized as a possibility, it has been accepted more and more over the years as a real threat to our economy.

THE walled city of Quebec, set on its mighty rock, is "the oldest and the most picturesque seaport on the American continent," as the publishers state with truth on the jacket of this book. Its story is the story of a new continent and the struggle of two great powers for its control.

THE Mexican War of 1848 gave Texas to the United States, but it did not make gringos of the Spanish-Indian settlers on our side of the border. Generations of them have come and gone in the South Texas brush country, living as their fathers lived, speaking only Spanish -- Mexican still, in spite of their birth on American soil.

LONDON, July 29 (U.P.) -- The Moscow radio announced tonight that Premier Stalin had received the Order of Victory by order of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet Council in recognition of his direction of the Red Army in its triumphant summer offensive.

BRAZIL has commemorated with a 40-centavo blue, yellow and red stamp the centenary of the founding of the Young Men's Christian Association. Inscribed are the dates 1844 and 1944 and "Centenario da Associacao Christa de Mocos" and the design features the Y.M.C.A.'s triangular emblem surrounded by the words America, Europa, Asia, Oceania and Africa.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The official Argentine Government's defense of its actions in relation to the Axis holds that Argentina is aiding the United Nations' war effort by lending products that now are better than a money loan.

I SUPPOSE nearly everybody hates something in particular about the modern theatre. You yourself may hate box-office managers, or ballets, or pathological comedy, and your best friend may hate revolving stages, or ebullient adolescents, or Hammond organs in productions of Shakespeare.

UNITED STATES NINTH AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS in Normandy, July 29 -- The roads south, east and west of the Coutances area were choked today with battered, burned-out and abandoned German tanks and motor vehicles of all types as American planes maintained their pressure on German elements attempting to get east of the American break-through in their line.

ROME, July 29 (AP) -- Allied warplanes from Italian bases shot down twelve Nazi planes during yesterday's operations, featured by an attack by more than 500 heavy bombers of the United States Fifteenth Air Force on oil targets at Ploesti.

YENAN, China, July 24 (Delayed) -- The downfall of the Tojo Cabinet was precipitated by recent Japanese defeats in the Pacific, particularly on Saipan, and mounting unrest, sometimes accompanied by sabotage, Shushumu Okano, leader of the Japanese Communist party, said today.
LONDON, July 29 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces communique:

STOCKHOLM (By Wireless). EVENTS of the last weeks have brought Germany's defeat perceptibly nearer. The stage now appears to be set for that Wagnerian twilight of the gods about which Adolf Hitler and his Nazis have long been talking as the only alternative to Nazi victory. A point of legitimate curiosity is to what extent the Nazis are prepared to carry out that threat now that their hand may soon be called.

HAMILTON, N.Y., July 29 -- A resolution calling for immediate creation of an international organization to establish and preserve world peace was unanimously accepted today by one section of the New York State Citizens' Conference at Colgate University and presented to the conference for consideration tonight.

ON gigantic sound Stage 7 at Warners, where only recently a Liberty ship was burning down for "Action in the North Atlantic" and where Errol Flynn was weaving his way through made-to-order snow for 'Northern Pursuit," the industrious Warner craftsmen have recreated a Welsh village for the picturization of "The Corn Is Green," Emalyn Williams' play about a young Welsh miner and a school teacher who sets him on the road to culture.

CANISY, France, July 29 (AP) -- Captured Germans told a senior American staff officer today that Field Marshal Gen. Erwin Rommel had been critically wounded in an Allied air strafing attack. A French Red Cross worker said they had told her that he had died later.

THOSE bright drifts of color that summer-flowering bulbs lend to a border were never as apparent as now, when bulbs planted earlier in the season are getting into full bloom. Should a garden not boast a few of these, this is the time to see them elsewhere, and add choices to the preferred list for next season.

LONDON, July 29 -- This scarred capital and other parts of southern England have now been under assault from flying bombs more than six weeks. Time has not made the experience any more pleasant or eased the abnormal life imposed on millions by the Germans' use of this indiscriminate weapon.
BOSTON, July 29 (AP) -- Rip Sewell, Pittsburgh's featherball hurler, today chalked up his eleventh victory as he pitched a five-hit shutout at the expense of the Braves. The score was 3 -- 0.

The availability of adequate funds will be an important requirement in reconverting our war plants to the production of civilian goods. Three Government agencies have now spoken on this problem. Last February the Survey of Current Business of the United States Department of Commerce estimated that business had sufficient funds in the aggregate to finance the transition to the pre-war level of peace-time output and some expansion above the pre-war level.

BOOK jacket blurbs usually come under the department of super-colossal overstatement. With Michael Venning's latest mystery novel the publishers say: "We make this challenge: once you have read the introductory chapter, nothing short of fire or flood will prevent you from reading 'Jethro Hammer'."

PAWLING, N.Y., July 29 -- The complete itinerary of Thomas E. Dewey's first Presidential campaign trip, starting at midnight tomorrow, was made public today as the candidate arrived here to spend a day at his farm prior to departure.

Representative Hamilton Fish's "narrow nationalist views and associations are the inevitable producers of anti-Semitism and a dozen other perils to democracy," Wendell L. Willkie, Republican candidate for President in 1940, said yesterday in offering his legal services to the group fighting Mr. Fish's bid for renomination in the new Twenty-ninth Congressional District.

DETROIT, July 29 -- Recent wildcat strikes in Detroit's war plants are a symptom of labor-management antagonisms which forecast a post-war period of great turmoil in labor relations, it is generally conceded here.

THE recent extension of the useful radio spectrum to wave lengths with respect to the physical size of radio apparatus has changed the analytical approach to high frequency engineering. Yet the approach is classical because, the short-cuts and simplifications of ordinary low frequency theory having proved inadequate, recourse is necessary to the fundamental field equations set forth in the last century by Clerk Maxwell.

The Petroleum Administration for War held out to motorists of the New York metropolitan area yesterday the prospect of a sufficient civilian supply of gasoline during August to redeem all legitimate ration coupons.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- It took Sgt. Manuel S. Gonzales of Fort Davis, Tex., just one hour after he went into action to win the Distinguished Service Cross, the War Department said today.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- Donald F. Cameron, secretary of the Confederated Unions of America, which is not affiliated with the AFL or CIO, said today that denial to the independent unions of membership on the War Labor Board had convinced them that "the Democratic party is playing politics in its labor policy."

A SUPERFORTRESS BASE IN WESTERN CHINA, July 29 (AP) -- The powerful force of B-29 bombers that blasted the heart of Japan's "arsenal of greater East Asia" today was the Superfortresses' first attack from high altitudes as well as by daylight.

In this era so prodigiously prolific in secret weapons and political slogans another term has recently been launched which is destined to become the object of passionate debate. This term is "super-state." It sounds terrifying.

Supreme Court Justice Benjamin F. Schreiber signed yesterday an order restraining the city from proceeding tomorrow with its scheduled public sale of the assets of the La Vie Parisienne, 3 East Fifty-second Street, one of the three clubs against which the city has placed a claim for unpaid sales taxes.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (U.P.) -- Congressional leaders began a race with allied military forces today to pass demobilization and reconversion legislation by the time Germany is knocked out of the war.
Stocks did nothing of importance yesterday. The dull trend of the week continued and volume was the smallest in two months. Prices drifted aimlessly and closed mixed.

Secondary education is destined to become universal throughout the United States in the post-war period, in the opinion of George L. Maxwell, new dean of administration at the University of Denver. Dean Maxwell has just concluded a study of post-war education and is one of the authors of a book in this field for the National Education Association.

FIFTH ARMY ADVANCE HEADQUARTERS, Italy, July 29 -- Two German mines, stepped on by an American soldier, exploded with a terrific roar today within 300 yards of a table where King George VI, Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark, Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of New York and Gen. Sir Harold R.L.G. Alexander were at lunch.

A CERTAIN practical shrewdness in New Englanders is harnessed to their militant morality. The combination has produced successful men in many fields. Persons very little better than the wicked have remarked at times that what distinguishes this shrewdness from low cunning is mainly the fact that it is applied in the service of high principles.

FOR twenty years the commercial theatre in America has been steadily contracting. It has finally reached the point where New York has practically ceased to exist as a center of theatre culture. Instead, Broadway is becoming more and more exclusively an amusement center.

THOUGH radio is not the easiest of the arts about which to grow sentimental, it being an impersonal and one-dimensional medium, as compared with the lushly storied theatre, it does have its more nostalgic moments.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 29 -- The Brazilian note on the United States-Argentine situation, released late last night, reaffirms once again the continental solidarity that Brazil has always tried to maintain. At the same time, the note carries a strong message to Argentina that in the present struggle for liberty the security of the Americas was threatened and Argentina did not respond.

BRIDGE, the first game played with the exposed dummy, was introduced in 1897. In the forty-seven years since then certain items of standard technique have come to be so universally accepted that experienced players use them automatically.

The Office of Price Administration announced yesterday the arrest of the first motorist in this five-State region to be indicted on a criminal charge for alleged ration cheating. The defendant, Harold Kilmer of 88 Railroad Avenue, Waterbury, Conn., is alleged to have created for himself a double-A gasoline rating by the expedient of having registered with two different local rationing boards for an A book.

Last week President Roosevelt was still traveling, far from heat-deadened Washington on an inspection trip. His movements were hidden by wartime censorship, a fact that aroused some Republican ire. Whether he was conferring with local Democratic leaders along the way would not be known until his return.

TO a windswept little cottage in County Kerry, "where the butter is sweet and the mountains are dark and wild," came Molly the Rogue, one day, carried in a basket, for no one had ever seen the old beggar-woman walk.

MOSCOW, July 29 -- Moving irresistibly forward on an 800-mile front stretching from the Gulf of Finland to the foothills of the Carpathian Mountains, Soviet troops this week battered down the German defenses at the gateways to Warsaw.

Senator Pepper's proposal for establishing a national Old Folks' Day deserves, we feel, the support of the Senate and the rest of the country. We don't quite like his selection of October as the month in which to honor the old folks. It suggests the evening of life.

MR. HARRINGTON has here given pleasing proof that an academic publication may be scholarly without being dull. This is the story, humanly and historically interesting and typically American, of Dr. Horace N. Allen, who brought the Gospel message and some rudiments of modern medicine to Korea and, in the author's words, "combined intrigue with soul-saving and became a dollar diplomat."

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- By far the biggest question mark in the Pacific as this week -- another period of unchecked advances for American forces -- drew to a close was the question of future Japanese strategy.

UNITED STATES EIGHTH AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS, England, July 29 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. James H. Doolittle, commander of the Eighth Air Force, asserted tonight at a United States War Bond rally, "We have got the Hun groggy."

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Japanese industrial targets, bombed early today by the Superfortresses of the United States Twentieth Bomber Command in their first daylight attack, were given in a War Department bulletin late today as Anshan, Manchuria, and Tangku, the port for the metropolitan center of Tientsin in occupied China.

WITH 116TH INFANTRY REGIMENT in France, July 23 (Delayed (AP) -- They passed out Presidential citations today to officers and doughboys who cracked St. Lo, the eastern hinge of the German battleline, and it was a sad ceremony to many because the "Major of St. Lo" was not alive to receive his.

THE most important postal piece in the collection of the late Col. E.H.R. Green is the only known block of eight of the United States 1918 24-cent air-mail stamps with inverted center, and it was announced last week by Walter S. Scott, who appraised the Green philatelic holdings at around $1,290,000, that this item will be offered when the next section of the collection is sold at auction, in November, by Harmer, Rooke Co.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The House Committee investigating the Federal Communications Commission may conduct another hearing Tuesday on the case of two Government employes of Japanese descent in whose apartment the committee last week seized restricted foreign broadcast files.

WITH neither the supply nor the quality of meat altogether satisfactory these days, it is good to know that chicken is unusually plentiful, and will continue so through most of September. Farmers are culling their flocks -- that is, they are sending to market the poor layers -- and the Government asks households to use the abundance in every sort of dish -- chicken fricassee, salad, croquettes and the like.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department was virtually closed today as an unrestricted source of information for the press, the trade and others on Government negotiations with foreign countries and agencies relating to agricultural commodities.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, ALLIED EXPEDITIONARY FORCE (By Wireless). A COLLECTION of squat, unimpressive buildings, not unlike the factories that have mushroomed all over this country since the war began, is the secret place from which the liberation of a continent is being directed.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (U.P.) -- An Army transport plane carrying twenty-six persons, including eighteen litter patients, was lost at sea somewhere between Iceland and Newfoundland Wednesday morning, the War Department announced today.

SUN FO is one of the most thoughtful of China's leaders, but by no means one of the most influential. There may be a causal relation between these two facts. He is the head of the Legislative Yuan, which would be the equivalent of a parliament if it had any legislative powers, as it has not.
MOSCOW, July 29 -- How a Russian private captured Lieutenant General Bamler, commander of the German Twelfth Infantry Division, was told today in the army newspaper, Red Star.

CHICAGO, July 29 (AP) -- Butler Brothers reported today a consolidated net profit of $561,443 for the first six months of 1944, equal, after dividend requirements of the preferred stock, to 31 cents a share. Net income for the corresponding period last year was $662,284, or 41 cents a share.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- In the third of four steps by which the War Production Board seeks to enable manufacturers to press forward preparations for the day when they will be permitted to turn to the manufacture of peacetime products, the board authorized today non-priority purchase orders for fifteen types of capital equipment, including machine tools and manufacturing machinery.

ONE of the hopeful signs of our time is the appearance of books which approach the problems of a long-lasting and well-founded peace from an understanding of the concrete situation. The material -- nations and men -- with which peace has to be established will not be ideal; if we wish to avoid dream castles or make-believe, it will be the only material with which we can build in the world of reality.

Admiral King, Commander in Chief of the United States Fleet, confirms what was obvious from the beginning: namely, that the fall of the Tojo Cabinet and the installation of General Koiso, the "Tiger of Korea," as head of a new Government in Tokyo will bring no aid or comfort to our side.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, July 29 (U.P.) -- Troops of the British Fourteenth Army today had pushed to within seven miles of the Burma border in the southeast Manipur and less than nine miles from the town of Tamu, the jumping-off point for the vaunted Japanese invasion of India last March.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Relations between the United States and Argentina, so long complicated by differing viewpoints on problems of the Americas, and in recent months by the attitude of the pro-Axis regime in Buenos Aires, reached the highest point of tension and what had the aspects of a complete deadlock when the State Department published this week its summary of our position toward the administration of President Edelmiro J. Farrell.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 29 -- If there is one phase of training that appeals to members of the State Guard most, veteran and 17-year-old rookies alike, it is firing for record in the rifle teats. Feeling that way about it, the units of the Fifth Brigade of Brooklyn went on the range at Camp Smith here and qualified the highest percentage of entries of any command to enter camp this season.

A NUMBER of recent minor publications of the Metropolitan Museum are of more than casual interest. One of them is a small conveniently arranged guide to the collections, with floor plans and a listing of the material on exhibition by departments and galleries.

CHUNGKING, China, July 29 -- (AP) -- Bitterly intensified fighting for the prized railway town of Hengyang, with the Japanese making more than ten attacks in a single day, was announced tonight by the Chinese High Comman, which said Chinese positions still stood firm.

Local race problems from various parts of the nation are being subjected to research at the Workshop in Intercultural Education which has just opened at Teachers College, Columbia University. To this laboratory teachers and principals are bringing for discussion and possible solution situations of their own communities which have been brought on by prejudice and discrimination against any minority groups -- both national and religious as well as racial.

Along with the growing interest in hair ornaments, the humble barrette has returned to play a stellar role. Always functional, barrettes are now decorative, especially when they are placed in the hair with imagination, according to Lura de Gez, hair stylist.

The first ancestor of all the legislatures of North America came into being 325 years ago today at Jamestown, Va. Those who have visited this lovely, enchanted spot, now only a place of memorials, will recall the historic church, with its three-century-old brick tower. The first Virginia -- and American -Legislature met in a wooden building on the site where the brick church was to be erected twenty years later.

"99 Park," headquarters of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, Inc.,* offers a partial list of free amusements available today, through the generosity of the entertainment world. Afternoon tickets from 11 A.M.; evening tickets after 4 P.M. Apply 99 Park Avenue (at Fortieth Street) for tickets.

Defending the post-war national fiscal and monetary plan submitted to the National Planning Association and made public last week, Beardsley Ruml, co-author with H.C. Sonne, asserted last night in a talk over the Columbia Broadcasting System that popular discussion and understanding of Federal fiscal policy would aid greatly in bringing about the conditions of high production and high employment, which we so much desire.
Yesterday's first communique, as broadcast in English to North America from Chungking and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

WHITE PLAINS, July 29 -- One contest will face the voters in Westchester County in Tuesday's primary. Joseph E. Venuti of Eastchester, regular Democratic organization candidate, is opposed by Mrs. Aranya Smart of Yonkers for the Democratic nomination for Representative in the new Twenty-seventh Congressional District.

Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican national chairman, announced yesterday that he would depart on Tuesday for a series of conferences with party leaders in the Midwest, thus accelerating the campaign for the election of Governor Dewey and his running mate, Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio.

THE twenty-five stories and twenty-eight cartoons in this book are winners in a contest sponsored by the Armed Forces Service League, whose fiction judges were Clifton Fadiman, Maj. Francis P. Frazier, AUS, and Lieut. Max C. Miller, USNR.

The drive of Soviet armies across the plains of Poland last week brought into sudden focus the dispute between Moscow and the Polish Government in Exile. In this dispute lay a basic problem in future international relations -- the question of Russia's intentions toward neighboring states and post-war Europe in general.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 29 -- Staging a five-run rally in the sixth inning, Princeton's baseball team chalked up a 6-4 victory over Pennsylvania today. Dutch Rohner, Nassau southpaw, received credit for the triumph, although Jim Anthony's final two rounds of hitless ball were needed to clinch the contest.

THE mountain village where Pierre kept watch over his townspeople's sheep had deliberately allowed itself to be forgotten when the Nazis overran France. But even its closely guarded secret could not escape those greedy eyes forever, and when the Germans burned the next hamlet Pierre, the good shepherd, found himself a very active part of the underground movement.

WITH the fall season just around the corner, concert managers report that this is going to be a busy year. Elizabeth Mathews, head of the recital department of Columbia Concerts, Inc., reports that eighty-seven recitals have already been scheduled by her firm for the New York concert halls next season, and that this figure represents a 25 per cent increase over the corresponding period last year.

CHICAGO, July 29 -- Mill buying of wheat futures, said to be against sales of fllour to the Army, advanced prices fractionally in the early trading today on the Board of Trade, but hedging pressure increased on the upturn and the market reacted, closing at about the bottom with losses of 1/4 to 3/8 cent a bushel from Friday's final prices.

Week-end covering by professional traders helped lift the cotton futures market from a slight early decline, and final prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were 3 to 6 points net higher on active months than Friday's close.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 29 -- Defying business agents of their union, a few machinists went to work today at the Federal-Mogul Corporation plant and sent out word that "it is time now to determine who rules our country and whether we are really a free people.''

In your article headed "War-News Films," appearing in THE TIMES June 25, you, using the device of comparison between the newsreel invasion releases and the War Department's six-reel film, "The Battle of New Britain," announced that "the newsreel as presently constituted is obsolescent if not obsolete." With that critical pronouncement I take violent issue.
DETROIT, July 29 (AP) -- Henry Ford, who will be 81 years old tomorrow, visualizes a "great age" ahead, "if we apply what we have learned and mix it with plenty of hard work."

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- Representative Dies of Texas announced tonight that a subcommittee of his House Committee on Un-American Affairs would investigate the CIO Political Action Committee. He did not announce the personnel of the subcommittee.

AMONG the many books about Japan that have appeared since Pearl Harbor few are more worth reading than this unpretentious story of an Englishman who spent four years in Tokyo as a teacher and technical adviser to the Foreign Office.

The Bethlehem Steel Company's Staten Island yard will launch on Thursday a 2,200-ton superdestroyer honoring the Marine Corps' first aircraft pilot, the late Lieut. Col. Alfred A. Cunningham. Mrs. Cunningham, his widow, will be sponsor for the new warship, designated by the Navy as the U. S. S. Alfred A. Cunningham (DD 752).
Hadley Cantril's article, "What We Don't Know Is Likely to Hurt Us," is, in my opinion, one of the most important and provocative of the year.

ED WYNN, who as "The Fire Chief" chalked up record popularity ratings a decade ago, is returning to the air this fall. He will portray "King Bubbles" in a program called "Happy Island" and will be heard from 7 to 7:30 P.M. Fridays on the Blue network and WJZ, beginning Sept. 8.

Eugene G. Grace, president of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, said at a New York press conference last week that he was "frankly optimistic" on the manpower situation for the future, both as a result of a meeting with Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, and because of the practical measures taken by local offices of the commission in plant cities.
KWEILIN, China, July 25 (Delayed) -- In the burning heat of late July Kweilin cannot make up its mind. A month ago the city was certain the Japanese were coming.

Brought here from Canada after a four-month legal fight against extradition, Ralph M. Wilby, 39 years old, of Vancouver, B.C., who formerly lived at 78-11 Seventy-eighth Street, Jackson Heights, Queens, was arraigned yesterday before Judge Jacob Gould Schurman in the Court of General Sessions on a seventeen-count indictment charging grand larceny.

LONDON, July 29 -- A settlement of the quarrel between the Soviet Union and the Polish Government in London can be expected, not a settlement that will please everyone, least of all the Polish nationalists, but nevertheless a settlement.

PORTSMOUTH, Va., July 29 (AP) -- More than 600 Army and Navy casualties, most of them wounded on D-day, were returned to the United States today on the Navy hospital ship Refuge, the former President Garfield of the Dollar Line.

THIS is the time of the year when America takes to the road. The time when automobile travel reaches its peak. The time when we are all most vulnerable to the insidious suggestion: "Fill 'er up?" It is, also, open season for the gasoline black market.

LA MERI and her company will present a program of Hindu, Spanish and Polynesian dances at the Ethnologic Theatre, 110 East Fifty-ninth Street, on Tuesday evening at 9. The program will be as follows: "Ushas," "Alarippu," excerpts from the ballet, "Krishna-Gopala" (Hindu); "Jota de Concierto," "Evocation," "Garrotin," "Bolero" (Spanish); "Alekoki," "Grass Shack," "Hoheeno Keia," "Samoan Song,"

Ace Adams either forgets that schoolroom adage about the burnt child dreading the fire, or places no stock in it at all. That's why the Giants yesterday had to be content with an even split in their twin bill with Bill McKechnie's Reds before a gathering of 9,673 spectators at the Polo Grounds.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 29 -- The United States Eighth Air Force put 2,000 planes over Germany today in a second-day bombing of the big Leuna synthetic oil plants at Merseburg and an attack on the port of Bremen.

WITH THE FIRST PROVISIONAL MARINE BRIGADE, on Guam, July 24 (Delayed) -- An audacious Japanese who walked boldly into an American command post near Agat and picked up a box of grenades touched off a dawn battle in which twenty-five Americans commanded by Lieut. Dennis Chavez Jr., son of the New Mexico Senator, slew sixty-eight Japanese.

THE biggest ripple in the summer calm of the New York art world last week was occasioned by the announcement on Tuesday of the purchase prizes and honorable mentions in the "Portrait of America" competition conducted under the auspices of Artists for Victory acting on behalf of the Pepsi-Cola Company.

BUENOS AIRES, July 29 -- President Edelmiro Farrell and War Minister Juan Peron reaffirmed Argentina's determination to defend her "dignity, honor and rights" in brief addresses they delivered this afternoon to a large meeting organized by labor unions in front of the Foreign Ministry.

A FEW nights ago in Radio City we saw our first longhair television experiment in videoing opera. Two scenes from operas calculated to entertain and to offer the intimate effects at present most adaptable for television purposes were

COMMISSAIRE Saturnin Dax of the Paris Surete is baffled by a series of murders, each signed with a playing card -- the ace of spades for the first, the deuce for the second, and so on. The first victim is a taxi driver, the second a photographer, and in each ease there is a promise of more to come.

THE Berkshire Museum will hold a one-man exhibition of work by Reginald Marsh, lent by the Rehn Gallery, from Aug 3 to 31. The annual summer members' night at the Berkshire Museum will be held on Aug. 3.

Teachers should work more closely with the community and participate in organizations and agencies that are trying to improve community conditions, it is recommended in a comprehensive study on teacher education prepared for the American Council on Education, made public last week.

The extraction by scientists of the United States Department of Agriculture of a valuable new drug from the leaves of bright, or flue-cured, tobacco is announced by the department's Eastern Regional Research Laboratory. The new medicine, named rutin, has been found to be a valuable glucoside (sugar) which is effective in treating conditions arising from high blood pressure associated with increased fragility of the small blood vessels (capillaries).

Testimony before the Murray War Contracts Subcommittee in Washington has outlined the future of American airpower with clarity and, it must be said, with surprising unanimity on the part of the witnesses. It has long been written in the skies that we must have and maintain military air forces far stronger than we have ever had before.

CHICAGO, July 29 -- Miss Ethel Hill of Beverly Hills, Calif., a movie script writer, possibly never wrote a scenario with more thrills than her thoroughbred -- War Knight -- provided for her today while galloping to an upset victory in the $56,200 Arlington Handicap at Washington Park.

With nothing more tangible than the meager description of "a dirty blue car" to go on, two radio patrolmen in Astoria rounded up early yesterday morning a gang of four deaf mutes -- one of them a woman -- that they said was responsible for attacking fifteen women and snatching their handbags in recent weeks.

OIL CITY, Pa., July 29 -- Lieut. Col. Francis S. Gabreski, highest ace pilot in the American Army with thirty-one enemy planes to his credit, was reported today as missing in action while his home town was preparing a welcome home celebration and preparations were being made for his wedding.

Encouraged by recent developments such as release of aluminum for production of civilian goods which will have a far reaching effect on the production of household goods, more than 2,300 buyers representing stores in all parts of the country attended the Housewares Show at the Hotel Pennsylvania last week.

TO satisfy the curiosity of American allies visiting the Dale of Skelt the venerable Archdeacon Trevining sets out to resurrect the Earl of Skeltby's murder. To allow the archdeacon to tell the story in his own way his creator. P.W. Wilson (former M.P. and veteran journalist). modestly effaces himself in favor of the gentle, prosy old cleric.
LONDON, July 29 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 29 (AP) -- Communique 107:

Jack McManis, the transplanted Californian who is the No. 2 seeded player in the New York State clay court championship now nearing its conclusion at the Seminole Club in Forest Hills, advanced to the final round yesterday as a result of an easy triumph over Nicholas Buzolich, towering 6-foot-7 basketball player from San Pedro, Calif.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, July 29 -- The arrival of a trained nurse of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America under Government sponsorship for a lecture tour has touched off a controversy in which Catholic clergymen have warned their congregations to shun the lectures and the Welfare Society -- an organization with nurses working principally among the poor -- has refused cooperation with the Health Department, deeming the birth-control scheme "outside the work of the society."

The proposed allocation of cash and securities to the Southwestern Railroad under the trustee-sponsored plan of the Central of Georgia Railway was defended yesterday by Earl F. Bidez of the accounting department of the Central of Georgia in rebuttal testimony at an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing at the Hotel St. George in Brooklyn before Examiner R.T. Boyden.
In the article about Mayor La Guardia's broadcasts mention is made of the sundry visitors who fill the Mayor's office during the few minutes before he starts his radio talks.
Leo Durocher's Dodgers tangled with the National League's outstanding club, the Cardinals, at Ebbets Field yesterday and result was precisely what might have been expected.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 29 -- Miss Pauline Betz, women's national tennis champion from Los Angeles, and Miss Margaret Osborne of San Francisco, fourth in the ranking and holder of the national doubles title with Miss Louis Brough of Los Angeles, will meet tomorrow at 3 P.M. in the final of the fifty-sixth invitation tournament of the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club.

LONDON, July 29 -- The slow, bloody tempo of the Normandy battle was greatly quickened this week when American armored and infantry columns burst through the German crust west of St. Lo, advanced toward the sea in the neighborhood of Coutances and threatened to cut off elements or remnants of five to eight German divisions.

International unity and the virtues of the Bronx were both given a boost yesterday in a letter sent to Queen Elizabeth of England by Bronx Borough President James J. Lyons, whose message was inspired by Her Majesty's recently expressed interest in the origin of the borough's name.

AN armful of summer garden flowers arranged in strategic places can do wonders for a home suffering from dog-day doldrums. Even if you have neither prize-winning blossoms nor priceless antique bowls and vases you can still work many a small miracle, provided you concentrate on arranging the flowers to complement the room and its style of decoration.
MOSCOW, July 29 (AP) -- American-made transport and Russian communications now face the greatest challenge of the Russian-German war.

AN old woman who remembers too much about her relatives and their pasts dies suddenly. Perhaps her death is accidental, but Lieutenant Eric Lund of the police has his doubts. These doubts become certainties when another death, which is indubitably murder, follows closely upon the first.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., July 29 -- Assuming the entire burden himself when business activities prevented his partner from participating, George Stuhr Jr., junior champion of Long Island and New York State, kept his team in the running in the annual member-guest tournament at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club today.

Mayor La Guardia made public yesterday a letter received from J. Monroe Johnson, director of the Office of Defense Transportation, commending the Mayor for his stand in a resent controversy with Martin J. Sweeney, president of the Hotel Association of the City of New York, Inc.

AMONG the few important political inventions of our time has been the public opinion poll, that device by which today's rulers can keep a constant hand on the public pulse without committing themselves in advance to a course of policy.

CHICAGO, July 29 -- Expectations here are that the fall market opening here tomorrow will draw an attendance of some 20,000 merchants, or slightly above the estimated 18,000 of last year. Expectations of the increase in attendance are based on the turnout for the July furniture market which exceeded last year despite a minimum of promotional publicity.

Mr. John Martin's defense of boogie woogie in THE TIMES Magazine for July 16 was not very convincing because he was pleading for boogie woogie on the grounds of its ancestry. Now I don't have any objection to boogie woogie, even own some myself, but to say that man is good because his ancestors were respectable citizens is an assumption which Mr. Martin would not make.

Mr. John Martin's defense of boogie woogie in THE TIMES Magazine for July 16 was not very convincing because he was pleading for boogie woogie on the grounds of its ancestry. Now I don't have any objection to boogie woogie, even own some myself, but to say that man is good because his ancestors were respectable citizens is an assumption which Mr. Martin would not make.

SINCE it is apparent that the votes of women will occupy a more predominant role than ever before in the forthcoming elections -- some predict a 65 per cent feminine representation in the ballot boxes -- Eve Garrette, who has been active in politics and a writer on political subjects for many years, decided that what every woman needed most at this period in the nation's history was a handy book about politics.

Pan American Airways announced yesterday, in connection with the observance of the fifth anniversary of its transatlantic service, that its post-war transports, already in an advanced stage of design, would be twice the size and capacity of its current Boeing Clippers and that, with increased capacity, passenger fare would be lowered.

BABY cries, won't go to sleep, and at last yells himself into a tantrum. But your sister-in-law says you'd "spoil" him if you picked him up. It's "good discipline," she says, to let him cry it out. Or it may be Howard, aged 1 1/2, who won't stay in his play pen, but follows his mother all around the house.

Possible sudden termination of the German phase of the war has brought no major revision of fall merchandising plans, it was reported here yesterday. Getting deliveries of the right merchandise continues the prime retailer objective.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The War Production Board announced today that monthly production schedules of four magnesium plants have been reduced and that of a fifth plant terminated in order to bring surplus supplies of magnesium more in line with the nation's stockpile objectives.

RETAIL trade here and in the other parts of the country was handicapped last week by high temperatures and humidity. Nevertheless, reports indicated volume showed a gain over the like week last year, although the increase was smaller than that recorded recently.

DEAR M -- Now that censorship restrictions on the bombardment of London have been lifted. I thought you might be interested in hearing a little more about it than can be told in the cable stories, although I am not at all sure that I can make this thing understood, even in a letter.

IN the summer of 1942 the advance of the Italo-German troops had achieved such success that Benito Mussolini considered it opportune to send urgently in a special airplane from Rome to Tripoli his own white horse, on which he desired to enter the Egyptian capital in triumph.

NEW ORLEANS, July 29 -- Southern Democratic leaders wanted Senator Harry Truman at Chicago as the running mate, but are not yet thoroughly satisfied. The issues foremost in discussion in political circles concern white supremacy, communistic influence in the labor unions and tariff modification to permit the agricultural South to have a greater share of national prosperity.

ARTISTS, writers and scientists, who usually are content to steer clear of politics but who now feel a compulsion to take an active part in attempting to secure Mr. Roosevelt's re-election, have formed a committee to work toward that end.

RICHMOND, July 29 -- The overwhelming defeat of Senator Ellison D. (Cotton Ed) Smith of South Carolina, who had sat in the Senate for six consecutive terms, was this section's most important political development in months. It not only removed a violent critic of the Roosevelt Administration, but its repercussions upon the State Democratic Convention, which meets in South Carolina next Wednesday to name Presidential electors, is expected to be considerable.

A SHORT time back William Tilden, in the course of his first press interview in the East in three years, named J. Donald Budge, now a lieutenant in the Army Air Forces, as the top tennis player of all time.
PHILADELPHIA, July 29 (AP) -- The Cubs combined five bases on balls off Barrett with six hits in the first six innings to score four runs and defeat the Phillies, 4 -- 2, tonight before 6,560.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Lieut. Gen. Leslie J. McNair, who was killed in action in Normandy this week, was honored today at a ceremony at the Army War College, where he made his headquarters as commanding general of the Army Ground Forces, a post he left recently after holding it during the building of our Army for this war.

OTTAWA, July 29 -- By sitting morning, afternoon and evening the Canadian Parliament has this week got through a more imposing amount of legislation than during all the previous months of the session. In doing so it has laid the course of Canadian after-war history in so far as it can be foreseen.

ASTRALIA -- The Commonwealth has opened a new transmitter that now enables Australia to reach eastern North America with a steady, strong signal in the evening hours. It is operating on 15.315 megacycles from 10:30 to 11:30 P.M.

PRESQUE ISLE, Me., July 29 (AP) -- Pvt. Thelma A. Young, who drives a staff car in the North Atlantic division station of the Air Transport Command, is one of a family of fourteen brothers and sisters in the war. Five boys have been lost in action.

From several recently published reports comes the news that corn germ, which constitutes about 7 per cent of the corn kernel, is a valuable protein food, containing 20 per cent of protein "of surprisingly quality," according to ing to Nutrition Reviews, published by Nutrition Reviews, published by the Nutrition Foundation.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 29 -- The terrific bombing of a mile strip on the St. Lo-Periers road that launched the American offensive last Tuesday was so impressive that it scared even high officers who had a hand in planning the operation.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 29 -- An abbreviated version of the famous Berkshire Music Festival got under way at Tanglewood this evening, under the direction of Dr. Serge Koussevitzky. Because of transportation and other problems arising from the war, only a comparatively small section of the Boston Symphony, thirty-eight players, including first desk men, are taking part in the Mozart festival.

BOSTON, July 29 -- The black-market gasoline situation throughout New England has become as scandalous as was Prohibition in its early stages. In Massachusetts alone more than 7,000 filling-station operators are linked to this unpatriotic racket which has started to bear the evil flowers of racketeering and murder, exactly as did the liquor traffic in days when patriotism meant nothing to the law-breaker.

IT takes no Delphic oracle to predict that programs like "Transatlantic Call" and "Atlantic Spotlight" point to a future of greater Anglo-American aerial intimacy. It is natural therefore that we have a look at what's doing on the dramatic homefront across the Atlantic.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

A MAN who loves his work is a man paid twice over. For the less lucky, work is ransom duly rendered. Done in its season (whether that be the day's midmorning or the strong years of life), done and well done, it will buy the spirit free for the noon's brief rest, and the long seat upon the rock in the wood when the thrush sings evening.

Cotton garment manufacturers, showing growing unrest toward pricing problems, and fearful that the Office of Price Administration may resort to the Vinson directive as an "out" in industry controversies regarding alleged inequitable regulations now in effect, are emphatic in statements that the formula will do them more harm than good.
NEW ORLEANS, July 29 (U.P.) -- The National Rivers and Harbors Congress approved yesterday the construction of a deep, tidewater channel from New Orleans to the Gulf of Mexico.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 95:

There is more than one type of room service. There is the familiar hotel room service in which the War Manpower Commission has just ordered a new slash of 50 per cent after earlier severe curtailments. There is a room service of which people speak only on special occasions and which, as a matter of fact, they never have in mind when they think about hotel meals served outside the dining room.
CHICAGO, July 29 (AP) -- Today's report of l ihe I restock markets here by the War Food iAdlnlnlstratlon follows:

CHICAGO, July 29 (AP) -- The White Sox gave a little confetti shower to Buck Newsom today, but the Athletics' garrulous right-hander, aided by Joe Berry's relief pitching and a three-run eighth-inning rally by his mates, pelted Chicago with a 6-to-4 defeat that ended a four-game winning streak.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Confronted by the fact that the supply of heavy-duty tires for buses and trucks would be exhausted some time next month if the outstanding certificates for purchase were honored, the Office of Price Administration today canceled all certificates for tires of 8.25 size or larger issued prior to July 15.

THROUGHOUT his eight successive years in Congress (from 1863 to 1869) the Honorable Ignatius Donnelly, member from Minnesota, must have been one of the most active men in the District of Columbia. He was attentive and faithful to the nation's business.

Nevil Ford, State chairman of the War Finance Committee, announced yesterday that New York City and State were approximately 20 per cent short of their E bond objectives with only two days remaining for sales of this issue to be counted toward Fifth War Loan quotas.

BOSTON, July 29 -- Eighteen chess experts, including Samuel Reshevsky, former United States champion, were listed in the open tournament of the United States Chess Federation which began at the Boston City Club today.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (Delayed) (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 94:

WHAT has come to be known among the travel fraternity as the ten-week season is running true to form, with beach, mountain and lake resorts all reporting near-capacity crowds. For years the majority of the country's vacationists have taken their holidays between July 1 and the second week in September and, despite efforts to spread these holidays through the twelve months, they still take them then.

PHILADELPHIA, July 29 -- Although it has been more than nine months since President Roosevelt gave his press conference a tip that there was definitely an undercover effort in many parts of the country to abolish the Securities and Exchange Commission, a detached appraisal of the situation now shows that the purported conspiracy still has not raised its head and that the life expectancy of the commission could hardly be better.

ROEBLING, N.J., July 29 -- The strike of 3,000 employes of the wire plant here of John A. Roebling's Sons Company continued today and no settlement is expected before Monday, when members of Local 2111 of the United Steel Workers of America, Congress of Industrial Organizations, will hold a meeting.

IN that very lively and often illuminating book, the "Avowals" of George Moore, there is a passage about the distinction between what is romantic and what is classical which, to my mind at least, sweeps the dust away from what has so often been an arid and unprofitable argument.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 29 (AP) -- The New York team of Lieut. August Ganzenmuller and his wife swept the courts at the Lake Placid Club's annual invitation tennis tournament to win titles in all matches.

Lieut. Comdr. James A. Farrell Jr., USNR, recently released by the Navy, has resumed his position as president of the American South African Line after thirty-seven months on active duty. He had served since June of 1941 in the District Intelligence Office of the Third Naval District.

Russell Maloney, in his review of the newly published "Letters of Alexander Woollcott" in THE TIMES Book Review, remarks that "the war has turned us all into letter-writers." We are become, indeed, a nation with pen in hand, a condition that is not without its perils.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) - United States military officials and representatives of the French Committee of National Liberation are reported to be making satisfactory progress toward a working agreement for administration of liberated areas of France.

Leases of a few large suites in houses on Park Avenue featured new rentals announced over the week-end as the lists indicated an early start of the rush for such apartments as are available for occupancy this fall.

DETROIT, July 30 -- Stumping through the West with the Yankees, one sees some new and interesting developments come to light almost every day. Not a little of it emanates from one Joseph V. McCarthy himself.

PHILADELPHIA, July 30 (AP) - The Chicago Cubs ran their string of successive victories to six today by defeating the Phillies twice, 4-2 and 11-2. Henry Wyse, although relieved in the ninth inning of the first game by Bob Chipman, got credit for his tenth victory.

CHERBOURG, France, July 30 -- Cherbourg is slowly and laboriously recovering from the economic and political effects of four years of German occupation. The French officials of the Porvisional Government of Gen. Charles de Gaulle and Allied civil affairs officers have made considerable headway in the last five weeks, but the city is far from normal.

LONDON, Monday, July 31 (AP) -- After smashing through the German lines in gains of up to fifteen miles, Russian troops battered their way through Shlyanova, five miles east of Kaunas, and Bobikly, less than five miles southeast of the former Lithuanian capital.

CLEVELAND, July 30 (AP) - The ninth inning was the deciding frame in both games as the Indians divided a double-header with the Red Sox today before 30,793 fans. Manager Lou Boudreau's double scored Paul O'Dea to give the Tribe a 3-to-2 triumph in the second game after Boston won the opener, 5 to 3, with a 3-run last-inning rally.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 30 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer is planning to co-star Clark Gable and Lana Turner in "Lucky Baldwin," a romantic screen dramatization of the life story of one of the West's most colorful characters. The film biography of the famous gambler, mining promoter and horse breeder is expected to be put into production late this fall upon the return of Gable, recently released from the Army, from a Northern California vacation.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Appointment of John J. Lyons of New York and Boston as price executive of the restaurant price branch of the Office of Price Administration was announced today. Mr. Lyons, who has had more than 20 years business experience in the marketing, distribution and merchandising fields, conducted his own business in New York as marketing consultant to retailers wholesalers and manufacturers before he entered Government service.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 30 -- Miss Pauline Betz of Los Angeles attained another goal on the tennis courts today when she joined the distinguished list of winners of the Seabright Bowl. In the final round of the fifty-sixth holding of this blue ribbon tournament, the national champion defeated Miss Margaret Osborne of San Francisco before a large gallery at the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club, 6 -- 2, 2 -- 6, 6 -- 3.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Real strides have been made in the Government action to save manpower in non-vital services, according to the first quarterly report to President Roosvelt of the Civil Service Commission.

LONDON, July 30 -- Despite the continued flying bomb interruptions, the London Stock Exchange managed to put through a substantial amount of business last week. Events in Germany and Prime Minister Churchill's reference to the possibility of peace coming earlier than generally had been expected put new heart into investors, and on certain days officially recorded bargains reached the highest daily total since November, 1942.

LONDON, July 30 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, was 117.5 on July 18, compared with 117.6 a fortnight and a month before, 114.7 a year ago and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

BOSTON, July 30 -- Playing his first important game since he won the national championship for the fourth time in 1942, Samuel Reshevsky of Brooklyn encountered Sgt. Roger B. Johnson from Fort Belvoir, Va., in the second round of the annual tournament for the open championship of the United States Chess Federation at the Boston City Club today.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 30 -- Corny Shields, with his International Class sloop Aileen; Miss Charlotte Perry, with her Atlantic Carolina; Bill Chesley, with his S class boat Auley; Lingard Loud, in the Victory boat First Call, and Skip Etchells, with his Star Shilleleh, were eventual winners over Larchmont Race Week, which wound up today.

For a while at Ebbets Field yesterday, while 20,136 enraptured Flatbush fans cheered themselves hoarse, Tommy Warren, the Casablanca kid, threatened to become the most popular Brooklyn pitcher in many moons by winning twice in one afternoon.

Vice President Wallace's speech at Des Moines merely confirms the conclusion of the Democrats at Chicago that his renomination would have been too great a liability for the national ticket to carry. He properly advised the Democrats of Iowa to "conduct the campaign on a high plane."
NEWARK, N.J., July 30 (AP) -- The Newark Bears moved into second place today, by defeating the Toronto Leafs in both ends of a double header, 9 -- 3 and 4 -- 0, before 5,368 fans.

The buying power of the community, as evidenced in recent increases in retail store sales, can be preserved in the post-war period if New York workers give a full day's work for a day's pay and employers keep wages up to current levels, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday in his weekly broadcast from City Hall.

Edgar MacGregor's schedule for the new season shapes up as a formidable one. Yesterday he was talking of doing no less than four plays. "Down to Miami" will be his first offering, opening Wednesday night, Sept. 6, at the Ambassador. It's a comedy requiring a complement of about fifteen players to unfold Conrad Westervelt's story in three settings designed by Stewart Chaney.

For the year 1943 the State Treasury of New York received $19,190,000 paid from bets under the pari-mutuel system. This was an increase of 90 percent over the receipts for 1942. The Federal Treasury looked on this contribution from money bet at the races as anti-inflationary, "since from 11 to 16 per cent of the public's money is lifted in the form of taxes."
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) - Pacific Fleet communique 97:

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 30 (AP) -- Negro troops of an anti-aircraft balloon battery and a quartermaster truck company today drew official commendation from Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower for their work in Normandy since D-day.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., July 30 -- Despite rumors of the possible ending of the European conflict order volume in the steel industry last week was heavier than ever. Along with this increase in steel bookings was a slight drop in the steel ingot rate.

Robot bombs are destroying no one knows how many buildings in England, together with the lives of the people in those buildings. New ruins lie in smoke and dust beside the historic rubble of 1940 and 1941. There are new bereavements. Life and death in "bomb alley" these days are full of horror.

The visiting team of picked Canadian RAF cricketers made a splendid showing in their return match by defeating a strong eleven representing the Joint Leagues of New York at Randalls Island yesterday by a margin of two runs with five wickets to spare.

Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York headed westward on his first campaign trip last midnight, leaving the Pennsylvania Station on a special train running as the second section of a regularly scheduled train. His first stop is Pittsburgh, where, at a series of conferences today, he will, he said last night, discuss the problems of reconversion of industry as a chief topic.

Mgr. Joseph V. S. McClancy, superintendent of schools for the Diocese of Brooklyn, and the Rev. Brother Calixtus Peters, community supervisor of schools for the Christian Brothers in the New York Province, received honorary degrees of Doctor of Pedagogy yesterday afternoon at the ninety-third commencement of Manhattan College.

If the New Deal has a basic economic theory, it would seem to be that the Government must spend more than he receives to fill the gap created by in dividual and corporate savings. That is permanent deficit economy. When the Federal debt was mounting toward 45 billions, one frequently heard the statement, "This cannot go on for ever."

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, July 30 (U.P.) -- Chinese and American units, battling through mud waist-to-shoulder deep in places, have almost cleared the Japanese from Myitkyina, while British units, driving the enemy from India's Manipur hill region, advanced another mile to within eight miles of Tamu.
Mr. and Mrs. Richard Lounsbery of the Savoy-Plaza have gone to Narragansett, R. I., for the remainder of the summer.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- "Political action" as defined and streamlined by the Congress of Industrial Organizations is something new in American political life.

Members of the British Empire Club, made up of British educators who are taking special courses at Columbia University, attended services yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel at the university, where the honorary president of the British Club, Dr. Samuel Henry Prince, Professor of King's College, Halifax, N.S., preached the sermon.

LONDON, July 30 (UP) -- There is increasing evidence that the plot to bomb Adolf Hitler was many times greater in scope than had been admitted. It is believed here that the entire Nazi military structure has been weakened to an extent that no purge could completely patch it.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast in English from Chungking and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

WITH BRITISH SECOND ARMY, in France, July 30 -- From a house on a hilltop overlooking a long green valley just south of Caumont there was unfolded today one of the grimmest Sabbath scenes ever witnessed in this part of Normandy.

SEA ISLE CITY, N.J., July 30 -- A naval air pilot and his gunner had an almost miraculous escape as their dive-bomber crashed in the ocean off here at 11 o'clock this morning after the pilot deliberately had headed his plane out to sea to avoid striking persons on the beach.

In tribute to the well-named Dauntless dive-bomber, the 5,936th and last of which has just rolled off the production line of the Douglas Aircraft Company, the Navy Department has made public the story of its accomplishment in the war against the Japanese.

Now about this word "miracle" as applied to production. The Democrats have taken it unto their bosom. The much maligned big and small businesses of the country have come through despite Democratic twaddle. With Government money loosed on the business world as it has been in these war years, who, tell me, regards the product as a miracle ? It is merely a natural result.
Commenting on the involvement of Count von Helldorf in the anti-Hitler plot, the London radio said yesterday:

The Giants generated enough power to batter the daylights out of the redoubtable Bucky Walters yesterday at the Polo Grounds in the first game of a twin bill with the Reds, witnessed by 24,443 fans. But the club's pitching suffered a sharp reverse in the afterpiece and Mel Ott's men had to be content with a split.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 30 (AP) -- Communique 109:

CHICAGO, July 30 (AP) - Jess Flores seven-hit shutout gave the Philadelphia Athletics an even split of their double-header before 16,738 here today, winning 3 to 0 after Bill Dietrich turned in his season's twelfth victory, 6 to 4, for the White Sox in the opener.

GUAM, July 30 -- The capture of Orote Peninsula has given United States Marines control of all three sides of the important Apra harbor and bodies of Japanese scattered among battered pillboxes and revetments along the 4,700-foot airfield and in the smoldering ruins of Sumay tell the story of the bloody battle.

BELLFORT, L. I., July 30 -- Six dogs -- five fox hounds and a mongrel -- broke into a turkey pen on the Woodcrest Farm of Nicholas Sbarra on Head of the Neck Road about dawn this morning and killed all but five of 250 four-months-old turkeys that were being raised for the Thanksgiving market.

NEW ORLEANS, La., July 30 -- Cotton futures moved up sharply during the first half of last week, mainly on buying stimulated by prospects for a technical correction following a recent $5 setback in quotations, but after gaining around $1.40 a bale, fresh liquidation and hedging cut best gains at least in half.

MOSCOW, July 30 (U.P.) -- Tass, official Russian news agency, today cited foreign press comment that the trip of Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk of the Polish exile Government to Moscow came too late to be effective.

The Saratoga race meeting will open today at Belmont Park, and the way the featured American Legion Handicap looks it seems to come down to the question of whether Devil Diver can carry 136 pounds after a long layoff.

Buying activity appeared quiet last week and fall purchasing proceeded along orderly lines, according to a summary of activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

NEW CITY, N.Y., July 30 - Maxwell Anderson, the playwright, and other members of the Good Government Committee of the Twenty-ninth Congressional District greeted as "wonderful news" the statement by Representative Hamilton Fish today that he would sue them for libel on the basis of a campaign advertisement which they had printed against him.

Addressing himself to all persons who desire world peace, the Rev. George H. Guilfoyle of the St. Patrick's Cathedral staff declared at the 11:45 o'clock mass there yesterday that there can be no better world and no peace of longer duration than an armistice until the heart of the world is softened by faith and men "come to a sane recognition of their status as children of God."

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- Federal taxes for the fiscal year 1944 reached the record yield of $40,118,819,808, or nearly double the 1943 total, the Treasury reported today, with individual income tax returns almost triple what they were a year earlier.
