ADVANCED ALLIED COMMAND POST, in Normandy, July 30 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Allied Supreme Commander, conferred here yesterday with Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery and Lieut. Gen. Omar N. Bradley, it was disclosed today.

No American soldier has lost his life in the crossing of the English channel on Army transports, despite robot bombardment of embarkation ports in the south of England, it was revealed yesterday. Maj. Gen. Homer M. Groninger, commanding general of the New York Port of Embarkation, set forth the safety record of the Army Transport Service on the basis of reports reaching him here.
Four new pictures are scheduled to arrive at midtown theatres this week. The program follows:

Monday was "round-up day" of the speculation, first for a rapid rise, then for an equally rapid decline. It was last of the thirty-one consecutive million-share days which began on June 12. Within that forty-three-day period, THE TIMES average had gained 5 3/8 points, then lost 3 7/8.
Your editorial of this morning has meat -- but may I carp a little on the subject-matter of "Wartime Restraints''?

NEWBURGH, N.Y., July 30 -- Despite Governor Dewey's denunciation of Representative Hamilton Fish's candidacy and the opposition of the "liberal" Republican wing in his own district, the indications today are that Mr. Fish will win renomination for his thirteenth term in Congress in the Republican primary on Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- At least 10 per cent of all casualty notifications are delayed in delivery because emergency addressees fail to keep the War Department advised of changes of address.

ISTANBUL, July 30 (Reuter) -- Gen. Ali Fuad Cebesoy, Turkish Minister of Communications, has told Turkish journalists that the temporary suspension of Black Sea sailings by the State Shipping Line will be extended to the Aegean and Mediterranean in coming weeks.

One of the country's leading airlines expects so many post-war marriages among its .women employes, "chosen for their attractive personalities and pleasing appearance," that no "major release" of women will be necessary.

In a United States hospital somewhere in England last week Queen Elizabeth was a visitor. She talked to a patient from the Bronx. With her usual intelligent curiosity, she asked the origin of the name. It is likely enough that it stayed in her memory from her travels in this country.

PEARL HARBOR, July 30 -- The battle of Tinian is nearing the end with scattered Japanese remnants now compressed into the island's southern tip in an area of about five square miles with the Second and Fourth Marines pressing in for the kill.

JOHN MORRIS, an Englishman, went to Japan in 1938 as "adviser" to the Japanese Foreign Office and teacher of English literature at one of Tokyo's universities. The country was just settling down to accept the realities of a long war with China, and Mr. Morris had an unexampled opportunity to observe the Japanese character as it reacted to the strains of an ever-tightening army rule.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 30 -- Twenty-seven Catholic priests, eight of them from the metropolitan area, departed for mission posts in South and Central America this afternoon after receiving blessings at the twenty-seventh annual departure ceremony in the cloister of Maryknoll Seminary here.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Monday, July 31 -- The great weight of the Royal Air Force Bomber Command, which scourged Stuttgart and Hamburg last week, was thrown into support of the Caumont offensive in Normandy yesterday, but the lashing of Axis oil sources in southeastern Europe was continued by the United States Fifteenth Air Force striking into Hungary.

General Mills, Inc., established a new sales record for the fifth consecutive time with the dollar volume reaching $281,286,512 as compared with $217,536,414 in the previous year, according to the report covering the fiscal year ended with May, released for publication today.

LONDON, July 30 (U.P.) -- The Sabbath quiet in southern England was shattered repeatedly today by blasts of Nazi robot bombs as smudged rescue crews combed through wreckage for survivors of last night's attack during which flying bombs crashed into London and the southern counties in short, sharp salvos.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 30 -- A bitter internal row in the Republican party in Connecticut came into the open today when Representative Clare Booth Luce made a veiled threat to decline renomination unless the Republican State committee refused to accept the resignation of J. Kenneth Bradley, her political mentor.

CHICAGO, July 30 -- A much firmer undertone has developed in the cash provision market. Soap manufacturers are reported to have purchased 3,000,000 pounds of prime steam lard and rendered pork fat last Friday and are expected to take additional quantities by Tuesday. New Government orders permitting a resumption of buying are expected shortly.

First Lieut. Dominic (Leonard) Ternan of the Order of Friars Minor, former assistant at St. Francis of Assisi Church, 135 West Thirty-first Street, was killed in action June 19 in France, the War Department has notified the Very Rev. Bertrand Campbell, minister provincial of the province of the Most Holy Name.

MOSCOW, Monday, July 31 -- Red Army forces yesterday cracked the German Niemen River line along a sixty-eight-mile front north and south of Alytus, driving fifteen miles deep and capturing more than 300 settlements, including Giby, twenty-four miles from the eastern border of East Prussia and six and one-half miles inside the Suwalki triangle, incorporated by the Reich into East Prussia in 1939.

CHUNGKING, China, July 30 (U.P.) -- The battle for the Hunan railway junction of Hengyang roared to a new intensity today, Heavy casualties were inflicted on both sides as the city's defenders locked forces with the enemy in an uninterrupted night-and-day battle.
The Indian Moslem leader, Mohammed Ali Jinnah, "has been given full authority to negotiate with Mohandas K. Gandhi," the British radio reported.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Monday, July 31 (AP) -- A communique:

ROME, July 30 (AP) -- Once again, as so often in the drive up the Italian peninsula, the Allies were faced with the possible necessity of firing on a storehouse of art and culture, for the enemy was setting up a heavy gun battery in the southern outskirts of Florence.

Jack McManis, the Californian who traveled east to prospect for tennis laurels when he received a medical discharge from the Navy, yesterday annexed the New York State clay court title at the Seminole Club in Forest Hills.

Although a relatively large number of individual price changes occurred during last week, increases had but a slight margin over decreases, so that the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose moderately from 112.89 to 112.96, a change of 0.05 per cent.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (U.P.) -- Post-war filling stations to serve automobiles and airplanes are under consideration by several major oil companies to meet the expected boom in private flying, it was disclosed tonight.

EAST WILLISTON. L.I., July 30 -- Jack Schief and Peter Ladislaw, Plandome, were three under par figures for fourteen holes to defeat Howard Schenck and Tom Strafaci, Plandome, 6 and 4, in the final of the annual member-guest tournament of the Wheatley Hills Golf Club today.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Massed in the Sylvan Theatre beside the Washington Monument, 10,000 of the 72,000 enrolled Waves celebrating their second anniversary heard Secretary Forrestal voice the hope this afternoon that the women's auxiliary of the Navy may yet serve overseas.

CHICAGO, July 30 -- Trading in wheat futures has become unusually quiet as a result of conflicting influences, and the market is holding around the Government support level, with peace talk and hedging pressure sufficient to prevent any rally of consequence above the price at which the Commodity Credit Corporation stands ready to take cash grain in elevators.

A trio of dessert sauces to take the place of the varieties that were imported from France and Holland before the war are appearing this week on the shelves of city groceries. They are prepared by the Homix Products, Inc., under the trade name of Chantilly.

Thirty-five hundred Waves from the Women's Naval Training School at Hunter College marched in review yesterday on the second anniversary of the creation of the service and received the acclaim of Mayor La Guardia for their "inspiring example."

WASHINGTON, July 30 (U.P.) -- The National Housing Agency is shaping plans for the disposal of $1,000,000,000 of permanent housing units which will become Government surplus with the end of the war, a spokesman for the NHA said tonight.

AUSTIN, Tex., July 30 -- An incomplete count today of the results of Saturday's county conventions, marked with walkouts and rump sessions and occasional fist fights, and covering 200 of the State's 254 counties, showed 93 delegation's elected favorable to the Roosevelt-Truman ticket, with 29 endorsing the stand of the anti-Roosevelt State convention, 44 sending their delegates to the Dallas State convention Sept. 12 as uninstructed and with about 25 counties holding no conventions.

BUENOS AIRES, July 30 -- In a notable editorial entitled 'International Panorama," Prensa this morning complains that the State Department memorandum on the Argentina situation was couched in terms that it defines as "unusual and such as not to fit the ideal of continental cordiality."

ADVANCED COMMAND POST, Normandy Front, July 30 -- Two G.I.'s and a lieutenant who saw that Normandy hedgerows were impeding the Allies' advance and then did something original about it are going to be rewarded by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

ROME, July 30 -- Reactionary interest are conspiring to hamper Italian Partisan activities because so many Partisans are Communists, Palmiro Togliatti, Communist leader, charges in an article in today's Unita. Signor Togliatti, Minister of State, is touching on a sore and vital point there, and when he says "reactionary interests" he does not mean only Italian ones.

The Medical Arts Building, a four-story office structure at 1019 Broad Street, in Newark, N.J., has been sold by the Fidelity Union Trust Company to the Newark Preparatory School, through Ralph G. Schwebemeyer Co. It fronts 47 feet on Broad Street and runs for 203 feet through the block to Beecher Street and will be altered from plans by John H. and Wilson C. Ely, architects.

Among the wartime refrigerators available to consumers without priority permits, and scheduled at a production figure of 821,000 for 1944 by the War Production Board, are models incorporating materials that can be expected to meet post-war standards.

I do not wish to tax your Rome correspondent, Herbert L. Matthews, with intentional levity in his interpretation of the Pope's utterance on peace to the Cardinals on June 2. Mr. Matthews exceeds the warrant of the text, however in construing that address as a pronouncement on the Allies' military and of unconditional surrender.
Accounts The Kinsey Distilling Company, Philadelphia, to J.D. Tarcher Co. to handle the advertising for Kinsey blended whisky and Kinsey gin.

Anna Kafitin, who acquired the two-family house on a plot 40 by 100 feet at 2034 East Fourteenth Street, near Avenue T, in Brooklyn, in 1939 through the Harry M. Lewis Company, broker, has resold it through the same broker. James Ruocco is the new owner.

ROME, July 30 -- Desperate German forces hurled five divisions in repeated counter-attacks today as veteran Eighth Army units after a night of grim fighting re-captured San Michele, five miles southwest of Florence on the last hill line before the city, and drove into Empoli, fourteen and three-quarter miles west on the Arno River.

CHUNGKING, China, July 30 (AP) -- Chinese troops have pierced the city limits of Tengyueh, principal Japanese Yunnan Province base and most heavily fortified bastion in the Salween area, and 2,000 Japanese are facing extermination at the hands of Chinese battering at the ancient city walls, an American review of operations said tonight.

In the reapportionment of Congressional districts in New York State, which becomes effective with this year's elections, the boundaries of all the districts in New York City have been altered. The accompanying map shows the new district lines for the entire city. It was prepared by the War Department to help servicemen locate their home district.

LONDON, July 30 (AP) -- A flight of German diplomats from Turkey was reported in Ankara dispatches received tonight. The German news agency DNB said the Turkish National Assembly would be informed Wednesday of the Government's decision to break diplomatic and economic relations with the Reich.
ROME, July 29 (Delayed) -- The Vatican newspaper, Osservatore Romano, today publishes an indignant note which it is thought, may bring into the open a rape case involving French Moroccan troops.
CHICAGO, July 30 -- New ceiling prices on cash oats announced last week were about in line with trade expectations and had relatively little effect as a price-making influence.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Congress, which went home a few weeks ago convinced that it had the situation well in hand and would not need to consider serious matters until after Labor Day at least and perhaps not until after the election, has been outflanked by the amazing progress of the Allied armies and returns to Washington Tuesday to tackle the momentous job of drafting a domestic blueprint for peace.
LONDON, July 30 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

BREHAL, France, July 30 -- The Germans left this town at 2 o'clock this morning and fled southward so rapidly that it was virtually impossible for our armored columns to make contact with them. I traveled south from this place without seeing any organized resistance, although the area was honeycombed with snipers and occasional German barrages were fired our way from German 88's.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 30 (AP) -- Miss Ann Curtis, 18-year-old San, Francisco girl, bettered the women's world record for the 880-yard free-style swim today with a time of 11:08.6.

Despite increasing German resistance, the Allied offensive in Normandy continues to drive forward and is now approaching the base of the whole Cotentin peninsula. The Americans on the western end of the battlefront have broken through the first hard crust of the German defense.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- The Army, acknowledging that malaria among troops has been "an important factor influencing military operations," reported today that the rates of the disease in highly malarious theatres are now but one-quarter to one-third of figures early in the war.

DETROIT, July 30 -- It was one step forward and one backward with the Yankees in the American League flag race today as they split a twin bill with Steve O'Neill's Tigers before Detroit's largest baseball turnout of the year, an overflow crowd of 49,994.

LONDON, July 30 -- An organization of Free Germans in London has grown up in the last eight months, seeking to play a part in overthrowing Adolf Hitler, but the British Government has refused to support it, as Moscow supports a similar movement there, in line with a long-established policy not to make any commitments, however slight, to any group of enemy aliens.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -The distillers month-long holiday from war production, starting Tuesday will bring to the consuming public about one normal year's supply of whisky and gin, liquor industry sources estimated today.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Monday, July 31 -- Battle-hardened British veterans, in a surprise assault from Caumont yesterday, thrust four and a half miles into some of the roughest country on the Normandy battle front while to the west the American armored drive that has shattered eight German divisions still pushed on toward the base of the Cotentin Peninsula.

Warning against over-optimism and reminding his listeners that the Allied armies have yet to fight their way across many miles of territory to strike at the heart of the foe, the Rev. Dr. Frederick W. Norwood, minister of St. James United Church, Montreal, Canada, declared yesterday that when victory comes there will be need of a spokesman who can utter the truth.
ABOARD THE SUPERFORTRESS MONSOON, Over Japanese-Occupied China, July 29 (Delayed) -- We twelve aboard the Monsoon have just witnessed a masterpiece of destruction and eleven of us had a hand in it.

Never before has a nation spent more on ships and the training of officers and crews to man them than has the United States during the present conflict. After the war, ships will be the one and only large item in the maze of war equipment that we can use to make a stable, peaceful, affluent world.
CHICAGO, July 30 -- Heavy rains fell over a large part of the main ...

The Grinnell, an apartment house for eighty-two families at 800 Riverside Drive, on the triangular block between 157th and 158th Streets, has been sold by the Bank for Savings to the Broadstreet Realty Corporation. It is assessed at $580,000 and was sold subject to a purchase money mortgage of $325,000. Joseph H. Lopin Co. were the brokers and title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.

The legalizing of "off-the-track" betting on horse races, advocated in a resolution adopted last week by the New York State Association of Police Chiefs, would pave the way for legalized roulette, faro, dice and other gambling games, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 30 (AP) -- Rochester made it four out of five in its series with Jersey City today by defeating the Little Giants in both ends of a double-header, 10 -- 9 and 1 -- 0.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 28 (Delayed) -- The Turkish Government is preparing to break diplomatic relations with Germany. Unless unforeseen circumstances arise, Turkey will take this step some time after Monday.

CHERBOURG, July 29 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Louis Jacquinot, Commissioner of the Navy in the French Provisional Government, said today that the revived French Navy was ready when needed to operate in the Pacific as well as in European waters.

As the German armies in Italy retreat northward they will pass close to the ruins of the ancient stronghold of Canossa. The castle of Canossa rose in the foothills of the Apennines some twenty miles southeast of the city of Parma. It is one of the famous castles of history.

Robert E Kennedy of the Brunswick-Balke-Collender Company has been appointed manager of the New York territory, effective Aug. 1. He succeeds Walter H. Roesing, who has been granted an indefinite leave of absence. C.L. Ellison, branch manager, Pittsburgh, will succeed Mr. Kennedy as manager of the sales engineering department in Chicago.

Cotton prices in the domestic market last week registered a slight improvement over the previous week when rather sharp losses were recorded. At the close of trading on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains of 11 to 21 points, with the greatest improvement in the March delivery.

JASPER, Ala., July 30 (U.P.) -- Senator Bankhead of Alabama said today that the possibility of an early German defeat and inability of the OPA and the cotton mills to agree on the cost of the raw commodity at the mills had depressed the price of cotton despite recent legislation to raise it to a parity.

BOSTON, July 30 (AP) -- Al Javery pitched a two-hitter as the Braves blanked the Pirates, 2 to 0, today to win a double-header. The Braves came from behind to capture the first game, 6 to 4. It was Javery's first victory since June 17 when he turned back the Giants, 5-1, at Braves Field.

Louis Rameri, a 26-year-old war veteran, who said he received a medical discharge in January after serving with the Army in Sicily and the European theatre for two years and four months, had a bad day at the race track on Saturday.

The Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, interrupting his vacation to return to the pulpit of the Riverside Church, declared in his sermon yesterday that the three major forces of the present are fascism, communism and democracy, and that the main emphasis is on the differences between them.

HAMILTON, N.Y., July 30 -- Speaking at the last general forum of the State Citizens Conference at Colgate University tonight, Prof. Eduard C. Lindeman of the New York School of Social Work declared that "peace schemes, world plans or international law" could not be depended on as sources of peace.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast domestically in Finland and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Emile Gauvreau, author of "Billy Mitchell: Founder of Our Air Force and Prophet Without Honor, tells the story of America's swift rise to air supremacy in "The Wild Blue Yonder: Sons of the Prophet Carry On." E. P. Dutton will publish it on Aug. 18.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- Relief is in sight from the annual complications of filling out income tax forms. The new forms, compared with the old, are as simple as 2 plus 2.

A SECRET UNITED STATES B-29 BASE, Somewhere in China, July 30 -- Crews of American B-29 Superfortresses reported today that they left a mass of flaming ruins in Anshan, Manchuria, Japan's second largest iron and steel producing center, in their raids against three major enemy objectives Saturday.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Army School of Military Government at Charlottesville, Va., has been opened to members of the Wac for the first time.
The Right Rev. Y. Y. Tsu, Assistant Bishop of Hong Kong, China, preached yesterday on "The Faith of Our Fathers," in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 30 (AP) -- Senator Arthur Capper, Republican of Kansas, and a member of the Foreign Relations Committee of the Senate, predicted today that a proposal to establish four or five great regional spheres of influence might be considered "very seriously'' before final peace treaties were written.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Monday, July 31 (AP) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur's Liberators smashed four Japanese airdromes in the Sorong sector at the northwest tip of Netherlands New Guinea in a heavy attack, announced today.

DETROIT, July 30 -- An additional 3,400 members of Local 235, United Automobile Workers, CIO, voted today to strike at five Chevrolet gear and axle plants, joining 3,600 who have been on strike since Wednesday.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 30 -- Two hundred and seven sick and wounded United States soldiers from battle fronts all over the world arrived at the Army's England General Hospital here last week to complete their convalescence and begin the training that will fit most of them for return to active duty, it was announced today.

At the request of the Treasury Department, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York has notified all banks in this area that it is "the general policy of the Treasury to require the endorsement (of checks to the order of members of the armed forces now serving overseas) by the payee or for him by power of attorney.

ST. LOUIS, July 30 (AP) - The Browns made good use of an opportunity to gain ground in the tight American League pennant race and won a double-header from the Senators this afternoon, 2 to 1, in 10 innings and 7 to 3.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 30 -- The first of two week-ends of Dr. Serge Koussevitzky's Mozart Festival at Tanglewood came to an end this afternoon, and it would be no exaggeration to say that not only is the festival a success, but that it is a musical achievement of major proportions.

Forty-two contests for party nominations are to be decided by the voters of New York State in tomorrow's primary elections. Twenty-eight of them are in the city, and fourteen elsewhere in the State. Nineteen of the contests in the city involve Democratic nominations, while eleven of the up-State contests involve Republican nominations.

A television fashion show of fall and winter styles will be offered in a series of three weekly programs scheduled by the DuMont station, WABD, New York, for Aug. 2, 9 and 16 and sponsored by the Aldens Chicago Mail Order Company.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- American Red Cross activities for soldiers on the Normandy beachhead are in full swing, according to information received today by Basil O'Connor, Red Cross chairman, from Harvey D. Gibson, American Red Cross Commissioner at London.
GUAM, July 27 (Delayed) -- United States sovereignty was re-established today on Guam through a proclamation by Admiral Chester W. Nimitz at a flag raising ceremony.
ROME, July 30 (AP) -- A communique:

WITH AMERICAN FORCES, in Normandy, July 30 -- The backbone of German resistance on the American front collapsed today. Pushing with all possible speed, our tanks and accompanying infantry threw another big loop around the disorganized enemy, trapping more hordes and firmly establishing themselves at Brehal, near the coast, some twenty-five miles below Tuesday's jump-off line.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The disposal of surplus war property, which is expected to reach a value of fifty to one hundred billion dollars at the war's end, is one of the Government's major post-war problems, the Office of War Information stated today.

HEADQUARTERS OF AN AMERICAN ARMORED UNIT, France, July 28 (Delayed) -- German infantrymen, attacked so savagely in the latest American offensive are hungry and tired and are trying to ingratiate themselves with American prisoners, according to the testimony of three GI's who were held by the Germans for three days and finally liberated by the American advance.

Favored players led a field of thirty-seven teams that started play for the national contract bridge mixed team-of-four championship in the eighteenth annual tournament of the American Contract Bridge League at the Hotel Astor here yesterday afternoon.

Victim of his determination to fight to the last for his team, Mel Ott was carried off the field last night before 15,213 fans in a battle which saw the Giants overcome the Reds, 9 to 7, to retain a slender grip on their berth in the National League's first division.

The third of this summer's series of Naumburg Memorial Concerts was given last night on the Mall in Central Park. Josef Stopak conducted the Naumberg Orchestra, and Willard Young, tenor, was the soloist, singing the "Flower Song" from Bizet's "Carmen" and the aria "Cielo e mar" from Ponchielli's "La Gioconda," with "Aubade" from Lelo's "Le Roi d'Ys" as an encore.

Both the challenge and the accomplishment in the important task of promoting safety in New York are emphasized in the annual report of Frank L. Jones as president of the Greater New York Safety Council. This report is published under the provocative title, "Hazards and Horizons."

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -Carl Newton, president of the Chesapeake Ohio Railroad, reviewed business relations with the Alleghany Corporation in an effort to show today that Alleghany's control of C. O. coincided with the law.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Tuesday, Aug. 1 -- In an amphibious leap of nearly 200 miles from the previous advanced position on Numfor Island, American troops seized the Sansapor coastal area of Netherland New Guinea and the islands of Amsterdam and Middelburg off the coast, giving the Allies control of virtually the entire New Guinea coastline.

Separate appeals for the defeat of Representative Vito Marcantonio in today's primary elections were issued yesterday by Thomas J. Curran, New York County Republican chairman, and Edward V. Loughlin, leader of Tammany Hall. Mr. Marcantonio, who is without opposition in the Labor party in the new Eighteenth Congressional District, is seeking the Republican and Democratic nominations as well.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Tuesday, Aug. 1 -- More than 3,000 American planes scourged the vials of Hitler's war machine from vest and south yesterday.

WITH THE AMERICAN FORCES IN FRANCE, July 31 (U.P.) -- A doughboy who escaped from his German captors wandered into headquarters today and reported that a German general sufficiently high to be surrounded by a satellite ring of bowing and scraping colonels had been killed by an American sharpshooting fighter plane on the right flank of the American advance.

Josef Lhevinne, the eminent pianist, was soloist at the Lewisohn Stadium last night in the Tchaikovsky piano concerto in B flat minor, but first attention should go to Fabien Sevitzky, Indianapolis Symphony conductor, who made his Stadium debut presiding over the Philharmonic-Symphony.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Congress, after a five weeks' convention recess, devoted to political fence-mending, will reconvene tomorrow only to find that what is regarded as its chief immediate task is still to be charted.
Too far gone to allow such trivial things as figures to distract, confuse or concern them, the Dodgers treated Morton Cooper like a fresh busher at Ebbets Field last night.

NEWARK, N.J., July 31 -- Indicating that the Washington order decreeing Newark an "acute" labor shortage area came to him as a surprise. George S. Pfaus, area WMC director, said today that it meant no changes in the area.

Sales of department stores in New York and Brooklyn increased 12 per cent last week, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the previous week the bank had reported a gain of 20 per cent.

Bob Montgomery, the lightweight champion, and Beau Jack, former titleholder, both now privates in the Army, attended a meeting of the War Finance Committee at the RKO Building yesterday, then went to Stillman's gymnasium to prepare for Friday night's ten-round non-title War Bond boxing match at Madison Square Garden.

PITTSBURGH, July 31 -- Using industrial Pittsburgh as a springboard, Governor Dewey advanced as a major issue of the campaign today the contention that the people would be electing in November a peacetime President rather than a wartime Commander in Chief.

AVRANCHES, France, July 31 -- The number of prisoners taken in this advanced sector had not been determined tonight, but this correspondent saw more than 2,000. They were in prisoner-of-war enclosures, walking along roads, riding on the hoods of jeeps and jammed in trucks.

This war is being fought largely by men who were born after Aug. 1, 1914. Nevertheless, that day, thirty years ago, was decisive for them as for their fathers. Anyone who re-reads the histories of World War I must realize that the old continental civilization of Europe perished in 1914 and that the struggle which began then never really ended.

It is a drab picture that John P. Marquand draws of the writer at work. "He considers the act of writing utter torture," according to Roger Butterfield, whose pen sketch of the novelist appears in the July 31 issue of Life.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 31 -- Raymond Massey has been assigned by Warners to portray Maj. Gen. Claire Chennault in the forthcoming screen adaptation of Col. Robert B. Scott's "God Is My Co-Pilot." The actor fills the role previously earmarked for Walter Huston, now cast for "Pillar to Post." Dane Clark also goes into the picture.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, July 31 (AP) -- Chinese troops have made new, sharp gains in the fighting at Myitkyina, both in the western and southern sectors of the besieged city, last remaining base of the Japanese in North Burma, a communique said tonight.

Shipments of peaches from near-by orchards reach their peak in August, and will continue to arrive until October. The harvest is especially good this year, with prices, which are limited by a flat ceiling of 14 cents a pound, ranging from cheap to reasonable.

AMONG other things time has a habit of adding luster to a performance that carries with it any meritorious quality whatever, and, in that connection, time has worked very well indeed in favor of Billy Conn in so far his memorable bout with Joe Louis is concerned.

Leonard J. A. Smit, 59-year-old refugee from the Netherlands and an international dealer in industrial diamonds, was sentenced to a year and a day in prison yesterday by Federal Judge John McDuffie. At the request of United States Attorney James B. M. McNally, the court also imposed fines totaling $102,000 on Smit and three of his concerns, Anton Smit Co., Inc.; Diamond Corebit and Tool Company, Inc., and Elsantum, Inc.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES in Normandy, July 31 -- All day long American armored columns have knifed southward toward the base of the Brittany Peninsula, smashing German resistance wherever the enemy tried to stand to halt the swift, sure advance in which lie the seeds of a great victory.

ST. LOUIS, July 31 -- Senator Bennett Champ Clark, frequent critic of domestic and international policies of the Roosevelt Administration, is said here to be faced with the most desperate struggle of his political career in his attempt to win a renomination for the Senate in tomorrow's primary election.

The Scovill Manufacturing Company has called for redemption on Sept. 1 its ten-year 3 1/4 per cent debentures due July 1, 1950, amounting to $4,500,000, at 102 1/2 and accrued interest. Payment will be made at the office of J.P. Morgan Co., Inc., trustee, 23 Wall Street.

The body of Patrick Flood, famous West Side detective who came to grief in the Arnold Rothstein murder case sixteen years ago, was identified in Queens County morgue yesterday by a niece, Miss Margaret Dowling of 64-45 Booth Street, Forest Hills, Queens.

BOSTON, July 31 (AP) -- Allowing only two hits, Lefty Fritz Ostermueller and his Pittsburgh mates today defeated the Braves, 9 to 2. The hurler rescued from the bushes by Frankie Frisch also clubbed three hits, scored twice and drove in a run.
LEXINGTON, Ky., July 31 (AP) -- Calumet Farm paid $40,000 for one colt at the Lexington yearling sales today, with six others bringing better than $10,000 each.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- In accepting the citation by the United States Treasury praising the Zionist Organization of America for distinguished service in raising $65,000,000 in the War Bond drive, Dr. Israel Goldstein, president, made a plea today for a refuge and a permanent home for the Jewish community after the war.

IN collaboration with the editors of Look Magazine, Gerald W. Johnson has essayed a new type of history in his "Woodrow Wilson: As the Camera Saw Him Then and as We Begin to See Him Today."* The idea is to let words tell the story when no pictures are available; but where the photographic morgue yields self-explanatory material the essayist in Mr. Johnson fades into the caption writer.

ROME, July 31 (U.P.) -- Nearly 4,000 members of the American, British and French armed forces were received today by Pope Pius XII, and a number of the soldiers were personally presented to the Pope by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of New York.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, July 31 (AP) -- Communique 111:
LONDON, July 31 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

OLD ORCHARD BEACH, Me., July 31 (AP) -- Titan Hanover, a bay colt by Calumet Chuck, racing out of the Goshen, N.Y., stable of Arden Homestead, won the $5,885.85 national stake for 2-year-old trotters by taking the second and fourth heats of a Grand Circuit elimination event today.

With profits amassed from "Good Night, Ladies" (the phenomenal touring attraction that set a new Chicago record of 100 weeks), of which he is co-producer, Howard Lang again will try his luck on Broadway. This time he has elected to present "School for Brides," which begins its curriculum at 8:40 tonight in the "air-conditioned" Royale.

Devil Diver and Plebiscite were the stake winners yesterday at Belmont Park where the Saratoga Association opened its 1944 meeting before 23,203 persons who wagered $1,907,455 on the eight-race program.

Several hundred young women volunteers serving as price panel assistants for local war price and rationing boards started a survey yesterday among New York City restaurants to check on the roll-back in coffee prices to 5 cents a cup.

Smaller amounts of bonds and larger issues of stock marked the new financing here in July, which, on the whole, was curtailed in the early part of the month when the Fifth War Loan Bond Drive was still on. New bonds offered publicly aggregated $92,707,000, representing nineteen issues, the smallest monthly figure in three months, and compared with $117,033,000 for sixteen offerings in the preceding month and $75,324,000 for eight emissions in July, 1943.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., July 31 -- Representative Hamilton Fish and Augustus W. Bennet, rivals in tomorrow's Republican primaries in the Twenty-ninth Congressional District, ended their campaigns tonight by issuing statements in which each voiced confidence in the outcome.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) - Chairman Doughton of the Ways and Means Committee said today that Congressional tax leaders would be ready, when the war ended, to stimulate economic expansion by making broad adjustments in tax burdens of individuals and corporations.

Formation of two new companies to handle all the export business of the American Home Products Corporation was announced yesterday by Walter F. Silbersack, executive vice president and general manager. The new concerns, which will start operations today, will be under the supervision of Donald C. Townley, vice president in charge of the parent company's foreign division.

The Fifth War Loan drive ended at midnight last night, with both New York State and city sales of E Bonds known to be little short of-- if not actually over -- their quotas. Although the books were closed on E, F and G Bonds and Series C Savings Notes, final sales figures on these savings issues will not be available until the end of the week.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The alien population of the United States now stands at about 3,400,000, as compared with 5,000,000 at the time of alien registration in 1940.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Chungking in English to North America and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

PHILADELPHIA, July 31 (AP) -- The Cubs ran their winning streak to seven and gained their twenty-fourth triumph in the last thirty-six games when they defeated the Phillies today, 5 -- 1, before a scant ladies' day crowd. It was the Phillies' ninth straight setback.

Editorials like your recent one, "History Revitalized," a subject about which there cannot be too much discussion, should be published daily until something is done about the widespread apathy toward our history. It is frightening to think how many Americans are going to the polls in November ignorant of the meaning of history, and therefore basing their decisions on rumor, myth or what their husbands or fathers think.

NEW DELHI, India, July 30 (Delayed) -- The agreement between Mohandas K. Gandhi and Mohammed Ali Jinnah, president of the Moslem League, to meet in Bombay on Aug. 8 to discuss the Moslem demand for an autonomous Moslem State in India has added momentum to Indian efforts to reach political settlements between themselves and with the British that would bring about an increased measure of self-rule for this country.

LONDON, July 31 -- Conversations among United States, British and Russian naval missions to prepare plans for the demobilization and demilitarization of the German Navy will begin shortly, Vice Admiral William A. Glassford Jr. disclosed today.

Racing their tanks across the Norman hills into Avranches, our soldiers must have seen, rising from the waves a few miles out, the noblest monument of ancient France. A few shells would bring the soaring pile of Mont St. Michel tumbling in ruin upon its sea-girt granite rock.

ROME, July 31 -- Indian troops of the Eighth Army, hurling back strong German tank thrusts, have cleared all but scattered resistance pockets from the high ground between the Pesa and Elsa rivers south of the Arno in their fast-developing drive on the great fortress city of Florence.

Roy Porter of the National Broadcasting Company broadcast Monday from Chengtu, China, the story of the murder of about three-quarters of the crew of a United States Liberty ship in the Indian Ocean in mid-June by seamen of a Japanese submarine, according to The United Press.

Manpower, cotton yarn and fabric problems, but somewhat brighter prospects on elastic thread, featured the outlook for corsets as the industry's fall market week opened here yesterday. Many buyers from stores all over the country arrived for the week, although considerable taking up of quotas permitted by manufacturers had been done during the last month.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month was slightly below that of June, but was the second largest of the year and the heaviest in six years for a corresponding month. Sales crossed the million-share mark in fifteen sessions, the largest of which was 2,435,770 shares on July 5 and the smallest was 562,690 shares on July 28.

PHILADELPHIA, July 31 -- The Indiana and Michigan Electric Company, a subsidiary of the American Gas and Electric Company in the Electric Bond and Share Company holding system, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a plan providing for the redemption and cancellation of two issues of preferred stock, restatement of its charter, and the issuance and sale of new preferred and additional shares of common stock.
Melvin E. Sawin, vice president of the Atlas Corporation, has been elected to the board of directors of Textron, Inc.
LONDON, July 31 -- German organs denied today that Field Marshal Gen. Erwin Rommel had been killed or seriously wounded in France.
ROME, July 31 -- The Bonomi Government's law punishing Fascists was promulgated today and Count Carlo Sforza pledged its full application in a conference with foreign and Italian correspondents.

There has been little or no change since January in the retail prices of clothing, rent, house furnishings and miscellaneous goods and services bought by the families of wage earners and lower-salaried workers in New York, according to a report issued yesterday from the New York Regional Office of the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics.

With New York's 1944 horse racing season just past the half-way mark as the Saratoga thirty-day meeting opened at Belmont Park yesterday, indications are that when the long stretch is completed in mid-November at least $400,000, 000 will have been wagered and the State coffers enriched some $27, 000,000, The Associated Press estimates.

A Collection of Mark Twain's anecdotes and jokes contributed by his friends will be published this fall by the Longfellow Press under the title "Mark Twain's Joke Book." Carl Sandburg has written the preface and Channing Pollock the introduction.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 31 -- While possible White House action was awaited in the uptown shops' overtime dispute sixteen members of Lodge 68 of the International Association of Machinists (AFL), continued to day their defiance of the lodge's business agents by reporting for work at the Federal-Mogul Corporation's bearing plant here.

Condemnation proceedings were filed yesterday in Supreme Court by the New York City Housing Authority to acquire title to the sites for two proposed post-war low-rent housing projects to be known as the Abraham Lincoln Houses and the Marcy Houses in Manhattan and Brooklyn respectively. The Manhattan action is returnable at 10 o'clock this morning before Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin.

The Army's youngest branch, the Transportation Corps, celebrated its second anniversary yesterday at headquarters of the New York Port of Embarkation, Army Base, Brooklyn, with a speech by Maj. Gen. Homer M. Groninger, commanding the Port of Embarkation, that probably will not be used by the Calais radio, whose boasts he quoted and hurled right back at the Fuehrer.

A German prisoner of war, in a broadcast to the German army yesterday, through the facilities of the British radio, accused Adolf Hitler of betraying "the soldiers and everybody else," and declared that "Hitler must fall."

Congress will convene today after a recess of more than a month. Some of the Congressional leaders seem to have been taking the duties of Congress rather lightly. When the House prepared to adjourn on June 23, Representative McCormack, the majority leader, told members that no legislative program was planned for August and that, even if the recess ended officially Aug. 1, they need not return on that date.
ST. LOUIS, July 31 (AP) -- Two home runs by Verne Stephens and George McQuinn helped the league-leading Browns a 3 to 2 victory over the Senators tonight.

BOSTON, July 31 -- With Samuel Reshevsky of Brooklyn kept busy for four hours in his third-round game at the Boston City Club today without reaching a decision, Weaver W. Adams of Dedham, Mass., and Edward S. Jackson Jr., of Short Hills, N.J., moved into a tie for the lead in the annual tournament for the open championship of the United States Chess Federation.

CHUNGKING, China, July 31 (AP) -- Desperately attacking Japanese have smashed into Hengyang proper after five weeks of bloody fighting, a Chinese announcement admitted tonight, and were battling in the streets with defenders whose stand in the Canton-Hankow railway junction has become one of the epics of the war.

LONDON, July 31 (U.P.) -- Dr. Joseph Goebbels, last week named plenipotentiary to mobilize Germany's total war effort, today told a gathering of Reich Cabinet Ministers and chief of civil administration of occupied territories that "we must reckon with closing down whole branches of public services."

SAN FRANCISCO, July 31 -The United States Steel Corporation was accused today by implication at a hearing of the Senate Small Business Committee of intending to cut some of the props from under the post-war industrial West by seeing that the $200,000,000 war-time steel plant at Geneva, Utah, does not operate after the war.

HAMILTON, N.Y., July 31 -- Expansion of the school system to include more adult and vocational education, widening of the tax base to relieve the load on small communities and more cooperation between laymen and educators were advocated today at a special joint conference on "First Issues of Education" held at Colgate University.
LONDON, July 31 -- The stock markets here started the week on a cheerful note and several issues among the industrials went ahead.
PEARL HARBOR, July 31 -- Late reports from Guam today suggest an unexpected collapse of enemy resistance throughout the southern half of the island.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Tuesday, Aug. 1 (AP) -- For two days before the landings American, Australian and Dutch pilots of the Far Eastern Air Force had roared up and down the coastline of the Halmahera Sea, clearing the enemy from the skies and pounding down his air bases to prepare a road for the Allied convoy heading for the far western tip of Netherland New Guinea.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 31 -- Stanley Hubbard, president of radio station KSTP, disclosed today that he had asked William H. Davis, chairman of the War Labor Board, to request President Roosevelt to use his wartime powers and take over the Minneapolis Musicians Union, Local 73, and order the sixteen striking musicians back to work.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, in Australia, July 13 (Delayed) -- The first Congressional Medal to be awarded to a Navy man in the Southwest Pacific was presented today by Vice Admiral Thomas C. Kinkaid to Lieut. Nathan G. Gordon, 27, former lawyer of Morrilton, Ark.

The answer of the Remington Arms Company, Inc., and Charles Krum Davis, its president, to the Government's anti-trust suit against these and other defendants was filed yesterday in Federal court here. The other defendants include Imperial Chemical Industries, Ltd., a British concern, and E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., which owns most of Remington's stock.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (UP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 98:

CHICAGO, July 31 -- Hedging sales and pressure from professional operators gave wheat and other grains an easy undertone today on the Board of Trade. Wheat held within relatively narrow limits, but received good support after a decline of around 1/2 cent a bushel and rallied to close with a net loss of 1/8 cent.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 31 -- Representative Clare Booth Luce announced late today that she would stand for re-election to Congress from Connecticut's Fourth District comprising Fairfield County, because a threat of "purging" her at the polls by Sidney Hillman's Political Action Committee "is a challenge I cannot ignore."

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Tuesday, Aug. 1 -- After an impetuous thrust, a heavy American armored column took a firm hold on Avranches, across the River See, at the western end of the base of the Cotentin Peninsula yesterday. By the capture of this medieval walled town the Americans have unhinged the first of two natural defense barriers lying between them and a break-through from the Cotentin Peninsula into Brittany and northwestern France.

CHICAGO, July 31 (AP) -- Irv Hall's lead-off triple in the tenth inning was crashed by Hal Epps' single tonight to give the Athletics a 3-to-2 victory over the White Sox. The triumph, their third in four games here, lifted the Athletics into seventh place.

DETROIT, July 31 (AP) -- Striking employes of five Chevrolet gear and axle plants involved in a dispute over production rates were ordered by the War Labor Board today to return to work by tomorrow morning.
KALAMAZOO, Mich., July 31 (AP) -- Seeded players breezed through their first-round matches in the national junior tennis championship today, all but one winning in straight sets.
PHILADELPHIA, July 31 (AP) -- "And when the war is over," Connie Mack penned, "I look for better, more exciting baseball played by more skillful men before greater crowds than we ever have known."
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINVEA, Tuesday, Aug. 1 (AP) -- A communique:

The merger of the New York Urban League and the Brooklyn Urban League-Lincoln Settlement Association to form the Urban League of Greater New York, was voted last night at an organization meeting at the New York Urban League office, 204 West 136th Street.

MIDDLETOWN, Ohio, July 31 -The American Rolling Mill Company earned $2,441,491 for the six months ended on June 30, Charles R. Hook, president, announced today. This is after provision for income and excess profits taxes of $4,390,542 and the addition of $1,120,000 to contingent reserve.
CLEVELAND, July 31 (AP) -- Rookie Steve Gromek of the Indians set the Red Sox down with two hits tonight, but lost, 1 to 0, when Boston scored an unearned run in the ninth inning.

LONDON, Tuesday, Aug. 1 -- Onrushing Soviet forces have smashed to within less than ten miles of Warsaw in a deep flanking maneuver, Moscow revealed last night, while Berlin said that Marshal Konstantin K. Rokossovsky's troops already had launched a large-scale attack on the eastern part of the Polish capital.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Although it rose to a peak for the year in June, production of farm machinery fell 11.3 per cent behind schedule for the twelve months ended on June 30, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, reported today.

The stock market, overrun by uncertainty, ended yesterday a month of contrasting movements in which it plunged to a new low mark for July after fresh highs had been attained. The closing session was unsatisfactory from every angle, with prices mixed at the close and trading again slow.

MEXICO CITY, July 31 -- President Manuel Avila Camacho opened the third annual meeting of the Inter-American Bar Association tonight. Nearly 500 delegates from nineteen countries were present in the Palace of Fine Arts.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 31 -- The peace negotiations on behalf of Rumania with the Allied powers have broken down and are not likely to be resumed. The Rumanian emissaries sent to Turkey and Egypt to negotiate with the Allies' representatives did not represent Premier Ion Antonescu's Government, but were authorized to speak for all parties in Rumania, including the Communists.

Because distillers will be permitted to dip into their 200,000,000 or more gallons of aged whisky in stock under the whisky "holiday," starting today, any reference to a shortage probably will be avoided in future advertising by most of the leading producers, it was stated yesterday in the trade.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- Unless paper production for military use is increased the Government may have to curtail supplies for publishers and commercial printers and "impose complete priority control" over paper, the War Production Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The prosecution in the mass sedition trial inched a bit forward today, as the case entered its sixteenth week, by presenting to the jury, over defense objections, letters held to connect William Dudley Pelley with the alleged conspiracy to cause disaffection in the nation's armed forces.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- So well organized is the routine for handling American casualties in this war, Maj. Gen. Norman T. Kirk, the Surgeon General, told a press conference today, that 80 to 90 per cent of the men wounded in the invasion of Normandy received medical care within ten minutes after being hit.
John Morrell Co., food packers, have announced the election of T. Henry Foster as chairman of the board, George M. Foster as president and Robert M. Owthwaite as vice president.

Declaring its fear that by the time the war has been won the largest part of the Jewish populations of Europe will have been extinguished, a mass meeting of 40,000 American Jews gathered in Madison Square Park yesterday afternoon adopted a resolution embodying a program for saving as many Jews in the Nazi-occupied territories as possible.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- Reflecting reduced supplies and a lower level of livestock production, civilian meat supplies during the fall and early winter may be 8 or 10 per cent below those available in the first half of this year.

On "Primary Promotion Day" yesterday, volunteer workers from the New York City League of Women Voters handed out fliers urging people to vote, and agreed that women were taking more interest in this year's elections than ever before.

A review of the whole period since the United States entered the war indicates that considerable success has been achieved in diverting to the, use of the Government, for the financing of the war, the funds that have accumulated in private hands between Treasury financing operations, according to the August review of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
The "Note on Limericks" in THE NEW YORK TIMES makes reference to the claim that John O'Tuomy, a Limerick man who lived from 1706 to 1775, was the originator of this famous form of verse.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast by the Nazi DNB Agency in English to East Asia and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The Union Pacific Railway System has $156,191,500 of bonds which will mature in 1946 and 1947, F. W. Charske, chairman of the executive committee, reported today to the Interstate Commerce Commission, when the system asked the ICC for authority to issue $8,120,000 of equipment trust certificates.

Jonas Bronck, originally of Swedish stock, lived in Denmark. Although Bronck came here from Amsterdam his associates were Danes and his personal library consisted of Danish publications. In fact Bronck served in the army of the King of Denmark. He was not an adventurer, but is reputed to have been a member of the Mennonites and suffered persecution.

Women telephone operators employed by the New York Telephone Company have contributed 5,500,000 packages of cigarettes for service men overseas during the last year, Mrs. David Bandler, vice president of the Citizens Committee for the Army and Navy, said yesterday.

The world premiere of "Wilson," the Technicolored biographical drama of President Woodrow Wilson and the era between 1909 and 1921, will take place tonight at the Roxy Theatre. Alexander Knox is starred as the World War President and the supporting cast is headed by Charles Coburn, Geraldine Fitzgerald, Thomas Mitchell, Ruth Nelson, Sir Cedric Hardwicke, Vincent Price, William Eythe, Mary Anderson, Ruth Ford and Sidney Blackmer.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Ord Bretherton of Villa Nova, Pa., have come to the St. Regis.

The former newspaper reporter, now Captain Bill Toumey with the American forces in England, who gave Queen Elizabeth his idea of the derivation of the name of Bronx Borough, decidedly won the award of $20 on a fluke. Nobody envies him the money, but the information he gave the British Queen regarding the origin of the Bronx is far from accurate.

WITH THE BRITISH SECOND ARMY, at St. Martin-des Besaces, July 31 -- What was left of this tiny village and its one-track railroad line after yesterday's onslaught by Allied bombers and British artillerymen was captured shortly after noon today, after a bitter slugging match by opposing ground forces.

An organization for international peace that would use military force if necessary was proposed here yesterday by Manley O. Hudson, judge of the World Court, as chairman of a committee of citizens, many of whom were in the Paris peace delegation of 1919 or officials of the League of Nations.

PHILADELPHIA, July 31 (AP) - The War Manpower Commission today classified the Philadelphia-Camden area, with 3,000,000 population, and the Newark area, with 1,600,000 population, as critical labor shortage areas, in which the award of new war contracts is restricted.

Early small gains made yesterday in the futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange were erased in the later trading and the finish was near or at the lows of the day, showing net losses of 10 to 15 points.
KANDY, Ceylon, July 31 (AP) -- A communique:

On the basis of polls taken on a non-partisan basis that confirm results shown in private Republican surveys, Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican National chairman, contended yesterday that the Republicans would carry at least twenty-five States in November.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- Senator J.G. Scrugham, Democrat, of Nevada, announced today that he and Senators J.G. Murray of Montana and Carl Hayden of Arizona would propose soon legislation providing for Government aid to permit resumed operation of gold mines, mill or smelting and other mining industries stopped by the War Production Board's regulations.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- A subcommittee of Senators, Tunnell of Delaware, a Democrat, and Ferguson of Michigan, a Republican, was named today by the Senate Campaign Expenditures Investigating Committee to look into the fund-collecting activities of the State Republican League, Inc., of Union City, N.J., and the Republican Citizens Committee of Jersey City.

Macy's mid-summer furniture show, which each season becomes more of a decorating exhibit, opened yesterday with three groups of new rooms that range from practical solutions of everyday living problems to pastel extravaganzas from the realm of decorators' dreams.

Genevieve McCallum, 18-year-old Negro of 585 Quincy Street, in the Bedford section of Brooklyn, was held in bail of $1,000 last night in Brooklyn-Queens Night Court on an assault charge preferred by Mrs. Lee Perlman, who said that the girl had struck and kicked her when she refused to give up her seat in a crowded Gates Avenue bus so that the defendant could share a double seat with a friend.

The mid-July parity price for cotton, issued yesterday by the Department of Agriculture, was 21.08 cents a pound, the same as for the last five months. However, July 15 parity price is more important than the others since it is used as the base price for the loan rate on the year's cotton crop.

The stalemate in coffee transactions between Brazil and the United States was broken yesterday by the completion of purchases of 1,000,000 bags of Santos coffee by the Army for immediate shipment, it was learned in the trade.
CHUNGKING, China, July 31 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

Artillery boomed from near-by emplacements and a small, hot wind brought the sound of distant machinegun and artillery fire as Colonel Silverthorn completed the reading of Admiral Nimitz's proclamation declaring Guam to be again under American control.

LONDON, July 31 -- Baron Franz von Papen, German Ambassador, warned Turkish Premier Shukru Saracoglu today that Turkey's reported plans to break diplomatic and economic relations with the Axis would have grave consequences for her, the Berlin radio reported tonight.

OTTAWA, July 31 (Canadian Press) -- The United States has five large air bases in Canada's sub-Arctic stretches around Hudson Bay and on Baffin Island and, it was learned here tonight, Ottawa officials will shortly visit each to see to what extent they can be made to fit post-war aviation.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Allied bombing attacks on Nazi supply plants and refineries have brought Germany face to face with her most critical oil shortage, Leo T. Crowley, Foreign Economic Administrator, declared in a statement here today.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- The successful operations of American submarines in the Pacific, coupled with the urgent need for other weapons, resulted today in a decision by the Navy to trim its undersea ship production program.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 1 -- The California Shipbuilding Corporation at Los Angeles notified the War Labor Board today that its production schedule of transports would be delayed if San Francisco machinists persisted in their refusal to work at the Federal-Mogul Corporation's bearings plant in this city.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 1 -- A special communique issued tonight on the activity of the French Forces of the Interior deep within France said that the Germans had already had the worst of a number of battles against the FFI, which were described as steadily building up into a grave menace to the enemy behind his lines.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Handicapped by absenteeism over the Fourth of July week-end and the taking of inventories, the aircraft plants of the country turned out only 8,000 planes in July, 499 below the number scheduled by military and production officials, Charles E. Wilson, chairman of the Aircraft Production Board, reported today.

LONDON, Wednesday, Aug. 2 (U.P.) -- Russian troops, in a sensational 32-mile break through, yesterday reached the Baltic Sea twenty-five miles west of Riga, trapping possibly 200,000 to 300,000 German troops in an area greater than Belgium and the Netherlands.

KALAMAZOO, Mich., Aug 1 (AP) -- The defending champion, Bob Falkenburg of Hollywood and Merced Field, Calif., paced a parade of favorites into the third round of the national junior tennis championship today, as only one seeded performer, Ed McGrath of Brooklyn, ranked sixth, met defeat.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 1 -- The Turkish Government is expected to hand German Ambassador Franz von Papen his passport tomorrow in breaking relations. This information came from most reliable diplomatic sources. If by any chance the break is not announced tomorrow it is expected within forty-eight hours.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended July 26, the Federal Reserve Board announced today:
The news that came to Mel Ott yesterday must have increased the pain from the badly sprained right ankle which kept him from personally leading his club for the first time this year.

The stock market staged yesterday a sudden break through on the recovery side, and although some resistance was encountered prices closed irregularly higher. Under a somewhat improved brand of leadership than characterized the spurt early in July, volume increased on the advance to the best in a week.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES, Outside Percy, France, Aug. 1 -- It was dawn when the first gun slammed from the copse to our right. As the sun climbed, battery after battery joined in the barrage and tanks and infantry went forward.

DETROIT, Aug. 1 -- Getting ready to return East after more than a fortnight's jaunt around the western wheel of the American League, this observer will fetch home with him as curious an impression as ever lodged itself in his skull in all the years he has been observing events in major league baseball.

The Federal Council in Berne has revised the views it has held from time immemorial on the right of asylum. It has whittled down that right considerably. Hitler, Goering, Himmler, Mussolini, Starace and the like would be turned out of Swiss territory tomorrow if they tried to step in by land or by air.
KANDY, Ceylon, Aug. 1 (UP) -- A communique:
Since in your editorial on July 31 you mention that you have never heard of Pieter Bronck, alleged son of Jonas Bronck, name-giver to the Bronx, I would like to call your attention to the following:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Immediate action by Congress to assert its control over Government-owned corporations and make such agencies subject to strict supervision by the Bureau of the Budget, the Treasury and the General Accounting Office was recommended today by the Joint Committee on Reduction of Non-Essential Federal Expenditures, of which Senator Harry F. Byrd, of Virginia, is chairman.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES IN FRANCE, Aug. 1 -- American Negro truck drivers, wielding jungle knives, charged into the fighting line today and started carving up the Germans with enthusiasm and inspiring efficiency in a savage melee north of Percy.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- Living conditions in German-occupied Greece are deteriorating rapidly and the country, saved from starvation by shipments of wheat from the United States and Canada in the last two years, urgently needs additional medical and food supplies, George Cartalis, new Greek Minister of Information in London, told a news conference today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 1 -- Twentieth Century-Fox will do a musical version of the play "Three Blind Mice," which already has been filmed twice by that company. The new edition, to be entitled "Three Little Girls in Blue," will have Vivian Blaine, June Haver and Jeanne Crain in the leads.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast in English to North America from Chungking and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

Lionel Barrymore's Partita (Prelude, Aria, Introduction and Fugue) will be performed for the first time in this city at tonight's all-orchestral concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, to begin at 8:30 o'clock at the Lewisohn Stadium. Fabien Sevitsky will conduct.

An increase of 90 cents a hundred pounds for potatoes was granted to Long Island farmers yesterday by the Regional Office of Price Administration to compensate them for a 40 to 50 per cent drop in crops caused by the drought.

In answer to casual questions to my husband regarding the bombing of the German oil fields I received an answer this morning. My husband is commanding officer of a Seabee battalion in the South Pacific. He has been out of the country for twenty months. To my way of thinking, letters like this from our men at the front could do much to discourage the buying of black market gasoline.
BOSTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Pittsburgh rattled eighteen hits all over Braves Field today and wound up on the long end of a 12-to-8 score in an uncompleted game with the Braves.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Tex Hughson was handed his fifth loss today instead of gaining his seventeenth victory as the Indians pounded him for eleven hits to turn back the Red Sox, 8 to 4, and secure an even break in the four-game series.

Only 248 New York men and women have been recruited toward a quota of 4,000 to 5,000 vacation workers needed on up-State farms during the peak harvesting periods from the middle of August to the end of October, according to a report yesterday from the United States Employment Service of the War Manpower Commission.

Rounding out the fourth successive quarter in which deliveries of war materials have been about $1,000,000,000, averaging $12,700,000 every working day for twelve months, General Motors Corporation reports a net profit of $82,769,895 for the first half of 1944, equal to $1.78 a share of common stock, against $64,801,085, or $1.49 a share, in the same period last year.
CHUNGKING, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command announced officially tonight that an "enemy advance" had been stopped by "troops of our inner ring" at besieged and encircled Hengyang.

There are ten girls as scenic background of "School for Brides," which paused at the Royale last evening in headlong flight 'twixt Chicago and oblivion. In the first act they wear bathing suits and that brown paint. In the second act they wear sweaters for the first scene and nightgowns for second, and an audience which lingers will see them in lounging pyjamas after the final intermission.

DETROIT, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Production of aircraft engine parts at five General Motors plants here was still at a standstill today as 7,000 workers ignored a War Labor Board back-to-work order and union officers stated that the international executive board of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, would be asked to take over the local organizations.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Americans who leaped 200 miles toward the Philippines to land at Sansapor on Sunday hopped ten miles farther west on Monday and seized a Japanese barge base.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 1 -- Great South Bay's annual Race Week, a combined event of ten yacht clubs along the south side of Long Island, started today with sixty-three craft competing and a score more entered that did not sail in the opening session.
SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- Manuel Quezon, 65, exiled President of the Philippine Commonwealth, died today at his summer home here.

NEW DELHI, India, July 31 (Delayed) -- Far-reaching objections voiced yesterday at Lahore by Mohammed Ali Jinnah, president of the Moslem League, to the Rajagopalichari-Gandhi formula for an agreement between the Moslem League and the All-India Congress party on the Moslem demands for a separate Indian State foreshadowed difficulties today for the discussion scheduled for next week in Bombay between Mr. Jinnah and Mohandas K. Gandhi.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- Prime Minister Churchill will rise in the House of Commons tomorrow to make his first comprehensive review of the war since February 22. He probably will have an opportunity to add a postscript to an Ankara announcement of a drastic revision of Turkish policy.

Someone has figured that if a person were to enter all the championship events at the Grand American trapshooting tournament to be held at Vandalia, Ohio, from Aug. 23 to 25, he would need 500 shells. No one has figured where he would get those shells unless he had a nice hoard laid away for the purpose.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 1 -- The mass evacuation of German wounded from hospitals in France indicates that great events are impending now that the Allies are pushing their way from Normandy into the interior. Competent circles expect a general movement northward from the Pyrenees and the Mediterranean in the relatively near future.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Communique 113:

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 1 (U.P.) -- Mauricio Hochschild, wealthy Argentine industrialist, has mysteriously disappeared and local authorities said today there was a possibility that he had been kidnapped.

"Mr. Winkle Goes to War," starring Edward G. Robinson, will open today at Loew's Criterion. The picture is about a meek bank clerk who is transformed into a hard-fighting Army hero. The supporting cast includes Ruth Warrick, Ted Donaldson, Bob Haymes, Richard Lane, Robert Armstrong and Richard Gaines. Alfred E. Green directed and Jack Moss produced the film for Columbia.

United States forces in the Pacific have moved into another phase of their converging campaign which brings them closer to the Philippines. The pincers are closing from two directions. General MacArthur's troops have just pushed into the northwest tip of New Guinea, bringing them within 600 miles of Mindanao, while the joint Navy and Army conquest of the Marianas nears completion.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 1 -- According to an official statement, President Risto Ryti of Finland resigned today. Field Marshal Baron Carl Gustav Mannerheim was appointed as his successor. In its bulletin the Government said the situation was too serious to allow a common election for a new President.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- Representative Hamilton Fish Jr., fighting for his political existence in territory largely new to him won renomination as Republican candidate for Congress in the new Twenty-ninth District tonight by the margin of about 3,000 votes.

For the first time in its history the Pepperell Manufacturing Company will embark on an advertising program designed to make its fabrics used in work clothing familiar to the consumer in the post-war period, it was announced yesterday.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 5.3 per cent in July over the same month last year, according to the monthly survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. In June these stores had an increase of 11.6 per cent.

Consolidated earnings of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., for the first half of this year were estimated yesterday by John A. Brown, president, at about $20,000,000. This estimate is after allowance for all taxes, including excess profits taxes, but it is in advance of final accounting.

The Pennsylvania Railroad Company stated yesterday, in a letter to stockholders and employes, that the proposed Railroad Social Insurance Bill should be withdrawn because in the end it would "undermine the whole structure of the railroad pension plan and might destroy it."
LONDON, Aug. 1 (U.P.) -- The flying bomb attack on England continued today as Home Secretary Herbert Morrison told the House of Commons that the Germans had employed a new silent robot.

Unless the Government in the immediate future inaugurates a program for collection of used clothing, particularly woolen and worsted garments, to be used for relief purposes among populations of reconquered areas, aims for such rehabilitation will remain largely unachieved, according to a spokesman for the wool spinning and weaving industries yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The Sixteenth Infantry, "New York's own," which saved an Army corps from catastrophe on D-day, received double honors today.

It might take a man ten years to read all the volumes that have been written in ten years about nazism and the German people. Wise and learned men, and women, too, correspondents who lived a long time in Germany, studying with keen eyes the strange marriage of a once-great nation with a loathsome idea, philosophers, sociologists, all have written of this horrible riddle.

In spite of yesterday's War Food Administration order curtailing the ice-cream output, 30,000,000 more gallons will be consumed in this country this year than in 1943, a WFA spokesman estimated. The order, which reduces the milk solid content used in the manufacture of ice cream to 65 per cent of 1942 standards, represents a cutback to the production level used in the corresponding month last year.
DETROIT, Aug. 1 -- The Yankees concluded their second Western invasion of the year on a sour note this evening as they went crashing down to defeat before the Tigers in the series final, 8 to 4.

While Navy textile procurements will continue at their present peak during the last quarter, substantial reduction in Army purchases can be expected prior to the end of the European phase of the war, according to Donald B. Tansill, vice president of the Pepperell Manufacturing Company.

OTTAWA, Aug. 1 (Canadian Press) -- General conditions for promising crops were well maintained last week and harvesting of grain crops is under way in many parts of Canada, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today in the tenth of its sixteen weekly reports on conditions on the prairies.

DETROIT, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Gerald L.K. Smith said tonight that the Michigan central committee of the America First party would nominate a successor to Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio as Smith's running mate on the party's ticket.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -Rear Admiral Charles P. Cecil, 59, died in an airplane crash in the Pacific Monday, the Navy announced today.

NOEL BUSCH'S "What Manner of Man?"* isn't exactly a psychoanalysis of Franklin D. Roosevelt, for Mr. Busch has no particular theory of human motivation to guide his investigations or to exploit for its dramatic unity. Nevertheless, Mr. Busch has achieved an eclectic substitute for the Freudian or Jungian approach. The result is a book that charms and baffles.

KWEILIN, China, July 28 (Delayed) -- In an obscure corner of the paper Ta Kung Pao was published an order for the first evacuation. Kweilin citizens who can conveniently leave the town were advised to go now before the roads and railroad are clogged with refugees.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- In a dual-pricing action on petroleum and petroleum products, the Office of Price Administration today revised price regulations covering crude oil from stripper wells, and established a new method for determining ceiling prices for fuel oil.

A good many people would have been considerably disappointed if Queen Elizabeth's expressed interest in the Bronx had not aroused an appropriate response in this country. Their potential disappointment has now been assuaged, and handsomely, by Borough President James J. Lyons.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Field Marshal Baron Carl Gustav Mannerheim, commander in chief of Finland's armed forces, tonight accepted Parliament's call to the Presidency, succeeding Risto Ryti and opening the way for formation of a "peace government."
PEARL HARBOR, Aug. 1 -- The Battle of Tinian ended last night when organized Japanese resistance crumpled beneath the island's southern cliffs.

Shelled from the mound in three frames the night before, Morton Cooper bounced right back yesterday at Ebbets Field and this time coasted to a 14-3 victory over the Dodgers. That the Cardinals routed the Brooks, however, is not the real, sad story. Rather, it was the failure of Whitlow Wyatt that cast a pall over the park.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 1 -- Possibly as propaganda in preparation for the Turkish Parliament meeting tomorrow, unconfirmed reports were allowed to "leak" through a rigorous German censorship late tonight of a "serious frontier incident" between Turkish and Bulgarian troops near Svilengrad in the lower Maritza Valley today.
LONDON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- Wanton destruction of Italy's cultural treasures by retreating German troops has been a common feature of the German Army's retreat north from Cassino, it was revealed here today by Sir James Grigg, Secretary of War, in a written reply to E.H. Keeling, Conservative member of the House of Commons for Twickenham.
