SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Wednesday, Aug. 2 -- The American First Army has broken out of the Norman Peninsula and into the battlefield of France.

A chain of self-service stores that will deal exclusively in frozen foods will be opened in New York City soon under an arrangement recently completed between Frozen Food Centers, Inc., a distributing company, and the Refrigeration Corporation of America.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (AP) -- For the Second straight game, Irv Hall, Philadelphia second baseman, hit an overtime triple to beat the White Sox today, the blow coming in the twelfth inning for a 2-1 victory.

ROME, Aug. 1 (U.P.) -- The Germans have hurled possibly 75,000 troops, including three top divisions, into the semicircular mountain line below Florence in a final desperate effort to halt the British Eighth Army's onslaught.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 1- The American Can Company plant here remained idle for a second day today as the result of a wildcat strike by approximately 900 employes in protest against the company's employment of part-time employes, limiting the amount of overtime the full-time workers receive.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The four-power Conference on Security Organization for Peace in the Post-war World will open here on Aug. 14 with sessions among representatives of the United States, the United Kingdom and the Soviet Union, Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Acting Secretary of State, announced today.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Considering the current question of the trial of German and Japanese war criminals by Allied tribunals, we must, I think, always bear in mind the results of the "trials" of war offenders in the last war.

Three Philadelphians and a New Yorker took the national contract bridge mixed team-of-four championship yesterday for the second year in a row in the eighteenth annual tournament of the American Contract Bridge League, in progress at the Hotel Astor.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 1 -- On his way to the conference of Republican Governors in St: Louis, Governor Dewey campaigned today in southern Illinois. Here are the highlights of his activities:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Action by agencies of the government has gone a long way toward ending a labor-renting "racket" costing millions in inflated charges for labor, a sub-committee of the House Committee on Military Affairs, reported today. The subcommittee headed by Representative Carl T. Durham, of North Carolina, mentioned the labor-renting evil in a report last March.

Hoodoo, Col. C.V. Whitney's clever colt, who has been carrying around a load that the more publicized Pukka Gin was expected to tote until he failed to stand up to training round about Kentucky Derby time, yesterday was even hotter than the scorching sun that caused 20,730 racing patrons to wilt and droop at the Saratoga Association's transplanted summer session at Belmont Park.

High taxes on furs have not hampered designers in making coats for next winter luxurious. Jay Thorpe, which displayed its collection in the Viennese Room of the St. Regis roof at luncheon yesterday, believes in the extravagant use of handsome pelts.

Representatives Vito Marcantonio and Hamilton Fish emerged victorious from yesterday's primary elections, in which the enrolled voters of New York selected party nominees for the November elections. Mr. Marcantonio made a clean sweep of the primaries in the new Eighteenth district, Manhattan, while Mr. Fish overcame formidable opposition to win the Republican nomination for Congress in the new Twenty-ninth district in the lower Catskills and Rockland County.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- After Senator Harry S. Truman was nominated for Vice President by the Democratic National Convention, the Republicans began a search of the record of his special committee on the war program in an effort to prove that the Democrats had nominated as the President's running-mate an open critic of his preparedness record who, with his committee, had squarely placed responsibility for its delays and basic defects upon Mr. Roosevelt himself.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Reconvening today with less than a quorum of either house on hand, Congress took to the sidelines and watched while rival groups sprang strategic surprises indicating an early taking of industrial demobilization measures to the Senate floor for a straight-out test between "liberal" and "conservative" programs.

Manuel Quezon, despite a long and stubborn fight for the independence of his native islands, which was climaxed by the passage of the Philippine Independence Act of 1934 and his own election as first President of the Philippines on Sept. 17, 1935, remained a loyal friend of the United States and a firm supporter of American arms in the war that engulfed his country.

Don't be surprised to find all roads leading to the "air-conditioned" Shubert this evening. There Mae West, who forsook Broadway for Hollywood thirteen years ago, will resume her affiliation with the street that catapulted her into prominence in "Catherine Was Great" at 8:30 P.M. She wrote the play, which was directed by Roy Hargrave.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 -- With only routine news appearing, prices of wheat on the Board of Trade held today within a range of about 1/2 cent a bushel. Mills were moderate buyers at times, with some selling attributed to Southwestern interests. Pressure was mainly on the May, and with a little spreading with September the price difference narrowed around 1/2 cent.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Nominations of ten Army officers for temporary promotion in recognition of their leadership and courage in various theatres of the war were sent to the Senate today by President Roosevelt. Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell leads the list recommended for the temporary rank of full general.

Six-year-old Bobby Baldini, whose ambition is to become a detective, has had his first case and it was solved yesterday. But, unfortunately, the mystery -- the disappearance of his aunt's engagement ring and wrist watch, valued at $340 and exchanged for thirty-five cents worth of trinkets -- was not "cracked" by him. In fact, the youngster was the central figure in the case.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The final yield of the Fifth War Loan was $20,639,000,000, Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. announced tonight.

In his letter entitled "Regimentation Is Foreseen" Albert A. Volk states that "the New Deal endeavors to create a way under the Constitution by which prosperity will come first to the bulk of the people, whence it will flow through their hands into those of the financial and industrial leaders in tax-limited measure."

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUATERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Aug. 1 (U.P.) -- Allied troops in a wide swing through the low hills southeast of Churachandpur have knifed into Japanese supply lines far to the enemy's rear and are threatening to cut the main escape route for the remnants of two Japanese divisions fleeing south along the Tiddim road, a communique said today.

Praising merchant seamen as "first-class citizens," William S. Newell, president of United Seamen's Service, Inc., said yesterday that "the USS along with other agencies is leaving no stone unturned in its effort to make it possible for these men to exercise their right to vote."

Manuel Luis Quezon, President of the Philippine Commonwealth, who died yesterday at Saranac, came to power in a community whose political institutions were modeled after ours but which had a Far Eastern background of its own. He was at once an adroit politician and the patriotic leader of a racially and socially diversified nation.

WILMINGTON, N.C., Aug. 1 (AP) -- A tropical storm of hurricane proportions veered inland slightly south of Wilmington late tonight after lashing this war-booming port for more than four hours and causing extensive damage.

J. Eugene Thompson of the home club, aided by an eighteen-stroke handicap, captured low-net honors with 84 -- 18 -- 66 in the one-day tournament of the Metropolitan Golf Association at the Pomonok Country Club in Flushing yesterday. A field of ninety-two started.

I have just returned from a half-business, half-pleasure trek which covered most of the Middle West, Pacific Coast and as far north as Vancouver, B.C. And, speaking as a born New Yorker, I wish we would take some lessons from the people of those sections.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The fundamental policies of the CIO-Political Action Committee, as they relate to the raising of campaign funds and its methods of operation, are meeting increasingly with stern resistance from some important elements in the American Federation of Labor and the independent railroad brotherhoods.

The annual report of the Dow Chemical Company and its subsidiaries disclosed yesterday a net profit of $8,573,503 for the year ended on May 31, equal to $6.34 a share of common stock. In the preceding fiscal year the company showed a net of $8,225,301, or $6.35 a common share.

The President has nominated Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell to the rank of full general. This will make him the sixth officer of our armed forces to win this exalted title since the war started. Our commander in the Burma-India-China theatre will stand in the group with Marshall, Eisenhower, MacArthur, Arnold and Malin Craig.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- Civilians as well as army officers were implicated in the recent attempt against Adolf Hitler's life, it was revealed tonight by Joseph Goebbels, who in a melodramatic broadcast named a Prussian politician, Dr. Karl Goerdeler, as having had a hand in the plot to assassinate the Fuehrer.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Authoritative sources disclosed tonight that steaks and roasts from utility grades of beef will be made ration-free beginning Aug. 13, but that hams and pork loins will be returned to the ration list. By Sept. 1 steaks and roasts from the better commercial grade of beef also will be made point-free.

NORTH BERGEN, N.J., Aug. 1 -- The threatened eviction of Mrs. Augusta Parrott, 60-year-old war mother, from her home at 19 Seventy-seventh Street, here, for nonpayment of taxes was averted late today when a married daughter arranged to purchase the property from the township.

Although not authorized to speak for the Chinese Government with regard to what should be done with Japan after the war, Dr. H.H. Kung, Vice Premier and Finance Minister of his country, outlined yesterday what he called "popular opinion" on this subject.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 1 -- John J. Keegan, 24 years old, a veteran of the Pacific warfare, who received a medical discharge last April, was charged with murder today after he shot and fatally wounded his estranged wife, Marie, 22, in a taxicab, according to police.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Howard V. Broenstrup, a defendant in mass sedition in trial, proposed in November, 1941, that a campaign be started for the impeachment of President Roosevelt as Commander in Chief of the nation's armed forces on the ground of insanity, the jury was told today.

Mrs. Evelyn Thompson, who works with the War Finance Committee at 1270 Sixth Avenue, declared a one-day holiday for herself yesterday when she saw a newspaper picture of her husband taken as he planted the United States flag on the island of Guam.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Senators Green and Lucas, authors of the soldier-vote law, today offered an amendment to it relaxing political propaganda restrictions by giving overseas service men access to the same publications and broadcasts they would get at home.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, Aug. 2 (U.P.) -- American forces in Northern New Guinea crossed the lower Driniumor River below Aitape on Monday and are driving eastward, apparently aiming at completing the annihilation of 45,000 trapped Japanese in that sector, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today.

Despite announcement by the Office of Price Administration of ceiling prices for canned spinach, asparagus and red sour pitted cherries of the 1944 pack, the canned foods market continues stagnant, it was learned yesterday in the wholesale grocery trade here.

LONDON, Wednesday, Aug. 2 -- The Moscow radio reported today that the Council of People's Commissars of the Soviet Union and the Polish Committee of National Liberation have exchanged representatives.

LONDON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Reports from inside Germany tonight said Gen. Otto von Stuelpnagel had killed himself after the plot to kill Adolf Hitler failed and that Field Marshal Gen. Ernst von Busch, commander of the German army in the central sector of the Eastern Front, had commtted suicide after he was grilled in connection with the plot and then dismissed.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission modified today its June 23 order approving the merger of four Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation subsidiaries to extend to Nov. 20 the original sixty-day period in which the transactions were to be completed.

Submitting to thorough physical examinations by Dr. William H. Walker and Dr. Ronald Nesi of the New York State Athletic Commission, Bob Montgomery and Beau Jack, principals in Friday night's non-title ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden, were declared fit yesterday.

OTTAWA, Aug. 1 -- At a cost of $76,811,551, Canada is taking over the two chains of airfields built by or in conjunction with the United States as a measure of continental defense in the war, Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King announced today in the House of Commons.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Aug. 2 -- The Soviet High Command last night announced the capture of Kaunas, pre-war capital of Lithuania, and reported that the Red Army farther north had severed all road connections between the Baltic States and East Prussia, virtually encircling the Riga garrison.
Smith, Barney Co. have announced the opening of a stock department at their 522 Fifth Avenue office under Geoffrey J. Dwyer.

BOSTON, Aug. 1 -- Defeating Edward S. Jackson Jr. of Short Hills, N.J., one of his chief rivals, in the fifth round, after taking his fourth-round match with Morton Hamermesh of Boston, Samuel Reshevsky of Brooklyn, former United States champion, made a two-point advance in his quest of the open championship of the United States Chess Federation at the Boston City Club today.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 1 -- Manley Hudson, judge of the Permanent Court of International Justice, outlined today the principles that in his opinion should be followed in building an international organization designed to insure cooperation among all the states of the world in an effort to secure permanent peace and cooperation.

ROME, Aug. 1 -- Don Luigi Sturzo's statement in his broadcast to Italy on Sunday that Allied chancelleries are negotiating a tentative peace agreement with Italy was published in this morning's newspapers and has aroused great hopes and satisfaction.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 1 (AP) -- Rutgers authorities, unwilling to drop collegiate football which Rutgers instituted with Princeton University seventy-five years ago, have decided to continue the university's abbreviated wartime five-game football schedule during the 1944-45 season, George E. Little, athletics director, announced today.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Wednesday, Aug. 2 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Local and State draft authorities got word from national headquarters today to proceeed with the induction of men over 25 years old who were making no contribution to the war effort. They were also instructed to sweep out of Class 1-A all the men over 25 whose work entitles them to deferment, leaving in 1-A only those registrants who actually were available for induction.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- Gilt edge issues were the feature in today's stock market, recent strength being stimulated by the Chancellor's announcement of a new issue of 3 per cent savings bonds maturing in August, 1975, and with the option to redeem in August, 1965.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 1 Industrialists, manufacturers and organized labor combined here today to protest the change in the Newark area from Group 2 to Group 1, by the Regional War Manpower Commission in Philadelphia, which has reclassified the district as an acute labor shortage area.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 1 -- Governor Bricker, Republican nominee for Vice President, denounced as "the cheapest of demagoguery" today the attempts of Gerald L.K. Smith to associate his name with that of Smith in the national campaign.

The Consumers Public Power District of Nebraska awarded yesterday $1,400,000 of North Platte Division refunding revenue bonds, due from 1945 to 1958, to John Nuveen Co., Stranahan, Harris Co., Wachob-Bender Corporation, and the First Trust Company of Lincoln, Neb.

Unless steps are taken to increase sugar production in areas which supply this country's requirements, there is likely to be a serious shortage for household and industrial use for several years after the war, John J. Riley, secretary of the American Bottlers of Carbonated Beverages, declared yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Senator Bennett Champ Clark trailed Attorney General Roy McKittrick tonight in a primary race for the Democratic Sena rial nomination which appeared to be so close that it may take absentee -which will be counted Friday -- to decide the winner.

Mayor La Guardia told the 130 assessors of the Tax Department at their annual meeting in City Hall yesterday that "in many circles there has been a tendency" to depreciate Manhattan real estate values, and warned the assessors that it was their duty to protect the values and prevent speculators from gaining a monopoly hold on the property of "the mightiest city in the world."
Steadiness prevailed yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange with final prices 3 to 6 points net higher on the day.

At the end of the third week of a waste paper salvage campaign being sponsored by the Board of Education, its 305 summer playgrounds throughout the city have been depots for the collection so far of nearly 324 tons of paper, it was announced yesterday by Francis J. Brennan, the board's acting director of recreation.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The Browns extended their American League lead to five and one-half games tonight -- their biggest margin of the season -- by defeating the hapless Senators, 11 to 6. It was the eleventh consecutive loss for the Senators and their fourth-in-a-row to the Browns.
LONDON, Aug. 1 (UP) -- A German communique, a broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Railroad Earnings Although gross revenues continue to mount, the net income of the nation's railroads are showing a steady decline. The Association of American Railroads yesterday estimated the net income of the Class I roads in June at $60,000, 000, compared with $70,626,341 in the similar month last year.

A collection of imports from the Republic of El Salavdor that will be found in New York stores toward the end of September presents an interesting adaptation of native handicraft techniques to the practical demands of the American homemaker.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1 -- The entire system of the Philadelphia Transportation Company, which operates all of the subway and elevator lines, street cars and buses in this city, one of the country's most important war centers, was paralyzed today by an unexpected strike caused by a dispute over the employment of Negro drivers.

WITH THE AMERICAN RED CROSS IN INDIA -- The opening of a Red Cross "on-post" club in the wilds of India is a big thing, important enough for eight of us girls from "big city headquarters" to fly 300 miles to attend.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Wednesday, Aug. 2 -- Nazi airports at Chateaudun, Orleans-Bricy, Tours and Melun, part of the enemy's system encircling Paris and the last effective Luftwaffe bases near the Normandy-Brittany battleground were bombed yesterday by about 750 heavy bombers of the United States Eighth Air Force escorted by more than 1,000 fighter planes.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 2 -- Germany intends to retain complete liberty of action toward Turkey, it was stated in the Foreign Office today following the news that Ankara had severed relations, according to reports from Berlin.
ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS ON NEW GUINEA, Thursday, Aug. 3 (AP) -- A communique:

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 2 -- Turkey broke her diplomatic and economic relations with Germany today at the request of Britain, backed by American diplomacy, but she clung to the hope of avoiding actual warfare. Prime Minister Shukru Saracoglu announced the Government's decision with his request for National Assembly approval. Most Deputies had been up almost all night at a caucus of the People's Republican party, Turkey's only political party, where the matter was settled.

A long-existent concern of the American Academy of Pediatrics over the administration of the Federal Emergency Maternity and Infant Care program by the Children's Bureau of the Department of Labor, evidently stemming from the possible implications of socialized medicine inherent in the plan, was brought into the open yesterday when the latest issue of the Journal of Pediatrics announced that the academy is withdrawing its support from the Children's Bureau.

America cannot and must not go back to pre-war levels of production, of employment, or of wages, in the post-war period, Paul G. Hoffman, president of the Stude-baker Corporation and chairman of the Committee on Economic Development, declared last night at a dinner in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Carrying on the drive of the Office of Price Administration to keep down the cost of living, OPA inspectors served summonses yesterday on seventy-five service establishments, largely shoe repair places, in Manhattan and the Bronx. They were charged with having failed to file with the OPA their pricing records for the base period of March, 1942.

LONDON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Berlin admitted tonight that Field Marshal Gen. Erwin Rommel, second in command of the German armies in the west, had met with "an accident" while driving in France during an air attack and was suffering from brain concussion.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Japanese forces have made sharp gains in the eastern sector of the Hunan Province fighting, but at encircled Hengyang, holding out in its fifth week of siege, ten separate enemy attacks were thrown back, the Chinese High Command announced tonight.

Venturing the prediction that "millions" of Republicans felt as he did, Russell W. Davenport, novelist and magazine executive, asserted last night that Governor Dewey had failed to grasp the basic issues of international cooperation and world freedom and that therefore he could not support him as a Presidential candidate.

Civilian consumption of cigars for the fiscal year ended June 30 was at the lowest level since 1933, reflecting manpower shortages, slow deliveries by distributors due to gas and tire shortages, and huge military purchases.
SOMEWHERE IN NORMANDY, Aug. 2 -- The winding hilly roads in this section, ground into ruts and thick, suffocating yellow dust by American armor, carried a considerable number of war refugees today.

Certainly the champion volunteer blood donor of this city and New York State, Ben B. Hofstadter, a Brooklyn employe of the Consolidated Edison Company, was even acclaimed yesterday as the nation's leading donor -- so far as the records of the American Red Cross are concerned.

A communication which was published today under the apt title, "Deficit Financing Puzzles," and which consisted of a series of questions on the New Deal theory of unlimited and unpayable Government debt, had the not unusual characteristic of answering every one of its own questions excepting only the last, or key, question.

COLUMBUS, S.C., Aug. 2 -- Ordering their eight Presidential electors to vote for Franklin D. Roosevelt and Harry S. Truman, the Democrats of South Carolina in convention today refused to join any revolt which might be staged in the Electoral College against the regular ticket.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The Defense Plant Corporation has completed arrangements for the sale of surplus Army and Navy airplanes, and several distributing centers already have been established all over the country. Secretary Jones said today that delivery of some planes to sales centers and storage deposits was already under way.
The death in Normandy of Lieut. Gen. Lesley J. McNair, whose monument must be the ground forces that he helped to build, is one of the anachronistic tragedies of war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- A $3,000,000,000 cut has been made in budget estimates for the current fiscal year ending next June 30 on the assumption that the war with Germany will have ended before then, Harold D. Smith, Director of the Budget, disclosed today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2 -- An attempt by a small group of operators of subway and elevated trains to restore partial service on two main lines of the Philadelphia Transportation Company failed within a few hours of its beginning tonight.

LONDON, Aug. 2 -- While still declining the challenge by Richard Stokes, a Labor M.P., to a duel -- the weapons to be a British tank and a German Mark VI tank -- Prime Minister Churchill assured the House of Commons today that the British and American tanks engaged against the Germans in France were "in every way fitted for their tasks."

The Radio Corporation of America and its subsidiaries showed gross income from all sources of $156,166,006 for the first half of this year, representing an increase of $15,164,640 over the $141,001,366 gross income for the corresponding six months a year ago, Lieut. Gen. James G. Harbord (retired), chairman of the board, reported yesterday.

Edwin F. Jaeckle, Republican State chairman, announced yesterday the appointment, in line with party rules, of a new Republican State Executive Committee of twenty-two members in addition to the officers of the State Committee and the two New York members of the National Committee.

MONTREAL, Thursday, Aug. 3 (Canadian Press) -- Tramcars started to leave Montreal streets shortly after midnight as employes in the operating departments of Montreal Tramways Company, members of the Canadian Brotherhood of Railway Employes, carried out their scheduled strike.

Briggs at Miami Beach tells us it has for sale the largest assortment of tropical jellies and marmalades in Florida. Though we cannot vouch for the size of the collection, we are certain it is one of the most unusual, for sitting before us as we write are sample jars with such exotic labels as carissa jelly, jambosa jelly and pitanga jelly.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 2 -- Bob Thomson's Carolina, representing the Stamford Yacht Club, today continued to lead in the annual championship races of the Junior Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound sponsored by the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- An announcement by the War Department today revealed that Lieut. Gen. Lesley J. McNair, former commanding general of the United States Army Ground Forces, whose death at the front in Normandy was reported last Thursday, had been killed by the explosion of an American bomb.

Despite the fact that his final heavy workout yesterday at Stillman's Gymnasium was his most impressive, Bob Montgomery was no better than an even choice to defeat Beau Jack in their ten-round War Bond bout at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 2 -- Accumulating returns from yesterday's primary election in Missouri showed Senator Bennett Champ Clark was defeated in his third-term bid for a seat in the United States Senate.

The Dodgers will have the local field to themselves today, when they clash with the Cubs in a double-header at Ebbets Field. The Giants have an exhibition at Fort Monmouth and will not resume league playing until tomorrow night, when they oppose the Phils under the lights at the Polo Grounds.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 2 -- Dr. P.H. Chang, Chinese Government spokesman, said today that American military observers were now en route to various points in the long-barred Communist areas of north China.

If Gerald L.K. Smith's "America Firsters" hoped for encouragement from Governor Dewey or Governor Bricker, they were as wrong and foolish on that point as on others. They have now been assured that Governor Dewey considers Mr. Smith "one of those rabble-rousers who, like Adolf Hitler, makes racial prejudice his stock in trade.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Following is the statement by the Director of the Bureau of the Budget:

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 3 -- A request that a former Argentine Deputy and a veteran Socialist leader, Dr. Nicolas Repetto, should be indicted for high treason on grounds that he had "compromised the peace and dignity of the Argentine nation" has been presented to the Federal public prosecutor in Buenos Aires.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 103:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Phenomenal advances by Lieut. Gen. Omar N. Bradley's troops in Normandy over the past several days make increasingly imperative the seizure of ports on the Breton Peninsula to relieve the strain on the supply services, a War Department spokesman said today.

Registration records of the Eighteenth Congressional District, where Representative Vito Marcantonio won renomination by all three legally recognized political parties, were subpoenaed yesterday by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan as Republicans went forward with plans to ask for a recount under court supervision.

LONDON, Friday, Aug. 4 -- Red Army troops shattered the Axis Vistula River line in Poland yesterday, smashing fifteen miles beyond that last natural defense barrier short of the "holy soil" of Germany in a broad flow of men and tanks that flanked burning Warsaw and sped toward German Silesia, only 100 miles away.

Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh was accused in a suit filed in Supreme Court yesterday by the Uniformed Firemen's Association of imposing a gag rule on New York's 7,000 firemen and violating their constitutional right of free speech.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 3 -- Condemning "the listlessness, negligence and lack of leadership in Washington" which, they charged, was now "standing squarely in the path of the future employment of our returning veterans and millions of displaced war workers," twenty-six Republican Governors demanded today "comprehensive and immediate action by the national Government" to pave the way for industrial conversion to peacetime production "under an enterprise system" of private business.

F. Eberstadt Co. head an underwriting group which today will offer 27,500 shares of Walter E. Heller Co. 5 1/2 per cent cumulative preferred stock, $100 par value, at $104 and accrued dividends. Each share carries a warrant to buy two shares of common at $15 a share on or before Sept. 30, 1947, and at $17.50 thereafter for three years.

The Metropolitan Opera Association's statement of operations for its season of 1943-44 is more than a report of facts and figures, in themselves a record of achievement. It is testimony to the remarkable progress made in the teeth of the difficulties and confusions of a war-torn world and in the course of the hardest decade in the history of the institution.

To most readers the revised Federal budget tables published yesterday will be merely another nightmare of whirling billions. The picture will be clarified, however, if we keep our eyes on a few central items. The revised estimates for the fiscal year 1945 show total estimated expenditures of $99,000,000,000; net receipts of nearly $46,000,000,000, and a consequent deficit of $53,000,000,000.

Compulsory military training after the war for both boys and girls, beginning with the 18-year-olds, was advocated yesterday by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt. She said the training should emphasize citizenship responsibility.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed increase in holdings of Government securities and note circulation for the system as a whole to be $89,211,000 and $169,734,000, respectively, while the ratio of reserve declined slightly to 56.1. Gold certificates were also somewhat higher.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- C. E. Wilson, Executive Vice Chairman of the War Production Board, is opposed to the ideas of Richard Frankensteen of the CIO as to severance pay for workers in war industries whose contracts are cut back.

ROME, Aug. 3 (U.P.) -- On the Fifth Army front American artillery dispersed 200 German infantrymen who had crossed the Arno, forming for a daring counterattack northeast of Pontedera, twelve and a half miles east of Pisa.

Two new films will open today. At the Strand will be "Janie," a Warner Brothers production, starring Joyce Renolds, with Clare Foley, Edward Arnold, Robert Benchley, Ann Harding, Robert Hutton and Alan Hale in the supporting cast. . . .
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Friday, Aug. 4 -- Brittany appears to be lost to the Germans.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The White Sox continued their season-long superiority over the Indians today by taking two low-hit games, 3 to 2 and 5 to 1, before 8,187 fans. The double triumph made it eleven victories in fourteen meetings with the Tribe this year and sent the Sox into a tie for fifth place with the Tigers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (U.P.) -- Army casualties increased 11,190 from July 6 to July 13, raising the total of announced American casualties to 277,978 -- 62,766 dead. 118,950 wounded, 45,703 prisoners and 50,559 missing.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Temporary promotion to the rank of brigadier general has been recommended to the Senate by President Roosevelt for Col. William O'Dwyer, formerly District Attorney of Kings County.

The disintegration of the German military and political position was well started yesterday in the first of the decisive weeks of August that will determine how long the Nazis can postpone the inevitable.

The souvenir craze got Seaman Steve Misera, 24 years old, of Reading, Pa., in trouble yesterday when he was arrested in Brooklyn on a Sullivan Law charge for possession of two dismantled Army machine guns and an Army rifle. The sailor, who is a member of a Navy armed guard on a freighter tied up in Brooklyn, said that he had picked the guns up on the Normandy beachhead.

A nose on the post, with Transformer winning, was the result at Belmont yesterday in the $5,020 Campfire Handicap which saw four go to the post in three betting interests. In line with the old axiom, the outsider won in a three-horse field.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 3 -- Dean Harens, former Broadway stage actor who made his screen debut in the lead of the Deanna Durbin film "Christmas Holiday," has been chosen for the top male part in the forthcoming Walter Wanger color production "Salome."

The eight-story 218-family apartment building at 1511-21 Sheridan Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by the Granel Realty Company, Inc., from a client of Harry J. Fine, attorney. Located diagonally opposite the Howard Taft High School, the property is assessed at $825,000 and was sold subject to a first mortgage of $690,000.

A petition to the Office of Price Administration and complaints to the Board of Health, the Fire Department and other municipal law enforcement agencies will be sent in behalf of the 105 families of the thirteen-story apartment house at 640 Riverside Drive, it was announced last night after a meeting of a tenants' committee of eleven.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- For their services as human guinea pigs in experiments which considerably expanded scientific understanding of sandfly fever, fourteen soldiers have received the Legion of Merit, the War Department said today.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Friday, Aug. 4 -- Myitkyina, largest town in northern Burma, has fallen to the forces of Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell as the climax of a siege that began last May 17, an Allied announcement said today.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 3 -- Nine statements of policy, adopted by the conference of Republican Governors were made public as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, Friday, Aug. 4 -- The full executive committee representing the 6,000 striking employes of the Philadelphia Transportation Company voted unanimously early today not to return to work under Army control unless given a written guarantee that Negroes would not be employed as operators of the company's passenger-carrying equipment.

Vic Dellicurti, 159 1/2, Harlem, outpointed Marvin Bryant, 160 1/2, Dallas, Tex., in the main bout of eight rounds last night at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation in Brooklyn. A crowd of 3,700 saw the victor, the aggressor throughout, drop his rival for a three-count in the second stanza.

I Former associates in the Police Department, including Edward P. IVIulreoney, one-time commissioner, and members of the headquarters staff were among several hundred persons who attended a funeral service yesterday for Patrick Flood, retired New York detective, who was drowned on Stlnday at Rockaway Beach while swimming.

NORTH PELHAM, N.Y., Aug. 3 -- A raid on rooms in an office building above the Postoffice at 1 Wolfs Lane here today uncovered what Westchester District Attorney Elbert T. Gallagher said was the first organized baseball betting organization in his knowledge.

WITH THE MARINES ON OROTE PENINSULA, Guam, July 30 (Delayed) -- The Japanese defense of the Orote airfield, prize of the peninsula campaign, came to a flaming end yesterday as marine tanks, rifles, machine guns and mortars blasted enemy fortifications and then infantrymen surged along the sides of the field advancing over heaps of blackened, broken corpses, many still burning.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The Japanese, in flight from their disastrous invasion of northeast India, are abandoning their dead and large quantities of ammunition, the Southeast Asia Command announced today.

Any competent man, firm or corporation needing bank credit for a constructive purpose may have it in adequate amounts and for adequate periods, according to the post-war small business credit commission of the American Bankers Association, now engaged in mobilizing the nation's 15,000 banks for the post-war and reconversion periods.

KWEILIN, China, Aug. 1 (Delayed) -- Although many persons have gone westward to safer communities, the laopaihsing, or "little people," remain -- selling rice and vegetables under trees along the lakeside or making wooden tubs and brass kettles in workshops along the city streets.

Charley Grimm's redhot Cubs continued to run a torrid temperature at Ebbets Field yesterday, as they flattened the Dodgers twice, 6-2 and 7-1, to run their winning streak to nine games and ascend into fourth place -- the highest spot in the National League standing the Bruins have occupied since 1939.

NEWARK, N. J., Aug. 3 (AP) -- Dr. Harrison S. Martland, Chief Medical Examiner of Essex County said today that an autopsy showed that the death of Lem Franklin 28-year-old Chicago Negro heavyweight boxer, resulted from "a type of injury where surgery offered no hope."

"Song of Norway," a tribute to the genius of Edvard Grieg, the Norwegian composer, will open at the Imperial Theatre on Monday night, Aug. 21. The operetta has completed successful engagements in Los Angeles, where total receipts of $130,000 crammed the till during a three-week stay; and San Francisco, where the intake was $101,000 for a similar visit.

The F.F.B. Realty Corporation, B.S. Moss, president, has sold the six-story apartment house at 4580 Broadway, opposite Fort Tryon Park, to an investing client of Joseph G. Abramson, attorney. Assessed at $460,000, the property is 200 by 150 feet and was sold subject to mortgages of $410,000. It was built in 1938 and consists of eight stores and 112 apartments.

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- Emissaries coming directly from the Polish underground gave assurance to the press today that the people and Government of Poland would support any agreement that Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, who is in Moscow, may reach with Premier Joseph Stalin.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 3 -- After officials of the machinists' union announced today that their ban against overtime work in plants engaged in war production had been upheld by union members, employers asked the Tenth Regional War Labor Board for permission to recruit workers outside the union.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Department-store sales rose 11 per cent for the week ended July 29, compared to corresponding period a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Andrew Burke observed a birthday yesterday -- his sixty-eighth -- but few ever had held a greater store of happiness than this one when he received birthday greetings from his four soldier-sons assuring him they had come through safely in the conquest of Saipan.
Many agree that our enemies cannot pay reparations in full and that they should be disarmed. To disarm them would save them great expense. To forego reparations entirely would be excessive leniency.

ROME, Aug. 3 -- Information was obtained today that may explain why so many Italians here and in New York think they have seen the Filippelli memorial on the Matteotti murder in some newspapers of the year 1924 or later.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- A delayed report on America's war production effort through the first half of this year was issued by Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, today as the country approached what military officials consider a highly crucial production period.

Only a few days ago it was the Battle of Normandy. Now it is also the Battle of Brittany. Soon it will be, as it was in 1940, the Battle of France, but with the roles reversed. This time it is the Germans whose lines are being broken. This time it is the Germans who are short of planes.

A considerable demand from Venezuela for a variety of American goods in the post-war period, in addition to the essentials which have been imported even during the war period, was foreseen yesterday by Carl Breuer, second secretary of the American Embassy at Caracas.

Contract bridge players assembled here for the eighteenth annual national tournament of the American Contract Bridge League began play in the most highly rated contest of the week at the Hotel Astor yesterday when ninety-two irs entered the first of four sessions for the masters' pair championship and the $5,000 gold cup presented by Waldemar von Zedtwitz.

DETROIT, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The Fisher brothers, who resigned yesterday executive positions which they had held over most of a quarter of a century with the General Motors Corporation, plan to re-enter industrial activity at some future date, but their plans are not sufficiently definite to warrant a specific announcement.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- A three-man subcommittee, two of whose members were recently defeated for renomination in the face of CIO opposition, was named today to make a Dies committee investigation of the CIO's Political Action Committee (PAC).

Since we are all united in an effort at this time to preserve the American way of life, it seems to the writer that it is a good time to include in the things to be thrown in the discard the custom of tipping.
ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 3 -- Bulgaria has agreed to terms preliminary to her surrender to the Allies, it was reliably reported here today.

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday that it will issue for sale on Aug. 15 a new series of general and refunding bonds aggregating $17,671,000 due in 1974. Proceeds from the sale of this issue, to be known as the eighth series, will be applied to the redemption of a like amount of the Authority's sixth series general and refunding 3 per cent bonds due in 1975.

A sudden jump in electricity or gas bills may be due to inefficient operation of an automatic refrigerator, the Consolidated Edison Company warned yesterday. Since virtually no new automatic refrigerators have been made in three years, the company estimates that more than half a million or almost one-third of those in use in New York City, are "over- age" and consuming greatly increased amounts of electricity.

Lack of near-by bids in a wide range of issues produced yesterday a moderate reaction on the stock market. Accompanied by a further expansion of volume, which again centered in the low-price motors, the retreat was as general, though tempered, as some during the recent corrective movement.
CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- Assassins armed with shotguns and revolvers ended the criminal career early today of Lawrence (Dago) Mangano, who had preyed upon the city for more than twenty years.

LONDON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The weekly condition statement of the Bank of England for the week ended yesterday shows an increase of 9,216,000 in note circulation. Private deposits decreased 13,249,000 and other securities were 2,605,000 higher. Public deposits increased 1,011,000.

UNITED STATES NINTH AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS, Normandy, Aug. 3 -- In the seven-day period beginning July 25, when American forces launched the break-through attack on the German line between Periers and St. Lo, United States Ninth Air Force fighter-bombers based in Normandy destroyed 384 German tanks and other tracked vehicles and 2,287 motor transports of all types, Major Gen. Elwood R. Quesada, commanding officer of the Ninth Air Force Fighter Command, announced here today.

Our baseball expert, John Drebinger, pausing in Detroit in preparation for returning East after a Western tour of American League stands, took occasion to shed a columnar tear about conditions in St. Louis.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3 -- A Negro who explained later that he was merely protesting against the public transportation tie-up here walked into Independence Hall today and hurled a heavy quartz paper weight against the cracked side of the Liberty Bell.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Aug. 3 (AP) -- Leslie Combs 2d of Lexington paid $46,000 at the closing session of the yearling sales tonight for a bay colt by Eight Thirty-Heritage. Combs' bid set a record for the 1944 sales, surpassing by $5,000 the previous high, and was the sixth highest price ever paid for a thoroughbred yearling at auction in the United States.
HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 3 -- As the result of sharp factional disagreements, the Democratic State convention opening here tomorrow may nominate a woman for the United States Senatorship.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on July 29 were 910,533 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 7,499 cars or 0.8 per cent more than for the preceding week, 25,008 cars or 2.8 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year and 40,857 cars or 5.4 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission denied today the request of the American Laundry Company and 151 other industrial shippers that the commission's order temporarily suspending increases in freight rates granted to the railroads on March 18, 1942, be made permanent.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Senator Harry S. Truman, chairman of the Senate's Special Committee investigating the National Defense Program since March, 1941, resigned his chairmanship as well as his membership on the committee today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- Dry weather talk from the Corn Belt is affecting professional sentiment in oats and rye, and although prices held within narrow limits the greater part of the day a rush of short covering came shortly before the markets closed and with light offerings prices swept upward and closed at the top.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (U.P.) -- Following is the text of Chairman William H. Davis' letter to President Roosevelt on the Philadelphia transit strike:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- When the Four Power conference on how to achieve post-war security begins its meetings here Aug. 14, the problem of keeping the German people peaceful and demilitarized will naturally dominate the discussions. Numerous plans have been circulated, largely political and military.

The Germans now confirm what has been rumored along the Normandy battlefront for the last three weeks, that Marshal Erwin Rommel, Hitler favorite and second in command of the German nies in the west, has been out of action since July 17. Allied reports are that he is dead.

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- Dispatches from the commander of the Polish underground army to the Polish Government in London said today that Polish forces had seized four widely separated sections of Warsaw in the rear of the German army defending the city against the advancing Red Army.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The mass sedition trial ended its fifteenth week today with the prosecution still struggling, over defense objections, to obtain presentation to the jury of several hundred documents seized by the Federal Bureau of Investigation at the Indianapolis home of William Dudley Pelley, a defendant.
CHUNGKING, China, Aug 3 (U.P.) The protracted battle of Hunan Province raged unabated today, with the Chinese gaining the edge in the latest fighting.

Emphasizing that the recent increase in infantile paralysis cases was "by no means epidemic," the Department of Health announced yesterday that 163 cases had been reported in this city since Jan. 1, with forty-nine occurring last week. In 1943 only forty cases were reported, while in the last "epidemic" year, 1937, there were more than 700 cases.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 3 -- Bill Picken, who will represent the local fleet in the Star Class world championship on Lake Michigan starting Aug. 20, showed sailing form today in winning with his boat Fo Fo in the Great South Bay race week regatta.

THE art of base stealing may have passed out with the horse-and-buggy age. But, just as the horse has come back in this gas-restricted era, so has the stolen base. Its modern trail blazer is a stockily built athlete named George Stirnweiss, better known as Snuffy.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3 (AP) -- No immediate reclassification of the Newark (N.J.) area from its new Group 1 critical labor shortage designation is indicated, Frank L. McNamee, regional director of the War Manpower Commission, said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Losses of our heavy bombers during attacks on synthetic oil plants and other production centers in Germany have dropped about 50 per cent in recent weeks, Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson revealed at a press conference today.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 3 -- Greystone, the eighty-seven-acre estate of the late Samuel Untermyer at Yonkers, is subject to taxation because Mr. Untermyer's children might conceivably devote the showplace's horticultural facilities to their own "private enjoyment" despite the estate's avowed charitable purposes, Supreme Court Justice Gerald Nolan ruled today.

Eugene P. Connolly, spokesman for the old left-wing faction of the American Labor party, has been appointed a member of the vote reminder committee of the Empire State Society of the Sons of the American Revolution, staunch foe of communism and all things left wing, it was revealed yesterday.

The United States destroyer Cunningham, named in honor of the late Lieut. Col. Alfred Austell Cunningham, "father of Marine Corps aviation," was launched last night at the Bethlehem Steel and Shipbuilding Company's yard at Mariners Harbor, S.I., in the presence of high naval officers, seventy-five invited guests and 500 shipyard workers.

When the New York State Conservation Department produced a rather imaginative bit of light summer reading matter some time ago purporting to show the dangers to our natural resources when returning service men directed the mechanical miracles of war against fish and game, there were snickers in some quarters.

KALAMAZOO, Mich., Aug. 3 (AP) -- Bernard Bartzen of San Angelo, Tex., national interscholastic tennis champion, won his quarterfinal match in the national junior singles championship at Kalamazoo College today. He swamped eighth-seeded Alan Watson of Short Hills, N.J., 6 -- 0, 6 -- 1.

KINGSBRIDGE, Devonshire, Aug. 3 -- American soldiers were exonerated by the regional commissioner for southwest England here yesterday of blame for the damage suffered by eight ancient South Devon villages during battle practice for the Normandy landings.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The Artloom Corporation, Philadelphia, registered today with the Securities and Exchange Commission 100,000 shares of its no par common stock to be offered to holders of its outstanding 200,000 shares of common at $5 a share. Of the total, 10,000 shares are to be reserved for sale to employes.

They come from all parts of the city, an "unselected' group of some fifty boys and girls, 12 to 14 years old, studying and working this summer in New York University's Junior High School demonstration class at P.S. 33 in Manhattan.

The time has come for all good gardeners to come to the aid of the craft. The situation on the tomato front has reached an impasse which must be broken before further progress can be achieved. Reports from Victory gardeners indicate the situation well under control so far as carrots, beets, spinach, lettuce and Swiss chard are concerned.

ON THE OUTSKIRTS OF RENNES, Aug. 2 (Delayed) -- An American armored column moved forty miles within twenty-four hours yesterday before meeting up with any degree of organized opposition and this came when they had reached the hills overlooking the beautiful cathedral town of Rennes.

Every week the ratio of total reserves to Federal Reserve deposit and note liabilities combined declines a trifle. On Aug. 4, 1943, it was 60 per cent. For the week ended on Wednesday it fell from 53.5 to 53.2 per cent, and there have been authoritative estimates that the year-end will see it at about 48 per cent.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug 3 (AP) -- Russian trucks loaded with speedboats, torpedoes and mines were speeding up the Soviet corridor to the Baltic Sea west of Riga today in an effort to bottle up any waterway escape of twenty to thirty trapped German divisions, advices from the Baltic countries said.

MONTREAL, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Montreal took the first day of its latest strike of street-car and bus operators in stride today, with thousands going to and from their regular occupations in automobiles and trucks, on bicycles and afoot.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Communique 117:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- How three destroyer escorts bagged a German U-boat that sought to attack an Atlantic convoy was related tonight by the Navy, which said an hour and a half of furious battling preceded the sinking of the submarine "off the Atlantic Coast" recently.

Juan T. Trippe, president of the Pan American World Airways System and pioneer in the field of international aviation, announced yesterday a program of low-cost, high-speed mass air transportation between the United States and Latin America, designed to expand post-war international trade, business and tourist travel far beyond pro-war peaks.

The Phelps Dodge Corporation and its subsidiaries, in a statement of operations for the first six months this year, issued for publication today, shows an increase in sales to $85,103,630 from the $78,956,736 volume for the half year ended with June, 1943.

LONDON, Friday, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Powerful Allied air fleets totaling ground 5,500 bombers and fighters smashed at flying bomb bases in northern France and aircraft plants and communications targets in Germany Thursday as the August air offensive mounted in fury with widespread operations from both Britain and Italy.
CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- A meeting of three groups here today took a long step forward in removing the troubles of the bedding industry over conflicting State laws and regulations.

THE fact that Turkey has just ended all relations with Nazi Germany makes Ernest Jackh's "The Rising Crescent: Turkey, Yesterday, Today and Tomorrow"* of more than ordinary interest. But Dr. Jackh's thesis is that Turkey has been on the side of the United Nations all along. As a "red-light neutral," she has "stood in the gap" ever since 1939.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 3 (U.P.) -- Kathleen R. Dial, 26, Army flight nurse of Florence, Ala., returned today from seventeen months' service in the southwest Pacific with her right shoulder in a cast and the Distinguished Flying Cross, Air Medal and Purple Heart pinned on her uniform.

WITH THE MARINES NEAR SUMAY, GUAM, July 28 (Delayed) -- Some part of the success enjoyed by marines in digging out last-ditch Japanese snipers on the way to Sumay is due to thirteen handsome Doberman pinschers belonging to the First Marine War Dog Platoon, the first outfit anywhere to use dogs as actual combatants.

WITH AMERICAN FIRST ARMY in Brittany, Aug. 3 -- Smashing forward at breakneck speed, American tank columns have trisected the base of the Brittany peninsula in a bold and surprising offensive in which all arms have been concentrated into a tremendously powerful spearhead that is driving forward with no thought of flanks or of enemy threats to its rear echelons.

Another attendance record for the season at the Lewisohn Stadium was set last night when more than 22,000 crowded into the amphitheatre to hear Jascha Heifetz make an appearance as violin soloist with the Philharmonic-Symphony.

Authorization by the Office of Price Administration for open contracts on all classes of cotton textiles will relieve the present "strangulated" condition among buyers and will open again channels of distribution, commission men in Worth Street stated yesterday.

ROME, Aug. 3 -- Democracy won a victory at the Vatican today when the custom of giving Allied officers front seats at Papal audiences and putting GI's in the rear was abandoned. This has been a source of complaint for two months now but it was not until a few days ago that one GI had the courage to complain to the Pope himself.

ROME, Aug. 3 (AP) -- German troops are pulling back behind the Greve River preparatory to a withdrawal from Florence and advance units of the British Eighth Army already have stabbed within three miles of the historic city, field dispatches said tonight.

The heavy rains of Wednesday and yesterday broke the serious drought in a wide eastern coastal belt extending from Virginia into eastern Pennsylvania and New Jersey, the Weather Bureau announced last night. Yesterday's storm moved into eastern New York and lower New England, sections still needing moisture, and forecasters expressed hope that the rain in that area would be sufficient to relieve conditions.

One larcenous monkey named Chico the Dip and a score of merchant mariners who have turned authors attended yesterday a luncheon marking the tenth anniversary of the Joseph Conrad sailors' library in the Seamen's Church Institute of New York, 25 South Street.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission granted permission today to four national Stock Exchanges to extend unlisted trading privileges.

In the strongest anti-Nazi declaration it has made to date, the German Confessional Church has issued a 3,000-word statement condemning the killing of human beings other than in war and berating Germans for failing to speak out against violations of "God's Commandments."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- With the shortage of heavy duty truck and bus tires one of the most critical problems facing war and production officials, the Army has agreed to furlough former tire workers who are now in this country back to their peacetime employers.

Declaring that there are too many unrelated attempts to curb juvenile delinquency in New York City, and charging that prevention of crime by youths should not be in the hands of "the so-called Coordinating Councils" of the Police Department, Magistrate Anna M. Kross announced yesterday a new plan, to be sponsored by the recently formed Action Committee for Delinquency.
ROME, Aug. 3 (AP) -- A communique:

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 2 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The Turkish Government today granted to German Jews and anti-Nazi Germans, whose lives might be in jeopardy if they were sent back to the Reich, permission to remain here, but it ordered about 100 undesirable Germans to leave by tomorrow morning.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Accusations that four large distillery groups were attempting to monopolize the production of alcoholic beverages were made by the Senate committee investigating the liquor shortage, of which Senator McCarron, Democrat of Nevada, is chairman.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Aug. 3 -- A slim, brown-haired, 24-year-old fighter pilot from Ridgewood, N.J., has now become the leading American ace in the Southwest Pacific area with twenty-one recognized "kills" of Japanese planes to his credit, headquarters of Lieut. Gen. George C. Kenney's Far Eastern Air Force disclosed today.

HEWLETT, L.I., Aug. 3 -- Matching par for the course, Campbell B. Carmichel and George Baird Jr. of Rockville led the first-day qualifiers with 36, 36 -- 72 in the tenth annual Arthur Man Memorial tournament at Seawane Harbor today.

A small army of boys and girls filled Grand Central Station with whoops and shouts yesterday noon as the third group from the Children's Aid Society left for summer camps at New Hamburg and New Paltz. Many of them carried their belongings in duffle bags slung over their shoulders, Army fashion, with butterfly nets and other play paraphernalia in their free hands.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

ALGIERS, Aug. 3 -- In the agreement now being discussed between Washington and the French Committee there is a clause to the effect that Allied correspondence be subjected in France only to military censorship. The clause was proposed by Washington, and probably will be accepted by the French, according to those in touch with the negotiations.

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- Adolf Hitler and Heinrich Himmler, the man he put in charge of home defenses, have tightened the Nazi grip on the German army with mass promotions of Elite Guard leaders to higher military ranks and appointment of one of the party's faithful as "chief Nazi political commissar" in the Wehrmacht.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- During the week ended Aug. 2 member bank reserve balances increased $91,000,000, the Federal Reserve System announced today. Additions to member bank reserves arose from an increase of $125,000,000 in reserve bank credit and a decrease of $142,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve banks, offset in part by increases of $150,000,000 in money in circulation, and $26,000,000 in Treasury cash.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Friday, Aug. 4 -- American infantry and artillery have smashed four successive attempts by remnants of the Japanese Eighteenth Army to break out of their jungle trap along the Driniumor River in the Aitape area of British New Guinea, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today.

Edwin P. Banta, 73 years old, was arraigned in Special Sessions yesterday and held in $1,500 bail for trial on Sept. 11 on a charge of having conspired to have a false charge of rape brought against Arthur Derounian, who, under the pen name of John Roy Carlson wrote the best seller "Under Cover."

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- One of the heaviest and most sustained flying bomb raids on London and southern England was launched by the Germans shortly after last midnight in what is believed to be an effort on the enemy's part to "saturate" the defenses.

Five up-State Democrats, three of whom are now members of the judiciary, are making strong bids for the Democratic nomination for Associate Judge of the Court of Appeals in place of Harlan W. Rippey of Rochester who is retiring this year because of age, it was disclosed yesterday.

Some late commission-house buying and covering by leading ring traders steadied the cotton futures market yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, and final prices showed net gains of 6 to 9 points.
CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 3 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The War Produceion Board has "substantially" reduced the tonnage of new replacement rail available for domestic railroads during the third and fourth quarters of this year under the combined pressures of lowered production and increased demands by other Government agencies, the Office of Defense Transportation announced today.

Normal month-end demand for currency, which sent money in circulation up by more than $150,000,000, plus an increase in reserve requirements of about $200,000,000, brought some money stringency last week, forcing member banks to sell Treasury bills to the Federal Reserve System, according to the system's report for the week which ended on Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- President Roosevelt ordered the Army tonight to take control of the Philadelphia transit system, which has been strike-bound since Tuesday.

Sidney Robinson, part owner of Copacabana, Inc., which owns the night club at 10 East Sixtieth Street, was indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday on charges growing out of the city's night club investigation. United States Attorney James B.M. McNally said Mayor La Guardia had called to his attention, a week ago, alleged irregularities in a bankruptcy petition filed by Robinson in the Federal court, Brooklyn, on May 11, 1942.

Food manufacturers and other users of paperboard containers for civilian items yesterday stated that the container shortage is "as critical as ever" and no let-up in waste paper collections or pulp production is possible if the nation's container requirements are to be met.

A pair of privates in the United States Army, Lightweight Champion Bob Montgomery and the former titleholder, Beau Jack, tonight will head a program that will be responsible for the turnover of the greatest sum of money ever realized by a boxing card.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 3 -- Bob Thomson, skipper of the shining red - hulled Carolina, flying the pennant of the Stamford Yacht Club, today was declared the winner of the annual Junior Yacht Racing Association championship and the Pequot Cup, symbolic of that title.

A pair of privates in the United States Army, Lightweight Champion Bob Montgomery and the former titleholder, Beau Jack, tonight will head a program that will be responsible for the turnover of the greatest sum of money ever realized by a boxing card.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 3 -- Bob Thomson, skipper of the shining red - hulled Carolina, flying the pennant of the Stamford Yacht Club, today was declared the winner of the annual Junior Yacht Racing Association championship and the Pequot Cup, symbolic of that title.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -Another disastrous farm land boom is developing, Secretary Wickard said today as he urged would-be purchasers to use extra money to retire debts or buy war bonds rather than to buy farm real estate at present inflated values.

The butter and cream, the wine and bread, the eggs and meat of Normandy seem to have astonished the first soldiers and correspondents who arrived in that rich land. The other side of the French picture is emphasized in a dispatch sent to this newspaper by Harold Callender.
PEARL HARBOR, Aug. 3 -- Army and Marine forces on Guam have battered forward for gains averaging two miles against stiffening enemy resistance, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz stated today.

Despite the restrictive effect of the Public Utility Holding Company Act on its operations, the Electric Bond and Share Company, the nation's largest public utility holding company, intends to remain in business, even to the point of entering other fields of enterprise, stockholders were informed yesterday in the concern's financial reports for 1943 and the first six months of this year.

"The Literature Between Two Wars" is the theme of the twentieth anniversary issue of The Saturday Review of Literature, to be published tomorrow, in which the literary personalities, the special trends in books, and the books regarded as having had the greatest influence on American thought during the period between the last war and the present one are discussed.
WITH THE BRITISH SECOND ARMY AT THE FRONT, France, Aug. 3 (U.P.) -- German tanks crashed into the British lines this afternoon and checked, for the moment, a big break-through east of Vire.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- In a move to recruit more men 18 through 25 years old, the Selective Service Administration directed local draft boards today to review the cases of all registrants in that age group who had been disqualified because of deficiencies of an educational or mental character.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Sponsors of the labor-supported industrial demobilization legislation, which was the subject of day-long debate by the Senate Military Affairs Committee, expressed a willingness tonight to compromise their proposed table for payments of unemployment compensation which, in some wage brackets, would enable workers to receive more when they were unemployed than when they were working.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- A bill empowering the Office of Price Administration to exercise the same wartime controls over commercial property rentals as it does over residential rents in defense areas was offered in the House today by Representative Samuel Dickstein, Democrat, of New York. The measure was referred to the Banking and Currency Committee.
LONDON, Aug. 3 -- A generally firm tone prevailed throughout today's stock markets here, although business was restricted in view of the bank holiday next Monday.

A total of $2,379,322 was spent in daily and Sunday newspapers during May for war-effort advertising, the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, announced yesterday. This brings the total from August, 1943, to $47,287,107.

Shoppers will find both a wide assortment and good supplies of fresh fruits available this weekend, with the possible exception of cantaloupe. Although the latter is abundant, the War Food Administration reports that stocks may be reduced temporarily within the next few days as a result of bad weather in the growing sections of Maryland, which threatens to retard shipments.

On July 27, the War Food Administration announced that ice-cream production would be cut again for an indefinite period after Aug. 1. Furthermore, this restricted output will be less rich. The cause -- insufficient milk porduction.

BOSTON, Aug. 3 -- Winning two more games -- an adjourned game from the third round and also his eighth-round fixture, Samuel Reshevsky of Brooklyn left the field well behind today in the annual tournament for the open championship of the United States Chess Federation at the Boston City Club.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES in France, Aug. 3 (U.P.) -- The story of how two Americans "captured" Granville and one "held" it all night with the help of a baldish, happy French World War I veteran was revealed only today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- To declare war on Germany, the Ankara Government has laid down very definite conditions. Among others, it insists on the Allied command's setting apart an air force for the special protection of Turkish territory and, above all, of Istanbul, against onslaughts by German bombers.

Before I get too mad I wish to make it clear that I, along with millions of GI's from any Allied nation you can name, think of New York as the serviceman's heaven. I get slightly embarrassed at the thought of the hospitality I have received in my four months here.

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- Prime Minister Churchill's castigation of Argentina as a nation that had chosen to dally with the "evil" and "losing side" of this war must have had a welcome reception in Washington. At first his words sounded as if Whitehall and Washington were speaking with one voice on the South American issue, where Anglo-American policy and interests have been at variance.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The Cardinals rode merrily on toward their third straight National League pennant today, increasing their lead to sixteen and one-half games by squelching the third place Pirates, 15 to 2.

Spectacular accomplishments by bombers and fighters have brought us some realization of the startlingly swift advances which have been made under the stimulus of war in the range, speed and reliability of aircraft. Combat reports have tended to overshadow, however, the correlative advances which are being made in commercial air transport.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- During the last week in July commodity prices in primary markets continued to move within a narrow range. For the third consecutive week the Bureau of Labor Statistics' index remained unchanged at 103.9 per cent of the 1926 average.

ALBANY, Aug. 3 -- In the list made public today of 113 students who passed the June examination for admission to the bar is the name of Edward M. Smallwood, 23 years old, of 324 College Avenue, Ithaca, a blind student who is entering the law firm of Col. William Donovan in New York.

The few treasured possessions that Dana Paul Todd accumulated in a varied career that included two "hitches" in the Marines and ended in a Japanese prison camp, were willed yesterday to the friends and relatives who furthered his education or staked him when his funds were low.

LONDON, Friday, Aug. 4 (U.P.) -- British dispatches from Stockholm today said that an unnamed German colonel general commanding the German Island of Rugen, off East Prussia in the Baltic Sea, had been killed by the Gestapo for complicity in the plot to assassinate Adolf Hitler, and that there had been a fearful blood-bath among the nobility on the island.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- A bitter fight over the Fair Employment Practices Committee was revived today as Southern Congressmen blamed the Philadelphia transit strike on that agency and warned that violence there foreshadows a possible return to race riots like that in the first World War.

Spectacular accomplishments by bombers and fighters have brought us some realization of the startlingly swift advances which have been made under the stimulus of war in the range, speed and reliability of aircraft. Combat reports have tended to overshadow, however, the correlative advances which are being made in commercial air transport.

Acting on widespread complaints that garment district landlords had conspired to force five-year leases on their tenants, the Department of Justice has conducted a four-week investigation, with the result that five of the biggest property owners have agreed to drop this policy, it was revealed yesterday.

Robert Douglas Skidmore, a turret gunner, wrote 'Valley of the Sky," which Houghton Mifflin will publish next Thursday, in camp,I aboard ship and overseas. It- is a !war novel, the hero of which is a bomber and her crew.

Safe beyond their most roseate dreams, a group of 984 refugees from Nazi-occupied European countries that comprised nationals of nineteen lands entrained last night at the Lackawanna terminal in Hoboken for Fort Ontario at Oswego, N.Y., where they will remain until after the war in an emergency refugee shelter, the first of its kind set up in this country.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 104:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 4 -- Helen Walker, who recently finished a part opposite Fred MacMurray in "Murder He Says," has been lent by Paramount to Edward Small for the feminine lead with Dennis O'Keefe in "Brewster's Millions."

In the near future retailers of gasoline will be included in ration banking. Louis J. Kroeger, director of the new division of ration currency in the Office of Price Administration, declared yesterday at a luncheon given for him at the Hotel Roosevelt by the ration banking committee of the American Bankers Association.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 4 (AP) -- A male infant was born without eyeballs at Muhlenberg Hospital here in July, the hospital announced today.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Saturday, Aug. 5 -- United States tank columns, dashing across Brittany to sever the peninsula, raced to within thirty-eight miles of St. Nazaire today, and other armored forces were within seventy-five miles of the great port of Brest, while comrades guarding their flank swept eastward unopposed across the plains in a new drive toward Paris.

Capt. Raymond C. Kidd, a coastwise steamship skipper from Quincy, Mass., who disclaims kinship to his famous seventeenth-century pirate namesake, is in the toils of the law. He is accused of steering his vessel, Iris, of Norwegian registry, through Hell Gate, from Long Island Sound into the East River, last Dec. 6, without a pilot's license.

PEARL HARBOR, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Preparing for a clean-up drive against the Japanese on Guam, American troops won control of Mount Barrigada dominating the flat northern plateau of the island, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz stated today.

Light hedge selling against cotton repossessed from Government loan stocks and liquidation in advance of the Federal crop estimate to be issued on next Tuesday caused yesterday a recession in the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange and final prices were 10 to 12 points net lower than on Thursday.

LONDON, Aug. 4 (U.P.) -- Storming through the streets of Warsaw in grim and bloody fighting, 25,000 troops of the Polish underground have driven strong German forces from the entire Stare Miasto (Old City) district and captured a skyscraper, the General Postoffice, the main power station and gas works and many other objectives over which they triumphantly raised Polish flags, it was announced today.

Prof. Albert Einstein repudiated last night the new biography of himself, "Einstein -- An Intimate Study of a Great Man," written by his former son-in-law, Dimitri Marianoff, in collaboration with Palma Wayne. Professor Einstein said he took the action with great reluctance, but said that the work is "generally unreliable."

The title is, of course, a mistake. One never could "own" a cat, as one possesses a dog, or a horse, or a parrot. One lives on with a cat as a companion, an equal personality, who is unique and repays careful study.

BOSTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The Red Sox opened a twenty-one game home stand today by splitting a double-header with the Senators. Emmett O'Neil pitched a two-hit, 4-0 victory after Washington had taken the opener, 7 -- 5.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Limited manufacture of cooking utensils and other household articles from a special allotment of aluminum is planned by the War Production Board to the extent that such production will not interfere with the war effort, it was made known today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4 -- Philadelphia forgot for a few hours tonight its sizzling heat wave and its worst transportation tie-up in history as 29,166 baseball fans packed Shibe Park to pay tribute to Connie Mack on the fiftieth anniversary of the grand old man's career as a major league manager.

MOSCOW, Aug. 4 -- Last night's meeting with Premier Stalin was Premier Mikolajczyk's second business conference since his arrival in Moscow Sunday night. The first was with Foreign Commissar Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff Monday night, but this was largely confined to formalities and preliminaries.

Observing its second anniversary at Cathedral Canteen, 17 East Fifty-first Street, at 11 A.M. breakfast tomorrow, the New York Chapter Knights of Columbus will provide the canteen's 47,000th guest with a war bond and a free telephone call to any point in the United States or Canada.

The poor attendance at home canning demonstrations held recently in the metropolitan area brought a warning yesterday from the War Food Administration that housewives who wish their families to be well fed next winter should can fruits, vegetables and poultry as they come to market in quantity.
