The two partners of the Belmonte Dress Company at 5-43 Forty-eighth Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, were shot and wounded seriously at 11 A.M. yesterday when they fought off two armed robbers who demanded $5,000 withdrawn from a bank to cash checks for workers who eat at a near-by tavern owned by one of the partners.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Shipbuilding officials have found it necessary to cut into the merchant ship program in order to meet the requirements of the Navy for converted cargo vessels capable of engaging in military operations, the Maritime Commission revealed today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 4 -- Harvard University was the scene today of the contests in the ninth round of the annual tournament for the open championship of the United States Chess Federation. The nine games played at the Lowell House were witnessed by summer students and service men in training here.

W. Mason Lichtenstein of New York and Joseph Cohan of Wooster, Ohio, led ninety-two pairs of contract bridge masters after the second of four scheduled sessions in the play for the national masters' pair championship at the Hotel Astor yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 4 -- In France, according to reliable clandestine information, the resistance movement, so far as it is coordinated, has been instructed to devote its principal attention to the Atlantic and Mediterranean seaboards and to harass the Germans there without cease, it was stated here today.

HEADQUARTERS, an Infantry Battalion in the Forest of St. Sever, Aug. 4 -- This is savage fighting in this gloomy forest in which every trail and road is copiously mined and rifle and machinegun fire whistles through the undergrowth twenty-four hours a day.
WITH THE BRITISH SECOND ARMY, in the vicinity of Villers-Bocage, Aug. 4 -- Villers-Bocage is not only No Man's Land, but also dead man's land.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The Office of the Controller General has ruled that the Office of Price Administration must observe only commercial grades in establishing ceiling prices over the 1944 pack of canned goods, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Senator James M. Mead of New York became chairman of the Senate's War Investigating Committee today, succeeding Senator Truman, Democratic Vice Presidential candidate, in the post.

Walter R. Darby, chairman of the Funding Commission of the State Department of Taxation and Finance of the State of New Jersey, announced yesterday plans for the refunding of obligations of Atlantic City under which there will be issued $22,119,000 of new bonds.

New Yorkers sizzled yesterday when the city endured its hottest day in four years as the mercury in the official Weather Bureau thermometer atop the Whitehall Building at the Battery touched 96.3 degrees at 4:15 P.M.

New financing in the local market this week was limited to three issues of municipal bonds totaling $21,890,000, compared with a diversified list of seven new issues aggregating $58,285,000 last week. A year ago three flotations amounting to $22,897,000 were made this week.

Paul E. Fitzpatrick, new Democratic State chairman, has notified New York City leaders that he is claiming a final veto power in the naming of a candidate for the vacancy on the Court of Appeals that is to be filled at this year's elections.

Fred M. Colpitts, a fox rancher at Salisbury, N.B., holds that forests can be stocked with big game just as streams are stocked with fish, according to a Canadian National Railways announcement. Colpitts bought a pair of young elk, a bull and a cow, back in 1936 and turned them loose on a woodlot.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 4 -- Governor Dewey headed for home tonight from the conference of twenty-six Republican Governors, expressing himself as completely satisfied with all aspects of the conference which ended early this morning. At the same time the conference presented to the country the last five of its declarations on Government activities, including labor, public expenditures, social welfare, education and public health, taxation and water resources.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 4 -- An improvement in the situation of estimated 600,000 Hungarian Jews who have so far escaped deportation, and worse, to Germany under energetic anti-Semitic decrees was reported today to the Swiss Minister in Budapest by the Hungarian Foreign Minister.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Bucky Walters makes good on his fifth try for his sixteenth victory tonight by going the route to beat the Cardinals, 5 to 3, before 25,133 fans.

Wall Street is awaiting with interest developments in the proposed financing program of the Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago. The financing, which may involve up to $178,000,000, according to the company's preliminary announcement, will be undertaken for refunding purposes.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- Thirty-seven electoral votes of Southern States are as good as counted against President Roosevelt and thirty-eight more are expected from organization work among dissident Democrats, according to leaders of the anti-New Deal American Democratic National Committee.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 4 -- The text of the last five points in the statement of policy adopted by the Republican Governors and the conclusion issued at the end of their parley are as follows:

Proof was given again that local stories will hold their own with great military or international events, according to the results of the Continuing Study of Newspaper Reading on the Sioux Falls Daily Argus-Leader which was made two days after the invasion of Western Europe.

Ben Chapman, once known as the Alabama Arrow when he was the American League's leading base stealer, and a Yankee outfielder, made his debut as a National League pitcher with the Dodgers under the Ebbets Field lights last night -- and how!

Inspectors of one of the local election boards that served in Harlem during last Tuesday's primary have been summoned to appear on Monday before the Board of Elections to explain discrepancies between reports they filed on primary night with the police and the report they turned in to the board, Thomas F. Mallee, chief clerk of the board, disclosed last night.

Supreme Court Justice Samuel Null vacated yesterday a temporary stay obtained by La Vie Parisienne, night club at 3 East Fifty-second Street, to prevent the city from attaching its assets in connection with an alleged city tax bill of $13,693.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

RENNES, France, Aug. 4 -- This cathedral city of 100,000 population, capital of Brittany, was captured today by the Americans. Amid scenes of wild jubilation the French greeted large forces of mobile units, most of which were passing through without stopping.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's dramatic campaign to drive the Japanese from northern Burma and establish a military supply highway from India to China approached fruition today as American and Chinese troops mopped up in captured Myitkyina after crushing the last of Japanese organized resistance.

ROME, Aug. 4 (U.P.) -- Baron Ernst von Weizsaecker, German Ambassador to the Vatican, has repudiated the Nazi Government after a dispute among members of the embassy staff and the Vatican secretariat is awaiting official word from the German Government for clarification of the situation, it was reported authoritatively today.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 4 -- Harold Halsted of the Moriches Bay Star Class fleet, with his Chuckle V, almost sailed into the point lead today in Great South Bay's race week. He won the fourth race and all but nipped Bill Picken for the top place, with the final event scheduled for tomorrow.

LANSING, Mich., Aug. 4 -- An order for the Detroit Edison Company to cut its gross revenue $10,450,000 and to file a plan of distribution by Sept. 15 was issued today by the Michigan Public Service Commission. The distribution, in the form of a refund to customers of the utility, must be made "on a uniform basis" before Dec. 31.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The Mortgage Bankers Association of America today announced a complete slate of candidates for officers and governors to be presented for election at the association's annual meeting here Oct. 20.

ABOARD UNITED STATES INVASION FLAGSHIP, Guam, Aug. 4 -- The surviving Japanese defenders of Guam, attempting to prevent their headlong flight from becoming a rout of annihilation, appeared today to be digging in for a last-ditch stand against the joint Army and marine trap closing on them at a rate of nearly two miles a day.

Woolen and worsted mill men, in discussing prospects for civilian goods supplies, yesterday said that they believed the situation on fall deliveries would be fairly favorable, but that a greater pinch is to be expected on deliveries of spring merchandise.

Federal and city agencies began independent investigations yesterday of complaints by tenants in the apartment house at 640 Riverside Drive that services in the thirteen-story building had been drastically curtailed since the new management took charge three months ago.

In your editorial of July 30, "America's First Legislature," the statement is made that "poor men, without land or pence, did not vote" in early Virginia. This assertion is somewhat misleading, as the Virginia Company Constitution of 1621 granted to all inhabitants of the Colony the right to vote for the Burgesses.

LONDON, Aug. 4 -- Adolf Hitler has undertaken a "ruthless purge" of the German Army as a result of the July 20 attempt on his life, the Berlin radio announced tonight, and a "court of honor" headed by Field Marshal Gen. Karl von Rundstedt and Field Marshal Gen. Wilhelm Keitel has been set up for an inquiry that will extend to every field marshal and general.

The Philadelphia rapid-transit strike continues in defiance of the United States Army. The ugly situation revealed by the strike remains. In the background there may have been an inter-union struggle, with James McMenamin's "general emergency committee" trying to undermine the Transport Workers Union.

The size of the surplus stocks anticipated by some persons upon the demobilization of our war economy has made the problem of their disposal seem almost insoluble. In an informative study prepared for the Committee for Economic Development, Dr. A.D.H. Kaplan has analyzed the components of the anticipated surplus supplies, as well as Government-owned plants and equipment.

Mr. Killheffer's letter on Mr. Gideonse's proposals and the Hull reciprocity agreements, as recently published in THE TIMES, fails to take into account the practical and realistic side of the Hull agreements -- namely, that each reduction in price of any commodity enlarges and broadens its use.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- A five-point program to assure payment of support prices to farmers and annual farmer-Government agreements covering the individual production of each farm, was urged upon the Government today by the National Farmers Union.

Either the Administration or Congress should long ago have turned over the post-war unemployment compensation problem to a committee of experts for study and recommendations. It is the failure of either the Administration or Congress to do this that has led to the present pressure behind unrealistic and dangerous proposals.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- A bill incorporating the principles which are held necessary to maintain powerful post-war air forces and sustain a strong aviation industry behind them will be introduced in the Senate this session, Senator James E. Murray of Montana indicated today.
CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 4 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

LONDON, Aug. 4 -- Taking the flying bomb menace and the threat of rocket bombs in all seriousness, the Ministry of Health plans to evacuate another million persons from London and southern England, it was announced tonight.

As an alternative to post-war Government operation of more than 400 Government-owned war plants, the Smaller War Plants Corporation is sponsoring among Government agencies and business groups a plan calling for subdivision of such plants and the rental of small space units to independently owned businesses, regional officials of the agency stated yesterday.

Reporting on operations of the Borg-Warner Corporation in the second quarterly statement issued yesterday, C.S Davis, president, said that while a number of its divisions are currently engaged on enlarged war contracts, the corporation's government business as a whole declined slightly from the first three months this year, but the volume was greater than for the second quarter of 1943.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Saturday, Aug. 5 -- American armored columns, which according to German reports are bearing down on all major ports of Brittany, are moving swiftly to take hold of the entire peninsula. Perhaps only ten to fifteen miles behind the tanks, the roads were reported full of trucks bearing infantry to consolidate the positions penetrated by the unflagging spearheads.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- Republican leaders from eleven Midwestern States comprising the center of party strength and carrying 140 electoral votes met today with Herbert Brownell Jr., national chairman, to plan Republican strategy in this area for the coming campaign.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The National Cooperative Finance Association, a parallel organization to the Cooperative League of the United States of America and the National Cooperatives, Inc., has been organized to serve as a clearing house for the financial needs of the organizations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Notwithstanding the refusal of Congress to sanction the militarization of the Women's Air Force Service Pilots, and the restrictions placed recently upon expansion of the unit, members of the organization will continue to take the special training course at Orlando, Fla., which qualifies them to operate at military bases, the War Department stated today.

WHAT makes John L. Lewis, boss of the United Mine Workers, tick? Scores of writers have tried to explain him, to unravel his contradictions, to penetrate the mystery of how a supposedly ruthless dictator can still retain the loyalty of the courageous and basically independent men and women of the Appalachian coal patches.

PHILADELPHIA, Saturday, Aug. 5 -- In open rebellion against the authority of the Army, a vast majority of the 6,000 striking employes of the Philadelphia Transportation Company cut such swift inroads into the ranks of returning operators that at 12:01 A. M. today the entire transit system here again was at a standstill.
GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, Aug. 5 (AP) -- A communique:

In the last twenty-four hours fourteen new cases of infantile paralysis have been reported to the Department of Health here, while throughout the State total cases for the year reached 946, an increase of 133 since Thursday.

While your editorial "America's First Legislature," in the issue of July 30, makes casual reference to "the time-honored custom of the House of Commons," it seems to me to convey an impression that this first Legislature of North America was an original creation. Especially is this idea presented in the closing sentence.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 4 -- A method of camouflaging industrial or military facilities through the use of stroboscopic light, a process for converting dextrose into levulose, and several schemes for producing high test gasoline are among the 397 inventions listed in the current issue of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

OTTAWA, Aug. 4 -- The preservation of the world from new wars could only be secured by the lowering of the temperature of nationalism, while its good features were preserved by the diminishing of national rivalries and the reduction of the importance of frontiers, Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King told the Canadian House of Commons today in a speech on foreign policy.

HARTFORD, Aug. 4 -- A strong plea for unity was made by Senator Samuel D. Jackson, Democrat, of Indiana at the Democratic State Convention here tonight as bitter party fights were in the making among the 1,100 delegates. After Mr. Jackson's keynote speech the convention adjourned until tomorrow for the nominations for a United States Senator, Governor and other State officers.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- A bearish construction was placed today by grain brokers on the Board of Trade on crop estimates by C.M. Galvin of J.E. Bennett Co., and although the weather map showed little rain where needed, there was fairly general selling of futures after the report was released that more than wiped out small early gains.

The recent action of the Federal Council of Switzerland qualifying right of asylum undoubtedly will have great effect on the Axis war criminals. But the Swiss action has greater import than what appears in the immediate offing.

The Perfection Products Company, manufacturer of paper articles, has purchased for occupancy the two and three story factory building at 14-18 North Second Avenue, Mount Vernon, N.Y., from the Mount Vernon Trust Company as co-executor with Daniel Tier.

The Japanese Domei agency said yesterday that Gen. Shizuitsu Tanaka, former supreme commander of the Japanese Expeditionary Force in the Philippines, had been appointed a member of the Supreme War Council and director of the Military Staff College.

Widespread liquidation hit the stock market yesterday in the final hour and plunged the list to even lower levels than in the recent corrective movement. Despite the force of the selling, the low-price motors held up exceedingly well, however, and this attributed to confirmation of recent reports in Wall Street that one and perhaps other independent automotive makers would get new leadership and fresh financial support.

Bathers have discovered a new type of lifeguard along the busy shorefronts of the Rockaways, Riis Park, Coney Island, Orchard and South Beaches this summer. Gone is the calloused and wrinkle-faced veteran, with his rugged features and powerful physique.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (AP) -- After an absence of a month the White Sox returned to the first division today, displacing in the fourth spot the Indians, whom they beat for a third straight time, 5 to 3. The sweep of the series gave the Chicagoans a four-game winning streak.

LONDON, Saturday, Aug. 5 -- Russian troops in a spectacular twenty-seven mile break-through behind the enemy's shattered Vistula River defenses yesterday swept southward to within thirty-seven miles of Cracow, Poland's fifth city and last big German stronghold barring the invasion road into Germany itself.
CHUNGKING. China, Aug. 4 (AP) -- A communique:

Tomatoes -- the versatile vegetable that is actually, botanically speaking, a fruit -- are the subject of a new Government bulletin, "Tomatoes on Your Table" (AWI-104), which is available free-on-request from the Department of Agriculture's Office of Information in Washington.

The United States Treasury Department realized $35,864,900 in war bond sales from the boxing program presented at Madison Square Garden last night. The card, headed by a non-title bout between World Lightweight Champion Bob Montgomery and Former Titleholder Beau Jack was sponsered by the War Bond Sports Committee, with the promotion undertaken by the Twentieth Century Sporting Club and all operating expenses underwritten by the Gillette Safety Razor Company.

GENERAL HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, Aug. 5 -- Battered and hammered, Japan's Second Army is in "full retreat" from Geelvink Bay and the upper Vogelkop Peninsula -- totaling nearly a third of all New Guinea -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Relief for alleged overcrowding of radio channels is one of the subjects to be taken up at the conference called by the State Department for Aug. 11-12.

With the original vendors of canned corn refusing to buy back from the War Food Administration early last month approximately 3,324,000 cans of the product, food distributors yesterday declared themselves astonished by the action of the Office of Price Administration in returning canned corn to the ration list at the beginning of this week.
LONDON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Force communique:

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4 (AP) -- A plan to merge the United Coach Company, New York, and Railway and Bus Associates, Wilmington, Del., into Associated Utilities was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Seventy to 80 per cent of American service men in Italy like serious music, according to Jascha Heifetz, the distinguished violinist who has just returned from a tour of the Italian war theatre made under USO camp show auspices.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Bill Nicholson's twenty-fourth home run of the season produced two ninth-inning markers to give Chicago a 4-3 victory over Pittsburgh before 10,022 fans tonight and extend the Cubs' winning streak to ten straight.

The Western Union Telegraph Company announced plans yesterday whereby it would offer its 4 per cent debentures on various bases of exchange to the holders of stock in six leased companies. The companies involved are the Gold and Stock Telegraph Company, the Chicago and St. Paul Telegraph Company, the Empire and Bay States Telegraph Company, the International Ocean Telegraph Company, the Southern and Atlantic Telegraph Company, and the Pacific and Atlantic Telegraph Company.

There seems to be a lot of discussion these days about men walking around in shirt-sleeves in New York. Will somebody please tell me what these men are waiting for? Whose approval are they seeking before they can shed their weighty coats and ties and hats?

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Aug. 4 (AP) -- Prosecutor Arthur F. Scheer said that Jackie Cooper, actor and star of a recent juvenile delinquency film called "Where Are Your Children?" was one of four persons for whose arrest warrants were issued today charging contribution to the delinquency of minors.

ROME, Aug. 4 -- Allied troops hammered through the last German defenses before the great Tuscan art center of Florence today and sent patrols stabbing into the heart of the historic city as far as the Arno River, beyond which the Germans had withdrawn after destroying five of six bridges spanning the wide stream.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 4 (U.P.) -- Field Marshal Baron Carl Mannerheim took the oath as President of Finland today after Parliament unanimously passed a bill conferring the office upon him in the face of the overwhelming Russian advance.
ALBANY, Aug. 4 -- The University of the State announced today that 750 students had been successful in the recent examination for State scholarships, 310 of which went to youths in New York City.

UP to within the last few years the oncoming of each football season has been heralded by a plea to give the game back to the boys. Meaning, of course, to put a curb on professional coaches and permit the players to run the show a la the English pattern.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Communique 118:
No one will ever call Hugh Luby of the Giants a power hitter. In fact, few will think of the little third sacker as any kind of hitter, and the records will bear them out.

LONDON, Aug. 4 -- Trading on the stock markets here generally was quiet today before the long bank holiday week-end, but prices ware firm with industrial leaders mostly harder. A feature was a rise of distillers on the Government's announcement that whisky distilling is to be resumed over the next twelve months.

RENNES, France, Aug. 3 (Delayed) -- Groups of armed members of the French Resistance movement are operating constantly through the villages and countryside in this area rounding up snipers and collaborationists and proudly marching them through village squares to the nearest compounds.
ROME, Aug. 4 (UP) -- 4 communique:

The rescue of several hundred thousand Jews in Hungary can be effected if sufficient temporary I shelter camps are established in I Allied and neutral nations, the Emergency Committee to Save the Jewish People of Europe declared in a report made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- A three-judge Federal court today dismissed an action brought by the CIO Federal Workers of America Union, seeking to bar enforcement of the Hatch Act provision forbidding Government employes to be active in political campaigns. Constitutionality of the act was attacked.

HEWLETT, L.I., Aug. 4 -- M. Donald Grant and Carl Timpson of Rockaway Hunt, bettered par by two strokes during the second day of qualifying for the tenth annual Arthur Man Memorial best-ball golf tournament to win medal honors with a card of 33, 37 -- 70, at Seawane Harbor today.

Before the month's end four new plays will have been unveiled, according to present schedules, in what clearly promises to be a season every bit as industrious as was the last. Besides the newcomers, two veterans of prosperity, "The Voice of the Turtle" and "The Two Mrs. Carrolls," will be back on the boards before Sept. 1.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Representatives of radio and telecommunications companies, the press and interested Government agencies were invited by the State Department today to attend meetings here Aug. 11 and 12 to discuss problems of post-war telecommunications.

LONDON, Aug. 4 -- Blasting their way through heavy German fighter opposition 1,200 Liberators and Flying Fortresses of the United States Eighth Air Force attacked enemy oil refineries, aircraft factories and dock installations from Kiel and Bremen to the eastern Baltic today.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 4 (UP) -- Forty days of furious Japanese assaults against the isolated Chinese garrison at Hengyang have taken a heavy toll of the hard-pressed defenders, but their morale remains high and they continue to hold their posiitons, a Chinese military spokesman said today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Following is the statement and directive on manpower, issued by James F. Byrnes, Director of War Mobilization:

MOSCOW, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Foreign missions regarded the Polish diplomatic situation with reserved optimism today after the Premier of the Polish Government in Exile held a long conference with Premier Joseph Stalin, who severed relations with the emigre regime fifteen months ago.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The Government acted drastically today to make sure that war production would reach the rate necessary to finish off an enemy whose "knees are buckling."

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- Fred Mulholland, chairman of the Newburgh Democratic city committee, has split with the county organization over a Democratic candidate for Congress in the Twenty-ninth District, and announced today that he would support Representative Hamilton Fish, Republican, in his campaign for re-election.

Retail trade here this week continued active. Fur offerings met better consumer response than heretofore. Main floor trade was brisk and clearances fared well. Department store volume, it was estimated, ran 10 per cent or more above the like week of 1943.

James Monroe Perkins has rented the four-story dwelling at 158 East Sixty-sixth Street from George M. Bodman and Dr. Alexander D. Ghiseling has rented the five-story dwelling with garden at 126 East Seventy-eighth Street from Henry Rogers Winthrop.

TRENTON, N. J., Aug. 4 (AP) -- The 5,700 employes of the Trenton and Roebling (N. J.) steel wire and cable plants of John A. Roebling's Sons Company, complying with a Regional War Labor Board directive ordering them to return to work at once, decided today to end an unauthorized walkout in protest over an alleged violation of a union contract by the company.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The "liberal" Kilgore-Murray industrial demobilization and reconversion bill, supported by organized labor and denounced by opponents as a formula for a post-war NRA and WPA, was approved late today by a 10-to-7 vote of the Senate Military Affairs Committee.

The Board of Education will hire public school students next fall to fill vacant positions as clerks, stenographers and typists, it was revealed yesterday. In a circular addressed to associate superintendents, heads of bureaus and directors in charge of divisions and activities at headquarters, Superintendent of Schools John E. Wade made available the services of pupils studying under the cooperative plan of education.
Eight, including Princequillo and Four Freedoms, are named for the $15,000 added Merchants and Citizens Handicap, on the Saratoga Association's first Saturday card of the year at Belmont Park today.
A good demand for various types of real estate in midtown Manhattan was indicated by deals reported yesterday.

GUAM, July 23 (Delayed) -- In their two and a half years on Guam the Japanese have made every effort to eradicate all traces of American possession of the island since 1898, even to the extent of forcing the native Chamorro children to learn Japanese in the schools and to abandon English.

"Fortress Japan," a short sub-I ject produced by the National Film Board of Canada as part of its! wartime series of World in Action l information subjects, will be released nationally to theatres in this country on Thursday by United Artists.
KANDY, Ceylon, Aug. 4 (UP) -- A communique:

Joseph W. Frazer, until last September president of Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., is scheduled to become chairman of the board of the Graham-Paige Motors Corporation early next week upon the consummation of a series of negotiations which will bring interests close to the Atlas Corporation into the Graham-Paige picture.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Solution of the Army's critical production problems was predicted today by Lieut. Gen. Brehon Somervell as a result of the imposition of labor controls by James F. Byrnes, Director of War Mobilization.

American woolen and worsted mills have an excellent opportunity to produce fine quality fabrics for the custom tailoring industry, due to the tightness in the import situation, but only a few organizations are taking advantage of the situation, Chauncey D. Hunter, executive secretary of the Merchant Tailors and Designers Association of America, stated yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- A Cycle Fashion Festival, with more than 2,000 bicyclists competing for war bonds and stamps, will be conducted on the Boardwalk at 8 o'clock Thursday morning. Judges will select the best-dressed riders as they pedal by the reviewing stand at Park Place.

History repeated itself last week and the German mind inevitably turned back with fear and faltering to the black days of August, 1918, as the thronging armies of the Allies drove closer and closer to the Reich.

In these mopping-up operations the bandits since June 6 have lost approximately 7,300 dead and 4,700 prisoners.

THIS is an appealing story of a little Navaho girl, beginning on her "nine-winters-old day" and telling of her gifts, the belt of silver disks strung on a leather cord which her father made for her, and the silver bell which her brother gave her so that the lambs could hear her running, and of her dreams that she would some day own many little lambs and become a fine weaver.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 4 (Delayed) -- General Maximino Avila Camacho, Secretary of Communications, denounced today what he termed the subversive maneuvers of "certain leaders who are exploiting the masses for their personal benefit and engineer sinful demonstrations."

Twelve 3-year-old colts and fillies probably will make up the field that will receive the word Wednesday afternoon in the rich Hambletonian Stake, blue ribbon event of the light harness world, at Good Time Park in Goshen, N.Y.
Except for most scarce items, "buying enthusiasm is milder than we have seen for some time," Kirby, Block Co. say in their market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 5 -- A report from the French frontier, carried by the Tribune de Geneve tonight with reserve, says that preparations are being made, "on German suggestion," for the complete evacuation of the Vichy government to some point nearer the Reich.

IN the quite gratifying response to a discussion in these columns two weeks ago dealing with certain phases of abstraction and some misunderstanding of its very real and important contribution to form and space conceptions in art, several artists who work in more or less abstract manner and several laymen have agreed with the point of view expressed here but raise their voices in warning.

Two very interesting communications dealing with the important problem of deficit financing have appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES this week. The contrast between their approaches is most illuminating.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- National Selective Service's immediate cancellation of draft deferments of all men 18 through 37 involved in the Philadelphia transportation strike was ordered today at the request of acting Secretary of War Patterson.

LONDON, Aug. 5 (U.P.) -- Polish underground units have captured two railway stations and control of almost the entire west and central sections of Warsaw despite vigorous counter-attacks by Germans with tanks and incendiary bombs from low-flying planes, General Bor, Partisan leader, reported in a communique today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Offering to increase enrollment and to keep boys and girls of high school age in classes until they complete their courses, the United States Office of Education, with the assistance of other Government agencies, opened a national go-to-school drive today.

THE Roosevelt-Hull proposal for post-war security which goes before the other major powers for consideration in the forthcoming Washington Conference has, in outline, been gradually and cautiously released to public view. Its emergence began when Cordell Hull made a long-term pledge at Moscow which was at variance with our traditional isolationism.

THE Lewisohn Stadium will present its second excursion of the season into the field of ballet tomorrow and Tuesday evenings, when the program will be given by Mia Slavenska, Leonide Massine, Igor Youskevitch, Yura Lazovsky, Audrey Keane and Norma Vaslavina, with Franz Allers as conductor.

The Procter Gamble Company, manufacturer of soaps, reported yesterday that excluding its subsidiaries in England, it had had a net profit of $19,440,182 in the year ended on June 30. This was equivalent to $2.94 a share on its common stock and compared with $3.13 a share on a net income of $20,677,054 in the year to June 30, 1943.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Probable appointment of James Hale Steinman of Lancaster, Pa., as the next director of the Printing and Publishing Division of the War Production Board was indicated today in WPB's announcement of the resignation of Arthur R. Treanor, present director, and Mr. Steinman's appointment as a consultant.

In the editorial "Is July Necessary?" your writer fails to remember that something we get for nothing is seldom appreciated. Just think, if the seventh month were not in the calendar there would have been no Ford. Henry 81, and I celebrated our birthday the same day.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5 -- Four leaders of the Philadelphia Transportation Company strike, arrested on Federal warrants charging them with violation of the Smith-Connally anti-strike act, advised their followers tonight to return to work in compliance with an Army ultimatum, calling for a full resumption of service on the entire transit system by 12:01 A.M. Monday.

LONDON, Aug. 5 -- A Bank Holiday exodus which is estimated to have taken half a million Londoners to more peaceful surroundings coincided over the week-end with offensive and defensive measures against the robot bombs that greatly reduced their effectiveness.

Making an appeal for continued and increased support for a large strong post-war United States merchant marine, J. Lewis Luckenbach, president of the American Bureau of Shipping, sounded a warning last week that our ship-owners, shipbuilders, repairmen and other people in the marine industry must band together in the effort to show the American people the value of our merchant marine or watch it slip back to its pre-war place.

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined $579,444,222 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. Average price per share of all listed stocks on July 31 was $35.07 compared with $35.55 at the end of June.

AN Anglo-American film distribution deal of the first importance now is being concluded in England by J. Arthur Rank, the British mill owner and movie tycoon, and Gradwell L. Sears, vice president in charge of distribution for the United Artists Corporation.

The partnership of the United States Navy and American colleges in the training of men selected as good officer material for the world's greatest Navy entered a new phase last week with the establishment at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Colgate University and the University of Pennsylvania of special officer-training courses particularly designed for enlisted men whose service with the fleet has been notably outstanding.

LAUREL, Neb., Aug. 5 (AP) -- Twenty-one Army airmen perished in the crash of two Flying Fortresses and an a T-26 fighter near Laurel today. This lifted to forty-nine the number of Army fliers to die in accidents in Nebraska this week.

Alfredo Alvarez Calderon, Peruvian economist, has put forward a plan for a post-war international commodity marketing organization which he calls Stabilem. His booklet on the subject is now circulating in business and financial circles here. It is intended to be the twin of the International Monetary Fund for which the Bretton Woods conference devised machinery.

ABOARD UNITED STATES ADMIRAL CONOLLY'S FLAGSHIP AT GAUM, Aug. 5 (Aug. 4 United States time) (via Navy radio) (AP) -- While American marines and Army troops closed in on the beleaguered Japanese on Gaum, United States artillery tonight sounded the ominous thunder before the great final storm that is gathering to blow the Japanese off the island.

SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Thrusting quickly across the Irrawaddy River from captured Myitkyina, Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's Chinese troops have taken two-thirds of Waingmaw, it was announced tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 5 -- The West Coast is pondering the effects, especially those in the postwar period, of long-standing labor disputes like those involving Lodge 68 of the International Association of Machinists, AFL, in San Francisco.

" OUT ON A LIMBO" is a collection of family anecdotes by the author of "And Beat Him When He Sneezes," built chiefly around the same three boys who were principals in the earlier volume. Readers who do not set their standards by Clarence Day's classic sketches of his father and mother and the series that made up "My Sister Eileen" and "Junior Miss" may find them amusing reading.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The fate of an elderly couple, only white persons on Attu Island at the time of the Japanese invasion of the Aleutians two years ago, still remains unsolved, the Department of the Interior said today.

A sound post-war Federal tax plan should be such as to promote the factors which make for national prosperity. Since prosperity is measured by production, the ideal tax plan would be one which retards least and encourages most the attainment of the maximum amount of production.

With the trend toward night baseball having reached an alarming state, so much so that many are wondering from where the future players will come, the answer may be found tomorrow afternoon at the Polo Grounds. For there on the diamond under Coogan's Bluff, two squads of youngsters, literally the cream of the country, will play in the inaugural All American Boys Game.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Congress, back from its convention and political fence-mending recess, is in a fever, fired by good news from the battlefronts but fearful that it may have left too much undone when it went away. It faces a series of problems that will develop with the war's end:
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug, 5 (AP) -- Kentucky Democrats renominated Senator Alben W. Barkley of Paducah, naming him over six opponents for his fourth term.

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., Aug. 5 (AP) -- Bishop Henry St. George Tucker, president of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, who has lived twenty-four years in Japan, expressed the belief in an interview yesterday that it would be better to let the Japanese keep their Emperor, whom he termed "liberal in sentiment."

OF all the novelties heard so far during the course of Sir Henry Wood's fiftieth season of Promenade Concerts at Albert Hall, the most genial and most completely satisfying has been Samuel Barber's violin concerto. It was played by the Australian violinist, Eda Kersey, with great dash and sympathy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The results of primary contests in a general election year are always examined for auguries of the larger decision of the voters in November. But only one general conclusion could be drawn from the recent Congressional primaries that would gain widespread acceptance.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 5 -- The rift between the officer class of the German Army and the Nazi party leaders, which recently flared into the open and whose full extent cannot yet be accurately gauged, actually commenced with the failure of the first Wehrmacht offensives in Russia late in 1941, according to an Italian officer who served as observer with the German forces during the 1941 and 1942 campaigns.

Despite the pressure of ceilings set by the Office of Price Administration, the food industry as a whole has prospered better than was expected under price control, according to a canvass last week of the principal branches of the industry.

The Japanese Domei agency said yesterday that the Japanese Cabinet "has decided to take steps to arm the entire people at the earliest possible moment" as a Japanese Information Board announcement revealed that a new Supreme War Council had been created to direct the war.

ALGIERS, Aug. 5 -- The principal issues that have been pending for almost a year between Washington and the French Committee of National Liberation will be liquidated next week with the signature of the accords that have been under discussion since Gen. Charles de Gaulle's visit to Washington, official French circles said today.

ROME, Aug. 5 (U.P.) -- The British Eighth Army has occupied all Florence south of the Arno River against withering fire from enemy artillery that the Germans, despite repeated assurances that the great cultural center would be an open city, have massed along the river's northern bank within the city.

LONDON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- A vaunted German inner defense line guarding the approaches to Paris and inland France has vanished into the air from which it was conjured by the German propaganda mills.

McCOOK, Neb., Aug. 5 (AP) -- Former Senator George W. Norris said here tonight that he had accepted the honorary chairmanship of the National Citizens Political Action Committee, although he did not intend to take an active part in the campaign.

Discounting alarming reports in the trade of heavy egg spoilage, the War Food Administration disclosed here yesterday that it had dumped only fourteen carloads of eggs purchased in the Northeast region this season under its price support program.

THE hot, dry weather of this midsummer has brought disappointment to those who count on home-grown lettuce all season long. But the gardener should not be discouraged from planting for fall use. It is not too late to do so in regions which have a growing season of 180 days, or where the average date of the first killing frost is about Oct. 15.

ROME, Aug. 5 -- Evidence that Italy has definitely renounced her "Kingdom of Albania" will be officially forthcoming in a few days, it was learned today. This will put almost the final touch to the dissolution of Benito Mussolini's "Roman Empire."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Sharp criticism of the "liberal" Kilgore-Murray industrial demobilization and reconversion bill came from Republican and conservative Democratic Senators today, foreshadowing a vigorous fight on the measure when it reaches the Senate floor Tuesday.

The official temperature in New York City reached a high of 95 degrees at 4:30 P.M. yesterday, one and three-tenths degrees under Friday's record for the year. It was the hottest Aug. 5 in the history of the local Weather Bureau.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Stalled in their drives in Kwangtung and Hunan provinces for control of the Canton-Hankow railway, Japanese forces have launched a new drive in the extreme southwestern portion of Kwangtung, the Chinese High Command announced tonight.

JASCHA HEIFETZ'S recently completed tour of the Italian war theatre was a huge success, according to Milton Kaye, WOR staff pianist, who took a leave of absence from his job in order to travel with the violinist. The trip lasted eight weeks and was designed to find out for USO Campshows just how much G.I. Joe cares about concert music.

ST. AUBIN D'AUBIGNY, Brittany, Aug. 5 -- The great bell in the church tower was tolling this morning just as it had tolled on that peaceful Sunday morning four years ago when the Allies drove out of the village toward Brest, with German tanks snapping at their heels.

A VALUED correspondent, Mr. Maurice Dumesnil, whose letter we quote in part, discusses the story, often affirmed, and as vigorously denied, that the early death of Bizet, three months after the premiere of his masterpiece, was due to the allegedly hostile reception of "Carmen."

An extended health service to reach adjacent communities has been made possible at Bennett College in Greensboro, N.C., through a grant of $21,310 from the General Education Board to cover a three-year period. This will enable the college to enlarge its health program, which has already proved successful.

DEATH has recently removed from "this book-collecting game" two of its most prominent collectors: Morris L. Parrish of Philadelphia and Frank J. Hogan of Washington, D.C. In their careers, in their aims and methods of gathering their libraries, and in their decisions as to the ultimate disposal of their renowned collections, the two men were totally different.

CROCUS -- like golden blooms -- will appear within three or four weeks, if started now, from Sternbergia lutea, an age-old floral delight that for no good reason is little known today. Of all autumn bulbs, Sternbergia makes possibly the best display and is the most satisfactory.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Plans for the production of more than five times as many commercial trucks during the first quarter of 1945 as were manufactured during the corresponding period of this year were disclosed today by the War Production Board when it was made known that 56,705 trucks were scheduled to roll off the assembly lines during the first three months of next year.

The paragraph captioned "Hitler's Doom" in THE TIMES Magazine ran over the varied possibilities for the end of Hitler as Fuehrer. It matters not how he ends up physically; if we don't look out he will go down in history as a great man.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- Members of the confectionery trade here were greatly interested in Washington dispatches hinting of an Office of Price Administration move to increase production of low-priced candy, but preferred to await details before commenting on its feasibility.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- A super explosive called pentolite, 20 per cent more powerful than TNT, is being used in rocket projectiles.

SIXTEEN-YEAR-OLD and orphaned Nancy decides to take her younger sisters and go to live with their Uncle Nathan, their father's elder brother, in order to keep the family together and to save the old man's farm.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Announcement that the country's synthetic-rubber industry is now producing artificial rubber in a volume more than 20 per cent greater than the annual imports of natural rubber in peace times gave rise this week to speculation as to how the tremendous output would be utilized when the war is over.

Margaret Cresson's article seems to contain all the misconceptions about modern art of the average citizen, including the belief that the world has produced no other art than that of Greece and the Renaissance. It is amazing that any one with an artist's knowledge can actually believe that the modern artist has derived nothing from the past, and that the sole object is to do something different and "keep young."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- More than 140,000 employes involved in the "Big Four" meat packing cases are not entitled to a general wage increase above the "Little Steel" formula, tripartite panels reported to the War Labor Board today.

American villages, the small rural population centers with 2,500 inhabitants or less, famed in the lore and tradition of this country, declined in number in the decade before the war. But this was largely because some of them grew into the status of towns, a statistical analysis of data from the United States Census, just reported shows.
The Turkish home radio said yesterday that German Field Marshal Gen. Erwin yon Witzleben, whom it identified as the "leader of the officers who plotted against Hitler," was "now in London."

WITH THE BRITISH FORCES IN FRANCE (By Wireless). BRITISH troops in France, from the high officers down to the lowest of all ranks -- the patient, courageous, long-suffering and unprintably eloquent Tommy Atkins -- are so cocksure that the European war will wind up in ignominous defeat of the Germans that they are now asking how long it will be before general orders are given to cease fire.
OSWEGO, N.Y., Aug. 5 (AP) -- Lake Ontario's breezes tonight brought a breath of freedom to 982 European refugees quartered today in the Fort Ontario emergency refugee center.
BOSTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Tex Hughson today became the first major league pitcher to win 17 games this season when the Red Sox turned back Washington, 6 -- 2.

THESE sketches of life among the smaller wild animals are for adults and older boys and girls rather than children. As we follow the fortunes of Tawny the beaver, Princess the peregrine falcon, Stripes the skunk, White Throat the mink, and the rest, we seem to become actual observers of their beginnings, their wanderings, their struggle to survive, which so often ends in sharp and sudden tragedy.

LONDON, Sunday, Aug. 6 -- Grimly fighting Russian troops, moving forward against fanatical German resistance, inched to within eight miles of East Prussia yesterday, while other Soviet forces captured the Nazi fortress of Stry in the Carpathian foothills and dealt a heavy blow to Adolf Hitler's dwindling oil supply.

LONDON, Aug. 5 -- Employing quickly devised techniques, Britain is fighting Hitler's robot bomb terror assaults with a threefold counter-action that is robbing the Germans of the success they hoped to achieve with this, their latest "psychological instrument of war."

A MOVIE director, sounding off to an interviewer a year or so ago, asserted that the theatre was dying, and that to devote yourself to it when you had the screen available was like deliberately choosing to engrave your message on the head of a pin.

The recent arrival of the Victory ship Poland Victory on the east coast marks the first circumnavigation of the globe by a vessel of that type. The ship's performance during this, its maiden voyage, brought forth high praise from operators and crew, the War Shipping Administration announced last week.

BEING man-of-the-house is a big job, even if one is all of 9 years old, as Eben found out when his father went to war. But Eben had promised to take good care of Mother, Granzie and his two little brothers, so he did his level best, with more than a thought to spare for Pansy, the prize Jersey cow which was the apple of Captain Tuttle's eye.

PROFESSOR WALLER is shocked. He finds that up to 1942 the United States had spent over $15,000,000,000 in military pensions. And all that money has been worse than wasted. It has encouraged pauperism and maladjustment and has interfered with rehabilitation.

HEADQUARTERS, Balkan Air Force, Aug. 5 -- A special Balkan Air Force with a personnel selected from the United Nations has now been established to arm, feed and give combat support to patriotic resistance groups in the Balkans.

There were two distinct markets yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The low-price motor shares extended their miniature bull movement as rumors about the plans of the Fisher Brothers swept through the district. Other issues generally were softer, however, and THE NEW YORK TIMES combined average, at its low point of 100.72, was at bottom since June 14.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- Liquidation in grains developed today on the Board of Trade as a result of heavy showers or good rains in Iowa, Missouri and eastern Kansas, with some moisture in parts of Illinois and Minnesota. This, with the continued favorable war news from Europe, led to bearish sentiment, and the markets lacked support the greater part of the day and closed about the bottom.

LONDON, Aug. 5 -- The Germans, who still entertained a doubt of their country's defeat, must have seen the writing on the wall this week when Turkey after months of shivering on the brink broke off economic and diplomatic relations with the Reich.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 5 -- In the closest Democratic State contest in many years former Governor Robert A. Hurley of West Hartford today won the Gubernatorial nomination in a three-cornered fight that was not decided until the twenty-second and last town, Torrington, had cast its votes.

NOTWITHSTANDING the exigencies of war and Nazi occupation, France continues to expand her philatelic gallery. A radiogram picked up in Algeria and forward to New York brings information that France has released stamps in honor of Edouard Branly, a wireless telegraphy pioneer, Charles Francois Gounod, composer, and Anne-Hilarian de Contentin, admiral and marshal.

" ONE DAMN THING AFTER ANOTHER," subtitled "The Adventures of an Innocent Man Trapped Between Public Relations and the Axis," is a lively and highly readable account of the adventures of a society editor who became a war correspondent.

PEEKSKILL, N.N., Aug. 5 -- With half their training tour at Camp Smith here completed, the 2,100 members of the Fourth and Fourteenth Regiments of Brooklyn and separate battalions from Richmond Hill and Flushing, Queens, have found the stepped-up training schedule of this year greatly progressive as compared with last year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (U.P.) -- Vice President Wallace, who will be out of office in January, has been mentioned as the "ideal man" to be director general of the proposed permanent United Nations' organization for the exchange of agricultural ideas, it was reported today.

The organization of the Columbiana Society, which is to assemble material recording the wartime history of Columbia University, was announced yesterday. The society, formed at the suggestion of Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, is composed of members of the faculty and administrative staffs, as well as alumni.

Time, it has often been proved in the past, means nothing when the Dodgers and the Braves come to grips and so, when they clashed again at Ebbets Field yesterday, it was not altogether surprising that the crowd of 7,079 fans, only 3,389 of whom paid, had to sit by and await overtime developments.

IN his fourth volume of contemporaneous history of the war, Professor McInnis, University of Toronto historian, views the period from October, 1942, to September, 1943, as a prelude to the great test of military strength that was then in prospect.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 5 -- Plans for the establishment of a program of collegiate studies for returning service men, effective immediately, were reported yesterday by President Charles Seymour. The program, which will be known as "Yale Studies for Returning Service Men," follows months of planning and research.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Knocking two pitchers from the mound and taking advantage of Ray Mack's three errors, the league-leading Browns defeated the Indians by 9 to 6 tonight.

WITH THE AMERICAN FIRST ARMY in the Field, Aug. 5 -- Armored divisions of the American First Army have been the decisive factor in the American offensive that was launched southwest of St. Lo on July 25 and that has now carved out a great segment of territory to the south and east and has bitten deep into the Breton Peninsula.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Adopting the Democratic platform but opposing the "Byrd-Smith machine," Mrs. Elizabeth Chilton Murray of Little River Pike, Fairfax County, Va., announced her candidacy today as an independent Democrat in opposition to the official candidate, Howard V. Smith, in the Eighth Congressional District.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Charlie Grimms' Cubs -- the hottest thing in baseball these days besides the weather -- ran their victory streak to eleven today, taking the Pirates into camp by 7 -- 2.

FROM Charles Beard, America's most distinguished historian, and his wife, Mary Beard, who holds the same rank among women historians, comes an impressive short work which rounds off a lifetime of brilliant studies of American civilization. Written expressly for the New Home Library, which publishes only books with an expected circulation of 100,000 copies, the Beards have volunteered to forsake the comforts of academic discourse and detail for the rigors of simple expression.

IT has become apparent that the major producing-distributing companies, particularly those with theatre circuit affiliations, have shifted the main responsibility for ridding the screen of double-features to Hollywood. Observers of industry trends note at least four indications of a growing plan to wipe out double-billing at the source.

A PERENNIAL with unusually good traits is Rudbeckia the King. This crimson-petaled, brown-centered daisy flower should not be confused with the ordinary coneflower (Rudbeckia purpurea) whose petals soon become limp and dispirited.

In his letter to the President regarding the Philadelphia transit strike William H. Davis, the chairman of the War Labor Board, wrote: "It involves upward of 6,000 employes of the Philadelphia Transportation Company. * * * It is depriving some 2,000,000 people of transportation, about 900,000 of whom are war workers."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The War Food Administration announced today that Government price-supporting loans to growers on 1944 crop cotton would be offered at an average rate of 21.40 cents a pound for 15-16 inch middling cotton, net weight.

The lights went out last night all over the Polo Grounds. A break in a Consolidated Edison secondary feed line up Eighth Avenue caused a short circuit in the ball park at 8:20 P.M., so that it was 9:58 P.M., a delay of 1 hour 13 minutes, before hostilities got under way.

Major marketing trends accelerated by the war will have a marked influence on the distribution of hosiery in the post-war period, but volume, as in the past, will remain with the popular-priced store, Victor Lebow, sales manager of Chester H. Roth Company, Inc., hosiery manufacturer, stated yesterday.

Stockholders of the Coca Cola Company decided yesterday at a special meeting held in Wilmington, Del., to increase the company's authorized common stock from 4,000,000 to 5,000,000 shares by an affirmative vote of about 84 per cent of the outstanding shares.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The first new cars, refrigerators and washing machines will cost 20 to 35 per cent more than their pre-war counterparts, a survey of Goverment and trade sources indicated today.

Every day it is becoming more evident that the war has entered upon its final phase, at least in Europe. The vast structure of might, murder and pillage erected by Hitler for the domination of the world for the next thousand years is beginning to creak in every joint and crack on every front.

The plan of raising day-old pheasant chicks in brooder houses and then keeping them in enclosures covered with high grass has proved more successful than the old system of trying to raise them from eggs, as far as the Southern New York Fish and Game Association is concerned.

THE war has caused an unprecedented shifting of human tides within the United States, a migration in which an estimated 16,000,000 civilians have changed their home addresses. The changes are politically important in this Presidential election year, for some 13,000,000 of the migrant civilians are of voting age; and, just when their votes are needed by both Democrats and Republicans, they are beyond reach of the organization workers in their election districts.

Lorin Maazel, 14-year-old conductor, appeared again last night at the Lewisohn Stadium as leader of the Philharmonic-Symphonic Orchestra, repeating the excellent impression he had made a year ago. Indeed, he showed improvement in one or two important matters, as in a fuller orchestral tone and a more continuous and even pulse.

In his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES concerning the shipment of large numbers of comic books overseas, "Lieutenant (j.g.)" criticizes the Government's action. The lieutenant apparently has never spent some leisure time in a post exchange in the States.

Adventures in "biological engineering," described in Science (July 28), have led to the discovery of a "fatigue meter," which promises to provide a means of measuring an individual's efficiency when that individual is at par and after he has been subjected to stress, and also to suggest clues to how the effects of fatigue may be counteracted by chemical means.

THOUGH next to water, tea is the most popular beverage in the world, it is regarded by many Americans as essentially insipid -- fine for the Wednesday afternoon meetings of the women's club, but otherwise to be scorned.

AMERICA'S children are talking back to their elders. They are fed up with the daily indictments of their generation. They reject the solutions offered to the problem of juvenile delinquency. They would do some indicting of their own -- of the adults who, they believe, are responsible for their so-called delinquency.

Can Goebbels rally additional manpower in Germany, as he promised to do in his recent speech? He may succeed in drafting several hundred thousand more soldiers, but it seems probable that the number of German casualties will be many times higher than the number of draftees.

MOST literate Americans have read or at least heard of Gen. Lew Wallace's tremendously popular "Ben Hur: A Tale of the Christ" which appeared with little noise in 1880. The book seemed at first a dismal flop, but within a year its sale started to pick up and it has never ceased.

ALBANY, Aug. 5 -- On a trip such as the one Governor Dewey has just completed the observer is impressed with the fact that people in general are, to date, taking their politics as a side dish, and are concentrating more on the war.

Expectations of peace soon in Europe brought in early selling yesterday but the announcement of the cotton loan rate for 1944 and price fixing steadied the market for futures, and final prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were at the best levels of the day or 7 to 13 points net higher.

In a number of instances retailers are advising mechandise resources that properly confirmed orders will not be subject to cancellation should the war end suddenly, it was learned here last week. At the same time recent war developments have given additional impetus to the move for a uniform order blank, and it is understood that two standard forms, already in use by leading retail organizations, may be urged for general adoption by retailers.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Hal Newhouser, Detroit's star southpaw, scored his seventeenth victory tonight for a crowd of 17,257, but only after the White Sox, who have been responsible for three of his six defeats this year, made five errors to boot in all the runs in the Tigers' 5-to-3 triumph.

TWENTY-FIVE years ago tomorrow, on Aug. 7, 1919, Broadway and the theatrical world in general were literally electrified by the announcement that " 'Lightnin' ' has struck." "Lightnin' " was one of the smash hits (it ran 1,291 performances).

IN "A Ring and a Riddle" two Soviet writers of popular books for children have borrowed the familiar form of the old fairy tales. But this time the magic gifts which enable the youngest son to make his fortune are explained in terms of modern science.

AN invalided lieutenant of marines, Jerry Williamson, goes to his aunt's farm in Connecticut to recuperate and discovers that the farm across the road has been converted into a school for opera singers. When one of the girl students is murdered, Jerry, having nothing better to do, decides to do some sleuthing.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 5 -- Col. Juan Domingo Peron, Vice President and Minister of War, announced today the release of several prominent political figures arrested during the past few months. He also said that Argentina would not attack any other country.

BACK around the first of the year, in one of those fat anniversary issues with which Variety, the show business weekly, annually greets the arrival of a new calendar, Clifton Fadiman noted a few items he would like to see in post-war radio, and among them was a good deal more of American folklore.

Figures on corporation war profits and individual war incomes have been compiled in a booklet written for the National Association of Manufacturers by its chairman of the board, Frederick C. Crawford, president of Thompson Products, Inc.

The rank and file of the nation "will not turn from experienced leadership to ambiguous ambition" in the Presidential election if they are acquainted properly with the issues, the executive board of the National Citizens Political Action Committee declared yesterday in defining its objectives in the campaign.

THOUGHTS turn willingly to shade during these hot days, and a border in such a location should be a source of especial pleasure. But too often the shaded area in a garden is a problem. Little enjoyment comes from the sight of plants that, poor and strained, show but meager signs of their potential beauty.

PEARL HARBOR, Aug. 5 -- Quickening American advances on both flanks of northern Guam's jungle fighting line Friday pressed the Japanese defenders back into a sector covering about a fourth of Guam's 225 square miles, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced today.
Mr. and Mrs. Arthur U. Crosby, their daughter, Miss Katharine Crosby, and son, Everett W. Crosby 2d, will leave the Waldorf- Astoria today for their home in Mount Airy, Pa.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Republican party "has demonstrated the necessary unity and spirit that will enable them to take over the administration of our country from January, 1945, to January, 1949 -- a peacetime administration," Herbert Brownell Jr., national chairman, said today.

The first sight of France caught by most American soldiers in the last war was the rocky headlands of the Breton Peninsula rising green and welcome out of the early morning mists to the east. As the big, dazzle-camouflaged transports formed in column to ride the swift-flowing morning tide through the narrow opening in the cliffs the inner bay opened to their view.

WHAT constitutes a biddable suit? Books on bridge do not agree on this question, nor do expert players.

American Negroes may be proud of the citations General Eisenhower has just given to two Negro units which took part in the D-day operations in Normandy. One was an anti-aircraft battalion which landed "under artillery, machine-gun and rifle fire" and despite losses "carried out its mission with courage and determination."

WITH an ear to the ground the American Steamship and Tourist Agents Association, Inc., is making plans for the post-war tourist. The energetic octogenarian who has already booked passage for the first European cruise come peace, may be multiplied many times, members of this organization believe.

MOSCOW, Aug. 5 -- Flight Officer Richard T. Andrews of Portland, Ore., landed his one-seater fighter plane in a Rumanian plowed field yesterday and picked up Lieut. Richard E. Willsie of Long Beach, Calif., who had been shot down.

THIS useful little book consists of lectures delivered in the spring of 1943 by faculty members of the University of California at Los Angeles. Of the six talks four deal directly with the Southwest area while one details clearly and succinctly the diplomatic background of the war and another deals very generally indeed with strategy.

THREE new exhibitions opened last week in local galleries. A group of attractive watercolors by British and American painters has been placed on view at the American-British Art Center, making that gallery temporarily a little island remote from war, politics and midsummer heat.

UNITED STATES ARMY HEADQUARTERS IN INDIA, Aug 4 (Delayed) -- The capture of Myitkyina late yesterday by Chinese and American troops marked the end of the remarkable seventy-eight-day battle for the town.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 5 -- Two hundred and twenty-seven sick and wounded soldiers from overseas, including twenty officers, arrived this week at the Army's England General Hospital here. A large percentage of the arrivals was brought by air from the European theatre of war and a majority of these are infantrymen from the Normandy battlefields.
WITH AMERICAN ARMORED FORCES, Near Huelgoat, East of Brest, France, Aug. 5 -- Strong formations of American tanks have raced across these rolling green hills down into the city of Brest.

KALAMAZOO, Mich., Aug. 5 -- Robert Falkenburg, brother of the Hollywood movie star and cover girl, Jinx Falkenburg, won the twenty-ninth annual junior singels tennis title today, defeating Bernard Bartzen of San Angelo, Tex., 0 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2, in the final on the Kalamazoo College courts.

The Turkish radio broadcast last night an exchange of messages between Premier George Papandreou of the Greek Government in Exile and Premier Shukru Saracoglu of Turkey, in which they foresaw an era of closer cooperation and friendship between their countries stemming from Turkey's break in relations with Germany.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 5 (AP) -- Truck operators in seven States, whose 6,000-odd semi-trailers were halted today by a strike of drivers over wage demands, will make no attempt to operate, Lou Hosking, secretary of the Midwest Operators Association, said late today.

Six pairs were bunched together at the top of a ninety-two-pair field, with one session to go, when play ended yesterday in the semifinal round of the national contract bridge masters' pair contest in the tournament in progress at the Hotel Astor.

The discovery of penicillin, product of the green soil mold Penicillium notatum, has opened up for exploration a vast new continent of living matter holding untold promises for the future of mankind. This new continent may be named "biotherapy," the curing of disease by means of chemical substances secreted by living things, such as molds and bacteria, lowly members of the vegetable kingdom.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sunday, Aug. 6 -- The spectacular American conquest of Brittany reached its climax yesterday when one armored column severed the peninsula from the rest of France by driving to the Loire River and another penetrated to its western tip, entering the outskirts of Brest.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 5 -- Bill Picken, popularly referred to as the Squire of Picken Creek, now recognized as an integral inlet from the shallow stretch of water off here, fairly breezed home a winner today in the final regatta of Great South Bay Race Week.

CONSUMER response to early offerings of new fall merchandise increased last week, with retail reports generally favorable. Thus far, the possible impact of sudden termination of the war with Germany has found little or no reflection in the field of distribution. In the wholesale markets, however, there is a spirit of greater caution.

FURNISHING the interiors of Philipse Castle at Tarrytown has progressed steadily since this Dutch-American restoration was officially opened to the public thirteen months ago. In selecting the furnishings, the restoration staff, like that of colonial Williamsburg, has endeavored to re-create not just a series of period rooms but rather a home that would tell the story of its original owners.

MARKING the tenth anniversary this year of Talking Books for the Blind (records supplied by the Library of Congress) is the completed recording of the King James Version of the Bible. Begun in 1934, when the Book of Psalms was recorded, it is the longest Talking Book, comprising 169 disks, or fifty more than "War and Peace," recorded last year.

MOSCOW, Aug. 3 -- The first details of the Soviet Union's ideas on another league of nations appear in the latest edition of a Leningrad monthly publication called The Star. The article was written by N. Malinin. It is a long and complicated story, but in it is a clear expression of the Russian ideas on a post-war international organization.

A nine-count information filed in the United States District Court yesterday accused Mrs. Eunice Skelly, widow of Hal Skelly, comedian, trading as "Unice Skelly House of Youth," at 743 Fifth Avenue, of having misrepresented in the mails results said to be obtained through the use of cosmetics she sells.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5 -- The Army posted this notice tonight at all properties of the Philadelphia Transportation Company:

GENERAL HEADQUARTERS in the Southwest Pacific, Sunday, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Strong American forces stabbed deeper into battered and trapped Japanese forces in British New Guinea, and a new landing on Biak Island, over 400 miles westward, drew a tighter noose on other encircled Japanese units, headquarters announced today.

A reluctant Congress reassembled in steaming Washington last week, after a five-week political conventions recess, for what may prove to be its most important session since the historic early days of 1942. Then it had been Congress' task to mobilize the nation for total war.

IT has often been said that if there had been no John Locke there could have been no American Revolution. Locke's ideas were the common currency of political thought among our Revolutionary forefathers, however greatly their material interests might clash.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Any expectation that Congress would grind out a full quota of legislation for the remainder of the year began to wane when Senators and Representatives returned to Washington this week after their recess for the conventions.

Princequillo and Pavot were the stake winners at Belmont yesterday, and Georgie Woolf, the Iceman, rode them both on what was just about the hottest afternoon of the season. Woolf is known as a boy who can sit still on a horse, cold as ice, never get excited, wait his chance, then come on at the crucial and winning moment and bring home the bacon.

LAST year The Stars and Stripes, the soldiers' newspaper in North Africa, carried an editorial during the coal strikes in this country that ended: "Speaking for the American soldier, John L. Lewis, damn your coal-black soul."

MOSCOW, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Polish Premier Mikolajczyk and members of the Russian-supported Polish Committee of National Liberation were expected to open discussions today on the question of Polish unity. Some observers surmised both sides were ready to grant concessions.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5 -- Although the thing isn't supposed to be catching, the Yankees today became as inert as this city's strike-ridden transportation system. In fact, they scarcely wiggled an ear as they lost invaluable ground in the American League flag race by allowing Connie Mack's Athletics to romp off with both games of a double-header to the utter amazement of 4,722 onlookers.
Memories of the French Harbor of Brest as he knew it almost a quarter-century ago, swarmed through Lieut. Gen. James C. Harbord's mind when he read of American troops advancing toward the port.

LONDON (By Wireless). CAN capitalism and communism live together in the same world? Of course they can. The world has never been a philosophic unit. It came closest to that state perhaps under the rule of the Roman Empire, but it was a wide and tolerant rule and the uniformity that was insisted upon was prudently kept to a minimum.

A final report on results of the Fifth War Loan, showing New York State 23.6 per cent beyond its overall objective, but short of its E bond quota, was issued yesterday by Nevil Ford, State Chairman of the War Finance Committee.
