LONDON, Aug. 5 -- Detailed operational reports reaching the Polish Government today said a large part of Warsaw was in the hands of General Bor's underground forces, but as the Germans threw tanks and planes against the uprising grave concern was expressed in London that it must fail for lack of arms if the Russian assault on the city was delayed many more days.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5 -- Racial intolerance erupted this week in the birthplace of American liberty to provide Berlin and Tokyo with a windfall of propaganda.

STOCKHOLM, Aug. 5 -- The week just ending is perhaps Germany's blackest in the second World War in that major military reverses both in the east and on the French invasion front have been accompanied by political setbacks of first magnitude -- Turkey's severance of diplomatic and economic relations with the Reich and the resignation of Finland's Nazi-friendly President, Ryti, heralding definite peace overtures on the part of Finland by Ryti's successor, Field Marshal Mannerheim.

PAWLING, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- Ending this evening his first campaign trip as he returned from the conference of Governors in St. Louis, Governor Dewey gave to reporters the general conclusions he had reached as the result of his discussions of the problem of industrial reconversion.

The fertilization of three human eggs in a test tube -- two of the "test-tube babies" being brought to the two-cell stage and the third to the three-cell stage -- is reported in the Aug. 4 issue of Science by Drs. John Rock and Miriam F. Menkin of the Harvard Medical School and the Free Hospital for Women, Brookline, Mass.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 5 -- Total Allied casualties -- killed, wounded and missing -- in the Normandy fighting from June to July 20 were 115,665, Supreme Headquarters announced tonight.

SOMEWHERE IN NORMANDY, Aug. 5 -- Tall, gaunt with weak blue eyes behind thick-lensed glasses this German prisoner stood in a cage of the First United States Infantry Division. He was typical of thousands of those taken by the American First Army in the last two weeks' fighting.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 5 -- Growers of flue-cured, or cigarette, tobacco from Virginia to Florida are disappointed because the Office of Price Administration refused their petition for a two-cent rise in price ceilings. But the early markets opened this week, despite the threat of growers and warehousemen that the leaf would not be sold until their demands were met.

THIS, they say, is to be a banner season for the ragweed. It seems also to be a grand year for the second guess, and while every effort is being made to exterminate the ragweed we fervently trust nothing is done to interfere with the normal development of the second guess and its host of disciples known as second guessers.

WHATEVER the real story behind the attempt on Adolf Hitler's life, one thing is certain: Heinrich Himmler, Minister Plenipotentiary and most powerful man within the Third Reich, has emerged as Germany's real dictator. This concentration of all powers in the hands of one man may help the Nazis prolong the war.
The design for runways at the city's new giant airport at Idle- wild, long a matter of bitter controversy, has been agreed to by the airlines which will use the field.

To meet the needs of returning war veterans as well as the problems to be faced by civilians during the post-war period, social-work schools throughout the country have revised their programs, gearing their course of studies to the new demands. A study made by the American Association of Schools of Social Work has evaluated the offerings of the schools and has presented recommendations for early improvement.

YENAN, China, July 12 (delayed) -- Foreign correspondents who attended the opening meeting of the Communist-led Shensi-Kansu-Ningsia Border Administration and the Standing Committee of the Regional People's Council saw the work of one of the sixteen anti-Japanese governments behind the enemy lines.

A new method of teaching college physics, which seeks to integrate all phases of the work -- lectures, class discussions and laboratory periods -- by basing them all on the same problems, has been adopted by the Cooper Union School of Engineering. Laboratory experiments, under the new program, are employed to demonstrate the specific principles discussed in lectures and class meetings.

HEWLETT, L.I., Aug. 5 -- M. Donald Grant and Carl Timpson of Rockaway Hunt, winners of the medal with a sub-par 70, were forced to travel twenty holes before defeating E.B. Sinclair and Capt. A.E. Kroeger, Burning Tree, Washington, D.C., by 1 up to gain the semi-finals of the tenth annual Arthur Man Memorial golf tournament today at the Seawane Harbor Club.

BUD and Constance Helmericks told their friends they were going to Alaska when they married. "Everyone else was going somewhere, and Alaska seemed so far away." An hour after their wedding in May, 1941, they departed for the north.

Songs have been sung and poems written to the glossy, fringed-top surrey and the practical, everyday democrat. The hayrack and the high-sided farm wagon have had recognition. But little has been written about the humble, workaday stone boat which has helped farmers since the days when men began making farms in a new world wilderness.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- A Coast Guard-manned destroyer escort sank a German submarine in the Atlantic "recently," the Navy reported today. Precise location of the action, in which a Navy-manned destroyer escort and a French destroyer escort joined was not disclosed.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 5 -- Henry Wallace, as defeated candidate for the Democratic Vice Presidential nomination, has been the subject of more talk during the last fortnight than Henry Wallace, as Vice President or Secretary of Agriculture, ever provoked.

PEOPLE don't like poetry. At least that is what they say. Yet boys and girls memorize the words of popular songs; men carry clippings of aphoristic verse in their wallets, and children skip rope to rhyme. The truth is that people need poetry, and long before the printing press, when literature was entirely oral, people listened to poetry because it was an integral part of their lives.
CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- Warren Wright, owner of the famed Calumet Farm, ran into another bonanza at Washington Park today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- Some 450 pro players -- a number which compares favorably with pre-war turnouts -- have begun assembling at various training sites to prepare for the opening of the National Football League season next month.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- Albert Marx played the tricky Long Island Sound breezes just right to achieve a victory which amazed veteran observers today in the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club's special regatta.

ENGLAND -- In BBC's American service one notes that Anthony Trollope has been revived this summer. Sundays at 7 and 11:30 P.M., "Framley Parsonage" is transatlantically aired. Mondays at 10:15 P.M. the old-timer "J. Canuck's Review" is worth a try.

A CHAT with Brock Pemberton, the ubiquitous man of the American Theatre Wing and of the theatre in general, found him enthusiastic over the possibilities for his new play, "The White Rabbit." It's a modern play with a touch of fantasy and nary a hint of the war.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 5 (AP) -- A mass revolt was developing tonight among Germans in Turkey against returning to their homeland despite hints by the Gestapo that reprisals would be taken against members of their families in Germany.

Three officials of a Brooklyn local of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, were arrested yesterday afternoon accused of receiving $600 each in marked bills under threat of ordering a cessation of work in a war plant manufacturing gun sights and marine lamps.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 5 (AP) -- A suit against Frederick H. Prince of Newport, 84-year-old financier, and the Chicago Junction Railways and the Union Stockyards Company was dismissed today by Federal District Judge John P. Hartigan.
FOR a cute little acrobat only an inch over five feet in height, Beatrice Leon turns out a large order of humorous literature dealing with remodeling an old house.

LONDON, Aug. 5 (U.P.) -- United States Fifteenth Air Force fighters shot up Nazi airfields and communications in Rumania in another shuttle flight to Russia on Friday, Allied officials announced today.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 5 -- The final week-end of Dr. Serge Koussevitzky's Mozart festival at Tanglewood began here this evening with a concert featuring Ruth Posselt as violin soloist in the D major concerto (K 218). Dr. Koussevitzky again presided over his festival orchestra, which is composed of thirty-eight principals and other members of the Boston Symphony Orchestra.

TODAY'S column is primarily a minority report on "The History of Rome Hanks" and a concurring one with the majority verdict on "A Walk in the Sun." Although both these novels -- "A Walk in the Sun" entirely, and "The History of Rome Hanks" in large part -- use as their material the conduct of men in battle, they are vastly dissimilar in the manner of their treatment.

BOSTON, Aug. 5 -- Countless thousands of New Englanders would go through almost any form of privation in wartime rather than do without their agricultural fairs. Therefore it comes as happy news to many that 165 county fairs, seventy-seven more than last year, will offer prize cattle, de luxe vegetables, blue ribbon horses, poultry, racing and other traditional items against the customary backdrop of tawdry carnival booths this fall season.

EASTON, Pa., Aug. 5 -- Two definite steps have been taken by the Lafayette College faculty to facilitate the resumption of studies by returned servicemen and civilians whose college courses have been interrupted by the war.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

FIRST UNITED STATES ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Normandy, Aug. 5 (U.P.) -- Three United States Army units, the Eighty-first Chemical Battalion, the 146th Engineer Combat Battalion and the Eighth Infantry Regiment of the Fourth Division, have received Presidential unit citations for their D-day accomplishments on the beaches of Normandy.

Lots of things are being done with furs this season. They are the big luxury item and they must live up to the luxury standard. First of all, the designers have given the coats huge sleeves -- sleeves with deep cuffs that can serve as a muff when a woman thrusts her hands deep into opposite sleeves. Sleeves are gathered, and skins worked into patterns of many kinds.

Harry A. Morgan, vice president of the American Communications Association, Congress of Industrial Organizations, announced yesterday that all dry cargo and passenger ship companies, affiliated with the Pacific Shipowners Association, the American Merchant Marine Institute and the Ship Operators Association, had been asked by his union to open negotiations for a universal master agreement, covering all radio officers employed by the companies.
Summer is the traditional time to prune climbing roses. Though it is not a tempting occupation in hot weather, a little pruning every year will hold the work to reasonable limits.

STOCKTON, Ga., Aug. 5 (AP) -- At least forty-five Negro laborers homeward bound for the week-end were killed and thirty- two others were injured here late last night when an Atlantic Coast Line passenger train hit a broken rail and was hurled into a sidetracked freight train.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 5 -- That "free-elector" idea conceived in Texas and toyed with in Louisiana, Mississippi and other Southern States, is losing its appeal in Louisiana at least. Among the voting masses the proposal was unpopular to the point of stirring up resentment.

Two months ago last night the French section of Hitler's Atlantic Wall was quiet except for the passage of Allied bombers overhead. In the east, along the vast front curving from the Baltic through White Russia to Rumania, the lull of several weeks remained unbroken.

It is safe to assume that he counted on starting them -- that being the only discernible reason why he should have dashed off the contents of this thin, but fully uninhibited, book about President Roosevelt.
This year the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis received $10,973,491, its greatest donation from the American public to date, Basil O'Connor, president, reported last-night.

Morgan, vice president of the American Communications Association, Congress of Industrial Organizations, announced yesterday that all dry cargo and passenger ship companies, affiliated with the Pacific Shipowners Association, the American Merchant Marine Institute and the Ship Operators Association, had been asked by his union to open negotiations for a universal master agreement, covering all radio officers employed by the companies.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 5 -- That "free-elector" idea conceived in Texas and toyed with in Louisiana, Mississippi and other Southern States, is losing its appeal in Louisiana at least. Among the voting masses the proposal was unpopular to the point of stirring up resentment.

Five major automotive companies are supplying many of the principal sub-assemblies for the B-29 superfortress, in continued close cooperation with the aviation industry and the Army Air Forces, according to the Automotive Council for War Production.

Retail trade was generally good last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey made for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Clearances got the most action; main floors were busy, and college shop volume picked up.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 6 -- The automatic sequence-controlled calculator, an algebraic super-brain developed by a Harvard University professor in collaboration with engineers of the International Business Machines Corporation, will be presented tomorrow to the university by the corporation.

ON THE BRITISH FRONT in Normandy, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Thirteen German divisions already have been "thoroughly eliminated" in France, a senior British staff officer declared tonight, and "the next two or three weeks may be the most critical of any time of the war for Germany."

PHILADELPHIA, Monday, Aug. 7 -- Virtually complete service was restored to the lines of the Philadelphia Transportation Company early today as hundreds of striking workers, returning to their posts in a steadily increasing stream, broke the back of the six-day, unauthorized walkout.
LONDON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

After more than half a century of service to the passengers of the Long Island Railroad, Conductor Joseph Kertz, 72 years old, still takes the 6:32 A.M. out of Oyster Bay for Jamaica -- and seldom misses. Mr. Kertz is celebrating his fifty-first anniversary as a conductor this month and beginning his fifty-sixth year as an employe of the railroad.
LONDON, Aug. 6 (UP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces communique:

LONDON, Monday, Aug. 7 -- Striking from bases in Britain and Italy nearly 2,000 United States heavy bombers again dealt hard blows to the German war machine yesterday, hitting factory, naval base and oil supply targets from Berlin and Kiel to Toulon.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Aug. 6 -- Matinecock Point, estate of the late J.P. Morgan on the East Island in Long Island Sound, sold a few weeks ago to Joseph Miller, a Beverly Hills real estate developer, for $120,000, has been resold.
DETROIT, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Striking employes of five General Motors Corporation plants voted today to end a twelve-day work stoppage and return to work tomorrow morning.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Cardinals evened their series with the Reds today by taking a hard-fought game, 5 to 4, on a single by Max Lanier and double by Johnny Hopp in the fourteenth inning.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The league-leading Browns capitalized on six-run streaks in the sixth innings of both ends of their double-header against the Indians today to win, 9 -- 6 and 6 -- 4, thus gaining their eighth victory in succession and coming within one of their season-opening nine straight.

There will be no peace and no security in the future unless we as a people are ready to accept "shared responsibility with the rest of the world," Dr. Howard William Hintz of Brooklyn College declared in a sermon yesterday at the Lenox Road Baptist Church, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (U.P.) -- Representative Martin Dies of Texas, chairman of the House Committee on un-American Activities, tonight formally demanded that Attorney General Biddle prosecute Government officials and leaders of the "Communist-dominated" CIO Political Action Committee for alleged violation of the Hatch "Clean Politics" Act.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The Office of Price Administration advanced today the price of cotton sheets and pillow cases by approximately 7 per cent at the manufacturers' level as another step in its efforts to revise prices of cotton goods to conform with the recently enacted Stabilization Act of 1944.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The United States and Great Britain will create, probably this week, an International Oil Commission designed to regulate the development and distribution of world petroleum supplies.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Monday, Aug. 7 -- The American Army that overran the length and breadth of Brittany in four days has whipped its left flank eastward on two main roads directly toward Paris, shoving out one armored spearhead toward Le Mans, which dominates the rail network southwest of the French capital.
PAWLING, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- Governor Dewey rested today at his Quaker Hill farm after his strenuous trip to the Middle West, his only activity of the day being nine holes of golf with three neighbors.

WITH UNITED STATES ARMED FORCES ON GUAM, Aug. 4 -- (Delayed) -- That subtle change in atmosphere that one senses when victory is impending is now discernible on Guam. The feeling is unmistakable on the beachheads and in the brand new tent cities.

The need for a vital, forward-moving church to meet the challenges of our times was emphasized by the Right Rev. Thomas N. Carruthers, recently elected Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of South Carolina, in a sermon yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

CURT RIESS, who is a one-man factory for the production of literature on the past, present and future of Nazidom, has written another admonition to the democracies in "The Nazis Go Underground."* The date when the mole-like disappearance began was May 16, 1943, when the intelligence department of the Gestapo split into two parts.

LONDON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Nazi flying bombs exploded intermittently today and into the night in London and southern England as rescuers dug dead and injured out of last night's debris. The British Air Ministry reported that fifty-six flying bomb storage depots in northern France had been destroyed and forty-four heavily damaged in recent Allied bomber assaults.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- A considerable part of a record prospective crop of 1,131,000,000 bushels of wheat has been harvested and combines are expected to start work early this week in the big producing area in the Dakotas. This year's harvest is 122,000,000 bushels in excess of the bumper yield in 1915 and compares with 836,000, 000 bushels in 1943 and a 1933-43 average of 760,000,000 bushels.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Pirates put an abrupt end to the Cubs' eleven-game winning spell today by taking both ends of a double-header, 13 to 5 and 5 to 4, before a crowd of 13,362 frenzied fans.

NORTHFIELD, Vt., Aug. 6 -- Universal military training for the youth of the country during peacetime was advocated today by Under Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson in speaking at exercises commemorating the 125th anniversary of the founding of Norwich University, first college in America to include military training as an intrinsic part of its curriculum.

The uniform sales contract of the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U.S.A. has been revised to conform with suggestions made by the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers, it was announced yesterday by Harry A. Corbin, executive secretary of the producers' organization.

Peter Leventritt of New York and Samuel Katz of Millburn, N.J., won the national contract bridge masters' pair championship, most highly rated title for which bridge players compete, in the tournament at the Hotel Astor here yesterday.

Payments to property owners who must vacate Idlewild Airport sites by Sept. 20 were provided for in decrees signed by Justice Charles C. Lockwood of the Supreme Court on Saturday and filed in the Queens County Clerk's office.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Continuation of lend-lease aid to Britain after Germany's defeat and at least until Japan surrenders is under discussion in high Administration circles, according to a statement in The NAM News, weekly publication of the National Association of Manufacturers, appearing today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Liquor sales at above "ceiling" prices have been effectively curbed at the manufacturing and wholesale sources where the Treasury has control, the Alcohol Tax Unit reported today to Secretary Morgenthau.

Three miniature rooms, fitted out with dolls' furniture, have been set up in the fabric department at Abraham Straus to illustrate a few of the uses for "Beautanol." This plastic coated cotton fabric combines the decorative qualities of chintz with the practical nature of oilcloth and is now available in a range of solid colors as well as in a few prints.

The saying that there is nothing new under the sun has recently received further confirmation as the result of research in an unusual field. Dr. Robert Galambos of the University of Rochester Medical School has disclosed before a General Electric Science Forum at Schenectady that the flight of bats, long a marvel to observers because of their swift and unerring agility in dusk and dark, is made possible by a sort of natural radar.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- Movement of hogs has dropped off to such an extent that packers have been forced to bid prices up to the ceiling level of $14.75 a hundredweight for weights of 150 to 240 pounds, and $14 on heavier weights in an effort to stimulate shipments from the country.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 6 -- The Berkshire Mozart Festival came to an end at Tanglewood this afternoon with the last of four all- Mozart concerts by an orchestra made up of thirty-eight principals and other members of the Boston Symphony Orchestra under the direction of Serge Koussevitzky.

Extracts from a captured German officer's diary, passed by the Allied field censors in France and London and brought back to this country by this correspondent, reveal a healthy German respect for Allied artillery fire and for Allied planes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (U.P.) -- Christmas packages for Army and Navy personnel overseas must be mailed between Sept. 15 and Oct. 15 to assure delivery on time, Postmaster General Frank C. Walker reminded tonight.

LONDON, Aug. 6 (U.P.) -- Polish underground forces, fighting savagely despite waning supplies and heavy strafing by the Luftwaffe, have captured four strategic positions inside flaming Warsaw, but their strength is ebbing, General Bors, Partisan commander, reported in a communique today.
BY coincidence, Theodore Roosevelt Pell was encountered on the North Shore of Long Island the day Esquire magazine came out with its poll on the greatest shotmakers in tennis.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Army officials will be called on soon to explain "an apparent inconsistency" in real estate transfers, according to Senator Harley M. Kilgore, Democrat, of West Virginia.

ROME, Aug. 6 -- Eighth Army troops crossed the Arno River on debris-littered Ponte Vecchio into the heart of Florence today and engaged enemy troops in sharp street fighting as the Germans, despite repeated assurance that Florence would be an open city, opened fire with 170-mm. guns -- largest German guns in Italy -- against Allied-held sectors of the great cultural center south of the river.

ROME, Aug. 6 -- Reports that Baron Ernst von Weizsaecker, German Ambassador to the Vatican, had deserted and informed the Holy See that he would no longer represent the German Government appear to be unfounded.

LONDON, Monday, Aug. 7 -- Russian troops yesterday captured the great Polish oil center of Drogobych, wiping out the next to last major source of fuel for Hitler's war machine, while other Soviet forces extended their control of the Vistula River's east bank to more than 200 miles.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 4 (Delayed) -- Ambassador Franz von Papen left Ankara this evening by express train for Istanbul on his way to Germany, forty-two hours after the rupture of relations between Turkey and the Reich.
ROME, Aug. 6 (AP) -- A communique:

The resignation of George A. Sloan as Commissioner of Commerce was announced yesterday by Mayor La Guardia in his Sunday broadcast over WNYC. Expressing the "thanks of the Mayor and of the people of the City of New York for the great services that he has rendered," the Mayor said Mr. Sloan had expected to serve only one year when he was appointed to head the newly created department in June, 1940.

Twenty-nine young baseball stars, each selected from a different city, will display their ability at the Polo Grounds this afternoon when the first annual East-West boys' game under the auspices of Esquire Magazine is held for the benefit of the Community War Memorials Commission.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES in France, Aug. 6 -- The results of today's fighting are the most significant of the entire campaign in France. The German left has been turned by the American armored infantry units that are smashing in a southeasterly direction toward Le Mans, 110 miles from Paris.

The newly formed group of American Theatre Wing War Players, headed by Katharine Cornell, Brian Aherne and Guthrie McClintic, husband of Miss Cornell, has gone overseas, it was announced yesterday by the USO- Camp Shows. For two months the troupe will tour in "The Barretts of Wimpole Street," after which Miss Cornell, Mr. Aherne and Mr. McClintic will return here.

KEARNY, N.J., Aug. 6 -- The giant troop carrier, Gen. W.P. Richardson, 200th ship to be launched at the Federal shipyards of the United States Steel Corporation here and in Port Newark, today proceeded down the ways into the Hackensack River.

SAG HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 6 -- For the first time since it was silenced by the hurricane of 1938, the steeple bell of the Whalers Presbyterian Church here tolled today in honor of the 100th anniversary of the church that gave the port of Sag Harbor its name.

Adolf Hitler told his party leaders in a meeting at his headquarters that the "criminal clique" that made the bombing attempt on his life on July 20 was "limited in numbers but important in influence," DNB, German news agency, said yesterday.

With a few exceptions, job opportunities for women after the war will be confined to fields in which women worked before the war, but employers expect there will be a larger percentage of women employed than in pre-war days, a recent survey conducted by Pauline Arnold, survey specialist of the Market Research Company of America, shows.

A change in menu for Allied war prisoners and civilian internees in German camps will occur when Red Cross food packages now being filled at the local packaging center of the New York chapter, 39 Chambers Street, arrive overseas.

Increases in the prices of livestock and spring wheat were sharp enough last week to outweigh the much more numerous price decreases, and thus cause the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices to rise from 112.95 to 113.06.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., Aug. 6 -- Arthur Davis sailed one of his good races today and when he is good he is very good, as he proved in winning the International Class championship last year with his Patricia.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The War Department announced yesterday that a majority of the 4,687 enlisted men in its civilian pilot training program, which has been canceled, will be returned to civilian life at their own request rather than remain as enlisted technicians in the Army air forces.

AT AMERICAN HEADQUARTERS IN BURMA, Aug. 6 -- The cleanup of the Japanese in Myitkyina brings to a victorious conclusion the first major phase of Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's campaign to reconquer North Burma and reopen land communications with China.

Prepared especially for Penguin Books and the Infantry Journal by Aimee Crane is "G.I. Sketch Book," a collection of more than 100 sketches and full color drawings by men in the armed forces. The book, pocket size, will be published today.
KANDY, Ceylon, Aug. 6 (UP) -A communique:

Sooner or later the man of the house, however lacking in artistic talent, is pretty sure to become a painter. It is rather unlikely that this will come about of his own free will and initiative. Pressure plays its part. The money to pay Professionals runs low.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Cutbacks in arms production may be expected to increase, but have not as yet produced a serious problem, according to a report by the Production Executive Committee of the War Production Board issued today by the Office of War Information.

LONDON, Aug. 6 -It is not necessary to look beyond the holiday demands for currency to find an explanation of last week's further increase of u50,000,000 in the fiduciary note issue of the Bank of England. This is the thirteenth addition since the beginning of the war and raises the total to u1,200,000,000, compared with 300,000,000 at th outbreak of the war.

The Army Air Forces on the various fronts need twice as many planes, bombs, shells, guns and tools as they did six months ago, Maj. Gen. O.P. Echols, Assistant Chief of Air Staff, Materiel and Services, said yesterday afternoon, as he warned against complacency because of a growing feeling of an early Allied victory.

The state of flux of post-war designs of many manufacturers of appliances has made it impossible for definite advertising commitments, agency men stated last week. The end of the European phase of the war will at least cause a "freezing" of these plans owing to the fact that release of much critical material is expected, they said.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Aug. 6 (AP) -- Capping a closing rush with an eighteenth-hole birdie, Byron Nelson, Toledo pro, captured first money of $1,500 today in the $5,000 Beverly Hills open golf tournament. His score for the four rounds was 71, 69, 68, 69 -- 277.

Although last week's war news was altogether favorable, financial markets did not resume their rise. Allied victories in Normandy, the further advance of Russia, the breaking-off by Turkey of diplomatic relations with Nazis, evoked no response.
CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 6 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 6 -- The steel industry noted last week a slight increase in raw steel rate production, when ingot output rose 1 point to 97 per cent of rated capacity. It is believed, however, that the last week of extremely hot weather will take its toll in tonnage.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Detroit swept a double-header and the three-game series from the White Sox before 18,801 today, Dizzy Trout winning his own five-hitter with a homer and double, 3 to 1, after the Tigers had pounded out nineteen hits to give Stubby Overmire a 10-to-3 verdict.

PEARL HARBOR, Aug. 6 -- Forty-six Japanese ships and small craft were sunk or damaged on Thursday and Friday when a fast United States carrier task force caught a large convoy in the Bonin and Volcano Islands area, and slashed away at it in a continuing action for the two full days, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 (U.P.) -- Alsab, the turf's Cinderella horse who became the fourth leading money winner of all time, has been retired to stud and will be shipped to Alsab Farm near Lexington, Ky., in the near future, owner Al Sabath announced tonight.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 6 (U.P.) -- The Japanese have cracked the defense of Hengyang, storming Chinese positions in the suburbs to batter into the heart of the Hunan Province rail center, where "bloody fighting" is raging in the streets, the Chinese High Command admitted today.

GRANVILLE, France, Aug. 6 -- At the pace most comfortable for grandmothers in rusty black dresses and children barely able to walk, scores of family groups are plodding along the roads out of this town tonight on the way back to their farms in this area.

HEWLETT, L.I., Aug. 6 -- Eddie Neu of Milburn and John H. Howe of Seawane scored a 1-up victory over John P. Mattheys and John Nicholson of Meadow Brook in the final of the tenth annual Arthur Man Memorial golf tournament at the Seawane Harbor Club today.

BOSTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Red Sox scored two runs in the seventh to defeat the Senators, 5 to 4, in the second game of a double-header today. Washington won the first contest, 3 to 2. The victory gave Boston the series, 3 to 2, the Senators taking their eighteenth defeat in twenty-one games on the road.

It would be hard to find in the whole history of American labor a strike in which so much damage has been done for so base a purpose as in the Philadelphia Rapid Transit walkout. The fact that the damage does not consist largely in destruction of property or injury to persons is incidental.

Black chesterfield coats continued to be in demand during the past week, with melton and suede fabrics leading, according to a summary of activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

The Political Action Committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations issued a formal statement yesterday reaffirming its intention to cooperate with all groups seeking "to weld the greatest unity and support behind our Commander in Chief, Franklin D. Roosevelt, and his running mate, Harry Truman."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 6 -- Sonny Tufts has been named by Paramount for the romantic role of Steven in the proposed remake of Owen Wister's "The Virginian," which is planned for production in Technicolor this fall. Also confirmed for the cast are Brian Donlevy in the part of Trampas and Joel McCrea as "The Virginian."
GENERAL, HEADQUARTERS, SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Monday, Aug. 7 (AP) -- A communique:

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 6 -- More favorable weather and crop conditions, disappointment over further delays in announcements on new goods ceiling schedules and early-peace implications in war reports teamed up against low private crop predictions and price fixations against textile orders during the past week in the local cotton future market.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 6 (AP) -- Kentucky Democrats renominated the Senate's majority leader, Alben W. Barkley of Paducah in yesterday's primary, and the Republicans named James Park of Lexington, Commonwealth attorney, to oppose Mr. Barkley's bid for a fourth term in the November general election.

CHERBOURG, France, Aug. 4 (Delayed) -- Captured enemy weapons examined by United States experts here have been uniformly of high quality. There is no evidence of any German lack of critical raw materials.
CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 6 (AP) --A communique:

Two youths, annoyed that gasoline they were siphoning from an automobile in a two-car garage in the rear of 5712 Fourteenth Avenue, Brooklyn, at 2 A.M., yesterday was spilling onto the floor instead of into their five-gallon container, struck a match to locate the trouble and caused an explosion and three-alarm fire.

Vanity is an underlying cause of many of women's foot troubles, according to Dr. Benjamin Kauth, a spokesman for the Podiatry Society of New York State. Commenting on a study by the Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor showing that fifteen women have foot trouble to every man thus afflicted, Dr. Kauth said that fashionable shoes and pedicure methods that imitate manicures were responsible for many of women's foot complaints.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -The assignment of Lieut. Gen. John L. DeWitt to succeed Lieut. Gen. Lesley J. McNair in an undisclosed command of great importance in Europe was announced tonight by the War Department.

Cotton prices in the domestic market yielded ground moderately in the last week. Trading was slow and fluctuations were held within a narrow range. At the close on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net declines of 9 to 14 points, which were in contrast to new gains of 11 to 21 points in the previous week.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6 -- After striving without success ever since July 16 to place two victories end to end, the Yankees finally attained their objective in the space of a single afternoon today as they came surging back from yesterday's double defeat to trip Connie Mack's Athletics in both ends of the afternoon's twin bill.

GENERAL STILWELL'S HEADQUARTERS, in India, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The famous Merrill Marauders have been reinforced and are still fighting "somewhere in the field" in Burma, the Army announced officially today.

Some recent remarks of F. C. Davidson in these columns give striking emphasis to the need for clarification concerning American shipping, its role in the war, and the part American shipping can and will play in maintaining a prosperous world at peace.
Mr. and Mrs. John Nicholas Brown have left Hampshire House for Harbour Court, Newport, R.I.

The Dodgers pulled a triple play at Ebbets Field yesterday, but the Braves won a double-header, so even the thrill of seeing a three-ply killing was scarcely enough satisfaction for the 15,605 fans who turned out to bid the "Bums" farewell until Aug. 29, which is the date of their next home engagement.
Howard W. Sugarman has been appointed Western regional manager for Schenley Import Corporation, with headquarters in Los Angeles.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 6 -- Greeks revealed today that the long-awaited communication from the Eam to the Greek Government in Cairo contained as the sole condition under which the Eam and other affiliated left-wing organizations would agree to cooperate was that George Papandreou resign the Premiership.

The arch-criminals responsible for the war would not have plunged the world into chaos if they had remained faithful to the sacrament of confession, the Rev. Michael J. Deacy of the cathedral staff declared at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- The peak of the after-harvest movement of oats from Illinois has passed with little or no accumulation of stocks here, a good part of the choice high test weight per bushel grain being taken by cereal interests. However, the movement in the Northwest is very heavy and promises to continue so for a long time to come as an excellent crop is being harvested.

General Stilwell's tommy-gunners, fanning out from captured Myitkyina, can see the misty peaks of Yunnan rising thirty-five miles away. There are no longer any Japanese troops, except stragglers, between them and China. Virtually all the enemy in this frontier area of northern Burma were drawn in for the defense of Myitkyina. Now they lie dead in the muddy graveyard that was once a thriving town.

The current heat wave tapered off slightly yesterday, with temperatures in the city ranging from one to twelve degrees below those of the previous forty-eight hours, when three local Weather Bureau records were established.

With most fruit crops unusually good this season, many women are likely to try their hand at jelly-making. The process is actually easier than sometimes thought and pays dividends by providing an accessory that may be teamed with meat or poultry, or spread on biscuits, toast, cake, crackers and so on.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 6 -- In operations against the Maquis in Upper Savoy near St. Gingolph, formations of Luftwaffe bombers and fighters flew over Swiss territory today an bombed and shot up the Swiss village of Morgins, about a mile from the French border.
LONDON, Aug. 6 (UP) -- 4 German communique:
SUPRME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Communique 120:

WITH AMERICAN FORCES IN FRANCE, Aug. 6 -- American troops have cracked the German line wide open and virtually completed the occupation of the entire Brest Peninsula. Complete and utter confusion exists in the ranks of the German Army as it retreats eastward, hotly pursued by American tanks and infantry, and harassed at every turn by the Allied air force.

Helen Geoghan bought for occupancy the four-story dwelling on a lot 21 by 100 feet at 302 Garfield Place, near Prospect Park West, in Brooklyn, from the Rocklyn Realty Corporation through the Charles Partridge Real Estate Company, broker.
WASHINGTON -- Aug. 6 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 106:

PAGO BAY, Guam, Aug. 1 (Delayed) -- Engineers following Seventy-seventh Division infantry have used shovels and bulldozers to widen carabao trails into motor roads and cut broad highways through head-high swordgrass and even across mountains where only jeeps could go yesterday.

Running afoul of three Philadelphia home runs and a sparkling pitching exhibition by the veteran Bill Lee, the Giants had to be content with a split of their twin bill with the Phillies yesterday before a gathering of 15,299 at the Polo Grounds.

OTTAWA, Aug. 6 -- Twenty-five years ago tomorrow Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King was chosen leader of the Liberal Party in Canada. The anniversary is being celebrated by a dinner in his honor and the presentation to the National Liberal Federation of a bust of the Prime Minister done by Dr. Avard Fairbanks.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Chinese troops have occupied the inner defenses of Tengyueh, main objective of the Salween offensive and key to a junction with Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's Burma forces, after scaling the centuries-old walls of the city with medieval-type ladders and using ultra-modern flame-throwers to cut their way forward.

LONDON, Aug. 6 -- The tempo of the London stock markets has slackened appreciably. In such striking contrast to the accelerated pace at which the war now is moving, this has disappointed some market men. It is, however, easily explained by the sudden plunge into the holiday season and by the flying bomb attacks and a considerable evacuation of that part of southern England most affected.

Changes in the city's budget-making procedure which would provide more time for public study and analysis and require more detailed information regarding vacancies and salary accruals have been submitted to Joseph T. Sharkey, vice chairman of the City Council, by the Commerce and Industry Association, Thomas J. Miley, its secretary, announced yesterday.

The Hendrick Hudson, an eight-story apartment house at 380 Riverside Drive occupying the blockfront from Cathedral Parkway to 111th Street, has been resold after a brief ownership by Henry Goelet, operator, to an investing client of J. Tobias Goldberg, attorney.

LONDON, Aug. 6 -- An entire German convoy of seven ships, possibly evacuating German troops from Brittany, was sent to the bottom early today off the Breton Peninsula by a British and Canadian cruiser and destroyer flotilla, the Admiralty announced tonight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- A woman, about 30 years old, was stabbed fatally while strolling along a footpath in a wooded area of Rock Creek Park today.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Aug. 6 (U.P.) -- Throwing the Japanese India invasion army back across the Burma border in the Manipur hills, British troops have captured the important enemy base of Tamu in western Burma and are knifing deeper into the Kabaw Valley in pursuit of the beaten foe, a headquarters announcement said today.
Two new pictures are scheduled to arrive at midtown theatres this week. The program follows:

BOSTON, Aug. 6 -- Having lost the exchange in today's game with Samuel Reshevsky of Brooklyn in the eleventh round of the open championship of the United States Chess Federation, Milton Kagan, former Boston city champion, held on until adjournment time, when, after forty-one moves, the New Englander still appeared to have a chance for a draw.

Restaurants in the metropolitan area must post large placards listing the prices of forty basic food items, including a cup of coffee, in their establishments by Aug. 16, the regional Office of Price Administration announced yesterday.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Aug. 6 (AP) -- A hope for renewed strength and faith with which to face a future "in which the dignity of the individual man will be recognized and assured everywhere" was expressed to 982 European refugees today by Secretary Harold L. Ickes.

Declaring that religious isolationism is just as evil as political or economic isolationism, the Rev. Dr. Theodore C. Speers urged the church to overcome this tendency within itself in a sermon yesterday in Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street.
Yesterday's Soviet communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communication Commission:

After our armed forces are demobilized, the general pattern of Amercian families by type probably will not be materially different, statisticians of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company predicted yesterday.

Restaurants in the metropolitan area must post large placards listing the prices of forty basic food items, including a cup of coffee, in their establishments by Aug. 16, the regional Office of Price Administration announced yesterday.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Aug. 6 (AP) -- A hope for renewed strength and faith with which to face a future "in which the dignity of the individual man will be recognized and assured everywhere" was expressed to 982 European refugees today by Secretary Harold L. Ickes.

Declaring that religious isolationism is just as evil as political or economic isolationism, the Rev. Dr. Theodore C. Speers urged the church to overcome this tendency within itself in a sermon yesterday in Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street.

Irving Berlin, composer and producer of "This Is the Army," reported yesterday, in his first interview after returning from four months of performances with the show before British and American troops in Italy, that the show plus the movie had earned $10,000,000 for the Army Emergency Relief Fund and probably would bring in $2,000,000 more before it was through.

After four scorching days, normal temperatures prevailed yesterday and fur scarfs, conspicuously absent while the mercury was hovering in the 90's, were in evidence again last night in the city. The high reading for the day was 78.6 at 1:30 P.M., a drop of 17.7 degrees from the year's high, set on Friday.

MOSCOW, Aug. 7 -- Two long conferences between representatives of the London Polish Government and the new Polish Committee of National Liberation were held today in which the discussions passed beyond the exploratory stage and reached a point where proposals and counter-proposals on the crucial questions of Poland's administration and her relations with Russia are due soon.

Sales of the National Dairy Products Corporation in the first half of this year rose to a new high of $291,079,094 from the previous peak volume of $288,299,546 for last year's period, L. A. Van Bomel, president, reported in the semi-annual statement released today.
CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 7 (AP) -- A communique:

The Cavendish Club team of B. Jay Becker, Mrs. Helen Sobel, Samuel M. Stayman and George Rapee with a 940-point lead, won the final match for the national masters' contract bridge team-of- four championship in the closing session of the American Contract Bridge League's tournament here last night.
LONDON, Aug. 7 (U.P.) -- The new propaganda line of the Nazis was this comment by Juerger Schlettstoesser, official German radio commentator, today:

WITHOUT any preliminaries whatever, the man in the sailor suit asked: "Do you know that we have eight-elevenths of what would make one of the best football teams in the country stationed at our base? And do you know that we have a former national tennis champion? And not only that. We have track stars, basketball players and -- "

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 -- Supplies of canned meats and pork for civilians may be curtailed heavily and supplies of beef will decrease during the last half of this year, Wesley Hardenbergh, president of the American Meat Institute, told a conference of the National Association of Retail Meat Dealers today.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Tuesday, Aug. 8 -- German heavy tanks have been kicked out of Mortain, where they attempted yesterday to jab into the narrowest segment of the corridor through which American troops and armor are pouring into Brittany and down the roads to Paris.

LONDON, Aug. 7 (U.P.) -- Southern England last night had one of its quietest nights in two months with only a few Nazi flying bombs launched against the area and only a small proportion of those getting past coastal and fighter-plane defenses.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Opposition by Senator Connally of Texas resulted today in postponement of consideration of "streamlining" Congress under a concurrent resolution proposed by Senator Maloney, Democrat, of Connecticut, for a joint committee to study the organization and operation of the House and Senate and to recommend improvements in methods.
STOCKHOLM, Aug. 7 (U P ) -- President Mannerheim, in an order of the day said in part:
CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 7 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Insurance for all workers was urged in a statement today by Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator. He said the board will begin tomorrow to pay off on its one millionth monthly insurance benefit in force under the Federal Old Age and Survivors' Insurance Act.

ON THE ORNE FRONT, France, Aug. 7 (AP) -- British infantry sweeping across the Orne River on a two-mile front drove today into the western fringes of the forest of Cinglais in a sudden move threatening to outflank German defenses on the vital hinge.
ROME, Aug. 7 (U.P.) -- Front reports said that the Germans had violated their promise to treat Florence as an open city.

APPROACHING ST. MALO, Brittany, Aug. 7 (AP) -- An American attack, backed by armored vehicles, artillery and dive bombers, has cracked through the outer defenses of this ancient seagirt fortress to within two miles of the center of St. Malo.

In the "automatic sequence-controlled calculator," invented by Comdr. Howard H. Aiken in collaboration with engineers of the International Business Machines Corporation and just turned over to Harvard University, we seem to have a machine that is smarter than the men who designed it.

As Jimmy Walker told the crowd of 17,803 persons, the youth of America was represented at the Polo Grounds yesterday. And, as Babe Ruth said in his pre-game speech, it mattered little which team won the All American Boys baseball contest, so long as it was played cleanly and hard.
KANDY, Ceylon, Aug. 7 (AP) -- A communique:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 7 -- Samuel Goldwyn has announced preliminary plans for a picture with a post-war theme to be titled "Home Again." It will be made on the scope of the current "Since You Went Away." The proposed story, according to Mr. Goldwyn, will involve a cast of fifty principals and continue the contemporary history of America where the Selznick picture left off.

LONDON, Tuesday, Aug. 8 -- Oil sources and stored supplies essential to the Nazi war machine were destroyed by Allied bombers yesterday in attacks on targets ranging from refining plants in Silesia far behind the fighting zones to fuel depots over a wide belt of France.

SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Aug. 7 (U.P.) -- Allied troops in North Burma have cracked the enemy's grip on more of the strategic Myitkyina-Mandalay rail line, while far to the west British Fourteenth Army troops mopping up in the Kabaw Valley following their rout of the enemy at Tamu are finding "shocking" evidence of complete Japanese disorganization, a communique reported today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Aug. 7 -- The rapid advance of American ground troops along the coast of New Guinea establishing bases ever closer to Japanese inner lines of communication now has enabled the Naval air force in the southwest Pacific to strike new blows at weakened Japanese shipping.

The mark of the totalitarian state is the complete control it attempts to exercise over all the activities of the individual. Yet, curiously, as a result of the war, many sincere people who constantly pay lip service to "democracy" and "freedom" seem afraid of the effects of democracy and freedom and the exercise of free economic choice by individuals after the war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- As a result of a request by the Soviet Union for more time to prepare talks, the International Conference called by the United States to discuss a world peace organization has been postponed until Aug. 31, Acting Secretary of State Edward R. Stettinius announced today.

The Stadium's second venture into the field of the dance this season took place last night in the from of a ballet concert involving the services of four stars and an assisting company of two. Mia Slavenska's name led all the rest, with Leonide Massine and Igor Youskevitch following and Yura Lazovsky bringing up the rear in smaller type.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The nation's railroads are planning a complete transportation monopoly, Wendell Berge, assistant United States Attorney General in charge of the anti-trust division, said today.

With new ceiling prices set on denims, chambrays and principal types of sheets, and with revised prices on printcloths in the offing, Worth Street textile men predicted yesterday that cotton textiles would begin moving again into civilian channels, at least to the extent effective before the enactment of the new pricing law.

LONDON, Aug. 7 (U.P.) -- The Polish underground army has recaptured the Zoliborz district of northern Warsaw in fierce fighting in which even 12-year-old boys attacked German tanks with homemade gasoline grenades, it was announced today by Polish headquarters here.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 7 -- Complete public transportation service was restored to Philadelphia today when all except thirteen of the 6,000 transit strikers returned to their jobs under Army supervision to end a six-day stoppage which was estimated to have cost more than 4,000,000 man-hours of labor in prime war-production plants.

HARTFORD, Aug. 7 -- Governor Dwight Griswold of Nebraska, nominator of Thomas E. Dewey at Chicago, made the keynote speech tonight at the opening of the State Republican Convention. Earlier the State Committee had accepted the resignation of its chairman, J. Kenneth Bradley of Westport, and unanimously elected as his successor Harold E. Mitchell of West Hartford.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., Aug. 7 -- Birdie 2s with the aid of handicap strokes at the sixteenth and eighteenth holes by Frank Caprice of the home club enabled him and Ernie Catropa of Salisbury to tie for first place in the weekly amateur-pro tournament of the Long Island P.G.A. with 35, 31 -- 66 at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club today.

ROME, Aug. 7 -- Battle-hardened Allied fighting men moved into position tonight for the next great assault on an Italian water barrier, the Arno River, barring their path to the enemy's fortified Gothic Line.
The Spelman Fund of New York during 1942 and 1943 granted a total of $830,000 to thirteen organizations active in the promotion of good government, according to its biennial report, issued yesterday.

Of gravy conservation very little has been written in the books on etiquette and very little has been said in the columns of advice to those who are searching for correct methods and techniques. It would seem that the time has arrived for a constructive policy. To be sure, certain groups more interested in the fundamentals than the trimmings have never been puzzled.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (U.P.) -- Col. Douglas C. McNair, son of the late Lieut. Gen. Lesley J. McNair, has died on Guam from undisclosed causes, the War Department reported tonight. His age was 37.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 -- The Gypsum Association announced today a program for stimulating building activity during the reconversion period. The aim, according to Henry Schwein, general manager, is to "help to promote realism" in the industry. The points in the program are:

Renewed efforts to get Great Britain to provide havens in Palestine for Jewish victims of Nazi oppression in view of the Hungarian Government's professed willingness to allow emigration there, and to obtain more emergency shelters in the United Nations like that at Oswego, N.Y., were urged last night at the opening session of the second national conference of the Emergency Committee to Save the Jewish People of Europe, held at the Hotel Commodore.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Search your closets for old clothes with a future is the advice of Clarice L. Scott, clothing specialist of the Bureau of Human Nutrition and Home Economics, and creator of a trunkful of make-overs which recently toured the Extension Service circuit in Pennsylvania, Massachusetts, Connecticut, Maine, Tennessee, Kansas, Indiana and Alabama.

That management must "unsell" its personnel on the widespread and "thoroughly erroneous conclusion that an unlimited boom" is ahead for the country is emphasized in the current issue of Grey Matter, monthly publication of the Grey Advertising Agency, Inc., issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, declared today that he was losing two "very good men" from his Bureau of Planning Statistics as a result of a dispute over the information which the WPB might publish on the progress of war production.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 7 -- The Westchester Board of Supervisors, seeking to determine whether the new $4,000,000 Westchester Airport at Rye Lake could be operated most economically as a county function or by private enterprise, today directed the Westchester Board of Acquisition and Contract to receive proposals from private interests for whole or partial operation of the port.

Legislation to create a permanent State commission with power to enforce existing and proposed laws against discrimination was advocated yesterday in a resolution adopted by the New York State Commission Against Discrimination at an executive meeting in the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Miss Sally Sessions, who is small enough to hide behind a golf bag, conquered the rugged Onwentsia course with a one-under-par 74 today, setting a record for the course and equaling the all-time low qualifying score in the forty-four-year history of the women's Western amateur tournament.

MOSCOW, Aug. 7 -- United States heavy bombers of the Eighth Air Force from Britain attacked a German aircraft factory at Rahmel, Poland, ten miles from the Baltic port of Gdynia, yesterday and then flew on to American bases in the Soviet Union. No bomber or escorting Mustang fighter was lost on the flight of more than 1,000 miles, said today's announcement by the Eastern Command, United States Strategic Air Forces.

A report of the Italian Superpower Corporation, investment company whose Italian security holdings are in Milan, Italy, has been issued covering the last two years by P.T. Hanscom, president. As business communications with Italy have been prohibited since the outbreak of war in December, 1941, the corporation has no knowledge as to what action, if any, has been taken by Italian or occupying authorities with respect to its securities or income there, Mr. Hanscom said.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 7 -- Fred Annon, Hickory pro, and Charlie De Lucca of Gedney captured best-ball honors in the Westchester PGA one-day tourney at the Elmwood Country Club today with a card of 31, 33 -- 64.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The Civil Service Commission determined today the order in which Federal workers will be laid off when personnel cuts become necessary. New regulations were issued stressing the rights of "career" employes and war veterans, as well as efficiency and length of service.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 7 (AP) -- In some of the heaviest fighting ever waged in China, the defenders have smashed another determined Japanese offensive against Hengyang, rail-junction fortress in northern Hunan Province, front dispatches said tonight.

OTTAWA, Aug. 7 -- All parties in the House of Commons joined this morning in paying tribute to Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King, who today celebrated the twenty-fifth anniversary of his election to the leadership of the Liberal party. During nearly eighteen of these twenty-five years the Liberals have held a majority in Parliament, with Mr. King as Prime Minister.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 7 -- Turkey's severance of diplomatic relations with Germany has been regarded here as an indication that the eastern Aegean coast "will form, sooner or later, a convenient base for operations toward the islands, western and northern coasts and hinterland" of Greece and therefore will probably accelerate the liberation of that country.

GRANVILLE, France, Aug. 3 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- A party of American sailors, caught on land by a German ambush beyond the front lines, fought like infantrymen among the French hedgerows yesterday. Survivors said today that a naval lieutenant had saved them by riding a jeep through the surrounding Germans to summon American tanks and troops from five miles away.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Communique 121:

CHERBOURG, Aug. 4 (Delayed) -- The pastureland of the Cotentin Peninsula, which felt the first impact of American invasion forces, is being converted into a vast storehouse of supplies for armies. Already there is enough of everything that travels on wheels or is fired to meet the demand no matter how far or fast the Allied armies may strike.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Until the war in Europe moved into its present high rate of progress toward the objective, the Administration has managed to have some kind of machinery ready for matured events. Its delays, and successive makeshifts, before providing efficient means to deal with conditions long foreseen, have levied a heavy toll on the nation and on our allies in the war against the Axis.

MOSCOW, Aug. 7 -- A strong demand for vengeance against the Germans responsible for the systematic executions of Poles, Russian Jews and prisoners of war was published in today's Pravda under the title: "On the Eve."

Arriving at the Playhouse this evening is "Good Morning, Corporal," the first attraction to inaugurate the new ownership of the theatre, recently purchased from William A. Brady for interests headed by Harry Fromkes, president of the City Title Insurance Company.

NEAR CHERENCE LE ROUSSEL, Normandy, late afternoon, Aug. 7 -- Everyone feels pretty good. For eight hours infantrymen of this unit have withstood attacks by at least a division of Germans, and now the enemy is withdrawing, leaving behind the smoldering hulks of at least twelve tanks and scores of bodies sprawling on the green turf in the hot sun.

Added to the new films opening this week is the Columbia melodrama, "Cry of the Werewolf," which will begin its engagement on Friday at the Rialto. Featured are Nina Foch, Stephen Crane and Osa Massen.

In the subway the other day I saw a startling bit of juvenile delinquency in action. A group of young boys, all about 18 years of age, were gathered at one end of the car, shouting and jostling the passengers. The conductor standing near by said nothing. Finally, an elderly man asked them to stop.

Liquidation in advance of the Government's crop forecast tomorrow and hedge selling against cotton repossessed from loan stocks brought about yesterday an easier market for futures on the New York Cotton Exchange, when final prices were at or near the lows of the day with net losses of 13 to 15 points.

When the Allied armies began their offensive in Normandy just two weeks ago today, they faced a consecutive and strongly defended German front stretching for nearly a hundred miles in a general east-west direction from around Caen to Lessay. In the last two weeks, in one of the most spectacular campaigns of the whole war, they have smashed the western end of that front completely and have punctured it at other points.

"99 Park," headquarters of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, Inc.,* offers a partial list of free amusements available today, through the generosity of the entertainment world. Afternoon tickets from 11 A. M.: evening tickets after 4 P. M. Apply 99 Park Avenue (at Fortieth Street) for tickets.

Mayor La Guardia spoke for a host of New Yorkers in paying tribute to the "great services" rendered this city by George A. Sloan during his four years as Commissioner of Commerce. Mr. Sloan has native qualities and an acquired experience that enabled him to see the city's problems in social as well as business terms.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 7 -- The 100-ton motor schooner Mafkura which, with two other schooners, each carrying three hundred Jewish refugees, left Constanta, Rumania, for Istanbul last Thursday, was torpedoed yesterday in the Black Sea by an unidentified submarine.

GENERAL HEADQUARTERS in the Southwest Pacific, Tuesday, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Americans, renewing their advance against Japanese trapped in British New Guinea east of Aitape, have inflicted heavy casualties, headquarters announced today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Joe Baksi, 22-year-old ex-coal miner of Kulpmont, Pa., took a ten-round decision from Lee Savold of Paterson, N.J., tonight to register his second triumph over Savold in three engagements.

LONDON, Tuesday, Aug. 8 -- Russian troops, attacking a bitterly-resisting foe beyond the Vistula River in southern Poland, yesterday smashed to within twenty-five miles of the German stronghold of Kielce, while other Soviet forces in the Carpathian Mountains captured the last of 2,000 Galician oil wells that had been feeding the Nazi war machine.

The Department of Justice took another step yesterday in its three-year fight to compel five major theatre-owning motion-picture distributors to divorce themselves from the exhibition business, when Attorney General Francis Biddle filed a motion in the Federal Court here asking for a modification of a consent decree filed in 1941.

A brief chase along Eighth Avenue and on West Forty-eighth Street ended yesterday at 3:25 P.M. in the death of a young hold-up man who a few minutes before had entered the photography shop of Eli Gordon at 804 Eighth Avenue and rifled the cash register of $5.75.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Militarization of women pilots now serving with the Army Air Forces, despite the action of Congress ending their training program, was urged today by Jacqueline Cochran, Director of Women Pilots, in a report of the two-year Wasp program.

AT THE OUTSKIRTS OF LAVAL, France, Aug. 6 (Delayed) -- Ever since the main American break-through in the Avranches sector United States columns have been rushing through France as though on maneuvers, always hoping to catch the enemy in the next town.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 -- Attendance at the start of the second week of the annual fall market soared to record proportions, officials of the Merchandise Mart reported today, with buyers arriving in such large numbers that an accurate check of attendance was virtually impossible.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 7 -- In a close finish, Skip Etchells of the Western Long Island Sound fleet today took the first race of the Atlantic Coast championship among the Star sloops from Johnny White of the same fleet.

After having been forced to stand in his stall all last winter listening to all the nice things people were saying about a fellow oat-eater, Pukka Gin, then a prospective Kentucky Derby winner, Col. C.V. Whitney's Hoodoo is now getting his revenge.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- By decision of the Democratic Steering Committee, headed by Senator Alben W. Barkley of Kentucky, the Senate will begin deliberation tomorrow on reconversion and unemployment compensation.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Members of the American Newspaper Guild were called upon today to work actively for a fourth term for President Roosevelt, and to support candidates endorsed by the Political Action Committee of the CIO in the primaries, but delegates to the Guild's eleventh annual convention awaited a report of a poll among the membership before acting on the suggestions.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Support prices for canned apricots, peaches, pears, fruit cocktail and fruit mix, packed in 1944, were announced today by the War Food Administration.

While Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx "shed a tear" for his brain child and suggested soundproofing the "world's finest doghouse," 150 indignant women stormed Bronx Magistrate's Court yesterday to protest the continued operation of the ornate quarantine quarters of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals at 156th Street and Elton Avenue.
WITH BRITISH SECOND ARMY in France, Aug. 7 -- The little town of Mont Pincon was firmly held in a British grip late today.

The Yankees, who are to open a vital series against the Browns tomorrow at the Stadium, learned yesterday that they will have the services of Rollie Hemsley, their first-string catcher, for at least another month. The 37-year-old Hemsley, who had requested that his induction papers be transferred here from Vienna, Mo., was told by his local draft board that the papers had not as yet arrived.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- William Dudley Pelley, one of the defendants in the mass sedition trial, claimed in 1939 to have had a "revelation" in 1929 that a young Austrian house painter was "coming to the head of the German people," would become "the great power in central Europe" and that this power "may extend over Russia, overthrowing there the Legions of Darkness."

Two Allied planes appeared over Davao in the Philippines, the Tokyo radio said yesterday, according to The Associated Press, and one dropped "three small bombs which landed harmlessly into the sea. Absolutely no damage was caused."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The War Production Board eased its grip on the nation's stock of iron and steel today by listing several military and civilian items that, for the first time in many months, may be made of those two metals.

Interception and punishment by a United States Pacific Fleet task force of a Japanese convoy apparently carrying reinforcements to enemy garrisons in the Bonin (Ogasawara) and Volcano Islands reiterate with bomb, torpedo and cannon shell the increasingly precarious position of Japan in the Pacific.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 10 per cent for the week ended Aug. 5, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the preceding week the bank had reported a gain of 9 per cent over the like period of last year.

The Budapest radio announced yesterday that three Ministers in the Cabinet of Premier Doeme Sztojay had been "relieved of their posts" -- Bela Imredy, Minister of Economic Affairs; Andor Jaross, Minister of the Interior, and Antal Kunder, Minister of Trade and Transport.

The temperature fell yesterday, affording some respite from the recent heat wave, but you could not convince the tenants in the thirty-family apartment house at 605 East 169th Street, the Bronx, that the mercury had not climbed a few degrees. They knew the heat was on.
WITH THE CANADIAN FIRST ARMY IN FRANCE, Aug 7 -- Canada, for the first time in her history, now has a separate army formation in the battlefield -- the Canadian First Army.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 108:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Senator Truman, Democratic Vice Presidential nominee, recommended today that Congress expand its investigating activities as a means of raising its power and prestige.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Edward R. Stettinius, Acting Secretary of State, denied today any State Department official had engaged in negotiations with the British regarding an extension of lend-lease aid after the war had ended, as indicated in the magazine of the National Association of Manufacturers.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 -- All deliveries of wheat and rye sold today at new seasonal low prices on the Board of Trade and oats came within a fraction or a cent a bushel of their lowest mark as the result of general liquidation by holders of futures based on continued favorable war news from the European front.

AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 7 -- Government agents are expected here this week, it was learned today, to investigate complaints that labor union restrictions on output are one of the important reasons for the lag in production of heavy duty tires.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 7 -- President Carl Gustav Mannerheim today finished the task of drafting a new Cabinet list, and according to reports from usually reliable circles in Helsinki, he has chosen a 63-year-old insurance man, Antti V. Hackzell, as Premier.

The recent news item concerning overtime pay of United States civil service employes contained several errors, despite the fact that it purported to be a corrected version of General Somervell's directive.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 7 -- Low-temperature food cabinets now in thousands of grocery stores are inefficient and costly and will be replaced as soon, as materials are made available by more modern units that provide maximum food protection, visibility and accessibility, G.D. Mentley, vice president of Birds Eye-Snider, Inc., New York City, declared here today at the opening of the four-day conference of the New York State Food Merchants Association.
The offer of Gandhi for a settlement of the Moslem-Hindu issue in India offers a favorable opportunity for breaking the deadlock in that great member of the United Nations.

During the fiscal year ended June 30, 1944, the alcoholic beverage industry maintained its position as the "number one tax collector" for the Federal Government, with record receipts, according to a study released yesterday by the research and statistical bureau of Allied Liquor Industries.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a plan for the simplification of the Cities Service Power and Light Company system through the merger of four operating subsidiaries in Missouri and Arkansas.

A UNITED STATES AIR BASE, Kweilin Area, China, Aug. 2 (Delayed) -- The United States Air Forces can be driven out of East China if the Japanese drive far south. Since our advanced bases have given the enemy constant trouble and made destructive sea sweeps possible the Japanese have never stopped trying to neutralize them by consistent bombing, which has continued these moonlight nights.
GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Tuesday, Aug. 8 (AP) -- A communique:

AT THE FIRST CANADIAN ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Aug. 7 (Canadian Press) -- Canadian army headquarters was first established in the spring of 1942 in Britain, when it was set up under Lieut. Gen. A.L.G. McNaughton and had one Canadian corps under its command.

BOSTON, Aug. 7 -- Samuel Reshevsky of Brooklyn encountered stout resistance on the part of Walter B. Suesman of Providence today in the open championship play of the United States Chess Federation at the Boston City Club.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 7 -- Die-hard collaborationists in France are striving to repeat the methods that they applied in Tunisia after the Allies' landings in North Africa in 1942: to bully the Government into compelling the French to take up arms against the Allies.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The Lake Placid Club, Adirondack mountain resort, will be taken over by the Army as a rest center for battle-weary GI Joes, the War Department disclosed today.

There is something strangely exhilarating in reading of how the famous Cherry Sisters, homespun Iowa vaudeville act of the Nineties, brought down the house for ten years and made a small fortune, in spite of all the critics could do to stop them.

Cookies for birthdays, weddings, special holidays and practically every other occasion, each one artfully shaped to represent a person or symbol, are among the attractions at the Farm and Garden shop, a tiny story in the RCA Building at 30 Rockefeller Plaza.
LONDON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 7 (AP) -- With the cheers of the season's best-paying crowd still ringing in their ears, the pennant-hungry Browns, leading the American League by six and one-half games, left town tonight on a possible make-or-break road trip.
NEW YORK Lieut. DeForest Paine Davis, USNR, and Mrs. Davis of Lake Forest, Ill., are at the St. Regis.

AT FIRST LIBERATION CAMP ON GUAM, Aug. 1 (Delayed) -- Several hundred Chamorros, the first American nationals to be liberated on Guam, were camping happily on the slopes of Mount Alifan today. They provided one of the most affecting sights in the war.
GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 7 (AP) -- Lydiamite became a doubtful starter today in the $42,000 Hambletonian Wednesday afternoon and Barbara Babcock a probable entrant.

The stock market was turned over yesterday to the low-price automotive issues almost to the exclusion of all other divisions. With gains of a point and more in the shares of the independent motor producers, the remainder of the list closed only irregularly higher and below the peaks of the day.

At least one-fifth of the 2,500 new medical students Great Britain will need annually after the war must be women, according to a report of a British Government Committee of Inquiry into Medical Education, which is described in the current transatlantic edition of The London Daily Mail.

HEADQUARTERS, United States Ninth Air Force, Aug. 7 -- Another airfield of the Luftwaffe has fallen into American hands in their headlong drive south and southeast. It is the third such installation to be captured by American forces in the course of the Normandy campaign and probably the first devoted solely to German fighter craft.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 7 (U.P.) -- A program of closer financial and economic relations between Argentina and Chile, including the granting of a loan to Chile in Argentine pesos, was outlined today by Eustaquio Mendez, president of the Buenos Aires Stock Exchange.

Democratic leaders from key counties of the State agreed last night at a dinner conference in the Hotel Biltmore to recommend to the Democratic State Committee the denomination of Senator Robert F. Wagner and the selection of Judge Marvin R. Dye of Rochester for the Court of Appeals.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 7 (AP) -- A hearing on United Light and Railway Company's proposed interim distribution of common stock to holders of preferred stock of the United Light and Power Company -- prior to final court review of a plan for the liquidation of Power -- will be held before the Securities and Exchange Commission on Aug. 23.

The day of a college girl was rounded out, where clothes are concerned, by Franklin Simon yesterday afternoon in the college shop. Gone is the sloppy look of past years, and in its place is a casual smartness, exemplified in the well-tailored jumper with blouse of plain or checked material, or the skirt and sweater worn for chilly days with a plaid woolen scarf crossed and belted at the waist.
