BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 7 -- The Colombian Foreign Office reeased to the press today the joint declaration of Colombia and Venezuela respecting their relations with the Farrell Government of Argentina and her intransigent attitude toward the other American nations.

The annual report of the Electric Bond and Share Company for 1943, just released, presents an interesting contrast with those issued by the company in previous years. For the first time in thirty-eight years Bond and Share, parent concern of the nation's largest public utility system, has utilized color scheme and color charts to illustrate the trend of its operations during 1943.
VANNES, France, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The "minute men of Brittany" -- there is no better name for these men of the French resistance movement -- handed over to the American Army today this city of 20,000.

A packaging plan in which the color selection of nail polish will be simplified for the consumer was announced yesterday by Arthur G. Alter, merchandising manager of Revlon Products. He said the idea would be in production soon.

Reassurance that all shipments against outstanding orders will be accepted, regardless of the end of the war or market conditions, provided that they are made in accordance with the stipulations of the order, has been given by Saks-34th Street in a communication to its merchandise resources, it was learned here yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Nazi Gauleiters and propagandists are off on a wild gallop against German aristocrats and generals who, they allege, are leagued with a "blueblooded international" plot to kill Adolf Hitler.

PEARL HARBOR, Aug. 7 -- American forces on Guam have rammed the enemy back nearly three miles in the center of the front and now control more than 80 per cent of the big island. Remaining Japanese garrison forces, which apparently include some naval troops, are now compressed into an area the equivalent of four by ten miles.

An all-day drive by the Internal Revenue Collector's office in the First District, embracing Kings, Queens, Nassau and Suffolk Counties and Staten Island, yesterday netted 3,000 motorists who failed to have affixed to their windshield the $5 Federal automobile use stamp.

ALGIERS, Aug. 7 -- Declaring that battle-hardened and modernly equipped French troops would soon take their place in the Allied front in France, Gen. Charles de Gaulle, in a speech broadcast to the French tonight, called on all his countrymen to take part immediately in "this supreme war effort of the nation in these decisive days."

ALBANY, Aug. 7 -- Thomas J. Curran, Republican chairman of New York County and Secretary of State in the Dewey Administration, has been chosen as the Republican candidate for United States Senator, to oppose Senator Robert F. Wagner in the November elections.

Democrats who supported Representative Martin J. Kennedy are considering an application for a recount of the vote in last week's primary election, in which he was defeated for renomination by Representative Vito Marcantonio, Irving H. Saypol, chairman of the Kennedy campaign committee, disclosed yesterday.

ROME, Aug. 7 -- The last thing expected by the Allied command or anxious Italians was that Florence would be turned into a battleground. The Germans had declared it an open city and it was taken for granted that they would withdraw northward as soon as Allied forces reached the suburbs.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (U.P.) -- The Senate Democratic steering committee was called together by Senator Barkley, after it became apparent that a bloc of conservative Democrats would line up with Republicans in a fight to defeat or force drastic revision of the Murray-Kilgore bill.
Because of short supply, butterless luncheons will continue in restaurants operated by members of the Society of Restaurateurs, Paul Henkel, president of the society, announced yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 8 -- Officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation here disclosed today the arrest of three men, one of them a silk manufacturer in Scranton, Pa., who allegedly created a $1,000,000,000 black market in nylon hosiery by diverting yarn intended for the manufacture of Army parachutes and glider towropes.

Cash available to Atlas Corporation on July 1 amounted to about $26,000,000, including $1,500,000 of Treasury certificates and the liquid resources of the 99.9 per cent-owned Rotary Electric Steel Company, whose plant, equipment and inventories were sold on that date.

The Emergency Committee to Save the Jewish People of Europe called upon the United States and Great Britain yesterday to set up centers for refugee Jews now housed in Turkey so that Turkey could open its doors to the thousands now held back at the borders for lack of space.

The familiar catbird is a chap with contrary characteristics. If politics be a major issue in the bird world, he has the qualifications for going far. He is loved, ridiculed, admired and condemned. But he goes on, serenely and confidently, knowing he has an exquisitely proportioned figure, a sleek, gray outfit and a Beau Brummel air.
The War Food Administration asked yesterday for bids on 47,066 cases of graded eggs that must be moved out of storage in Providence R. I., to make way for the new apple crop.

It seems that the members of the Sportsmen Anglers of New York are all worked up over their surf shark-fishing contest which takes place on Sunday at Oak Beach, L.I. On the word of Howard Freytag, many of them no longer look forward to the spring and fall runs of lesser fish; the summer months that bring large sharks within casting range of the beach are all they live for.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 8 -- All German troops in Bulgaria are now reported to be leaving the country and there are strong indications that new negotiations between the Bagrianoff Government and Allied representatives are progressing. Premier Ivan Bagrianoff is believed to be resolved to make peace.

GREAT LAKES, Ill., Aug. 8 -- The Dodgers have started a Western trip by winning a ball game, which may be news of great import, without their manager, Leo Durocher, present to witness the phenomenon. The Brooks came from behind to beat Mickey Cochrane's Great Lakes team, 7 -- 4, today while about 11,800 sailors looked on.

Men, not women, were judges yesterday afternoon at Saks Thirty-fourth Street's college showing when three Army and three Navy men expressed their opinion of twenty styles. They did not like slacks. The saucy round bowlers that sat well down on the head won favor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Rear Admiral Don Pardee Moon, who commanded a task force during the landings in Normandy, ended his life Saturday. Secretary James Forrestal said "with regret" today that "apparently Rear Admiral Moon had taken his own life as a result of combat fatigue."

Expressing a belief that "the status of Italy should be decided by the United Nations," Mayor La Guardia told the Italian people in his weekly short-wave broadcast to them Sunday that he would be off the air "until I have something definite to say."

For nine years Ernest Rupolo, eagle-beaked and one-eyed self-confessed assassin-for-hire known as "The Hawk," served time in Sing Sing Prison for the shooting of Willie Gallo, a bodyguard of big-shot thugs.

A banking group headed by Lehman Brothers yesterday was awarded the $24,000,000 first mortgage 2 3/4 per cent, Series G, bonds of the Cincinnati Union Terminal Company on a bid of 101.08. The bonds, which are due Aug. 1, 1974, were reoffered at 101.85.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The War Food Administration announced today that manufacturers of frozen dairy foods would no longer be restricted in the use of non-fat milk solids in ice cream so long as the total quantity of milk solids they use did not exceed 22 per cent.

Ending a fight of nearly a year against what he termed "arbitrary rules" of the Solid Fuels Administration, Paul Skobbeko, 25 years old, disabled veteran of World War II, yesterday resumed business as a coal dealer.

BOSTON, Aug. 8 -- Held back through a draw in the thirteenth round and a loss in the game postponed from the tenth and finished today, Samuel Reshevsky of Brooklyn resumed his winning streak in the fourteenth round of the open championship of the United States Chess Federation at the Boston City Club tonight.

Four advertisements that have as their theme "Courtesy now -- customers later," placed by Detecto Scales, Inc., during the past four months in House Furnishing Review have attracted considerable attention in the advertising and other fields.

I think that it is against historical truth to assume, as your correspondent from Rome has done, that all the Duce's opponents did not dare to use it (Filippelli's memorandum), although by using it they could have overthrown the Fascist regime in June, 1924.

The swing of the fashion pendulum toward "more hat" already has been accepted by America's best-dressed women, 200 members of the millinery, accessories and ready-to-wear divisions of the Fashion Group were told at a luncheon yesterday at the Murray Hill Hotel.

The combination home, printing establishment, Wild West museum, Boy Scout center and Indian stamping grounds which residents of South Ozone Park, Queens, have for many years pointed out with a mixture of pride and awe is about to disappear and become just another lawn or runway in Idlewild Airport, it was learned yesterday.

Planning for the post-war construction of a building for its home offices, the National Sugar Refining Company has acquired two properties on Front Street. With these purchases, 124 Front Street, from Harris D. Colt trustee, and 126 Front Street from the City Farmers Trust Company, trustee for the estate of David C. Johnson, the company now has a group of six buildings at the northwest corner of Wall and Front Streets.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 lending cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 2, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

ROME, Aug. 8 -- If in Rome you do as Romans and not as Americans do your first occupation is search for food. So this morning this correspondent followed Roman housewives on a round of market places. Everybody was stockingless and hatless, even "signorine" who formerly never appeared in the streets with uncovered heads.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today forecast this year's cotton crop at the equivalent of 11,022,000 500-pound bales.

After momentarily easing yesterday on the bearish estimate of the cotton crop issued by the Federal Crop Reporting Board, the futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange rallied and closed at the best levels of the day with net gains of 5 to 7 points in the active months.

The threat of inflation will increase rather than diminish immediately after the war, in the opinion of the majority of seventeen industrialists who were polled by an organization called Life Insurance Companies in America, at 60 East Forty-second Street, which announced the result yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The red-robed presiding judge of the Senate of the People's Court was quoted as interrupting testimony and browbeating a general today into calling himself an ass and then contradicting him with the juristic observation: "You always will be a schweinhund (pig dog)."

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 8 -- After a two-day blitz trial recalling in all its scope of details the Reichstag fire travesty that ended with the execution of Marius van der Lubbe in 1933 for something to which he had "confessed," eight high officers of the German Army were hanged in Berlin this afternoon two hours after having been sentenced to death for treason by a special "people's tribunal" under Judge Roland Freisler.

HARTFORD, Aug. 8 -- President Roosevelt was accused of trying to institute a one-man government by United States Senator John A. Danaher at the Republican State Convention here today. Senator Danaher and Gov. Raymond E. Baldwin were renominated by acclamation.
Mrs. Robert A. Taft and Miss Maria Herron of Cincinnati have arrived at the Carlyle.

Since this is the month in which you count ten before starting any drama review, let today's note be sullenly factual. "Good Morning, Corporal," by Milton Herbert Gropper and Joseph Shalleck, opened last evening at the Playhouse, an event which found the Broadway theatre standing solidly at the nadir -- or even just a shade below it.

The War Department has revealed that a shortage in the production of heavy-duty tires has been threatening a shortage of heavy trucks and heavy artillery movers for the invasion forces in France, as well as essential transportation on the home front, and is thereby endangering the prospects of early victory.

The three-story "taxpayer" building at 101-107 Prospect Avenue, Mount Vernon, N.Y., has been purchased by the Arto Painting Company from the Bowery Savings Bank through the Raymond R. Beatty organization. Assessed at $100,000, the property consists of seven stores, three offices and six apartments.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Wednesday, Aug. 9 -- Thrusting four miles into the strong German defenses blocking the road to Paris, Canadian and British forces have opened a new offensive south of Caen, while American troops, according to the Germans, have speared to the Sarthe River within 100 miles of the capital.

Senator Robert F. Wagner, legislative sponsor of many major New Deal measures, was renominated yesterday for a fourth term at a meeting of the Democratic State Committee in the National Democratic Club, 233 Madison Avenue.

Leading men and women amateur tennis players of the country gather for the first time of the season in the metropolitan area today with the opening of the Eastern grass court championships at the Westchester Country Club, Rye.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Employment of children this summer is fully as great as last summer when an estimated 5,000,000, between 14 and 17, were at work, Beatrice McConnell, director of the Industrial Division of the Children's Bureau, said today.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES, Near Mortain, Aug. 8 -- The German counter-offensive in this sector, a bold bid to dam the onrushing tide of American troops in France, lies broken and wrecked today on the green hills and narrow winding roads of this sector.

IN THE ANGLO-CANADIAN FRONT LINES, Aug. 8 (UP) -- The German hinge south of Caen is creaking under the weight of the Anglo-Canadian offensive that has pushed almost five miles since this morning's kick-off.

Robert E. Hannegan, Democratic national chairman, was quoted yesterday by a group of Negro newspaper publishers as having told them at a private conference that this year's election might be decided by the vote in eight of the larger cities of the country where there are heavy Negro populations.

ALBANY, Aug. 8 -- The Republican party, in nominating today its State ticket, consisting of Thomas J. Curran of New York for United States Senator, and John Van Voorhis of Rochester for Associate Judge of the Court of Appeals, gave also its keynote for the campaign in the State.

Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totaled 870 against 932 in the preceding week and 874 in the like period a year ago, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals numbered 385 against 529 last Tuesday.

The Newspaper Commission of the War Labor Board yesterday ordered maintenance of union membership by news employes of the New York office of The Associated Press. The maintenance clause was voted by Dr. F.S. Deibler, public member, and Sam Eubanks, labor member, of the commission.

LONDON, Wednesday, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Allied aerial armadas that number well over 3,500 planes smashed at vital German sea and land transportation and strategic supply areas during Monday night and yesterday, in addition to giving strong direct support to our ground offensive in France.

On the front page of THE TIMES is a block "War News Summarized." Some day that block could have a different title, "Your Government Today." If this block were set up now to balance the war news, it might chase the war news off more quickly.

MOSCOW, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk relayed to his exiled government in London today the details of his lengthy discussions with the Polish Committee of Liberation and National Council.

In the fourth week of their paper salvage drive, boys and girls using the Board of Education's 305 vacation playgrounds collected 163,022 pounds of waste paper, bringing their salvage total so far to 404 tons, Francis J. Brennan, acting director of community education, announced yesterday.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 8 -- The third conference of the Inter-American Bar Association ended today, after a storm raised at a meeting last night by the Puerto Rican delegation and an Ecuadorian lawyer who attempted to turn the session into a manifestation against the United States.

The Department of Agriculture's forecast yesterday of a yield of 11,022,000 bales from this year's cotton crop was about 500,000 bales more than the trade had expected. A crop of that size, however, will be virtually sufficient to take care of demands in the present season without taking into consideration the surplus of about 10,500,000 bales from previous crops.

WALTER B. PITKIN, who published the glad tidings some years ago that life begins at forty, has been enjoying his second, or post-forty, life for twenty-six years. According to his own popular precepts his recent years should have been richer, fuller and more rewarding than those of his childhood, youth and early maturity.

Twilight Tear, prima donna of the 3-year-old show, attempted a "one-night stand" in New York yesterday, but she finished second in the Alabama Stakes, which was to have been her vehicle to a higher than ever pinnacle.

"Hail the Conquering Hero," a comedy written and directed by Preston Sturges and starring Eddie Bracken, win open today at the Paramount. Others in the cast include Ella Raines and William Demarest. Similar to Mr. Sturges' recent hit "The Miracle of Morgan's Creek," the locale of the story is a small town.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Those chiefly concerned in the drafting of the Anglo-American agreement with the French Committee of National Liberation, and particularly the Committee's representatives here, are expressing general satisfaction with the contents of the document, which is almost ready for initialing in Washington and in London.

The steel industry produced 7, 474,297 tons of steel in July, a gain of nearly 260,000 tons compared with June and about 66,500 tons over the output in July, 1943, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. It was the smallest output for a thirty-one-day month since December, when 7,255,144 tons were produced.

Manners Yesterday and Today Newspaper editors still get, and print, letters from readers disturbed by the bad manners and discourtesy they find in New York. There has been a minor rash of them recently. A letter to this newspaper deplored the thoughtlessness for others made manifest by the wearing of large picture hats in crowded elevators.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The Office of Price Administration provided new methods today with which manufacturers and wholesalers will compute their ceiling prices over elastic webbing, braid and cord beginning on Aug. 14.

ALTHOUGH this may be a bit soon to discuss spring training plans for 1945, still and all, considering how the matter was rushed up on the baseball magnates last winter, it might not be a bad idea to give the subject a preliminary airing even at this early date.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

A UNITED STATES NINTH AIR FORCE BASE, Normandy, Aug. 8 -- Further evidence of the Luftwaffe's weakened state came in an abortive attempt by Nazi planes yesterday to support the German Army's defeated counterattack in the Mortain area.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Headed toward a compromise measure, the Senate at recess this afternoon had before it for consideration tomorrow the George Bill on unemployment compensation, expanded by amendment to the proportions of the Murray-Truman-Kilgore legislation, which embraces, as well, re-conversion and post-war readjustment.

TORONTO, Aug. 8 (Canadian Press) -- Rampaging Newark moved within half a game of the International League lead tonight by sweeping a double-header with Toronto, 5 -- 0 and 6 -- 3, as first-place Baltimore dropped two games at Rochester.

The 1944 Alfred A. Knopf Fellowship in Biography has been awarded to Stearns Morse, Professor of English at Dartmouth College, and the Fellowship in History to Edward Townsend Booth, contributor to the editorial page of The New York Herald Tribune.

LONDON, Aug. 8 (U.P.) -- French Forces of the Interior, harassing German troops moving to the battlefront, today struck at German communication lines and columns and forced troops to evacuate a large part of Nievre Department, 100 miles southeast of Paris, a communique issued by authoritative quarters revealed.

During the last year 98 per cent of all criminal cases prosecuted by the office of United States Attorney James B. M. McNally resulted in victories for the Government, either by conviction after trial or by pleas of guilty, according to the annual report submitted to Mr. McNally yesterday by his chief assistant, John F. X. McGohey.

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- Reflecting favorable progress of the war the stock market here reopened today after the bank holiday with a firm tone. There was a fair volume of buying orders and transactions were slightly larger than those of last Tuesday.

ROME, Aug. 8 (AP) -- British troops, splashing through the rain, were wiping out the last islands of enemy resistance south of the Arno River around Florence today, while the bulk of the Allies' armies in Italy rested for the grand assault on the Gothic Line just ahead.

PEARL HARBOR, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The twenty-day campaign to re-conquer Guam, overrun by Japan in the first week of the war, today approached the inevitable climax of a suicidal "banzai" charge by several thousand Japanese survivors or a precedent-setting mass surrender.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 8 -- Marguerite Chapman has been named by Columbia for the feminine lead opposite Paul Muni in "Counter Attack," a film version of the Janet and Philip Stevenson play to be produced and directed by Zoltan Korda.

With reference to the story in THE NEW YORK TIMES of July 26, describing the belief of air cargo experts that a rate of from 5 to 10 cents a ton-mile would produce a profitable mass market for air freight, Col. Edgar S. Gorrell, president of the Air Transport Association, writes:

GOSHEN, N. Y., Aug. 8 -- On the eve of the trotting of tomorrow's Hambletonian Stake there was no change in public estimation of the chances of that sweet bay filly Yankee Maid. At the close of the first day's racing of the annual Grand Circuit meeting at Good Time Park today the sleek daughter of Volomite-Elizabeth, she by Peter the Great, was held at 4 to 5.

PEARL HARBOR, Aug. 8 -- Enemy resistance on Guam apparently is crumbling under the unrelenting pressure of American assault forces that advanced northward yesterday from three to six miles along the entire line.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 109:

Orderly channeling of shoe production now to meet easing and termination of wartime restrictions is recommended by the post-war planning committee of the National Boot and Shoe Manufacturers Association, it was learned yesterday. Following recommendations adopted by the committee and approved by the group's board of directors, the proposals have been forwarded to the various war agencies in Washington.

CHUNGKING, China, Wednesday, Aug. 9 -- A grim, dramatic message from within walled Hengyang left little doubt today that the city, after a heroic stand of more than six weeks, was completely in the hands of Japanese forces and that the way was open for the Japanese to drive down the rest of the Canton-Hankow railway to complete their control of a 1,000-mile band across China.

The editorial "Privilege of Asylum" in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 3 interested me greatly. I feel, however, that it did not place the recent decision of the Federal Council of Switzerland, with regard to the revision of the right of asylum in the proper historical perspective.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Upsets marked the first-round play today in the women's Western amateur golf championship, but three of the highly favored stars -- the defending champion, Miss Dorothy Germain; the medalist, Miss Sally Sessions, and Miss Phyllis Otto -- came through with crushing triumphs as the field was reduced to sixteen contestants.
MONTREAL, Aug. 8 -- Premier Adelard Godbout's Liberal Administration in Quebec Province was beaten in the provincial election held today.

No tourists of any nation ever made the rounds of Europe's art galleries and historical monuments with as much thoroughness as the Germans. After the first World War they could be seen in the Louvre in Paris or in the Uffizi in Florence, disciplined, attentive, giving each picture, each statue, each tapestry a properly measured attention.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 8 -- Out where the West begins, as baseball topography is measured, the Giants today began their battle to stay in the National League's first division with gratifying results. In the comparative quiet of Forbes Field they plastered Max Butcher and Xavier Rescigno with a fifteen-hit assault under which they buried the Pirates, 8 to 4.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- Liquidation developed early today on the Board of Trade and all deliveries of oats and rye and December barley sold at new seasonal low prices before short-covering appeared and caused a good rally. Wheat showed considerable resistance to pressure, due to buying on resting orders, and failed to go as low as yesterday.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- F.D. Cronin, New York regional administrator, War Food Administration, assured the New York State Food Merchants Association, in convention here, that while WFA's policy for disposing of surplus foods will be to get rid of Government stocks as fast as market conditions allow, and at fair prices, in no case will decision as to rate of disposal be made without consultation with the industry.

A new national, non-partisan organization called Americans United for World Organization has been formed by the consolidation of six existing organizations, and with the collaboration of eleven others, to fight for the establishment of a world organization with power to enforce peace and to oppose isolationist candidates for office.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Members of the Senate's special committee that is investigating the national defense program (the Truman Committee) began closed hearings today to inquire into the Army's plans for abandoning the Breakers Hotel at Palm Beach, Fla., which has been converted into a general hospital for the treatment of service men.

It will be a case of now or never, so far as the pennant hopes of the Yankees are concerned, when Joe McCarthy leads his charges against the Browns in the first of a four-game series at the Stadium today. The next four days loom as the most important of the campaign for the home forces, who realize how vital it is for them to cut into the margin now enjoyed by Luke Sewell's aggregation.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 8 -- Berlin now is faced with a grave new problem -- that of streams of Berliners returning from East Prussia, whither they were at one time evacuated out of range of Allied bombs. Now they are trekking back to get away from Russian bombs and the prospect of Russian shells.

The State Superintendent of Insurance has sold the two five-story apartment houses at 523-525 East Eighty-first Street to the Colgate Realty Corporation. Located on a plot 50 by 100 feet, the property is assessed at $39,000 and is reported to be fully rented at $7,500 a year.

However much the German officers' corps might be denounced for arrogance and lust of conquest, it still lived and fought according to a tradition which, with all its odious exaggerations, was based on the fundamental military virtues of discipline, honor and patriotism.

Three modern "Sis Hopkinses" captured coiffure honors yesterday in the pigtail contest conducted by the Children's Aid Society at its Lower West Side Center, 209 Sullivan Street. Little girls ranging in age from 20 months to 12 years paraded their pigtails in the out- door playground while the boys at the center sat on benches shouting typical bleacher comments.

Reporting the highest operating revenues for any quarterly period in its history, United Air Lines, Inc., announced yesterday that record utilization of equipment and abnormal wartime passenger-mail-express traffic were responsible for the results for the second quarter of the year.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- Mark Stuart of Winged Foot, playing in his first tournament of the year, won the Metropolitan Golf Association's one-day event with a competitive record score of 33, 31 -- 67 at the Siwanoy Country Club today.

ALGIERS, Aug. 8 -- Replying today to American and British criticisms of the press laws for France adopted in Algiers, Henri Bonnet, Commissioner for Information, said that the scheme for a news agency as well as for the revival of newspapers was purely temporary and designed to get the press started again.

Consumers' complaints about violations of price control and rationing rules are regularly "filed and forgotten" by the Bronx County War Price and Rationing Board, it was alleged in a statement presented yesterday to Daniel P. Woolley, regional administrator of the Office of Price Administration, by the Bronx Consumers Coordinating Council.

John Gough has purchased from Capt. Vincent Astor, USNR, the property at the northwest corner of Eighth Avenue and Forty-fifth Street which has been in the Astor family for more than 100 years. The improvement, on a plot 100 by 100.5 feet, comprises four four-story buildings containing seven stores and twenty-four apartments and is assessed at $515,000.

MONTREAL, Aug. 8 (U.P.) -- Provincial police were holding seventy-one whites and Negroes involved in sporadic election riots here today, which, according to police, resulted in the shooting of three men and the stabbing of a fourth. All three who were shot were white and suffered leg injuries.
The New York City Housing Authority yesterday awarded $1, 350,000 of temporary loan notes to the United States Trust Company on an 0.40 per cent basis. The obligations mature on March 8, 1945.

Complying with urgent requests from the War and Navy Departments, the USO-Camp Shows is in the process of sending overseas nine plays and seven musicals. In order to concentrate on the rush order the entertainment group has temporarily laid aside its other activities.

Corn is ripening in the fields of Pennsylvania and New Jersey, the Hudson River Valley and Long Island. The vegetable (really a cereal) is at its most delicious now when it comes to market from near by, for it has less chance of losing flavor than earlier in the season when it hails from distant points. Prices, too, are cheapest at this time of year, hovering in the vicinity of a nickel an ear.

Whatever the stocks of other Navy does not have an over-abundant supply of cotton textiles, underwear or hosiery, a survey of opinion in the trade revealed yesterday. In hosiery particularly, supplies of certain types are down to nothing, owing to the fact that socks in actual battle were used at a rate far in excess of widest estimates, trade spokesmen indicated.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 8 -- Again it was the Shillelah, the big stick of Erin, that held forth today in the second race of the Atlantic Coast Star Class sloop championship on Great South Bay. Skip Etchells took another contest, this time by thirty-eight seconds from Harold Halsted and his Chuckle V of the Moriches Bay fleet.

SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Less than 5,000 effective Japanese fighting men were reported left in India today and an Allied spokesman declared that the Japanese who invaded Manipur "have taken the biggest hiding they've had on any front."
A communique, as broadcast in English to North America from Chungking yesterday and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

AKRON, Aug. 8 -- Court records in two cases of rubber workers who have been sentenced to jail for beating fellow employes contain evidence not only that union restrictions on output have held down war production in the Akron tire factories but also have been accompanied by a campaign of terror to enforce them.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

Confidence that more civilian goods will be available before the end of the year as military successes stimulate reconversion was expressed yesterday by resident buyers here. At the moment, the situation with respect to metal and other items which have been off the market for some time shows practically no change, with only a bare trickle of goods becoming available in accordance with changes in War Production Board orders.

ROME, Aug. 8 (U.P.) -- Although the Germans have been pushed back to the Arno on three sides and are being battered by relentless attacks from the fourth, it was believed that they would be able to withdraw their defending forces safely across the river when the exposed position became untenable.

LONDON, Aug. 8 (U.P.) -- Strong elements of three Polish divisions, numbering more than 20,000 fighters, are holding dominating strategic points in Warsaw in the face of heavy German counter-attacks and frequent aerial bombardment, Polish headquarters here said today on the basis of reports credited to patriot forces in the embattled city.

ON THE BRITISH FRONT, in France, Aug. 8 (AP) -- A newly captured German intelligence officer asserted today that Heinrich Himmler had been assassinated and that Reich Marshal Hermann Goering was wounded in a new outbreak against the Nazi hierarchy.

Gen. Kuniaki Koiso, Japanese Premier, was quoted by Domei, Japanese news agency, as having told the people of Japan yesterday that Allied gains in the Marianas and in the New Guinea area and their apparent intention "to strike at our homeland in a single blow" had confronted the empire with "national difficulties of unprecedented seriousness."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Following are the texts of a State Department Memorandum and the Anglo-American agreement on Petroleum:

An unusual arbitrage situation in the stock of the Certain-teed Products Corporation last month sent the short interest in that concern's common shares from 1,755 to 49,405 shares, accounting for more than the 39,671-share change in aggregate short interest on the New York Stock Exchange.

ABSECON, N.J., Aug. 8 -- Asserting that he believed Congress would take prompt action on any new concept for post-war taxes, John M. Hancock, co-author of the Baruch-Hancock report, today urged business men to foster in Congress a return to former corporate tax rates.
GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Wednesday, Aug. 9 (AP) -- A communique:

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Morris L. Ernst, New York attorney, declared at the American Newspaper Guild convention today that newspaper practices "have induced a terrible cynicism" among the reading public and that "thirty men control the pipelines to the minds of the nation."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Arrangements were made at the recent meeting of shipping representatives of the United Nations in London to insure the continued availability of their tonnage resources for all purposes of the United Nations in the changed circumstances that are looked for in the later phases of the war, the State Department announced tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 8 -- Mayor Bernard Samuel and James H. Malone, Director of Public Safety, will be among the first witnesses called upon to testify tomorrow when the Federal grand jury opens its investigation of the Philadelphia Transportation Company strike, it was announced today by Henry A. Schweinhaut, special assistant to the United States Attorney General, who will be in charge of the investigation.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Communique 122:

J. Carlton Ward Jr., president of the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation, announces in the annual report for 1943, to be released today, that sales set a new high record of $102,450,364, representing a rise of 118 per cent above the 1942 sales of $47,080,224 and 642 per cent over the 1941 volume.

Supreme Court Justice Samuel Null yesterday vacated the temporary stay granted the Copacabana night club, 10 East Sixtieth Street, to prevent the city from attaching its assets in connection with tax levies totaling $37,371.

Sixty-seven new cases of poliomyelitis were reported to the City Health Department during the week ending Friday, compared to fifty cases the week before. Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins announced yesterday. One death resulted from the disease against five the week before.

WITH THE EXPEDITIONARY FORCE TO THE MARIANAS, June 10 (Delayed) -- A recorded concert played over a gravel-throated loudspeaker would ordinarily create little stir among the sweating soldiers idling on the forecastle of a crowded transport in a humid Pacific latitude, but here this afternoon the first number brought forth a cheer the like of which was never heard before in this part of the world. The tune was "Garry Owen."

TRENTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- New Jersey's Republican leaders are going "all out" in their efforts to elect Governor Dewey of New York and Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio as the nation's leaders, Gov. Walter E. Edge and Lloyd B. Marsh, State Republican chairman, said today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- A flexible, life-like plastic tinted to blend exactly with any skin pigmentation, has been developed by Dr. Stanley D. Tylman, University of Illinois Dental College professor, as an immediate replacement for missing noses, ears, fingers and other parts of the human body, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- An agreement to assure the orderly development of petroleum resources for international trade and to provide the basis for a multilateral world-wide oil accord in the post-war era was entered into by the United States and the Government of the United Kingdom and Northern Ireland today after long negotiations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- There is full agreement between top officials of the Army and the War Production Board on estimates of military supplies, Maj. Gen. Lucius D. Clay said today in reference to a statistical report whose withdrawal led two members of the WPB staff to submit resignations.

WITH CANADIAN FORCES, South of Caen, Aug. 8 -- The Canadian sector suddenly blazed with volcanic fury today as the tough Dominion fighting men, with British troops, launched another attempt to break up the Germans' strong concentrations of armor south of Caen.

Argentina is persistently pursuing her efforts to woo her South American neighbors from the cause of hemisphere solidarity, but she is not succeeding. Colombia and Venezuela have made public in Bogota the text of a joint statement reaffirming their own positions and urging Argentina to abandon her plea of special interests.

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- The final phase of the Battle of the Atlantic is being fought tonight on the land approaches to the Germans' great U-boat lairs on the Breton peninsula -- at St. Nazaire, Brest and Lorient, where Adolf Hitler cradled the raiders that almost cut the Allies' Atlantic lifelines in 1942 and 1943.

LONDON, Wednesday, Aug. 9 -- The Germans are launching desperate counter-attacks along virtually all of the 1,000-mile Eastern Front, but are being "bled white," Moscow reported today as it appeared that the Nazis had managed to stem the Red Army advance by drawing heavily on their dwindling central reserves.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- Samuel J. Graham of Greenwich Country Club recorded 39, 38 -- 77 over Winged Foot's West Course this afternoon to win the seventeenth annual senior championship of the Metropolitan Golf Association by a stroke.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Labor and management in the tire industry, guided by the Government, will undertake through a series of conferences this week to put into effect two measures to increase individual productivity and step up output of critically needed heavy truck and bus tires, the War Production Board said today.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 8 (AP) -- Gov. Homer M. Adkins conceded defeat tonight as returns showed him trailing Representative J.W. Fulbright in the run-off race for the Democratic Senatorial nomination to succeed Senator Hattie W. Caraway.

Rumors of more attacks on Nazi figures and denials of some of the recent rumors about the low-price motor shares checked enthusiasm yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange and an early price bulge was deflated. The close was irregularly lower than Monday's final prices.

Thomas J. Curran, who was picked by the Republicans on Tuesday as their candidate for United States Senator, will stump the State on behalf of himself and the Dewey-Bricker ticket, starting soon after Labor Day, it was disclosed yesterday as Mr. Curran, Edwin F. Jaeckle and other Republican leaders returned from Albany.

The 1,065 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $101,559,186,057 par value as of July 31, had a total market value of $102,284,657,208, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday. As of June 30, there were 1,057 issues, aggregating $95,728,780,260 par value which had a total market value of $96,235,324,054.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Aug. 10 -- Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk of the Polish Government in Exile announced early today that he was returning to London to lay before his Cabinet definite proposals for a new Polish Government and told reporters he had been satisfied during his stay here that "the Russian Government wants full unity among all the Polish people except such Poles as are fascist-minded."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The War Production Board, in an effort to increase production of much needed automobile replacement parts, liberalized restrictions today on their manufacture with the result that makers of parts may use as much of their manpower and machine capacity for producing parts not being used to fill war orders.

With the aid of radar and other technical devices and improvements developed in the war, airlines operating from Idlewild Airport expect to maintain their schedules with railroad precision in fog, rain, snow or wind, it was learned yesterday as Mayor La Guardia made public the revolutionary design for the runways of the huge field under construction on Jamaica Bay.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Thursday, Aug. 10 -- American tanks have crashed into Le Mans and beyond in their drive toward Paris. The German radio reported last night that the fast motorized forces were only eighty-seven miles from the capital, though the latest dispatch from the American front put the distance at approximately 100 miles.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- At Red Cross chapters throughout the country and also in the August issue of The Prisoners of War Bulletin, relatives of American airmen interned in two German prison compounds will have opportunity to read the first two "home-front editions" of prison camp newspapers received in this country.
GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 9 -- Surrounded by State troopers with locked arms, Yankee Maid was crowned champion 3-year-old trotter of 1944 at Good Time Park today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 9 -- Even German sources admit that Parisians' hatred of the "occupant" has grown beyond bounds, but they use the word in such a way as to imply that any "occupant" would be so hated. This is not true.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 9 -- Confronted with a chance to strengthen their hold on fourth place tonight at Forbes Field, the Giants could not raise a decisive assault against the left-handed shoots of the veteran Fritz Ostermueller, and bowed to the Pirates before a gathering of 12,683.
Xavier Cugat, orchestra leader, has leased a garden house at 122 East Thirtieth Street through Rose Fabricant, broker.

Out in the great open spaces of Wyoming, on the lone prairie where a philosopher's mind has elbow-room, the sergeant editor of The Fort Warren Sentinel has been pondering a grave subject, namely, the absence of navy bean soup from the Army menu. "There are few dishes with the robust, bourgeois appeal of navy bean soup," he writes.
The operational bulletin, as broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 9 -- Reports from Spain said tonight that the entire families of the eight high German officers hanged for complicity in the bombing attack on Adolf Hitler's life were executed Tuesday.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 9 (AP) -- The seizure of financial reports and contributor lists from the State Republican League of Union City, N.J., and records of The Hudson News, Union City publication, for examination by the Senate Campaign Expenditures Investigating Committee, was announced today by Harold Buckles, chief of the committee's four-man staff of investigators working in New Jersey.

A 17-month-old girl with "severe malnutrition," for whom a blood transfusion was ordered, was being cared for yesterday at the New York Foundling Hospital in Manhattan, and her 6-year-old brother was sheltered at the Brooklyn Children's Society, while their parents, who returned separately to their home in pre-dawn hours, were arrested and charged with willful neglect of their children.

An orchestra in which all the players are nuns played a varied concert yesterday at the Collins Auditorium, Fordham University. The Rev. John W. Ziemak, director of music at Cardinal Hayes High School, the Bronx, lifted his baton, and his thirteen pupils in the special music course, summer session, School of Education, offered an hour and a half of chamber music, concert selections and jazz.
Felicitations fly back and forth between Berlin and Tokyo, and between each of those capitals and the seat of Italian Fascist power, wherever that portable seat happens to be at the moment.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The Navy reported today that it was placing on inactive duty and returning to the rubber industry "a number of rubber workers skilled in the building of tires."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Factional lines became taut today in the Senate as hours of debate on reconversion legislation brought adherents of the pending George Bill and of the rival Murray-Truman-Kilgore measure nearer to the ballot test on unemployment compensation -- the principal and practically the only remaining point of divergence.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Boston's sixth-place Braves pounded two Cincinnati hurlers for twelve hits today and, bunching six runs in the third, won handily from the runner-up Reds, 9 -- 6.

Robert E. Hannegan, Democratic National chairman, opened national campaign headquarters yesterday at the Biltmore Hotel. Asserting that all reports he received indicated that President Roosevelt would be returned to the White House for a fourth term, he predicted that Governor Dewey would receive no more votes than former President Herbert Hoover did in 1932 when Mr. Roosevelt was chosen for his first term.

"Dragon Seed" is breaking box-office records at the huge Radio City Music Hall with a three week gross of more than $375,000, it was reported yesterday by G.S. Eyssell, managing director of the 6,200-seat house. The M-G-M production of the Pearl Buck novel on China, in which Katharine Hepburn is starred, will enter its fourth week today.

MONTREAL, Aug. 9 (AP) -- French Canada, comprising almost a third of the Dominion, had placed before the rest of the country today a firm announcement of its annoyance at war-time regulations of Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King's Liberal regime in the Federal capital at Ottawa.

It is gratifying to learn that the United States and Great Britain have reached an agreement to assure the orderly development of petroleum resources in international trade. Their intention is to supplant this with a multilateral world-wide oil agreement "as soon as practicable." The agreement must be hailed as a significant step forward in international collaboration.
"Pedal Pushers" in plaids, black flannel for the campus and navy denim jumpers were featured in the show presented yesterday in the College Shop at Altman's.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- William H. Davis, chairman of the National War Labor Board, today strongly denounced the strike of musicians at radio station KSTP, Minneapolis, which he said violated the normal process of handling such situation. He gave this view when the strike case was put to the NWLB for hearing here.

Plans for a fourteen-story and penthouse building to contain stores and apartments at 657 Madison Avenue, northeast corner of Sixtieth Street, were filed with the Department of Housing and Buildings yesterday by Sylvan Bien, architect, for Louis Katz, owner, who acquired the vacant plot last fall from the State Insurance Department.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- A demand for shorter hours and part-time jobs for mothers working for the Government so they may pass more time with their children was announced today by the United Federal Workers of America on its first Working Mothers Conference.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Evidence believed to show heavy inventories of war equipment held by the Army and heretofore withheld from both public and official view will be presented to the Joint Chiefs of Staff for the purpose of determining whether a reduction in some Army requirements is desirable, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, disclosed today.

A net profit of $7,959,891 for the six months ended on June 30 was reported yesterday by the Ohio Oil Company in a statement issued to stockholders by O.D. Donnell, president. The profit is equal to $1,21 a common share and compares with $6,432,526, or 97 cents a share in the first half of 1943.

A former United States Government official who recently returned from England has a sidelight on the arrival of Rudolf Hess, former No. 2 Nazi, in Scotland in 1941. Prime Minister Churchill was visiting a friend in the country near London, according to the account, and, after an excellent dinner, while the party was viewing a motion picture, a messenger whispered in the ear of his host.

Sgt. Joseph Flink, a Polish refugee from Berlin who joined the United States Army fourteen months ago, said yesterday that he never dreamed that his parents, interned in Italy, would cross the Atlantic before he went overseas to help liberate them, but that is exactly what happened.

Reporting on operations of the United Aircraft Corporation in the first half of 1944, F.B. Rentschler, chairman, informed stockholders in his statement for publication today that shipments of aircraft, engines and propellers were 26 per cent larger than in the same period of 1943, but yielded only 4 per cent more net income.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Emphatic objections by defense attorneys to continued presentation to the jury of documents and letters seized at the home and office of William Dudley Pelley, defendant in the mass sedition trial, marked the session today. They were offered as evidence to link the defendants in a conspiracy and raised a religious issue.

Field Marshal Baron Carl Gustav Mannerheim, President of Finland, delegated some of his powers yesterday to Premier Anders Werner Hackzell, according to a Finnish broadcast that said that Mr. Hackzell had been authorized to issue certain decrees on behalf of President Mannerheim.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Uncorking a sample of her famous pressure shooting, the defending champion, Miss Dorothy Germain of Philadelphia, rallied to win six consecutive holes today for a 5-and-3 victory over Miss Jean Hopkins of Cleveland and gain the quarter-final round of the women's Western amateur golf tournament along with such other favorites as the medalist, Miss Sally Sessions, and the Misses Phyllis Otto and Betty Jean Rucker.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Lefty Al Smith pitched and batted the Indians to a 4-3 victory over the Athletics tonight, ending a six-game losing streak for the Tribe. Bobo Newsom, pitching for Philadelphia, allowed twelve hits while Smith was scattering eight.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 9 -Attorney General Walter D. Van Riper was excluded by the Hudson County grand jury today from its opening session when it began an investigation of charges that attempts had been made to "pack" jury lists from political sources. The State Attorney General is serving as acting Hudson County Prosecutor.

Lilies, which all who saw them yesterday agreed are the finest ever exhibited in this city, offered strong competition to gladioluses, the featured flowers of the Midsummer Show sponsored by the Horticultural Society of New York at its headquarters, 598 Madison Avenue, in cooperation with the Eastern New York Gladiolus Society.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 9 -- There now exists an understanding in principle between Bulgaria and the Soviet Union regarding Bulgaria's post-war status and the policy she is to pursue until the end of the war, according to authorities here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Even as amended by the Senate Committee on Military Affairs, the Murray-Kilgore bill for the reconversion of industry is a lazy man's dream, or a collectivist's, or the vision of one of those union labor politicians who thinks organized workers should be the favored class and that the size of the national debt is nothing "because we owe it to ourselves."

As a channel through which seven organizations will seek to locate persons who have been displaced by war whose whereabouts are unknown, the Central Location Index, Inc., has been established in this city, it was announced yesterday by Moses A. Leavitt, president of the agency.

Independent nominating petitions for Lieut. Robert C. Palmer, USNR, were placed in circulation yesterday in the Eighteenth Congressional District, where he was defeated for the Republican nomination by Representative Vito Marcantonio in the primaries, William A. Meyerhoff, treasurer of the Palmer campaign committee, announced last night.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 9 -- A Federal grand jury opening today an investigation of the six-day Philadelphia Transportation Company strike was charged by Judge George A. Welsh in Federal District Court to "uncover the hidden motives" behind the walkout, but was reminded that with a national election in the offing it should be doubly certain of its charges.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 9 -- Greek guerrilla units, presumably belonging to the leftist Elas organization, are cooperating with Marshal Tito's Yugoslav National Liberation Army, which has entered Greek Macedonia, and the two patriotic organizations have captured Edessa in Greek Macedonia, according to the Free Yugoslav radio.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- American trucks and other rolling equipment from this country have been largely responsible for the success of the great Soviet offensive on the Eastern Front, Maj. Gen. John R. Deane, chief of the United States military mission to Moscow, said today. The 48-year-old general spent five days at the front just before departing for Washington.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 9 -- With a union estimate that 20,000 workers had left their jobs, the three-day-old strike of employes of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation plants in the area spread today to the company's Wood-Ridge plant, engaged in building motors for B-29 bombers.

ROME, Aug. 9 -- A decision by Italian Communists and Socialists to cooperate was announced today. Political circles here regard it as marking the beginning of the second phase of Italy's painful awakening from the long hypnosis of Fascism.

A committee of five representing major branches of the women's apparel industry was appointed yesterday to begin work on a model order blank and confirmation form at a meeting of the Conference of Apparel Credit Men at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
ROME, Aug. 9 (AP) -- A communique:

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 -- Playing in an unaccustomed, sparkling manner, the Dodgers put another smudge on the ambitions of the Cubs by beating them, 5 -- 2, today in the first of a four-game series at Wrigley Field. The victory lifted Brooklyn out of the National League cellar into seventh place and the Phillies made it stick by losing a night game.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Proposed legislation regulating the disposal of Government-owned wartime surpluses will be ready for presentation to the House Monday, Representative Carter Manasco, Democrat of Alabama, predicted tonight.

ALBANY, Aug. 9 -- Governor Walter E. Edge of New Jersey, following a conference with Gov. Thomas E. Dewey issued a statement today quoting the Republican Presidential nominee as being determined that "any future threat to the peace of the world will be promptly stamped out by international action."

AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 9 -- Charges that workers' restrictions on output are responsible for a substantial part in the lag in production of heavy tires for large trucks, other vehicles and artillery which has endangered the success of the Allied invasion of Europe have been officially confirmed by an eight-week manpower utilization survey just completed by the War Manpower Commission in plants of Akron's four largest tire companies, it was learned today.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 9 (U.P.) -- Fighting in the south Hunan region around Hengyang, which the Japanese yesterday claimed to have captured after a forty-four-day siege, blazed to new intensity today as Chinese forces rushed efforts to prevent the launching of a general Japanese offensive southward from the strategic junction along the railway route to Canton.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Accusing the Fair Employment Practices Committee and especially its chairman, Malcolm Ross, with having precipitated the Philadelphia transit strike, Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia declared in the Senate today that President Roosevelt should disband the agency.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Aug. 9 -- A formal statement by Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell released at headquarters today revealed that Brig. Gen. Frank D. Merrill, former commander of the noted Marauder detachment in Burma, has been appointed head of the liaison group for the China-Burma-India theatre here.

ANNUALLY at this time of the year members of the Westchester Country Club who call to make a room reservation are informed that the place is booked so solid that it would be a good trick for even one of the Four Marx Brothers to find space. That means just one thing. The swank of the tennis world have marched on Rye for the Eastern grass-court championships, and the season is in the homestretch.

SPRING MOUNT, Pa., Aug. 9 -Pfc. Alton W. Knappenberger, the 20-year-old 120-pound, 5-foot-4-inch country boy who blasted sixty Nazis to their doom, held off two attacking German infantry companies and won the Congressional Medal of Honor, arrived on an unannounced furlongh last night and so surprised his mother and stepfather, Harvey Seibert, that Mrs. Seibert burst into tears.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The New York Central Railroad filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission an application for permission to receive bids on $15,500,000 of equipment trust cer tificates to cover 75 per cent of the cost of freight cars and locomotives totaling about $21,067,000. The balance of the purchase price would be paid in cash.

Declaring that an exchange of views between British and American shipping men would accomplish much toward eliminating dangerous post-war struggles for control of international shipping trade, Basil Harris, president of the United States Lines, yesterday invited British shipping leaders to confer on maritime problems that must be faced in the post-war era.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The loss of 390,000 tons of anthracite coal which has resulted from work stoppages since May 20 in a number of mines in Pennsylvania has been "a serious blow to our nation's welfare at a time when every citizen should be doing his utmost to bring the war to a quick conclusion," Secretary Ickes, as Solid Fuels Administrator, declared today.

A suit for treble damages, based on alleged rent overcharges, was filed yesterday in the Federal District Court in Brooklyn by the Office of Price Administration against a corporation owning and operating fifty one-family homes, occupied chiefly by war workers, in Oyster Bay, L.I.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The film "Wilson," dramatizing the career of former President Wilson, has been banned by the Army for distribution to troops, as has "Heavenly Days," starring Fibber McGee and Molly.

ALBANY, Aug. 9 -- Located in barns, deserted shacks, unused camp buildings and in a camp clinic nurseries for children of migrant farm laborers in New York State have been set up in seventeen labor settlements up-State.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Tying a major league record of winning 73 out of 100 games, the Cardinals tonight eked out a 4-2 victory over the Phillies. Frank Chance's Cubs of 1907 achieved the same record. St. Louis now leads the National League by 17 1/2 games.

The first three days of the drive to remind motorists to buy and display the $5 Federal automobile use tax stamp have resulted in summonses being handed to 5,340 drivers in Kings, Queens, Nassau and Suffolk Counties and Staten Island, it was announced yesterday.

ROME, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The city of Florence, tightly locked in a deadly vise formed by the British and German armies, was reported to be facing a series of food and water shortages and beset by looting and outbursts of civil strife today.

WITH CANADIAN FORCES, At Cintheaux, Aug. 9 -- How two companies of Canadian infantrymen held a hill a short distance south of Bretteville-le-Rabet until reinforcements of tanks and more infantry arrived was told today.

If Fire Warden were a human instead of an equine, many a house would burn down for lack of getting there on time, but yesterday at Belmont Park was not all occasion for the unpredictable 5-year-old son of Burning Blaze. In fourteen races this season Fire Warden has won three, but in all fourteen he started like a house afire, only to peter out-in most as if some one had cut the hose.

Front-line action photographs by Robert Capa, Life photographer, will illustrate "Invasion? the story of the Normandy battle, by Charles Wertenbaker, Life and Time correspondent, which Appleton-Century will publish in September.

ABSECON, N.J., Aug. 9 -- The defeat of Germany will release between 3,000,000 and 4,500,000 workers from the munition industries and wartime Government employment and pose an unemployment problem which industry and business must prepare to cope with, A. Ford Hinrichs, Acting Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, Department of Labor, declared here today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 9 -- Warner Brothers has announced plans for a sequel to "Janie," to be made under the title "Janie Meets the Marines." Joyce Reynolds again will be starred. Josephine Bentham, one of the authors of the play from which the picture was adapted, and Gertrude Keck have been signed in the East to write the screen play.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 9 -- The Star Class sloops of the Atlantic Coast fleets sailed the third race today for their year's championship and the winner for the third straight time in the series was Skip Etchells' Shillelah, one of the representatives of the Western Long Island Sound fleet.

The New York Stock Exchange made yesterday an unusual ruling with respect to the preferred stock of the Chicago North Western Railway. While books for the payment of a $15 dividend on that stock will close on Aug. 11, the Exchange ruled that the shares will not sell ex dividend until Sept. 1, which is the payable date for the dividend.
ROME, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Antoine de St. Exupery, 44 years of age, French pilot and author, is missing after a mission over southern France, an official announcement said today.

Five hundred delegates representing affiliates of the United Steel Workers Association, the United Automobile Workers and the United Radio and Machine Workers in the New York and New Jersey area, all affiliates of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, at a conference in the Hotel New Yorker last night called upon the National War Labor Board to grant the applications of these unions for a 17-cent adjustment in basic wage rates and a guaranteed annual wage.

Supreme Court Justice Benjamin F. Schreiber dismissed yesterday a taxpayer's suit brought by the Citizens Budget Commission that charged Mayor La Guardia and the Board of Estimate with making an illegal appropriation of $3,500,000 in the 1944-45 budget.

Among the Chinese it must now be such. QUEBEC, Aug. 9 (Canadian Press) -- The Union Nationale party, headed by Maurice Duplessis, Premier from 1936 to 1939, won an over-all majority of one in the ninety-one-seat Quebec Legislative Assembly in yesterday's Provincial election, but the result was so indecisive that general comment predicted another general election shortly.
DETROIT, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Federal conciliation agencies and union officials moved tonight to end two major strikes which have made more than 10,000 war workers idle in the Detroit area.

Under the Taft amendment to the Soldier Voting Law service men and women are in the same position as jurors, with a single exception.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 -- Dry and hot weather over the Corn Belt, with a lack of rain in States east of the Mississippi River where the outlook is now reported as unfavorable, led today to buying of oats, rye and barley futures on the Board of Trade.

A syndicate of investors represented by Michael Rozental, broker, has purchased from the Radnib Realty Corporation the nine-story apartment building containing fifty-four suites at 203 West Eighty-first Street for cash over a mortgage of $284,465. Schiff, Dorfman, Stein Brof were the attorneys for the seller.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 9 (AP) -Delegates to the American Newspaper Guild (CIO) convention endorsed today the candidacies of President Roosevelt for a fourth term and of Senator Truman for Vice President.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- More than 500 Nazi submarines have been sunk since the war began, President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill announced tonight.

Consolidated net income of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation and subsidiaries for the first six months of this year, after operating expenses, taxes and special reservation charges, was $2,849,571, the corporation announced yesterday.

OTTAWA, Aug. 9 (Canadian Press) -- With the exception of wheat, the principal Canadian crops showed during July some deterioration from the outlook during June, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today. Wheat conditions in the Prairie Provinces, based on weather factors, showed improvement in Manitoba and Alberta but only a slight gain in Saskatchewan.

Gabriel Beneth, 48 years old, former Army captain, of 155-01 Ninetieth Avenue, Jamaica, Queens, was arrested by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents yesterday charged with accepting a bribe of $300 from an official of a New Rochelle, N.Y., war plant for his efforts in getting strategic machine tools used in the manufacture of war materials, E.E. Conroy, special agent in charge of the FBI, announced.

LONDON, Thursday, Aug. 10 -- Slowed but not stopped by desperate German counter-attacks all along the Eastern Front, powerful Russian armies yesterday ground out nine to twelve mile gains in the battle of Latvia, renewed the offensive northeast of Warsaw and climbed higher into the Carpathians toward Czechoslovakia.

LONDON, Aug. 9 -- German troops in Bulgaria are evacuating Varna and Burgas on the Black Sea and German control of the Turkish-Bulgarian frontier has ceased, according to information that has reached London from reliable Bulgarian sources.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 9 -Characterizing President Roosevelt as "a sort of super-duper, highly cultured political boss," Representative Clare Booth Luce said tonight that his re-election this autumn might pave the way for the seizure of power four years from now by "some budding dictator nutured in his own corrupted party."

Distributors at all levels cannot look for any sizable offerings of surplus textile lines either now or in the event the war in Europe comes to a sudden end, Lee Fleming, director of the textile and women's apparel section, Surplus Consumer Commodities Division, Treasury Department, said yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 9 -- Enterprising Paris black marketers have cornered and already sold out all available window seats along the expected route of the Allies' triumphal march through the city, it was reported today.

LONDON, Aug. 9 (U.P.) -- Polish paratroops and airmen in Britain today requested permission to fly to Warsaw to aid their besieged compatriots as a communique from the Polish capital, released by Polish headquarters here, said the Germans had launched strong counter-attacks backed by heavy artillery against the underground forces of General Bor.

LONDON, Aug. 9 -- The Sudeten German Social Democratic party in London has been warned by its chairman that plans are being prepared for the post-war compulsory transfer of 10,000,000 Germans from East Prussia, Danzig, Silesia and Czechoslovakia to Germany and his statement was confirmed today in official Polish and Czechoslovak circles here.

A deal is virtually consummated, according to reliable sources, whereby Metro will acquire the film rights to "Soldier's Wife" and, in addition, assist in financing William Brown Meloney's stage production of the Rose Franken play, which went into rehearsal yesterday under the author's direction.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday at about the best levels of the day and 7 to 10 points net higher. Fluctuations were narrow and trading was mostly between professionals and trade houses.

W.S.S. Rodgers, chairman of the Texas Company, said yesterday that in his opinion the Anglo- American agreement on petroleum production and distribution was constructive and that, depending upon the spirit in which it was interpreted by the two Governments, it should be helpful to the petroleum industry of the United States and foreign countries.

LONDON, Aug. 9 -- About 750 Liberators and Flying Fortresses of the United States Eighth Air Force, escorted by equal number of Thunderbolt, Mustang and Lightning fighters, struck in southwestern Germany today, smashing war plant and rail targets at Stuttgart and the freight yards at Saarbruecken.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 9 -- The Government issued a decree tonight declaring a general journalistic amnesty affecting all newspapers that in the past felt the weight of the present Government's displeasure.

LONDON, Aug. 9 (U.P.) -- French Forces of the Interior, cooperating with Americans swarming over Brittany, have taken the towns of Quimper and Morlaix in Finisterre Department, authoritative French quarters said today. Dispatches from Spain said French Patriots had seized control of Bordeaux.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- A decision in the growing Midwest truck strike, possibly by President Roosevelt, may be handed down within the next forty-eight hours, a high Government personage said tonight.

BOSTON, Aug. 9 -- With the two leaders, Samuel Reshevsky of Brooklyn and Bob Steinmeyer of St. Louis, playing to an adjournment after 49 moves, Edward S. Jackson Jr. of Short Hills, N.J., and Anthony E. Santasiere of the Bronx both advanced in the open championship of the United States Chess Federation at the Boston City Club today.

Crude oil production in the United States last week again established a new peak, according to the American Petroleum Institute. For that period production averaged 4,650,650 barrels daily, an increase of 42,200 over the 4,608,450 in the previous week.

Although trading eased in the afternoon, prices on the New York Stock Exchange staged yesterday a moderate rally in the final hour and the closing level was irregularly above Tuesday's close. Pressure on the low-price motors continued and modest demand appeared for the shares of utilities, construction and realty holding companies, mostly of the low-price category.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 9 -- With nine of the first ten ranking women players of the country and two of leaders among the men included in the field, the Eastern turf court tennis championships started to- day at the Westchester Country Club.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 -- Charging the United States Department of Agriculture with inefficiency in its meat grading system and accusing many of its graders of dressed meats with upgrading, members of the National Association of Retail Meat Dealers announced today that they were taking a stand against improper grading of dressed meats in order to protect the retail meat dealer and the consumer.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Hunters will have a longer open season on ducks in the fall and more ammunition to shoot them with.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The Committee on Education of the House of Representatives will make a three-month study of the effect of the war on colleges and universities, it was announced yesterday by Representative Graham A. Barden of North Carolina, chairman.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Probability of a vote tomorrow on the George and the Murray-Kilgore demobilization and post-war reconversion bills was forecast as the Senate recessed today, with Senator Barkley, majority leader, calling for limitation of debate and an earlier schedule to achieve that end.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Aug. 10 -- The Japanese have apparently abandoned their remaining bases east of what Gen. Douglas MacArthur has called the Philippines-Halmahera line, to stand, fall or starve without the benefit of important air support and even the inner area is showing extreme reluctance to gamble their fighters in an attempt to block the almost daily attacks from American heavy and medium bombers.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Department store sales of the week ended Aug. 5 were 4 per cent above sales of the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Miss Mary Beard, for the last six years director of the American Red Cross Nursing Service and responsible for the recruitment under which 50,000 American nurses have been added to the Army and Navy Nurse Corps, has resigned for reasons of health, the Red Cross announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- During the week ended Aug. 9 member bank reserve balances decreased $74,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Reductions in member bank reserves arose from increases of $176,000,000 in money in circulation, $226,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks and $22,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts, and a decrease of $4,000,000 in Treasury currency, offset in part by an increase of $355,000,000 in reserve bank credit.
