LONDON, Aug. 10 -- Pessimism on the part of the Poles in London on the possibility of reaching a satisfactory agreement on Russo-Polish relations was apparent today, though official silence was being maintained on what some Poles here had no hesitation in describing as a "breakdown" in the Moscow negotiations.

A report that Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse have added "Wings of the Morning" (a play dealing with B-26 operations, by Lieuts. Robert C. Cooke and Benjamin McCartney) to their holdings was confirmed yesterday in Hollywood by Mr. Lindsay.

ABSECON, N.J., Aug. 10 -- In an effort to determine the contribution retailing can make to a successful reconversion of the nation's economy to a peace-time basis, the post-war planning committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association announced today that it will undertake a canvass of its members and other retailers on their merchandise, material and personnel needs.
Victory gardeners are having a tough time in New York City these days, and two of them were in court yesterday.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 10 -After her wind-eating performances for three days, during which she had defeated in straight races all the other crack Star Class sloops out on Great South Bay in their Atlantic Coast championship, Skip Etchells' Shillelah of the Western Long Island Sound fleet proved today that she was a "ghoster" as well.

LONDON, Aug. 10 -- The stock markets here today were cheerful in tone, but movements were irregular. British Celanese advanced at the start but finished near yesterday's closing prices, while Courtaulds declined further.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 10 -Mayor Bernard Samuel and James H. Malone, Director of Public Safety, headed a list of officials who told the Federal grand jury today what they knew of the strike which paralyzed the Philadelphia Transportation Company system.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 -- There were strange doings in Wrigley Field today and out of the melange of oddities the Dodgers emerged with their second straight triumph over the Cubs, 6 -- 4. The Brooks had to go into the tenth inning, though, and there were several times when a different result appeared likely.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- United States exports of merchandise in June were valued at $1,271,000,000, according to the figures released today by the Bureau of the Census. The June total, the second highest monthly total in the nation's history, represents a decrease of 10 per cent below the record May figure of $1,419,000,000, and an increase of 27 per cent above the June, 1943, total of $1,002,000,000.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 10 -- Six seats in the rear of the Earle Theatre, crowded at the time by 1,800 patrons, burst into flames this afternoon after they had been soaked with an inflammable liquid.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 10 -- The RCA Victor division of the Radio Corporation of America today announced a broad program for reemployment of approximately 6,000 of its former employes now serving in the armed services. Forrest H. Kirkpatrick, personnel administrative director of the company, stated that the plan includes beneficial arrangements that go well beyond the Federal laws enacted to protect the re-employment status of those in the armed forces.

HONOLULU, July 29 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- President Roosevelt talked informally a number of times during his stay in Hawaii, speaking to thousands of Navy yard workers on one occasion and on others to only two or three wounded men in a hospital.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The War Production Board announced today that it will grant exemptions from restrictions of the textile conservation order M-328 in certain instances where manufacturers of textiles or related articles undergo abrupt contract termination proceedings or cutbacks in their military output.

Earnings of Paramount Pictures, Inc., for the second quarter ended on July 1 are estimated at $4,081,000 after all charges, including provision for taxes, according to the report announced yesterday. The earnings represent $1.09 a share on the 3,752,136 shares of common stock outstanding and compare with $3,827,000, or $1.02 a share, for the quarter ended on July 3, 1943.
GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Friday, Aug. 11--Allied aircraft have bombed Japanese airdromes at Davao, on Mindanao Island in the southern Philippines, headquarters announced today.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Aug. 0 (AP) -- Taungni, a Japanese strong point ten miles southwest of Mogaung on the Myitkyina-Mandalay railway, has fallen to Allied troops pressing their moonsoon campaign to throw the Japanese out of northern Burma.
" Cry of the Werewolf," starring Nina Foch, Stephen Crane and Osa Massen, opens today at the Rialto. The mystery was directed by Henry Levin and produced by Wallace MacDonald for Columbia.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 10 (U.P.) -- The Chinese High Command today confirmed the fall of Hengyang, strategic Hunan Province rail junction town, but Chinese and American air men, intensifying their slashing attacks against the enemy there, have pinned the Japanese forces down and denied them the opportunity to exploit their success, a communique from Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters reported.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- A bipartisan bill providing for civilian rather than military control over the decision as to what property or supplies acquired by the Government during the war shall be declared surplus was offered to the Senate today.

LONDON, Aug. 10 -- Some of the robot bombs falling in London and southern England during the past few days have carried small incendiary bombs in addition to the usual ton of high explosive, it was announced tonight. These incendiaries, sometimes twenty in number, are scattered by the force of the explosion on impact, but so far no fires of any importance have been caused by them.

ATLANTA, Aug. 10 -- John B. Wilson, Secretary of State, designated today as the regular Republican organization in Georgia the "White Republican" group headed by Clint W. Hager and gave it the right to file the list of Republican candidates for electors in the November general election.

Predicting an increase in the number of married couples who will return to school after the war, Miss Anna Marie Driscoll, Professor of Industrial Management at the University of Utah, stressed yesterday the need for young women trained as residence hall directors to plan special housing accommodations for married students.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- In a move to insure full quotas of workers for foundries, rubber factories and other plants producing highly critical materials of war, the War Manpower Commission acted today to strengthen its established priority referral plan, which places control of the hiring of most employes in the United States Employment Service by ordering its field directors to set up employment ceilings for war and less essential industries.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 10 (AP) -- Staff Sgt. Paul B. Huff, winner of the Congressional Medal of Honor in the Italian campaign, has arrived in the United States and expressed the hope that he could drop in on his home town, Cleveland, Tenn., by parachute.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 10 (AP) -- William Boyd McKechnie signed a two-year contract renewal as manager of the Reds today and later told newsmen that he would retire from baseball in 1946. Shipments have been largely from northern waters, for production in this area has been lagging.

ROME, Aug. 10 (U.P.) -- British troops driving against the left flank of German positions defending northern Florence have forced the enemy main body across the Arno from one of two strong pockets they held below the river, it was disclosed today, while in Allied-held southern Florence a special force of Italian Partisans and Canadians rounded up 150 anti-Allied Italian snipers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Army field generals have offered concrete evidence that shortages in supplies of bombs, trucks and other material have interfered with battle plans, Lieut. Gen. Brehon B. Somervell, commanding general of the Army Service Forces, revealed today.

The new converting priority order affecting cotton textiles previously sold on unrated orders will result in a substantial curtailment of so-called luxury lines for the balance of the war period, W. Wray Bell, president of the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York, stated yesterday.
Navy communique 535:

E.E. Conroy, special agent in charge of the Federal Bureau of Investigation here, announced yesterday the arrest of Joseph Milstein, 45 years old, a resident at a midtown hotel, as the fourth member of a group that allegedly conspired to divert in the hosiery black market Nylon yarn intended for the manufacture of parachutes and glider tow ropes.

LE MANS, Aug. 9 (Delayed) -Traveling with the first Americans to enter this city, we drove into the west end at 11:30 o'clock this morning and ran into resistance from all sides. The Americans have this end of the city secured at this writing -- l:30 P.M. -- while other American infantry units are moving on the city from the west.

LONDON, Friday, Aug. 11 -Shooting broke out yesterday in East Prussia, West Prussia and the Danzig area when Nazi Elite Guardsmen attempted to arrest German Army officers, the Moscow radio said Thursday.
Mr. and Mrs. Robert Strausz-Hupe of Newtown Square, Pa., have come to Hampshire House.

The new Japanese battle cry, chosen by the Imperial Rule Assistance Association out of 176,000 slogans entered in its 1,000-yen prize contest, is translated into English as "Spirit, harmony, stamina, total action." Even a Japanese soldier, trained to endure all sorts of hardships, couldn't spit out this mouthful under fire.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -The United States, the Netherlands and Great Britain have agreed to study post-war world rubber production and requirements as a preliminary to agreeing on some sort of international rubber control program.

LONDON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Britons, jittery under the fall of German robot bombs, were warned today to go easy on sedatives lest they "end up by jumping at the sound of slammed doors or tensing themselves at bumblebees."

LONDON, Aug. 10 (AP)--Approximately 2,000,000 refugees without a country will remain after Europe's uprooted millions are returned to their homes after the war, the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration estimated today.

Public utility issues yesterday became the favorites of those whose principal requirements in a stock is that it have a low price. Aided by rumors which prove to be either baseless of unverifiable, they displaced the motors and motor accessories in the forefront of market activity on the New York Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10--The leaders of the Army must necessarily concentrate on their business in hand, which is the making of successful war. The War Production Board, on the other hand, must think more and more of the coming industrial transit to peace while at the same time trying to furnish the Army-- as also the Navy--with the materiel deemed necessary to win the war as soon as possible.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Acting Secretary of State, declared "we don't want fascism in this hemisphere" in praising today the joint statement of Venezuela and Colombia announcing that they would refrain from recognizing the Farrell regime in Argentina.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 10 -- The consolidation of Allied combined airborne forces in one command, approximating an army in size and importance, was announced tonight and Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower declared that through its effective employment the war would be ended far more quickly.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 10 -The four-day-old wildcat strike that had crippled production at four plants of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation in this area was settled at 11:15 o'clock tonight after a two-hour plea to 800 of the strikers by Richard T. Frankensteen, vice president of the United Automobile Workers, CIO.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Aug. 5 were 890,458 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 20,075 cars or 2.2 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 18,325 cars or 2.1 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year and 40,237 cars or 4.7 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -Sweeping changes in the aircraft production program, foreshadowing vast offensives against Japan, were ordered today by the War Department.

MONTREAL, Aug. 10 (AP) -Charley Fuchs turned back the Newark Bears with six hits as Montreal took a 3-1 decision in the second game to split a double-header tonight after Floyd Bevens had hurled the Yankee farmhands to a 7-3 victory in the opener.

Sketches depicting "the store of the future," forming a window display at the Schulte cigar store at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, have attracted widespread public interest, company officials reported yesterday. Two sketches, developed by Donald Deskey, industrial designer, are shown.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Frieda H. Miller, director of the Woman's Bureau, who was formerly a special assistant on the staff of the United States Embassy in London, recommended today a new bureau booklet, "British Policies and Methods in Employing Women in Wartime," as a guide to a deeper understanding between the working women of Britain and America.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Francis Biddle is serving as Attorney General of the United States under complete legal authority, but from records of the United States Supreme Court, it was learned today, one might infer his term ended long ago, and all of his subsequent acts and opinions were unlawful.
ABOARD A JOINT EXPEDITIONARY FLAGSHIP, Marianas Islands, July 12 (Delayed) (AP) -Chief Radioman Tweed, in his eyewitness story of the battle for Guam, related these details:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The London Commission of European Affairs is going ahead with its task -- the disposal of all the problems related to the eventual armistice. It is now possible to describe the method the great Allied powers intend to follow when the burden of German affairs is thrown on their shoulders, the day Hitler's army comes to unconditional surrender.
The Soviet operational bulletin, as broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
LONDON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:
BOSTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The Red Sox beat Chicago, 2 to 1, today, but the White Sox stole the show with a triple play, their second of the season against Boston.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Sixteen more Japanese vessels, including an enemy warship, have been sunk by American submarines in the Pacific area, the Navy Department reported today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 10 -- Regarded as heralding an imminent break between Finland and the Reich, all wives and children of members of the Finnish Legation staff in Berlin are being evacuated to Finland by way of Stockholm, according to a report received in Finnish circles here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The B-29 force that attacked Kyushu, in flying from China, demonstrated that the Japanese penetration in the region southeast of Chungking had not interfered with planned operations from fields there against the heart of Japan.
PACIFIC FLEET HEADQUARTERS (Delayed) -- This is the story of the last man out of Guam.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -Despite damage by drought in July in a large East Central area, the aggregate crop production this year now seems likely, the Department of Agriculture reported today, to exceed last year's output by 2 or 3 per cent and to exceed production in any previous year except the record 1942 season.

A NEW SECRET B-29 BASE, Near the Equator, Friday, Aug. 11 -- United States B-29 Superfortresses flew the war's longest aerial mission and carried out the first fire-bombing of the Japanese mainland tonight when they blasted harbor facilities at Nagasaki, Japan, and the huge Pladju refinery at Palembang, Sumatra, far to the south.
The fighting spirit of Warsaw is indomitable and on Aug. 1, 1944, it was reborn like the legendary phoenix from ashes.

It has become habit to think of the present war as a global war, one in which all mankind is fighting, or at least affected. Yet there are peoples in the world who scarcely know there is a war going on.

PEARL HARBOR, July 29 (Delayed) -- President Roosevelt in a dramatic journey following immediately upon his acceptance of the nomination has just completed a visit to the scenes of the outbreak of the war in December, 1941, to confer with his Pacific war leaders.

Excess reserves of the Federal Reserve System dipped sharply in the week ended on Wednesday, declining $200,000,000 to about $1,000,000,000. Principal factors in the decline were an increase of $176,000,000 in money in circulation, an increase in reserve requirements and an increase of $226,000,000 in Treasury deposits. Holdings of United States Government securities rose $331,000,000.

LONDON, Aug. 10 -- An announcement tonight by French headquarters in London that the two main Bordeaux-Paris railroad lines and the Toulouse-Agen line have been cut by the French Forces of the Interior indicates that the time is rapidly approaching when the FFI will play a decisive role in all France.

Aroused to a high pitch of enthusiasm by predictions of the triumphant re-election of President Roosevelt from Secretary Harold L. Ickes, Senator Robert F. Wagner, Sidney Hillman and other speakers, the State convention of the American Labor party again gave its nomination to the President last night.

The operators of twenty-five rooming houses on the lower West Side were found guilty yesterday by Magistrate Leonard McGee in Jefferson Market Court for violating Office of Price Administration regulations covering rooming house rents.
CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 10 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

A head finish decided the $10,975 Sanford Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday as fourteen juveniles rushed down the Widener chute with The Doge on the head end. Ferril Zufelt, a driving finish, and a final lunge by the son of Bull Dog and My Auntie decided the issue in favor of the brown colt owned by Mrs. Jay Secor and others who race under the name of the Pentagon Stable.

WITH CANADIAN FORCES, in the Forward Area, Aug. 10 -- On a hilltop that he helped to capture, Sgt. Vincent Jorgenson, a brawny 23-year-old athlete of Kemora, Ont., was busily getting his tank ready for action again today just after having rested up from as grueling an experience as one can have and live to tell about it.

James B.M. McNally, United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, and Irving L. Levey, a former assistant corporation counsel, were chosen yesterday by the Democrats of the first judicial district as their candidates for vacancies on the Supreme Court bench.

MOSCOW, Aug. 10 -- Circumstantial evidence that Leon Blum, Popular Front Premier of France, met his death in 1943 in a German concentration camp near Lublin, Poland, was published in today's army newspaper Red Star in an article by Konstantin Simonoff, one of the Soviet Union's ace war correspondents and top-flight play-rights.

Cleo Shans, 133, Los Angeles lightweight contender, scored a quick knockout over Paul (Blond Tiger) Freschetti, 132, Nashua, N.H., in the main bout scheduled for eight rounds last night at Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn. A crowd of 5,000 saw Shahs, after being stunned in the first round, punish his opponent so severely in the next two rounds that Referee Young Otto had to halt hostilities after 1:55 of the third.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 10 (AP) -The Indians made it two in a row over the Athletics, 5 to 4, at Shibe Park here today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -George E. Deatherage, a defendant in the mass sedition conspiracy trial, was quoted to the jury today as asserting in 1940 that he had made his home, near an Army camp in West Virginia, "an open house for officers and thought he had gotten some very good work."

Tito Schipa, Italian tenor who was ,the idol of American opera-goers in the Twenties and Thirties has joined the Nazis in Germany, while his wife and daughters, members of the Italian underground, use his fashionable Rome apartment as a headquarters for partisan gatherings, Ralph Howard of the National Broadcasting Company, reported last night from Rome.

Grace Moore was the soloist with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Alexander Smallens, at last night's concert in the Lewisohn Stadium. The soprano, who made her first appearance at the Stadium on this occasion, was heard by an audience of more than 22,000 persons, one of the largest gatherings of the entire season.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 10 -- Darnley, bay horse by Scotland -- Fionne, she by High Moon, today won the Trotting Derby, featured race of the third and final day of the Grand Circuit meeting at Good Time Park.

Thomas V. De Lorenzo, president of Local 365 of the United Automobile Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations affiliate, was found guilty yesterday by Judge John McDuffie in Federal District Court of making false statements to the United States Civil Service Commission in connection with an application for appointment as a labor panel member of the regional War Labor Board.

A suit for a judicial ruling whether the freedoms of speech, the press and religion exist in a greater degree in Great Britain than in the United States was filed in Federal court yesterday by the Truth Seekers Company, Inc., dealers in books of the "free thought" school.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Aug. 10 (AP) -- President Roosevelt, who has completed a three-day strategy conference at Pearl Harbor, spent three action-filled days in San Diego before boarding a cruiser for Honolulu. The Chief Executive left for Pearl Harbor the day after delivering his nomination speech from aboard a train at the United States Marine Corps base here.

Additional awards for gladioluses were announced yesterday before the close of the two-day Midsummer Flower Show held by the Horticultural Society of New York and the Eastern New York Gladiolus Society at 598 Madison Avenue.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 10 -Mrs. Mary A. Doherty and Ulysses S. Mowle, Hudson County Jury Commissioners appointed recently by Gov. Walter E. Edge, submitted today to Chief Justice Thomas J. Brogan of the New Jersey Supreme Court a petit jury panel of 1,008 names and a grand jury panel containing 150 names.

A thirteen-story and penthouse building containing stores and offices to replace the late Gen. Cornelius Vanderbilt's imposing brownstone mansion at 640 Fifth Avenue, northwest corner of Fifty-first Street, was among plans filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Income payments to individuals during June amounting to $13,946,000,000 were the highest figures ever recorded, Secretary of Commerce Jesse Jones announced today.

The Celanese Corporation of America showed in the first half of this year a consolidated net profit of $3,737,125, after allowing $6,528,000 provision for Federal taxes on income, according to the report of Dr. Camille Dreyfus, president, mailed to stockholders today.

OTTAWA, Aug. 10 -- Mustering-out pay for Canadians who have enlisted in the forces has been fixed at $15 for every thirty days of service overseas or in the Aleutian Islands; $7.50 for every thirty days of service in the Western Hemisphere, exclusive of the Aleutian Islands.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 10 (AP) -Horse racing at the two tracks now operating in New Jersey has produced to date this season $1,062,319 in revenue for the State, which receives 4 per cent of the total betting handle, State Racing Commission Secretary Fred H. Ryan said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The Polish question that has been under discussion in Moscow is regarded here as a current political problem that will have no place in the forthcoming exploratory conversations here on a security organization for the post-war world, Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Acting Secretary of State, said at a press conference today.

What the Republican party meant when it pledged itself in its Chicago platform to a post-war international organization which would "direct peace forces to prevent or repel military aggression" is a question which has been widely discussed and variously answered ever since the convention adjourned.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 -- Short covering and commission houses buying based on continued high temperatures and dry weather east of the Mississippi River resulted in oats and rye scoring moderate advances in the early trading today on the Board of Trade.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 10 -- A collapse of pitching today sent the Giants crashing to defeat before the Pirates on Forbes Field, 10 to 4, to the undisguised delight of 4,324 spectators. Frankie Frisch's sluggers went on a rampage that encompassed fourteen hits, two of them homers by Frankie Colman.

Returning from a tour of eleven Midwestern States, Herbert T. Brownell Jr., chairman of the Republican National Committee, declared yesterday that he was greatly encouraged by dissension in the ranks of the Democrats.
In regard to C.L. Sulzberger's dispatch in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 8, "Greeks Preparing Territory Claims," may we point out that the statements concerning the Dodecanese are incomplete.

Gay but travel-worn, thirtyfour young English, Scottish and Irish wives, with fourteen children, arrived in New York yesterday from England, on their way to rejoin the Australian service men they married in Britain and have not seen in four years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- President Sergio Osmena of the Philippines today organized his new government on the basis of a pledge of full post-war cooperation with the United States. He named a war cabinet, made his first presidential address to this cabinet and held his first press conference.

The Department of Health's decree to destroy unleashed dogs found in Bronx streets went back into effect yesterday as Borough President James J. Lyons hurriedly sought a new doghouse to replace his canine Valhalla in 156th Street and Elton Avenue, which is being abandoned because of the neighbors' protests.

The Citizens Transit Committee, 233 Broadway, of which Paul Windels is chairman, has started to circularize tenants and small homeowners on the mailing lists of many civic organizations with a bulletin urging their support of the committee's demand for a Transit Authority to run the subways and for charging of a self-sustaining fare, it was learned yesterday.

More than 100,000 signatures have been obtained for the independent nominating petitions of the Liberal party, Dr. John L. Childs, State chairman, and Joseph V. O'Leary, State secretary, announced yesterday. The petitions are being filed next Wednesday with the Secretary of State in Albany.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Utility or lower grades of beef and lamb will become ration-free on Sunday, giving consumers what Chester Bowles, Price Administrator, called "a real meat bargain," but pork loins, hams and canned fish will be returned to the ration list at the same time after a point-free holiday since May 4.
I read with very much interest the recent remarks of F.C. Davidson in your columns and those of Basil Harris, president of the United States Lines Company.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- A bill to stamp out the black market in liquor by tightening the Treasury Department's control over permits for distilleries and others and increasing its authority to enforce observance of all regulations was introduced in the Senate today by Senator Kilgore, on behalf of Senator McCarran, chairman of a special subcommittee investigating the liquor industry.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- President Roosevelt recently reassured Vice President Henry A. Wallace that he wants him to have an important place in the Government if the Roosevelt Administration is returned to office in November.

OUTSIDE ST. MALO, France, Aug. 10 -- Beseiged and beseeched, Colonel von Aulock -- "the madman of St. Malo" -- still refused to surrender tonight, and continued to fight on from his underground citadel with a handful of German holdouts.

Moving nonchalantly through their paces, without a sign of the terrific pressure that generally goes with a long winning streak, the Browns recorded their tenth straight victory for a 1944 American League record yesterday at the Stadium.
BOSTON, Aug. 10 -- Finishing with a score of 15 1/2 -- 1 1/2, Samuel Reshevsky of Brooklyn today captured the open championship of the United States Chess Federation at the Boston City Club.
Edward F. O'Brien, a vice president of the Frankfort Distillers Corporation, has been named Eastern divisional manager by Ellis D. Slater, president, it was announced yesterday.
LONDON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Note circulation increased 4,541,000 to the all-time record high of 1,150,560,000 as reported today in the weekly Bank of England statement.

At 3 A.M. yesterday 5-year-old Jean Fekete, attired only in panties, was found wandering in the street near her home in an apartment house at 128 Clay Avenue, the Bronx, by a policeman who took the child to her home and found two younger sisters and a brother asleep but unattended.

ALBANY, Aug. l0 -- Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican national chairman, conferred with Governor Dewey tonight on the results of the tour that he, the chairman, made recently in eleven Middle Western States, where he discussed campaign plans with party leaders.
KANDY, Ceylon, Aug. 10 (AP) -- A communique:

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 10 -Capitalizing on Nazi SS-Wehrmacht clashes in France -- for neither German armed force can now devote its full energies to policing the Maquis -- French resistance has intensified its efforts all along the line to prevent the withdrawal of much German materiel now being rushed out of the southwesternmost areas of France in anticipation of encirclement.

Just before he left Washington on his current trip, President Roosevelt wrote a short note to Wendell L. Willkie inviting the 1940 Republican standard bearer to confer with him on his return concerning the foreign relations policies that the United States should follow for the immediate and more distant future.

LONDON, Friday, Aug. 11 -- The Soviet High Command, abruptly renewing a full-scale battle for Warsaw, yesterday sent Russian troops smashing south and northeast of the Polish capital in twin assaults designed to outflank the embattled city and drive a great wedge between Warsaw and Cracow.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 10 -- Within the next two weeks Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will put into production its Women's Army Corps feature, which at one time was titled "Women In Uniform" and which has been in abeyance for several months.

PEARL HARBOR, Aug. 10 -Yesterday afternoon, after a day less than three weeks of fighting, the beaten Japanese garrison on Guam could no longer offer real resistance against overpowering American strength, and the battle was declared over.

Nothing daunted by the fact that Boswell's life of Dr. Johnson is probably the most famous biography ever written, Joseph Wood Krutch is writing another life of the famous literary figure. The first in recent years, it will make use of much new material.

LONDON, Aug. 10 (U.P.) -- Polish underground troops fighting the Germans in Warsaw issued a desperate appeal for help today and said they faced "total extermination" unless immediate and large-scale aid was received.

ROME, Aug. 10 -- The almost static situation in Florence, where Fifth Army contingents and enemy troops have confronted one another across the narrow Arno River bed for nearly a week, is due partly to the desire of the Allied command to spare the city and civilian population.

Joseph B. Graham sold yesterday 265,000 shares of the capital stock of the Graham-Paige Motors Corporation to Joseph W. Frazer and associates for $2 a share, according to a report made by the corporation to James J. Caffrey, regional administrator of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and later released to the press.
CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 10 (AP) -- A Chinese High Command communique:

In a rather featureless though steady market, cotton futures closed 4 to 7 points higher here yesterday. Trade brokers took the bulk of the contracts, while the hedge selling was light and liquidation was mostly on the scale up.

WAR changes more of the world than just those regions where the destruction and devastation take place. Scores of islands in the South Seas now transformed by airfields and naval bases will never be the same again. In Africa and India other airfields and military centers are introducing the wonders of our mechanical age to regions that without the spur of war might not have become acquainted with them for many years to come.

PEARL HARBOR, July 29 (Delayed) -- President Roosevelt reviewed the Seventh Division at Schofield Barracks yesterday. By that time his cavalcades had been seen several times on the island's highways and there was scarcely a person in Honolulu unaware that the Chief Executive was here.
ST. MALO, France, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Beleaguered Germans shot their officers today and then surrendered.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Pitcher Mort Cooper pitched his fifteenth victory -- a shut-out to boot -- and George Kurowski hit his thirteenth home run as the Cardinals defeated the Phillies, 2 to 0, tonight.

LONDON, Aug. 10 -- Colonel Harry A. "Paddy" Flint, who accepted the surrender of German military and naval commanders at Cherbourg, was buried on July 26 in a military cemetery near Ste. Mere Eglise in Normandy, it was announced today.

Accumulated savings of the American people now top the greatest amount they ever have spent in a single year, according to official figures collated by the Institute of Life Insurance. Only in the depression year of 1932, when spending was relatively low, has the year-end savings figure ever before exceeded the amount spent in the preceding year.

The truckers' walkout in the Midwest extended into new territory yesterday, while estimates of the number of men and women on strike throughout the country ranged up to 79,000, The Associated Press reported.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Sharp seasonal decreases in market prices for most fruits and vegetables and lower prices for cotton and oats brought the Bureau of Labor Statistics' comprehensive index of prices in primary markets down 0.3 during the first week in August.

Just outside of the Halloran Hospital grounds on Staten Island there is a park containing a small pond. Around the pond you will find every once in a while several men in blue and red bathrobes, assiduously casting with fly rods, almost always with the awkwardness characterizing the beginner.
GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Saturday, Aug. 12 (AP) -- A communique:

The American Labor party balked temporarily yesterday at endorsing the Democratic candidates for the New York State Supreme Court but reversed itself at the last minute to accept the entire slate. The only Democratic candidate whose nomination by the ALP had been in doubt was Irving L. Levey, a former assistant corporation counsel.

Not even the Browns, who by now must be accorded at least an edge over the rest of the league, could go on indefinitely, flouting (1) the law of averages and (2) the Yankees. Sooner or later defeat, which has a habit of doing such things, was due to catch up with the pace-setters and it did yesterday before a ladies' day crowd of 12,042 at the Stadium.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Saturday, Aug. 12 -- Severe punishment was administered to the Germans yesterday by more than 2,000 American and British heavy bombers in a series of attacks principally devoted to oil and rail targets.

Ready-made "built-in" furniture units that homeowners could take with them when they move were forecast as a probable deelopment in post-war furniture design by Edward J. Wormley, industrial designer, in an interview yesterday. Mr. Wormley, who recently resigned as chief of the furniture unit of the Office of Price Administration, is currently at work on post-war designs for two large furniture manufacturers.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Cardinals clouted Philadelphia all over Sportsmen's Park in the fourth inning, collecting two homers and four singles for six runs, giving the league leaders a 9-to-4 victory over the Phils tonight.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 11 -- Indicating feverish political and diplomatic activity aimed at getting Finland out of the war, George A. Gripenberg, Finnish Minister to Sweden, flew to Helsinki today. Private advices told of a conference among President Karl Mannerheim, Mr. Gripenberg, Premier Antti V. Hackzell and Finland's envoy to Berlin, T.M. Kivimaeki already progress at the Presidential Palace.

Two new films will bow into Broadway theatres today. "Atlan tic City," a Republic musical set in the early days of the New Jersey resort playground, opens at the Republic Theatre, Broadway and and Fifty-first Street. Until yesterday the house was known as the Manhattan.

BOSTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The White Sox defeated the Red Sox, 9 -- 7, today when Pitcher Clem Hausmann walked a batter to force home the winning run with the sore tied at 7 -- all and two out in the ninth inning. George (Pinky) Woods, who relieved Hausmann, then walked the next man, and Chicago had its nine runs.

Despite sufficient supplies of meat of one kind or another for consumers during the rest of the year, trade conditions are growing increasingly worse, Joseph Cohn, counsel of the Meat Trade Institute declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The United States, Britain and the Soviet Union have decided to establish a joint commission to administer the affairs of Austria until the people of that country have an opportunity to create the conditions necessary to economic and political independence.

In your editorial of Aug. 8 "Control for Control's Sake" you seem to make the following assumptions: (1) all control is the antithesis of freedom and democracy; (2) complete freedom is the best means of attaining the economic goal -- the distribution of scarce goods to the end of best satisfying human wants.

Thomas V. DeLorenzo, labor leader found guilty Thursday in Federal Court of making false statements in a civil service application, was in court again yesterday. This time he was before Magistrate Charles Solomon in Flatbush Court acused of striking a neighbor in a dispute over the actions of DeLorenzo's dog.

Jose Felix de Lequerica, Spanish Ambassador to the Vichy French Government, has been appointed Spanish Foreign Minister by Generalissimo Francisco Franco to succeed Count Francisco Gomez Jordana y Sousa, who died Aug. 3, the Spanish home radio said yesterday in a broadcast reported by United States Government monitors.

Edward V. Broderick never intended to be "wilfully disrespectful" to the late Judge John J. Freschi in his recent Wayne Lonergan trial, he asserted yesterday in a petition filed in Supreme Court in connection with his application for a writ of certiorari signed Thursday by Supreme Court Justice George Frankenthaler.

A plot of land on the west side of Eighty-third Street, 240 feet south of Thirty-seventh Avenue, in Jackson Heights, Queens, has been purchased by Evadne, Inc., which contemplates the erection of a theatre when materials are available.

Under the auspices of the Laymen's Movement for a Christian World, with headquarters at 347 Madison Avenue, a conference will be held next Friday, Saturday and Sunday at the Gramatan Hotel, Bronxville, N.Y. "to decide upon some specific things which laymen can do to practice Christian principles in their dally affairs."

LONDON, Aug. 11 -- The spectacular development of the Allies' airborne forces in the last four years was traced today by a young wing commander of the Royal Air Force who in peacetime was an insurance clerk with a fondness for gliders, which he flew over this country and Germany.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Coaches of two-score colleges will hold a "secret" meeting Monday in New York to consider making their own changes in football rules for the coming season, The Philadelphia Record said tonight.

ROME, Aug. 11 -- Rome is a stage whereon, amid the trappings of the old drama "fascism," the first act of a new play is being fumblingly rehearsed. A curious feature in the present performance is that the change affects the visitor more than it affects the Italians themselves.

A dispatch from Suva announces that "Fiji infantrymen attached to the United States Fourteenth Corps" have just returned to their native islands after seeing action, over a period of fifteen months, at Guadalcanal, Kolombangara, Florida and Bougainville. The incident sets one thinking. It isn't so long ago that "Fiji Islander," used as a term of reproach, implied a particularly lively kind of savagery.

ROME; Aug. 11 -- Prime Minister Churchill has arrived in Italy on his first visit here since the start of the war and his second to a major war front within the week, it was disclosed tonight in an announcement from an Allied force headquarters.

ROME, Aug. 11 (U.P.) -- The battle for the historic cultural center of Florence lagged, with most of the action taking place in the great Arno River bend at the foot of the Prato Magno mountain mass some twelve miles to the east.

CHARLES AND MARY BEARD have spent a long lifetime m the collaborative authorship of books on American history. Their "Basic History of the United States,"* which is offered at the bargain price of 69 cents for a volume that would ordinarily retail for $3 .or $4, carries with it the prefatory announcement that this is their final effort as a Writing team.

OTTAWA, Aug. 11 -- Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King made a series of statements in the House of Commons today that are considered here as of the greatest internal and external significance with regard to Canada's role in the war and post-war planning.
The Coast Guard Auxiliary is starting today a six-day campaign to enroll 2,000 men in this area as temporary members of the Coast Guard Reserve.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 11 -- In a statement published today Foreign Secretary Ezequiel Padilla said that the Chamizal boundary dispute between the United States and Mexico, which dates back to the last century, would be settled by peaceful negotiation.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Chinese forces, striking in a new area in their effort to thwart the Japanese in central China, have recovered the stronghold of Pingsiang, about 100 miles northeast of Hengyang, and pushed the enemy westward thirty miles to the outskirts of Liling, a Chinese spokesman said today.

I very much enjoyed your recent editorial "Gravy Conservation." Though you said very little had been written in etiquette books on the subject, we are not without sound comment on this gastronomical delight. The authority is M. Todgers, proprietor of a London commercial boarding house.
WITH AMERICAN FORCES in Brittany, Aug. 11 -- This battle is not so easy as it looks on the map.
New strikes yesterday offset the return to work of thousands of men and women and, at the end of the day, about 59,000, including the Midwestern drivers and helpers, were idle.
CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- Conservatism marked the attitude of most buyers attending the fall market here during the last two weeks, observers said today in analyzing the results of the showings.

It is more than battle that is taking place in France as the armored columns clatter along the old roads, as the infantry runs swiftly along the streets of shattered towns, as the smoke of burning rises to heaven, as men stumble and die among the orchards, vineyards and ripening crops.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Office of Price Administration, in an effort to tighten its price controls, announced today several changes in the regulation governing ceiling prices of domestic cooking and heating stoves. Effective Aug. 16, the revisions are being made as a result of a "careful study" of the operation of the original ruling when it was issued on Oct. 4, 1943, the OPA said.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES IN FRANCE, Aug. 11 (AP) -- St. Malo's mad commander, Col. Andreas von Aulock, fought on today, squandering the lives of his men in a futile battle despite the third truce since the siege of St. Malo citadel began.

Lewis Gannett, the reformed book critic, reporting from London to our contemporary on Fortieth Street, says the British bank holiday crowds were considerably disturbed when they could find no decent hotel rooms at the beaches, and complained because they had difficulty reaching the sea because of the barbed wire.

Furniture manufacturers and their sales representatives, who feared the arrival of Aug. 1, the effective date of the "stringent" War Production Order L-335 as amended, have discovered that thus far the greatest bottleneck to production is not a lack of lumber, that many believed would result from the order, but a growing lack of labor, it was learned yesterday.

THE triumph of Yankee Maid in the Hambletonian, coming as it did on the heels of the stunning defeat administered to Twilight Tear in the Alabama Stakes, doubtless did much to restore men's faith in women, particularly women of the equine world.

VANNES, France, Aug. 11 -- An American tank in Brittany, suddenly meeting a huge German Tiger tank head-on, only thirty yards away, rammed the unwieldy enemy vehicle, Navy style, and then blew it apart with a gun that was almost touching the turret of the enemy vehicle.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Detroit made it three in a row over Washington when the Tigers overcame the Senators, 11 -- 4, tonight. Stubby Overmire, though hit freely, held the Senators safe in the pinches. Dutch Leonard, Roger Wolff and Bill Lefebvre faced the Tigers.
CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 11 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 11 -- With American armored columns converging on Paris at lightning speed, the situation within the French capital has become chaotic. No direct news is available, of course, and "frontier reports" may be discounted.

Cotton closed yesterday at the best levels of the day on the New York Cotton Exchange, with net gains of 15 to 17 points. A moderate business was done. The best buyers were brokers who usually act for Southern mills.

A large number of advertisements featuring reupholstering furniture services have appeared in newspaper and trade publications within the last few weeks. This is partly due, it was explained in retailing circles, to a seasonal slackening off in the reupholstering business and to the shortage of fabrics for covering new upholstered furniture which threatens to become increasingly serious.

LONDON, Aug. 11 -- Operation of the Army's plan for insuring equitable distribution in the European theatre of political news on the forthcoming elections was outlined today at a press conference here.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 11 -- The Nationalist press has more than once expressed high approval of Sumner Welles, former Under-Secretary of State, when he has criticised Cordell Hull's policy toward Argentina. Today, however, the paper Fronda joins issue with him on one point, rejecting the suggestion he made that another Pan-American conference should be convoked and Argentina invited to attend it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Three American prisoners of war, one of them a Brooklyn boy, were condemned to death and executed by the Japanese on July 31, 1943, the Navy Department announced today. The victims, with their ages, parents and home addresses were:

Ten me, including four suspended race track jockeys, were arrested yesterday in midtown on grand larceny charges in exposure of a racing swindle which netted them between $75,000 and $100,000 in the last seven months, according to the police.

The mercury reached a record high for Aug. 11 in the 44-year-old history of the local Weather Bureau yesterday when it registered 96 degrees at 3:30 P.M., three-tenths of a degree under the year's high set on Aug. 4.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission issued today a memorandum opinion stating its tentative conclusions on the reorganization of Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation. A hearing will be held Sept. 19. The opinion was issued at Columbia's request.

Although war forces us to do much that is distasteful, never was there a time when so many ready-made excuses existed for avoiding what we would rather get out of. This is an almost daily blessing for which we may not have been sufficiently grateful.

GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Saturday, Aug. 12 (U.P.) -- Allied bombers sank or damaged seven Japanese freighters, one coastal vessel and a number of smaller craft in a heavy attack against Halmahera and the waters around the strategic island, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- Miss Margaret Osborne of San Francisco, the defending titleholder and recent winner of the Delaware tournament in which she defeated Miss Pauline Betz of Los Angeles, the national champion, and Miss Louise Brough of Beverly Hills, was eliminated from the Eastern grass court championships today at the Westchester Country Club.

A fire that raged out of control for four hours last night, fed by exploding drums of inflammable liquids, destroyed Pier 4 at Second Street, Hoboken, N.J., a landmark of New York Harbor, where the Leviathan was loaded in the first World War.

The defense began calling witnesses yesterday in the General Sessions trial of three men accused of robbing Lieut Col. Joseph W. Clough, stationed at Fort Jay, Governor's Island, of $156, his gold wrist watch and a pen and pencil in Greenwich Village on June 26.
Yesterday's Soviet communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
A communique, as broadcast yesterday from Chungking in English to North America and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The attacks by B-29 Superfortresses of the Twentieth Bomber Command yesterday on "two centers of Japanese industrial strength" brought good results, Gen. Henry H. Arnold, Chief of the Army Air Forces, reported today in his capacity as commander of the giant bombers.

MOSCOW, Aug. 11 -- Measures to facilitate the opening of new churches in Russia have been among principal concerns of the Soviet Council on Orthodox Affairs since its formation ten months ago, it was revealed here by Georgi Grigorievitch Karpoff, head of the five-man Council, in an interview with Religious News Service.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- With a coalition of Republicans and Southern Democrats in command, the Senate adopted today the revised version of the George Demobilization and Reconversion Bill by a vote of 55 to 19.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Aug. 11 -- Unconfirmed but insistent reports reaching the Franco-Swiss frontier throughout the day said that the provisional capital of Vichy was on the eve of being stormed by an underground army estimated at some 10,000 men armed to the teeth and now marching in from the east, south and west despite sporadic efforts to halt it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Maury Maverick, the plain-speaking Texan who runs the Smaller War Plants Corporation, today forecast a bright future for women in small business if this country rolls into full production after the war.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by the Associated Press:

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 11 -- E.W. Etchells of the Larchmont Yacht Club, a representative of the Western Long Island Sound Star Class fleet, accomplished something today that no other skipper ever had done. In winning the Atlantic Coast championship with his sloop Shillelah and with his wife for crew, he took five straight races.
HEADQUARTERS, United States Ninth Air Force, Aug. 11 -- The efforts of the Luftwaffe to support the German divisions counter-attacking around the Mortain sector increased somewhat yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- An article in Stars and Stripes, quoting an Army supply officer as saying sale of British newspapers was banned in United States Army camps because of a short supply, brought a statement today from Maj. Edward Strode, executive public relations officer in this theatre, that the order actually was issued under the soldier vote law.

Representative industrial and railway shares rubbed shoulders yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange with the usual mixed assortment of low-price performers, and the market gained further ground in active trading. Enthusiasm dwindled in the afternoon, however, but most of the early gains held and the list closed fractionally higher on the day.
LONDON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Germans have sent an ultimatum to General Bor's underground troops holding parts of Warsaw that they must surrender or die, the Polish Telegraph Agency said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Nonpartisan senatorial support was given today for amending the service men's voting law to remove, as Senator Taft, Republican, of Ohio, said, "all excuse for over-zealous interpretations of the political propaganda features of the act" by the armed services.

The Rev. Dr. Frederick R. Knubel, pastor for the last seventeen years of the Lutheran Church of the Reformation, Rochester, N.Y., will take up his duties Sept. 1 as president of the United Lutheran Synod of New York, a full-time salaried office.
A communique issued yesterday, as broadcast from Tokyo in English to North. America and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

ROME, Aug. 11 (AP) -- An offensive by Polish troops on the Adriatic flank of the Eighth Army has rolled forward to the Cesano River only seventeen miles from Pesaro and the eastern end of the Germans' Gothic Line across northern Italy, Allied Headquarters announced today.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Chinese troops and Kachin levies have driven seven miles south of captured Myitkyina in a new push toward Bhamo, Japanese base on the Irrawaddy River, seventy-three miles farther south, Allied headquarters announced today.
WITH POLISH FORCES, in the Caen Sector, Aug. 11 -- These Poles are terrific fighters and they are always looking for places where the fighting is hottest and there are plenty of Germans to kill.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Athletics touched three Cleveland pitchers for thirteen hits and a 6-to-3 victory over the Indians before 8,399 at Shibe Park tonight.

PEARL HARBOR, Aug. 11 -- Heavy bombers of the Seventh Army Air Force bombed Iwo Island in the Volcano group Wednesday in the first full-scale heavy strike from newly won airfields in the Marianas. Iwo is 689 miles from Japan.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- President Roosevelt ordered tonight the seizure of 103 Midwestern trucking companies in a step to bring the immediate return to work of 20,000 strikers and avert a halt in the flow of war materials. The strike, which began last week, affects companies carrying 4,720,000 net tons of goods annually.
KANDY, Ceylon, Aug. 11 (AP) -- A communique:

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Aug. 11 -- A concentrated drive to draw between 1,200 and 2,000 women into the Bethlehem Steel Company plant here has been started with the full cooperation of the War Manpower Commission. Needed for jobs which scientific studies have determined that they can do, the recruits will join about 2,100 women who have been hired by the plant for production work during last year.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Twentieth Air Force communique 8:

Lipstick cases -- post-war -- will be made either of aluminum, a new plastic now used only for war purposes or a brand-new lightweight metal, planning experts in the cosmetic industry predicted in interviews yesterday. It is expected that these materials will supplant heavier pre-war metal because it is thought that women now prefer the lighter weight of present paper and plastic cases.

The Salt River Project, Agricultural Improvement and Power District of Arizona, at a special election held on Thursday approved the refunding of $7,332,000 of the district's bonds. Full details will be made available later.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 11 -- " 'Die Amerikaner' will be here in two weeks or less if the going is good," is the slogan racing like wildfire in Paris today among the 200,000 or 300,000 German civilians there, according to a neutral who was in Paris at the beginning of the week.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 11 -- Alexis Smith, who has just returned to Hollywood from her wedding trip with Craig Stevens, has been assigned the role of Nora in Warner Brothers current "Of Human Bondage." She will share co-starring honors in the Somerset Maugham story with Eleanor Parker and Paul Henreid.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Communique 125:

THIRD AMPHIBIOUS CORPS HEADQUARTERS, Guam, Aug. 12 (Aug. 11 United States time) -- Fighting on Guam developed into a human rabbit hunt today after Maj. Gen. Roy Geiger officially pronounced the island "secure."

Representative Martin J. Kennedy, who was defeated for renomination by Representative Vito Marcantonio in the recent Democratic primaries in the Eighteenth district, announced last night that he would not run independently but would leave the field clear to Lieut. Robert C. Palmer, USNR, whom Mr. Marcantonio had defeated for the Republican nomination.

GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Saturday, Aug. 12 (AP) -- American planes yesterday harassed retreating Japanese in the Aitape-Wewak area of British New Guinea. Yesterday's communication announced conclusion of organized Japanese resistance in this region, where the enemy fruitlessly attempted to break Allied encirclement, losing an estimated 18,000 dead and wounded.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 11 -- A television device for use in marine salvage, an industrial roof "supported by air pressure," and a treatment for pine logs to give the lumber high color are among the 564 inventions listed in the current issue of The Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

The urgent need for young women as technicians in physical therapy was stressed by G. Samuel Bohlin, director of the Division of Vocational Rehabilitation of the New York State Education Department, at graduation exercises yesterday for the first class of physiotherapists at Columbia University in Earl Hall on the university campus.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State now offered by dealers.

One of the marvels of our production of aircraft has been the improvement in speed, range and weight of armament concurrent with expanded output. Another remarkable accomplishment, less spectacular but hardly less important, has been the simplification of design and fittings from the point of view of maintenance in the field.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Miss Dorothy Germain of Philadelphia, the defending champion, today defeated Mrs. H.M. Sims of Evanston, Ill., the 1941 Minnesota State titleholder, 4 and 3, and will meet Phyllis Otto of Omaha tomorrow in the 36-hole women's Western amateur golf final.

An unsuspected source of Vitamin C -- the nutrient found so abundantly in oranges and requisite for strong teeth and resistance to infection -- is the homely carrot. Its contents were studied recently by the Colorado Experiment Station, which reports that the vegetable yields moderate amounts of C provided it is eaten fresh from the garden.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Aug. 11 -- A suit seeking the recovery of more than $100,000,000 alleged to have been lost through mismanagement of the affairs of the United Corporation, one of the largest holding companies in the nation, has been filed in the Federal District Court in Wilmington, Del., it became known today.
ROME, Aug. 11 (AP) -- A communique:

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Japanese are pouring reinforcements into the Philippines and Formosa to meet an American onslaught and are believed to be bolstering defenses in the Canton area against a feared landing on China's coast, a Chinese army spokesman said today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- The recent doings of the Dodgers have put most observers in a daze, while Jolly Cholly Grimm tonight found himself a in a deep indigo haze.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 11 -- Little change was reflected in the level of business in the Pittsburgh district last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. Slight decreases were reported in industrial production and in originating shipments, but a moderate gain in the volume of trade was sufficient to offset declines in production and shipments.

Sales of leading mail-order and chain-store companies in July increased 6.8 per cent over the same month last year, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES, covering thirty-four companies. Total sales were $400,624,051, compared with $375,101,128 in July, 1943.

Consolidated net earnings of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana for the first six months of this year amounted to $27,868,559, equal to $1.82 a share, according to the semi-annual report announced yesterday. For the comparative period of 1943 the earnings were $22,079,417, or $1.44 a share.

LONDON, Saturday, Aug. 12 -- Russian troops, renewing a powerful offensive into Estonia, yesterday surged through Nazi defenses on a forty-three-mile front below Lake Pskov and advanced as much as sixteen miles, while other Soviet forces opened a new drive toward Lyck, big German rail junction in southeastern East Prussia.

Recurrence of hot weather had some effect on retail trade here this week by slowing consumer response to early fall offerings. However, volume inrceased over a year ago at close to the same rate as in recent weeks. The increase for department stores was estimated at about 8 to 10 per cent.

BOMBAY, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The old economic law of supply and demand has been brought into play in the silver market here in an attempt to force down the price of the white metal usually hoarded by Indians but, after a slight drop, the price still runs far above that in the United States.
LONDON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

LONDON, Aug. 11 (U.P.) -- Speaking over the London radio last night, Polish Vice President Jan Kwapinski told the Poles in Warsaw that considerable quantities of material were on their way to Warsaw. He did not indicate how the needed supplies were sent.

CHINESE EXPEDITIONARY FORCE HEADQUARTERS, on the Salween Front, Aug. 10 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Their nostrils smeared with sweet smelling tiger balm to ward off the stench of death, Chinese assault forces battled today through breaches in the high stone wall surrounding the ancient city of Tengyueh.

At the Theatre Guild's headquarters plans have been made to put "Embezzled Heaven," starring Ethel Barrymore, into rehearsal the first week in September. The play, a dramatization by Ladislaus Bus-Fekete and his wife, Mary Helen Fay, of the Franz Werfel novel, will be tried out of town in late September and open in New York in October.

Hundreds of rooming house operators have appeared since Thursday at the New York area rent office of the Office of Price Administration at 535 Fifth Avenue to register their properties under OPA's rent control program, a step which all landlords were supposed to have taken before the program went into operation in November, 1943.

Declaring that the National Can Corporation of 110 East Forty-second Street charged above-ceiling prices for steel containers sold to the Chemical Warfare Service of the War Department and the E.I. du Pont de Nemours Company, Wilmington, Del., the Office of Price Administration yesterday iled a treble-damage action against the can company for $155,101.53 in Federal court here.
Premier Ion Antonescu of Rumania has handed his resignation to King Michael, the British radio reported yesterday in a broadcast recorded by the Federal Communications Commission.
NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 10 (AP) -If Manuel Jose Da Silva, 41 years old, of 132 Ferry Street, had not sought to become a citizen, he might have lived in the United States for the rest of his life.

HEADQUARTERS, United States Ninth Air Force, Aug. 11 -- Fifteen minutes after he bailed out of his flak-crippled Thunderbolt between the German and American battle lines near St. Pois-on-the-Mortain front Lieut. William H. Porter of Tampico, Mexico, received the Purple Heart.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The heat handicapped the pitchers today and the Braves and Cincinnati put on a slugging match, with the Reds taking it, 12 to 6.

From Konstantin Simonoff, Soviet war correspondent, comes the report that Leon Blum, former Premier of France, died last year in the Nazi "extermination camp" near the recently liberated city of Lublin. The evidence is not conclusive, but if M. Blum did perish there, he was one of many mar tyrs from all over Europe, by Russian estimates "several hundred thousand," who were there foully put to death.

For the second time in two weeks the War Food Administration has rejected bids on a large lot of graded eggs it must move from storage in Providence, R.I. to make way for the new apple crop. The local office of WFA at 150 Broadway announced yesterday that bids on 47,066 cases of eggs offered for sale had been rejected because they were below ceilings.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Hil-home in Westchester County, New York, estate of the late Percy S. Straus, former chairman of the board of R.H. Macy Co., became today the property of the United States Public Health Service, which will make it a convalescent home for merchant seamen and Coast Guardsmen.

GREAT LAKES, Ill., Aug. 11 (AP) -- Lieut. Comdr. Gordon S. (Mickey) Cochrane's Great Lakes Bluejackets went on a rampage today with a sixteen-hit barrage that included five home runs, in defeating Indianapolis Indians of the American Association, 14 to 3.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 11 -- Under the terrific pressure of a six-run lead, the Giants went into a precipitate nose-dive tonight on Forbes Field, lost their third game in a row to the Pirates, and avoided a plunge into the second division only because the Dodgers had beaten the Cubs in the afternoon.

A letter has been sent recently to Cape Cod farmers offering them $1.50 an acre of what turns out to be Government money "to conform to good production and conservation practices" through planting green manures as instructed.

BUFFALO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The New York Department of the American Legion today petitioned the United Nations to declare and enforce economic sanctions against any nation which gives sanctuary to "international war criminals" and refuses to deliver them to the United Nations for trial.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 11 (U.P.) -- The latest assault by B-29 Superfortress bombers set raging fires at Nagasaki and Palembang and struck a heavy blow at the enemy's war potential, pilots' reports said today.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Saturday, Aug. 12 -- The American armored forces' "silent" offensive beyond Le Mans took a sudden turn to the north yesterday that threatened to cut off part of the German Seventh Army's tanks from a retreat to the Seine for a stand before Paris.

ROME, Aug. 11 -- A statement saying that "nothing is known about the news according to which the Soviet Government proposed 'coordinated action between Moscow and the Vatican in the postwar solution of moral and social problems'" appeared in today's special bulletin of the Vatican press service issued by the newspaper Osservatore Romano.

After almost two years of study the Securities and Exchange Commission has announced the minimum capital requirements for brokers and dealers. After Nov. 9, a broker or dealer may not borrow more than twenty times his net capital.

LONDON, Aug. 11 -- Business was quiet today on the stock markets, with price movements irregular. Industrial shares eased slightly, shipping issues showed an upward trend and breweries continued to improve. Tobaccos were on the dull side and stores eased fractionally.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- Continued dry and hot weather in the Corn Belt States east of the Mississippi River and a reduction of 50,000,000 bushels in the estimated crop, as given late yesterday by the Department of Agriculture, led to commission-house buying and short covering in oats and rye early today on the Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, was reported today applying final touches to his order empowering local officials to authorize civilian production on Aug. 15, with the firm conviction that he will have to fight for his reconversion program against the recently granted veto powers of the War Manpower Commission.

The historic Travers Stakes, oldest race run in the United States, having been established in 1864, is up for renewal today at Belmont Park with only five named for the $15,000 added mile and quarter test, once known as the Midsummer Derby.

Arthur Krock's column in THE TIMES of Aug. 4 accents the economic control necessary to prevent the recrudescence of the Nazi horror. Too much emphasis cannot be placed upon this point. The economic supremacy which the Nazis acquired through their mechanical ability, their coal and their iron, alone made conceivable their attempt to conquer the world.

An eighteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 421 to 431 Park Avenue, to cost $2,010,000, is envisioned in plans filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings by Walker Gillette, architects, and William I. Hohauser, associate architect, for the 435 Park Avenue Corporation, of which Charles J. Mylod is president.
We have read with interest in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 7 the editorial celebrating the capture of Myitkyina. However, we feel obliged to draw your attention to a rather serious misstatement.

A method of conversion to consumer goods production that would keep factories rolling and provide a large variety of temporary post-war products to the housewife was suggested yesterday by George Kosmak, industrial designer.

After spending more than a year in the death house at Sing Sing Prison for the murder of Mary Rycoith, a war worker, of 16 Catherine Place, Mariners Harbor, S.I., Dominic Taddio, 39 years old, also a former war worker, of 62 Tompkins Street, Stapleton, S.I., was set free yesterday by Judge Thomas J. Walsh in the Richmond County Court at St. George on a motion by District Attorney Farrell M. Kane.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- Red-headed Japhet Lynn, slender right-hander who once did a little mound work for the Giants and who discarded a job as a railroad brakeman to take up the business of baseball, today put the upstart Dodgers in their places by whitewashing them on five hits as Cholly Grimm's Cubs won the game, 2 -- 0.

It is often said that whereas the last war was a chemist's war, the present war is a physicist's war. The presentation last week to Harvard University of "the world's greatest mathematical calculating machine," a "revolutionary new electrical device of major importance to the war effort, to be used by the Navy for the duration," reminds us that this war is also a mathematician's war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Thus far the Navy has experienced no difficulties or criticism in connection with its distribution of news and reading matter to the armed forces such as has recently raised controversy within the Army.

In "In Defense of Modern Art" Mr. Jewell is instructive and broad-minded and refreshing. I find all forms of art interesting, beautiful, amusing, and so on, for a variety of reasons until my feet get tired. Or perhaps too many Norwegian landscapes or too many fruit pictures in a room make me lose interest.
LONDON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Naval planes operating from a carrier force attacked shore installations on a sixty-five-mile sector of the Norwegian coast, the British Admiralty disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The conferees on post-war world communications who met yesterday at the invitation of the Department of State to consider proposed restrictions of international agreements and regulations concluded their organization and preliminary discussions in three major committees today and adjourned to meet again within the next few weeks.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The grand-scale conference of Pacific leaders held at Pearl Harbor by President Roosevelt probably had little effect on the course of the war in the Pacific, since what is done today invariably was planned months ago, but it did set a bold-face exclamation point to the statement that our forces are grinding ever faster toward the unconditional surrender decreed for Japan.
BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 12 -- Pierre Laval has decided to make his last stand in Paris.

Ten men arrested Friday on charges of grand larceny and forgery in an alleged race-track swindle denied yesterday in the line-up at Police Headquarters being members of a ring that police said did a monthly business exceeding $5,000.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 12 -Despite the fact that both Mississippi's and Louisiana's delegations at the Democratic convention, under the unit system, cast their ballots for Senator Byrd of Virginia for residential nominee, in the last week the drift has been decidedly toward Roosevelt.

MR. SUMNER WELLES in his recent book affirms that he is "one of those who believes that the present World War would not have cursed mankind had the United States followed a different course during the past quarter of a century."

LE MANS, France, Aug. 11 (Delayed) -- A young French intellectual who speaks perfect English with an Oxford touch arrived here today after having walked from Paris through the German lines during the past ten days.

POST-WAR building projects have been figuring prominently in the news for months. There promises to be phenomenal activity in the field of architecture. And now is the time when decision should be reached as to whether the American architecture of tomorrow is to be modern, in the sense that it reflects our own age, or "period" or conglomerate flub-dub, as in the past.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Senator Kenneth S. Wherry has asked Senator Harry F. Byrd, as chairman of the Committee on Reduction of Federal Nonessential Expenditures, to investigate the status of Dr. Herbert Schimmel as a clerk of the Military Affairs subcommittee that handled the Murray-Kilgore bill.

CAPE COD continues to attract both old-timers and new friends. In fact, the attraction this year has been so strong that agents say they have been put to it to find space for prospective clients. When gasoline restrictions went into effect some time ago, many thought it meant slack days for the Cape.

BOSTON, Aug. 12 -- If by some miracle peace should come this year, will New England business men and industrialists be ready for transition? According to agencies like the New England Council, the Massachusetts Committee on Post-War Readjustment and the Associated Industries, heads of business enterprises doing war work started long ago to plan for reconversion and will not be caught short.

Retail trade was active last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Main floors were crowded. Accessories met a brisk call, while the demand was good for coats and suits, dresses and children's wear.

SALEM, N.H., Aug. 12 (AP) -Snow Maid, owned by Mrs. E.A. Frolichs, raced up from last place in a ten-horse field today to win the $10,000 added New Hampshire Jockey Club Special as Rockingham Park closed a three-week meeting. A crowd of 15,000 dumped $661,156 into the mutuel machines for a total of $9,412,125 during the meeting and a daily average of $522,895.

Secretary Wickard's warning regarding the boom in farm land prices is in line with the results of a study by the Ohio Farm Bureau. This organization has published for its members the conclusions reached by farm economists of thirteen States who were queried by twenty large life insurance companies.

LEO T. McCAULEY, Consul General of Eire in New York, was informed last week by the Minister of Posts and Telegraphs at Dublin that a 2 1/2-pence stamp would be issued on Aug. 29 to mark the centenary of the death of Edmund Ignatius Rice, founder and first Superior General of the Christian Brothers of Ireland.

THE stunning upset defeat of the 1-to-20 Twilight Tear the other day recalls a story which convinced this observer even before the Tear was born that in all this world there can never be a sure thing where man or beast is involved.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

WITH AMERICAN INFANTRY BATTALION, Near Mortain, France, Aug. 12 -- This battalion was rescued this afternoon after having been cut off by the Germans for five and one-half days on an ear-shaped hill just east of Mortain.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Aug. 12 (Canadian Press) -- The right of the press to criticize censorship regulations was upheld here today with the verdict of the full court in favor of Robert H. Billens, newspaper editor, convicted early this year of a breach of New Zealand censorship regulations.

The Tokyo radio said yesterday that the Japan Industrial Machinery Control Association had decided to set up a supervisory and "efficiency" office that would be empowered to order "divisional shifts and other emergency steps" in machine tool factories "to cope with the enemy air raids."

The pioneer work of Prof. Alexander A. Bogomoletz on the diseases of old age and on the mechanisms involved in the processes of aging has only recently been made available to American medical men and biologists through the new publication, American Review of Soviet Medicine, edited by Prof. Henry E. Sigerist of the Johns Hopkins University Medical School.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (U.P.) -The British delegation to the Dumbarton Oaks conference on postwar international security arrived here late today as plans for the American-British-Russian talks reached a virtually complete stage.

WASHINGTON. ON occasions when Washington's whimsical weather is element a large, highly polished car may be seen negotiating the capital's swollen traffic streams, generally headed toward Potomac Park, carrying in the tonneau, sometimes alone, or perhaps accompanied by a friend, a white-haired, distinguished appearing man wearing a gray Homburg hat.

AS our troops thunder on Paris and the nation cheers them on, the time for asking questions about war production could scarcely be less appropriate. But last week the civilian leader who has shaped the production marvel now helping so powerfully to bring victory on the world's battlefronts has finally been compelled to put up such questions to the combined Chiefs of Staff.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12 (AP) -A story of murder on the high seas was related by the crew of an American ship which docked here today, with three of its hands slain and three wounded by another crewman who later took his own life.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 12 -- Following today's first and second round matches in the New Jersey State amateur championship now in progress at the Essex County Country Club, it was the carefully considered opinion of students of Garden State golf that the outcome of the tournament ending tomorrow now hinges on one match -- the one in the semi-final between Mike Cestone, Montclair mailman, and Dr. Stephen G. Lee, Wesleyan graduate.
