WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -Gasoline rations for motor boats powered by inboard engines will be curtailed sharply and allotments for outboard craft will be trimmed to a lesser extent, effective Oct. 1, the Office of Price Administration announced tonight.

Speedy return to "normal" drinking habits by the public will be the most important result of the August liquor holiday, according to industry spokesmen yesterday, with the trend already well defined. Gin sales, which this year reached new lows because of the scarcity of grain neutral spirits, are expected to increase to a point nearly normal.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Political forces opposed to the re-election of the President have been awaiting with mixed feelings release of the news of his visit, as Commander in Chief of the Armed Forces, to Hawaii and the Aleutians. Their feelings were mixed because they are uncertain how to deal with these official activities in the terms of getting votes against him, and yet they feel that somehow they should make the effort.

THE Archpriest of Hita once wrote a defense of little things that is still quoted these four hundred years later. No one has yet penned so spirited a defense of elephants. Which is a pity, for a book like this -- 973 pages long, by fifty-nine authors in the learned professions -- needs a lively justification to save it for the layman.

One patrolman was disarmed and another was shot early yesterday morning in an upper Park Avenue bar and grill they had entered to question four young Negroes about the theft of an automobile. Two suspects were captured after running pistol fight.

Hundreds of thousands of bathers gathered on Coney Island's beach to escape the heat yesterday found themselves the unexpected witnesses of a spectacular, multiple-alarm fire that swept over half of the sixteen-acre Luna Park, one of the island's two principal amusement centers, before firemen brought it under control.

By Jimminy and Pavot, favorites with a crowd of 29,875, won yesterday at Belmont Park in two of the Saratoga Association's historic stakes which for decades have attracted the top thoroughbreds in the juvenile and 3-year-od divisions. Walter M. Jeffords' Pavot may be the champion 2-year-old, for he still is unbeaten after five starts and his score in the Saratoga Special was just as convincing as those in past races.

To every citizen the current discussion concerning the soldier vote is of paramount concern. The vote of the New York soldier is determined by the State Constitution, the Federal war ballot law and the State war ballot law.

IT was inevitable that a boy of Augustus' character and talents should, Army regulations to the contrary, drive a jeep. His motives, of course, were the most patriotic. He came across the jeep in a Florida swamp, carefully hidden by Uncle Sam and Jeems, one old and one young Negro, who were determined to guard it and its important military secret until Colonel Baxley came back from the hospital.

BOSTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Jim Tabor's eighth-inning home run, his ninth of the season, today gave the Red Sex a 5-to-4 victory over Chicago. The score was tied 4 -- 4, and one was out when Tabor hit the first pitch for Boston's third triumph in the four-game series.

IN the spring God suddenly reminds you one day what summer is like in Kansas: you begin to feel the great hot suction of the sun-pulling the water from the land and you think that here there are only two seasons, violent and sluggish. And then you think that there is only one, summer -- and that all the earth is cracked, all the leaves dusty and curling, and all the grass gray-brown.
LONDON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 12 -John Brown, president of Brown Bros., a brass foundry and electroplating plant at 46 Garden Street, shut down the war plant and today said he would retire and offer the place for sale rather than be dictated to by a union.
Although the mercury climbed only to the 93-degree mark in the tube yesterday, three degrees below Friday, a simmering citizenry seemed to find conditions even more uncomfortable.

A guide to comparative literature and intercultural relations, designed to help improve the teaching program in these fields, is now being prepared under the joint sponsorship of the American Library Association, the Association of American Colleges and the National Council of Teachers of English.

THOUGH Tin Pan Alley has not produced an "Over There" for the present war -- defenders of the music world say radio quickly plays to death any number that might show such possibilities -- the men in service, as always, are fighting with many a song on their lips.

Although recurrence of hot weather hampered retail trade to some extent last week, volume continued to compare well with a year ago. Department store sales, it was estimated, ranged from 8 to 10 per cent over a year ago. Early consumer interest in new fall styles is growing, with newness of fashion appeal a strong promotional point.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Sunday, Aug. 13 -In a surprise attack on Japanese air bases on Halmahera Island, outpost of the Philippines, American medium bombers destroyed or severely damaged a total of forty-one enemy planes on the ground.

Establishment of a new military command, to be known as the Naval Reserve Officer Training Center at 417 West 117th Street, which will assume control over eight officer training units in the Third Naval District, was announced yesterday during ceremonies at the Naval Reserve Mid-shipmen's School of Columbia University.

HOLLYWOOD studios, in the midst of an unprecedented revival spree, are continuing to comb their vaults for additional story material suitable for refilming. While the idea of remaking past screen successes is not new by any means, there never has been a period in movie history when the practice has been quite as popular as it now appears to be.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 12 (U.P.) -- While a military band played "Here Comes the Bride," 295 Australian war brides marched off a luxury liner today onto United States soil, where Red Cross nurses had arranged a line-up of baby carriages for the seventy-four babies who accompanied their mothers.
LONDON, Sunday, Aug. 13 (U.P.) -- Flying bombs crashed in London and the rest of southern England last night and early today after a lull during daylight yesterday.

The building of the new type heavy destroyers is being transferred from the Kearny, N.J., yard to the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company's "junior" yard at Port Newark, N.J., it was announced yesterday by Lynn H. Korndorff, president of the company.

Renewing his plea to Governor Dewey for a special session of the Legislature to liberalize soldier voting laws, Dean Alfange, Liberal party leader, said yesterday that there is still time "to unscramble the complicated machinery now obstructing the GI vote in New York State."

Allied Blitzkrieg last week roared across western France. Hammerblows by at least three Allied armies and huge Allied air fleets were cutting up the German Seventh Army, opening the roads to Paris, throwing the whole Nazi defense system into turmoil and paving the way for a Wehrmacht disaster.

As the tide of war rolls over more and more Pacific islands, reclaiming them from Japanese mandate or conquest, the question of their eventual disposition when peace be restored in the greatest of oceans poses a diplomatic problem to which some study should be given.

TWO-WAY radio highways linking many cities and industrial centers of the country -- each highway three times the width of an ordinary television "wave" and 2,000 times as wide as a broadcast program channel -- are forecast in applications filed simultaneously a few days ago with the Federal Communications Commission.

The Anglo-American petroleum agreement signed last week in Washington is the first important step toward the control by government of the distribution of oil in international trade. Provided other oil-producing nations join the pact it will be the first time in modern history that such an essential commodity has been brought under strict control by either government or private industry.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 12 -With the victory of Skip Etchells and his boat Shillelah in the Star Class Atlantic Coast championship, the event next year logically would go to the Western Long Island Sound fleet, but there is a possibility it may not. Etchells is a member of the Larchmont Yacht Club.

PERHAPS the best of all testimonials to the beautifying effects of sufficient sleep is the fact that Hollywood stars are sound asleep long before midnight to look fresh and glamorous for work the next day. Many women, never on familiar terms with insomnia before, today are finding out that the tensions caused by working at top speed, or by worry, together with the summer heat, are exacting a heavy beauty toll in sleep-hours lost.
WASHINGTON, Aug 12 (AP) -Detroit spotted Washington four runs in the first inning and then went on to sweep the four-game series by winning tonight, 12 to 5.

Mail orders for better coats and suits were heavy last week and reorders were sizable for all types of merchandise, according to the market report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.
WILDWOOD, N.J., Aug. 12 -- A Boardwalk fire, the second in eight months, destroyed last night a business block, including a 1,000seat theatre. Ten persons were injured.

BUFFALO, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The New York Department of the American Legion recommended today that war veterans be represented at the peace table "to the end that American democracy in this republic be maintained and in order that the scourge of war be not again inflicted upon us."

LONDON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Hints of Hohenzollern complicity in the plot to kill Adolf Hitler are beginning to appear in German press comments on the hanging this week of Field Marshal Gen. Erwin von Witzleben and other officers in connection with the July 20 bombing.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Communique 126:

JOHN GOLDEN, who has been signing checks with such abandon lately, is getting ready to affix his signature to the five financial prizes he posted in the Third Naval District's one-act play contest. More than 200 scripts from men and women of the Navy, Coast Guard and Marine Corps came to the judges' committee, headed by Mr. Golden, and out of these the fortunate five have been selected.

SEATTLE, Aug. 12 (AP) -- It has been two and a half years since R.A. Rankin, boatswain's mate first class, and seventeen shipmates dodged the Japanese fleet and escaped after Corregidor fell, but the dreams of the 23-year-old sailor from Long Beach, Calif., still are nightmares and he calls out his shipmates' names in his sleep.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- Playing each shot with grim determination, Miss Dorothy Germain defeated Miss Phyllis Otto, 5 and 4, today to retain her women's Western amateur golf championship, an achievement not duplicated in the last twelve years.

UNITED STATES AIR BASE IN CHINA, Aug. 6 (delayed) -- Since Maj. John C. Herbst of Los Angeles will be all of thirty-five years old next month the boys of his squadron respectfully call him Pappy. Look closely and you can see a few gray edges in his dark hair.

THERE is apparently no connection between the appearance of Mr. Opdycke's "Say What You Mean" and the fact that this is a year of campaign oratory. Mr. Opdycke has been informing the public -- and scolding it in a nice way -- on correct writing and speech for a number of years.

A REPRINT edition of 450,000 copies of Betty Smith's "A Tree Grows in Brooklyn" will be issued by Doubleday tomorrow, just one year after publication, and while the novel is still high on best-seller lists. Harper's relinquished the book because of the drain on its paper quota: 500,000 copies (not counting the 400,000 Literary Guild copies) have been sold in this country.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

A study of the "Promotion of the Economy of Panama Through Post-War Immigration and Colonization" will be undertaken on Jan. 1, 1945, by the Institute of Social and Economic Research of the Inter-American University of Panama. The study will take into account all the principal aspects of the country's economic and social position.

CONEY ISLAND, some people will try to tell you, is not an island at all, and has not been since the little tidal creek that used to separate it from the mainland was filled in some years ago. Don't listen to any such sophistry. Irrespective of creeks and geographical hair-splitting, Coney is definitely an island; in fact, it is virtually a continent.

Obviously a sound post-war tax plan alone will not accomplish a complete peacetime restoration of full employment. Unless the pre-war policy of discouraging investment of risk capital is changed business is not unlikely to resume its indifferent course of the Nineteen Thirties.

A CHILD who steals, or breaks windows, or commits any other lawless act, may be taken to court and end up as a "delinquent." Another child may behave in this way and never have to tell it to the judge. He may not be apprehended in his sin, or if he is he may be protected -- the theft made good, the breakage paid for, the outraged property owner persuaded to withdraw the charge.

Alec Templeton, pianist, appearing before 10,500 persons at the Lewisohn Stadium last night, played the Mozart Concerto for piano in B flat major (Koechel 595) with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Alexander Smallens conducting, and later in the program almost "broke up the show" with his improvisations and inventions.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 7 (Delayed) -- Representatives of Arab States will meet during the last ten days of next month to discuss the calling of a congress to consider the formation of a league of Arab States.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 12 (AP) -- British troops who captured the strategic north Burmese railway town of Taungni, seventeen miles south of the former Japanese base of Mogaung, found it wrecked, with disease rampant and with so many dead Japanese that the Allied troops found it impossible to enter the city in force, a Chinese communique stated.

The Fisher Brothers, founders of the Fisher Body Company, which was acquired and became an important part of General Motors Corporation twenty-five years ago, made public ten days ago their decision to withdraw at last from an association which has endured over a quarter century.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- With imports of cork substantially increased in recent months, the War Production Board is studying a proposal to raise the monthly allocations of cork to industries, it announced today.

PRIZEFIGHT literature is in a class by itself. The number of ways in which the Big Fight can come out are small -- mathematically -- but a skillful literary contender can always come up at the end of round fifteen with still another surprise.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Distilleries of the country were working overtime this month to produce as much potable spirits for the thirsty throats of a nation at war as they possibly could within the thirty-one day span which the War Production Board has allowed in its "holiday" from the production of war alcohol.

THE Soviet Union's little people have paid a high price for the victory over Hitler's invaders. They are the innocents in this terrible struggle. But their innocence has not saved them from the destruction of their homes, their furniture and their household utensils and the loss of their clothing at the hands of the brutal, pillaging German soldiers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Invitations extended by Supreme Court Justice Frank Murphy to join the National Committee Against Persecution of the Jews have been accepted by 250 prominent Americans of almost every State, the committee announced today.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 11 (Delayed) (AP) --Rumanian political leaders under the Peasant party chief, Juliu Maniu, have formed a provisional peace government, according to information obtained today from a source in close contact with Budapest.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sunday, Aug. 13 -- The Germans reported yesterday that they had wheeled their forces around in the swift and fluid fighting southwest of Paris to combat the extremely menacing American armored thrust that was rapidly closing a circle around a large body of Field Marshal Gen. Guenther von Kluge's Seventh Army.

ROME, Aug. 12 -- The Germans have pulled out of Florence, releasing Italy's most beautiful city from a vise in which it had been clutched for a week as contending armies stood on opposite banks of the Arno River, which runs through it.

A CABLEGRAM from Moscow to J. H. Stolow says 30-kopecs, 50k, 60k, 1-ruble and 2r stamps are being issued this month to mark the centenary of the birth of Ilya Yefimovich Repin (1844-1930), painter and Professor of Historical Painting at the Academy of Fine Arts in St. Petersburg (Leningrad).

A return to the humanities and greater emphasis on liberal education are anticipated by college presidents throughout the United States when the war ends and higher education can "return to normal." At the same time, the college heads maintain that a proper balance will be needed between the pre-Pearl Harbor type of education and the technical and vocational schooling that will be demanded by former service men and women.
IT'S been tried and it works! This grand old show town came into its own during the season just closed, with application of methods similar to those in use by the concert platform for years.

Two of the largest cotton mills in the South will switch the major portion of their productive capacity to rayon spinning and weaving as soon as rayon staple is available, commission men in Worth Street reported yesterday. The action is the beginning of a trend away from cotton weaving which will cut total industry production as much as 50 per cent of normal pre-war years, they said.

OTTAWA, Aug. 12 -- To the already intricate situation between the Federal and the Provincial Governments in Canada and between these latter this week's events have added a new and significant complication. Superficially the political division of the country seems to have been increased.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The role of organized labor in the national political campaign is becoming clearer as the issues come into focus.

Proskauer, its president.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Official quarters were obviously disturbed by the report circulated this week in the magazine of the National Association of Manufacturers which stated that the British were desirous of having lend-lease aid continued to them after the war.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- Despite encouragement felt by big users of corn on estimates of a near-record yield, prospects indicate that the nation may again see a tight situation develop in the market.

YENAN, China, July 14 (Delayed) -- The People's Council of the Communist-created ShensiKansu-Ningsia border region is an elected body that legislates for itself and for the Border Region Administration, and the council's standing committee, which is meeting in Yenan, acts for it between sessions.

WHAT is the role of fear in battle? Three hundred Americans who fought with the Abraham Lincoln Brigade in Spain have cooperated with Dr. John Dollard and his assistant, Dr. Donald Horton, of the Institute of Human Relations of Yale University to find an answer to this question.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Legislation dealing with post-war problems will hold the right of way again next week in both Senate and House.

ONE of the most desirable of all perennials, yet one rarely seen in the average border of hardy plants is shrubby clematis. Why it is so seldom grown remains a mystery, for few garden favorites can boast greater hardiness even in low-temperature climates, higher resistance to insects and diseases, nicer adaptability to varying soil conditions or more abundant bloom.

IT seems that even some discriminating Germans have stopped believing Goebbels. However, some journalists in Allied countries apparently still believe in him. All old Spanish song well defines the various aspects of his falsehoods: "Some sing of what they know, others know about what they sing."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 12 -- A part from the inglorious hanging inflicted on rebel generals and Adolf Hitler's assurance that he was not afraid of "external enemies" the week inside the Reich has been marked by an intensification of Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels' campaign to have his fellow countrymen believe a miracle will save Germany.

In view of the persistent rumors going the rounds that the Yankees are about to be sold -one report insisting the transaction will be completed within three weeks -- Ed Barrow, president of the club, decided yesterday to issue a formal, signed statement.

ALBANY, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Less dependence by parents upon "educational fol-de-rol" and more upon "the old-fashioned woodshed" is recommended by the State Sheriffs Association as an antidote for juvenile delinquency.
STATISTICS are now piling in on the summer music seasons in various cities, and it appears that this summer, war or no war, has been an extremely musical one.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 12 -- A wartime sports policy for Princeton University, providing for intensification of the intramural program of athletics and the maintenance of informal intercollegiate teams in ten sports, was announced tonight by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 12 -- "At every referendum on amendment of the Australian Constitution I can remember," once said former Prime Minister Robert G. Menzies, "orators from a thousand platforms have displayed an almost diseased ingenuity in explaining the calamitous things the Commonwealth Parliament could do if it had the power to deal with matters now reserved to the States."

ALGIERS, Aug. 12 -- Members of the French Committee of National Liberation, who last night discussed at length the relation of France to the European settlement aproos of Rene Massigli's prospective journey to London, believe that, as a result of Gen. Charles de Gaulle's visit to Washington, France is about to be accepted into the circle of the great powers for diplomatic purposes.

Continuation of the downward trend in consumption of cotton and of the disinclination of mills to purchase substantial quantities of new crop cotton brought in yesterday enough liquidation in the futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange to check the rise in prices, and quotations on the close of trading were unchanged to 3 points lower than on Friday.

THE first murder victim in this story is Gerald Chase, a student at the Potter School for Boys. Sheriff Thad Shaw, once a student at the same school, investigates and encounters a curious reticence on the part of various persons who might have given him valuable information.

LONDON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Dr. G.J. van Heuver Goedhart, the new Netherlands Minister of Justice, promised "Dutch justice" tonight for collaborationists who have been "filling their pockets" working for the Germans or trading on the black market.

EDWARD G. ROBINSON, playing as a guest artist in an R.A.F. Film Unit film, paused between shots at Pinewood one day last week to deliver a spirited defense of the motion-picture people back home. A lady reporter, taking an afternoon off from flying bombs, had expressed a doubt that Hollywood was really in touch with modern life.

NO teacher is ever likely to forget the first year of her career -- the first awful stage fright, the conditions and personalities for which practice teaching hasn't prepared one, the unwilling sense of being a public character with no private life.

LONDON, Aug. 12 -- The robot bomb attacks on London's civilian population when it was obvious Germany had lost the war may prove the greatest psychological mistake the enemy has ever made, to judge by the growing demand in this country for reprisals and a hard peace.

LONDON, Aug. 12 -- High explosives rained down on the roads and railways, bridges and airports of German-occupied Europe today as the Allied Air Command carried into its sixth consecutive day an intensive assault on enemy communications.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 12 (AP) -With unions and truck operators giving complete cooperation, the Government moved rapidly tonight toward resumption of over-the-road freight service on 103 Midwestern lines by Monday.

MOST of us approach a new book on this country with much the same feeling we approach a fortune teller at a country fair. We are expectant, pleasantly excited, and slightly fearful -- but in general we go away with our vanity pleased by what we have been told.

AFEW plants of tarragon should be in everyone's garden, not only because its bright green is a cheerful sight but because it is a source of magnificent flavor. Tarragon has a thousand uses in cooking.

LONDON, Sunday, Aug. 13 -Two mighty Soviet armies yesterday began hammering a great wedge between East Prussia and embattled Warsaw, while other Russian troops smashed deeper into Estonia and Latvia in a drive to chop up Germany's trapped Baltic armies.

RENNES, France, Aug. 10 (Delayed) -- Built by the British before they were expelled from France in 1940 and used as a bomber base until last May by the Luftwaffe is a 1,000-acre airport on the outskirts of this city. As one soldier put it: "I hope the next change of tenancy here sees a revivified French air force in charge for the next hundred years."

AT last the American doughboy, wherever he may be overseas, is getting his ration of movies in an abundance which should fill his heart's desire. On an average, 2,000 film shows are played daily for our soldiers abroad, and the gripes which were voiced at the lack of movies are petering out.

LIEUT. LONNIE COLEMAN, author of "Escape the Thunder," is 23 years old now. He wrote this first novel in his senior year at the University of Alabama. One might have guessed something of this without the information on the jacket, for the first few chapters seem to set the familiar pattern of the undergraduate novel, a restatement of Greek tragedy in modern terms.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- In addition to injecting a sinister note into home front activities the arrest of these men in New Jersey by FBI agents this week on charges of building up a gigantic black market in nylon hose shocked a public prone to chaffing its women about their stylish nylon stockings, if any.

SERGEANT SKIDMORE'S setting for his first novel is a heavy bomber, the Harpie, a veteran of many actions in the Southwest Pacific. His cast is the bomber's crew of nine. WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -United States Army bombers will need more than 700,000 tons of high explosives the rest of this year. Since Jan. 1 472,000 tons have been dropped on German and Japanese targets.

ROME, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Fifteenth Air Force heavy bombers delivered a blistering attack on German military installations in the coastal areas of southern France today, following up an opening attack yesterday by the Tactical Com mand of the Mediterranean Allied Air Force.

Britain's plan for a new-type secondary school, in which boys and girls from 16 to 18 will "earn and learn," is a direct outgrowth of a war-learned lesson. Industrial, educational and military leaders have declared that all citizens of the future must be skilled in vocational work before they leave school.

TEN-MINUTE sprinklings, repeated every evening, may be very much the mode in watering Victory gardens, but they are not very effective. These brief, light wettings doubtless satisfy one's conscience that something has been done about drought, but they do not wet the soil and roots.

SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The expulsion of the final remaining Japanese from Northeastern India was imminent tonight with the Allied capture of the last large village on the Tiddim Road before the Burma border.

UNITED STATES ARMY HEADQUARTERS in India, Aug. 8 (Delayed) -- American airmen who bail out safely or who survive plane crashes over the wild jungle-covered mountains of the Hump route between Assam and China now have a 10-to-1 chance in their favor of getting back to fly again.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 12 -- Slowdowns by workers who limit the day's work done by themselves and fellow workers in some war plants are among the principal factors responsible for the current lag in production of equipment needed by the invasion forces in Europe and the Pacific, according to Cleveland manufacturers.

GROTON, Conn., Aug. 12 -- The Electric Boat Company, builder of submarines for the Navy, reported tonight that its employes had voted 6,334 to 1,717 against a strike called for 6 A.M. Monday by the Shipbuilding and Marine Engineers Union, independent.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -The destroyer escort Fiske was sunk by an enemy torpedo recently in the Atlantic, the Navy announced today.

One of the chief lies by which Hitler rose to power was his contention that Germany had lost the First World War from within and not from without -- that it had been "stabbed in the back." He has set forth this legend somewhat incoherently in the pages of "Mein Kampf."
LONDON, Aug. 12 -- The Atlantic has been crossed by air 20,000 times since the war began, it was announced today.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12 (AP) -Confusion in the Cleveland outfield gave the Athletics a 4-to-3 victory today and an even split with the Indians in their four-game series.

SCARBORO, Ont., Aug. 12 (AP) -Al Watrous, veteran professional golfer of Oakland Hills, Detroit, today won the $3,000 first prize in the $5,000 added Maple Leaf invitation open tournament. His total for the seventy-two holes was 280 -- four under par.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 12 -- Billy Southworth, whose Cardinals are winging their way to their third straight National League pennant, signed a contract today to manage the team though the 1945 and 1946 seasons. He is the first pilot of the Cardinals to receive a two-year contract from President Sam Breadon, who also departed from his usual custom in making such an early decision.

Through May, 1944, war contracts awarded in thirty-three major industrial areas have totaled $120,000,000,000, or more than $2,500 per capita, according to figures compiled by the National Industrial Conference Board. About 45,000,000 civilians live in these areas, which together have a per capita average of war contracts nearly twice the corresponding national average, the organization stated yesterday.

One of the difficult problems attending the use of penicillin has been the rapid elimination of this chemical from the body through the kidneys. This made it necessary to administer the drug at frequent intervals, which, in consequence, led to the requirement of rather large doses of this chemical.

AFTER his first experience as a radio actor, T/Sgt. Joseph Patrick Richey, former tail gunner of the Eighth Air Force Flying Fortress Shackeroo, thought maybe he preferred combat flying to broadcasting. The 20-year-old sergeant, who wears the Distinguished Flying Cross and the Air Medal with three clusters, tossed aside his script and signed with relief.

QUEBEC -- The Quebec Provincial Exhibition, which gets under way the beginning of September, promises to be one of the biggest events of its kind this year. It replaces the widely known Toronto Exhibition during the war, for the latter event has suspended operations until hostilities are over.

WHEN you eat at a restaurant these days it is a moot question exactly who is the waiter. You wait for a table. You get a table. Then you wait for the waiter. First you try being meek; then when you think you've caught the waiter's eye you venture a cajoling smile, and finally but futilely, anguished with hunger, you bark: "I've been waiting here a half hour!"

CAIRO, Aug. 12 -- In April, 1940, when he was still commanding France's Levantine army from his Beirut headquarters Gen. Maxime Weygand told a high-ranking British officer who now holds a very important position in the Middle Eastern Command: "Mark my words, the end of the war will come in the Balkans, although the final battle may not necessarily be fought there."

Despite the heat wave and Wall Street absenteeism prices held firm yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange and managed to add fractions. Volume was the smallest for a two-hour session in two weeks; 374,470 shares against 463,130 a week earlier.

DEBUSSY'S last work, the Sonata No. 3 for Violin and Piano, has been recorded for Columbia by Joseph Szigeti, violinist, and Andor Foldes, pianist (album X-MX-242, two twelve-inch records). It is a brief work, and in many ways a cryptic one, but the Messrs. Szigeti and Foldes have recorded it convincingly and with authority.

A BOMBER BASE, in England, Aug. 12 (AP) -- What with putting the wong end of Russian cigarettes in their mouths and having the tears brought to their eyes by vodka, the Americans who flew on the second three-way shuttle flight to Russia and Italy found it took a while to get acclimated in a strange country.

FROM now through most of October lower-quality beef will be plentiful and, to a lesser extent, lower-quality veal and lamb. Such meat may be identified by meager amounts of fat -- in other words, it does not have that good intermingling of fat and lean to be found in top-quality cuts, which gives them a streaked appearance called marbling.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 12 (U.P.) -- The battle in the suburbs of Leiyang has raged to new intensity, with Chinese troops fighting desperately to stem the Japanese advance south along the Canton-Hankow railway in Hunan Province, the Chinese High Command reported tonight.

LONDON, Sunday, Aug. 13 (Reuter) -- The Moscow radio broadcast a statement early today saying that full responsibility for the revolt in Warsaw "lies with Polish circles in London, who have not thought to coordinate it with the Soviet high command."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -The Federal Communications Commission issued subpoenas today for certain radio scripts by Upton Close, Fulton Lewis Jr., Boake Carter, DeWitt Emery, Sheelah Carter and Col. Robert McCormick, which were broadcast over Station WHKC, Columbus, Ohio.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Opportunities for greater use of prisoners of war are limited, according to a report of the War Department made public today by James F. Byrnes, Director of War Mobilization.
IRUN, Spain, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Southwestern France was reported almost bare of German troops today.

STATISTIC: The Treasury totted up last week the amount of money in circulation and reached an all-time high -- $22,726,812,783. Based on a population of 138,121,000 it was enough to provide -- in theory -- every citizen with $164.54.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -The Army admitted tonight that two motion pictures it had said were banned from distribution to troops were never even considered for distribution and disclosed that its list of forbidden books had grown to fifteen, including Raymond Clapper's "Watching the world."

THOMAS MANN, whose character delineations usually run to no less than 5,000 words, established his all-time record in terseness when once he described his friend Thomas Mitchell simply as "earthy." Mitchell, the actor, playwright, director, art collector and champion of the Elizabethan word craftsmen, likes that description.

ETHEL BARRYMORE, seldom heard on the radio, has signed for a series of half-hour dramatic broadcasts, entitled "Lighted Windows," to be heard at 3:30 P.M. Sundays, beginning Sept. 17, over the WJZ-Blue network. The series will portray the effects of the war on an American family.

AMERICAN motion pictures have staged a triumphal comeback on Roman theatre screens, and once more the people are putting up photographs of their favorite stars and buying movie fan magazines like hotcakes. DURING the hot, dry days of midsummer, when the garden is practically devoid of flowers, the gay, colorful blossoms of the gladiolus are especially welcome. CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- American business men and Washington officials, confronted with the knotty problem of reconversion, have shown keen interest in a plan started here this week by the Chicago Association of Commerce to assist industrial firms in obtaining prompt settlement of canceled war contracts.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 12 -- Two events of the past week have focused the attention of Midwesterners quite strongly on one of their long-time major problems, transportation.

Erwin Rommel plotted his futile anti-invasion plans in the same stately stone chateau and at the same table where Gen. John J. Pershing worked in World War I and where British Army headquarters was located for a time early in this war.

German resistance on the Eastern Front stiffened materially last week, but the Allied offensive in the west moved into the plains of Paris and the Germans were reported to be evacuating all of southwestern France.

On the other side a group of American officers fingered pencils, looked at a list of names and puzzled over the language the fishermen spoke. In the middle a tall naval lieutenant, neither uneasy nor puzzled, shifted from French to English as he talked first to one group and then the other.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (U.P.) -Relief which appeared in view tonight for certain classes of "B" book motorists may be the only relaxation of gasoline rationing until some months after the end of the European war.

PAWLING, N.Y., Aug. 12 -Governor Dewey began today the writing of his campaign speeches, the first of which he is expected to deliver early in September.

ROME, Aug. 13 -- Prime Minister Churchill's presence in Italy is causing considerable stir in Rome. He appeared on the Italian battlefront on the same day the last Germans were cleared out of Florence, two months after the liberation of Rome and on the eve of the transfer of the Rome area from AMG to Italian rule.

OTTAWA, Aug. 13 -- Canadian exports are expected to run to approximately $3,000,000,000 this year and to maintain at least a portion of that business and avoid a sudden slump after the war the Canadian Parliament has passed a measure of Export Credit Insurance.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 13 -- Still struggling against manpower shortages, heat and other production problems, the steel industry last week was able to maintain steel output at 97 per cent of rated capacity.
