The Goldman Band, Dr. Edwin Franko Goldman conducting, concluded its twenty-seventh season of summer concerts on the Mall in Central Park last night. The concert, the 1,577th of the series, opened with Moszkowski's "Moorish March," followed by numbers by Verdi, Bach, Wagner, Rossini, Goldman, Gliere and Liszt.
ROME, Aug. 13 (AP) -- A communique:

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- Prospects of a large movement of oats in the Northwest and favorable news from Europe resulted last week in a break of around 3 cents a bushel in futures on the Board of Trade, all deliveries selling at a new seasonal low before the selling movement ran its course.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force. Aug. 13 (AP) -- Communique 127:

BOSTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- In dramatic fashion the second-place Red Sox rushed in a raw rookie pitcher to defeat the first-place Browns, 7 -- 6, in the opening thirteen-inning game of a double-header today and then bowed to the league leaders, 6 -- 1, in the second five-inning game.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, called upon the workers of his organization today to increase production of the vital war materials needed by the armed forces.

Playing a relatively more important part in building activity today than it did a year ago, private construction gradually is getting back to the pre-war position it occupied before publicly financed projects crowded it out of the field, according to a survey of the F.W. Dodge Corporation, fact-finding organization in the construction industry.
ROME, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Bandolfo Pacciardi, a leading figure in the Republican party, reiterated today a suggestion heard on all sides that the British were supporting the monarchy.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- Ceiling prices continue to prevail for cash corn, and the best posted interests in the grain trade say there is little or no prospect of a decline for some time to come, some professing to believe that the 1944 crop will start to move at the maximum level, especially until more is known regarding the size of this year's crop and whether farmers will sell freely.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (U.P.) -- New techniques developed to safeguard the health of soldiers have cut the Army's death rate from disease to 20 per cent of total deaths, the lowest in history, the War Department said tonight.
Mrs. Jeanette Dickie Bogle has rented a private house at 184 East Ninety-third Street through Culver, Hollyday Co.

It is a year this month of August since William Lyon Phelps died; and, as was expected, we have found no one to equal or approach him in his one great, unique quality: his tremendous capacity for appreciation.

Picking up tonight where it left off on July 1 is "The Two Mrs. Carrolls," starring Elisabeth Bergner, at the Booth. When the Martin Vale (Mrs. Bayard Veiller) melodrama, one of last season's surprise hits, suspended in order to allow the star to rest up from her arduous duties, the attraction had attained a run of 383 performances.
Only two new films are scheduled to arrive at midtown theatres this week. The programs are:

WITH THE BRITISH ARMY in France, Aug. 13 -- We are paying the Germans back tonight with compound interest for every bloody blow they struck at our columns plodding to Dunkerque more than four years ago.

Figures showing that war orders received by the automotive industry have far exceeded cutbacks, were revealed yesterday by the Automotive Council for War Production. Since the invasion began, the industry has produced one and a half times the number of tanks previously scheduled.

The execution last week of Field Marshal Erwin von Witzleben and seven other German Army officers convicted of complicity in the "plot" against Adolf Hitler has only one precedent in modern military history: the execution in 1937 of Marshal Mikhail Tukhachevsky, then Vice Commissar of Defense of the Russian Army.

PEARL HARBOR, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Admiral Nimitz, just returned from a Guam-Saipan inspection trip and conferences with Vice Admiral Marc A. Mitscher, Vice Admiral Richmond Kelley Turner and Maj. Gen. Roy S. Geiger of the Marine Corps and others, said that he was anxious to move his headquarters to a fighting area.

Undismayed by Mayor La Guardia's letter ousting the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals from its recently established quarantine station for dogs in the Elton Avenue bathhouse building, Bronx Borough President James J. Lyons urged in a letter to the Mayor yesterday that the city continue to cooperate with the society "whole-heartedly in their humane objectives" until the Legislature has given the city jurisdiction.

The third spectacular fire in the metropolitan area in three days destroyed more than half of Palisades Amusement Park yesterday afternoon, causing damage estimated at $500,000, sending to hospitals nineteen persons, six of whom were listed as seriously injured, and bringing lesser injuries to 100 others, half of them firemen overcome by smoke.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 13 -- Myron Friedman, 29-year-old Newark defense plant worker, today became the holder of the New Jersey State amateur championship through one of the most startling upsets ever registered in Garden State golf history.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Royalties of $14,529 given to the American Red Cross from the first four months' sales of "Lend-Lease, Weapon for Victory" by Under-Secretary of State Edward R. Stettinius Jr. will be used to send medical supplies to prisoners of war in German and Japanese hands, it was announced today by Basil O'Connor, chairman of the Red Cross.

Upholstered furniture, as the moderns design it, is more than likely to be sectional furniture. But although the terms "sectional" and "modern" are almost synonymous, there is no law that says the simple lines and versatile arrangements of sectional pieces would not be just as much at home in an otherwise traditional room.
LONDON, Aug.. 13 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin:

Technically, the process of milking a cow is a method by which the lacteal fluid is extracted. But that is an insufficient explanation to the countryman who likes his cows. In most big herds, and in small ones, an electrical machine has taken over the job. There are some 25,000,000 cows in the United States, and perhaps half of them are on the family-size farms where the cows are milked by hand.

GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Monday, Aug. 14 (AP) -- In the fourth Philippines raid within five days, a night-ranging Liberator sank a 3,000-ton Japanese freighter in Mindanao Island's Davao Gulf early Saturday, headquarters announced today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Before a sweltering throng of more than 46,000 fans, the West team trimmed the East squad, 7 -- 4, at Comiskey Park today in the twelfth annual Negro All-Star baseball game, to square the series at 6-all.

Members of the armed forces who willingly give their bodies to preserve the ideals of the spirit and soul, understand the Christian concept of "the mission of the body," Mgr. Joseph F. Flannelly, administrator of St. Patrick's Cathedral, declared at solemn mass there yesterday. He denounced "body-consciousness" as "a fundamental error of those without religion."

The Hawkesworth twins, William and James, 10 years old, who ran away from the Mission of the Immaculate Virgin, at Pleasant Plains, Staten Island, over the affection of their pet dog Whitey, received more bad news yesterday when they were told they could not keep the pet at the institution.
GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Monday, Aug. 14 (AP) -- A communique:

WITH AMERICAN ARMY IN FRANCE, Aug. 13 (AP) -- In every sort of military vehicle, withdrawing German forces were racing back toward Paris tonight before the sustained and powerful advance of Lieut. Gen. Omar N. Bradley's American forces along the clawlike arched front extending from the Vire region to Mortain.

ROME, Aug. 13 -- While Empoli, Arno River city 15 miles west of Florence, fell to the British Eighth Army, in Florence itself Partisans and Fascists equipped mainly with small arms, continued their deadly quarrel throughout yesterday, with small detachments engaging each other in open squares and side streets.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 13 -Using a jeep at Camp Smith here today Representative Walter G. Andrews of Buffalo, chairman of the House Military Affairs Committee, as guest of Brig. Gen. Anson C. Goodyear, commander of the Second Brigade.

BARI, Italy, Aug. I3 (AP) -- A reliable and seemingly unprejudiced observer said today that Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch, ousted War Minister of the Yugoslav Government in Exile accused of being a collaborationist, actually moved his headquarters every few days to frustrate repeated German efforts to capture him.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The Taft amendment to the OPA Act, which precludes use of Department of Agriculture grades on canned foods, is worded to permit the OPA to set clothing standards for a broader system of dollar and cents ceilings, in the opinion of the OPA consumer advisory committee, according to Mrs. Esther Cole Franklin, new consumer relations advisor to OPA and executive secretary of the committee.
CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- Teachers from all parts of the country are assembling here for the four-day annual convention of the American Federation of Teachers, which opens tomorrow.
THERE'VE been some changes made in the football coaching picture since last fall, and one of them involves a figure in the New York scene for nearly fifteen years.

Cotton prices in the domestic market last week improved moderately, principally on mill and trade price-fixing operations. At the close on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed for the period net gains of 18 to 24 points.

Tomorrow the Ways and Means Committee of the House is scheduled to begin a study of the George amendment to the Social Security Act, adopted by the Senate on Friday by a vote of 55 to 19. Proponents of the Murray-Kilgore bill, which was superseded in the Senate by the George amendment, will try in the House to pass a bill offered by Representative Celler which is similar to the Murray-Kilgore measure.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 13 (UP) -- German Maj. Gen. Ritter von Elber von Dawams and eighteen officers believed to be members of his staff were killed June 10 by a Royal Air Force Mitchell bomber attack on what was believed to be Nazi Panzer headquarters south of Caen, it was revealed today.

BARI, Italy, Aug. 6 (Delayed) (AP) -- The National Army of Liberation in Albania, now 40,000 strong, is badly in need of more arms and ammunition, Col. Bedri Spahui, head of its mission to the Allies, reported today.

An emigre from one of the small countries that have suffered greatly from Nazi occupation once said to me that what this nation of ours enjoys most is an excellent press. He was impressed by the freedom and the objectivity with which our newspapers cover their daily assignments.

The heads of two large American rubber companies, who had been in London attending important discussions on rubber, were among the eight transatlantic passengers who arrived at La Guardia Field aboard a Pan American Airways clipper last night.
WITH BRITISH FORCES in Normandy, Aug. 13 (AP) -- A British staff general, recapitdlating today what he termed a very good week, said the Germans were now jumping to our tune.

William E. Gluskin, previously with the sales department of the Manhattan Shirt Company, has been named associate manager of the sportswear division. Lou Rapp in future will devote his full time to the management of the neckwear division.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 13 -- There were eighty-five competitors out on Long Island Sound today in the championship series regatta of the Huguenot Yacht Club, equaling the previous high mark of the year other than in Larchmont Race Week.

WITH AMERICAN TROOPS Besieging St. Malo Citadel, Aug. 12 (Delayed) (AP) -- Stubborn Col. Andreas von Aulock and the German garrison still held on to their redoubtable seagirt fortress in St. Malo harbor tonight after a picked American assault group reached the inner wall of the rocky citadel but was unable to crack an entrance.

LONDON, Aug. 13 -- The stock-markets here made an unexpectedly enthusiastic response to the good news from Normandy and for two days after the Bank Holiday on Monday an unusually high number of bargains was recorded when allowance was made for the fact that a large part of the country was holiday-making. Thereafter until the week-end quieter conditions prevailed, with here and there some reaction.

A product that should prove popular with the novice in the kitchen, as well as with the busy housewife whose family always craves dessert, is a new lemon-flavored filling called Cloverbrook. The jelly-like substance comes ready to use except for a few minutes of heating in the top of a double boiler until it is soft enough to pour.

LONDON, Monday, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The Partisan forces of Marshal Tito in an offensive in central Serbia are closing on the rail town of Krusevae and advanced units have slashed German communications, a Free Yugoslav communique said today.

PEARL HARBOR, Aug. 13 (U.P.) -- United States land-based aircraft blasted Japanese installations over a 3,000-mile Pacific front from the Kuriles to the Carolines and the Marshalls on Thursday and Friday, pounding shipping, airfields and defense areas, it was announced today.

Justifying the Polish underground army's fight against the Nazi forces in Warsaw, Sylwin Strakacz, Polish Minister Plenipotentiary and Consul General of Poland here, yesterday declared "the Pole does not want to be liberated, he wants to liberate himself."

About 25,000 idle drivers in eight midwestern states are ready to start over-the-road trucks rolling again today, according to word received by The Associated Press from a closed meeting in Minneapolis yesterday of 103 operators of trucks seized by the Government on Saturday.

After moving downward for a week or two, with an eye to post-war readjustment, last week, the stock market slowly advanced. Transactions were somewhat larger than of late, three days crossing the million-share mark again. Recovery was slow, however, and concentration on some special groups of stocks reflected little general outside participation.

During the past week the commodity market was relatively inactive. The changes that occurred, however, influenced the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices sufficiently to cause it to rise to a new all-time high of 113.08.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- In an open letter to Production Chief Donald M. Nelson, Dr. Willard H. Dow, president of the Dow Chemical Company, asserted tonight that it was "the plain duty of the War Production Board to remove at once all controls" from the magnesium industry.

AN EIGHTH AIR FORCE FIGHTER BASE, England, Aug. 13 -- Their eyes red-rimmed with the strain of searching northern France for "anything that moved," P-47 Thunderbolt pilots dropped one by one onto the runways of their field here late this afternoon to describe a small part of the intensive air assault launched against the Nazi army in the field.

SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Burmese and Chinese troops pushing deeper into North Burma from the captured Japanese base at Myitkyina toward Bhamo have occupied the village of Kazu, twenty miles south of Myitkyina, a Southeast Asia Command communique announced today.

LONDON, Monday, Aug. 14 (U.P.) -- The Moscow radio today quoted German Field Marshal Gen. Friedrich von Paulus, who was captured when his Sixth Army surrendered at Stalingrad, as having told his fellow-captives that Germany had completely lost the war, since the "Red Army * * * has already reached the East Prussian border and Anglo-American troops in France have broken German defenses and come out on a broad operational area."

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Aug. 13 -- Walter Reid Jr. of Allenhurst, president of Charms Company and Tastyeast, Inc., has purchased the twelve-story Electric Building at 501 Grand Avenue, his attorney, Richard W. Stout, revealed here today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 13 -- Mike Turnesa, host club pro, and Harry Miller, last pair home in a field of thirty-three teams, posted 31, 32 -- 63, seven below par, to win the second annual member-pro tournament by a stroke at the Knollwood Country Club today.

More than 800 medically discharged veterans are working in the shops, lofts and offices of the New York Navy Yard in Brooklyn, according to an announcement from the office of the Commandant of the Third Naval District yesterday.

PROCESSED FOODS (various canned or bottled vegetables, fruits, fruit juices, soups, baby foods, jams, jellies and other special products, and certain dried beans.) Blue stamps A$ through ZS, also A5 through F5 in War Book 4, good indefinitely at 10 points each. Stamps B5 through F5 are valid indefinitely. Frozen fruits and vegetables and dried fruits now point-free.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Snapping a five-game losing streak, the Senators Swept a double-header from the Indians, 2 -- 1 and 4 -- 1, today.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 13 -- The Giants ran their record to six straight reverses in a double bill against the Reds on Crosley Field today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -The Maritime Commission announced today that six manufacturing companies had received the "M" award for production for the Victory Fleet and that nine other companies now flying "M" pennants had received gold star renewal awards.
WITH THE EIGHTH ARMY IN FLORENCE, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Italian Partisans were relentlessly cleaning up the city street by street today.

LONDON, Monday, Aug. 14 -- The Allies' Italy-based air fleets struck additional blows yesterday against the defenses of the jittery Nazis spread thinly along the French Mediterranean coast. Before Sunday dawn the Royal Air Force returned to saturation attacks on German aircraft and armament industries, cascading 2,400 tons of bombs on the vital centers of Brunswick in the northwest and Ruesselsheim in the southwestern Reich.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 13 (AP) -- With Frankie Colman, a regular for less than a week, batting in the winning run in both games, the Pirates took two from the Braves today, 8 to 1 and 3 to 1. The victories were the twelfth for Rip Sewell and the eleventh for Fritzie Ostermueller.

LONDON, Monday, Aug. 14 (U.P.) -- In an editorial on the forthcoming international security conference, the Times of London outlined today three major world spheres of influence likely to be dominated separately by Britain, the United States and Russia.

MONT ST. MICHEL, France, Aug. 13 -- It is a paradox, but the deeper we get into France, the less real this war seems. That is because now our columns are slashing so swiftly in wide, audacious swings that great areas of the country are being liberated intact.

LONDON, Aug. 13 -- It is asked in the United States, will economic conditions in Great Britain be affected by the war. There is, of course, a much wider subject of post-war world conditions but it is as much as the city can tackle at present to attempt to visualize conditions as they may develop at home.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Monday, Aug. 14 -- Elements of two German armies in northwestern France, the Fifth and the Seventh, have started to break and run under relentless fire from thousands of Allied aircraft.

It pays to be a Christian, but only in so far as the benefit derived extends from one's self to mankind, the Rev. Dr. Theodore C. Speers declared in a sermon yesterday in Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street.

Common courtesy demands an expression of gratitude for what we enjoy, and after long delight in the nature editorials which appear from time to time upon your editorial page, I write to say a sincere thank you to those who write them. May they live long and retire to live in the country!

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Detroit and Philadelphia divided a double-header today with the Athletics, snapping the Tigers' nine-game winning streak by taking the first, 6 -- 1, and bowing to Detroit, 6 -- 0, in the second game.

The tragedy and devastation of war will not have been in vain if as a consequence of this war mankind finds new faith in the strength of the spiritual, declared the Rev. Dr. M. Stephen James, Professor of Preaching at the New Brunswick Theological Seminary, yesterday in the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

Leo Brecher, who last week filed plans for a seven-story theatre building on the property at Sixth Avenue and Fifty-third Street he acquired from the Mutual Life Insurance Company, has purchased the five-story store and apartment building at 555-57 Madison Avenue from the Greenwich Savings Bank.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 13 -- The mighty Wehrmacht, which astonished the world with the speed and efficiency of its blitzkrieg, has been jolted to a stand-still in France by the most sustained and devastating air assault ever made upon an army in the field.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- Traders in wheat continue to act with caution as a result of highly conflicting influences in the market. The Department of Agriculture estimated last week that the yield of wheat this year would be 1,132,000,000 bushels, a new high record.

ALBANY, Aug. 13 -- Plans for developing and promoting a regional handicrafts program for off-season work of residents of various communities in the Adirondack region will be discussed at a conference at Paul Smith's College, Paul Smith's, on Thursday, under the auspices of Oakley Furney, assistant commissioner for vocational education in the State Education Department.

LONDON, Aug. 13 -- A post-war Germany shorn of East Prussia, Pomerania, Silesia and the left bank of the Rhine and required to contain within her narrowed frontiers at least 10,000,000 Germans transferred from these amputated territories seems to be emerging from the declarations of policy made by Allied politicians recently.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (U.P.) -- A study of Korea to be published tomorrow by the American Council on Public Affairs charges that the Pacific war is being impeded because the United Nations have declined the cooperation of the Provisional Korean Government and its underground movement.

ALGIERS, Aug. 13 -- The apparent decision of Allied military authorities to repatriate French prisoners of war from Germany within some seven months after the armistice caused dismay here today for several reasons.

IF George Bancroft, America's first great historian, could look upon the world today he would not only be shocked and dismayed, he would be bewildered and surprised. For the last eighty of the ninety-one years of his busy, tireless, distinguished life he believed firmly "that humanity is steadily advancing, that the advance of liberty and justice is certain."

LONDON, Aug. 13 -- The Financial News' index of thirty industrial shares based on July 1, 1935, as 100 was 116.8 this week as compared with 116.6 last week, 113.9 last month, 104.6 and 77.5 last year. Since the beginning of the war last year's low of 94.1 was on Jan. 4 and last year's high was 106.1 on Oct. 1.

A 70-year-old woman was severely beaten in a desperate struggle yesterday afternoon to resist the advances made by a 20-year-old youth who, police charge, entered the woman's apartment with the intention of robbery, then attempted rape.

Towering flames from the Palisades Amusement Park fire slowed traffic on the West Side Highway yesterday as thousands of motorists paused to watch the spectacle. More thousands of spectators lined Riverside Drive, crowded the roofs of apartment houses from Ninety-sixth Street to the George Washington Bridge, and craned necks from house windows.

Despite the complacent refusal of many Christians to take sides in the moral issue ever present between God and the world, the Christian church can become a mighty engine for the building of a new society, declared the Rev. Dr. Bernard Iddings Bell of Providence, R.I., in a sermon yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Great expansion of American world trade is to be expected after the war unless the period is allowed to become one of "economic nationalism, quasi-isolationism and narrowly regarded self-sufficiency," says a report of the Foreign Policy Association issued today.

Carl Van Doren, whose "Benjamin Franklin" won the Pulitzer Prize for biography in 1939, has taken Franklin's famous biography, which tells his life story only up to 1757 (he lived until 1790), and added to it letters and other personal writings to fill out the years up to 1757 and contnue it through the years after 1757.

ADVANCED BASE, Marshall Islands, Aug. 10 (Delayed) (AP) -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz made a surprise visit to this base today and brought a surprise gift to Vice Admiral Marc A. Mitscher, commander of the world's most deadly carrier force.

A concert tonight on the Mall in Central Park will bring to a close a week-end celebration of the twentieth anniversary of WNYC, the municipal radio station. Mayor La Guardia will speak during the intermission of a program by a special symphony orchestra of sixty-five members assembled for the occasion with Edwin McArthur as conductor.

Anyone in the crowd of 27,460 persons at the Stadium yesterday would have thought, after watching rookie Mel Queen humble the White Sox, 10-1, in the opener, that Hank Borowy, ace of the Yankees, would have no trouble at all in the afterpiece.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (AP) -- With Ron Northey hitting his fourteenth homer in the opener and clearing loaded bases with a double in the afterpiece, the Phillies rose up to nip the Cubs twice today, 3 to 2 and 7 to 6, before 38,576 fans.

LONDON, Aug. 13 (Reuter) -- While Lord Beaverbrook is in the United States conducting informal discussions on post-war international aviation, the independent committee in Britain that last year produced a report on the future of civil aviation had issued a second report.

Immortality means not life after death but a never ending living through the influence we exercise in the development of character, Bishop Bruce R. Baxter of the Portland (Ore.) Methodist area declared in a sermon yesterday in the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and West Forty-ninth Street.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 13 (Reuter) -- Gen. Helge Jung, Commander in Chief of the Swedish armed forces, is being sued for libel by the Swedish Nazi paper Dagsposten, which he recently banned from all officers messes and military depots.
CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 13 -- The 13,000-ton heavy cruiser Fall River was launched into the Delaware River today from the ways of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation.
PEARL HARBOR, Aug. 13 -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz said today that we might be able to force Japan to surrender without invading her homeland islands.

Department store advertising expenses in relation to net sales dropped during 1943 to the lowest figure in fifteen years an examination of department store data compiled by the Bureau of Business Research of Harvard University revealed yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The Athletics unleashed a five-run barrage in the fourth inning and then pushed across two more tallies in the fifth to turn back the Tigers, 7 -- 5, tonight behind the eight-hit pitching of Bobo Newsom.

Trustees for the Central Railroad of New Jersey filed yesterday in Newark, N.J., a petition in the Federal Court asking the court to find that a recent ruling of the New Jersey Court of Errors and Appeals does not invalidate the Railroad Tax Settlement Acts of 1941 and 1942 as they pertain to this railroad.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force Advance Command Post in Normandy, Aug. 13 (Delayed) -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower told his forces today they had created a "fleeting but definite opportunity" for a major victory and that this week would be "a brilliant" and fruitful week for us, a fateful one" for the Nazis.

ALBANY, Aug. 14 (U.P.) -- The State Health Department's Division of Communicable Diseases disclosed today that the 1,222 cases of infantile paralysis reported since the start of the current epidemic were still far below the records set twenty-eight years ago.

Mayor La Guardia and four former city commissioners of plant and structures who had charge of Radio Station WNYC during their terms joined last night in tributes to Morris S. Novik, director of the municipal broadcasting station, at the fourth and final night of WNYC's celebration of its twentieth anniversary on the Mall in Central Park.

Five football rules, including that on the out-of-bounds kick-off, were revised yesterday by the executive committee of the Eastern Intercollegiate Football Association at a special meeting held in the Central Office for Intercollegiate Athletics in the Hotel Biltmore.

Reflecting the rise in gross sales over the comparative period a year ago, the Sinclair Oil Corporation announced yesterday in its report to stockholders covering the first half of this year, that the net profit increased to $15,364,205 from $9,536,952 last year.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 14 per cent for the week ended Aug. 12, in comparison with the like week of last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the previous week the bank had reported an increase of 10 per cent in sales.

ROME, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The Mediterranean Air Force, striking at southern France for the third successive day, hit hard at bridges over the Rhone and coastal installations yesterday, it was announced today.

Inflationary trends have been carefully curbed in the revised MPR-208 order of the Office of Price Administration, which will be released on Thursday, industry spokesmen declared yesterday, and the President's "hold-the-line" order will not be broken. The revision will take the place of all previous price orders covering work clothing, it is reported, with pricing procedure described at manufacturing, wholesaling and retailing levels.

Play in the Negro national tennis championships started at the Cosmopolitan courts yesterday with competition in men's and women's singles opening the week-long program. A total of eighty-four players made up the men's singles list, while thirty-nine were scheduled to participate in the women's singles.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The reconversion of industry from war to civilian output moved its longest step forward today when Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, issued his order empowering local production and manpower officials to permit the manufacture of long-unavailable civilian articles on the basis of local material and labor conditions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The American Jewish Conference submitted to the State Department today a four-point "International Bill of Rights" with the request that it be put before the four-power conference on post-war and international security scheduled to meet here next Monday.

GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, in the Southwest Pacific, Tuesday, Aug. 15--Gen. Douglas MacArthur's bombers have "practically neutralized" the Japanese airdromes on Halmahera Island, headquarters announced today.
The German Army, despite disastrous defeats in Russia and in France, is still a coherent fighting force, which is on the whole well led, well-equipped and well-trained.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expenditionary Force, Aug. 14 -- The story of the Eighth Air Force Fighter Command's systematic destruction of Nazi supply and communication lines to the front west of Paris last week was told here today by one of the men responsible for the success of the campaign.

The President has directed the Navy to take over nominal control of five machine shops in San Francisco where an A.F. of L. machinists' lodge had defied War Labor Board orders to cease a ban on overtime and Sunday work. WLB merely wished individual workers to be allowed to make their own choice without Fear of union penalty.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -The War Food Administration announced today that the wheat acreage goal for 1945 is about 68,500,000 acres, or 1,900,000 acres more than that planted for harvest this year.

THIRD ARMY HEADQUARTERS, France, Aug. 14 (AP) -- On Aug. 1 the United States Third Army's tanks took off on a roundup attack against the Germans, still brilliantly progressing after two weeks of ceaseless advance.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Communique 128:

Jacob A. Latona, New York State Commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, said yesterday that a stormy debate on the right of women to join the VFW was expected at the national convention to be held in Chicago from Aug. 22 to 24.

SPOKANE, Wash., Aug. 14 (AP) -- Little Freddie Annon, one of the dark horse contenders among the country's golf professionals, scrambled around the Manito course in below par fashion today to lead a classy field in the first round of the 36-hole qualifying test for the 1944 National P.G.A. championship.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The people of France were summoned today by Gen. Charles de Gaulle's French Committee of National Liberation to strike for their freedom with a general uprising against the Germans, whose hold on the country is weakening under Allied blows.

MORTAIN, France, Aug. 12 (Delayed) -- This ancient town of some 1,500 persons is a French counterpart of any United States "Stringtown on the Pike." Except for its Thirteenth Century Gothic church and its happy location in The Gorge of the Canoe it would lie unnoticed even by tourists, for it happens to be just one long street slightly off the beaten track.

Clearing up a tangled situation that has kept alive charges by exporters that lend-lease shipments were being re-exported by Great Britain to markets where import controls prevented American exporters from trading, Leo T. Crowley, administrator of the Foreign Economic Administration, has advised traders that India has been re-opened as a market for American printing inks, it was learned yesterday.
CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 14 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

Despite limits on the weight, color and amount of paper used, traditional calling cards and wedding and birth announcements are still holding their own. There has, in fact, been an increase of well over 70 per cent in orders for wedding announcements, although the ones currently being mailed out are usually 4 1/2 by 5 inches instead of 5 1/2 by 8 and are cloaked in one envelope instead of two.

LONDON, Aug. 14 -- French railway issues were marked up a point and other European bonds responded to the favorable war news on the stock market here today. Polish issues also gained a point. Generally, the market was firm at the opening but business became quiet and there was some profit-taking industrials after the weekend orders were filled.

Whether a 14-year-old photographer's model can legally pose without working papers was the point at issue yesterday in Yorkville Court. The case was adjourned until Sept. 11 by Magistrate William Klapp, however, because Patrolman George S. McClancy of the midtown squad, whose vigilance last month brought up the problem, was absent on sick leave.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 14 -- Carrying out the Presidential order, Rear Admiral Harold G. Bowen, accompanied only by his staff, took formal possession of five machine shops here today, posted official orders and announced that everybody on the payrolls was now "a civilian employe of the United States Government."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- In a free-hitting and wild base-running contest, Washington made it three in a row over Cleveland tonight, 8 -- 5. Roger Wolff and Steve Gromek faced each other to start, but Wolff was relieved after three innings and Gromek after five.

FLORENCE, Aug. 14 (Canadian Press) -- The central part of Florence lying north of the Arno River remained an inhabited "no man's land" today with partisans mopping up snipers at a cost to date of 100 killed and 300 wounded.

ALGIERS, Aug. 14 -- Commenting on President Roosevelt's address of Saturday, Gen. Charles de Gaulle, head of the French Committee of National Liberation, today compared American concern for security in the Pacific with French concern for security on the Rhine.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- By President Roosevelt's direction, the Navy Department seized today five machine shops in the San Francisco area where refusal of an AFL machinists' union to permit a work week longer than forty-eight hours has impeded production of Diesel engines for ships and landing craft.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Soviet Russia has proposed to the United States and Great Britain the creation of a world security organization backed by an "international military air corps" which would warn and punish future aggressors, it was learned today.

SAG HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 14 -- Two men were drowned and three youngsters, including the son of one of the men who drowned, were rescued today when their small rowboat capsized in the choppy waters of Great Peconic Bay, three miles west of this village.

ROME, Aug. 14 (U.P.) -- Negotiations were reported far advanced today to replace the liberal Government of Premier Ivanoe Bonomi with a "national concentration" Cabinet headed by Vittorio Emanuele Orlando, 84-year-old World War I Premier and delegate to the Versailles Peace Conference.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Declaring that he was "amazed" by President Roosevelt's recent statement that "we weren't allowed to fortify Guam," Senator Gurney, Republican, of South Dakota, said today the Chief Executive never had recommended to Congress that the Pacific island be fortified.

Cotton gray goods mills and yarn spinners will not make sales commitments on the basis of announced prices until the prices have been approved officially by the Office of Price Administration, it was learned yesterday in Worth Street.
CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The uprising Phillies won their fourth straight game today when southpaw Ken Raffensberger held the Cubs to only one run on eleven hits and beat them 6 to 1.

Showing a fine burst of speed in the stretch run, Neil G. Gibbons' consistent bay gelding Sammy Angott flashed home the winner of the Sacandaga Purse, Class D mile-and-a-half race for 3-year-olds which featured the program of the Saratoga Association at Belmont Park yesterday.

Resignation of Frederick E. Williamson, president of the New York Central Railroad Company since 1932, was announced yesterday by the board of directors. Gustav Metzman, vice president of the system with headquarters in Chicago, was elected president to succeed Mr. Williamson, who will continue in an advisory executive capacity for the remainder of the year.

WITH AMERICAN ARMORED FORCES in France, Aug. 14 (U.P.) -- Scores of shell-shocked Germans, some still carrying their unused weapons, stood along the highway to this city waiting to be herded into prisoner pens. French civilians carrying confiscated German weapons stood guard over some of these groups.

Despite an anti-strike vote Saturday, a disputed number of workers struck yesterday at the yards of the Electric Boat Company, Groton, Conn. The company is the largest private producer of submarines for the Navy.

ROME, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Eighth Army troops pushing toward the Adriatic end of the Germans' Gothic line in Italy have captured the mountain town of Frontone on the north bank of the Cesano River, twenty-seven miles from the sea, Allied headquarters announced today.
Mayor La Guardia expressed surprise yesterday that in a short-wave broadcast his reference to the Emperor of Japan as "not the son of heaven" but "the son of something" had been deleted.

In an order of the day through which run echoes of Sedan and Stalingrad and all the other classic battles of encirclement and annihilation, General Eisenhower has declared that the Allied armies in France have now "a fleeting but definite opportunity for a major victory" which would equal any of these great engagements.

Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Tammany leader of the old Fifteenth District and a former Supreme Court Justice, has been chosen to manage Senator Robert F. Wagner's campaign for re-election on the Democratic, American Labor and Liberal party tickets, it was announced yesterday.
The tinder-like condition of large frame structures in the Eastern drought area worried fire chiefs and other public officials yesterday as week-end fire death tolls mounted.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Senator Robert R. Reynolds, Democrat, of North Carolina, chairman of the Senate Military Affairs Committee, called upon Secretary of War Harry L. Stimson today for an official explanation of published reports that "sick men" among the famed Merrill's Marauders were called upon to defend the Myitkyina airport in northern Burma from Japanese attack.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- In his radio address Saturday night from the Puget Sound Navy Yard the President, making a passing reference to Pacific naval problems, past, present and future, said:

With Nick Etten exploding a ninth-inning home run to deadlock the score at one-all, it is quite possible the Yankees and White Sox might have carried on their heat-blistered ball game at the Stadium yesterday indefinitely had not Ralph Hodgin, Jimmy Dykes' energetic young third baseman, decided to take matters into his own hands.
CHICAGO, Aug. 14 -- A one-year program of compulsory military training for all American youth was proposed today by Joseph F. Landis, president of the American Federation of Teachers.

OTTAWA, Aug. 14 -- Canada is still paying her annual contribution of $214,600 for the expenses of the League of Nations, it was revealed today when during a discussion on the external affairs estimates, Opposition Leader Gordon Graydon asked whether it was the intention of the United Nations to disband the League to allow the new organization proposed at the Moscow Conference to take its place.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Distinguished Service Medal to Brig. Gen. Frank A. Keating of 44 Washington Place, Ridgewood, N.J., for service from June 1, 1942, to March 16, 1943, as first commander of the amphibious training center.

Rocky Graziano, 149, East Side, defeated Jerry Fiorello, 156, Red Hook, in the main bout of eight rounds last night at the Queensboro Arena, Long Island City, before a crowd of 5,000. Graziano scored the only knockdown, in the sixth.
Has anyone ever made a study of the way people read their morning papers in New York? The findings of such a study would, I think, dictate certain changes in the make-up of large-size newspapers.

Elizabeth Goudge's "Green Dolphin Street," to be published Aug. 24 by Coward-McCann, has been selected, out of ninety-nine novels, as the winner in the first Metro-Goldwyn-Meyer annual novel contest. Miss Goudge will receive from $125,000 to $175,000, depending upon the sales of the novel, and Coward-McCann will receive $25,000 upon publication.

Black market trading in gold jewelry involving millions of dollars was seen as ended here yesterday when news was received that the War Production Board had revoked order L-45, thus eliminating restrictions on the use of the yellow metal and palladium.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 -- Hot and dry weather in the States east of the Mississippi River continues to be a factor in the grain markets. forecast of possible showers led to selling early today which carried the deferred futures of rye to a new seasonal low on the Board of Trade here.
BOSTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- With Emmett O'Neil tossing four-hit ball, the Red Sox today reduced the Browns' lead to five and a half games by defeating the American League pace setters, 5 -- 1.

LONDON, Aug. 14 -- The Polish Cabinet met today to receive and consider the report of Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk on his visit to Moscow and his talks with Premier Joseph Stalin and with leaders of the rival Committee of National Liberation, which has received Soviet endorsement.

Mrs. Joan Schlutter, 29 years old, who on June 13 kidnapped 7-month-old Barbara Ann Goggin from the New York Foundling Hospital in East Sixty-eighth Street, waived examination yesterday in the Homicide Court and was held in $5,000 bail for the grand jury. She had been under observation at Bellevue since her arrest with Barbara Ann in an apartment at 201 West Ninety-fifth Street.

With the ranks of brokers and of customers depleted yesterday by the continuing heat wave, the market on the Stock Exchange had the smallest volume in two weeks, although a broad range of shares was dealt in and no particular trends noted.

Admiral Nimitz dropped in for a visit somewhere in the Marshall Islands and pinned the Bronze Star on Vice Admiral Mitscher, known by his classmates at the Naval Academy as "Pete," to the experts as a tactician of genius, to all Americans and the world generally as the Sweeper of the Pacific.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 14 --Warner Brothers have lent Jane Wyman to Paramount for the feminine lead opposite Ray Milland in the forthcoming screen adaptation of Charles Jackson's "The Lost Week-End." A condition of the deal is that Eddie Bracken, Paramount player, later will be lent for a Warner picture.

LONDON, Aug. 14 -- The war in the west has reached a critical and perhaps decisive stage. If the German Seventh Army, which represents all the hopes and fears of the Third Reich, loses its life in the death struggle now raging in the narrow valley's handkerchief-sized fields of the Falaise-Argentan pocket, the occupation of Paris and the invasion of Germany will follow.

Representative Vito Marcantonio, New York County chairman of the American Labor party, denied categorically yesterday that he was a party to any judicial deal with Tammany Hall and inferentially placed the onus for the Tammany-ALP understanding on nominations for justices of the Supreme Court at the door of Sidney Hillman, State chairman of the ALP and national chairman of the Political Action Committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

ALENCON, Aug. 12 (Delayed) -- In a daring thrust directly north from Le Mans French and American forces spearheading the drive designed to encircle the Germans in Normandy rolled into this city early this morning. It was the first large French city liberated by the French.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Chungking in English to North America and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 14 -- A 36-night harness racing program that may prove even more successful than the spring meeting of the Old Country Trotting Association was launched tonight at Roosevelt Raceway before 6,927, who wagered a total of $260,654.

LONDON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Relentless armadas of close to 3,000 American and British heavy bombers smashed Germany's home and fighting fronts today in answer to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's call to deny with all aerial might German ability either to fight on or flee.

FORT DEVENS, Mass., Aug. 14 (AP) -- When a German Panzer division hit the American First Division at Gela, in Sicily, a brigadier general roared: "The ocean's behind us and we can't swim out of here. Let's go forward and stop the tanks."
Continued favorable reports on the progress of the war, served yesterday to discourage buying of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange and liquidation caused net declines of 9 to 12 points.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 14 (U.P.) -- Australia and New Zealand newspapers were generally agreed today that President Roosevelt's discussion of America's post-war plans in the southwest Pacific had outlined a reasonable and just program.

IRUN, Spain, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Most of the French Maquis forces in the Central Plateau region, the Pyrenees foothills and Savoie have moved northward and are fighting in the rear of the German armies along the Loire, advices from France said today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 14 -- A secret session of the Finnish Parliament was held today and Finland's renewing of contact with the Soviet Government looking toward an armistice was discussed, according to a report from Helsinki. Juho K. Paasikivi, who is Finland's highest authority on Russia, was said to have been present.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Lieut. Joseph Patrick Kennedy Jr., 29-year-old son of the former United States Ambassador to England, was lost last Saturday, the Navy said today, while piloting a Navy plane on a special mission in the European theatre.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 14 -- The night club habitue who dotes on a highball or cocktail loomed today as a thirst-stricken casualty of Atlantic City's ice-rationing program.

One of the most plentiful vegetables at this time of year is eggplant, now coming from near-by sections and selling at reasonable prices -- from 6 to 12 cents a pound. Since it cooks quickly, it is also one of the simplest to serve. The following recipes, tested in THE NEW YORK TIMES' kitchen, are some of the many variations that may be employed in preparing it.

Creation of a campaign committee to work for the election of the Roosevelt-Truman ticket was announced yesterday by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, of which David Dubinsky is president.

GROTON, Conn., Aug. 14--A walkout at the submarine building yards of the Electric Boat Company here today brought conflicting figures from the union and the management. The union said that 3,000 to 4,000 men were out on the first shift, which began at 6 A.M., and the management asserted that only 1,289 had failed to show up, 407 in excess of usual Monday absenteeism for all reasons.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 14 -- About the most charitable thing that can be said about what happened today on Crosley Field is that there were comparatively few natives around to see it.
KETCHIKAN, Alaska, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Thursday afternoon was a red letter day for Joe Samuel and the crew of the seiner Harold, the veteran Ketchikan fisherman reported today.
GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Tuesday, Aug. 15 (AP) -- A communique:
LONDON, Aug. 14 -- A P-47 Thunderbolt squadron of the Ninth Air Force today "captured" more than three hundred Nazi soldiers.
IN the early Nineteen Thirties the Communists and the more "militant" wing of the Socialists used to sing a song that went:
Tributes to Mr. Arnstein were paid yesterday by friends and associates, including the following:

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 14 -- The Longwood Cricket Club returns to the national tennis spotlight this week with the gathering of the ranking women players of the country and the revival of the national veterans' championships for men and women after a year's lapse.

Because of the uncertainty in the casualty insurance business that has followed the recent United States Supreme Court decision holding that insurance is commerce and therefore affected by the anti-trust laws when it crosses State lines, Gov. J. Melville Broughton of North Carolina has appointed a fifteen-man commission to make a full study of the situation and to submit recommendations to the next General Assembly of the State.

The three big fires in the metropolitan area, all apparently of accidental origin, that swept through three Hoboken piers, Luna Park at Coney Island and Palisades Amusement Park across the Hudson from Riverside Drive did damage estimated at $5,000,000 or $6,000,000 and injured in various degrees 554 persons.

The maximum penalty of ten years imprisonment and a $10,000 fine was imposed yesterday on Mrs. Velvalee Dickinson, the 50-year-old owner of a doll shop at 718 Madison Avenue, when she appeared for sentence before Federal Judge Shackelford Miller Jr.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 14 (AP) -- After being backed down to 3 -- 5, Charley Rufi's speedy Mintlock reeled off six furlongs in the track-record-equalling time of 1:10 1-5 after coming from behind to defeat E.J. Daily's Johnny Jr., by six lengths today in the Block Island Purse, feature event of Narragansett Park's forty-two day fall opening.

KANDY, Ceylon, Aug. 14 (U.P.) -- Allied troops slugging their way southwest along the strategic Myitkyina-Mandalay railway in North Burma have driven to within six miles of Pinbaw and have occupied the village of Mingon after a five-mile advance from Taungni through waist-deep water, a headquarters bulletin said today.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 14 -- The Dodgers stubbornly maintained their hold on the National League cellar tonight when they went down before the Cardinals for the thi d straight time. The score was 4 to 2 and the Brooks muffed several opportunities to turn it in their favor.

Under orders from the War and Navy Departments, every eligible voter in the armed services is receiving a postcard application form for an absentee or special war ballot, it was disclosed yesterday as the forms were distributed to naval personnel at the New York Navy Yard, in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The War Production Board issued orders today to hosiery knitters and spinners of cotton yarn in an effort to assure the fulfillment of military requirements of mercerized cotton hosiery and lightweight wool socks.

Early termination of the war with Germany would have little or no adverse reaction upon retail sales of toilet goods, while the liberation of France should begin to make available to manufacturers here the essential oil imports that have been unavailable for many months, it was reported in the trade here yesterday.

"Dragon Seed," Metro's adaptation of the Pearl Buck novel starring Katharine Hepburn, is continuing its record business at the Radio City Music Hall and will have grossed nearly $500,000 upon completion of its fourth week tomorrow night, according to an estimate by the management. "Random Harvest," which holds the length of run record for the theatre with an eleven-week engagement, grossed $474,300 during its first four weeks.
Yesterday's communique as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

SOMEWHERE IN FRANCE, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Wearing brilliant red forage caps and riding Sherman tanks, the bronzed and eager Frenchmen, many of them veterans of North Africa, began arriving on the Normandy beaches late in July.
LONDON, Aug. 14 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Under a finding of the finance division of the Interstate Commerce Commission today, the Seaboard Air Line Railway Company, in receivership for over fourteen years, can become a solvent carrier again.

ALTHOUGH civilian fans and baseball folk alike have become sort of inured to the passing of their favorites from the diamond to the bigger game now being fought on foreign fields, it is going to be with more than passing regret that the boys will bid farewell to Rollie Hemsley this Thursday as the Yankee catcher stows away his gear for the duration and reports for military service.

Youth's contention that the present juvenile delinquency problem is caused by the negligence of our adults was indeed startling to me, a student of 17. (THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine, Aug. 6.) In no instance did the boys and girls criticize their own generation for the misconduct so prevalent today.

BERNE, Ewitzerland, Aug. 14 -- After two months of only sporadic activity, during whiich it amassed considerable materiel, both parachuted and captured, the resistance movement in northern Italy has launched large scale operations near Messa, northeast of the German positions behind Pisa, according to a frontier report received here tonight.

Insufficient, spotty week-end rains left the corn belt east of the Mississippi River parched by long drought yesterday, The Associated Press reported, injuring not only corn but soybeans and garden produce.

The report of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on June 30, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income, after operating expenses, taxes and other charges, of $11,588,182. This was equal, after preferred dividend charges, to 42 cents a common share, and compares with $11,549,419, also equal to 42 cents a share, in the twelve months to June 30, 1943.
ADVANCE COMMAND POST, in Normandy, Aug. 13 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The text of General Eisenhower's order of the day follows:

A banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and the First National Bank of Chicago won yesterday the award of $3,400,000 of Spokane County, Wash., school district No. 8 bonds. The bankers paid 105.402 for the issue as 2's, 1 3/4's, 1 1/4's and 1's, maturing serially from Sept. 1, 1946 to 1967.

SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 14 -- Comedian Bob Hope and his troupe of soldier-entertainers escaped injury today in the crash-landing of a Catalina flying boat near Laurieton, New South Wales, Australia. Others in Hope's party were Jerry Colonna, Patty Thomas and Tony Romano.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- A paradoxical situation on Capitol Hill sent Republican leaders scurrying today to nip a movement sponsored by first-term Representative Ed Rowe of Ohio to reorganize the House on the ground that the minority party now constitutes an actual working majority and should take over the reins.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14 (AP) -- General Gas and Electric Corporation (Gengas) and its parent, Associated Gas and Electric Corporation, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a plan for divestment of Gengas' assets, simplification of its corporate structure and more equitable distribution of its voting power.

LONDON, Tuesday, Aug. 15 -- Red Army forces smashed to within sixteen miles of the southern border of East Prussia yesterday by capturing the fortress city of Osovets, while Soviet spearheads in southern Estonia advanced sixteen miles toward the Gulf of Riga in a drive to split the remnants of thirty Nazi divisions trapped in Latvia and Estonia.

Veterans of the AEF Service of Supply are pricking up their ears. Middle-aged survivors of the battles of Nantes, Savenay, Brest and St. Nazaire can almost see our columns pounding down the Route de Rennes toward Nantes and filling the river road from Savenay toward St. Nazaire.

Bronzed and hardened by almost five years of war under the hot sun of Africa and the South Pacific, 200 Australian Army volunteers en route to a secret mission in England yesterday swung up Broadway from the Battery to City Hall before 25,000 cheering New Yorkers gathered along the line of march.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 14 (AP) -- Vince Dell 'Orto, Philadelphia veteran, tossed a monkey wrench into the fight plans of Phil Terranova of New York tonight when he outpointed the former N.B.A. world featherweight champion in ten rounds.

Serious curtailment of ship repair and ship construction in the metropolitan area was feared as a result of a strike vote taken yesterday by 2,000 electricians engaged in sub-contract work. The result of the voting would be made known this morning, it was expected.
I commend you heartily for your editorial "What Shall a Soldier Read?" and agree with you that "A thinking Army and Navy is our best defense against militarism."

MOSCOW, Aug. 14 (U.P.) -- The armored warfare expert of the Soviet Army newspaper Red Star, Col. P. Kolomeitzeff, gave high praise today to the accomplishments of American tank forces in France. The Germans' attempted counter-thrust toward Avranches was too late and useless, he said.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Tuesday, Aug. 15 -- Against an Allied double thrust from the north and south German armor and artillery were fighting today to prop open the jaws of an Allied pincers that was within twelve miles of closing on by far the greater part of the German forces southwest of the Seine.

The news dispatches from Pearl Harbor, recounting an interview with Admiral Nimitz about our military plans in the Pacific, strike a new high in American optimism. But they are also an object lesson to the public on how to read war reports.
The text of the French summons, issued last night by the Committee of National Liberation, as broadcast to the French by the British radio and recorded by the Office of War Information:

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14 -- As Gov. Edward Martin, Mayor Bernard Samuel and Maj. Gen. Philip Hayes, War Department operator of the Philadelphia Transportation Company, held a special conference tonight reliable sources indicated that return of the PTC to civilian management was impending.

Owners, managers and advertising managers of 1,000 radio stations throughout the country have been asked by the War Production Board to join publishers in toning down the advertising appeals made over their stations for textiles, textile products and furniture, it was revealed yesterday.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 14 -- "Attorney General Francis Biddle is either obsessed with the possibility of becoming a dictator through perversion of the Anti-Trust Act or is indulging in cheap politics," said Joseph H. Hays, counsel for the Western Association of Railway Executives, before a gathering of business men today.

LONDON, Aug. 14 (UP)--Polish patriot forces in Warsaw, fighting under a hail of German artillery and mortar fire and a withering bombardment from Vistula River gunboats, launched a day-long offensive in the west end of the old city today and reported making some headway in the Zoliborz district.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Congress turned today to the third major problem in the vast industrial demobilization program, clearing the way for consideration by the House, beginning tomorrow, of methods of disposing of an estimated $75,000,000,000 of surplus war property, represented in manufacturing plants, machines, materiel and materials.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 14 -- The Second French Armored Division has gone into action on its native soil under command of tough, wiry, Brig. Gen. Jacques-Philippe Leclerc who became a legend in France as leader of the "Leclerc Column" and its fabulous military feats in the desert warfare of 1941 and 1942.

A serious ice shortage is expected in the Bronx and upper Manhattan with the curtailment of operations yesterday of six Bronx ice manufacturing plants and at least three in Manhattan, all operated by the Bronx Ice Associates, Inc., of 220 East 149th Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Secretary of State Hull announced today that a preliminary understanding has been reached with Russia on post-war civil aviation. Both sides favor establishment of an international authority for civil aviation, with consultative and technical functions, he stated.
Thirty-four new cases of infantile paralysis were reported here over the week-end, bringing the total number of cases this year up to 262, the New York City Department of Health said yesterday.

Attorney General Nathaniel Goldstein said today that orders had been served to conserve the remaining assets of clients in six-ten brokerage accounts of George Jackson, whose operations are under investigation and whose accounts in the last five months have totaled about $200,000.

As sirocco-like winds fanned the city yesterday the temperature soared to 93 degrees at 4:30 P.M. to smash the record for the date, 92.2 set twenty-six years ago. The reading, however, was still 3.3 degrees below the high for the year on Aug. 4.
WASHINGTON, Tuesday, Aug. 15--American, British and French troops are landing on the southern coast of France, a special communique from Allied headquarters in Italy announced today.
LONDON, Aug. 14 (Reuter) -- Authoritative sources said today that the French Forces of the Interior had taken Quimperle, Bannalec, Douarnenez and Chateaulin in Brittany.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Leaders of the United Mine Workers pledged today efforts to end a six-week unauthorized strike of more than 4,000 Pennsylvania anthracite miners. The prospect was that if the effort failed the Government would seize the affected mines within a week.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The Pirates went into a tie for second place in the National League today by winning two games from the Braves, the second one a two-hitter for Preacher Roe. The first game, play-off of an eight-inning 5-5 tie July 2, ended 7 to 6; the other, 5 to 0.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Many of the 1,800 Wacs now in the Mediterranean want to stay on when the war is over and serve in rehabilitation work with the Army of Occupation, Lieut. Col Westray Battle Boyce reported today on her return from a year's service as Wac staff director in the North African theatre of operations.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 14 (U.P.) -- Chinese troops who smashed back into the suburbs of battered Hengyang are locked in a blazing street battle with the Japanese, while eighty miles to the northeast the enemy has been blasted from Lienhwa, one of the Kiangsi Province anchor points on the east flank of the Japanese drive into south China, a Chinese communique reported today.

Musicologists and all students of the history of music and Gregorian chant should note with extraordinary interest your editorial "Our Hearts So Stout," a touching tribute to the ancient Irish tune "Garryowen."

MOSCOW, Aug. 14 -- The Soviet newspaper Pravda published today the text of the letter written by Field Marshal Gen. Friedrich won Paulus, the haughty former commander of the German Sixth Army, which was liquidated at Stalingrad, and the first German Field Marshal captured in this war, urging an immediate overthrow of Adolf Hitler and a cessation of hostilities with the Allies to avoid further "senseless bloodletting."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Navy spokesmen withheld comment tonight on what action the Navy might take to counter the strike at the Electric Boat Company plant at Groton. Concerning the question of Navy seizure of the plant, a procedure which has been followed in previous cases where vital Navy production was halted by strikes, spokesmen pointed out that such action could be taken only when authorized by executive order.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 14 -- Lieut. Gen. Omar N. Bradley was disclosed tonight as commander of the whole American fighting force in France, which includes, besides the original First Army, a new Third Army that the Germans have said was commanded by Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton Jr.

Through blizzards and through heat waves Charles E. Chamness of Bartlesville, Okla., has walked a pipeline for an oil company for thirty years. Except in his annual week off, he has not missed a day on the job in all that time.
ON THE ORNE RIVER FRONT IN FRANCE, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The Germans continued to hasten their flow of tanks and troops to the east today in a dramatic race against time.

LONDON, Aug. 14 (U.P.) -- Haphazard launching of German flying bombs against Britain's civilian population continued today even as Nazi propaganda officials boasted of a new and more terrifying weapon that could be fired from great distances and even from ships at sea.

SPOKANE, Wash., Aug. 15 (AP) -- This may be getting slightly monotonous, but Byron Nelson, the Toledo, Ohio, shotmaker, and Harold McSpaden of Philadelphia, ran one-two today in the 36-hole qualifying trials of the 1944 National P.G.A. championship.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., Aug. 15 -- Returning to her estate here shortly after midnight, Mrs. Charles Moore 3d thought the station wagon she was driving had brushed something on Cedar Swamp Road, near the Winthrop W. Aldrich estate, a short distance from her home.

It continues not only in the Nazi press but in some sections of the American press. Thus we are being told that American casualties in northern France have been greater than British and Canadian casualties.
ROME, Aug. 15 -- Long before H-hour naval forces had been disposed in widely dispersed ports.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- A Pacific Fleet announcement:

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 15 (Reuter) -- Faced with the threat of imprisonment or possibly death in Germany, hundreds of non-Nazi German residents of long standing in Turkey are making desperate efforts to avoid expulsion. They include many Austrians and Sudeten Germans with German passports.

WITH CANADIAN FORCES, At Hautmesnil, Normandy, Aug. 14 (Delayed) -- There was another big flare-up in the Canadian sector today but it did much to hamper the Canadians from reaching Falaise, their immediate objective.

New York City is slated today for its seventh consecutive day with the thermometer in the steaming 90's, the mercury having reached a peak of 92.1 degrees at 4:25 P.M. yesterday. A continuation of the hot and humid spell was forecast for today, with the highest temperature about 90 degrees.

Four years ago this month General de Gaulle sent Captain Leclerc to the Cameroons. In the preceding June the captain had escaped to England, disguised as a butler. His name is borrowed to insure the safety of his relatives in France. He is said to be a member of a distinguished family.
Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Peyton have come to the Savoy-Plaza from Isleham, their place in Princeton, N.J.

LONDON, Aug. 15 -- Five German vessels were damaged early this morning by a British naval blockade force led by the cruiser Mauritius, near the enemy-occupied naval base of La Rochelle, the Admiralty announced tonight.

ROME, Aug. 15 -- I have just returned from the southern France beach area now under attack by Allied forces. I flew in one of hundreds of planes of a troop carrier command, carrying thousands of American and British parachutists who were dropped in a south France hamlet some miles inland just before dawn today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The fall of Germany will enable American industry to increase non-war production 30 per cent and bring the output of civilian goods up to the level reached in 1939, the highest to that time, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, predicted today.

By unanimous vote yesterday the Senate retreated from the Taft amendment to the Soldiers Voting Law, under which the Army had felt itself forced to refuse to distribute to our armed forces any one of a dozen or more books, all of which are being widely read by the civilian population of the country.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Pirates made it nine in a row by defeating the Braves, 7 -- 5, tonight, sweeping a series of five games. A three-run rally in the eighth inning provided the Pittsburgh margin of victory.

LONDON, Aug. 15 -- The stock markets responded today to Allied landings in the south of France with a "wait and see" attitude. Trading was light with scattered selling and easier prices that firmed toward the close.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 15 (AP) --Representative Thad Wasielewski, an Administration supporter in most legislation except the Smith Led Connally Anti-Strike Act, led Anthony P. Gawronski, who had the backing of the CIO Political Action Committee, in Wisconsin's primary today.

It may be necessary to curtail the pheasant hunting season or decrease the bag limit on the birds in New York State this fall. Whether either or both measures are essential will be discussed at public hearings announced by Conservation Commissioner John A. White yesterday for Albany and Rochester.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Cary Grant packed his luggage and departed today from the Brentwood mansion where he has lived with the former Barbara Hutton since their marriage two years ago.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 15 -- Harry Feldman did a pretty good job of beating himself tonight on Crosley Field, as the Reds tumbled the Giants into their eighth straight defeat, 6 to 3, and sank them a game and a half behind the fourth-place Cubs.
ROME, Aug. 15 (UP) -- A Headquarters announcement accompanying the special communique:

Some of the principal shows on Broadway, including "Oklahoma!" "One Touch of Venus," and "Mexican Hayride," failed to receive their regular ice deliveries yesterday and as a result their conditioning systems did not provide the usual amount of air-cooled comfort.

ROME, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Capt. William R. Grady of Springfield, Mass., and First Lieut. James F. Shannon of 133 Amity Street, Brooklyn, N.Y., were on the last, flight of heavy bombers to go over the beaches before troops landed in southern France today.

The National Board of Fire Underwriters, representing stock fire insurance companies, and the Association of Casualty and Surety Executives, representing stock casualty and surety companies, each presented yesterday a memorandum to the subcommittee on Federal legislation of the National Association of Insurance Commissioners on the problems brought about by the recent decision of the United States Supreme Court that insurance is "commerce" and therefore comes under the anti-trust laws when it crosses State lines.
CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (AP) -- After losing the first three games of the series the Cubs captured an abbreviated finale, 4 to 1, from the Phils today. The game was called after six innings because of rain.

Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totaled 810, against 870 last week and 800 in the like period a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals numbered 379 against 385 last Tuesday.

The editorial "Mr. Dewey's Opportunity" in your issue of Aug. 11 gives a much-needed emphasis. The American people have a right to know just what the Republican party and its leader mean by the Chicago platform pledge of a post-war international organization, which will "direct peace forces to prevent or repel military aggression."

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- Warning that unless plans were made immediately to solve the educational problems of youths 14 to 18 years old this country would find itself with another "lost generation," Mrs. W.A. Hastings, national president of the Congress of Parents and Teachers, asked teachers today to formulate a training and guidance program for youngsters who left school to take war jobs.
LONDON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Gault MacGowan, veteran New York Sun correspondent, was reported by the Germans today to have been captured near Chartres on the road to Paris.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Plans to direct the surge of peoples to the borders which lie between them and their own homes, in the event of a German collapse, have taken definite shape in a multilateral proposal drafted by the technical subcommittee on displaced persons of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, for signature by the United Nations affected.

ROME, Aug. 15 (AP) -- An air force spokesman said today that the major pre-invasion tasks of knocking out railroads from the beachhead area northward through the Rhone Valley and eastward into enemy-held northern Italy had been accomplished and that the landing area had been virtually isolated.

Welfare Commissioner Leo Arnstein, who died in this city on Sunday, gave so much during the best years of his life to the public service that his private business was almost a side line. Certainly when he had to choose between helping his fellows and attending to his own interests he always put the personal interests second.
HAMILTON, Mass., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Informed today by newsmen that her husband was commanding the newly-formed Third Army in France, Mrs. George S. Patton Jr., said:

A Whitney horse won the Whitney Stakes yesterday at Belmont Park, where the Saratoga meeting was continued. Devil Diver got down in front at 1 to 4 in the Memorial race which is a tribute to the various generations and branches of the Whitney family which have done so much for the sport in general, and Saratoga racing in particular.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- On July 20 a man was killed at Adolf Hitler's headquarters whom the murderer believed to be Hitler. Indeed, he bore a striking physical likeness to the Nazi dictator. But the murderer had merely laid to the ground one of Hitler's protective "doubles."

Pvt. Robert Rowland of Walterboro, S.C., 1942 runner-up, the last time the Negro National Tennis Championships were held, arrive by plane yesterday for the tournament being conducted by the American Tennis Association at the Cosmopolitan Club.

The rent strike of tenants in the 105-family apartment house at 640 Riverside Drive apparently has been cleared up to the satisfaction of both tenants and landlord the regional Office of Price Administration said yesterday, and some of the tenants have paid the rent they had been withholding.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 15 -- Linda Darnell has been named by Twentieth Century-Fox for the feminine lead in the psychological murder mystery, "Hangover Square." She will play the part of a London tavern entertainer. Fox has borrowed Joan Leslie from Warner Brothers for the chief feminine role, opposite Fred MacMurray, in the forthcoming musical fantasy, "Where Do We Go From Here."

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 15 (U.P.) -- Bitter fighting raged yesterday on the outer ring of Hengyang as Gen. Hsueh Yueh's Chinese troops battled to retake that battered Hunan Province rail junction, which fell to the Japanese a week ago after a grim forty-four-day siege, a Chinese communique said today.

ALGIERS, Aug. 15 -- Algiers followed the news of the Allied landing in the south of France with keen interest today but with little surprise. The imminence of the blow had been common knowledge for several weeks, and even the date had been more or less accurately discussed in the cafes.

LONDON, Wednesday, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Frontier reports to the London press said this morning that Paris had gone wild with joy at the news of the Allies' landings in the south of France and sporadic fighting between patriots and collaborationists had broken out in the streets when crowds assembled singing the "Marsellaise."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- With House leaders confident that body will reach a vote by Friday on the bill for surplus property disposal, Congress moved ahead with its post-war legislative program today.

ROME, Aug. 15 (U.P.) -- Americans swarming ashore on southern France had to face a line of barbed wire and scattered strongpoints which originally were capable of laying down blistering interlacing fire, according to a former Italian lieutenant who helped build the defenses.

Striking another mortal blow at Nazi Germany, a new Allied army has stormed ashore on the beaches of southern France to establish the fourth major front in Europe. Brilliantly conceived, brilliantly executed and brilliantly timed, the new invasion is another stirring demonstration of the grand Allied strategy of constant attack, which is the secret of victory.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- American newspapers, despite paper shortages, the European invasion and a national political convention, carried a record volume of advertising and news column promotion of the recently concluded Fifth War Loan.
GROTON, Conn., Aug. 15 (U.P.) -- Officials of the Electric Boat Company admitted tonight that the strike at its yards here had halted building of submarines.

LONDON, Aug. 15 -- A handsome, red-haired Frenchwoman who fought and killed Germans in World War I and received four decorations from the French and British governments, who led one of France's resistance movements for the last four years and only a few weeks ago evaded the Gestapo to reach England, met the American and British press here today and said she was "intimidated."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Ken Keltner's single in the twelfth inning gave the Indians a 1-0 victory ever Washington tonight, breaking up a pitching duel between Al Smith and Dutch Leonard.
