Keltner's low scored Oris Hockett, who had got on base on Johnny Sullivan's error and advanced to second on Pat Seerey's sacrifice, the first Cleveland runner to get past first.

LONDON, Aug. 15 (U.P) -- The refusal of Germany and some satellite countries to permit Jewish children to leave has handicapped the various relief bodies in their efforts to rescue children from Europe during the past year, it was revealed today.

Consolidated net sales of the B.F. Goodrich Company, rubber manufacturers, in the six months ended with June increased 15 per cent to $206,273,349 from the $179,161,773 volume for the corresponding period a year ago, according to the semi-annual statement released yesterday after a meeting of directors.

The Rhone-Saone Valley, bisecting southern France from Marseille to the Plateau de Langres, about 180 miles southeast of Paris, forms a broad highway leading to Germany's back door at Wuerttemberg and Mannheim. Except at the coast line and around Lyon, it is not as heavily populated as the Channel coast and the Belgian-Netherlands lowlands.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- Asserting that he was educated at the "university of hard knocks," Gustav Metzman of Chicago told some of his feelings today on becoming president of the 11,000-mile New York Central system. On Sept. 1 he will assume the position made vacant by the retirement of Frederick E. Williamson on account of ill health, which was announced yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 15 -- This area put in its bid as a great post-war fashion centre with the announcement of plans for construction of a $4,000,000 "apparel city." Financed largely by the apparel industry itself and sponsored by the California Reconstruction and Re-employment Commission.

LONDON, Aug. 15 -- The object of today's Allied landings in Provence is nothing less than the complete annihilation of the Nazi forces guarding Europe and Adolf Hitler's inner citadel from the west. Thus after seventy days of bitter, hard fighting in Normandy, Allied strategy begins to unfold.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 15 -- In the summer lassitude of the eighth year of the war Chungking moves with a kind of lumbering inertia. Nothing less final than the presence of the enemy at the gates could alter this sprawling, heedless motion.
BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Capt. Paul Campbell of Martha's Vineyard has the story to end all fish stories about the one that got away.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 15 -- The exercise of sanctions, in the form of cancellation of occupational draft deferments, supplemental gasoline rations and rights of job referral, was authorized today against recalcitrant machinists following yesterday's seizure of five San Francisco machine shops by the Navy under presidential order.

Scores of instances of 16 and 17-year-old youths representing themselves to be 18 in efforts to get into the armed services have occurred in New York City local draft boards, Col. Arthur V. McDermott, New York City director of Selective Service disclosed yesterday.

LONDON, Wednesday, Aug. 16 -- Soviet field dispatches said last night that Red Army troops had crossed the Bobr River in northern Poland, striking through a fifteen-mile belt of Axis defenses guarding imperiled East Prussia, while Moscow announced that Marshal Ivan S. Koneff's Fourth Ukraine Army had killed or captured 172,360 Germans.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Wednesday, Aug. 16 (AP) -- In an official statement today, Supreme Headquarters said that there had been no change in Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery's status as Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's deputy commander in the field.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Backing up its Military Affairs Committee, the Senate confirmed today the promotion of Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton Jr. from the permanent rank of colonel of cavalry to major general. The vote was unanimous, both in the Senate and in the committee, which acted only a short time before the chamber convened.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- News Service, an official organ of the American Federation of Labor in an article published in today's issue, attacked Governor Dewey of New York for his failure to respond favorably to a request for a Labor Day message for printing in the weekly publication and the labor papers it serves.

Diminutive Adelaide Meureiter, 18 years old, of 1715 First Avenue, described by Magistrate Anna M. Kross in Bowery Court as a prototype of the "khaki-wacky girl" in a midtown play dealing with juvenile delinquency, was found guilty yesterday of falling into Central Park lake on Monday evening "while under the influence of liquor, causing a crowd to collect and daring an officer to arrest her."
The air lines and steamship companies began yesterday to clear up the pattern of contention for international air routes upon which the Civil Aeronautics Board will have to make decisions soon.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Hal Newhouser joined his teammate, Dizzy Trout, as a nineteen-game winner today when the Tigers defeated the Athletics, 3 -- 2. in eleven innings, squaring their series.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- With speed and unity, the Senate adopted today amendments to the Servicemen's Voting Act that are designed to eliminate the "propaganda" restrictions which, as interpreted by the War Department, have caused the withholding of widely circulated books, magazines, some newspapers and movies and other "political" matter from Army posts.

Police of Hoboken, N.J., announced yesterday that the fire on Pier 4 there last Friday, which did damage estimated at $4,000,000 and caused the death of three dock workers, was probably due to the accidental ignition of nitrecellulose by sparks from a truck exhaust.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES, In Southern France, Aug. 15 -- An American Army numbering many thousands is well into southern France this afternoon and going fast. It has struck virtually without opposition and with amazingly small casualties. The Germans were caught completely by surprise. What few were waiting for us have been scattered or captured.

As Allied armies swept ashore in southern France yesterday in an invasion long planned, the most powerful American army ever put in the field, organized for the first time in our history in an army group, fought in Normandy with British and Canadian Allies to close a trap about the badly mauled German Seventh Army.

A double feature decorating exhibit opened officially at McCreery's yesterday afternoon with a press preview of two sets of completed interiors that have been visible to shoppers in various stages of development for the last few weeks.

In Greenwich Village, at 474 Sixth Avenue, between Eleventh and Twelfth Streets, a small shop called Patisserie Parisienne specializes in home-made pastries that are exceptionally good. An unusually wide assortment is offered, and although French varieties predominate, the establishment also excels in such purely American desserts as Boston cream pie.

ON THE FIRST UNITED STATES ARMY FRONT, Aug. 15 -- Of all the scenes of destruction of German manpower and military equipment spread before us since the Allies' break-through on the St. Lo-Coutances line, nothing compares with that in this Normandy pocket. It is roughly a thousand square miles of destruction.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS ADVANCED COMMAND POST, in Normandy, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Fresh tales concerning Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton Jr., tank commander, are spreading in the wake of his swift maneuvers.

ABOARD H. M. S. RODNEY, Aug. 12 (Delayed) (AP) -- H. M. S. Rodney, principal heroine in the sinking of the German superbattleship Bismarck, anchored twenty miles off the Channel Island of Alderney today and leisurely hurled seventy-five one-ton 16-inch shells into a Nazi battery without return fire.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 14 (Delayed) -- The underground movement in Germany, which is seeking to overthrow the Hitler government and negotiate peace with the Allied Powers, began its formal organization in 1939, shortly after the outbreak of the war, and now has placed its agents in virtually every important ministry of Hitler's Reich, as well as establishing contact with the highest German army circles, according to certain emissaries with whom this correspondent has talked.
LONDON, Wednesday, Aug. 16 (UP) -- The Russian Tuesday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:
You are to be warmly commended for publishing Lyman Beecher Stowe's revealing and inspiring communication, "World Plan Advocated," in your issue of Aug. 6.
LONDON, Aug. 15 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

ROME, Aug. 15 -- Thousands of Allied troops, mainly American and French, swarmed on to the south coast of France on a broad front between Marseille and Nice today, seized and extended firm beachheads against inconsequential German opposition and, taking high ground inland, drove northward with the avowed intention of joining the Allies in northwestern France.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Assurance that the Office of Price Administration plans no major changes this fall or winter in cattle and corn price structures was received here today in a letter from Chester Bowles, head of the Government agency to the Kansas City Star.

Thomas J. Curran. New York Secretary of State and Republican candidate for United States Senator, promised yesterday to make his position clear on all the major issues before the voters during the current campaign, in which he is opposing Senator Robert F. Wagner.

The Navy Industrial Association has been organized to maintain and to perpetuate the close relationship which has been built up between the Navy and industry during the war, it was announced yesterday by C.C. Felton, vice president of Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., and president of the organizing committee.

LONDON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The British Lancaster and Halifax heavy bombers that attacked nine German fighter bases in Belgium and the Netherlands today caught twenty or thirty Nazi planes parked on each field and wrecked them.

After the Kings County District Attorney's office had acknowledged that it had received "very helpful information" from the defendant, Ernest (The Hawk) Rupolo, 20 years old, of 1947 Sixty-fifth Street, Brooklyn, won yesterday in Brooklyn County Court an indefinite postponement of sentence on a charge of assault in the first degree.

WITH UNITED STATES ARMORED FORCES, at Argentan, Aug. 13 (Delayed) -- Huge German Army forces, trapped tonight by converging Allied armored spearheads, began immediate attempts to smash out of 300 aquare miles enclosed by a steel vise clamped on the greatest Allied armored round-up of the war.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Aug. 15 (U.P.) -- British Fourteenth Army troops in eastern India have driven to within five miles of the Burma border and Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten's communique said today that the Mogaung-Myitkyina sector "no longer is a combat line but a secured line of communications."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Disruption of rail transport in southern France because of invasion operations necessitated Red Cross negotiations with five Governments to provide safe passage for prisoner-of-war relief supplies by a northern route to Germany.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- President Roosevelt today nominated Ugo Carusi, executive assistant to Attorney General Francis Biddle, to be Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization in the Department of Justice. Mr. Carusi of Barre, Vt., succeeds Earl G. Harrison of Philadelphia, who resigned recently to resume his private law practice.

With the exception of men's work socks, civilian production of men's hose will be cut approximately 80 per cent by the War Production Board order freezing production on specified types of machines, hosiery manufacturers predicted yesterday.

More than 300 manufacturers who yesterday approached the regional and district offices of the War Production Board on how they could return to the production of civilian items found that there will be little conversion to such output until the manpower situation eases considerably.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Reaction to the Soviet Government's proposal that the United Nations form an international military air corps to keep the peace after the war was divided in the capital today.
New York City housewives have begun no rush to buy point-free "utility" grade beef, lamb or mutton, it was reported yesterday by members of the retail food trade and by Federal market observers.

The Eastman Kodak Company's net profit for the twenty-four weeks ended on June 10 increased to $9,224,506, or $3.66 a common share, from the $8,532,590, or $3.38 a share, earned in the corresponding period the year before, according to a report to stockholders yesterday signed by F.W. Lovejoy, chairman, and T.J. Hargrave, president.

The keynote of the "Food Fights for Freedom" campaign in the fourth quarter of this year will be compliance with price ceilings and avoidance of black markets, the War Advertising Council announced yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 15 -- Tomasz Arciszewski, newly appointed President-designate of Poland, assorted tonight that Poland counted on urgent action by the United States, Britain and Russia to aid the Warsaw underground forces, said the Allies "canot escape their part of the responsibility of providing help, and asked, "Is Poland to remain deserted now that she has fulfilled all her obligations?"

Topics of the Times, in the Aug. 4 issue, erred somewhat in thinking that perhaps the reason for the decline in baseball attendance at Sportsmen's Park, which is home to the two teams leading the major league baseball race is the weather.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Senator Kenneth McKellar, Democrat, of Tennessee, today introduced a resolution calling on this country to seek permanent possession of all Japanese-owned and mandated islands between the Equator and the Thirtieth Parallel of Latitude North, including Formosa and the Ryuku Islands.

ROME, Aug. 15 -- The visit of Prime Minister Churchill to Italy, which has been the cause of considerable political speculation in the Italian press, was made primarily for military purposes, correspondents were told today.

Extension of the cost-of-living bonus to school teachers and other employes of the Department of Education was urged on Mayor La Guardia, the Board of=Education and the Board of Estimate in a resolution adopted u2nlraously by the City Council at its meeting yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 15 -- The Dodgers crept away from this "double" league-leading city tonight without having won one of the four-game series with the champion Cardinals. The Red Birds took them tonight under the lights by a 6-3 score, running the Brooklyn losing streak to five.

Envisaging the end of the war in Europe before the close of 1945, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick declared yesterday that the "brilliant success of the Allied arms in recent weeks" made it imperative for the city to prepare a capital budget permitting a part of its billion-dollar post-war program to be carried into effect "should this devoutly hoped-for event occur."

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 15 -- Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton Jr. is the tactical genius who has driven the rampant United States Third Army across Brittany, through Le Mans and then northward through Alencon and Argentan, completing the southern jaw of the trap on the Nazi Seventh Army.

Taking issue with those who see a Republican trend in State and local elections held since 1940, Senator Robert F. Wagner predicted confidently yesterday the re-election of President Roosevelt and his own return to the Senate. He made the forecast as he was leaving Democratic State headquarters after a conference with Paul A. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State chairman.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 15 -- The Cleveland Transit System will earn an estimated profit of $2,500,000 this year, it was revealed today by Controller William H. Morrison in his annual report to Mayor Frank Lausche. The report shows gross income of $22,006,756 for 1943, a reward for the system in the city's first full year of operation.

AMONG the hordes of authors who have been mass-producing historical novels about America's past for the last fifteen years Howard Fast stands out like a bull moose in a flock of sheep. His special gifts are of a high and uncommon order: an ability to cut his novels to the bone and suggest the parapher nalia of a period instead of cataloguing it, a fine feeling for character, and an engrossing narrative power.

An unabridged paper-bound edition of "One-Man Air Force," by Capt. Don S. Gentile, as told to Ira Wolfert, war correspondent, is being published by Graphic Enterprises simultaneously with L.B. Fisher's publication of the regular bookstore edition.
Yesterday's communique as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
LONDON, Aug. 13 (UP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

ROME, Aug. 15 -- The Luftwaffe's desperate attempts to decipher Allied invasion plans in the Mediterranean area were described today in an Air Force report which told of the futile efforts of German reconnaissance pilots to obtain photographs of Italian and Sicilian harbors.
From crisp, cool salads and rainbow-hued vegetable plates three prize winners were chosen yesterday in a Girl Scouts' Victory Garden recipe contest sponsored by Schrafft's restaurants.

OTTAWA, Aug. 15 -- In view of the attitude taken by certain provincial government leaders and especially by Premier George Drew of Ontario, Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King told the House of Commons late last night that he had decided to postpone the proposed Dominion-Provincial conference until after the general election.

Several members of the Coast Guard from the New York area are Known to have participated in the invasion of southern France, it was announced yesterday at the office of the Coast Guard, 90 Church Street.

As the mercury went up during the last few days, the number of boys and girls in city playgrounds operated by the Board of Education went down because "even the kids couldn't stand it," Francis J. Brennan, director of the division of recreational and and community activities, said yesterday.

The third of a series of Army Blueprint Specials is "Three-Day Pass," a GI interpretation of how those leaves are spent all over the world. After several trial performances at a near-by Army installation in about six weeks everything in the offering will be reduced to essentials and blueprinted so GI Joes, no matter where stationed, will have no trouble putting on their own entertainment with proven material.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 15 -- Following upon her crushing defeat in the final at Rye, Miss Pauline Betz of Los Angeles, the national tennis champion, started anew to prepare for the defense of her crown at Forest Hills the end of the month by scoring a victory in love sets today as the women's invitation tournament began at the Longwood Cricket Club.

Reports to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York from commercial paper dealers showed $142,900,000 of open-market paper outstanding on July 21, against $136,500,000 on June 30, last, and $149,800,000 on July 31, 1943. Most of the money represents the financing of food-products manufacture and the amount corresponds fairly close to the crop-loan situation which embarrassed the banking system of this country from the earliest days until the formation of the Federal Reserve System.

ROME, Aug. 15 (UP) -- Allied fighting men wounded in the invasion of southern France will have speedier and more efficient medical care than was thought possible even a year ago, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Representative James C. Auchincloss of New Jersey said today the Federal Housing Authority was considering sale of Jersey Homesteads in Monmouth County, which was built originally as a rural resettlement and rehabilitation project to provide homes and subsistence gardens for low income families.
LONDON, Aug. 15 -- British Radio Correspondent Vaughn Thomas, broadcasting from southern France today, said the troops who opposed the invaders on the coast "did not have their hearts in this job."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The American Red Cross announced today that it is equipping ten hospitals of 500 beds each for the civilian population of freed areas of the Soviet Union where a hospital shortage exists.

The validity of the Reno divorce obtained by Mrs. Doris Duke Cromwell from James H.R. Cromwell, former United States Minister to Canada, was brought before the New York courts yesterday. Supreme Court Justice Thomas A. Aurelio reserved decision on a motion to vacate a subpoena obtained in behalf of Mrs. Cromwell to examine a witness living in this city.
CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 15 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:
ALBANY, Aug. 15 -- Thomas E. Dewey today characterized President Roosevelt's recent inspection trip to Pearl Harbor and the Aleutians as a "holiday."

The idea of an international air force to police the world and enforce the peace is in the forefront of post-war discussion and planning. To airmen the kind of aerial establishments sketched in this connection by laymen or by military experts whose knowledge of aviation is hazy seems utterly unrealistic.

In a silent sort of a way Bill Zuber made a lot of noise on the mound at the Stadium yesterday as he hurled the Yankees to a 3-1 victory over the White Sox in the latter team's last appearance here this season. It was, indeed, one of the best-pitched games by a New Yorker all year, what with the visitors making only three hits, one of which was a scratch single.

The Electrolux Corporation reported yesterday for the six months ended on June 30 a net proifit of $238,419, equal to 19 cents a share, after all charges and Federal Income tax. Net profit for the corresponding half of 1943 was $83,222, or 7 cents a share.

Australia could have sent no finer representatives of her Imperial forces than the small group that are for a few days our guests en route to their new noncombatant assignment in England. Among them are men who have served on three continents and two islands. The suns of Greece and Crete and Tobruk, of Lae and Salamaua have tanned their hides and crinkled the corners of their eyes.

SEATTLE, Aug. 15 (AP) -- A Negro soldiers' raid on sleeping members of an Italian military service unit at Fort Lawton was reported officially tonight, and a military statement said that "a short time following the fight the body of one of the Italian soldiers was found hanging from a near-by tree."
GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Wednesday, Aug. 16 (AP) -- A communique:
LONDON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Aug. 15 -- The Army has completed its first step in setting up machinery through which the votes of service men and women for the November State and Federal elections will be recorded in the Southwest Pacific theatre area, ranging from cities to deserts, from jungles to coral islands nearly twice as large in extent as the United States.

ROME, Aug. 15 -- The Feast of the Assumption is a great religious and secular midsummer holiday in Italy. Today it also marks the assumption by the Italian Government of administrative authority in three more provinces, including Rome. While one of the war's greatest battles unfolds in France this change is of secondary interest to the outside world, but it is an event of major importance to Italy.

Buying by the mills to fix prices absorbed early selling in the cotton market yesterday and after showing early losses of 8 to 13 points, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange rallied and closed at about the top of the day with net gains of 2 to 6 points.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Controller of the Currency told the nation's bankers today that their major responsibility, once the war is over, "will be the search for lending opportunities in a society of free enterprise and personal initiative."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Military observers here emphasized today their belief that, despite the spectacular new landings on the southern coast of France, the battle sector in northern France remains the important area, where "very decisive" results may be achieved.

For rescuing a shipmate trapped in the forward fireroom of the U.S.S. Corry on invasion day after word had been given to abandon ship, Lieut. (j.g.) John Oliver Parrott of Pasadena, Tex., received the Navy Cross at ceremonies yesterday at Fort Jay, Governors Island.

TRENTON, Aug. 15 -- The request of Gov. Ellis Arnall of Georgia for the extradition of Herman Powell, 35 years old, a Negro, who was captured in Newark after escaping from prison in the Southern State while serving a life term for murder was granted today by Gov. Walter E. Edge, who urged clemency for the fugitive.
A communique, as broadcast in English to North America from Chungking and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

Tony Janiro, 135 3/4 Youngstown, Ohio, knocked out Leo (Red) Brown, 134, Brooklyn, in 2:08 of the fifth of the scheduled main attraction of eight rounds last night at MacArthur Stadium in Brooklyn before 4,200 fans. The victor had his opponent, a substitute for Tommy Mills, so outclassed that Referee Ed Josephs had to intervene.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15 -- The Federal grand jury reconvened today to continue its investigation of the recent Philadelphia Transportation Company strike and heard Charles E. Ebert, executive vice president of the company.

LONDON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Germans said tonight that the Allies' invasion of southern France was in full swing along a 125-mile stretch of the Mediterranean coast between Cannes and a point west of Toulon.
BING MILLER coughed. "I gotta cold," he said and then added accusingly, "you did it, Dykes. You stole my shoes."

Sixteen States have started to mail State ballots for the November elections to members of the military services and most of the other thirty-two are planning to start their mailings within the next three weeks. Eight began the distribution of their ballots yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Ben Lindas, Government-appointed and unpaid attorney for George Sylvester Viereck, a defendant in the mass sedition trial, today asked Justice Edward C. Eicher to consider his contention that publication of a book called "Blackmail," by Henry Hoke, was prejudicing his client's case.

"In Society," a Universal comedy starring Abbott and Costello, will open this morning at Loew's Criterion. This marks the comedy team's first film release in more than a year. Among the supporting players are Marion Hutton, Arthur Treacher, Ann Gillis, Thomas Gomez and Will Osborne and his orchestra.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Wednesday, Aug. 16 -- Invigorated by the landing of another liberation army in Europe, the Allies' forces in northwestern France are showering steel on the ten-mile gap that has all but closed on the back-tracking rear-guard elements of two German armies.

The Port of New York Authority awarded yesterday to Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and Blyth Co., Inc., and forty-five associates $17,671,000 of general and refunding bonds maturing Aug. 15, 1974. The winning syndicate paid 95.85 for the issue as 2 per cent obligations.

ROME, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Canadian troop newspaper Maple Leaf in an editorial column praising the daring tactics of the Americans in northern France declared today that "our allies from another of the 'decadent democracies' have done a magnificent all-around job.

LONDON, Wednesday, Aug. 16 -- A unique and powerful assault on the German Air Force was made yesterday when more than 1,000 American heavy bombers and at least 1,100 British "heavies" carried out a task of mauling enemy airfields and air stations in the Reich, the Netherlands and Belgium.

It is an old American custom that when a man has committed a fault he be called to account for it. If he acknowledges his mistake and makes amends the matter is closed. General Eisenhower took that attitude last year when Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton Jr., himself weary from battle, berated and slapped two "combat fatigue" cases during the Sicilian campaign, then apologized to them and to the Seventh Army for his conduct.
ROME, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The text of General Maitland Wilson's message:
ROME, Aug. 15 (AP) -- A communique:

The Brooklyn Red Cross Blood Donor Center at 57 Willoughby Street apparently was the victim yesterday of "the war is over" optimism brought on by the invasion of southern France. Officials at the blood bank reported that cancellations of appointments had reached a new high record.

Equitable pricing programs will be pressed for by the shoe industry advisory committee at a meeting to be held with Office of Price Administration executives in Washington tomorrow, it was learned yesterday. The meeting has been called by OPA, it is reported, due to expected easing of curbs in the leather conservation order, M-217.
BOSTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Browns, paced by a grand slam swat by Shortstop Vernon Stephens, defeated the Red Sox, 6 to 5, today and regained their American League lead of six and a half games.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 9:

PEARL HARBOR, Aug. 15 -- Land-based bombers and fighters from Admiral Chester W. Nimitz's command attacked Japanese-held targets from the Kuriles to the Marianas and Nauru during the week-end, including a new target in the north Pacific, it was announced today.

Boy and Girl Scouts will receive two gifts from the "God Bless America" Fund in memory of Brig. Gen. Theodore Roosevelt, a trustee of the fund, who died last month in Europe, it was disclosed yesterday by fellow trustees. Simultaneously, it was announced that his widow would succeed him as trustee.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The Office of Defense Transportation, in a step to distribute vehicles no longer required by the Government, resumed today the acceptance of applications for the purchase of new light motor trucks for essential civilian use.

CAMDEN, H. J., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Ariel Flight, 8-1 shot, racing for Samuel Feinberg and showing a pronounced disregard for his three well-fancied opponents, drove to a two-length victory over Max Wexler's Plucky Raider in the Westmont Purse, featured offering at Garden State Park today.

Matthew M. Levy, chairman of the Liberal party's law committee, asked the major bar associations in the first judicial districts yesterday for advice in the selection of two candidates for vacancies on the State Supreme Court. In so doing, the Liberal party became the first to seek guidance from the organized bar in advance of naming candidates.

ROME, Aug. 15 -- The maximum effort was exerted today by the Mediterranean Allied Air Force, which threw in its full striking power to support the invasion of southern France, with more than 14,000 airmen participating. In addition, it made special sorties to drop tons of pamphlets giving directions to the French Forces of the Interior and the civil population.

The stock market accorded yesterday only nodding recognition to the new front opened by the Allies on the southern French coast. Hesitancy was again prevalent on the Stock Exchange, with narrow movements and a continuance of the dull trading, while the bulk of the interest centered in the low-price motors, all of which edged higher or closed unchanged.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Government coal officials, predicting a 6,000,000-ton shortage of domestic anthracite this winter compared with 5,000,000 last year, acknowledged today failure to accumulate emergency stocks of hard coal.

In spite of the heat wave a total of 67.7 tons of waste paper was collected in the last week at the Board of Education's 305 summer vacation playgrounds adjoining public schools in all parts of the city. Playgrounds in Brooklyn led all other boroughs with 57,382 pounds of salvaged paper to their credit for the week; the Bronx was second, then Queens, Manhattan and Richmond.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 15 (AP) -- A communique:

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- Short covering induced by reports of serious damage to the corn crop in Illinois, Ohio, Indiana and the Ohio Valley gave the grain markets a decidedly strong tone today on the Board of Trade. News of a bearish character was ignored and with heavy short covering, especially in oats, prices moved up quickly.

In what is believed the first action of its kind by a trade group with respect to wartime substitute goods, a committee of the Toilet Goods Association yesterday urged caution against creating surpluses of this type of merchandise. The committee recommended that manufacturers shape production and sales policies to avoid overstocking of wholesalers and retailers.

WITH ALLIED FORCES ATTACKING SOUTHERN FRANCE, Aug. 15 -- Until a few hours before troops stormed ashore today in southern France, the coastal defences of the underbelly of Adolf Hitler's Europe appeared about twice as tough as those encountered in Normandy. But the expected resistance failed to materialize.

The New York Reconstruction Home at West Haverstraw, N.Y., an institution for orthopedic patients, opened its two new buildings yesterday because of the increasing number of infantile paralysis cases. The buildings -- unused up to now -- were opened by order of the State Department of Health.

Edward G. Elkins, a personal property custodian for the city, appeared at the La Vie Parisienne, 3 East Fifty-second Street, last night with orders to take over the night's receipts, when the night club closed at 4 A.M. as part settlement of the city's claim against the club for taxes totaling $13,461.

ROME, Aug. 15 (UP) -- Polish troops of the Eighth Army battling northward in the Apennines today captured Monte Vecchio, two miles east of Frontone which was taken yesterday. American Fifth Army units around Pontedera and Larotta along the Arno River east of Pisa clashed with German patrols.

As an aftermath of accusations at the Hart City Council Committee hearings last year that city officials had been using municipal automobiles to drive to the race tracks and other places not having to do with city business, Mayor La Guardia's three-man committee suggested in a report yesterday certain "reasonable" rules to control the use of official cars.

One of the regrettable trends of our generation has been to make the production of children less profitable to parents. In the old days on the farm they were actually a good investment, helping assiduously with the chores and in the fields.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Chungking in English to North America and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

When reports come in from time to time of large game fish cavorting off our shores, the inclination here is to step up the electric fan another notch, mutter something profound like "So what?" and turn to matters not quite so unattainable.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16--A national campaign to urge approximately 7,000,000 members to vote in the November election was launched today by the American Federation of Labor.

LONDON, Aug. 16 (U.P.) -- A small force of British planes flew 900 miles across Europe Sunday night and dropped guns and ammunition to aid the hard-pressed Polish patriots fighting the Germans in Warsaw, it became known today.

On the strength of a dramatic, ninth-inning homer by Bud Metheny, the Yankees scored an 11-8 victory over the Indians yesterday at the Stadium in an endurance contest that lasted just 3 minutes short of 3 hours. It was questionable who suffered more, the contending teams or the crowd, although in the end all was forgiven.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Two Democratic candidates supported by the CIO for Congressional nominations were defeated, while United States Senator Alexander Wiley, Administration critic, was renamed by the Republicans in yesterday's primary election.
CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 16 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

MOSCOW, Aug. 16 (U.P.) -- Rapid Allied successes in southern France were predicted today by Konstantin Gofman, military analyst of the Soviet Army newspaper Red Star, principally, he said, because the Germans had been forced to divert the bulk of their reserves in that area to the Eastern Front.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- Necessity of improving medical school curriculums, the early release during the demobilization period of physicians on medical school faculties, and provision of further education for discharged medical officers comprise the challenges facing the profession today, it was indicated by a survey by the Journal of the American Medical Association.

LONDON, Thursday, Aug. 17 -- A deep thrust into the vitals of Germany's air power and oil supply sources was made yesterday by more than 1,000 heavy bombers of the United States Eighth Air Force, protected by an equal number of the Eighth's fighters.

Southwest Pacific, Thursday, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Allied bombers, in new blows at the Philippines and the Spice Islands, raided Davao, on Mindanao, and destroyed eleven airplanes at Halmahera, headquarters announced today.

Senator McKellar of Tennessee has introduced a resolution calling on our Government to seek permanent possession of all Japanese-owned and mandated islands between the Equator and the Thirtieth Parallel North. This would include Formosa and the Ryukus, which run north from Formosa toward the main islands of Japan.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Errard, a son of Challenger II that seems to enjoy racing in mud, captured today's $10,000 added Prairie State Stakes at Washington Park under the colors of the Chicago contractor, John Marsch.

LONDON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Flying bombs were hurled in artillery-like salvos at London and South England today and tonight, ending the dark-hour respite for the metropolitan area, as the public speculated on possible new terrors from improved rockets.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 16 -- The Allies' twin drives into France from the north and south are already linked from the Channel to the Mediterranean and from the Atlantic to the Alps by powerful operations of the French Forces of the Interior, who are now fighting with armor, it was announced today.

WITH THIRD ARMY, in France, Aug. 15 (AP) (Delayed) -- Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton's break-through from the Cherbourg Peninsula has been a typical Patton rampage. He sent his tanks storming forward and when they hit something they couldn't crack immediately he sent them around it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Now that the East Coast and many other parts of the country are sweltering in the heat wave, the old question comes up whether the Weather Bureau records the actual temperature of a city.

Provision for meeting the problems of shortages and surpluses in the New York milkshed and the New York market was contained in proposed amendments to the Federal-State marketing order outlined yesterday by William C. Welden, assistant chief of the Dairy and Poultry Branch of the War Food Administration.

This country being a free country, all of us are free to issue predictions of things to come. Many of us delight to take advantage of that privilege. It is an easy way of acquiring merit. As prophets, we can always be sure of a little honor, if only in our own households.

SPOKANE, Wash., Aug. 16 (AP) -- The favorites, led by Harold McSpaden of Philadelphia and Byron Nelson of Toledo, crashed through to one-sided victories today in 36-hole first-round matches of the National P.G.A. golf championship.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Steps taken by Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, for the resumption of production of much-needed civilian goods will not hamper output for war, the Senate committee investigating the defense program reported today.

The ice shortage throughout much of the New York metropolitan area became increasingly acute yesterday, forcing the abandonment of virtually all cooling systems fed by ice and the institution of many local rationing practices to spread the dwindling supplies.

CALDWELL, N.J., Aug. 16. -- The Navy Department permitted today description of the blimp that can back up. Sailors at the Lakehurst Naval Air Station already have named it the Killaloo for the bird that flies backward so it can see "where it came from."
In referring to the "Prussian Code," a recent editorial makes the reader believe that the code was broken by the laying of a bomb -- a plebeian weapon -- against a "civilized" Government.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- In a letter today to J.H. Moseley, president of the Civic League of Westchester, County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach accused Mr. Moseley of being "nasty and impertinent" in recent criticism of airport inspection trips by county officials.

In a statement upbraiding the New Deal for "slapping down the legitimate claims of Negroes," Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican National chairman, announced yesterday that a court action was being instituted in Georgia to require State officials to substitute a list of white and Negro Republican candidates for Presidential electors for a slate of "lily white" Republican electors they already have accepted.

My interpretation of your editorial on Aug. 8, "Control for Control's Sake, was exactly the reverse of that of the ladies whose criticism of it was printed in THE TIMES of Aug. 12. They said, "You seem to wish to open economic opportunities only to those who already possesses economic power."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The Internal Revenue Bureau plugged a possible loophole in the wage stabilization program today by ruling that the value of options granted to employes to buy stock in the employer's company must be treated as salary.

A new management, dissociated from the Southern Railway, was suggested yesterday for the Georgia Southern Florida Railway by Ernest E. Norris, president of Southern, in a formal letter to the security holders of the Georgia Southern Florida.
ROME, Aug. 16 (UP) -- A communique:

All of 16-year-old Paul Malden's friends were in the Army, so Tuesday night when he was to meet them at the Central Park Zoo, he, too, decided to show up in uniform, Paul told Magistrate William Klapp yesterday in Yorkville court, where he appeared to answer a charge of unlawfully wearing an Army uniform.

A violent thunderstorm, accompanied by a downpour and heavy winds, swept the city at sunset last evening, flooding subways all over the city and delaying thousands of persons during the height of the evening rush hour.
LONDON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- British fighter planes have practically doubled their destruction rate of German aircraft within the past six months as a result of a new gyro gunsight that has brought about a "revolutionary change" in aerial fighting, the British Air Commission announced here tonight.

"All this talk about immediate post-war production of home appliances being limited to 1942 models simply isn't true," J. Gordon Lippincott, industrial designer, said in an interview here yesterday. Asked how soon we will get new products, he said:

Four white youths who had been arrested on Aug. 6 as suspects in the slaying of Beasley Player, 24 years old, a Negro, of 168 Lenox Avenue, when he was walking on Third Avenue near 116th Street, were paroled for a hearing yesterday. Magistrate Anna M. Kross explained she had taken the unusual procedure because their detention tinged of "seventeenth century justice."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- 1orty-five manufacturing companies now flying the Maritime Commission's "M" pennant have received Gold Star renewal awards for continued achievement in production for the Victory Fleet. In addition to the companies' 38,000 employes now wearing the "M" badge, new employes eligible for this production badge will be honored.

In your issue of today Morris E. Ernst concludes his more than adequate answer to Charles E. Turtle's argument respecting the soldiers' vote, by saying that Governor Dewey has "successfully" employed the Constitution to deprive soldiers of their vote without giving the courts an opportunity to pass upon the constitutional question involved.

LONDON, Aug. 16 (U.P.) -- Traditionally, the Black Rod of the House of Lords marches to the Commons, heralded by cries of "Make way for the Black Rod." There, the chamber doors are closed in his face. Three times he knocks with the black ebony rod which is the symbol of his office, and then the doors are opened for him to deliver his message.

Plans for an as yet undisclosed municipal project to cost in the neighborhood of $43,000,000 will be released to the public within a month, Mayor La Guardia disclosed yesterday at a luncheon of the Kiwanis Club at the Hotel McAlpin.

Because the amount of gold held for any foreign nation is a confidential matter which the Federal Reserve Bank does not divulge, there is likely to be no official announcement on the amount of Argentine earmarked gold frozen in this country by yesterday's order in Washington.

If estimates of mercerized yarn production in the third quarter are an indication, mercerized hose will not be manufactured at all for civilians in the last quarter of 1944, hosiery men stated yesterday. Third quarter production has provided no free yarn in 31's to 40's plied and not enough of these counts to cover low priority ratings.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 16 Twentieth Century-Fox has opened negotiations with Metro-Goldwyn Mayer to borrow Kathryn Grayson for the singing lead in the proposed musical version of "State Fair." Miss Grayson, now in "Anchors Aweigh" at M-G-M, also is scheduled for "Brighton Beach," with June Allyson and Jimmy Durante.

IT was very early in the season that the telegram arrived. "Don't look now," it stated, "but are the St. Louis Browns actually leading the American League?" The message was from Jimmy Conzelman, the gay caballero who is the assistant to the president of the Brownies. Since then, however, it has become proper to look.

NORMANDY FRONT, Aug. 16 (U.P.) -- More than 100,000 French civilian refugees herded from their homes by the Germans and now left helpless somewhere inside the tightening Allied ring west of the Falaise-Avranches road present a difficult potential problem for Allied relief authorities.

To the surprise of most race-goers in a crowd of 19,809 Crispin Oglebay's Price Level yesterday captured the $18,900 Spinaway Stakes at Belmont Park by the amazing margin of four lengths, and at better than 18 to 1. With a dozen going to the post for the fifty-third running of Saratoga's six-furlong filly dash, most bettors were thinking about almost anything except Price Level.

ROME, Aug. 16 (AP) -- An all-American team under Gen. Sir Henry Maitland Wilson directs the invasion of southern France on the ground, in the air and on the sea, Allied Headquarters announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The United States Government has frozen Argentina's gold stocks in this country and is considering the application of much stronger economic pressure against that country, it was learned today.

ALBANY, Aug. 16 -- Thomas E. Dewey, acting in his capacity as Presidential candidate and leader of the Republican party, struck out today in a formal statement of his views on foreign affairs, at all proposals which call for domination of the post-war world by the four-power combination of Britain, Russia, China and America.

ON THE FALAISE FRONT, France, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Field Marshal Gen. Guenther von Kluge's "butchers and bakers" defense sagged heavily today inside the Normandy bulge as British patrols swept unopposed into Conde-sur-Noireau and the first signs of chaotic confusion appeared in enemy ranks.

Electric power production for the week ended Aug. 12 was 4,415,368,000 kilowatt-hours, compared with 4,399,433,000 in the preceding week, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. This was 3 per cent over the corresponding period last year when the total was 4,287,827,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The American Labor party is a "communistic outfit" in no way representative of American labor, Representative Fish, Republican, of New York, told the House today, and aded that those who accept its support must take the responsibility of being affiliated politically with the Communists.

Advertising lineage in fifty-two cities throughout the country during July was off 5.8 per cent compared with the same month last year, according to Media Records. Classified continued to have the largest loss, or 15.7 per cent. Department store advertising was next with 9 per cent; retail, third with 5.4 per cent; and total display, fourth with 2 per cent.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16 -- Hundreds of defiant AFL machinists failed to report today for overtime work at uptown machine shops seized by the Navy under Presidential order, with the result that Rear Admiral Harold G. Bowen, officer in charge, began putting into immediate effect sanctions authorized last night by Fred M. Vinson, Director of Economic Stabilization.
LONDON, Aug. 16 -- The Russian draft proposals for post-war security are similar, in principle, to those proposed by the United States and Great Britain, a British spokesman said tonight.

Assisted by an advisory committee of thirty leading restaurateurs, the Office of Price Administration has worked out plans to protect persons who dine out against diminishing portions and dishes renamed to command higher prices, Russell Hall, assistant to the regional price executive, reported yesterday.

Independent nominating petitions for national, State and local candidates were filed yesterday on behalf of the new Liberal party, the Socialist party and the Industrial Government party. Other groups, such as the City Fusion party, the Victory party and the Constitutionalist party, filed for one or more candidates for local office.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The Roosevelt Administration, through James F. Byrnes, Director of the Office of War Mobilization, was reported today to have advised the House Ways and Means Committee in executive session that it believed no State should provide maximum unemployment benefit payments of less than $20 a week and that the duration of the payments should not be less than twenty-six weeks.

DETROIT, Aug. 16 -- Labor slowdowns resulting from workers' "Self-imposed" restrictions on output are a common occurrence in Detroit, despite the need for all-out war production, and are seriously interfering with the effort to produce the heavy trucks, tanks, guns and other items now on the Army's critical list, according to the leading automobile companies and other manufacturers of military equipment.

LONDON, Aug. 16 -- The Italian Government has established what may prove a welcome precedent by approving in principle a request by the Intergovernmental Committee of Refugees that it should naturalize some of the non-Italian refugees in Italy and allow them to remain.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 16 -- Weary of being shoved around by the hoi polloi of the National League, the Giants stepped out on Sportsman's Park tonight to take one on the chin from the champions. The Cardinals took full advantage of the occasion, plastering the eleventh shut-out of the campaign on the Polo Grounders, 5 to 0.
ROME, Aug. 16 -- All the objectives set for the Allies first day's operations in southern France between Cannes and Toulon have been taken according to schedule.

BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, Aug. 17 -- Frontier reports early this morning announced that in Haute-Savoie, where they had previously avoided major clashes with the Germans, the FFI had launched an offensive to clear Savoie of German forces.

The aircraft industry was warned yesterday that it must prepare for the downhill pull of contract termination just as it prepared for the uphill battle of production, still going on, if the industry was to be saved for the future.

A UNITED STATES BOMBER BASE in England, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Lieut. Edward Witty of Walbridge, Ohio, 19-year-old Fortress pilot, told here tonight of "the worst forty seconds I ever spent in my whole life" -- forty seconds in which his B-17 Squadron was ripped to bits in a suicidal attack of German fighter planes, his buddy was lost and six of the eleven planes in his squadron were shot down.

In the midst of Germany's worsening military position, the German Foreign Office's NPD Agency has transmitted abroad a propaganda dispatch quoting the periodical Berlin-Rome-Tokyo as appealing for a peace based on a "genuine compromise of interests" among "victors and vanquished."

TORONTO, Aug. 16 (Canadian Press) -- Toronto moved to within a game of fourth place Jersey City in the International League standings tonight by taking their second straight twilight-floodlight doubleheader from the Little Giants, 1 -- 0 and 11 -- 5.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (P -- I The Terminal Railroad Asociation I

ALGIERS, Aug. 16 -- Thousands of copies of a single French news sheet, the Courrier des Nations Unies, were dropped on southern France today to tell the French about the Allies' landings and advise them how they could help. The Landser Post, addressed to the German soldier to give him an idea of the Allies' power against which he fights a hopeless struggle, was similarly distributed.

Cotton textile manufacturers will join the Office of Price Administration in opposing any move by the Southern cotton bloc to have textile prices reflect 105 per cent of parity and raise loans to cotton farmers to 97 per cent of parity, it was learned yesterday in Worth Street.

Developments in Washington, where legislation is being proposed to assure that cotton farmers receive parity for their cotton, more than overbalanced yesterday the continued favorable war news on the New York Cotton Exchange. After opening with overnight gains of 5 to 8 points, followed by some reaction, prices worked up steadily and closed near the best marks of the day, with net gains of 19 to 23 points.

"The Scarlet Lily," a novel based on the life of Mary Magdalene, by the Rev. Edward F. Murphy, pastor of the Blessed Sacrament Mission at New Orleans and head of the Departments of Philosophy and Religion at Xavier University, New Orleans, has been named the winner of the Bruce-Extension prize novel contest.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The regulation fixing ceiling prices over staple work clothes was completely revised today by the Office of Price Administration in an action designed, it was said, to "hold the line" on the cost of living.

Edward Grasing of Englewood, N.J., reached the quarter-final bracket, a round ahead of the men's field, in the Negro national tennis championships yesterday at the Cosmopolitan courts by eliminating Brabell Nesbitt of Elizabeth, N.J., 6 -- 1, 6 -- 0, in the only fourth-round match played.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 16 -- Redoubled effort toward adoption of a national service act so that America's manpower and material resources would be available if the country was again imperiled was urged today upon the California Department of the American Legion by Warren H. Atherton, National Commander, at its twenty-sixth annual convention.

In contrast to moves by some large manufacturers who are setting up direct factory outlets in metropolitan areas, nine radio, television, refrigeration and electrical appliance manufacturers announced yesterday establishment of distributor relations in the New York area "as the best means of getting their planned expanded production to the consumer in the post-war period."

Although the Barrymore Theatre has been definitely reserved for "The Perfect Marriage" on Oct. 11, that house will get "Last Stop," scheduled to arrive there on Aug. 28. The Forrest previously had been booked for "Last Stop." The switch was made, according to a spokesman for the attraction, because the Barrymore is equipped with an air-cooling system.

INSIDE FALAISE, Aug. 16 -- The town of Falaise is going up in flames and smoke tonight amid a riot of cannon and machine-gun fire as the Canadians drive back the Germans in a fight that rages from street to street.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- Unanimously re-elected president of the American Federation of Teachers, which is holding its annual convention here, Joseph F. Landis today promised that the union would protect American youth against curtailment of opportunity and would attempt to expand public school services to meet the needs of the post-war period.

LONDON, Thursday, Aug. 17 (U.P.) -- Russian troops yesterday smashed into the streets of Sandomierz, vital Nazi base on the Vistula River 115 miles south of Warsaw and an obstacle before a Red Army drive on the Polish capital from the south, while Berlin reported that other Soviet forces had launched major attacks against East Prussia's eastern frontier.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Appeals for "driving all Communists and Jews into the oceans or burying them here if they can't swim" were addressed to an anti-Communist convention at the headquarters of the German-American Bund in Los Angeles in 1938, the jury was told in the mass sedition trial today.

ROME, Aug. 16 -- Three-fourths of Florence's population is said to be drawing food rations from the Allied Military Government, whose members operate throughout the city at a great risk to their lives, aided by patriots and civilians, in danger always lest the enemy seize their families in reprisal.
A rise in the price of grade eggs for the second consecutive week was authorized yesterday the Office of Price Administration

The Encyclopaedia Britannica is not certain even of the derivation of the word "infantry," but it devotes thirty-one and a half of its precious columns to an exhaustive study of the genesis of the infantry, its development and its present-day use.

If it isn't thrown off the plane for priority cargo, 400 pounds of lettuce will arrive in New York from Salinas, Calif., next Wednesday, part of one of the largest shipments of vegetables and fruits ever to be sent express by United Airlines.

John Gassner, who formerly headed the play-reading department of the Theatre Guild, has joined Columbia Pictures and will represent the company in its future theatre activities, it was announced yesterday. Columbia is opening a special office for Mr. Gassner at 655 Fifth Avenue, through which will pass all matters pertaining to the financing, selection and development of plays for the Broadway stage.

A fantastic story of a homicide, first revealed to the authorities by the voluntary confession of a 19-year-old Columbia sophomore, was converted yesterday from a nightmarish fantasy into a horrible reality by the discovery of the bound and stabbed body of the victim in the murky waters of the Hudson River.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Eddie Lopat, Chicago rookie southpaw, pitched seven-hit ball tonight to notch his sixth victory of the season and give the White Sox a 7-to-2 triumph over the Senators.

Six young neighborhood friends acted yesterday as pallbearers at the funeral of 17-year-old Joseph Good, who, police say, was killed last Friday by striking his head against a chair after a scuffle with his brother James, 19, a former soldier.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Aug. 16 (AP) -- James Aaron Thacker, former president of a United Mine Workers local union at Middlesboro, was sentenced in Federal District Court here today to two concurrent one-year terms in prison on charges of violating the War Labor Disputes Act in connection with a coal strike at a Government-operated mine in Bell County last year.

William P. Snyder Jr., a director of the Crucible Steel Company of America since 1930 and chairman of its executive committee since July, 1942, was elected yesterday chairman of the company to succeed F.B. Hufnagel, who has resigned as both chairman and president of the company.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Aug. 16 (AP) -- Chief Radioman George Ray Tweed, 42, who was rescued from Guam after thirty-one months of eluding the Japanese, has received an interlocutory decree of divorce from his wife, Mary Frances Tweed, 27, records in Superior Judge Jacob Weinberger's court revealed today.

Public offering of $1,300,000 of Pittsburgh, Pa., general public improvement bonds will be made today by a banking group composed of Braun, Bosworth Co.; Hallgarten Co.; Newburger, Loeb Co.; Francis I. du Pont Co. and R.H. Johnson Co.

A program calling for a year in the Army or Navy for all physically fit young men "immediately at the cessation of hostilities" was recommended yesterday by the Army and Navy Legion of Valor of the United States at the closing business session of the organization's fifty-fourth annual reunion in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Since, in its statement of the principles that should guide a post-war collective security organization, Governor Dewey's warning today follows the line which the American Government, particularly Secretary of State Hull, has steadily taken, it created interest but no alarm here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- In one of a series of moves intended to force cotton prices upward, Senator Bankhead of Alabama urged producers today to hold their crop off the market until parity had been reached.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Liberator bombers of Maj. Gen. Claire L. Chennault's United States Fourteenth Air Force last night raided the Japanese naval base of Mako in the tiny but strategically important Pescadores Islands, it was announced today.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., and its subsidiaries showed a net profit for the first six months of 1944 of $13,686,390 after depreciation, amortization, taxes and other charges, Robert C. Stanley, chairman and president, reported in the semi-annual statement to be released today.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Thursday, Aug. 17--In another swift and unexpected thrust, hard-riding Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton Jr. was reported by the Germans yesterday to have whipped his tanks within a little more than forty miles of Paris in an effort to outrun and outflank German forces fleeing toward the Seine from the Argentan-Falaise trap.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 16 (AP) -- A Federal court trade monopoly suit today named the General Electric Company of New York and charged the firm with controlling 90 per cent of the lamps manufactured and sold in the United States.

Spreading out along the world's most gorgeous playground, the Cote d'Azur, an Allied army under an American commander, Major General Patch, of Guadalcanal fame, has now completed the first stages of a new invasion of France "according to plan."

THIRD ARMY HEADQUARTERS, France, Aug. 16 (11:15 A.M.) -- The German Seventh Army is breaking up into roving guerrilla bands and appears today to have passed the point where it is able to mass its remaining men and supplies for a break-through to the Seine River to join other broken and disorganized units fleeing beyond Paris.
The coast of southern France thundered to the sounds of war yesterday as the Allies, in a "textbook classic" of "triphibian" war, extended and secured their beachheads.

The nation's output of crude petroleum last week again established a new high record, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production averaged 4,667,300 barrels daily, an increase of 16,650 over the previous peak of 4,650,650 recorded in the previous week.

With $25,000 already pledged, a drive to raise funds for the relief and reconstruction of cooperators and cooperatives in the war-torn areas of the world will be started officially Sept. 1, Wallace J. Campbell, director of the Freedom Fund Campaign, announced yesterday.

Word from Army authorities that Thomas A. LaBarca, 25 years old, of 40-45 Ninety-ninth Street, Corona, Queens, a private attached to an aviation unit near St. Petersburg, Fla., will be called back into active service if he were continued at liberty under $4,000 bail pending trial on a first-degree robbery charge resulted yesterday in cancellation of the bail before Judge Thomas Downs in Queens County Court.

ILE DU LEVANT, Aug. 15 (Delayed) -- This desolate island, guardian of the eastern approaches to the great French naval base of Toulon and commanding a good stretch of the Riviera coast where the American Seventh Army landed this morning, was seized early today in an amphibious operation unusual for its emphasis on stealth rather than overwhelming firepower.

MOSCOW, Aug. 16 -- The Red Army gave ground tonight for the first time since the beginning of the summer offensive on June 23, evacuating the village of Ossow, seven miles northeast of Warsaw, in the face of tremendous German tank attacks.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- Charging that federalization of State unemployment compensation would result in a further centralization of authority in the national Government, the Illinois Federation of Retail Associations went on record today in opposition to the move now before Congress, Joe Meek, secretary of the association, announced.

Two employer groups having collective bargaining contracts with the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America were solicited for financial contributions to the Citizens Political Action Committee at recent meetings called to consider changes in their agreements with the union, it was disclosed yesterday.

With yesterday's collection of waste paper by Department of Sanitation trucks in the city dropping forty-three tons under the amount salvaged on the preceding Wednesday, Mayor La Guardia conferred with salvage officials of the War Production Board and the New York Newspaper Publishers Association on how to check the downward trend.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Thursday, Aug. 17 (UP) -- A communique:

ATLANTA, Aug. 16 -- The Davison, Paxon Company has purchased the business of the Saxon-Cullum Company, one of the oldest and largest stores in Augusta, Ga., Charles H. Jagels, president of Davison, Paxon, an affiliate of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., announced here today.

Huge reserves of savings in the hands of the public, estimated at $75,000,000,000, may hold the volume of dollar and consumer credit extended in the two years after the cessation of European hostilities to approximately one-half of that outstanding in the pre-war period, according to a survey issued yesterday by Arthur Fertig Co., accountants and auditors.

A sealed indictment charging Thomas Gorman, 43 years old, fugitive Port Washington, L.I., real estate man, with selling 60,441 cases of liquor at prices above those set by the Office of Price Administration, at a profit of well over $1,000,000, was opened by United States Attorney James B.M. McNally in Federal Court here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (U.P.) -- Chairman Tom Connally, Democrat, of Texas, of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee revealed tonight that the forthcoming postwar security talks will be followed within two or three weeks by "the real conferences on a higher level" and predicted that a treaty providing for a world organization will be agreed on by this fall.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Miss Frieda Miller, new chief of the Women's Bureau who has studied women's war work as a special assistant to Ambassador John Winant in London and as New York Industrial Commissioner, sees serious wage and Job security problems ahead for women after the war.

With greatly increased cattle slaughter this year compared with last, and with the easing of shoe production restrictions already in effect, the luggage industry is hopeful that the War Production Board may modify or terminate some of the regulations that ban production of leather luggage, observers stated yesterday.
A LANDING BEACH, Southern France, Aug. 15 (Delayed) -- It is H-hour plus 6 and the landing on this central beach has succeeded beyond the wildest hopes.

Dr. Benjamin Parry, Weather Man, is a man to be envied as well as liked. Think of him in his topless tower, cloud-cooled, kept always at the right temperature by his Arctic surname. He was cradled in a refrigerator, he was air-conditioned at 12. He is kind to the less fortunate. He keeps promising us less mugginess, cooler weather.
LONDON, Aug. 16 -- The stock markets here were quiet today and an easier tendency prevailed generally.

TINIAN, Marianas Islands, Aug. 4 (Delayed) (AP) -- Hunched behind a gray limestone rock, two Japanese soldiers watched an American marine officer drive his jeep into No Man's Land, park it and non-chalantly climb out to look around.

Because Monday night's receipts were too small to warrant keeping a nightly vigil by a representative of the city in its action against the La Vie Parisienne, 3 East Fifty-second Street, for collection of sales taxes, the night club was ordered closed yesterday by Almerindo Portfolio, city treasurer.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 15 (Delayed) -- Refugees from the motor boat Bulbul arrived overland in Istanbul today from the small Turkish port of Igneada on the Black Sea and with them arrived five adult survivors from the boat Mefkure, which was sunk with 345 aboard by an unknown surface craft.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Two big innings, one including Bill Nicholson's twenty-seventh homer, gave the Cubs an 11-to-3 victory over the Braves in the opening game of their series today. The bases were filled when Nicholson connected.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16 -- Approval by the Securities and Exchange Commission of a refinancing program to retire $52,446,000 of 4 per cent bonds and 198,952 shares of $5 and $6 preferred stocks was sought today by the Ohio Edison Company of Akron.

This seems to be a good season for dessert sauces, for two more have recently made their appearance and are now available at Macy's. One, called Crush Strawberry, designed especially for use on ice cream, is particularly noteworthy in view of the shortage of that fruit.
LONDON, Aug. 16 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

CINCINNATI, Aug. 16 -- The first step in Leo Durocher's "four-game plan" against the Reds was a marked success today. Having deliberately kept Curt Davis, as well as Art Herring and Ben Chapman, out of the Cardinal series so that all three might be used against Cincinnati, Leo cashed the first dividend when Davis pitched the Brooks to a 3-1 triumph over Bill McKechnie's men.
Yesterday's communiqug, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federa Gommunieations Oommission:

No city on earth is more tragic than Warsaw today. Bombed, shelled and partially burned in 1939; scene of hideous murders and persecutions ever since 1939; containing a Nazi-created ghetto in which conditions were so horrible that its inhabitants rose in despairing fury and died by thousands under the fire of Nazi tanks and planes; now it is again being tortured by an unequal battle.
ROME, Aug. 15 (UP) -- Swarms of heavy and medium bombers cruised far into southern France today to blast bridges, highways and military installations without once seeing a German plane.

BOSTON, Aug. 16 (AP)--Rex Cecil's debut as a starting major league pitcher was spoiled today by the big bat of Rudy York, Detroit first baseman, as the Tigers defeated the Red Sox, 4 to 2. The victory put the Tigers only one-half game behind second-place Boston.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- Scattered showers fell over part of the Corn Belt on Tuesday night and yesterday morning but were too light to be of much benefit to the corn crop. The moisture, however, led to fairly general selling of oats and rye futures early today on the Board of Trade, oats declining 3/8 to 3/4 cent a bushel and rye around 1 cent before the break was checked.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Reports that President Roosevelt would begin pressing for a peacetime compulsory military training program soon, after his return to the capital, met a cool reception today among Congressional leaders who, nevertheless, appeared in substantial agreement that such a step must be undertaken before, or soon after, the end of hostilities abroad.

ST. TROPEZ, France, Aug. 16--Mistakes will happen with amphibious landings, so American parachutists took this resort in France when they should have been somewhere far inland. There was a group of tough, happy youngsters here this morning and they and the Allies' command are equally satisfied.

The stock market broke yesterday through the stalemate of the past few sessions, and scored its widest gains in about three weeks. The upturn, however, did not appear until the final hour and then under the leadership of a group of pivotal industrials.

John B. Turk, suspended chairman of the Downtown Rationing Board, and David Loeb, president of McGinnis Broadway Restaurant, Inc., entered guilty pleas yesterday in Federal Court to indictments charging them with conspiracy to deprive the Government of Turk's impartial services.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Gerald L.K. Smith, "America First" candidate for President, has been thwarted in his effort to obtain a buffalo from Yellowstone National Park to be named "America First" and to serve as the symbol of his party.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The House completed Congressional action today on the Senate-approved amendments to the Servicemen's Voting Law to eliminate restrictions which, as they have been interpreted by the War Department, have caused the withholding of much reading matter, including some books and newspapers, from members of the armed forces.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- Speed and production are everything in the final stages of the war, and America's women must not let it be said they "let down" at this crucial time, warned Miss Margaret Hickey, national chairman of the War Manpower Commission's advisory committee, which today opened a two-day meeting here.

PRIMOS, Pa., Aug. 16 -- The anthracite industry lifted today the shroud of mystery from the "secret-weapon," embodying an entirely new principle of heating, with which it will do battle with the oil companies in the fight for the huge fuel market in post-war homes.

TRENTON, Aug. 16 -- The military addresses of 50,000 Hudson County voters who are serving in the armed forces are being used for political purposes by the Democratic organization of Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, it was charged today by Gov. Walter E. Edge.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 16 -- It was hot enough this afternoon to discourage any one from exerting himself more than to reach for a cooling drink, and no one would have found fault with Miss Shirley Fry if she had decided to fan herself out of the Longwood invitation tennis tournament quickly after losing the first four games of her match with Miss Dorothy Head of Alameda, Calif.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 16 -- Announcement from Washington that gold shipments to Argentina have been suspended reached Buenos Aires today too late for publication in the afternoon newspapers and it therefore so far has passed unnoticed by a majority of Argentines.

President Roosevelt's popularity with the general public has increased in the last four weeks, according to a poll conducted for Fortune magazine and made public yesterday. It reported that 52.5 per cent of the public favored the President's re-election while 43.9 per cent supported Governor Dewey of New York, the Republican candidate.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Russ Christopher scored his fifth straight pitching victory tonight as the Athletics defeated the Browns, 4 -- 2, before a crowd of 13,567.

A UNITED STATES NINTH AIR FORCE FIGHTER BASE in France, Aug. 17 -- The German armored and mechanized units that have been stubbornly resisting American and Allied forces in the Normandy pocket for the last several days started late this afternoon withdrawing through the still unclosed Argentan-Falaise gap.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Mrs. Millard Tydings, wife of the Maryland Senator, and Mrs. W. Warren Barbour, widow of the New Jersey Senator, have served as nurses' aides here, and their experiences may result in bringing to the city a modern hospital center.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- A flying bomb narrowly missed Buckingham Palace recently, it can now be revealed. The robot struck a tall ash tree in the palace grounds and exploded before it reached the ground, blasting a stone wall separating the gardens from Constitution Hill.

Rent executives of the Office of Price Administration in the New York area reported yesterday that many landlords and agents of apartment houses and other rented residential buildings in the city were resorting to "improper methods'' in an apparent effort to force many tenants to give up their living quarters.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Friday, Aug. 18 -- American heavy and medium bombers have again struck hard at Halmahera Island, dropping eighty-seven tons of bombs on Miti airdrome, one of the three major Japanese air-bases on the island.

CHICAGO, Aug. l7 -- Although rye and wheat advanced sharply in the early trading today on the Board of Trade, the strength came largely from a continuation of short-covering that developed earlier in the week. Both grains were up around 1 cent a bushel at one time, but heavy profit-taking and professional selling developed in rye as the result of good rains and much lower temperatures in many sections of the main Corn Belt.

AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Continuance of outdated pay rates for newly created rubber industry jobs -- a system to which "both management and labor are opposed" -- has cost from 30 to 60 per cent in worker productivity of heavy-duty tires, the War Manpower Commission asserted today.

ROME, Aug. 17 -- The Allies have driven thirty-five miles inland from the Mediterranean coast of France and fanned out close to both Cannes and Toulon, it was officially announced tonight. Draguignan, thirty-five miles from the shore, was taken by the Americans, as were Vidauban, Besse and Cuers. Other troops were in La Napoule, in the outskirts of Cannes, while the western force was within ten miles of Toulon.

Six parcels of real estate in the metropolitan area have been sold during the past few weeks by Cornell University, Ithaca, N. Y., according to Realty Management, a division of Realty Mortgagee Corporation.

The Liberal party announced yesterday that Vice President Wallace, its nominee as President Roosevelt's running mate, had signed a declination and that the party would support Senator Harry S. Truman, the Democratic Vice Presidential nominee.

Rivalry between the Army and the Navy has resulted in appalling wastages of funds, manpower, time and critical materials, Senator Harry S. Truman, Democratic candidate for Vice President, said in a signed article appearing in this week's issue of Collier's magazine, which goes on sale today.

GROTON, Conn., Aug. 17 (AP) -- Work was resumed late today at the submarine plant of the Electric Boat Company after union and company officials announced they had found, during a conference with Governor Baldwin, a formula for ending the strike which started Monday.

With what Governor Dewey says about giving the smaller nations an honorable and proper share in the organization of peace, and avoiding anything like an attempt at domination by the four Great Powers, this newspaper is in agreement. We have frequently expressed the belief that any plan based exclusively on a four-Power alliance would fall short of the needs of the post-war situation and prove unacceptable to the American people.
Sales by banks of several housing and business properties in scattered sections of Manhattan were announced yesterday.
