Indicating its intention of ultimately approving the project, the Board of Estimate at a meeting yesterday referred to Ignatius M. Wilkinson, Corporation Counsel, a plan to permit residents of Broad Channel, a city-owned island in Jamaica Bay, to purchase home sites from the city and pay the cost of improving the area over a twenty-year period.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The American Federation of Musicians, AFL, headed by James C. Petrillo, refused today to obey the National War Labor Board command of June 15 to withdraw the union ban against making phonograph records and transcriptions for some companies.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 17 -- Rear Admiral Harold G. Bowen, operating five machine shops seized by the Navy under Presidential order, expressed dissatisfaction today over the attitude of "non-complying" workers and continued certifying recalcitrants for induction into the armed forces or loss of jobs and extra gasoline rations.

LONDON, Friday, Aug. 18 -Russian troops for the first time in thirty years carried the war to the German border yesterday, smashing across a battlefield littered with Nazi dead, burned-out tanks and battered gun platforms and reaching the East Prussian frontier along the Sesupe River in western Lithuania.
Floyd W. Leonard, recently with the War Production Board, has joined the William L. Gilbert Clock Corporation, Winsted, Conn., as merchandise manager.
WASHINGTON, Aug. l7 -- Brig. Gen. James E. Wharton has been killed in action in France, where he was on an unannounced assignment.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 17 -- The Argentine press tends to minimize the importance of the suspension of gold shipments to Argentina. No major paper comments on it editorially, though the Nationalist organ Federal clearly reveals its resentment by printing the news of it under the headline, "New Sample of Yankee Animosity."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- President Roosevelt returned to the capital today from his Pacific tour after having informed the world in a train interview that Germany and Japan would be occupied by Allied troops regardless of when or how they surrendered.

EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 17 (AP) -- L.R. Boulware, operations vice chairman of the War Production Board, expressed the belief today that the nation must absorb an output of peacetime goods two-thirds to three-fourths above the 1935-39 average "if all the people who want employment are to have it after the war."

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Electric Power and Light Corpotation asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today to approve its proposed surrender to the Arkansas Power and Light Com. pany, Pine Bluff, Ark., of 7,697 shares of the latter's $7 preferred stock and 1,233,635 shares of its no par value common stock.

A plea of curiosity was entered by two young British merchant seamen yesterday to Brooklyn County Court Judge Louis Goldstein when they were arraigned on an indictment charging them with the theft of a truck. The defendants are Kenneth Coakley, 20 years old, and James C. Graham, 19 both of Middleboro, Yorkshire, England.

WITH THE SEVENTH ARMY on the Rrench Riviera, Aug. 16 (Delayed) -- A French conquering force set foot on it sown beautiful southern coast this morning and began to do its part in the reconquest of France as part of the Seventh Army under Major Gen. Alexander M. Patch.

Although it is believed in many quarters that an early peace will bring about a sharp reaction in commodity prices as a result of the upheaval expected upon the widespread cancellation of Government contracts, the Commodity Research Bureau, Inc., in a survey just released, declared that price recessions probably will not be as severe as many expect.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Aug. 12 were 896,172 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 5,714 cars, or 0.6 per cent more than for the preceding week, 9,008 cars, or 1.0 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year and 27,327 cars, or 3.1 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Lieut. Gen. Jonathan Wainwright, who was the commanding General on Bataan when the Philippines were overrun and a prisoner of the Japanese for almost two and a half years told a representative of the International Red Cross that conditions in his camp in Formosa were "as good as can be reasonably expected," Red Cross headquarters reported today.
LONDON, Aug. 17 (Reuter) -- A communique issued yesterday by General Bor, commander in chief of the Polish Home Army, received today by the Polish Telegraph Agency, said:

A dirt-encrusted ring, appraised at nearly $1,000 but considered of little value when a scrub woman found it on the floor of the Lawyers Trust Company in the Empire State Building last April 25 cost a bank official a day in Jefferson Market Court yesterday and provided the Police Department with a test case for a loosely drawn municipal ordinance dealing with lost property.
HAVANA, Aug. 17 -- The entire commission, appointed recently by President Fulgencio Batista to negotiate the sale of Cuba's coming sugar crop to the United States, resigned today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The jury in the mass sedition trial today heard continued prosecution reading of documents seized by the Government in a raid on the German-American Bund headquarters in Los Angeles the day after the Pearl Harbor attack.

Paced by Long John Lindell, who equaled a major league record of long standing by unloading four doubles, the Yankees bagged their second straight triumph over the Indians at the Stadium yesterday, 10 to 3. That extended the McCarthymen's latest winning streak to four games in addition to giving the crowd of 5,922 something to forget the insufferable heat.

Clasping a copy of "A Vision," a philosophic work by W.B. Yeats, under one arm, Lucien Carr, 19-year-old Columbia sophomore, listened lackadaisically to the proceeding as he was arraigned yesterday morning before Magistrate Anna M. Kross in Homicide Court.

With the mercury at 92.6 degrees at 2:40 P.M., yesterday was the hottest Aug. 17 ever recorded by the Weather Bureau and the eighth successive day of 90-degree temperatures. But there was a distinct note of cheerfulness in the official weather prognosticator's voice last night when he forecast that while today would be cloudy and warm, a break would come with thunder showers in the afternoon, followed by cool weather continuing over the week-end.

An important corner in the textile district came under one ownership yesterday as the result of the purchase of three buildings at the southwest corner of Broadway and Worth Street by the Iselin-Jefferson Company, cotton goods.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 17 -- Rumanian negotiations with the Allies to reach an agreement on possible armistice terms are continuing secretly, although at present they seem to be in a condition of stalemate. The most recent series of discussions took place in Lebanon between the Rumanian delegation, headed by Prince Barbu Stirbey, who went to Cairo last March, and Constantin Visoianu, who passed through here two months ago, and a group of Allied representatives.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- Swiss reports said tonight that most members of the Vichy Government had fled to Berlin, leaving 5,000 mobile guardsmen of doubtful loyalty guarding the capital menaced by the Allies and a multitude of patriots storming ahead of them.

WITH FIRST CANADIAN ARMY FORCES, in Falaise, Aug. 17 -- This birthplace of William the Conqueror was a lost but liberated town today, lost to the Germans, lost to those seven thousand or more persons who used to live here, but freed by the Canadians from the grip in which it had been held by the Nazis for these last four years.
LONDON, Aug. 17 (UP)--A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Once again, in the successful invasion of the French Mediterranean coast, the effectiveness of vertical attack has been demonstrated. Paratroopers and glider-borne infantry, together with their light guns, jeeps and other motorized equipment, were dropped behind the German coastal defenses with beautiful precision on D-day.

MOSCOW, Aug. 17 -- United States Ambassador W. Averell Harriman has given the Lublin Polish group, which is recognized by Moscow, what it regards as assurances that there will be no serious trouble between the Soviet Union and the United States on Polish problems, it was disclosed today.

To pave the way successfully to complete peacetime use of its "war-swollen" capacity, industry must start now to lay a foundation of public understanding of its problems in the plant -- cities where industry exists and is closest to the people, according to the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association.

DETROIT, Aug. 17 -- George Romney, general manager of the Automotive Council of War Production, said today that experts in the automobile industry, which is now converted almost entirely to war work, believed that production could be increased 20 to 30 per cent if the workers would work as hard and fast as they could.

The Continental Bank and Trust Company, as trustee, sold the twenty-two story building at 5 East Fifty-seventh Street to an investing client of Dwight, Voorhis Helmsley, Inc Erected in 1927 by Arthur Brisbane for the Hearst interests, the building is on a lot 30 by 100 feet and was taken over last October at foreclosure by the Continental Bank.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Aug. 16 (U.P.) -- The victorious British Fourteenth Army has driven the last of Japan's ill-fated "invade India" army out of India, with the exception of a very few starving stragglers, and pushed them two miles south of the Burma border along the Tiddim Road, an Allied spokesman said today.

GUAM, Aug. 11 (Delayed) -- A non-stop war in the Pacific, with separate teams of amphibious forces under Admirals Raymond A. Spruance and William F. Halsey alternately planning and fighting the future operations, was outlined here today by Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet and Pacific Ocean areas, in an interview during a thirty-six-hour visit to Guam.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The Allies "are now a day ahead of their schedule" in southern France and the Germans "definitely seem to be on the toboggan," Acting Secretary of War John J. McCloy declared today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- A rise of six-tenths of 1 per cent in living costs from June 15 to July 15, based on the Bureau of Labor Statistics Index, was reported today by Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins.
WITH FRENCH FORCES IN SOUTHERN FRANCE, Aug. 16 (Delayed) -- A reborn and rearmed French Army has struck its own first amphibious blow for the liberation of the motherland.

Spreading out with explosive force Allied power continues to sweep through France. With almost reckless abandon and complete disdain for any German threats to their flanks, the armored columns of the American Third Army plunge ahead as though through empty space, overrunning whatever German garrisons they find in their path, taking one important city after another, spanning rivers, overcoming all obstacles.

With five States reporting outbreaks of infantile paralysis reaching epidemic or near-epidemic proportions, more cases of the disease were recorded in the United States in the first thirty-one weeks of 1944 than during any comparable period in twenty-eight years, the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Following the market decline early in August, advancing prices for agricultural commodities, particularly livestock and fresh fruits and vegetables, caused the Bureau of Labor Statistics index of commodity prices in primary markets to rise 0.4 per cent during the week ended in Aug. 12.

Strong indications that bulk purchases will remain an important factor in foreign trade with British areas as long as the War Production Board continues the Controlled Materials Plan in its present form, have been given to exporters by Captain W.G. Coventry, director of the British Supply Mission in the United States, it was learned yesterday.

In a letter which appeared in this column in reply to mine, Dr. Post Wheeler, criticizing Gandhi's present proposals for a settlement of the Indian question, asks me wherein they differ from his earlier proposals, made before his arrest. Gandhi was then ready, Mr. Wheeler says, to agree "that he would consent to the British troops remaining if merely for defensive operations, but that the Indian people must be set free meanwhile."

The first two years of the Pacific war, from the Solomons to the Aleutians, are described in "Pacific Battle Line" by Foster Hailey, NEW YORK TIMES war correspondent. The book, to be published by Macmillan Sept. 5, contains photographs and maps.

Jacob Berman, key figure in a $40,000,000 stock swindle in Los Angeles seventeen years ago, was named a defendant yesterday in a suit filed in Supreme Court that revealed that since he had been freed from Alcatraz Prison in 1935 he had victimized a host of other people, including two lawyers well known here.

With the recent amendment to general order 31 of the War Labor Board further clouding the outlook, retailers now face a far tougher problem than last year in adding seasonal employes to take care of the fall and Christmas holiday selling periods, it was reported yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Premier Ivan Bagrianoff, addressing an extraordinary session of the Bulgarian Parliament, extended a peace bid today, declaring "the Government is determined to remove all obstacles that stand in the way of the Bulgarian peoples' love for peace."

Money conditions were easy in the week which ended on Wednesday, but the sixteen reporting New York City banks, members of the Federal Reserve System, ended the period with a deficiency in required reserves of $15,000,000 as reserve balances fell $6,000,000 and requirements went up $14,000,000.

Many armies have filed through the streets of Chartres: Roman, Norman, German. Once great kings journeyed to the city. Popes made pilgrimage there. Built in honor of the Virgin, the cathedral of Chartres is a canticle in stone. Its towers, one of which dates from the eleventh century, are wonderfully wrought.
ROME, Aug. 17 (AP)--A communique:

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed increase in holdings of Government securities and note circulation for the system as a whole to be $9,133,000 and $108,487,000, respectively, while the ratio of reserve declined slightly.
CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Chinese Army has begun fresh operations north and south of the Yangtze River in the vicinity of Tungting Lake in central China, the High Command announced today.

NEW DELHI, India, Friday, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Field Marshal Viscount Wavell, Viceroy of India, has rejected a request for an interview by Mohandas K. Gandhi, who offered to urge full Nationalist support of the war effort if India were granted immediate independence, it was announced today.

JONES BEACH, L.L., Aug. 17 -- The State Council of Parks marked the twentieth anniversary of its establishment by the Legislature at its annual meeting and luncheon here today by planning post-war expansion of the State park system.

LONDON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- A nephew of Baron von Riehthofen, leading German ace of the last war, was captured with 563 other enemy troops at a radar station in Brittany by two American officers and taro unarmed civilians, it was announced today.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Friday, Aug. 18 -- Patrols of Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton's army are approaching Paris today across the storied battleground of central France.
GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Friday, Aug. 18 (AP)--A communique:

Two new John Wanamaker shops will be opened soon in Manhattan, it was announced yesterday by Charles R. Shipley, president of John Wanamaker. He revealed that leases had been signed for space at 385 Madison Avenue and at 59 Liberty Street.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 17 -- Joyce Reynolds, who had the name lead in Warner's "Janie," has been chosen by that company for the second lead in the proposed screen version of James M. Cain's "Mildred Pierce." She will play a youthful murderess, the daughter of Joan Crawford.

Reports of misuse of their commissions by some notaries public in certifying applicants for waterfront identification passes are under investigation, it was disclosed yesterday with an announcement by Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran that public hearings involving three licensed notaries would be held on Aug. 28, 29 and 30 at the State Office Building, 80 Centre Street.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., Aug. 17 -- Representative Edward J. Hart of the Fourteenth Congressional District, Jersey City, was elected today chairman of the New Jersey Democratic Committee to succeed Representative Mary T. Norton, also of Jersey City, who resigned effective today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Department store sales for the week ending Aug. 12 were up 13 per cent over sales for the like period of last year, it was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board.
LONDON, Aug. 17 -- Business on the stock markets here today was dull, with a slight tendency toward the end of the session to improve.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Miss Frieda Miller was sworn in today as director of the Women's Bureau in ceremonies held in the office of Frances Perkins, Labor Secretary.
LONDON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The weekly condition statement of the Bank of England for the week ended on Aug. 16 showed a decrease of u3,614,000 in note circulation.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 17 -- Anna, a Seeing Eye police dog, did her best to save her new master from being accidentally struck by an automobile while he was crossing Fifth Street at Franklin Street, here, about 10:50 o'clock last night.

As the war begins to go better and better for our side, thousands of Americans are disposed to quit their war jobs and hurry to peacetime jobs, eager to get in early on the prosperity that, they believe, awaits them just round the corner.

In the old pre-unionized days the boss would occasionally recommend to his workers that they vote for his candidate. There was no coercion or threat, you understand, but the worker was usually made to feel that his job would be safer and his promotion more likely if his political opinions turned out to be the same as those of the boss.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- One of the most uplifting items of news that exiled Frenchmen have heard since France fell they learned today from the German conqueror. It was that Paris today, for the first time since 1940, could hear the intermittent thunder of approaching gunfire.

BARI, Italy, Aug. 14 (Delayed) -- It is possible to form some impression here of the opinion prevailing among Greek guerrillas who recently were fighting in the homeland against both external and internal foes and who now are sick or wounded, being cared for in British hospitals.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Chungking in English to North America and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:
ROME, Friday, Aug. 13 (UP)--A special headquarters announcement:

ROME, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Allies have driven inland through the Argens Valley and along the main road and rail lines leading to Marseille. This drive has taken the coastal ridge of the Alpes-Maritimes known as the Chaine des Maures.

The Army and Navy sent 249 service men yesterday to help continue the work on service craft in the Bethlehem Steel's shipyards in Hoboken and at Fifty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, that has been halted by a walkout of nearly 400 laborers who are protesting a War Labor Board decision that granted wage increases to certain skilled classifications but denied them to the laborers.

SPOKANE, Wash., Aug. 17 (AP) -- While the two tournament hot shots breezed to easy victories, two other name players were tumbled out of competition today to provide the upsets of second-round matches in the national Professional Golfers Association championship.

The editorial "Hitler Hangs His Generals," in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 9, struck me as an ingenious device for destroying the last remnants of our confidence in certain groups and individuals among the German people.

MOLLESULAZ, French-Swiss Frontier, Aug. 17 -- Surrounded by a detachment of the French Forces of the Interior, estimated at 5,000 men, that commands all the strategic heights for more than twelve miles around, some 450 Germans of the army, the Elite Guard and the German customs services at Annemasse are solidly preparing for a last-ditch stand only a mile up the road from this frontier post.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Out of a gross income of $9,000,000,000 in 1943 the Association of American Railroads set aside $300,000 for technological research to insure improved equipment and methods of operation in the post-war era, R.V. Fletcher, vice president of the association, told the Kilgore subcommittee on war mobilization of the Senate Military Affairs Committee today.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Browns resumed their march toward the American League pennant by bunching their hits for a 10-to-5 victory over the Athletics today.
Cloud Wampler, president of the Carrier Corporation, maker of air-conditioning and refrigerating equipment, announced yesterday a new $3,500,000 financing program.
Two business buildings were among the East Side properties figuring in Manhattan realty transactions reported by brokers and operators yesterday.

ALBANY, Aug. 17 -- The State Education Department began an intensive campaign today to persuade boys and girls under 18 that they can best serve their country by going to school. Edwan R. Van Kleeck was placed in charge of the program which will be carried into each of the States 5,500 school districts.
The text of last night's appeal by a French Committee of National of Liberation spokesman to the people of Paris, as reported to the Office of War Information follows:

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 17 -- Digging a new low level for themselves tonight before 5,353 fans at Sportsman's Park, the Giants not only swallowed their tenth defeat in a row, but their second shut-out in two games and their twelfth white- washing this season.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 17 -- Miss Polly Andrews of Innis Arden scored her second consecutive triumph in women's Westchester - Fairfield Golf Association competition with a round of 41, 42-83 at the Apawamis Club today. In the association's previous event, at Woodway, the former Westchester - Fairfield champion began her come-back after a two-year absence from tournament play.

Mayor Edward J. Kelly of Chicago conferred yesterday with Edward V. Loughlin, leader of Tammany Hall, for about an hour at Mr. Loughlin's headquarters, 331 Madison Avenue. The visit, both agreed afterward, was social rather than political.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 -- The continuance of the present emergency training program, but on a broader basis and more flexible schedule to meet the post-war needs of youths who have taken war jobs before finishing school, was asked by the American Federation of Teachers today at its annual convention.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The Office of Price Administration established a number of conditions today under which manufacturers of low-priced consumer durable goods of many varieties will be able to apply for price increases.

ALBANY, Aug. 17 -- Governor Dewey declined today to continue the controversy which he started yesterday when he attacked what he termed proposals to have the post-war world dominated by Russia, Britain, China and the United States.

A petition by the Stork Club to prevent the city from attempting to collect $181,375 in back sales and business taxes was dismissed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Samuel Null. He gave the club five days to file a new petition or bring other action to prevent the city from selling its assets.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17 -- The Army returned control of the Philadelphia Transportation Company to civilian management at 11 A.M. today, about two weeks after it took over operation of the transit system, and began immediately to move its troops from the city.

Benny Tobolsky, 66-year-old veteran of many brushes with the law, who on Tuesday was used as a living example that "crime does not pay" by Magistrate Charles Solomon in Queens Felony Court, got a break yesterday from the same magistrate in the same court.

" Janie" begins a third week today at the Strand.... "Cry of the Werewolf" starts a second week at the Rialto.... The revival of "Dead End" is continuing for an eighth week at the Gotham Theatre.... "A Bill of Divorcement" and "Winterset" compose the dual revival program to be shown for ten days, starting today, at the Thalia Theatre.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 -- Congressional action is not necessary to validate State regulation of insurance, Floyd Jacobs, president of the American Reciprocal Insurance Association, said today to a subcommittee of the National Association of Insurance Commissioners.

As the first step toward removing "all Government control" from the poultry industry, support prices for poultry and poultry products should be lowered from the current legal rate of 100 per cent of parity to "75 to 80 per cent and not over 90 per cent" of parity, according to a resolution adopted yesterday by the Northeastern Poultry Producers Council in convention at the Hotel New Yorker.

BOSTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Rain today forced a temporary halt in the Red Sox-Detroit battle for second place in the American League. The game was called with the score 3 to 3 in the first half of the sixth inning with one out. The teams, separated by only half a game, will play a double-header tomorrow.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- The Bomber Command of the Royal Air Force carried out what must have been one of its greatest fire raids early this morning when about 1,000 four-engined aircraft showered 70,000 heavy incendiaries on the German ports of Kiel and Stettin.

Last April Artur Rodzinski, conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony, met RAF Wing Comdr. John Wooldridge, a 33-year-old pilot and composer. Commander Wooldridge showed Dr. Rodzinski a new work he had written, called "Constellations," and the conductor gave it a hearing at a Philharmonic rehearsal.

Lieut. Alex Santilli of the Marines, Fordham, '42, who was responsible for the Fordham University football team's victory over Missouri in the 1942 Sugar Bowl contest, was killed in action on Saipan July 8, according to a telegram received by his mother.

Because of the increased number of Americans taken prisoner by the enemy, an additional appropriation of $2,361,000 has been granted to War Prisoners Aid, participating agency in the New York War Fund's fall appeal, it was announced yesterday by Richard W. Lawrence, campaign chairman.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17 -- A registration statement covering 100,000 shares of $10 par value capital stock was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Mutual Telephone Company, Honolulu, T.H.

PASSAIC, N.J., Aug. 17 -- Stanley A. Carlson, 37 years old, president of the Howe Machinery Company of this city, was found dead in his office early this morning after the New York Telephone Company had requested Passaic police to investigate a call made at 6:55 A.M. to a woman registered at the Roosevelt Hotel in New York City.

A consolidated net profit of $3,379,676 for the fiscal year ended with June was reported by Best Foods, Inc., in the annual statement to stockholders, out today. The profit, which is equal to $2.25 a share, compares with $2,460,704, or $1.64 a share, for the previous fiscal year.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Hal Trosky's long fly brought Guy Curtright in from third in the ninth inning and gave Chicago a 1-0 victory over Washington tonight.

WHEN France fell four years ago she did not do so merely because she was over-powered by superior force. A number of her most responsible leaders, through their own folly, incapacity, greed, fear and even treason, had been busily preparing the way, had been digging France's grave. That they should have done so and brought France down to such depths of despair, humiliation and suffering is probably the greatest national tragedy of this century.

In spite of all the dry weather, housewives will have no difficulty finding fresh vegetables this weekend, according to the War Food Administration, for although some crops have been affected, many varieties are nevertheless plentiful, inexpensive and of good quality.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 17 -- Miss Doris Hart of Miami and Miss Margaret Osborne of San Francisco, the third and fourth ranking women tennis players of the country, were eliminated from the women's invitation tournament at the Longwood Cricket Club today.
SAINT RAPHAEL, France, Aug. 16 (Delayed) -- We hold not only this place hut Frejus, and American troops are probing well up the Argens Valley and into the hills to the north.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 17 -- Mrs. Edwin Luchs and Pete Ladislaw, Plandome, and Dr. and Mrs. R.S. Millen, Piping Rock, tied for the Long Island mixed foursomes championship today in the seventh annual tournament. The former pair returned a card of 84 -- 13 -- 71, the Millens had 89 -- 18 -- 71.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES, on the French Riviera, Aug. 16 -- The fangs that the enemy had kept hidden for more than twenty-four hours on this right flank of the beachhead were suddenly bared today as two previously unreported powerful pillboxes along the coast opened fire.

Directors of the Celanese Corporation of America authorized yesterday the declaration of a dividend of one share of common stock for each 70 shares of common held, payable Sept. 30. Shareholders received similar stock dividends in March and June.

ROME, Aug. 17 -- The Germans moved several tanks into Florence yesterday and, before they were withdrawn to positions previously held in a semi-circle about the northern section of the city, their guns killed a number of Carabinieri and a few score of civilians.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The House tentatively adopted today an amendment to the War Property Surplus Bill requiring the surplus property administrator to establish industry advisory committees.
ORLEANS, France, Aug. 16 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- American troops from Kansas, Nebraska, and Missouri poured into historic Orleans, capturing the city in one of the war's strangest battles.

Penalties involving the reduction of their quotas of anthracite coal have been imposed upon forty-two coal dealers in the New York metropolitan area who were charged with violating regulations of the Solid Fuels Administration for War, Walter J. Dockerill, regional representative of the SFAW, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The Wilsonian doctrine that a world security organization must be made an integral part of the treaties of peace has been rejected by the Administration.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Price Administrator Chester Bowles discussed publicly for the first time today the pricing of goods in the reconversion post-war periods, and promised to hold the cost of living "tightly in check" and guard against increases in rents and the prices of clothing and food.

A hearing called to consider means of increasing the quantity of fluid milk for consumers in the New York market was adjourned yesterday over the objections of a spokesman for independent dealers that a current shortage would grow more serious unless corrective measures were taken.

B. H. Levy Brother Co., Inc., Savannah, Ga., has been purchased by the Allied Stores Corporation, it was stated yesterday by B. Earl Puckett, president of Allied. This brings the total number of stores in the Allied chain to sixty-five. The sum involved in the purchase, which is effective immediately, was not made known.

CHARTRES, Aug. 16 (Delayed) -- This city was captured by American forces at 1:30 this morning after sporadic unorganized resistance but late this afternoon street fighting was still going on and snipers fired persistently from the north Gothic tower of the famous Chartres Cathedral.
LONDON, Friday, Aug. 18 -- The Ankara radio said today, "Allied forces have landed at Durazzo in Albania." The report was without Allied confirmation.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- Two years ago today an expeditionary force of twelve United States Flying Fortresses crossed the English Channel for the first time to drop eighteen tons of bombs on enemy railroad yards at Rouen, France. It was the initial bombing mission of the Eighth Air Force.

Aaron Perry, the youthful Washington welterweight who has built up an impressive record through the past year, will appear in the main bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. His opponent will be Jimmy McDaniels of Los Angeles.

Basing his analysis on more than a year's fighting, including the raids on the Gilbert Islands, Wake Island and in the recent victory of Task Force 58 off Saipan, Comdr. Ernest M. Snowden, commander of carrier-based Air Group 16 predicted yesterday a long Pacific war and warned against any relaxation when the European fighting is over.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 17 (AP)--Communique 131:

Thomas Jefferson Miley, secretary of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., wrote to Mayor La Guardia yesterday calling for abandonment for the time being of the City Planning Commission's proposed zoning amendments.

Victor Gargiulo, 46-year-old ex-convict, of 26 Amsterdam Avenue, was held yesterday in Felony Court in $5,000 bail, charged with a robbery in which a woman was offered nylon hose in quantity at $2 a pair and then robbed of her purchase money.

With a working capital of $200, City College's student loan fund has made 200 loans totaling $740 since its inception in January, 1943, it was revealed yesterday by Dr. John L. Bergstresser, dean of students and chairman of the Department of Student Life, which manages the fund.

The recovery movement in the stock market gained added momentum yesterday under a sudden burst of buying which pushed prices higher by a point and more. It was the widest advance in more than two months as the list returned to the position it occupied in mid-July.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Jim Tobin was combed for fourteen hits today, but secured his thirteenth victory as the Braves routed two Cubs' pitchers for a 7-to-5 triumph that evened the series at a game apiece.
CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 17 (AP)--A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

Two of the eight so-called "Boiler Room Boys" who last winter defrauded numerous business men of contributions for advertising in fake labor union publications they pretended were supporting the Red Cross and other war agencies, received prison terms yesterday in General Sessions, while the others got off with suspended sentences.

The quarter-final bracket in the men's singles of the Negro national tennis championships, being conducted by the American Tennis Association, was completed yesterday at the Cosmopolitan courts. Dr. Reginald Weir, of this city, winner of the crown last contested in 1942 and top ranked, had little trouble eliminating Pvt. Donald Ellis, also of New York, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1.

Commissioning ceremonies for the New York City "barracks" of the Navy's Women's Reserve were held yesterday afternoon in the auditorium of the refurbished Manhattan Towers Hotel, Broadway at Seventy-sixth Street. Rear Admiral William R. Munroe, USN, commandant of the Third Naval District, was the commissioning officer.

Maj. Gen. Alexander M. Patch, Commander of the Seventh Army, which ran the landing into southern France, is an old friend in a new place. In the spring of '42 he led the United States troops that, in association with the Free French Forces, defended New Caledonia from seizure by the Japanese.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Secretary Hull assured Governor Dewey today that the United States had never contemplated establishing a four-power military alliance to coerce the rest of the world and invited the Republican Presidential nominee to come to Washington "in a nonpartisan spirit" to discuss the security problem with him.

Argentina, a rich young nation, shows the characteristics of those families which, having succeeded in making a fortune, try by every means, including some that are bizarre, to cut a figure in society. It seems that this elemental egoism is based on natural law to judge by its continual reappearance in all ages down to the present.
The William Colgate house, built about 1840 at 22 East Twenty-third Street by the founder of the Colgate soap firm, has been sold by Miss Jessie Colby to the Ren-West Realty Company.

Our Hollywood sentinel yesterday asked Fredric March to confirm reports that he would appear on Broadway in the early fall as Maj. Victor Joppolo, the AMG official, in "A Bell for Adano," Paul Osborn's dramatization of John Hersey's best-seller.

A Navy meritorious service award in recognition of his services as senior civilian member of the Manpower Survey Committee of the Third Naval District was awarded yesterday to Chester I. Barnard, president of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company, at a brief ceremony at 90 Church Street.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Sweeping a double-header, the Pirates ran their victory streak to eleven straight -- tying Chicago for the longest in the National League this season -- in defeating Philadelphia, 7-6 and 6-5, today. Late rallies won both games as Pittsburgh tightened its grip on second place.

Stronghold and Bardia took the Class C and D races, respectively, at Belmont Park yesterday. Carrying the Wheatley Stable silks, Stronghold hammered his way through the stretch to capture the Champlain Handicap by a half length, while Gallant Bull ran third to burn up the $74,982 wagered on him.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- When the Secretary of State went to Moscow he took with him documents so well and carefully prepared that they were adopted with little change by the representatives of Soviet Russia, Great Britain and China in what became known as the Declaration of Moscow.

Financial markets in New York City will be closed on the next three Saturdays. The Board of Governors of the New York Stock Exchange voted yesterday afternoon to make the move. The reason given was that the Street's employes were exhausted.
ALBANY, Aug. 17 -- Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Hanley testified today, at his own request, before the special grand jury investigating reports of irregularities in legislative expenditures.

ALBANY, Aug. 17 -- Plans by Governor Dewey for two speaking engagements were announced today confirming the understanding that his formal campaign for the Presidency would begin immediately after Labor Day.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The United States and Great Britain will give "temporary" refuge to any Jews able to leave Hungary by virtue of regulations set up by this enemy country authorizing the emigration of Jews, the State Department announced here tonight.

The buying movement in cotton futures that started on Tuesday on the New York Cotton Exchange continued yesterday and prices advanced 18 to 20 points. This made an almost perpendicular rise of more than 50 points, or $2.50 a bale from the low point of Tuesday.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 17 -- Warning that Americans must not accept the philosophy that this war will end all wars and that there will never again be a need to resort to arms, Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson has called for universal peacetime military training to maintain the security of the nation.

Hyman N. Blumberg, vice president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, defended yesterday the solicitation of financial contributions to the Citizens National Political Action Committee at meetings between union officials and employer groups and said he expected further appeals during the Presidential campaign.

MOSCOW, Aug. 17 -- Orthodox priests in Russia are now free to carry on proselytizing work both in churches and outside, according to Georgi Grigorievich Karpoff, head of the Soviet Council on Greek Orthodox Church Affairs.

REBELLION against recognized authority rarely should be condoned or approved. But the Eastern Intercollegiate Football Association deserves a robust pat on the back for its recent decision to bypass the Football Rules Committee and set up its own code for the coming gridiron campaign. Maybe the heat wave is responsible for unfreezing the frozen rules but the main thing is that they have been given a thawing-out treatment.

The American soldiers now engaged in France, Italy and the Pacific or stationed in other remote parts of the world may be glad to learn that they have now been promoted out of the political kindergarten class. Under the reamended Servicemen's Voting Law they will now be given access on their posts to adult books.

THE postman seemed to be working overtime for the past few weeks, because a vacationing columnist found a rather large bundle of mail awaiting him on his return. Skimming through the top layer, we found the following:

" Adventure in Bokhara," a Russian-made Oriental folk tale, will have its first local showing today at the Stanley Theatre. The lead role is played by Lev Sverdlin as Nasredin, a fabulous Robin Hood of the Orient whose native wit enables him to keep one jump ahead of the Emir's executioners.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 18 (AP) -A fiery object, believed to have been a meteor, hurtled across Middle Western skies this morning and reports of its "landing" in a hundred places plagued newspapers, police, radio stations and military officials.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 18 -- Paramount is postponing production of "Our Hearts Were Growing Up" until November so that Gail Russell can have the lead opposite Alan Ladd in the racing story "Salty O' Rourke," which is due to start Aug. 28.
LONDON, Aug. 18 (UP) -- A communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Topics of The Times, discussing the disasters of the commercial laundryman and his customers, reports that a Topeka homemaker does the weekly washing for her sister, a war worker in New York, and comments, rightly, that this undoubtedly sets the world's long-distance weekly wash record.
ROME, Aug. 16 (U.P.) -- Along the central and eastern Eighth Army flanks the Allies were driving northward through the Tiber Valley and the Appenines almost entirely unopposed.

For more than four years the presence of the Nazis in Paris has been a continuing insult not only to a noble city, not only to a great nation, but to all who had a taste for wisdom and wit, graciousness and beauty, freedom and tolerance. It was not that Paris was a perfect sample of the highest civilization. She had her slums, her vice, her astute commercialism, her corruption.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -The Third Naval District Coast Guard Officer in New York has been instructed not to revoke the licenses of bona fide commercial fishermen regardless of how many fishing trips they make, Representative James C. Auchincloss of New Jersey said today, making public a letter from Vice Admiral R.R. Waesche, commandant of the Coast Guard.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18 (AP) -Ten men batted for the Athletics in the fifth inning tonight, when they scored all their runs in a 5-4 victory over the league-leading Browns before 16,430 spectators.

The Regional Office of Price Administration forecast yesterday that lox, or smoked salmon, an important item in the diet of the Jewish community, which disappeared from stores in recent months, soon would reappear at prices ranging from 70 to 75 cents a pound retail.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Communique 132:

It is comparatively easy to see that when millions of GI Joes return from the battlefields some months hence there may, shortly after the glad and tearful greetings, be some arguments also with the girl friends. A good many of these soldiers are said to be expressing a preference for settling down on a little farm after the war.
GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Saturday, Aug. 19 (AP) -- communique:

WITH ALLIED SEVENTH ARMY, in Southern France, Aug. 17 (Delayed) -- Civilian France is coming to life again as armies of liberation move forward, but it is not the same France as before, and already one can see problems shaping up, upon whose solution the fate of the country depends.
CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 18 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 18 (AP) -Miss Ann Curtis dethroned two titleholders tonight to turn the halfway mark in her quest of a history-making sweep of four free-style races in the women's national A.A.U. swimming meet that got under way at the Swope Park Pool.

Just when it looked as if the Yankees had found themselves, they had the misfortune to run into the veteran Mel Harder on an afternoon when his half-speed curves were breaking perfectly, and almost before they realized what was happening the New Yorkers had succumbed to the Indians 2 -- 0, before a ladies' day crowd of 6,343 at the Stadium yesterday.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 18 -The Bulgarian Government has officially advised the Turkish Government through its Minister to Ankara, Nickola Balabanoff, that Bulgaria would do its utmost to oppose any German military action against Turkey through an Axis Balkan satellite.

Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, and John A. Coleman, chairman of the board, reminded members of that institution yesterday of its rules against the circulation of unsubstantiated rumors and urged "ceaseless vigilance" in tracking them down.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
Jimmy McDaniels, Los Angeles welterweight, got up from the floor to score a knockout over Aaron Perry of Washington in the star bout of eight rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -Abolition of the Southern freight rate differentials by order of Congress is sought under a bill introduced today by Senator Lister Hill, Democrat, of Alabama, to set up a permanent, Federal transportation authority.

Price-fixing by mills and local and commission-house buying caused yesterday a rally of about $1 a bale, or 20 points, from an early decline on the New York Cotton Exchange and the final quotations were up 5 to 7 points net on the day.

The pre-war quality of Calvert whisky will be stressed by the Calvert Distillers Corporation in its fall advertising, it was announced yesterday. Advertisements with the theme, "Anyone who knows can tell the real thing" will appear in 215 newspapers from coast to coast, in twenty national magazines and in car cards in thirty-seven cities.
BOSTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Marine Sgt. Peter B. Saltonstall, 23, one of three children of Gov. Leverett Saltonstall serving in the armed forces, has been killed in action in the Pacific.
Questions and answers on the forthcoming duck-shooting season, with W.E. Crouch, chief of the Game Management Division of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, supplying the answers:

CINCINNATI, Aug. 18 -- Lippy Durocher started an argument with Umpire Dusty Boggess in the twilight opener of a double-header at Crosley Field tonight, was promptly thrown out, and the Dodgers suffered two stinging defeats from the Reds, who moved back into a second-place tie with the Pirates.

Independent Milk Marketers, Inc., 105 Hudson Street, telegraphed Marvin Jones, War Food Administrator, yesterday to arrange an immediate meeting to discuss a plan to increase the fluid milk supply of the New York market.

ALBANY, Aug. 18 -- Challenging the validity of the American Labor party petition nominating President Roosevelt and other Democratic candidates, Walter J. Flanagan of Brooklyn asked the Secretary of State today to reject the nominations which, he said, were in violation of the State law and ALP rules.

It was a wise move on Secretary Hull's part to invite Governor Dewey to discuss with him "in a nonpartisan spirit" the problem of post-war security and an equally wise move on Mr. Dewey's part promptly to accept this invitation by designating John Foster Dulles as his representative.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Cubs combined Claude Passeau's steady pitching and a thirteen-hit attack for a 5-to-3 victory over the Braves today, putting them ahead in the series, two games to one. Passeau allowed eight hits in scoring his eighth victory, one more than he has lost.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -Losses in American heavy bombers have been so much less than expected that production is being cut back gradually and 294,000 workers will be laid off in the aircraft industry by July, Maj. Gen. Oliver P. Echols said today.

Unless the War Production Board sets up some system such as that used in the textile industry whereby a manufacturer cannot obtain materials unless he agrees to make certain low-end items vitally needed, there will be no appreciable increase in the production of low-end furniture items, a canvass of the industry revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- From a labor turnover of almost 100 per cent a year prior to Pearl Harbor, the maritime industry has achieved one of the lowest marks in any industry, about 20 per cent annually, officials of the War Shipping Administration reported today.

Sgt. Graves Gladney, in active service on the Normandy front, has purchased the one-family dwelling at 633 Lorraine Street, Mamaroneck, N.Y., from the Home Owners Loan Corporation. Sergeant Gladney's wife and three children are now occupying the house. The sale was made through Peter C. Doern Jr., Inc., as broker.

BOSTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- After being shut out, 3 -- 0, by Lefty Hal Newhouser as he became the majors' first twenty-game winner this season, the Red Sox defeated the Tigers today, 7 -- 4, with a late second-game surge. Boston remained in second place, half a game ahead of Detroit.

Although plans were filed yesterday for a twelve-story and penthouse department-store building to be erected at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-first Street, the identity of the owner and prospective occupant remained as much of a mystery as when it was revealed three months ago that a major post-war construction project was in prospect for that valuable site.

" Good Morning, Corporal," the Milton Herbert Gropper-Joseph Shalleck comedy, closed after last night's performance at the Playhouse. The management decided to throw in the towel after letting the play run thirteen performances. With Charita Bauer, Joel Marston and Francis Tannehill in the cast, the comedy dealt with the doings of an ultra-patriotic girl, who was married in quick succession to a sailor, a marine and finally a soldier.

BOMBAY, India, Aug. 18 (U.P.) -Mohandas K. Gandhi, Indian Nationalist leader, whose request for an interview with the Viceroy, Viscount Wavell, on Indian independence in return for full war support was declined, said today that it was apparent that Britain would not relinquish her hold on India until forced to do so.

MOLLESULAZ French - Swiss Frontier, Aug. 18 -- The frontier town of Annemasse fell this morning to the French Forces of the Interior after more than three hours of fighting. The Maquis casualties were five wounded. Only half the German garrison escaped.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Saturday, Aug. 19 -- The Battle of the Seine has been joined, a battle whose aim for the Allies is the destruction of all that is left of German forces west of the river.

Misfit, the missing black spaniel mascot of the crew of a destroyer that took part in the invasion of Normandy, was returned Wednesday to Seaman First Class Murray Warshaw, 22 years old, of 1962 Sixty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, it was made known yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UP) -- A Pacific Fleet press release:

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today granted the Cities Service Power and Light Company a year's extension of time in which to comply with provisions of the Holding Company Act.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18 -More than fifty San Francisco machinists under 38 years of age have been certified to State Selective Service headquarters at Sacramento for possible draft into the armed forces or for limited service as a result of their defiance of Government orders following the Navy's seizure of five uptown machine shops here on Monday.

Westheimer Co. of Cincinnati head the group that is making a public offering of 16,992 shares of the E. Kahn's Sons Company's 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock, $50 par value, at $50 and accrued dividends. The offering is the unexchanged portion of a new issue of 35,000 shares.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 18 -- Another shipment of gold reached the port of Buenos Aires at noon today. It was composed of eleven small barrels containing over a ton of gold, having a reputed value of $1,237,889.

Members of the New York Archdiocesan Union of the Holy Name Society have suffered 6,875 casualties so far in the war, it was revealed yesterday by Mgr. Joseph A. McCaffrey, spiritual director of the organization. The third annual patriotic service of the union, he announced, will be held at 5 P.M. on Sunday, Oct. 8, at the Polo Grounds.

The Cairo radio announced yesterday that the EAM [National Liberation Front], largest guerrilla organization in occupied Greece, had decided to participate in the "national unity" government of Premier George Papandreou in Cairo, thus ending a developing Cabinet crisis in which Mr. Papandreou had offered to resign.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Secretary Hull informed Governor Dewey by wire late today that he would be "delighted" to confer with his representative on foreign policy, John Foster Dulles, at any time convenient to Mr. Dulles.

Gross profits on converted printcloths will be cut immediately by 30 to 40 per cent as a result of Amendment 22 to MPR 127, it was learned in Worth Street yesterday. The amendment, which came out simultaneously with the official confirmation of new printcloth prices, specifies that converters' mark-ups must be computed on June 29 prices even though converters will be paying the new prices of 2 1/2 cents more per pound.
A communique, as broadcast yesterday from Chungking in English to North America an recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

ROME, Aug. 18 (U.P.) -- American infantry divisions that invaded southern France were identified today as the Third, Thirty-sixth and Forty-fifth -- all veterans of the Anzio beachhead campaign and formerly part of the Fifth Army.

The procedure of he New York Curb Exchange in suspending a member without giving him the right to cross-examine witnesses was criticized yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Bernard Botein when he denied a motion by the exchange to dismiss a damage suit for $354,540 brought by John W. Jones, former member of Avery Co.

The Germans have thrown a huge, heavily armored tank into action on both the Russian and northern French fronts in an effort to stem the Allies' advances, but first reports denied it was a "super weapon."

Decision of the New York Stock Exchange to remain closed today and on the next two Saturdays has been followed generally throughout the country. All the major Exchanges save the Chicago Board of Trade and the cotton markets will leave their doors shut and the Over-the-Counter houses will do likewise.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 18 (AP) -Alfios, racing for William Helis, was a popular victor in the mile and a furlong Warwick Purse at Garden State Park today. Under Nick Jemas' guidance Alfios dominated the running from the start and finished a length ahead of Red Rosette.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Striking the Japanese throughout the western Pacific area, American planes pounded enemy bases in the Volcano, Marianas and Caroline Island groups Wednesday, blasting airfields, storage dumps, gun positions and other defense installations, a Navy bulletin said today.

William McFee, who edited the anthology "World's Great Tales of the Sea," has written a novel, "Ship to Shore," which Random House will publish on Sept. 6. In it he tells the love story of a sea captain and a New York working girl.

The lease which the John Wanamaker company has just signed for a midtown store at 383 and 385 Madison Avenue carries options which will permit extensive expansion of these quarters to give at least double the original space taken, it became known yesterday in realty circles.
ROME, Aug. 18 (UP) -- A communique:
KANDY, Ceylon, Aug. 18 (AP) -- A communique:

An extensive post-war development in home freezing units, as well as in community locker plants, is anticipated. By studying the freezing methods now used, homemakers will be better prepared, it is felt, to take advantage of the mechanical appliances that will increase after the war.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 18 -- A lubricant for use at temperatures as low as 132 degrees below freezing, a method of making colored fluorescent glass, and a new antigen for lymphogranuloma, a venereal disease, are among the 519 patented inventions reported in the current issue of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

LONDON, Saturday, Aug. 19 (U.P.) -- The regular Paris and Vichy radio network broadcasters entered their second straight day of silence today. A new, mysterious station, claiming to speak in the name of the Wehrmacht, used Paris radio wave lengths for a verbal attack on Adolf Hitler and a plea for German soldiers to cease fighting.

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- For four years France has seemed to people in this country as remote as Mars. But today this correspondent went there as comfortably and as casually as any business man flying from New York to Boston. Logically there isn't anything so terribly remarkable about that, considering that about 1,000,000 American soldiers had preceded me there the hard way.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -Representative Clare Boothe Luce of Connecticut tonight admonished against "demands" for permanent acquisition of Atlantic and Pacific islands, other than Japanese mandated islands, "lest America become involved in imperialism."

LONDON, Aug. 18 (U.P.) -- Polish patriots, apparently firmly established in the center of Warsaw, reported by radio today that German forces in the city had intensified artillery action and that huge fires raged throughout the capital.
Ten, forming the best field of the meeting, are named for the $50,000 added Saratoga Handicap today at Belmont Park, a test that should give an accurate line on the top ones in the division.

The latest contribution to postwar kitchen planning is offered by Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., with the release today of drawings and details for "The Living Kitchen," designed by J. Gordon Lippincott, as part of Revere's series of post-war housing suggestions.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- The American Federation of Teachers, at the final session of its annual convention today, unanimously approved a resolution condemning the New York City Board of Education for its use of "permanent substitutes."

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Stewart-Warner Corporation has issued an unaudited statement, subject to review under the Renegotiation of Contracts Act, indicating a profit of $1,733,197, equal to 89 cents a capital share, for the first six months of 1944.
The German flying, bomb which has been launched against London in salvos in the past week is a portent of the shape of things to come.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The divergence between House and Senate over methods for disposing of surplus war property had widened tonight to a point where legislative leaders forecast a long and difficult fight to reconcile the two points of view.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 18 -The visit three days ago of German Field Marshal Gen. Wilhelm Keitel to Helsinki was provoked by advanced Finnish separate peace plans, usually well-informed circles in the Finnish capital said today.

ST. MALO, France, Aug. 17 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Shaggy, grimy and reeling from a farewell party of cognac, wine, and cider -- but with their boots shining -- the motley German garrison of St. Malo stumbled out blinking in the sunlight today to surrender.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 18 -- Miss Vivian Marie Rogers, 20-year-old Pennsylvania Railroad conductor, fell from a New York-to-Point Pleasant train this afternoon as it rounded a sharp curve aproaching the station here. Hurled fifteen feet beyond the trackbed and down an embankment, the conductorette was injured critically.

Dr. Reginald Weir of New York City, the titleholder, yesterday reached the semifinals of the men's singles in the Negro national championships being conducted by the American Tennis Association at the Cosmopolitan courts. The New Yorker routed Edward Grasing, Englewood, N.J., 7 -- 5, 6 -- 1.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Germany's surrender will flash the green light on resumption of production of civilian radios, WPB officials informed members of the Radio Industry Advisory Committee here this week. For the remainder of this year, however, they added, the radio-radar production program must be maintained at its present which is about 16.4 per cent above the July rate.

ALBANY, Aug. 18 -- Governor Dewey accepted by telegraph today Secretary Hull's "invitation" to consultation on international security questions and named John Foster Dulles, his adviser on foreign affairs, as his "representative" at the conferences.

At his press conference yesterday the President made a beginning at discussing a question of great importance to the country -- the question of post-war military training -- but he did not succeed in making his precise position clear. By coincidence his remarks were made on the same day that witnessed the publication of a strong statement on the same subject by Secretary Stimson.

John Foster Dulles, who has been designated by Governor Dewey to represent him in conferences with Secretary Hull, said yesterday that he was thoroughly familiar with the Republican candidate's views on the organization of peace and was willing to exchange ideas with the Secretary.

In an editorial July 30 THE TIMES pointed out what it considered to be a conflict between a statement appearing in the Federal Reserve Bulletin concerning probable financial needs of business during reconversion and two other statements by Government agencies on the same subject -- one by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the other published in the February Survey of Current Business of the Department of Commerce.

Home-made gifts from the folks back home are sure to provide a personal and sentimental touch to the Christmas of that sister, daughter or sweetheart serving overseas, says the Women's Army Corps Headquarters in Washington.

AN EIGHTH AIR FORCE FIGHTER BASE, England, Aug. 18 (U.P.) -- A United States Mustang pilot did some expert broken-field running with his plane today and plucked a former Vanderbilt University football star out of enemy territory north of Paris.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Implementation of the previously announced increases in the prices of fabrics in the cotton print cloth yarn group, in conformity with the new standard incorporated into the Stabilization Extension Act, was announced today by the OPA. The rise amounts to 2 1/2 cents per pound at the mill, over existing ceilings.
ROME, Aug. 18 (U.P.) -- The powerful naval force that paved the way for the Allies' invasion of southern France laid down a barrage of 15,900 heavy-caliber shells, it was disclosed officially today.

SINCE the Germans are so incontestably evil at the moment, it is scarcely to be wondered at that emotional historians should try to endow the evil with a thousand-year pedigree. Nevertheless, to argue that badness has always been a dominant characteristic in the germ plasm of each and every German is to fall prey to a racism that is very much like Hitler's.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Proposals for the establishment of a basic national policy on air power as an instrument of national defense and international security as well as expansion of civil aviation were introduced in the Senate and House today.

WITH THE SEVENTH ARMY IN SOUTHERN FRANCE, Aug. 17 -The best way to understand how and why the beachhead is expanding so rapidly is to see what the troops are meeting at the front, or, rather, not meeting.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- President Roosevelt today nominated for promotion to lieutenant general Maj. Gen. Alexander M. Patch Jr., commander of the Seventh American Army now invading southern France. General Patch holds the temporary rank of major general and his present permanent rank is colonel of infantry.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- A proposal for public study of a one-year Government training program for youths, not necessarily military, in the post-war period was offered today by President Roosevelt.
LONDON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- A mysterious voice broke in today on the long-silent wave length of the Axis-controlled Paris radio and shouted in German: "They're coming!"

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Great interest has been aroused among the representatives of small nations by Secretary Hull's intimation that a conference of many powers would be called this fall to review the decisions of the "Big Four" security talks which will take place here at Dumbarton Oaks next week.

LONDON, Saturday, Aug. 19 (AP) -Great fleets of Allied planes blasted Nazi airfields in northern France yesterday, rained death and destruction on the retreating Germans, shot from the skies thirty-five enemy fighters of a temporarily resurgent German Air Force and were out again early today for more blows at the enemy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- A proposal to set up a Missouri Valley Authority to undertake the unified development of power, navigation and flood control projects throughout the nine States of the Missouri basin was advanced today by Senator Murray (Democrat, of Montana).

GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Saturday, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Heavy American bombers, attacking in force, smashed Japanese airdromes at Amboina and Ceram Islands, west of New Guinea, headquarters announced today.

New Yorkers relished the mild summer weather of yesterday, with the mercury reaching a high of 82.1 degrees for a brief period at 4:15 P.M. For most of the day the temperature hovered in the refreshing 70's and there were cooling breezes to add to the relief.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Senator Harry S. Truman, Democratic nominee for the Vice Presidency, held today his first personal conference with President Roosevelt since the Democratic National Convention, at a luncheon served on the lawn of the White House.

YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 18 -Four of the sixteen pro-amateur teams which competed in the Westchester P.G.A. one-day event at Dunwoodie this afternoon finished in a tie for first place at a best-ban score of 68. Both Pat Circelli, Metropolis pro, and C.W. Benedict, Mount Kisco amateur, appeared on two of the leading tandems.

The stock market further entrenched itself yesterday on the come-back trail by extending its previous gains, although less spectacularly, but interest diminished somewhat prior to the lengthened week-end holiday. Nevertheless, the session on the Stock Exchange was the broadest in almost a month.

The Swedish-American Line has offered a trip home to Sweden to the fifty-six former crew members of the liner Kungsholm remaining in this country, but so far has received mainly refusals. The men and women who have declined are working in war plants along the Atlantic Coast.

Record heat took toll of retail trade here this week. Department store volume slipped 5 to 10 per cen under the comparative 1943 week. Main floor volume was fair, but practically all other departments shared in the decrease.
LONDON, Aug. 18 -- The stock markets here were irregular today. Gilt-edge stocks met some investment demand and prices improved fractionally, but home rails were dull.

The Mid-Continent Petroleum Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the first six months of this year a net income of $3,317,111 after all charges, including $1,473,250 provision for Federal and State taxes on income. The income is equivalent to $1.79 a share.

Recent unwillingness of canners to pack private labels for wholesale grocers is adding to the difficulties of canned food buyers for many jobbing houses, who cannot find new sources of supply, it was learned in the trade yesterday.

Orleans was liberated by a spearhead of the American forces Friday. On the right bank of the Loire at its most northern point it is the natural center of traffic between the Loire and Paris. Caesar found a town there. Its ancient and famous successor has accumulated history for not far from two thousand years. Kings have resided there.

GROTON, Conn. Aug. 18 (U.P.) -- Several hundred workers walked off the job at the submarine building yards of the Electric Boat Company tonight, resuming a strike which had been ended Thursday following a conference called by Governor Baldwin.

WITH THE ALLIED FORCES IN SOUTHERN FRANCE, Aug. 18 -- Our beachhead is expanding like a balloon and this afternoon we were within ten miles of Toulon on one side and ten miles from Cannes on the other. I went to one point on the perimeter of our beachhead today -- Le Luc -- and, while we were pinned down for a while by German guns, there really was little opposition.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -Chicago made it three in a row over Washington by winning tonight's game 2 -- 1. Although outhit, seven to five, the White Sox managed to bunch three safeties with a long fly to score their two runs in the seventh inning.
ROME, Aug. 18 -- While there were signs of increased resistance today the Germans still appeared unable to muster sufficient strength to impene the Allies' advance into southern France.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- President Roosevelt told reporters today that he expected to have another conference with Prime Minister Churchill soon, but would not become more specific as to the date.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 18 (U.P.) -Throwing more weight into their drive south along the Canton-Hankow Railway in Hunan Province, the Japanese have blasted the Chinese out of most of Leiyang, railway town forty miles below Hengyang, and a Chinese military spokesman revealed today that the enemy had also massed six divisions on the west bank of the Siang River in preparation for a push on the Chinese stronghold of Kweilin in Kwangsi province.
May I offer a few words relative to the letter of Caryl E. Cohen in THE TIMES of Aug. 14.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -The total vote in this year's Presidential election will be heavily reduced from the nearly 50,000,000 of 1940 if the aggregate of ballots of both parties in recent Statewide primaries is any indication.
LONDON, Saturday, Aug. 19 -- A Berlin broadcast quoted a German War Ministry official statement today as saying: "We must be prepared for a German withdrawal from France."
LONDON, Saturday, Aug. 19 (AP) -- A powerful Soviet Army massed on the East Prussian frontier threatened momentarily to spill over into German soil for the first time in thirty years.

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- The breach between the National Socialist party and the German Army, which recently found expression in the plot of the generals against Adolf Hitler, has reappeared as a split between the Elite Guard and the regular army formations in the field.
LONDON, Aug. 18 -- Reports reaching London tonight indicated that retributive warfare being waged on the Nazis by the French Forces of the Interior was reaching new intensity.
MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 18 (AP) -- A medium-sized United States merchant ship was sunk in the South Atlantic by two torpedoes late in July without loss or injury to any of the sixty-six men on board.

World industry today is using industrial diamonds at double the rate of current production and the supply of gem stones "is almost equally inadequate, according to a review of the diamond industry in 1943 by Sydney H. Ball of Rogers, Mayer Ball, mining engineers.

SPOKANE, Wash., Aug. 18 (AP) -- Two more favorites tumbled out of the National Professional Golfers Association championship in 36-hole quarter-final matches today but the big gun, Byron Nelson of Toledo, was still much in the running. He beat Willie Goggin of White Plains, N.Y., 4 and 3.
The letters from Charles H. Tuttle and Morris L. Ernst in your issue of Aug. 13 contain the clearest statements I have seen of the soldier's vote muddle in this State.

The city, in a ninety-minute auction sale yesterday liquidated the night club, La Vie Parisienne, 3 East Fifty-second Street, alleged with the Stork Club and the Copacabana, 10 East Sixtieth Street, to owe city sales taxes amounting to more than $235,000.

DRAGUIGNAN, France, Aug. 18 -We have come twenty-five miles northwest since our landing seventy-two hours ago. A British paratrooper, Segt. David David Williams of Liverpool, has just turned over $29,000 in French currency to Maj. Robert H. Travis of Beaumont, Texas.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Ken Raffensberger quelled a last-inning uprising in pitching Philadelphia to a 3-2 victory over the Pirates here tonight, severing Pittsburgh's 11-game winning string.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -American amphibious technique is becoming virtually invincible, Rear Admiral Alan G. Kirk, who commanded the vast United States task force that landed our troops in northern France and supported the landings by bombarding enemy shore installations, asserted here today.

YENAN, China, Aug. 1 (Delayed) -- Today's Emancipation Daily News, the Communist party organ, carried two belated reports of the operations of Communist guerrillas in the vicinity of the great north China port of Tientsin and Wang Ching-wei's puppet capital of Nanking early in June.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 18 -- The strategic fortress of St. Malo, fanatically defended for nearly two weeks by the Nazi "madman of St. Malo," fell to American might at 4 P.M. yesterday along with its 600 defenders, crumpling the last German resistance along the north coast of Brittany.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, Rome, Aug. 18 -- American armored columns plunged through crumbling resistance by the Germans within five miles of the great French Mediterranean naval base of Toulon today and began flanking it on the north with a swift six-mile drive toward Marseille.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- The wheat market today reversed its action of yesterday and broke sharply, closing deals on the Board of Trade showing losses of 1/2 to 1 3/8 cents a bushel, the deferred deliveries leading. Lack of support rather than aggressive selling was given as the cause for the break.

The heir to a fortune made in the United States by a German brewmaster was inducted as a private in the United States Army yesterday. He was Gert Hans von Gontard, who had a right to the title of Baron in Germany until he renounced it and became a United States citizen five years ago.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Aug. 19 -- The Red Army yesterday stormed and captured Sandomierz, below the Vistula River bend south of Warsaw, and encircled three German divisions in a pocket north and west of Sandomierz. The Russians are now engaged in a battle to annihilate the trapped Germans.

BOSTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Richard Whitney, five times president of the New York Stock Exchange, until he was sentenced to Sing Sing prison for grand larceny, may organize a new frozen-fruit business, the Massachusetts Parole Board said today.

One-half of a large Governors Island barracks, specially refitted for feminine comfort, was taken over yesterday morning by 180 Wacs, the first women soldiers to be housed at the 144-year-old Army post. Previously they had been quartered at the Beaux Arts Apartment Hotel, 310 East Forty-fourth Street.

STAUNTON, Va., Aug. 18 -- The Rev. Dr. E. Stanley Jones, former missionary to India, sounded a warning at the Interdenominational Bible Conference at Massanette Springs, near Harrisonburg, that the fate of India would determine in large measure whether there was to be war or no war in the next few decades.

Shipments of ducks from eighty farms on Long Island will cease from Aug. 28 to Sept. 5 because of the shortage of ice, R.W. Hallock, president of the Farmers Commission House, Inc., 403 West Fourteenth Street, announced yesterday.

Lumber production decreased 14.1 per cent last week, compared with the like week last year, according to reports received yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. Shipments were down 10.1 per cent, orders up 17.4 per cent.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 18 -- The Giants had to be content with a moral victory tonight at Sportsman's Park. They discovered the formula for scoring runs against the Cardinals. Indeed, they even got out in front of the champions on one occasion.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- In a letter placed in the record today as the Interstate Commerce Committee of the Senate ended hearings on measures to terminate land grant rates, Secretary Forrestal stated that repeal of railroad land grant freight rates to the Government would cost the Navy $80,000,000 to $90,000,000 a year during the war period.

CANBERRA, Australia, Aug. 19 -- The electors of Australia refused by a substantial majority today to give the Commonwealth Parliament fourteen additional legislative powers for post-war reconstruction. ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- Outdoor competitions hold attention this week with the Ventnor Shuffle Board Club tournament entering its final half and a duo of casting events scheduled for the week-end. Afternoon tickets from 11 A.M.; evening tickets after 4 P.M. Apply 99 Park Avenue (at Fortieth Street) for tickets.
