WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The War Production Board's policy on special sales of idle and excess controlled materials on an excess allotment authorization has been inserted in a new amendment to rules governing such special sales, WPB announced today.
LONDON, Aug. 19 -- The flight of the Vichy Government has begun. Tonight it was believed to have moved closer to Germany in preparation for a final dash across the border.

YENAN, China, July 31 (Delayed) -- Who are the Chinese communists and whose support have they gained? What groups are represented not only in the upper ranks but also in the middle and lower ranks of the leadership of the party and of the armies?

After numerous complaints about his lack of cooperation in enforcing the price-control program, Adolph J. Chesley was dismissed yesterday as chairman of the Bronx County War Price and Rationing Board by Daniel P. Woolley, regional administrator of the Office of Price Administration.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 19 -- It is hard to get a big part of Mississippi interested in politics, because of oil discoveries being made in that State. The people are more excited about the latest oil pro ducer than they are about who will be the next President.

THIS slim volume by Mrs. Barbara Klaw, 24-year-old reporter of The New York Post, is the story, slightly fictionalized, of her camp-to-camp trek with her husband, Spencer Klaw, during his Army training here before assignment overseas.

THE extended hot spell and drought this summer were a distinct handicap to Victory gardens. Although artificial watering helps to maintain growth of the crops, many people are wondering whether anything more can be done to keep the soil productive in spite of these dry seasons that are a natural occurrence.

AN INTERESTING phase of the shortage of "top-name" screen acting talent, particularly male, is the film companies' current practice of sharing players' contracts with one another. A classic example is Gregory Peck, whose contracts are split among four companies.

As an aftermath of recent fires at Luna Park, Coney Island; Palisades Park, N.J., and at the circus in Hartford, Conn., Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi, head of the State Labor Department, set in motion yesterday a program to revise and modernize the "antiquated'' State Standard Building Code for places of public assembly and to extend his department's jurisdiction in the enforcement of safeguards.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Browns' lead in the American League pennant race was cut to five and a half games today when they bowed to the Athletics, 4 -- 3, in twelve innings, for their third setback in the four-game series.

The American village is holding its own, notwithstanding the notion that the population of the United States is moving to the cities. The village is still out there on its hill or in its valley and doing very well, thank you.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 19 -- Acquitting themselves with ability and high morale throughout twelve days of intensive training on the Camp Smith Reservation here with the temperature ranging between 98 and 100 degrees daily, 2,400 State Guardsmen of the Second Brigade of Manhattan broke camp today and left for their home armories well tanned and enthusiastic about the stepped up training schedule of this season.

ALBANY, Aug. 19 -- Apart from his acceptance speech and his trip to St. Louis for the conference of Republican Governors, Thomas E. Dewey has still to begin his formal campaign for the Presidency. It will start soon, and all indications point to a well-thought-out and yet orthodox drive.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 19 -- Mort Cooper was doing the pitching at Sportsman's Park today. Walker Cooper was doing the hitting.

BASLE, Switzerland, Aug. 19 -- Travelers arriving here from Germany today brought copies of the first clandestine newspaper published in Germany since the war began, so far as is known here. Entitled "Es Stimmt" -- "That's Right" -- the newspaper violently attacks Hitler for putting Heinrich Himmler in command of the German Home Army.

Despite repeated warnings by procurement agencies that industry must prepare itself to cope with an increasing number of claims on terminated contracts, a survey conducted among companies already affected by terminations showed that three "most common" errors are contributing to delay in getting termination claims approved, Arthur W. Holiday, head of Arthur W. Holiday and Associates, Norwalk, Conn., declared yesterday.

THE funny thing was that they were not very much concerned with what was facing them ahead. Each had his own problems, his own desires and wishes. They kept these personal things uppermost in their minds, as they had always done ever since they came into the Army.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 19 (AP) -- Saving ground all the way as Jockey Mike Gonzalez snugged him along the rail, H.C. Genter's Swiv, an invader from Garden State, rallied from fifth place at the quarter pole to win the $5,000 added Pawtucket Handicap by two and a half lengths today at Narragansett Park.
QUESTION: What led to the organization of International Pictures?

LONDON, Aug. 19 -- Premier Joseph Stalin told Polish Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk in their recent meetings in Moscow that if he would be reasonable about Russia's demands for frontier revisions in the east to the Curzon Line the Red Army would extend Poland's western frontiers to a line of the Oder and Neisse Rivers, including Stettin and Breslau within her borders, it was learned today.

Warsaw, Poland's war-ravaged capital, was a modern city; its 1,300,000 peacetime inhabitants made steel, machinery, shoes, textiles. Warsaw was also a romantic city; its authorities carefully preserved the medieval charm of the Old Town, where the houses were four-windows wide for princes, three- windows wide for nobles and two-windows wide for commoners.

FRANZ HOELLERING, Austrian-born novelist and anti-Nazi, has put the home front of Hitler's Germany under glass in his latest book, "Furlough." An earlier novel, "The Defenders," did the same for the Vienna of the Nineteen Thirties, where democracy was dying beneath the blight of fascism.

HERE is an anthology so revealing and absorbing that one wonders why it was not thought of sooner. German Arciniegas has gathered materials from all the literatures of Latin America to compose a self-portrait of its lands as seen by their historians, biographers, essayists, novelists and thinkers.

American airmen who during this war have crashed, or bailed out of burning planes, and who have been left with torn and disfigured faces, will profit from the four years of plastic surgery that has been financially aided in England by the British War Relief Society, a member agency of the National War Fund.

LEOPOLD STOKOWSKI will return to Mayor La Guardia's City Center of Music and Drama this fall to conduct at least six pairs of concerts with the New York City Symphony Orchestra, it was learned late last week. Modestly priced subscriptions will be sold for the initial twelve concerts, which will extend into December.

RADIO has a new daytime audience, but radio is assiduously avoiding it. These new listeners are the thousands of young women who follow their husbands in uniform and set up homes wherever and whenever possible.

A two no-trump rebid by a player who has previously made a take-out double should be a far stronger bid than most people realize. The double has already promised substantial values. A later bid which, like two no trump, is a try for game, should show considerably more than the values which were previously guaranteed by the double.

BOSTON, Aug. 19 -- This was a week of affliction in a New England plagued by unprecedented heat waves. Aside from lack of the famed east wind, which usually brings cooling draughts from Labrador at times of summer stress, the six States bemoaned a drought which has ruined $10,000,000 worth of crops.

ALLEN JENKINS is going back to the Hollywood he left in despair two years ago. After ten very profitable, if not artistically satisfying, years in which he figured prominently in some 100-odd pictures, Mr. Jenkins called it quits in 1942, signed himself over to the USO and went out to entertain the GI's in the Pacific and in Europe.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- United Air Lines, seeking permission to fly from Los Angeles and San Francisco to Honolulu, said today that it expected to cut both the fare and the flying time if they receive a certificate from the Civil Aeronautics Board.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Norman Thomas, the Socialist party's Presidential nominee, commenting on the coming conferences on post-war security between Secretary Hull and John Foster Dulles, foreign relations adviser to Governor Dewey, said tonight: "The first necessity is that we know what sort of peace the post-war world organization is to enforce."

FAVORITE: The little red tokens hold no terrors for the steward of the Harvard University Faculty Club. Faculty diners are reportedly partial to unrationed horsemeat, preferably smothered in onions and dished up with a green salad and beverage. An estimated 100 pounds of horsemeat was consumed weekly last winter.

Westbrook Pegler, World-Telegram columnist, will leave the Scripps-Howard newspapers at the end of his present contract to join the Hearst newspapers, which will syndicate his column through King Features, it was announced yesterday.

DESPITE the heat and other irrelevancies, a group of people have formed the Columbia Theatre Enterprises, capitalized at $50,000, for the purpose of financing plays. Item A on its schedule may well be the backing of "Trio," or Howard and Dorothy Baker's dramatization of the latter's novel.

Capt. Bennet F. Buie has been awarded the Order of the Red Star by the USSR "for outstanding ability and professional skill in locating and developing a dependable water supply for the Russian Military Service." He is attached to the Persian Gulf Service Command, and it is his job to apply geology in carrying out military operations.

Record high temperatures here last week limited consumer interest in fall merchandise. Department store sales dropped from 5 to 10 per cent under the like week of 1943, interrupting a long series of weekly gains. Practically all departments shared in the dip, but women's apparel and furs were chiefly affected.

THE clues that are sought are clues to the life of Christabel Strange and to her death. A year has passed since she died, apparently of undulant fever, and now her friend Marcia Wentworth is planning to write Christabel's biography. She asks Dr. George Cardew, who has known Christabel as a child, before she became famous, to help her.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- All signs here indicate that the time now is ripe for Gen. Douglas MacArthur to launch his return to the Philippines -- a move that competent military observers believe may prove the beginning of the end for the Asiatic enemy.

The three different types of launching sites for the flying bomb and the rocket that the Germans have been constructing in France and the Low Countries represent in the aggregate tremendous expenditures of effort and man-hours.

SHERIDAN, Wyo., Aug. 19 -- The fate of Jackson Hole, one of the most admired of this State's scenic valleys, goes before a Federal court here Monday in a further step in years of controversy over efforts of conservationists to preserve the area permanently as a public monument.

BOMBS, blitzes and blasting have revived Bach, Beethoven and Brahms on an unprecedented scale in Britain. People are singing, playing and listening to more serious music than ever before, and the demand for the classics has increased in direct proportion to the length of the war.

A UNITED STATES FIGHTER BASE in Britain, Aug. 18 (Delayed by Censorship) -- The German rocket-propelled fighter plane now in use as an interceptor against American bombers over the Reich moves so fast that even the men who have engaged it victoriously in close combat can give only sketchy descriptions of it.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 19 -- Aided by a vital double play while the tyling run was on third base, the Dodgers nosed out the Reds today, 3 -- 2, dropped them back into third place and gained an even break in the four-game series.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- President Roosevelt today proclaimed the week of Oct. 8 Fire Prevention Week. Saying that the prevention of waste was as essential to the supplying of an "increasing flow of goods and materials to every battlefront as is the production of goods," he cited the large waste in the nation from preventable fires each year.

AN EVACUATION HOSPITAL, in Southern France, Aug. 19 -- The first American nurses to arrive on this beachhead debarked from a hospital ship today. Within an hour and a half, they were at work in tents nursing wounded doughboys.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Senators snapped a four-game losing streak tonight by defeating the White Sox, 3 -- 2, before a crowd of approximately 3,500.

SPOKANE, Wash., Aug. 19 -- Byron Nelson, greatest golfer in the country off his record, and Bob Hamilton of Evansville, Ind., a newcomer to the championship flight, will meet tomorrow over thirty-six holes at the Manito course for the 1944 National P.G.A. title.

He had chosen as his text "We reach forward," from St. Paul's, "forgetting those things which are behind and reaching forth unto those things which are before."

Because the war has been far from our shores, a good many of us Americans have felt lucky. We have been out of it, so far as our personal comfort is concerned. CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- The Corn Belt drought became a subject of acute concern this week to the country's war leaders and to farmers and other civilians as a blazing sun continued to sear already parched fields throughout most of the Middle West.

FLINT, Mich., Aug. 19 -- Four Democratic candidates said today that they had rejected a demand to appear before a regional group of the CIO Political Action Committee for questioning with loss of its endorsement as the alternative.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- In a move to tighten control by Congress over the disposition of surplus war property owned by the Government, the Senate Committee on Military Affairs approved today an amendment requiring quarterly reports from a proposed surplus property board.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The war was going swiftly and well this week, but with every victory abroad production officials at home were moving toward their next big job -- turning industry back to the civilian economy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Warplanes and other supplies valued at $1,500,000 were salvaged recently by American Liberty ship seamen aided by British soldiers and sailors "almost under the nose of the Lutftwaffe," the War Shipping Administration reported tonight.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 19 -- Arrival this week of 179 sick and wounded veterans brought the total number of patients at the Army's England General Hospital here to a new high. The patients were speeded here by plane and hospital train from all major theatres of the war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The purpose of the Dumbarton Oaks conference, starting here Monday, is both complex and inspiring. The conferees are forced with reconciling the two conflicting principles of nationalism and international action to assume the collaboration of the great powers in a system of collective security without infringing on the rights of the smaller powers, and to further "that viewless goal, perpetual peace."
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 19 -- Three up and one to go was the score for Miss Ann Curtis in her quest of a clean sweep at the women's national A.A.U. swimming championships.

The competition among steamship companies for possession of the "youngest skipper" took on another entrant yesterday when Gaillard F. Ravenel, vice president of the United States Lines, declared that Capt. Charles R. Stevens of Brooklyn, master of the West Honaker, was commissioned a captain at the age of 22 years, 9 months and 21 days.

AT TENGYUEH, China, Aug. 17 (Delayed) (AP) -- The Chinese siege of Tengyueh, with the attackers holding half the city and all surrounding positions, was developing today into one of the bloodiest engagements of its size ever fought in China.

THOUGH the county fair has not swung back to its old days of glory, it is more numerous this year than at any time since the war started. It is less than a year since the Italian surrender, yet numerous changes have already taken place in the nominal Government of that country. The King has been forced to turn over his powers; there have been frequent Cabinet changes; Badoglio as Premier has given way to Bonomi, and already there is discussion of replacing the latter, in turn, by a "national concentration" Cabinet under the 84-year-old Orlando.

WASHINGTON, Aug, 19 (AP) -- Stephen Early, White House secretary, termed "untrue" today a story in THE NEW YORK TIMES saying that President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill planned to hold their next meeting "in London or Paris, perhaps both, at a date very possibly before the November election."

With only thirty-two players remaining from the original field of over 600, match play in the annual municipal golf championship started at the Split Rock course in Pelham Bay Park, the Bronx, yesterday. The sixteen survivors moved into the second round, which will be played today.

ENLIGHTENED laziness over late summer perennials is a good thing. SIR ROBERT WILSON, forgotten hero of the Napoleonic Wars, was, according to Thomas B. Costain, "the most unusual soldier that England had produced in many generations." His bold stand in Spain, a "second Thermopylae," gave Wellington time to land his Peninsular army.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- More than 6,000 civilians have thought up ways to increase war production to such an extent that the War Production Board has awarded them commendations, certificates, citations or honorable mentions, the agency announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- President Roosevelt gave orders to the Navy late this afternoon to take over and operate ninety-nine more machine shops in the San Francisco area, where a union dispute over overtime has resulted in work limitation.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 19 -- Great Lakes bulk freight shipping records were shattered for the fourth consecutive month in July, when the fleet hauled 22,857,536 net tons of ore, coal and grain, it was disclosed today by the Lake Carriers Association.

Sixteen students are registered in the Division of Honors Studies at the University of Rochester for the scholastic year beginning in September. Making their farewell appearance of the season at the Stadium, the Indians, who somehow never wear out their welcome in the Bronx, brought their visit to a pleasant close yesterday by plunging headlong down to defeat before the Yankees.

THIS is the season for fresh vegetables -- when corn and squash and peas and all the other colorful varieties, whether purchased at the market or derived from a Victory garden, are at their most tender and delicious. IN her latest novel of England on the home front, Helen Ashton treats with considerable interest and insight a subject which should preoccupy novelists in general, and English novelists in particular, for a long time to come.

GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Sunday, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Continuing the steady patrol of southern Philippine waters, a Liberator bomber damaged a small Japanese freighter off Davao, headquarters announced today.

THE Ramsay twins, Jon and Dee, are planning to write a mystery story based on two seemingly unrelated deaths among persons of their acquaintance. Presently they begin to suspect that they have a real murder mystery on their hands.

The Bulgarian Parliament, continuing debate yesterday on Premier Ivan Bagrianoff's speech voicing determination to remove all "obstacles" to peace, heard an Opposition leader express warm support of the new policy and warn that "We have no time to lose."

Duck shooters who found they had received a present of ten extra days of sport when the season dates were announced by Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes recently will be cheered further by the news that there will be at least 10 per cent more birds this year than there were last.
Mrs. Ralph R. Stewart has arrived from Washington and is at the Waldorf-Astoria.

LONDON, Aug. 19 -- The great German port of Bremen was setablaze by the Royal Air Force in a violent fire-bombing attack last night. More than 1,000 British heavy bombers were assigned to this task and other missions during the night.

AT TENGYUEH, China, Aug 11 (Delayed) (AP) -- Ragged, poorly fed Chinese troops are pressing their siege of Japanese-held Tengyueh from foxholes blasted out of the city's stone wall.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 19 -- The foremost subject of conversation in Germany these days is Paris. According to travelers from the Reich one hears all over the place the question: Are we really going to have to give up "das schoene Paris."

Weight, the great leveler at a race track, cut a wide swath in the $53,350 Saratoga Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday when all the champions were up the stretch, and the obscure 17-to-1 shot, Paperboy, scampered home first with the feather of 103 pounds on his back.

EVERYBODY in Hollywood seems to have some sort of an avocation nowadays which provides not only release from the continuous whirl of film making but also, in many cases, pays a pretty profit as well. The list is long and varied, from Preston Sturges' restaurant to Joel McCrea's extensive cattle ranch.

THE weekly program by La Meri and the Natya Dancers at the Ethnologic Theatre, 110 East Fifty-ninth Street, will consist this week of dances of India and Spain together with a group of animal dances of India and America.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Instructions to "put the heat on" to step up production of items of which the Army stands in critical need, were given by President Roosevelt to Charles E. Wilson, executive vice chairman of the War Production Board at a White House talk today.

ST. RAPHAEL, France, Aug. 18 (Delayed) -- The French underground army is firmly behind Gen. Charles de Gaulle as the symbolic chief of the French nation, Allen Dupont Dimmick, 50-year-old American citizen who lived on the Riviera through the Vichy regime and the German occupation, said in an interview today.

WITH UNITED STATES MARINES ON GUAM, Aug 13 (U.P.) -- Sgt. Peter B. Saltonstall was killed by rifle fire this afternoon in a brief, pitched battle between marines and Japanese patrols in the jungle wilds of northern Guam. He was leading a small patrol cleaning out stray Japanese when he was killed.

Provision for building 2,500 small housing units in Palestine for Jewish refugees from Hungary and other Balkan countries and additional relief and transportation for 8,000 persons will be made by the Jewish Agency for Palestine, according to a message received yesterday by the United Palestine Appeal from Eliezer Kaplan, treasurer of the Jewish Agency in Palestine.
Sports pipelines and grapevines hinted last night that the impending all-St. Louis world series may be witnessed by an all-St. Louis crowd.

As a part of its study of post-war education now in progress, DePauw University, in Indiana, announces the establishment of a bureau of testing and research which will give new students, regular students, and returning war veterans individual diagnoses for vocational, educational and personality adjustment problems.

BOSTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Red Sox today defeated the Tigers, 9 -- 1, behind the three-hit pitching of Joe Bowman, who chalked up his ninth victory.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 19 -- Rails awash in a fine northwest breeze that cooled and cleared the air and seemed to put new life in their sails, fifty-three starting craft had full-sway going today in the special regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club.

CHARTRES, France, Aug. 18 (Delayed) -- This city continues to be one of the most interesting and confusing segments of the front lines. PINE CAMP, N.Y., Aug. 19 (AP) -- More than 2,000 West Point cadets, engaged in summer maneuvers, will end their training period with a three-day tactical problem next week.

BARI, Italy, Aug. 19 (AP) -- A German force of fewer than sixty divisions, most of them far under strength, is holding the entire Balkans, including the front facing Russia, recent reports indicated today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19 -- Rear Admiral Harold G. Bowen, who since Monday has operated five San Francisco machine shops for the Navy, began this afternoon seizing ninety-nine more under Presidential order.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- The Library of International Relations in Chicago, a center providing specialized sources of foreign information, has "come of age" after a twelve-year struggle under the leadership of Miss Eloise ReQua, its founder and director.

On the other hand, both my daughters have always wanted to pitch for Brooklyn, and a quick glance at the National League standings confirms my suspicions of where and how they fritter away their spare afternoons.

Basic principles to govern the surplus foods disposal program already have been submitted to the War Food Administration by a Regional Advisory Committee on Surplus Foods Disposal appointed in the Northeast, F.D. Cronin, Regional Director of the Office of Distribution, WFA, announced yesterday.

Earning of the Food Machinery Corporation for the nine months ended with June amounted to $2,704,722, compared with $1,225,118 for the similar period of the preceding fiscal year, the company announced yesterday. The volume of business for the nine months rose to $124,899,543 from $27,719,063.

ABOARD A UNITED STATES AIRCRAFT CARRIER AT SEA (Delayed) -- A new 27,000-ton Essex-class carrier is on her way to the war zone, ready to join the scores of other United States carriers in waging the new-style naval warfare against the ships, planes and shore installations of the enemy.

"RICHARD PETERS" is the ninth volume of "Pennsylvania Lives," a series of biographies of less familiar but noteworthy Pennsylvanians. But the fact that Richard Peters' career was a Pennsylvania life at all was entirely accidental -- the consequence of several unfortunate youthful mischances.

SCRIBNER'S orders for "The History of Rome Hanks," the Civil War novel now in its tenth edition, include one from a bookseller who requests twenty copies of "The History of Rome" by Hanks. . . . Louis Bromfield's "Mrs. Parkington" heads a recent list of best-selling novels in Sweden. . . .

"THE BARRICADES" is an unusual, sometimes brilliant, yet in several ways unsatisfying, novel by a 28-year-old Englishman who shows perhaps as much promise of substantial achievement as any of his contemporaries.

THE first volume for children published by John Newbury, "A Little Pretty Pocket Book," appeared in London in 1744. For the 200th anniversary year Frederick Melcher has issued this miniature book in facsimile (from the first American edition), and it is a pretty little contrast to the output in children's book publishing as of 1944.

The concluding portions of the Paul S. Nathan article "Hunting With a Movie Scout" was as judicious an appraisal of the relative status of stage and screen in our day as any I have recently read. It has become the fashion to berate the films for their more aggressive methods of attracting talent, just as we are constantly being urged to shed a figurative tear for the lean pocketbooks of theatrical entrepreneurs.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sunday, Aug. 20 -- American Third Army tanks smashed their way into the southern suburbs of Paris yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The OPA set a jobbers' ceiling price of $48.96 a gross today on triple-stitched shuttlecocks made from the middle wing feathers of white geese.

Pressure for termination of shoe rationing this year will be brought by certain divisions of the retail end of the business, according to industry observers, with proponents of the program believing that the inventory position of dealers will be far superior this fall and winter than at any time during the forthcoming year.

President Roosevelt, "tanned and jovial," one correspondent reported, was back in Washington last week from his seventh trip abroad since Japan plunged the nation into war on Dec. 7, 1941. He had covered 15,000 miles since mid-July, passed through twenty-one States on two cross-country

THE War Production Board opened a page from Arabian Nights in the week and industry sat down to a Barmecide feast. There were all kinds oil delectable things to make under Priorities Regulation No. 25, the long-awaited reconversion order, but when the guest reached for them they were not there.

After a series of studies which began in December, 1942, continued through to April, 1943, and concluded during an influenza epidemic in January, 1944, a Commission on Influenza announces that two common types of influenza known as "A" and "B" can be controlled by vaccines.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19 -- The disturbing question of whether West Coast war workers are to be penalized for staying on the job longer than those in other parts of the country took the No. 1 spot on this week's "trend of thinking" agenda with the invasion of southern France and the growing feeling that the end of the European war is around the corner.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 19 -- The appointment of Heinrich Himmler head of the German Secret Police, Commander of the German Home Army and Chief of Armaments after the July 20 bomb attack on Adolf Hitler has brought the Reichswehr and the Nazi Elite Guards still closer, asserts Field Marshal Gen. Walther von Brauchitsch in an article published in the Nazi party newspaper Voelkischer Beobachter today.

ROME, Aug. 19 -- An American column circling inland north of Toulon is paced by a French armored force that has liberated St. Maximin, a town of crucial importance situated at the junction of two great highways leading to Marseille, twenty-five miles to the southwest. St. Maximin is twenty-two miles below the vital road center of Aix-en-Provence.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 19 -- An eleven-point program for preserving American way of life after the war is outlined in a preliminary report of The American Legion commission on post-war America made public today by its chairman, Col. Louis Johnson of Clarksburg, W. Va., a past national commander and former Assistant Secretary of War.
CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- With markets for securities closed, trading in grain futures fell off materially today on the Board of Trade, but prices fluctuated nervously.

MRS. MEADOWCROFT, when she writes a story of the past, adds to accurate historical knowledge of the period a wealth of detail and handles her characters with warmth and imagination. Philadelphia, in the year 1777, feared an invasion by the British, so 11-year-old Gilbert Emmet and his younger sister, Jennifer, were sent to Valley Forge to stay with cousins.
The Battle of Europe roared to a new climax in east and west last week, as German troops fought desperately for time.

All French Forces of the Interior in the departments of southeastern France were urged to "begin immediate and total action," in instructions broadcast yesterday by Gen. Gabriel Cochet, delegate of the French Committee of National Liberation for southern France, according to the Columbia Broadcasting System.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Picking up a run an inning for four straight frames, the Braves backed Nate Andrews' eight-hit pitching for a 4-to-2 victory over the Cubs today, gaining an even split in the four-game set. Infield errors by Don Johnson and Phil Cavarretta led to two Boston runs.

Buying seems to have lost its zest in some departments, with fill-ins and reorders accounting for most of the activity last week, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.
THE second part of the twenty-fourth annual of the Rockport Art Association is to continue through Sept. 11. In the Upstairs Gallery the "Little Show" is also current.

DAYTON, Ohio, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Lieut. Col. Melbourne W. Boynton, 39, chief of the medical safety division of the Office of Flying Safety, with headquarters in Winston-Salem, N.C., was killed today in a high-altitude test jump at the Clinton County Army Air Base near Wilmington, Ohio.

ONE of the minor but vexing problems of our times is the behavior of the perfectly grooved, slick-paper, character brought into head-on collision with war. In general, he must adjust his double-talk overnight to GI slang, his trade-marked capers to 4-4 (or 4-F) time.

The bumblebee is a fellow of good American traits. He's a sturdy, blocky chap, with six legs, one pair of big wings, a secondary pair of smaller ones immediately behind the larger, and two short antennae. He has a chunky head and shoulders, a very narrow Victorian waist, and a plump rear section.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- President Roosevelt announced tonight that Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board and Maj. Gen. Patrick J. Hurley would soon leave on special missions to China, as his personal representatives to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Russia's delegation to the preliminary security talks between the four great Allied powers which are scheduled to begin Monday at the Dumbarton Oaks estate here, "is in this hemisphere, probably in Canada," it was said at the Soviet Embassy in Washington today.

The cotton trade assumed yesterday a waiting position pending developments this week in Washington on Senator John H. Bankhead's proposals to raise prices. In the absence of new buying, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange became reactionary under weekend liquidation and profit-taking, coupled with a moderate amount of hedge selling.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 19 (AP) -- The highest obligation of any labor group is to assist in bringing prosperity to the industry of which it is a part, Bishop Francis J. Haas, a pioneer in the field of labor relations, declared today at the convention of the International Typographical Union.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Landlords who can prove they have suffered substantial hardships through increased taxes or operating costs may be permitted by the Office of Price Administration to increase rents, under an amendment to the rent regulations which was announced today.

ALBANY, Aug. 19 -- In a proclamation designating Monday, Sept. 4, as Labor Day Governor Dewey praised the working men and women of the State today for their "superb cooperation" without which it would have been impossible "to send out our magnificently equipped armies to attack the enemies of freedom."

WHEN Linda Todd's uncle Ned went into the Army, Linda's parents agreed to move to his farm and run it during his absence. It was short notice and the packing up and the journey by train with two dogs and a radio proved almost too eventful.

A UNITED STATES NINTH AIR FORCE FIGHTER BASE, in France, Aug. 19 -- Armed Thunderbolt reconnaissance planes operating today over the battle area and eastward as far as Paris reported three things of possible significance.

IN 1931 Erskine Caldwell published his first collection of short stories, "American Earth." Reading it over, I find him uncertain in technique but experimenting with irony, fascinated with violence, and distinguished chiefly by his humor.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 19 -- Miss Pauline Betz of Los Angeles, the national tennis champion, and Miss Louise Brough of Beverly Hills, second in the women's ranking, will meet once again tomorrow in the final of the invitation tournament of the Longwood Cricket Club.

ONE of the current myths about the last peace-making is that in 1919 the American people were against joining an international organization -- that they "turned the League of Nations down cold." Like most myths repeated over and over this is now firmly believed.

WARDHA, India, Aug. 18 (Delayed) -- Mohandas K. Gandhi, spiritual leader of the All-India Congress party, declared today in an interview with a correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES that the Allies' appeal to the democracies of the world to unite in the fight against nazism would sound hypocritical so long as India's almost 400,000,000 persons were kept in subjugation to a foreign power.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 19 -- One of the arguments most frequently used by Argentines, who complain that the United Nations are treating their country harshly owing to its international attitude it assumed, is to point out that no severe measures have been taken against Ireland, which has not moved even as far as Argentina toward the Allies.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Administration plans to ask every city and town in the country to join in an air-marking program to aid private fliers. Such markings on cities have been forbidden under wartime Army regulations, but the CAA requested the War Depart ment several weeks ago, to end the restriction.

Friedrich von Paulus, victor of the Battle of the Don Loop, promoted Field Marshal by Hitler on the very day when he surrendered the remnants of the Sixth Army and the Fourth Tank Group to the Russians in front of Stalingrad, praised in German communiques after the surrender for his "exemplary leadership," was silent for eighteen months after he fell into captivity.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 19 -- The recent appeal of Gov. Colgate W. Darden Jr. for medical care and hospitalization for every Virginia citizen gave impetus to movements already under way in this State and in North Carolina for providing such care.

IN "Big Brownie," the tale of a Kodiak bear, Rutherford Montgomery combines an authentic picture of the ways of the largest flesh-eating animal in the world, with an excellent story of life in the open.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 19 (AP) -- Taking seven first places, Princeton ran up 68 points to score an easy victory in the neighborhood intercollegiate track and field meet in Palmer Stadium this afternoon. Villanova was second with 33 and Penn third with 30.

Since the abolition of the income tax in respect of corporations has been recommended in connection with post-war tax planning, the revival of the undistributed profits tax has been suggested as an alternative measure. This seems highly inadvisable.

At the same time millions of men and women who have been engaged in war work will be seeking employment in peacetime pursuits.

LONDON, Aug. 19 (U.P.) -- Strengthened by ammunition and weapons dropped from Allied planes which had flown a 900-mile route, General Bor's Warsaw liberators today occupied German SS [Elite Guard] headquarters in the city after a day-long battle, a Polish communique said tonight.

KANDY, Ceylon, Aug. 19 (U.P.) -- Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's north Burma forces, consolidating a fifty-six-mile front between Pinbaw and Kazu, have clashed with Japanese troops at the confluence of the Irrawaddy and Nam Tabet Rivers, six miles southwest of Nampadaung, a communique reported today.

OTTAWA, Aug. 19 -- The decision of Prime Minister Mackenzie King to postpone the proposed Dominion Provincial Conference until after the next general election, and the reasons he gave, has once more called attention to the anomalies and anachronisms of the Canadian situation under the British North America Act, in effect the country's Constitution.

QUINCY, Mass., Aug. 19 (AP) -- The light cruiser Topeka, named in honor of the capital city of Kansas, was launched today at the Bethlehem Steel Company shipyard with Mrs. Frank J. Warren, wife of the Mayor of Topeka, as sponsor.
LONDON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- A French Forces of the Interior communique:

MOSCOW, Aug. 19 (U.P.) -- Pravda, official Communist party newspaper, said today in a front page dispatch that the Warsaw insurrection was doomed to failure from the beginning and that the men who died fighting German mechanized troops in the Polish capital were "foully deceived by a group of adventurous and political speculators of London emigre governments."

IN rapid-fire, staccato fashion "Sky Ride" tells of some actual flying done by two small boys. They make the acquaintance of the head of a flying field where student aviators are trained, and he invites the boys to visit the field.

THE postal law requires that publications admitted to the second-class mailing privilege shall be "of educational value." A Federal judge, in upholding the right of the Postmaster General to deny the privilege, remarks that the law was drafted in the Victorian long-ago by members of Congress "brought up on the McGuffey Readers."

ALEX ROBB, the turf historian, was discussing dead heats the other day and uncovered considerable information on them. Racing fans were awed a couple of months ago when Brownie, Bossuet and Wait a Bit thundered across the line together in the Carter Handicap at Aqueduct. Mr. Robb was duly impressed, of course, but he was able to top it.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- Barley futures, after showing a heavy undertone for some time, turned upward last week as the result of a better demand for the feed grades of that grain and an announcement that Canada had put an embargo on further exports until the needs of eastern provinces could be determined.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- The strange sensation of victory came to the Giants today at Wrigley Field -after they had tied the longest losing streak a Giant club has experienced in forty-two long years, before the largest paid crowd of the season here.

BOSTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- With a sixteen-hit barrage, which included seven doubles, a triple and a home run by Bob Johnson, the Red Sox swamped Cleveland, 11 -- 4, in the second game of a double-header today. The Red Sox also won the first contest, 8 -- 6.

New York is to have its first union terminal for over-the-road freight trucks as soon as materials for construction become available. Frank C. Ferguson, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, which will build the terminal, said yesterday that an estimated two-thirds of all merchandise freight entering and leaving the Port District now is carried in trucks and that the traffic is growing rapidly.
Mayor La Guardia in his regular Sunday broadcast assailed the Federal Government yesterday for failing to give consumers any benefits from its vast egg price support purchasing program.
ROME, Aug. 20 -- One of the most interesting changes that have taken place in Italy during the war is that in the position of the Pope.

LONDON, Aug. 20 (U.P.) -- Hunting out Germany's hidden oil sources, 500 United States heavy bombers from Italy today ripped three hitherto untouched refineries and an airdrome in Poland, Slovakia and Hungary.

ALGIERS, Aug. 20 (Reuter) -- The operations of the French Forces of the Interior have been intensified during the past week and now cover nearly a third of France, today's communique from French headquarters disclosed. Dealing with operations between Aug. 12 and 19, it added:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, speaking on the tenth anniversary of membership of the United States in the International Labor Organization, said today that the war has removed the old barriers to international cooperation and will spur the work of the ILO throughout the world.
KANDY, Ceylon, Aug. 20 (AP) -- A communique:
Mrs. Edward W. Crane has purchased from the Laffel Realty, Inc., the one-family dwelling at 63 De Koven Court, in Brooklyn, through Paul A. Bogossian, broker.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- Light receipts of hogs and fairly liberal shipments of products have resulted in cutting down stocks of lard in cold storage at a rapid rate, local holdings being reduced 2,243,000 pounds in the first half of August to 60,874,000 pounds, compared with 53,121,000 last year.

CANBERRA, Australia, Aug. 20 -- By their negative vote in the constitutional referendum Saturday, the people of Australia have refused to accept the unpalatable details in the fourteen points submitted to them to provide a broader federal foundation on which to build Australia's future.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 20-James H. Gorley, controller of the University of California, today announced that it plans to spend more than $27,500,000 for post-war improvements on eight campuses.

A B-29 BASE, Western China, Monday, Aug. 21 -- American Superfortresses, staging their first day-and-night attack on the Japanese mainland Sunday, struck industrial Yawata with the heaviest bomb load ever hurled against a single target in the China-Burma-India theatre of war.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 20 (AP) -Cincinnati and Philadelphia exchanged honors in a double-header today, the Reds taking the opener, 2 to 1, as Bucky Walters recorded his eighteenth victory. The Phils, behind five-hit pitching by Charley Schanz, grabbed the second, 4 to 1.

Capt. R.A. Kerley is an American from Houston, Tex. Not many days ago Captain Kerley and a battalion of American infantry were cut off and surrounded by German SS troops on a mountain near Mortain, France. The Germans demanded surrender. Captain Kerley answered: "I will surrender when every one of our bullets has been fired."

Drought is full of heartbreak for the gardener. For the farmer too, and for the fruit grower; but for the gardener it is heartbreak right there in the back yard, a very personal kind of disappointment. The gardener knows every bean row, every tomato plant, almost every leaf, He coddled them as seedlings, hand-picked the bugs and worms that attacked them, watched over their blossoming and glowed at each individual sign of their fruitfulness.

ROME, Aug. 20 -- Civil-affairs officers were attached to the invading army in southern France to enter towns and villages as soon as liberated, it was disclosed tonight. Some were landed with the airborne forces.

Liberal party leaders are scheduled today to decide on four judicial candidates for their ticket to fill vacancies arising from the declinations of their original temporary choices. Two of the blank spaces on their ticket involve nominations for the Supreme Court in Manhattan, one for associate judge of the Court of Appeals and one for County Judge in Brooklyn.

For the fourth time in just over two months the "sacred soil" of the Japanese home islands has been ripped and scarred by American bombs. For the third time, according to the Tokyo radio, the great steel-making city of Yawata on Kyushu was the main target.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20 (AP) -The White Sox and Athletics split a double-header before 19,683 fans at Shibe Park today, the Mackmen taking the second fray, 8 -- 3, after the White Sox won the opener, 3 -- 2.

ON THE BRITISH FRONT, in Normandy, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Marshal Guenther von Kluge's northern flank along the English Channel coast was under a new and violent assault tonight as British troops driving east toward Le Havre captured Merville and Franceville and stormed into the streets of Cabourg.

Fair-sized buying activities are reported for the past week, according to a summary of activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Coats and suits are off to a good start, and dress business also was reported active.

LONDON, Aug. 20 (U.P.) -- Marshal Tito's Yugoslav and allied Greek Partisans were reported attacking German garrisons and vital sections of enemy-held rail lines on a 200-mile arc through southern Yugoslavia, northern Greece and Albania today.

WITH THE UNITED STATES SEVENTH ARMY in southern France, Aug. 20 (U.P.) -- Three of America's top generals, Lieut. Gen. Jacob L. Devers, Lieut. Gen. Ira C. Eaker and Maj. Gen. John Cannon, narrowly missed being hit by a bomb during a German air raid a few nights ago.

Continuing the steady improvement which has been registered throughout the Latin-American market for the past four years in credits and collections by American foreign traders, the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau of the National Association of Credit Men yesterday reported that all the Latin countries had received top ratings on collections in the bureau's thirty-second annual credit survey.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 20 (AP) -- Newark's amazing Bears, who were in last place as late as July 6, completed their sensational climb to the top of the standing today by winning from Jersey City, 6 -- 5, in twelve innings and 6 -- 1 in seven frames.

Registration is now open at the American Women's Voluntary Services Manhattan headquarters, 39 West Fifty-seven Street, for a course in civic responsibility designed to familiarize women with the functions of the Federal Government and voting procedure.
David Polikoff has been appointed sales manager of Jos. S. Finch Co., Chicago. Mr. Polikoff for the past ten years had been associated with Schenley Distillers Corporation sales organization.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Monday, Aug. 21 -- From Paris to the sea the Allies' line in France is winging forward, threatening the Germans with a strategic defeat on a grand scale.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 20 -- A Swiss communique announced tonight that, on the request of local German military authorities for transit facilities for 150 sanitary soldiers and 450 wounded from Evian-les-Bains, the Federal Council had authorized the passage of the sanitary personnel and the seriously wounded, but would intern all those recovering from slight wounds or sickness.

PORTBOU, Spain, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The entire Pyrenees region of southwestern France from the Atlantic to the Mediterranean is now in the hands or under the control of the FFI, reports reaching here today said.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 20 -- Lippy Leo Durocher received a telegram from President Ford Frick of the National League this morning, to keep his distance from the Brooklyn dugout today or face an extension of the five-day sentence already imposed by the circuit head.

In an attempt to elude pursuing policemen, four youths in a stolen automobile careened wildly through the Bedford section of Brooklyn yesterday and terrified motorists and pedestrians in a mile-long chase that ended when the machine turned over on Park Place near Classon Avenue. One of the boys was killed and the others injured.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (U.P.) -- Preparations for simultaneous investigations into political activities of the Congress of Industrial Organizations were being completed tonight by two separate committees of the House of Representatives.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 20 -- In her final match preparatory to defending her national championship at Forest Hills, Miss Pauline Betz of Los Angeles won the women's invitation tennis tournament at the Longwood Cricket Club today.

WITH THE BRITISH AND CANADIAN FORCES, France, Aug. 20 -- All along the British and Canadian sectors of the Allied front in Normandy today the Germans were resisting stubbornly, yielding ground inch by inch and at some places, notably in the Falaise trap, losing uncounted hundreds of men and large quantities of material.

Adolph J. Chesley, who was summarily dismissed as chairman of the Bronx County War Price and Rationing Board last Saturday after numerous complaints of his lack of cooperation in enforcing the price control program, announced yesterday that he would demand "an immediate personal hearing on these complaints, which are still a complete mystery to me."

Science, philosophy and learning in general are international. For centuries the thinkers have made little of national boundaries as they pioneered in their fields of knowledge. In our own time a few in certain lands have yielded to fear or temptation and betrayed humanity's faith in them by turning nationalist. But in doing so they have ceased to be thinkers, and their names are already forgotten.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 20 -- More rumblings from Washington about efforts of farm interests, particularly cotton States' representatives, to boost cotton prices to parity for the producer, confirmation of an advance of about 2 1/2 cents a pound in ceiling prices of print cloths and a better-than-expected consumption report combined last week to carry cotton futures up more than $2 a bale on the New Orleans Cotton Exchange.

Japanese-American citizens cannot be allowed to serve in the United States Navy, because their presence would "create collateral racial problems of a complex nature which cannot be handled adequately under war conditions," Acting Secretary of the Navy Ralph A. Bard has ruled.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 20 (UP) -- Chinese troops in southwest Hupeh Province captured three key points between the Japanese-held Yangtze bastion of Ichang and Tangyang, twenty-eight miles to the northeast, and are closing in on Tangyang from three sides, the Chinese High Command announced today.
Sam Goldwetz, owner of a candy store at 295 Schenectady Avenue, Brooklyn, likes satisfied customers, but yesterday he caused dismaying inconvenience to a patron, Mrs. Harriet Taret.

In your issue of Aug. 7, Basil Harris, president of the United States Lines Company, paints a very optimistic picture of our merchant marine as he sees it after the war. I hope he is right, and he should be right if we stay on the job we have done for war. But will we? Or will we travel the road we followed after the last World War?

A comfortably furnished waiting room, containing $3,000 worth of easy chairs, sofas, low tables and reading matter, was presented to the Air Transport Command unit at La Guardia Field yesterday afternoon by Mayor La Guardia on behalf of B'nai B'rith, whose Brooklyn lodge undertook the project of furnishing the room.

ALBANY, Aug. 20 -- Wendell L. Willkie will meet in New York City tomorrow John Foster Dulles, representative of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, for a conference on the Governor's views as the Republican candidate for the Presidency on the coming security conference and international affairs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -Superfortresses hammered Japan's home industries in two attacks on the Yawata steel plants today, one the first daylight strike at the enemy homeland since Lieut. Gen. James H. Doolittle's daring swoop on Tokyo more than two years ago.
LONDON, Aug. 20 (Reuter) -- Bremen, Germany's second largest port, has suffered the fate of Hamburg, the British Air Ministry reported today.

UNITED STATES THIRD ARMY HEADQUARTERS, in France, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The spearhead of the American drive to Brest in a ten-day advance of 250 miles was the Sixth Armored Division, it was officially disclosed tonight.
AFUA, Drinlumor River Front, New Guinea, Aug. 11 (Delayed) (AP) -- American wounded and headquarters soldiers can fight, too, when they must.

Mayor La Guardia, in his regular Sunday broadcast over WNYC, the municipal radio station, declared yesterday that there was "every reason to believe no serious epidemic" of infantile paralysis would develop here this fall.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Misgivings that the Anglo-American petroleum agreement, just announced, may prove to be the first step toward "a super-state cartel in all parts of the world for the post-war years," were expressed by J. Howard Pew, president of the Sun Oil Company, in an open letter he addressed today to Senator Tom Connally, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

LONDON, Aug. 20 -- The Daily Worker, Communist organ, in a statement issued tonight declared that the withdrawal of its war correspondent, Clemens Dutt, from the battle zone of southern France, reported to have been ordered by the War Office here, was an "inglorious vendetta against the newspaper."

ALGIERS, Aug. 20 -- General de Gaulle, who is the actual commander of the French Forces of the Interior, is greatly concerned with the prevention of destruction within Paris and the insuring of the resumption of food distribution in the city as soon as possible. Dr. Ralph Walker, pastor of the First Baptist Church of Portland, Ore., said yesterday in his sermon at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue at Twenty-ninth Street.

WITH AMERICAIN ARMOR on the Seine, Aug. 19 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- American tanks and armored vehicles, moving with the fluid ease of old-style cavalry, pushed forward to the banks of this twisting, treacherous river approximately thirty miles northwest of Paris early today, and jeeps and reconnaissance cars are ferreting out enemy "hot spots" along the shoreline.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The private investor may become the principal factor in the so-called inflationary price movement in city and farm property, the Mortgage Bankers Association of America asserted today in a report on a study made among its members.

Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State chairman, in a letter to all Democratic County chairmen and vice chairmen, made public yesterday, asked that they set up special service vote committees in their communities and enlist the aid of non-partisan groups to assure all members of the armed forces of the right to vote.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Congress goes into its fourth week of work on legislative machinery to shift the nation from a war to peacetime production basis with clarification of major issues of policy still impeded by controversy.

Cotton prices in the domestic market were generally firm to strong last week, owing in part to agitation in Congress for measures designed to assure parity prices to growers, according to the weekly review of the New York Cotton Exchange.

WITH THE UNITED STATES THIRD ARMY, Near Chartres, France, Aug. 20 -- The French Tricolor is flying everywhere in the towns and villages the American troops have liberated in the push on Paris, but a beautiful American flag -- so good to see -- is waving in the breeze on a flagpole over the doorway of the spacious Chateau d'Oursieres near the picturesque village of Beaumont des Autels.

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 20 (AP) -- Technological advances achieved during the war are equal to twenty-five years of usual peace-time progress, Allen B. DuMont of Passaic, N.J., a pioneer in the elements of radar, declared today.

LONDON, Aug. 20 (U.P.) -- Polish underground fighters in Warsaw struggled today to seal off serious German tank and infantry penetrations into their lines in the "old city" section of the capital while the patriots' commander, General Bor, appealed anew for Allied aid.

Retail sales of the Jewel Tea Company, Inc., for the first twenty-eight weeks of 1944 reached the record volume of $29,517,922, increasing from the $28,327,988 volume for the corresponding period a year ago, F.J. Lunding, president, informed stockholders in the report issued for publication today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Rear Admiral Husband E. Kimmel, former Navy commander at Pearl Harbor, today protested to Senator Truman that Mr. Truman had made false statements in a magazine article relating to his (Kimmel's) conduct at the Hawaiian base before the Japanese attack in 1941.

There are things more powerful than the robot blitz; one of them is the longing for home. This was emphasized yesterday by the United States Committee for the Care of European Children in reporting that thirty young boys and girls had been returned to England at their parents' request since the bombing began on June 17.
Leases of large apartments in buildings on the East Side were among rentals reported over the week-end.

PROCESSED FOODS (various canned or bottled vegetables, fruits, fruit juices, soups, baby foods, jams, jellies and other special products, and certain dried beans.) Blue stamps A8 through Z8, also A5 through F5 in War Book 4, good indefinitely at 10 points each. Frozen fruits and vegetables and dried fruits now point-free.

Leopold Stokowski will return to the City Center in October as Music Director of the New York City Symphony, Mayor La Guardia announces. Dr. Stokowski will conduct another series of six pairs of concerts, which will be offered to the public at special subscription prices, on Monday evenings and Tuesday afternoons.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The most important attempt to form an international security organization since Versailles will begin tomorrow when representatives of the United States, Soviet Russia and Great Britain open a series of formal conversations in the music room of the Dumbarton Oaks mansion in Georgetown, Washington suburb.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -The Petroleum Administration for War today authorized production of oil in September at the rate of 5,051,000 barrels daily, the highest output ever certified to the various-oil-producing States.

The Rev. Dr. Theodore C. Speers, in a sermon on"'Religion's Appeal to the Naive," in the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street, of which he is the pastor, said yesterday that religion had always possessed a peculiarly strong appeal for the simple and naive.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20 (AP) -The Western Union Telegraph Company, New York, has registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission $24,603,000 principal amount of twenty-year convertible debentures.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -The last-place Senators swept a double-header with the league-leading Browns today before a crowd of 18,048, taking the opener 4 -- 2 and humbling the Browns 12 -- 1 in the second encounter. The St. Louis lead was reduced to three and a half games as the Red Sox won twice.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- Weather conditions last week were much more favorable for the corn crop than they had been previously. Light showers to heavy rains fell over a wide area, and although many sections received too little moisture to be of much benefit, local rains broke the drought in other areas, and the general situation is regarded as more favorable.
SPRING MOUNT, Pa., Aug. 20 (AP) -- The "One-Man Army of Anzio" received his official welcome home today, and most everyone in the Perkiomen Valley opined they "never saw anything like it."

WITH THE AMERICANS in Normandy, July 23 (Delayed) (AP) -- Three American chaplains seeking out wounded under fire in a marshy No Man's Land brought a spontaneous unofficial cessation of hostilities in this sector for three hours today.

The family of nations comes in for frequent mention nowadays. Many of an anxious voice implores the nations to remember that, notwithstanding their differences, they are a family; that, in the words of St. Paul and the song, they are "all one body," and that therefore they ought to have a little thought for the family's future welfare.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 20 -- The way was cleared today for settlement of the machinists' overtime work dispute which has resulted in Government seizure of 104 machine shops here.

LONDON, Aug. 20 -- Britons were told bluntly by some of their leaders over the week-end that now that their military survival was guaranteed they must continue wartime sacrifices to assure their economic future.

Operettas based on the careers of famous composers always seem to strike a responsive chord with music lovers and hordes of others. Regardless of the quality of the story fabrication, those musicals generally find favor with many chiefly because of their immortal melodies.

News of successful invasion of southern France, rendering early complete defeat of Germany more probable, caused advance on the Stock Exchange; first slow, then toward the week-end rapid when dispatches foreshadowed capture of Paris.
The giant rocket, termed by the Germans "V-2," or their second "weapon of revenge," may soon play a part in the war.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Declaring she was "the happiest girl alive," Miss Ann Curtis of San Francisco climbed out of her lane at the Swope Park Pool today, the only woman ever to win four national free-style swimming titles in a single meet.

ROME, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The United States Navy announced today that 641 of the total of 1,500 ships and other craft in the Allied assault force that staged the landings in southern France on Aug. 15 flew the colors of the United States.

AN ADVANCED AMERICAN OUTPOST, Southern France, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Capt. Mills Brandes pointed mournfully at his feet, encased in bedroom slippers, and ruefully explained that the only hard part about being in southern France doing advance work two weeks before the invasion was that his shoes did not last long.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Adopting an industry safety campaign method, the Army will begin on Sept. 4 the issuing of a booklet, "Pvt. Droop Has Missed the War," with every furlough pass.
LONDON, Aug. 20 -- The Germans are reported to be combating an armed revolt in Paris. There also are reports of strikes and of the populace singing victory songs in the boulevards.

MOSCOW, Aug. 19 (Delayed) -The loss of twenty-one British heavy bombers flying arms to the Warsaw insurgents is considered here as a sad and puzzling fact.

SPOKANE, Wash., Aug. 20 (AP) -- In the most spectacular upset in the history of the tournament, Bob Hamilton, Evansville, Ind., defeated Byron Nelson, Toledo, Ohio, 1 up over thirty-six holes today to win the 1944 P.G.A. golf championship.
ROME, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Polish troops on the Adriatic sector of the If]inn front have advancedi more than three miles reaching the! towns of GabrielH and Aondolfo, Allled headquarters said today.

WITH THE AMERICAN SEVENTH ARMAY, in Southern France, Aug. 20 -- While the Americans were making their remarkable dash to the outskirts of Aix-en-Provence today, the French were closing a steel net around Toulon and Hyeres.

GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Monday, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Heavily punished Japanese air forces are withdrawing from Halmahera to bases westward beyond Allied bomber range, Gen. Douglas MacArthur reported in a communique today.
GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, in Southwest Pacific, Monday, Aug. 21 (AP) -- A communique:

The triumphant news this morning, dramatized by General de Gaulle's arrival in Cherbourg with the declaration that "we will rebuild together a stronger and more beautiful France," is like a breath of spring in this late summer of the Nazis. But behind the exultant dispatches is something more than the liberation of a single country.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 20 -- A deal is expected to be made between Twentieth Century-Fox and Warner Brothers, which would give the former studio Humphrey Bogart for the role of Major Joppolo in "A Bell for Adano" and the latter company the services of Betty Grable for "Silver Lining," a screen biography of the late Marilyn Miller.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Supported by United States Fourteenth Air Force planes, Chinese troops stormed and captured Laotungpo, a strongly fortified hill position southeast of the Burma Road city of Lungling, and inflicted an estimated 130 casualties on the enemy, the Chinese High Command said today.

A householder who has moved since the close of last winter's heating season should file his declaration forms for next season's coal supply with the same dealer who furnished fuel to the former tenants of the house, the New York area advisory committee on coal distribution, set up by the Solid Fuel Administration, emphasized yesterday.

Several weeks ago, the United States Department of Agriculture's Western regional research laboratory developed, for commercial manufacture, a new frozen fruit dessert that has the smooth texture of ice cream. Called velva fruit, the department has now devised a recipe for making it at home, either in a hand freezer or in the tray of a mechanical refrigerator.
LONDON, Aug. 20 (UP) -- A German communique:
Honors in the eight classes of the Bayside Yacht Club's sixth annual junior regatta on Little Neck Bay were shared by representatives of five clubs as the two-day event ended yesterday.
ROME, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Communique:

The Balkans, as is well known, constitute a danger spot. A possible helpful peace influence occurs to me. In each Balkan nation there are dissatisfied minorities whose situation could be improved by the erection of a Superior Balkan Council, to consist of small numbers of elected and appointed members for each racial group, regardless of numbers or of country of residence.

In fact, it is frequently pointed out that, if anything, it will be even better, since many restrictions will be removed.

Honors in the eight classes of the Bayside Yacht Club's sixth annual junior regatta on Little Neck Bay were shared by representatives of five clubs as the two-day event ended yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Distinguished Service Cross to Major Edmund F. Driscoll, Infantry, 5 Cedar Street, West Hempstead, L. I.

The recent decision by the Fisher brothers to break away from General Motors is causing a flurry among advertising men here who are speculating on whether the Fishers will introduce a new automobile when conditions permit. If they do decide to put a new car on the market, it was said, the agency receiving the account for promotion will have one of the largest advertising appropriations that has been placed in many years.

ROME, Aug. 20 -- In a speech this morning before an audience that crowded the Eliseo Theatre and overflowed into the Via Nazionale, Count Carlo Sforza, Minister Without Portfolio, proposed that the port of Fiume, long a bone of contention between Italy and Yugoslavia, be made "one of the seats" of a super-League of Nations.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

LONDON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Allied air forces acted swiftly today to aid in closing the new trap on fleeing Germans in the vicinity of the Seine River after the greatest air scourging in history left the German Army in the Normandy pocket at Falaise floundering in a graveyard of strewn corpses and military vehicles.

Creation of an independent committee, headed by John Haynes Holmes, to support Norman Thomas and Darlington Hoopes, Socialist candidates for President and Vice President, respetcively, was announced yesterday. In its initial statement the committee repeated the Socialist charge of past campaigns that there were no fundamental differences between the Republicans and the Democrats.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- A campaign to acquaint the public more fully with ceiling prices in grocery stores and thereby intensify the fight against inflation was announced today by the Office of Price Administration, with the cooperation of the leading food trade associations.

LONDON, Aug. 20 -- For some time the attitude of the British people toward the problem of post-war treatment of Germany has been stiffening. To this trend the buzz-bomb attacks on southern England have made no small contribution.

With Allied airpower already supreme in the skies, the Petroleum War Council announces that new and super-powerful fuels are ready for the rise of our air arm. Even before the entry of the United States into the war, the contribution of the petroleum industry to the cause of the United Nations was a major one.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- The question whether Wacs and other women serving overseas should be admitted to membership in the Veterans of Foreign Wars will be threshed out at the three-day V.F.W. convention which opens on Monday.

SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Two British Fourteenth Army columns have by-passed the last knot of Japanese resistance along the Tiddim Road a mile north of the Burma frontier in the East Indian State of Manipur and stabbed beyond a mile south of the border, a communique from Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten's headquarters said today.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The Braves snapped the Cardinals' winning streak today in the second game of a double-header by winning, 5 -- 3. The Cardinals had triumphed, 15 -- 5, in the opener for their ninth straight victory.
CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 20 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- Endorsement of President Roosevelt for re-election and of his foreign policies by the convention of the New York State Federation of Labor, largest State unit in the American Federation of Labor, with a membership of 1,500,000, appeared certain today when it was learned that its executive council had voted to recommend such action.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20 -- The aircraft carrier Antietam and the heavy cruisers Chicago and Los Angeles, 53,000 tons of fighting steel, were christened in a triple ceremony at the Philadelphia Navy Yard today, marking the largest christening of warships at any one time or place in naval history.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- Canadian oats are playing an important part in determining the trend of the American markets. Although the peak of the after-harvest movement in the Central West occurred less than thirty days ago, steamers with 340,000 bushels of Canadian grain arrived here last week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The imminent departure, expected early this week, of Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, on a special Presidential mission to China, gave rise to speculation throughout Washington today as to whether his absence at this time might prove a check to his recent victory in launching his program for reconversion to peace-time industry.

MIAMI, Aug. 20 i/P) -- Jamaica was struck by the 60-mile-an-hour winds of a tropical storm today and the Federal Storm Warning Service here issued a hurricane alert for the south coast of western Cuba, the Isle of Pines and !the Cayman Islands.

The world is saved not by "good people" but by "moral heroes and heroines, by saints," the Rev. Dr. Bernard Iddings Bell of Providence, R.I., said in a sermon yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church, Broadway at Wall Street. He asserted that the individual who was satisfied with goodness felt no need of repentance or prayer or sacraments.

TODAY, while the war in Europe is reaching a crescendo of fury in France, the word invasion as it is generally used means only one thing, the attack through Normandy. The attack through the Riviera is the second invasion. But there were at least three other military actions of momentous importance in the Mediterranean theatre that were invasions also -- the inva sionof North Africa, the invasion of Sicily and the invasion of Italy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The Army Nurse Corps today added three awards to its list, bringing to an even 100 the number of Army nurses who have been decorated in this war, and to 108 the total list of women's awards and citations in line of duty with the armed services.

When Adm. Chester W. Nimitz declared the other day that Japan could be defeated without invasion, by assault, the general public was startled. Coming from a top naval leader, the statement sounded "heretical." It seemed a confirmation of the claims of "air enthusiasts" that nowadays nations can be knocked out without mile-by-mile conquest.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- There were eighty-two starters today out on Long-Island Sound in the New York Athletic Club's annual championship regatta, which was run by the Larchmont Yacht Club. They had a nice southwest breeze that backed up a little at one stage and drooped at another, but wound up with a fine sailing strength that again made finishes in spilling water.

In spite of the increasing number of price changes for individuaI commodities, the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices has been fluctuating within less than one tenth of 1 per cent for the last few weeks. Last week it dropped from 113.08 to 113.05.

Five buildings comprising an entire blockfront on Grand Street between Mercer Street and Broadway and known as 106 to 112 Grand Street and 461-67 Broadway have been bought by Harry and Irving Cohen, who have insured title with the Lawyers Title Corporation of New York.

The Greek Government in Cairo, broadcasting a vigorous attack on Bulgaria Monday night, likened her leaders' present professions of a desire for peace to "the lamentations of a thief who has been caught in the act."

LONDON, Aug. 21 (Netherlands News Agency) -- About 3,000 Netherlanders, including all the Jews left at the notorious Nazi concentration camp at Vught and the occupied part of the Netherlands, have been transported to Germany for reinternment, a report from the German-occupied country said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Plans for establishing new Navy transmission facilities on Guam within the next five weeks to make possible transmission of news and photographs from Pacific battle-fronts to the United States within a matter of hours were disclosed today by Navy spokesmen.

The job of presenting a complete picture of France today is too much for even the most gifted reporters and the most expert map makers. The reporters can dip here and there into the clouds and smoke that have been swirling over the country. The map makers can lay out with lines and shadings the expanding area of Allied control.
In addition to the flying bomb and the rocket the Germans have introduced or are working upon other new weapons or inventions -- some of them of tremendous potential, others merely fads and duds.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Gerald Driscoll, 19-year-old skipper from San Diego Bay (Calif.), won the opening race of the 1944 international Star Class regatta today, sailing the ten-mile course in 3:04:58.

The first shipment of whole blood for wounded Americans was flown out last night by plane to Europe. It was provided by the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross and delivered at an airfield to the Army Transport Command by the chapter's motor corps.
LONDON, Aug. 21 (Reuter) Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, the Polish Premier, saw British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden this afternoon.

A brand of dehydrated fruit juice, developed for distribution to the armed forces overseas, has recently been made available to civilians for the first time. Tradenamed Freshie, it is put up by Sunway Fruit Products and provides a simple method of preparing a satisfactory, fresh-flavored beverage.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- President Roosevelt took steps today, extraordinary in such circumstances, to spike reports that the departure of Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, on a special mission to China meant a change in WPB policies or the standing of that official.

Half an hour away from the target and several hours after the daylight attack, crews of American B-29's boring in for a night strike at the Japanese industrial area of Yawata said they saw great flames against the sky. The "minor" damage reported by the Tokyo radio would seem to have been somewhat more than that.

ROME, Aug. 21 -- More than a third of the famed Pontine Marsh area, which the Germans flooded last spring to delay the northward advance of the Allies, has already been drained, while in most of the other flooded areas experts are now supervising reclamation projects, it was disclosed today.
KANDY, Ceylon, Aug. 21 (UP) -- A communique:

So many shows have been announced for the new season that one wonders whether there will be enough theatres to go around for all the great expectations. As if by magic there is always a house available for the right attraction and/or producer.

In a letter to Senator Connally, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, J. Howard Pew, president of the Sun Oil Company, has raised questions about the Anglo-American petroleum agreement that should be answered. "What is the meaning," he asks, "of the phrase 'fair prices'?

Walter Dubiel, freshman right-hander of the Yankees, did not exactly mow down the opposing batters throughout the afternoon, and he did find himself in straits from time to time, but the Yankees came through with enough long-range wallops to enable Dubiel to go all the way as the McCarthymen conquered the Tigers, 5 -- 1, yesterday at the Stadium.

There is one type of wartime child delinquency which constitutes a problem by itself. We have an example in the case of Gerald W.
