Haddon of Chicago, who has just fallen into the toils of the law, so to speak. After a period of useful service as a seaman second-class in the Mediterranean and participation in no fewer than thirteen landings in Normandy it is discovered that Gerald is only 15 years old.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Frank Hayes' single with the bases loaded in the tenth inning ended a pitching battle between Bill Dietrich and Don Black, giving the Athletics a 3-2 victory over the White Sox tonight.

Vegetables ranging from midget tomatoes to a thirty-seven-pound pumpkin were displayed by their growers yesterday atop the RCA Building in Radio City at a "Country Fair in the Clouds." Fifteen hundred pounds of vegetables produced by employes of the Shell Oil Company's New York office and the Asiatic Petroleum Corporation were included in the show, which was attended by 1,100 persons.

WITH BRITISH-CANADIAN FORCES, Near Trun, France, Aug. 21 (U.P.) -- Ten American soldiers captured by the Germans appeared out of the woods north of Argentan with their twenty captors in tow as captives, and then stayed on to fight alongside the Canadians, a young Canadian colonel said today.

The Richfield Oil Corporation, in its semi-annual statement of operations to be released today, disclosed a net income for the first half of 1944 of $1,710,079, equal to about 43 cents each on 4,010,000 shares outstanding. Net income for the corresponding period a year ago was $1,515,255, or approximately 38 cents a share.

DRUEX, France, Aug. 19 (Delayed) -- Tom Treanor, 35 years of age, correspondent for the National Broadcasting Company and The Los Angeles Times, was injured fatally and two other correspondents and the driver of their jeep were hurt yesterday when a tank they were attempting to pass on this front near Beval swerved suddenly and crushed the jeep.

Hinting that the new German secret weapon might be of a chemical or bacterial nature, the Brazzaville radio, quoting London sources, reported last night that "very suspicious preparations have been made in Germany during the past few days," according to the Columbia Broadcasting System.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 21 -- Attorney General Francis Biddle said today at the noon meeting of Town Hall that the Department of Justice will resume a normal course of prosecuting anti-trust violators within the next six months.

ALBANY, Aug. 21 -- The State Education Department announced today that secondary school enrollment in New York State has dropped 152,000 in the last four years, or a total equivalent to the population of Yonkers or Albany.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 21 -- American heavy bombers have dropped "thousands of tons of arms, ammunition and other supplies" to French Forces of the Interior, the Eighth Air Force announced today.

Justice George Frankenthaler, Republican, was chosen last night by the new Liberal party as one of its candidates for vacancies on the Supreme Court bench in the First Judicial district, consisting of Manhattan and the Bronx. He is now sitting on the court for an interim term by appointment of Governor Dewey.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The House of Representatives adopted tentatively today a restriction in its Surplus War Property Disposal Bill which would subject to specific Congressional authorization the sale, exchange, lease or transfer of any property of the United States Navy from war vessels and auxiliary craft down to PT boats and former private yachts, stations, establishments or facilities, including manufacturing plants.

DRAGUIGNAN, France, Aug. 20 (Delayed) -- The biggest collaborationist caught in southern France, Fernand Bouisson, 71-year-old former President of the French Chamber of Deputies, is in jail here awaiting whatever penalty will be meted out by French justice.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today the Mississippi Power and Light Company's refinancing program, including the issuance and sale of $12,000,000 of first mortgage bonds due in 1974.
Kobbe, Gearhart Co., Inc., announced yesterday that their offering of 100,000 shares of the Clyde Porcelain Steel Corporation had been completed and the books closed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Representative Ralph E. Church, Republican of Illinois, told the House today that the full story of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor would "shock" the world and added, "Washington was to blame."
ROME, Aug. 21 (UP) -- A special Headquarters announcement:
ROME, Aug. 21 (AP) -- A communique:

New York State will not be able to provide facilities for the vocational training and rehabilitation of its returning veterans without assistance from industry, Oakley Furney, assistant State Commissioner of Education in charge of vocational education, declared at a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.

BRITISH HEADQUARTERS IN THE FIELD, France, Aug. 21 (U.P.) -- A torrential rain washed the broken men who once were part of the Germans' proud Seventh Army out of the woods in the Trun pocket, and by nightfall 10,000 of them, many hundreds of them wounded and some still panicky after having been fired upon by their own uncaptured comrades trying to escape, were in British hands.

Without any wish to add to the Indian controversy that is now concerned with Mahatma Gandhi's latest proposal to the Viceroy, except by way of clearing the air, I venture to quote a few lines from Lord Wavell's reply to Gandhi, the full text of which has just reached me:

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, Near Florence, Aug. 20 (Delayed) (AP) -- Prime Minister Churchill told a Canadian tank brigade today that the great battle raging in Normandy promised to bring the end of the war much nearer.

The New York State Liquor Authority is determined that there will be no recurrence of the "price wars" among package stores that prevailed before the war, industry spokesmen said yesterday. The Authority, in a statement issued yesterday, declared that "the trade and industry certainly do not want any chaotic conditions to arise which will tend to reflect discredit upon the industry and the State Liquor Authority has a definite interest in preventing such conditions."

An unusual number of uncommon happenings marked the program of the Saratoga Association at Belmont Park yesterday. There were two disqualifications, a dead heat, a triple by Eddie Arcaro and doubles for two jockeys.

Wendell L. Willkie and John Foster Dulles, Governor Dewey's adviser on international affairs, conferred yesterday at Mr. Dulles' residence for an hour and a half, exchanging views on the problems of insuring against future wars and the stand which the Republican party should take toward meeting them.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 21 -- Rear Admiral Harold G. Bowen, who is supervising the operations of 104 uptown machine shops from a six-room suite with a staff of three men and two Waves, announced today that the application of "sanctions" against machinists employed in the ninety-nine plants that were seized Saturday by the Navy as the result of a dispute involving overtime would depend on reports due Wednesday morning.

BOSTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- A high fly lofted by Mickey Rocco down the foul line carried the right field stand with a few inches to spare today, but it was a good enough homer to give the Indians a 7-6 victory over the Red Sox in thirteen innings.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Communique 135:

DENVER, Col., Aug. 21 -- Victory over Germany should permit the gradual release from the armed services of 1,000,000 to 2,000,000 men, Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, national director of Selective Service, said here today.

The summary dismissal last Saturday of Adolph J. Chesley as Bronx County rationing chairman by Daniel P. Woolley, head of the regional Office of Price Administration, will be aired at a public hearing at regional OPA headquarters in the Empire State Building this morning at 10 o'clock.

A woman who wants to get married and stay that way should hunt for a husband in the ranks of firemen, civil engineers and agricultural laborers, according to a study of United States Census figures published in the current Woman's Home Companion.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Whether the aid of the United Nations Rehabilitation and Relief Administration will be extended to enemy territory will be discussed at the Montreal meeting of the organization, starting Sept. 15, Sir Arthur Salter, Senior Deputy Director, said today. The scope of UNRRA now does not cover these lands:

The union motor-truck terminal which the Port of New York Authority promises to build when materials are available has been a crying necessity for years. South of Fifty-ninth Street two-thirds of all city-merchandise and freight has long been carried in motor trucks. As the traffic grew it threatened to choke itself.

ROME, Aug. 21 (U.P.) -- Polish troops of the British Eighth Army pushed their way along the Adriatictic coast today to capture several important heights between the Cesano and Metauro Rivers and reported that patrols advancing three miles farther north had not made contact with any of the enemy.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 21 -- A. Felix du Pont, vice president of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., has retired as a member of its finance committee, effective Aug. 1, it was announced here today after a meeting of the board of directors. He will remain a member of the board.

WITH THE FIRST SPECIAL SERVICE FORCE in Southern France, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Censorship release of the presence in southern France of the joint American-Canadian First Special Service Force today partly lifted the curtain on one of the most hush-hush organizations in the United Nations' warbag.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Senator John H. Bankhead, Democrat, of Alabama, proclaimed to night his readiness to fight until Christmas to raise prices of cotton to parity. He talked today with a group of cotton shippers to get their support for suggestions that cotton be withheld from the market until the market approximated parity, which, he said, was $6 to $8 a bale higher than the 1944 loan rates of the Commodity Credit Corporation.

Elite Guard Gen. Hans Juettner has been named "Heinrich Himmler's permanent representative in his capacity as commander of the reserve army," the German Trans-ocean Agency said yesterday in a wireless dispatch transmitted overseas in English and reported by the Federal Communications Commission.

LIVAROT-SUR-VIE, Normandy, Aug. 21 (U.P.) -- A German field marshal who probably was Field Marshal Gen. Erwin Rommel died of a fractured skull about 3 A.M. July 18 in a hospital at Bernay near the Seine River, Mayor Marcel Lescene of this town reported today.

Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican national chairman, said yesterday that he intends to "look into" reports that unions affiliated with the Congress of Industrial Organizations are soliciting funds from employers with whom they have union contracts, to be used by the Citizens National Political Action Committee in support of President Roosevelt.

ST. EUTROPE, France, Aug. 21 -- Admiral Siegfried Wieder, 55-year-old commander of German marine forces in southern France and charged with the defense of naval establishments from Nice to Perpignan, committed suicide in this village at the outskirts of Aix-en-Provence four days before the Allies' invasion.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (U.P.) -- Senator Connally, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, and Senator Carl A. Hatch of New Mexico proposed today that the United States acquire title or lease of all Pacific and Atlantic islands necessary for its security, with acquisition "subject only to negotiations with the Allies."

LONDON, Aug. 21 (U.P.) -- The French Forces of the Interior have captured Toulouse, it was announced today, and liberated the Pyrenees border town of Hendaye at the French end of the International Bridge into Spain.

If a battle should be fought at Solferino in northern Italy in this present war it would differ from the horrible battle fought there in June, 1859, in many respects but in none more than the care given the wounded. To receive a major wound at Solferino in 1859 was almost surely to be condemned to a torturing death.

Few certifications permitting labor to produce civilian goods under the war-production program for reconversion to consumer lines will be made in the next thirty days owing to the continued critical needs for war materials, Joseph B. O'Connor, acting regional director of the War Manpower Commission for Region II, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21--The Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company today asked authority of the Interstate Commerce Commission to purchase 5,472 additional shares of the common stock of Wheeling Lake Erie Railway Company from the Alleghany Corporation at $59 per share, plus the cost of all incidental Federal and State documentary transfer taxes, and interest at the rate of 3 per cent per annum from Aug. 2 to the date of payment for the shares.

WASHINGTON, Aug 21 -- In the largest proposal for the refunding of existing capitalization to be received at the Interstate Commerce Commission in recent years, the Great Northern Railway Company today asked authority to issue $100,000,000 of the general mortgage gold bonds.

As part of its plan to provide practical information in the postwar period on adequate lighting in the heavy traffic days expected, the street-lighting section of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association will run a series of advertisements in trade publications at that time, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The War Production Board announced today a four-point policy to stimulate production of important materials and parts needed in war production and designed to protect the productive capacity of subcontractors.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Photographs of family and home and other things reminding American service men and women of relatives and friends are deeply desired for Christmas presents by members of the armed services abroad, the Office of War Information said today.
Mrs. Anthony D. Duke has come to the Plaza from Southampton.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 21 -- The Dodgers today were in possession of a four-game losing streak, compiled in two afternoons here. They dropped a double-header yesterday to the Pirates and, by playing half an inning of the July 9 suspended game and ten innings of the regularly scheduled contest, were beaten twice today by the Bucs, 9 -- 7 and 7 -- 6.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The largest single current bag of Japanese ships ever reported sunk by United States submarines was revealed today when the Navy announced that American underwater raiders had sent another nineteen enemy vessels, including a light cruiser and an escort vessel, to the bottom.

Textiles, for which the Belgian Congo native spends 60 per cent of his earnings, are the backbone of the war program in that territory, Dr. H.A. Cornelis, textile controller and price controller of the Belgian Congo Government, said yesterday. American types of gray goods are exactly what they need, he said, because of their high quality and low price.

Grand Central Terminal was crowded with grimy children and welcoming parents last night as the first of the wartime day-coach trains bringing children back from summer camps arrived at 9:30 o'clock with 2,800 campers from fourteen Maine camps.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 21--Senator Harry S. Truman of Missouri, Democratic candidate for Vice President, in a statement made late today declared that every statement he had made in an article in the current issue of Collier's Magazine was correct and that he was certain the court-martial of officers commanding at Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7, 1941, would bear out every assertion he had made and more.

MOSCOW, Aug. 21 -- For the first time in their history the Moslems of Russia have elected a Sheik to be supreme spiritual leader of the faithful throughout the Soviet Union. He is Ahund Aga Alizade of Baku, of whom it is said in the Caucasus that few men have more right to the title of Sheik ul Islam.

Today our ship received all the details about voting in the November elections. However, when we merchant seamen from New York State examined the regulations we were ashamed to see and embittered, too, that our home State had disenfranchised us. As merchant seamen we are not eligible to receive the State ballot, nor has the State made any provisions for us to use the Federal ballot.
May I offer a few words of comment on the statement by Caryl E. Cohen in a letter to THE TIMES and quoted by Edward I. Fenlon in THE TIMES of Aug. 19, namely:
LONDON, Aug. 21 -- Although the stock markets here started the week on a cheerful note, buyers were few and prices tended to ease where shares changed hands.
CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- Aggressive professional buying of rye futures disclosed a lack of selling pressure today on the Board of Trade and the market advanced rapidly after a small early dip.

HIS main fault had been lack of control. But it wasn't so much his failure to control his pitches which made him a disappointment and a failure. It was his inability to control himself. So Hal Newhouser took a firm grip on his terrible temper and thus became the first winner of twenty games in the major leagues this season.

LONDON, Tuesday, Aug. 22 -- Powerful Russian forces yesterday cracked the main Nazi defense line northeast of Warsaw, sweeping one to six miles across the Bialystok-Warsaw railroad on a twenty-one-mile front in a massive drive to outflank the embattled Polish capital to the north.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 21 (AP) -- One man pleaded innocent today and seven others will be arraigned tomorrow on charges of illegal voting and registration contained in an indictment returned by a special grand jury ordered by Governor Dewey to investigate crime in Albany County.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 21 (AP) -- Reopening of the transfer books of preferred stock of the Central States Electric Corporation is provided for in an order by Judge Robert N. Pollard of Federal district court here.

In furtherance of the War Department's decision to place more emphasis on athletics, officers of the Special Services Division and a committee of sports followers from civilian life met for a week to devise a greatly enlarged program, and the plan, still in a formulative stage, was explained yesterday at 30 Church Street.

SAIPAN, Aug. 15 (Delayed) -- American sports are being taught to Japanese youngsters on Saipan at an athletic center constructed by United States Army engineers and special service officers for the civilian population of the island and are being well received, officers say.

In a few sentences yesterday in his opening remarks to the international security conference at Dumbarton Oaks Secretary Hull drew from the experience of the last few years the one great lesson which must never again be ignored or forgotten. "We have witnessed, and are witnessing today," he said, "the sweep of forces of savagery and barbarism of the kind that civilized men hoped and believed would not rise again.

Plans for Morrisania Houses, one of the New York City Housing Authority's major post-war projects, will be filed today with the Department of Housing and Buildings, Edmond B. Butler, chairman of the Authority, announced yesterday.

Establishment of a new company, Affiliated Retailers, Inc., for the cooperative development, buying and promotion of merchandise by the May Department Stores Company and R.H. Macy Co., Inc., was made known yesterday in a joint statement by Nathan L. Dauby, vice president of the May organization, and Jack I. Straus, president of Macy's. The combined sales volume of the two companies is around $350,000,000.

NINTH AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS, in France, Aug. 21 -- Three American war correspondents and one artist accredited to the United States Army and assigned to the Ninth Air Force in France, were summarily recalled to London yesterday by the Ninth Air Force.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Last night's air blow against Yawata, Japan's "Pittsburgh," by our Superfortresses was administered by the light of fires still blazing from yesterday's daylight attack, Twentieth Air Force Headquarters disclosed today in a second communique on the double-barreled attack.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Reactionary agrarian and conservative quarters in Finland are attempting to delay an armistice with Russia, according to information received here from Finland.

After spending such time in the lower depths that even its best friends had begun to wonder, the theatre last evening showed it still can produce a pleasant show when it wants to try. Last night's occasion was the arrival here from the Coast of "Song of Norway," an operetta about Grieg and using his music.

Industry and distribution can maintain employment and sell the huge increase in production after the war "only if they are willing to sacrifice immediate, quick profit in the interest of a more permanent prosperity," Charles J. Michaels, president of the American National Retail Jewelers Association, said last night at the opening of its four-day conference at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

ROME, Aug. 21--Toulon, the great French Mediterranean naval base, is virtually in the Allies' hands tonight. French troops entered the northern and western sections last evening, pouring their armor through the suburbs of Les Quatre Chemins, Les Routes and Labourdine.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- A bill to provide industrial medical services for all Federal employes, the current total of whom is about 2,700,000, was endorsed today by officials of the Federal Government and a representative of the American Medical Association at hearings before the House District Committee.

Toilet waters, eaux de colognes, deodorants and perfumes for men are included in the plans of leading manufacturers for the expansion of men's toiletries lines. Though it is admitted that men may offer some resistance to such preparations, it is hoped by the manufacturers that through new types of packaging, promotion and some help on the part of women in the propagandizing of the products the present masculine stand can be broken down.

Five subsidiaries in the packaged drug division of the American Home Products Corporation have been unified into a single operating unit named Whitehall Pharmacal Company, it was announced yesterday by Walter F. Silbersack, executive vice president and general manager of the corporation.

WITH BRITISH AND CANADIAN ARMIES in France, Aug. 21--Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery, in a message today to Allied troops, praised them for the smashing victories won in northwestern France and told them "the end of the war is in sight--let's finish off the business in record time."

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 21 -- The high prices paid today for a champion shorthorn bull at the annual cattle show indicated that Argentine cattle-breeding circles felt no apprehension that Great Britain would refuse to renew her meat purchasing contract on behalf of the United Nations when it expires Sept. 30.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decrease of 8 per cent last week under the comparative week of last year, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the preceding week the bank had reported a gain of 14 per cent in sales.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Don Gutteridge's home run in the twelfth inning with Frank Mancuso on base gave the Browns a 5-3 victory over Washington tonight, breaking a four-game losing streak.
ROME, Aug. 21 (U.P.) -- The frontal break-through into Toulon was made when the French seized Le-Revest-les-Eaux, two miles above Toulon; Mont Caume, Menones-les-Montries and Sollies-Toucas.

The development of Laskin Mouton into a serviceable and wearable fur that can take its place in the style picture was exhibited yesterday at a luncheon showing on the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis Hotel. This hardy fur, which in former days took its place only among sports items, was made up in good-looking wraps that could serve for any purpose.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 21 -- Bulgarian Premier Ivan Bagrianoff is continuing his efforts to arrange an armistice with the United Nations. The Soviet Union, which is not at war with Bulgaria, is urging speed through its Sofia legation.

WHAT has been going on inside Germany during the last two years and what has been going on inside a typical Nazi soldier are matters about which men of good-will in more or less civilized countries can only speculate. Yet these very matters are the theme of an interesting novel written by a man better qualified than most to assay so difficult a fictional task.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The need to create quickly an international security league, backed by force and organized to give all nations responsibility commensurate with their power, was emphasized today at the opening session of the "Washington Conversations on International Organization."

GENERAL EISENHOWER'S HEADQUARTERS, Aug. 21 -- Secretary of the Navy James V. Forrestal came from a conference with Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower today "tremendously impressed" with the spirit of cooperation that he said the Supreme Commander has fostered among the British, Americans and their Allies.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 21 -- The mining of Baltic and North Sea waters by the Allied air forces is causing Germany to lose the use of at least 400,000 tons of Swedish shipping. The Reich may also lose 2,000,000 to 3,000,000 tons of Swedish iron ore due to be delivered to north German ports the remainder of this year.
LONDON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Germans hurled one of the heaviest daylight robot attacks since the first weeks of the flying bomb assaults on London and southern England today.

PEARL HARBOR, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Bombers of the Seventh Army Air Force raided Yap in the western Carolines, 525 miles southwest of Guam, for the first time Saturday and also struck northward at Pagan and Alamagan in the Marianas.

TRUN, France, Aug. 21 (U.P.) -- Pvt. Earl McAllister of Hamilton, Ont., single-handedly captured 160 fully armed Germans in the battle of the gap today to break the record set in France in World War I by Sgt. Alvin York, the famed Tennessee mountainer.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Dumbarton Oaks, the former estate of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Woods Bliss, provided an appropriate setting for the preliminary diplomatic conversations on international organization which opened today.
Sunday's communique, as broadcast yesterday from Chungking in English to North America and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

ROME, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Prime Minister Churchill praised the Fifth Army today as one of the great striking forces of the Allies and paid a special compliment to American troops of Japanese and Negro ancestry.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The War Food Administration announced today an additional egg purchase program of dried eggs for shipment to England and Russia.
CHICAGO, Aug. 21 (AP) -- They hoisted the curtain on the mob scene first act of the seven-day Tam o' Shanter $42,500 three-ring all-American golf circus today.

ROME, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Nazi airfields in Hungary and central Serbia were blasted today by United States Fifteenth Air Force Liberators and shot up by escorting fighters. P-47 Thunderbolts, switching from the invasion of southern France for lack of targets there, dealt a surprise blow in several waves on the Alessandria rail yards in northern Italy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The motorship Gripsholm will leave New York on or about Wednesday to carry out a new American-German exchange of seriously wounded war prisoners entitled to repatriation under the Geneva Convention.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Rear Admiral J.M. Irish testified today before the former Truman committee, now headed by Senator Mead of New York, that the public could expect to benefit fairly promptly from the release to the open market of large quantities of medicines as a result of efforts to streamline Navy inventories.

The stock market revalued yesterday the current military position as a result of the Allied sweep in France and, with buying power held in reserve, sufficient selling engaged the list to produce a moderate retreat. While it endeavored to maintain its shock-proof attitude toward a sudden end of fighting in Europe, events seemed to be moving at a faster pace than had been expected.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., Aug. 21 -- Authorities announced today that $2,500 had been contributed for free telephone calls for wounded soldiers here. The donations resulted from the misapprehension that wounded soldiers were unable to call their loved ones on arriving from overseas because of payroll lags and lack of credit.

Miss Frieda Miller poses no argument against the equal rights amendment when she says, in your issue of Aug. 18, "No amendment can give women consideration at the hands of the employers who hold the jobs in this country. Nor will anyone hire, say, a woman lawyer because of the equal rights amendment."

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Tuesday, Aug. 22 -- Armored forces of the United States Third Army have thrust across the Seine southeast of Paris, winning a second bridgehead across the enemy's main natural defense line and completing a swift and brilliant movement by which Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton Jr. has turned the left flank of the German Fifteenth Army.

LONDON, Aug. 21--There are no signs yet of inflation in France as a result of Anglo-American occupation. Nor has there been any marked objection on the part of French peasants to accept the fiat money printed in the United States before D-day as legal tender.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The official list of the Soviet, British and American representatives who are taking part in the conversations at Dumbarton Oaks:
LONDON, Aug. 21 (U.P.) -- German forces have begun the evacuation of Warsaw's largest airport today, reports from the Polish capital asserted today.

MANTES, France, Aug. 20 (Delayed) -- At 3 o'clock this morning American patrols crossed the Seine River at this city, thirty-five miles northwest of Paris, and have been followed throughout the day by long lines of armor and infantry.

For the first part of the election campaign, Democrats will devote their main efforts toward qualifying as many voters as possible, Robert E. Hannegan, Democratic national chairman, announced yesterday at a press conference in his headquarters at the Hotel Biltmore.

The State of California Toll Bridge Authority will offer for sale tomorrow various issues of San Francisco-Oakland Bay Toll Bridge 4 per cent revenue bonds, aggregating $3,260,000. The bonds are dated March 1, 1938, and their maturities range from March 1, 1950, to Sept. 1, 1976.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 21 -- Sharon McManus, a 7-year-old actress from Norfolk, Neb., who has appeared in two short subjects for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, is to be featured by that company in "Tenth Avenue Angel," a story by Angna Enters, who provided the idea for "The Lost Angel."

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 21 -- The Southampton invitation tournament, one of the oldest turf court tennis fixtures, will start tomorrow at the Meadow Club under a novel arrangement reminiscent of the challenge round feature of the national championship over thirty years back.

GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Tuesday, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Pitching aerial assault upon the Moluccas and near-by islands to a new intensity, Allied planes delivered the heaviest bombing attacks yet made upon Halmahera and Buru Islands, headquarters announced today.

WITH AMERICAN TROOPS IN BRITTANY, Aug. 7 (Delayed) (AP) -- French mademoiselles armed with enemy Luger pistols and carrying potato masher grenades in their belts have joined resistance leaders in Brittany's greatest outdoor sport -- the capture of Germans.

According to present indications the Birmingham Electric Company, a unit in the Electric Bond and Share Company system, will issue invitations before the end of this month for bids on its proposed issue of $10,000,000 of new first mortgage bonds maturing in thirty years.

Five hundred and thirty-nine dozen unfinished pairs of nylon stockings were seized here yesterday by deputies of United States Marshal James E. Mulcahy, acting on a search warrant obtained by United States Attorney James B. M. McNally.

Two new films will open in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Astor, the new attraction will be "Kismet," Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's screen version of the Edward Knoblock play. Set in the legendary Bagdad of 1,000 years ago, the extravaganza, which was filmed in Technicolor, stars Ronald Colman and Marlene Dietrich.

GREAT LAKES, Ill., Aug. 21 (AP) -- Lieut. (j.g.) Paul E. Brown, former football coach at Ohio State, today assumed head gridiron coaching duties at Great Lakes Naval Training Center, relieving Lieut. Commdr. Paul D. (Tony) Hinkle, the bluejackets' athletic officer.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Miss Shirley Fry of Akron, Ohio, favorite in the girls' national junior tennis championships, defeated Miss Mary Cunningham of El Paso, Texas, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 4, in the second round as play started on the Philadelphia Cricket Club's grass courts today.
GUAM, Aug. 12 (Delayed) -- American bulldozers, cutting what might be called roads on Guam, have just about upset the sense of direction of some natives.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Henceforth the press will be excluded from the peace conversations at Dumbarton Oaks, but at the opening sessions today they had their innings and photographers especially took over the proceedings.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Following are the prepared texts of the addresses by Secretary Hull, Sir Alexander Cardogan, leader of the British delegation, and Andrei A. Gromyko, Russian Ambassador, at the opening of the International Security Conference:
Yesterday's German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:
CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- Ernie Lombardi was knocking down fences and Cholly Grimm's ball players at a brisk pace on Wrigley Field today as the Giants' winning streak went "soaring" to two games.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Tom Treanor arrived in England shortly before D-day and reported the invasion of France.

SHERIDAN, Wyo., Aug. 21 (AP) -- Corp. John J. McIntyre, Wyoming's soldier-attorney, argued in the Federal Court today that the Jackson Hole National Monument was created because John D. Rockefeller Jr. threatened to withdraw a gift of land to the National Park Service unless the Grand Teton National Park was enlarged.

GUAM, Aug. 14 (Delayed) -- Japanese residents of Guam, some of whom were well known in the American naval community, were quick to accept the Japanese invaders in December, 1941, reliable Chamorros said.

In the absence of important developments in Washington in connection with proposals to raise Government cotton loans to a point where producers would receive parity, traders on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday assumed a waiting position.

Toulouse has fallen to the French underground forces. If the country about it is windy in winter and dusty in summer, as the hotelkeepers in other places tell you, none the less it is one of the most charming cities in France. It is or seems prevailingly red. Its houses are built of red brick.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- Isolationism loomed tonight as a lively subject for the delegates to the annual encampment of Veterans of Foreign Wars as representatives from 3,800 posts in the United States and Hawaii packed hotels on the eve of the first session tomorrow.
GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Tuesday, Aug. 22 (AP) -- A communique:

The Book-of-the-Month Club has made another dual selection for November. The books chosen are "The American Character," by D.W. Brogan, a Knopf publication, and Herbert Best's novel, "Young 'Un," on Macmillan's list. The October book of the month will be Van Wyck Brook's "The World of Washington Irving."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UP) -- Twentieth Air Force communique 10:
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- An explanation of the secrecy maintained about details of the discussions at the conference at Dumbarton Oaks was given to newspapers today by the press officer of the American delegation, who requested that his name not be used.
American armored spearheads reached across the Seine yesterday and the Russians crossed the Bug River northeast of Warsaw.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Mayor La Guardia of New York declared today that "a junk dealer philosophy" underlay present methods of disposing of Government surpluses, and urged the Mead Committee to recommit all pending legislation on the matter and to revise it to meet future harsh realities.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 -- Immediate acceleration of the reconversion program wherever it can be accomplished without interfering with the even flow of vital war production was asked today by the executive council of the American Federation of Labor, which is holding its midsummer meeting here.

Production of civilian goods under the War Production Board's spot authorization order is awaiting implementation principally from the awaited "go-ahead" orders of the War Manpower Commission, Dr. William Y. Elliott, vice chairman of the Office of Civilian Requirements, WPB, said yesterday in an interview following an address before the Commerce and Industry Association at its headquarters in the Woolworth Building.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- A Pacific Fleet announcement:

PAWTUCKET, R.I, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Coming from far back, Max Marmorstein's favored Chaldon Heath won the Newton Purse by two and one-half lengths today at Narragansett Park. Held off the pace until the three-eights pole, he ran the mile and a sixteenth in 1:46 3-5.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- In an atmosphere devoid of partisanship, Democratic and Republican Senators who are concerned with this country's foreign relations joined today in discussing the Dumbarton Oaks Conference as leading to an ultimate happy outcome for world peace.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The Army was severely criticized by the Senate War Investigating Committee today for having acquired the Breakers Hotel at Palm Beach as a hospital and for now giving it up. In a report to the Senate the committee said the acquisition was "high-handed and arbitrary" and the recent decision of the Army to abandon the property was not "justified by the facts."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- His Excellency, the Most Rev. Amleto Giovanni Cicognani, Apostolic Delegate to the United States, today issued the following statement concerning the death of His Eminence, Luigi Cardinal Maglione:

Every year the hunting season brings its tale of death and injury in the field because of careless or inexpert handling of firearms. The shooting is not far away and so the question arises, "Should hunters undergo examinations on their knowledge of gun handling before getting their licenses, just as automobilists must pass driving tests?"

Formation within the Second Service Command of a "Citizens Committee for Universal Military Training of Young Men" was announced yesterday with the release of a letter from Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson commending the purposes of the undertaking.

The presence of millions of pounds of refurbished clothing, baled and ready for shipment, in New York warehouses when there is a world-wide shortage of clothing and textiles and when the day of liberation of the occupied countries is at hand, is drawing attention to the diversified problems of overseas relief.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The successful strategy of the Allies in France is about to put Gen. Charles de Gaulle to the most exacting test that can well be conceived. On the day he enters Paris he will have, within a few hours, to reach decisions that are bound to seal the fate of his "Provisional Government."

At the outbreak of war there was no practical method of shipping whole blood to the battlefront. This week the American Red Cross sent the first 500-pint lot of whole blood by air to Europe and thus demonstrated that biological research has taken another forward step.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Wednesday, Aug. 23 -- An armored column of the American Third Army has struck beyond the boundaries of the present battle through the heart of France to the approaches to Germany.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- An American Federation of Labor publication declared today that the CIO was trying to "buy" the November election because the CIO president, Philip Murray, and Sidney Hillman "and their CIO followers are afraid their organization will fall apart and be wrecked when the post-war pinch comes."

Today has fittingly been chosen for two historic ceremonies. One will be the signing of an agreement between the British Government and the Provisional Government of France. This will take place in London, with British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden and French Foreign Commissioner Rene Massigli affixing their signatures.

In the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries Grobianus, an imaginary person, became the type in German literature of the boor, the clown, the slattern. Grobian, Grobianism were familiar terms. If they have become obsolete, the ill-breeding they express survives among the Nazis. An English newspaper man found in a German headquarters in Normandy a Table Order for an Officers' mess.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Gerald Driscoll, 19-year-old Annapolis appointee from San Diego, Calif., continued his sizzling pace in the twenty-second international Star Class yacht championships today with his second straight triumph in the five-race series.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The chaff was separated from the wheat as twenty-six of 384 amateurs and twenty-five of forty-nine women qualified for 72-hole medal play in the Tam o'Shanter All-American golf tournament, for which preliminary rounds were completed today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 -- "Although some legislation has been adopted to help disabled war veterans the present program for rehabilitation is wholly inadequate and insufficient," William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, told delegates to the National Encampment of the Veterans of Foreign Wars of the United States today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Shipments of petroleum to the East Coast by pipeline reached a record high mark in the week ended Aug. 5 when deliveries averaged 715.222 barrels a day, the Petroleum Administration for War reported today.

ROME, Aug. 22 (U.P.) -- Prime Minister Churchill, after visits to the Mediterranean fighting fronts, has arrived in Rome for conferences with the Pope and Italian leaders, and the talks are expected to deal with peace settlements.

An animal that had been described earlier as a "large and ferocious bulldog" and "about the size of a medium-sized police dog" made an appearance yesterday before Judge Shackelford Miller Jr. in Federal Court. Its visit was occasioned by argument over whether Treasury Department agents, following the scent of fermenting mash, had obtained entry illegally to a house at 53 Crosby Place, New Rochelle, N.Y.

Plans to add five stories to the eight-story building at 89-97 Maiden Lane, corner of Gold Street, were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings by York Sawyer, architects for the owners, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which occupies the structure for offices.
ROME, Aug. 22 (UP) -- A communique:

State headquarters of the new Liberal party announced yesterday the endorsement of four additional Democratic candidates for Representatives in Congress as it filed substitutions for a number of temporary candidates for local offices carried on its original independent nominating petitions.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Advance Command Post, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 22. -- Six United States labor leaders dropped in on Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower for luncheon today to get first-hand impressions of how the war is run from the top.

WHEN Avery Brundage read of the suggestions of British writers that the resumption of the Olympic Games be postponed for some twenty-five years, he practically set a new Olympic record for the running high dudgeon. Mr. Brundage hit the ceiling, but recently he was found to have calmed down considerable and willing to discuss not only the entire Olympic movement but the strong possibility of Russia becoming part of it.

Incredible as it sounds, the Yankees had a 9-0 lead over the Tigers in the fifth inning at the Stadium yesterday, but still had to hold their breaths, cross their fingers and hope that all would turn out right in the series finale before 8,221 fans. In the end it did, but not before Detroit had stranded the potential tying run. The final count was 9 -- 7.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, Aug. 23 -- Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain has been a prisoner in the hands of the SS [Elite Guard] since 8 o'clock Sunday morning following the expiration of a one-hour ultimatum to get dressed and come along without resistance or the Germans would bomb Vichy, according to reliable information received early this morning by the Swiss Telegraphic Agency in Berne.

The Second World War has increased the tempo of the agricultural revolution in the South. The two L's, legumes and limestone, are working vast changes in Dixie's traditional one-crop system of farming. The program, sponsored by the Federal Government, and backed by the State colleges, extension services, bankers and a far-sighted press, has accomplished results which portend more prosperous rural areas, with the logical concomitants of increased income, better living and improved educational opportunities.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The constitution of a proposed permanent international organization to help free the world from hunger and to improve the economic lot of farmers has been submitted to the Associated and United Nations for ratification, its authors announced tonight.

Comment on the Argentine gold situation gets more and more confused. There has been no freezing of Argentine assets in this country. Normal trade has not been interrupted. The United States continues to import Argentine products.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Johnny Niggeling hurled shut-out ball tonight as the Senators defeated the league-leading Browns, 3 -- 0, in a game enlivened by a free-for-all between the rival teams in the seventh inning.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Home runs gave the Phillies the first half of a twilight-night double-header tonight, 4 to 3, and tight pitching gave the Reds the other half, 5 to 1.

RENO, Nev., Aug. 22 (AP) -- Film Producer Samuel Goldwyn tonight capped what he termed his "long fight against monopolistic practices" in movie exhibition with the showing of the color picture "Up in Arms" in a rented dance hall near the Reno railroad tracks.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Communique 136:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The Swedish War Insurance Board announced today it no longer would underwrite Swedish ships traveling to German ports. This has the effect of eliminating all Swedish vessels from trading with Germany.

Reduced admission prices at neighborhood movie houses for children between the ages of 12 and 16 will become effective tomorrow or Friday, it was learned yesterday. The cut-rate scale, which varies in different localities and normally applies only to children up to the age of 12, was suggested by Mayor La Guardia in his radio broadcast on Sunday.

A frequent visitor in the mails these days is a letter from an American Red Cross girl or a sailor in the Merchant Marine, who wants to know whether she or he will have a chance this year, if a resident of the State of New York, to cast an overseas ballot. The answer is No, as matters stand at present.

Buyers' Total Higher Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totaled 815 against 810 last week and 934 in the like period a year ago, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals numbered 376 against 379 last Tuesday.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 22 -- Twice tonight the beleaguered Dodgers thought they had a chance to win a game at Forbes Field, but in the end the inevitable happened. The Pirates triumphed, 7 -- 5, and 19,444 ardent Bucco fans went home happy.

ROME, Aug. 22 -- "Due to your courage, resourcefulness, zeal and aggressiveness," said Maj. Gen. Alexander M. Patch, commander of the Seventh Army in southern France, in an order of the day to all officers and men of the Seventh Army, "we have achieved a great initial victory.

Wayne Wright rode a triple at Belmont Park yesterday but was without a mount in the Tonawanda Handicap, captured by Eternity, who has become a lion-hearted finisher under the training of the veteran Tom McCreery. Five started in this mile run on the Saratoga program, and Johnny Longden had the handling of the racer who was first by a length and a half.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- To inform veterans of the present war of their rights and benefit privileges, in transition from military to civilian life, approximately 2,500,000 copies of a pamphlet entitled "Your Rights and Your Benefits, a Handy Guide for Veterans of the Armed Forces and Their Dependents" will be distributed to discharged service men.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Reflecting effect of wartime production and establishment of war industries in new areas, income payments to individuals rose sharply in most States during the past year and exceeded the 1942 level in every State, the Department of Commerce reported today in an article in its Survey of Current Business.

I read with much pleasure and interest the editorial "Milking" in your issue of Aug. 14. I recognize this as having been written by that same fine writer who has contributed several other enjoyable editorials on farming.

Normal in every respect except that he was not breathing, a seven-pound son was born to Mrs. Audrey Apman, 26 years old, of 1135 Eightieth Street, Brooklyn, at 2 A.M. yesterday in Norwegian Hospital there. The attending physician, Dr. John A. Davis, noted normal heart beats but no respiration.

As blue-eyed triplet daughters played yesterday in fresh pink sunsuits, Mrs. Muriel Bachant, informed on Monday that her husband had been missing in France since Aug. 1, sat quietly in her Bronx apartment and hoped that he would be reported a prisoner of war "because I just couldn't believe anything else."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- After six days of debate and preliminary tests, the House passed by a voice vote today its bill for disposal of an estimated $75,000,000,000 of surplus war property through an administrator vested with sweeping powers to act and delegate authorities.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast in English to North America from Chungking and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

The War Food Administration is releasing 3,000 tons of olive oil to the civilian trade, it was learned last night. No ration points will be needed for the oil, which has become something of a collector's item since the war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The aspect of the American plan for a new peace-keeping league which is most likely to divide the country into opposing groups is not what Gov. Thomas E. Dewey made the basis of his recent "warning": the eventual role the small nations will play.
LONDON, Aug. 22 -- Business in today's stock markets was small and the general tone was dull. Prices eased owing to some selling and a decline in the demand.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The Red Cross made a tally of prisoner-of-war totals today on the eightieth anniversary of the founding of the International Committee of the Red Cross.

Salt-crusted, rust-streaked, the crews bleached out by weeks at sea without sun, the Pacific submarines return at regular intervals to their docks or to their mother ships to report increasingly large bags of Japanese merchant vessels and combat ships. The latest score reported by the men of the silent service, nineteen vessels, is the largest to date.

Sears, Roebuck Co., in its report of operations covering the twenty-four weeks ended on July 16, disclosed yesterday a net profit of $12,159,373 after all charges including provision of $25,041,000 for Federal income and excess profits taxes.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 22 (AP) -- A Supreme Headquarters statement on the withdrawal said today:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- John Foster Dulles, adviser to Governor Dewey on foreign affairs, arrived in Washington today by automobile to confer with Secretary Hull on "implementing bipartisan cooperation to obtain a lasting peace"
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
CHICAGO, Aug. 22 -- Selling of wheat futures by houses with Northwestern connections, attributed to hedging business, gave the market for that grain an easy undertone today on the Board of Trade.

A compulsory labor service law for all unmarried able-bodied girls and women from 12 to 40 years of age, with the exception of those whose families are dependent on them, went into effect yesterday in Japan, the Japanese Domei agency said.
LONDON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Allied air leaders are working on an unprecedented problem in handling beaten Germany, the installation of an occupation air force.

A new field for the advertising man and the profession as a whole can be opened up in the post-war period if management can be persuaded that a satisfied employee is just as vital to successful business operations as a satisfied customer, according to E.W. Falcon, manager of the advertising department of the Warner Swasey Company, machine tool builders, Cleveland, Ohio.

For three hours and forty-five minutes yesterday Mrs. Samuel Guttner tried to prevent her Negro maid, Hattie Beverly, 35 years old, from leaping from an inner courtyard window of the Guttners' tenth-floor apartment in the Eldorado Towers, 300 Central Park West, at Ninetieth Street.
Deaths in the city last week from all causes, many traceable to the effects of the heat, rose sharply, the Health Department reported yesterday.

BOSTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Cleveland defeated the Red Sex, 5 to 3, today and the score might have been much higher except that the Indians left thirteen on bases. Emmett O'Neil, Boston hurler, walked seven men, threw two wild pitches and yielded ten hits in six and one-third innings.
Col. Alfred McCormack, USA, and Mrs. McCormack will come to Hampshire House today from Washington, D.C.

PEARL HARBOR, Aug. 22 (U.P.) -- Army, Navy and Marine aircraft attacked scattered enemy positions in the Pacific on Sunday, striking shipping at Marcus Island, four hours flying time from Tokyo, and bombing Yap Island in the Carolines, Pacific Fleet headquarters announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- A constitution for an international organization to increase the efficiency of agricultural production throughout the world and to raise the standards of living of all peoples has been prepared by an interim commission composed of representatives of the Associated and United Nations, who have studied the problem for a year.
LONDON, Aug. 22 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

From all indications things are moving along satisfactorily for Blevins Davis and his forthcoming operetta, "Rhapsody," containing tunes by Fritz Kreisler. Arnold Sundgaard and Harry Wagstaff Gribble have joined forces to do the book, the direction of which has been entrusted to Mr. Gribble.

A Buenos Aires newspaper, Cabildo -- which is on the blacklist of the United States Government -- charges that THE NEW YORK TIMES "has shown itself repeatedly and for a long time an enemy of Argentina." We had hoped that what was actually said in these columns was being read in Argentina, even by blacklisted newspapers, more carefully than the quotation suggests.

Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican national chairman, reported yesterday at a press conference in Republican national headquarters at the Hotel Roosevelt that members of labor unions were becoming increasingly resentful of attempts to compel them to vote for the re-election of President Roosevelt.

Many people were saying that Donald M. Nelson's contemplated visit to China would seriously affect our re-conversion plans at home. Other people were wondering how the China trip would affect the personal fortunes of Donald M. Nelson.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 22 -- Fifty thousand workers paraded today, commemorating the second anniversary of Brazil's entry into the war against the Axis. Offices and banks closed for half a day.

ALBANY, Aug. 22 -- Governor Dewey's first campaign trip, starting with a speech in Philadelphia on Sept. 7, will be a protracted one, it was indicated here today, and probably will be the trip during which he will make a visit, hitherto scheduled indefinitely, to the Pacific Coast States and the Southwest.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Maj. Gen. Lucius D. Clay, Army Service Forces director, was revealed tonight to have told the Senate War Investigating Committee that July production of some vital war items dropped as much as 53 per cent below June output and that further lags aggregating millions of dollars were expected in August.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 22 -- Columbia has named Irene Dunne for the Ruth Gordon role in the forthcoming film version of "Over Twenty-one." Previously the studio had earmarked the part for Rosalind Russell, now committed to do "Elizabeth Kenny" for RKO-Radio before returning to Columbia. "

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The special subcommittee of the Senate on post-war aviation asked President Roosevelt today to hold up any contemplated action by the Executive branch on applications by American companies for foreign air routes, "until full consideration of Government policy can be had by Congress."
ROME, Aug. 22 (U.P.) -- American and French troops brought the enemy's escape corridor west of Marseille under artillery fire today.

Anyone who heeds the President's request to form an opinion concerning post-war military training may consult his remarks and those of the Secretary of War and the Secretary of the Navy. THE TIMES gave editorial endorsement to Secretary Stimson's appeal for continuance of conscription, but said that President Roosevelt "did not succeed in making his precise position clear."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 22 (AP) -- Declared legally dead by the Probate Court here in 1942, Henry Fenney, 50 years old, of 32-12 Thirty-first Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, returned to this city today for a reunion with his brothers and sisters, whom he had not seen since 1925, and to straighten out his estate.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Japanese troops have launched an attempted enveloping movement against Chinese in the area of the enemy-held Canton-Hankow railway junction of Hengyang and were engaged by the defenders eighteen and twenty-five miles northwest of the city, the High Command announced tonight.

KANDY, Ceylon, Aug. 22 (U.P.) -- British troops, driving southward along Tiddim Road, have advanced five miles inside Burma on the wheels of retreating Japanese who in recent days have avoided contact with Allied forces in this area.

LONDON, Wednesday, Aug. 23 -- Two Soviet armies, launching offensives in Rumania and Bessarabia, have captured the fortress city of Jassy and have plunged to within seventy-three miles of Galati, gateway city to Bucharest and the Ploesti oil fields, Moscow revealed last night.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 22 -- Arriving here from Boston, where he won the national veterans' tennis chamipionship, J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange, N.J., started out in quest of the Southampton Bowl at the Meadow Club today with a 7-5, 6-4 victory over Maj. Alexander H. (Zan) Carver of the Army Air Forces as the fifty-fifth annual tournament got under way.

LONDON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The FFI and the Germans were reported by the Algiers radio today to be locked in "fierce fighting" inside the Maginot Line city of Belfort, to which Pierre Laval fled from Vichy.
ADVANCE ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, France, Aug. 22 (U.P.) -- Mr. Stringer was killed by enemy shellfire last Thursday but the details were not released until the next of kin had been notified.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Industrial psychiatry "to forestall and prevent serious mental and emotional maladjustments among industrial employes" was urged today by Dr. Lydia Giberson of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company before the House Civil Service subcommittee which is considering the Randolph bill for an industrial medical program for Federal employes.
Sing Sing Prison's gates will open Sept. 12 to free James J. Hines, once Tammany's most powerful district leader, the State Parole Board announced yesterday.

ALBANY, Aug. 22 (AP) -- An amended petition for authority to issue $30,000,000 of general mortgage sinking-fund bonds and $12,000,000 of sinking-fund debentures was submitted by the Brooklyn Union Gas Company at a hearing before the Public Service Commission today.

Variety in serving gives added interest to the now abundant green and yellow vegetables. Here are several different guises, all tested in THE NEW YORK TIMES kitchen, in which they may appear at your dinner table.

A new corporation, the Embassy Book Company, Ltd., of Toronto has been organized to handle McGraw-Hill and Whittlesey House books in Canada, James S. Thompson, president of the McGraw-Hill Book Company, has announced. The new agency will make available in Canada the entire McGraw-Hill and Whittlesey line of 2,500 titles and is designed to further the company's "global policy" in developing foreign markets.

A letter written by Sidney Hillman as chairman of the Political Action Committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations to religious leaders of all creeds, outlining the aims of the PAC, was made public here last night at headquarters of the CIO committee.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 22 -- The newspaper Nacion this morning published a brief item on its editorial page to the effect that the Argentine organization called the Comite France-Amerique had asked the Buenos Aires police for permission to hold a public manifestation in France's honor on the day Paris is freed.

Justice Thomas A. Aurelio in Supreme Court directed the Board of Elections yesterday to permit Capt. Eugene B. Sullivan of the Army to register in person for this year's elections. The board had held that he was required to apply for a war ballot and vote it since he was a member of the armed services.

RAMBOUILLET, France, Aug. 22 -- This beautiful little city, once a playground for the Kings of France and their courts, is now a center of patriot activity, although only this morning German tanks roamed the fields a few kilometers beyond and a Nazi suicide rear guard shot the helmet off an American officer's head midway between here and Versailles.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The War Department wrote today what is perhaps the final word to the current chapter of the political censorship controversy when it acknowledged that there no longer will be any legal restrictions against the distribution or exhibition of books, magazines, newspapers, movies or other forms of entertainment to soldiers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- It was learned today that two cables had been sent to Supreme Headquarters in Europe by Maj. Gen. A.D. Surles, Army director of public relations, acting for Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson, requesting full information on the reported ousting of three war correspondents and one artist by the Ninth Air Force.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Fifteen Grand American trapshooting titles go on the block tomorrow when firing begins among 900 gunners in the forty-fifth annual three-day world series of scatter-gun shooting.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 22 -- W. Randolph Montgomery of New York, counsel to the National Association of Credit Men, in an address at the closing session here of the conference of the National Association of Referees in Bankruptcy called for reforms with respect to tax claims in bankruptcy.

WITH THE AMERICAN SEVENTH ARMY, In Soutern France, Aug. 22 -- Bitter German resistance around Toulon continued all last night and this morning. This story is being written at 1:30 P.M. and the French troops are not in Toulon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The War Production Board announced tonight that all of its division directors have been asked to re-examine their stockpile and public purchase programs and to review their estimates of proper reserve stocks for each program.

BOSTON, Aug. 22 -- Sidney Hillman, chairman of the CIO Political Action Committee, said today that the special House Committee investigating campaign expenditures would be "shocked to learn how little money his organization has on hand" when he testifies next week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 16, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

Further ground was surrendered yesterday by the stock market as increased caution dried up purchasing power at current levels. Fractional losses again prevailed in a large section of the list although wider inroads peppered some of the pivotal and high-price issues, particularly the steels.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 22 -- Negotiations are still in progress between the Communists and the Chungking Government. Lin Tsohan, administrator of the Communist Border Government, has seen Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek once during his two months in Chungking and has met many times with the Generalissimo's representatives, Wang Shih-chieh and Chang Chi-chung.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The CIO United Auto Workers argued today at a War Labor Board hearing that post-war security fund for General Motors employes equal to the fund set aside by the corporation for post-war contingencies was necessary for high worker morale now.

Immediate investigation of alleged unpleasant and unsanitary living conditions in the National Youth Administration Center farm work project at Newburgh, N.Y., where 110 girl farm workers are housed, was promised yesterday by officials of the War Manpower Commission here.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 22 (AP) -- My All, racing for Mrs. Sidney S. Zell and installed a stout favorite, was an easy winner of the six-fur-long Kensington Purse, featured offering at Garden State Park today.

LONDON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Nazi flying bombs plunged into southern England today on an accelerated scale, bringing a heavy toll of casualties, while people dug into debris with ears cocked for news of the United States Third Army's headway toward the rocket coast across the Channel.

Important changes have been made by the War Production Board in the leather conservation order, M-217, which eases curbs in shoe production, the National Boot and Shoe Manufacturers Association stated yesterday. The order has been signed, it is pointed out, and will become effective on next Monday.

LONDON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- American heavy bombers flying from Italian bases smashed into Germany and Austria today, hammering a synthetic oil refinery at Oderthal, eighty miles southwest of Breslau, and other oil installations in the Vienna area.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 22 -- For the first time in the twenty- seven years that the Democratic organization of Mayor Frank Hague hag been in power in Hudson County, a grand jury today returned nine indictments naming fifty-two persons in connection with raids June 9 on horse race betting wire rooms by Attorney General Walter D. Van Riper, his staff and fifty-five State troopers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The United States, Great Britain and Soviet Russia outlined today to the delegates at the Washington Conversations on International Organization their broad proposals for the creation of an international league to prevent and repel aggression.

Continuing its record pace at the box office, "Wilson," Twentieth Century-Fox's Technicolor film about the first World War President, which starts its fourth week today at the Roxy, will gross approximately $450,000 for its first three weeks, according to an estimate by the management yesterday.

ROME, Aug. 22 -- As French forces battered their way into the surrounded fortress city of Toulon today, advance forces of the American Seventh Army raced west and north to points within three miles of Marseille and within thirty miles of Avignon, key road and rail center of the lower Rhone Valley.
The Fifth Avenue Coach Company's request for one-man operation of its 240 double-decked buses was denied yesterday by the regional War Labor Board.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 22 -- The French Forces of the Interior have liberated fourteen departments and all but one of their capitals, totaling more than 50,000 square miles in southern France, it was officially announced tonight.

ALBANY, Aug. 22 -- Governor Dewey has announced the appointment of Col. Roy P. Monahan of New York City as adviser, representing the Disabled American Veterans, Inc., to the New York State Veterans Agency.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 22 -- In a decree published today President Manuel Avila Camacho inaugurated a nation-wide campaign against illiteracy that will ultimately enable about 10,000,000 more Mexicans to read and write.

The regional Office of Price Administration yesterday affirmed the summary dismissal of Adolph J. Chesley as chairman of the Bronx County War Price and Rationing Board. Mr. Chesley was dismissed last Saturday by Daniel P. Woolley, regional OPA head, following complaints of his failure to cooperate in the price-control program.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 20 (Delayed) -- Although Bulgarian Premier Ivan Bagrianoff's reference to the Jewish question in his address to Parliament was vague, there is good reason to hope that the Government will soon abrogate the anti-Jewish laws in Bulgaria.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 22 (U.P.) -- Foreign Minister Parvan Draganoff of Bulgaria said tonight that Bulgaria was doing her utmost to make peace with the United States and Britain. In an address to the Bulgarian Parliament, he said Bulgaria had withdrawn her troops from Yugoslavia, advices reaching here said.

Reports from Washington that legislation may not be necessary to bring about an advance in the price of cotton to parity caused yesterday a reaction in the cotton market on the New York Cotton Exchange. Final quotations were 8 to 15 points lower than on Monday.
CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 22 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

ROME, Aug. 22 -- Florence may be said to have been liberated by the British Eighth Army and is now firmly in the Allies' hands, an official statement said today. British patrols are reported to be pushing beyond the city.

The close of the sixth week of the wastepaper salvage campaign being conducted by the 305 school playgrounds of the Board of Education raised the total of paper collected to 533 tons so far, it was announced yesterday by Dr. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 22 -- With a statement that "we shall not permit reaction to succeed" Senator Wagner told the convention of the State Federation of Labor today that the continuance in office of the Roosevelt Administration was essential to the interests of the nation.
CHICAGO, Aug. 22 -- The Giants today closed their final swing through the West with a triumph on Wrigley Field.

ROME, Aug. 22 -- Exactly how is liberated Italy being administered? Operating in this country is a system of Allied control in which we experiment in governing occupied territory. It is extremely complicated and topheavy and comprises so many agencies that it is very difficult to find out just how to fit it together, how authority channels down from the top levels to the plane where it affects the everyday life of the people.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 22 -- Oliver M. Stevens, head of the American Mission for the rehabilitation of Mexico's national railroads, has completed his task and will resume his private duties as president of the American Transit and Refrigerator Company on Sept. 1, it was announced today.

A general revision of the titles of officers and members of the administrative personnel of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company to indicate more clearly the duties and relationships of the official staff, was announced yesterday by Frederick H. Ecker, chairman oil the board, and Leroy A. Lincoln president.

LONDON, Aug. 22 (Reuter) -- William Stringer, 27-year-old Texas-born Reuter correspondent with the American First Army, was killed while covering the advance of American troops in a forward zone in France, it was officially reported today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Russ Christopher pitched his seventh straight victory and his eleventh of the year today as the Athletics defeated the White Sox, 5 -- 1. The victory gave the Mackmen three triumphs in the four-game series.

A woman was killed and five persons, including a 10-month-old baby, were injured last night by a 1 1/2-ton truck that mounted the sidewalk on First Avenue between East Seventy-third and Seventy-fourth Streets. The dead woman was Mrs. Margaret Pavlicek, 38 years old, of 334 East Seventieth Street.

Following disclosure to stock-holders of the Peter Fox Brewing Company at their annual meeting in Chicago on Monday that income from oil wells in Oklahoma owned by the company had reached $75,000 monthly and soon would attain $100,000 a month, the board of directors voted yesterday to double the dividend rate and declared a dividend of 25 cents a share on the 500,000 common shares which resulted from a four-for-one split-up in July.

HENDAYE, France, Aug. 22 -- French military authorities said that a third Allied landing in France had started tonight in the area of Bordeaux, which was reported to be under a coordinated attack by American and French columns.

WITH THE BRITISH SECOND ARMY, at Lisieux, France, Aug. 22 -- Shell-torn, bomb-wrecked Lisieux, strategically important gateway to the Seine River, fell to the British this afternoon after a night of terror for the few inhabitants who still doggedly clung to their ruined homes.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The International Harvester Company announced today formation of a foreign operations organization which will handle all its foreign activities except Canadian. G.O. Hoyt will head the organization as vice president.

May I tell you my story about peas from the tomb of Tut-ankh-amen? At the time the tomb was headline news because its contents were daily being brought forth from their centuries of concealment, the late Robert de Forest, director of the Metropolitan Museum, promptly went to Egypt.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- President Roosevelt nominated Theodore Paul Wright today to succeed Charles L. Stanton as Administrator of Aeronautics. Mr. Wright is vice president and general manager of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation, and has played a major part in directing the nation's wartime aircraft production program.

LONDON, Wednesday, Aug. 23 -- A conference between Prime Minister Churchill and President Roosevelt on French soil will take place within a matter of weeks, with Mr. Roosevelt "already packing his bags for the trip," Don Iddon, New York correspondent of The Daily Mail who recently returned here, wrote today in his weekly diary column.
GENERAL HEADQUARTERS; Southwest Pacific, Wednesday, Aug. 23 (AP) -- A communique:

LONDON, Aug. 22 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Gen. Kurt Dittmar, one of the most plain-spoken German commentators, said tonight that Allied victories in France imperiled "an essential part of the basis of our military power," according to a broadcast by DNB, German news agency.

Envisioning a period of "unparalleled prosperity" in this country after 1946, John E. Harem, economist of the Blow Company, New York, said yesterday that on the basis of four assumptions, the intervening period would see a possible drop in gross national product from $200,000,000,000 in mid-1944 to $105,000,000,000 by the end of 1946.

James J. Bambrick, former president of Local 32B of the Building Service Employes International Union, asserted yesterday in Supreme Court that he was the victim of a $10,000 shakedown at the time he headed the local and that he used union funds to pay off.

American absorption with the exploits of the United States Navy in the spectacular fighting in the Pacific may have obscured what is made abundantly clear in a current report of the British Information Services on the job the British Navy has done in helping hold control of the seven seas during almost five years of war and the punishment it has taken.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 -- There is plenty of most all varieties of spices except pepper, and a boost in the price ceiling on that spice would increase the quantity in commercial channels considerably, fifteen representatives of the spice trade here today told Fletcher H. Long, chief of the spice section of the War Food Administration, at an informal meeting.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- President Roosevelt told delegates to the Washington Conversations on International Organization today that if the United States, Soviet Russia and Great Britain could maintain their new and close friendship and spread that friendship around the world "we may have a peaceful period for our grandchildren to grow up in."

ALBANY, Aug. 23 -- Governor Thomas E. Dewey, in a formal statement issued today, hailed the freeing of Paris as "one further assurance of the inevitability of final victory," but warned that "we must not relax for one moment in our all-out war effort until Germany and Japan are so utterly defeated that the people of their countries shall vow 'never again.'"
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Following are the defendants in the Government's suit against the country's railroad executives and banking concerns:

Regardless of their feelings concerning extension of lend-lease, relief and rehabilitation programs, owners of cotton textile mills will endorse continuation of Government controls for their industry after the war if demands arising from these programs are greater than the immediate capacity to produce, Worth Street commission men indicated yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Charles E. Johnston, chairman of the Western Association of Railway Executives, said today that the issues involved in the Government's antitrust suit "strike at the keystone of the economic and political structure of this country.

De Beers Consolidated Mines, Ltd., will launch in the coming year the biggest diamond advertising, publicity and promotional program ever undertaken by that organization, it was revealed yesterday by Charles R. Hogen of N. W. Ayer Son, Inc., advertising counsel for De Beers.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Foreign Minister Oswaldo Aranha, whose resignation was accepted today by President Getulio Vargas, was quoted tonight as saying "The foreign policy of Brazil will continue the same, unalterable, come what may."

JERUSALEM, Aug. 23 -- Armed Jewish political extremists struck again last night with attacks on the Jaffa divisional police headquarters and two police stations on the Jaffa-Tel Aviv boundaries with bombs and gunfire. They wounded three constables and stole a quantity of arms.

THE unerring eye of Joseph Goebbels spotted another rift behind the scene in the United States last October and triumphantly broadcast the news to the occupied lands. "There are fresh atrocities in the United States," he stated. "The Yankees, not content with their pious interference all over the world, now are beating up their own Cardinals in St. Louis."
