GREAT LAKES, Ill., Aug. 23 -- After a pleasant sojourn in Chicago the Giants ran into rough seas at the Great Lakes Naval Training Center today and lost to Lieut. Comdr. Gordon S. (Mickey) Cochrane's bluejackets, 5 to 1, on Constitution Field.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 -- Senator Harry S. Truman predicted today that American veterans of the present World War will see to it that a conflict does not recur "in another twenty-five years" and described war veterans as the "most potent" voting group, who have it in their power to insure to this country "the greatest era in history."

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 23 -- Desperate measures are reported being taken by German garrisons in Greece to maintain troop morale in the face of the growing disasters on the eastern and western fronts and to drain off all possible supplies and forced labor for German factories.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UP) -- Wartime living conditions, including rationing, have apparently caused no increase in diseases among American school children, the Public Health Service reported tonight on the basis of observations made since 1939 on some 8,000 school children of Hagerstown, Md.

WITH THE AMERICAN SEVENTH ARMY, Aug. 23 -- A last-ditch fight for Toulon has raged during the past twenty-four hours with some French troops battling in the city but with the Germans blocking every road.

The Bucharest radio, in a late broadcast yesterday, reported by the Federal Communications Commission, said that Gen. Constantin Sanatescu had been named to head the new Rumanian Cabinet and that a new Army Chief of Staff and mayor of Bucharest had also been appointed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- In a civil suit flied at Lincoln, Neb., today major railroad interests of the United States were accused by the Federal Government of violating the Sherman Anti-Trust Act by collusive rate-fixing and discouraging improvements in service and equipment in the western part of the country.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 -- Asserting that the Roosevelt Administration's handling of the American Federation of Labor's request for increases from the Little Steel formula wage level looked like "a complete stall," William Green, AFL president, said today that the President would be asked to discard the formula.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Cutting deeper into the George bill carrying a program for industrial demobilization and post-war readjustment, the Ways and Means Committee eliminated today the proposal to extend unemployment compensation to an estimated 3,000,000 Federal workers in shipyards, arsenals and other Government establishments not covered by the Social Security Act.
LONDON, Thursday, Aug. 24 -- Rumania deserted the Axis and joined the United Nations last night.

Directors of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., authorized yesterday the declaration of two dividends on the common stock, one of 50 cents to be paid on Oct. 2 and the other of 40 cents for payment on Jan. 2, 1945.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., Aug. 23 -- Dave O'Connell of Essex Fells Country Club won his first major title today when he scored a pair of three-under-par 69's over the Homestead Golf and Country Club course to capture the New Jersey Professional Golfers Association championship with a 36-hole total of 138.

Premier General Kuniaki Koiso, appealing for a swift increase in "fighting power" and an immediate improvement in Japan's air raid defenses to cope with an "unprecedentedly grave national crisis,'' told a conference of prefectural governors in Tokyo yesterday that American bombers were certain to step up attacks on the Japanese mainland and warned them bluntly to keep in mind also that "the enemy is watching for an opportunity to land on our homeland."

LONDON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The Germans released a stream of flying explosives at southern England in a dawn barrage today, as if trying to use up their stock of buzz-bombs before launching sites are overrun by the drive of the Allied armies, but improved Channel weather and intensified anti-aircraft defenses brought a lull later in the day.
Charles D. Hummel has purchased the interest of Harry W. Bragg in the Bragg Hummel Electric Company and will continue the business under the same name at 547 Greenwich Street.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 23 -- Jack Jossi of California, Charles Oliver of Perth Amboy, N.J., Pvt. George Ball of the anti-aircraft training center, El Paso, Tex., and J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange, N.J., the four seeded players, gained their allotted brackets in the semi-final round of the Southampton invitation tennis tournament today at the Meadow Club.

Advance of the Allied armies toward the Swiss border will make possible renewal of exports of watches and movements from Switzerland. Roland Gsell, president of the American Watch Assemblers Association, said yesterday.

James G. McDonald, adviser to the Blue Network on post-war relations and former League of Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, has been named chairman of the nationality advance gifts committee of the New York War Fund's 1944 appeal, it was announced yesterday by Newbold Morris, chairman of the home front mobilization of the campaign.

Mayor Edward J. Kelly of Chicago declared yesterday that there would have been no United States if President Roosevelt had not taken the proper steps to meet the Nazi threat and credited the President with having saved Great Britain and Russia from probable defeat.

Shifts in population, return of veterans, taxation, competition and other problems of retail grocers will be studied by a post-war guidance committee of the food distributors group of the New York Credit Men's Association, C.A. Maguire, chairman of the committee and credit manager of Francis H. Leggett Co., announced yesterday.

With operations steadily expanding because of the war demand, the earnings of the petroleum industry for the current quarter should be the best for any similar period in years. Production of crude oil is recording new high levels almost weekly and refinery operations are near capacity.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- A mystery was cleared up during the period from yesterday afternoon, when Governor Dewey's representative on foreign policy, Mr. Dulles, arrived here, to this afternoon, when he called on the Secretary of State, Mr. Hull.

Having leased the Belasco for two years, Max J. Jelin is inaugurating his tenancy of the famous theatre tonight with his own production of "Lower North." A newcomer to the Roaring Forties, Mr. Jelin, heretofore content with the ownership of a New Brunswick picture house, has gone all out on the comedy-drama of Navy life based on the experiences of the author, Martin Bidwell.

A banking group headed by Kuhn, Loeb Co. won yesterday the award of $37,800,000 of first mortgage series G 2 7/8 per cent bonds of the Chicago Union Station Company. The bonds, dated July 1, 1944, and maturing on July 1, 1963, will be offered to the public at 101 1/2.
LONDON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- A joint Air and Home Security Ministries communique:

A hopeful word for cheeses and watches of the "made in America" varieties was spoken yesterday by Mayor La Guardia at the laying of the cornerstone of the Bulova School of Watchmaking, Sixty-second Street near Woodside Avenue in Woodside, Queens. The school is to open in October with tuition-free courses in watchmaking for war veterans.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The Cardinals extended their complete mastery of the Cubs to twelve straight games tonight, blasting out an 11-to-1 decision behind the nine-hit pitching of Mort Cooper.

ONE of the fundamental dogmas of the book reviewing business (at least in the "Books of the Times" office) is that there is no such thing as an uninteresting book about China. Poorly written ones, superficial ones, prejudiced ones and pedestrian ones abound. But they all, no matter what their shortcomings, contain quantities of interesting information.
Rome, Aug. 23 (UP) -- A communique:

MONTREAL, Aug. 23 (Canadian Press) -- The National Hockey League is looking for a new chief following announcement today by Mervyn (Red) Dutton that he would not be available next winter for the $15,000 job.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Secrecy became an interesting side issue today of the international peace talks at Dumharton Oaks when criticism arose not only from the press but also from political circles and even from within the conference itself.

Man-catching is an important job whether you're a college girl, a business executive or a wartime debutante with lots of things to keep you busy -- at least, so thinks Barbara Barrie of the Tailored Woman. Three years ago she opened a bridal shop for that Fifth Avenue specialty shop.

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- Early dealings in today's stock markets showed no change from yesterday's dullness, owing to further selling and lack of new buyers. Toward the close, however, some demand set in for leading industrials and several shares rallied, mainly in textile, motor and tobacco sections.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 23 -- With the Vichy regime relegated to the condition of an itinerant exiled government, its Chief of State a prisoner and the news from all fronts running swiftly against them as Rumania quit the war, the German people were left gazing today on a picture of forlorn hope.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The Federal Government has acquired, during the war, more than 34,000,000 acres of land, exclusive of tracts taken over by the Defense Plants Corporation, Senator O'Mahoney of Wyoming said today. The total value, he said, is undetermined but the Government already has paid $565,325,816 for the properties.

The text of the proclamation of King Michael of Rumania, accepting for his country the Allied armistice terms, as broadcast domestically by the Bucharest radio and reported by the Federal Communications Commission, follows:

Production of crude oil in the United States last week again climbed to a new record level at 4,675,100 bushels daily, according to the American Petroleum Institute. This represents an increase of 7,800 barrels over the output of 4,667,300 daily in the previous week.
The city is now making plans for an official celebration of "V Day" when the European phase of the war is successfully ended, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday.
NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 23 (AP) -- The Yankees defeated their Newark farmhands in an exhibition tonight, 7 to 1, before a paid attendance of 12,893 at Ruppert Stadium.

ALGIERS, Aug. 23 -- To put an end to the present inflation and restore stable currency, the Provisional Government of France will reduce the circulation of banknotes from the present 550,000,000,000 francs to about 250,000,000,000, it was said in official circles here today.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23 (AP) -- R.E. Taggart said today that while seizure of his company's mines was "regrettable" it apparently was "the only way to end the outlaw strike."

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- The people of London received the news of the liberation of Paris with mixed emotions today. They were happy that the French capital was rid of the Germans but, looking over their own bomb-scarred city, they found it hard to rejoice.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Beamed toward every corner of the world, American broadcasts are carrying the gist of proceedings at the Dumbarton Oaks Conference to countries large and small, twenty-four hours around the clock.

The Office of Price Administration announced yesterday establishment of flat retail ceiling prices for the first time on table grapes in this city, but housewives found it virtually impossible to get the fruit at any price.
LONDON, Aug. 23 -- The first Allied capital to be liberated will present to the Allies' authorities the gigantic problem of succoring the population, it is realized here.

As a result of the tight situation prevailing in the apartment-renting field here, a new and subtle form of gouging has sprung up to plague many tenants and new residents engaged in a well-nigh frantic search for living quarters in the city.

PEARL HARBOR, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The sinking of two cargo ships, with a third set afire, near Chichi Island in the Bonin Islands, by Navy search Liberators was announced today by Admiral Chester W. Nimitz.

IRUN, Spain, Aug. 23 (AP) -- American and French forces, reinforced by troops landed last night from the sea, were reported by French authorities at Hendaye to be pushing steadily toward Bordeaux from both sides tonight.

As part of the political activities of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, the Greater New York CIO Council has prepared a "finder" to locate the Assembly and Congressional district of every resident of New York City and has set up machinery to insure that every one of its eligible members qualifies as a voter by registering this year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- A report that in every case of group lay-offs caused by cut-backs thus far a considerable proportion of the women concerned "faded from the labor market" was issued today by the Office of War Information.

Two world wars should teach us that we cannot afford to relapse into complacency when peace comes again. The Axis Powers came desperately close to achieving their purpose by swift action. Two oceans will not again give us two years in which to muster our military and industrial strength.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Thursday, Aug. 24 -- The last German army south of the Seine River and west of Paris is being destroyed.

There was limited demand for both wild and ranch mink, with strong price resistance, at the sale conducted yesterday by Lampson, Fraser Huth. Wild mink sold up to $17.75, while ranch mink brought a top of $23.50. Most of the offering of 305,660 muskrats was unsold, the top being $2.64.

Plebiscite captured the $10,475 Albany Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday, as most in a crowd of 22,723 expected he would, and now more than ever it appears that George D. Widener has a first-class 2-year-old to offset some of the bad racing luck that has overtaken Platter, Lucky Draw, Stefanita and others this season.
CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 23 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:
LONDON, Aug. 23 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by the United Press:

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 23 -- The Federal Circuit Court of Appeals sustained today the conviction of a group of San Francisco Bay lumber concerns and mill operators. They were charged, along with union leaders, of violating the Sherman anti-trust law to maintain local prices for their products. Conviction of the union leaders was reversed.

ROME, Aug. 23 (U.P.) -- Polish patrols of the British Eighth Army, against steadily lessening German resistance along the Adriatic coastal sector today, held control over at least twelve miles of the southern bank of the Metauro River.

The altar before the statue of Our Lady of Victories in the St. Vincent de Paul Church, religious heart of the French colony of New York, was ablaze with lighted candles yesterday symbolizing the thanksgiving of thousands of French men and women here for the freedom of Paris, after four years of suffering and hope.

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- Following the ordered withdrawal of Clemens Dutt, Daily Worker correspondent with the French forces in the invasion of southern France, the War Office today issued a statement explaining the action.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 23 -- Marsha Hunt, whose last picture was "Bride by Mistake" at RKO, has returned to her home studio, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, to play the second feminine lead in the film version of Marcia Davenport's "Valley of Decision."

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Golfdom's giddiest whirl, with some of the confusion eliminated by three days of qualifying, will get under way over the seventy-two-hole medal play route tomorrow in the woman-amateur-professional All-American race for $42,500 over Tam o'Shanter's rolling terrain.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 -- Members of Congress and Government officials are expressing so much concern over the post-war outlook for agriculture that the grain trade is taking notice of the utterances and regards them as a bearish market influence.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 23 -- Bulgarian armistice parleys, which cannot yet be formally described as negotiations, have made further positive progress and there is concrete reason to believe that if all goes well the departure of Adolf Hitler's small Balkan satellite from the war is increasingly imminent.

Jo Davidson, the sculptor, chairman of the Independent Voters Committee of the Arts and Sciences for Roosevelt, pledged support of 600 of the nation's leading writers, actors, artists, musicians, scientists, physicians and educators to the President at a reception yesterday, marking the formal opening of the committee's headquarters in the Hotel Astor.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Miss Jean Doyle of San Diego, Calif., advanced to the semifinals and a meeting with the favorite in the junior girls' national tennis championship today with an upset victory over Miss Barbara Scofield of San Francisco, 6 -- 4, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 2.
Appointment of teachers now on high school eligible lists to junior high school posts was approved yesterday by the Board of Education at its regular meeting at 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn.

ROME, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Several hundred American heavy bombers and fighters fought through large forces of Nazi interceptors today and bombed military installations in the Vienna area of Austria for the second straight day. Medium bombers attacked rail bridges in southern France near Lyon.

ROME, Aug. 23 -- Marseille, France's second city and greatest seaport, fell to the swift onslaught of French infantry and armor today as American forces swept 140 miles inland from the Mediterranean and were within less than 240 miles of a junction with Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's legions below liberated Paris.

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- Paris is free again and, because of that, the rest of the world can breathe a little more freely. In a manner befitting a capital with the history and tradition of Paris, its own citizens rose and threw off the tyrant's yoke as soon as their own troops and the Allies' armies of liberation had given them the opportunity to challenge their conquerors on equal terms.

In the midst of the robot bombings in London, the Jewish community there has undertaken a reorganization of its fund raising body, the Central British Fund for Jewish Relief and Rehabilitation, and is planning an intensive campaign this fall for refugee relief and rehabilitation, Donald B. Hurwitz, overseas worker for the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- "Considerable progress toward bipartisan cooperation with regard to problems of the peace" was made today at a consultation between Secretary Hull and John Foster Dulles, representing Governor Dewey.
LONDON, Aug. 23 (Reuter) -- The Algiers radio announced this afternoon that Gen. Georges Catroux had ordered that every public building throughout Algeria display the flag.

Henry E. Bruckman, former chairman of the State Liquor Authority and before that chief of the city's detectives, was sworn in yesterday as chairman of the Bronx War Price and Rationing Board. He fills the vacancy caused by the dismissal last week of Adolph J. Chesley on charges of having failed to administer rationing properly and permitting favoritism.

If there was ever any doubt of the existence in France of a strongly organized, well led and fiercely patriotic underground movement, the events of the last few days have dispelled it. What has happened in Paris is happening all over France. Cities and towns and entire Departments are being liberated by this new ally which has suddenly appeared at the side of the British and American armies -- the French Forces of the Interior.
VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Capt. Joe Hiestand of Hillsboro, Ohio, and Fort Myers, Fla., today became the first man in history to win the North American clay target championship four times.

Increased liquidation developed yesterday in the cotton futures market and, after opening unchanged to 4 points up, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were on the downgrade during most of the session, closing with a partial rally but with net losses of 11 to 17 points.

Data to show how much or how little members of the New York Stock Exchange have been responsible for the recent surge of activity in low-price motor stocks are being sought by the Stock Exchange itself and the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Although the War Production Board has just relaxed limitations on colors, heel heights and design of women's shoes, these changes will not be evident to the consumer much before next spring, George Miller, president of I. Miller, Inc., declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Legislation to create a Government guarantee system for business loans, looking toward expansion of private enterprise in the post-war era, was proposed today by Chairman Marriner S. Eccles of the Federal Reserve System.
LONDON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Bulgaria's latest efforts to get out of the war before Germany collapses received a cold reception today from belligerents on both sides.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The War Food Administration today issued a statement urging communities to plan for a school-lunch program before the new terms begin in September.
GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Thursday, Aug. 24 (AP) -- A communique:

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 23 -- In a brief proclamation to the Rumanian people broadcast from Bucharest at 9:25 o'clock this evening, King Michael of Rumania ordered his armed forces to cease fire against the forces of the Allies, saying he had accepted their terms of unconditional surrender in the name of the nation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- President Roosevelt acted today to restore full anthracite production by ordering the seizure of the workings of the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company. Following this Abe Fortas, Assistant Secretary of the Interior, called upon the four thousand idle miners to return to their work by Friday morning.

GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Thursday, Aug. 24 -- Striking into the southern Philippines for the tenth time in two weeks United States Navy Liberators touched off towering fires at Davao and sank a small Japanese freighter northeast of Mindanao, headquarters reported today.

Charging that certain interests in industry are seeking the replacement of Donald Nelson as head of the War Production Board, members of the American Business Congress sent a telegram to President Roosevelt yesterday protesting against such a move.

The speed with which they are retaking France must be almost bewildering even to the Allied armies and French patriots who are actually doing it. Just as, in the black days of 1940, it was many months before our minds could credit and take in the full implications of a France under Nazi control, so it is difficult now to follow the speed and take in the full meaning of French liberation.

ITHACA, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- Summarizing what he described as the desperate need for thousands of city and village people to help harvest and process the State's farm crops, which in some cases will reach record-breaking size, Dr. W.I. Myers, dean of the College of Agriculture at Cornell University, said today that success or failure on the home food-front depended on the response of voluntary workers the next few weeks.

Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican National Chairman, announced yesterday the appointment of Godfrey Hammond of Scarsdale, N.Y., as director of publicity for the Republican National Committee. Mr. Hammond, president of the Popular Science Publishing Company, which publishes Outdoor Life and Popular Science Monthly, is on leave of absence for the duration of the campaign.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 23 -- With a passenger list of German war prisoners and German civilians and mail and Red Cross Christmas packages for American war prisoners in Germany, the Swedish liner Gripsholm sailed from here at 3:50 o'clock this afternoon for Goeteborg, Sweden, for another exchange of Germans for Americans.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast in English to North America from Chungking and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 23 -- Lester F. and Robert F. Kennedy, champions of the home club, captured the twenty-first annual father and son championship of the Long Island Golf Association with a 98 -- 24 -- 74 at the Garden City Country Club today.
PARIS, Aug. 23 -- The French Second Armored Division entered Paris today after the Parisians had risen as one man to beat down the German troops who had garrisoned the city.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Senator Brewster of Maine, new vice-chairman of the Republican Senatorial Campaign Committee, said "a favorable report" on Republican prospects was given today to Herbert Brownell Jr., national chairman.

Leading designers of women's clothing who have been independent of Paris leadership for the last four years were overjoyed yesterday by the liberation of the great French city. While expressing fervent hope that it soon would be back to normal, they doubted that it would dominate the fashion world as completely as in the past.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 23 -- Commenting on Rumania's capitulation, former King Carol today expressed his happiness over the fact that "my son listened to the real sentiments of the people and pulled Rumania out of the war."

Cooler weather and the return of summer vacationists were credited with an increase of nineteen tons yesterday over the previous week in the weekly waste paper salvage total of Department of Sanitation trucks, which collected 299 tons in the five boroughs, compared with 280 tons on the preceding Wednesday.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 23 -- Against the vigorous opposition of supporters of Governor Dewey, the convention of the New York State Federation of Labor, representing 1,500,000 AFL members, adopted today a resolution endorsing the re-election of President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad Company asked authority today of the Interstate Commerce Commission to issue $40,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage bonds, series of 1974, the proceeds to be applied to redemption of $40,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage 5 per cent bonds.

There is no reason to anticipate any great increase in crime in this city when the war ends, if demobilization of the armed forces and industrial reconversion are carried out in a "sound and scientific manner," Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine said yesterday.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Communique 137:

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS Allied Expeditionary Force, Normandy, Aug. 23 -- The first American Red Cross girl to be decorated in the European Theatre of Operations Clubmobile Group is Captain Elizabeth Schuller of Upper Montclair, N.J.

ROME, Aug. 23 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill has not confined his activities in Italy to visits to the military fronts. In addition to his conversation last week with Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia, he has seen a number of important political personages.

Squash, a plentiful vegetable at this time of year, is also one of the most variable ones, for it comes in giant and dwarf sizes, in crookneck and straight neck forms, and in green, yellow and white. A favorite food of the Indians, from whom it derived its name, it is less in demand today despite its savoriness.

The Church of the Strangers has been evicted from its place of worship at 309 West Fifty-seventh Street in a mortgage foreclosure action in which treasured belongings such as the holy communion service were piled on the sidewalk in front of the edifice and pulpit furniture and pews were taken by the authorities, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Overseas veterans of the Army Ground and Service Forces will begin moving tomorrow into resort hotels at Miami Beach, Fla., and Santa Barbara, Calif., which have been designated as the first of five AGF-ASF redistribution stations where men returning for duty within the United States will be reclassified and reassigned.
LONDON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- General Koenig, military Governor of Paris, is expected to go to the capital tomorrow with his entire London staff and may join General de Gaulle there.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- President Roosevelt sent to Congress today a quarterly report on lend-lease operations and asked that such aid should continue until the unconditional surrender of both Germany and Japan.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Assertions that there was a countrywide trend toward the Dewey-Bricker ticket in the coming Presidential election were made today by Herbert Brownell Jr. chairman of the Republican National Committee, who said he based his opinion on a check of polls of public opinion and reports from party leaders throughout the country.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 23 -- The freeing of Paris, although expected almost hourly for the past two days, caused a wave of the deepest emotion to spread over Argentina, whose people have always been very responsive to French cultural influences.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- In the first directive he has issued since assuming direction of the Office of Contract Settlement, set up under the Contract Settlement Act of July 1, Robert H. Hinckley established uniform procedures for Federal Reserve Bank guarantee of termination loans (T-loans) made by commercial banks to contractors whose war contracts are canceled.

John J. O'Connor, president of the Greater New York Federation of Sportsmen's Clubs, is now a resident of the Bronx, but he comes from Boston and retains a Bostonian's interest in Cape Cod fishing. Consequently, he made it his business to find out what the regulations were governing fishing in the canal.

"To make the love of music a little more intelligent" is John Erskine's aim in a forthcoming book called "What Is Music?" in which he discusses the history, structure and functions of the various instruments that make up the modern orchestra, as well as musical careers today.

LONDON, Thursday, Aug. 24 -- The two-fisted Soviet offensive that knocked Rumania out of the war roared through its fourth day yesterday, capturing Vaslui, 140 miles northeast of the Ploesti oil center, and toppling the two big Bessarabian bastions of Bendery and Akkerman on the west bank of the Dniester, besides more than 400 other towns.
A high level of public taste was evident at the "college caucus fashion show" at Abraham Straus yesterday noon, in voting on the forty-four models offered Three winners were selected.

Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., had in the nine months ended with June a consolidated net profit of $2,854,356, or $1.24 a share of common stock, after Federal income and excess profits taxes of $15,793,100 and $4,760,000 reserves, Ward M. Canaday, chairman of the board, reports in a statement to be released today.

Women today are wearing richer, deeper shades of face powder than they did four years ago, according to figures on quantities of certain basic colors used for powder blending reported by the largest manufacturer of custom-blended face powder.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The White House released the following as the text of "Informal remarks" of President Roosevelt on receiving the delegates to the Dumbarton Oaks Conference:

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- Thrown out of control in a violent thunderstorm, a B-24 Liberator bomber of the United States Eighth Air Force crashed into a school at Freckleton, Lancashire, England, at 11 o'clock this morning, killing at least seventy-six persons, including fifty-one children, all of whom were under 5 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Nelson A. Rockefeller, Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs, said today that his agency's functions would eventually be transferred to permanent Government agencies to continue the Good-Neighbor policy.

The surge of battle across France has devastated most of the cities and towns in Normandy -- an area roughly comparable in size to the State of Maryland -- and has caused heavy destruction to St. Malo and many of the port cities of the Brittany peninsula.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Approximately half a million small business enterprises failed to survive under the stress of wartime conditions between Pearl Harbor and the end of 1943, but this total does not even closely approach estimates which were made at the beginning of hostilities, Senator James M. Mead of New York reported today in behalf of Senate Committee on Small Business.

GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Aug. 23 -- This is the story of the collective conscience of a group of American bomber pilots, whose gifts will help to build, when peace comes, a fine new cathedral in the Australian mandate of New Guinea.

Because Arthur Roennfeldt, 36 years old, of 113 West Seventy-fifth Street, looks like the late Leslie Howard, stage and screen star, he was arrested last night and charged with burglary. He is accused of robbing three apartments at 41 West Seventy-third Street of $2,000 worth of jewelry, cameras and clothing.

The French in New York City celebrated the liberation of Paris yesterday with impressive restraint. They sang "La Marseillaise" while ticker tape and handmade confetti danced above them in the sun, but hearts were still weighed down by worry over kin from whom they have not heard for years.

"Kismet," the Metro extravaganza starring Ronald Colman, got off to an auspicious start at the Astor by setting an opening-day attendance record for the house on Tuesday. The film played to 8,988 admissions, bettering by 1,056 the previous opening-day mark set by "See Here, Private Hargrove."

Realists at Work It is now almost a week and still we cannot rid ourselves of the haunting thought. Indeed, every day that passes only drives home the profound conviction that if the Dumbarton Oaks conference is to be a success one preliminary safeguard must be set up.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The Pottsville (Pa.) Gas Company is to be dissolved under a plan filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by Pottsville and its parent, the Consolidated Electric and Gas Company.

"Kismet," the Metro extravaganza starring Ronald Colman, got off to an auspicious start at the Astor by setting an opening-day attendance record for the house on Tuesday. The film played to 8,988 admissions, bettering by 1,056 the previous opening-day mark set by "See Here, Private Hargrove."

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- Carrier-based Barracuda planes of the British Fleet Air Arm today delivered the third smashing attack on the German battleship Tirpitz, the Daily Telegraph's Stockholm correspondent reported.

Fall pattern books came to life yesterday in a fashion show of costumes made from patterns and fabrics offered at John Wanamaker's. Each of the models carried a price tag indicating the cost of the costume when sewed at home. Many were around $15, including the cost of the pattern and the yard goods.

In its first change of ownership since 1904 the property at 677 Fifth Avenue, near Fifty-third Street, has been sold by the estate of Cornelius Vanderbilt to Frederick Brown through Clark T. Chambers and Gilliam McVay.

Interest received on bonds issued by the Port of New York Authority and the Triborough Bridge Authority is exempt from Federal income tax, according to two split decisions handed down yesterday by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals.

The California Toll Bridge Authority awarded yesterday to the Chemical Bank and Trust Company and the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association $3,260,000 of 4 per cent revenue bonds of the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Toll Bridge.

The New Jersey Fish and Game Commission made two announcements yesterday, the one of most immediate interest being that a week from today the trout season will reopen and a three-month season on rail birds will begin. The new seasons were described as preludes to the wildfowl, upland game and deer seasons to follow later in the fall.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- A flying suit containing "built-in tourniquets" has been designed by two Navy doctors as a possible aid in the control of bleeding among wounded pilots during combat.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (U.P.) -- Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson urged Americans today to muster all their strength and unity for the knockout punch against a Germany that is tottering on all fronts.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 24 -- Warner Brothers have named Eleanor Parker and Robert Hutton for the co-starring lead in the forthcoming "Rendezvous," a film to be based on the career of Maj. Gus Deymond, a former member of the Eagle Squadron of the RAF.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 -- Liquidation developed early today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade on the favorable European war news, May and July wheat and July oats selling at new low prices for the season, but the market rallied sharply on an announcement that the Senate had approved an amendment sponsored by Senator John H Bankhead to the reconversion bill that would increase the Government loan on cotton.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 24 -- A post-war program, the major part of which will be development of a series of completely decorated rooms available for duplication by its 200 registered dealers throughout the country, was announced yesterday by the Grand Rapids Furniture Makers Guild here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Aug. 19 were 887,446 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 8,726 cars or 1.0 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 3,894 cars or 0.4 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 18,012 cars or 2.1 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Sensationally favorable war news from Europe on the one hand and developments in Washington on the other resulted yesterday in wide fluctuations in the futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange. Early in the session the market was down 11 to 14 points under commission-house liquidation based on the belief that peace was coming and that commodities would decline.

GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Aug. 24 -- Throughout the Pacific area there is jubilation over the announcement of the freeing of Paris and the defection of Rumania from the Axis. With German resistance apparently crumbling fast under Allied military pounding, there is a general feeling that it will be possible to bring the full United Nations' power to bear against Japan far sooner than had been expected.

LONDON, Aug. 24 -- The whole German front in the Balkans appeared to be crumbling tonight. Signs multiplied that Bulgaria was about to follow Rumania out of the war.
