The theft of 827 tons of coal entrusted to him for delivery to Halloran General Hospital and Fort Wadsworth was charged yesterday to George Fahy, 43-year-old former president of Fahy Brothers. Coal Company, Inc., of Rosebank, S.I This charge was contained in an indictment handed up to Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo in Federal Court, Brooklyn.

D.W. Sanford has been appointed resident vice president of Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company of California in Los Angeles. E.L. Mefford has been appointed western division sales manager, the position formerly held by Mr. Sanford.

A property in the heart of the downtown jewelry district passed to new hands yesterday when the Mutual Life Insurance Company sold the fifteen-story Jewelers Building at 9-11 Maiden Lane to the Omnibus Realty Corporation. The Mutual Life acquired the building from the Maternity Hospital, to which it had been presented by the late J.P. Morgan, who is said to have paid $1,000,000 for the property, subject to a mortgage of $600,000.

Reporting on operations of the Creole Petroleum Corporation, C.H. Lieb, president, informs stockholders in a statement to be released today that production of petroleum in Venezuela, stimulated by war demands, is running 86 per cent ahead of the volume of a year ago.

WITH CHINESE FORCES, on the Salween Front, Aug. 22 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Maj. Gen. Howard C. Davidson's India-based Tenth United States Air Force today joined the assault on the Japanese in southwest China for the first time, strafing and bombing enemy remnants trapped within the battered walls of the ancient citadel of Tengyueh twenty-five miles west of the Salween River.
LONDON, Aug. 24 -- The capitulation of Rumania and the latest war news from France had a stimulating effect on today's stock markets here, principally in the foreign and industrial sections.

Vito W. Rizzi, 34 years old, a discharged war veteran, of 1073 First Avenue, was indicted yesterday in the murder on Jan. 31, 1941, of Michael J. Flanagan, an elderly recluse grocer, in his apartment at 657 Second Avenue. He will be arraigned in General Sessions today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Lieut. Col. Francis Gabreski, missing since he flew out on volunteer extra duty July 20 to protect his standing as a leading air ace, is a prisoner of war.

Mrs. Belle L.W. Willard, widow of Joseph E. Willard, diplomat and owner of the Willard Hotel in Washington, D.C., has leased the sixteen-room terrace apartment in 120 East End Avenue which was built for and occupied by Lawrence Tibbett, opera singer.

TWO of the senior officers stationed at a great RAF Wellington bomber base a few miles from Oxford were discussing some of the more delicate problems that sometimes arose to plague their personnel. "The great adventure on this station isn't bombing Germany," said one of them bitterly. "They don't think anything of that. Falling in love is the big business here."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- An Anglo-American oil agreement, signed for the declared purpose of assuring fair utilization of the world's petroleum resources, was submitted to the Senate by President Roosevelt today in the form of a treaty requiring ratification.

A 17-year-old Glendale, Calif., schoolgirl has been named winner of a $250 war bond in a "design and name it" contest to discover the styles that 'teen-agers want. The winner, Marian Sweet, submitted a sketch for a dress with a swinging skirt and high round neck, trimmed with hands of felt applique. The name "Cokeette" has been givn to the prize design, as suggested by Dolores Vaccaro, Pittsburgh, winning for her a $25 bond.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 -- Enactment of a law providing for universal peacetime compulsory military training with a minimum of one year's service was demanded of Congress today by the Veterans of Foreign Wars of the United States, holding its forty-fifth annual encampment here.

For the 982 European refugees now settled in their temporary home at Fort Ontario, Oswego, N.Y., America has offered a series of surprises. Miss Anna Kaufman and Mrs. Esther Beckwith Kaunitz of the National Council of Jewish Women who have just returned from the eighty-four-acre shelter, told yesterday of the people's joy at sleeping on mattresses instead of boards, and their wonder at the abundance of food.
NEAR PARIS, Aug. 24 -- The Battle of Paris began this morning.

General de Gaulle was reported leading his own troops last night into a city in which Germans were still fighting. Nazi treachery, the patriotic impatience of the French and the priority of military operations against what is left of the German Seventh and Fifteenth Armies had all combined to change the picture of the situation in Paris between Saturday the 19th and Wednesday the 23d.

LONDON, Aug. 24 -- The closing down of all entertainments and cultural activities except the radio and movies, introduction of a sixty-hour week in all offices, suspension of all holidays, mobilization of students for war work an introduction of the death penalty for infringement of the new "total war regulations" were announced tonight by the German radio in the process of mobilization.

For the second time in this war proof is being given that it is much easier to make an alliance with Hitler than to break one. The Italians have had that experience in rich measure. It was no trouble at all for them to enter the German partnership. They were received with open arms and large acclaim.

The Concord Building Company has purchased the five-story forty-six-family apartment building at 309 Seventy-ninth Street, North Bergen, N.J., from the Glassburo Realty Company. The property, reported to have an annual rent roll of more than $20,000, is assessed at $80,400. Sale was made through the C.B. Snyder Realty Company.

CAIRO, Egypt, Friday, Aug. 25 -- Germany's southeastern front appeared to be collapsing rapidly Thursday night with the expectations of a Bulgarian request for an armistice increasing hourly and the Nazis attempting to crush what looks like an incipient revolutionary attempt in Greece.
LONDON, Aug. 24 (UP) -- A German communiqu, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

LONDON, Friday, Aug. 25 (U.P.) -- Racing more than twenty-eight miles through abandoned Rumanian defenses and surrendering enemy ranks, two mighty Soviet armies yesterday plunged to within 138 miles of Bucharest.

At six o'clock last night, or two hours and forty minutes before the curtain was scheduled to rise on the premiere of "Lower North" at the Belasco, the huge third act setting, weighing about a ton, crashed to the stage. Nineteen stagehands, according to S. Jay Kaufman, general manager of the production, barely had time to escape.

LONDON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The capture of Bordeaux was reported by the French radio at Algiers. The sprawling advance in southern France was so fast, apparently, that official reports could not keep up with the action. But accounts of Allied successes were abundant from unofficial sources.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Formation of counseling services within war plants to advise workers about their personal problems as a means of reducing rates of labor turnover and absenteeism and improving labor-management relations was recommended today in a report by a committee of fourteen representatives of national and Federal organizations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Charles E. Wilson resigned today as executive vice chairman of the War Production Board on the grounds that his value to the war-production program was being "impaired" by attacks made upon him in the press and on the radio at the instigation of "subordinate officials connected with the personal staff of Mr. Nelson (Donald M. Nelson, board chairman)."

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 24 -- Jack Jossi, who comes from Oakland, Calif., and plays tennis in a manner worthy of the home town of Don Budge and Frank Kovacs, defeated J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange, N.J., the national veterans' champion, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 3, today to gain the final round of the Southampton invitation tournament at the Meadow Club.

Surely, one of the most profitable long-term investments in the whole history of commercial enterprise must be the money which Louis XVI of France gambled on the success of the American firm of Washington, Franklin, Jefferson and Company, in the business they started around the year 1776.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Ted Wilks pitched his tenth straight victory tonight as the Cardinals defeated the Cubs, 2 to 1. It was St. Louis' thirteenth victory in thirteen games with Chicago this season.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Aug. 24 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur's air force made its heaviest raid to date on Halmahera, dropping 156 tons of bombs in the Galela Bay area in the north.

TO look at him now, one never would suspect it, but Stout Steve Owen, the sprightly 270-pound coach of the Football Giants, once was consumed by a burning ambition to be a jockey. That, however, was approximately 190 pounds and thirty-odd years ago. He can't remember learning to ride a horse, although he does recall that he was riding when he was only 4 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Assurance that China is "prepared to back up a properly constituted world organization with all we have, in the enforcement of peace" was given in a speech to the Senate today by Dr. H.H. Kung, Chinese Minister of Finance and Vice President of the Executive Yuan.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- A resolution was offered in the Senate and House today urging President Roosevelt and Secretary Hull to use their influence to persuade Britain to permit free entry of Hebrews from Hungary into Palestine.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 24 -- Dr. Joseph Goebbels, the man designated by Adolf Hitler to stamp out an army of a million men and women for war service at home or at the front, is proceeding ruthlessly in his determination to bring the war to the doorstep of every German home.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -Internal revenue collections during July totaled $2,620,224,038, compared with $1,999,196,414 in the same month of last year, the Treasury Department reported today.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed increase in holdings of Government securities and note circulation for the system as a whole to be $360,861,000 and $81,022,000, respectively, while the ratio of reserve declined to 54.8.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- President Roosevelt hailed the "liberation" of Paris today as a "brilliant presage of total victory." He described the French capital as "a precious symbol of that civilization which it was the aim of Hitler and his armed hordes to destroy."

A $16,600 centralized radio system was presented yesterday afternoon to Halloran General Hospital, at Willowbrook, S.I., by Lieut. Gen. James G. Harbord, retired, chairman of the New York Chapter, American Red Cross, on behalf of the chapter.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Lieut. Col. Robert Tyre (Bobby) Jones Jr., Ninth Air Force intelligence officer, has applied for a discharge from the Army under the over-38 regulation and has left for the United States, the Ninth Air Force disclosed today.

Although 564 cases of infantile paralysis had been reported in New York City up to Wednesday, compared with 89 at this time last year, the incidence of the disease is still far below that in such epidemic years as 1931 and 1935, Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins said yesterday.

LONDON, Friday, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Russia called upon Rumania today to send her armies against the Germans "hand in hand with the Red Army for the liberation of Rumania" and fixed this as the price of an armistice with the Allies.

Officials of the New York Stock Exchange spent much of their time at the telephone yesterday. The reason was a report circulated in Wall Street that the Exchange was considering closings on Saturdays for the duration of the war. The board of governors was said to be discussing the matter.
Yesterday's communiqu, as broadcast from Chungking in English to North America and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:
GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Friday, Aug. 25 (AP) -- A communiqu:

Twentieth Century-Fox will release twenty-seven feature films, fifty-four short subjects, including thirteen issues of The March of Time, and 104 issues of Movie-tonews, its newsreel, during 1944-45, it was announced yesterday by Tom Connors, vice president in charge of sales.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 24 -- The military government of Rumania under Marshal Constantin Senatescu, which assumed this morning after King Michael's proclamation announcing capitulation to the United Nations, has consolidated its position throughout most of the country, according to a broadcast from Bucharest tonight.

The Columbia Broadcasting System issued the following statement yesterday concerning a Paris-datelined dispatch under the byline of Charles Collingwood, CBS correspondent in France, that was broadcast and distributed to the press Wednesday night:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The texts of Charles E. Wilson's letter of resignation as Executive Vice Chairman of the War Production Board and President Roosevelt's letter of acceptance are as follows:

The stock market returned yesterday to a state of indecision as Wednesday's bulge in peacetime issues failed to impress traders. A period of liquidation around midday which centered in some of the pivotal stocks produced enough uneasiness in the list to bring about a fractionally lower closing.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. denied at his press conference today reports from France that inflation had developed there as a result of the use of American invasion currency. On the contrary, he said, prices have been dropping in the American-occupied areas.

MARSHAL TITO'S HEADQUARTERS IN YUGOSLAVIA, Aug. 24 -- Marshal Tito is sending his pistol -- which he carried through three years of warfare in Yugoslavia's hills and mountains -- to Mayor La Guardia of New York as a token of his esteem.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -Mothers of eleven champion war stamp salesmen among the coun~ try's 150,000 newspaper boys and l girls will be designated by the Maritime Commission to christenJ new ships in October, the war: finance division of the Treasury l Department stated today.

LONDON, Friday, Aug. 25 -- A direct hit by a flying bomb partly demolished a "famous and historical" building in southern England last night as the Germans, stepping up the tempo of their terror offensive before Allied spearheads reach the Pas de Calais launching area, sent heavy salvoes of the blind missiles crashing across the Channel.

WITH BRITISH FORCES AT DEAUVILLE, Aug. 23 (Delayed) -- Where there used to be smartly clad manikins smirking along the boardwalk in the latest beach fashions, there are now khaki-clad men in baggy trousers carrying rifles at the ready.

Housewives voting in a poll on how they would change their kitchens if they could, want glass doors for oven and refrigerator, sliding glass doors on kitchen cabinets, vitrolite walls and a disappearing sink. Their preferences for more transparent and washable surfaces in the kitchen of tomorrow were recorded by the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company, whose post-war kitchen has been visited by more than three-quarters of a million potential post-war home builders.

" The Pearl of Death," the latest melodrama produced by Universal and starring Basil Rathbone as Sherlock Holmes, will open this morning at the Rialto. Among the featured players are Nigel Bruce, who plays Dr. Watson, Evelyn Ankers, Dennis Hoey and Miles Mander.

Retail credit collections of local stores showed a decrease of 3.02 per cent in July, according to the twenty-store index, issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York. The average collection percentage last month was 54.60, against 57.62 for July, 1943.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- For Germany, defeat has followed so closely upon the heels of defeat this week that the jubilation in Washington today was almost unrestrained.

GREENVILLE, Ohio, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Filly Direct today showed enough staying power to beat the flower of the country's pacers and capture the Horseman's Futurity for 3-year-olds at the Darke County Fair Grounds.

MOSCOW, Friday, Aug. 25 -- Soviet tanks, cavalry and motorized infantry raced down the Rumanian valley between the Siret and Prut Rivers yesterday toward Galati, Bucharest and the Ploesti oil fields, while other Red Army men between the Prut and the Dniester liberated Kishinev, capital of Moldavia, inflicting heavy losses on outflanked enemy army groups.

TRENTON, Aug. 24 -- Gambling investigations were launched today in Atlantic, Bergen and Passaic Counties with the benefit of a list of alleged meccas of chance furnished to Gov. Walter E. Edge and Attorney General Walter D. Van Riper by a Jersey City attorney who contends that Mr. Van Riper is interested in cleaning up gambling only in Hudson County, it being Democratic.
LONDON, Aug. 24 -- England's eastern and southern beaches, from the Wash to Lymington, including the Isle of Wight, will be opened to the public tomorrow, the War Office announced tonight.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 -- The National Association of Commodity Exchanges and Allied Trades, Inc., which proposes to "develop, improve and extend commodity futures trading in the interests of producers, consumers and the American people," was founded here today.

A green mold that inhibits growth of tuberculosis germs has been discovered accidentally in an ice box at the University of Buffalo School of Medicine, it was announced in Science, America's official scientific journal, yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 24 -- The Pacific Coast Shipbuilding Stabilization Conference, which opened ten days ago, broke up today with failure to reach agreement on the first item of the agenda, the subject of ship repair rates, disputes over which have caused many wartime work stoppages in this area.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 24 -- W. M. Jeffers, president of the Union Pacific Railroad, issued today the following statement in commenting on the suit filed by the Department of Justice at Lincoln, Neb., in which violations of the Sherman Anti-Trust Law are charged:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The "conservative" industrial demobilization and post-war adjustment bill which the Senate adopted Aug. 11, after rejecting the "liberal" Kilgore-Murray program, was reported to the House by the Ways and Means Committee late today, stripped to a mere shadow of its original self and providing for little more than the setting up of machinery to direct and coordinate reconversion under general Congressional instructions.

Homemaking instruction for both boys and girls of junior high school age has been outlined in a "proposed course of study" submitted to the New York City Board of Education. Associate Superintendent Jacob Greenberg said yesterday that the outline, approved by the Board of Superintendents, probably would be utilized this fall by elementary and junior high schools, although the Board of Education has not yet formally considered it.

Fledgling and Step Across, both ridden by Bobby Permane, scored at Belmont Park yesterday with opposite kinds of luck for the form players, who are having an easier path than usual at a Saratoga meeting. Fledgling won for Alfred G. Vanderbilt at $4.10 for $2, while the Wheatley Stable's Step Across ran past all the heavily played horses to return $24.70.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Although agreed that compulsory training of all able-bodied youths must be the keystone of a sound peacetime military program, leaders of the House Post-War Military Policy Committee, are not certain as to the best time to put that controversy before Congress.

Lucien Carr, 19-year-old Columbia University sophomore, was indicted yesterday for second-degree murder in the stabbing of David Kammerer, 33, on Aug. 14. At the same time the police revealed that they had uncovered a second material witness, William Seward Borroughs, 30, of 69 Bedford Street.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 24 -- George Stuhr Jr. of the home club, defending champion, led the qualifiers with a 40, 43 -- 83 in the twenty-first annual junior tournament of the Long Island Golf Association today at the Garden City Country Club.

Ogden Nash's sister, Eleanor Arnett Nash, has written a first novel. Called "Footnote to Life," it is the story of the rise to power and wealth of a self-made man. Appleton-Century will publish it Sept. 11.

LONDON, Aug. 24 -- The United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration has prepared for the relief of occupied Europe now being so rapidly liberated a preliminary program of supply of requirements for the growing of food.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Plans for a new foreign service graduate school, which will have in its student body advanced trainees of both commercial concerns and Government agencies, were revealed today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- American coal-mining machinery and mining methods when used to the full in British mines will "step up" production at the rate of more than 20,000,000 tons a year providing additional supplies that will contribute to the Allied war effort and to the alleviation of the world coal shortage, according to the report made public today by a group of experts who recently returned from England.
In your editorial "Tragedy at Warsaw" you state that "the Warsaw Poles should not have risen until they keyed their movements with those of the Russians -- which they obviously did not do."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- After Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson announced at his press conference this morning that the War Department had received no detailed information on the public relations policies of the Ninth Air Force in France, Maj. Gen. Alexander D. Surles, Army Director of Public Relations, announced tonight that the War Department would not drop its investigation.

CHARTRES, France, Aug. 17 (Delayed) -- The Roman tower of the world-renowned Chartres Cathedral was hit by German artillery fire early this afternoon, sending chunks of granite from this eleventh century edifice crashing into the streets.

Train and intercity bus travelers should cancel any proposed Labor Day week-end trips unless their journeys are directly connected with the war, Col J. Monroe Johnson, director of the Office of Defense Transportation, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower gives his confidants the impression that he is convinced there can be no civilian collapse in Germany this time until the German Army has been completely defeated, Secretary of the Navy James Forrestal revealed here today.

Consolidated net profit of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and its subsidiaries, the National Theatres Corporation and Roxy Theatre, Inc., for the twenty-six weeks ended on June 24 amounted to $6,338,433, equal to $3.12 a share on 1,742,006 shares of common stock, it was announced yesterday.

Godfrey N. Nelson in his article on tax relief for corporations "especially condemned" a tax on undistributed profits as an alternative to the present double taxation of corporation income. The tenor of his article indicates he was thinking of the undistributed profits tax actually passed by Congress in 1936.

MARSEILLE, France, Aug. 23 (Delayed) -- A French armored unit burst into Marseille this morning through the northern suburbs of St. Julien and with surprising ease spread throughout France's greatest port.There was firing down on the Rue Cannebiere, from which the writer has just come, and German cannons from the fort of St. Frioule in the harbor keep pumping 6-inch shells into the Vieux Port, that most famous spot in western Europe's oldest city.

Due almost entirely to the war there has been a shrinkage of 17 per cent in the number of concerns in business in the New York region, it is revealed in the third quarterly report on small business organizations published yesterday by the New York regional office of the Department of Commerce, 138 West Forty-second Street, Zone 18.

The Cocoa Kid, 154, New Haven, Conn., making his first ring appearance in a year, scored a quick knockout over Billy Campanelli, 159, Pittsburgh, in the feature bout scheduled for eight rounds last night at the Fort Hamilton Arena in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- A bill for the Maritime Commission to dispose of the country's wartime merchant fleet at the rate of $100 for each deadweight ton for Liberty ships was introduced today by Senators Radcliffe of Maryland and Bailey of North Carolina.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Sveinn Bjoernsson, the first President of the new Republic of Iceland -- youngest republic in the world -- was received with ceremony at the White House this afternoon by President Roosevelt.
LONDON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communiqu:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Great Britain has proposed to the United States, Soviet Russia and China the creation of a United Nations Military Staff Committee which would be established under a new world security league council to help prevent and repel aggression.

Dungeness crabs fresh from Pacific waters, rainbow trout caught Wednesday in Rocky Mountain streams and fresh fruits and vegetables picked that same day in California, northwestern Washington and Colorado were served to 250 representatives of the food, transportation and research fields at a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Taking sharp issue with Army critics of his civilian reconversion program, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, was disclosed today to have testified that, with minor exceptions, all critical munitions programs were being met.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24 -- John N. Landberg, former Philadelphia lawyer, who was disbarred by the Pennsylvania Supreme Court in 1938, was indicted by the Federal grand jury today on charges of using the mails to defraud.

LONDON, Aug. 24 -- The elaborate "festung" economy of the Third Reich, built around the might of the Wehrmacht, is crumbling. Confronted with the prospect of losing Rumania's oil, cut off from Spain, with France as good as gone and Sweden and Switzerland aloof, Germany is on the verge of standing alone, which she cannot do for long.
Yesterday's communiqu, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 24 -- Nothing known here today indicates that the Japanese have abandoned their drive southward from Hengyang. Although they suffered casualties of more than 30,000 from the United States Fourteenth Air Force and the Chinese infantry, they have moved two new divisions in and have about ten divisions south of Changsha.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 24 (AP) -- A 72-year-old veteran who has been doing trapshooting for forty years and an 18-year-old West Virginia girl overcame a chilly wind today to take two of the Grand American tournament's most coveted crowns.

Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, announced yesterday that he would confer with thirty-eight county chairmen between tomorrow and Tuesday during the first of a series of up-State tours. He will be accompanied by Oscar R. Ewing, vice chairman of the Democratic National Committee.

Nine thousand fewer boys and girls are working illegally in New York State as a result of the special drive against unlawful child labor instituted April 17 by investigators of the State Department of Labor, Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi reported yesterday.

The anti-trust suit filed by the Department of Justice against forty-seven railroads, J.P. Morgan Co. and Kuhn, Loeb Co. has all the earmarks of a political move in the Democratic election campaign. It certainly does not seem to make sense on any other interpretation.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Communiqu 138:

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 24 (AP) -- Organization of the Theta Delta Chi Education Foundation "to further sound learning by creation of scholarships and endowments" was announced today. William F. Love of Rochester, State Supreme Court justice, was elected foundation president at a meeting of trustees and grand lodge officers.

LONDON, Friday, Aug. 25 -- Two columns of French troops, with Gen. Charles de Gaulle in personal command, drove into Paris last night to reinforce their comrades fighting bitterly against pockets of Germans barring complete liberation of the capital, front dispatches reported early today.

The Manufacturers National Bank of Troy, N.Y., has sold the one-family dwelling at 11 Birchfield Road, Larchmont, to H.B. Bernstein, who now occupies the property. Boehm Co. was the broker in the transaction, in which the bank was represented by Realty Management, a division of Realty Mortgagee Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Led by a sharp reaction in agricultural commodity markets, particularly for fresh fruits, vegetables and livestock, the Bureau of Labor Statistics index of commodity prices in primary markets dropped 0.4 per cent in the week ended Aug. 19.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The Consolidated Vultee Aircraft Corporation opposed the extension of the joint wage review system to its Fort Worth division, at a War Labor Board hearing today, contending that it was not conducive to sound labor relations.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 -- record-tying performance by Johnny Bulla, Eastern Airlines pilot on the Atlanta-Chicago run, featured the start of the fourth annual All-American open golf championship under the main tent at the Tam o' Shanter Country Club in nearby Niles today.

Marseille, another cosmopolis, the Babylon and Babel of the South, is a memorable place. More than 2,500 years old, it has no large store of antiquities. The greatest Mediterranean port, you can go from there to almost everywhere reachable by sea, but you were lucky, in peacetime, if you could find anywhere else a gayer or more vivid life.

One hundred and nineteen years ago a little band of men known as the "Triente y Tres" (the "Thirty and Three") met secretly in the city of Florida in what was then the southernmost territory of the Empire of Brazil to issue a declaration of defiance to the Portuguese rulers of the Bande Oriental and an affirmation of the independence of South America's smallest nation.
LONDON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The statement of condition of the Bank of England for the week ended yesterday reports a decrease of 2,508,000 in note circulation.

ROME, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Taking quick advantage of lessening enemy resistance in the upper Arno valley southeast of Florence, British and Indian troops have advanced and captured several important points, including Mount Foresto, it was announced today.

LONDON, Aug. 24 (UP) -- Germans were reported today to be evacuating the eastern sector of Warsaw after throwing in additional strength and fire-power against Polish patriots in the old city area of the capital.

Commemorating the ninety-fifth birthday of the late August Heckscher, the newly formed Heckscher Children's Symphony Orchestra yesterday gave its first concert before an audience of 150 children and parents.

Good supplies of fresh fish and a wide choice of varieties will be available to shoppers today for the first time in many weeks, according to the Fish and Wildlife Service. While receipts of whiting were the heaviest, ample stocks of haddock, lemon sole and yellowtail flounder also came to market yesterday from New Bedford.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 - The Office of Price Administration modified its highest price line limitations in the women's fur garment price regulations as applied to wholesalers and manufacturers. The action, effective tomorrow, was taken to give relief to manufacturers and wholesalers of certain volume selling categories of women's fur garments whose highest price line limitations under former provisions of the regulation are below permissible levels established today, OPA said.

After studying further reports of bonuses and other "gratuities" exacted from would-be tenants by superintendents of some buildings here as a condition for the renting of an apartment, executives of the Office of Price Administration have decided that the practice is illegal and must be stamped out.

ROME, Aug. 24 -- A highly mobile American task force of tanks, motorized infantry and artillery sped northward beyond Grenoble today along highways already largely cleared of the enemy by French patriots -- racing to join forces with Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's Allied armies in northern France.

A new cream containing lanolin, designed to protect the hands of war workers whose jobs bring them into contact with cutting oils, mild acids and alkalies, is being distributed to plants, it was announced yesterday. Made by the duPont Company, the new cream, named "Pro-Tek No. 2," is water resistant, and is the successor of "Pro-tek" which is water-soluble.

Your editorial "Toulouse" certainly gladdened the heart of at least one of the hundreds of thousands of refugees who found a haven in the "pink city," as it is affectionately called, during the tragic days of 1940.

The Philharmonic-Symphony announced yesterday that twenty-seven soloists will appear with the orchestra during the coming season, which opens on Oct. 5 under the direction of Dr. Artur Rodzinski. The first soloists to be heard will be Yehudi Menuhin, who will play the Mendelssohn Violin Concerto during the third week of the season, and Robert Casadesus, pianist, who will appear during the fourth week.

MARSHAL TITO'S HEADQUARTERS, in Yugoslavia, Aug. 22 (Delayed) (AP) -- Plans for much closer coordination of military operations by Allied forces in Italy and the National Army of Liberation in Yugoslavia were worked out at the recent conferences of Prime Minister Churchill, Gen. Sir Henry Maitland Wilson and himself, Marshal Tito said today.

ALBANY, Aug. 24 -- Governor Dewey, who has been virtually in "retreat" this week for the purpose of concentrating on speech-writing, is scheduled to continue this for several days, it was indicated here today. The Governor will go to his Pawling farm tomorrow afternoon for a stay which will last beyond the normal week-end.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor pledged today the full support of the organization's nearly 7,000,000 members toward wiping out the war production shortages which still exist and reiterated its protests against "unnecessary governmental manpower controls."
ROME, Aug. 24 (AP) -- A communiqu:

The Goya and the Velasquez, two six-story apartment houses, each on a plot 100 by 100 feet, at 605 and 611 West 156th Street, between Broadway and Riverside Drive, have been sold by the Mosholu Building Company, Murray Blumberg, president, to M. Emanuel Balt, attorney and publisher.

Borrowings of the Federal Government in the current fiscal year probably will be about $50,000,000,000, against $62,000,000,000 in the year which ended on June 30, according to the current issue of the Federal Reserve Bulletin.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 24 -- Germany's precious oil resources were bombed today by the greatest force of United States heavy bombers ever to fly over Adolf Hitler's Reich. No fewer than 1,300 four-engined planes took off from this country while 600 more operated from bases in Italy.

PEARL HARBOR, Aug. 24 (U.P.) -- American fliers in widespread attacks against Japanese positions throughout the Pacific, struck Paramushiru Island in the northern Kuriles on Sunday and attacked the island of Yap for the fourth consecutive time, Pacific Fleet Headquarters announced today.

Back from Washington conferences with members of Congress, Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican National Chairman, declared yesterday that the Republican national ticket this year would get a larger percentage of the union labor vote than it had received in many years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The Treasury is opposed to a bill espoused by Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, to permit the Federal Reserve System to guarantee up to 90 per cent of virtually all types of post-war business loans not already covered by its V, VT and T loans, all of which are for special purposes.

A 78-year-old spinster, who once rejected an offer of $125,000 for the ancestral estate on Staten Island where she has lived almost her entire lifetime, was saved yesterday by the Office of Price Administration from eviction from the pre-Revolutionary stone and brick dwelling that she had lost through foreclosure ten years ago.

Walter P. Reuther, vice president of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, of Detroit, has sent a statement to THE NEW YORK TIMES taking issue with charges made by the General Motors Corporation concerning workers' self-imposed limits on production of such war equipment as heavy trucks and tanks and their components now on the Army's critical list, as contained in a Detroit dispatch from Russell Porter published in this newspaper on Aug. 16.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 24 -- Thomas A. Murray, head of the Building and Construction Trades Council of New York City, was re-elected president of the State Federation of Labor at the final session of its convention today. E.W. Edwards, secretary-treasurer, and the thirteen vice presidents, also were re-elected.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (U.P.) -- John Foster Dulles, foreign policy adviser to Governor Dewey, said tonight after his second meeting with Secretary Hull that they "are trying to do something rather novel in American political life," but he would not elaborate.

New York State families must make the harvest of local crops their "personal business" if service men are to be properly supplied with food this winter, Joseph B. O'Connor, acting regional director of the War Manpower Commission, declared yesterday in an appeal for 140,000 workers, needed between today and Oct. 10.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Robert L. Lippincott of Riverton, N.J., today took the third race in the International Star Class yacht world championship to tie the series with Gerald Driscoll of San Diego, Calif., winner of the first two races.

U.S. AIR COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, England, Aug. 24 -- Capt. John T. Godfrey, Mustang fighter pilot of Woonsocket, R.I., shot up four JU-52's on a German airdrome today to bring his score of enemy aircraft destroyed to thirty-six, the highest total of enemy planes destroyed on the ground and in the air for any Eighth Air Force Fighter Command pilot.

Contending that elimination of Regulation W will hasten reconversion and wide distribution of consumer goods, the American National Retail Jewelers Association in a resolution adopted at the concluding session yesterday of its wartime conference at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria called for rescinding of the Federal Reserve Board curb on consumer credit as soon after the end of the European war as is administratively possible.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Organization of a transportation department to streamline operations for expansion after the war was announced today by E. Lee Talman, executive vice president of Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc. John A. Collings of this city, who has been vice president of operations, heads the department. All regional and district offices, as well as operations, will be under his direction, effective Sept. 1.

The bells of St. Paul's Cathedral were rung yesterday in London for the first time since the start of the war, the British radio reported in a broadcast heard by the Federal Communications Commission. The bells were rung during the broadcast in celebration of the liberation "and rebirth of France."

Since Boy Scouts of the city began an intensive summer paper salvage drive Aug. 1 they have collected ninety-seven tons, officials of the organization announced yesterday. Brooklyn Scouts contributed twenty-five tons, Queens was a close second with twenty-four tons; Manhattan had twenty-one tons; Bronx eighteen and Richmond nine.
Free dissemination of news in all countries is urged as a requisite of durable peace by Kent Cooper, executive director of The Associated Press, in an article in the September issue of Free World.

A new high school course in American history, the theme of which is the development of a peaceful and progressive democracy, has been approved by the Board of Superintendents and forwarded to the Board of Education for ratification, it was announced yesterday by Jacob Greenberg, associate superintendent in charge of personnel and teacher training.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Japanese have launched a new drive northward from the neck of Liuchow Peninsula in south China opposite Hainan Island, and heavy fighting is in progress with both sides suffering considerable losses, the Chinese command announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Signs of a new Congressional battle over food subsidies and farm-products price ceilings appeared today as the Administration made plans to ask for additional funds to finance war food production programs.

The New York Stock Exchange, the New York Curb Exchange and other stock exchanges of the country and the over-the-counter markets are to be closed today, but the cotton and grain markets will remain open and several Wall Street houses will have departments open today for customers interested in those commodities.

OMAHA, Aug. 26--More than 500,000,000 pounds of frozen foods will be packed this year, exceeding last year's output by about 15 per cent and allowing about 85 per cent of the total production for civilian consumption, Edwin T. Gibson, director and former president of the National Association of Frozen Foods Packers, announced here today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Existence of a previously secret deadly weapon known as the "Crocodile," which is used in conjunction with the Churchill tank and throws a "geyser of fire" for a distance of more than 450 feet, was revealed here tonight in a joint announcement by the British Supply Council and British Army Staff.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- "We cannot let the men whose lives depend on this equipment pay the price for our quarrels at home," six American labor leaders who are visiting the French battlefields under War Department sponsorship have declared in a message sent back here to their unions.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 25 -- Strikes, spreading through western Pennsylvania's bituminous fields today, closed a ninth mine in the supervisory employes recognition dispute, with a daily production loss of nearly 30,000 tons.

New York City's 9,000 municipally owned vehicles reduced their gasoline consumption 22 per cent in the second quarter of this year, compared with the corresponding period last year, the Regional Office of Price Administration announced yesterday.

ALGIERS, Aug. 25 -- Driven to desperation by inroads made in resistance forces in recent weeks by a systematic house-to-house manhunt by the Gestapo and Vichy militia in Paris, local leaders precipitated the uprising and battle in the capital without awaiting the approval of either Gen. Charles de Gaulle or the Allies, who had hoped to avoid that battle, according to information reaching Algiers from Paris.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 25 -- No fewer than 109 of the 605 patents listed as granted in this week's Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office went to alien inventors, most of them Germans, or residents of German-occupied countries.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The Senate, by an apparently unanimous voice vote, passed late today its own bill calling for the disposal under the direction of an eight-member board of an estimated $75,000,000,000 to $100,000,000,000 worth of surplus war property ranging from GI socks to aircraft factories.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Rookie Fred Schmidt of the Cardinals called a sudden halt tonight to Pittsburgh's six-game winning streak, blanking the Pirates, 4 to 0, on six hits.

ROME, Aug. 23 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Prime Minister Churchill and Pope Plus XII held a forty-five-minute conference today, which Vatican City observers said would have a widespread influence both on the terms of peace in Europe and on the future of Italy.

A "Service of Thanksgiving" for the liberation of Paris will be held in the French Episcopal Church of Saint Esprit, 109 East Sixtieth Street, at 11 A.M. tomorrow. The French Provisional Government will be represented by an official delegation at the worship.

With the virtual elimination of vacancies in apartments usually rented by middle-income groups, a number of practices which increase substantially the cost to the tenant have been reported. Some landlords are refusing to redecorate apartments for new tenants. Building superintendents in some cases are refusing to handle applications from prospective tenants unless they receive a liberal gratuity.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 -- Expected large surplus generating capacity of some Federal utility projects after the war should not be used "to create further unfair competition" with private utilities, P.L. Smith, president of the Middle West Corporation, said today in an address at the annual meeting of the National Security Traders Association, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower today placed in effect certain arrangements that will give Frenchmen a greater part in their country's affairs during military operations, the State and War Departments announced jointly.

Acting on complaints that many service men and women and other visitors to the city recently have been forced to "tip" hotel clerks as much as $5 to get a room, the Office of Price Administration warned yesterday that this form of gouging was illegal and said it was taking steps to end the practice immediately.
GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Saturday, Aug. 26 (AP) -- A communique:

Featured by the largest railroad financing of the year to date, new bonds offered publicly in the local market this week totaled $49,865,000 for five issues, the highest total in a month, and compared with $24,116,000 for a like number of issues last week, when emissions were all in the tax-exempt field.

Cooler weather spurred consumer interest in fall merchandise here last week in sharp contrast to the preceding week. Department stores had sales increases over the comparative 1943 week, with estimates putting the gain at from 5 to 10 per cent.
A communique, as broadcast yesterday from Chungking in English to North America and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

Two Park Department workmen found a young woman dead of strangulation yesterday in a bush clump beside the main door of Hayden Planetarium in Manhattan Plaza, south of Eighty-first Street between Columbus Avenue and Central Park West.

Residents of the Greenway Terrace section of Forest Hills, Queens, were surprised yesterday afternoon to see several autos filled with detectives draw up to the fashionable home of Frank H. Sincerbeaux, an attorney, at No. 43. Soon afterward the detectives emerged with a dignified middle aged man as their prisoner.

A recasting of the board of directors of the United Cigar-Whelan Stores Corporation is contemplated for the annual meeting in Wilmington, Del., on next Wednesday to give representation to Joseph I. Lubin and associates, who will be the second largest owners of stock of the company as a result of the liquidation of the Phoenix Securities Corporation, now in progress.

RAMBOUILLET, France, Aug. 23 (Delayed) -- One of the few clear elements in the confused situation at Paris is that there has been some unhappy misunderstanding -- the first serious misunderstanding that has arisen in France since D-day.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Army reported today that large amounts of supplies and equipment are being abandoned along the Alcan Highway because they are not worth the cost of shipping home.

Gene Currivan and two other newspaper men have had the peculiar experience of climbing one tower of Chartres Cathedral while the Nazis were shelling the other. He reports that the exterior damage is negligible. From the inside everything precious has long been removed.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 25 (U.P.)--Military and civil police using tear gas and gunfire regained control today of the Duval County jail in which insurgent armed prisoners led by a crippled man had barricaded themselves for more than six hours.
What is meant by "foreign policy"? One hears so much about it nowadays. Would it not be better before we go any farther that we should know just what we mean by that term?

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 25 (AP) -- William G. Heiner, trustee for the bankrupt Pittsburgh Terminal Coal Corporation, informed Federal Judge R.M. Gibson today that companies and individuals accused of "exploiting" the corporation had agreed to settlement of a suit which would cost them more than $4,800,000 in cash and relinquished claims.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 25 -- Although the Red Army does not yet appear to have pierced the Galati Gap in Rumania, Soviet and Rumanian authorities together ap pear to have preponderant control in the eastern portions of Hitler's collapsed satellite state as far south as the Danube Valley.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
I have just read the items about the number of fires, including the "earnest request" of the President "to devote special thought and effort" to prevent fires.

Plastic sections of houses, plastic furniture and appliances can have a far-reaching role in low cost housing after the war if the numerous materials already developed are applied correctly to consumer products, according to Frederick Z. Pearson, manager of the plastics division of Lyon Metal Products, Inc., writing in the current issue of Plastics magazine.
More plans for new housing to be erected as soon as materials are available were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings.

The Kennecott Copper Corporation and its subsidiaries had a consolidated net income of $21,538,872 after all charges but before depletion, equivalent to $1.99 a share, according to the report for the six months ended on June 30, released for publication today. In the first half of last year the consolidated net income before depletion amounted to $22,324,375, or $2.06 a share.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Oct. 1, 1944, is the Army's "tentative" date for finishing its job against Germany, Chairman Woodrum told the House Post-War Military Policy Committee today.
CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 25 -- Rumors attributed to Soviet sources say the Bulgarian Government has broken with Germany. Whether this is true or not, Bulgaria's fall is inevitable and imminent.

RANDOLPH, N.H., Aug. 25 (AP) -- Prof. Emeritus Robert H. Richards, oldest living graduate of Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the last member of its first class, will observe his one hundredth birthday quietly tomorrow.

John La Ware has been appointed manager of the bulk products I department and John V. Clissold has been named manager of the consumer products department of the drug and pharmaceutical division of Standard Brands, Inc.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 25 -- Lieut. W. Donald McNeill, USNR, national champion in 1940; Francisco (Pancho) Segura of Ecuador and William Talbert of Indianapolis arrived on the scene at the Meadow Club today and moved into the semi-final round of the Southampton invitation tennis tournament.

For several weeks, in articles and editorials, THE NEW YORK TIMES has brought to the fore the subjects of wage incentives and restricted production, both of which bear upon the question of production per man-hour.

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- Henry U. Willink, Minister of Health, today appealed to parents to keep their children out of the flying bomb danger zone. "Parents must not let the glorious victories of the Allied armies blind them to the risks to which children who are kept in London and other evacuation areas are still exposed," he said.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Miss Kathleen Small of the Women's Land Army returned today from an inspection trip which included New York State, and said that she found women doing a good job of harvesting crops. She expressed the opinion, however, that there might be an acute need for more such workers, especially to save the apple crop in the Hudson Valley, when vacationers return to school and to business jobs.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Communique 139:

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- The Allies were considering as early as 1943 large-scale operations against Japan by the Southeast Asia Command of Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten and General Joseph W. Stilwell, but plans were recast in the light of needs for the Anzio landings and the invasion of France.
GREAT LAKES, Ill., Aug. 25 (AP) -- Three meet records were bettered tonight as the men's national outdoor A.A.U. swimming championships opened in the Green Bay area pool.

Clemon Allen, 18 years old, who was committed to a State reform school three years ago as one of four boys who fatally stabbed another boy in a hold-up at Fifth Avenue and 104th Street, was held in $500 bail yesterday in Felony Court for carrying a five-inch knife in Central Park, near Seventy-second Street, the night before.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 25 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has bought the screen rights to Joseph Stanley Pennell's current best-seller, "The History of Rome Hanks." The studio plans to make this war history of a Southern family early next year. No announcement as to casting or production has been made.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 25--According to word received by Mr. and Mrs. J. Averell Clark of Hitchcock Lane, here, their younger son, Flight Sgt. Thomas Hitchcock Clark of the Royal Air Force, was killed in action over France on March 31.

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- The new Rumanian Government, after having denounced German perfidy tonight, openly declared war on the Reich, thereby fulfilling a Russian prerequisite for acceptance of the Rumanian offer to change to the Allied side.

Shepherded by Horton Henry, a State Department aide, thirty-four of the British, Russian and American delegates to the Dumbarton Oaks Security Conference in Washington arrived in New York last night for the week-end.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Details of conditions found in two prisoner-of-war camps in Japan proper were released today by the International Red Cross, whose representative this spring visited the camps, finding them in general satisfactory, although they were overcrowded, cold in winter and prisoners complained of a lack of enough protein and fat in their diet.

From an authoritative source comes the information that Warner Brothers have obtained the screen rights to "The Visitor." This is Herman Shumlin's next offering, a detective melodrama adapted by Kenneth White from the Carl Randau-Leane Zugsmith book of the same name, which is scheduled to open early in October.

ACINCINNATI fan, John Mueller by name, gets quite critical of our Leo Durocher, but there is much in what he says. "Is Durocher trying to become the best-hated man in baseball?" he asks. "If so, he is achieving his objective. He came here breathing fire and brimstone. And he fanned to a white heat his feud with the Reds.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- President Roosevelt admitted today that he had been in communication with Wendell L. Willkie, the 1940 Republican candidate for President, thus ending a series of reports and denials that the Chief Executive sought a conference with his former opponent.

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- An attack by Lord Brabazon, former Minister of Aircraft Production, on British official unpreparedness for the resumption of civilian flying made notable here today what had been intended as a peaceful celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of British commercial aviation.

The cotton futures market was steady yesterday and prices on the New York Cotton Exchange, after opening with over-night gains of 3 to 5 points, continued to work upward and closed with net gains of 17 to 20 points, or 85 cents to $1 a bale.

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- After a quiet start today the stock markets developed a firm tone and yesterday's recovery in industrial shares continued with fresh gains recorded. Support was again forthcoming for textiles and chain stores improved.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Senator Harry F. Byrd notified Senator Kenneth S. Wherry of Nebraska today of his assent to the latter's request that an inquiry be made by the Special Committee on Reduction of Nonessential Expenditures into the practice of Government agencies putting experts from their staffs at the disposition of Congressional committees.

On the eve of American and French landings in southern France General de Gaulle gave the long-awaited signal: "Frenchmen, arise." He was speaking to what you call "the underground" -- what Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower calls the French Forces of the Interior -- to what we call "the Resistance," or the Maquis.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission disapproved today the General Gas and Electric Corporation's proposed sale of common stock in the Tide Water Power Company, Wilmington, N.C., to Warren W. Bell for $55,000.

Representative Hamilton Fish admitted yesterday that he had quietly dropped the quarter of a million dollar libel suit he filed during the heat of the recent primary campaign on the basis of an advertisement linking him in prewar days with Fritz Kuhn and others of known un-American sympathies.

ALBANY, Aug. 25 (AP) -- First sentences in the investigation ordered by Governor Dewey of Albany County crime were pronounced today, when two men received jail terms and a third a suspended sentence, on pleas of guilty to illegal registration.

ROME, Aug. 25 -- American troops lunging suddenly eastward from their Riviera beachhead, in southern France, have captured the famous resort towns of Cannes and Antibes and tonight were fighting forward less than twenty miles from the Italian frontier.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Aug. 25 -- A Japanese cruiser and seven Japanese freighters were sunk or severely damaged and forty barges and luggers were shot up as a force of fewer than twenty-five of Gen. Douglas MacArthur's Liberators made a surprise low-level attack yesterday on Manado, in Netherland Celebes, which is the enemy supply point for Halmahera.

From every part of France yesterday there came good news. The Germans surrendered Paris. The French Second Armored Division was in the capital, and in control. On the main battlefield of northern France the headlong retreat of Marshal von Kluge's beaten army suggested a withdrawal as far as the line of the Somme and Marne Rivers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The Yankees, thoroughly counted out of the American League flag race only a short while ago, bounded back into the picture tonight as they vanquished the Senators, 4 to 2, in eleven innings to the keen disappointment of 10,170 onlookers.

Pleasant, indeed, was the homecoming of the Giants, who returned to the Polo Grounds last night and, before a remarkable turnout of 35,832 fans, including 1,889 service men, handed the Dodgers a 10-2 setback. Even for this time-honored interborough rivalry the crowd, biggest under the local lights all season, surpassed expectations.

Less emphasis will be placed on generalities in electronics and more on the products of that science in copy placed for the International General Electric Company throughout Latin America during 1945, it was announced yesterday by Grant Advertising, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- More than 500 names have been sent in for the Roster of Qualified Women to be compiled as a result of the June White House conference on how women may share in post-war policy-making, it was reported today by Charl O. Williams of the National Education Association, chairman of the continuing committee.

A survey of waste in fruits and vegetables caused by failure to specify grades in the price regulations issued by the Office of Price Administration is being conducted by the New York produce trade, leaders revealed yesterday. The data, when it is collected for this season, will be presented to OPA in the fall as a protest, it was said.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP)--The chief of Merrill's Marauders acknowledged today that there had been a temporary break in the morale of his celebrated jungle fighters in Burma, but described it as a "storm in a tea pot" that blew over in about ten days.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 25 -- The crushing weight of American airpower descended on the Luftwaffe again today after a period in which oil and industrial targets had received their periodic mauling.

Devil Diver, the handicap champion, will try his luck again at Belmont Park today, but this time under scale weight instead of the crushing imposts recently imposed upon him. In the $15,000 added Wilson Stakes, the Greentree Stable star will have to carry 117 pounds, a lot of weight for some horses but merely a trifle for a star who only last week raced under 135.

Faced with the second of the three lengthened week-end holidays due to Saturday closings, traders either held to the sidelines yesterday or switched positions in the stock market. A creeping recovery in the final hour, which ended the dullest session so far this month, permitted the list to close on a firm note and with the advantage of fractional gains.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Hopes of the Red Sox to overhaul the Browns in the American League pennant race faded tonight as they dropped a doubleheader to the Athletics, 6 -- 1 and 9 -- 4, before a crowd of 23,302 and fell from second to fourth place. Five-run rallies sewed up both games.

The beleaguered Warsaw underground made repeated dramatic appeals yesterday over its Polskie radio to the International Red Cross to send aid to "tens of thousands" of citizens of Warsaw whom the Germans had driven into a concentration camp at Pruszkow, twelve miles from the city.

SEATTLE, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Representative Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat, told The Post-Intelligencer on the telephone from Washington tonight that he had heard reports, in Washington and on the West Coast, that, at the request of the Japanese, United States naval and aerial patrols were curtailed in the central Pacific at the time the Japanese struck Pearl Harbor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25--The War Department changed its mind today on whether President Roosevelt's speech at Bremerton, Wash., on Aug. 12 was "political," holding first that it was and several hours later reversing itself to hold that it was "not political."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- President Roosevelt said today that the matter of fulfilling the latest lend-lease report's prediction that the lend-lease program "is likely to have stimulating effects on the commercial post-war foreign trade of the United States," raised the whole question of post-war credits.

ROME, Aug. 25 -- Today in Rome they have been staging a demonstration to celebrate the liberation of Paris. Staging is the wrong word. No longer seen here are the organized crowds, the smart parades, files of singing youth. The characteristic street pageant of the Fascist capital has disappeared as completely as if it never had existed.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 25 -- The Paris radio announced late tonight that the French capital had been liberated and that the German commander had signed a document ordering his troops to cease fire immediately.

DETROIT, Aug. 25 (U.P.) -- Production of Pratt Whitney airplane engines was halted at the Ford Motor Company's Highland Park plant today when 2,800 members of the United Automobile Workers Union (CIO) walked cut in protest against pay classifications and lay-off procedure.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Leslie C. Jepsen of Dwight, Ill., who hasn't owned a gun for almost two years, today won the forty-fifth annual Grand American handicap trapshoot and perpetuated the axiom that an unknown always wins the "Grand."

DETROIT, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Tigers, scrapping to keep alive a chance at the American League pennant, pulled a double steal for the only run today as Paul (Dizzy) Trout shut out the Browns, 1 to 0, with a four-hit pitching job for his twenty-first victory of the season.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 -- Golf's oldest truism: "As goes the putter, so goes the golfer" was brought to mind today when Johnny Bulla, commercial airplane pilot, who had been the talk of the tourney after his sensational 65 in yesterday's opening round of the $42,500 All-American open, stalled, spiraled and finally crashed at Tam o'Shanter.

PHILIP TOYNBEE is a clever young English writer who looks rather like an Oxford or Cambridge version of Gary Cooper, Like Aldous Huxley, he carries the weight of an ancestry heavily burdened with literary talent. Arnold Toynbee, considered by many the most eminent historian of this century, is his father. Gilbert Murray, maintained by many against the dissent of quite a few to be the finest translator of Greek drama into English, is his grandfather.

After a Thursday postponement caused by suddenly collapsing scenery, "Lower North" finally opened last evening at the Belasco. It should receive due credit for surviving vicissitudes and near disasters, but the misfortune is that while it has fulfilled its obligations by going on, it isn't much of a show.

Germany will be knocked out of the war "within a matter of weeks" because the capitulation of Rumania has made the Reich's position in eastern Europe untenable, it was predicted yesterday by Charles A. Davila, former Rumanian Minister to the United States and now the representative here of Juliu Maniu, a Minister of State in the new Bucharest regime.

ROME, Aug. 25 (UP) -- Allied headquarters said today that German forces in the area west of Florence were believed to be moving northward to the comparative safety of the Gothic Line, and terrific explosions heard from Nazi positions indicated that a demolition program was being carried out.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Saturday, Aug. 26 -- Three resounding victories were won along the 200 mile-long front in northern France yesterday.

The Allied capture of Paris was ignored last night by the Tokyo radio, which quoted alleged "military experts in Paris" as saying that the much-vaunted V-2 German secret weapon had been already employed in the east and would soon be put into action "also on the Western Front."

HAMILTON, Mass., Aug. 25 (U.P.) -- A poem entitled "The March to Victory" and written by two Boston school employes was on its way today to Lieut. General Patton after it was accepted by his daughter, Mrs. James W. Tottem of Hamilton.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25--The question whether Donald M. Nelson will resume his chairmanship of the War Production Board on his return from a special mission to China for President Roosevelt was raised today when the President told his press conference that he did not know whether Mr. Nelson would resume his duties at that time.
PARIS, Aug. 25 -- For the last six hours we have been watching a tumultuous demonstration of gratitude by the liberated people of Paris.

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- The agreements providing for the taking over of civil administration in liberated France by the French "Provisional Government" may prove the penultimate stage in the restoration of French sovereignty.

PARIS, Aug. 25 -- Yesterday, even before I entered Paris, I learned by a telephone call that Mme. Blanchard, who has been housekeeper for the American Embassy in Paris for sixteen years, was excitedly awaiting the arrival of the Americans so she could raise the Stars and Stripes over the embassy again.

Home canners who keep an eye on the sugar bag will do well to consider preserving fruit in the form of butters. Of all the sweet spreads -- jellies, jams, marmalades and so on -- butters require the smallest amount of sugar in proportion to the fruit needed.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 25 (AP) -- Issuance in July of 3,885 building permits for construction estimated to cost $30,000,841 set a five-year record, State Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi announced today. The total was the highest since February, 1939, when permits issued were valued at $49,752,569, and the dollar volume was higher than any July during the last decade, he said.

Another interesting item for the students of language. Utility beef is something in which American housewives, or at any rate New York housewives, see no utility. It is the new rationless grass-fed beef that is just as nutritious as the other corn-fed kind; but aside from being nutritious, it is apparently good for nothing at all.

TRENTON, Aug. 25 -- Representatives of New Jersey egg producers and marketers who are protesting a Federal order requiring Federal inspection of premium grade eggs announced today that they would comply with the regulations, but would not drop their objections.
ROME, Aug. 25 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Senator Robert F. Wagner, Democrat, of New York, declared in a radio speech today that the impending collapse of the Nazi regime at last provided a chance to rescue some of the victims of Hitler tyranny.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The current Washington Conversations on International Organization at Dumbarton Oaks will probably be followed in the near future by other international conferences of both military and political significance.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 -- Prices of grains fluctuated nervously today on the Board of Trade, spreading operations featuring trading in wheat and rye. However, the undertone was easy most of the day and closing trades were well toward the bottom. July wheat and oats went to new low prices for the season.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Members of the National Security Traders Association, Inc., were told today that municipal bond dealers may make a vital contribution to post-war prosperity by assisting in planning sound, well-financed projects.

LONDON, Saturday, Aug. 26 -- "France will take her place among the great nations that will organize the peace," Gen. Charles de Gaulle declared tonight to the people of liberaetd Paris. According to the Fighting French radio General de Gaulle entered the capital at 7 P.M. and was received at the Town Hall by the new Prefect.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the Republic Service Corporation's proposal to use the proceeds from the sale of its subsidiaries in Virginia toward the pro rata payment of 60 per cent of its collateral trust bonds will be considered at a hearing on Sept. 11.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Apparently the Republican party will try to lift the specific question of American participation in a world security organization out of party politics in the Presidential campaign, but there will be no moratorium on discussion of the Administration's conduct of foreign policy as a whole.

State headquarters of the Liberal party announced yesterday that Secretary of State Thomas J Curran had overruled the objections against its nominating petitions for President Roosevelt, Senator Harry S. Truman, candidate for Vice President, Senator Robert F. Wagner and Marvin R. Dye, candidate for Associate Judge of the Court of Appeals.

A meeting sponsored by District 50, United Mine Workers of America, to gain support of 4,100 workers of the Third Avenue Railway Company in a State Labor Relations Board election Tuesday, ended in wild disorder last night at Audubon Hall, 166th Street and Broadway, when members of the Transport Workers Union, Congress of Industrial Organizations, the opposition union in the election, packed the hall and shouted down the first of four scheduled UMW speakers.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

E.H. Rollins Sons and the Mercantile Commerce Bank and Trust Company of St. Louis purchased yesterday $700,000 of State of Arkansas highway refunding bonds from the Kansas City Life Insurance Company of Kansas City, Mo. Rollins Sons bought $500,000 of the bonds as 3 1/4s, maturing from 1958 to 1969, at a price of 115,202.

It will be a long time, perhaps, before Chinese troops of liberation fight their way into Peiping. Nevertheless, the situation in the Yangtze Valley, which has been a critical area this summer, looks somewhat better than it did. Last May the Japanese started to hammer their way along the railroad line from Hankow to Canton.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 25 -- "Loose talk" about increases of 25 to 35 per cent in the prices of new automobiles over 1942 levels and of vastly higher prices for consumer durable goods in general was denounced today as irresponsible and dangerous by Chester Bowles, Price Administrator.

Shipment of war surplus soft goods abroad on long-term credits will not prove harmful to American industry provided prices charged approximate those of newly manufactured goods of similar types and the transactions are cleared through regular trade channels, exporters of textiles asserted yesterday.

The proposed Bretton Woods monetary agreements constitute a vital step in expansion of post-war world trade and in avoiding the international economic anarchy of the Nineteen Thirties which finally culminated in war, E.M. Bernstein, representative of the Treasury Department, said yesterday.
CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 25 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Because of an acute shortage of high-grade Appalachian coal suitable for making coke and by-products, the Solid Fuels Administration will begin immediately to divert 1,680,000 tons of this fuel to steel mills from industrial plants using it for generating steam.
LONDON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

CLEVELAND, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Representatives of the United Automobile Workers (CIO) moved tonight to block Frederick C. Crawford's scheduled address to a mass meeting of his employes at the Thompson Aircraft Products Company Monday, on the eve of a plant bargaining agency election.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Among actions announced today by various war agencies were the following:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The special House committee investigating executive agencies called on Congress in an interim report today to restrict the authority of Federal executive agencies, holding that they were assuming "more and more of the actual government of the nation."

Projected improvements for Jones Beach to cost $765,000 and a proposal to expand the causeway system feeding to the playground at a cost of $5,000,000, have been approved by the State Post-War Planning Commission, Robert Moses, president of the Long Island State Park Commission disclosed yesterday.
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Senator Harry S. Truman will be notified officially of his nomination as Democratic Vice Presidential candidate in a night program at Lamar, Thursday.

August Derleth, writer of mystery stories and head of Arkham House, which publishes only weird tales, has edited and written a foreword to "Sleep No More: Twenty Masterpieces of Horror for the Connoisseur," to be published by Farrar Rinehart Sept. 21.

The resignation of Charles E. Wilson as executive vice chairman of the War Production Board brings into the open a feud that had been simmering for some months. Mr. Wilson, in resigning, makes a serious charge that misstatements about him have for some time been "inspired by subordinate officials of the Board connected with the personal staff of Mr. Nelson," and though the latter "has disclaimed any responsibility for these attacks," the attacks have continued.

BOSTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Braves opened a siege of three consecutive double-headers by splitting a twin bill with the Phillies today, winning the second game, 4 to 3, after bowing in the opener, 9 to 7.

LONDON, Saturday, Aug. 26 -- Two Russian armies racing toward the heart of Rumania at a better than a mile-an-hour clip yesterday reached the Galati Gap defenses at Tecuci and also drove a spearhead down to the Danube River delta at Kiliya in a six-day whirlwind offensive that Moscow announced had cost the enemy nearly 205,000 in killed or captured.

Many men, and women too, now living as cliff dwellers in cities have had the experience of hitching the roader to the buggy and going with grandfather or father to salt the young stock and dry cows in the summer pasture. There are still many summer pastures in the Northeastern States.
LONDON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- A joint Air and Home Security Ministries communique:

LISBON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Jules Sauerwein, French newspaperman who fled Paris just before Patriot attacks started against the German occupying forces, said today that 72-year-old Eduard Herriot, former president of the Chamber of Deputies, was alive.

PAWLING, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- Governor Dewey, accompanied by Elliot V. Bell, Superintendent of Banks, arrived at his Pawling home tonight to work on some of the Presidential campaign speeches which the Governor will deliver in September.

PEARL HARBOR, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Striking over a wide ocean front, bombers of the American Central Pacific Command were reported by Admiral Chester W. Nimitz today to have blasted Japanese-held islands ranging from the Volcano group, some 700 miles south of Tokyo, to Nauru, west of the Gilberts.

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- Adolf Hitler's house of Balkan satellites has crumbled. The United States and British Governments have received word from Bulgaria that she is ready to accept unconditional surrender.

ROME, Aug. 24 (Delayed) -- As a result of Prime Minister Churchill's meetings with members of the Italian Government, cautious hopes were expressed in official circles here today a possible change in the status of Italy vis-a-vis the Allied governments.

Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins yesterday reassured parents that within two weeks there would be a marked decrease in the cases of infantile paralysis here. In a five-minute radio broadcast for the War Services and News division of station WOR, he said that to date 597 cases had been reported.

When Dr. Manfred Sakel of Vienna and now of New York discovered about ten years ago that a dose of insulin could shock a schizophrenic back to a state where he would cease to be a charge on the community or his family, even though he might not be completely "cured," psychiatrists were convinced that their discipline had been enriched with a treatment that was promising.

The "air cargo" luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last Thursday stimulated enthusaism of leaders in the produce trade for the post-war possibilities of air-borne food and confirmed the conservatism of Railway Express Agency officials, their comments indicated.

A GENEROUS helping of Dorothy Parker's writings have been committed to records by Victor (album M-971, two twelve-inch records) as read by Ilka Chase, actress and authoress. Three of the four sides are devoted to Mrs. Parker's poems, while the fourth sets forth the purple passions of "Sentiment," from "Here Lies," the book of short stories.
